title: 'The Bonfire of the Vanities'
description: Now comes Tom Wolfe, aging enfant terrible, with his first novel, (his first novel!), six hundred and fifty-nine pages of raw energy about New York City and various of its inhabitants - a big, bitter, funny, craftily plotted book that grabs you by the lapels and won't let go. As in much of his other work, such as ''The Right Stuff,'' Mr. Wolfe's strategy is to somehow batter the reader into submission, using an incantatory repetition of certain emblematic phrases, (HIS FIRST NOVEL!), detailed description of people's clothing, hyperbole, interior monologue whenever he feels like it, and various other New Journalism devices he is apparently too fond of to give up. What is amazing is that he gets away with it. I read ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' straight through, in two sessions on two consecutive days, and enjoyed it enormously. It swept me right up. When he writes about process he knows what he is writing about, whether it's the Wall Street bond market, the Bronx District Attorney's Office, print and television journal-ism, or the working habits of sleazy lawyers -the man knows how to prepare and he knows how to research. As well, he knows how to tell a story, and how to make us laugh, qualities not always present in the work of some of the more polished, more literary or ultimately more ambitious novelists of his generation.

title: Carey Campaign Says Rival Also Broke Donation Rules
description: The campaign of Ron Carey, the teamsters' president, has been pilloried for months about fund-raising improprieties, but this week the Carey camp began to marshal what it described as evidence that supporters of Mr. Carey's opponent, James P. Hoffa, also engaged in illegal fund-raising.

title: ORION IN DEAL FOR REST OF GUARANTY NATIONAL
description: The Orion Capital Corporation said yesterday that it agreed to pay about $104 million for the remaining 19 percent of the Guaranty National Corporation, an insurer, that it did not already own. The all-cash offer amounts to $36 a share. Orion Capital's bid replaced an earlier $34-a-share offer that included a mix of $27.20 cash and the rest in stock. That offer is under review by the Securities and Exchange Commission, an Orion Capital spokeswoman said. Guaranty National gives Orion Capital access to the fastest-growing part of auto insurance, covering drivers with high-risk records, fast cars or other traits that keep them from standard coverage.

title: Navigating the Maze Of Minutes and Morale
description: He could have given John Starks the hook and no one would have called him on it. The third quarter was waning, Starks launched a careless 3-pointer and Charles Oakley was yelling at the combustible shooting guard for jogging back on defense.

title: Purcell Amid Statuesque Postures
description: Purcell's ''Dido and Aeneas'' belongs not only to the early history of opera but also, as Thursday's performance at Florence Gould Hall reminded us, to that of ballet. Within the defective score that has come down to us, dances have their places in a chain of events that also includes songs, dialogues and choruses, but probably in a 17th-century performance the infiltration of dancing went further. Graceful movement and posing would have been expected of the soloists as much as beautiful singing, and members of the chorus, in their bodies and the spacing of their bodies, would have given a visual equivalent to their music. All this would make sense, whether the work was written for a girls' school in London or, as modern scholarship implies, for the court of Charles II.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: In Verdict, Little but Grief, On Both Sides of Atlantic
description: A 19-year-old English nanny was sentenced yesterday to life in prison with no chance of parole for 15 years for murdering an 8-month-old Massachusetts boy she was caring for.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROCK, DAN S.
description: BROCK-Dan S. Suddenly in Chester, CT. On October 30, 1997 of 317 West Main St. Formerly of Woodbridge, CT. and Manhasset, L.I. Husband of the late Ruth Willets Brock. Father of Dan W. Brock and Carolyn B. Brooks. Brother of Ruth B. Morris. Memorial service at First Church of Christ, Woodbridge, CT. Tuesday 3PM. Memorial gifts may be made to the Church, Meetinghouse Lane, Woodbridge, CT. 06525.

title: Excerpts From Mayor's Conversation With Editors and Reporters
description: In an interview with reporters and editors of The New York Times yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani discussed his mayoralty and his top priorities. Following are excerpts from that conversation.

title: Opening Up Japanese Skies
description: The market for airline service between the United States and Japan works nothing like a market. Governments, not customers, decide which airlines fly, where they fly and what they charge. The system serves passengers badly because fares are high and flight schedules are skimpy. The system also badly serves the carriers. Many are shut out of the market entirely. Others find that Japan restricts their right under a 1952 agreement to fly passengers or, in FedEx's case, cargo between Japan and other countries in Asia.

title: Feel Like Screaming? Excellent! You're in Demand
description: Hysteria is back, sweet with the scent of Victorian madness. Perhaps it's because of the millennium, or the influence of television and the Internet. Perhaps it's the fault of feminists and literary critics, or the cold mechanistic ways of doctors. Maybe hysteria never really left us. Maybe it's never been here. Whatever the case, hysteria, a psychological ailment with no known physical cause, multifarious symptoms and a checkered past, is more fashionable than ever.

title: Life Sentence for Au Pair Leaves Britons in Shock
description: LONDON  Britons reacted with shock and disbelief on Friday to the murder conviction of a 19-year-old English au pair in a Massachusetts court, a verdict that to many people here demonstrated serious flaws in a harsh and vindictive American justice system.

title: Girl With a Bird's Name Needs to Flee That Nest
description: A 9-year-old girl turns to her mother and asks whether her father, an engaging but violent alcoholic, is a bad man. ''It ain't about bad or good,'' the bruised woman replies. ''It's about dreaming too much.''

title: Sports of The Times; Looking For Further Greatness
description: THE Indiana Pacers had finished their shoot-around at Continental Arena yesterday morning as workers scurried to complete the finishing touches for the Nets' season opener. Reporters descended in the direction of the players, but they went past Reggie Miller, past newly acquired Chris Mullin.

title: Bangkok Journal; As Times Grow Hard, Thais Look to a Lost Past
description: Deep into the night, incense fills the air at the foot of the bronze statue of King Rama V, splendid on horseback. Hundreds of people kneel at tiny makeshift altars piled with fruit, candy, cognac, cigars and pink roses -- his favorite things.

title: U.S. 'Morals' Devastated Latin America
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSILKIN, CHARLES
description: POSILKIN-Charles. Beloved father of Gary, Robert and Mitchell, and father-in-law to Vicki, Linda and Susan. Cherished grandfather of Alex, Ethan, Jessie, Joshua, Mason, and Scott.

title: A Former Champion Is in It For a Pal
description: In her prime, Allison Roe of New Zealand was one of history's best marathon runners. When she won the New York City Marathon in 1981, her time of 2 hours 25 minutes 29 seconds was a world record.

title: Beliefs
description: Walk by an older church in almost any city neighborhood. It may be hard to miss the handful of poor or homeless people gathering for the opening of the soup kitchen, but out of sight are the dozen or so elderly folks playing cards, slapping down dominoes or just chatting over a hot snack in the church hall. And does anyone except the harried working mother any longer notice that the sign posting the hours of services also announces registration for the church's child care program?

title: CBS in Another Deal for an Internet Site
description: The CBS news division will join with the Data Broadcasting Corporation to provide business and financial information over the Internet to individual investors and business professionals.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Earlier Bar Hours Face Vote
description: Voters in Wildwood will decide on Tuesday whether to close the bars in the seaside town two hours earlier -- at 3 A.M. instead of 5 A.M. Police have sought the change for years as a way to stop drunken revelers from flocking to Wildwood when bars close in neighboring towns, said Police Capt. William M. Fisher. Residents joined the cause when a North Wildwood man, John W. Vollrath Jr., was beaten to death outside a nightclub in February, he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOHN, NAOMI
description: SOHN-Naomi. Our beautiful, sweet Naomi, may you finally find the peace and love that you so deserve. We will miss you and you will forever be in our hearts. Uncle Pinky, Ann, Robin, Steve

title: Forgotten in the Hoopla: Tibet's Young Torture Victims
description: Addressing an audience of Asia experts last Thursday, President Jiang Zemin of China contended that his country's occupation of Tibet had accomplished something ''similar to the liberation of black slaves in American history.'' China, he maintained, had freed the Tibetan people. It would be hard to find a more dishonest piece of historical revisionism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, HEDWIG (HATTIE)
description: PRICE-Hedwig (Hattie). Beloved mother of Regina Fiorito Sokol, passed away peacefully in her 101st year October 28, 1997. Services Sunday 12:15PM, ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: International Briefs; Colombia's Top Brewer To Split Operations
description: Shareholders of Bavaria S.A., Colombia's biggest brewer, voted yesterday to split its beverage interests off from its other businesses. The beverage operation, which has been valued by one analyst at more than $2 billion, will keep the Bavaria name and will manage all the company's domestic and international beer and soft-drink interests, the company's president, Augusto Lopez, said.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day on Thursday about the appointment of a new chief executive by Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. misstated his given name. He is Robert A. Ingram, not Richard.

title: Fed by Rumors, Fears of Gangs Keep Pupils Home on Halloween
description: On a Halloween Day filled with rumors that took on an almost ''War of the Worlds'' tone, hundreds of thousands of New York City students stayed away from public schools yesterday because they, or their parents, feared a rash of gang-related attacks.

title: International Briefs; Redland Urges Holders To Oppose French Offer
description: Redland P.L.C., a British building material company, advised its shareholders yesterday to reject a takeover bid of $:2.07 billion ($3.5 billion) from Lafarge S.A. of France, and said it was discussing the sale of all or part of Redland for a higher price. Buying Redland would make Lafarge the world's largest producer of aggregates, second to RMC Group as a ready-mix concrete maker and the biggest maker of roof tiles.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HARTIG, HERBERT
description: HARTIG-Herbert. 11/1/91. Miss you dreadfully. Love your visits. Don't be scary. Naomi

title: Senator Seeks a Deal on Affirmative Action Policy
description: A pivotal Senate Republican is linking his support for a nomination that would put the first Asian-American in the Government's top civil rights post to the Clinton Administration's willingness to not support a challenge to California's law against affirmative action programs.

title: EQUESTRIAN: NATIONAL HORSE SHOW
description: Led by clear rounds from McLain Ward on Omnibus, Leslie Burr-Howard astride Ulane du Plessis and Margie Goldstein-Engle riding Hidden Creek's Alvaretto, the United States Equestrian Team won the Nations' Cup last night at the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden. Canada was second with 32i, a quarter of a penalty ahead of third place Germany.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIPRUT, SOLOMON, MD.
description: CIPRUT-Solomon, MD. The entire family of Maimonides Medical Center expresses a profound sense of loss on the passing of Dr. Sol Ciprut. A member of our institution for nearly 40 years, his life was intertwined with Maimonides. Through the years, he was an intern, a chief resident, a past president of the Medical Staff Society and leading member of the Department of Surgery. At Maimonides he was a daily presence and will be sorely missed. We extend our sympathy to his wife Lorraine, his sons, daughter, daughters-inlaw and grandchildren. Maimonides Medical Center Martin D. Payson, Chairman, Board of Trustees Stanley Brezenoff, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHBURN, FRANK DAVIS
description: ASHBURN-Frank Davis. Age 94, of Westwood on October 2, 1997. Distinguished Headmaster Emeritus of Brooks School, N. Andover, Massachusetts. Beloved husband of Jean (Lang) Ashburn and the late Phyllis (Batcheller) Ashburn. Devoted father of the late Phyllis A. Kissel and Nancy A. Whitaker. He is survived by 7 grandchildren & seventeen great-grandchildren. Private service and burial at the Ashburn Chapel, Brooks School. Memorial services will be at Brooks School on Saturday, November 1, 1997, at 11:00 AM and at the Chapel of St Bartholomew's Church, Park Ave at 51st St, New York City, on Monday, November 3, 1997, 2:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be sent to The Ashburn Chair, Brooks School, N. Andover, MA 01845. Information: the Holden-Westwood Funeral Home, Westwood, MA.

title: Pilot Hiring Plan Reported
description: American Airlines Inc. will hire its first new pilots in five years to fly new airplanes that will begin arriving next year, The Dallas Morning News reported today. Airline officials did not disclose the number of pilots to be hired, but indicated it could be as many as 2,000. American, a unit of the AMR Corporation, already employs 9,000 pilots. Most big carriers have now resumed hiring after a period of restraint.

title: International Briefs; 2 Big Czech Companies Post Weak Earnings
description: The extent of the Czech Republic's economic woes was underlined yesterday when Komercni Banka A.S., the largest Czech bank, reported that its third-quarter net fell 92 percent because of losses in its securities portfolio while the state-controlled electric company CEZ A.S. said profit plummeted on lower demand.

title: Giuliani and Messinger Plot the Endgame
description: The two leading mayoral candidates entered the last weekend before Election Day with a flurry of televised appearances, new advertisements and Halloween parades, as they prepared for the final frenetic days of campaigning that will include a visit by President Clinton for Ruth W. Messinger and a 48-hour bus tour of the city by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: After Jiang Moves On, Albright Appoints New Coordinator to Focus on Tibet
description: A day after President Jiang Zemin of China said the people of Tibet were ''living and working in happiness and contentment,'' Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright appointed a new special coordinator today to focus attention on China's suppression of Tibet's cultural and religious traditions.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Stolen Perfume Recovered
description: Some 100,000 bottles of Italian perfume that were stolen last month from a container truck at the Sealand Terminal in Port Elizabeth were recovered yesterday by detectives from the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.

title: Global Rally Lifts Markets As Tumultuous Week Ends
description: A global rebound in share prices helped buoy Wall Street yesterday, ending a tumultuous week of trading that some global investors feared would result in more wrenching declines.

title: Clerical Workers End Walkout at Columbia
description: Clerical workers at Columbia University ratified a contract agreement yesterday, ending a two-week-old walkout, university and union officials said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Times Square signs that were awarded blue ribbons by the Municipal Art Society misstated the location of the Nederlander Theater. It is on West 41st Street, not West 40th.

title: NATIONAL STEEL PLANNING TO RESTATE ITS EARNINGS
description: The National Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest steel company, said yesterday that accounting irregularities had led it to restate earnings for 10 periods dating as far back as 1993. In five cases, earnings were higher than previously reported; in five cases, they were lower. During the third quarter of this year, the company said, its audit committee ''was informed of allegations about managed earnings,'' as well as ''allegations about deficiencies in the system of internal controls.'' An investigation is continuing, said the company, which is based in Mishawaka, Ind.

title: The Rush? It's a Bye Week
description: As the final minutes of practice wound down today, the minds of some of the Giants players were already drifting to the 70 hours away from football that was awaiting them in their bye week. Their bodies were soon to follow.

title: Sea Horses Aren't Pets
description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court in Louisiana Blocks Award in CSX Case
description: The Louisiana Supreme Court blocked a $3.4 billion jury verdict, including $2.5 billion against the CSX Corporation, from taking effect yesterday until the injuries received by all 8,000 victims of a 1987 railway fire in New Orleans can be assessed.

title: Prosecutors Seeking Victims Of Man Infected With H.I.V.
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office announced yesterday that it was seeking to bring criminal charges against Nushawn J. Williams for any role he might have played in infecting girls or women in Brooklyn with the virus that causes AIDS. Investigators with the District Attorney's office have begun posting signs in Mr. Williams's old neighborhoods in an effort to get potential victims to come forward.

title: In His Own Words
description: JAMES E. McGREEVEY

title: International Briefs; Unilever Completes Brazil Ice Cream Deal
description: Unilever N.V. said yesterday that it had completed the $930 million purchase of Kibon, Brazil's biggest ice cream maker, from the Philip Morris Companies of the United States. With the deal, Unilever, the British-Dutch food and personal-products company, consolidates its place as the world's biggest maker of ice cream. The cash purchase, announced Oct. 20, includes Philip Morris's half-share in an ice cream venture in east Brazil called Sorvane.

title: Fracture Puts Formal Gold Out of the Breeders' Cup
description: The Breeders' Cup Classic lost its second major contender in less than a week today when it was announced that Formal Gold, the winner of the Woodward Stakes, had suffered a fractured cannon bone in his right hind leg.

title: Pirro's Fame at Issue in Prosecutor's Race
description: Ask Joanne Naughton about her chances of unseating Jeanine F. Pirro, the telegenic and ubiquitous Westchester County District Attorney, and she will answer with a waver in her voice that ''stranger things have happened.''

title: Long Island Endorsements
description: For Nassau County Executive: Lewis Yevoli, a Democrat, is waging an uphill battle in his campaign against the incumbent Republican, Thomas Gulotta, who will probably be able to outspend his opponent 20 to 1. Mr. Yevoli, the Oyster Bay Town Supervisor, is a longtime fixture in Nassau politics who has been a persistent critic of the Republican political establishment.

title: Russian House Approves Treaty Banning Chemical Arms
description: The lower house of the Russian Parliament today approved the international treaty banning chemical weapons, marking a major advance in the effort to end the development and possession of poison gas.

title: PILOTS CONTRACT DEAL HELPS NEW PURCHASES
description: US Airways Group Inc. pilots ratified a new five-year labor contract with the airline yesterday, opening the way for the company to lower costs and proceed with the purchase of new Airbus Industrie planes. The Air Line Pilots Association, which represents 4,800 US Airways pilots, said 84 percent of the pilots voting approved the contract. About 88 percent of the union members voted, a spokesman said. After 18 months of sometimes stormy labor negotiations, the agreement may allow the airline to enter a period of relative labor calm. US Airways shares rose $1.0625, to $46.9375, on the New York Stock Exchange. The airline, based in Arlington, Va., is the nation's fifth largest. It is now expected to confirm the purchase of 120 Airbus Industrie planes.

title: Liberties; My Scoop: The Pumpkin Tapes
description: So I was out doing a little last-minute pumpkin shopping. I passed a pile of orange blobs on Pennsylvania Avenue that were selling for a song. The White House, it seems, had requisitioned too many of the gargantuan gourds and was hawking the extras to raise money for the President's legal defense fund.

title: Hillary Clinton Sees Hope in Ulster, Too
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton stayed strictly on track today, traveling to this troubled city to sound the themes she has embraced in her carefully planned re-emergence: women, children and families.

title: The Economic Stakes in Asia
description: When the Clinton Administration explained today why it was contributing $3 billion to a fund to stabilize Indonesia -- and with it the economies of Southeast Asia -- it argued that far more than stock market shocks and fluctuating currencies were at stake.

title: A Well-Grounded Jet Must Move a Mountain
description: Ernie Logan, a no-frills man who has a watch with a compass, has a no-frills job. He is the Jets' nose tackle. He is also the kind of player Coach Bill Parcells tabs as a ''hold-the-fort guy.'' Nothing flashy. Stick around until a better player arrives or a youngster emerges to take his place.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Watergate, I guess, spoiled us a little bit.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWENS, ROBERT M.
description: OWENS-Robert M. At Easton, CT., on October 31, 1997, partner Owens, Schine and Nicola; beloved husband of Carol Michaelsen Owens; father of Victoria, Edward and Fritz, all of Easton; brother of Clarisse Loughran of Fairfield, CT., and Howard T. Owens, Jr. of Bridgeport, CT. Memorial Mass, Egan Chapel of St. Ignatius Loyola, Fairfield University, Fairfield, Connecticut, Monday, November 3 at 11:00 A.M. In memory of Bob, contributions to the Robert M. Owens Memorial Fund, Fairfield University, North Benson Road, Fairfield, Connecticut 06430.

title: Gingrich, to Quell Critics, Says House Should Vote on Campaign Finances
description: A day after Senate Republicans agreed to allow a vote on a campaign-finance bill by next March, Speaker Newt Gingrich said today that the House should take up similar legislation by early next year.

title: International Briefs; National Westminster Rejects Bid for Unit
description: National Westminster Bank P.L.C. rejected a bid yesterday from Deutsche Morgan Grenfell for the global equities division of its NatWest Markets investment banking operation, saying the proposal was ''not in the best interest of its shareholders.''

title: IMF Deal, Linked to Reforms, Aims to Reassure the Markets : Indonesia to Get Aid of $23 Billion
description: SINGAPORE  The Indonesian government and the International Monetary Fund agreed Friday on an emergency economic-stabilization package for Indonesia that will be backed by loans of at least $23 billion, provided that Jakarta carries out wide-ranging reforms.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: $26 MILLION INVESTMENT IN ENGINE UNIT SET
description: Deutsche Lufthansa A.G. said yesterday that it had agreed to invest $26 million for a 20 percent stake in the Heico Corporation's engine parts subsidiary, Heico Aerospace. The German airline's investment includes $16 million to partly finance accelerated development of replacement parts for jet engines. Lufthansa had pretax profit of 119 million marks, or $69.3 million, for the first six months of 1996. Heico, based in Hollywood, Fla., is an aerospace and aviation products maker.

title: Tibetans and Christians Speak Out
description: Wearing a dapper blue suit, Guo Binzhao, a Chinese graduate student from Yangzhou, went down to Wall Street yesterday for a glimpse of his President, Jiang Zemin, and found himself arguing in rapid-fire Chinese with a cluster of Tibetan exiles who had come to protest Mr. Jiang's visit.

title: Whitman Works to Shore Up Her Softer Areas of Support
description: With the clock ticking down until Election Day and new polls showing that her re-election remains in doubt, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman turned her attention today to some of her softer areas of support, giving a speech on personal responsibility that seemed intended to appease social conservatives in the Republican Party and expressing her solidarity with minority voters who traditionally favor Democrats.

title: Seattle and Portland Push To Avert a Paradise Lost
description: In the final week of his campaign for mayor of Seattle, Charlie Chong was asked how he would like the rest of the country to view the city best known for coffee, cyber-billionaires and flying fish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, DONALD
description: PHILLIPS-Donald. On October 24. Beloved husband of Annette. Loving father of Wendy Dunn and Susan Phillips. He was the most generous of men. Memorial service to be held at Orchard Cove in Canton, Massachusetts at 11:00 A.M., Sunday, November 9.

title: Homeowners Record Is Set in Third Quarter
description: There is nothing special about the beige house with the burgundy door, except of course to its owner, Shari Crittendon.

title: Think Tank; Lofty Ideas That May Be Losing Altitude
description: The New York Times asked six scholars what they thought was the Most Overrated Idea. Here are their responses, compiled by Janny Scott.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUERTAS, ETHEL
description: HUERTAS-Ethel. On October 29, 1997. Beloved wife of Thomas. Loving mother of Thomas, Jr., Paul, Catherine, Christopher and Joseph. Also survived by nine grandchildren. Visitation Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY. Funeral Mass Monday, 10:30 AM, at St. Joseph's Church, Croton Falls, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to the American Diabetes Assocation, 1660 Duke St., Alexandria, VA. 22314.

title: Clinton and Congress Brace for Trade Fight
description: As White House aides scurried to barter promises of economic aid and worker assistance in exchange for crucial Democratic votes on free-trade legislation, President Clinton took his campaign for the bill out to the country today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALANCE, THOMAS JOSEPH
description: VALANCE-Thomas Joseph. On October 31, 1997. World War II Veteran. Participated in D-Day landing, first wave Omaha Beach. Received Bronze Star and Purple Heart. Beloved husband of Virginia (nee Stewart). Loving father of Nikos, James, Daniel, John and Stephen. Devoted brother of Anne Venditto. Also survived by six grandchildren. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard at 193 Street. Funeral Mass Monday, 10AM, Holy Family RC Church. Cremation private. Visiting hours Sunday 2-5 and 7-10 P.M.

title: Woman Reports Robbery By Men in Clown Suits
description: A Brooklyn woman reported last night that two men dressed as clowns broke into her apartment in Starrett City, handcuffed her and stole $20,000, the police said. The woman, Saladin Simpkins, 25, is an off-duty postal police officer.

title: No Accord, and Little Optimism, at Bonn Talks on Global Warming
description: Delegates from 143 countries ended their preliminary talks on global warming here today with no agreement on key issues and growing concern about the prospect for success at the concluding meeting, to be held in Kyoto, Japan, in early December.

title: Theater Is Half the Show as Boxing Comes to the Apollo
description: Rarely does a theater overshadow the event that is being staged there, but that is the case for tonight's Lou Savarese-David Izon heavyweight fight at the Apollo Theater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARCE, HENRY
description: PEARCE-Henry, 89 years young. Loving Husband of Sally; Adoring Father of Dr. David and Linda and Dr. Norton Rosensweig; Proud Grandfather of Jonathan and Laurie Rosensweig and Julie and Paul Schwartz. Founding partner of Pearce Mayer & Greer in 1928, devoted his career to Real Estate Philanthropy and his Family. Memorial services will be held at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Monday, November 3rd, at 11:15 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, BENJAMIN F.
description: BECKER-Benjamin F. Of West Babylon, N.Y. on October 31, 1997. Past Vice President, International Freight, American Express. Former member N.Y.A.C. Loving husband of the late Grace. Survived by his niece Marcia Varon. Services were private. For further information call Whitting Funeral Home, Inc., Glen Head, N.Y.

title: IDEAS: One Mind, But What A Mind; Defining the Passions Of the Liberal Elite For Over 2 Decades
description: It was in the famously disheveled old offices of The New York Review of Books, amid the dust balls and book heaps and lingering smoke of tiny cigars, that Mark Danner, fresh out of Harvard in 1981 and looking for a job as an editorial assistant, had his first encounter with Robert B. Silvers.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Board Refuses to Move Pupils
description: The Atlantic City Board of Education voted Thursday to defy an order from Leo F. Klagholz, the State Commissioner of Education, to remove fifth- and sixth-graders from the violence-plagued Albany Avenue School. Putting 900 pupils in the city's overcrowded elementary schools would be ''a grand mess,'' Marven F. Hill, the school board president, said yesterday.

title: Tax-Free Accounts Imperil Public Colleges; Working Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Thursday about a campaign appearance by Ruth W. Messinger with former Mayor David N. Dinkins at a Harlem senior center misspelled the given name of the black union leader for whom the center is named. He was A. Philip Randolph, not Phillip.

title: Crew Ousts a Board Member Over Her Job as a School Critic
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew yesterday ousted a local school board member who had been critical of his policies, saying that it was a conflict for her to also hold a job with a Brooklyn-based nonprofit advocacy group that sometimes deals with the Board of Education.

title: Allegheny Teledyne Plans to Buy Oremet
description: Allegheny Teledyne Inc., a maker of stainless steel and other specialty metals, agreed yesterday to buy the Oregon Metallurgical Corporation for $560 million in stock.

title: The Nanny Verdict
description: The murder case of the British nanny Louise Woodward first captured public attention because it connected with all working parents' fear that their children will be harmed when they are at work. Then yesterday it captured even wider attention because of the possibility that the prosecution may not have met its burden of proving murder beyond a reasonable doubt and a sense that Ms. Woodward's lawyers may have refused a plea bargain that would have avoided a life sentence.

title: ILC TECHNOLOGY TO BE ACQUIRED BY BEC GROUP
description: ILC Technology Inc., a maker of specialized light sources for lasers and other equipment, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by BEC Group Inc. for about $120 million in stock. Shares of ILC rose 19 percent on the news, gaining $2.25, to $14, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of BEC rose 18.75 cents, to $5.8125, on the New York Stock Exchange. As part of the deal, BEC plans to spin off its Bolle Inc. sunglasses unit to shareholders, allowing it to focus on lighting products. It will also conduct a reverse 1-for-2 stock split, which will halve its outstanding shares but double their value. BEC, to be renamed Lumen Technologies Inc., will exchange 4.36 of its shares, or 2.18 when taking into account the reverse split, for each ILC share.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Assurance on Chemical Panel
description: A long-dormant board to investigate chemical accidents will soon be up and running, United States Senator Frank R. Lautenberg's office said yesterday. His aides said that President Clinton had assured the Senator that he would not veto a $4 million appropriation for the Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board.

title: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE VOTERS / CAMPAIGN STOP -- Views From the Neighborhoods; Park Slope's Proud Democrats Feel Tug of Strained Loyalties
description: Susan Friedland, a 29-year-old city planner, sounds a lot like many Park Slope residents when she talks about the mayoral election. She's a Democrat, she detests the Republican Party, and she thinks Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's popularity shows that voters have abandoned the ideal of social change to vote for their narrow personal interests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLEICHER, JOSEPH W.
description: GLEICHER-Joseph W. On October 30, 1997. Beloved husband of Lillian. Father of Ellen, Hanalea Jane, Bert and Bonnie. Grandfather of Rick Joseph and Vicki, Joanne and Tom, Cathy and Victor, and Katarina Baila. Great grandfather of Anna Catherine. Services will be held on November 2, 1997, on Sunday at 12 noon at Congregation KOL AMI (Jewish Community Center), 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY.

title: Welcome, A Bit Blase, For Fellow Traveler
description: For many Chinese in New York, President Jiang Zemin's trip yesterday to their new hometown was in a strange way not that different from their own journeys to America.

title: Ireland Picks Ulster Woman as President
description: Mary McAleese, 46, a law professor from the British province of Northern Ireland, has won the Presidency of the Irish Republic, becoming the first northerner ever to hold the office, according to official results announced today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHLACHTER, HELEN
description: SCHLACHTER-Helen. 11/1/94. 3 years without our darling Mamele. Deeply loved, constantly missed. Daughters Susan and Karen

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KATZ, MITCH AND SUZI
description: KATZ-Mitch and Suzi. Forever together, forever remembered. Love, Arlene, Stanley, Ed, Sandy, Gerrie, Michael, Joan, Gi, Charlie, Reyna and Marc.

title: A Realistic 'Tannhauser' Returns to the Met
description: ''Tannhauser'' may be the least successful of the Metropolitan Opera's true-to-life Wagner productions. Its gauzy realism -- the Hudson Valley School of opera, if you will -- offers at its best a benign unobtrusiveness to the Met's ''Ring'' production. But with only intermittent moments of good singing to occupy and center our attentions, Thursday's revival only underlined the general drabness of this particular affair. Gunther Schneider-Siemmssen's set dates from 1977 but looks even older.

title: Samuel Fuller, Director, Is Dead at 85; A Master of Unsettling Low-Budget Films
description: Samuel Fuller, a director, screenwriter and producer who was widely viewed as the reigning virtuoso of low-budget films and was ranked by European critics as one of the best directors in the world, died on Thursday at his home in the Hollywood Hills. He was 85 and had homes in France and California.

title: About New York; Struggling To Impart Lesson of Life
description: SHAMEL UPTEGROW says his classmates at Morris High School aren't into current events. Sure, he said, they knew about Nushawn Williams, the H.I.V.-positive man who the authorities said had had unprotected sex with dozens of young women and girls. But his friends did not dwell on the grim scenario.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Pier Fire Closes Boardwalk
description: Fire broke out yesterday on the Central Pier, causing a section of the Boardwalk to be closed off for about two hours.

title: Mao's Heir Finds Path: Wall Street
description: President Jiang Zemin of China trod a capitalist road yesterday from Wall Street to the suburban campuses of hi-tech American industry.

title: Peter Savino, Mafia Associate Who Became an Informer, 55
description: Peter Savino, a longtime Mafia associate who became a major Government witness against his former confederates, including such top mobsters as the recently convicted Vincent Gigante, died on Sept. 30, Federal prosecutors said in a court document filed this week.

title: Evergreen Ecstasy, Taken Out Of Storage
description: It's a strange job, being rock's Dionysus in the 1990's, but Perry Farrell has volunteered for it again. Between songs, he was swigging from a red-wine bottle and preaching about love when the reconvened Jane's Addiction performed on Thursday at Hammerstein Ballroom. It was the official opening (after warmup club shows in Los Angeles) of the band's first American tour since 1991. On Tuesday, Warner Brothers Records is to release ''Kettle Whistle,'' an album of alternate versions of old songs along with two new ones.

title: Hoch Overtakes Tour's Big Hitters With Pinpoint Accuracy
description: What Scott Hoch lacks in power, he compensates for with ability.

title: McGreevey Given Counsel by Newark Voters
description: Even before State Senator James E. McGreevey walked in the door at most of his stops here today, it was clear that he was preaching to the converted.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RULNICK, DORIS
description: RULNICK-Doris. November 1, 1992. Five years-how long, how short. Always with me in mind, heart and deed. In loving memory, your dear daughter, Joyce

title: New Constitution Wouldn't End Albany Gridlock; Waste of Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Ambitious Inquiry Hit Political Reality
description: The investigation into campaign finance practices led by Senator Fred Thompson never had the star witness or the surge of energy needed to generate heavy television coverage, but the greatest weakness of the inquiry was the failure of the chairman and committee to deliver on the opening pronouncement that a Chinese plot to pour money into American politics ''affected the 1996 Presidential race.'' That and the failure to score a direct hit on President Clinton left the inquiry without the steam to go on.

title: U.S. Intervenes On Problems Of Union Pacific
description: Federal regulators declared a transportation emergency in the West yesterday, but stopped short of a major takeover of the troubled lines of the Union Pacific Railroad, choosing instead to open only a small area in Texas to a local competitor of the railroad.

title: Will Wall Street Now Have to Pull In Its Horns?
description: The not-quite-finished office building in Stamford, Conn., is an apt symbol of Wall Street's health and boundless optimism. It cost some $200 million to build, contains an up-to-date trading floor and by year-end will have created some 2,200 new jobs for the region.

title: INSIDE
description: Maneuvering Over Nominee

title: New Constitution Wouldn't End Albany Gridlock; A State Conversation
description: To the Editor:

title: Guess Who Wasn't Invited to Dinner?
description: Among the celebrity names on the list of those invited to the White House dinner for President Jiang Zemin of China, there were prominent members of the Clinton Administration, senators and representatives, television anchors and print journalists, plus numberless chief executive officers.

title: 2 Additional Moons, Both Tiny, Are Discovered Orbiting Uranus
description: Astronomers using the 200-inch-diameter telescope on Mount Palomar in California have discovered two pint-sized moons orbiting the planet Uranus, bringing the number of its known satellites to 17.

title: Global Warming Is Real
description: To the Editor:

title: Television in Review; A Long Reliable Formula For Revealing the Perp
description: 'Murder, She Wrote: South by Southwest'

title: WATKINS-JOHNSON SELLS DIVISION TO STELLEX
description: The Watkins-Johnson Company said yesterday that it had sold its military electronics operations to Stellex Industries for more than $100 million as part of its plan to emphasize commecial electronics. Watkins-Johnson, based in Palo Alto, Calif., makes computer chip manufacturing equipment and radio frequency products. It had 1996 revenue of $438 million. Stellex is an affiliate of a privately held investment concern, the Mentmore Holdings Corporation. It makes engineered components and subsystems for the commercial aviation, military and space markets. Stellex will incorporate the tactical subsystems and microwave device business as a new unit to be called Stellex Microwave.

title: New Constitution Wouldn't End Albany Gridlock
description: To the Editor:

title: An Indictment On Ferrofluidics
description: The former chief executive and founder of the Ferrofluidics Corporation, Ronald Moskowitz, has been indicted on charges that he helped inflate the company's earnings and organize a fraudulent sale of $12 million in stock.

title: Dance of the Unbeatens: Cougars at Risk
description: There are seven undefeated teams remaining in Division I-A, and the one facing the sternest test today is Washington State on the road at Arizona State. The Sun Devils, the defending Pac-10 champions, have a 5-2 record, 3-1 in the conference with the loss to Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, ROBERT
description: WILLIAMS-Robert. Age 69, of Tenafly, NJ, suddenly on Thursday, October 30, 1997. Beloved husband of Dr. Lee Gardner. Devoted father of Allison Mangot and Brant Williams. Cherished brother of Beverly Eligator. Adored grandfather of Arianna, Ryan, Brendon and Micaela. You were cherished and loved in life and you will be forever missed. Services 12:00 PM, Sunday, November 2, 1997, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt 4 East, Paramus, NJ. Charitable contributions may be made to Congregation Sharei Gilah C/O 405 Pine Lane, Haworth, New Jersey 07641 or your local A.S.P.C.A

title: Pataki Plane Loses Pressure And Makes Abrupt Landing
description: A small state-owned plane carrying Gov. George E. Pataki made an emergency landing at Greater Rochester International Airport this morning after its cabin began to lose pressure and exhaust fumes began to seep into the passenger area, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSTON, JAY
description: WINSTON-Jay. On October 30, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Betty. Loving father of Linda and John,and father-in-law of Renate, grandfather of Claudia, Paul, Valerie, Hella and David. Great grandfather of Ruby Rose. Dear brother of Ruth Winston Frank. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Tax-Free Accounts Imperil Public Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil, Oil Everywhere, but Few Rigs; A Glut of Fields, a Dearth of Workers and Drilling Gear
description: Along the muddy banks of the Mississippi, a huge oil-drilling platform is taking shape here at a newly revived shipyard. About 700 workers are busily assembling the drilling rig, which already towers over 300 feet and, when completed, will soar 552 feet toward the sky -- taller than the United Nations building.

title: Rangers Pay in Practice for Lackadaisical Loss
description: The Rangers are normally smiling and laughing at their mid-morning practices. Most days the routine includes an hour of casual drills followed by a few minutes of brisk skating.

title: Dr. William Sweeney 3d, Researcher on In-Vitro Fertilization
description: Dr. William Joseph Sweeney 3d, a Manhattan gynecologist who took part in the early research on in-vitro fertilization, died on Oct. 23. He was 75 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMBERG, LORRIE NORR.
description: BLUMBERG-Lorrie Norr. On October 29, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Leonard. Loving mother of Robert, Peter, Andrew and H. James Erdman. Also survived by two stepchildren, David and Susan Blumberg. Visitation on Saturday, 7-9 PM, at the George T. Davis Funeral Home, New Rochelle, NY. Services will be conducted on Sunday, 11 A.M., at George T. Davis. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her name to the National Kidney Foundation, Inc., 30 E. 33rd St, NYC 10016, attn: Transplant Research Fund, or to the charity of your choice.

title: Treat New York's Gangs Like a Crime Family
description: Conflicting reports about how much of a threat the Bloods and other gangs may pose to New York City's serenity highlight the difficulty in reliably identifying the city's most violent groups. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's recent proposal to create special police units in each borough to investigate gang activity could help to dismantle these groups.

title: The Person, the Group: Reflections From China
description: The Chinese dancers on stage are from Guangdong and are on their first United States tour. They are sensational performers and look hip. Most of the women sport spiky, short haircuts like Laurie Anderson, and two of the men have long ponytails. There are more T-shirts and mod outfits on view than tights.

title: Tentative Pact Will Allow Census to Test the Sampling Method
description: Negotiators from the White House and Speaker Newt Gingrich's office have reached a tentative agreement that would allow the Census Bureau to test its hotly debated new method for estimating the country's population, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: Even With Balanced Diet, Vitamins Can Be Essential
description: To the Editor:

title: In Her Own Words
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER

title: Television in Review; For Harrowing Horror Tales, Dreams Are a Fertile Field
description: 'Sleepwalkers'

title: Mayor Foresees Better Relations With Minorities
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani predicted yesterday that his relationship with many minority groups would improve in a second term, as residents of poor neighborhoods realized they were sharing the benefits of lower crime and an improved economy.

title: Panel of Experts Rebuffs Effort to Absolve Saccharin
description: The artificial sweetener saccharin, which for 20 years has been dogged by suspicion that it causes cancer, was denied the scientific equivalent of parole today when a board of independent experts recommended that it remain on the Government's list of suspected carcinogens.

title: Another Image of Sibling Bondage, but Not a Mirror Image
description: ''You two are a hard sell with that stuck-together thing.'' So says the worldly promoter to the stardom-bound Siamese twins in ''Side Show,'' the wonderful new musical on Broadway. Oops! Wait a minute. No one, surely, would be so vulgar or flip in ''Side Show,'' which, given its subject, is a model of restraint. My mistake. This particular piece of show-business wisdom comes from the other new musical about the triumph and heartbreak of conjoined sisters in show biz, ''From the Hip (Siamese Twin Variations),'' at Here in the South Village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, CAROL S.
description: LEVY-Carol S. On October 29, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Edgar I. Levy. Devoted mother of Liza Levy, Angela Carroll and Kristin Lizotte. Cherished grandmother of Jacklyn, Jennifer and Adam. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, November 2 at 4 PM at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81st St. Contributions may be made in her name to The Education Action Fund, C/O Jonathan Kozol, POB 145, Byfield, MA. 01922 or a charity of your choice.

title: Television in Review; A Monster With a Lawyer? Now THAT Is Scary!
description: 'House of Frankenstein 1997'

title: In Debates, Nassau Candidates Clash on Lilco and Police Pay
description: Finally facing each other in the waning days of their race for Nassau County executive, the Republican and Democratic candidates clashed sharply Wednesday night and again this morning in their only two debates of the campaign, arguing over taxes, police pay and electricity rates.

title: Reuters Given Big Tax Deal For Its Project In Times Square
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and executives of Reuters American Holdings announced yesterday that the giant British media company would build a 32-story headquarters in Times Square with the help of tens of millions of dollars in tax breaks.

title: At 87, His 5th New York Marathon; A Life, Much Like a Race, May Be Long
description: The first time Abraham Weintraub tried to enter the New York City Marathon, he was not thinking about how fast he could cover the 26 miles and 385 yards. All he wanted to do was push his wife, Ruth, in her wheelchair.

title: Connecticut's Landreth Wins
description: Travis Landreth of the University of Connecticut, a 21-year-old junior who is majoring in exercise physiology, took charge at the one-mile mark yesterday and went on to win the Big East Conference cross country championship in 29 minutes 49 seconds at Van Cortlandt Park's five-mile course.

title: Whitman Stands on Record, But Newer Issues Stir Voters
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman was elected four years ago on the strength of a bold promise: she would cut state income tax rates by a third. Her opponents said it couldn't be done. She did it in two years, not three.

title: New Constitution Wouldn't End Albany Gridlock; Change the Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Even With Balanced Diet, Vitamins Can Be Essential
description: To the Editor:

title: Queens Girl, 15, Is Accused In Death of Her Newborn
description: A teen-age girl from Queens was arraigned on murder charges yesterday in the drowning of her infant daughter after she gave birth to the girl in her bathroom, the police said.

title: U.S. ECONOMY GREW AT A STRONG PACE IN THE 3d QUARTER
description: The American economy grew at a vigorous pace over the summer and a key measure of inflation dwindled to a level not seen since 1964.

title: French Team Takes a Lead At the World Championship
description: A great French team, playing with determination and accuracy, seemed headed for victory in the world championship here today. After 112 of 160 deals, France led against the United States by 64 imps. The French players, all past or present world champions, are Christian Mari, Frank Multon, Alain Levy, Herve Mouiel, Paul Chemla and Michel Perron. The first four were winners of the World Olympiad Teams a year ago on the Greek island of Rhodes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISS, HOWARD
description: REISS-Howard. Temple B'nai Sholom mourns the loss of our long-time member. We extend condolences to the family. Services Gutterman's Rockville Centre, Sunday, November 2, at 12 Noon. Dr. Martin Greenberg, President Dr. Barry Dov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: The Stuff of Dreams: Dutch Schultz's Buried Loot
description: As a crew of gravediggers prepared a fresh plot in a sprawling cemetery here, three women with a video camera, a handful of daisies and a pint of Chivas Regal approached the granite headstone of Arthur S. Flegenheimer, a.k.a. Dutch Schultz, the ruthless gangster featured in E. L. Doctorow's novel ''Billy Bathgate.''

title: Think of the Children
description: To the Editor:

title: First Union Sought Deal For Corestates
description: Preliminary merger talks between the Corestates Financial Corporation, the last major bank based in Philadelphia, and the First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., have recently ended, according to advisers to different parties close to the talks.

title: Pitino Begins Era by Beating Bulls
description: The Celtics were supposed to be somewhat improved after last season, behind the expensive new head coach and president, Rick Pitino, but this good?

title: With Drummer Gone, R.E.M. Becomes a Trio
description: R.E.M., the critically acclaimed, platinum-selling rock quartet, has announced that its drummer, Bill Berry, has decided to leave the band. Instead of auditioning for a new drummer, band members said in an interview on Thursday, the band will continue as a trio.

title: Camelot Seeks Wall Music
description: Camelot Music Inc. said it agreed to buy W. H. Smith Group P.L.C.'s Wall Music Inc. unit for $47 million.

title: Never in England, Britons Say of Verdict
description: Britain reacted to the murder conviction in Cambridge, Mass., of Louise Woodward with shock, bewilderment and anger at American judicial practices and pledges of solidarity with Ms. Woodward, a 19-year-old English au pair.

title: Rhythm Worn Inside Out
description: All rhythmic music is mathematical, though composers tend to want to make the time-counting unnoticeable: an overt preoccupation with numbers alienates listeners. But there's a thread of esthetic history in rock in which rare and flummoxing time-signatures are made evident, like clothes turned inside out to reveal the stitches; the thread runs from the long-form progressive rock of the 70's (bands like Magma and Rush) through the early-80's punk miniatures of the Minutemen and some more recent speed-metal. The Ruins, a decade-old bass-and-drum duo from Japan, are expert at this game: they make the stitching into the design itself.

title: First-Night Reviews: Nets a Hit; Knicks Stand Firm
description: Larry Bird was back on the sideline tonight. The Indiana Pacers could have used him on the court in the final minutes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AARON, MATTHEW
description: AARON-Matthew. Beloved father of Howard and Alice, grandfather of Susanna and Max, great-grandfather of Samuel and Jasper. Services Sunday, 10 A.M., Riverside Chapel, 1 Ocean Pkwy, Bklyn.,N.Y.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP., Pittsburgh, said it completed the sale of its Thermo King refrigeration unit to Ingersoll-Rand Co., of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., for $2.56 billion in cash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDAU, GERTRUDE A.
description: LANDAU-Gertrude A. On October 30, 1997. Formerly of New York City. Wife of the late Morris, mother of the late Robert. Survived by one daughter, Edith Litt, one sister, Ethel Rosenblum, four grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Services private. Memorial contributions to the Robert Stephen Landau Scholarship Fund at Harvard University. For further information contact Dwyer Funeral Home, Tarrytown, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, NAOMI
description: GREENFIELD - Naomi. The Woodmere Club deeply regrets the passing of our good friend and member, Naomi Greenfield. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to her husband Jonathan and to the other members of the family.

title: Yanks and Boggs Parting Ways
description: First, the Yankees uttered goodbye to Dwight Gooden three days before tonight's midnight contract deadline. Now, they have done the same to Wade Boggs.

title: U.N. Arms Inspectors Plan To Defy Iraqi Expulsion Order
description: The leader of a United Nations arms inspection team in Iraq said today that his monitors, including 10 Americans whom Baghdad has ordered expelled, would resume work on Monday in defiance of President Saddam Hussein's ban on United States participation in their work.

title: Michigan to Retire Howard's Uniform
description: The University of Michigan will retire Desmond Howard's uniform No. 21 next season, the school said yesterday.

title: Gold Falls as Plan for Swiss Sale Advances
description: Gold futures prices tumbled 2 percent yesterday after the Swiss Government endorsed the sale of 800 metric tons, prompting speculation that other nations would sell some of their reserves and flood the market.

title: U.S. Historian Relates How Vichy France Served Nazis
description: The American historian who provided the French with the first comprehensive picture of the crimes of the Vichy regime in World War II defended his views today in a court that will for the first time pass judgment on a senior Vichy official.

title: Political Realities
description: At Senate testimony this week, Senator Fred Thompson complained that ''the Administration had sought to have it both ways'' by appearing publicly to cooperate with investigators yet stiffing them privately.

title: Unions Oppose Constitutional Assembly
description: A letter to union members warns that constitutional provisions protecting their ''homes, families and jobs'' are in ''extreme danger.'' A labor official walking door-to-door tells people that their union pensions could be jeopardized. A television commercial darkly predicts that taxes will go up.

title: Even With Balanced Diet, Vitamins Can Be Essential
description: To the Editor:

title: Miami's Election for Mayor Rouses Sour Mood in Voters
description: The mood of Miami voters was in evidence on Tuesday at Bayfront Park, where 20,000 baseball fans celebrating the Florida Marlins' World Series victory lustily booed the Mayor who had promised to build a stadium to keep the team here.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Trauma Center Clears Hurdle
description: Even though it is a major transportation hub, Mercer County is the only metropolitan area in New Jersey without a medical trauma center nearby. On Thursday, the Helene Fuld Medical Center came closer its goal of becoming a trauma center when it received provisional approval from the state, said Al Maghazehe, chief executive officer of the hospital. The hospital has spent $3 million on the specialized equipment needed to qualify as a trauma center and plans to spend $2 million a year on staff to treat severely injured patients 24 hours a day. The hospital must meet a few conditions before complete certification, including a review by the American College of Surgeons, Mr. Maghazehe said.

title: Arts & Ideas
description: NEW ON SATURDAYS

title: Jury Rejects a Smoker's Suit
description: In a trial watched closely for its effect on the proposed national tobacco settlement, a jury in Jacksonville, Fla., ruled yesterday in favor of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.

title: Resume: From Buzz And Rattle To Mahler
description: The Polish composer Krzysztof Penderecki must know that historians have already assured him a place in the accounts of 20th-century music. By the early 1960's, he had won the attention of composers and a significant public following for his avant-garde music -- his ''sound effects'' pieces, as they have been called -- works that experimented with unconventional ways to produce sound and relied on graphic notation of squiggles and such rather than precise pitches. At the time, young composers in universities were poring over scores like ''Threnody for the Victims of Hiroshima,'' Mr. Penderecki's groundbreaking work for 52 strings.

title: Pope Ties 'Unjust' Teachings to Anti-Semitism
description: Pope John Paul II said today that certain Christian teachings, based on ''wrong and unjust'' interpretations of the New Testament, had helped contribute to the Holocaust and the persecution of Jews in Europe over the centuries.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, ELEANOR
description: HOWARD-Eleanor. On October 30, 1997. Wife of Jack Rohe Howard. Sister of Mrs. Jean Bankier, of New York City, Walton Harris, of Santa Monica, CA., and Whitley Harris, of Ojai, CA. Stepmother of Michael Balfe Howard and Pamela Howard. Private memorial services held November 1, 1997. Contributions to the Hoover Institute of War, Peace and Revolution, Scripps Howard Foundation, and to Stanford University, would be appreciated.

title: PHOENIX NETWORK ENDS BID FOR MIDCOM COMMUNICATIONS
description: Phoenix Network Inc. told Midcom Communications Inc. yesterday that it would not go forward with their merger in the wake of a 75 percent plunge in Midcom shares after Midcom projected disappointing revenue for the next two quarters. Phoenix, which is based in Golden, Colo., also said it would put itself up for sale. It was to have been acquired by Midcom, a Seattle-based telecommunications services provider, for 9.1 million Midcom shares. Earlier, Midcom agreed to pay the Sprint Corporation nearly $8 million to settle a service and billing dispute even though the payment might eventually bankrupt the company. Midcom stock then tumbled $5.125, to $1.5624, in Nasdaq trading.

title: International Briefs; Nikon Profit Off 55%; Technology Costs Cited
description: The Nikon Corporation said yesterday that net profit for the first half of this year plunged 55 percent from a year earlier, to 2.64 billion yen ($21.9 million), because of higher-than-expected costs associated with the transition to next-generation excimer laser steppers for computer chip production. Excimer laser steppers are used in the production of 64-megabit dynamic random access memory chips while the more conventional i-line steppers are used mainly in the production of 16-megabit D-RAM's.

title: Attacking a Constitutional Convention
description: Citizens Against a Constitutional Convention, which includes unions, environmentalists, trial lawyers and abortion rights advocates, has begun running 30-second television commercials around the state.

title: 'Side Show' Star Is Back
description: Emily Skinner, who plays one of the Hilton sisters in the new musical ''Side Show,'' will return to the stage at the Richard Rodgers Theater with today's matinee, ending a four-day hiatus caused by a sore throat, said a spokesman for the show.

title: Quietly Avowing Innocence, Nanny Is Sentenced to Life
description: It has been an entertaining drama followed by millions, the show known as ''The Nanny Murder Trial.'' But today, as a 19-year-old British au pair was sentenced to life in prison for a murder she steadfastly disavows, and a pair of bereaved parents described their life of daily pain, there was a sense that the final reality of the case was: everybody loses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTELLO, BARBARA T.
description: COSTELLO-Barbara T. October 31, 1997 of Garden City. Beloved wife of the late Peter J. Loving mother of Peter, Robert and Kathleen. Cherished grandmother of Tara, Bobby, Erin, Maura, Kerry and Megan. Visiting at Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City 7-9 PM Saturday and 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial St Joseph's Church, Garden City, at 10 AM Monday. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, New York.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Rebound Modestly, Ending Week of Turmoil

title: A Pianist Confronts Schumann Quirks
description: Curious are the strategies of the touring orchestra. Consider Daniele Gatti and the Royal Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall this week. Mr. Gatti, with a big reputation in Europe and a handful of admired appearances in New York, comes to our city with his new London orchestra and presents two high-profile concerts. Yet what a drab repertory of music he brings us. All the items are masterpieces, major or minor, but masterpieces so often repeated by orchestras great and small that any pretense of freshness, adventure or imagination is precluded.

title: CAMPAIGN PANEL TO END HEARINGS ON FUND-RAISING
description: With a tone of frustration at the obstacles he faced, Senator Fred Thompson put an end to the Senate's hearings on campaign finance abuses today, complaining that he had not been afforded enough time to do a thorough job.

title: Despite Rumors, All's Quiet at Washington Irving High
description: The rumors swept through Washington Irving High School as early as in September, first on the lips of students, then on the lips of radio and television reporters: the Bloods gang would rampage through the school on Halloween.

title: When All Politics Is Truly Local
description: AN anonymous caller delivered a message one recent night for the First Selectman of Orange, Robert Sousa. According to Mr. Sousa, a Democrat, the caller told his wife, Denise, that Mr. Sousa might want to consider pulling out of his race for re-election because ''we know who he represented.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUERSWALD, DR. E.H. (DICK)
description: AUERSWALD-Dr. E.H. (Dick), October 23, 1997, San Francisco, at age 71. Dr. Auerswald was a founder of the family therapy movement and the originator of the ecosystemic therapeutic paradigm. In his work, he developed family-centered, community-based, health delivery systems in New York and Hawaii. He served on the Board of Directors of the American Family Therapy Association and the journal ''Family Process''. He is survived by his companion Alma Zito Menn, his children Sarah and David and their families, and his niece Colette and nephew Philip. Donations may be made to the ACLU.

title: Say 'Ch-e-e-s-e'
description: EVERYBODY had been warned.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Meet the Press Fifty Years of History in the Making. By Rick Ball and NBC News. McGraw-Hill, $39.95.

title: Halloween Was the Safest In Decades, Officials Say
description: Despite the specter of gang-related mayhem that kept thousands of children away from classes on Friday, city officials said yesterday that there were no incidents of gang violence in any of the five boroughs on Halloween.

title: PULSE ; The G Force
description: With its vibrant colors and high-tech design, the Baby G watch is the timepiece whose time has come. Made in Japan and introduced in the United States a year ago, the watch is showing up on the wrists of celebrities like the Spice Girls and Tori Spelling. At $130 each, it's not impossible to own more than one, and some people wear several at once.

title: Screenplays Join 'Rolexes' As Sidewalk Fare
description: New ''must buy'' items are on Manhattan sidewalks these days, where busy corners teem with merchants selling children's books, sunglasses and knockoff designer watches. They are movie scripts, ''guaranteed authentic'' by a man named Vlady.

title: I Dreamt I Ran the Marathon in My Sports Bra
description: AS the horn sounds on the Staten Island side of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge this morning, more women than ever -- at least 8,800 -- will be taking part in the long and winding road that is the 28th New York City Marathon.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about liturgical dance misidentified a group dancing at Rutherford United Methodist Church, and the work it was performing. The group was Spirit Dance, an independent interfaith group that is not affiliated with the church, but rehearses there. The piece was ''Amazing Grace,'' not a Shaker dance.

title: LOST AND FOUND
description: The Andy Warhol silk screen of Marilyn Monroe that goes on the auction block at Sotheby's next Sunday has a unique provenance. For years it hung on the cafeteria wall of Lasalle Secondary School in Sudbury, Ontario, its authenticity unknown until recently, when the school's current principal, Bert Brankley, found an old letter in the files from a Toronto art dealer who referred to ''the Warhol.'' The print was originally bought by an art teacher in 1969 for $250. The school hopes to make thousands, which it will use to buy computers, and Brankley believes former students will get in on the bidding. ''One told me, 'I looked at that every day eating my lunch and I loved it. It's going to be mine.' ''

He distinguished himself in a 35-year career at YU. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Lila; children; grandchildren, and the entire family.

title: The Discreet Charm Of Passy-Auteuil
description: I WENT back to Auteuil -- or Passy-Auteuil, as residents call the district between the Seine and the Bois de Boulogne -- to pack up my possessions and say goodbye. It was late April and rainy as usual. (April in Paris, in spite of the song, is exactly like April in London.) Between decisions about what to ship home to the United States and what to donate to Secours Catholique, I made farewell visits: to the hardworking, joking girls at my local boulangerie-patisserie on the Avenue de Versailles, beloved for its real-looking pink marzipan pigs; to the sad old Arab newsagent from whom I bought a final Canard Enchaine; to the mixed-breed black and white dog, Chanel, who spends the daylight hours happily at Madame Berchaut's notions and lingerie shop on the Rue Florence Blumenthal, while her mistress works in an office.

title: A Child of Difference
description: Hedley seems stuck on the illogic that she and her husband are tall, hence her children must share the same trait. Parents with perfect eyesight bear children who need glasses, parents with average I.Q.'s bear geniuses and yes, six-foot parents may bear a child with achondroplasia.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Crazy, Mixed-Up Kids
description: In MESSAGE TO THE NURSE OF DREAMS (Cinco Puntos, paper, $11.95) Lisa Sandlin displays a deep, instinctive understanding of the ways in which generally close-knit families compulsively bicker and splinter -- and the ways in which a teen-age girl can, unexpectedly, be as concerned about her moral nature as she is about her complexion. Since the stories are set in the rapidly changing social world of the Texas Gulf Coast, Sandlin's characters' inherent confusions are both aggravated and ennobled by racial intermingling. In ''If You Don't Watch Out,'' for example, an adolescent named Mayda gains increasing respect for a courageous black family she first encounters in a local restaurant; in a lighter vein, the story called ''Vidor'' provides a hilarious account of a racially mixed high-school football team. Throughout the collection, Sandlin's stories focus on young women, using their naivete to build moving portrayals of people coming to understand others even as they remain unsure about themselves. This strategy achieves a peak of gritty lyricism in a story called ''Cold in the Bone,'' whose narrator painstakingly puzzles out the behavior of her embattled family -- and of a stricken girl ''who came back to school with my name and affected my life in a way I wished I didn't have to understand.'' Bruce Allen

title: Oct. 26-Nov. 1; School's Out Indefinitely
description: Ontario's 2.1 million students were treated to an unexpected holiday last week as the province's publicly funded schools were closed by a teachers' strike, the largest ever in North America. The issue is the provincial government's plans to amalgamate school boards and make decisions about spending, class size and teacher prep time. Teachers fear Ontario's grab for power will end local control. By the weekend, the government was asking the courts for a back to work order. Parents meanwhile scrambled to find day care. ANTHONY DePALMA

title: With Reservations, a Home for the Retarded Is Accepted
description: The man is 61 and he lives in a small Manhattan apartment with his elderly mother. Because he is mentally retarded, he relies on her for simple things like getting dressed and eating. But his mother, who recently broke her hip, is now dependent on home health care assistance. Health officials wonder what will become of him.

title: Heart of Stones
description: I will never dispute that the Stones are indeed the world's greatest rock-and-roll band (I have not missed a tour since l966), and I think their take on the blues is second only to their mastery of the Chuck Berry riff (Culture Zone: Heart of Stones, by Michiko Kakutani, Oct. 12).

title: Antwerp
description: To the Editor: I was delighted to read ''On the Trail of Rubens in Antwerp'' (Sept. 14). Antwerp is one of my favorite European cities, and I am glad to realize it is coming into its own as a tourist destination. You mention the cafe Het Elfde Gebod (The Eleventh Commandment). But the article did not mention that every square foot of the cafe is filled with religious statuary, paintings and icons. It is rather like having lunch in the cathedral itself, an amusing and mildly sacriligious experience.

title: When the Dream Dies
description: WAITRESS. Typist. Receptionist. Entertainer. On some days, Natalie Gamsu can forget who she is or why she left behind a successful singing career in South Africa. During the week, she answers phones at a midtown travel agency: a harried voice with an alluring accent. At night, working the pre-theater shift at a Times Square restaurant, she is just another bow-tie-wearing server with a strained smile.

description: With months of campaigning by New Jersey's gubernatorial candidates about to end, the two sides are gearing up for exceptional efforts to get out the vote, which they now say could play a more significant role than anyone expected in the surprisingly close race.

title: Malling Armani
description: The words ''Giorgio Armani'' and ''discount'' don't usually go hand in glove, but at the new Giorgio Armani General Store at Woodbury Commons Premium Outlets in Central Valley, N.Y., there are discounts of 35 to 80 percent off retail prices for women's and men's items. They include shirts, sweaters, scarves, ties, shoes and suits -- like a Giorgio Armani women's navy wool suit, down from $2,075 to $1,277, or an Emporio Armani men's navy wool suit, from $860 to $559. Hours: 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. daily; (914) 928-9400. There are two other such Armani shops in the country -- in Manchester, Vt., and Cabazon, Calif. -- but this one is only a credit card's toss away. title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Making Do on Nothing
description: Sunlight jabs through the haze of swirling vapors enveloping a tangle of jerry-built huts. The ground is littered with plastic bags, piles of scrap lumber and a capsized bicycle. Nearly lost in the confusion, a mother and child sit by a cooking fire, casually taking a meal. Sebastiao Salgado has earned a reputation as one of the world's greatest photojournalists by creating quiet monuments to the dignity of the poorest of the poor out of the silver light and velvet shadows of their often miserable lives. TERRA: Struggle of the Landless (Phaidon, $55) is a collection of photographs taken in Salgado's native Brazil between 1980 and 1996. Combining some of his most famous images from books like ''An Uncertain Grace'' and ''Workers'' with recent shots, ''Terra'' tells the story of Brazil's rural poor. Facing drought and starvation, many fled the hinterlands for hellish urban shantytowns. Others rose up against landlords in acts of de facto agrarian reform. Salgado's photographs invoke the rich physical, cultural and symbolic texture of these people's lives. His unsparing yet compassionate vision produces images of moments we could not have imagined otherwise. In one picture two young girls stand eating popsicles in the doorway of a store that sells both bananas and child-size coffins. Jake Miller

The fire alarm went off. I grabbed the earplugs and buried my head under the pillow. They can't fool me. I am a veteran of false alarms.

With his future as a football player suddenly in limbo, and those of friends in jeopardy, Harriott stepped to a board in a meeting room and began to write:

title: ART REVIEW ; Quadruple Vision: Still Life With Pitcher, Etc.
description: DO a fish-shaped vase, a pair of iridescent candlesticks, a ceramic pitcher with an apple motif, and a blue oval platter constitute reality? The habit of calling certain contemporary painters realists invites a host of misunderstandings -- at least, if the term is taken to imply that their work is more solidly grounded in reality than others'. Yet it is handy enough for designating those painters, now a distinctly embattled minority, who find pleasure and challenge in the odd project of translating portions of the three-dimensional reality before their eyes into a somehow equivalent two-dimensional reality on canvas.

title: Adultery's Double Standard
description: 'Prince Charles is our Emma Bovary? Whoa! Specious. Charles married one woman while he was still in love with another. Premeditated adultery? His was the first strike. The essay does not, in this case, apply. Rehabilitating Charles's image is a hideous chore, no doubt, but this is not the way. He done her wrong. What she did was not so much the stuff of a Harlequin romance -- which is about rapturous, fulfilling love -- but about giving as good -- or as bad -- as she got.

title: A New York Autumn for a New York Troupe Is News
description: FOR ITS FIRST FALL SEASON in New York in nearly two decades, American Ballet Theater will dance some of its most prized works. During its 57-year existence, Ballet Theater has commissioned so many enduring pieces that it has amply fulfilled the intent of its founder, Richard Pleasant, to establish ''a museum of the dance.'' At the same time, it has proved that great choreographic works can develop their own history and their own life.

title: Combativeness Marks Election in Harrison
description: NEGATIVE campaigning may characterize some contests in this election season, but few can rival Harrison, where elections often resemble gladiator combat rather than restrained discussion.

title: The Nation; Holding the Chips, Tribes Naturally Play Politics
description: FROM the beginning of European settlement through the days of Custer to the militant American Indian Movement, Indian tribes have always been held out by mainstream American society as different: Sometimes better, more spiritual, more ecology minded and noble, and sometimes worse, more dissolute or lazy or dishonest. They have been symbols and backdrops on which America projected its values and prejudices.

title: Doc Rotella's Cure for the Thinking Athlete
description: As midlife crises go, Dana Quigley's was right on schedule: just in time for his 50th birthday, he found himself entertaining fantasies of playing golf again for a living. Years before, he had made a respectable, if unremarkable, showing out on the tour, which he left in 1983 when he took a steady job as a resident pro at the Crestwood Country Club in Rehoboth, Mass., to provide some security for his family. Now, however, there was momentum in his life: he had quit drinking; he had a new wife who took an active interest in his career. So he called Bob Rotella, the sports psychologist. ''I always thought that most of my shortcomings as a golfer were probably in my head,'' Quigley says.

Still, at 91, he swims at least three times a week, and when the weather permits he takes his sailboat out on weekends.

And it was hard for anyone to take control.
