title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWENS, ROBERT M.
description: OWENS-Robert M. At Easton, CT., on October 31, 1997, partner Owens, Schine and Nicola; beloved husband of Carol Michaelsen Owens; father of Victoria, Edward and Fritz, all of Easton; brother of Clarisse Loughran of Fairfield, CT., and Howard T. Owens, Jr. of Bridgeport, CT. Memorial Mass, Egan Chapel of St. Ignatius Loyola, Fairfield University, Fairfield, Connecticut, Monday, November 3 at 11:00 A.M. In memory of Bob, contributions to the Robert M. Owens Memorial Fund, Fairfield University, North Benson Road, Fairfield, Connecticut 06430.

title: The Barefaced Pleasure Of a Shave in Turkey
description: IT takes a certain amount of faith to let a perfect stranger singe your ears, stick scissors up your nose and run a straight razor around your throat.

title: Disney Cruise Ship and Newest Ride Hit Snags
description: All those people who sneer at Disney entertainment because it seems a bit too perfect got two examples to the contrary recently. Two showpiece enterprises -- Disney's first cruise ship and a high-tech thrill ride at Epcot Center in Walt Disney World -- are suffering delays.

title: Alison Ebner and Mark Herman
description: Alison Barbara Ebner, a daughter of Sydell and Stanley Ebner of Westbury, N.Y., was married last evening in Roslyn, N.Y., to Mark Adam Herman, a son of Ina and Herbert L. Herman of Westfield, N.J. Cantor Henry Weintaub performed the ceremony at the Roslyn Clairmont Hotel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLAZER, ALBERT
description: GLAZER-Albert. Beloved husband of the late Cecelia. Cherished brother of Bea Rubenstein, Fannie Sterling and Will and Esther Glazer. Loving uncle of many nieces and nephews, and grandnieces and grandnephews. Services at ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer'' Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd. and 76th Rd., Forest Hills, Sunday, 11 AM.

title: Playoff Pitchers Show the Price of Many Teams' Impatience
description: Patience might be a virtue, but it is not a trait that managers and general managers often practice. To find a glaring example of their impatience, look no further than the recently concluded playoffs and World Series.

title: Belts to Fit Any Waist And Almost Any Ego
description: TALK about an initial public offering.

title: Keeping Cool, or Feeling the Heat, as Wall St. Ignited
description: Rio de Janeiro

title: Classics: Strings and Ellington
description: THE winds, brass and percussion sections of the Fairfield Orchestra are still resting up from their Carnegie Hall debut on Oct. 23, but the ''Sensational Strings'' have an 8 o'clock Saturday date at the ensemble's more usual performing venue in the Norwalk Concert Hall.

title: Anne R. McIntyre, Raymond Merritt
description: Anne Regina McIntyre, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel E. McIntyre of Short Hills, N.J., was married last evening to Raymond William Merritt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond W. Merritt of New York. Msgr. Harrold A. Murray performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Style; Lights! Camera! Fashion!
description: In an early scene in ''Fashions of 1934,'' a feature film made (naturally) in 1933, a Park Avenue matron is seen buying a Paris original -- an exclusive, she is assured -- for $375. Cut to the woman at home, wearing the dress, about to interview a prospective maid sent over by the employment agency. In walks the candidate, wearing the same dress, which, she proclaims, she bought for only $16.95. Copying -- the scourge of fashion then and now -- is the somewhat unlikely subject of a plot that revolves around William Powell, an entrepreneur whose latest fly-by-night venture specializes in bootleg drawings of designer clothes, and Bette Davis, a fashion illustrator and his partner in crime. Inevitably, their work takes them to Paris, where they open their own couture house, the Maison Elegance, with an extended fashion show choreographed by Busby Berkeley. When the filming was over, Davis reportedly announced that she would never make another movie in which the clothes got more attention than she did.

title: Rescuing Treasures of Persian Judiac Heritage
description: SOMETIME in the early part of 1995, an Iranian artist from Isfahan who spent a lifetime carving Torah covers and plaques in minute detail tried to send his collection to the West.

title: It's Shakeout Time At New Charter Schools
description: WHEN the Integrated Day Charter School's computers were delivered, on a Friday morning several weeks after the school opened in Norwich, it generated excitement among teachers, parents and students. While one of the parents hooked up the new machines in the library, an open area of bookshelves, used tables and comfy chairs, students drifted by to try out some of the new software's tricks.

title: 'The High-Rise, High-End Life'
description: To the Editor:

title: Passing
description: THE BLACK NOTEBOOKS

title: Baroque Concertos By Chamber Orchestra
description: THE Chappaqua Chamber Orchestra begins its season at Temple Beth El of Northern Westchester in Chappaqua next Saturday at 8 P.M., as the music director, James Sadewhite, showcases a number of his ensemble musicians in an evening of Baroque concertos -- by Marcello, for oboe; Vivaldi, one for bassoon, another for a pair of trumpets, and Bach, for two violins. Tickets will be available at the door, or they may be obtained by calling 921-4642.

title: Keeping Cool, or Feeling the Heat, as Wall St. Ignited
description: Hong Kong

title: On Language; Hair-Raising Fund-Raising
description: Lanny J. Davis, the White House senior spinmeister, used his favorite modifier again the other day: ''We understand that the military office . . . may have inadvertently neglected to photocopy the first two sheets.''

title: The World; How to Fix A Crowded World: Add People
description: IN the 200 years since Thomas Malthus published his ''Essay on the Principle of Population'' and threw a scare into the human race about the limits of the earth's resources, people everywhere have been asking: Are there too many of us?

title: F.Y.I.
description: It Wasn't Built in a Day

title: Roman Candles
description: CARDINAL GALSWORTHY By Edward R. F. Sheehan. 493 pp. New York: Viking. $26.95.

title: Dr. De Simone, Mr. Segalla
description: Dr. Deborah Maria De Simone, the daughter of Sally R. De Simone and Herbert F. De Simone of Providence, R.I., was married yesterday to Mark David Segalla, the son of Julia D. Segalla of Canaan, Conn., and the late Anthony D. Segalla. The Rev. Dr. David P. Proctor performed the ceremony at the Beneficent Congregational Church in Providence.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEIRSTEIN, ABRAHAM
description: FEIRSTEIN-Abraham. 14 years gone by. Remembered everyday with love. Edna

title: Cheers, With Food
description: GIUSEPPE'S is the kind of place my father loved, a restaurant above a bar. It's the kind of place where you'd never find women like my mother.

title: The Slipper Still Fits, Though the Style Is New
description: ON SUNDAY EVENING, MARCH 31, 1957, 14 years to the day after they introduced Broadway to the pioneering inventions of ''Oklahoma!,'' Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, by then the reigning storytellers of American mass culture, tried something else new: a 90-minute musical fairy tale for television starring the toast of Broadway, a 22-year-old British ingenue named Julie Andrews, moonlighting on her night off from ''My Fair Lady.''

title: Thai Envoy Loses Jewels In Burglary at Her Home
description: Thieves slipped through a second-story window into the home of Thailand's consul general on Friday night, stealing more than $500,000 worth of jewelry as 15 people prepared for a wedding downstairs, the police said.

title: Ms. Valinoti And Mr. White
description: Marguerite Theresa Valinoti, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J. Valinoti of Murray Hill, N.J., was married yesterday to James Terry White, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. White of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Thomas F. Blind, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at St. Teresa of Avila Church in Summit, N.J.

title: The Beauty of Beast Barracks
description: It is refreshing to note that West Point is shifting the source of stress in the summer training environment away from screaming cadre and toward challenging training events like rappelling, field marches and gas chambers.

title: An Investor's Guide
description: Starting in Hong Kong and working its way around the globe, wave after wave of investor frenzy battered world stock markets last week. Emotion seemed to dictate the markets' ups and downs, and professionals proved to be more panicky than individual investors.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE TASTE OF A MAN

title: Adventure Travel: Aiming (Really) High
description: There are people who will pay almost anything to fly in space -- or so a new company hopes. Space Adventures, a venture of Mike McDowell, president of Quark Expeditions and Omega World Travel, is planning sub-orbital flights and other space-related adventures.

title: 'Sweetheart, Get Me Rewrite'
description: AT Kean University, the editorial staff of The Independent, the campus paper, has not been able to put out an issue all semester.

title: THE GUIDE
description: DRAWINGS OF DANCERS

title: Mild-Mannered? Tough? Fassel Selling His Ideas
description: Twenty-two years ago, Jim Fassel was a salesman for an air-conditioning company. On face value, that seems like a job that would suit Fassel, a guy who looks at home in a business suit.

title: Sculptor's Objects Take On Lives of Their Own
description: KITCHEN tables, rubber boots and other inanimate objects take on a life of their own at the hands of Roman Signer, the Swiss sculptor. He uses water pressure and wind to power transformations that can last a matter of seconds, leaving only what he calls sculptural remains. Some 40 photographs of these transformations are on display through Dec. 23 at the Swiss Institute, a cultural center founded in 1986 to promote artistic dialogue between Switzerland and the United States.

title: The Future Wears White; Nurses Treading on Doctors' Turf
description: MARY BIDGOOD-WILSON and her business partner of five years, Wendy Wilson, provide basic health care for 4,300 people in rural central New Hampshire, where doctors are scarce. Both women are nurse midwives. Ms. Bidgood-Wilson is also a family nurse practitioner. Insurers pay them the same rate as doctors.

title: The Beauty of Beast Barracks
description: My son graduated from West Point in the class of 1994. Your article brought back memories, some sad, some happy, but all worth remembering. I imagine parents whose sons and daughters survived the dreaded Beast Barracks would agree with me.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Long Rain

title: Reveling in the Curlicues Of a Victorian Melodrama
description: HERE'S a prediction: Tomorrow, the day after PBS presents the two-hour ''Masterpiece Theater'' production of ''The Moonstone,'' viewers will be storming bookstores for additional sensational stories by Wilkie Collins. In his day, Collins, the English novelist, was the uncontested master of melodrama. This adaptation of his 1868 gem offers modern audiences a tantalizing taste of the literary form that had Victorian ladies swooning discreetly behind their fans.

title: Officers in Brooklyn Kill Man Said to Have Gun
description: Police officers in Brooklyn killed a man on Halloween night after receiving a report that the suspect had a shotgun and was menacing people, the police said.

title: Oct. 26-Nov. 1; Crime and Crack
description: The homicide rate has dropped for five straight years, but politicians, law enforcement officials and criminologists have been divided on the causes of the decline. Mayors and police chiefs point to their innovative tactics. Conservatives say it is tougher sentencing laws.

title: Harvard Rips Dartmouth For Ivy League Supremacy
description: It would have been fitting had John Lyons, the Dartmouth coach, just handed over the Ivy League trophy -- a large silver bowl -- to his Harvard counterpart, Tim Murphy, after today's game and said, ''Here, it's yours.''

title: MARKET WATCH ; These Good Times Will End With a Whimper
description: The bull market lives on, thanks to millions of Americans who did exactly what they had told pollsters they would do: They stayed calm when Wall Street panicked. Some even bought stocks.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Remember the Morning

title: The Egyptians Also Called It an Art
description: RUDI KARUKAS of Stamford has a fetish for skeletons. But a tattoo? On her lower back, right above her tan line? Her co-workers were appalled at the prospect. Her husband, Paul, refused to accompany her when she had it done.

title: Adultery's Double Standard
description: Power is what is missing from Roiphe's account of adultery's double standard. A woman's affair redresses some imbalance of power in a marriage; a man's intensifies it.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: DANCE FROM CHINA

title: Marcia C. Magid, Paul B. D'Ari
description: Marcia Caryl Magid and Paul Benjamin D'Ari were married last evening in Washington. Herbert Blinder, an adjunct leader of the Washington Ethical Society, officiated at the Kennedy-Warren Ballroom.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Suzuki GLX Plus; A Neat Bit of Style That Comes at a Price
description: SUZUKI is a mere dot on America's automotive landscape, a name probably better known for motorcycles than for cars and sport utilities. But back home in Japan the company is a serious player, with two modern plants and 14,000 employees churning out vehicles for distribution in 171 countries. And it has ambitious plans for the American market, with a goal of 100,000 sales annually -- triple the current volume -- by the year 2000.

title: Stormy Weather Cuts Power and Delays Flights
description: Heavy rains and high winds delayed flights at New York airports and knocked down power lines across the region yesterday, leaving tens of thousands of households without electricity, officials said.

title: THEATER REVIEWS ; A Woman as Oppressing as Her Creator's Killer
description: ''THE House of Bernarda Alba'' is not a 2,000-year-old Greek tragedy, but a Spanish drama from 1936. Tell that to Emily Mann, and she's likely to ask what's the difference.

title: There Are Exclusives, and Exclusives
description: It was about a year ago that the would-be seller of a two-bedroom co-op on Manhattan's Upper East Side came to the offices of the Douglas Elliman brokerage firm and signed an agreement giving the company the exclusive right to sell the apartment.

title: The World; Prosperity's Traffic Jams Eastern Europe's Roads
description: THE Poles are having, but not really enjoying, a love affair with the car. It's not quite the same romance that Americans had when they cruised Main Street in the 50's in their new Chevys and Pontiacs.

title: At Sales Time, What Price Discretion?
description: CRAMMED into a less than commodious conference room one recent Monday afternoon, 15 sales agents from the Halstead Property Company hunched over a distressed-wood table, sipping soda, crunching potato chips and poring over column after column of real estate classifieds.

title: An Official Sulk
description: To the Editor:

title: Non-Orthodox Jews Push for Expanded Religious Role in Israel
description: Rabbi Eric H. Yoffie, president of Reform Judaism's organization that represents 875 synagogues, said the group would continue to press the Israeli Government for official recognition of non-Orthodox rabbis in Israel.

title: Historical Flourishes at an Inn in Garrison
description: ALTHOUGH the Bird and Bottle serves lunch as well as dinner, it is in the evening that this 18th-century coach stop presents itself to greatest advantage. Worn spots sloping into the old wide-plank floors show time's burnish in the candlelight and commemorate generations of guests gone before. Diners with a historical turn of mind will find it easy to imagine the dusty coaches rattling toward the inn and the dustier Colonial passengers alighting, eager for the warmth and coziness of the inn's hearths as the horses are refreshed. Upstairs, a few guest rooms, each with fireplace and a four-poster, await the truly road weary.

title: Help With the Tax Law
description: The new tax law has mutual fund companies scrambling to assist investors with fund-related decisions. Here are some of the latest guides:

title: Bending the Law
description: Beyond All Reason The Radical Assault on Truth in American Law. By Daniel A. Farber and Suzanna Sherry. 195 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $25.

title: RAIN AND APATHY DOG MAYORAL RACE AS IT WINDS DOWN
description: Confronting pelting rain, bursts of wind and often small crowds, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Ruth W. Messinger headed into the final weekend of their campaign yesterday, as Mr. Giuliani again played what he considers his political trump card -- the latest decrease in crime -- while Ms. Messinger warned that things were not as good as they seemed.

title: POP VIEW; Country's New Women Find Fans Who Get It
description: NOT LONG AGO I encountered the future of country music in the back seat of a mini-van in Baltimore. I was visiting my relatives, and before we could get out of the driveway, my 6-year-old cousin began bouncing up and down shouting, ''Sha-ni-a! Sha-ni-a!'' and refusing to let us leave until Shania Twain's latest CD, ''The Woman in Me,'' was placed on the stereo. When my cousin's favorite song came on, the rock-infused ''(If You're Not in It for Love) I'm Outta Here!,'' she started slicing the air in the manner of a young girl learning to take charge.

title: INSIDE
description: Converted in Ulster

title: Massacre Trials in Rwanda Have Courts on Overload
description: Dressed in a pink prison uniform, the defendant glared at the floor, arms crossed, jaw clenched while a clerk read the charges against her.

title: China's New Generation Wants to Join the World; Better Lives for Women
description: To the Editor:

title: One Game In, and Johnson Has Knicks Just Comfy
description: Larry Johnson slipped into his surroundings Friday night as if he were settling into a favorite easy chair.

title: Absolutely the Last Dodger Memoir Ever
description: More than any other team of that era, the Dodgers fielded a nine-man lineup. Snider, Hodges, Robinson, Furillo, Campanella, Reese, Marshal Blucher, Lamont Cranston, Sir Humphry Davy, Alfred Apaka and the Surf Riders: they all meld together, in memory's crepuscular gloaming, into that something some call ''Dodgerness.'' Which, by the bye, was strictly for the poets. ''About or having to do with the Dodgers baseball club'' was how we kids always put it.

title: Scioli Heading Full Throttle to Key West
description: Daniel Scioli, a champion powerboat racer from Argentina, is no stranger to speed. He is also used to life in the fast lane.

title: Whistle-Blowers Need Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: Taiwan Artists Who Flaunt Their Traditions
description: Tracing Taiwan: Contemporary Works On Paper

title: China's New Generation Wants to Join the World
description: To the Editor:

title: Adultery's Double Standard
description: The goals of feminism amaze me lately, but hectoring women to seek fleshy liberation through adultery is frightening. In a world of disintegrating families, out-of-control children and sexually transmitted diseases, we now must contend with adultress chic.

title: Ex-Tabloid Journalist Turns to Crime Thrillers
description: AS a crime novelist investigating a double murder involving the wife of a television executive, how far would you go to get the story? ''As far as it takes,'' said Joanna Elm of Woodbury, a journalist turned novelist.

title: Young Director's Film on Teen-Age Life
description: THE opening night of the Hamptons Film Festival is a bit blurry for Mark Schiffer, a writer-director. To put it mildly, he was riding on a high, but not the kind of chemical high the characters in his film, ''The Strong Island Boys,'' are on.

title: A Musical Triumph It Isn't
description: YOU MAY WANT TO CARRY EARPLUGS IF you go to the Royale Theater to see ''Triumph of Love,'' the new, modestly scaled musical adaptation of Pierre Carlet de Chamblain de Marivaux's 18th-century French comedy. The seven cast members have been so miked that even a whisper could be pumped up to reach every cranny in Yankee Stadium.

title: As Hedge Funds Grow, Their Walls Don't Look So High
description: TRADITIONALLY, hedge funds have been to investing what Park Avenue is to real estate. But these vehicles for the rich are now becoming both more common and modestly more accessible.

title: Democracies That Take Liberties
description: The American diplomat Richard Holbrooke pondered a problem on the eve of the September 1996 elections in Bosnia, which were meant to restore civic life to the region. ''Suppose the election was declared free and fair,'' he said, and those elected are ''racists, fascists, separatists, who are publicly opposed to [peace and reintegration]. That is the dilemma.''

title: BENEFITS
description: A Jamesian Evening

title: Catharine Warren, Bradley Geist
description: Catharine Keating Warren was married in New York on Friday evening to Bradley Bowers Geist. The Rev. Stuart Hoke performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church.

title: Church's Labyrinth Offers Path to Peace
description: RESIDENTS of this community and nearby areas have become used to seeking peace and enlightenment despite the noise of passing Metro-North trains. In fact, notices at the Pelham station urge commuters to ''Find Your Way Home.'' The path suggested is a circular labyrinth at the Community Church of the Pelhams nearby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, LEO
description: MEYER-Leo. Of Riverdale, NY (formerly Jaret Int'l an escapee to Shanghai). Beloved husband of the late Ilse. Devoted father of Linda Schoenberg and Marian Meyer. Loving grandfather. Services ''Wien & Wien,'' Englewood, NJ, Sunday, 1 PM, 1-800-322-0533.

title: Marie Breaux, Brian Epstein
description: Nina Marie Breaux, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Valentin D. Breaux of Lafayette, La., is to be married today to Brian Glenn Epstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Epstein of Montclair, N.J. Rabbi Harvey S. Goldman is to perform the ceremony at the Pleasantdale Chateau, a conference center in West Orange, N.J.

title: Q. & A.
description: Changing A Co-op's Bylaws

title: Mott Street? What Street?
description: Remember ''Who's on first'' from Abbott and Costello? Try finding an address on ''What Street.''

title: McGreevey Avoids Personal Definition, and Whitman Asks Why
description: In the final days of Christine Todd Whitman's race for governor four years ago, her campaign abruptly shifted its advertising strategy. After months of television spots attacking the Democratic incumbent, Jim Florio, it began showing a softer side -- scenes with Mrs. Whitman's children and a feel-good endorsement from a popular former Governor, Thomas Kean.

title: Expansion Faces Fight in Southold
description: SETTLED in 1640, Southold is one of the earliest English settlements on the North Fork. Some residents now fear that their sense of place and quality of life are in jeopardy.

title: A Garden For Adults Of Any Age
description: A WOMAN at the East Shore Regional Adult Day Center in Branford was wheeled outside for a breath of fresh air one day a couple of years ago. She turned to her attendant, as Donald Hyatt, chairman of the board, tells it, and remarked how wonderful it was to be outdoors.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Neighborbood Report last Sunday about a party honoring Rita Nealon Cooley, a retired professor at New York University, misstated the age of one guest, Justice Joseph Fisch of State Supreme Court in the Bronx. He is 64, not 68.

title: A Show of Animal Photographs Stresses Beauty and Character
description: A FROG breeches the smooth surface of a lake; three Angora goats stand side by side, looking like flappers in a chorus line; cats foregather, cattle muse, and jellyfish undulate -- all of it in ''Fauna.'' On view at the Candace Perich Gallery here, this show of 44 animal photographs will attract animal fans but is not aimed at them -- obviously not, since it is an all black and white production and one devoid of sentimentality. That is, the 10 photographers involved treat wild and domestic animals not as accessories to human life but rather as organisms existing in the same context as humanity but each possessed of its own beauty, character and sense of purpose.

title: White House Scandal
description: Alan J. Pakula's ALL THE PRESIDENT'S MEN (1976) is a toweringly right and realistic account of the steady journalistic probing and sleuthing that caused the downfall of the Nixon Administration. With Dustin Hoffman and Robert Redford (above) as the two young Washington Post reporters, Carl Bernstein and Bob Woodward, and Jason Robards as their editor Ben Bradlee, the film ticks off exploding events after the bungled Watergate break-in, as the two sleuthing writers close in and contact an array of Washington characters. The picture was exquisitely directed by Mr. Pakula. If you missed this back when, grab it now, or savor it again -- TUESDAY at 8 P.M. on FAM. Howard Thompson

title: Pre-Hours Primping With the Power Birds
description: A BIRD'S metabolism is so small that when it wakes up at sunrise, the urge to eat is fierce. This time of year, with all the migratory birds passing through town, Central Park is as busy as Restaurant Row before an 8 P.M. curtain. In the Ramble, small songbirds that have been flying all night are feeding alongside resident starlings and sparrows. Blue herons and cormorants are working the Reservoir and ponds as if they were sushi bars at lunch hour. It's a scene.

title: Elizabeth Haiken
description: Haiken is the author of ''Venus Envy: A History of Cosmetic Surgery,'' just published by Johns Hopkins University Press.

title: The View From: White Plains ; Retiring From Office, O'Rourke Plans to Stay Off the Stage
description: THE retiring County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, was sitting in his office with some visitors recently, trying to find out how most concisely to describe this coming Tuesday as it relates to him. After a minute or two, he said, ''This is the first Election Day that I'm holding an office that I'm not running for.''

title: Party Elders vs. Money Grubbers
description: As Congress winds down, the cause of campaign finance reform is battered but still alive. After preaching a funeral oration that convinced some spin-friendly commentators, Trent Lott was forced to guarantee a vote next spring on the McCain-Feingold bill. House Speaker Newt Gingrich agreed Friday to allow a similar vote. The day's other big event was Senator Fred Thompson's announcement that his investigative committee will suspend its hearings. He was frustrated by his own overreaching at times, but even more by fleeing witnesses, by White House foot-dragging and by a coalition of special-interest pols led by Mr. Lott and the Democrat's John Glenn.

title: Two Goals By Palffy Spark Isles
description: ISLANDERS 4, KINGS 2

title: Clinton, Marathon and Fans Could Tie Up the City Streets
description: Start with more than 30,000 people running 26.2 miles of streets through five boroughs. Add a Presidential motorcade. Mix in thousands of football fans headed to Giants Stadium. Stir in a little rain. A recipe for gridlock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOHN, NAOMI
description: SOHN-Naomi. Our beautiful, sweet Naomi, may you finally find the peace and love that you so deserve. We will miss you and you will forever be in our hearts. Uncle Pinky, Ann, Robin, Steve

title: Bonds Are Back, but Be Wary When Buying
description: IN the wake of the stock market's canyon-sized dip on Monday, many investors moved money into Treasury securities, which sent their prices surging.

title: Welcome! And Thanks For Lunch
description: Ideally, the union of new employee and new job is a match made in heaven. The happy, eager employee receives a figurative embrace of welcome, a supply of information to smooth the transitional path and perhaps a few thoughtful trinkets to show that while the company means business, it possesses both a caring heart and a sense of humor. Well, as these letters indicate, sometimes there's heaven on earth, and sometimes it seems there's hell to pay.

title: Decades Later, the Quest for Meaning Goes On
description: I HAVEN'T really the foggiest idea what some of it means . . . But if we stop and discuss every line we'll never open.''

title: Laura Silverstone And Jan Frouman
description: Laura Stephanie Silverstone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Silverstone of New York, was married last evening to Jan David Frouman, the son of Barbara Ann Curley of Monkton, Md., and Malcolm Frouman of Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbi Charles Lippman officiated with the Rev. L. Denver Hart, an Episcopal priest, at the University Club in New York.

title: Feminism's Failure As Political Ideologue
description: The opinion expressed in ''A Disastrous Loss for Feminists'' [Oct. 19] speaks to the heart of why the feminist movement, as political ideologue, fails. If the person in question was male, this action of choosing family over business would have been lauded.

title: Dina Eisner And Eric Green
description: Dina Michelle Eisner, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joel W. Eisner of Phoenixville, Pa., was married last evening to Eric Howard Green, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy E. Green of New York. Rabbi Gerald I. Wolpe performed the ceremony at the Har Zion Temple in Penn Valley, Pa.

title: Making the Most of a Bumpkin With a Big Heart
description: FOR TOO LONG, OPERA ON VIDEO has tended to mean either scratchy, starchy black-and-white archival footage or curiously didactic and antiseptic ''modern'' interpretations of beloved classics.

title: Adultery's Double Standard
description: I agree, Katie Roiphe, that there should be no double standard where adultery is concerned (Adultery's Double Standard, Oct. 12). But Prince Charles is still no Emma Bovary. Unlike Emma, the Prince has civic power and money of his own, plus a precedent for solving his problems -- namely, by giving up the throne to marry the woman he loves.

title: Oct. 26-Nov. 1; DDT and Breast Cancer
description: One more environmental scare bit the dust last week as scientists from the Harvard School of Public Health reported that their large and meticulous study found no evidence that exposure to the chemicals DDT and PCB's are linked to breast cancer.

title: A Composer and a Concert Violinist Team Up for a World Premiere
description: MICHELLE EKIZIAN and Ani Kavafian share an Armenian heritage and the profession of music. But Ms. Ekizian, an award-winning composer, and Ms. Kavafian, a nationally known concert violinist, had never worked together before Ms. Ekizian was commissioned to write a piece for the eighth annual Interfaith Concert of Remembrance at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Manhattan.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: A New Borders With Books, Coffee, Music and Authors

title: A Marco Polo Going Backward At Full Tilt
description: THE BUSY CHINESE-BORN composer Tan Dun, who will conduct the American premiere of his ''Marco Polo'' at the New York City Opera on Saturday evening, is about to move out of his apartment in Chinatown in Manhattan. Like his works, it is crammed with instruments, ancient and modern, from all over the world. And it is dominated by a Ping-Pong table, which he uses not only for table tennis but also for dinner parties and as an orchestration desk.

title: The Things That the Great Lived With
description: ALONG WITH THE PLEASURES of reading often comes a desire to enter into an author's life as a way of enhancing the experience and picturing the times. The Pierpont Morgan Library, a famously rich trove for anyone seriously interested in the written word, has always collected, along with books, manuscripts and drawings, a variety of objects imbued with the aura of the authors or statesmen who once possessed them.

title: Yankees' Outreach
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Change Is Choppy Sea For a Navy In Africa
description: Until a year ago, this strike craft was called the Kobie Coetsee. Mr. Coetsee, a former Minister of Defense, is still alive but the South Africa that named ships after apartheid-era leaders is not.

title: Adultery's Double Standard
description: That women who commit adultery do so for the same unglorious reasons men do is beside the point. The positive symbolism attached to women's affairs by the press is merely another instance of assuming that equality is achieved by meeting male standards. Remember those female power suits of the 1980's, replete with ties? Or the denial of familial roles by ambitious women of the 70's and 80's?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHARMAN, FRIDA
description: SCHARMAN-Frida. Died peacefully Saturday, October 25 at her home after a long illness. Born in 1908, she was the daughter of August Charles Scharman and Lillie Rueger Scharman of Brooklyn. Miss Scharman was a lifetime resident of New York City and was a talented squash racquets player. She represented the United States against Great Britain in 1931. She also won innumerable tennis titles in doubles at The River Club in New York City, Piping Rock Club, Locust Valley, and The Heights Casino in Brooklyn. She was a graduate of Smith College, Northampton, MA., and of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, New York. She joined the American Red Cross in 1942 and served in London during the Blitz. After the war, she was a volunteer at the United Nations. She leaves a niece, Ann Hester Huntoon, Charleston, SC, two grand-nieces, Susan Payson, Tucson, AZ, and Jill Kennedy, San Diego, CA., and a cousin, Mrs. John MacKay, Locust Valley. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Red Cross, POB 37243, Washington, D.C. 20013, marked for the Frida Scharman Memorial Fund.

title: Perth
description: Enriched by discoveries of gold and diamonds and tucked between expanses of treeless plains and an even vaster Indian ocean, Perth is a bright nugget of civilization amid much emptiness. Farther from Sydney than from Jakarta, Perth is one of the world's most isolated major cities, and while it's smaller than Sydney and Melbourne, it's growing faster than either. It is the capital of the gargantuan state of Western Australia, three times the size of Texas. Most of the state's two million inhabitants live in and around the city.

title: Spirits Rise In the Park After Dark

The Central Park Conservancy, which spends all year asking for treats, was holding its Halloween Ball. Brightly feathered masks were handed out at the entrance for those arriving merely as their munificent selves.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE; As Cap Replaces Kaffiyeh, Arab Parents Look for Help
description: Sana Yousefi, 14, wears gel on her hair and jeans. She listens to rap music and speaks with a heavy Brooklyn accent. Although Sana was born in New York, her family is from Yemen, one of the most traditional Arab countries. Her parents wanted to raise her the way they grew up: unconditional respect for family, no dating and no parties.

title: Calling All Pundits: No More Predictions
description: A MILLENNIUM IS LOOMING. WE are in for a lot of big thought and big talk. Resist! Big thought and big talk have made nothing but trouble for music. My millennial wish is that the 21st century will discard them and get over the obsession with centuries and millenniums that gives people the itch to micromanage decades.

title: Rising Fires Renew Threat to Amazon

In southern Para state near the Amazon frontier, people gasping for air have collapsed and ended up in hospitals. In the city of Manaus, the sun has disappeared for days at a time.

For example, there's Mother Noella Marcellino, a microbiologist, Fulbright scholar and expert on cheese production. And Mother Dolores, the actress formerly known as Dolores Hart, a 50's stage and screen regular who was Elvis Presley's sidekick in King Creole.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIPRUT, SOLOMON, M.D.
description: CIPRUT-Solomon, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the untimely death of Dr. Solomon Ciprut. Dr. Ciprut was associated with Maimonides Medical Center in the Department of Surgery for over 40 years. He was a staunch supporter of the Medical Staff and played a very active part in its leadership, serving as President from 1973 to 1974. He was loved and respected by all who knew him. He will be sorely missed by everyone. Sincere condolences are extended to his entire family. As per the family's wishes, donations to the Solomon Ciprut, M.D. Memorial Fund at Maimonides Medical Center can be sent to the Medical Staff Office. Warren Wexelman, M.D., Pres. Jacob Shani, M.D., Pres. Elect David Feldman, M.D. Secretary Salvatore DeGliuomini, M.D., Treasurer

title: When Looking Neat Helps the Appetite

Our handsome table had a glass top, which was my undoing. My mother sent me from the table to put on shoes. Her shock then was equal to mine now as I read in the Westchester Weekly about diners showing up at restaurants in T-shirts [''Upscale Tastes Demand Quality, and Restaurants Raise Sights,'' Oct. 5].

What a reversal of centuries of male tradition. But our Emma Bovary? Give me a break. A major difference between Charles and that touchstone heroine is that his adulterous love was reciprocated.

title: Couple Accused of Beating Daughters Tell of Adoption Ordeal
description: In Moscow one night in May, Richard and Karen Thorne watched one of their newly adopted daughters tuck her doll under the covers, whack it on the head with a shoe, then calmly straighten the covers. It seemed just part of her routine, like a good-night kiss. Only it was a good-night smack.

title: Lives; I Was a Red-Diaper Baby
description: I never thought i would feel nostalgic about Communism. As a 60's activist and child of lefty parents, I once took as gospel beliefs that now seem quaint: human beings are basically good; if people, not capitalists, owned the means of production, poverty would disappear; economic equality could cure all social ills. Misguided and dangerous though Communism was, the passion for social justice and compassion for working people that it represented is gone from the planet, and I, for one, miss it.

The church's stained-glass windows are the color of the sea, and inside, the building seems submerged in deep, turquoise water.

title: The Beauty of Beast Barracks

Douglas MacArthur's 1962 speech to the corps of cadets in which he said, Your mission remains fixed, determined, inviolable -- it is to win our wars.

title: A Child of Difference
description: I was born with hypo-pituitary dwarfism in 1945, when doctors understood little about my condition (Lives: A Child of Difference, by Lisa Abelow Hedley, Oct. 12). As a result, it wasn't actually diagnosed until I was 12. As a child I suffered from an acute sense that something terrible and secret was wrong with me. I was very small for my age (I'm now 4 feet 9 inches), my head was large for a little girl and my nose, which had no cartilage, spread insistently across my face. In retrospect, I realize how much easier it might have been for me to know, from an early age, that I had a specific hormonal disorder.

title: Lewis Has Shaped Up. So Has His Game.

title: Croatia
description: To the Editor: Your article ''The Dalmatian Coast Beckons Once More'' by Perri Klass (Sept. 28) brought to mind an episode involving my wife, our three children (ages 15, 11 and 5) and me while driving from Budapest to Dubrovnik, by way of Zagreb, Rijeka and Split. Our daughter, the teen-ager, met two local boys, also 15, at the beach in Split. They spent the day with her, practicing their limited English, and took us on a tour of Diocletian's Palace. This was in July 1963.

title: Hot on the Trail Of Che Guevara

At least three biographies of Guevara have been published recently, formal commemorative ceremonies took place last month in Bolivia, and informal remembrances were going on elsewhere in South America.

title: When Really Big Creatures Roamed
description: THESE dinosaurs don't move, make loud crowing sounds or scare toddlers. Rather, in ''Discovering Dinosaurs: Solving Prehistoric Puzzles'' at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich through Jan. 4, the change-of-pace focus is on how scientists and artists collaborate to reconstruct dinosaurs: their appearance, social behavior, hunting methods and the world in which they lived.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY

The price also covers hotel accommodations with an American breakfast daily, sightseeing and an evening's entertainment, hotel service charges and taxes, transfers and entrance fees.

title: A Hometown Memorial Service For Johnny Vander Meer
description: The last time Midland Park honored its native son Johnny Vander Meer was April 1996 when a permanent display of his memorabilia, including baseballs from his back-to-back-no-hitters for Cincinnati in 1938, was dedicated in the library. The occasion, a kind of celebration of the player, the man and the town, drew an overflow crowd.

title: Bring Me the Script of Gianni Versace
description: ''As soon as I heard Versace was killed, I thought: movie,'' says Sam Lupowitz, chairman of Pan Am Pictures, a small Miami Beach company that is filming The Versace Murder, ''a quickie movie about the killing of Gianni Versace that will be ready for distribution next month. At least two other companies have entered the race to be first, but they're losing to Lupowitz, who got rolling on Sept. 13, less than two months after Versace was killed. Isn't he exploiting a tragedy? ''Did you ever see that movie Spielberg made? 'Schindler's List'? ''he says. That's my answer.'' Whatever that means, Lupowitz's $5-million Gianni-pic will be finished soon; the climactic scenes were shot early last month. Here's a look from the set.

title: Science Fiction
description: The uses of science fiction are many. The same tricks of the trade that animate so many whiz-bang genre stories -- the futuristic settings, the hardware of space travel or time travel -- also provide a ready-made framework for the modern novel of ideas. Because it gives writers the freedom to invent and populate entire societies, even worlds, science fiction has become the natural home of the anti-utopia -- the cautionary novel of ideas as practiced in this century by Yevgeny Zamyatin, Aldous Huxley and George Orwell.

title: A Growing Festival Spreads Jazz's Joyful Message
description: Shirley Cook, a caterer, has been a fan of the city's annual jazz festival in recent years, attending performances whenever she could. So when she and her partners opened a downtown lunch emporium called the Commerce Food Court in May, she made sure that this time around she would be serving up some jazz with the usual buffet of cold and hot entrees.

title: Southern Fortitude
description: THE CONFEDERATE WAR By Gary W. Gallagher. Illustrated. 218 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $24.95.

title: Adultery's Double Standard
description: In her article Roiphe writes, This hypocrisy about male and female sexuality is so acceptable, so much a part of our culture, that we barely notice it. Indeed, there are other gender-based double standards that have become so acceptable that we barely notice them. One is the increasing move toward girls-only schools when women are hellbent on getting into traditionally male-only schools (military and otherwise). Most insidious, however, is the double standard regarding domestic violence: when a woman uses a form of violence against a man (other than in self-defense), it is often excused as getting emotional, whereas when a man hits a woman for any reason, he is automatically called a batterer.

title: The Crash and the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBERTS, TRACY KEITH
description: ROBERTS-Tracy Keith, Oct. 31, 1977. 20 years have passed and the pain of never being able to see your face or hear your voice still remains. You're in my heart and my mind always. I will always love you with the very special love we had. Hugs and kisses, Mom

title: In Off Season, East End Offers Bargains Galore
description: KNOWLEDGEABLE Long Islanders know that the best time to visit the Hamptons is when the city types have returned to Manhattan and the weather turns crisp and golden.

title: France Trumps the U.S.
description: France won the world bridge championship here today, defeating the United States by 27 international match points.

title: Schools' Books on Gay Families Stir Seattle
description: A city councilwoman's efforts to place books about gay families in the school libraries has run into strong opposition from some conservatives in this city where most parents seem to have accepted the move.

title: The Rolling Stones Keep Fans Jumping
description: ONCE they got started on Oct. 25 at the Capitol Theater on Westchester Avenue here for their MTV ''Live From the 10 Spot'' concert, the Rolling Stones acted as if they would never stop.

title: Adultery's Double Standard
description: The motivations and circumstances of adulterers and other transgressors are always individual, usually complex and generally only ambiguously revealed. Roiphe's protest-too-much position belies a state of adolescent rebellion, perhaps aimed at her mother, Anne Roiphe, whose illuminating feminist writings have enriched our understanding of the human heart. A potentially insightful writer, Katie Roiphe is succumbing to the media mantra of our times: simplify, simplify, sell, sell. Or is it just her youth?

title: Founder of Poverty Program Will be Honored
description: Monsignor Vincent E. Puma, who built a comprehensive poverty program in Paterson called Eva's Village out of a basement soup kitchen, may have retired, but he is not forgotten. Friends are organizing a dinner for him on Nov. 13 at the Madison Hotel in Convent Station.

title: Knapping Stones As in the Days of Old
description: PREHISTORIC skills drew blood and sweat from modern practitioners at the ''knap-in'' held here recently at Croton Point Park by the county's Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation. Knapping is the technique used by early people to shape stones into weapons and tools.

title: Oct. 26-Nov. 1; No Big Hoop
description: Knowing they had paid their dues in their profession, Dee Kantner and Violet Palmer kept wondering what all the fuss was about. As Ms. Kantner said, ''If we weren't qualified, we wouldn't be here.''

title: Americans Are Waiting to Exhale
description: Few enjoy the poisonous intensity of Mexico City's air pollution, but Bora Milutinovic, the coach of Mexico's national team, could not hide his glee as he peered through a window and saw that a choking cloud of yellow smog was blanketing the city.

title: Commercial Property/Lodging in New York City; Hotel Occupancy and Room Rates Are Up
description: BERNARD GOLDBERG stood in the lobby of the Roger Williams Hotel at Madison Avenue and 31st Street, waved his arms expansively and explained to a visitor, ''You 're standing where the noodle shop used to be.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We're the people who suffered the consequences, we're the ones who carried the coffins down our streets, who visited friends in prison and who have had to come to terms with having taken others lives.''

title: VIEW ; Andy Warhol's Nocturnal Exposures
description: I WAS a Columbia graduate student when I went to work for Andy Warhol Enterprises in 1970, but I soon dropped out because I was learning a lot of things they didn't teach at film school. For example, one evening in the middle of a lively gallery party Andy said something to me about how hard we were working. I thought he was talking about what was going on at the Factory that week, what was going on with the films, what was going on with Interview magazine. But no, he was talking about the party. ''Oh, this is such hard work,'' he moaned.

title: Jay Bluestine, Meredith Gunsberg
description: Meredith Lee Gunsberg, a daughter of Trudi and Franklin Gunsberg of Ramsey, N.J., is to be married this afternoon to Jay Howard Bluestine, a son of Elinor Sands of Floral Park, Queens, and Richard Bluestine of Hewlett, N.Y. Rabbi Milton Weinberg is to officiate at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Mixing It Up
description: STRANGERS TO THE TRIBE Portraits of Interfaith Marriage. By Gabrielle Glaser. 265 pp. Boston: A Marc Jaffe Book/Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.

title: Gloria Cestero Diaz, 87, Leader Among Puerto Rican Immigrants
description: Gloria Cestero Diaz, a champion of New York's Puerto Rican community since its early days some 60 years ago, died on Oct. 24 at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged. A resident of the Upper West Side of Manhattan, she was 87.

title: Oct. 26-Nov. 1; Thompson Halts The Hearings
description: After 32 days of public hearings on campaign finance practices, Senator Fred Thompson pulled the plug last week. ''I will not be holding hearings just for the sake of additional hearings,'' he declared, saying that he will now focus on filing a final report of his findings by the end of the year.

title: Bellport Beats West Islip On Big Day for Slogging
description: Long Island

title: Adultery's Double Standard
description: I have read many exceptional articles, in this magazine and elsewhere, on subjects that in my opinion were of significantly greater importance than Roiphe's on the gender dual standard. However, never before have I been as inspired to express my reaction to a piece. Roiphe is right on point. The examples she uses for illustration are superb. I'm so glad the essay was written by a woman.

title: For Congress in Staten Island
description: The race to succeed Representative Susan Molinari of Staten Island is the only Congressional contest in the nation this year. Given the narrow division in the House, it has been loaded with political import. The hitherto obscure candidates are being showered with millions of dollars for television commercials, and joined on the stump by everyone from President Clinton to former Senator Bob Dole and former President George Bush.

title: Off the Coast of Florida, a Group of Students Rushes to the Rescue
description: DURING a storm on May 9, 1980, a 609-foot freighter, The Summit Venture, plowed into the old Sunshine Skyway Bridge. It hit with with such force that the span, which linked Bradenton, Fla., with St. Petersburg, crumbled into Tampa Bay, taking with it cars, buses and 35 lives.

title: Supreme Court Agrees to Rule On Taxing Cargo at U.S. Ports
description: The Supreme Court has agreed to rule on the constitutionality of a lucrative Federal cargo tax that has yielded more than $1 billion for improving the nation's harbors and shipping channels in the decade it has been in effect.

title: Judge Halts Drug Testing Of High School Athletes
description: A state Superior Court judge last week blocked Ridgefield Park from randomly testing its student athletes for drugs until the district can show in court that drugs are indeed a widespread problem. Judge Sybil R. Moses ruled in Hackensack on Tuesday that affidavits by coaches and players attesting to marijuana and other drug use contained hearsay, and ordered that direct testimony be given some time this spring. The case is believed to be the first challenge to such testing in New Jersey, where a handful of schools engage in the practice.

title: Word for Word/Child Abuse; A Glimpse Into a Hell For Helpless Infants
description: CHILD abuse typically occurs behind a veil of family privacy and deceit. In the current issue of the journal Pediatrics, British researchers part that veil a bit. And the picture they present is harrowing.

title: Amtrak Is Fighting Off a Walkout
description: Almost every afternoon for the last week, a group of union leaders, Transportation Department officials, Amtrak managers and members of Amtrak's Board of Directors have gathered in the office of the Transportation Secretary for discussions that lasted into the early morning hours, with occasional breaks for take-out Chinese food.

title: Last Vestige of the Dodgers in Brooklyn
description: It is a nondescript gray wall, two blocks long, the face of an industrial building a block from the Gowanus Canal. The building houses Consolidated Edison trucks and tools, and the facade melds seamlessly into a Brooklyn neighborhood of warehouses, factories and makeshift signs offering vacant lots for development.

title: New York Hotels Filling Up Faster Than Ever
description: When Manhattan hotels racked up a record 83.6 percent occupancy rate last year, stunningly higher than the 1996 national average of 65.7 percent, the industry's biggest worry -- fittingly, perhaps, for a borough that includes Broadway -- was, What will we do for an encore? So far in 1997, the city is continuing to break hotel-occupancy records, according to the Coopers & Lybrand Lodging Research Network.

title: Streetscapes/The Beaux-Arts Apartments, 307 and 310 East 44th Street; A Matched Pair of 1930 Monuments to Art Deco
description: THE pair of modernistic apartment houses on 44th Street between First and Second Avenues, the first steps in a projected $100 million development, were going to make their architect-developers rich. But it didn't work out that way. The two buildings, with a total of 648 apartments, opened three months after the stock market crash of 1929.

title: The 15th, a World of Its Own
description: MY love affair with Paris's 15th arrondissement began, as love affairs often do, by mere chance. A studio was available there for this past July, the month I had chosen, at a price I could afford to pay. And it was within walking distance of the school where, in my continuing quest for fluency, I would again be studying French.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-19

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOICHIS, HAYIM, M.D.
description: BOICHIS-Hayim, M.D.. The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the passing of a distinguished pediatrician and medical educator who was associated with our medical school for 35 years. A uniquely gifted teacher, Dr. Boichis influenced and inspired colleagues and generations of our students and residents alike. He will be missed and remembered. We extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: The Beauty of Beast Barracks
description: There is a line between discipline and harassment, sanctified by the hypothesis of learning to take it. Beast Barracks is nothing more than a license, in the guise of leadership training, to let older cadets beat up on teen-agers. It is no more than a form of organized gang warfare.

title: The Cynic Who Never Soured
description: It is not every day that a new collection of Tom Lehrer songs arrives: nearly 12,000 passed between ''That Was the Year That Was'' in 1965 and the CD released by Rhino Records in May. If this one -- a remastering of his first two albums, along with some bonus material -- does as well as its predecessor, it will rocket to platinum by 2029, in time for Lehrer's 101st birthday.

title: Danger in the Air
description: IN a lifetime in the circus, Joseph Bauer has had three career triumphs.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Oct. 19 with an article about Rolling Stone magazine's 30th anniversary referred incorrectly to a photograph of John Lennon that appeared in its first issue. Mr. Lennon is shown in a scene from the 1967 film ''How I Won the War,'' not at an antiwar rally.

title: America Rediscovers Lewis and Clark
description: As a bald eagle wheeled overhead and a campfire smoked, 24 people dressed in buckskins waved ancient muzzleloading rifles and swords in the air and cheered.

title: Jennifer A. Coen, Steven R. Isko
description: Jennifer Anne Coen and Steven Richard Isko, lawyers in New York, were married last evening. Rabbi Amy Ehrlich officiated at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARCE, HENRY
description: PEARCE-Henry, 89 years young. Loving Husband of Sally; Adoring Father of Dr. David and Linda and Dr. Norton Rosensweig; Proud Grandfather of Jonathan and Laurie Rosensweig and Julie and Paul Schwartz. Founding partner of Pearce Mayer & Greer in 1928, devoted his career to Real Estate Philanthropy and his Family. Memorial services will be held at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Monday, November 3rd, at 11:15 A.M.

title: Pitino's Young Guns Overrun The Bulls
description: The Celtics slouched to the locker room at halftime of their season opener Friday night looking properly glum. But the gloomiest visage belonged to their pricey new coach, Rick Pitino. After all, this summer he had signed a seven-year, $50 million contract to paint a smile on the faces of these sweaty employees as well as the 18,000 and change seated in the Fleet Center.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article last Sunday about marijuana use in the National Basketball Association referred incorrectly to the plea made by Isaiah Rider of Portland to a charge of marijuana possession. He pleaded not guilty to the charge, not no contest. He was found guilty and fined $500, and is appealing.

title: Sacking Samarkand Again; Dreams of Tourism, Acts of Genghis Khan
description: FOR centuries the name Samarkand has carried with it an air of almost mystic exoticism. Captured by Alexander and sacked by Genghis Khan, later the capital of Tamerlane's vast empire, this fabled city lies deep in the Central Asian steppe on the outer limits of geography.

title: SOAPBOX; The Squirrel in the Air Shaft
description: I WAS alone in my bathroom and the hair stood on the back of my neck. I knew I was being watched. I looked behind. Nothing. Opened the shower curtain. Nothing. I looked out the small window to the air shaft. A tiny squirrel with black marble eyes stared me down. I did what anyone would do. I screamed bloody murder.

title: The Beauty of Beast Barracks
description: As the father of a daughter who survived this year's Beast experience, I enjoyed Winerip's article on West Point's technique for breaking in plebes.

title: POSTINGS: Round the Clock in Cyberspace; Mortgage Desk On a Web Site
description: Intuit, the software company that made balancing a checkbook easier with its personal finance program Quicken, is hoping to simplify another dreaded financial activity -- mortgage shopping. On Tuesday, Intuit, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., is to introduce QuickenMortgage, an Internet-based service designed to provide round-the-clock cyberspace shopping.

title: Founders of Shelter Honored at a Benefit
description: BEFORE domestic violence was called by that name people used to consider it life, said Gloria Steinem, the feminist writer who helped found Ms. magazine. In a keynote address at a fund-raising dinner here last month for My Sisters' Place, a refuge for abused women in Westchester, Ms. Steinem identified intimate violence as the familiar and acceptable seed of larger arenas of violence in society. ''Violence feels like home,'' she said.

title: No Shore Is Safe for Emerging-Market Funds
description: INVESTORS who have embraced the gospel of global diversification preached so fervently by investment advisers in recent years have no doubt found themselves filled with growing frustrations and skepticism the last two weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AARON, MATTHEW
description: AARON-Matthew. Beloved father of Howard and Alice, grandfather of Susanna and Max, great-grandfather of Samuel and Jasper. Services Sunday, 10 A.M., Riverside Chapel, 1 Ocean Pkwy, Bklyn.,N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REES, DR. MINA S.
description: REES-Dr. Mina S. A memorial service will be held for the Founding President of the Graduate School and University Center of the City University of New York on Monday, December 8th at 4PM in the Proshansky Auditorium, City University Graduate Center, 33 West 42 Street, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWER, CLARK BALDWIN
description: TOWER-Clark Baldwin, 85. Oxford, NY formerly of Madison, NJ, on October 23. Husband of Sarah Rapalje. Father of Christina, Margaret, Catherine and Elizabeth. Princeton U. 1935, chemical engineer Colgate-Palmolive 41 years

title: A New Wave of Rentals for Eighth Avenue in the 50's
description: IT will be an old-fashioned apartment house, says Scott N. Resnick, executive managing director of Jack Resnick & Sons, with ''a lot of nooks and crannies.''

title: Switzer's Tirade Has Wobbly Cowboys Perplexed
description: The Dallas Cowboys face perhaps their most crucial game of the season when they play the San Francisco 49ers today. A victory could save their season; a loss could hurt their playoff chances.

title: The Exploration Of the West, Through 90's Eyes
description: MERIWETHER LEWIS AND William Clark were a parable waiting to happen. In the new television documentary ''Lewis and Clark: The Journey of the Corps of Discovery,'' Ken Burns, the director and producer; Dayton Duncan, the writer, and their various talking heads put all their cards on the table, framing the story of Lewis and Clark as a parable of national unity.

title: No Harm Done
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Spot Where Businesses Try, Try Again
description: The huge papier-mache cow is history. Until about three months ago, it jutted out from the facade of 250 West 86th Street, just west of Broadway, at the entrance of Holy Cow, a steakhouse named in honor of Phil Rizzuto that just didn't seem to catch on.

title: THEATER; Essence of an English Species of Hero: The Fop
description: AT THE START OF THIS CENTURY, a rather dumpy young woman stood on a platform at the Temple subway station in London. Through the murky darkness, she suddenly became aware of a tall and handsome English aristocrat, dressed in the fashion of the 1780's. ''I saw him in his exquisite clothes, his slender hands holding up his spyglass; I heard his lazy, drawling speech, his quaint laugh . . .''

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Not Just for the Birds
description: At its most basic level, the world can be divided into two kinds of people: birders and nonbirders.

title: Balktalk; A Father's Pride in His Daughter's Devotion to Running
description: On a recent Sunday, when I joined my older daughter, Allison, 24, on the last few miles of her 20-mile training run for today's New York City Marathon, my thoughts drifted back to when she was a 9-year-old runner and I was a crazy Stage Dad.

title: The Iron Duke
description: Wellington A Personal History. By Christopher Hibbert. 464 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley. $30.

title: Adultery's Double Standard
description: As a divorce lawyer for 32 years, I have found that the main cause of divorce is the same today as it was when I started practicing -- male infidelity. The Bridges of Madison County probably struck a romantic note with women because it was such a fantasy. The reality is that most infidelity still involves middle-aged men with much younger women.

title: Plan to Include Mattituck and Laurel in Deer Hunt Raises Concerns
description: DESPITE numerous attempts at control, deer continue to plague the East End. Farmers, including nursery and vineyard owners as far west as Laurel, have reported damage and lost crops to the State Environmental Conservation Department.

title: Now, a Few Nonpolitical Words
description: They've talked about auto insurance. They've talked about property taxes. They've talked about the merits of an Atlantic City tunnel. So after all these months of talking, anybody who has been listening should have a good idea about where Governor Whitman and State Senator James E. McGreevey stand on these issues. So when editors of the New Jersey section had a chance to question the candidates, they decided to ask something different.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 12 about the debate over the nature of art included an outdated reference to the art historian Thomas McEvilley. He is no longer a contributing editor of Artforum magazine.

title: Nazi Gold Was Recast And Issued In the U.S.
description: Of the many bizarre tales seeping from archives around the world in the Nazi gold investigations, few are as strange as this one: In 1950, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York melted down hundreds of gold bars bearing the swastika imprint and recast them with the pristine stamp bearing the words ''United States Assay Office.''

title: Smartwentcrazy
description: ONCE, naming a rock band was so simple. Bob Dylan had a band. Thus, you had Bob Dylan and the Band. And according to popular lore, a guy named Buddy had insects in his garage and, voila, it was Buddy Holly and the Crickets. In short, in the old days musical groups has good clean names that suggested forthrightness and a decided lack of imagination.

title: Dr. Schwartzbach And Mr. Bolzan
description: Dr. Caryl Jane Schwartzbach, a research scientist, and Alan David Bolzan, an architectural production manager, were married yesterday at the Carolina Inn in Chapel Hill, N.C. The Rev. Ronald E. Gonia, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

title: Luther Simjian Is Dead at 92; Held More Than 200 Patents
description: Luther G. Simjian, a prolific inventor who held patents on devices as diverse as the flight simulator, the self-focusing camera, the automated teller machine and the Teleprompter, died at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Oct. 23. He was 92.

title: In Her Own Words
description: CHRISTINE TODD WHITMAN

title: PULSE ; Wax. Relax.
description: When Michael Shanahan, the massage director at the Paul Labrecque Salon and Day Spa on the Upper West Side, prepares for Para Fango, the first step is to calm his client. ''I always tell people exactly what I'm going to do,'' he said, ''because the sheer anticipation won't allow anyone to fully relax.''

title: Money Sends Messages That Messinger Couldn't
description: The advertisement opens with a scene of Ruth W. Messinger at a mayoral debate, proclaiming that the election is ''not about the past.'' An announcer then challenges that assertion, sifting through Ms. Messinger's past to evoke images of one incident when she marched on behalf of a Washington Heights drug dealer who was killed by a police officer, and another in which she allegedly gave a party for a killer of an Attica prison guard.

title: Kara Devlin, Joseph Donovan
description: Kara Marie Devlin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Devlin of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Joseph Drexelius Donovan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Donovan of Buffalo. Msgr. Frank C. Wissel performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Mary in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Here, Homeless Aren't the Beggars
description: They are consumers, just like other New Yorkers, swamped with choice. To attract their attention, enterprises serving them must advertise and make them offers, just like other businesses. And the pitch must be right or the consumer won't buy.

title: POSTINGS: New for New York Botanical Garden; Ivy-Walled Herbarium
description: By the year 2000, people entering the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx via Mosholu Parkway will immediately see a 78-foot deciduous ivy wall that will cover one side of a new wing to the Beaux-Arts Museum Building completed in 1900.

title: PULSE: Cafe Ole; P.R. Bauble of the Week
description: Jumbo coffee cup promoting the movie ''Bean,'' opening on Friday, with Rowan Atkinson as an oddball museum employee.

title: East Meets West
description: The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle

title: Toni Dorfman, John Lewis Gaddis
description: Toni Dorfman, a theater director, and John Lewis Gaddis, the historian of the cold war, are to be married today in the Helen Mauck Galbreath Chapel at Ohio University in Athens. The Rev. Dr. Charles J. Ping, a Presbyterian minister and president emeritus of the university, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Why They Kill Their Newborns
description: Killing your baby. what could be more depraved? For a woman to destroy the fruit of her womb would seem like an ultimate violation of the natural order. But every year, hundreds of women commit neonaticide: they kill their newborns or let them die. Most neonaticides remain undiscovered, but every once in a while a janitor follows a trail of blood to a tiny body in a trash bin, or a woman faints and doctors find the remains of a placenta inside her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CERRUTI, LEO E.
description: CERRUTI-Leo E. Died October 21, 1997. He will be remembered as an outstanding person and missed by all. Beloved by Deborah and his children, Leo E.Q. Cerruti and Nina C. Wolfe; son-in-law, Wade Wolfe; grandchildren, Ryan, Rachel, Sarah Wolfe.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/TriBeCa; From Quiet, Desolate Streets To High-Priced Neighborhood
description: TO hear the old-timers tell it, TriBeCa has gone from a quiet community to a glitzy, high-priced urban neighborhood in a scant 15 years. The old-timers are those who moved in before property values began a steady and precipitous climb, before lofts three times the size of an average New York City apartment became fashionable, and before amenities like groceries and dry-cleaners could be found nearby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, JULIE CORCORAN
description: WEISSMAN-Julie Corcoran. The American Society of Adolescent Psychiatry expresses condolences to our colleague Dr. Sidney Weissman and Sharon, Kathryn, Allison at their loss of a wonderful woman known for her commitments to teaching and children. Contributions to American Cancer Society. Alex Weintrob, President

title: A Child of Difference
description: Hedley worries about how she will explain her daughter's difference to others. When her daughter LilyClaire becomes a little older, the burden of explanation will fall upon herself. How will she cope with people who stare and point?

title: Excuse Me, You're Fired
description: The company no longer has need of someone's services, and the message must be delivered. How does it come? Often, awkwardly: The corporate apartment's landlord asks for a moving date, the computer no longer recognizes a password, or the office lock is changed. How has your company handled dismissals? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Correction
description: An answer in the Q & A column on Oct. 19 about help for Americans in finding jobs in Italy misstated the role of the Italian Embassy in Washington and included a telephone number incorrectly. The embassy's commercial office does not provide general help on employment, and the number listed was not for use by the public.

title: Questions of Justice
description: The nine men and women who sit on the Supreme Court of the United States are the ultimate arbiters of the nation's legal issues. Below, find out how much you know about them and their influential rulings.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GIORDANO, EDWARD
description: GIORDANO-Edward. November 2, 1996. Remembered and loved always by his friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, CAROL S.
description: LEVY-Carol S. On October 29, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Edgar I. Levy. Devoted mother of Liza Levy, Angela Carroll and Kristin Lizotte. Cherished grandmother of Jacklyn, Jennifer and Adam. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, November 2 at 4 PM at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81st St. Contributions may be made in her name to The Education Action Fund, C/O Jonathan Kozol, POB 145, Byfield, MA. 01922 or a charity of your choice.

title: City's Gun Enthusiasts Should Look at Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: Film Makers Take Root at Purchase
description: THE huge, monolithic building looks like an unlikely breeding ground for artists. Yet, in the mid-1980's it turned out a generation of young directors, producers and screenwriters who continue to capture attention today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOTKIN, LOUIS
description: KOTKIN-Louis. Of Ridgewood, NJ. Beloved husband of Catherine. Devoted father of Arthur Howard and the late Jay Stuart. Step-father of Dorothy Molnar and Richard Morris. Dear brother of Max, Alex and Betty Traurig. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'' corner of Passaic and Park St., Hackensack, NJ on Monday at noon. Contributions to Wayne Hospice.

title: Looking for a Creative Life After 'Doogie Howser, M.D.'
description: ''HE LOOKS VERY DIFFERENT'' was the warning from Neil Patrick Harris's publicity agent. Sure enough, when the erstwhile star of ''Doogie Howser, M.D.'' arrived at the Santa Monica restaurant, it was evident that the baby face that used to smile down from posters on sleeping preteen-age girls had hardened and the beanpole body had filled out. More startling, this Neil Harris was sporting hipster sunglasses and close-cropped, chemically concocted yellow hair.

title: Eric Bogosian, Flicking Mosquitoes Off His Laptop Screen
description: With his coiled hair, bug eyes and high-decibel mouth, Eric Bogosian is a striking presence, a playwright, stage performer and film actor who has built a career out of New York angst. For the last two years he has also been a presence on the World Wide Web.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEUERMAN, FLORENCE
description: FEUERMAN-Florence. Of Boro Park, Brooklyn. Passed away October 31, 1997, in Hollywood, CA. Born January 11, 1909 in Manhattan. Loving wife of Bernard. Beloved mother of Robert and Kenny. Dear sister of Frances, Belle, Charlotte, Janet, Sidney and Emmanuel. Loving grandmother of Gary and Stephen. Dear motherin-law of Gail. With many other loving relatives and her very dear friends and canasta players. Services Tuesday, 11 AM, at ''Parkside Chapel'' 98-60 Queens Blvd. (corner 66th Ave.), Forest Hills.

title: In His Own Words
description: JAMES E. McGREEVEY

title: To Be, or Not to Be, Right There at the Site
description: A PECULIAR feature of life in New York is that so much of it is televised. This isn't to say that a camera is parked on every corner, of course, but with remarkable regularity New Yorkers are given a novel choice when something is happening down the block. They can either put on their shoes and go see for themselves or stay in their slippers and watch it on television.

title: SOAPBOX; Gone With the Wind?
description: IT'S autumn. Meaning it's hurricane and nor'easter season in New Jersey. Which also means it's time for the inevitable reports from the town of Sea Bright about the valiant residents there and their equally inevitable annual battles with the flooding cause by the storms of New Jersey's own ''mean season.''

title: Planning Boards And the Environment
description: In his environmental commentary (''The Environment: Worth Fighting For,'' Oct. 5), Robert F. Kennedy Jr. writes that sprawl is northern Westchester's most significant environmental issue of the day. All if not most county planning and local municipal officials involved with land-use decisions would agree with this assessment. All of us have grappled with this issue as we update our local comprehensive plans and their implementation.

title: Prisons: A Growth Industry for Some; Colorado County Is a Grateful Host to 7,000 Involuntary Guests
description: A few miles from the ''Alcatraz of the Rockies,'' the maximum security Federal prison where Timothy J. McVeigh spends 23 hours a day in an isolation cell, a cheery billboard beckons tourists: ''Stop and do time with us. Colorado Territorial Prison Museum and Park. Historical, Educational, Exciting.''

title: And Something for Your Dog as Well?
description: IN the classic children's story ''Lyle, Lyle Crocodile,'' the crocodile who lives in an Upper East Side town house is committed to the zoo after visiting a department store. But if Lyle were a dog, he'd be welcomed in many of the best stores in Manhattan.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Reviving a Parsippany Town-House Project
description: FOR nearly eight years legal problems caused by the real estate recession have thwarted plans to transform into housing 48 acres at the intersection of Route 46 and North Beverwyck Road in Parsippany-Troy Hills. But now the site is being prepared for a $32 million town-house condominium community.

title: Good Old Stuff
description: To the Editor: It is comforting to find a soulmate like Louise Rafkin, who shares my preference for detritus of times gone by (''Secondhand Souvenirs,'' Sept. 28). How much more meaningful is a glass, albeit chipped, bought in Sioux Falls than a mini Statue of Liberty bought at Ellis Island. But Ms. Rafkin should be warned. Every achievement (in her case, finding that vintage Girl Scout handbook) is an enslavement. There is no end.

title: From Russia, With Individuality
description: AMERICA'S streets may not be paved with gold, but they still look shiny to artists in countries where currency is soft and artistic independence hard to achieve. They are drawn to the thriving United States to show their skills and try their luck. At the moment, principal dancers from the 260-year-old Kirov company of St. Petersburg, Russia, are making their first American tour, performing excerpts from traditional ballets with which their company is associated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTALBANO, ROSE (NEE AMARI)
description: MONTALBANO-Rose (nee Amari). Beloved aunt, we feel blessed by having had her in our lives. Jo S. Stigliano and Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCULLEN, ROBERT K.
description: McCULLEN-Robert K., 78. Of Saddle River died on October 28, 1997. He was a graduate of both Columbia University and Columbia University Law School. Mr. McCullen was an employee of the Mendes & Mount Law firm where he had been a partner. Mr. McCullen was a navy veteran of World War II. Survived by his loving wife of 54 years Gwen of Saddle River, a brother Thomas of Panama City, Florida, as well as a number of nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held on Monday, November 3, at 11:00 A.M., at the C.C. Van Emburgh Chapel, 306 East Ridgewood Avenue, Ridgewood. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Columbia University Alumni Educational Fund, the National Resources Defense Council, or the Nature Conservancy.

title: Dead Souls
description: ECHOES OF A

title: Hanging On to Hartford's Past
description: WITH the Old State House, the State Capitol and the former homes of Mark Twain and Harriet Beecher Stowe, among other, Hartford has more than its share of historical structures. But it also has close to 1,000 vacant and abandoned buildings that are a blight on many of the city's neighborhoods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, JOSEPHINE DAWES
description: HALL-Josephine Dawes. Widow of Frederick Bailey Hall. Died September 29, 1997. She was a resident of Norfolk, CT and San Francisco, CA. She was born in Englewood, NJ, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Franklin Dawes. She was a graduate from Milton Academy and Sarah Lawrence College.
