She was active in Planned Parenthood of Bergin County, the Hospital Auxiliary in Englewood, NJ and Sheltering Arms in NYC. She was a member of the Colonial Dames and of the Colony Club in New York. Mrs. Hall is survived by a daughter Adele Zachrisson, two grandsons Carl and Christopher Zachrisson and a son-in-law Carl Zachrisson all of San Francisco, California.

title: The Real Crime
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, JOHN M.
description: WASSERMAN-John M. On October 30, 1997. Beloved husband of 65 years of Miriam (Wertheimer) Wasserman. Devoted father of Ann Kiggen and Jane Ferrar, grandfather of Andrew, Carolyn, Linda, Derek and Jessica. Great grandfather of Aaron, Daniel, Peter, Jessica, Danielle, Michael and Quinn. Former Senior Partner Asiel & Co., former National Governor National Association of Securities Dealers, former Governor American Stock Exchange, former longtime Trustee Altro Health and Rehabilitation Services. Age 94. Memorial service at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave. and 81st St, Wednesday, November 5, at 12 PM. Friends may call from 11 AM until time of service. Contributions may be made in his memory to charity of one's choice.

title: Ulster Ex-Militants Press New Cause: Nonviolence
description: In a land that is no stranger to horrific violence, the killings by Robert (Basher) Bates were so savage that the judge sentencing him to 14 life sentences in 1979 said that his crimes would ''remain forever a lasting monument to blind sectarian bigotry'' and that he should remain forever in jail.

title: Two Highways To the Market
description: A key decision for bond investors is whether to buy shares of bond mutual funds or to invest in individual bonds, provided they have enough money to buy them directly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, HEDWIG (HATTIE)
description: PRICE-Hedwig (Hattie). Beloved mother of Regina Fiorito Sokol, passed away peacefully in her 101st year October 28, 1997. Services Sunday 12:15PM, ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Colleges Are Often Unsung Film Stars
description: Most people haven't heard of Agnes Scott College, a private women's college here, but they have probably seen it. When filmmakers needed to recreate the University of Alabama at Tuscaloosa for ''The Bear'' (1983), about Paul (Bear) Bryant, the legendary football coach, they used Agnes Scott. The shady driveway leading from the college's front gates showed up in ''Driving Miss Daisy'' (1989), which won that year's Oscar for best picture. And the elegant Victorian porches of the dormitory known as Rebekah Scott Hall were featured in a commencement scene at a fictional school in ''Fried Green Tomatoes'' (1991). When ''Scream II'' is released next month, Agnes Scott will be on screen again, as a fictional college.

title: Food; The Family That Sautes Together . . .
description: Michel Rostang, the chef and owner of the Parisian restaurant that bears his name (as well as two Michelin stars), is viewed by many as the holy man of haute cuisine.

title: Columbia Keeps Its Grip On Slippery, Windy Day
description: Columbia quarterback Bobby Thomason was raised in Los Angeles, and tailback Norman Hayes comes from Richmond, Calif. So while they did not grow up playing football in wet weather very often, it hardly showed today.

title: China's New Generation Wants to Join the World; To Praise a Conqueror
description: To the Editor:

title: Dizzy Spell; Confusion as an Economic Indicator
description: MONDAY was an awful day on Wall Street. Stock prices went straight down. Tuesday was wonderful. Prices went straight up. Wednesday, they went both ways and ended in the middle. If Wall Street were a person we'd think he was mentally ill.

title: Travel Agency Expands but Stays in Family
description: WHAT began as an idea to let two young teachers make some extra money metamorphosed into a $60 million travel business.

title: Debra Getraer and Ira Powell
description: Debra Michele Getraer, the daughter of Steven L. Getraer of New York and the late Ruth I. Getraer, was married last evening to Ira Michael Powell, a son of Ellen and David Powell of New Springville, Staten Island. Rabbi Steven M. Rosman performed the ceremony at the City Midday Club in New York.

title: Running the F.B.I.
description: He had interrogated suspects in back rooms as an F.B.I. agent, made witnesses sweat when he was a United States Attorney and sat in judgment from the Federal bench, but Louie Freeh had never been in the hot seat himself, not the way he was last spring and summer, staring grimly over batteries of microphones as Senators and Congressmen grilled him about his failures and mistakes at the F.B.I. They berated him for being too cozy with the Clinton White House, for the shabby tricks agents played on Richard Jewell when he was a suspect in the Atlanta bombing case, for violating the rights of leading Republicans by supplying confidential security files to a low-level White House employee -- even for Waco and Ruby Ridge, disasters that occurred well before he became F.B.I. director in September 1993. Freeh was questioned about the sloppy science at the scandal-ridden F.B.I. forensics lab, about the bureau's failure to upgrade its plodding criminal- records computers and its glacially slow fingerprint division, which still depends on bleary-eyed clerks who have to thumb through inky index cards, sometimes taking up to six months to come up with a match.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: CROWS OVER A WHEATFIELD

title: Essay; Let's Try 'Disciplined Engagement'
description: Like Johnny Chung and Charlie Trie, Chinese President Jiang Zemin knew exactly how to gain access to the Clinton White House: lay the money on the table.

title: Big, if Not Quick, Rewards From College Internships
description: To the Editor:

title: Removing the Suspense From Your Trades
description: Q. Is it best to use a market or limit order when buying or selling stocks?

title: OFF THE SHELF ; Genius Nerds, New Machines And the Culture They Made
description: ''THE SOUL OF A NEW MACHINE,'' Tracy Kidder's classic 1981 narrative about the creation of a computer, has been reissued by the Modern Library ($16.50), and it feels as up to date as ever.

title: Mayors in Largest Cities Coasting to Re-election
description: Buoyed by economic prosperity and declining crime rates, mayors in many of the nation's largest cities appear to be gliding toward easy re-election on Tuesday, a striking turnabout, given that only a decade or so ago some of those cities were considered all but ungovernable.

title: Croatia
description: To the Editor: The article about the fascinating Croatian Coast neglected to mention an important aspect of Split -- for many years it was the home of the sculptor Ivan Mestrovic (1883-1962). He eventually migrated to the United States, and President Eisenhower gave him American citizenship in a White House ceremony.

title: Habitats/210 West 78th Street; A Triplex Penthouse Topped by a Triangle
description: TEN stories above West 78th Street between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue a small triangular structure juts out of the Upper West Side streetscape like a ski chalet. It seems to reflect the Tudor style of the facade of the building that serves as its perch.

title: Into Thin Air
description: EAST TO THE DAWN The Life of Amelia Earhart. By Susan Butler. Illustrated. 489 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley. $27.50.

title: War With the D.E.P. on Lake Waramaug
description: AS environmental debates go, the one surrounding plans by the State Department of Environmental Protection to install a public boat launch on the 680-acre Lake Waramaug sometime next year is hot as blazes.

title: Tough Guy Finds His Warm and Fuzzy Side
description: THE OTHER DAY, SAMUEL L. JACKSON could be found compiling a list of characters he has played who may resonate with his 15-year-old daughter, Zoe. ''There's Carl Lee Hailey,'' said Mr. Jackson, referring to the grieving father on trial in ''A Time to Kill.'' Then he brought up Andrew Sterling, the cultivated millionaire from the little-seen comedy ''Amos and Andrew.'' After that, Mr. Jackson fell silent as he deliberated about the many men he has portrayed in his 25 years in film. ''Gee,'' he finally conceded. ''There's not a lot more.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHENKER, LUCILLE
description: SCHENKER-Lucille. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Lucille Schenker, associated with The Times from 1968, until retiring in 1991.

title: PULSE ; Fairest Bloom Of the Season
description: Peonies in November may seem as odd as Christmas in July, but the flower of the moment is the peony imported from New Zealand. Just ask Robert Isabell, the Manhattan party and floral designer. He says his clients are clamoring for them, even at $10 or $12 a stem. ''It is special to have them around in November, and it's a historic moment for the peony, because we usually only see them in May and June,'' he said. ''My peony lovers are rich, rich, rich.''

title: The Politics of Personality
description: Among the high moments, low moments and many, many embarrassing moments in the young life of ''CBS News Saturday Morning,'' the breakfast souffle for which Susan Molinari left a seat in Congress, one of the more telling came when Michael Riera, a family therapist, spoke on the show about the self-consciousness of teen-agers. If ''you go to a classic high school,'' Riera told Molinari and her buttery co-anchor, Russ Mitchell, ''all the kids are working hard to look relaxed and cool.''

title: Useless Check
description: To the Editor: While in Europe this summer, I had a difficult experience. To reserve a room in an Amsterdam hotel that does not accept credit cards I sent a Thomas Cook international check for 290 guilders for two nights. When I arrived at the Jupiter Hotel it would not cash the check or apply it to my bill, even though the check was written to their hotel, explaining only that it was too costly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTLE, JOHN WATSON II
description: LITTLE-John Watson II. On November 1, 1997, after a brief but valiant struggle with lung cancer. Loving husband of Jean Remmel Little. Brother of Elizabeth Shippee of Greenwich, CT. Father of Lucy Tucker Little of Scarsdale, NY, David Knox Little of Portland, ME, Dr. Liza Little of Nottingham, NH, Carl von Kienbusch Little of Mt. Desert, ME, and John Watson Little IV of Seattle, WA, and seven grandchildren. A funeral service will be held on Saturday, November 8, at 11 AM, St. John's Episcopal Church, 100 South Main St., Southampton. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate gifts to the Southampton Hospital, Southampton, NY.

title: Milestones and Memories; Creative thinkers, innovative ideas and movements that changed education in this century.
description: 1901: The Indiana Supreme Court upholds the constitutionality of Indiana's compulsory school attendance laws. By 1918, all the states will have passed some kind of compulsory school attendance legislation.

title: A New Constitution: Yes or No?
description: IT sounds like a dance, but it isn't. It also sounds sexy, although it isn't that either. It is, however, attracting many second looks -- along with some serious takers. And no one denies that it could change your life.

title: Write a Book, Alienate Owners, Win Games
description: Fear no one no matter what their wealth,

title: Feminism's Failure As Political Ideologue
description: Rosalie Osias seems to ignore the gains that women have made, when she writes that the women's movement is a failed revolution. Now women are half the paid work force, and have moved into every profession.

title: Helen Wright Greuter, 82, Astronomer and Author
description: Helen Wright Greuter, an astronomer and author, died on Oct. 23 at the Thomas House Retirement Home in her native Washington. She was 82.

title: CHINA'S PRESIDENT DRAWS APPLAUSE AT HARVARD TALK
description: President Jiang Zemin of China, a permanent smile on his face, basked today in the prestige of Harvard University, where the White House, fearing large protests, had urged him not to go.

title: Coming Soon: Face-to-Face Help from the I.R.S.
description: LET'S say you received a notice from the Internal Revenue Service saying that you failed to pay tax on some oil-company dividends and that you owe the Government $230. You responded with a letter saying that you have never owned that stock, but the I.R.S. keeps sending bills.

title: The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle
description: June and July 1984

title: Mayor Sues City Council For Curbing Van Licenses
description: The battle over the expansion of routes for private commuter vans has ended up in court, with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani suing the City Council for enacting a yearlong ban on new licenses for the vans.

title: Cuomo Says Ad by Gadfly Candidate Stretches Truth
description: Abraham Hirschfeld, the parking-lot millionaire known for quixotic gadfly political campaigns, came up with yet another novel touch yesterday in his race for Manhattan borough president: an advertisement picturing him and former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo side by side, beaming like the old buddies they never were.

title: HAPPY TOGS
description: * Created in the 30's as a tourist diversion, the Hawaiian shirt gets icon treatment in an exhibition opening this month at the Honolulu Academy of Arts. * On display are aloha shirts dating from 1938 to 1951, created by John Meigs, a.k.a. Keoni of Hawaii, a self-taught designer who is the star of ''The Master Book of Hawaiian Shirt,'' just published in Japan. * Among the specimens: shirts from Meigs' Gauguin period and his ''Around the Islands'' volcano shirt. * The shirts are from the collection of Dan Eskenazi, a Seattle boutique owner who has appraised thousands of vintage alohas, including early hand-painted specimens valued at up to $5,000. * Charles Valoroso, a Honolulu contemporary artist, is cashing in with still lifes: his ''portraits'' of Hawaiian shirts fetch up to $15,000 and have been snapped up by celebrities like the Eagles' Glenn Frey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, WILLIAM J., M.D.
description: NELSON-William J., M.D. The entire family of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center mourns the passing of William J. Nelson, M.D., a former Director of Urology at Roosevelt Hospital, former President of the NYS Medical Society, and former President of the New York Section of the American Urological Association. He exemplified our finest traditions of medical excellence, was devoted to his patients and beloved by colleagues, and will be sorely missed. To his wife, Olive, and his entire family, we offer our condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman of the Board Ronald C. Ablow, MD President Richard P. Fried, MD President of the Medical Board

title: Joan Avagliano And Tom Psathas
description: Joan Marie Avagliano, the daughter of Mary and Peter J. Avagliano of Jersey City, was married yesterday to Tom Psathas, a son of Bessie Psathas of New York and the late Anthony Psathas. The Rev. Robert Robbins performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: A Hotter Zone
description: THE COBRA EVENT

title: A Path Through the Maze
description: How do you choose a hedge fund? Look at the fund's portfolio, annual audits and the partnership agreement that describes the manager's salary and investment style, said Harry Strunk, an investment consultant in Palm Beach, Fla. And be wary, he added, of any funds in which a manager invests less than 40 percent of his net worth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORAN, RITA M. (NEE O'CONNELL)
description: MORAN-Rita M. (nee O'Connell). On October 31, 1997. Beloved wife of Edward. Beloved mother of Ann Martin, Elizabeth Maguder, Nikki, Kathy and E.J. Cherished grandmother of 15 and greatgrandmother of four. Active in numerous charities. Reposing at the Kennedy-Roth Funeral Home, 41-45 58th St., Woodside, Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, November 3, 1997, at 9:45 AM at St. Sebastian Church, Woodside. Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; You've Found Your Dream. Stop Yawning.
description: WHEN my husband grumbles that he hates his job, my response is predictable. ''Of course you do,'' I tell him. ''That's why you're so successful.''

title: Bonnie S. Werner, Richard Swart 3d
description: Bonnie Susan Werner, the daughter of Judith Werner of Little Silver, N.J., and John V. Werner of Red Bank, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard Emanuel Swart 3d, a son of Jo Anne Swart of San Diego and Mr. Swart Jr. of Hood River, Ore. The Rev. Dr. John L. Musgrave performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Red Bank.

title: Store Owner Faults Music for Decline
description: ANOTHER Saturday afternoon and Herb Smith, the proprietor of Arcadian Music and Books, was waiting for his next customer. Occasionally, he looked up from a magazine as cars and other vehicles positioned in and out of the parking spaces across from his small storefront here in the Arcadian Shopping Center on Route 9, though everyone seemed to be heading toward the neighboring supermarket and home-decorating store.

title: Garry Kasparov He Isn't, but the Lessons Are a Bargain
description: Usually, the man who wears a hat labeled ''chess teacher'' shows up, with his table and his shopping cart and his ''No Gambling'' sign, outside the McDonald's on Broadway near 81st Street at 2:30 P.M., around the time school lets out. Since many of his customers are children, he said, he doesn't want to tempt them to play hooky.

title: Brooklyn Man Charged With Stabbing 10-Year-Old Daughter
description: In a nightmarish family fight, a drunken father stabbed his 10-year-old daughter four times in the chest early yesterday and waited for the police inside the family's apartment in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, while his bleeding child stumbled outside and passed out on the sidewalk, the police and neighbors said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LESSER, STANLEY R., M.D.
description: LESSER-Stanley R., M.D. November 4, 1917-August 2, 1986. A gentle giant, Buddha, Huckleberry Finn.

title: President Spends a Weekend With Big Donors
description: Bill Clinton may think he is underappreciated. But he is not undervalued.

title: A Modest Proposal: Give Me a (Tax) Break
description: MAYOR GIULIANI, you're brilliant. Like a late-night infomercial host, you have shown me the path to financial freedom. And that path leads to New Jersey.

title: Helping a Few Taxpayers At the Expense of Many?
description: REPUBLICAN Congressional leaders say their bill to overhaul the Internal Revenue Service, which President Clinton now supports, will protect people from abuse by the tax agency. But as tax practitioners take a close look at the bill, they see changes very different from what the politicians see.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Out of Yugoslavia, Film Makers Put Aside Old Enmities
description: Bojana and Dejan Kovacevic may not seem like such an unusual married couple. Like so many others in New York, they are struggling artists. She is an actress. He is a film director and recently shot his first short feature film. They are co-authors of the screenplay.

title: Lifelong Learners
description: To the Editor:

title: The World; China's Top Tourist Fills His Scrapbook
description: WHEN a Chinese bureaucrat wangles a trip to the United States, as thousands do each year, the most enjoyable part is often not the travel itself but rather the prestige it wins from friends and colleagues back home.

title: Wreck of the Britannic
description: To the Editor:

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: More Who Worship Through Liturgical Dance
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Are Those Guys on the Sidelines?
description: THE Meadowlands was a wall of sound. Only a few minutes left in the New York Jets-Miami Dolphins football game. And only a few points separating the teams.

title: Army Takeover Feared as Pakistan Leader Acts to Bolster Power
description: Nine months after the election in which Nawaz Sharif won a landslide victory and became Prime Minister again, his bruising drive to entrench his authority has raised fears that Pakistan could be headed for another cycle of upheaval.

title: After a Rocky Ride, It's Time to Recall the A B C's
description: O.K, O.K., admit it. For weeks and months you have been muttering things like ''trees don't grow to the sky'' and ''all good things have to end.'' But in your heart of hearts you didn't really believe that stock prices would have the audacity to crack.

title: Beneath a Smooth Surface, Mendelssohnian Depths
description: TAKE 10 MINUTES ON TUESDAY to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the death of Felix Mendelssohn. Ten minutes will suffice if you spend them listening actively to ''The Hebrides,'' the celebrated concert overture composed and revised between 1829 and 1835.

title: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE CANDIDATES ; Whitman and McGreevey Shore Up Support in Party Strongholds
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and her Democratic challenger, State Senator James E. McGreevey, took their fiercely fought campaigns back to their strongholds today, imploring supporters to help get voters to the polls on Tuesday.

title: What to Read Before You Read the Menu
description: Some are quick bites and some aren't.

title: Sampras in the Final
description: Pete Sampras, playing with an aching shoulder, beat Yevgeny Kafelnikov, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3, in one semifinal in Paris yesterday.

title: Scott Humphries, Stacy Kleiner
description: Stacy Nicole Kleiner, the daughter of Risa A. Kleiner of Princeton, N.J., and Judge Steven Z. Kleiner of Bridgeton, N.J., was married last evening to Scott Anthony Humphries, a son of Lynne and Rod D. Humphries of Houston. The bride's father, who sits in Atlantic City on the Appellate Division of the Superior Court of New Jersey, officiated at the Pen Ryn Mansion in Bensalem, Pa.

title: African, American, Male and More
description: EVEN though ''Geography'' has been in development at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven and other spaces for more than five months (and evolving for more than a year), the attempt by the choreographer Ralph Lemon to fuse the scenic and the textual with elements of music and movement remains an exercise in anatomical spatial relationships. Don't expect a piece of integral theater that stirs the soul and the senses, the spirit and the intellect. That may happen at moments perhaps, but not for long.

title: In Hollywood, Discord On What Makes Music
description: AT A TIME WHEN LOOSE collections of pop songs increasingly displace integrated orchestral scores in motion pictures, it makes sense that composers and cinephiles alike are nostalgically looking back to an era when film music was a vibrant and respected art.

title: Oregon's Suicide Law Creates a Slippery Slope; Doctors' Opposition
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Rider Best in Field
description: The 114th National Horse Show closed on cue last evening at Madison Square Garden with the most dazzling spectacle of the four-day event, the $50,000 Budweiser Grand Prix of New York, the grand prix that has been stumping top riders since the turn of the century.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: MY VAST FORTUNE

title: Get Set
description: Even dinner for one can be a glamorous affair, when your companions are as charming as these illustrious settings.

title: VIEWPOINT; Social Security's Black Box
description: JUST how far is Social Security under water? People like to quote numbers as if they're gospel. The Government says Social Security can stay afloat until 2072 if it raises payroll taxes by 2.2 percent. But that's hardly the end of it.

title: Oct. 26-Nov. 1; One-Man H.I.V. Epidemic
description: Nushawn J. Williams charmed the high school girls he picked up at parks or parties in Chautauqua County in western New York, a lakeside sanctuary 70 miles south of Buffalo. They were fascinated by his big-city ways, his largesse and flattered by his romantic small talk.

title: City Life In 17 Syllables
description: Readers continue to respond in large numbers to the City section's invitation, published on Oct. 12, to submit haiku with a New York flavor. One haiku writer asked about copyright, and, yes, the poets published here do retain copyright to their work.

title: Little Known but Not Forgotten
description: WHEN NICK DRAKE died in 1974, he was an obscure 26-year-old British singer-songwriter who had made three albums. Today he is one of the best-known unknown artists in popular music.

title: New Directions In the East 60's
description: ARCADIA*** [rating: three stars]

title: A New Cash Crop: The Farm as Theme Park
description: In Queen Creek, Ariz., Mark Schnepf can make up to $15,000 on a good weekend: not by harvesting cotton, potatoes and grains the way his parents once did on their 600-acre farm, but with live country bands, hay bale mazes, a tricycle course and a petting corral.

title: China's New Generation Wants to Join the World; Why Yuan Is Immune
description: To the Editor:

title: Ramona Ponce, Eric Mueller
description: Ramona Luz Ponce, a daughter of Patricia L. Ponce of Florence, Colo., and Paul V. Ponce of New Windsor, Md., was married in New York on Friday to Eric Anthony Mueller, a son of Frederick E. Mueller of Bradford Woods, Pa., and the late Erin F. Mueller. Judge Sara P. Schechter of Family Court in Manhattan, the bridegroom's aunt, officiated at the Puck Building.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Westchester and Connecticut copies last Sunday about land sales in Westchester misspelled the surname of a lawyer representing property owners. He is Stuart R. Shamberg, not Scamberg.

title: Making Soup as Easy as Boiling a Potato
description: PROFESSIONAL chefs love to make soup, but home cooks often find making soup intimidating. ''They think that they are time consuming and labor intensive,'' said Leslie Kaul, executive chef at the Daily Soup, a retail outlet with five locations in Manhattan (and two more opening this month). ''Some soups may need long cooking, but if you make your stock or cook your beans the day before, you can make a wonderful soup in the time it takes to boil a potato. Soups are easy to make over a weekend. The great thing is that they mellow so nicely overnight.''

title: Adultery's Double Standard
description: The biology of human sexuality has evolved slowly, as all biology does, but Roiphe can take comfort in the rapidity with which attitudes and values regarding sex and gender behavior have changed. In the mid-1950's, a group of social scientists conducted a study at a top women's college on the East Coast. A part of the study involved repeated interviews with a representative sample of students over their four years at school. In their senior year, I asked if they thought adultery was grounds for divorce. They all said yes, if the guilty partner was the wife. If it was the husband, they would question where they had failed their partners and would try to make amends! The double standard was alive and well!

title: Political Memo ; 1996 Campaign Left Finance Laws in Shreds
description: The Senate investigation into campaign finance abuses in the 1996 election has produced a confusing picture for the public, a tangled saga of intrigue and overzealous fund-raising. But beneath the cloudy surface of the Senate hearings, one clear picture has emerged: The post-Watergate campaign finance laws that were passed to restrict the influence of special interests in politics have been shredded.

title: Jessica E. Levin, Aaron Lieberman
description: Jessica Estelle Levin, a daughter of Betty and John Levin of New York, was married last evening at her parents' house in Rye, N.Y., to Aaron Oscar Lewis Lieberman, a son of Evelyn and Lawrence H. Lieberman of Phoenix. Rabbi Joel S. Goor performed the ceremony.

title: American Abroad
description: PARIS IN THE FIFTIES By Stanley Karnow. Illustrated by Annette Karnow. 352 pp. New York: Times Books/Random House. $25.

title: It's Collective Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Q&A: Robert Pilarski; Genetic Testing, the Pluses and Minuses
description: AS coordinator and counselor of the Cancer Genetics Program at the University of Connecticut Health Center, Robert Pilarski counsels and tests patients who may be at risk for heritable forms of cancer, considered to be 5 percent to 10 percent of all cancers.

title: After the Roaring 80's in Art, A Decade of Quieter Voices
description: THE ART WORLD CAN OFFER A LESSON OR two about the sobering effect of a stock market plunge, like the one last week. Ten years ago, on another bleak October day, the Dow Jones average came tumbling down, bringing with it the curtain on the giddy, go-go art market of the 80's, when stars were born and fortunes made. In the decade since, sandwiched between one Wall Street convulsion and another, the art scene has not been the same.

title: Island Paradox
description: PUERTO RICO

title: Steps to Preparing a Home for Sale
description: WHEN a homeowner puts his house up for sale, he wants a quick sale for the best price. Most sellers, however, do not take the time to prepare their homes for sale. Consequently, a house may be on the market for a long time and may sell for less.

title: Back on That Infuriating But Irresistible Broadway
description: EMANUEL AZENBERG, universally known as Manny, has a habit. Even though he suspects that at 63 he ought to know better, he keeps producing Broadway plays.

title: Rights Group Gives Martin Luther King 3d His Father's Old Post
description: Martin Luther King 3d, the eldest son and namesake of the first leader of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, was elected the fourth president of that eminent civil rights group today.

title: PULSE ; Takeoff, Tee-Off
description: For most Manhattan golfers, this is the season the clubs move into the closet. The summer is a faint memory, and the indoor driving range at Chelsea Piers is about as good as it gets. But for those fanatics who can never play enough, USAirways offers weekend trips to the golfers' paradise of Hilton Head Island, S.C., for as little as $178 round trip (there's a stop in Charlotte, N.C.).

title: Pesky Devils Are On a Roll
description: DEVILS 3, CAPITALS 1

title: A Truly Grand Staircase Beckons Hardy Hikers
description: THE Explorer shuddered from the antilock brakes as its tires slipped from hardscrabble rock to the loose red sand of the southern Utah benchlands. Although the near collision with a sleepy-eyed black cow had stirred my adrenaline, it was of little interest to the cow, which sauntered aimlessly across the washboard road.

title: Waiting for Those Dreams to Get Cheap Enough to Buy
description: IT has been a tough year for value investors -- the bargain hunters whose search for cheap stocks has been frustrated by the climb of the Dow Jones industrial average. As the bull market reached new heights, thrift-minded fund managers carried more cash than they wanted and even adjusted their definitions of a good buy.

title: David Rosenberg, Jessica Lattman
description: Dr. Jessica Lattman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman S. Lattman of New York, was married last evening to Dr. David Brent Rosenberg, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul A. Rosenberg of New York. Cantor Irwin Gelman performed the ceremony at the Water's Edge restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Myths and Heroes
description: Some favorite myths and stories are the subject of ''The Storyteller,'' an HBO series combining live action with puppetry, which is some of Jim Henson's last work.

title: Facing Intense Pressures, Hospitals Step Up Mergers
description: THE merger of two premier teaching hospitals and the reorganization of four Roman Catholic hospitals is changing health care on Long Island and reflecting rapid shifts across the industry.

title: Having a Go at Noodle Dishes From Asia
description: TUCKED discreetly into the small Nayaug Shopping Center in South Glastonbury is Char Koon.

title: South Africa
description: To the Editor: In 1996 I took the overnight Rovos Rail trip from Pretoria to Kruger Park. Donald G. McNeil Jr.'s description in ''Out of Pretoria, by Luxury Train'' (Oct. 12) is accurate with one major omission: For a nonsmoker like me, the trip was torture. The only escape from the smoke-filled public spaces was the bedroom.

title: Oct. 26-Nov. 1; Standoff in Iraq
description: In a move than mystified United Nations officials and diplomats, Iraq last week succeeded in reversing a trend in its favor by abruptly barring Americans from working with an international arms control team responsible for destroying that country's prohibited weapons. Only a week earlier, France, Russia, China, Egypt and Kenya had broken with the United States over adding new Security Council sanctions to an embargo that has crippled the Iraqi economy. It can be lifted only after Iraq is declared clean of weapons of mass destruction.

title: The Nation; An American Jury Shocks Britain
description: LOUISE WOODWARD revealed very little of herself as she sat impassively in a courtroom in Boston day after day, charged with shaking and slamming a baby to death. In her round, placid face you could read what you wanted to read.

title: One Vote for Series
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSTON, JAY
description: WINSTON-Jay. On October 30, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Betty. Loving father of Linda and John,and father-in-law of Renate, grandfather of Claudia, Paul, Valerie, Hella and David. Great grandfather of Ruby Rose. Dear brother of Ruth Winston Frank. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Lisa E. Boehne, Andrew L. Tobias
description: Lisa Elena Boehne, the daughter of Dr. Patricia J. Boehne and Edward G. Boehne of Devon, Pa., was married yesterday in Valley Forge, Pa., to Andrew Lindsay Tobias, a son of Joan L. Tobias and Dr. Gordon L. Tobias of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Richard L. Stinson performed the Episcopal ceremony at Washington Memorial Chapel in Valley Forge National Historical Park.

title: Sean Gumbs, Melissa Caldwell
description: Melissa Bolade Caldwell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan E. Caldwell Jr. of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Sean Adrian Gumbs, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert F. Gumbs of Jamaica, Queens. The Rev. Glyger G. Beach performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue United Methodist Church in Manhattan.

title: UP AND COMING: Jurnee Smollett; Calm Child at the Center of an Adult Storm
description: KASI LEMMONS, WHO wrote and directed the new film ''Eve's Bayou,'' said she had a dream about whom she wanted to play the young central character, Eve Batiste. She envisioned a light-skinned black child of no more than 10 years of age, a spirited child of the 1990's who could capture and convey the nuances of a Creole child of the 60's, a little girl who could exude a womanly allure while maintaining a veneer of innocence.

title: TECHNOLOGY; How Students Get Lost in Cyberspace
description: When Adam Pasick, a political science major at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, started working on his senior honors thesis this fall, he began where the nation's more than 14 million college students increasingly do: not at the campus library, but at his computer terminal.

title: The Beauty of Beast Barracks
description: Although only 16 percent of the West Point class of 2001 are women, at least 50 percent of Winerip's article addressed their contributions, their problems and the problems caused by their presence. The same imbalance af-flicts all military branches, wherein valuable training is sacrificed to permit lectures on sensitivity, sexual harassment and social (political) correctness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOTOV, SELMA H.
description: NOTOV-Selma H., on October 31, 1997. Beloved wife of Harvey. Devoted mother of Sandi, Shari and Daniel. Dear sister of Elaine Someth. Cherished grandmother of Melanie, Jenna, Jaime, Alex, Abbe, Adam and Drew. Services, Monday, 10 AM at ''Gutterman's, Inc,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHANZER, BEN
description: SCHANZER-Ben. November 2, 1984. In loving memory of our dear husband, father and grandfather.

title: Vietnam Is Resurfacing As a Hot Topic on Campus
description: Lis Brown remembers when the draft notice came in the mail. It was December 1966. ''We were terrified,'' she recalled. ''We associated Vietnam with death.''

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTOR'S GUIDE /Page 4/

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; How Shelton Won a Role in Fairfield's Office Market
description: IN 1975 Shelton's largest employer, the sponge-rubber plant that B.F. Goodrich had leased out a year earlier, was firebombed and destroyed in an insurance-fraud scheme, marking the end of the city's smokestack economy and its dependence on a single industry. The fire put 4,500 people out of work.

title: Market's Nod To a Rebirth; In South Bronx Enclave, Rising Property Values And Suburban Living
description: Sunday afternoon. A middle-aged couple slowly cruise up and down rows of nearly identical ranch houses on streets lined with trees. The wife looks intently at the homes on the right; the husband, at the wheel, scans the left.

title: Southeast Asia Tourism Is Smothered by Smog
description: WHEN athletes from around the region gathered in Jakarta, Indonesia, last month for the Southeast Asia Games, officials were unable to light the ceremonial torch. A huge magnifying glass was to have beamed a ray of sunlight into a giant bowl, but there was no sun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSELL, MCDURWOOD
description: RUSSELL-McDurwood. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of McDurwood Russell, associated with The Times from 1960, until retiring in 1990.

title: In Prints, Nuances of Gloom
description: THERE is no more potent and instantly understood umbrella term in art than German Expressionism. It is a dark umbrella, instantly conjuring up the moody atmosphere and the luxurious tension of Germany between the World Wars. These sensations are expertly captured in vigorous prints, and the Connecticut Graphic Arts Center in Norwalk has a gallery and a hallway full of classics.

title: Symphony of Whiners
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Shoot for the Spiritual, and Keep On Winning
description: ''I really don't care about the streak,'' said the coach, Martin Jacobson, pacing the sideline on the evening his team went after its 31st straight victory. ''That's vanity. I'm into beauty. I'm -- look, look,'' he suddenly shouted. ''That's beauty!''

title: Setting in Motion Mythology Old and New
description: Good ideas do not necessarily inspire good choreography. Take ''Myths,'' which the Olympic Dance Company, a troupe from Milan, presented on Thursday night at the Kaye Playhouse.

title: In the Denver Area, a Battle of the Car vs. the Train
description: Conjuring up the dreaded specter of Los Angeles, environmentalists and business leaders here are joining hands to urge voters to approve on Tuesday a $16 billion plan to graft a hub-and-spoke light rail system onto Denver's booming metropolitan area.

title: The Wrong Medicine for Asia
description: In a matter of just a few months, the Asian economies went from being the darlings of the investment community to being virtual pariahs. There was a touch of the absurd in the unfolding drama, as international money managers harshly castigated the very same Asian governments they were praising just months before.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINMAN, BEVERLY (NEE ROSENZWEIG)
description: FEINMAN-Beverly (nee Rosenzweig) on November 1, 1997. Devoted wife of Sheldon; beloved mother of Andrew, Joshua and Debra; loving grandmother of Amanda and Melissa; adoring sister of Arnold. A beautiful, caring person who touched the lives of all who knew her. She will be sorely missed by all.

title: The Perils of Being The Next Michael
description: This icon business is rough. You have to sign everything placed in front of you and smile often, even when you're not happy. On an off night, when you would rather be spending quality time with your family, you end up at some Chinese restaurant in the Village doing a promotion.

title: Rookie Kicker Loses the Diaper
description: One of the compelling plots in the Jets' sudden rise has been Bill Parcells's handling of John Hall, the rookie kicker. Hall made only 9 of his first 15 kicks of fewer than 40 yards, prompting Parcells to bring in his former kicker, Matt Bahr, to tutor Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARCE, HENRY
description: PEARCE-Henry, 89 years young. Loving Husband of Sally; Adoring Father of Dr. David and Linda and Dr. Norton Rosensweig; Proud Grandfather of Jonathan and Laurie Rosensweig and Julie and Paul Schwartz. Founding partner of Pearce Mayer & Greer in 1928, devoted his career to Real Estate Philanthropy and his Family. Memorial services will be held at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Monday, November 3rd, at 11:15 A.M.

title: Slowed by the Weather
description: As one of the oldest runners in the New York City Marathon, Abraham Weintraub, 87, was not worried about fast times. Weintraub ran New York for the first time in 1992 and finished in 7:59:29. Last year, in his fourth try, he had lowered his time to 6:18:34. Yesterday's wind and rain were not conducive to fast times, so Weintraub settled for 6:26:05. . . . Dana Andrew Jennings, a Times sports editor from Montclair, N.J., who wrote about training for his first marathon, fought through leg cramps and finished in 4:19:56. . . . Also profiled last week: Allison Bloom finished in 4:50. It took 10 minutes to get to starting line. She felt very good during the first half, but it was tough finishing in the rain. . . . Jillian Walker, a blind runner who was guided by the 1981 New York City marathon winner, Allison Roe, crossed the line in 3:49:58.

title: A High Point for High School Runners
description: Scott Burns was glad he caved in to parental pressure. Burns felt sluggish in a race on Friday and considered withdrawing yesterday from the New York City Marathon's inaugural 2.25-mile prep event.

title: Satellite TV Provider Waits for World to Catch Up
description: It is one thing to have a vision but quite another to stay the course through 16 years of evolving regulations, advancing technologies and shifting business plans. Not to mention a falling stock price.

title: More Coffee Mysteries
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERELSON, FRANCES
description: PERELSON - Frances. Beloved wife of the late Bernard E. Devoted mother of Barbara Nissim and the late Arthur J. Dear sister of Lee Finkel. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Services today, 1:30 PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'' 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, JULIUS
description: SCHNEIDER-Julius. On October 31, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Ruth; loving father of Abby and Wendy; devoted brother of the late Seymour and the late Leon. Loving brother-in-law of Iris; loving companion of Carol. Past Vice-President, Investments, Dean Witter, and amateur actor. Always a warm and caring person and eternal optimist. Services Monday, 1 PM, at Gutterman, Hackensack, NJ 201-489-3800. Contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society. We will miss you.

title: Foreign Affairs; Elephants Can't Fly
description: I was invited last week to a luncheon for China's President, Jiang Zemin. On my way, though, I had to stop off at my 9-year-old daughter's school, because she was running for treasurer of the Burning Tree Elementary student council, and she and the other candidates were giving their campaign speeches to a school assembly. After the Pledge of Allegiance and ''My Country 'Tis of Thee,'' these grade school kids got up in front of their classmates, one by one, and campaigned for votes, each promising to do the most to improve the school. It was really touching, and it reminded me how deeply rooted is the American democratic experience.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Election Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Duval Ends Season With Quite a Streak
description: Once again, David Duval was unrelenting and unbeatable.

title: Publication Date Open to Dispute In Internet Age
description: There was a time not so very long ago when publishing a magazine meant putting it on the newsstand or mailing it off to subscribers.

title: Mother Charged in Killing Of Her 3-Year-Old Daughter
description: In what investigators described as a brutal weeklong ordeal, a 3-year-old girl was repeatedly punched and kicked by her 26-year-old mother inside a Kips Bay apartment, where the girl was sent flying into walls and furniture until she died early Saturday morning from severe internal injuries, the police said.

title: Weak Concrete Stops Work on West Side Trump Project
description: A city inspector who learned of defective concrete at Donald Trump's Riverside South project has done what community protests, four lawsuits and an energetic lobbying effort in Washington could not do: stop, at least temporarily, another Trump tower from rising on the Upper West Side.

title: French Trucker Strike Raises Specter of Chaos on Continent : War and Peace in European Labor
description: PARIS  Striking French truckers began to blockade roads throughout the country Sunday for the second time in a year, threatening chaos in neighboring countries that rely on the trans-European highways running through France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, SHELDON L.
description: GOLDBERG-Sheldon L. On Friday, October 31, 1997. Of North Caldwell, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved husband of Barbara (nee Kleinberg). Devoted father of Marc and David. Period of shiva will be observed through Thursday evening at the family residence, 5 Hemlock Dr., North Caldwell, NJ.

title: Last-Minute Campaign Help
description: At a rally here yesterday, President Clinton urged more than 1,500 supporters of James E. McGreevey, the Democratic candidate for governor, to ''send a signal to the rest of the country'' with their support for Mr. McGreevey tomorrow.

title: Checking Off Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ANDREW
description: SMITH-Andrew on November 1, 1997. Son of Richard and Penny; brother of Douglas Smith. Family will receive friends at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave, Scarsdale, Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Pius X Church, Thursday 10 AM.

title: A Private Eye; Buddhism's Flowering in America: An Inside View
description: Buddhism is everywhere. Oprah Winfrey has recently been seen discussing meditation with Richard Gere. The new movie ''Seven Years in Tibet,'' with Brad Pitt, and Martin Scorcese's version of the Dalai Lama's story, ''Kundun,'' which will open soon in spite of China's disapproval, prompted Time magazine to run a cover article on ''America's Fascination With Buddhism.''

title: The Future Is Glimpsed Through a Mahler Skylight
description: Under the title given Saturday's program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, ''After Mahler,'' almost any Western classical music of the last hundred years could have been presented: Boulez or Shostakovich, Britten or Webern, Bartok or Feldman. Mahler is the universal ancestor, the totem claimed by all.

title: Kenyan Scorches Course Despite Flapping Shoelaces
description: Saturday afternoon, John Kagwe of Kenya spotted a new shoe at a running expo, picked up a pair and thus violated a cardinal rule of marathoning: never run in a pair of untried shoes.

title: Of Chinese Painting, and the Art of a Book Deal
description: When Margaret Thatcher went to Beijing to sign the 1984 accord that sealed Hong Kong's fate, one of the symbolic offerings she was given by the then-boss of the Chinese Communist Party, Hu Yaobang, was a Chinese-English dictionary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBLINER, IMMANUEL
description: LUBLINER - Immanuel, Rabbi Emeritus of the Greenburgh Hebrew Center, Dobbs Ferry, NY. Survived by wife, Sylvia; son, Rabbi Jonathan Lubliner, daughter-inlaw, Susan; sister, Henrietta Fassler, and brother, Felix. Funeral 12:30 PM today, Monday, November 3, 1997, Greenburgh Hebrew Center, 515 Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, NY. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Shiva will be observed at the family home.

title: Amtrak and Union Reach Tentative Deal
description: Amtrak and the union representing 2,300 track and tunnel workers have reached ''the basic terms of a new labor agreement,'' the Transportation Secretary said today.

title: Dr. Benjamin W. Zweifach, 86, Leader in Bioengineering Study
description: Dr. Benjamin W. Zweifach, a pioneer in the study of microcirculation, which involves small blood vessels, and in the field of bioengineering, died on Oct. 23 at Sharp Memorial Hospital in San Diego. He was 86 and lived in San Diego.

title: Metro Matters; Term Limits: The Campaign Never Ends
description: AND they're off.

title: Testing The Limits Of Boredom, Intelligently
description: Jonathan Burrows proceeded to test the outer limits of boredom and exhaustion on Thursday night at The Kitchen, then prodded his audience into thinking about exactly what those limits were. The results, paradoxically enough, were invigorating.

title: Eyes on a War: Fixed Images, Stilled Shutters; Southeast Asia as Viewed By Those Who Died There
description: ''Requiem,'' a sad and gruesome pictorial chronicle of the war in Vietnam by photographers who died there, skews the normal function of documentary pictures. Usually, photographs of war are a way of seeing the war itself. In this volume, they are a way of seeing the photographers, through their own eyes. Whatever these photographers were focusing their cameras on, from the end of the Indochina war in the 1950's to the fall of Saigon in 1975, they were all, whether they knew it or not, looking at their own deaths.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JADATZ, HAROLD B.
description: JADATZ-Harold B. Of Deer Park, LI, on November 1, 1997. Beloved husband of Helga. Devoted father of Isabella E. Tobia and Andrew H. Loving father-in-law of Ronald L. and Christine M. Cherished grandfather of Jonathon, Clarisse and Michael. Caring brother of Hans of Germany and Irmgard of England. Family will receive friends today, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 at the Lang-TobiaDiPalma Funeral Home, Inc., 406 Deer Park Ave., Babylon Village. Religious services Tuesday, 10 AM, Ascension Lutheran Church, Bay Shore. Cremation to follow at Washington Memorial Park, Coram. In lieu of flowers, donations to cancer research appreciated.

title: Roy McMillan, 68, Shortstop Renowned for His Fine Fielding
description: Roy McMillan, one of baseball's smoothest-fielding shortstops of the 1950's with the Cincinnati Reds and later a New York Mets manager, died yesterday at Northeast Medical Center in Bonham, Tex. He was 68.

title: Patents; Checkout scanners may soon be ringing up fruits and vegetables based on their scent.
description: IN 1992, President George Bush made headlines when he discovered that he could buy groceries using a bar-code scanner at the supermarket checkout counter. The President apparently did not realize that ordinary Americans had been shopping that way for years.

title: Dipping Small Toes Into Mythological Waters
description: Jim Henson's genius was, among other things, the ability to combine childlike wonder with a core of reality, the kind that lies at the heart of the best fairy tales. (If truth be told, Miss Piggy could use several years of intense psychotherapy, a Zoloft prescription or both.) So what better subject than mythology for Henson, who died in 1990, to have tackled?

title: Americans Get a Golden Point
description: Hobbled by injuries and one man down after an expulsion early in today's World Cup qualifying match, the United States mounted a tenacious and gutsy defense, holding Mexico to a scoreless tie that felt more like a magnificent victory.

title: Man Is Killed in East Village After a Dispute at a Wedding
description: One of the busiest street corners in the East Village was the scene of a fatal shooting shortly after midnight yesterday when a 22-year-old man was gunned down at St. Marks Place and Second Avenue after a dispute with another man at a nearby wedding reception, the police said.

title: Twice the Vice Drops Out
description: The Breeders' Cup lost another star yesterday when Twice the Vice was withdrawn from the $1 million Distaff with a stress fracture of her left front cannon bone and was retired.

title: Ex-Rep. Helen S. Meyner, 69; Born Into Democratic Politics
description: Helen Stevenson Meyner, a liberal Democrat who was elected to two terms in Congress by a heavily Republican district in New Jersey, died yesterday after a long illness at the Heartland Health Care Center, a nursing home in Fort Myers, Fla. She was 69.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BYRNES, COLETTE
description: BYRNES-Colette. On November 1, 1997. Survived by many friends. Memorial Mass on Wednesday at 11 AM, at St. Augustines Church, Larchmont, NY. Contributions to Barat House, Manhattanville College, 2900 Purchase Street, Purchase, NY 10577, would be appreciated. For further information, contact John J. Fox Funeral Home, 914-834-0144.

title: Figures Fault State's Bridges
description: Federal highway statistics show that more than 2,600 bridges in New Jersey -- about 42 percent -- either are in disrepair or do not meet Federal safety standards or traffic loads, the Associated Press reported.

title: INSIDE
description: Amtrak and Union Reach A Deal, Averting a Strike

title: Wheelchair Battle
description: The best race of the day came between two Swiss men in the wheelchair division. The 38-year-old Guido Muller won in 1:50:22.22 and 39-year-old Franz Wietlispach was second in 1:50:22.54. Because fractions of a second are rounded upward in a marathon, they got the same official time -- 1:50:23. The women's winner was 40-year-old Tatyana Tarasova of Russia in 3:42:53. FRANK LITSKY

title: Woman Achieves Goal With Time to Spare
description: Allison Suchenski, 35 years old, running her first New York City Marathon yesterday and wearing No. 120, knew she had a great chance to join the prestigious Three-Hour Club after she zipped through a four-mile tuneup race a week before in her hometown of Trumbull, Conn.

title: A Dreary Day, a Doomed Program
description: There was no escape from the gloom on Saturday afternoon, not in Storrs, Conn., where the wind caused the flagpole to bend and the rain symbolized the beginning of the end for Boston University's football team. A decision to disband the B.U. program had managed to make two teams miserable. The timing of the move had prevented the Terriers from achieving any preparation.

title: Demolition Bond on Ballot
description: The city of Newark is asking its residents to approve a $20 million bond sale tomorrow to finance the demolition of more than 1,000 abandoned houses seized for non-payment of property taxes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, JOHN M.
description: WASSERMAN-John M. On October 30, 1997. Beloved husband of 65 years of Miriam (Wertheimer) Wasserman. Devoted father of Ann Kiggen and Jane Ferrar, grandfather of Andrew, Carolyn, Linda, Derek and Jessica. Great grandfather of Aaron, Daniel, Peter, Jessica, Danielle, Michael and Quinn. Former Senior Partner Asiel & Co., former National Governor National Association of Securities Dealers, former Governor American Stock Exchange, former longtime Trustee Altro Health and Rehabilitation Services. Age 94. Memorial service at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave. and 81st St, Wednesday, November 5, at 12 PM. Friends may call from 11 AM until time of service. Contributions may be made in his memory to charity of one's choice.

title: Taking In the Sites; No Card Necessary at Net Libraries
description: The proliferation of library Web sites is a lesser-known story of the Internet. Most colleges and universities now have at least their card catalogues on line. Most major metropolitan libraries are also on the World Wide Web.

title: A Vital Musical Spirit With a Theatrical Muse
description: Calling it ''The Devil's Fiddle'' was perhaps a bit of a stretch for Halloween, but the program Marin Alsop and the Concordia Orchestra presented at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday was undeniably clever.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The visit achieved the goal of enhancing new understanding, broadening common ground, developing cooperation and building a future together, thus bringing China-U.S. relations into a new historical stage of development.''

title: Two Newark Employees Are Indicted in Arson
description: A civilian employee of the Newark Police Department and a member of the Newark Fire Department's arson unit were indicted on Friday on charges that they burned down an apartment building in December to collect $75,000 in insurance money, prosecutors said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSTON, JAY
description: WINSTON-Jay. The members of the City Athletic Club mourn the loss of its esteemed member, Jay Winston, and wish to express heartfelt sympathy to his family. The Board of Governors

title: Clinton Enters Final Act of Campaigns: In New Jersey, Trenton Is Focus
description: With just 48 hours before Election Day, prominent national leaders from the Democratic and Republican Parties waded into the New Jersey governor's race today, telling voters that their actions on Tuesday would send a message to the rest of the country.

title: Worry Over Brazil's Money Chills the Shopping
description: As turmoil in world financial markets increased pressure on the Government to devalue the currency, Brazilians began watching their pocketbooks this weekend, delaying purchases and refusing to take on new debt.

title: Experts Doubt Rise Of Greenhouse Gas Will Be Curtailed
description: Climate experts have warned for years that a doubling of heat-trapping carbon dioxide in the atmosphere could have serious consequences worldwide. Now a growing number of scientists and policy makers say it will be difficult if not impossible to avoid such a rise.

title: Reunion of Munchkins Revives Magic of Making 'Oz'
description: She steps off the bus, no bigger than a minute in her dirndl dress, flower-pot hat and flame-red fingernail polish, ready to greet her fans. She takes a seat at the end of a long table, the better to pose for the pictures she knows will come. She has a pint-sized place in Hollywood history and is proud to say so.

title: Sports of The Times ; When One Is Higher Than Five
description: ONE night after collecting his National Basketball Association championship ring, courtesy of Michael Jordan, Brian Williams became convinced that Grant Hill would someday win him another.

title: Clinton Enters Final Act of Campaigns: In New York, He Backs Bid by Messinger
description: Recalling that Ruth W. Messinger had ''stuck by me'' through his own difficult New York political contest five years ago, President Clinton made a long-sought trip to Manhattan last night and vigorously urged voters to support her mayoral bid. He asserted that she had grasped the main issues confronting the city now that crime was in decline: failing schools and lingering unemployment.

title: Abroad at Home; Menacing The Judges
description: The Framers of the American Constitution took care to assure the independence of Federal courts from political pressures, making the judges removable only by the process of impeachment. That independence has enabled the courts to play their crucial role in keeping this a free and open country.

title: Carol C. Tatkon, 59, Former Oil Official
description: Carol Clark Tatkon, a former senior vice president for Exxon U.S.A., died on Oct. 11 at a family home in North Egremont, Mass. Mrs. Tatkon, a resident of Houston, was 59.

title: When Children Fall Victim to AIDS Predator; Not Attempted Murder
description: To the Editor:

title: Could NBC Live Without 'E.R.'?; Bidding War Looms for TV's Hottest Drama Series
description: ''E.R.,'' the Mona Lisa of contemporary television, is about to be put up for auction -- and every network in America wants this work of prime-time art hanging on its wall.

title: In Bossa Nova's Pulse, the Sensual Rhythms of Life
description: You have only to listen for a few minutes to the music of Antonio Carlos Jobim, the Brazilian composer and prime mover behind the bossa nova movement, to sense the supreme ease with which he fused the yin and yang impulses of popular music.

title: James Gantsoudes, 55, Wall St. Executive
description: James G. Gantsoudes, global head of the equity capital markets department at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company, died Oct. 17 at his home in Redding, Conn. He was 55.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, JACQUES J.

description: Winding down a campaign that has reverberated far from Staten Island, the two candidates for the House seat representing the borough took vastly different tacks yesterday trying to woo voters: The Democrat paraded his backing from President Clinton, while the Republican embarked on a whirlwind tour of the borough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUOHY, THOMAS F., JR.

title: Pentagon Bias on Gulf War Illness
description: Two independent reviews of the Government's handling of Persian Gulf war illness have now made it inescapably clear that the Pentagon is too biased to conduct a credible investigation. Even after what appear to be genuine efforts to expand and upgrade its inquiry, the Pentagon -- in the view of a Presidential panel and a House committee -- remains so blindly convinced that chemical weapons exposures are of little import that it cannot seem to conduct a hard-digging inquiry. Whatever the Pentagon ultimately concludes, neither veterans nor the public will believe that it has taken an objective look.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When GEORGE CLOONEY learned that his aunt ROSEMARY CLOONEY was making plans to marry DANTE Di PAOLO this week, he sent a bouquet of flowers with a note asking, ''What's the rush?''

title: In Her Own Words
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER

title: An Ancient, Neglected Art Finds Its Modern Audience
description: Given all the erudition that has been dispensed on the peoples who competed for space and influence in Europe before the Romans, it is odd to think that one civilization could be overlooked. Yet until a century ago the Iberians were not recognized as a cultural entity, and until now their artistic legacy has never been presented in a single near-complete exhibition.

title: Izon Says the Apollo Has Found a New Star
description: Lou Savarese, the Bronx-born heavyweight, withstood a barrage from George Foreman in April at Madison Square Garden. But he could not stand up to the bombs David Izon delivered on Saturday night (early yesterday, actually) at the Apollo Theater, and Savarese was knocked out in the fifth round.

title: Controversy Stalks Leaders After Rochat-Moser's Upset
description: The women's part of yesterday's New York City Marathon may be remembered not for the upset victory of a 31-year-old Swiss lawyer-restaurateur or the disappointing seventh-place finish of the crowd favorite. Instead, it may be memorialized as the marathon where many of the leaders received help, planned or otherwise, from friends or strangers who provided them with high-energy drinks or water during the race.

A lot of the company's longtime well-wishers had more or less given up on what seemed to be a slide into artistic and economic oblivion. The procession of sloppy productions of the obvious and ill-advised adventures into the avant-garde were, at any rate, hardly promising.

title: U.S. Quarterly Refunding Is Set This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week features today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and the Treasury's quarterly debt refunding over three days. The refunding begins tomorrow with the sale of $14 billion of three-year notes, followed on Wednesday by $11 billion of 10-year notes and Thursday with the sale of $10 billion of 30-year bonds, accompanied by a $12 billion sale of 52-week bills.

title: Walter J. Kuron, of Red Baron Era, Dies at 102
description: Walter J. Kuron, a German-born choirmaster who made music his life and his World War I dogfighting days his legend, died Tuesday at a New Jersey nursing home the way he lived , listening to Bach. He was 102 and had not quite lived down the myth that he was the last man alive to have flown with Baron Manfred von Richthofen, the Red Baron.

title: Increasingly, Electronic Cooks Are Being Used to Keep the Soup From Spoiling

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COMNAS, GEORGE DEMETRIE
description: COMNAS-George Demetrie. Of Bridgehampton, NY, passed away on November 1, 1997. Born in Vancouver, BC, on April 22, 1913. George was raised in Cuero, Texas, received his B.S. in Chemical Engineering from Texas A&M University ('35); from 1936 to 1942 he served to Captain in the U.S. Army and was awarded Best Drilled Trooper in the U.S. Cavalry. He received an M.B.A. from New York University and was a student of Advanced Management Practices at Harvard University. George Comnas had a highly distinguished career as an oil and shipping executive, beginning in 1935 with Humble Oil & Refining in Baytown, Texas, continuing with Standard Oil Co. of New Jersey (Esso), based in New York, Caripito, Venezuela, London, England, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil and Geneva, Switzerland. He joined C.M. Lemos & Co., Ltd., as Managing Director and Chairman of the Board between 1969-74, thereafter serving as an oil and shipping consultant to several governments until retiring to Bridgehampton in 1987. George Comnas served as a senior warden and vestryman in both the Episcopal and Greek Orthodox churches throughout the world. He was a member of Shinnecock Hills G.C., Oyster Harbor G.C., Royal St. Georges G.C., Royal Wimbledon G.C., Golf Club de Geneve, Larchmont Yacht Club, and was a Knights Templar (Shriner). In 1976 he was named Distinguished Alumnus of Texas A&M University. George is survived by his loving wife, Jo Ann (Booth), his devoted children Basil G. Comnas, Demetrie G. Comnas and Aspasia Comnas Neuman, and by five adoring grandchildren. Reposing at the J.M. O'Connell Funeral Home, 30 Little Plains Road, Southampton, NY, Monday from 7-9 PM and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. There will be a Funeral Service at The Greek Orthodox Church of The Hamptons, 111 St. Andrew's Road, Southampton, NY, on Wednesday at 11 AM. Interment will follow at Edgewood Cemetery, Bridgehampton, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Greek Orthodox Church of The Hamptons would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHARMAN, FRIDA
description: SCHARMAN-Frida. Died peacefully Saturday, October 25 at her home after a long illness. Born in 1908, she was the daughter of August Charles Scharman and Lillie Rueger Scharman of Brooklyn. Miss Scharman was a lifetime resident of New York City and was a talented squash racquets player. She represented the United States against Great Britain in 1931. She also won innumerable tennis titles in doubles at The River Club in New York City, Piping Rock Club, Locust Valley, and The Heights Casino in Brooklyn. She was a graduate of Smith College, Northampton, MA., and of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, New York. She joined the American Red Cross in 1942 and served in London during the Blitz. After the war, she was a volunteer at the United Nations. She leaves a niece, Ann Hester Huntoon, Charleston, SC, two grand-nieces, Susan Payson, Tucson, AZ, and Jill Kennedy, San Diego, CA., and a cousin, Mrs. John MacKay, Locust Valley. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Red Cross, POB 37243, Washington, D.C. 20013, marked for the Frida Scharman Memorial Fund.

title: Livingston Street's Sloppy Records

Such was the case last week when the board's headquarters at 110 Livingston Street disclosed a $70 million surplus in state aid. Had the surplus been forecast early enough, it could have been put to good use right away.

description: To the Editor:

title: Mood Is Grim as Israeli-Palestinian Negotiations Resume
description: Israeli and Palestinian negotiators have been spelling out sharply contradictory goals for a new round of peace talks that is scheduled to begin in Washington on Monday, which does not bode well for the American diplomatic effort.

title: In Congress and White House, Debate Begins on How to Use Future Budget Surpluses
description: After decades in which huge Federal budget deficits cast a shadow over politics and the economy, Congress and the White House face the possibility that the Government will begin running surpluses in the next few years, and a heated debate is already breaking out over what to do with the money.

title: Norwegian's Frozen Ship
description: To the Editor:

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Suspect in Spread of AIDS Virus To Be Sentenced on Drug Charge
description: Six weeks ago, a rather ordinary buy-and-bust sting intended to catch drug dealers led the police in the Bronx to Nushawn J. Williams, the man believed to be at the center of a rather extraordinary one-man AIDS epidemic.

title: When Children Fall Victim to AIDS Predator; A Fitting Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Curfew Introduced for Cars
description: In an effort to cut down on auto theft, the police in Harrison will introduce a curfew for cars and trucks today. Voluntary participants will place reflective decals in their back windows to alert the police that they want their vehicles pulled over if spotted from 1 to 5 A.M., said Lieut. Michael Green of the Harrison police.

title: Nanny Case Provides No Guidance for Parents; Not Really Au Pairs
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli-Palestinian Talks Get Off to a Shaky Start in Washington
description: New Israeli-Palestinian talks opened here today, but with little chance of quick accomplishments since key Palestinian officials failed to show up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, MAXINE
description: BARNETT-Maxine. November 2, 1997. Beloved mother of Linda Mandel and Samuel Barnett, cherished grandmother to David and Lisa Mandel. Services on Tuesday, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: 49ers Revitalized, So Give Cowboys Credit
description: The San Francisco 49ers have re-invented themselves.

title: Journal; What, Me Worry?
description: Four months without having to have an opinion! This was the situation in which I found myself as I took the first extended break ever in a 20-year-plus journalistic career of spewing out opinions for readers purportedly in desperate need of them.

title: Metro Business Briefs; Alpine Group Acquisition
description: The Alpine Group Inc. of New York said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the refractory businesses of American Premier Inc. for $133 million in cash, stock and assumed debt, expanding Alpine's line of heat-resistant materials used in the production of steel, aluminum, glass and cement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, LEE JOHN
description: FISCHER-Lee John, died November 3, 1997 at the age of eighty. Survived by step-children Ben Hedges and Anne Hedges. Devoted lifelong friend of Charles Baker Finch and beloved friend and caretaker of Eileen Sparkey. There will be no services as requested by the deceased. Forever in my heart, Charles's son, William

title: Lazard Names a Chief for Banking Division
description: Lazard Freres & Company L.L.C., the New York investment bank, has appointed Gerald Rosenfeld, 50, head of its banking department.

title: Newark to Make School Into a Center of Family Services
description: In an effort to make a public school a full-service place for children and their parents, school and city officials here today unveiled the Camden Middle Community School, which would offer after-school programs for children as well as job training, family counseling and health and aerobics classes for their parents.

title: Listening to Music of the Hemisphere, Spun by Its Composers
description: As an organization with a distinguishing mission, the American Composers Orchestra has the luxury of assembling its programs without worry about the thematic connections that have become fixations for so many other ensembles.

title: In Her Own Words
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER

title: Nanny Case Provides No Guidance for Parents; Videotaping as Abuse?
description: To the Editor:

title: Second Trial Opens In Oklahoma Blast
description: As they opened their case in Federal District Court in Denver, prosecutors portrayed the defendant, Terry L. Nichols, as working side by side with Timothy J. McVeigh in preparing the bomb that destroyed the Federal building in Oklahoma City on April 19, 1995, and killed 168 people. Prosecutors began constructing a case that includes previously undisclosed evidence and is broader than the one against Mr. McVeigh that in June led to his conviction and condemnation to death on murder and conspiracy charges.

title: Overnight Success Takes Decades
description: Outside the Hollywood Park race track, a few furlongs down Century Boulevard from the Los Angeles International Airport, where streets have championship names like Kelso Boulevard, there is no hint on the marquee that a revolution is being plotted for Saturday when the 14th Breeders' Cup races are run.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWLER, KELLY SIDES
description: LAWLER-Kelly Sides. Of South Orange, N.J. Beloved wife of John A. Lawler. Devoted mother of Madeleine, Jack and Nicholas Lawler. Loving daughter of Robert S. and Margaret Lanier Sides. Dear sister of Robert L.; Richard L. and James S. Sides. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral from The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, 2122 Millburn Ave., Maplewood, Thursday, Nov. 6 at 8:30 AM, thence to Our Lady of Sorrows Church, South Orange, where a Funeral Mass will be offered at 9:30 AM. Visiting hours Tuesday, 7-9 PM and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Donations may be made to the American Cancer Society, NJ, 767 Northfield Avenue, West Orange, NJ 07052.

title: Rescue of Besieged Orangutans Aids Research
description: TRAPPED within a few forested acres on the South Pacific island of Borneo, an orangutan blustered as wildlife researchers tightened their circle around her, then she retreated angrily up a tree. Many hours later, the orangutan crept near the ground, close enough for a marksman to shoot a tranquilizer dart into her thigh, and she tumbled into brush that had been piled up to cushion her fall. When she opened her eyes again, she was in a wildlife reserve with room to roam.

title: Pataki Plan Seeks U.S. Funds To Cover Uninsured Children
description: The Pataki administration submitted plans today to use $255 million a year in new Federal health care funds to expand the state's subsidized health insurance program for the working poor, setting a goal of covering all of New York's 420,000 uninsured children from low-income families by 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, JULIA WEBER
description: GORDON-Julia Weber. Age 85, on November 3, 1997 in Princeton, NJ. Noted educator and author of ''My Country School Diary''. Widow of Philip Gordon, conductor, composer and arranger of classical music for schools and colleges. Cremation will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDER, KARL
description: FELDER-Karl. Loving husband of the late Helen. Adored father of Paul and Judith Dechter. Dear grandfather of Jesse and Ashley. Beloved brother of Rhoda Asher, Louisa Solomon and Lawrence. Graveside services, 11 A.M., on Wednesday, at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, New York.

title: L.I. Race Could Tip Balance of Power
description: The two major parties have poured hundreds of thousands of dollars into a special election on Long Island that could help shift the balance of power in the State Senate, a chamber Republicans have held for all but one year since World War II.

title: At Lunch With Hector Feliciano -- A Bulldog on the Heels Of Lost Nazi Loot; A Cause Uncelebrated Becomes a Passion
description: Sitting at a corner table at Sette MOMA, the restaurant in the Museum of Modern Art, is a warm, engaging man who laughs easily and is clearly enjoying his spinach-and-ricotta ravioli in black truffle sauce. Glasses frame his deep-set brown eyes. He is neither short nor tall and, though broad-shouldered, is not the least bit physically imposing.

title: Council to Consider Taxi Hoods for Hire
description: Just when it seemed that every square inch of public space in New York City was already plastered with advertisements, comes a new proposal from the City Council: why not allow ads on the hoods of taxicabs? The Council's transportation committee is to consider a bill on Thursday to allow cab owners to turn their hoods into rolling billboards.

title: The Slap: It Costs O'Neal One Game and $10,000
description: Shaquille O'Neal said he was sorry yesterday, but the National Basketball Association was not impressed with his apology. O'Neal, the Lakers' All-Star center, will miss his second game of the season tonight at Sacramento after the league suspended him for one game and fined him $10,000 for delivering an open-handed slap to the head of Utah Jazz center Greg Ostertag last week.

title: Montgomerie Won't Join U.S. Tour
description: Colin Montgomerie announced yesterday that he would not join the PGA Tour next season. It had been widely speculated that Montgomerie, one of the world's top players, would leave the European PGA Tour and play primarily in the United States.

title: Boeing to Phase Out 2 Jets From McDonnell Douglas
description: The Boeing Company said today that it would phase out two of the four lines of civilian jets it inherited when it acquired the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and that it was still uncertain about the long-term future of a third.

title: Wolverines Defense Is Feared
description: In the big game at Penn State on Saturday, the result of which may ultimately decide the Big Ten championship, Rose Bowl participation and perhaps the national championship, the matchup numbers favor Michigan.

title: In Last Leg, McGreevey Sticks to Main Streets
description: Rolling through a dozen of New Jersey's more modest main streets today, State Senator James E. McGreevey brought his campaign to a close by drawing a comparison for voters between his own humble roots and the patrician background of his opponent, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Prison Term for Embezzling
description: In 1994, Alan Damsky, then an accountant at the Army's Fort Monmouth Communications and Electronics Command, fulfilled a promise to his dying father and took his mother on a cruise around the world. Yesterday, Mr. Damsky, 27, of East Brunswick, was sentenced in United States District Court in Newark to a year in prison for embezzling $75,000 from the Defense Department to pay for the trip, Federal prosecutors said.
