title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Luther G. Simjian, inventor of devices including the flight simulator and the automated teller machine, referred imprecisely to his nationality. While he was born in Turkey, he was of Armenian descent.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's; Take a Little Sass, Add Sunshine
description: What does a smash song sound like right now? The answer pretty much belongs to those inexhaustibly cute Spice Girls. Hailed as the commercial face of a new wave of brash femininity -- Girl Power -- the English quintet also stands for the dynamic center of the musical mainstream. Its second album, ''Spiceworld,'' comes out today, with a new single already on the charts. Here, a look at that album and several of its competitors on the hit parade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COUGHLIN, CATHERINE
description: COUGHLIN-Catherine, 86. Died Nov. 2, 1997. She is survived by many loving family members and friends who will miss her counsel, company and sense of adventure. Her generous spirit remains with us. She was administrative assistant to the Presidents of Sarah Lawrence College and Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation. Memorial donations to the New York League for the Hard of Hearing, where she was working as a consultant. Calling hours Tuesday from 5-7:00 PM at the Horne-Dannecker Funeral Home, 336 W. 23rd Street, NY, with funeral service at 7:00 PM. The funeral procession leaves the funeral home at 10:00 AM, Wednesday with burial taking place at Holy Cross Cemetery on Tilden Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Dow Up 232 As Markets Soar Abroad
description: A rebound in Asian and European equity markets fueled a rally for American stocks yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average roaring ahead more than 232 points. Those gains brought the Dow within 41 points of where it was before it plunged 554.26 points just a week ago yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODE, RUTH
description: GOODE-Ruth, 92. Beloved mother of Daniel and Judith, grandmother of Aviva and Jonathan, died October 27 at New York Hospital. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Accountant Is Sentenced In Government Theft
description: In 1994, Alan Damsky, then an accountant for the United States Army at Fort Monmouth, N.J., fulfilled a promise to his dying father and took his mother on a cruise around the world. Yesterday, Mr. Damsky, 27, of East Brunswick, was sentenced to a year in prison for embezzling $75,000 from the Defense Department to pay for the trip, Federal prosecutors said.

title: An Assault With Pepper Spray
description: Representative Frank Riggs's defense of the Humboldt County police officers called in to remove anti-logging protesters from his Congressional district office in Eureka, Calif., seems bizarre in light of the abuse documented on police videotape. On Oct. 16, four protesters chained together appeared in Mr. Riggs's office and refused to comply with police orders to leave. The protesters had secured their arms inside steel pipes to make it difficult to separate them, and admittedly this presented the officers with a problem. But there was no immediate threat to life or property, making all the more puzzling the officers' use of chemical brutality to deal with a sit-in.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONDER, RABBI DAVID
description: BONDER-Rabbi David. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. Born in 1906, he served as JWB Midwest Regional Director before making aliyah. In Israel, he served our movement as assistant director of the Center for Conservative Judaism in Jerusalem. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his widow, Ruth, and his daughter Bayla Rae, and all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi David L. Lieber, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP, The Rabbinical Assembly

title: The Chiefs Allen Can Pass Too
description: CHIEFS, 13 STEELERS 10

title: Republicans Drop Plan for Address Challenges
description: The Republican State Committee has amassed a list of 287,000 people who have recently changed their addresses but not their voter registration, for the purpose of voter challenges at the polls. But the committee has decided to abandon the effort because its legality is ''ambiguous.''

title: Lamoriello Picks 17 Olympians, Including Leetch and Richter
description: Seventeen players were picked yesterday to represent the United States in the 1998 Olympic Winter Games in Nagano, Japan, the first to allow National Hockey League players to compete.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Public TV Seeks New Income
description: It will not run commercials, but New Jersey Network, the state's public television system, is exploring ways to raise revenues in the face of cuts in state financing, network officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACKERMAN, REBECCA
description: ACKERMAN-Rebecca. The Officers and Trustees of the Jewish Center of the Hamptons extend their deepest condolences to Leonard Ackerman, a devoted member of our Board of Trustees, and to his family on the death of his mother, Rebecca. David Gelfand, Rabbi Debra Stein-Davidson, Cantor Betty L. Marmon, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINE, DAVID
description: FINE-David, 85, Died Sunday in Louisville, KY. He was a native of Brooklyn, New York and a retired executive at M. Fine and Sons Manufacturing Co. Survivors sons Martin L. and Allan H. of Louisville; brother Leo, N. Palm Beach, FL. Five grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Funeral and interment Monday in Louisville.

title: Review/Fashion; Sprouse's American Hurrah
description: It has been years since the crackle in the opening days of the New York women's fashion showings was generated by Americans pushing the boundaries of design.

title: Academy of Sciences, Fighting to Keep Its Panels Closed, Is Rebuffed by Supreme Court
description: The National Academy of Sciences, an elite club of the nation's leading scientists and a major provider of scientific advice to the Federal Government, was dealt a painful setback by the United States Supreme Court yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Inside Art column on Friday about Henry Kravis's sales of part of his art collection misidentified the New York auction house where John Singer Sargent's ''Cashmere'' (1908) was sold in December for $11.1 million, a record for the artist. It was Sotheby's, not Christie's.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: G.E. Cashing In Stake In Lockheed Martin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ANDREW
description: SMITH-Andrew. On November 1, 1997. Son of Richard and Penny; brother of Douglas Smith. Family will receive friends at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, Tuesday 7-9, Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Pius X Church, Thursday 10 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, PATRICK JOHN
description: FITZGERALD-Patrick John, police officer NYPD, of Pelham Manor, NY, on November 2, 1997. Son of Lona and Edmund Fitzgerald, Jr. Brother of Edmund III, John and the late Sgt. Walker S. Fitzgerald, NYPD. Grandson of Richard and Joan Warnimont and the late Edmund Fitzgerald and Katherine McVeigh Fitzgerald. Nephew of Brian. Calling hours at Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4 PM and 7-9 P.M., Tuesday and Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Mary's Church, South Broadway, Yonkers, Thursday, November 6, at 10:00 A.M.

title: Nassau's Property-Tax System Under Attack
description: Experts in the obscure world of property-tax assessments say no other assessing system in the United States is as strange, or as costly, as the one in Nassau County.

title: New Director at Tanglewood Center
description: After a year of internal turmoil, the Boston Symphony Orchestra has announced that Ellen Highstein, formerly the executive director of Concert Artists Guild, has been appointed director of the Tanglewood Music Center. Richard Ortner, who had served as administrator of the program, was dismissed last year by Seiji Ozawa, the music director of the Boston Symphony, which runs the center.

title: Workers Detail Slips In Energy Dept.'s Data
description: Hazel R. O'Leary stood proudly in front a chart depicting the Department of Energy's success in awarding contracts to minority-owned companies.

title: Reviews: THEATER REVIEW; It's Lust, but Not Strictly Sexual
description: In their haunted bedroom, the besotted lovers of ''Therese Raquin'' obsess not over sex, but death. ''Show me how,'' the guilt-racked Therese beseeches her new husband, and it isn't lovemaking that she is talking about. She wants the virile Laurent to re-enact the murder of her first husband, puny, asexual Camille.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS TO ACQUIRE A UNIT OF CERIDIAN
description: The General Dynamics Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the Ceridian Corporation's Computing Devices International unit for $600 million. Computing Devices, based in Bloomington, Minn., is a military electronics and systems integration business with estimated 1997 sales of $600 million. It employs 3,300 people in Minnesota, Canada and Britain. General Dynamics, based in Falls Church, Va., designs and manufactures nuclear submarines, surface combatant ships and combat systems.

title: FOOTBALL: The Lombardi Legacy; Grandson of the Coaching Great Makes Good
description: When a young lieutenant at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base applied last year for a job on the coaching staff of the University of Dayton Flyers, the head football coach, Mike Kelly, took notice of the candidate's name.

title: First-Place Giants Keep One Eye On N.F.C. East, Another on Jets
description: It was Giants linebacker Corey Miller who first stated the obvious today. The first-place 6-3 Giants are locked in a public relations match with the first-place 6-3 Jets, each team trying to hold serve in the court of popular opinion, with neither side wanting to fall behind in this not-so-subtle regional rivalry.

title: Recipe for a Brain: Cups of Genes and Dash of Experience?
description: NOBODY really knows how the mind works, but that does not stop many articulate, combative, creative scientists from laying out opposing theories to explain how the ''meat'' inside the human skull gives rise to consciousness and laughter, the ability to hear a sonata or dance a jig, and decisions on what to have for dinner tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPPENHEIM, KARL
description: PAPPENHEIM-Karl. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community in Israel, a former school principal in Switzerland and Israel; beloved husband of Beate; father of Rachi (and David) Grossman, Avraham (and Nechama) Pappenheim, Elisheva (and Yitzchak) Altman, and Binyomin (and Miriam) Pappenheim; and brother of Erica Jesselson and Lucy Lang. Mrs. Jesselson is Chairman of the YU Museum Board. She and her late husband Ludwig Jesselson, distinguished philanthropist and longtime YU Board Chairman, are Benefactors who have played a leadership role in a wide range of University programs. Mrs. Lang is a member of the Museum Board and a dedicated supporter of YU, as was her late husband, Edmond. We extend our heartfelt condolences as well to grandchildren, great-grandchildren, nieces, nephews, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Iraq Threatens To Shoot Down U.S. Spy Planes
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, in a move sure to isolate his country further, threatened today to shoot down the American U-2 spy planes used by international disarmament monitors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, JOSHUA BENJAMIN
description: ROSEN-Joshua Benjamin. The leadership of UJA-Federation of New York offers its sincere condolences to Rachel Freedman, cochair of our White Plains Women's Campaign, and her husband, Daniel Rosen, on the tragic and untimely passing of their infant son, Joshua Benjamin Rosen. We share their sadness, though we cannot begin to know their pain. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Joan Ginsburg, Chair Westchester Women's Campaign Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Baron Edmond de Rothschild, 71, French Financier, Dies
description: Baron Edmond de Rothschild, the French-born financier who was said to be the wealthiest of the surviving descendants of the legendary banking family, died in Geneva on Sunday. He was 71.

title: Clinton Tosses A Late Pitch In Virginia
description: In a final effort to aid the Democratic candidate for governor of Virginia, Donald S. Beyer Jr., President Clinton came to Northern Virginia today and urged voters to reject the tax cuts promised by Mr. Beyer's Republican opponent, James S. Gilmore 3d.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ADLER, HARRY
description: ADLER-Harry. Assistant Director of The Reece School. Memorial service on Wednesday, November 5, 1997, 5:30pm, St. Ignatius Loyola, Wallace Hall, 84th and Park Ave. Memorial contributions may be made to The Reece School, 180 E. 90 Street, NYC 10128 and GMHC, 129 West 20 Street, NYC 10011.

title: Thai Prime Minister Quits, a Casualty of Economic Crisis
description: Thailand's Prime Minister resigned under fire today, becoming the first political casualty of Southeast Asia's economic crisis. The Government struggled to find a new leader as the country's currency and stock market continued to fall.

title: Parcells, Only Human, Waffles on Quarterback
description: Bill Parcells, never known to waffle, gave a rare display of what appeared to be soul-searching today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANVILLE, SMITH, WALTER, III
description: GRANVILLE-SMITH-Walter, III, age 63, of Mollusk, Virginia, died November 1, 1997. The son of the late Walter and Jean GranvilleSmith, he was born in New York City on October 5th, 1934. He is survived by his wife, Pamela, his four sons, Richard, Stephen, David and Peter of Rowayton, CT., and his sister, Beverly Bullwinkle of Westport, CT. Mr. Granville-Smith was a 1952 graduate of Choate in Wallingford, CT., and a 1956 graduate of Dartmouth in Hanover, N.H. He began his business career in advertising with Benton & Bowles in New York City. He later worked at Young & Rubicam as a Vice President, and Needham, Harper & Steers as a Senior Vice President. In 1987, he and his wife, Pamela, moved to Mollusk, Virginia, where they ran a bed and breakfast inn at Greenvale Manor. He was a member of the Northern Neck Board of Realtors. While living in New York and Connecticut, he was an avid sailor, which included one-design and offshore yacht racing. Throughout his life, he had a passion for boating and fishing. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, November 4 at 11 AM at the Grace Episcopal Church in Kilmarnock, Virginia. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Upper Lancaster Rescue Squad, P.O. Box 176, Lively, Virginia 22507 or the Upper Lancaster Fire Department, P.O. Box 205, Lively, VA. 22507.

title: Board Member's Ouster By Crew Draws Criticism
description: A City Councilman, an Assemblywoman and about a dozen parents accused Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew yesterday of trying to stifle dissent by ousting a member of a Manhattan school board who has been a frequent critic of Board of Education policy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHAR, REBECCA L.
description: BEHAR-Rebecca L. Of Long Beach and The Sephardic Home. Died peacefully November 2, 1997. Devoted mother of Elia, Sonya and Jamila. Cherished grandmother of Robin and Eric, Alvin and Rochelle, Allan and Joyce, Valari, Ralph, Alan, Marc, and the late Eric Behar. Loving great grandmother of Jessie, Miles, Mason, Steven, Stacey, Annie, Jason, Alexa and Sophie. Dear mother-inlaw of Tobi, Jack and the late Simon Elias. She was loved dearly by all of us whose life she touched. Memorial service Wednesday, November 5 at 10:30 AM, I.J. Morris Funeral Chapel, 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, New York.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERGOLA, CHARLES A.
description: PERGOLA-Charles A. In Trumbull, Connecticut, November 2, 1997. Former President of the Revlon, Beauty Care Group, New York and SmithKline Beecham Consumer Brands and senior executive for twenty-five years in the Health and Beauty Aids Industry. Friends may attend a Memorial Mass Wednesday, at 9:30 AM, in Notre Dame Church, Easton, CT. Survivors include his wife Yvette Zuliani Pergola, two daughters, Tanya and Lara Pergola, a brother, Sam Pergola, two sisters, Mary De Melis and Jennie Cisto; also several nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, those who so desire may make contributions in his memory to the American Brain Tumor Association, 2720 River Road, Des Plains, Illinois 60018.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of the New York City Opera's production of Handel's ''Xerxes'' misidentified the performer with David Daniels. She was Amy Burton, not Lorraine Hunt.

title: Metro Business Briefs; 2 Real Estate Firms Agree to a Merger
description: Two New York-based real estate service firms, Douglas Elliman Commercial and Friedman Realty Group, have agreed to merge, the latest indication of the pressure on real estate service providers to grow rapidly and broaden geographically.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, BARBARA
description: BERNARD - Barbara. Temple B'nai Sholom mourns the loss of our long-time member. We extend condolences to the family. Services were held Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, Monday, November 3. Dr. Martin Greenberg, President Dr. Barry Dov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: Fear Fills the Schools; Use the Lottery Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Nanny Case Provides No Guidance for Parents; 'Niceties' of Proof
description: To the Editor:

title: Time Inc. Makes Editorial Shifts at 2 Magazines
description: In a new editorial structure for Time Inc., John Huey, the managing editor of Fortune magazine, will also oversee Money magazine beginning in January, Norman Pearlstine, the editor in chief of Time Inc. said yesterday.

title: Younger Williams Wins in Chicago
description: AMERITECH CUP

title: MARSHALL & ILSLEY TO ACQUIRE ADVANTAGE BANCORP
description: The Marshall & Ilsley Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Advantage Bancorp Inc. for about $201 million in stock. Marshall & Ilsley, a bank holding company based in Milwaukee, said it would exchange 1.2 shares for each Advantage share. But the ratio may change if Marshall & Ilsley's price exceeds $61.67 a share or is less than $46.67. Based on Marshall & Ilsley's closing price on Friday, the deal is valued at about $201 million. Shares of Advantage rose $3.375 yesterday, to $59.375, in Nasdaq trading, while Marshall & Ilsley fell 50 cents, to $51.375. Advantage, based in Kenosha, Wis., is the parent company of Advantage Bank, which has 10 branches and $1.1 billion in assets. Marshall & Ilsley has about $19 billion in assets.

title: Two Reports Show Strength in Economy
description: Two economic reports showed today that manufacturing unexpectedly strengthened in October and personal incomes rose in September, signs that the economy might not be slowing enough to keep the Federal Reserve from raising borrowing costs.

title: Election Day Choices
description: Today voters will choose New York City's next mayor, New Jersey's next governor and other officials. They will also vote on important ballot issues. Polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. in New York State, and 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. in New Jersey. Here is a summary of our endorsements:

title: A Clinton adviser argues the economic case for self-regulation of sales pitches in cyberspace.
description: THE Clinton Administration's point person on Internet issues is lobbying Madison Avenue to help insure that a policy providing for the self-regulation of cyberspace -- including sales pitches aimed at children -- withstands strong, sustained challenges.

title: Stock Market Surprise Had Clear Warnings
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Declines to Hear Appeal Of Ban on Affirmative Action
description: The Supreme Court declined today to hear a challenge to California's ban on race or sex-based preferences in public hiring, contracting and school admission, leaving disputes over the measure to be sorted out in the State Legislature, courts and county governments around the state.

title: By Subway, Ferry and Bus, Seeking Votes
description: Ruth W. Messinger turned to public transportation yesterday in a final 19-hour quest for votes, riding 10 subway lines and the Staten Island ferry to campaign in all boroughs. Energized by what she called ''a huge emotional boost'' from President Clinton's visit on Sunday, Ms. Messinger urged Democrats to ''take back City Hall and move New York City into the 21st Century.''

title: NORTHERN TELECOM OFFERS TO ADD BROADBAND NETWORKS
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. offered yesterday to acquire Broadband Networks Inc., a closely held Canadian wireless network supplier, for $586 million (Canadian), or $416 million (United States), in cash and stock. Northern Telecom would pay $6.0278 (Canadian) in cash and 0.0856 a share for each Broadband Networks share outstanding. Certain Broadband shareholders representing 24.1 million shares, or 81 percent of the company's 29.6 million shares outstanding, have agreed to the offer. Broadband Networks, based in Winnipeg, Manitoba, makes fixed broadband wireless communications networks. Northern Telecom, based in Toronto, is a telecommunications equipment maker. Its shares rose $2.3125, to $92.

title: Vote, and Stay With Party, Whitman Tells Republicans
description: On the final stops of her 10-day bus tour, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman worked on shoring up her Republican base today, repeatedly urging party members to vote and not to meander to a third party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGELOFF, ALLAN
description: AGELOFF-Allan. Age 94. Real estate developer. On November 1, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Pauline, loving and devoted father of Ann and Sherman Tufel and the late Joelle Shankman. Precious Poppy of Scott, Dr. Andrew, Michael, Joanne, Seth and Tammy, and the late Mark. Dear brother of Ruth Poulos. His love, strength and wisdom were an inspiration to us all. Services today, 1 PM, at Sherman's, Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue (Avenue J), Brooklyn.

title: Justices Grapple With Merits of Polygraphs at Trials
description: The Supreme Court wrestled today with the question of whether a criminal defendant's constitutional right to a legal defense includes the right to present evidence of having passed a lie detector test.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Election Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: INSIDE
description: Global Equity Markets Rise, But Thai Prime Minister Falls

title: Long Behind, Louisville Is Experiencing a Surge
description: Almost as a symbolic affirmation of this city's resurgence, Muhammad Ali is coming home.

title: Man in the News: Charles Ossola Rossotti; Hope for I.R.S. in 2000
description: When President Clinton nominated Charles O. Rossotti to head the Internal Revenue Service, the candidate's expertise in computers seemed ideal for an agency whose technology was outmoded and overwhelmed. When Mr. Rossotti was confirmed by the Senate today, he took on an even bigger mission: regaining the trust of the American people.

title: Population Predictor
description: To the Editor:

title: Computers Model World's Climate, but How Well?
description: TOM'S RESTAURANT at 112th Street and Broadway in Upper Manhattan is right out of ''Seinfeld.'' But six floors above, Dr. Makiko Sato and Dr. James E. Hansen are conjuring up a bigger world from the innards of what looks like a slightly oversized personal computer. This is no ordinary computer, however. It contains the earth's atmosphere and oceans, albeit in mathematical form, interconnected to create a virtual global climate system.

title: Clause Nets Avery $3.9 Million
description: Steve Avery turned his manager's act of courage -- or foolhardiness --into a $3.9 million payoff yesterday.

title: True to Their Missions, Two Guitarists' Guitarists
description: Two guitarists' guitarists have visited New York lately: Derek Bailey at the Knitting Factory, on and off since last Monday, and John Fahey at Tramps on Sunday night. Their music stakes out diametrically opposed ideas about memory, structure and strategy. Yet in some ways, they are parallel figures. Both emerged in the 1960's, both started mini-movements and both make music that is inseparable from the wood and metal of their guitars.

title: Rangers' Slump Continues With Tie Against Oilers
description: It was a chance for the Rangers to regain some of their confidence before going on the road to play a couple of the National Hockey League's premier teams this week. But all they could muster against a decidedly mediocre Edmonton Oilers team last night was a 2-2 tie on home ice.

title: Personal Health; Girls and Puberty: the Crisis Years
description: THE teen-age years have never been easy. They can be especially difficult for girls, who experience hormonal influences that wreck their prepubescent physical equality with boys, cause radical changes in body shape and weight and sometimes touch off emotional and reproductive upheavals. But for many reasons, the challenges facing adolescent girls have never been greater than they are today. An unprecedented number of girls fall from the grace of childhood innocence to discover cigarettes, drugs, alcohol, depression, eating disorders and unwanted pregnancies.

title: Mental Illness Considered In Suspect in H.I.V. Cases
description: The man accused of knowingly infecting women and girls in western New York with the virus that causes AIDS was prescribed antidepressant medication in prison and has told law enforcement officials that he is schizophrenic, officials said yesterday.

title: That Magical Isle of Talent, Extravagance and Doom
description: PLAYS WELL WITH OTHERS

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The virus has spread so fast in Kaliningrad that even the few people who

title: With Coffers Full of Cash, Leaders Fight for Control
description: New Jersey Democrats, who controlled the State Senate for nearly two decades, are waging a battle of words and money against their Republican opponents with the heady goal of regaining the power they lost six years ago.

title: Strong Stocks And Economy Hobble Bonds
description: The prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday as strong economic data raised concerns about inflation and as a strong rebound in stocks pulled money out of the bond market. The losses came despite increased confidence that the Federal Reserve would not raise short-term interest rates at next week's monetary policy meeting.

title: Market Place; A G.E. deal is good news for Lockheed stock, but why?
description: GENERAL ELECTRIC is cashing in its investment in Lockheed Martin with a big profit. For reasons that are not entirely clear, Wall Street seems to think that is good news for Lockheed Martin.

title: Indonesian Car Maker Shifts Personnel
description: PT Timor Putra Nasional, the Indonesian car company owned by the youngest son of President Suharto, has appointed executives from the rival PT Astra International to prominent positions in its assembly unit. The move comes amid speculation that Astra, Indonesia's largest car maker, will take over the national car project.

title: His Subjects Petition King Rudolph
description: UNLESS Ruth W. Messinger can pull off New York's greatest upset since Bobby Thomson cleaned the Dodgers' clock in 1951, today is shaping up less like Election Day than Coronation Day for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Then again, why not a coronation for a race whose liveliest, if least edifying, moment featured the incumbent doing his Henry IV imitation?

title: Nickles Used Office to Film G.O.P. Video
description: Senator Don Nickles, the Oklahoma Republican who criticized President Clinton's White House events for Democratic donors, filmed a promotional video in his Senate office for a company that matches Republican donors with Congressional races.

title: Patterns
description: The Woes of Chelsea Piers

title: Fear Fills the Schools; Sign-Language Hurdle
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computing error at Morningstar Inc., the mutual fund table in the Money and Business section on Sunday misstated weekly changes for Dean Witter stock mutual funds. The figures reflected changes from the close of Monday, Oct. 27, through Friday, thus disregarding the large drop in stock prices on Oct. 27. Readers wishing corrected copies of the list may write to Business Day, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1474.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOTKIN, RICHARD
description: PLOTKIN-Richard. On November 2, 1997. Beloved husband of Marisa, devoted son of Fredi Plotkin and Jack Plotkin, loving brother of Michael, and half brother of Elizabeth and James, dear nephew. Services Wednesday, November 5, 12 Noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Could Iraq Manage to Hit a U-2? Unlikely, but Possible
description: Iraq has the ability in theory to carry out its threat to shoot down United States U-2 spy planes flying over its territory, but its chances of actually doing so are slim, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Payroll Was Too High, Yankees' Owner Says
description: In subtle and strong ways yesterday, George Steinbrenner continued his crusade against offering Bernie Williams a $10 million-a-year contract by emphasizing that he does not want the Yankees to have the fattest payroll in major league baseball again next season and by criticizing the center fielder's agent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRY, MARY J.
description: BARRY-Mary J. of New York City and Cobh, Ireland on October 30, 1997. Died peacefully in Washington, D.C., at 90 years of age. Beloved wife of the late Michael. Loving mother of John, Sheila and Brenda, and devoted grandmother of nine. Interment in Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, New York, on November 5 at 3 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEBLES, MARTHA M. (NEE LARA)
description: FEBLES-Martha M. (nee Lara). Of Pearl River, N.Y., formerly of Manhattan. Loving mother of Martha Velez of Kew Gardens, N.Y., Norma Santiago of Las Vegas, NV., Rosemarie Moriarty of San Antonio, TX., Nellie Donnelly and Linda Lopez of Pearl River, N.Y., George of Yonkers and John Febles of Great Neck, N.Y. Also survived by 26 grandchildren, and 17 great-grandchildren. Mass of Christian Burial to be held Wed., 10AM, St. Margaret's RC Church, Pearl River, NY. Visiting Tuesday, 3-5 & 7-9PM at the Wyman-Fisher Funeral Home Inc., 100 Franklin Avenue, Pearl River, New York. Memorials to The Fox House, 111 East 117 Street, NY, NY 10035.

title: Acquisition by Pricellular
description: The Pricellular Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire a cellular networking license for a rural area of Tennessee for $73 million from Bachtel Liquidity L.P., an affiliate of Bachow & Associates. The area, close to Knoxville, has a population of about 264,000. Pricellular, a cellular phone network company, said the service would become part of its Kentucky operation, helping it expand into tourist areas like the Great Smoky Mountains National Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINN, JOSEPHINE
description: QUINN-Josephine. Of Hartsdale, N.Y. Dear aunt of Mary Lynn Faries, Eugene Grossman and James P. Quinn. Funeral mass Thursday, 10 AM at Sacred Heart R.C. Church, Hartsdale, NY. Interment at Rolling Green Memorial Park, Camphill, PA. Reposing at The Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, NY, Wednesday 2-5 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, HARRISON
description: ROTH-Harrison. On November 2, 1997. Devoted husband of Judith McKuown, cherished father of Jessica, beloved brother of Judie Tarpey. Services at ''The Riverside'', 76th and Amsterdam Avenue, on Tuesday at 1:30.

title: By Design; Fur, or Not Far From It
description: To update your winter wardrobe instantly, you might think about a fur-trimmed coat or jacket. It doesn't matter if the fur is fake; even an accessory will do the trick.

title: Talk Show Host Joins Cancer Fight
description: The General Motors Corporation is disclosing details of an agreement with Rosie O'Donnell for the talk show host to promote the company's ''Concept:Cure'' efforts to fight breast cancer.

title: Protesters Back Au Pair in 2 Towns Far Apart
description: Lawyers for Louise Woodward, the 19-year-old British au pair convicted of murdering the baby in her care, plan to ask the judge on Tuesday to set her free. But on the streets here and in Elton, England, Ms. Woodward's hometown, her outraged supporters were already making their case today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPPER, BERENICE S.
description: POPPER-Berenice S. Beloved wife of the late Milton, devoted mother of David and Adrienne, Susan and Larry Tolchin. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother of Josh and Lara, Jonathan, Jeffrey, Andrew and Zachary. ''The kindest and sweetest person you will ever know.'' Services Wednesday, 10 AM at ''Gutterman's, Inc,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Luxembourg Banker Arrested in Fraud Case
description: The chief executive of Kredietbank Luxembourgeoise S.A., Damien Wigny, has been arrested and is being held in a Brussels prison in connection with a fraud inquiry, court officials and the bank said yesterday. The bank said the arrest was made in a tax inquiry involving Rita Verstraeten, the heiress to the estate of Roger Gosset, a Belgian cigarette entrepreneur. Ms. Verstraeten is accused of evading taxes on the estate, which was valued at more than two billion Belgian francs ($55 million). Many of Luxembourg's neighbors, like Belgium, have said their citizens use the nation as a tax haven.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, MILDRED (NEE SALZBERG)
description: FRANK-Mildred (nee Salzberg). On November 3, 1997. Devoted wife of Abraham, loving sister of Harriet Sukoff Fogler and Calvin Salzberg. Graduate of Brooklyn College 1935. Religious services are on Wednesday at 11 A.M., from Gramercy Park Memorial Chapels, 152 2nd Avenue, NYC. Interment Beth David cemetery.

title: Chung Joins Walters and Sawyer at ABC
description: The network of Barbara Walters and Diane Sawyer has hired another of the most prominent female names in the news business. ABC News announced yesterday that Connie Chung had signed on as a correspondent and substitute anchor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASINETZ, ZEV, RABBI
description: KASINETZ-Zev, Rabbi. 95. One of the early organizers of Lubavitch in the United States. Later appointed by the Lubavitcher Rebbe to International Board of Agudas Chasidei Chabad-Lubavitch. Was interred Friday near Rebbe's Ohel. Husband of the late Ethel. Father of Moshe A. Kasinetz, Rabbi Suburban Torah Center, Livingston, New Jersey and wife of Sarah. Father of Devorah, wife of Rabbi Yehuda Krinsky. To all the above and his scores of grandchildren and great-grandchildren our heartfelt condolences. May the Almighty comfort you amongst all mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Lubavitch World Headquarters

title: TV Series With Ambiguities, Some Intentional
description: These are a few of the things viewers have come to know about Michael Hayes, television's newest crusading prosecutor: he puts family and loyalty first, but his pursuit of a corruption case forced his surrogate father to commit suicide; he hates legal loopholes, but he used one to introduce in court a man's dying confession to a priest; he believes the justice system protects the innocent, but when he pressured a good-hearted doctor to testify against an H.M.O., her career and marriage were destroyed.

title: Arts Abroad; Harrison Ford's Not in 'Titanic'? Well, No Matter!
description: Yes, ''Titanic,'' the $200 million love story-disaster film that Hollywood gossips have dined out on for the last three years, was making its world premiere here on Saturday.

title: Chess; Former Women's Champion Captures the Title Again
description: Esther Epstein, a women's international master of Newton, Mass., won the 1997 United States Women's Championship, which was held in Chandler, Ariz., from Aug. 23 to Sept. 1. Her 7 1/2-1 1/2 score surpassed that of last year's winner, Anjelina Belakovskaya of New York, who was runner-up with 7-2. Third place went to Anna Gulko of Fair Lawn, N.J., who tallied 6 1/2-2 1/2.

title: ARRIS PHARMACEUTICAL TO BUY SEQUANA FOR $166 MILLION
description: The Arris Pharmaceutical Corporation said yesterday that it would buy Sequana Therapeutics Inc. in a stock transaction worth about $166 million. Arris, based in South San Francisco, Calif., would issue 1.35 common shares for each Sequana share. The combined company would be named Axys Pharmaceuticals Inc. Sequana, based in La Jolla, Calif., is a genetic research company that has contracts to conduct research for major drug companies. It announced separately that it had formed an alliance with the Parke-Davis division of Warner-Lambert valued at $103 million to find new treatments for schizophrenia and manic depression and that it would modify an agreement with Glaxo Wellcome to discover genes associated with diabetes and obesity.

title: Riven Picks Up Where Best-Selling Myst Left Off
description: CONFESSION: I never finished Myst. I never even escaped from the game's main island. To my shame and embarrassment, I never reached the various ''ages'' created by the multitalented magician called Atrus, except once at the home of a teen-ager with lots of time on his hands.

title: Oakley Is Disgusted By What He Sees
description: Charles Oakley was grumbling, which adds considerably to his charm. It is only two games into the season, but if Oakley wasn't grumbling, you would hardly recognize him.

title: Man Once Seen as Gotti's Chosen Successor Receives a 10-Year Prison Term
description: He was in line to become the head of a powerful Mafia organization, the designated successor to the imprisoned John Gotti, law enforcement authorities said. But yesterday, Nicholas Corozzo, known in the underworld as Little Nick and the Little Guy, was in line only to receive more prison time.

title: October Auto Sales Weak Except for Newest Designs
description: People shopping for a new car last month were ready to plunk down money for the hottest new or redesigned models, leaving auto makers with lackluster sales for all but the freshest designs.

title: New Study Supports Effectiveness Of Little Used Chickenpox Vaccine
description: FOR years, parents and pediatricians eagerly awaited the approval of the chickenpox vaccine in the hope of preventing a highly contagious illness that is usually uncomfortable and occasionally life-threatening. But in the two years the vaccine has been on the market, many doctors have disregarded Federal recommendations that most children be immunized.

title: On My Mind; Bridge-Burning Time
description: Saddam Hussein has won a 3-in-1 victory, the biggest since he was allowed to live and rule after his defeat in the gulf war six years ago.

title: Prosecutor Urges Jury to Convict 2 in Trade Center Bombing
description: Speaking for nearly five hours, a prosecutor asked a Federal jury in Manhattan yesterday to convict two ''cold-blooded killers'' for what the Government said were their key roles in the bombing of the World Trade Center in 1993.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SANDRA KRASKIN, the director of the Sidney Mishkin Gallery at Baruch College of the City University of New York, had little idea what a treasure trove she would find when she began searching for art owned by alumni for an exhibit opening Friday.

title: Fidelity Reorganizes System Of Selling Mutual Funds
description: Fidelity Investments yesterday overhauled its system of selling mutual funds and discount brokerage services to retail customers and named as head of the new unit J. Gary Burkhead, who six months ago was removed from his position as the company's top investment executive.

title: Applied Materials In Patent Settlement
description: The Dutch semiconductor-equipment maker ASM International N.V. will pay Applied Materials Inc. of Santa Clara, Calif., $80 million plus royalties to settle a patent-infringement lawsuit, the companies said today.

title: Reversing Course, Hilton Raises Its Offer for ITT
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation raised its hostile bid for control of the ITT Corporation yesterday, reversing an earlier position that it would not offer more in the face of a bid by a new suitor favored by ITT.

title: BLACKSTONE GROUP BUYS A 65% STAKE IN CLARK USA
description: The Blackstone Group said yesterday that it had bought a 65 percent controlling stake in Clark USA Inc. from the Trizec Hahn Corporation for about $135 million. Clark is the sixth-largest independent oil refiner and marketer of petroleum products in the United States. It is the seventh-largest direct operator of gasoline and convenience stores in the United States, with 800 retail outlets in 10 Midwestern states. The St. Louis-based company's revenue exceeded $4 billion last year. The Occidental Petroleum Corporation and the Gulf Resources Corporation will retain their minority interests in Clark. Clark operates one Texas Gulf Coast refinery and two Illinois refineries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUN, LEV, PH.D.
description: BRAUN-Lev, Ph.D. Beloved husband of Micheline and dear uncle of Chaia Bekefi. Also survived by grand-nephew Ariel Bekefi and grand-niece Tamara Bekefi. Dr. Braun was a retired Professor of Political Science at Fairleigh-Dickinson University and prior to that, during W.W. II, he was a broadcaster for Radio Free Europe and the BBC. Funeral service Thursday, 1 PM, at the Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, West 72nd St, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SZYPULA, EDWARD
description: SZYPULA-Edward. November 2, 1997, at the age of 85 at home in Woodhaven, NY. Son of the late Adam Szypula and Ludwika (Wolosz) of Majdan Krolewski, Poland. Beloved husband of Stephanie (Tokach). Devoted father of Richard and father-in-law to Daniela. Loving grandfather of Michael and Paul. Funeral Mass 10:30AM November 5th at Saint Stanislaus R.C. Church.

title: Driven By Light, And Dark
description: It is said of Richard Pousette-Dart (1916-1992) that he was one of the best of the lesser-known Abstract Expressionists. To place him in that camp is somewhat misleading, however. He did paint abstract, imposingly physical and mythically charged pictures, but he was more a Symbolist than an Expressionist and his art was driven less by darkness and conflict than by light, harmony and spiritual optimism. This could produce painting of vacuous prettiness, but it led as well, especially in the later phase of his career, to works of powerful emblematic presence, as can be seen in a 33-painting retrospective opening today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: In His Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: Panel to Quiz Clinton's '96 Campaign Chief on Stock Gift
description: It began with billionaires from Asia and Chinese restaurateurs from Arkansas and moved to Buddhist nuns from California and American Indians from Oklahoma. Now, the dispute over campaign financing has shifted to a most unlikely person: a 13-year-old schoolboy, and the story of his $20,000 windfall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARCE, HENRY
description: PEARCE-Henry, 89 years young. Loving Husband of Sally; Adoring Father of Dr. David and Linda and Dr. Norton Rosensweig; Proud Grandfather of Jonathan and Laurie Rosensweig and Julie and Paul Schwartz. Founding partner of Pearce Mayer & Greer in 1928, devoted his career to Real Estate Philanthropy and his Family. Memorial services will be held at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Monday, November 3rd, at 11:15 A.M.

title: Fear Fills the Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: The Missing Leader, And Other Race Gaffes
description: In marathon coverage, the only thing worse than missing a runner's dramatic break for the lead late in the race is missing the finish.

title: The Doctor's World; Sex, Privacy And Tracking H.I.V. Infections
description: Public identification of a man who has apparently spread the AIDS virus among young women in upstate New York has thrown a harsh spotlight on one of the touchiest issues in the AIDS epidemic: whether and when doctors or health officials should tell sex and drug partners of infected people that they may be infected as well.

title: Steward Is Named To Head TV Guide
description: David H. Steward was named president and chief executive of TV Guide yesterday by the magazine's parent company, the News America Publishing Group unit of the News Corporation.

title: Infection to Keep Anet Out of $1 Million Mile
description: Might the luck that followed Bob Baffert last spring in the Triple Crown be abandoning him? With the Breeders' Cup just five days away, the silver-haired, silver-tongued trainer lost one of his main contenders today when he announced that his 3-year-old colt Anet had an infected foot and would bypass Saturday's $1 million Mile at Hollywood Park.

title: A Dancer Returns, Abstract And Storied
description: American Ballet Theater will look boldly to its founding goals when the company opens tonight for two weeks at City Center in a retrospective of works commissioned since 1944. That was the year a youngster named Jerome Robbins sent three happy-go-lucky sailors on shore leave dashing into ballet history in ''Fancy Free.'' Other landmark ballets were to follow, with Ballet Theater providing a creative home to choreographers ranging from Mr. Robbins, Agnes de Mille, Antony Tudor and George Balanchine to Twyla Tharp, Clark Tippet and Mark Morris, all of whom are represented in the City Center repertory.

title: Vladimir Sokoloff, 84, Pianist Who Accompanied the Famous
description: Vladimir Sokoloff, a pianist on the faculty of the Curtis Institute of Music who accompanied many of the world's leading singers and instrumentalists, died on Oct. 27 at Allegheny University Health Systems Hahnemann Hospital in Philadelphia after a long illness. He was 84 and lived in Philadelphia.

title: 'Cinderella' Attracts a Huge Audience
description: ABC created a television event on Sunday night with the new version of Rodgers and Hammerstein's musical ''Cinderella,'' posting the network's best ratings in 13 years for the two-hour time period.

title: Nanny Case Provides No Guidance for Parents; Archaic Penal Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Wal-Mart Pact Loses in Canada
description: Workers in Canada have rejected a contract offer that was the first negotiated with Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the world's largest retailer, and included pay increases and eliminated the forced daily performance of the company cheer.

title: Delivering The Rant, Rhythm And Rasta
description: Lee (Scratch) Perry had a lot on his mind on Friday night at Wetlands. During his two-and-a-half-hour set, Mr. Perry discoursed on Jah Rastafari and Jesus, Krishna and Moses, space aliens and marijuana, poverty and the International Monetary Fund, computers, supermarkets and sex.

title: FIRSTMERIT IN CASH AND STOCK DEAL FOR COBANCORP
description: The Firstmerit Corporation agreed to buy Cobancorp Inc. for $157 million in cash and stock, as the bank looks to build its business in Ohio. Under the agreement, Firstmerit will exchange 1.745 shares for each share of Cobancorp, for up to 70 percent of the outstanding shares. That's about $44.50 for each share of Cobancorp, which is based in Elyria, Ohio. The remaining shares, not to exceed 49 percent, will be exchanged for $44.50 in cash. Firstmerit, based in Akron, Ohio, is a $5.2 billion bank holding company. Its stock rose 12.5 cents, to $25.625, in Nasdaq trading. Cobancorp gained $2.25, to $42.50.

title: Integrated Health to Buy Some Healthsouth Assets
description: Integrated Health Services Inc. said yesterday that it would buy long-term-care assets from the Healthsouth Corporation for $1.15 billion in cash.

title: A Prescription To Keep P.& G. Growing Strong; Big Household Name Tries To Be a Drugstore Hit, Too
description: The Procter & Gamble Company is so obsessed with outdoing the competition that its executives have been known to peek into friends' closets to make sure they are not stocking rival brands of soap, dishwashing liquid and shampoo.

title: APPLE IS CUTTING THE NUMBER OF DOMESTIC DISTRIBUTORS
description: Apple Computer Inc. said yesterday that it was cutting the number of its domestic distributors from five to two as of Dec. 1 to more effectively manage the company's shrinking sales. Ingram Micro Inc. and Microage Inc. will be the remaining distributors of Macintosh computers in the United States. The Techdata Corporation, the Inacom Corporation and Merisel Inc. will sell Macs overseas. The move reflects insufficient sales by Apple to spread among five resellers. The company said in September that it was cutting to $2 million from $20 million the amount dealers must spend on Apple annually to buy computers directly from the company. Apple shares rose 34.375 cents, to $17.375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTLE, JOHN W., II
description: LITTLE-John W., II. The Board of Directors and the Staff of the South Hampton Nursing Home express deepest sympathy to their esteemed Board Member, Jean Remmel Little on the loss of her devoted husband, John W. Little, II. Barbara H. Lord, President Maureen O. Mahoney, Administrator

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEGEN, ABRAHAM
description: DEGEN-Abraham George, 66. Passed away peacefully in his sleep, on November 1, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Sandra, loving brother of Ralph Degen and the late Jerry Degen. Loving stepfather of Susan and Brett. Devoted son-in-law, brotherin-law, cousin, uncle and dear friend. President of Degen Fabrics and highly respected member of the textile industry and Garment Center Congregation. A kind and generous man who will be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his name to the Parkinson Foundation at the Columbia Presybterian Medical Center. Funeral will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Tuesday, November 4, 12:30 PM.

title: Sunday Circulation Decreases At Many Big City Newspapers
description: Newspaper publishers, who have been hoping that gains in Sunday circulation will help offset a long downward trend in weekday readership, may be disappointed at the circulation figures released yesterday, which show Sunday sales dropping at many of the biggest Sunday papers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERNON, ANNA (NEE CAHILL)
description: HERNON-Anna (nee Cahill). On November 1, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Loving mother of Ann Hernon-Mooney and Arlene Hernon. Dear sister of Elizabeth Cahill and Geraldine Serenson of Hudson, Florida. Cherished sisterin-aw of Florence Cahill. Loving grandmother of Christina Jensen. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard at 193 Street. Visiting hours Wednesday 2-5 and 7-10PM. Funeral mass Thursday, 9:45AM St. Kevin's R.C. Church. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Pakistani Defendant Pleads Not Guilty In Slayings at C.I.A.
description: The Pakistani immigrant accused of murdering two C.I.A. employees outside the agency's headquarters in Virginia in 1993 formally pleaded not guilty yesterday, and his court-appointed lawyers said he had a neurological disease that might have affected his judgment.

title: At a Western Outpost of Russia, AIDS Spreads 'Like a Forest Fire'
description: The young man sitting before the psychiatrist stared darkly at the wall and bit his lip to keep from crying. He had answered a dozen questions about his sexual habits and absorbed in silence a lecture about how AIDS would change his life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMBURG, HANS HENRY
description: HAMBURG-Hans Henry. Sunday, November 2, 1997, of Washington, D.C., formerly of New York. Loving husband of Eva S. Hamburg (nee Rawraway). Beloved father of Doris A. Hamburg and Steven P. Hamburg and their spouses Gerald Garfinkel and Sally Barker. Proud grandfather of Hemma Hamburg, Johanna Garfinkel, Rebecca Garfinkel and Sarah Garfinkel. Devoted brother of Gerhard Hamburg and Ilse Isbey. Interment and graveside services will be at 1 PM on Tuesday, November 4, 1997 at the Menorah Gardens section of Parklawn Memorial Park, 12800 Veirs Mill Road, Rockville, MD. The family will be sitting Shiva on November 4 through 6 at the Hamburg home in Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the National Parkinson Foundation, 1501 NW 9th Avenue/Bob Hope Road, Miami, FL. 33136 or the American Parkinson Disease Assocation, Inc., 1250 Hylan Boulevard, Staten Island, New York 10305.

title: Union Membership Drops Worldwide, U.N. Reports
description: Labor union membership has dropped in most industrial countries between 1985 and 1995, pushed down by the shift away from manufacturing and the loss of many unionized jobs, but unions have not lost their influence, especially in Europe, the International Labor Organization said yesterday in its annual report.

title: SEALY TO BE SOLD TO MANAGEMENT AND AN INVESTOR GROUP
description: The Sealy Corporation, the Cleveland-based mattress maker, said yesterday that the company would be sold by the end of the year to management and an investor group led by Bain Capital. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. The announcement comes 10 months after Sealy sold its Woodstuff Manufacturing unit to an investor group for $35 million. The company said selling the wood-furniture making unit would allow it to concentrate on making and selling mattresses. Boston-based Bain Capital has invested in more than 90 companies, including Brookstone Inc., Staples Inc. and GT Bicycles Inc. Sealy said bedding sales for the third quarter rose 29 percent, to $229.9 million.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DESKTOP DATA Inc. Burlington, Mass., agreed to acquire Individual Inc., a provider of personalized electronic news services, for about $84 million in stock. After the acquisition, the company will be called Newsedge Corp.

title: Adverse Diabetes Drug News Sends Warner-Lambert Down
description: The shares of the Warner-Lambert Company fell sharply yesterday after the Food and Drug Administration said that Rezulin, the company's promising new diabetes drug, might cause liver damage.

title: Bukhara Journal; In This Islam, Practices (Not Beliefs) Make Perfect
description: From a tree-shaded campus a few miles outside this ancient capital, one of the world's largest Muslim orders seeks to radiate tolerance and peace throughout the world.

title: Jordan Lifts Bulls In 2 OT's
description: Michael Jordan rescued the Chicago Bulls again last night. He hit a 3-pointer to force overtime, made a tying jumper in the first overtime and scored 3 of Chicago's final 4 points in the second extra period as the Bulls outlasted the visiting San Antonio Spurs, 87-83.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMES, KRICKER
description: JAMES-Kricker, founding member of Chain Lightning Theatre, on November 3. Funeral Rites on Thursday, 10:00 A.M., The Church of The Most Holy Redeemer, 173 East 3rd Street, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHMAN, ANNA
description: FLEISCHMAN - Anna. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Loving mother of Gloria Friedman and the late Marylin. Devoted sister of Shirley Wistreich. Cherished grandmother of Lisa and Mark Friedman. Services today, 1:30, at Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave. (corner of Ave. M)

title: When to Vote, and Where to Call With Questions
description: Today is Election Day, and there will be elections for governor in New Jersey, mayor in New York City and a host of other offices throughout those two states and in Connecticut.

title: Nanny Case Provides No Guidance for Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLOBERMAN, SOPHIE
description: GLOBERMAN-Sophie. November 2, 1997. Devoted wife of the late Abraham ''Vevvy''; adored mother of Barry and Alyce Harris; mother-in-law of Barry; cherished grandmother of Sean, Sari, Jonathan and Chad; friend of many. A special lady who will be missed by all who knew her. Services will be at 12Noon, November 4, 1997 at Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Boulevard, Flushing, Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IRAJ, IRAJ, MD
description: IRAJ-Iraj, MD. 1/23/36-11/4/96. A year has passed. My compassionate physician, treasured friend & advisor. Remembered always. Eternally missed. Joe

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBLINER, RABBI IMMANUEL
description: LUBLINER-Rabbi Immanuel. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. Ordained in 1960, he served the First Hebrew Congregation of Peekskill, NY and in 1964 assumed the pulpit of Greenburgh Hebrew Center in Dobbs Ferry, NY, becoming rabbi emeritus in 1977. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his widow, Sylvia, his sister, Henrietta Fassler, his brother Felix, and to his son, our colleague, Rabbi Jonathan Lubliner, and all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi David L. Lieber, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP, The Rabbinical Assembly

title: CHRONICLE
description: It seems to be something of a tradition in the family of ROBERT L. BERNSTEIN to crusade for human rights around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MISHKIN, JOSEPH
description: MISHKIN-Joseph. A remarkable example of the ''old old,'' Joe was until his life's end at 98, full of vitality and intelligence, a generous and truly heroic spirit. He will be lovingly remembered by Charlotte, his children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren.

title: Observer; Gold Plating Preserved
description: The gods are angry with Senator Fred Thompson. How else can we explain the arrival of a rich new batch of Nixon Watergate tapes at the very moment Thompson's own investigation of dirty political money is fizzling out?

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; On Ballots, How to Govern
description: Residents of at least 10 towns or counties can vote today to alter or even throw out their forms of government, or at least to begin the process. In Belleville, voters will decide whether to go back to five at-large members of a Board of Commissioners after seven years of a ward-based system. Bradley Beach voters may choose to have their mayor appointed from among five elected council members, instead of electing the mayor separately.

title: MTV Sues Fox Over Executive
description: Viacom Inc.'s MTV Networks is suing the News Corporation and its Fox Kids Worldwide unit, contending that they illegally hired Richard Cronin, senior vice president of MTV.

title: At Levi Strauss, A Big Cutback, With Largess
description: Levi Strauss announced a drastic cutback yesterday to eliminate a third of its American manufacturing jobs. But in an extraordinary gesture of largess, the jeans maker coupled the bad news with a generous severance package that included extended benefits and even cash rewards for employees who find other work.

title: Teacher's Aide Charged In Sex Abuse of Youth
description: A 30-year-old teacher's aide was arraigned in Suffolk County Criminal Court yesterday on a seven-count indictment charging him with sexually abusing a 14-year-old New Jersey boy he met on an America Online chat line.

title: MOVE UNDER WAY TO TRY TO BLOCK HEALTH CARE BILLS
description: Business and insurance lobbyists who helped kill President Clinton's health plan in 1994 are mobilizing a new campaign to block more modest proposals that would set Federal standards for the quality of care.

title: Indonesia Securities Firm Is Expected to Cut Jobs
description: PT Lippo Securities, one of Indonesia's biggest brokerage firms, will dismiss most of its foreign analysts, salesmen and traders to save money, according to people at the firm. Lippo earns revenue in rupiah and pays most foreign employees in dollars. The rupiah has lost almost a third of its value this year, inflating the dollar salaries of foreign workers. Some senior executives were making as much as $500,000.

title: 2 Sides of Bombing Suspect Are Depicted as Trial Opens
description: Terry L. Nichols worked ''side by side'' with Timothy J. McVeigh to prepare the bomb that destroyed the Oklahoma City Federal Building, prosecutors charged today as they opened their case against him before a Federal Court jury here.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies yesterday about a measure on today's ballot that would set up a $20 million state fund to provide loans for the demolition of abandoned buildings referred incorrectly to its scope. While the measure was sponsored by a State Senator from Newark and some money would be expected to be used there, funds would also be available to cities and rural areas throughout the state.

title: Science of Fetal Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFFIN, MARJORIE MARIE
description: GRIFFIN-Marjorie Marie. Of Short Hills, New Jersey, Friday, October 31, 1997. Sister of Martin T. Griffin of Short Hills. Funeral is to be announced later.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Mayor to Be Chosen Today
description: While most eyes will be on the gubernatorial race today, Paterson, the state's third largest city, will be choosing its chief executive. Martin G. Barnes, who was appointed interim mayor in January, is running against City Councilman Jose Torres to fill the unexpired term of former Mayor William J. Pascrell. Mr. Pascrell, a Democrat who was elected to the House of Representatives last year, is supporting Mr. Barnes, a Republican, in what is technically a nonpartisan race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANTELL, NATHAN
description: MANTELL-Nathan. Beloved husband of the late Frieda, loving father of Gerald and Walda Sue and Charles and Eileen, loving grandfather and great-grandfather. Dear brother of Esther, Sonia and Pearl. Former C.E.O. of Pandora Frocks. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. 11:30 A.M., Tuesday.

title: Confident, Playful, Giuliani Rolls On
description: From the Showplace Bowling Center on Staten Island's west shore to a Home Depot in Flushing, Queens, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wound up his campaign yesterday with a 48-hour bus tour that was part get-out-the-vote exhortation, part pure New York political theater and part pre-election celebration.

title: AIDS Surge Is Forecast for China, India and Eastern Europe
description: The World Bank said today that the AIDS epidemic is about to explode in China, India and eastern Europe and threw its political and financial weight behind needle exchange, condom distribution and other prevention programs.

title: Clinton Wins Support on His Trade Authority
description: After weeks of lobbying, President Clinton today virtually secured Senate renewal of the trade negotiating authority that he has called a centerpiece of his economic policy.

title: G.E. Unit Acquires 191 British Properties
description: MEPC P.L.C., Britain's third-largest property company, has sold 191 small British properties to the GE Capital Services unit of the General Electric Company of the United States for $:300 million ($501 million).

title: Princess and Her Ghosts
description: ''The Legend of a Princess Named Shokushi,'' created and performed by Masaki Iwana on Saturday night at the Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium at Japan Society, began and ended with a silence and stillness more profound than anything between.

title: Wealth of Mine Barons Turns to Dust at Source
description: Guggenheim Berlin, Guggenheim Bilbao, Guggenheim New York, Guggenheim Venice. Why not a Guggenheim Leadville?

title: Casino Ship Suspends Cruises, Saying 12-Mile Rule Has Hurt Business
description: A casino ship in Brooklyn that offered short offshore gambling cruises has suspended operations, putting an abrupt halt to a venture that the Giuliani administration had feared would lead to a flotilla of such ships in the waters around New York City.

title: Fluor Sees Plunge in Profits Of $100 Million for the Year
description: The Fluor Corporation said today that it expected profits for its new fiscal year to fall about $100 million, some 25 percent to 30 percent, below Wall Street estimates because of deteriorating business conditions, partly as a result of the financial turmoil in Asia.

title: Kagwe Slow to Find Best Distance for Him
description: The domination of distance running by Kenyan men has been dented in recent years by Ethiopians and Moroccans. But in the marathon, the Kenyans still rule.

title: Festival With a Boom And a Beat of Its Own
description: The Sonic Boom festival, which opened at the Miller Theater on Sunday afternoon, is to continue until Nov. 20, with a concert every two or three days, a good rhythm for programs of new music. Among the composers to be represented by recent works are Milton Babbitt, Mel Powell, Bernard Rands and Martin Bresnick; one whole concert, on Nov. 15, will be devoted to the music of the late Conlon Nancarrow; and another, two days earlier, will offer music-theater pieces by Karlheinz Stockhausen, Frederic Rzewski and Peter Maxwell Davies. The outlook is promising.

title: John Durniak, 68, Ex-Editor Of Photos at Times and Time
description: John Durniak, a former picture editor of The New York Times and of Time magazine, died yesterday at his home in Suffern, N.Y. He was 68.

title: Jury Tells Six Competitors to Pay Unocal
description: A Federal District Court jury here ruled today that six big oil companies must pay the Unocal Corporation at least $68 million for infringement of a patent on clean-burning gasoline that is sold in California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDIS, ANN
description: GORDIS-Ann. Born April 28, 1908. Died November 30, 1997 at her home in N.Y. Cherished mother of Elizabeth and Susan, wife of Philip, stepmother of Kent, sister of Lorraine Gruner. Burial private.

title: Trump Project Went On Despite Warning About Concrete
description: The company that provided concrete for Donald J. Trump's Riverside South project poured five batches of defective concrete in mid-August, officials said yesterday, even after a consulting engineer had determined that the material was not strong enough to bear the weight of a 46-story luxury condominium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIESS, EDNA
description: ZIESS-Edna. On November 3, 1997. Wife of the late Joseph. Mother of Fred and Alan Ziess. Grandmother to Jason. Mother-inlaw of Wendy. Services Wednesday 12:15PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, JACQUES J.
description: HESS-Jacques J. Beloved husband of the late Lee. Devoted father of Michael. Loving grandfather of Laurie and Geoffrey. Adored brother of Gertrude Parker and Frances Adlerblum. Funeral service 12:30 PM, Tuesday, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Diplomacy and Force on Iraq
description: Just when United Nations Security Council members like France, Russia and China were losing their zeal for ferreting out Iraq's secret biological and chemical weapons programs, Saddam Hussein has sparked new outrage by singling out American inspectors for special harassment. He no doubt hoped to widen divisions on the Security Council, but instead his brazen challenge to U.N. authority has, at least temporarily, reunified the Council against him.

title: Elections Today
description: NEW JERSEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, RICHARD C.
description: THOMPSON-Richard C. Of Whitehouse Station, New Jersey. On Saturday, November 1, 1997. Beloved husband of Ceil (Wilkinson) Thompson. Loving father of Janet Moran, of Monson, MA., and Tina Thompson, of Palisades Park, NJ. Dear brother of Norman, of Ann Arbor, MI., 3 stepchildren and 5 grandchildren. Memorial service Sunday, November 9, 1997, at 2PM, in the Wyckoff Reformed Church, Wyckoff, NJ. For information call Kearns Funeral Home, 908534-2422. In lieu of flowers, memorials to the Hope College Memorial Scholarship Fund, c/o Office of the President, Hope College, 141 East 12th Street, Holland, MI 49423.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSBORN, MILLICENT (GREEN)
description: OSBORN-Millicent (Green), at age 92, on November 1, 1997, peacefully at home, amongst her family, as she wished. She joins her adored husband of over fifty years, the late playwright, Paul Osborn. Born in Poland, 1905, emigrated USA as a child, and in her teens won a scholarship to the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, going on to be a featured actress both on Broadway and West End. After her marriage she wrote short fiction for numerous publications, among them The Saturday Evening Post and The New Yorker. Her glamour, her flair and her unique style remained, right to the end. She is survived by a brother, Jack Green of Palm Desert, California, a daughter, Judith Osborn MacGillivray, a granddaughter, Gabrielle Osborn Gidney, a son-inlaw, William Gidney, and five great grandchildren, Shannon, Chelsea, Keith, Satania and Daimon, all of NYC. The memorial gathering will be private. Condolences to the Osborn Family, at 1165 Park Avenue, New York City.

title: Opening The West, Banjos In Tow
description: The words are full of drama and action. ''Some of the places are so steep that some of our horses fell backwards and rolled 20 or 30 feet among the rocks,'' a soldier named John Ordway wrote of his trek across the Bitterroot Mountains with Lewis and Clark. Yet as Matthew Broderick reads those words, what we see on the television screen is a prettily filmed, bland image of a distant hill in what is now Idaho. No horses; no tension. There you have the essential problem with Ken Burns's lovingly made but wrongheaded film, ''Lewis and Clark: The Journey of the Corps of Discovery.'' The pictures are rarely equal to the subject. (The two-part program begins tonight on PBS.)

title: The Doctor Who Writes An Ultimate Prescription
description: During the 1990's, ''Dr. Death,'' a k a Jack Kevorkian, has ''assisted'' several score people to die via his ''suicide machine.'' Pardon the quotation marks, but everything about this pathologist's work sounds either like a prosecutor's brief or the defendant's publicity release. The sardonically titled ''Calling Dr. Kevorkian: A Date With Dr. Death,'' tonight on HBO, is in the main a justification for his mission from himself and his lawyer, Geoffrey Fieger, and from now-departed patients or victims or clients, depending on your point of view. But it also raises questions about diagnoses and techniques.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Official Won't Move Students
description: Atlantic City's Superintendent of Schools yesterday defied a state order to remove 500 fifth graders from a troubled middle school and return them to the elementary schools, The Associated Press reported. The Superintendent, Benjamin Williams, said in a letter to State Education Commissioner Leo F. Klagholz that student behavior at Albany Avenue School had improved, that fifth-grade teachers had signed a petition to stay, and that parents of fifth graders opposed the move, the A.P. reported. The district had until yesterday to respond to the state's order after the school, which has 1,800 students in grades five to eight, was the site of violence, including attacks on teachers, and arrests last month. Peter Peretzman, a spokesman for Mr. Klagholz, said the state was weighing its options on what to do next, the A.P. reported.

title: Sports of The Times; New Tactics In Olympic Logo Wars
description: THEY have done away with my favorite spectacle at the Olympics. I don't know how I can bear to cover the Winter Games in Nagano, Japan, in three months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE ROTHSCHILD, EDMOND
description: de ROTHSCHILD-Edmond. The Board of Directors and staff of the American Friends of the Israel Museum and of the Israel Museum, Jerusalem mourn the death of Baron Edmond de Rothschild, Founding Chairman of the Israel Museum's International Council. In addition to his enormous contributions to the Israel Museum, the Baron served for fifteen years as International Chairman, calling upon friends and associates to provide the funds to build a major museum for art and archeology in Jerusalem. We offer heartfelt condolences to his wife Baroness Nadine de Rothschild who succeeded him as Chairman and to their son Benjamin who continues the family tradition of leadership in business and in charity. Teddy Kollek, President, I.M. Dov Gottesman, Chairman, I.M. James Snyder, Anne and Jerome Fisher Dir, I.M. Maureen Cogan, Chairman, A.F.I.M. Judy Steinhardt President, A.F.I.M. Michele Cohn Tocci, Executive Director, A.F.I.M.

title: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE CAMPAIGNS -- The Politics of Peeping; 2 Guys Named Ed Spy, Politely, on Enemy Campaigns
description: One of the more unusual, if inevitable, creations of modern campaigning is the job of the tracker. Part intimidation, part political reconnaissance, the job entails showing up at an opponent's public appearances, usually with a video camera, to document any verbal blunders and carry information over enemy lines.

title: Turbid Tap Water May Be Source Of Unexplained Intestinal Ailments
description: A STUDY of tap water in Philadelphia from 1989 to 1993 has linked small increases in cloudiness to gastrointestinal infections that cause nausea, vomiting and diarrhea in children. Heightened turbidity can indicate microbial contamination, and even though turbidity levels in Philadelphia never exceeded Federal limits during the study, the researchers said their findings suggested that tap water might be the source of millions of cases of unexplained illness that people now attribute to food poisoning or unknown causes.

title: Science Watch; Churchgoing May Aid Health
description: REGULAR attendance at religious services does a lot for the soul, but now researchers at Duke University Medical Center say it may help the body as well.

title: Teardrop to Buy Golf Unit
description: The Teardrop Golf Company, a golf club maker, said today that it had agreed to acquire the Tommy Armour Golf Company from U.S. Industries for $24.5 million in stock and cash. Teardrop, based in Union, makes ''roll face'' putters and Spin Master brand wedges. Armour is a leading maker of drivers and irons. Under the agreement, Teardrop will pay about $10 million in cash and the rest in stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSLER, FRANCES E. (STEIN)
description: KESSLER-Frances E. (Stein), 54. Of Marlboro, New Jersey, on November 3, 1997. Wife of Kalman. Mother of Kimberly Ellen Kagan and Eric. Daughter of Blanche Stein and the late Aaron Herbert Stein. Sister of Barbara Moses. Service Wednesday at 12:00 in Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, Cranbury Rd. at Evergreen Blvd., East Brunswick, New Jersey.

title: Garciaparra Is Named Top Rookie in Landslide
description: As Ken Griffey Jr. stood talking to reporters in the hubbub of the American League's All-Star locker room last summer, a young man in a Boston Red Sox uniform with a shy smile reached through to shake Griffey's hand, stated his pleasure at meeting the game's premier center fielder and asked for an autograph.

title: Soybean Prices Rise Sharply As Exports Exceed Estimates
description: Soybean prices surged to a three-week high yesterday after a Government report showed stronger-than-expected sales to China and other large importers.

title: Real or Fake: Scientists Look at Art
description: IF Paul Revere had made all the silver cups and spoons attributed to him, he would not have had time for his famous midnight ride.

title: INSIDE
description: A City Council bill would allow ads on the hoods of taxicabs. PAGE B3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARETSKY, LENA
description: ZARETSKY-Lena. May our Machteiniste Irma Ehrenreich, her siblings and family be comforted upon the loss of this grand lady. Daniele and Jules

title: Q&A
description: Too Much Oxygen

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTMANN, BARBARA MOORE
description: MATTMANN - Barbara Moore. Daughter of the late Albert V. Moore, co-founder of Moore McCormack Lines. Passed away on November 1, 1997, after a prolonged illness. She is survived by her devoted husband Charles T.; beloved daughters Sandra Gros, Barbara Walkley, Wendy Read, Debbie Mattmann; and ten loving grandchildren. Service St. John's of Lattingtown, Thursday, 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to North Shore University Hospital at Glen Cove.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEPPER, JEFFREY
description: TEPPER-Jeffrey. The Officers, Board of Directors and Members of Engineers Country Club mourn the passing of their beloved member. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the Tepper Family.

title: Reshaping the Culture at Columbia/HCA
description: Marking his 100th day as chairman and chief executive of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, Dr. Thomas F. Frist Jr. today outlined changes that he said would fundamentally reshape the health care giant.

title: Mentally Ill Lose Out
description: To the Editor:

title: If Not Arafat, Who?
description: Two years ago today an enemy of peace murdered my father, Yitzhak Rabin. On this day of mourning, I grieve again, not only for a lost loved one, but also for a nation that has lost its way. Just last week, a fanatic burned down the Jerusalem offices of Dor Shalom, a grass-roots movement started by young Israelis on the night my father died.

title: Nanny Case Provides No Guidance for Parents; Society Fails Mothers
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a debate over what should be done with a possible budget surplus misattributed a quotation in response to Speaker Newt Gingrich's proposals at a House Budget Committee hearing. The speaker -- who called Mr. Gingrich's proposals ''a tall order, you will have to admit, for a surplus that has yet to materialize'' -- was Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the ranking Democrat on the committee, not Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is the committee's chairman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUNICK, CARL
description: TUNICK-Carl. October 31, at home. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother and uncle. Private burial. Please omit flowers

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MODUGNO, JOSEPH
description: MODUGNO-Joseph. Died November 4, 1996. One year has passed without you. You are always in our thoughts and in our hearts. Romola and Children

title: Metro Business Briefs; Garment-Maker Promotion
description: The thousands of small- and medium-sized clothing manufacturers in New York City are the focus of a new $1 million marketing program intended to promote the local fashion business, the program's sponsors are expected to announce today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAXWELL, GERTRUDE (NEE BERNSTEIN)
description: MAXWELL-Gertrude (nee Bernstein). Of Great Neck, New York, on November 1, 1997. Beloved wife of James, loving mother of David and Anne, and mother-in-law of Madeleine and Jon. Cherished grandmother of Justin, Stephen, Nicholas and Daniel. Dear sister of Martin Bernstein and Milton Benson. Service private.

title: A Point, But at A Price
