description: The ''golden point'' that United States Coach Steve Sampson said his team earned in its scoreless tie with Mexico on Sunday came with a price, one that may be very costly in Sunday's qualifying game against Canada in Burnaby, British Columbia, outside Vancouver.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Get What You Pay For
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW VENTURE TO INVEST $1 BILLION IN ENTERTAINMENT SITES
description: The New York investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. said it had formed a joint venture with the Simon DeBartolo Group to invest at least $1 billion in race tracks, movie theaters and other entertainment properties in the next 18 months. The partnership, called Simon/DLJ Entertainment Properties Inc. L.P., is in talks to buy projects in the United States, Europe and Asia. The venture will be financed by bank loans and equity stakes from the investment bank and Simon DeBartolo, a real estate investment trust based in Indianapolis.

title: Chefs and Shoes: A Bond Forged in Battle
description: TERRANCE BRENNAN, the chef and owner of Picholine on the Upper West Side, figures he has spent more than $500 and countless hours this fall in search of a perfect pair of work shoes.

title: Metro Business; Lawsuit Against Cityscape
description: A shareholder suit was filed against the Cityscape Financial Corporation of Elmsford, N.Y. for alleged misrepresentation of material information and stock-price manipulation.

title: U.S. Stock Indicators Up as Hong Kong Falls
description: Wall Street loosened its link to international equity markets yesterday, as stocks finished modestly higher despite another selloff in Hong Kong.

title: Argentina Breathes Easier as Crisis Eases in Brazil
description: Brazil appears to have weathered a chaotic move by speculators to devalue its currency, the real. And no one could be happier than its worried neighbor, Argentina, whose fortunes and those of other South American countries are closely linked to Brazil, the continent's largest economy.

title: The Taliban's War on Women
description: A woman comes into a Kabul hospital with burns over 80 percent of her body. An official of the Taliban, the fundamentalist group ruling most of Afghanistan, prohibits the doctor from undressing her. The doctor says she will die if he does not treat her. ''Many Taliban die on the battlefield,'' replies the official. The woman, untreated, dies.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUSS, BEN
description: RUSS-Ben 24th Yahrzeit. In my soul for all eternity. Marion

title: The Sound of Intense Concentration
description: The sold-out show that concluded Yo La Tengo's four-day run at the Westbeth Theater was open to all ages, but few in the crowd appeared to be under 21. The fans on Sunday afternoon were mostly aging underground rockers, exactly the folks who have watched this trio, based in Hoboken, N.J., mature over a decade of club engagements.

title: Pentagon's Promise?
description: To the Editor:

title: She Memorizes and He Improvises: Family Ties on 'Spin City'
description: When Tracy Pollan falls into the arms of Michael J. Fox on tonight's episode of the ABC sitcom ''Spin City,'' longtime television fans may smile at the sense of deja vu.

title: Four A's Forms Special Committee
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York has formed a Hispanic Advertising Committee dedicated to member agencies that specialize in campaigns aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers. Adolfo Aguilar Jr., 43, president and chief executive at Bromley Aguilar & Associates in San Antonio, was elected chairman of the committee.

title: Running and Gunning Back to the Garden
description: Nearly 10 years ago, Rick Pitino had a vision: he saw a world of sinewy 6-foot-8-inches athletes sprinting down court. They would pressure the ball and hoist 3-pointers until their shooting hands hurt. It would invalidate every grainy black-and-white book written by a curmudgeon coach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, JACQUES J.
description: HESS-Jacques J. The Members of the Board of Trustees of the Horace Mann School extend our heartfelt sympathy to Michael Hess, our Chairman, and his family, on the death of his adored father, Jacques Hess. Marjorie Silverman, Vice-Chairman William Aaron, Treasurer Franklin Speyer, Secretary

title: Herbert Coombs, 91, Economist And Australian Bank Governor
description: Herbert Cole Coombs, an economist who was governor of Australia's central bank for 20 years, advised seven Prime Ministers and was one of Australia's most influential public servants, died on Oct. 29 in a Sydney nursing home. He was 91.

description: NEWS

description: MICHAEL JORDAN was curious about the recent HBO documentary on Joe DiMaggio. ''I didn't know a lot about DiMaggio,'' said Jordan, ''and some people have compared me to DiMaggio. I wanted to see it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELLIN, MILTON R.
description: BELLIN-Milton R. Oct. 29. Beloved husband of the late Thorne Goldfaden Bellin. Renowned national artist and retired Asst. Principal of the High School of Art and Design. Brother of Blanche Goldin and the late Jack Bellin. Private memorial service New Haven, CT.

title: Rangers Confront Sakic And What-if Syndrome
description: It could be argued that center Joe Sakic of Colorado will be the best player on the ice Wednesday night when the Rangers play the Avalanche in the first of their two cross-conference matches this season.

title: Restaurants; Genuine French Bistro, Nearly Perfect
description: PAYARD Patisserie and Bistro has a problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPPENHEIM, KARL
description: PAPPENHEIM-Karl. Bar-Ilan University in Israel and its American Friends mourn the passing of a widely respected member of the Jewish community both in Israel and in Switzerland. Mr. Karl Pappenheim was the brother of Erica Jesselson and Lucy Lang. Mrs. Jesselson is an esteemed member of The Executive Committee of our American Board of Trustees. Mrs. Jesselson and her late husband, Ludwig Jesselson, the eminent philanthropist and longtime Chairman of our Global Board of Trustees assumed critical leadership in assuring the University's growth and impact on society in Israel and for the worldwide Jewish community. May the family draw solace from inspiring memories. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor Prof. Moshe Kaveh, President Selik Wengrowsky, Chairman Global Board of Trustees Jane Stern Lebell, President, American Friends Brig. Gen. (Res.) Yehuda Halevy, Executive Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, HARRISON
description: ROTH-Harrison. Harry was a dear friend for more than 30 years. I already miss his wit and wisdom. Sincere condolences to his daughter Jessica and family. Martin Askowitz

title: Hevesi and Green Are Re-elected; Fields Gets Borough Post
description: New York City's Public Advocate, Mark J. Green, and Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, coasted to re-election yesterday after conducting aggressive campaigns that were as much about cultivating support for future bids for higher office as they were about fending off little-known challengers.

title: Reviews/Fashion; Why Coy Can Sizzle Hotter Than Brazen
description: In Marc Jacobs's intensely coy show, Naomi Campbell, who could make sackcloth and ashes catch fire, looked oddly miscast. But she would have fit neatly into John Bartlett's arresting presentation a few hours earlier, where the gridlocked stairway was not the only fire hazard: staring the audience in the face was Mr. Bartlett's steamy evocation of breathless nights and unspeakable menace, of dangerously sexy film noir women.

title: An American in Paris, Moving Briskly About Town
description: PARIS IN THE 50'S

title: Toni Carabillo, 71, Author At Forefront of Feminist Cause
description: Toni Carabillo, a leader and historian of the modern feminist movement, died on Oct. 28 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 71.

title: NEWCOURT CREDIT IS IN TALKS TO ACQUIRE AT&T CAPITAL
description: Newcourt Credit Group Inc., a fast-growing company based in Toronto, said yesterday that it was in talks to buy the AT&T Capital Corporation in a deal that would create one of the world's leading equipment leasing and finance companies. Terms were not disclosed, but The Wall Street Journal said the price was expected to be $1.7 billion. Newcourt's stock jumped $2.50 a share, to $37.9375. AT&T Capital, which is based in Morristown, N.J., was shed by the AT&T Corporation in a management buyout last year for $2.2 billion. Nomura International P.L.C., a London unit of the Japanese securities firm, owns 98 percent of AT&T Capital, whose revenue was $1.95 billion last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCORDATO, FRANCES
description: SCORDATO-Frances. The Board of Directors and staff of United Cerebral Palsy of Queens express deepest sympathy to their Board member, Emil A. Scordato on the loss of his wife Frances. Jack Weinstein, Pres. Charlie Houston, Exec. Dir.

title: Iraq Extends Deadline for American Arms Inspectors to Leave
description: Iraq today extended its deadline for expelling American arms inspectors while a diplomatic delegation sent by Secretary General Kofi Annan tries to persuade the Iraqis to lift the expulsion order entirely.

title: A Book That's Still a Family Business
description: ETHAN BECKER has inherited the house that ''Joy'' built. It is a sprawling, Bauhaus-style home that his parents sited on the crest of a hill in northeast Cincinnati, surrounded by acres of orchards, wildflowers and gardens.

title: Auto Giants Expand In Asia Despite Crisis
description: Despite an economic crisis that has plagued Southeast Asia since the summer, American and Japanese makers remain largely undeterred in their expansion push in the region.

title: Salvadoran, Former Rebel, Is Deported
description: A former Salvadoran guerrilla commander who was resettled in the United States despite evidence that he once helped plan an attack in which six Americans were killed has been deported to El Salvador, immigration officials said yesterday.

title: In Messinger Camp, an Air of Subdued Resignation
description: As Ruth W. Messinger entered the Sheraton New York Hotel's New York Ballroom last night to deliver what might be her last speech as a politician, there was no aura of anticipation. The returns, showing a wide margin of victory for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, offered no hope. The mood was resigned, the crowd subdued. A deejay played Elton John's ''I'm Still Standing'' -- the Messinger campaign's theme song -- as she climbed onto a platform with family and Democratic elected officials gathering behind her.

title: Jiang's Awakening
description: President Jiang Zemin of China has come and gone, and Wei Jingsheng and Wang Dan are still in prison. There are still at least 3,000 other political prisoners in China. People are still being tortured in Tibet. Religious groups are still being persecuted.

title: Nets Have a Shot at Their Best Start: 3-0
description: It is probably too early to talk about a turnaround.

title: Senator Deals Serious Setback to Clinton Choice for Rights Job
description: The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Orrin G. Hatch, said today that he would vote against the nomination of Bill Lann Lee to be Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights, possibly dooming Mr. Lee's effort to become the first Asian-American to serve as the Government's top civil rights enforcer.

title: TV Notes; Tight Race for the News
description: The horse race between the network evening news programs keeps getting closer and closer as the ''CBS Evening News'' gains viewers and ABC's ''World News Tonight'' loses them.

title: Clinton Wins Senate Test On Trade-Negotiating Bill
description: President Clinton won a round in his drive to renew expanded trade negotiating authority when the Senate voted today to shut off stalling tactics by dissident Democrats.

title: Post-Plunge Layoffs Start in New, Lean Era : Grim Financial Reality Depresses Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  Empty stockbroker bars and polite real estate agents?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, ELINOR REMER
description: ROTH-Elinor Remer, on November 1, 1997. Survived by her husband, Charles, her son, Charles Peterson, her daughter-in-law, Maureen, and grandchildren, Maggie and Colin.

title: INSIDE
description: Another Russian diplomat gets into a clash with the police.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, JOHN
description: WASSERMAN-John. The Board of Governors and members of Sunningdale Country Club are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed member, John Wasserman. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Miriam and to the entire family. William Ettelson, President Michael Roth, Secretary

title: Auto Makers Report Weak October Sales
description: The Big Three American auto makers reported weak sales in October, giving the industry a slow start in the first month of the new model year.

title: FOOTBALL: A Dominant Force at Cornerback; Michigan's Woodson Gets Involved in Offense From Distant Spot
description: The routine was not what changed as Charles Woodson prepared for his junior year at the University of Michigan. Lacking the structure of the football season and the direction of spring practice, there is only so much to do; stadium steps, hills, up and down, hour after hour. The difference could be found in Woodson's intent.

title: Off the Menu
description: Serene and French

title: Facet of Immigration Law Is Argued
description: A constitutional challenge to a Federal immigration law governing the citizenship of foreign-born illegitimate children who have an American parent led to a spirited Supreme Court argument today, one that ranged over the respective natures of motherhood and fatherhood and led Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg to suggest with unusual directness that the Clinton Administration was endorsing sex discrimination.

title: For Incumbents in Cities, Celebrations Came Easily
description: A parade of incumbent mayors were swept back into city halls across the nation yesterday, capping a remarkably calm campaign season in cities that only a decade ago were bastions of political upheaval.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: After Intense Fight, Republicans Fend Off Challenges to Their Majority in State Senate
description: Despite hard-fought State Senate campaigns by Democrats across New Jersey, the Republicans retained control of the chamber tonight.

title: Field Trips Are Gaining Serious Tone
description: The field trip, once eagerly anticipated by teachers and students alike as a mindless day off at the local zoo or historical site, has evolved into serious work at many schools.

title: Woods Still Seeks Challenges
description: The PGA Tour's off season has begun, but Tiger Woods is staying busy. Woods travels to Japan this week for the first Tiger Woods Invitational, a Nike promotion that will also feature Mark O'Meara, Nick Price and Shigeki Maruyama. The three-day event, to be held at Musashigaoka Golf Club in Hannoshi, Japan, will have a pro-am on Friday, a $600,000 skins game Saturday and a competition on Sunday featuring the professionals playing with junior golfers from Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and Thailand.

title: The Chef
description: THE pear is a very modest fruit -- usually firm-textured with a gentle, understated sweetness. It's best either propped up with neutral flavors that yield to its subtlety, or framed by bold tastes that allow its purity to shine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, JOHN J.
description: ROBERTS-John J., 79, Bradenton, Florida, died November 1, 1997. Survived by his wife, Marjorie; sons, Jeffrey of Peterborough, NH and Steven of Loudonville, NY; a sister, Marian Lippett of Santa Anna, CA and 4 grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEROSE, MARK D.
description: DeROSE-Mark D., 43. Died peacefully at home on September 15, 1997 after a long and courageous struggle with lymphoma. Teacher, social worker, nurse, clinical systems analyst and avid cyclist who lived life to the fullest. Former Area Coordinator of Manhattan Special Olympics, Co-Chairperson of Cycling, Unity '94, on Advisory Committee of 5 Borough Bike Tour and Bicycle Tour Leader for American Youth Hostels. Survived by his parents William and Arlene; sister Lillian; brother Jeffery; half brother Michael Siglow and his lover, Eugene Malinowski. Cycling friends' memorial celebration on Sunday November 16 at 12 noon at Historical Park, Fort Lee, NJ. Memorial service on Thursday, November 20 at 12 noon at St Lukes/ Roosevelt Chapel, 1111 Amsterdam Ave. Entrance on 113 St.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about efforts to increase the capacity of Wall Street computers referred incorrectly to a problem on Oct. 28 with the Nasdaq trade reporting system. While Nasdaq stopped providing some stock price data that afternoon to users of the market's terminals, it continued to provide all the data to users of other terminals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELOWSKY, ANNA
description: ELOWSKY-Anna. Beloved wife of the late Aaron. Devoted mother of Lawrence and Joseph. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Services Wednesday 11:30AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Business Travel; United is testing a trade-off: Lowest fare requires flying with only one carry-on bag.
description: IN what many in the travel industry expect to become a standard on airplanes, United Airlines will soon begin an experiment in which passengers who pay the lowest fare will be limited to one carry-on bag a flight, instead of the usual two.

title: Food Stuff
description: Soup That's Like a Model T: Have Any Size You Want

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUNICK, CARL
description: TUNICK-Carl. October 31, at home. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother and uncle. Private burial. Please omit flowers

title: A Bacardi Account Goes to Burrell
description: Bacardi-Martini U.S.A. Inc. in Miami, which markets the Bacardi line of rums, has named Burrell Communications Group in Chicago as the first agency to handle consumer and trade advertising and promotions aimed at black consumers. Billings were not disclosed. Burrell, which will also handle event marketing and sponsorships, was awarded the account after a three-month review that also included three undisclosed agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DAVIDSON, JOSEPH
description: DAVIDSON-Joseph and Lillian Special memories today of Uncle Joe and Aunt Lil. Ever, Ellie and Family

title: Republican Wins U.S. House Seat Left by Molinari
description: In a race that escalated into a battle attracting national attention, Vito J. Fossella Jr., a 32-year-old City Councilman, was elected last night to the seat in Congress representing Staten Island. Mr. Fossella's victory capped a frenzied race in which the Republicans fought vigorously to retain the seat the party has held for 16 years, most recently by Susan Molinari.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERFEL, WILLIAM
description: WERFEL-William. Beloved husband of Betty. Loving father of Diane Blake, Monte, Lauren and Stephen Kolins. Devoted grandfather of Peggy and Philip Blake, Emily and Kate Kolins. Dear brother of Lillian Berger, Ann Lieberman, Moe Werfel and Ceil Gelman. ''Good night sweet prince.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: ERICH LEINSDORF rates an important footnote at the New York Philharmonic: he appeared with the orchestra 375 times, more than any other guest conductor in its 156-year history.

title: TV Notes; 'X-Files' vs. a Monster
description: If anyone had any doubts about the continuing appeal of Fox's ''X-Files'' -- and apparently NBC did -- Sunday night's new season premiere put them to rest: ''The X-Files'' scored its second-highest rating ever.

title: The Deciding Issues: Taxes and Insurance
description: In her annual speech to the Legislature in January, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman promised to pass legislation that would reduce the state's high auto insurance rates. And although her proposal to lower premiums was rejected by the State Legislature, it provided the fodder for what would become the most important issue in the Republican governor's re-election bid.

title: Weak Results For Oxford And Aetna
description: Two managed care companies, Oxford Health Plans and Aetna Inc., reported weak financial results for the third quarter yesterday, providing new signs of trouble in the industry, especially in the Northeast. Both companies had softened the blow by forecasting bad news ahead of yesterday's announcements, but for both, the results were worse than Wall Street analysts expected.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Economic Data Point to Future Growth
description: An index intended to forecast the economy rose again in September, pointing to further growth in the months ahead as the expansion heads toward its seventh year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, NAOMI
description: GREENFIELD-Naomi. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue mourns the death of the sister of our esteemed member, Alan Sohn, and extends to him and the bereaved family our heartfelt condolences.

title: Charles Jordon, Publisher, 52; Led Word Inc.
description: Charles Jordon, a leading publisher of Christian and inspirational literature, died on Thursday at Baylor University Medical Center in Dallas. He was 52 and lived in Irving, Tex.

title: Studies Show Overall Value In Air Bags, Despite Deaths
description: Even though air bags have killed dozens of children, old people and short people, they are still a benefit over all, according to a study published today by researchers at Harvard University who have found that that benefit is as large as that of common medical procedures that cost the same.

title: Bomb Defendant May Be Unpopular but Is Not Guilty, Lawyer Says
description: The lawyer for Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, the man accused of organizing the bombing of the World Trade Center in 1993, told a jury yesterday in Federal Court in Manhattan that although his client was ''an unpopular defendant,'' prosecutors had failed to prove his guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOODMAN, JULIUS
description: BOODMAN - Julius, of Long Beach, New York on November 3, 1997. Born December 25, 1908 in Brooklyn, New York. A retired retailer. Died of heart failure, after a long, honorable, productive and fruitful life. Survived by his wife Helen of 64 years, a son Richard, of New York City and Long Beach, New York, a son Barry of Stamford, Connecticut, and two grandsons, Ben and Charlie, of Boulder, Colorado. Services will be private at graveside. There will be no calling hours. Donations to any of the following charities in lieu of flowers would be appreciated: The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, The Southern Poverty Law Center, The Simon Wiesenthal Center, United Jewish Federation.

title: High Court Says Price Ceilings And Some 'Fixing' Are Allowed
description: In one of its most important antitrust decisions in years, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a manufacturer or supplier does not necessarily violate Federal antitrust law by placing a ceiling on the retail price a dealer can charge for its products.

title: U.S. IS BUYING MIG'S TO STOP IRAN DEAL
description: The United States announced a novel tack today in its years of efforts to stop advanced weapons from spreading to unfriendly countries: buying them first.

title: Fish Stock Demystified
description: THERE is a long-held belief in French cooking that fish stock must not be cooked for more than 20 to 40 minutes. As a young cook, I ignored this rule and cooked my fish stocks for long hours, just as I did other meat stocks. As I learned more, I persisted in what turned out to be a very satisfactory habit.

title: GIULIANI SWEEPS TO SECOND TERM AS MAYOR; WHITMAN HOLDS ON BY A RAZOR-THIN MARGIN
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman narrowly won re-election to a second term last night, beating back a surprisingly strong challege from a Democratic opponent who tapped into voters' anger over the high cost of automobile insurance and property taxes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORTELL, HARRY
description: CORTELL-Harry, 90, died on Friday, October 31, 1997. He was a designer of fine jewelry. He was predeceased by his wife, Gertrude Garr Cortell. He will be missed by family members Marc Cortell, Lindarose, Richard, Alison, and Daniel Berkley. A celebration of his life was observed privately.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NASHUA CORP., Nashua, N.H., an imaging products and mail-order film-processing company, said it would sell its specialty coated products and non-United States photofinishing units.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORRE, GABRIEL E.
description: TORRE-Gabriel E. Passed away November 2, 1997 in Salt Lake City at the age of 90. He was born May 11, 1907 to Joseph and Rose Vaccaro Torregrossa in Greenwich Village, New York City. At the time of his death he was married to Blanche B. Johnston. They had recently moved from New York City to Sandy, Utah. Gabriel E. Torre graduated from Fordham Law School and was a single practitioner for most of his career in New York City specializing in business and real estate law. During the 2nd World War he was Secretary to Kenneth Rocky, Chairman of the Renegotiation Board for the Navy. Upon his return to practice in New York, he lived in Montclair, New Jersey. He also raised and raced thoroughbred horses for several years. Upon the death of his first wife, Gladys Loring, he moved to New York City. He later married Dorothy Day Coughlin, deceased, and continued to practice and live in New York City. He is preceded in death by his mother and father, and also his only brother, Joseph Torre. He is survived by his wife, Blanche B. Johnston, a niece, Rosann Porcellini of Congers, New York and Lake Lucerne, New York, and a nephew, Joseph Torre of Long Island, New York. Funeral Services will be held Thursday, November 6, 1997 in Salt Lake City.

title: Voters Turn Back Affirmative Action Ban Much Like the One in California
description: In the first major referendum on the issue since California voters banned state-supported affirmative action last year, the electorate of the nation's fourth-largest city today turned back a measure that would have prohibited affirmative action in Houston's contracting and hiring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUOHY, THOMAS F., JR.
description: TUOHY-Thomas F., Jr., age 82, on November 1, 1997. Survived by his sisters Marian Tuohy and Helen T. Ives, his nephew John J. Tuohy and nieces Jane Tuohy Whelan and Anne Scriptunas. Funeral mass at Most Holy Trinity Church, 57 Buell Lane, East Hampton, Thursday 11AM with burial to follow at Most Holy Trinity Church Cemetery.

title: Hong Kong Raises Margin Minimums
description: Hong Kong raised margin requirements today for trading futures contracts on its benchmark stock index by 20 percent. It is the fourth time in three months that officials have moved to limit risks posed by stock market volatility.

title: Tanglewood Is Divided Over Moves By Ozawa
description: Gilbert Kalish's decision to resign as chairman of the faculty of the Tanglewood Music Center, the internationally esteemed summer training program for young musicians in Lenox, Mass., came after a year of turmoil on the job, and a month of soul-searching.

title: TV Notes; Happy Ending For 'Cinderella'
description: The huge success of ''Cinderella'' will mean more musicals for television, probably as early as next year.

title: Excerpts From Speech By Mayor on His Victory
description: Following are excerpts from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's victory speech last night, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Colorado Storm's Toll in Cattle Staggers Beleaguered Industry
description: On a treeless plain, midway between Wild Horse Creek and Deadman Ditch, a front-end loader appeared on the horizon today, laboring slowly as it dragged two dead cows and carried a third in the front scoop.

title: Mr. Postman: Bring Me a Sumptuous Turkey This Season
description: Correction Appended

title: Unable to Beat Rebels, Sri Lanka Eases Stance
description: When Maj. Gen. Lionel Balagalle of the Sri Lankan Army greeted visitors to his headquarters recently, he cut an unusual figure for a military commander faced by one of the world's most feared guerrilla groups.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Midas of the Gold (Yes, I Do Mean Gold) Cudgel
description: Bad timing? Or tasteless publicity stunt? Over the weekend, copies of Donald Trump's irresistibly scrappy new book ''The Art of the Comeback'' arrived in bookstores, while city officials slapped a stop-work order on Riverside South, the residential complex Mr. Trump is developing on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. A coincidence, surely, that the project contained defective concrete. Still, it's a measure of Mr. Trump's power to inspire lurid fantasies that one might fleetingly imagine otherwise. Did he order up a batch of bad concrete just to sell a book?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Supreme Court Allows Retail Price Ceilings

title: Harold Friedman, 74, Executive Of Union Convicted of Felony
description: Harold Friedman, a baker who rose to vice president of the teamsters' union and was convicted of labor racketeering, died on Wednesday at Meridia Hillcrest Hospital in Cleveland. He was 74 and lived in Pepper Pike, a suburb of Cleveland.

title: The Minimalist; Curry Blends, An Ancient Fast Food
description: IF you're a curry aficionado, you know that curry powder is a spice blend, containing a variety of spices like cumin, turmeric, coriander, cardamom, ginger, fenugreek and black pepper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, RAYMOND
description: MARKS-Raymond. On November 3, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Ethel Marks. Loving son of the late Jacob and Jennifer Marks. Kind and generous uncle and great uncle. Services Friday November 7, 10:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERTIG, HILDA L.
description: FERTIG-Hilda L. Beloved wife of Felix. Loving mother of Ann Freedman and Mack Fertig. Devoted sister of Barbara Newmark. Cherished mother-in-law of Lisa Fertig and Robert Freedman. Adored grandmother of Jessica Freedman and Sara, Eric and Amy Fertig. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Gladney Center, 2300 Hemphill, Ft Worth, TX 76110. Funeral services Friday, 12:00 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 333 Amsterdam Ave (bet 75th and 76th St).

title: Indonesia Bank Closing Draws a Protest
description: Bambang Trihatmodjo, the second son of President Suharto of Indonesia, went on the offensive today against the Minister of Finance, Marie Muhammad, for signing an order to shut down his bank, PT Bank Andromeda, late last week.

title: The Process Was Slower But Surer, an Official Says
description: Board of Elections officials said the counting of votes in yesterday's citywide election was slowed somewhat because they intensified their efforts to count accurately after the problems encountered in September's primary election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARCE, HENRY
description: PEARCE-Henry. The Board and staff of the Joint Passover Association offer heartfelt condolences to the family of Henry Pearce and most especially to his wife, Sally, who has been for many years a devoted and tireless supporter of our efforts on behalf of needy Jewish families at Passover. Michael Stoler, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPPER, NATALIE
description: KOPPER-Natalie. Beloved wife of the late Bertram Feldstein and Edward A. Kopper. Loving mother of Carole and Elayne. Cherished grandmother of Helene and Barry. Great grandmother of Lauren, Ari and Jason. Our woman of valor. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. 11:30AM Wednesday.

title: Her Lawyers Ask Freedom For Au Pair
description: Lawyers for Louise Woodward, the 19-year-old British au pair sentenced to life in prison for murdering the baby in her care, placed her fate directly in the hands of her trial judge today, imploring him to overturn her jury conviction because ''logic and science'' were on her side.

title: CHRYSLER TO BEGIN ITS $2 BILLION BUYBACK PLAN FOR 1998
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it had completed its $2 billion stock buyback program for 1997 and would begin buying back $2 billion more. Chrysler, the nation's No. 3 auto maker, said the recent volatility in the stock market had allowed it to complete its 1997 buyback in October and begin the new program for 1998. Companies use buybacks to increase earnings per share by reducing the number of outstanding shares. Chrysler had 679.2 million shares as of Sept. 30, which means that the new buyback program covers about 8 percent of its outstanding stock. Its shares closed yesterday at $35.8125, down 56.25 cents.

title: Auto Giants Build a Glut of Asian Plants, Just as Demand Falls
description: Shoppers have deserted car dealerships across Southeast Asia since the region's currency crisis began last summer, while investors who have lost fortunes in plummeting stock markets have flooded the used-car market with late-model luxury cars.

title: U.S. Business Squanders Its Leverage on China
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOEN, JOSEPH
description: SCHOEN-Joseph. On Monday, November 3. Formerly of Manhattan. Husband of the late Henrietta (Goldstein). Father of Billie Brenner of Boston, MA. Grandfather of Robin Brenner and Russell deLucia, Jamie and Rodney Gutner, Lisa Brenner and great grandfather of Tristan and Cassidy Gutner. Brother of Murray Schoen and the late Gertrude Ashkin. Services at The Levine Chapel, Brookline, MA on Thursday, November 6 at 1:00pm. Memorial observance through Friday at the home of Billie Brenner. Remembrances may be made to Pine Street Inn, 434 Harrison Ave, Boston, MA 02118.

title: First Down, Many Goals to Go
description: Eddie George was a senior tailback at Fork Union Military Academy in Virginia when it was time for star players to choose their colleges. To continue their track toward greatness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, CAROL BENEDICT
description: HALL-Carol Benedict, of Mantoloking, NJ and Vero Beach, FL died at 75 in Boulder, CO on November 1. Rodney Dennis Hall, Jr, her husband of 39 years, died in 1982. She is survived by two daughters Louise Allen Grauer and Judith Hall Dominguez; four grandchildren, and a sister Anne B. Swain. Services will be held at 11 AM on November 8 in St. Simon-By-the-Sea, Mantoloking, NJ. Contributions in her memory can be made to Hospice of Boulder County, 2825 Marine Street, Boulder, CO 80303; Kent Place School, 42 Norwood Ave, Summit, NJ 07902, and Vassar College, Box 159, Poughkeepsie, NY 12604.

title: A Triumphant Giuliani Promises More Unity
description: To the theme of ''Rocky,'' Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani strode triumphantly into the New York Hilton's grand ballroom last night and onto a stage filled with some of the Republicans, Democrats and union leaders that he had assembled for his decisive victory.

title: Finding Saints on the Space Shuttle
description: Astronauts have always been natural candidates for medals, but how about for beatification? In ''Defying Gravity,'' Jane Anderson's clever and uplifting fantasy play about space travel, spirituality and the Challenger disaster, the heavens are viewed as a vast house of worship and the people who blast off into them as pilgrims in search of a new religious order among the stars.

title: ONE BUYER REMAINS FOR BZW UNITS OF BARCLAYS
description: Barclays P.L.C. is in exclusive talks with Credit Suisse First Boston to sell part of its BZW investment bank, both banks said yesterday. The banks also said the BZW businesses in the Asia-Pacific region and the equity derivatives business were not part of the talks. Barclays said it would seek to sell those businesses to someone else. The two banks are trying to negotiate a deal for Credit Suisse First Boston to buy BZW's British and continental European equities, equity capital markets and mergers and acquisition advisory businesses. Barclays has been trying to sell most of BZW for about a month, and an initial group of about 20 bidders was whittled to one late last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWITZ, RICHARD
description: LEWITZ-Richard, on November 3. Beloved husband of Nancy Lipshitz. Devoted son of Belle Lewitz. Caring brother of Charles Lewitz and Karen Lewitz. Loving uncle of Andrew Schall and Daniel Lewitz. Son-in-law of Harold and Pearl Lipshitz. Brother-in-law of Jay Schall, Marsha Lipshitz, Shel Young and Kathy Raymond. A truly good person who will be missed by all who knew him.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: A sign of the times:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''To have this kind of aircraft with a nuclear capability of deploying a weapon of mass destruction -- it seems to me it's in our overall interest to see to it that it doesn't fall into their hands.''

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Oct. 27 about that night's ''Nova'' program titled ''The Proof'' referred imprecisely to what was being proved. It was Fermat's last theorem, not the Pythagorean theorem. Fermat's last theorem states that the equation xn + yn = zn has no solution when x, y and z are positive whole numbers and n is a whole number greater than 2. When n equals 2, the equation has many solutions and is known as the Pythagorean theorem: in a right-angle triangle, the square of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides.

title: First, Don't Compete
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLESSER, JOSEPH W.
description: PLESSER-Joseph W. 92, on Nov. 3, 1997. Wife of Eunice. Father of Lori, Ronald and Andrew and grandfather to Benjamin, Rebecca, Jeremy and Michelle. Memorial service on Sun, Nov. 9 at 3 P.M, Temple Emanuel, Great Neck, NY

title: Canucks Fire Quinn, Then Lose
description: CAPITALS 2, CANUCKS 1

title: Market Place; ITT and Hilton finally meet. Will Starwood offer more cash?
description: IT took more than 10 months to happen, but yesterday representatives from the ITT Corporation finally sat down with people from the Hilton Hotels Corporation to sign a cooperation agreement and exchange information.

title: Streaking Devils Lose Power Suddenly
description: After producing 16 goals in the previous 3 games with a good deal of help from their power play, the Devils fired blanks tonight. They had 36 shots on goal and 6 manpower advantages, but came up empty in a 3-0 loss to the Los Angeles Kings at Continental Arena.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Plaza May Brighten Up Stately Edwardian Room
description: For much of the last 90 years, the baronial, clublike Edwardian Room at the Plaza Hotel has been a stately reminder of the era when top hat, white tie and tails were evening de rigueur. Restaurant critics, dubbing it the hotel's showcase dining room, would praise its ornately painted, cathedral-height dark oak ceilings, wainscoted wood walls, towering windows, quiet atmosphere, soft lighting, huge painted chandeliers and superb view of Central Park.

title: Eating Well; How Buttermilk, Once So Souring, Turned Sweet
description: MY first encounter with buttermilk, somewhere between age 3 and 4, was a mistake. I was expecting ordinary whole milk in my blue Shirley Temple glass but got buttermilk instead -- and it never touched my lips again. That is, until about 15 years ago, when, as an adult whose tastes had broadened somewhat, I used it in a plum sherbet recipe with extremely satisfying results.

title: Medicine Rooted in Old Tibet
description: If this gentle, optimistic film about the wonders of Tibetan medicine, becomes popular, it could drive hordes of the terminally ill to seek the painstakingly concocted herbal remedies for which the physicians and researchers interviewed in the movie make dramatic claims. How valid those assertions are, of course, is anybody's guess. But if what the ''The Knowledge of Healing'' says about the effectiveness of these cures is true, the Tibetan system, which dates from the 12th century, deserves serious consideration as a supplement to Western medical technology.

title: Russians Are Springing Up All Over; Few medium and large American ballet troupes lack emigres.
description: Ellen Tharp wanted to start a ballet company on Staten Island. But where to find dancers? A Russian cabdriver who had been an engineer at home gave her an idea. Why not advertise in Novoye Russkoye Slovo, the Russian-language newspaper, and on Russian cable television? The response was overwhelming.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIEDEL, IVAN
description: FIEDEL-Ivan. Co-Founder of the Fiedel School on Long Island. Died on November 2 in Santa Barbara, CA. after a long illness. He is surived by his beloved wife Rosalind, his children Gina (and Douglas) and Brad (and Ann), a brother Barry and his wife Kathy, two grandchildren, Alixandra and Zoe.

title: French Truckers' Strike Snarls Freight Traffic Across Europe
description: November, time for the annual French transport strike, and truckers blocked highways across the country for the second straight day today, disrupting freight shipments across Europe just as they did in a 12-day strike at about the same time last year.

title: 2 Energy Concerns Name Agencies
description: Two new energy enterprises have named agencies.

title: $2.4 Billion in Borrowing For Schools Is Rejected
description: Evidently showing more concern about the state's deep debt than the condition of its aging schools, New Yorkers tonight rejected a measure that would have allowed the state to issue $2.4 billion worth of bonds to pay for school construction projects.

title: GIULIANI SWEEPS TO SECOND TERM AS MAYOR; WHITMAN HOLDS ON BY A RAZOR-THIN MARGIN
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani last night became the second Republican in 60 years to be elected to a second term as Mayor of New York City, defeating Ruth W. Messinger, a fixture of Manhattan's Upper West Side, as he continued to redefine the rules of partisan politics in New York municipal elections.

title: Woman in the News: Christine Todd Whitman; Just in Time, a Listener
description: As the youngest of four children growing up among the landed gentry in New Jersey's hunt country, Christine Temple Todd would hide under the kitchen table and wait for her older siblings and their friends to sit down. Then she would bite them. ''Yes, she did that sometimes,'' her sister, Kate Beach, recently recalled.

title: Essay; Reading Saddam's Mind
description: Listen to them all: ''Foolish Saddam -- just when France and Russia and China show signs of splitting from the U.S. on the sanctions against Iraq, the Iraqi unites them with his demand that the U.N. inspection team not include Americans.''

title: Green and Hevesi Win Easily
description: Public Advocate Mark J. Green and City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi coasted to re-election over little-known rivals, while C. Virginia Fields was elected Manhattan Borough President. Page B4.

title: Charge Against Investigator Muddles Apartheid Inquiry
description: It was a dramatic moment. A frail-looking gardener waded into the audience during his testimony before the Truth and Reconciliation Commission last week looking for the getaway driver for a terrorist attack four years ago that killed four people. Then he pointed out the Commission's own head of investigations, Dumisa Ntsebeza.

title: Children Minding Children
description: Total dependence on adults renders children completely vulnerable to adults. And as many parents know, taking care of babies and toddlers all day alone can be high-stress business. So why do we expect an untrained teen-age girl to be able to manage an infant -- just because we call her an au pair?

title: Gulf War Alliance: 6 Years Later, Seams Fray
description: The simple act of sending a United Nations delegation to meet with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq over arms inspections reflects a fact that troubles American officials: the gulf war coalition is fraying after more than six years of sanctions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, ROBERT
description: WILLIAMS-Robert. Temple Sinai of Bergen County mourns the passing of its member, Robert Williams. Beloved husband of Dr. Lee Gardner and devoted father of Brent Williams and Allison Williams Mangot and step-father of Andrew Gardner, Julie Anne Gardner and Nancy Gardner. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Bruce S. Block, Rabbi Richard Simon, President

title: Rolen Named Top N.L. Rookie
description: Scott Rolen won the National League rookie of the year award yesterday, and he doesn't play for the Los Angeles Dodgers. Rolen is the third baseman for the Philadelphia Phillies, so he broke the Dodgers' streak of five consecutive rookies of the year.

title: The Value of Pulsipher Continues to Go Down
description: With every walk, with every wild pitch, the stock of left-hander Bill Pulsipher continues to fall. In the immediate future, that may be a good thing for the Mets, as they decide which players to protect from the Nov. 18 expansion draft, and which to leave exposed.

title: Only the Yanks May Stand Between Mets and Martinez
description: The Mets and the Yankees engaged in a protracted tug-of-war over Hideki Irabu last spring, and they might bid against each other again if the market for Montreal pitcher Pedro Martinez shrivels.

title: I.M.F. Seeks Thai Decision on Lenders
description: The International Monetary Fund wants the Thai Government to move faster on deciding the future of 58 finance companies that have been shut since June because of insolvency, the central bank governor said today.

title: Reichel, Counted Out, Is Once Again Scoring
description: Robert Reichel's time as an elite center in the National Hockey League was thought to be finished. But since joining the Islanders, he has proved that any such write-off was premature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEGEN, ABRAHAM GEORGE
description: DEGEN-Abraham George. We mourn the loss of our dear friend. He was everything a friend could ever be. Devoted and loving, he stood by his friends and helped them through the ups and downs of life. His words and sage advice will never die, nor will the results of his many acts of kindness. We will miss him so and love him forever. Sandy and Leon B. Rosenblatt

title: Stony Brook President Is Considering Texas Post
description: Shirley Strum Kenny, the president of the State University of New York at Stony Brook since 1994, informed colleagues this week that she was among five finalists for the presidency of the University of Texas at Austin, her alma mater.

title: An Aperitif With Sex Appeal: The Secret's in the Pomegranates
description: TALL, slender, cool and effervescent, the Picholine aperitif is a sexy drink. And a pure one.

title: Marriage Isn't Answer to Family Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecutor Says Slain 10-Year-Old Was Sexually Assaulted
description: A 10-year-old girl found dead Monday night about a half-mile from her home here had been severely beaten in the head, stabbed and slashed repeatedly and sexually assaulted, the authorities said today.

title: In Era of Good Feeling, Messinger Was Up Against an Unbeatable Opponent
description: By the time Ruth W. Messinger delivered the concession speech last night that had seemed a foregone conclusion for so long, one fact seemed hard to refute: This was a race that, in all probability, no Democrat could have won.

title: Oregon Stays With Its Law On Suicides
description: Oregon voters refused yesterday to repeal the country's only law allowing doctor-assisted suicide, first passed three years ago but never put into effect because of a series of legal and political challenges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE ROTHSCHILD, EDMOND
description: de ROTHSCHILD-Edmond. The leadership and staff of Israel Bonds mourn the death of Baron Edmond de Rothschild, a longtime and generous supporter of Israel's economic development. His warmth, leadership and great contributions to Israel and the world Jewish community will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Baroness Nadine de Rothschild, and their son Benjamin. Sam Rothberg, Julian Venezky Founders of Israel Bonds Gideon Patt President Burton P. Resnick National Campaign Chairman William Belzberg Chairman of the Board Susan Weikers-Volchok International Campaign Chairman Michael Siegal North American Campaign Chairman

title: Netanyahu Enmeshed In Fiasco, Panels Told
description: A pair of committees looking into Israel's bungled attempt to assassinate a leader of the militant Islamic group Hamas six weeks ago have heard testimony that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu played a direct role in selecting the target, according to reports in the Israeli news media.

title: Carr, Nehemiah Trot Into Hall
description: Henry Carr and Renaldo Nehemiah were world recordholders in the days when track and field was an amateur sport with no prize money. Both gave up track for short careers in pro football, and neither thinks he achieved what he might have in track.

title: Furniture Plant to Close
description: Bassett Furniture Industries said today that it would close its Booneville, Miss., plant in January, eliminating 300 jobs. The furniture maker, which is based in Bassett, said the Booneville plant had operated at a slight loss in 1997. The closing is part of the company's effort to improve manufacturing efficiency. Also, Bassett said it was moving its motion upholstery production to its complex in Dumas, Ark., which should result in the addition of 50 jobs there.

title: The Race for New Jersey Governor
South Bronx Suburbia
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERJANIAN, BARBARA L., R.N., C.S.W. (NEE RULON)
description: MERJANIAN-Barbara L., R.N., C.S.W. (nee Rulon). Devoted wife of Stephen. Survived by her nieces Linda Busch, Sandra Hickson, and nephew Gilbert Rulon, and five great-nephews and one great niece. Reposing at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28 St., NYC. Service at St. Vartan Armenian Cathedral, 2nd Avenue at 34th St., Friday 10am. In lieu of flowers contributions to Fordham University G.S.S.S.A., appreciated.

title: Microsoft Seems Near Deal to Invest in U S West Cable TV
description: The Microsoft Corporation is close to an agreement to invest up to $1 billion in the cable television operations of U S West, according to several people involved in the negotiations.

title: Republican Health-Care Mistakes
description: The Republicans are pushing hard on health-care reform, but in the wrong direction. Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, is mobilizing corporate lobbyists against Congressional efforts to pass consumer protections. His argument is that we do not need more costly regulation. Meanwhile, Senator Jon Kyl is fighting for a bill that would allow Medicare patients to pay doctors more than Government-set rates. That might appear to expand individual freedom, but what it would really do is encourage fraud, cause administrative havoc and create a two-tiered health system, one for the rich and one for everyone else.

title: Earth Lonely for Word From Mars Craft
description: In the end, mission officials could not quite bring themselves to say it was all over for Mars Pathfinder.

title: Knicks Surge; Pitino Stumbles; Oakley Smiles
description: The seat was still warm for Charles Oakley last night. It was the same spot on the bench where he had been planted down the stretch of the fourth quarters of the last two games.

title: Parcells Pondering Quarterback Choice
description: For Bill Parcells, the delay in naming his starting quarterback this week is in contrast to the way he has whipped his team into a contender by being decisive and by flooding their brains with his ''my way'' philosophy.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about allegations that the Energy Department manipulated figures on minority contracting referred incorrectly to a spokeswoman who responded. She was Brooke Anderson, director of the Office of Public Affairs at the department -- not the spokeswoman for Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary quoted elsewhere in the article.

title: U.S. Business Squanders Its Leverage on China; Misleading Military Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Use of Troops to End Truck Strike, as in '92, Is Ruled Out : Jospin Not Looking for a Fight
description: PARIS  Unlike 1992, when another Socialist-led government sent in troops to break up a strike by truck drivers, the current French administration has ruled out the use of force to end the blockade of the country's highways, officials said Tuesday.

title: It Was a Dark and Gloomy Goth
description: Robert Smith insists that he is not a goth. It's true that the macabre goth subculture, to which his band, the Cure, is tied, does not reflect Mr. Smith's own style, which since the early 80's has been as colorful as goth is gloomy. But there's no mistaking the pouty auteur as the model for prevailing goth stereotypes.

title: Franchise for Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Books; Getting Spooked By King's Tactic
description: The buzz in book publishing continues to be about Stephen King. Not because he's asking for $17 million-plus per book. Basketball players and movie actors regularly demand such sums, so why shouldn't a writer? No, the talk is about the much-criticized negotiating strategy the novelist and his agent embarked upon. Like that of a ballplayer or actor. In public.

title: Gulf War Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Microsoft Cable Deal Seen

title: Tale of the Cat Added To the Cup Injury List
description: The casualty list for the Breeders' Cup grew even longer today when Tale of the Cat, the speedy sprinter from New Jersey, was declared by his trainer ''not 100 percent'' and likely to be withdrawn. And several hours later, the Classic, the main event of Saturday's championship program, lost another candidate when Down the Aisle was withdrawn with a fractured coffin bone in his left front leg.

title: Menu at G.O.P. Feast: Soft Money for Appetizer and Dessert
description: The two chief opponents of efforts to overhaul campaign finance laws in the Senate, Trent Lott and Mitch McConnell, will preside over what is expected to be the most lucrative Senate fund-raising dinner ever. The goal of the event on Wednesday, sponsored by the National Republican Senatorial Committee, is to raise at least $6 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, JACK
description: GILBERT-Jack. Beloved husband of Lillian, devoted father of Barbara Gilbert Stein, Larry and Barbara Gilbert, devoted brother of Milton and Harold, adored grandfather of Jacqueline, Danielle, David, and Alyssa. Services Wednesday 10 A.M. at The Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opp LIRR. For information call The Riverside at 516-487-9600.

title: Pro-Nazi Incidents in German Army Raise Alarm
description: Just a few months ago, Germany's army finally seemed to be shaking off some of its ghosts.

title: The Races for . . .
description: Winner

title: AT&T Will Simplify Its Pricing Structure
description: The AT&T Corporation, the leading long-distance telephone company, said yesterday that it would sharply simplify its pricing, making it easier for millions of residential users to figure out the price of a long-distance call.

title: Rift in WTA Board Costly for Director
description: The abrupt overhaul of the WTA Players Association board has not only created a schism between the top 10 players and their less heralded peers but deprived Sara Fornaciari, the executive director of the association, of her vote on the board.

title: Temptation; Marrons Glaces: They're Very Adult
description: LET the children have their visions of sugarplums. It's marrons glaces -- glazed chestnuts -- for me. These voluptuous confections are another of France's gifts to the table. Never mind that the Italians claim to have come up with the recipe in the Piedmont region some 150 years before marrons glaces were introduced in the court of Louis XIV. Most marrons glaces are made in and around the city of Privas, in the Ardeche near the west bank of the Rhone River, and they are known everywhere by their French name.

title: Democrat Elected County Executive in Westchester
description: Andrew J. Spano, a homespun veteran of politics and government, easily won election today as Westchester County Executive, making him only the second Democrat ever to capture the helm of a locale known almost as much for its preference for Republicans as for its leafy affluence.

title: About New York; The Election That Failed To Electrify
description: THE surest indication that yesterday was special in some way was the sight of cars staying put in prime spaces. Alternate-side parking was suspended on Election Day, so you could ignore the rules bolted to the lampposts in Morningside Heights. Closer to street level, there were few campaign signs for either Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani or Ruth Messinger. The International Socialist Organization seemed to be the only group that had worked the area, taping on walls and poles fliers proclaiming, ''Rudy v. Ruth. What's the Difference?'' or ''Crash Giuliani's Victory Party. Don't Mourn, Organize.''

title: Harrison Roth Is Dead at 65; Was Options Trading Expert
description: Harrison Roth, who was known as an expert on the trading of options, a form of investment contract, died Sunday from cancer, his employer, Cowen & Company, said yesterday. He was 65.

title: New Jersey Voters Pick Local Officials and Decide on Changes in Government
description: New Jersey voters went to the polls yesterday to choose mayors, freeholders and other local officials and to decide local and statewide questions. In as many as 10 communities, residents were asked to decide whether to change their form of government. New Jersey law gives towns and cities wide latitude in determining how to run their affairs.

title: ROCKWELL TO BUY HUGHES IN-FLIGHT ENTERTAINMENT UNIT
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said it had agreed to acquire Hughes-Avicom International Inc. Terms were not disclosed. Hughes-Avicom, based in Pomona, Calif., is the in-flight entertainment subsidiary of the Hughes Electronics Corporation, which in turn is a unit of the General Motors Corporation. Hughes-Avicom has projected 1997 sales of about $120 million. Rockwell, the electronics company, is based in Costa Mesa, Calif., and has annual sales of $10.4 billion. Hughes-Avicom would become part of its Collins aviation electronics business.

title: Mayor Now Has a Mandate to Aim High
description: For much of the last four years, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has enjoyed portraying himself as the embattled quarry of New York City's Democratic establishment, scuffling for every victory and succeeding despite vast battalions of ''old-fashioned politicians'' arrayed against him.

title: Emergency Landing For Out-of-Control Plane
description: A pilot apparently lost control of a small plane yesterday at Republic Airport on Long Island and made an emergency landing in a nearby airplane parking lot, officials said.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Excerpts From Speech by Whitman on Her Re-election
description: Following are excerpts from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's victory speech last night, as transcribed by The New York Times.

title: Internet Profiles To Acquire a Rival
description: There was a significant consolidation in the field of Internet audience measurement yesterday as the Internet Profiles Corporation in Redwood City, Calif., said that it had agreed to acquire the technology and other assets of a rival, Netcount L.L.C. in Los Angeles. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Sextet Of Stars Performs Brahms
description: Perhaps the classical music world's very busy necrology department has it all backward: instead of commemorating the death of great composers by giving more performances than usual of works that are already repertory staples, wouldn't it be more dramatic to take the ''It's a Wonderful Life'' approach, and have a year in which none of the composer's works are performed anywhere? Probably, but business is business, and these commemorations are, in the end, marketing opportunities.

title: Village Reaps Windfall Selling 4,600 Acres for a Preserve
description: Michael Mills was smiling despite the bitter wind that pummeled him as he walked along the crest of Sam's Point, a mountain ridge half a mile above the autumn-gilded floor of the Hudson River Valley.

title: Study Suggests That Exercise After Brain Injury Is Beneficial
description: Several years ago, an auto accident left Ellis Stavin mentally and physically shattered. He was in a coma for four months, a wheelchair for two and a half years. Doctors told him he might never walk again. His self-image took a beating when he realized he could no longer talk, walk or think as he once could.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERR, SEYMOUR
description: HERR-Seymour. Beloved husband of Miriam (nee Rubine). Devoted father of Betty, Howard and Richard Herr. Loving grandfather of Elizabeth and Jennifer Herr and of Anne and Steven Hopengarten. Services at the Teaneck Jewish Center, 70 Sterling Place, Teaneck, NJ, on Wednesday, November 5, 1997, 11 AM. Contributions to Hackensack Dialysis Renal Fund of Hackensack Medical Center, or to the American Heart Association would be appreciated. For information call (Gutterman-Musicant) 800-522-0588.

title: Liberties; Scrapple In the Apple
description: Even frogs can dream.

title: Voters Reject Constitutional Convention
description: Apparently swayed by a last-minute campaign mounted by labor unions and their allies, New York voters set aside their anger at state government today and defeated a ballot measure that would have called a convention in 1999 to amend the State Constitution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIERDS, ESTHER PEARSON
description: BIERDS-Esther Pearson, of Huntington, on Nov. 3, 1997, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved mother of Virginia Bierds Davis and the late William Pearson Bierds. Also survived by eight grandchildren and thirteen great-grandchildren. Graveside service to be held Wed., 1:30PM at the Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc., 1380 New York Ave., Huntington Station. For information call 516 423-2185

title: U.S. Business Squanders Its Leverage on China; Not 'Held Hostage'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, JOSEPH H.
description: ROSENBERG-Joseph H. The Board of Governors and members of Bocaire Country Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member on Monday, November 3, 1997. He will be missed. Services will be held Wednesday, November 5, 11am, at Gutterman - Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, FL. Burial at Riverside Cemetery, Lodi, NJ. Barry Berger, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLEIBERG, ROBERT
description: BLEIBERG-Robert. November 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Diane Beverly. Loving father of Ellen Van Landingham Smith and Richard Bleiberg. Devoted brother of Lawrence. Memorial service will be held at the New York Genealogical & Biographical Society, 122 E. 58 St., NYC to be announced at a later date.

title: U.S. Business Squanders Its Leverage on China; Scholars Stay Home
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Opposes Application By BellSouth
description: Dealing another blow to the ambitions of the regional Bell telephone companies, the Justice Department recommended yesterday that the BellSouth Corporation not be allowed to offer long-distance service in South Carolina.

title: Races Leave Republicans Still Holding Major Offices
description: Republican incumbents swept most contests on Long Island today as voters handily re-elected County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta in Nassau, District Attorney James M. Catterson Jr. in Suffolk County and Republican majorities in the Legislatures of both counties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIZZO, ROSE K.
description: RIZZO-Rose K. Beloved mother of Vivian, Joseph, Peter and MaryAnne. Wife of Joseph. Grandmother of ten.

title: Again, It's Diplomats vs. New York, With Both Sides Demanding Apologies
description: Tensions have flared between the superpowers again, as New York City police officers have clashed with a Russian diplomat's chauffeur, prompting Moscow to demand an apology from the United States and City Hall, in turn, to assail the envoys as ''intolerable'' lawbreakers who ought to apologize to the police.

title: $25 and Under; For a Filling Dinner, Breakfast Dishes From India
description: IF you happen to be looking for a vegetarian Indian restaurant that is also kosher, I have just the place: Pongal, a small, good-looking restaurant that opened about a year ago on a block with a couple of other Indian-kosher restaurants. Best of all, it's worth seeking out even if you couldn't care less about vegetarian food, not to mention a kosher diet.

title: Accounts
description: * Residential Metal Roofing Association, Seattle, to Eisner & Associates, Baltimore, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $16 million over four years.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about an order to the Union Pacific Railroad to open traffic in the Houston area to a small rival, the Texas Mexican Railway, misstated the ownership of the Texas Mexican. It is controlled by Transportacion Ma ritima Mexicana, which owns 51 percent, not Kansas City Southern Industries, which owns 49 percent.

title: At Second Bombing Trial, Stories Are Terse, but Still Powerful
description: Jurors at the trial of Terry L. Nichols heard today about the Oklahoma City bombing from some who lived through it, but the stories were strictly curtailed so as not to cloud the jurors' vision with tears. At least four jurors, one man and three women, wept anyway.

title: OTHER ELECTION NEWS
description: STATEN ISLAND

title: How the Polls On Election Day Were Conducted
description: The two Election Day polls were based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left voting stations across New York City and throughout New Jersey.

title: U.S. Joins Lawsuit Against Ingersoll-Rand
description: The Justice Department joined a $40 million lawsuit that accuses a unit of the Ingersoll-Rand Company of deceiving the Federal Government in a pair of contracts for excavation equipment.

title: Calendar
description: Have a Beer. No, Have 30 Beers.

title: Union Misgivings on Nafta Are Clinton's Latest Worry
description: Four years after the Clinton Administration said it would prod Mexico to improve workers' rights through agreements made along with the North American free trade pact, many Democrats and labor unions say results have been scant, complicating the White House's efforts to win new trade-negotiating authority.

title: U.S. Business Squanders Its Leverage on China; Push on Two Fronts
description: To the Editor:

title: Anger Behind Them, Krupp And Thyssen Plan Merger
description: Germany's two biggest steel companies, the Krupp-Hoesch Group and Thyssen A.G., announced a friendly merger today, less than eight months after Krupp aroused a nationwide furor by attempting a hostile takeover that would have accomplished the same end.

title: Amtrak Pact Faces a Major Obstacle in Congress
description: The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, said today that the tentative workers' agreement that Amtrak reached on Sunday was ''a total nonstarter.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: There is a first time for everything, which may be the best way to explain why JOHN HADLEY NICANOR HEMINGWAY will read part of his father's short story ''Big Two-Hearted River'' before an audience tomorrow.

title: COVENTRY TO ACQUIRE PRINCIPAL HEALTH FOR $375 MILLION
description: The Coventry Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Principal Health Care Inc. for about $375 million in stock. Coventry, which is based in Nashville, will issue 26 million shares plus warrants, amounting to a 40 percent stake in the company, to Principal Health Care's owner, Principal Financial Group, which is based in Des Moines. The company will be renamed Coventry Health Care Inc. Coventry, whose health plans serve 898,000 members in six states, will gain 674,000 members in the Midwest and Southeast. The combined company is expected have revenue of about $2.4 billion in 1998. Coventry's shares rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $14.875.

title: Bill for Education-Savings Accounts Fails to Win Vote in the Senate
description: A proposal to permit educational savings accounts, a linchpin in the Republicans' agenda, was yanked from the Senate floor today after it failed to overcome a second filibuster. But Senate leaders vowed to revive it early next year.

title: Review/Fashion; The Rewards of Keeping Faith
description: To be true to self while constantly moving forward is the challenge a serious designer faces each season. This involves developing a signature that remains recognizable as it evolves with the times. The trick is to avoid stagnation without succumbing to every passing trend. The best designers master this art early in their careers, building up a faithful clientele and regularly adding new fans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOTKIN, RICHARD
description: PLOTKIN-Richard. On November 2, 1997. Beloved husband of Marisa, devoted son of Fredi Plotkin and Jack Plotkin, loving brother of Michael, and half brother of Elizabeth and James, dear nephew. Services Wednesday, November 5, 12 Noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Races for City Council
description: x - Winner

title: Class Notes; The Elis of 1937 rally around one of their own, seeking to mend a rift over a perceived Yale snub.
description: Some wounds take longer to heal than others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, BEATRICE D. (BEATSY)
description: BROWN-Beatrice D. (Beatsy), on Nov. 4, 1997. Wife of the late Irving Brown. Mother of Bonnie Moroff and Donner Brown. Grandmother of David and Steven Moroff. Aunt to Susan West and Richard Lewis. Services and interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITTLEMAN, DR. LOUIS A.
description: GITTLEMAN-Dr. Louis A. 80. November 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Bernice, father of Lisa and Ron and grandfather of Rebecca.

title: Hailing the Wooden O's Resurrection on the Thames
description: Agincourt is on the bill tonight, but before ''Great Performances'' gets around to ''King Henry V,'' Act IV, it offers a quick tour of the new old Globe Theater. That's the replica of ''the wooden O,'' built on the Thames in 1599.

title: Tough Guy at Treasury; Rubin's Point Man on Policy Is in Tune On Economics, Off-Key on Politics
description: At times in the last few weeks, it has seemed as if the hand and mind of Lawrence H. Summers could be found lurking beneath the surface of just about every tangled problem facing the White House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLANT, ESSIE
description: GALLANT-Essie. On November 3, 1997, age 94. Beloved wife of the late Earl I. Gallant. Loving mother of Elaine and Stanton F. Roth and Lois and Arthur Gallant. Adoring grandmother of Debra, Stephen, Laurie and Glenn. Great grandmother of Danielle, Madison, Evan, Michael and Sarah. She will be deeply missed by all of us. Services Thursday, 12:15pm at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Democratic Majority Retains Wide Margin
description: Some Democrats on the City Council had feared that having a formidable Republican at the top of the ticket might siphon off votes. It didn't matter. Last night, as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani cruised to victory, so did all of the Democratic incumbents on the Council.

title: Ewbank Is Out Of the Hospital
description: Before discharging Weeb Ewbank from McCullough-Hyde Memorial Hospital today, doctors offered the 90-year-old former football coach advice: Do not watch the Jets on television.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEFF, WALTER S.
description: NEFF-Walter S. Born Philadelphia 1910. Educated in Central High School in Philadelphia. BA and MA degrees from University of Pennsylvania. PhD from Cornell University. Assistant Professor University of Maine and City College of New York in the 1930's. Second Lt. US Army Medical Corp during WWII, China-Burma-India Theater of Operations. Following the war Dr. Neff was employed by the Jewish Vocational Service in Chicago. 1960-1975 Professor of Psychology, New York University, author of many articles and ''Work and Human Behavior'', a seminal text in the field of psychology of work. Preceded in death in 1988 by his wife of 42 years, Mary Himoff Neff. He is survived by his beloved Vivian Emmet of West Palm Beach Florida, his son and daughter-in-law Alan H. Neff and Meade Palidofsky of Chicago, Illinois and his son Richard Reno Neff of West Orange, New Jersey and by 4 grandchildren.

We extend our sympathy to his children and his loved ones. May his memory abide as a blessing. Hazzan Henry Rosenblum, Pres. Hazzan Abraham B. Shapiro, Executive Administrator

title: It's a New 'Joy,' but Is It the Old Love?; The Cookbook Now Speaks in a Corporate Tone
description: MOST food sensations are accidents. James Beard wanted to be an actor, Julia Child wanted to be a spy. Irma S. Rombauer was recently widowed and needed to make a living when she self-published 3,000 copies of a 396-page volume of recipes.

description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's re-election is a uniquely personal achievement.

title: A Cosmopolitan Horse Makes His Final Stop
description: His trainer was born in Barbados and now lives in England. His jockey was born in Italy and has become a champion in England. His owner, a member of the ruling family of Dubai in the Persian Gulf, has hundreds of horses in Europe and North America.

title: Verjus, a Tart Splash for All Dishes
description: THOUGH most American cooks are just now learning how to pronounce its name, verjus, a tart grape juice, has been used by European and Middle Eastern cooks for hundreds of years. Neither vinegar nor wine, verjus (pronounced vair-JHOO, as in au jus), the pressed juice of unripe grapes, has a taste in between those two. Unlike vinegar's mouth-puckering jolt, verjus's taste is sweet, tart and mildly acidic.

title: The chronicles of Andy Berlin continue with at least his fourth new agency in 14 years.
description: THE peripatetic adman Andy Berlin made another move yesterday as he unexpectedly announced the opening of another agency bearing his name -- at least the fourth in 14 years.

description: STRASSER-Sarah (nee Resnick). description: James S. Gilmore 3d, a former State Attorney General, was elected governor of Virginia today, leading the first ever Republican sweep of the state's three highest offices.

title: The Race for Mayor
description: By Assembly district.

title: Watson Begins War of Words With Agent
description: The Yankees went on the offensive in the contentious Bernie Williams negotiations yesterday, with General Manager Bob Watson alleging how unreasonable Williams's agent, Scott Boras, has been in conversations about a new contract. Watson charged that Boras wants $70 million over seven years for his client and said the Yankees' initial offer of five years for $37.5 million had been ridiculed by Boras, who has denied asking for $70 million.

title: Excerpts From Messinger's Speech
description: Following are excerpts from Ruth W. Messinger's speech last night conceding victory to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, as recorded by The New York Times.

description: ''THE hardest to part with was the 1931 Cadillac,'' said the Marquis de Goulaine. ''Sixteen cylinders and bulletproof. What a car.''

title: Public Eye; Technology and design run wild in the soles of the newest sneakers.
description: JAPANESE legend has it that the minute the Buddha was born, he got up and took seven steps to the east, leaving a path of flowers in his wake. Mere mortals, if they are wearing snea-kers, are apt to leave crop circles or vertebral ridges. The physical marks made by the average person on his or her 115,000-mile shuffle across this earth are as identifiable as fingerprints, with sneaker makers opting for baroque combinations of geometry and architecture.

title: Orders Rose At Factories In September
description: Orders placed with manufacturers unexpectedly rose in September for the fourth consecutive month, the Government said today in a report that reflected an expansion of business investment in factories and equipment.

title: Personal Shopper; A Chair of One's Own
description: ONE can never be too young or too small, it seems, to appreciate a chair that fits. And it is never too soon to help a fledgling feather a nest with furniture that will be fondly remembered someday.

title: Accounts Awarded To DDB Needham
description: Two offices of the DDB Needham Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group have been awarded accounts with billings estimated at more than $15 million.

title: Share Its Turf? Royal Opera Shudders
description: It has been a very bad year for the Royal Opera House, currently wandering listlessly around London as its home in Covent Garden undergoes a $358 million reconstruction. It has had three chief executives in the last year. It is teetering on the brink of insolvency. And it has become the country's latest political punching bag, forced to squirm in silence as members of Parliament hurl unflattering adjectives at it (''shambolic'' comes up quite a lot).

title: Jiang Gone, House Begins Venting Anger Against China
description: A week after the summit talks between President Jiang Zemin of China and President Clinton, the House began voting today on measures intended to punish the Chinese Government and express Congressional displeasure over Beijing's rights record.

title: News Flash: Quarterback Job Belongs to Kanell
description: The symbiotic seasonlong dance of the Giants and Jets took another twist today. Hours after Jets Coach Bill Parcells made Glenn Foley his choice to start at quarterback, Giants Coach Jim Fassel announced that Danny Kanell would be his starter for the rest of the season, officially ending Dave Brown's four-year run as the quarterback of the future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERJANIAN, BARBARA L., R.N., C.S.W. (NEE RULON)
description: MERJANIAN-Barbara L., R.N., C.S.W. (nee Rulon). Devoted wife of Stephen. Service at St. Vartan Armenian Cathedral, 2nd Avenue at 34th St., Friday 10am. In lieu of flowers contributions to Fordham University G.S.S.S.A., appreciated.

title: U.S. Diplomat Leaves Austria After Being Caught Wiretapping
description: A United States intelligence official, apparently a Central Intelligence Agency officer, has left Austria after being arrested for wiretapping the phone of a North Korean diplomat in Vienna, Government officials said today.

title: Phil Soto, Hispanic Political Leader, Dies at 71
description: Phil Soto, a one-time television repairman who became an inspiration to a generation of Hispanic politicians in California when he broke through decades of prejudice to become one of the first two Hispanic members of the State legislature since the 19th century, died on Tuesday at his home in Pomona. He was 71 and had served two terms in the State Assembly, from 1962 to 1966.

description: BROTHMAN-Charles A. In loving memory of a dear father and a good man, gone these forty years. Gus

title: Corrections
