NBC's ''Nightly News'' had an average rating of 8.8, not 8.3, and ABC's ''World News Tonight'' had an 8.3 rating, not 8.2. Each rating point represents 980,000 homes.

title: Former Aide Tells Inquiry He Did Not Lobby Clinton

In spite of brisk economic growth, the Government's most comprehensive measure of inflation rose at the slowest pace since 1964. Strikingly, though, not all the interpretations of the data are sanguine.

title: Officers On 2 Wheels Unleashed On Traffic
description: The 1,251 police officers on bicycles in New York City are a testament to the fact that cycling is often the fastest way to chase criminals through gridlocked streets. But until now, the patrolling of traffic itself has been left to police in cars and scooters or on foot.

title: Currents; FRIENDLY AND TRANSLUCENT -- From a Dream Comes a Lamp That Would Do Casper Proud
description: For those who like living with ghosts, there's the K-Series Lamp, designed by Shiro Kuramata (1934-1991), who created furniture, lighting and interiors in Tokyo and with the Memphis group in Milan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HONIG, MURPHY, ADRIENNE

title: Currents; DESIGN DU JOUR -- Help Yourself to the Potatoes, But Don't Drop the Objets d'Art
description: A mixing bowl may be a humble item to one person, no more worthy of attention than a dust mote. But to another, it may be a collectible -- and even a subject for a book.

title: In New Jersey, a Search for Solutions Mattered More Than Partisan Politics
description: ''This is a tough state,'' Christine Todd Whitman said emphatically, just minutes after she edged past James E. McGreevey early this morning to win a second term as governor.

title: Currents; WINDOW DRESSING -- A Better Face Forward
description: Van Cleef & Arpels, the jewelry store that has presided over Fifth Avenue and 57th Street since 1942, has been given a younger and friendlier look by Jean-Pierre Heim, an architect with offices in New York and Paris. Gone are the small windows surrounded in black. Now they are framed in a pale blue-green arch of sandblasted glass. Gone, too, is the uninviting curtained door. The new clear-glass entry says: ''Come in. Please!''

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Oct. 27 about recent changes in accounts misstated the scope of an account for Neet depilatories awarded by Reckitt & Colman to McCann-Erickson Advertising Worldwide. It was for Canada only. (Neet is sold in the United States by Premiere Brands through a licensing agreement with Reckitt & Colman; that account is handled by Gianettino & Meredith of Short Hills, N.J.)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about results of Tuesday's New York City Council elections misstated the amount spent by Councilman Andrew S. Eristoff's campaign on television and radio advertisements. Campaign officials said yesterday that ads cost $50,000, not $250,000, out of a total of more than $400,000 Mr. Eristoff spent to retain his seat on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: Omnicom to Acquire Harrison, Young
description: The Omnicom Group said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Harrison, Young, Pesonen & Newell Inc., a leading media services agency in Toronto. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Life Is Hard, and Death's No Picnic Either
description: Even death is no cure for loneliness in the atomistic world of ''Brutality of Fact,'' Keith Reddin's heartfelt comedy of despair at Primary Stages. Such, in any case, is the evidence offered by the dreams of the play's central characters, in which the afterlife assumes all the comforting warmth and conviviality of an airport at 3 A.M. You can imagine the odds of success for these people in less extreme bids for overcoming isolation, like getting married or having sex with a stranger.

Sister of Gert, the late Jack (Mildred), and Evelyn (Meyer). Many years devoted to New York school children. Contributions may be sent to For The Children International, APDO.544, San Miguel de Allende, GTO. Mexico.

title: Aiming at Top Dollar For the Simpson House
description: If you have any doubts that the seven-bedroom English country manse behind the ivy-covered wall is no ordinary house, they disappear the minute Fred Sands, Brentwood's real estate broker to the stars, greets you in the curving brick-and-concrete driveway: you realize that he is not talking foundation, but wearing it.

title: Accord Reached Clearing Way For Most Major Spending Bills
description: With Congress rushing to recess, lawmakers worked out tentative agreements today on two contentious issues -- national testing and the census -- clearing the logjam on most of the remaining spending bills.

title: German Unemployment Rises for a 7th Month
description: Germany's unemployment rose to a record for the seventh straight month in October, led by job losses in eastern Germany. The unemployment rate climbed to 11.8 percent from 11.7 percent, a post-1945 record that was in line with expectations, the Federal Labor Office said. Unemployment rose 19,000, to 4.52 million.

title: Kish Journal; Island of Shocking Lyrics in a Sea of Disapproval
description: To understand what sets Kish apart from the rest of Iran, listen for the music.

title: Islanders Let Down at First, but Gain Tie
description: The Islanders were due for a letdown, having won three straight entering tonight's game against the Edmonton Oilers.

title: Miami Beach Journal; Traditional Drumbeats Bridge City's Ethnic Divide
description: For all its celebrated ethnic diversity, Miami is still an area where populations remain so isolated that a Cuban, a Haitian or a Brazilian may never talk to one another and, even if they tried, still may not communicate because of the language divide common to cities of new immigrants. But lured by curiosity and opportunity, and fighting some trepidation, a group of residents gathered from the neighborhoods, restaurants and churches that identify South Florida's cultural enclaves is trying out a new dialogue in this sun-bathed Tower of Babel. It sounds something like this:

title: Byrne at Center Stage With 3 Early Favorites
description: Seventy-seven horses were entered in the seven Breeders' Cup races today, 17 fewer than expected one week ago, but three of them trained by Patrick Byrne lived up to their reviews when they were made the favorites in their races: Favorite Trick at 7-5 in the Juvenile, Countess Diana at 9-5 in the Juvenile Fillies and Richter Scale at 3-1 in the Sprint.

title: Editorial Observer ; And Now, a Few Bracing Notes From the Land of Electoral Reality
description: The 1997 elections are over, and the American people have delivered a resounding message: Don't touch anything! You might break it! From sea to shining sea, the voters demonstrated their unshakeable determination to keep things exactly the same, right down to Christine Todd Whitman's election margin. The blessings the nation has enjoyed in the Age of Clinton -- plummeting crime, soaring stocks -- seem so inexplicable that the public apparently fears any tinkering, no matter how unrelated, might set the whole structure tumbling. If the fall of the value of the Thai baht could cause the Dow Jones industrial average to teeter precariously, who knew what might happen if Cincinnati said yes to a new elephant house, or the Navajos O.K.'d a casino? Voters looked at referendum options, progressive or reactionary, and came to the same consistent conclusion. Whatever was standing yesterday was good enough for tomorrow, be it assisted-suicide laws in Oregon or affirmative action in Houston or the right to bear arms without safety instruction in Washington. Leave it alone! Go play someplace else!

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

description: Jon Weiser, the man who has raised the fashion consciousness of New Yorkers more than a few notches over the years, is holding court in his multilevel store on West 57th Street, a minimalist monument to au courant clothing. ''Isn't that Marky Mark?'' he asks, peering toward the entrance from a space displaying nubby charcoal jackets for $680. Apparently, it isn't.

description: The Ohio Edison Company's Firstenergy Services Corporation unit said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Roth Brothers Inc. and RPC Mechanical Inc. for an undisclosed amount to expand its line of energy-related products and services. The companies to be acquired had 1996 revenue of $81 million and are expected to have 1997 revenue of $91 million, while Firstenergy, based in Akron, Ohio, has annual revenue of about $5 billion. Samuel Roth is president and chief executive of Roth, based in Youngstown, Ohio, and RPC, based in Cincinnati.

His adoring family and many friends will miss him and will always remember his humor, generosity and gentle loving nature. Interment in Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY on November 7 at 1PM. The company is predicting net income of more than 3 billion marks for the new fiscal year.

title: AFTER WAVERLY PUTS ITSELF UP FOR SALE, ITS STOCK RISES
description: The shares of Waverly Inc. rose 46 percent yesterday after the company said it had put itself on the block. The stock of the company, a medical and scientific publisher, rose $12.75, to $40.125. The Baltimore-based Waverly said it had hired Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company to find a buyer after its board decided customers would benefit from an acquisition by a larger, well-managed company. Waverly, which has 600 employees, said it would consider potential buyers committed to keeping its operating base in Baltimore. Waverly publishes books that include ''Student Atlas of Anatomy'' and ''Remington: The Science and Practice of Pharmacy'' and periodicals on medicine and related disciplines.

Mr. Lunding, a Tokyo-based partner in a Manhattan law firm, got to argue his own case, a $3,724 dispute with the New York State tax authorities that could well end up changing the way New York treats tax deductions claimed by people who live outside the state but who earn income and owe taxes here.

title: Funds for Transportation Are All Right for Now

But New Jersey managed to squirrel away $274.8 million in transportation money over the last few years, State Department of Transportation officials said yesterday.

title: Trade Pact Free-for-All: Behind the Hyperbole
description: Here is what President Clinton and his aides say will happen if Congress fails on Friday to give him new power to negotiate trade agreements around the world:

title: Nassau Lags Its Neighbors In Vote Tally
description: It took Nassau County officials until noon today to finish counting the votes from Tuesday's election, but the authorities say things will work better next year, when additional computers are installed.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Ex-Mayoral Aide Gets Dispensation
description: Charges that Norman Steisel, a First Deputy Mayor in the Dinkins administration, tried to buy oral sex from a policewoman posing as a prostitute will be dropped if he stays out of trouble for six months, under an agreement with the Brooklyn District Attorney's office.

title: Big Board to Drop Rule Barring Companies From Leaving
description: The New York Stock Exchange plans to drop a rule that makes it nearly impossible for a company listed on the exchange to move to another market voluntarily, exchange officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERTIG, HILDA L.
description: FERTIG-Hilda L. Beloved wife of Felix. Loving mother of Ann Freedman and Mack Fertig. Devoted sister of Barbara Newmark. Cherished mother-in-law of Lisa Fertig and Robert Freedman. Adored grandmother of Jessica Freedman and Sara, Eric and Amy Fertig. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Gladney Center, 2300 Hemphill, Ft Worth, TX 76110. Funeral services Friday, 12:00 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 333 Amsterdam Ave (bet 75th and 76th St).

title: Songs of Martyred Nuns
description: The kindly nuns of Elizabeth Swados's ''Missionaries'' are selfless humanitarians devoted to the church, the poor and good works. Showered in hot white light on the stage of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Majestic Theater, they positively glow with compassion and religious feeling. ''Hard work, long days,'' they sing. ''This is what the soul takes strength from.''

title: Radioactive Matter Left in Taxi Trunk
description: A milliliter of yttrium 90, a radioactive substance used in cancer treatment, was left in the trunk of a yellow taxi on Tuesday afternoon by a lab technician at New York University Medical Center, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STECKLER, WILLIAM
description: STECKLER-William. Dear father of Karen and David died peacefully on Nov. 3rd. Cemetery services at Beth Olem, Thursday, 1:30 PM.

title: Up Close and Kaleidoscopic: Ballet Theater Unfurls Its Repertory
description: American Ballet Theater returned to its roots on Tuesday night at City Center in a bubbling, warmhearted celebration of the glories of good choreography and brilliant dancing. Ballet Theater will present ballets by some of its best-known and most interesting choreographers in this two-week inaugural season of a planned annual fall festival of commissioned works at City Center. Like the ballets themselves, the theater offers audiences the chance to savor Ballet Theater up close and very personally.

title: Search Continues For Help at Catcher
description: After being told that a deal for Jim Leyritz was highly unlikely, Mets General Manager Steve Phillips continued his search for a catcher yesterday. Doug Melvin, the general manager of the Texas Rangers, said he told Phillips in a phone conversation yesterday that he did not think a deal could be arranged for Leyritz.

title: Champion for Minorities Finds He Is an Underdog
description: Sitting on a pink and white-striped sofa in an office a stone's throw from the White House, Bill Lann Lee tells a tale about his father that speaks volumes about the son's motivations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, PAUL
description: GREENBERG-Paul. On November 4, 1997 in Albany, NY. Husband of Esther Novogrodsky Greenberg. Father of Benjamin Greenberg of Sommerville, MA, Francine Greenberg Reizen of Chicago, IL and Jessica Greenberg Dennis of Thousand Oaks, CA. Grandfather of Shira Belle Dennis, Jonah Chaim Dennis and Rachel Reizen. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by three brothers, Sherwin, Howard and Ellis Greenberg. Services at Congregation Ohav Sholom, Albany, NY on Thursday, 1P.M. For information contact the Levine Memorial Chapel, Albany, NY at 1-800-427-0280.

title: The House Threat to Family Planning
description: The House Republican leadership, in an irrational effort to strike a blow against abortions, is continuing to back legislation that can only weaken international family planning efforts. The misguided crusade would deny Federal family planning money to any overseas program or organization that performs abortions or lobbies to change abortion laws in foreign countries, even if the organizations pay for those services and activities from other funding sources.

title: ITT Directors Discuss Rival Bids But Do Not Announce Decision
description: Directors of the ITT Corporation did not announce a decision yesterday on whether they would recommend one of two competing bids for control of the company.

title: Putting a Christian Stamp on Congress
description: Every Tuesday night, Representative Steve Largent of Oklahoma and four fellow Congressmen get together to pray and get personal. After dinner, they put their feet up on the coffee table in his Capitol Hill row house and ask one another: What did you do this week to make your wife feel special? Did you work too much? Were you too self-centered? Are you getting too big for your britches?

title: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: RIGHT TO DIE ; In Oregon, Opening a New Front in the World of Medicine
description: As recently as 15 years ago, doctors were prosecuted for withdrawing life-support systems from dying patients, even at the behest of a family. Today in Oregon, after a surprisingly strong vote that takes one state to the frontier of medical ethics, doctors can begin helping terminally ill patients kill themselves.

title: To Liven a Report, Gore Includes Some Cartoons
description: He still makes conversation by saying things like ''G.P.R.A. and N.P.R. are already intertwined and integrated.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAUSCHMAN, ALFRED J.
description: RAUSCHMAN-Alfred J. Furlong, PA, formerly of Warren, NJ. November 5, 1997 after a long illness. Survived by his wife, Ardith (nee Orlinger); two daughters, Alix and Amy Rauschman. Memorial mass at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church, 235 East State St., Doylestown, PA on Saturday, November 8 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Diabetes Association, 1 Plymouth Meeting, Suite 520, Plymouth Meeting, PA 19462. Reed & Steinbach Funeral Home, Doylestown, PA.

title: At Home With: Jane Jacobs; Urban Hero
description: BECAUSE Jane Jacobs believes nothing should ever be thrown out, she uses a World War II experiment to hold open her front door. It is a smooth wooden block, a model for a fuel tank that would fit in the wing of a fighter plane.

title: Round 1: She Supports Abortion, He's Opposed
description: With its excellent acting and its mixture of romance, humor and sadness as it addresses the issue of abortion, ''The Water Children,'' by Wendy MacLeod, is a fascinating play. But watching it is like watching a championship fight with an unsatisfying finish. For 11 rounds, two evenly matched opponents slug it out. Then, with the outcome still in doubt, the referee suddenly intervenes, ends the battle and awards victory to the combatant she favors.

title: Metro Business; Ad Agency to Move Office
description: Bates Worldwide, the advertising agency, is moving its headquarters from the Chrysler Building to 498 Seventh Avenue, filling four lower floors at the 77-year-old building at 37th Street.

title: Sports of The Times; O'Donnell Is a Lesson For Williams
description: THE white towel that Neil O'Donnell playfully used to shoo photographers away in the Jets' locker room yesterday represented no surrender to Glenn Foley, no embracing the idea of himself as a permanent backup.

title: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: Man in The News -- Vito John Fossella Jr.; City Hall To Capitol
description: Within 24 hours after voters had transformed him from an obscure city councilman to the newest member of Congress, Vito J. Fossella Jr. had received three standing ovations from fellow House Republicans, been sworn in by Speaker Newt Gingrich and voted to overhaul the Internal Revenue Service.

title: The Oregon Trail
description: Advocates of physician-aid in dying won an overwhelming victory in Oregon on Tuesday, and that victory may well represent the first step down a road that all of America could travel.

title: Devils End Their Frustration in Florida
description: Jacques Lemaire thought he had ample reason to be worried. The Devils' coach checked on his weary athletes periodically before tonight's game against the Florida Panthers and didn't like what he saw.

title: British Airways Posts 2d-Quarter Decline
description: British Airways P.L.C. said yesterday that its profit fell 44.4 percent in its second quarter, hurt by a summer strike by cabin crews and a stronger pound that cut the value of its overseas bookings. Net income at the carrier, Europe's largest airline, dropped to $:153 million ($252 million), or 13.9 pence a share, in the three months that ended on Sept. 30 from $:275 million in the corresponding period a year ago.

title: Exposed: Royal Chronicler With the Woman's Touch
description: A man long thought to have been the chief assistant to Helen Cathcart, a well-known author of popular royal biographies, has acknowledged that he in fact wrote the books and that no Mrs. Cathcart ever existed. He made his admission in his own death notice.

title: Johnson, the A.L. Manager of the Year, Resigns From Orioles
description: In a bizarre development unprecedented in baseball history, Davey Johnson resigned as manager of the Baltimore Orioles yesterday just as he was about to be named the American League manager of the year for guiding the team to the league's best record.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A fire caused $75,000 worth of damage at the home of WILLIAM F. BUCKLEY in Stamford, Conn., fire officials said. Deputy Fire Chief William Smith said the blaze started on the second floor and spread through two bedrooms and a bathroom of the large old house on Long Island Sound.

title: Trust Our State Courts to Defend Civil Liberties; Polygraphs Can Lie
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Panel on Acupuncture Calls for Wider Acceptance
description: An independent panel of experts concluded today that the ancient practice of acupuncture was an effective therapy for certain medical conditions, especially those involving nausea and pain, and should be integrated into standard medical practice for these problems.

title: Turf; With Greasepaint Off in Camp Big Apple
description: IN the frost-shrouded air of midnight, the rows upon rows of house trailers are serene, their wheels resting on gray stone pavers in the heart of New York City, their inhabitants fast asleep. The elongated windows of the Metropolitan Opera House peer down on the encampment; an electric chandelier casts a dim glow on the rounded roof of a circus performer's home.

title: Metro Business; Aid for Historic Buildings
description: The New York Landmarks Conservancy, a nonprofit historic preservation group, has awarded 23 grants totaling $80,500 for the preservation and repair of historic religious buildings in New York State, including six grants totaling $23,500 in New York City, the group has said.

title: Courage on Trade
description: President Clinton accurately portrays tomorrow's vote in the House on ''fast-track'' as crucial to his ability to maintain America's leadership in world trade. A favorable vote would provide him with the authority to negotiate agreements that Congress can reject but not amend. But irresponsible political forces in both parties stand in his way.

title: NABISCO AGREES TO BUY CORNNUTS, SNACK FOOD PRODUCER
description: The Nabisco Holdings Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase Cornnuts Inc. for an undisclosed price to expand its snack food business. Nabisco, which makes Oreo cookies, Ritz crackers and Planters nuts, said the strong Cornnuts presence in convenience stores would add to its sales there. Cornnuts makes a line of corn kernel snacks. Nabisco said there were no plans to close the Cornnuts processing operations in Fresno, Calif., and Urbana, Ohio. But it will eventually close Cornnuts headquarters in Alameda, Calif., where about 30 people work. Last year, snack foods represented 80 percent, or more than $7.1 billion, of Nabisco's $8.9 billion sales.

title: Review/Fashion; Forever Lauren: A Racy Elegance
description: Ralph Lauren pulled off quite a feat in his spring show, injecting his clean-cut all-American image with a healthy dose of sex appeal. He is a designer who doesn't know the meaning of sleaze but understands sensuality and managed to translate it into both day and evening clothes that offer his customer a whole new way to dress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PESKIN, HENRY, M.D.
description: PESKIN-Henry, M.D. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins the physicians and staff of the Department of Surgery in acknowledging with sadness the passing of our esteemed friend and former colleague, Henry Peskin, M.D., a member of the Beth Israel family for more than fifty years. To the entire Peskin family, his friends and all who loved him, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President Jerome S. Breslaw, M.D., President, Medical Board Sidney K. Stein, M.D., President, Doctors Alumni Association Moses Nussbaum, M.D., Chairman, Department of Surgery

title: Legislation Reining In the I.R.S. Clears House on Vote of 426 to 4
description: The House overwhelmingly passed legislation today to give taxpayers new rights in their dealings with the Internal Revenue Service, with members of both parties saying Congress should now begin turning its attention to a more daunting problem, the complexity of the tax code.

title: A Touch of College Life, But at $1,900 a Month; 34 Graduates of One Business School Wind Up Living at One Columbus Place
description: Steve Audi, a 29-year-old investment banker with a 1997 M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, can pound a broom on the ceiling of his Manhattan apartment and communicate with two other 1997 Wharton graduates, who live one floor above him. And he discovered recently that he could speak into the air vent in his kitchen and talk to another classmate from Wharton, Nadine Orosa, whose kitchen is one floor below his. They could chat through the duct work, Mr. Audi suggested, and stay in touch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTLE, JOHN W. II.
description: LITTLE-John W. II. The Board of Directors and the staff of Southampton Hospital express deepest sympathy to their esteemed Board member, Jean Remmel Little, on the loss of her devoted husband, John W. Little II, former member of the Hospital's Board of Directors. Elliott E. Vose, Chairman of the Board John J. Ferry, Jr., M.D., President and CEO

title: Patients Mark Success Of Heart Transplants
description: Every March, and again in August, Andrea Bleznick writes notes to a 12-year-old girl and a 40-year-old woman she never knew. She ties the two notes to heart-shaped balloons filled with helium and releases them into the air, watching them rise until they fade from sight.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in some copies yesterday with an article about the elections in Virginia reversed the party affiliations of the two main candidates for governor. James S. Gilmore 3d, the winner, is a Republican; Donald S. Beyer Jr. is a Democrat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACE, IRVING
description: WALLACE-Irving. On November 4, 1997. Beloved father of Dorothy and Allan. Beloved grandfather of Peter, John, Dana and Lindsay and great-grandfather of Spencer Mark and Zachary Eric. Services at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Rockville Centre, N.Y. Friday November 7, 12 noon.

title: Ban Sought on South Asian Rugs In Campaign Against Child Labor
description: CHILD-LABOR opponents asked the Customs Department yesterday to ban imports of rugs from South Asia unless the makers can prove that they are not made with forced child labor.

title: Pagans and Holocaust
description: To the Editor,

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Would every governor seeking re-election love to be carried into office on the shoulders of an adoring electorate? Of course, you would. But that's not reality; that's not what happens. And it certainly doesn't happen in a state like this.''

title: Wildwood Mayor Fights Earlier Bar Closings
description: Mayor Fred Wager of Wildwood, who lost his fight against a ballot measure to roll back the summer closing time of the seaside community's many bars, said yesterday that he would work with bar owners to try to make up for the anticipated drop in business.

title: Referendum in Houston Shows Complexity of Preferences Issue
description: Just one day after the United States Supreme Court upheld California's sweeping ban on affirmative action policies, Houston's voters have put a surprising brake on a national movement that has often seemed to have the momentum of an unstoppable freight train.

title: Pressure Builds on Corestates' Chief Over Merger Stance
description: Once again, Terrence A. Larsen is on the hot seat.

title: What Worked And What Didn't In a Tight Gubernatorial Race
description: Various influences in the New Jersey gubernatorial election and how they affected -- or did not affect -- the outcome.

title: Currents; SIGN LANGUAGE -- Their Regards to Broadway: Times Square's Light Shows
description: Mr. Peanut waving his walking stick on Broadway between 46th and 47th Streets. The Camel man blowing rings of smoke (actually Con Edison steam) on Broadway between 43d and 44th Streets. These are some of the 150 images and replicas in ''Signs and Wonders: The Spectacular Lights of Times Square,'' a show that will open Wednesday and run through March 8 at the New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street.

title: BURNHAM IN $314 MILLION DEAL FOR 20 RETAIL CENTERS
description: Burnham Pacific Properties Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the California retail portfolio of Golden State Properties for more than $314 million. Burnham, based in San Diego, is a real estate investment trust. Golden State is a private investment partnership between Highridge Partners of Los Angeles and Blackacre Capital Group L.P. of New York. The 2.7-million-square-foot portfolio consists of 20 retail centers each anchored by a grocery. The deal had an initial value of up to $314 million and a total value of up to $344 million, Burnham said. Under the agreement, Blackacre Capital and Westbrook Partners L.L.C., a private investment fund manager based in New York, will buy $120 million of newly issued Burnham Pacific shares.

title: Men Assault Pastor, 100, And Rob His Church
description: Three armed men tied up a 100-year-old pastor and his 68-year-old neighbor, doused them in gasoline and robbed their church yesterday afternoon in Brownsville, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Trust Our State Courts to Defend Civil Liberties; 'Activist' Judges
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: The police said a 12-year-old Brooklyn boy accidentally killed a toddler.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, SCHUYLER MERRITT, JR.
description: MEYER-Schuyler Merritt, Jr., 79, on November 4, at home in Dover Plains, after a long illness from cancer. Philanthropist, foundation leader, founder of the George Bird Grinnell Indian Children's Fund, Board Member of State Council on Waterway, Volunteer Skipper of New York State Erie Canal Tugboat Urger, former President and Chairman of the Edwin Gould Academy, former President of the Edwin Gould Foundation for 23 years, and Board Member for over 40, Chairman of the National Maritime Historical Society, President of Crystal Run Environmental Center and Project Sail, recipient of Distinguished Service Commendation from New York State. World War II Veteran, Navy Commander, recipient of three honorary degrees: Doctor of Humane Letters from College of Human Services (Audrey Cohen College), 1989, Doctor of Education from Middlebury College, 1989, Doctor of Law from Cumberland College, 1992. Recipient of the Eleanor Roosevelt Val-Kill Medal in 1990 for work on behalf of American Indians, Sequoya Fellow of the American Indian Science and Engineering Society. Survived by his wife of 55 years, Barbara Scott Meyer, their five children, Schuyler M., III, of Plano, TX, Molly of New Haven, CT, Aileen (Chuca) of Washington, DC, Scott of Millbrook, NY, and Allen of Millbrook, NY; his three sisters, Molly O'Connor of Seattle, WA, Janet Denison of Sutton, VT, and Helen Germann of Buffalo, WY; and five grandchildren, Charles John, Lawton, Anna, Whitney and Schuyler. Memorial service to be held December 7 at Millbrook School Chapel. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to George Bird Grinnell American Indian Children's Fund C/O AISES, Attention: Norbert Hill, 5661 Airport Boulevard, Boulder, CO, 80301-2339. The Edwin Gould Foundation for Children

title: INSIDE
description: Fresh Charge Against Iraq

title: Arafat Is No Pawn
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Securities Rise in Price
description: The prices of Treasury securities snapped a three-day decline yesterday, after the second part of the Government's quarterly refunding of debt showed decent results.

title: A New Trainer for Moorer, and Possibly a New Holyfield
description: In preparation for his heavyweight title fight against Evander Holyfield on Saturday night, Michael Moorer, the International Boxing Federation champion, wanted to return to the freedom of his Kronk Gym days. One problem was that his trainer at the well-known Detroit gym, Emanuel Steward, wouldn't return to his corner.

title: Crazy Weather
description: Like everyone else, I'm worried about El Nino. I too recall the terrible storms, floods and droughts of 1982 and 1983. But do you remember what else that stretch of warmer ocean temperatures brought us? I'm talking about the really strange, frightening occurrences for which there is no rational explanation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, BEATRICE D. (BEATSY)
description: BROWN-Beatrice D. (Beatsy), on Nov. 4, 1997. Wife of the late Irving Brown. Mother of Bonnie Moroff (Scott) and Donner Brown. Grandmother of David and Steven Moroff. Aunt to Susan West and Richard Lewis. Services and interment private.

title: Rangers Cash In With Hard Checks
description: Hoping to break a four-game streak without a victory and a three-game losing streak on the road, the Rangers took a conservative approach tonight when they visited the powerful Colorado Avalanche at McNichols Arena.

title: Arts Abroad; In Vienna (Where Else?), a Show on Art and Insanity
description: Given the recent vogue for art by the insane and the fact that early 20th-century Vienna was the hothouse for psychoanalytic thought, the season's major art show here, ''Art and Insanity,'' seems a natural fit of idea and place.

title: Jersey City Schools Show Much Improvement
description: Jersey City's public schools have improved enough to justify returning them to local control as early as the fall of 1999, the state-appointed superintendent of schools, Richard DiPatri, said yesterday. He said that district scores on the High School Proficiency Test had risen significantly compared with those of other poor urban districts since the state took over Jersey City schools in 1989. Attendance has improved, he said, increasing to a daily average of 91.3 percent in the 1996-97 school year from 89.4 percent the previous year.

title: Contrasts for Democrats Are Stark in 2 Counties
description: In the traditional Republican bastions of New York City's suburbs, Tuesday night's election tallies signaled stark contrasts in Democratic fortunes: a stunning victory in Westchester but crushing losses in Nassau.

title: Financial Crisis Leaves Asian Leaders Shaky
description: SINGAPORE  The forced resignation of Thailand's prime minister is a warning to other leaders in the region that they need a strong base of political support and a credible policy to weather an economic downturn, especially since the International Monetary Fund and investors are insisting on painful reforms, officials and analysts say.

title: Toy Market Sees Green and Purple Holidays
description: That annoying purple dinosaur has teamed up with Bill Gates, that first-time dad, to go interactive. Holiday Barbie has a dye job -- she is a brunette for the first time. And youngsters are bonding in a big way with electronic key chains that need to eat, sleep and study.

title: Judge is Given Names of Accused Generals
description: Lawyers for Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney prepared today to make good on their threat to expose high-ranking Army officers who have been not been punished by the Army even though they have faced serious accusations of sexual misconduct.

title: Currents; CREATURE COMFORT -- Maurice Sendak's Very Extended Family
description: When the Gay Men's Health Crisis moved to its new offices at 119 West 24th Street, the group asked a favor of Maurice Sendak, the illustrator and author of ''Where the Wild Things Are'' (HarperCollins, 1963). Would he decorate the 1,200-square-foot Child's Life Room, a place where children with AIDS or H.I.V. (or whose parents are clients) can spend time with volunteers while their parents have appointments in the building? He said yes.

title: Acupuncture Panel Calls for Acceptance
description: An independent panel of experts concluded yesterday that the ancient practice of acupuncture was an effective therapy for certain medical conditions, especially those involving nausea and pain, and should be integrated into standard medical practice for these problems.

title: Review/Fashion; Finding Motifs On Other Shores
description: American sportswear may have infiltrated many parts of the world with its ease and understatement, but American designers have also been inspired by other cultures. Asia, Africa and even Europe are being referenced by adventurous designers. This is manifesting itself in the current spring shows in a new accent on adding, rather than subtracting, and in experimentation with ways of cutting and draping fabric.

title: S.E.C. Contends Five Profited From Illegal Insider Trading
description: A former compliance officer for the Bankers Trust Securities Corporation, his brother and three others were charged yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission with netting $458,200 from illegal insider trading related to a tender offer by the ITT Corporation for Caesars World Inc. in 1994.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, HARRISON
description: ROTH-Harrison. Harry was a friend and a client from day one. His keen understanding of the options market and his assistance in enhancing our product will be sorely missed. Condolences to his family and to his friends. Barry Hertz, President Track Data Corporation

title: Monacelli Continues His Winning Ways
description: Amleto Monacelli rolled three strikes in the final frame to come from behind and win the Ebonite Challenge in Chesapeake, Va., his second title in three weeks.

title: Big Victory, but Gains For Mayor Are Modest
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani may be far more popular now than he was four years ago, but a detailed analysis of his re-election victory on Tuesday shows that his base of support was strikingly similar to what it was in 1993, with only a few significant inroads into new neighborhoods or demographic groups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZ, BELLA (NEE LEVI)
description: HERZ-Bella (nee Levi) Age 92. On November 3, 1997. Beloved mother of Larry and the late Karen. Devoted mother-in-law of Carol. Adored Oma to Jon and Eric. Her love, valor and tireless energy will be greatly missed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Three of the grandparents of CHARLES F. DOLAN came from Ireland, but the only one he knew as a child was the fourth, the grandmother who had immigrated from Germany. ''German was the second language in the house for years,'' he said. ''It took me a while to recognize that I had something to do with Irish.''

title: MAIL-ORDER GROUP AGREES TO COLLECT STATE SALES TAXES
description: The coming holiday season could be the last for a cherished loophole that lets mail-order shoppers avoid paying sales taxes on purchases from out-of-state companies.

title: With Proposal on Tobacco, Quest for Safe Cigarettes
description: When the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company recently test-marketed a new cigarette throughout Oklahoma in packages of its Winston Select brand, it quietly promoted the product as having a special ''flavor'' filter that improved its taste.

title: Consolidated Plans to Buy No. 2 Discount Store Chain
description: The Consolidated Stores Corporation said yesterday that it would buy Mac Frugal's Bargain Close-Outs Inc. for as much as $995 million in stock, creating a nationwide chain of stores that sell goods at discount prices.

title: Princeton (4-3) Plays on the Road and Likes It
description: For more than a century, Princeton football teams have been known as the Tigers, mainly because of the orange and black striped jerseys the players wore during their early years.

title: For the Jets, It's Now First and Foley
description: With his team in first place in a season of revival and promise, Jets Coach Bill Parcells made the bold decision today to bench Neil O'Donnell, the veteran quarterback who had started every game, and replace him with the backup Glenn Foley.

title: Professional Help
description: I'd like to paint the floor myself.

title: Advantage, Republicans They Talk of 'National Reach' for Next Year After Successful Off-Year Elections in the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans have won the key contests in off-year elections, with Newt Gingrich, speaker of the House, declaring Wednesday that the victories would provide the party with "national reach" in full array of elections next year.

title: Toddler Killed; Brooklyn Boy Is Charged
description: An 18-month-old Brooklyn boy who was left in the care of neighbors on Tuesday when his mother went into labor was accidentally killed by the neighbors' 12-year-old son, the police said.

title: JP FOODSERVICE TO REDUCE AMOUNT OF STOCK FOR RYKOFF
description: JP Foodservice Inc. said yesterday that it would reduce the amount of stock it issues in its acquisition of Rykoff-Sexton Inc., valuing the food service company at $1.4 billion, including debt. Under the new deal, Rykoff shareholders will get 0.775 share of JP Foodservice for each Rykoff common share, down from 0.84 JP Foodservice share. The amendment reflected a $3 increase in the share price of JP Foodservice since the deal was made June 30. JP Foodservice is assuming about $670 million in Rykoff debt. JP Foodservice said yesterday that it had also acquired the Outwest Meat Company, a Las Vegas meat distributor with 1996 sales of $62 million. Shares of Rykoff rose $1.875, to $23.

title: Two Deals by Staffmark
description: Staffmark Inc. agreed today to acquire RHS Associates Inc. and the Emjay Companies, two information-technology recruiting firms. Terms were not disclosed. Staffmark, based in Fayetteville, provides diversified staffing services to businesses; it has full-year revenue of $198.4 million. RHS, of Birmingham, Ala., has $9 million in annual revenue. Emjay Contract Services and Emjay Computer Careers, with offices in Houston and Atlanta, have annual revenues of about $11 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPPENHEIM, JACOB KARL
description: PAPPENHEIM-Jacob Karl. The leadership and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Jacob Karl Pappenheim, an ardent supporter of the Jewish community in Israel and Switzerland, and a beloved husband, father, grandfather, and great grandfather. His sister, Erica Jesselson, is a valued and devoted member of UJA-Federation's Board of Directors. Erica and her late husband, Ludwig, have received international recognition as extraordinary Jewish communal leaders and philanthropists. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: With Big Issues Absent, The Little Things Count
description: Forget the post-mortems about ideological shifts, Republican revivals or which candidate had the most money. The legacy of the off, off-year elections on Tuesday may simply be this: Think small.

title: Albright Says Consensus Is Emerging on the Future of U.S. Troops in Bosnia
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that ''a consensus is developing'' between the Administration and Congress that American troops will be needed in Bosnia after the mandate of the current NATO-led force expires next June.

title: Clinton Offers Programs, Seeking Votes in House for Trade Bill
description: Scrambling to entice Democrats to support enhanced trade negotiating authority for President Clinton, the White House offered programs today to aid workers and communities hurt by future trade agreements.

title: Metro Matters; Sharpton And Coalitions Old and New
description: ALMOST from the beginning, Ruth W. Messinger was stuck between a rock and Al Sharpton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DASKALOPOULOS, GEORGE
description: DASKALOPOULOS-George. Beloved husband of Potoula. Loving father of Joan Selby. Grandfather of Alexis, Theodore and George. A dear and generous friend to many; he will be missed. Reposing Basis Funeral Home, Inc., 27-12 23rd Avenue, Astoria, NY, Thursday 10AM-12 Noon. Service to follow. In lieu of flowers, donations to Make-A-Wish Foundation, would be greatly appreciated.

title: After Nonappearance, Donna Hanover Returns to Work
description: Donna Hanover is to return to work this morning as a correspondent for ''Good Day New York,'' the local news program on WNYW-TV from 7 to 9 A.M., after a nearly two-month leave of absence she took to avoid an appearance of conflict with the campaign of her husband, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGAN, PHYLLIS R. (NEE PIZZOLANELLA)
description: EGAN-Phyllis R. (nee Pizzolanella) on November 5, 1997. Beloved wife of Eugene. Loving mother of Michael and Ellen Montleone. Dear daughter of the late Michael and Carmela Pizzolanella. Beloved sister of Dolores Malizio, Norma Cody, Celeste Palumbo and the late Vivian Gagliano. Cherished grandmother of Stuart and Edward. Reposing David J. Hodder & Son Funeral Home, 899 McLean Avenue, (near Kimball Avenue), Yonkers. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:45am, Saint Barnabas Church. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Canadian Court Puts Bre-X in Bankruptcy
description: Bre-X Minerals Ltd. was put into bankruptcy today by the Court of Queen's Bench of Alberta.

title: After Guilty Plea, Former Head Of OTB Quits as SUNY Trustee
description: Three weeks after pleading guilty to stealing $13,000 from a cancer-stricken employee of the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation, the agency's former president, Hazel N. Dukes, resigned from the State University of New York's board, a SUNY vice chancellor said last night.

title: In One Manic Soul, The Incarnation of New York on the Edge
description: About 10 minutes into Joseph Edward's ''Fly,'' starring the playwright, you begin to think it would be no more startling to see him stretch out his arms and soar above you -- something he thinks his fetish, a portable pyramid, will empower him to do one day -- than it is to see the springs and struts and minute-to-minute transformations he performs. His character, called Fly, is a young black man on a Brooklyn rooftop wound up so tight by energy, anger, longing and confusion that he careens along the edges of his midair platform like a dervish on a high wire.

title: Foreign Affairs ; Head Shot
description: When you think about how the U.S. should respond to Saddam Hussein's latest attempt to evade U.N. sanctions, just keep this in mind: Saddam Hussein is the reason God created cruise missiles. Cruise missiles are simply the only way to deal with him.

title: An Islander Builder Arrives
description: Although National Hockey League approval of the purchase of the Islanders is not expected until early next year, the group that has agreed to buy the franchise took a crucial step today in preparing for the takeover.

title: Preseason Tourney Ushers in New Rules
description: When college basketball begins next Tuesday night with the Ikon Classic preseason tournament in East Rutherford, N.J., four playing rules will be introduced for men. One will be permanent, while the others will be experimental and in force only until Dec. 1.

title: Imagine Seamless Cities
description: To the Editor:

title: Spotless Start (3-0) Is a First For Nets
description: The subject of Coach John Calipari's pre-game sermon was about breaking down barriers.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''For the first 20 years I was in New York, I was ignored by the radio and television museum,'' DON IMUS said yesterday. Not any longer. The Museum of Television and Radio held a seminar yesterday with Mr. Imus and six staff members from his syndicated radio program, including the producer, BERNARD McGUIRK. ROBERT M. BATSCHA, the president of the museum, moderated an hourlong question-and-answer session.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RICHARDS, JESS
description: RICHARDS-Jess. November 6, 1994 Always in my heart, Melanie

title: U.S. Trade Sanctions Appealed by NEC
description: The NEC Corporation and its American subsidiary said today that they had appealed United States trade sanctions to the Court of International Trade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEFFERNAN, VERONICA E.
description: HEFFERNAN-Veronica E. Retired Chief of Payroll Department of Probation, NYC Family Court. Wife of the late Professor Christopher J. Heffernan. Mother of Noreen A. Danko, Christopher E. Heffernan, Joan L. Padian. Mother-in-law of Patrick R. Padian. Grandmother of Elizabeth and Thomas Sexton, Valerie and Ernest Tumminello, Robert Danko, Thomas and Lynn Padian. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM Thursday and Friday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Saturday, November 8 at 10AM.

title: Health Care Lobbyists Are Behind the Curve
description: To the Editor:

title: Evolving From Ideology Toward Pragmatism
description: The decisive re-election of a Republican mayor in a Democratic city on Tuesday was, for all its breadth and drama, something short of a sudden transformation of New York City's politics. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's election was more the culmination of a slow evolution that began 20 years ago: a triumph of nuts-and-bolts pragmatism over the ideology and party loyalty that once ruled elections in New York.

title: A Famous Battle, Usually Distorted
description: MONITOR

title: Trust Our State Courts to Defend Civil Liberties
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 26 about the debate over the death penalty in Massachusetts misstated the affiliation of an opponent, William Keach. He is the state organizer for the Campaign to End the Death Penalty, not director of the state chapter of another group, Citizens Against the Death Penalty.

title: Girl in H.I.V. Case Is Held on Drug Charges
description: A girlfriend of a man suspected of knowingly infecting young women with the AIDS virus has been arrested on suspicion of selling crack cocaine in Chautauqua County, the police in Jamestown said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, WILLIAM J.
description: RYAN-William J. On November 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Kathleen Healey Ryan. Devoted father of Tom and Cathy Ryan, Mary and Gerry Bambrick, Kathleen Ryan and Richard Ayoub, Eileen and Chris Moran, William M. Ryan and Patrick and Kristen Ryan. Loving grandfather of James, Tricia, Chris, Sheila, Danny, Ricky, Meggie and Mary Kate. Dear brother of Edward and Catherine Ryan, John B. and Jeanette Ryan. Teacher of many. Friends may call at The Abbey, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St Thursday 2-5 and 79PM. Funeral Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th St Friday 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Saint David's School.

title: Whitman Pleased at Victory In New Jersey, However Slim
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman put the bravest and most optimistic face possible on her narrow victory today, saying that the election that almost ended her political career was, in fact, a triumph.

title: GIULIANI CREDITS MINORITY VOTERS FOR WIDE MARGIN
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani turned his attention yesterday to his second term, beginning the process of revamping his cabinet and claiming a broad mandate from New Yorkers, including increased support from many black and Hispanic neighborhoods that shunned him four years ago.

title: Oct. 27 Drop Nearly Erased As Dow Rises
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rebounded yesterday to where it was before last week's 554-point plunge, but could not hold on to the gains. The Dow ended up just 3.44 points, at 7,692.57.

title: UConn Is Favored, As Is Syracuse
description: A preseason coaches' poll chose St. John's to finish second behind Connecticut in the Big East Six division of the Big East Conference, and the Red Storm's senior guard, Felipe Lopez, said he would not let expectations weigh him down.

title: Ralph Rogers, 87, Philantropist Who Led and Defended PBS
description: Ralph Burton Rogers, a former chairman of the Public Broadcasting Service who helped defend the organization against attacks by President Richard M. Nixon in the 1970's, died on Tuesday at his home in Dallas. He was 87.

title: Bridge; A Squeeze and Endplay By Women's Team Champs
description: The American women's team that captured the Venice Cup title at the world championships in Hammamet, Tunisia, last week won the final relatively easily, by 60 imps against China. But Mildred Breed, Tobi Sokolow, Lisa Berkowitz, Marinesa Letizia, Randi Montin and Jill Meyers had to survive two hard battles earlier. They won their semifinal by just 5 imps against an American squad, headed by Kathie Wei-Sender, and their quarterfinal by 24 against Italy, pulling away at the finish in a match that had been close throughout.

title: Calendar; Talks and Exhibitions
description: Tallest Tale

title: While Diplomats Talk, Iraq Is Said to Hide Arms Evidence
description: As the United Nations gives Iraq an opportunity to talk about settling the crisis over United Nations weapons inspections, President Saddam Hussein is using the time to hide evidence and disable surveillance equipment, the head of the disarmament commission told the Security Council today.

title: Chiefs Sign Tolliver
description: The Chiefs signed the free-agent quarterback Billy Joe Tolliver to a two-year contract, two days after their starter, Elvis Grbac, broke his left collarbone Monday night during the Chiefs' 13-10 victory over Pittsburgh. Grbac will be out at least a month.

title: Failed Campaign Aside, McGreevey Ponders 2001
description: Unbowed by the first political defeat of his life, State Senator James E. McGreevey said today that he would ''most probably'' run for governor again in four years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROWES, BERNARD
description: ROWES-Bernard. On November 3, 1997. My father, a self-made man under the tutelage of Tevel Kaleko, rose from the obscurity of an orphan to great prominence in the diamond industry. In love for 56 years with his wife Emily, he doted on his son, grandchildren and cared for his friends as family. Barbara Rowes, Daughter

title: WHOLE FOODS TO BUY MERCHANT OF VINO FOR $41 MILLION
description: Whole Foods Market Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Merchant of Vino for $41.2 million in stock, expanding its natural-foods supermarkets into the Detroit area. Whole Foods will buy Merchant of Vino for 1.03 million shares of Whole Foods stock. Merchant of Vino owns four natural-foods supermarkets and two wine and gourmet stores in the Detroit area. The company had sales of $42 million in the 10 months ended Oct. 31. Whole Foods, based in Austin, Tex., is the nation's largest chain of natural-foods supermarkets, with 76 stores in 17 states. Whole Foods shares rose 6.25 cents, to $40.0625.

title: Organic Clothing: On Backs, Not Minds
description: Americans cannot seem to get enough organic food. Consumption of fruits and vegetables grown without pesticides or chemical fertilizers has soared 20 percent a year since 1990, creating a $2.5 billion industry.

title: Trade Secrets; Paint, Stain or Collage Makes a Floor a Canvas
description: THE FLOOR, as designers often point out, is a room's fifth wall. No one embraces this notion more fervantly or audaciously than Veva Crozer, a floor designer in Greenwich, Conn., who doesn't own a single rug.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDEL, MORRIS
description: HENDEL-Morris. On November 4th, 1997. Age 96. Beloved husband of Lillian. Loving father of Edward Hendel and Joan Esses-Scheier. Loving step-father of Ruth Factor. Beloved grandfather of Steven and David Hendel, and Jerome and Allen Esses. Proud greatgrandfather of Sarah, Emily, Michael, Elizabeth, Marc and Samuel Hendel, and Adam and Zachary Esses. Devoted brother of Stefanie Wilner, Evelyn Fishalow, and Stanley Hendel. Associated with Owners & Tenants Electric Co, Inc for 60 years, including 41 years as president. Private services.

title: Voters Refuse to Take Chances On Bond Act and Convention
description: In the defeat of a state constitutional convention and a school construction bond act on Tuesday, many New York lawmakers and political analysts today saw an emphatic demonstration of the depth of voter cynicism about state government.

title: The Smithsonian Receives a Gift of $20 Million
description: Kenneth E. Behring, a California real estate developer and the former owner of the Seattle Seahawks of the National Football League, said this evening that he would donate $20 million in cash to the Smithsonian Institution, the largest grant in the 151-year history of the national museum system.

title: Lights, Camera, Auction: A Design
description: It might be the most unusual presale exhibition organized by an auction house.

title: Market Place: Red-Hot Revival in Real Estate; Overheating Is Feared With Surge in Vulture Investing
description: In the world of professional real estate investing, no one is flying higher than Wall Street's vulture funds, which in the early 1990's swooped in to buy distressed properties whose values have since soared as the economy has recovered.

title: Mills's Role Off Bench A Jump-Start for Knicks
description: This is an unfamiliar process for Chris Mills. He has never had to spring off the bench, cold, and provide instant offense.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BLOUNT INTERNATIONAL INC., Montgomery, Ala., a maker of outdoor, industrial, power and sports equipment, has acquired Pentair Inc.'s sporting goods ammunition unit, Federal Cartridge Co., for $112 million in cash.

title: Brewers Cleared to Shift To N.L. Central in '98
description: The Milwaukee Brewers, as expected, are moving to the National League.

title: Negotiators End Effort for Accord on Bill to Limit Damage Awards
description: After coming to the brink of agreement, negotiators for the White House, business interests and the Senate today conceded that they will be unable to enact legislation this year to limit damage awards to people harmed by products as diverse as toasters, cardiac pacemakers and tractors.

title: 'Memory' Therapy Leads to a Lawsuit And Big Settlement
description: While undergoing psychiatric therapy at a Chicago hospital from 1986 to 1992, Patricia Burgus says, she was convinced by doctors that she had memories of being part of a satanic cult, being sexually abused by numerous men and abusing her own two sons.

title: MAPLE LEAF FOODS PLANS TO ACQUIRE SCHNEIDER OF CANADA
description: Maple Leaf Foods Inc. said yesterday that it had offered to acquire the Schneider Corporation, a Canadian meat processor, for $19 (Canadian) a share, or about $130 million (Canadian), or $92 million (United States). Maple Leaf, the largest food-processing concern in Canada, has annual sales of more than $3 billion (Canadian). Schneider, based in Kitchener, Ontario, has annual sales of about $800 million (Canadian). Maple Leaf said its cash offer for all of the common shares and class A shares of Schneider was at a premium of 40 percent for Schneider's common shares and 43 percent for its class A shares based on their average trading prices to Oct. 31. The combined company would have total estimated sales of about $4 billion (Canadian).

title: At Hunter, a Coach Aims to Rekindle a Spirit
description: Mike Brown used to love Big East Media Day. Like autumn leaves turning, Media Day marked the crucial demarcation where scrimmage turned into practice. As a Seton Hall assistant basketball coach for nine years and as an aide at West Virginia for another three years, Brown saw Media Day as the engine roaring at the starting post.

title: Gun-Control Measure Is Decisively Rejected
description: Gun advocates around the country took heart yesterday in their long struggle with gun-control advocates after Tuesday's decisive defeat of a Washington State ballot initiative that would have required safety tests for handgun owners and trigger locks on handguns.

title: A Lack of Order In the Court
description: Lawyers for the New Jersey Nets and Dan Garcia, a reporter who sued Coach John Calipari for cursing him last spring, squabbled yesterday over how cooperative the team has been in providing information in the pre-trial discovery phase.

title: Robert Bleiberg, 73, Ex-Editor And a Top Executive at Barron's
description: Robert M. Bleiberg, who retired in 1991 after long service as editor, publisher and editorial director of Barron's, the weekly business and financial newspaper, died Monday at New York Hospital. The cause of death was leukemia, according to Dow Jones & Company, which publishes Barron's and The Wall Street Journal.

title: Duval's Success on Tour Gives Him New Esteem
description: After winning his last three golf tournaments, David Duval has learned something.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELGORT, MILTON
description: ELGORT-Milton. Beloved husband of the late Ruthe. Devoted father of Stephen Sanford Elgort and Vicki S. Elgort-Rosen. Dear brother of Beatrice Chase. Adored grandfather of David Alan Rosen, Jessica Beth Rosen and Sara Michelle Elgort, Jeremy Elgort and, ''the Music Man'' for the seniors. Services Thursday 10AM at the Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opposite LIRR.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUNICK, CARL
description: TUNICK-Carl. Sincerest condolences to the family of our respected Carl Tunick. It was our honor to have known him these many years. 425 Park Avenue Company Milton A. Horowitz, Gen'l Partner

title: Death Penalty Is Ruled Out in the Slaying of Jonathan Levin
description: Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, announced yesterday that he would not seek the death penalty for the man accused of killing a popular high school teacher, Jonathan M. Levin, during a robbery in May.

title: Affirmative Action in Play
description: The Supreme Court's most momentous decision of the current term may turn out to be its refusal this week to hear a challenge to the constitutionality of California's anti-affirmative-action initiative, Proposition 209. The Court's sidestep allows California to proceed unimpeded with its rollback of remedies that are, regrettably, still needed to address the nation's persistent problem of race and gender discrimination. It may also encourage other states to follow California.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Mail-Order Merchants In Tax Deal With States

title: People
description: * Richard O'Brien, vice chairman and worldwide client services director at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., left to join Special Olympics International, Washington, in the new position of executive vice president.

title: Design Notebook; Native American Quilts Rejuvenate a Tradition
description: IN 1947, so the story goes, Tessie Four Times, a doting grandmother on the Fort Peck Indian Reservation in Brockton, Mont., expressed pride in her grandson's basketball playing by wiping the sweat from his back with a shawl and then casting it onto the gym floor.

title: Tycoon Purged From Kremlin as Reform Battle Heats Up
description: In an apparent effort to loosen the stranglehold of the Russian oligarchy, President Boris N. Yeltsin dismissed one of Russia's most powerful tycoons from high Government office today.

title: Paterson Police Chief Is Accused of Insults
description: Paterson's Police Chief was suspended without pay on Tuesday after he called Mayor Martin G. Barnes a ''liar and a thief'' at a political rally, city officials said yesterday. Chief Vincent Amoresano was accused of violating a rule barring police officers from taking part in political campaigns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, JACK
description: GILBERT-Jack. Beloved husband of Lillian, devoted father of Barbara Gilbert Stein, Larry and Barbara Gilbert, devoted brother of Milton and Harold, adored grandfather of Jacqueline, Danielle, David, and Alyssa. Services Wednesday 10 A.M. at The Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opp LIRR. For information call The Riverside at 516-487-9600.

title: Modern Masters of Collecting; From One Couple's Treasures, One Important Auction
description: For the last two weekends, more than 1,000 people a day have been visiting Christie's Park Avenue salesroom. Dealers and collectors, museum experts and art lovers, they have been drawn by an extraordinary group of works by just five artists: Picasso, Jasper Johns, Robert Rauschenberg, Frank Stella and Eva Hesse. They were collected by Victor and Sally Ganz, a quiet Manhattan couple who spent their Saturdays perusing galleries wherever they happened to be.

title: Good Day for The Staus Quo
description: Incumbents, and the incumbent party, generally did well in state and local elections on Tuesday, and efforts to change the laws or raise taxes in referendums were turned back almost everywhere. Winners are in bold face; where no party affiliation is given, elections were nonpartisan. New York and New Jersey results begin on page B2.

title: Companies Reported Spending More on Research
description: Pushing to develop new products, or new twists on old ones, American companies increased their spending on research to $118.65 billion last year, 9 percent more than in 1995, the National Science Foundation reported yesterday. Another big jump is projected for this year as companies seek to sustain sales by offering something new to consumers.

title: Classical Music and Dance Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.

title: Capitalizing on Rule-Breaking and 3 Dancers' Power
description: With its opening gala behind it, American Ballet Theater got a new repertory season off the ground Wednesday night with a formidable vehicle for three phenomenal dancers.

title: A Soul Rotten or Tortured?
description: Rock's first British Invasion, in the 1960's, was a rush of youthful exuberance. Its current one, with bands like Oasis, Radiohead, Blur and Pulp, projects the opposite: an end-of-the-empire, end-of-the-century disillusionment merged with the self-absorption of a prolonged adolescence. The Verve, a band that is beloved in England and catching on in the United States, came to Irving Plaza for a sold-out two-night stand that started on Wednesday, using the heft and resonance of its guitars to make self-pity sound like tragic nobility.

title: YACHTING: A SAILOR'S JOURNAL -- WHITBREAD ROUND THE WORLD RACE; Learning a Lesson at Sea
description: Ten yachts, all about 64 feet in length with a maximum crew of 12, completed the grueling first leg of the Whitbread Round the World Race from Southampton, England, to Cape Town. The 31,600-nautical-mile race restarts on Saturday for a 4,700-nautical mile voyage from Cape Town to Fremantle, Australia. The route is through the treacherous Southern ocean, where wind and weather conditions are brutish as they are capricious. The competitors are hoping the trip will take about 16 days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, SCHUYLER
description: MEYER-Schuyler. In loving memory of our gentle and gracious friend, a true ''honorary member'' of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd. We treasure his friendship and remember his generous support of our work. Both at Good Shepherd Services and Center for Family Life, Schuyler has left a rich legacy of help and hope for children and families. We extend our prayers and condolences to his family and the Edwin Gould Foundation. The Sisters of the Good Shepherd

title: Huizenga Sticks to Plan To Sell His Champions
description: Not even the euphoria of winning the World Series could alter the state of H. Wayne Huizenga's business mind. Huizenga, who built successful businesses before he built a monopoly in South Florida sports, yesterday reaffirmed his decision to sell the Florida Marlins, who became baseball's champions in only the fifth year of their existence.

title: Suspension of Principal Saves a Charter School
description: A wrenching episode involving assault, racial epithets and the future of a beloved charter school in the District of Columbia ended today with a compromise that disciplined the principal but kept the school open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASTORE, EMIL M.
description: PASTORE-Emil M. Died November 5, 1997 in Fla. at age 91. Born in Italy, September 26, 1906 he immigrated to Waterbury, CT in 1912. He graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Amherst College in 1928 and received his masters in history in 1929. His career was at the New York Telephone Company and AT&T, retiring as V.P. of New York Telephone in 1966. He is survived by his wife, Virginia S. Pastore, his children Richard Pastore, Susan Rollinson, Grace Boyd and John Pastore, his fourteen grand and twelve great-grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLNER, ROSE (GOLDSHEIN)
description: WILLNER-Rose (Goldshein). On Nov. 4,1997. Widow of Ben Willner. Beloved mother of Mark and Arthur. Dear mother-in-law of Sheila and Susan. Adoring grandmother of Jordana and Shoshanna. A woman of valor. Services Fri. 11am ''The Riverside'', 76 St.& Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers donations to Dorot appreciated.

title: Couple Found Dead In Murder and Suicide
description: The State Police and the Somers Police Department are investigating an apparent murder and suicide.

title: A Rising Disquiet Among the Bogs; Environmental Worries Block Plan by New Jersey Farmers To Expand Cranberry Fields
description: Steve Lee watched the rising water flood the sunken cranberry fields, gently buoying the vine-tethered crop. Then the harvesting machines rolled through, shaking the berries loose to float on the surface like a vermilion carpet.

title: Art in Review
description: Cheryl Donegan

title: Off-Track on Trade
description: President Clinton has lobbied the House furiously for so-called fast-track trade-negotiating authority, which allows Congress the right to approve or disapprove trade agreements, but not amend them.

title: ''E.R.'s'' Cost-Containment Crisis
description: When its current contract with NBC expires, Warner Brothers reportedly plans to ask $10 million for the license to air a single episode of its hit show ''E.R.'' That is a record. At 22 to 25 episodes per season, licensing ''E.R.'' could cost NBC or one of its competitors nearly $500 million for a two-year contract, or the equivalent of NBC's annual profit.

title: 3 Aid Groups For Refugees Are Charged With Fraud
description: To the unemployed refugees who were its clients, the Albanian American Civic Association in the Bronx seemed to offer a much-needed helping hand. When they visited its storefront on Astor Avenue, they would receive stacks of brochures, chat with a ''job developer'' and fill out detailed forms. Then they would go home to await calls for job interviews.

title: Seat Sold for $1.5 Million
description: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange sold this week for a record $1.5 million. The seat sold for $25,000 more than the previous high, set on July 31. Owning one of the 1,366 stock exchange seats is the admission ticket to trade stocks on the world's largest stock exchange and vote at exchange meetings.

title: An Employee On Wall St. Is Arrested
description: Prosecutors said yesterday that they had arrested a brokerage firm employee responsible for protecting market-sensitive information and charged her with using the information to profit from insider trading.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NORWICK, DOUGLAS J.
description: NORWICK-Douglas J. Your star burns brightly and your spirit dances on. Always love. Herbert J. Baker

title: Review/Fashion; Invoking Tribal Spirits as 90's Muses
description: The style tribe as a concept is gaining currency. It explains the splintering of fashion as it becomes more susceptible to a range of influences from the street, the runway and a variety of cultures. It also dovetails with designers' refreshing new tendency to subordinate trends in favor of an individual statement on style.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, ROBERT S.
description: SHAW-Robert S. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Robert S. Shaw, a member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Victor D. Ziminsky, Jr., Pres. Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: Theater Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were available at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth last weekend for last Friday and Saturday nights' performances. ++ means discounted tickets were available for Friday night only.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STACK, ELIZABETH V.
description: STACK-Elizabeth V. on November 5, 1997 of Plandome, NY. Beloved wife of the late James A. Jr. Loving mother of Russell, Eileen, Elizabeth, Mary Jayne, the late Richard and the late James A. III. Also survived by 8 grandchildren and 5 great-grandchildren. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Friday 3-5 and 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass 10:30 am Saturday St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Iraq Takes Advantage
description: While Secretary General Kofi Annan's emissaries are petitioning Saddam Hussein to lift his ban on Americans participating on United Nations arms inspection teams, Iraq has been disabling surveillance cameras and moving suspicious materials and equipment out of the inspectors' view. This new interference could mask an effort to produce biological weapons on the sly and will undermine the long-term credibility of the arms monitoring effort. Even if they return, the inspectors will have to restart many of their monitoring efforts from scratch, greatly delaying completion of their work.

title: Aloofness Is the Least of Their Problems
description: ''Cold Around the Heart'' may have looked good on paper, but on screen it's not a hot property.

title: Give Clinton 'Fast Track,' or We'll Pay the Price; Victims of Globalism
description: To the Editor;

title: Art Dealer Pleads Guilty to Fraud
description: Todd Michael Volpe, a well-known Manhattan art dealer who built a reputation advising Hollywood celebrities like Jack Nicholson on building their collections, pleaded guilty yesterday to five counts of wire fraud, admitting in some cases that he sold artwork belonging to clients and kept the money himself.

title: For Family's Second Son, A Solemn Police Farewell
description: Once more the bagpipes skirled, once more police officers in dress blues solemnly lined the streets, and for the second time in two months, the Fitzgerald family of Pelham Manor, N.Y., gathered here today to bury a son who had served in the New York City Police Department and died an untimely, unnatural death.

title: CHRONICLE
description: STEPHEN SWID, chairman of the Municipal Art Society for 12 years, stepped down yesterday.

title: Asia Drop Sends Shivers Through Builders
description: Engineering and construction companies the world over salivated when Southeast Asia planned some of the world's tallest skyscrapers, the world's longest building, an Asian Silicon Valley, mega-scale dams, dozens of power plants, thousands of miles of roads and numerous refineries, railroads, water systems and airports.

title: Price of Long Bond Rises a Bit as Auctions Stir Demand
description: Treasury bonds with long maturities bounced back from early weakness yesterday to finish higher for a second day, after the Government's quarterly debt refunding concluded with strong demand. Shorter maturities lagged, however, and ended the session mixed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDBERG, BENITA
description: GOLDBERG-Benita. I feel your star shining down on me and see you smiling back at me. Pleasant dreams Superstar, Love, Me

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LUCENT TECHNOLOGIES CORP., Murray Hill, N.J., will close its Huizen, Netherlands, manufacturing plant and lay off 702 workers because more efficient technology had reduced the number of plants it needed.

title: Metro Business; Bell Atlantic Applies For Long Distance
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation says it has applied to New York to offer long-distance telephone service, seeking to be the first regional Bell company to offer such service.

title: Sour Taste of Nafta: Old Friends Become Foes
description: For Representative Scotty Baesler of Kentucky, the turning point came last summer when Fruit of the Loom announced that thousands of workers in his state would be laid off and the jobs moved to Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERTIG, HILDA L.
description: FERTIG-Hilda L. Beloved wife of Felix. Loving mother of Ann Freedman and Mack Fertig. Devoted sister of Barbara Newmark. Cherished mother-in-law of Lisa Fertig and Robert Freedman. Adored grandmother of Jessica Freedman and Sara, Eric and Amy Fertig. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Gladney Center, 2300 Hemphill, Ft Worth, TX 76110. Funeral services Friday, 12:00 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 333 Amsterdam Ave (bet 75th and 76th St).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACE, COREEN E. (NEE COLEMAN)
description: WALLACE-Coreen E. (nee Coleman) November 5, 1997. Beloved wife of James, mother of Frank, Jay and Ellen Wallace and Coreen Wallace Scharfe. Devoted grandmother to eight loving grandchildren. Beloved aunt to Judson Lange. Services November 10th, 10am at St. George's Episcopal Church where she served on The Alter Guild, Choir and Choral Society for many years. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave, November 8th and 9th between 2-4pm and 7-9pm.

title: Jets May See Same Issue Same Time Next Week
description: Coach Bill Parcells's decision to bench Neil O'Donnell for Glenn Foley, despite the Jets' first-place status, was dramatic and unusual, but it actually surprised no one who has been around the coach. Even Foley, who hasn't even taken his first snap as the starting quarterback, conceded today the job is not permanent. Or that it might even last beyond Sunday.

title: A Lone Woman in the Forest? Is This a Neil Simon Play?
description: On most nights just after 8, a lone woman wanders onto the stage of the Broadhurst Theater with a marveling, slightly stunned expression. As she looks intently at the very sylvan setting around her, running her hands over a piece of rustic furniture, she seems to be asking a silent, probing question, one no doubt shared by much of the audience watching her: ''Hey, am I in the right place? I thought there was supposed to be a Neil Simon play going on here.''

title: Bronx and Staten Island Recover All Lost Jobs as Other Boroughs Lag
description: The Bronx and Staten Island are the first boroughs to recover all the jobs that were lost in the recession of the late 1980's and early 90's, a report on the city's economy said yesterday.

title: Americans Becoming Lax About High Blood Pressure
description: In a surprising reversal of longtime health gains, fewer adult Americans are aware they have high blood pressure, fewer are getting effective therapy, and more are dying as a result, Federal health officials said here today in issuing new treatment guidelines for the ailment, which affects 50 million Americans.

title: Park Service Selects Developers for Gettysburg
