description: The National Park Service today selected a group of developers to build a new visitor center, museum and large-screen theater within Gettysburg National Military Park, an expansion of park services that some preservationists call a commercial intrusion onto hallowed ground.

title: Suspect Killed in Princeton Bank Robbery
description: Police officers and F.B.I. agents swarmed the streets of Princeton, N.J., last night after a bank robbery that left an armed suspect dead, the police said. Two other armed suspects were at large.

title: Review/Fashion; The Evening Still Casts Its Spell
description: At times during the course of the New York fashion shows, you get the impression that designers think that come spring, American women will give up their jobs and their families to spend their days sleeping late and preening for big nights on the town. Why? Because evening clothes so often outnumber day clothes.

title: Giants' Calloway Blossoms Into a Very Feared Receiver
description: He is quiet in the locker room, quiet in the huddle, quiet just before the football is snapped, even if the cornerback across the line of scrimmage is chattering away or when the linebacker he is assigned to block is making menacing threats.

title: F.D.A. Warns About Herbs for Weight Loss
description: Two months after it forced the popular diet drug combination known as fen-phen off the market, the Food and Drug Administration today issued a consumer warning about the possible dangers of herbal weight loss cocktails, which are widely available in diet clinics and health food stores and over the Internet.

title: Cabaret Guide
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes highly recommended shows.

title: Angry Customers Hinder Mail-Order Tax Accord
description: Angry consumers took to the phones yesterday and told mail-order companies in no uncertain terms that they would not support an agreement that would require them to pay sales taxes on more of the goods they buy from catalogues.

title: Mail-Order Retailers Retreat on Tax Deal
description: Faced with protests from angry consumers, mail-order companies are backing away from a tentative agreement on sales taxes that their trade association had reached with tax authorities from a number of states.

title: BREED TO TAKE A PRETAX CHARGE OF ABOUT $300 MILLION
description: Breed Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it would take a second-quarter pretax charge of $250 million to $330 million, halt dividend payments and report a loss of 12 to 15 cents a share in its first quarter, which ended on Sept. 30. Breed, one of the world's largest manufacturers of automotive-safety systems and steering wheels, said the charge, to be booked in the quarter ending on Dec. 31, reflected the costs of cutting jobs and closing or selling manufacturing, sales and engineering plants in the United States, Europe and Asia. The cuts are expected to generate savings of $800 million in the next five years. Shares of Breed Technologies fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $22.0625

title: Art in Review
description: John Currin

title: U.S. Accuses Two of Selling Counterfeit Calder Artworks
description: There were telltale signs that might have tipped off connoisseurs: a smallish letter M near the base, and the mention of a French foundry with a name very similar to one where Alexander Calder had his works made.

title: Car Crash Kills 3 Students on Way to School
description: Three students on their way to high school were killed this morning when their car swerved on a narrow country road, hit a tree and caught fire, the police said.

title: Sarah Lawrence College To Name New President
description: Sarah Lawrence College is to officially announce today that its next president will be Michele Tolela Myers. Dr. Myers, 56, the president of Denison University in Ohio and chairwoman of the American Council of Education, will succeed Alice Stone Ilchman next August.

title: Loroupe Has Stress Fractures
description: Tegla Loroupe, the 24-year-old Kenyan woman who won the New York City Marathon in 1994 and 1995, has been found to have two serious stress fractures in her spine. She will undergo treatment that will not allow her to run for at least four months and not allow her to run a marathon for at least eight months.

title: Give Clinton 'Fast Track,' or We'll Pay the Price; Help Displaced Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Falls Against Pound On Surprise British Rate Rise
description: The dollar tumbled against the British pound yesterday after the Bank of England surprised financial markets by raising interest rates.

title: Antiques; The Clothing Not in Style But Above It
description: This year, a sexy, champagne-colored, silver-appliqued evening gown that Marilyn Monroe wore in the 1953 film ''How to Marry a Millionaire'' sold for $57,500 at Christie's Los Angeles, an auction record for a woman's movie costume. Very few vintage dresses sell for that much, although Sotheby's ''Paris a la Mode'' couture auction last week totaled $320,000, which was $90,000 above the sale's high estimate, according to Tiffany Dubin, Sotheby's fashion specialist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUNICK, CARL
description: TUNICK-Carl. The Trustees of the Painting Industry Insurance Fund mourn the death of Carl Tunick. His wise counsel and sound judge ment will endure and for that we are forever in his debt. Sandy Vagelatos, Co-Chair J. Brendan Murray, Co-Chair

title: Legislators Promise Overhaul of New Jersey Car Insurance
description: Two days after Gov. Christine Todd Whitman barely defeated a candidate who tried to harness voters' anger over high auto insurance rates, Republican legislative leaders promised today that they would push through major proposals to reduce premiums. But, they said, the solution would not be Mrs. Whitman's plan, and it would probably not happen until next year.

title: Chicago Takes 3 MetroStars
description: The MetroStars lost three players in yesterday's expansion draft by Major League Soccer's two new teams.

title: Stephen King and Simon & Schuster in Deal
description: The best-selling author Stephen King and Simon & Schuster struck a tentative deal yesterday to publish his novel ''Bag of Bones'' in an unconventional arrangement that will give the horror writer a share of nearly 50 percent of the profits.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Biology Gone Bad
description: At the center of the trouble between Iraq and the United Nations is the issue of genetically engineered biological weapons, or what some experts call ''black biology.'' Today, genetic engineering has become a normal part of the process of bioweapons development.

title: A Pas de Trois Across Moral Terrain
description: The sumptuously appointed London town houses and Venetian palazzos that dazzle the eye in ''The Wings of the Dove'' are just the trimmings in Iain Softley's spellbinding screen adaptation of Henry James's 1902 novel. Few films have explored the human face this searchingly and found such complex psychological topography. That's why ''The Wings of the Dove'' succeeds where virtually every other film translation of a James novel has stumbled.

title: Spaghetti Comedy With a Saucy Flavor
description: For anyone who might welcome a brief visit to Italy before winter sets in, Maria Tucci is the ideal cicerone in her bravura performance of the title role of ''Filumena,'' Eduardo De Filippo's witty and wise comedy on life, love and marriage alla Napolitana.

title: Who Is Courting the Flying Lady?
description: BY putting Rolls-Royce on the block, Vickers P.L.C. has set off a scramble among potential buyers for one of the world's best-known brands. The leading candidates are BMW and Daimler-Benz, the German auto makers, although others have stepped forward, including Mohamed al-Fayed, who owns Harrods in London.

title: TENNIS: ROUNDUP
description: AMERITECH CUP

title: Pop and Jazz Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Indonesian Currency Gets a Helping Hand
description: Indonesia, Japan and Singapore joined forces again yesterday to buy up the rupiah, pushing it as much as 3 percent higher against the dollar. The Indonesian rupiah rose to as high as 3,242.5 to the dollar compared with 3,312.5 at the close of Asian trading yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Sues to Block Long Island Radio Deal

title: Arnold Acquires Houston Herstek
description: Arnold Communications in Boston said yesterday that it had acquired Houston Herstek Favat, a Boston agency that was put up for sale in July after the loss of several accounts with billings estimated at $100 million. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THEODORE, ION
description: THEODORE-Ion. The Horace Mann School community expresses deep sorrow at the death of its beloved former Head of the Arts Department. He was a multitalented man-sculptor, athlete, philosopher, historian, thespian, naturalist-above all, he was a gentleman and a gentle man, a teacher and colleague who imparted as his lasting legacy a love of truth and art. We are indeed diminished by his loss. Michael D. Hess, HM '58 Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Uncertainty Puts Thailand in a Political and Economic Vacuum
description: Thailand's top leadership has all but ceased to function this week, with a welter of political parties battling for power after Prime Minister Chavalilt Yongchaiyudh announced his resignation on Monday.

title: Three States Investigating Sales Practices of Met Life
description: Regulators in Florida and Texas and the Attorney General in Massachusetts are investigating whether the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the nation's second-largest insurer, has misled tens of thousands of life insurance customers, increasing the costs of their coverage and promising benefits that many never got.

title: Topics of The Times; $2.4 Billion, Lost in the Maze
description: Disappointed supporters of a $2.4 billion statewide school construction initiative may be wondering how it went down to defeat when New York City residents, the bulk of the state's voters on Tuesday, supported it by a margin of over 70 percent. The answer is simple. That was 70 percent of those who actually voted on the school bond act, but most city voters didn't address the issue. They couldn't find it on their ballots.

title: Give Clinton 'Fast Track,' or We'll Pay the Price; Read the Report
description: To the Editor:

title: ITT Seeking More Bidding, With Board As Auctioneer
description: Continuing a multibillion-dollar chess match, the directors of the ITT Corporation said yesterday that they wanted the bidding between the Hilton Hotels Corporation and the Starwood Lodging Trust for control of the company to continue, and that they were best qualified to handle the auction process.

title: A Touch of Voodoo in a Steamy Eden
description: Louisiana's delta country has never looked more darkly, lusciously sensual than it does in ''Eve's Bayou,'' a Southern gothic soap opera, written and directed by Kasi Lemmons, that transcends the genre through the sheer rumbling force of its characters' passions. This powerfully acted supernatural fever dream, which suggests Tennessee Williams filtered through ''Oprah'' with a dash of voodoo, explores the ties that bind the women of the Batiste family, an affluent black clan who live what at first appears to be a robust fairy-tale existence in a steamy paradise.

title: Despite Sluggish Sales, Toyota Earnings Rise
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that earnings rose in the fiscal first half as cost cuts, growing exports to the United States and Europe, and the weaker yen made up for slack sales in Japan.

title: At the Movies; Grisham's Law Attracts Coppola
description: A little more than two years ago, Francis Ford Coppola walked into a shop at Kennedy International Airport to find some books to read on a flight to Paris. ''I had never read a John Grisham book, and when I saw 'The Rainmaker' on the stand, which was the No. 1 best seller, I decided to buy it,'' said Mr. Coppola, director of, among other films, ''The Godfather'' trilogy and ''Apocalypse Now.''

title: Home Video
description: Eschewing The Ordinary

title: Art in Review
description: Kate Millet

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the New York Stock Exchange's plan to replace a rule that made it difficult for companies to move their stocks to other markets misidentified the source of the first report of the development. It was Bloomberg News, not The Wall Street Journal.

title: Star-Crossed Cup: Singspiel Withdrawn
description: When Singspiel galloped down the backstretch for the first time early this morning, he appeared full of energy. Then he disappeared into the fog that enveloped Hollywood Park, and began a four-furlong workout intended as his final prep for Saturday's $2 million Breeders' Cup Turf.

title: In Mexico City's War on Crime, Citizens Are Armed and Angry
description: A Mexican woman formed a defense group for assault victims two years ago after she was hurled to the ground and pistol-whipped by two armed robbers in a bustling department store at midday.

title: Fluffing Up Warhol: Where Art and Fashion Intersect
description: Andy Warhol, who died in 1987, remains one of the most provocative American artists of the postwar years. It is almost impossible not to have complicated feelings about him -- as a cultural figure he was as repellent as he was attractive -- but his influence on contemporary art and thinking has been immense and continues to grow.

title: Movie Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Running times and ratings of films are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 9.

title: Florentine Treasure at Smith College
description: A rare-book auction in Northampton is not the likeliest place to find an original work by a significant 16th-century Florentine artist. But there it was at the sale last fall, a double-sided sheet by Lodovico Cardi (1559-1613) -- known as Il Cigoli, from the name of his hometown -- in an 18th-century tome that reproduced drawings in major British collections. One of its plates had been replaced by the Cigoli original, owned in the past by the artists Peter Lely and Joshua Reynolds but unknown to modern scholars.

title: On Stage and Off
description: Enter a Freak, Self-Styled

title: On My Mind; Nasty at the U.N.
description: Immediately after Iraq demanded withdrawal of American members of the United Nations weapons investigation team and threatened to shoot down U.S. surveillance planes, the world organization took important action. It decided to put Israel on trial.

title: No Cheering in Booth No Problem for Griese
description: Bob Griese is not an overly emotional man or a very excitable announcer. And the ABC college football analyst's approach to calling games played by his son Brian, the University of Michigan quarterback, is characteristically cool.

title: BORDEN AGREES TO SELL UNITS FOR $310 MILLION
description: Borden Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its wall covering and vinyl units to a Blackstone Group investment fund for about $310 million. Borden said the transaction valued the units, Borden Decorative Products Holdings, at about $320 million. Blackstone Capital Partners III Merchant Banking Fund is to pay $310 million in cash and Borden is to keep an 11 percent interest. Borden, itself acquired by the leveraged-buyout firm of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company in 1995, sold its dairy business for $435 million in September as part of an effort to focus on its chemicals unit and food products like Creamette pasta and Classico sauces. Decorative Products Holdings, which is based in Britain, has about 2,650 employees worldwide.

title: Long Season Is Taking Its Toll
description: Dr. Alex Harthill answered his mobile phone while walking the shed row of a barn at Churchill Downs yesterday afternoon. He has operated on hundreds of race horses in his career and handled hundreds of emergencies. In 1992, he determined that A.P. Indy had a cracked hoof, causing the colt to be scratched on the morning of the Kentucky Derby. And now, Singspiel.

title: Knicks, After Another Blowout, Set Sights on Shaq
description: There was an image of the Phoenix Suns as a team that was almost unbeatable, a multitalented group that was as quick as a sneeze. But this is desert country. And sometimes what everyone sees is just a mirage.

title: A Troubled Oxford Health Takes Action
description: Under pressure from New York insurance regulators, Oxford Health Plans Inc., the troubled managed care company, announced organizational changes yesterday that Stephen F. Wiggins, the chairman, described as ''our turnaround plans.''

title: Shutdown of Refinery Lifts Gasoline Prices
description: Crude oil and gasoline prices climbed yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange following an unexpected shutdown of a refinery in New Jersey. Renewed tensions between Iraq and the United Nations over weapons inspections, reviving fears of a disruption of supplies from the Mideast, also increased prices.

title: Eating Out; Dessert Places
description: Dieters, read no further. But those of you who delight in the good old all-American pastime of rewarding yourselves with a smashing dessert, listen up! Here are a dozen places where the desserts are not simply sweet or loaded with calories: they are wonderful, unusual or served in particularly pleasant surroundings. (Here are some summaries, written by Eric Asimov, taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAFKA, EMANUEL
description: KAFKA-Emanuel. At age 70, on November 6, 1997. Loving husband of Sheila. Adored father of Brad and Shera, Fran and Jeff, Saundra and Kevin. Caring stepfather of Cheryl and Michael, Suzan and Michael, Eric and Linda. Devoted grandfather of Jordana, Eric, Sara, Ilana, Ari, Jason, Rena, Marisa, Jonathan, Adam, Jared, Aaron and Nicole.

title: Havana Journal; Castro's Cigar, a Namesake, and Smell of Trouble
description: There may be times when, as Freud said, a cigar is just a cigar. But when the cigar in question happens to be a Cohiba, that is surely not the case.

title: TRAVELERS AND TISHMAN SPEYER IN REAL ESTATE VENTURE
description: The Travelers Insurance Company said yesterday that it had formed a real estate venture with Tishman Speyer Properties with an initial investment by the companies of $800 million. Travelers, a unit of Travelers Group Inc., said the venture would focus on global real estate acquisitions and development. The venture is starting with a portfolio of 15 office properties and five development sites. Travelers is investing $420 million in real estate and $100 million in cash, and Tishman Speyer is investing $280 million in properties and cash.

title: Carolina Agency Lands SDRC
description: SDRC, a software company in Cincinnati, has named Howard, Merrell & Partners in Raleigh, N.C., to handle its account, which had been inactive since 1993. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $7 millon. The decision came after a six-week review that also included Angotti, Thomas, Hedge in New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies; Kearns Design in Dayton, Ohio; McConnaughey Stein Schmidt Brown in Chicago, and M& C Saatchi in New York.

title: Health Care Is Too Important for Partisanship; Overlooked Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTLE, JOHN WATSON, II.
description: LITTLE-John Watson, II. On November 1, 1997 at Southampton after a brief but valiant struggle with lung cancer. Class of 1940 Dartmouth. He participated in initial assaults in WWII in Sicily and Omaha Beach and was an agent in the U.S. Army Counter Intelligence Corps. A poet and writer, Jack was published in a wide range of journals. He served as Vice President of Southampton Hospital and Hampton Day School and on the Executive Committee of Dartmouth Library. Beloved husband of Jean Remmel Little. Brother of Elizabeth Shippee. Father of Lucy L. Tucker, David K. Little, Dr. Liza Little, Carl V. Little and John W. Little, IV. A service will be held Saturday, November 8, 11A.M. St. John's Episcopal Church, Southampton. In memory of Jack, contributions may be made to Southampton Hospital.

title: My Manhattan; Happily Married To a Gritty City
description: Until 1981, when I moved to New York from San Francisco, I always saw this city in glimpses. The first was in 1930, when, as a 6-year-old immigrant from Romania, I stood with my mother and brother at the rail of the Berengaria as it drifted past the Statue of Liberty toward what seemed a rigid and ominous silhouette of a city. I remember the salty taste of the offshore breeze, the exclamations of awe and the looks of wide-eyed wonder or anxiety on the faces of the other immigrants crowding the rail.

title: Mezzos in the Middle Of a Lyric Explosion
description: Let's face it. One of these days, some enterprising impresario is going to try to pack a stadium for an event called ''The Three Mezzos.'' But when he sets out to do so, he will have the devil's time whittling the candidates down to a short list.

title: Market Place; Hilton may regret its ITT offer to guarantee a share price.
description: Forecasting the price of a stock is not easy. But in tense takeover battles, that sometimes does not stop companies from offering ''money-back guarantees'' that their stock will rise at least a certain amount.

title: H. Richard Hornberger, 73, Surgeon Behind 'M*A*S*H'
description: H. Richard Hornberger, a surgeon who wrote the novel ''M*A*S*H,'' the inspiration for the film and long-running television series of the same name, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Portland, Me. He was 73.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology and Design; Rolls Has Made a Virtue Of Virtual Obsolescence
description: ROLLS-ROYCE is not for sale,'' Graham Morris, the company's chief executive, asserted in August. What a difference a few months can make.

title: Health Care Is Too Important for Partisanship; Competent at 65
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: For the second time in two months, a family says farewell to a police officer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLAUGHLIN, JAMES P.
description: McLAUGHLIN-James P. Devoted husband, father, grandfather and philanthropist passed away peacefully in his home in San Antonio, Texas on Sunday morning, November 2, 1997. He is survived by his wife of nearly 55 years, Genevieve and seven children, Mary Caruso, Dorothy Petell, Jean McLaughlin, James, Robert P., Paul and Mark McLaughlin and 13 grandchildren. The funeral mass and burial will be held Friday, November 7, 1997 in Williamstown, Massachusetts. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to St. Peters/St. Joseph's Children's Home in San Antonio, TX through the office of the George M. Hopkins Funeral Home, 61-67 Spring Street, Williamstown, MA 01267.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, BERNARD
description: GOLDBERG-Bernard. Beloved husband of Hortense. Loving father of Neil A. Goldberg and Arthur and Carmen Goldberg. Cherished grandfather of Jane, Rafi and Rebecca. Devoted brother of Rose Essig and the late David. Services today 11:00 a.m. at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave (Ave J),Bklyn.

title: Health Care Is Too Important for Partisanship; Kyl Proposal Isn't New
description: To the Editor:

title: A Concrete Subcontractor for Trump Has Been Banned From City Contracts
description: The owners and executives of the company that poured defective concrete at Donald J. Trump's Riverside South complex on the Upper West Side have been banned from competing for city contracts and have a long history of trouble with law enforcement officials, including indictments by New York and New Jersey.

title: New U. S. Sector in Berlin: Little Guggenheim Branch
description: After the fanfare of Bilbao, the elegance of Venice, the sweep of New York, the Guggenheim Foundation opens its newest branch on Friday -- Deutsche Guggenheim Berlin -- boasting a different theme: modesty.

title: A Director Who Keeps Chekhov Open to Change
description: In the Russian-language version of ''The Cherry Orchard'' now at the Martin Beck Theater, the director Galina Volchek approaches Chekhov as her contemporary. Over the years, she has staged four different productions of the play, and each time she has taken into account ''what is happening outside the window.''

title: Rules on Ticket Scalping To Remain in Place
description: Tickets for sports events and concerts in New Jersey will remain subject to strict anti-scalping rules for at least four more months. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman conditionally vetoed legislation yesterday that would have lifted those controls.

title: Spy Plane Has Its Uses
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE GRUYTER, PRINCESS FATEMEH KHANOUM
description: de GRUYTER-Princess Fatemeh Khanoum, 97, on November 4, 1997. Wife of the late Professor Wilhelmus Josephus de Gruyter. Mother of Veronica Catherine Isabelle de Gruyter Hearst. Grandmother of Carlos Alexander Beracasa and Maria Fabiola Beracasa. Private services and mass were held on November 5, 1997.

title: After a Loss at Blackjack, Trouble Was in the Cards
description: BOB THE GAMBLER

title: CHRONICLE
description: After more than 30 years as a playwright, JEAN-CLAUDE van ITALLIE, 61, has decided that it is time to appear in one of his works. He is playing a starring role in his new play, ''Guys Dreamin','' which opened last night at La Mama Experimental Theater Club.

title: Inside Art
description: Art Foundation Settles a Lawsuit

title: Prosecutor Seeks to Oust Union Leader
description: An in-house prosecutor hired by the Laborers' International Union of North America moved yesterday to oust the union's president, Arthur A. Coia, on charges that he associated with members of organized crime.

title: Book in Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: Hong Kong Stocks Fall 5%; Investors Act on Interest Rates
description: Stocks fell sharply in Asian markets early today.

title: Metro Business; Art Store Opening in SoHo
description: Artists will soon have another outlet for paintbrushes, canvases and other supplies, with the opening of the Art Store in a landmark building in SoHo.

title: America Online Reports Good Quarter and New Members
description: America Online Inc. said yesterday that it had added another 821,000 subscribers in the last three months, as the company reported quarterly profits that matched Wall Street's expectations.

title: The Secrets In Rhythms
description: The vibraphonist Stefon Harris came to jazz sideways, and his music works within straight-ahead jazz without fear of altering its conventions. A 24-year-old whose first record will be released next year by Blue Note, he was pursuing a career as a classical percussionist until recently. There's no mistaking his fresh perspective. He demonstrated on Wednesday night at the Jazz Standard that a balanced application of arrangements and strong, engulfing rhythms -- in his case, some from Cuba and West Africa -- never ceases to improve the music.

title: Baker's 35 Lift Seattle
description: Supersonics 109, Raptors 92

title: Never Enough Band-Aids
description: ''Sick: The Life and Death of Bob Flanagan, Supermasochist'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 3. The film opens today at the Angelika Film Center, 18 West Houston Street, at Mercer Street, Greenwich Village.

title: Boy to Face Juvenile Case Of Homicide In Baby Death
description: Faced with an apparent case of rough horseplay that turned deadly, prosecutors said yesterday that they were preparing to bring homicide charges against a 12-year-old boy accused of killing a toddler in his care.

title: 11 Ridiculed but Rewarding Institutions
description: Although the Presidential libraries have been mocked as ego trips for former Presidents (the fortress-like dimensions of the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library in Austin, Tex., are a particular target of critics), most scholars who have used them agree that they are an enormously valuable resource for academics, students, authors and the general public.

title: INSIDE
description: Vote Delayed on Nominee

title: Isaiah Berlin, Philosopher And Pluralist, Is Dead at 88
description: Sir Isaiah Berlin, the philosopher and historian of ideas, revered for his intellect and cherished for his wit and his gift for friendship, died of a heart attack following a long illness Wednesday evening in Oxford, England. He was 88.

title: Holyfield Corners Market on Charm
description: It is a brutal reminder of the last time he stepped into a boxing ring, but Evander Holyfield calls the crescent-shaped piece missing from his right ear a little nip and figures his ear is now as popular as Vincent van Gogh's.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the revelation that a biographer of Britain's royal family was a man writing under the nom de plume Helen Cathcart referred incorrectly in some copies to the source of the information. The death notice that revealed Harold Albert's career-long subterfuge was written by a friend of Mr. Albert's, not by the writer himself.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WOODLAWN CEMETERY BROOKSIDE MAUSOLEUM
description: WOODLAWN CEMETERY BROOKSIDE MAUSOLEUM 4 interments. $15,000. Call 914-245-8433 evenings

title: Diplomatic Approach to Iraq Is Big Risk for U.N.'s Leader
description: Less than a year after taking office as Secretary General of the United Nations, Kofi Annan may have put his reputation on the line in his first major crisis by choosing diplomacy over confrontation to deal with Saddam Hussein.

title: Topics of The Times; The Circle of Presidential Power
description: It is rare that four living Presidents get together and compliment each other, but it ought to happen more often. As Jimmy Carter noted at the dedication of the George Bush Presidential Library, the ex-Presidents' club is a small one, and its meetings convey a reassuring sense of continuity and resilience.

title: Art in Review
description: Christian Marclay

title: Man Pleads Guilty To Photo Pornography
description: An unemployed computer engineer from Long Branch pleaded guilty yesterday to taking sexually explicit photographs of a 14-year-old girl two months after meeting her in an Internet chat room, Federal prosecutors said.

title: The Odd Allure of Spanish Still Life
description: One of the most arresting pictures on view in Manhattan is a still life painted close to 400 years ago by a Spanish painter called Sanchez Cotan (1560-1627), on view at the Stair Sainty Matthiesen gallery. It has a beguiling strangeness that for a moment stops the heart.

title: To Make Point, Mayor Opens Door
description: It was a typical senior staff meeting of the Giuliani administration early yesterday morning, with one tiny exception: for the first time, members of the outside world were allowed in to observe the dedication of the city's top public servants, back at work as if the election campaign were simply a temporary annoyance.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AKE, CLAUDE E.
description: AKE-Claude E. February 18, 1939 to November 7, 1996. We miss you so very much, and we will never forget you. Love, Anita, Ibra and Brieri.

title: Accounts
description: -- Mad Dogs and Englishmen, New York, was named as the first agency to handle two accounts: Road Runner, Stamford, Conn., an Internet service owned by two units of Time Warner Inc., Time Warner Cable and Time Inc., and Kobrand Corp., New York, to handle national advertising for wines like Fortant de France. The Road Runner billings were estimated at $2.4 million in paid media and in Time Warner media; the Kobrand billings were not disclosed.

title: 'Low Point' for the Press?
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Says He Lied In Story of a Brother Slain in Bias Attack
description: It was, as James Ware told it, the tragedy that made him ''hungry for justice'': the murder of his teen-age brother, Virgil, in a racist shooting in Birmingham, Ala. at the height of the civil rights struggle in 1963. That moment inspired Mr. Ware to earn a law degree at Stanford University and, eventually, an appointment from George Bush as a Federal District Court judge in San Jose, Calif.

title: Victor Mills Is Dead at 100; Father of Disposable Diapers
description: Victor Mills, who led an engineering team that invented the first mass-market disposable diaper and changed the way millions of parents attend to infants, died on Saturday at his home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 100 years old.

title: Art in Review
description: 'New Photography 13'

title: Professorial, Unprintable And Pregnant
description: Jessica Litwak opens ''A Pirate's Lullaby'' as a blustery pirate, standing on deck shouting angry, unprintable language at the top of her lungs. Then her mother (Delphi Harrington) arrives, insists that she wear a life jacket and says: ''Where are your glasses? Fix your hair.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, RUTH G.
description: MANDEL-Ruth G. Loving wife of Lenard. Devoted mother of Richard G. and Rosemary Mandel and Carol M. and Andrew R. Milstein. Dear sister of Leslie J. Garfield and Elaine Kite. Cherished grandmother of Amanda and Daniel Milstein and Aaron, Ethan and Maria Mandel. Service today 11:30am at The Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 11
description: Game of the Week

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIS, RABBI PAUL S.
description: REIS-Rabbi Paul S. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague, age 50. After ordination, he served as director of the Hillel Foundations at W. Virginia University and North Carolina, as rabbi and educator in Pittsburgh, and since 1983 as rabbi of Congregation Beth Israel in Flint, MI. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his widow, Sara; mother, Edith; brother, Irwin and to his sons, Ezra, Ari and Efrem, and all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi David L. Lieber, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: The Most Sincere Form of Flattery: Mass Marketing
description: Fashion designers have enough problems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, JACK
description: GILBERT-Jack. Beloved husband of Lillian, devoted father of Barbara Gilbert Stein, Larry and Barbara Gilbert, devoted brother of Milton and Harold, adored grandfather of Jacqueline, Danielle, David, and Alyssa. Services Wednesday 10 A.M. at The Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opp LIRR. For information call The Riverside at 516-487-9600.

title: Backers of Rights Nominee Delay a Vote
description: With the Senate Judiciary Committee poised to defeat the nomination of Bill Lann Lee to be the Government's top civil rights enforcer, Mr. Lee's backers today delayed a vote to make a last-ditch drive for support for him.

title: Unsure About Hundley, Mets Try to Sign Olerud
description: The Mets extended a contract offer to the free-agent first baseman John Olerud yesterday, their first major push to retain their top run producer from last season.

title: Independent Pay Phones To Have Lower Prices
description: Starting in April, operators of independent pay phones that charge higher rates than major companies for credit card and operated-assisted calls will have to lower their prices, state regulators ruled yesterday. The State Board of Public Utilities voted to limit the cost of a five-minute operator-assisted call to $4.25, said an agency spokesman.

title: Centocor Drug Wins F.D.A. Approval
description: Centocor Inc. said today that the United States Food and Drug Administration had approved its heart drug Reopro for preventing complications in two new groups of patients.

title: Francine Katzenbogen, 51; Gave Cats the Lap of Luxury
description: Francine Katzenbogen, a Brooklyn-born lottery millionaire who loved cats so much she worked tirelessly for animal adoption agencies, donated generously to their support and housed 20 beloved strays in luxury at her own suburban Los Angeles mansion, died on Oct. 30 at her home in Studio City. She was 51 and may have loved cats rather more than was good for her.

title: Sports of The Times; Two Queries For the Two Holyfields
description: IT'S as if there are two Evander Holyfields: the recent one and that other one.

title: Drug Barons and Plastic Surgeons: Who's Dead, Who's Hiding?
description: Four months after Mexico's most influential drug trafficker was reported dead after plastic surgery, Mexicans have continued to puzzle over the mysteries of his passing.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WIENER, RICHARD J.
description: WIENER-Richard J. Richie, you are with us daily in our thoughts, always in our hearts. We miss you and love you so. Vicki, Annie, Oliver and Elizabeth

title: SINGER TO ACQUIRE 80% STAKE IN GERMAN MANUFACTURER
description: The Singer Company said yesterday that it planned to acquire an 80.5 percent stake in G. M. Pfaff A.G., a German sewing machine manufacturer, from Semi-Tech Global Ltd. for $157.5 million. Singer, the sewing machine manufacturer, said it would pay $82.5 million in cash and $75 million in Singer preferred stock. The company said the remaining 19.5 percent of Pfaff's stock would remain publicly traded on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange. Singer said Pfaff had 1996 sales of $448 million. Singer plans to streamline operations in the worldwide plants of both companies to lower manufacturing costs. Semi-Tech Global, based in Hong Kong, is 42 percent owned by the Semi-Tech Corporation, based in Toronto, which also owns 50 percent of Singer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HONIG, MURPHY, ADRIENNE
description: HONIG-MURPHY-Adrienne. On November 5, 1997. Beloved wife of Kevin Murphy. Loving sister of Susan Honig Scott. Devoted aunt of Heather and Courtney Scott. Services Friday 12PM, ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Children Behind Bars Need More Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Cool to LaFontaine's Olympic Hopes
description: The Olympic Games can often deliver sports at their most political. Perhaps that is why defenseman Brian Leetch and goalie Mike Richter of the Rangers offered such diplomatic and noncommittal answers when they were asked about their teammate Pat LaFontaine.

title: A Strong Halloween Increased October Sales at Retail Stores
description: American retailers yesterday reported unexpectedly strong October sales, underscoring the increased importance of Halloween as a selling holiday.

title: In Paris, Stencil Artists Talk to the Walls, and Their Work Is Washed Away
description: For those who associate stenciling with ''Post No Bills,'' ''Ambush in the Streets'' at Cooper Union will come as a big surprise. As seen through the eyes and camera lens of Jules Backus, the stencil images found in the streets of Paris are entrancing conceptual art: exuberant, provocative, mysterious.

title: Lots of Ham, Please, With a Side of Polyester and Platforms
description: Hoping for ''Smoke,'' the merry Brooklyn microcosm in a cigar store, ''The Deli'' sets up shop in a New York delicatessen and waits for colorful neighbors to drop by. They do, since the cast includes small roles for various familiar figures, performers as varied as Ice T, Jerry Stiller, Heather Matarazzo and Iman. But John Gallagher's film rarely gives them more to do than ramble and improvise excitably. On this deli's menu, there's way too much ham.

title: Not Even Whistler's Mother Can Escape From Mr. Bean
description: Mr. Bean is a man of few words, many tics and practically no superego.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Pop and Jazz Guide of Weekend last Friday about the singer Mike Watt, once the bassist with the Minutemen, misstated the year that D. Boon, the Minutemen's guitarist and singer, died. It was 1985, not 1990.

title: CHRONICLE
description: An appeals court in Paris yesterday ordered that the body of Yves Montand, the French singer and actor who died in 1991 at 70, be exhumed for genetic tests to determine the validity of a paternity lawsuit, Agence France-Presse reported.

title: Of Media Madness and a Sad Soul
description: There is no more delightful high ground for Hollywood than the perch that looks down on television news. Here is the perfect vantage point for denouncing slick packaging, aggressive exploitation, shady ethics, self-serving motives and so many other frailties that movies never know.

title: New Jobless Claims Jump to 2-Month High
description: The number of United States workers applying for state unemployment benefits jumped last week to the highest level in two months, a sign that job growth may be losing momentum.

title: Jeffs Look to Settle a Score
description: It is about time Amherst (7-0) scored a victory over Williams (6-1), its foremost rival. The Lord Jeffs have not won in this 111-game series since 1986. Tomorrow's game at Williamstown, Mass., marks the second year in a row, and the sixth time since 1957, that Amherst brings an undefeated team into this final game of the season. Each time, Williams has won, including by 19-13 a year ago with a touchdown in the final 36 seconds.

title: Former Executive Sues Columbia
description: A former hospital administrator for the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation contends in a Florida whistle-blower lawsuit that she was dismissed after informing company lawyers about possible document destruction by an executive in the wake of a Federal raid on the company.

title: Girl Stabbed by Father Dies in Hospital
description: A 10-year-old girl who the police said was stabbed four times by her drunken father last Saturday in the family's apartment in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, has died at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: Plodders No More, The New Knicks Run Wild in Phoenix
description: Things that could foil the championship dreams of the Knicks: Michael Jordan's heart. Patrick Ewing's knees. Jerry West's mind.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING ; All Aboard for the Campaign for a Few Good Mentors
description: The ability of the communications industry to persuade Americans to modify their behavior for what are deemed laudable causes is being tested again by an ambitious project to sell the concept of mentoring. It is being brought to you by the same people who successfully sold the concept of the designated driver.

title: Council Offers Tax Cut Plan For Businesses
description: The City Council plans to propose $300 million in tax cuts next year to help create jobs in emerging and growing industries like new media and telecommunications, the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said yesterday. He said another proposal would add $50 million to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's antidrug initiative.

title: Art Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Food Workers at Smith Barney Seek Union
description: Cafeteria workers at Smith Barney are demanding that the brokerage house allow them to join a union.

title: At SUNY, A Conference About Sex Is Criticized
description: The president of the State University of New York at New Paltz is under fire from the Governor and one of the system's trustees after a women's studies conference on sadomasochism, lesbianism and other sexual topics was held on the New Paltz campus last weekend.

title: Fertilizer Salesmen Are Unable To Remember Bomb Defendant
description: Two Kansas men who sold the fertilizer that prosecutors say was used in the bomb that destroyed the Oklahoma City Federal Building told a Federal District Court jury today that they could not remember either Terry L. Nichols or Timothy J. McVeigh as having been the buyer.

title: Corrections
description: The New York Stock Exchange table in Business Day yesterday misstated Wednesday's price for class B shares of the Security Capital Group. They closed at 32 3/4, down 1/8 -- not at 6 1/8, down 26 3/4.

title: Committee Republicans Accuse White House of 'Stonewalling'
description: House Republicans investigating campaign finance abuses shifted tactics today to a broadside accusation that the Clinton White House had engaged in five years of systematic ''stonewalling'' of assorted inquiries, from Whitewater to White House political coffees.

title: Spinning a Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ALAN
description: COHEN-Alan. On November 5, 1997. Beloved husband of Sheila (nee Halpern). Loving father of Pamela and Evan. Graveside service at Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ, Friday (today) 12:30 PM. For information call the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Larchmont, NY.

title: No Bugs Too Large For This Swat Team
description: ''Starship Troopers'' is the film version of Robert A. Heinlein's rabidly militaristic novel about a human infantry battling giant insects from the planet Klendathu. Speaking of other planets, where exactly are the hordes of moviegoers who will exclaim: ''Great idea! Let's go see the one about the cute young co-ed army and the big bugs from space.''

title: Prison Chief Is Resigning Amid Inquiry
description: William H. Fauver, who has led the State Department of Corrections for almost two decades, submitted his resignation today. He is the first top official in the administration to step down as Gov. Christine Todd Whitman prepares for her second term.

title: A Lament by the Hudson, as Trump Eclipses the Moon
description: One of the secret pleasures Shirley Liebman took from her Lincoln Towers apartment was wearing her torn gold slippers and nothing else. She sang Gershwin, or listened to opera, and never bothered with the blinds. Outside her 11th-floor window lay only the Hudson, and beyond that New Jersey, and on clear evenings she would watch the sun fall like a red stone.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about vulture funds that buy distressed real estate misstated the given name of the director of real estate consulting for the Frank Russell Company, who was quoted on pension funds' interest in such funds. He is Karl H. Smith, not Kurt.

title: Panel Holds Up House Measure On Preferences
description: As a crowd of several hundred people broke into cheers, the House Judiciary Committee voted today to delay a bill that would end the Government's affirmative action programs.

title: Art in Review
description: The Print Fair

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINCOFF, MILTON
description: SINCOFF-Milton. On Monday, November 3, 1997, of North Caldwell, NJ. Surviving are his children, Eric and Meredith from his marriage to the late, beloved wife Donna (nee Blis), and a son, Jeffrey, from his previous marriage, and a sister, Lenore. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, NJ on Friday, November 7, 1997 at 1:00 PM. Interment in the B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the Milton Sincoff Memorial Fund, C/O T.J. Martell Foundation, 6 West 57th St., NY, NY 10019.

title: Bear, Stearns Is Called an Extortion Target
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested a Lebanese lawyer in New York yesterday and accused him of trying to extort $15 million from Bear, Stearns & Company in return for the lawyer's arranging to have a client testify favorably in a civil lawsuit against the investment company.

title: REPUBLIC AGREES TO BUY FOUR CAR DEALERSHIPS IN HOUSTON
description: Republic Industries agreed yesterday to acquire four car dealerships in Houston for $75 million in stock. Republic, the world's largest car dealer, said it had agreed to buy Texan Ford, Texan Lincoln-Mercury/Isuzu and Champion Ford from the franchise owners, Anthony and Mary Gracely, and Mike Hall Chevrolet-Geo from the owner, Mike Hall. Terms of the individual purchases were not disclosed. Republic, led by the billionaire H. Wayne Huizenga, hopes to generate more sales and cut costs by clustering dealerships in Houston, where it operates three Autonation USA used-car superstores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARGOT, FANNIE STERN
description: PARGOT-Fannie Stern. On November 4, 1997 in Wakefield, R.I. Longtime devoted NYC teacher and principal. Sister of H. Anthony Stern. Aunt of Patricia Clark, Desmond Whitney, Christopher Stern and William Taubman and Philip Taubman. Gathering of friends 2PM Sunday, November 9th, at South Bay Manor, Wakefield.

title: Health Care Is Too Important for Partisanship
description: To the Editor:

title: Spare Times
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: A Hearing Focuses on Lyrics Laced With Violence and Death
description: A father told a Senate committee exploring the effects of music on children today that his 15-year-old son killed himself last December after listening to songs about death and the Antichrist.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop; The Sounds Of Ageless Loneliness
description: ''I got to talk,'' said Othar Turner, apologizing for his need to teach about his music on the bandstand. This was in 1992, when he came to play in New York City from Gravel Springs, Miss., with his Rising Star Fife and Drum Band. ''There's so many that don't know.''

description: Success can be a disaster. Just ask Maurizio de Rosa. One day he has this sweet little restaurant on Second Avenue with his mom and his brother in the kitchen and the family name over the door.

title: G.O.P Just Wants to Check Whether Anybody Likes the I.R.S.
description: After spending several months castigating the Internal Revenue Service for harassing taxpayers, Congress is now considering a plan to spend more than $30 million to ask taxpayers what they think of the tax-collection agency.

title: LeFrak Announces Plans for 189-Room Tourist Hotel in Jersey City
description: In a new sign of resurgence in Jersey City, Sam LeFrak, the developer, announced plans yesterday to build the first hotel on the waterfront intended for tourists as well as business travelers.

title: New Video Releases
description: Face/Off

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOFFLER, DAVID
description: KOFFLER-David, age 53, passed away on November 3, 1997. Beloved son of Ruth, brother of Sandra, Cindy and Michael. Uncle of Daniel, Brian, Ian and Joshua. Cherished in our hearts forever. Shiva is being observed at the home of Michael and Lori Koffler.

title: Residential Real Estate; For Co-ops and Condos, Some Credits on Taxes
description: Thousands of co-op shareholders found a pleasant surprise on their monthly maintenance bills this month -- a credit representing a partial abatement of the New York City local property tax that they pay on their units. Condominium owners received their good news several weeks ago, when they received 1997-98 tax bills that included credits against current taxes.

title: Swiss Bank Net Called 'Significantly Higher'
description: The Swiss Bank Corporation, the first big Swiss Bank to describe its performance in the first nine months, said yesterday that its net income was ''significantly higher'' than a year earlier and repeated that it expected higher full-year net. Swiss Bank said earnings advanced in all divisions in the first nine months, suggesting profit growth continued in the third quarter after first-half net income swelled 84 percent, to 1.326 billion Swiss francs ($928 million).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEJBZON, OLEK
description: LEJBZON-Olek. A veritable lion of a man. He survived five years of concentration camps, and came to America to build a successful business and a full and fruitful life. He will be missed by all those who loved him. He is survived by his wife, Sahimi, and his daughter, Robin. Services 10 AM, Friday, at The Riverside, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street.

title: Man Accused of Shooting Woman and Companion
description: A man who had been stalking his ex-girlfriend tracked her down on a busy street on the Lower East Side yesterday afternoon and shot her and a companion, the police said.

title: Daneyko Is in Treatment
description: The mystery surrounding Ken Daneyko's absence from the ice is over. The National Hockey League and the players union announced yesterday that the Devils defenseman had voluntarily entered an inpatient treatment facility as part of the substance abuse and behavioral health program that the league and the union established as part of the collective-bargaining agreement two years ago.

title: 5 Years After Finishing 2d, The 41st President Is No. 1
description: In the company of three other Presidents, six First Ladies and 20,000 or so of his closest friends, the 41st President of the United States was celebrated today at the dedication of the George Bush Presidential Library and Museum.

title: Firm Grasp of Fashion; Tenacious President Transforms Calvin Klein
description: When it comes to body language, Gabriella Forte can be deafening.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Give Clinton 'Fast Track,' or We'll Pay the Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Abroad at Home; Toward a Coup d'Etat
description: The conservative attempt to block the nomination of Bill Lann Lee as Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights is as revealing a political event as we have had in this country for a long time.

title: Do Real Cowboys Eat Cheese Blintzes?
description: Do real cowboys have medical insurance? I don't know, but the upstate dude ranch we set our sights on wisely doesn't take chances on city slickers like us.

title: Life After Williams? Yanks Float Trade Offer
description: A Yankee proposal for a five-player trade with San Diego was quickly squashed by the Padres yesterday, according to a person involved in the discussion. But the effect of the move offered a clue into the Yankees' thinking about their contract dealings with center fielder Bernie Williams.

title: Judge Backs a Dow Jones Libel Award
description: A Federal judge in Houston let stand a $22.7 million libel judgment against Dow Jones & Company that stemmed from a 1993 article about a Houston brokerage firm that appeared in The Wall Street Journal, the company's flagship newspaper.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''One man's trash is another man's dissertation.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIGGINS, THOMAS E.
description: HIGGINS-Thomas E. On November 5, 1997, in Montgomery, AL. Survived by his daughter, Barbara Carter. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 10 a.m., St. Catherine of Siena R.C. Church, 411 E. 68 St.

title: TV Weekend; Guided Tour To Death On Everest
description: As pure fiction, ''Into Thin Air'' would have been laughable. Its characters are sketchy; its improbable drama includes a man's deathbed call to his pregnant wife, made from an icy ledge on Mount Everest. But the story is now famously true, the tale of how eight people died in May 1996, caught in a fast-moving storm as they headed down from Everest's summit. Like those climbers, who struggled simply to breathe and walk, this straightforward film functions at a primitive but effective level. ''That really happened'' may be the least sophisticated response a movie can evoke, but it works here, making ''Into Thin Air: Death on Everest'' more absorbing than two hours' worth of ice, wind and hokey dialogue ought to be.

title: Adjournment Fever in Congress
description: It says a lot about the vacuous state of national politics that the overriding focus of Congress right now is adjourning rather than legislating. The current target for escaping Washington is this weekend. Lawmakers usually hang around the capital past Thanksgiving. No one wants to admit it, but most in Congress believe that the more they stay at work, the less the voters like them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, SALLY G.
description: DEUTSCH-Sally G. On October 16, 1997, in her 98th year. Beloved wife of the late J. George Deutsch. Beloved mother of Dr. Walter S. Deutsch and mother-in-law of Jean Deutsch. Beloved mother of Martin R. Deutsch and mother-inlaw of the late Gragina G. Deutsch. Beloved grandmother of Craig M. Deutsch and Adam G. Deutsch. Beloved sister of Louis B. Gilbert and of the late Morris Goldberg, Samuel Goldberg, Leo A. Goldberg, Kitty Weissman, Meyer S. Goldberg, Cele Hurwitz, and Harry J. Gilbert. Mourned and loved by her family and friends. Contributions to Alzheimer's Association, 919 N. Michigan Ave., Suite 1000, Chicago, IL 60611-1676.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPPENHEIM, KARL
description: PAPPENHEIM-Karl. The Ramaz School family mourns the passing of the beloved brother of its devoted friend and benefactor, Erica Jesselson, and extends its heartfelt sympathy to all the members of the bereaved family. David N. Kahn, Chairman, Board of Trustees Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, Principal

title: Albright to See Arafat and Netanyahu to Try to Break Impasse
description: With only modest progress after four days of Israeli-Palestinian talks here, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright is making plans to meet in Europe next week with leaders from both sides, American and Israeli officials said today.

title: 9 U.S. Lifters Suspended In Colorado
description: In a scandal that will further damage a sport already hurt by poor performances and monetary problems, nine weight lifters have been suspended from a residence program at the Olympic training center in Colorado Springs for allegedly using banned substances, weight lifting officials said last night.

title: Brazilian Leader Battles Speculators, and Wins This Round
description: For President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who is up for re-election next year, it was a do-or-die situation last week when he staved off financial speculators who tried to force Brazil to devalue its currency, the real.

title: BERNARD CHAUS TO CLOSE 20 OF ITS 21 OUTLET STORES
description: Bernard Chaus Inc. said yesterday that it would close all but one of its 21 outlet stores, where it sells its clothing at discounts. The company, a struggling maker of Chaus women's clothing and Nautica sportswear, said it would close the stores and liquidate their inventory this quarter. The moves follow a restructuring begun earlier this year, when Chaus hired Lehman Brothers Inc. to consider ways to shore up its business. Chaus has not had a profitable year since its 1992 fiscal year. The company also reported yesterday that net income in the quarter ended Sept. 30 rose to $2 million, or 8 cents a share, from $361,000, or 1 cent, in the period a year earlier. The company's shares rose 37.5 cents, or 50 percent, yesterday to $1.125.

title: Art in Review
description: Barbara Kruger

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, DR. ROBERT
description: MILLER-Dr. Robert. Age 82, on October 24, 1997, retired Temple University History Professor of Philadelphia, PA., cousin of Dorothy and Samford Maier, James and Elinor Schatz and Lucille and Sid Goff. Relatives and friends and Temple University colleagues are invited to a memorial service to be held in the 4th Flr. Auditorium at Logan Square East, Two Franklin Town Boulevard, Philadelphia, PA, Saturday, November 22, 1997 at 2:00 PM. In lieu of flowers the family suggests contributions to Temple University, c/o Office of Development, 1601 North Broad St., Philadelphia, PA 19122.

title: U.S. Acts to Bar Chancellor Media's L.I. Radio Deal
description: After approving more than 1,000 radio station mergers since Federal rules were liberalized nearly two years ago, the Justice Department filed suit today to block one for the first time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, MILTON
description: LEVY-Milton. Loving husband, father and grandfather. Survived by wife Fran, sons Jeffrey and Stuart, grandchildren Matthew, Caryn and Millie. He will be greatly missed. Services Friday, 10 AM at I.J. Morris Inc, 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn.

title: NETS
description: After impressively opening the season with victories over the Indiana Pacers, the Milwaukee Bucks and the Golden State Warriors, it is time to find out if the Nets are indeed for real.

title: Excerpts From Comments on Nominee
description: Following are excerpts from comments today by Senator Orrin G. Hatch in a meeting of the Senate Judiciary Committee explaining why he opposes the nomination of Bill Lann Lee as Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights, and from the White House response to criticisms of his record:

title: The Met's 'Don Giovanni,' With Three New Voices
description: There were patches of empty seats at the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday evening for the first performance this season of the Franco Zeffirelli production of Mozart's ''Don Giovanni.'' The reasons may have been less than noble -- primarily, no doubt, a lack of big and familiar names in the cast -- and it would be a nice comeuppance to report that the absentees missed a lot.

description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, WILLIAM HEYWARD HOMER
description: TURNER-William Heyward Homer, noted corporate philanthropist, founder and Executive Vice President of the U.S. Steel Foundation, died recently in Stamford, Connecticut. He was 93. A native of Atlanta, Dr. Turner will be buried in Atlanta on Monday, November 10. He is survived by his wife Veda, his sons, Roger and William Heyward from his marriage to the late Clara Andres, several grandchildren and greatgrandchildren.

title: Army Outpost At Crossroads Has New Foes
description: NAME the cause, and it's better than even money that it has ignited a demonstration outside the armed forces recruiting station that sits on a traffic island in Times Square.

description: LOTWIN-Rosemarie. Remembering you on your birthday and always. Sean, Kelle, Dakota, Mother, Lee and John

title: PRESIDENT ISSUES LAST-MINUTE PLEA ON TRADE MEASURE
description: President Clinton, fearing defeat in his quest for expanded trade negotiating authority, made an unusual public appeal for support tonight, accusing interest groups of intimidating members of the House who might otherwise vote for the bill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, ROBERT STUART
description: SHAW-Robert Stuart, 64, a retired executive of Chase Bank, died on Tuesday, November 4, 1997 in West Palm Beach, FL, where he resided. Mr. Shaw was born in New Rochelle, NY, the youngest son of Leo N. and Marie Heffernan Shaw. Mr. Shaw graduated from Amherst College in 1955 and later served in the U.S. Army. During his 32 year career with Chase Manhattan Bank, he was assigned to London, served as general manager of Paris and Singapore, and as deputy general manager in Tokyo. In addition, he served in various capacities in New York, including managing the New York branch system just prior to his retirement. He was a member of the Owasco Country Club, the Everglades Club of Palm Beach, the Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick and the University Club of New York City. Mr. Shaw was an active member of the Board of Directors of the Boys and Girls Club of Palm Beach County. He contributed his time generously to many other community service organizations. Surviving are his wife, Ann Holm Shaw of West Palm Beach, FL; one daughter, Elizabeth N. Powell and her husband, James, of Taipei, Taiwan; two sons, Robert S. Shaw, Jr., and his wife, Florence, of Paris, and Christopher L. Shaw and his wife, Linda, of Seattle, WA; one brother, Lee N. Shaw of Vero Beach, FL. One sister, Virginia Sweeney of Chappaqua, NY. He is also survived by six grandchildren, several nieces and nephews. Friends are invited to call at the Brew Funeral Home, 48 South Street, Auburn, NY, from 5 to 8 on Sunday, November 9. The Funeral Mass will be held on Monday, November 10, 1997 at 11 a.m. in Sacred Heart Church, Melrose Road, Auburn, NY. Interment will be in St. Joseph's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Boys and Girls Club of Palm Beach County, Suite 204, 800 North Point Parkway, West Palm Beach, FL 33407-1946, or to the charity of one's choice in memory of Mr. Shaw.

title: PATRIOT AMERICAN BUYS STAKE IN HOTEL AT DISNEY WORLD
description: Patriot American Hospitality Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire a 95 percent stake in a hotel at Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla., for $97.1 million. Patriot said the hotel, the Buena Vista Palace Resort and Spa, had 1,014 guest rooms and recently underwent a renovation that cost more than $6 million. Patriot, a hotel real estate investment trust, said it was making the acquisition from a pension fund managed by ERE Yarmouth, a New York-based investment firm, and from the Buena Vista Investment Fund.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about James E. McGreevey's plans after losing the election for governor in New Jersey misstated the percentage of potential Hudson County voters who turned out on Tuesday and the percentage of their votes that went to him. Turnout in the county was 51 percent, not 45. Sixty percent voted for Mr. McGreevey, not 68 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVEREST, PHILIP J.
description: EVEREST-Philip J., 90, the former Chairman of Transportation Displays, Inc. of New York City died November 5, 1997 in Naples, FL. Survived by his wife, Evelyn, a daughter Beverly E. Shaw of Chicago, IL, 5 grandchildren and 6 great grandchildren. Memorial Service Saturday, November 8th, 3PM at the First Presbyterian Church of Naples. Contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Support Network, 660 9th St, N. Naples, FL 34102. Contact Fuller Funeral Home, Naples, FL 941592-1611.

title: From London, Enigmatic Errands and a Harpsichord High
description: Two dances by Siobhan Davies glowed with cool fire when the Siobhan Davies Dance Company made its New York debut on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. An inventive choreographer, Ms. Davies is fond of devising intricate patterns. But there was no sense of clutter or contrivance about ''Bank'' and ''The Art of Touch,'' the evening's offerings.

title: Memories of a Captivating Conversationalist
description: There will be innumerable tributes to Isaiah Berlin. Some will recall the wartime dispatches that he sent back from Washington, some will praise him as an enemy of totalitarianism, others remember his passion for opera.

title: Confusion at the Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: For Girls, Lowered Self-Esteem Starts Early; Healthy Fitness Craze
description: To the Editor:

title: Reporting on AIDS Would Hinder Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: East Europeans Fill Job Gap in Florida
description: This is the land of the perpetual help-wanted sign.

title: Furor Over a Sex Conference Stirs SUNY's Quiet New Paltz Campus
description: For more than a century, this town has been best known as a mecca for weary New Yorkers seeking refuge at the fabled Mohonk Mountain House or for hikers drawn by the fall foliage in the Shawangunk Mountains.

title: Mutating Viruses
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROEHM, CONSTANCE HOLT
description: ROEHM-Constance Holt. On November 5, of Newtown Square, PA, formerly of New York City. Sister of the late Helen Sylvia Roehm. Funeral service Monday, 9:30 A.M., at the Dill-Sweeney Funeral Home, Newtown Square, PA. Entombment at Chelten Hills Abbey, Philadelphia, PA.

title: Michael von Clemm, 62, Eurobonds Pioneer
description: Michael von Clemm, an investment banker who used a lifelong interest in anthropology to help pioneer the global Eurobond market, died on Thursday at his family home in Wellesley, Mass. He was 62.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREITENBACH, ALICIA T.
description: BREITENBACH-Alicia T. Of Ridge, LI (formerly of Amityville), November 6, 1997. Beloved wife of Alfred G. Devoted mother of Roy W. Loving sister of Mary Collins. Dear mother-in-law of Jacqueline. Reposing 7-9:30PM Saturday, and 2-4:30PM and 7-9:30PM, Sunday at the Powell Funeral Home Inc., 67 Broadway (Route 110), Amityville. Order of the Eastern Star Service Sunday, 7:30 P.M. Funeral Mass Monday, 10 A.M., Saint Anselm's Episcopal Church, Shoreham. Cremation private.

title: Rome Talks Seek to Defuse Trade Disputes
description: Dismantling hidden barriers to increased trans-Atlantic trade was the focus of two days of discussions here by European and American business leaders with government officials from both sides of the Atlantic.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a California judge's withdrawal of his nomination for a seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, referred incorrectly in some copies to the California Governor who appointed him to the State Superior Court in 1988. It was George Deukmejian, not Pete Wilson.

title: Drive-Through Cities
description: In the swell of Election Day on Tuesday, the Mayors of three comeback cities stepped up to the lectern with the confident stride that comes with victory. It was no surprise that Rudolph Giuliani in New York, Dennis Archer in Detroit and Michael White in Cleveland were all easily re-elected. They are part of an exciting group of mayors who have, on the surface at least, lifted cities out of the ashes.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Editorial Notebook; The Killers and Their Consciences
description: So Pol Pot, leader of a Cambodian regime that killed perhaps more than a million people, sleeps well at night. In his only interview since 1979, published in the Far Eastern Economic Review, Pol Pot admits only to necessary killings of political enemies, saying he came to ''carry out the struggle,'' not to kill people.

title: Rangers, in Overtime, Again Make a Point
description: Despite falling behind by 2-0 to a good team tonight, the Rangers gave the Stars a good game in Reunion Arena. They did it with the new conservative style they packed with them on their two-game Western trip. They did it without Aleksei Kovalev, who spent most of the game on the bench after displeasing Coach Colin Campbell.

title: KILROY REALTY AGREES TO PURCHASE OF ALLEN GROUP
description: The Kilroy Realty Corporation has agreed to acquire the principal assets of Allen Group, a San Diego-based real estate and investment company, in a multi-phase transaction valued at more than $300 million. Kilroy said yesterday that it had immediately acquired eight office and industrial properties in San Diego, Stockton, Calif., and Las Vegas, Nev., for a total investment of $79.6 million. Altogether, Kilroy said it had purchased or agreed to purchase in the future more than 1.7 million square feet of office and industrial space and a development pipeline of about 750,000 square feet. In a second phase of the purchase, Kilroy will buy four properties currently under construction as each property is completed and occupied.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, BERNARD I.
description: GOLDMAN-Bernard I. On November 7, 1997. Beloved husband of Charlotte. Devoted father of Eileen and Jerry. Cherished grandfather of Cody, Boz, Rachel and Samantha. Services Sunday, 11:30 AM, ''Guttermans, Inc'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Foes of Rebels In Mexico Attack Bishop And His Kin
description: A clash between the Roman Catholic Church and pro-Government groups in the southern state of Chiapas, the stronghold of the Zapatista guerrillas, intensified sharply this week with two violent attacks aimed at Bishop Samuel Ruiz Garcia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONRAD, LUCILLE (AKA LOLA ROSS)
description: CONRAD-Lucille (aka Lola Ross). Judith Malina and the Living Theatre Company share with the family of our dear friend and lifelong colleague Lola Ross as Lucille Conrad was known in the Theatre, our sorrow at the news of her passing. Lola was part of the Living Theatre community from its very beginning in the 1940s and she continued to contribute her art and her energy to our work even to this day. We remember her with love and gratitude and we already miss her.

title: For Girls, Lowered Self-Esteem Starts Early
description: To the Editor:

title: Lapointe's Late Goal Lifts the Islanders
description: After missing the playoffs by a couple of games last season, the Islanders are leaving nothing to chance. They are stockpiling points early, just in case.

title: After Vault, Strug Finds Balance in Life
description: When people first lay eyes on Kerri Strug, their impulse is to pick her up and have a photograph taken cradling her in their arms. This goes for guys on the street to Jerry Jones, the owner of the Dallas Cowboys, to Shaquille O'Neal to Arnold Schwarzenegger.

title: Jewish Identity Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: REGIONS FINANCIAL IS SET TO ACQUIRE KEY FLORIDA BANCORP
description: The Regions Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Key Florida Bancorp Inc. for about $38.5 million in stock. Key Florida, based in Bradenton, Fla., has seven branches on the west coast of Florida and assets of $212 million. Regions, based in Mongomery, Ala., has 430 offices in five Southeastern states and assets of $22.2 billion. Under terms of the deal, Regions said it would issue 0.3666 of a Regions share for each Key Florida share. The deal is expected to close in the first half of 1998. Regions' stock slipped $1.125, to $37, in Nasdaq trading, while Key Florida rose 25 cents, to $12.75.

title: Liberties; Takin' Up for Daddy
description: The Bushes were supposed to be celebrating. But they were too busy vindicating.

title: Yankees Take $5 Million Hit to Deal Rogers
description: The Yankees continued their makeover yesterday by sending the underachieving Kenny Rogers to Oakland and swallowing $5 million of his contract in exchange for a utility player, Scott Brosius. But their more important off-season quests, involving Bernie Williams and Pedro Martinez, remained unresolved.

title: U.S. Immigration Court Grants Asylum to German Scientologist
description: A Federal immigration court judge has granted asylum to a German member of the Church of Scientology who claimed that she would be subjected to religious persecution had she been required to return to her homeland, the woman's lawyer and a Scientology official said today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DEVRIES, MARALYN
description: DeVRIES-Maralyn and Harold. November 8, 1996 died together. I still miss you and love you. Ann

title: Reporting on AIDS Would Hinder Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: With the Apocalypse Almost Now, It Becomes a New Field of Study
description: Doomsday prophecies have already become a familiar staple of popular television series, shrill tabloid headlines and trade paperbacks, but now the coming millennium has found a home in academia in a new scholarly field: millennial studies.

title: Grocery Giant To Be Created In $2 Billion, 3-Chain Merger
description: Continuing a rapid consolidation of the supermarket industry, Fred Meyer Inc. will acquire Quality Food Centers Inc. and the Ralphs Grocery Company in separate deals that will create the fourth-largest chain in the nation, the companies announced yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about President Jiang Zemin's visit to Harvard included an erroneous translation of a remark by Mr. Jiang about his previous visit there. He said it was 14 years ago, not 40.

title: Battles of Unbeatens: Games Players Play For
description: For Michigan and Penn State, and for Florida State and North Carolina, the obstacles they face on Saturday are not the final ones along paths that began in the heat of summer. Just the biggest ones. It is possible for an eventual national college football champion to overcome a loss in November, as the Florida Gators discovered last season. It is just not advisable to try.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Amtrak's tentative settlement with track workers misstated its estimated cost through 2000 if the terms were extended to the railroad's 11 other unions. Republicans in Congress say Amtrak told them it would amount to about $260 million, not $26 million.

title: Review/Fashion; Finding the Sanctity in Magic
description: Beneath a ceiling strung with bare red, white and blue bulbs casting shadows of voodoo magic, Rifat Ozbek sought to put a spell on New York, where he was staging his runway presentation for the first time, having moved it from Paris.

title: Sidney Darlington, 91, Dies; Leader in Design of Circuitry
description: Sidney Darlington, a Bell Labs mathematician who pioneered the design of electronic circuits and whose formulas helped launch rockets 300 times without error, died on Oct. 31 at his home in Exeter, N.H. He was 91.

title: Champions Promise A Livelier Rematch
description: The last time Evander Holyfield and Michael Moorer hooked up, back in 1994, many fight fans would have needed an intravenous drip of espresso to keep from dozing off. Moorer won the 12-round snoozer on a narrow majority decision and stripped Holyfield of his title that night.

title: To Be Poor and Infected With H.I.V.
description: After the shock and outrage that followed the case of Nushawn Williams, who the authorities say may have transmitted H.I.V. to 10 or more young women, public officials have reiterated the need for young people to receive better education in the life-and-death matter of AIDS.

title: From Solos to Small Ensembles
description: Thursday night's program, the second of eight in the Sonic Boom festival of contemporary music at Columbia University, posed a not altogether unserious question: When an American composer supported by the prestigious Rome Prize spends a year living in a villa in Rome, where the weather is idyllic, the urban life stimulating and the cuisine delicious, does this have any effect on the music said composer writes?

title: Multiracial Americans
description: Under new Federal rules for reporting racial and ethnic information, Americans will be able to identify themselves on government forms as members of more than one race. People with both black and white ancestry, for example, would be able to check both boxes. The new rules also split the vast and arbitrary category of ''Asian or Pacific Islander'' into ''Asian'' and ''Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander.'' While hardly earth-shaking, these changes took four years of debate and testing to produce, which shows how politically sensitive the racial classification issue remains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, ROSE HAZEL
description: BERMAN-Rose Hazel. On November 7, 1997 in her 101st year. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Berman. Dear mother of Joan and Richard Lees, Noel and Claire Berman. Adored grandmother of Rhonda, Eric and Liz, Matthew and Susan, Mitchell and Ingrid, Diana, Peter, Orin and great grandmother of Rachel Eliana. Services Sunday, November 9, 12:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.
