title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE DECLINES TO 4.7%, LOWEST SINCE 1973
description: Unemployment fell last month to 4.7 percent, the lowest rate since 1973, helping push the hourly earnings of workers higher, the Government reported today.

title: Rubbing Away Art, Mastering The Voice
description: Jose van Dam has always seemed to offer the voice of experience in his singing, and as time goes on the experience intensifies, in the two ways it can.

title: Union Begins to Dismantle Blockades : French Truck Strike Ending With a Pact
description: PARIS  The union representing the majority of striking French truck drivers signed an agreement Friday with the trucking companies, effectively ending a dispute that has caused chaos in France and beyond.

title: HOUSE POSTPONES TRADE-ISSUE VOTE
description: President Clinton encountered new obstacles today in assembling the majority needed to pass legislation granting him expanded trade authority, forcing him to ask House leaders to delay a vote on the bill at least until Sunday.

title: If Landmarks Could Talk
description: Since the Grim Wrecking Ball hasn't quite demolished us yet, we seem to have been designated as ''living landmarks,'' or rather as one joint living landmark, along with some other New Yorkers whose lives could serve as maps of the city over many years.

title: Trial in Boy's Killing To Be Open to the Press
description: Most of the trial of a 15-year-old boy charged with murdering, robbing and sexually assaulting an 11-year-old neighbor will be open to the press, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: Journal; Whitman's 1% Blowout
description: The greatest untold story of the mangy little election year of 1997 is (a) the Staten Island ballot initiative to recall Susan Molinari from CBS News; (b) Ruth Messinger's last-minute request for campaign tips from Betsy McCaughey Ross, or (c) the potent subliminal effect of Bob Dole's much-photographed, newly taut face on turning out the G.O.P. youth vote.

title: El Nino Versus El Nonsense; Keeping Cool Heads in Midst Of Serious Ocean Warming
description: Early this summer, Smith Barney Inc.'s Latin American stock trading desk in New York held a meeting for brokers and money managers on how the latest episode in the periodic warming of Pacific Ocean waters known as El Nino might affect corporate profits across that continent.

title: INSIDE
description: Panel on Gulf War Chemicals

title: Ewing Outduels O'Neal; Lakers Pull Out Victory
description: Maybe it was too much to ask. The Knicks scraped and banged as long as they could, but they could not put together two flawless performances in a row, not when they had to face a Los Angeles Lakers team that had youth and speed -- and even size -- on its side.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REACH, BARBARA
description: REACH-Barbara. November 8, 1992. Lovingly remembered. Deeply missed. Ellie

title: Old Bird Duet Is Back, With Some New Tricks
description: ''In Volo'' (''In Flight''), which the French choreographer Jean-Christophe Maillot has created at American Ballet Theater for Alessandra Ferri and Ethan Stiefel, is a perfectly good 1950's ballet for the 1990's.

title: CENTRAL PARKING TO PURCHASE KINNEY SYSTEM
description: The Central Parking Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Kinney System Holding Corporation for about $187 million in cash and stock, increasing Central Parking's presence in New York City and creating a more efficient base in Boston, Philadelphia and Washington. Central Parking will also assume $18.6 million in Kinney debt. The closely held Kinney System, the largest operator of parking facilities in the New York area, is also one of the largest parking companies in the Northeastern United States. Central Parking's stock rose $5.25 a share, to $60.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. New York-based Kinney System operates more than 400 parking facilities with about 171,500 spaces, of which about 76,600 are in New York City.

title: Casino Owner Stops South Africa Book
description: In an early test of press freedom under South Africa's new Constitution, a well-known international casino magnate has delayed the publication of a biography of him and is trying to ban it.

title: 2 Top Staff Members Are Leaving G.O.P.
description: The top two staff members of the Republican National Committee have resigned, party officials said today, in a move that underscores schisms within the party just days after Republican victories around the country in Tuesday's elections.

title: Starwood Sweetens Bid for ITT; Hilton Expected to Follow Suit
description: In an effort to sway investors before an important shareholder vote on Wednesday, the Starwood Lodging Trust said yesterday that it had increased its offer for the ITT Corporation by $3 a share, to $85 in cash and stock, and proclaimed it far superior to the Hilton Hotel Corporation's rival bid.

title: Youth Shot by Agent Had Candy, Not a Gun
description: A 17-year-old high school student was shot and wounded on Thursday afternoon by an undercover Federal agent who mistook a foil-wrapped candy bar that the youth was holding for a handgun, officials said. The Queens District Attorney's office is investigating the shooting to determine whether the incident violated any laws.

title: Edmond Moriarty, Merrill Executive, 69
description: Edmond N. Moriarty Jr. of Bernardsville, N.J., a senior executive of Merrill Lynch & Company, died Oct. 26 at Morristown Memorial Hospital in Morristown, N.J. He was 69.

title: Rothschild to Manage Devils Rays
description: Two years after the other expansion team hired its manager, the Tampa Bay Devil Rays named theirs yesterday.

title: Panel Clears Texas Lawmaker Of Complaint in Lobbying Case
description: The House ethics committee dismissed a complaint today against Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the majority whip, that had been filed a year ago by a Congressional monitoring organization.

title: It Seems Art Is Indeed Monkey Business
description: ''Give! give! give! . . . Brush! brush!''

title: Unlikely Envoy: U.N. Point Man on Iraq
description: Richard Butler, the man in the middle of the United Nations standoff with Iraq, is a blunt Australian well known for using salty language to make a point.

title: Arts & Ideas
description: Each Saturday, the arts pages center on this new feature, with coverage of intellectual trends and issues. Today, a sharpening of the debate on race, along with an appreciation of Isiah Berlin, the new scholarly field of millennial studies and a university course on the Princess of Wales. PAGES B7-16.

title: Acupuncture and Western Science
description: American patients would not spend $500 million a year on acupuncture, mostly from their own pockets, unless they believed that it worked. Now the procedure has got the endorsement of a panel of scientists convened by the National Institutes of Health who judged it effective in controlling nausea from pregnancy and chemotherapy as well as pain after dental surgery. Whether it works for other ailments, such as lower back pain, is less certain.

title: In South, Prayer Is a Form of Protest
description: The students are demonstrating here.

title: A Racist Tape and the Fallout; Local N.A.A.C.P. Leader Faces Officer's Lawsuit Alone
description: A white police detective in this mostly white Hudson Valley city was talking to his girlfriend on the telephone. She was speaking on a portable phone. A black neighbor using a scanner, it turned out, was listening in and recording it.

title: Judge Maxwell Heiman, 65
description: Maxwell Heiman, a former Connecticut trial lawyer, past president of the state bar and a judge of the Connecticut Appellate Court for the last seven years, died on Wednesday at Hartford Hospital. He was 65 and lived in Newington, Conn.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's daily staff meeting misstated the process by which Housing Court judges are chosen. They are appointed by the chief administrative judge of the New York State courts, not elected.

title: Markets Fall Worldwide; Dow Off 101
description: The around-the-world stock slide was back in sync again yesterday with another 3 percent fall in Hong Kong helping to depress markets in Europe, Latin America and the United States.

title: Getting Down to the Business of Playing
description: The American pianist Awadagin Pratt has drawn a lot of attention, and much criticism, for his unconventional way of playing. He sits on a bench so low to the floor that it would make an ideal stepping stool for aerobic workouts.

title: Floundering on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N.'s Envoys Fail To Budge the Iraqis On Inspection Issues
description: A defiant Iraqi Government told a visiting United Nations delegation today that it would not change its policy of barring American arms inspectors from the country and renewed a threat to attack American U-2 spy planes flying over its territory as part of the weapons monitoring.

title: Ike and Nixon on Line?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Conductor Shows His Subtler Side
description: When Charles Dutoit brings the Montreal Symphony to New York, he tends to offer programs that show off that ensemble's coloristic flexibility and sheer power. The program that Mr. Dutoit conducted as a guest of the New York Philharmonic last night and on Wednesday and is to repeat tonight has its showy aspects too, but mostly it afforded Mr. Dutoit an opportunity to present the subtler side of his music making.

title: Police Cleared In Shooting Death
description: A grand jury cleared the police of wrongdoing in an upper Manhattan shootout last month that resulted in the accidental death of a building porter, prosecutors announced yesterday.

title: Man Acquitted of Murder In 1995 Store Robbery
description: The man accused of being the ringleader of a 1995 robbery that left a store owner's wife dead was acquitted of murder charges yesterday, a prosecutor said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFCOURT, MICHAEL
description: LEFCOURT-Michael. Died on November 6th, 1997. Adoring husband of Carol Blumenson Lefcourt. Devoted father of Jill Lander and Peter and Jack Lefcourt. Cherished grandfather of Jennifer, Allison, Scott and Nancy. Art Director at Dell Publishing until his retirement in 1988 to Boca Raton, FL. A very special man of humor and presence who will be greatly missed. Services private in Florida. Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel, 1-800-992-9262.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANAHAR, MATTHEW L.
description: DANAHAR-Matthew L. Of Riverview, Florida. Formerly of East Norwich, NY. November 6, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Mary. Loving father of Mary Louise and Elizabeth. Visiting at the Francis P. DeVine Funeral Home, 293 South St., Oyster Bay, Sunday 3-5, 7-9PM. Funeral mass Monday 10:30am, St. Dominic's R.C. Chapel. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Aided by 'Balmoral Coup,' Zia Sets Indian Club Slam
description: The most charismatic player in the world championships in Tunisia last month was Zia Mahmood of Manhattan, a celebrated globe-trotter. In the past he has played in world championships for his native Pakistan, and twice led his team to the final of the Bermuda Bowl, but now he was representing the United States for the first time.

title: Racism Is (a) Entrenched? Or (b) Fading?; The Answer for Many Is (b) as Optimists Dispute Decades of Pessimism on Race Relations
description: ''America in Black and White,'' a new book by Stephen and Abigail Thernstrom, is a vast, data-laden study whose most important conclusion is that the United States has gone a long way in the past six decades toward eliminating the stain of racism from the white American heart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JIN, MORGAN LI KUNG
description: JIN-Morgan Li Kung. Millbrook, NY, November 7, 1997. Father of Patricia Ann Haight and David M. Jin, brother of Plum Eng, grandfather of 5. A mass of Christian burial will be offered at 10:00AM Monday at the Church of the Good Shepherd, Rhinebeck. Burial will be private. Friends may call on Sunday from 4:00-7:00PM at White Funeral Home 91 E. Market St., Rhinebeck. Memorial donations may be made to the American Diabetes Assoc-Lower Hudson Chapter, 200 White Plains Rd, Suite 523, Tarrytown, New York, 10591.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBERG, FREDA
description: WEISBERG-Freda. Age 96, died November 6. Loving wife to Arthur, dear mother to Sidney Weisberg and Phyllis Rosenfield, cherished grandmother of Glen and Robert Weisberg and Greg, Paul and Richard Kagan, delighted great grandmother to Danielle, Matthew, Stefan, Lukas, Zoe and Jack. Also survived by devoted daughter-in-law and son-in-law, nephews and nieces. Burial will be private for the immediate family.

title: LEGG MASON IN TALKS TO BUY BRANDYWINE ASSET
description: Legg Mason Inc. is in talks to buy the Brandywine Asset Management Company for about $150 million in a move to beef up the brokerage firm's money management business, according to an investment banker familiar with the negotiations. Brandywine, which oversees about $7 billion in assets, hired the investment bank Goldman, Sachs & Company earlier this year to evaluate different options, including a possible sale. Officials at Legg Mason, Brandywine and Goldman did not return calls seeking comment. No agreement has been reached and the negotiations could break down, the banker said. Shares of Legg Mason, based in Baltimore, fell 75 cents, to $49.875.

title: Mets Pass On Gooden
description: The Mets are looking for a No. 1 starting pitcher, but a former Flushing ace, Dwight Gooden, apparently does not fit the bill. Steve Phillips, the Mets' general manager, yesterday rejected an overture by Gooden, who is a free agent.

title: President Decides on Panel To Supervise Gulf Inquiry
description: President Clinton has decided to create a special Federal oversight board to help direct the Pentagon's investigation of whether Iraqi chemical weapons are responsible for some of the health problems reported by thousands of Persian Gulf war veterans, Administration officials said today.

title: In Milestone, President Will Address a Gay Group
description: After bitterly disappointing gay men and lesbians during his last campaign by signing legislation they detested, Bill Clinton on Saturday will become the first sitting President to address a gay and lesbian civil rights organization.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PLOT WITH 4 GRAVES IN KENSICO CEMETERY
description: Plot with 4 graves in Kensico Cemetery, ''Garden of the Apostles,'' in Westchester County. $2,300. Call 704-696-3729

title: Police Search New Jersey For 2 Robbers
description: The authorities searched extensively yesterday for two armed robbers who, they said, fled with about $140,000 from a bank in the tranquil commercial district of Princeton, N.J., after terrorizing several young tellers and stealing an elderly man's car at gunpoint Thursday evening.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Ratings by The New York Times computer. All times Eastern.

title: PHILIP SERVICES WEIGHS A BID FOR SAFTEY-KLEEN
description: The Philip Services Corporation is considering making an offer for the Safety-Kleen Corporation, a waste recycler that is the target of a $1.8 billion hostile takeover bid by Laidlaw Environmental Services Inc. Philip has begun a review of Safety-Kleen and signed a confidentiality agreement, a company spokeswoman said yesterday. Laidlaw's bid, announced Tuesday, is worth about $26 a share, consisting of $14 in cash and 2.4 of its shares for each Safety-Kleen share. Philip, based in Hamilton, Ontario, acquired three steel scrap processing companies last month for $496 million.

title: Nike Shoe Plant in Vietnam Is Called Unsafe for Workers
description: Undermining Nike's boast that it maintains model working conditions at its factories throughout the world, a prominent accounting firm has found many unsafe conditions at one of the shoe manufacturer's plants in Vietnam.

title: Boccioleto Journal; In Italy's Remote Alps, a Priest's Lonely Ministry
description: ''A christening, now that would be cause for celebration,'' the young priest said cheerily, settling into a cozy family restaurant that looked out onto mountains lightly covered with snow. ''We certainly don't need any more funerals.''

title: Maker of Rolls-Royces May Buy Back Shares
description: Vickers P.L.C., which makes Challenger 2 tanks and Rolls-Royce cars, said yesterday that it might buy back some shares in the latest step to refocus the company. Vickers faces a hostile bid from the Mayflower Corporation P.L.C., a smaller engineering company whose ability to finance a bid Vickers questions.

title: The Scars Of Life And a Long Marriage
description: Stretching across more than half a century of the Jewish immigrant experience in America, Jack LaZebnick's play ''Sam and Itkeh'' gets the 25th season of the American Jewish Theater off to an auspicious start.

title: French Truckers Ease Siege As a Settlement Is Reached
description: French truck drivers began lifting a five-day siege of the country's highways tonight after members of their biggest union approved an accord with trucking companies providing a 6 percent raise and a minimum annual salary of $21,000 for experienced drivers within three years.

title: House Inquiry Summons Johnny Chung to Hearing Next Week
description: Frustrated with uncooperative witnesses, House Republicans investigating campaign abuses today subpoenaed Johnny Chung, a controversial fund-raiser for President Clinton, to appear at a public hearing next week, fully expecting that he will claim his constitutional right to silence.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Surge in Jobs Last Month Raises Inflation Fear

title: Police Seek Suspect In Shooting at Office
description: A 37-year-old man was shot three times in a Manhattan office yesterday by an unknown assailant, the police said. The victim, Donato Ramirez, was shot twice in the torso and once in the arm, and was in critical but stable condition last night at St. Vincent's Hospital.

title: Ex-Morgan Trainee Admits Stock Fraud
description: A former analyst trainee at J. P. Morgan & Company has pleaded guilty to insider trading in the stocks of four banks that were takeover targets.

title: Senator Quits Minority Post In New Jersey
description: John A. Lynch, the mastermind behind the Democrats' ultimately unsuccessful attempt to retake the State Senate this year, announced today that he was stepping down from his post as Senate minority leader.

title: Nets Seek New Lease
description: Two years ago, the Devils sued and threatened to leave the state, and they got an enhanced 12-year lease to stay at what was then the Byrne Meadowlands Arena. Now, the arena's other tenant, the Nets, wants a new lease to begin in 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACE, COREEN E. (NEE COLEMAN)
description: WALLACE-Coreen E. (nee Coleman) November 5, 1997. Beloved wife of James, mother of Frank, Jay and Ellen Wallace and Coreen Wallace Scharfe. Devoted grandmother to eight loving grandchildren. Beloved aunt to Judson Lange. Services November 10th, 10am at St. George's Episcopal Church where she served on The Alter Guild, Choir and Choral Society for many years. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave, November 8th and 9th between 2-4pm and 7-9pm.

title: Sports of The Times; With Ties To 2 Teams, Flip a Coin
description: FOR J. T. White, rooting interest in this afternoon's Michigan-Penn State showdown has come to this: a coin flip.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSANOFF, NATHAN
description: ROSANOFF-Nathan, 69. Of Coral Springs, Florida, formerly of New York, New York, passed away Wednesday, November 5, 1997. Beloved husband of Olga; loving father of Frayne, Wilfred and Captain Leonard Rosanoff and his wife Melissa; dear brother of Gloria, Evelyn and Minnie. Services will be held 1:00PM, Sunday, November 9, 1997 at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Exp., Fresh Meadows, N.Y., (800) 446-0406.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATKINSON, WALTER
description: ATKINSON-Walter. To our longtime friend of forty yearswe'll miss you very much. Peter, Mary, Nicholas and Kathryn Kalikow

title: Iranian Opposition Figure Sees Little Hope for Real Change
description: Iran's leading opposition figure has said that while Mohammed Khatami, the country's new President, sincerely wants to liberalize the country and improve relations with the United States, the short-term prospects for either development are poor.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about mail-order foods misstated a telephone number for Indian Rock Produce. It is (215) 536-9600. The toll-free number is (800) 882-0512.

title: Think Tank; Diana Media Mania: A Classroom Example
description: When two academics at Berlin's Free University met at the photocopy machine a couple of months back and got to talking about a new lecture course, neither one figured they were about to cause a media explosion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINN, CATHERINE CONVERSANO
description: FINN-Catherine Conversano. Of Sea Cliff, New York, on November 6, 1997. Beloved wife of the late John F. Finn, Jr. Loving mother of John C. and Terence T. Dear grandmother of Heather, Lauren, Kevin and Timothy. Dear sister of Isabel, Helen and Louise. Visiting Sat 2-4 PM and Sun 2-4 and 6-8 PM. Whitting Funeral Home, Inc., Glen Head, New York. Funeral service 10 AM, Monday at the Funeral Home. Interment Mount St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Contributions may be made to Nightingale-Bamford School, 20 East 92nd St., New York, NY 10128.

title: ARAMARK TO REPURCHASE STOCK HELD BY OUTSIDERS
description: The Aramark Corporation said yesterday that it planned to buy back all outstanding stock held by outsiders and become 100 percent employee-owned. The Philadelphia-based managed-services company plans to repurchase all shares held by outside stockholders and about 30 percent of the shares in its benefit plans. Aramark said the repurchase of the stock would cost $440 million. The company said its plan completed a buyout process started in 1984, when it became a private company after a $1.2 billion management buyout.

title: Floundering on Iraq; Two of a Kind
description: To the Editor:

title: An Even Bigger Title Rides On the Breeders' Cup Races
description: As they jogged around the track at Hollywood Park on the day before the Breeders' Cup, it was difficult to pick out the Horse of the Year. Which horse was he, and which of the seven races did he have to win to earn the most prized title in thoroughbred racing?

title: Nets Stay Perfect at 4-0, Believe It or Not
description: Believe it. Because as unbelievable as it may seem, the Nets are 4-0 for the first time in their 21-year history.

title: House Farewell to Queens Democrat
description: The House of Representatives interrupted its political business this afternoon to take up a matter that has caused bipartisan sadness among the lawmakers: the imminent departure of Representative Floyd H. Flake, Democrat of Queens.

title: The Nixon Implosion
description: Richard Nixon labored for 20 years after Watergate to rehabilitate his reputation. But now a voice from the grave -- his own, taped, naturally -- has undone much of that work. Excerpts from these tapes, which sat in the National Archives for two decades while Mr. Nixon's lawyers challenged their release, have already appeared in several publications and will be out soon in a book, ''Abuse of Power: The New Nixon Tapes,'' by Stanley Cutler.

title: Daneyko Gave No Hint
description: John MacLean has been Ken Daneyko's best friend on the Devils for a long time. They made their debut for the Devils on the same day in 1983 and have been close ever since, but today MacLean said he had no warning from Daneyko of his plans to enter a substance abuse and rehabilitation center.

title: Lewis Lost for Rest of the Season
description: Thomas Lewis, the Giants' first-round draft pick in 1994, will have surgery to correct a fracture in his left foot sometime in the next 10 days. The procedure will end his season and, most likely, his career with the Giants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNOLLY, KEVIN JOSEPH
description: CONNOLLY-Kevin Joseph, 63, husband of Elizabeth Fraser Connolly, of Fairfield, CT., died Thursday, November 6, 1997, in Bridgeport, CT. Born in NYC, Mr. Connolly was a graduate of Fordham University and the Bernard Baruch School of Business. He was a former resident of Shrewsbury, NJ prior to relocating to Fairfield 14 years ago. He was a V.P. of Human Resources for Tetley/Allied North America prior to his retirement. In addition to his wife, he is survived by one son, Dr. Kevin J. Connolly, Jr. of Newbury, VT; two daughters, Elizabeth Dell of Fair Haven, NJ and Suzanne Lynch of Marietta, GA; three sisters, Anne Schrager of Rensselaerville, NY, Mary Burnett of New Hyde Park, NY and Joan Loughran of Queens Village, NY and six grandchildren. A Mass will take place on Monday at St. Pius X Church. Friends may call on Sunday from 2-4 and 6-8 p.m. at the Shaughnessey Funeral Home, 50 Reef Road, Fairfield, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to Catholic Relief Services, P.O. Box 17090, Baltimore, MD. 21203-7090.

title: Dispute in Iraq Bolsters Prices of Crude Oil
description: Crude oil prices climbed yesterday after talks between United Nations envoys and Iraqi officials failed to resolve a dispute over weapons inspections, raising the chance of military action against Iraq.

title: L.I. Teacher Fined $39,000 Over Drinking by Students
description: A Long Island high school teacher has been fined $39,000 by the State Education Department, which says she allowed students to drink beer and wine on a 10-day trip to Italy in 1995 that she chaperoned.

title: Taliban's Misogyny
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIERNEY, MICHAEL P.
description: TIERNEY-Michael P. November 5, 1997, of Rutherford, New Jersey. Beloved husband of Mary Tierney (nee Wiegmann), loving father of Thomas, Rosemary, Joseph and Elizabeth, dear brother of Daniel. Visitation Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, the Diffily Funeral Home, 41 Ames Avenue, Rutherford. Funeral Mass 10 A.M., Monday, St. Mary's Church, 91 Home Ave, Rutherford. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, North Arlington. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to Legal Center for Defense of Life Inc., 210 East 23 Street, 5th Floor, New York, New York 10010 or Good Counsel Corp., P.O. Box 6068, Hoboken, New Jersey 07031.

title: In Cat-Killing Case, Town Sees Old Divisions Erode
description: When an Indian yogi bought the bankrupt old Parsons College in the 70's, droves of urban New Age pioneers began arriving here in Iowa corn country, drawn to the new Maharishi International University.

title: Mother's Plea Moves Mayor to Act
description: The Brooklyn woman called Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's radio talk show with tears in her eyes and children crying in the background. And help came like a flood.

title: Thai Claims Support To Become Next Premier
description: A Thai opposition leader who is the favorite of investors and business executives announced today that he had gathered enough support in Parliament to form a new government.

title: Review/Fashion; 3 Thinking Designers Outdo Themselves
description: Each collection challenges the designer to make clothes that are good enough to reap praise from the press, to be photographed by magazines, and to be bought in quantity by stores. Of course, some designers have sufficient financial clout to advertise widely, which assures them of a certain acceptance even in a weak season.

title: U.S. Says It Is Prepared To Use Force on Iraq
description: Signaling a growing frustration with diplomatic efforts, the Clinton Administration made clear today that the United States was prepared to retaliate with force if President Saddam Hussein continued to defy the United Nations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, BERTRAND
description: GOLDBERG-Bertrand. Beloved husband of the late Nancy Florsheim Goldberg. Devoted father of Lisa, Nan (Nickel Van Cleve) and Geoffrey (Lynne Remington) Goldberg. Loving grandfather of Lillian Van Cleve and Nathan Goldberg. Dear brother of the late Lucille Goldberg Strauss. Fond uncle of Peter (Susan) Strauss, Ellen (William) Hunt, Jr. and the late Barbara (James) Heller. Memorial Services Friday, November 14, 1997, 3:30PM, at The Art Institute of Chicago (in the Stock Exchange Trade Room), 230 S. Columbus, Chicago, IL. For information, please call Furth Funeral Direction, (773) 784-4300.

title: House, in Passing Spending Bill, Limits and Delays Clinton's Testing Program
description: Laboring under a deadline for adjournment, the House tonight approved a $277 billion spending bill for the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education that includes a deal to delay and restrict President Clinton's national educational-testing program.

title: Prison Term Given to Livoti In Choking Of Teen-Ager
description: Francis X. Livoti, the police officer acquitted last year of strangling a young Bronx man with an illegal choke hold during an arrest, was sentenced yesterday to seven and a half months in prison for choking a Bronx teen-ager in a separate confrontation.

title: ATRIX LABORATORIES STOCK TAKES A DOWNWARD TURN
description: The stock of Atrix Laboratories Inc. fell 10 percent yesterday after the company said its collaboration with Gensia Sicor Inc. to develop a prostrate cancer treatment had been terminated. Late on Thursday, Atrix said Gensia's decision to terminate its work with Atrix came six months into the development of a sustained-release prostate cancer treatment. Atrix said it would continue to develop the treatment, and plans to begin clinical trials late next year. Shares of Atrix, a dental and medical products company based in Fort Collins, Colo., fell $2 to close at $17.50 on the Nasdaq.

title: FOOTBALL: N.F.L.
description: KANSAS CITY

title: Agent Mistakes Candy Bar For Gun and Shoots Youth
description: A 17-year-old high school student was shot and wounded on Thursday by an undercover Federal agent who mistook a foil-wrapped candy bar that the youth was holding for a handgun, officials said yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: OHIO EDISON INC., Akron, Ohio, has completed its acquisition of Centerior Energy Corp., creating a holding company called First Energy Corp. that will serve about 2.1 million customers in Ohio and Pennsylvania.

title: Surgery Survey By New York Is Expanded
description: In a continuing effort to monitor the risk of dying as a result of surgery, the New York State Health Department has added a second procedure, angioplasty, to an evaluation program it started six years ago, and is considering expanding the program to other procedures including brain surgery and childbirth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUNICK, CARL
description: TUNICK-Carl. A tower of strength, source of security, humor, honor and love. He leaves a void that can never be filled. We'll cherish his memory always. Our condolences to Hilary, Justin and Zachary. Lovingly, Max and Barbara Gersh

title: Belgian Quartet Digs With Schnittke
description: As commercials go, it was not offensive or, for that matter, very commercial. The Rubio String Quartet, founded in 1991, is named for the instruments the members play, made by the English luthier David Rubio, who was introduced during their concert on Thursday evening at Weill Recital Hall.

title: Corrections
description: A table on Tuesday with an article about property tax assessment practices in Nassau County reversed the pictures of two houses used as examples. The smaller house, pictured at the top, is the one at 44 Angevine Avenue in Hempstead, with a current appraised value of $173,000; the lower picture shows the house at 104 Garden Street in Garden City, which sold for $400,000 in 1995.

title: Michael Pugliese, 41, Composer
description: Michael G. Pugliese, a composer, conductor and percussionist, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 41.

title: About New York; At Exhibition, Digital Eyes To Die For
description: MARIO RABADI thought he had sworn off video cameras. He had switched from taping weddings to commercial photography because it seemed that a new camcorder came on the market every other day.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Saturday about the study of hysteria omitted the given name and affiliation of a historian who commented. He is Edward Shorter, a professor of history at the University of Toronto and the author of ''From Paralysis to Fatigue: A History of Psychosomatic Illness in the Modern Era.''

title: I.M.F. Backs Hong Kong In Keeping Peg to Dollar
description: The International Monetary Fund has endorsed Hong Kong's decision to maintain its link to the United States dollar, a stand that slashed the stock market's value by more than 15 percent in a month. The I.M.F. said in an annual report on Hong Kong that it was encouraged by the Government's steadfast adherence to maintaining the Hong Kong dollar's 14-year link to the American currency. The peg removes risks for foreign investors.

title: Religion Journal; A Cleric Chosen to Lead Reflects on What It Takes
description: What does it take to be an effective leader? And what can one reasonably expect from the people one would lead? These are perennial questions for religious figures.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Prosecutors Try To Link Theft With Nichols In Bomb Case
description: Prosecutors in the Oklahoma City bombing trial today sought to link Terry L. Nichols to explosives that were stolen almost seven months before the blast.

title: For Girls, Lowered Self-Esteem Starts Early; Waifs of Advertising
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Department Tests Urged in H.I.V. Scare
description: People who fear they may have been infected with the AIDS virus by a former Chautauqua County man should be tested at the County Health Department instead of using home H.I.V. tests that were given away by the manufacturer and three drug stores, the County Health Commissioner said.

title: With Marino Ahead, Jets' Lips Are Sealed
description: When the Jets and Dolphins meet on Sunday, Dan Marino may be limping to his position with a sprained right ankle. But the Jets were careful today not to provide him with any added inspiration by taking potshots at him or his team. They were preparing for him as if he is still the superman he has been almost every time he takes the field and sees green.

title: 'Zero Emission' Car Still Fouls the Planet
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, DANIEL
description: MARTIN-Daniel, age 89. On November 6, 1997. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Devoted father of Robert and David, and loving grandfather of Julie, Erik, Allison and Anne. Service Sunday 11AM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, New York Chapter.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Everyone around here is God-believing. Everyone around here believes in Christ, as far as I know. Having Jesus in our school is something that we need. It gives us strength.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEFFER, MORRIS
description: PFEFFER-Morris. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Devoted father of Marilyn Goldman and Janet. Dear brother of Shirley Stein and Faye. Adored grandfather. Graveside services Sunday, 1:15PM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y. For further info call Parkside Memorial Chapels 718-896-9000.

title: Ex-OTB Head Tells Judge She Stole From an Ill Friend
description: In a courtroom packed with the defendant's friends and supporters, a judge in Manhattan demanded that Hazel N. Dukes, the head of the state N.A.A.C.P. and former head of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation, acknowledge directly that she had stolen $13,201 from a friend who was suffering from leukemia.

title: Temporary Leader for Arts Fund
description: The White House has named Kathryn Higgins, the Deputy Labor Secretary, as acting leader of the National Endowment for the Arts pending selection of a permanent replacement for Jane Alexander.

title: DIVIDING LINES: A special report.; Colleges Look for Answers To Racial Gaps in Testing
description: Universities around the country are facing an agonizing dilemma: If they retain their affirmative-action admissions' policies they face growing legal and political challenges, but if they move to greater reliance on standardized tests, the results will be a return to virtual racial segregation.

title: With One Election Barely Over, Schumer Starts His TV Campaign for Senate
description: Three days after the last election, Representative Charles E. Schumer, who is seeking the Democratic nomination to oppose Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato in the next election, ran his first television commercial. It was broadcast yesterday in western New York, where Mr. Schumer's advisers say the Brooklyn Congressman is not well known.

title: In Shipwreck Linked to Pirate, State Sees a Tourism Treasure
description: No one believes that Blackbeard the pirate left any treasure on his flagship when she sank on a sandbar in 1718, but a pile of rusty cannons, rotted anchors and encrusted artifacts discovered here is proving to be booty worthy of a 20th-century buccaneer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIEGLER, MURRAY
description: ZIEGLER-Murray. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Murray Ziegler, associated with The Times from 1946, until retiring in 1992.

title: Au Pairs Aren't Nannies, and Many Are Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy Williams And John White
description: Nancy Grimes Williams and John Gordon White, account executives at MTV Networks in New York, were married yesterday in Miami Beach. The Rev. Dr. Garth R. Thompson performed the United Church of Christ ceremony at the Miami Beach Community Church.

title: A Clarification On Letter
description: My Letter to the Editor, published on Oct. 26, contained an error. In the second paragraph, the first two sentences should read as follows:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATKINS, EDGAR C.
description: WATKINS-Edgar C. Our dear friend passed away on October 30 in San Antonio. Please call 212753-9092 about memorial details on December 7th. Tom Lampson, Carolyn Harcleroad and Liz Maas

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONASERA, NICHOLAS ANTHONY
description: BONASERA-Nicholas Anthony, on November 7, 1997, of Farmingdale, NY. Beloved husband of Palma (nee D'Angelo). Loving father of Linda Sorrentino, Carolyn Ciminna and Dr. Gregory Bonasera. Dear grandfather of Michael, Lisa, Daniel, Joseph Jr., Vincent, Donna and Thomas, and Nicholas and Alexander. Fond brother of Josephine Hrbek. Reposing at the James Funeral Home, 540 Broadway, Massapequa, NY. Visiting Sunday 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM. Funeral mass Monday 10:45 AM at St. James RC Church, Seaford, NY. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. In lieu of flowers please make donation to Residents Gift Fund c/o CLNH, PO Box 667, Center Moriches, NY 11934.

title: B.U. (1-8) Romps in Last Home Game
description: What was supposed to be a funeral Boston University's last home football game -- turned into a celebration today. The Terriers, who learned two weeks ago that the university was dropping football after this year, played superbly and routed Massachusetts, 33-8, for their first victory of the season.

title: IN THE EAST VILLAGE WITH: Sebastian Junger; The Pose After the Prose
description: THE day Oprah beckoned, Sebastian Junger was conflicted. He recoiled from the prospect of another tango with the news media that he guessed would be all about promoting his brooding good looks instead of his best-selling book.

title: Facing Wind and Cold En Route to Fremantle
description: Grant Dalton, a yacht skipper competing in the Whitbread Round the World Race, was taking a few sponsors for a sail-testing ride last Thursday off Cape Town. The guests went aboard Merit Cup, his team's 64-foot ocean-racing sailboat, between legs of the global competition.

title: Mr. Bean to Johnny Rocco, They're All in a Box
description: ABOUT MID-AUGUST HOME VIDEO starts hankering for the holidays. Rooting about the vaults for underemployed movies and television shows, studios and broadcasters begin boxing up old materials in new and marketable combinations. Movies with big names serve nicely, of course, as do collections of classic television series. Some boxed sets are drawn from the arts, both fine and performing, while others go back to the days when the movies began. The British, always in demand in this country, fill up boxes with comedy and drama. And, to round out the supply, there are the documentaries. Here is a selection due out soon or already on the shelves.

title: Academic Progress by Asian-Americans Is Found to be Uneven
description: While Asian-American children rank high in academic achievement, their standing as a group has obscured the needs of pockets of Asian children, many of whom are immigrants or refugees living in poverty, according to a recent national study.

title: Footloose in Montreal
description: WITH its proud French heritage, lively night life and general air of bonhomie, Montreal is often called the most European city in North America. In fact, Montreal is the second largest French city in the world, after Paris. And like the great cities of Europe, it is a wonderful city to tour on foot.

title: Judy Morrill, Randall Taylor
description: Judy Ball Morrill, a daughter of DeWitt C. Morrill of Southbury, Conn., and the late Jane Ball Morrill, was married yesterday to Randall Lenox Taylor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Taylor of Ferndale, Wash. The Rev. Phillip Channing Ellsworth Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church in New York.

title: When Visiting the Mainstream Is an Experiment
description: A COUPLE OF WEEKS AGO, GUS VAN SANT, a movie director who maintains his outsider status by living and doing much of his work in Portland, Ore., was in Hollywood, of all places, tying up loose ends on his new film, ''Good Will Hunting.'' Amid anonymous furniture in a small, rented production office, he appeared to be doing his best to become invisible. He sat hunched over, arms crossed, chest caved in. His demeanor suggested that whispering would be more appropriate than talking.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column on Oct. 19, about Manhattan as seen in a pair of panoramic photographs taken in 1871, misstated the location used by the photographer. It was the roof of 53 East 54th Street, not No. 55 or 57.

title: Major Spending Bill Passes Amid Jockeying on Trade
description: The Senate gave final approval today to the largest of the Federal spending bills for 1998, but Congress remained deadlocked on other contentious issues as supporters and opponents of expanded trade authority for the President maneuvered for advantage and votes.

title: Deepening the Great Divide; Film Makers Say Article Distorted Sharpton's Views
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: A Celebrity Favorite Moves Downtown

title: A Little Bit of Everything (Except for Superheroes)
description: THE BEST THING ABOUT the holiday film season is that it includes what many studios and auteurs consider their best work of the year -- or at least the work they think has a shot at Oscar nominations. The downside: Some wonderful films will be lost in the crowd. This year, a bevy of critically praised novels and plays are coming to the cineplex, mixed with a gaggle of sequels and a pride of first-time directors. And here's the really odd thing: not a superhero in sight. ANITA GATES

title: Another Amazing Feat in Magical Year for Byrne
description: The other morning, Patrick Byrne, the trainer of Favorite Trick, was asked to describe his favorite trick.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: HOUDINI!!!: The Career of Ehrich Weiss

title: Men at War
description: From a London film studio, with the country brought to its knees by Nazi bombings, came Noel Coward's IN WHICH WE SERVE (1942), a towering human drama about a British destroyer and her crew. The battered sailors watch their torpedoed vessel sink, as they cling to rafts and debris and reminisce about home and family. The nostalgic vignettes center on the captain (Coward, above left), his first mate (Bernard Miles) and a young crewman (John Mills). Coward's portrayal and the ship's plight were reportedly based on his friend Lord Louis Mountbatten and his doomed boat off Crete -- THURSDAY at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. on HIST. Howard Thompson

title: Life's a Gamble. A Few People Make It a Profession.
description: FOR Lem Banker, becoming a professional gambler was a matter of joining the family business.

title: Lives; Unfinished Business
description: Early on a brilliant, summer sunday morning, my wife, Lynn, and I turned onto Rural Route 381 and drove into South Carolina between endless cotton fields. With a certain foreboding, we headed for the little mill town of McColl.

title: Wendy Kligerman and Wayne Stober
description: Wendy Iris Kligerman, a daughter of Carole B. Kligerman and Howard Kligerman of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married last evening to Clifford Wayne Stober, the son of Ruth L. Stober and Gerald S. Stober of Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Robert Levine performed the ceremony at the Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Construction Bustles at an Old Hospital's Grounds
description: SIGNS of new construction are everywhere on the grounds of what once was the Central Islip Psychiatric Center, with industrial space, housing and a $212 million Federal building and courthouse all under way.

title: INSIDE
description: NATO's Quiet Pitchman

title: Pamela Fornero, Robert Kulesh
description: Pamela Ann Fornero, the daughter of Leo Fornero of Springfield, N.J., and the late Barbara C. Cullen, was married yesterday to Robert George Kulesh, the son of Josephine B. Kulesh of Greenwich, Conn., and the late George Kulesh. The Rev. Mark Hallinan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISNER, BERNARD J.
description: WEISNER-Bernard J. On November 5, 1997. Loving husband of Roslyn; cherished father of Claire and Elisa; beloved brother of Carol, Harold and Frances. Devoted grandfather of Cynthia and Ethan. Contributions to Yale Hillel, POB 209077, New Haven, CT 06520-9077.

title: A Tribute to Copland
description: ONE day after what would have been the 97th birthday of Aaron Copland, Sarah Lawrence College faculty members and the Chamber Choir are convening in Reisinger Hall to pay homage to the composer and raise funds for the Copland Heritage Association. Proceeds of the concert next Saturday at 5 P.M. will help restore Copland's former home in Cortlandt and eventually convert it to a composers' residence and center for musical activities.

title: ON THE MAP; Who Killed the Parson and His Mistress? A Trial Replayed
description: The 88-year-old white marble Somerset County courthouse in Somerville is a sublime sight. But 71 years ago, its serenity was disturbed by hordes of reporters covering the notorious Hall-Mills murder trial. The trial is to come to life again Nov. 14 through 16 and 21 through 23, in a play staged in the courthouse where it took place.

title: Nancy Lasher, Jordan Hamowy
description: Nancy Jeanne Lasher, a daughter of Carol M. Lasher of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and Douglas S. Lasher of Marlborough, N.H., was married on Friday to Jordan S. Hamowy, a son of Cynthia and Edwin W. Hamowy of New York. Justice Phyllis B. Gangel-Jacob of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated in her chambers.

title: Alexis Dudden, Michael Eastwood
description: Alexis Bray Dudden, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur P. Dudden of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married there yesterday to Michael Woodbury Eastwood, a son of Faith W. Eastwood and Bruce S. Eastwood, both of Lexington, Ky. The Rev. Lewis Hartman Mills, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Redeemer.

title: So Far Knicks Are a Hit, But Just Until the Final Act
description: The Knicks cannot seem to make a graceful exit, often tripping over the threshold as they leave a building.

title: Syracuse Letterman, 99, Looks to the Millennium
description: THERE seems to be a fountain of youth in New York State. It may not work for everybody, but it appears to be propelling 99-year-old Walter Rose into an unusual position: by the millennium he will have lived in three centuries. The name of this powerful force: homecoming weekend at Syracuse University.

title: Ms. Boughner, And Dr. Miller
description: Suzanne Marie Boughner was married on Friday to Dr. David Lee Miller. Helen A. Ali, the registrar of the Supreme Court of the British Virgin Islands, officiated at Little Dix Bay, a resort on Virgin Gorda.

title: How Brazil Scares Korea, and Vice Versa
description: When it comes to speculation, there are no national boundaries. As world markets swooned at the end of last week, the most intriguing report came out of South Korea. Banks there had borrowed money and loaded up on Latin American bonds. Now, facing margin calls, they were dumping the bonds.

title: Word & Image; The Postwar Trance
description: Washington and its media monitors went into a mild tizzy when the President fired his new weapon, the line-item veto, to shoot down 50 of the hundreds of Pentagon projects that Congress habitually spreads among influential members. Although Bill Clinton was careful to spare the rich contracts destined for the hometowns of the Republican leaders of the House and Senate, many of their troops have come to regret arming the White House with the power to unbundle their appropriations.

title: A Twilight Special That's Really Special
description: IF there is a better three-course dinner on Long Island for the money ($18.95) than the West End Cafe's twilight special I have not tasted it. Moreover few, if any, complete meals priced under $20 offer the sophisticated dishes available here.

title: In Praise of Lights, Many Neon
description: Times Square, which is bursting with a new generation of moving signs and illuminated images, is the focus of an exhibition celebrating its near-century of bright lights. The New-York Historical Society show ''Signs and Wonders,'' which opens on Wednesday and is to run until March 8, includes fragments of actual signs, reduced versions of others and old photographs of historic signs.

title: An Airport Bar Takes Off and Goes Into Orbit
description: RARE is the airport bar that leaves an impression. Harshly lighted and uncomfortably furnished, most are suitable only for a quick belt between flights.

title: Sports of The Times; The Day Lloyd Carr Bought a Little Time
description: AT intermission of the so-called Judgment Day game between undefeated Michigan and undefeated Penn State yesterday, the legendary Bo Schembechler sat contentedly after watching the Wolverines manhandle the Nittany Lions. In a rain-soaked battle of Big Ten powers, Michigan had built a 24-0 halftime lead. It had played with such suffocating dominance that the home fans no longer were pulling for a victory but simply for a pride-saving touchdown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARP, MORRIS L.
description: KARP-Morris L. In Miami Beach, Florida, on November 5, 1997. Beloved husband of Edith. Loving father to Eugene and Sue. Adored grandfather of Alyssa and Steven Sadoff and Valerie Karp. Very proud great grandfather of Annabelle. Brother of Joe and Abe. Services are on Sunday, November 9, Garick's, 1700 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, 11:30 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE GRUYTER, PRINCESS FATEMEH KHANOUM
description: de GRUYTER-Princess Fatemeh Khanoum, 97, on November 4, 1997. Wife of the late Professor Wilhelmus Josephus de Gruyter. Mother of Veronica Catherine Isabelle de Gruyter Hearst. Grandmother of Carlos Alexander Beracasa and Maria Fabiola Beracasa. Private services and mass were held on November 5, 1997.

title: Arts Center Sees Newark as an Audience and a Muse
description: From the beginning, there was some concern that the New Jersey Performing Arts Center would be a distant and haughty cultural pavilion that offered only opera, ballet and symphony orchestras, viewing its neighbors as more in need of conversion than entertainment.

title: A Cracow Minyan
description: To the Editor: In ''A Section of Cracow Restores Its Jewish Past'' (Sept. 14), Jane Perlez says ''about 200 elderly Jews are registered in the local community.'' I was surprised. When my wife and I visited the Remuh Synagogue in Cracow 12 years ago, we left believing that nowhere near that number would be around in the not-too-distant future.

title: Slower Population Growth Won't Last Forever; Literacy and Fertility
description: To the Editor:

title: F.Y.I.
description: Where Have You Gone, Verrazano Street?

title: Sausalito at Its Best: Off-Season
description: SEASONED travelers who visit Sausalito, Calif., the pocket-sized Marin County community just across the Golden Gate Bridge from San Francisco, sometimes remark on how much the town of 7,500 reminds them of places along the French Riviera.

title: An Ecological Battle Over River Basins in California
description: Disregard the abandoned shopping carts, half submerged in the stream beds, and the cottonwoods, willows and reeds growing in the muddy concrete channels. Ignore the noise of the surrounding freeways, the foul smell of the water and the electrical towers strung along the riverbank.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREM, SYBIL GERTRUDE NICHOLS
description: PREM-Sybil Gertrude Nichols. On November 6, 1997 in Bridgeville, PA., at The Country Meadows Nursing and Rehabilitation Center at age 98. A long-time resident of Larchmont, N.Y., and New York, NY, she was the wife of the late F. Herbert Prem, a senior partner in the New York City admiralty law firm of Bigham, Englar, Jones & Houston, who died in 1974. For many years she had been active in fund raising activities for the New York Philharmonic Society, and had also served as Chairwoman of the Comite Maritime International Meeting in the United States. She is survived by her son, F. Herbert Prem, Jr. of New York, New York, Sharon, CT., and West Brooksville, ME., her daughter, Lois Prem Simon, of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL., five grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. Services will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NOVIK, MORRIS S.
description: NOVIK-Morris S. To my brother who will always be in my heart. He was my best friend and I sorely miss him. Mary P.

title: Election's Over. It's Problem-Solving Time
description: FURIOUS about paying the highest car-insurance premiums in the country, voters nearly tossed Christie ''Landslide'' Whitman out of office last week.

title: Transporting Lawsuits Across State Lines
description: AT first, the headlines seemed too good to be true. After months of hard negotiations, the attorneys general of 40 states reached a proposed $368.5 billion settlement in June with the nation's once-invincible tobacco makers, one that would allow the states to recoup a fortune in Medicaid payments spent on behalf of smokers.

title: New Yorkese
description: Granted, New Yorkers go to the beach while people from New Jersey go to the shore or, more accurately, downashowa.

title: November 2-8; Just Imagine a New 'Joy of Sex'
description: The helpful illustration showing how to skin a squirrel is gone (hold down the tail with your foot and pull the body out). And if your idea of cocktail canapes has a chunk of canned pineapple at its heart, some of the joy is definitely gone.

title: Defining Moments; Istanbul: Transfiguration of an Audience
description: The International Istanbul Music Festival is a stunning compendium of Western hipness, symbol to the city's citizens of its rebirth as a secular culture capital. When I attended, five years ago, the festival included -- along with performances by Tracy Chapman, David Byrne and Baryshnikov -- an evening of dervish music and dance.

title: A Family Practice: Yet Another Redgrave
description: AS Dr. Eleanor Bramwell in the ''Masterpiece Theater'' series ''Bramwell,'' Jemma Redgrave is proud, determined and willful as she helps the poor and downtrodden in Victorian London. In character, Ms. Redgrave has a sense of resolve: she knows what she wants to do and she will use any means to achieve her goal.

title: Health Plans With Choice: Good Deals?
description: IT'S open enrollment time for many benefits plans, and a big question for families is this: Should they stay with their low-cost H.M.O. or switch to a managed-care plan with more freedom to choose a doctor or other professional, called a ''point-of-service'' feature?

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SARAH CONLEYBy Ellen Gilchrist.Little, Brown, $23.95.

title: Where Writers Really Live: In the Imagination
description: AFTER a mostly dour potpourri of plays called ''Rowing to America: The Immigrant Experience'' last season, the Playwrights Theater of New Jersey here is bracingly, if perhaps unwittingly, thrusting well-aimed gibes at its previous heart-on-sleeve, earnest intentions.

title: All the Pope's Men
description: To the Editor:

title: Style; Having Fun Yet?
description: Whoever you are, you probably have more fun than I do on Saturday nights. By 11 P. M. in my neighborhood -- the Upper East Side -- I can hear an Elsa Peretti pin drop. I'm sure you live on a street bustling with action around the clock. My block is so desolate I may one night rent a car just for the thrill of getting a great parking space.

title: Voice of America
description: THE AMERICAN OPERA SINGER

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: LEON AND BOB. Written and illustrated by Simon James. Candlewick. $15.99. (Ages 5 to 9) Leon is new in town, and Bob is the imaginary friend he confides in. Leon makes breakfast for Bob, goes to school with him and wants to take him to meet the new boy who has moved in next door. But, at a crucial moment, Bob disappears. Or does he?

title: Save '27 Bank, Petitions Ask
description: The Marine Midland Bank on the northeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue and 96th Street is the sort of solid, stately presence that nearby residents have come to assume is permanent. So when the bank began preparing to move to a storefront across the street and rumors began to circulate that the building would be sold, perhaps to a high-rise developer, concerned neighbors swung into action.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS; Streamlining a Big Small-Cap Lineup
description: THE 1990's have been rough on Charles M. Royce, a pioneer of small-cap value investing.

title: Stretch Effect
description: Not all women are to a long neck born. But at least now the illusion can be acquired.

title: The Big Round One
description: THE END OF TIME

title: Florida to Spend $2.7 Billion to Build Schools
description: The Florida Legislature decided on Friday to spend nearly $3 billion on school construction and repairs over the next five years to ease overcrowding that is among the worst in the nation.

title: Toddler, in Critical Condition, Apparently Took Methadone
description: A 2-year-old boy was in critical condition last night at Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx, apparently after swallowing methadone, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about legislation to overhaul the Internal Revenue Service misstated the proposal's scope. Tax experts expect that only a few hundred taxpayers a year will benefit from provisions shifting the burden of proof in Tax Court cases to the Government, but larger numbers stand to benefit from other aspects of the proposal. [A letter from Bill Archer, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, appears today on page 44.

title: What's Really Needed To Help Students
description: AN advocate for children with learning disabilities, Ann W. Seigel, of West Hartford, said she gets an upset stomach every time she hears talk of reducing the number of children being diagnosed with learning problems. Ms. Seigel says she worries that if educational services are cut for these children, the risk of their dropping out of school will rise sharply and they could become unemployable, or even commit crimes. Ms. Seigel said she gets sicker with fears that parents of other children will rally to support cuts in special education programs.

title: A Tragedy Recalled in Dance
description: A DANCE PIECE by Robin Lake titled ''Dissonance'' will be performed at 7 P.M. tonight in Jorgensen Auditorium at the University of Connecticut in Storrs. The work commemorates Krystallnacht, the night of Nov. 9, 1939, in Germany when a reign of terror against Jews began with the breaking of windows.

title: November 2-8; The U.S. Takes a Few MIGs Off Moldova's Hands
description: If you can't beat them, buy them.

title: Rooms With a View -- of the Sidewalk
description: BROKER and buyer, real estate agent and renter, even the ones who basically love the ground-floor apartments they live or traffic in can quickly reel off the reasons to hate them.

title: Book Portrays J.F.K. as Reckless and Immoral
description: ''The Dark Side of Camelot,'' a new book by the investigative reporter Seymour M. Hersh, relentlessly tries to demythologize John F. Kennedy, portraying him as a reckless, often-immoral cad who accepted the aid of mobsters to steal the 1960 Presidential election, became obsessed with the need to assassinate Fidel Castro, and, against his better judgment, steered the United States deeper into the Vietnam war so as not to appear weak in his campaign for a second term.

title: On Language; Gimme the Ol' White Shoe
description: ''She is a lawyer in a white-shoe firm,'' wrote Randy Kennedy in The New York Times about Tiffany Palmer, an attorney at a prestigious law firm.

title: Meetings Around Brooklyn, District by District
description: DISTRICT 1 -- Greenpoint, Williamsburg; next meeting, Nov. 18, 7 P.M.; 211 Ainslee Street, corner of Manhattan Avenue; Board President: Vincent Abate; District Manager: Gerald Esposito; (718) 389-0009. Agenda: To be anounced.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report last Sunday about the opening of a Borders bookstore on Park Avenue misstated the ownership of the Borders chain. It is no longer part of the Kmart Corporation. The current owner is the Borders Group, which became a publicly held corporation in 1995.

title: Drawing Attention To Alzheimer's Services
description: On behalf of Alzheimer's disease patients and families everywhere, we appreciate your article on the Rita Hayworth Gala [''Volunteer Heads Gala to Fight Alzheimer's''] on Oct. 2.

title: In the Region/Westchester; County Residential Sales Are at a Record High
description: RESIDENTIAL sales in Westchester reached record highs for both average prices and numbers of homes sold in the third quarter of this year. And for the first time, the average price of a detached home broke the $400,000 mark, due primarily to brisker-than-expected sales of more expensive properties.

title: Red Corner
description: The woman in red was a lone voice. From shoes to scarf, her nail-polish-red ensemble spoke loudly for the joy of wearing color as a relief from the all-black look of spectators at the New York collections last week. Designers at all price levels have been trying for seasons to tempt women back into color, but to little avail. Today's all-black wardrobe, with its undeniable practicality and thinning elegance, has a parallel in the day clothes of the late Victorians, who became addicted to black.

title: Jennifer Brodlieb, James Cacioppo
description: Jennifer Bess Brodlieb, a daughter of Nancy and Richard Brodlieb of Huntington, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Anthony Cacioppo, a son of Coletta and Joseph Cacioppo of Miami. The Rev. Stuart H. Hoke performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Attack of the 90-Foot Teen-Agers
description: THIS is a quiz: Gavin, Leonardo and Claire, J. T. T; extra points if you can name all five Spice Girls; extra, extra points if you know Buffy the Vampire Slayer's last name.

title: Taking the Hint
description: The company no longer has need of someone's services, and the message must be delivered. How does it come? Often, awkwardly: The corporate apartment's landlord asks for a moving date, the computer no longer recognizes a password, or the office lock is changed. How has your company handled dismissals? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: The View From: Stamford; For This Audience, Nothing but World Scale Itself Will Do
description: THE three men pored over papers as they sat amid the plush splendor of the Tara Stamford Hotel lobby one recent Sunday afternoon, trying to figure out how they were going to mesh their presentations.

title: Deepening the Great Divide; The East-West Divide Extends Beyond Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: More Briefs in N.A.A.C.P. v. East Haven
description: In 1993 the Greater New Haven branch of the N.A.A.C.P. filed a lawsuit against the town of East Haven claiming the town's hiring practices discriminate against African Americans.

title: Then There Were 80: Assembly Race Results
description: In the 80 Assembly contests, the Democrats picked up one seat, for a total of 31. The Republicans still hold a decisive edge, with 49 seats. Here are the winners, as reported by the Associated Press.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLAN, ROBERT J.
description: DOLAN-Robert J. ''Bob,'' 56. Passed away November 1, 1997, at home in Los Altos Hills, California after an eight month battle with cancer. Former President of Peninsula Office Supply with eleven stores in Northern California. Loving husband of Katherine ''Kathy'' Coddington Dolan, proud father of Clipper Dolan of Boulder, Colorado and Dana Dolan of Los Altos Hills, California.

title: Defining Moments; Florence: A Protest at a Crossroads
description: After a month in Florence we still haven't been to the Uffizi, or to the Pitti Palace, or the Bargello, or the Duomo. My children are about to start school without knowing a word of Italian; my wife has been (unwittingly) washing our clothes in fabric softener instead of detergent, so that my pants grab onto my legs like thousands of tiny tickling spiders. The stores are about to close, really close, for a three-day holiday; the butcher shop churns with women carrying string bags. There is no line, no queue, but there is some kind of invisible order, because after 20 minutes I am thrust to the front, where I confront the butcher.

title: State Revives Plan to Control Building in Fire Island Dune Areas
description: FOURTEEN years ago, when the state held a hearing on building in the dune area of Fire Island, Alan Brockman was one of more than 500 property owners who protested.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: HISTORIC SITES

title: STURM UND SONG
description: * The Golden Gate Bridge district board is trying to pick an official song for the structure. * The leading contender is ''The Bridge: Golden Gate,'' words by Noah Griffin (a former mayoral press secretary), soft-jazz tune by Bob Voss (a local songwriter). * Some 300 songs have been written about San Francisco -- only three about the bridge. * In 1984, ''I Left My Heart in San Francisco'' was displaced as the city's official song by the more rollicking ''San Francisco.'' * Some people think the bridge theme was chosen without enough public input. At one board meeting, Jean Anderson, an elderly dance instructor, protested by singing a song that her mother, Irene, wrote in 1934. * John Kress, a bridge official, says the selection process has been extended. Why? ''We underestimated the intensity of public feeling.''

title: Reaching the Height of Danger and Beyond
description: AN exhausted mountain climber stranded in a storm at the loftiest, most remote point on earth cradles a two-way radio in frostbitten fingers and bids farewell to his pregnant wife thousands of miles away, proposing a name for their unborn child. In a novel, such a scene would strain credulity, but it happened last year just below the summit of Mount Everest. The full tragedy was told unflinchingly by a traumatized survivor, Jon Krakauer, in his harrowing book, ''Into Thin Air.''

title: A Place for the Traditional in Port Chester
description: WE have often noted that this village's Main Street affords the adventurous a wealth of culinary choices from all parts of the globe. But to satisfy a yen for the familiar, diners will find that no establishment along this thoroughfare delivers traditional finesse as well as does Alba's. Here diners expect a fine meal and gracious service and are rarely disappointed.

title: NATO's Salesman Finds the U.S. Tough Territory
description: When Javier Solana, NATO's most senior civilian official, arrived late for a television interview in San Francisco last month, the host was already questioning a stand-in.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CAPALDO, LOUIS A.
description: CAPALDO-Louis A. Passed away November 1970. His spirit and love lives on and is ever with me. Beloved wife, Susan Capaldo

title: Defining Moments; Quito: It Must Have Been the Altitude
description: Several women prayed in the penumbra of candlelight in the San Francisco church of Quito, Ecuador. I stood still, facing the altar mayor, caught in the suspension of time. In the 16th century, the Baroque from Middle Europe, medieval mudejar art from Spain's Arab invasions, the Italian Renaissance and the genius of Inca craftsmanship had all come together here, freezing history in this gold over red, dazzling, blooming masterpiece.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Adele

title: Restaurateur and Dangerous Character
description: MELVA Max has a date at Criminal Court on Wednesday to answer charges of obstruction of justice, harassment and disorderly conduct. I can't decide whether her version of how she came to be such a dangerous character should be submitted to ''NYPD Blue,'' ''America's Most Wanted'' or ''Mad TV.''

title: A Magical Yet Fragile Palette: Houses, Beaches and Shining Water
description: FROM the shoreline the water surrounding Long Island usually looks a drab gray. But from a helicopter over Fire Island on a recent morning the gentle waves were an almost luminous aqua.

title: Kings, Castles and Kids
description: ARKADY GELLER strides the room in his chalk-striped suit, rhythmically tapping a pencil on his hand as he studies eight chess games in progress.

title: Pass the Madeleines
description: THE YEAR OF READING PROUSTA Memoir in Real Time.By Phyllis Rose.268 pp. New York:Scribner. $23.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUNICK, CARL
description: TUNICK-Carl. A lifelong friend and special human being. You will always be with us and we will miss you deeply forever. Jack and Ruth Widerker and family

title: Trail Is Back in the Running
description: Several generations of athletes -- from Ireland, from California, from across the street -- had run on the cross-country trail at Van Cortlandt Park. But the trail, built in 1914, had deteriorated badly by the late 70's. Its deep, muddy ruts and jutting roots and rocks were breaking runners' ankles and twisting their knees. School coaches began holding their meets elsewhere.

title: Mariners, Still Playing for Guts, Glory and No Pay, Near a Title
description: The Brooklyn Mariners have prevailed. They are the 1997 Garden State Football League Champions. Coached by the legendary Pudgie Walsh, the semipro team based in Marine Park beat the Connecticut Mustangs, 35-27, to win the championship on Oct. 18. But their quest continues to regain the national title they won in 1991.

title: U.S. Is Divided on Adoption, Survey of Attitudes Asserts
description: The first broad national survey of attitudes toward adoption has found that Americans remain deeply ambivalent about open adoption, in which the birth parents may have contact with the adoptive parents and child, and about whether unmarried pregnant teen-agers should raise their babies themselves or place them for adoption.

title: The Socratic Method
description: ALWAYS OUTNUMBERED, ALWAYS OUTGUNNED

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, WOLCOTT W., JR.
description: ROBINSON-Wolcott W., Jr. Age 56, on November 7, 1997. Loving husband of Jane Bunn Robinson and loving brother of Gail Galli. Caring son of Wolcott W. Robinson, Sr. Services private.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: A LEHRER PARTY

title: Babes in Toe Shoes
description: I feel a deep sadness for these young ''up and comers'' to the ballet world (''Babes in Toe Shoes,'' by Susie Linfield). As a former dancer with seven years at that other big-time company, American Ballet Theater, and seven more in ''Phantom'' on Broadway, I want to scream when I think of the teen-age experiences and memories that these young dancers will never have.

title: Culture Zone; Bananas for Rent
description: They are as pervasive as roaches, as persuasive as the weather, as popular as Princess Diana. They adorn our clothes, our luggage, our sneakers and our hats. They are ubiquitous on television, unavoidable in magazines and inevitable on the Internet. The average American, it is estimated, is pelted by some 3,000 advertising messages a day, some 38,000 TV commercials a year.

title: After Isolation in North Korea, Japanese Wives Visit Homes
description: Fifteen Japanese women who have lived in North Korea for most of their adult lives arrived in Japan tonight for a brief return visit, a result of an unofficial ''wives for food'' exchange between the countries.

title: Tracing Agatha Christie In Torquay
description: BUT for the sweet charms of Torquay, an English seaside town, Agatha Christie might have grown up an American. Her father, Frederick Miller, born and brought up in Massachusetts, married an Englishwoman and expected to raise his family in America. The couple settled in the popular Victorian resort of Torquay, temporarily they thought, while awaiting the birth of baby Agatha. But the town's attractions caught them up and they never left.

title: Photo Ops for Uncle Joe
description: THE COMMISSAR VANISHES

title: Election Returns: Bond Issues And Wildwood Bar Hours
description: Seemingly lost in the shadow of the gubernatorial race were three referendum questions on ballots Tuesday, all concerning the use of bond money to help municipalities finance local projects. All three were approved. A question asking whether unused funds from the Water Supply Bond Act of 1981 should be lent at low interest to communities to build water supply projects passed 989,779 to 601,850. A similar question regarding sanitary and storm sewer projects and a 1989 bond act passed 1,005,315 to 615,372. And a proposal to issue $20 million in new bonds to help urban and rural centers tear down abandoned buildings was approved 962,918 to 761,686.

title: Running Around in High Circles
description: NO REGRETS

title: DIARY
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Helping Children Of Divorce
description: FOR most preschoolers, playing house is as familiar and predictable as learning to ride a tricycle or build a block tower. For the half-dozen or so children who show up on Tuesday afternoons at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center Westchester Division here, playing house takes on a different dimension.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKO, SOLOMON
description: BERKO-Solomon. On November 6, 1997, in New York, at age 100. Beloved father of Albert and Jay. Devoted father-in-law of Florence and Barbara. Beloved brother of Divorah and Pesel. Adored grandfather of Robin, Jane, David, Patti, Neal, Steven, Robert, Renee, Richard, Donna. Cherished greatgrandfather of Joe, Peter, Kelley, Chloe, Matthew, Ivan, Annie, Lonnie, Max, Leif, Zachary, Mallory, Courtney, Lauren, Michael. You are in our hearts always.

title: Shrine Reconsiders Its Plans For a Dali Painting
description: Last month the spotlight was on a Salvador Dali painting that the Blue Army Shrine in Washington Township had for years stored, forgotten, in a closet (In Brief, Oct. 19). Estimates of the value of ''A Vision of Hell'' commissioned in 1960, ranged from $600,000 to $3 million, but the shrine said it had no plans to sell it. Last week, its board of trustees changed its mind, saying it would consider offers.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 10/

title: Buenos Aires
description: Buenos Aires is catching its rhy thm again thanks to an improving economy that has put money back into the pockets of Argentines. This fiscal rejuvenation, following a two-year recession, even attracted the attention of President Bill Clinton, who visited this sophisticated city, the world's ninth largest, last month to promote his vision of increased interhemispheric trade.

title: Continuing Growth In Bias Crimes
description: As to current trends in bias crimes, ''New Responses to Soaring Bias Crimes'' (Oct. 19), the greatest impact on the future will be our mosaic society, that is, increased ethnic diversity in our communities and work forces. Between the 1980 and 1990 censuses, the Asian-American population more than doubled, growing by 108 percent, twice as fast as the Hispanic population, which grew by 53 percent, eight times as fast as the black population, which grew by 13 percent, and 15 times as fast as the white population, which grew by 6 percent. As our society becomes more of a mosaic, there will inevitably be increases in bias crimes.

title: In Repairing the I.R.S., Big and Many Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Sarah Svertesky, Daniel McGee
description: Sarah Elaine Svertesky and Daniel Thomas McGee were married yesterday in Washington. The Rev. Lawrence J. Madden performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church.

title: In the Footsteps of Dickens, With Great Trepidation
description: IF HOLLYWOOD IS THE ULTIMATE refuge for the cynical and the jaded, how then do we explain Mitch Glazer?

title: New Yorkese
description: Thanks for the nostalgia (On Language: ''New Yorkese,'' by William Safire). We New Yorkers are special enough even to have our own linguistics.

title: The Pain of Being Forbidden to See or Contact Grandchildren
description: ELEVEN years ago, a Manhattan businesswoman lost three people she dearly loved. First, her 36-year-old daughter died of leukemia. Then, her daughter's husband kept her from seeing her two granddaughters, even though they lived not far away.

title: Heather Epstein, Richard Klein
description: Heather Robin Epstein, a Federal prosecutor in Alexandria, Va., and Stephen Richard Klein, an arms control adviser in Washington, are to be married today. Rabbi Azriel C. Fellner is to officiate with Steven P. Schwartz, a rabbinical student, at the 200 Fifth Club in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLATT, MINNIE
description: BLATT-Minnie. On November 6, 1997. Beloved mother of Marilyn Carr. Devoted grandmother of Andrea and Beth. Adoring great grandmother of Alexandra. Graveside Service today at Maimonides Cemetery, Elmont, Long Island, New York at 11:30 A.M.

title: FILM: THE ACTRESS; Getting the Chance To Make Hollywood Lengthen Its A-List
