description: THERE IS A SCENE BETWEEN Helen Hunt and Jack Nicholson in the darkly romantic comedy ''As Good as It Gets'' that James L. Brooks, who directed the film, described in the script in this way: ''She hands him a letter.''

title: Southampton Press at 100 Years
description: DONALD LOUCHHEIM, co-publisher of The Southampton Press, expects to be history within a year. This year, however, he is celebrating the 100th anniversary of the paper he bought 25 years ago. His eldest son, Joe, is poised to take over the helm, but Mr. Louchheim isn't giving the goods away so easily.

title: Mutual Insurers' Plans Gain a Formidable Foe
description: CONSUMER advocates who have been fighting a campaign by some of the nation's largest insurance companies to overhaul their corporate structures gained a powerful new ally last week.

title: Voters Approve Fund To Preserve Land
description: PROPONENTS for preserving open space in central Westchester received political help recently. Voters in Greenburgh supported the town's referendum to establish a public fund for land preservation in Tuesday's election, while State Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky recently announced that Albany would allocate substantial funds from the environmental bond act to help buy the 135-acre Gaisman estate in Hartsdale from the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

title: Parish Holidays
description: To the Editor: My friend and I recently enjoyed a Parish Holiday in Carshalton, Surrey, England, a trip we read about in The Times (''A Taste of Life in an English Village,'' March 17, 1996). We were a group of 9 Americans and 30 parishioners from All Saints Anglican Church in Carshalton. We certainly saw all the sights, but it was the warm hospitality of those who were hosts and drove and guided us for nine days as their contribution to their church that made this experience memorable. Who said the English are reserved?

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday referred incorrectly to Federal law governing the investment of taxable money in offshore hedge funds. The law does not prohibit such investments, but investors are often subject to tax consequences that make them unappealing. These include an inability to use net losses to offset gains and an obligation to pay interest charges on gains for which tax payments are deferred. Some offshore hedge funds are not willing to provide investors with the information they need to avoid interest penalties.

title: Hispanic Voters Emerge as a Powerful and Unpredictable Force
description: While last week's mayoral election was marked by a generally sparse turnout, an unexpectedly large number of Hispanic residents cast ballots, suggesting that the Hispanic vote in New York City is turning into a formidable force -- one that is not necessarily aligned with the Democratic Party.

title: A Pie of the People
description: ''PIZZALANDIA'' reads the sign outside a basement tavern with sidewalk tables three blocks from the Vatican. More than 20,000 similar places -- some fancier, others more modest -- are scattered throughout Italy, from the shores of Sicily to Alpine villages, feeding a million or so people every day.

title: Corrections
description: The contents page on Oct. 19 positioned a listing incorrectly for the review of ''The End of the Novel of Love,'' by Vivian Gornick. The book is nonfiction.

title: Shore Excursion
description: That dinghy with tourists heading for shore has a serious shock in store.

title: Leah Bieler and Ron Fish
description: Leah Nicole Bieler, a daughter of Gloria and Mark Bieler of Scarsdale, N.Y., is to be married this evening to Rabbi Joseph Ron Fish, a son of Joy and Rabbi Judah Fish of Kingston, N.Y. Rabbi Gordon Tucker is to perform the ceremony at the New York Botanical Garden.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Books From The Times
description: What happens to everybody has happened to the people featured in THE LAST WORD. The New York Times Book of Obituaries and Farewells: A Celebration of Unusual Lives (Morrow, $25), edited by Marvin Siegel, who oversees obituaries at The New York Times. This collection, as Russell Baker points out in a foreword, is not concerned with towering personalities but with some who ''enriched the tale of life in the 20th century without shaking the earth'': people like Douglas Corrigan, who flew the Atlantic solo in 1938, starting from Brooklyn, and ever after maintained he had been heading for California; Orville Redenbacher, who had a vision and saw popcorn; Margaret G. Cahill, the first Miss America, who won the title in a flat-out no-redeeming-social-value beauty contest in 1921; Albert B. Blaustein, ''the Jewish James Madison,'' a lawyer who specialized in devising constitutions for new countries; Meyer Michael Greenberg, who circulated on the Bowery giving gloves to those who had none every winter from 1963 to 1993; and 90-odd others whose responses to the moving and the shaking of the era were such as would make them anybody's favorite unforgettable aunt, uncle or cousin.

title: $400,000 Median Price Sets County Record
description: CONSUMER demand during the third quarter of the year drove the median sale price of a single family house beyond the $400,000 mark for the first time since the Westchester County Board of Realtors began collecting data in 1981.

title: FUNDS WATCH
description: Garzarelli Closing Fund

title: Opening of Guide Dog School Is Delayed
description: A SCHOOL intended to teach blind children both academics and the ability to work with guide dogs has been delayed from opening because of a zoning dispute.

title: More Investors Wary About Going Abroad
description: WILLIE W. TAYLOR has a little money in international mutual funds. But given the risks of foreign investing, he generally likes to play overseas markets the old-fashioned way: by buying stock in American multinational corporations.

title: The Nation; Desperately Seeking the Next Susan B.
description: CONGRESS is on the verge of replacing the much-maligned Susan B. Anthony dollar, but now the question is, with what?

title: Ellen Breslau, Eric Leventhal
description: Sara Ellen Breslau, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Breslau of West Newton, Mass., was married last night to Eric Barnett Leventhal, a son of Elaine Leventhal of Westbury, N.Y., and the late Dr. Fred Leventhal. Rabbi Andrew Warmflash officiated at Temple Emanuel in Newton Centre, Mass.

title: INVESTING WITH: Foster S. Friess; Brandywine Fund
description: THE recent stock market break did not faze Foster S. Friess, manager of the 12-year-old Brandywine fund, a top-notch mutual fund that buys mostly midsized stocks with big growth prospects.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-8

title: Clinton Stalks G.O.P. Votes In Final Push for Trade Bill
description: As the House of Representatives went into an unusual weekend session and the wheeling and dealing on President Clinton's trade legislation began in earnest, Commerce Secretary William M. Daley declared: ''If you like attention, this is a good time to be undecided.''

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2

title: A Wonderment of Birds
description: Across a rain-Brailled slough in the Cosumnes River Preserve, on the eastern edge of California's Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta, my birding companion from the Nature Conservancy, Brad Northrup, and I watched five greater sandhill cranes, necks extended, veer in. These are long-legged, predominantly gray birds with tinges of rust color and bald red crowns. When they landed, each crane awkwardly hopped a few yards, then held stock-still. In a moment they all displayed outstretched wings as if drying racks of wet neckties. Folding in their wings, they started up an elegant choreography of head-bobbing, slow-motion, high-strutting steps, prowling the stubble field in five different directions. The background distinctly resembled a Rothko painting, its floating color fields -- gray sky on top, reedy beige of the sloping wetlands below -- silhouetted other incoming groups of sandhills against the horizon. This bleak, chill November day in north-central California struck me as perfect for viewing cranes.

title: Pamela Brier and Peter Aschkenasy
description: Pamela Sara Brier and Peter Aschkenasy are to be married today at their home in Brooklyn. District Attorney Richard A. Brown of Queens is to officiate. Rabbi Julie Schonfeld will take part in the ceremony.

title: Deepening the Great Divide; The East-West Divide Extends Beyond Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: Alicia Alexander, Sean Cadogan
description: Alicia Celeste Marie Alexander, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George D. Alexander of Rosedale, Queens, was married yesterday to Sean Anthony Cadogan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Winston A. Cadogan of Cambria Heights, Queens. The Rev. Donald A. Kavanagh performed the ceremony at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Cambria Heights.

title: Henna Beyond Hair
description: Henna over lunch, henna when you drink and henna while you shop. There's nothing new about the ancient art of henna painting, in which designs are painted on the body, except that it's being done where you would least expect to see it. Like at the trendy Indian restaurant Akbar (above) on Park Avenue and 58th Street, where it is available, starting at $10, with Saturday lunch. Or the Diesel clothing stores and the new club Jet 19, where the designs start at $25.

title: From Carol Gilligan's Chair
description: What began as an idea jotted down at her kitchen table has grown into a central tenet of feminist thought: women differ from men; they are more concerned with the nexus of relationships that hold society together. Their psychological and moral development must be considered in their own light, not against criteria used to measure the behavior of men. That common-sense idea first came to Carol Gilligan, a developmental psychologist, in the early 70's, when she noticed that researchers were drawing conclusions about girls from studies of boys. In 1975 she published a paper that grew into a landmark book, ''In a Different Voice.'' In September, at 60, Gilligan was named the first holder of a chair in gender studies at Harvard's School of Education -- a rare commitment for such work and one that carries with it a research endowment of half a million dollars.

title: Small-Town Dreaming
description: ON a rainy, chilly morning in late October, a small group of rugged New Yorkers gathered in the safety of a classroom to seek advice on gratifying a few special human needs, like nature and animals and space.

title: Unafraid in Asia
description: Although the economic tigers of Southeast Asia may be looking more like alley cats, American and Japanese auto makers continue their Asian expansion, apparently undaunted. G.M. and Ford are building huge new assembly plants in Thailand, where a crumbling economy caused the Prime Minister, Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, below, to resign after just 11 months in office. The auto makers are also preparing to open up to five more factories in Southeast Asia and China. Toyota and Honda are cutting back production temporarily but are not changing their basic plans. . . . At home, Detroit's Big Three reported weak sales in October, the first month of the new model year. G.M. sales fell 4 percent; Ford's, 2.1 percent, and Chrysler's, 8.3 percent. Buyers showed enthusiasm only for the hottest new or redesigned models, like the brawny new Dodge Durango sport utility vehicle or the redesigned Honda Accord. Honda's sales rose 11.2 percent.

title: Corrections
description: The listing of coming films today on page 41 of the special Holiday Movies section, 2A, misstates the date for ''The Big Lebowski.'' It is to open in March 1998, not this Dec. 25.

title: Where the Boys Went
description: Your issue was a timely, sentimental journey for this displaced New Yorker, living for the last 10 years in Miami Beach, and currently coping with my worst Manhattan jones ever (Where the Boys Went,'' by Jesse Green).

title: A Naive Attack
description: To the Editor:

title: Dissents on Iran and Iraq; Carrots-for-China Policy Haunts U.S. in the Gulf
description: EACH in his own way, President Jiang Zemin of China and President Saddam Hussein of Iraq threw the spotlight last week on a central contradiction of the Clinton Administration's foreign policy -- a policy most notable for its heavy emphasis on trade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WROBEL, SIDNEY
description: WROBEL-Sidney. Loving husband, devoted father, adoring grandfather and great grandfather. On October 18. He will be missed forever.

title: Let Them Eat Elsewhere
description: Philippe Delgrange has been shut up in his little ''psychologically complex bistro'' too long (''Let Them Eat Elsewhere,'' by Bob Morris). He says he hates the French, but he is all about the French attitude. Anyone who chooses to be a part of this circus is not someone I want to be around when I'm eating.

title: Memory Therapy Is a Danger to Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: Donna DePetro, Nicholas Perry Jr.
description: Donna Jean DePetro, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. DePetro of Edgewood, R.I., was married yesterday to Nicholas Newlin Perry Jr., a son of Mr. Perry of Bradenton, Fla., and the late Marilyn C. Perry. The Rev. J. Barrie Shepherd performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLLER, ANNE H. (NEE HART)
description: MOLLER-Anne H. (nee Hart). Of Hackensack, NJ, formerly of Harrington Park, NJ. Beloved wife of the late John H. Moller. Devoted mother of John H. Moller of Ellicott City, MD, and Marilyn Moller of Southampton, PA. Loving grandmother of John Scott Moller of Rochester, NY, and Michelle Diane Moller of NYC. Funeral mass Tuesday, 10 AM, Holy Trinity RC Church, Hackensack, NJ. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Visitation Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the Volk-Leber Funeral Home, Teaneck, NJ.

title: Michelle Spahn, Philip Rosato
description: Michelle Judith Spahn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Spahn of Rockville Centre, N.Y., was married yesterday to Philip Richard Rosato, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ernest F. Rosato of Ardmore, Pa. The Rev. Charles T. Dougherty performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Families Plagued by a Home-Wrecking Mold
description: Excuse Randi Armstrong, a 34-year-old Staten Island resident, if she gets a little excited when she talks, but she is fighting an insidious enemy that has left her and her two daughters confined to bed for days at a time.

title: Home Sweet McGillicuddy's
description: A winter in Streeter, N.D., or Granville, N.D., is probably enough to make a person want a shot of Dr. McGillicuddy's schnapps, a point not lost on the Sazerac Company, the New Orleans-based importer of the Canadian booze. The two small, often-snowbound farming communities are competing to be renamed McGillicuddy City for the next four years. The winning town -- probably whichever one is judged to have the most recreational opportunities -- will get $100,000 and a chance to be the host of conventions for McGillicuddy's sales representatives.

title: Corrections
description: A article in the special Education Life section last Sunday about college campuses as movie sets misstated the title of Mary Zimnik at Agnes Scott College in Decatur, Ga. She is the filming project manager in the public relations department, not the department head.

title: To the Fund-Raiser Born
description: I'm sure that Robin Duke is a very nice lady; I'm equally sure that your staged cover photo is the closest she has ever come to riding in the subway (''To the Fund-Raiser Born,'' by Alex Witchel).

title: A Community of Strangers
description: I enjoyed Joseph McElroy's Lives column, ''A Community of Strangers,'' and was glad to know that someone else takes notice of his window neighbors. We moved into a corner apartment in the richly di-verse neighborhood of the Mission District in San Francisco. We choose not to have a television. We have found our windows provide ample entertainment (without commercials).

title: A Portrait of New Jersey Voters
description: In 1993, Christine Todd Whitman became Governor of New Jersey by defeating her Democratic opponent by 2 percentage points. This year, the contest was even closer. Mrs. Whitman defeated her Democratic challenger, James E. McGreevey, by only one percentage point.

title: Dominicans Face Strike As Hardship Fans Unrest
description: For months, the electrical power grid has been failing and the price of food rising throughout this Caribbean country. Protesters have been taking to the streets to burn tires and cars and throw stones and homemade bombs at the police.

title: Word for Word / The Nixon Tapes; Take My Vice President, Please! The Lighter Side of Watergate
description: WATERGATE was no laughing matter. Subverting the Constitution is serious business. And yet, amid the hard work of laundering money, breaking and entering, obstructing justice and other high crimes and misdemeanors, there was always time for a little levity in the Oval Office.

title: A Fight For On-Air Supremacy
description: ANYBODY who has happened on WNBC-TV, Channel 4, lately may have come upon a particularly portentous advertisement. The scene is some sort of a hangar, bathed in rich blue light and filled with a sibilant whirr.

title: Apartheid Torturer Testifies, As Evil Shows Its Banal Face
description: Jeffrey Benzien was one of the many minor but effective functionaries who made apartheid work for South Africa's white Government.

title: Jordan's Fragile Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: A Town Hall Of True Elegance Graces Clinton
description: KAREN L. MARSDEN glanced over her office as a bright autumn sun flowed in through three huge arched windows, accentuating the wainscoting, the black Italian marble fireplace, the carved wood mouldings where the walls meet the ceiling, the delicate pink and off-white pattern.

title: Dead-End Kids
description: Circumnavigation

title: Down in the Valley
description: Apple

title: Dependency's Double Edge; Addicts Uneasy in the New Era of Welfare, Their Godsend and Pitfall
description: Johnny, a 52-year-old man with a 40-year-old drug habit, sat in a meeting room recently in Damon House, a residential drug treatment center in the Southside neighborhood of Brooklyn, and whispered, ''Welfare -- I just wish I had never touched it.''

title: 'Lion King' Leaps Off the Screen Into Costume
description: TRANSLATING ''THE LION KING,'' Disney's animated film, into a musical has meant reconceiving all the animal (and vegetable) roles for the bright lights of the stage. In the case of the baboon-shaman Rafiki, the transformation went even further: a male character in the movie has become a female on the stage. The actress Tsidii Le Loka's own transformation into the character is shown below.

title: Europe Tire Test: Rainbow Hits the Road
description: Red tires might be cool, Ibrahim Mansur Ali thought. But no, Aetna Red clashed with the muted burgundy of his two-door Fiat Panda Eleganza.

title: The Loire Valley, Land of Kings and Troglodytes
description: The sky colors the Loire in its western valley while its narrower tributaries are the green of trees. I was in Amboise, in central France, planning to follow the blue river toward the celebrated Apocalypse Tapestry in Angers, 90 miles downstream - but I had a week to get there. Time to wander some green rivers, plains of sunflowers and corn and grapes ripening in the late-summer sun and the pale stone cities of Tours, Chinon, Saumur. No telling what I might see on my way to the Apocalypse.

title: Imagining a World That Would Follow An Apocalypse
description: THERE HAS BEEN SOME kind of global holocaust, part nuclear, part chemical. The big cities are all gone; the electricity's off; cars have long since run out of gas. A few people scrabble for sustenance in isolated settlements, surrounded by society's rubble.

title: E-Tickets
description: To the Editor: In regard to Sam Garcia's letter (''Fie on E-Tickets, Sept. 7), the following happened to my wife and me during a recent United Airlines check-in for a New York-to-Los Angeles trip. We were asked to show photo identification, and we showed driver's licenses. We were then asked to show the credit card that we used to buy the tickets.

title: Tracking of Radiation Exposure in Bomb Work Is Questioned
description: In the first 45 years of nuclear weapons production in this nation, the Government failed to properly track the radiation exposure of thousands of bomb workers, according to a new report by a private nonprofit group, which based its assessment on Government documents.

title: Jim Bakker
description: Jim Bakker is the subject of a new book, ''Jim Bakker: Miscarriage of Justice,'' by James A. Albert. Bakker, who was divorced from the former Tammy Faye Bakker in 1992, now lives on a farm in Hendersonville, N.C., where he

title: Doby Thrown a Curve, and Hangs In There
description: If anyone needs proof of the caliber of person needed to smash something as insidious as institutionalized racism, meet Larry Doby.

title: Jill Goldsholle, Paul Yonover
description: Jill Hayley Goldsholle and Dr. Paul Matthew Yonover were married last evening in Brooklyn. Rabbi Alvin Kass performed the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens.

title: Set to Build Dam, China Diverts Yangtze While Crowing About It
description: In a feat of engineering that China's leaders turned into a major political event, an army of workers and engineers diverted the Yangtze River from its natural course today, clearing the way for construction to begin on the world's biggest dam.

title: Guadalajara: Murals and Mariachis
description: One fist raised above his head, the other thrusting forth a flaming torch, the figure of Father Miguel Hidalgo looms over the staircase of Palacio del Gobierno, stirring all who climb the steps with his radical vision of violence and freedom. Beneath his torch is a sea of red flags and hundreds of men slashing and killing one another with bayonets vomited from the mouth of a gigantic serpent.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS; When Funds Merge: A Checklist
description: With competition sizzling, many fund companies want to present themselves as both leaner and stronger. They are quicker, therefore, to fold weaker performers into star performers.

title: November 2-8; Affirmative Action, Yes; Safer Handguns, No Thanks
description: Tuesday was a day for Americans to elect mayors and other state and local officials, but in some places voters spoke on national issues.

title: New Danger Tripping Up Wheelchairs
description: Sharon Brown, 57, uses her $26,000 motorized wheelchair to run errands near her Upper West Side apartment. But in April, and once last year, Ms. Brown said, she was thrown onto the sidewalk when her wheelchair suddenly stalled. She and other disabled New Yorkers who have had similar experiences say the problem is coming from an unlikely source: cellular telephones.

title: Fatal Fight Over Spoils By Insiders In Belgrade
description: Three top associates of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia and about a dozen of their lieutenants have been killed in recent months, apparently as part of a struggle within the ruling elite for control of the country's state-run industries and vast black-market rings.

title: Kerry Nagle, Douglas Pearl
description: Kerry Ann Nagle, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John A. Nagle of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Douglas Lester Pearl, a son of Carol E. Pearl of Longmeadow, Mass., and the late Sumner Pearl. Msgr. William Nagle, the bride's uncle, officiated with Rabbi Charles D. Lippman at the Stamford Yacht Club.

title: In America; Algerian Terror
description: In an interview at The New York Times, Zazi Sadou spoke through a translator about the nightmare in her homeland -- the murderous rampages in the name of God, the violent attacks on teachers and students and artists and intellectuals, and especially the horrendous ways in which women have been targeted, how they are raped and maimed and casually killed, or kidnapped and forced into sexual servitude.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Bohemia, L.I.; For Fleeing Czechs, a Suffolk Refuge
description: IN the mid-19th century, Czechs fleeing persecution in what was then part of Austria-Hungary found safe haven in the Suffolk County area that was later to become Bohemia. Today, this hamlet of modest homes on parcels of land that range from about a third of an acre to two acres is considered a safe haven from urbanization by many of the people who live there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OST, WARREN W.
description: OST-Warren W., Rev. On November 6, 1997. Survived by his wife, Nancy and daughter, Laura. Services at Madison Ave. Presbyterian Church, Madison Ave. at 73rd St., Thursday, November 13 at 11 AM. Memorial gifts may be made to A Christian Ministry in the National Parks or to the above church.

title: U.S. Hopes to Finally Cope With Uneasy Role of Favorite
description: The World Cup is sitting there, like some sugary confection in a bakery window, so close the Americans can almost taste it. With a victory against Canada on Sunday, the United States could treat itself to a slice of soccer's world championship pie next summer in France. But this is a maddening team, always susceptible to heartburn at times of expected feasts. While Nike just signed on as a sponsor, a more appropriate choice might have been Rolaids.

title: Wolverines Overwhelm Bewildered Penn State
description: Wherever their season ends and however it is defined, the Michigan Wolverines will be able to look back on the chilling, damp, unforgettable day they created a masterpiece.

title: Temps, the New Wave in the Work Force
description: KATHERINE LAMPOS often feels the urge to go whitewater rafting in New Mexico or visit a national park. So she does, for a week or two. That's O.K. with her boss, because Ms. Lampos, 52 years old, doesn't have one. She's a self-employed ''professional temp,'' one of a growing number of people who work project by project rather than the classic 40-hour week.

title: The Power of a Million Prayers
description: ''I am here to serve you, allah! Here I am!'' With these words, more than two million pilgrims converge each year on the Saudi Arabian city of Mecca.

title: Miracles Happen
description: FOUR LETTERS OF LOVE

title: Installing Openers for Garage Doors
description: GETTING out of your car on a cold, rainy night to open the garage door can be inconvenient, uncomfortable and even harmful if the door is heavy and you're not in good physical condition. An automatic opener will lift the door while you remain in your car. Most models are reasonably priced and easy to install.

title: IN BRIEF; Farmer Blames Hot-Air Balloon For Death of Prized Ostrich
description: For years, farmers in Hunterdon County have complained about low-flying hot-air balloons scaring their animals, and now one says an errant flyer has claimed one of his prized ostriches.

title: A Frontier Chinatown
description: IN California, history is just a glance at the rear-view mirror. Only a few missionary chapels and prospectors' shacks stand as testament to the good old, bad old days less than a hundred years back. Yet two hours' drive northeast of San Francisco, and a scant 20 minutes from the easternmost gleaming tentacle of BART, the Bay Area's megasubway, sit the uneven boardwalks of a miniature main street that comes closest to being the state's leading living museum.

title: In All Recorded History . . .
description: I was hunched over a transcribing machine, my foot on the pedal, listening to the first of the tapes Lyndon Johnson secretly made of 10,000 of his private conversations. I knew that Johnson was the only President to tape himself from the start of his Presidency until the end. But before deciding to create a book based on the tapes, I wanted to make sure they did not simply show Johnson posturing for the microphone, but instead captured all facets of his daily private and public life -- heroic and otherwise. Did they reveal moments that Johnson would rather not have us hear?

title: At 25, Excellence and Big Budgets For a Late Bloomer
description: WHEN HBO TOOK HOME 19 Emmy Awards in September, it was an early birthday present for the cable channel, which turns 25 years old this weekend.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Dodge Durango SLT; Chrysler Plugs a Truck Into a Hole in the Market
description: IN simpler times, the market for four-wheel-drive utility vehicles consisted mainly of big brutes like the Chevrolet Suburban and little goats like the Jeep Wrangler, with not much in between.

title: Going for Election: Mudslinging or Just Presenting Facts?
description: NEGATIVE campaigning was one of the losers in last Tuesday's municipal elections, according to politicians who survived it. What's referred to as mudslinging by victims and pointing out factual allegations by attackers didn't work in Waterbury and Orange where incumbents won re-election.

title: So Achingly Stylish
description: For many New Yorkers, black evokes sophistication and stylishness, and white is a fashion faux pas. But what if they sprain a wrist or break an arm or finger and suddenly need a splint? Now there is hope.

title: If They Build It, Will Even More Come? Cape May Ponders Parking Garage
description: Is it a threat to the past or a leap into future that has pitted Laura Calnan, chairwoman of Cape May's Historic Preservation Commission, against a proposed parking garage and renovation of the Congress Hall Hotel in the Jersey Shore town best known for its Victorian architecture?

title: King of Clubs, Awaiting Trial, Seeks to Reopen
description: He was known as the King of Clubs. Like a buccaneer, complete with black eye patch, Peter Gatien presided over New York night spots like the Tunnel and the Palladium for more than a decade, turning them and the Limelight, his first club, into night life legends.

title: Essay; Trusting A Stranger
description: Louise Woodward is the 19-year-old au pair from Britain convicted of second-degree murder by a jury and sentenced to life in prison for murdering a baby in her care. The trial judge, who can affirm or reduce the charge, or order a retrial, promises to finish his review of her case early this week.

title: The World; A Drug Plague Boils Out of Russia's Kitchens
description: LAST week Russia celebrated the 80th anniversary of its Bolshevik Revolution. Despite Communism's legacy of suffering and despair, the anniversary remains a national holiday, and millions of its victims unashamedly present each other with cognac, flowers and chocolate as if it were Christmas.

title: An Individualist Who Is Master of All Styles
description: THE SEARCH FOR IDENTITY, the author Ralph Ellison once said, is the American theme. In American culture, where so many different ethnic and regional strands make up the national fabric, the concepts of identity and authenticity are never far from each other. The question ''Who are you?'' often translates as ''What group do you represent?''

title: Ms. Schwartz, Mr. Ferdman
description: Stephanie Leigh Schwartz, the daughter of Sheryl and Barry K. Schwartz of New York, was married last evening to Michael Bennett Ferdman, the son of Susan Rodman of Lincolnwood, Ill., and Seymour Ferdman of Glencoe, Ill. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein performed the ceremony at the Central Synagogue in New York.

title: 'New American Blues'
description: To the Editor:

title: Bashing New York Includes Us
description: RECENTLY I attended a seminar on negativity. The facilitator, an arrogant fellow from down South, found a kindred spirit in a recent transplant to New York. Suddenly the two of them got into a discussion about New York, and the bashing began.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Nets (4-1) Lose, but It's Respectable
description: It had to happen sometime. The Nets were not fated to go 82-0. Still, it took the two-time National Basketball Association defending champions to make sure of that.

title: Victimhood Runs Amok In Workers' Comp
description: To the Editor:

title: Levy and Sarezky? Is Comedy Ready?
description: ATTENTION NBC security: Next time two self-assured, teen-age males attempt to schmooze their way into the Rockefeller Center office of the ''Saturday Night Live'' producer Lorne Michaels saying they are his clean-up crew, his cousins -- maybe even his chiropractors -- step aside and let them through. They may just have the right stuff to be the network's newest comedy stars.

title: On Pigeons, Bank Cards And Tourists
description: God is dead, Marx too

title: Russian Fairy Tale
description: MICHAEL AND NATASHA

title: A Resplendent City's Golden Heart
description: As a name, ''Municipal House'' does not have the seductiveness of the Doge's Palace in Venice, let alone of the Taj Mahal in Agra. It may even sound like the kind of place where people stand in line for hours to get a fishing license. But the Municipal House in Prague is not like that. It is an open house in an open society, a place of magic that draws an immense and eager public.

title: Volunteer Center To Help With Jobs
description: THE Volunteer Center of United Way in White Plains will take part in the county's effort to get recipients of the Temporary Assistance to Needy Families program into job training and jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, DANIEL
description: MARTIN-Daniel, age 89. On November 6, 1997. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Devoted father of Robert and David, and loving grandfather of Julie, Erik, Allison and Anne. Service Sunday 11AM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, New York Chapter.

title: The Round Room Comes to an End
description: When, early in this century, Virginia Woolf needed to find out the truth about women, she headed to the Round Reading Room of the British Museum, for ''if truth is not to be found on the shelves of the British Museum, where,'' she asked, ''is truth?'' Truth, it pains me to report, decamped last month to a new library near St. Pancras Station, loosed from its moorings in the British Museum after an intermittently happy marriage of nearly two and a half centuries. The great Round Reading Room where, Woolf said, one stood ''as if one were a thought in the huge bald forehead,'' is to be parted from its readers. Among divorces, it was perhaps one of the more easily predictable, but nonetheless painful to those of us whose inner landscape has been irreversibly redrawn.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Stalled Shopping Center Starts Up in Piscataway
description: STALLED by three years of litigation, a project has begun to turn 50 wooded acres in the center of this Middlesex County community into a 421,000-square-foot shopping center.

title: Brodeur Shakes Off the Flu And Shuts Down the Bruins
description: Martin Brodeur was stunned with a shot to the mask and a collision at his blue line but held his ground the rest of the way for a 2-0 Devils triumph over the Boston Bruins tonight in the first sellout of the season at Continental Arena.

title: With Historic Brownstone Gone, Is Development at Hand?
description: The blockfront of Court Street between Schermerhorn and State Streets has lain fallow since the early 1990's, and Brooklynites have wondered what would become of the site. A decent supermarket? A movie theater? A Barnes & Noble superstore? A Brooklyn Law School dormitory? None ever materialized.

title: A Portrait of New York City Voters
description: In 1989 Rudolph W. Giuliani lost the election for Mayor of New York City by two percentage points. In 1993, he won by two percentage points. This year, Mr. Giuliani's victory was dominating, winning with a margin of 16 percentage points over his Democratic opponent, Ruth W. Messinger.

title: POSTINGS: Cooperative Housing Conference; 64 Workshops And Seminars
description: The 17th annual Cooperative Housing Conference next Sunday at Hunter College in Manhattan will offer 64 workshops and seminars on such issues as ''Renovation Disasters and How to Avoid Them,'' ''Hi-Tech Needs of the 21st Century'' and ''Grooming Future Leaders.''

title: Me Too
description: My great-grandmother endured multiple childbirths and years of child rearing and housekeeping; my grandmother silently accepted the lack of a formal education; my mother witnessed the suffragists' movement and the entry of women into the labor force; I lobbied for equal rights and opportunities for women so that the descendant of this long heritage -- my daughter -- can hobble around in stiletto heels, clad in a bit of material stretched from breast to thigh line!

title: November 2-8; Cold Comfort From Statistics For Air Bags
description: Air bags, those bomb-like devices conceale/ in car dashboards with benevolent intent, do more good than harm, even if they have killed 38 children, according to two new studies.

title: November 2-8; A Drug Czar's Surgery Is Deadly Business
description: Four months after a billionaire Mexican drug trafficker, Amado Carrillo Fuentes, was reported dead following plastic surgery, the Mexican authorities finally ruled his death a homicide. They also announced that three plastic surgeons had been charged with murder, accused of intentionally giving Mr. Carrillo a lethal cocktail of anesthetics and a sedative.

title: Amonte Too Good for Isles
description: The Islanders were a step slow at the start tonight, perhaps a little tired playing on the second night of back-to-back games, perhaps a little full of themselves after pulling out a last-minute victory at Carolina on Friday.

title: Raise High the Roof Beam
description: THE ARCHITECTURE PACK

title: Deepening the Great Divide; Italian-American Students Need a Role Model, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Illustrious Illustrators
description: THE question of the day at the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences might be ''Is it art?'' Peggy Hammerle, curator of ''Viewpoints: Five Staten Island Illustrators,'' would say yes. The five, whose works are on display through March, had their greatest success as Staten Islanders.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: SUN DANCING

title: Creating Myths
description: To the Editor:

title: Hot Phobia
description: Germ awareness is spreading. Ask celebrities like Kathie Lee Gifford, Donald Trump and Cameron Diaz. Or the growing number of subway riders who carry germ-busting lotions like Purell.

title: At Parties, Backward Runs Time
description: THERE must have been a general amnesty declared for 1980's pop stars last week; all over town, they provided the entertainment at the nicest parties.

title: L.I. Potato Packager and Idaho at War
description: MORE than 50 years ago, Henry Pollak started a small business in the Hicksville farmlands selling fertilizer and insecticides to Long Island farmers. In those days, payment was in potatoes and other vegetables, a surplus the Island native turned into profit, packaging and reselling the produce to local retailers.

title: Assault on 'Camelot'
description: In his new book, ''The Dark Side of Camelot,'' Seymour M. Hersh portrays John F. Kennedy as an often immoral cad who accepted the aid of mobsters, was obsessed with killing Fidel Castro and widened involvement in Vietnam for political gain. But historians question key accounts.

title: Girl, 9, Is Found Dead In a Bronx Apartment
description: The severely burned and bruised body of a 9-year-old girl, who had moved from one troubled home to another since she was an infant, was found in a Bronx apartment by police officers responding to a 911 call about an unconscious child, the authorities said. The girl's sister and her husband were being questioned by the police, and a spokeswoman for the city's child welfare agency said an investigation would be opened.

title: Recalling a Dark Time With Some Who Lived It
description: AS the air chills and autumn's light wanes on wind-spun leaves, ritual observances on the calendar reflect preparations for darkness and death, and remembrance of the dead: Halloween (All Hallows Eve); All Saints' Day (or All Souls'), when names of the year's dead are read in church; Guy Fawkes Day in England, Veterans' Day. In fear of the symbolic absence of God, people light candles and curse the darkness.

title: New Auto Emissions Tests Are Delayed for Two Years
description: The more stringent automobile emissions tests that were to be phased in starting this month will be two years late. The Division of Transportation announced last week that not only was it not going to start the new tests on time, but also that it would not get proposals for installing and running the testing equipment until next month.

title: Mr. Giuliani's Next Term
description: New York City's Mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, sounded some worthy themes for the future during this fall's campaign. Now that the election is over, he needs to broaden his agenda.

title: Downtown Moves Uptown Redux
description: There must be something about the space at 240 West 52d Street (near Broadway) that makes it a magnet for the downtown scene.

title: A Hymn to Her
description: HOW much is that corn flakes box in the window -- the one with the picture of Vanessa Williams, Miss America 1983, who gave up her crown after Penthouse magazine published nude photographs of her?

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Education Life section last Sunday about the search and rescue team at Eckerd College in St. Petersburg, Fla., misstated the surname of the Coast Guard group commander in the St. Petersburg area from 1993 to 1996. He was Capt. Roy Casto, not Castro.

title: Vacation Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: Trailblazers, A Fund for You
description: AS if emerging markets did not prove exciting enough for investors recently, now comes an even more speculative alternative: The Pre-Emerging Markets fund, introduced last week by State Street Global Advisors, the money management arm of the State Street Corporation in Boston.

title: Far From Broadway, a Leading Man With an Edge
description: ''CAROLINE IN THE CITY'' was supposed to die after it left its protected Thursday night time slot between ''Seinfeld'' and ''E.R.'' But it didn't. The character Richard Karinsky, quintessential cynic and lonely guy, wasn't supposed to be the title character's love interest. But he is. Richard was supposed to be 10 years younger than Caroline. But he isn't.

title: STAGE VIEW; Of Jackie Onassis and the Stargazer in Every Heart
description: SOME KILLJOYS MAY SAY, ''Let Jackie rest in peace.'' But that is not the way desire works. No one wants to put away a good toy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COMMERFORD, SR. ROSE MARY (FORMERLY SISTER MARY RAYMOND)
description: COMMERFORD-Sr. Rose Mary (formerly Sister Mary Raymond). Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity. Social worker, administrator, teacher, and former counselor for the Sisters of Charity. On November 8, 1997. Survived by cousins. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark St., Yonkers, NY, on Sunday, 4-8 PM, and Monday 1-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10:30 AM, at St. Mary's Church. Interment at St. Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Ave., Bronx, NY 10471.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Great American Broadcast

title: BENEFITS
description: WPA Theater Evening

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, DOROTHY FOX
description: GOODMAN-Dorothy Fox. Devoted wife of the late Dr. J. Bardin Goodman. Loving mother of Stephen and Joyce, Edward and Laurence. Cherished grandmother of Jordan, Risa and Bob, Andrew, Jennifer and Mark, Johanna, Jonathan, Marisa, Robert and Alan. Adored great-grandmother of Sarah. Services private.

title: East Hampton Targets Ferries
description: AFTER a two-year moratorium on ferry services seeking new permits in the Town of East Hampton, officals have drafted an amendment to the town code to ban all vehiclular ferries, strictly limiting the size and speed of passenger ferries and re-defining parking regulations for ferry services.

title: 'Nowhere Wholly at Home'
description: THE COLLECTED POEMS OF AMY CLAMPITT

title: Vistas Along the Waterfront
description: BRIDGE to bridge and beyond, the San Francisco waterfront has never looked better or offered more to visitors and residents. No longer are the attractions limited to Fisherman's Wharf, that well-touristed half mile of the peninsular city's 21 miles of coastline. Thanks to a shrinking military presence, a destructive earthquake and an energetic citizenry, the waterfront is being returned to the people.

title: Crime
description: The trouble with romantic mysteries is that the romance usually smothers the mystery. More praise, then, to Deborah Crombie for making the tangled love relationships in DREAMING OF THE BONES (Scribner, $22) the very heart of her mystery by linking them with questions about our responsibilities to the ones we love -- on occasion, love to death.

title: Adam Kennedy, 77, Novelist and an Actor
description: Adam Kennedy, a novelist, actor and artist, died on Oct. 16 at his home in Kent, Conn. He was 77.

title: Government As Apologist
description: To the Editor:

title: A Glittering New Kazakh Capital, on the Face of It
description: In a shiny green sports jacket and tie, Aybek Nurtaev was scurrying around the top hotel in this nation's new capital the other day.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE DINOSAUR CLUB

title: When Small Groups Try Fund-Raising
description: As a resident of one of the communities on the eastern end of Long Island and a member of the board of East End Hospice in Westhampton Beach, I was not surprised to read of the huge sums that are raised in the Hamptons [''Benefit Events Gained Huge Sums,'' Oct. 12]. It has become increasingly obvious that this summer playground appeals to many people who enjoy its natural beauty and bounty. There are few places that encompass so many financially able people in so few square miles in so short a period of time.

title: Claire Falkenstein, 89, Sculptor Of the Abstract and Functional
description: Claire Falkenstein, an American sculptor known for both abstract and functional works, died on Oct. 23 at her home in Venice, Calif. She was 89 and had lived in Venice since 1963, after spending more than a decade in Europe.

title: U.S. Marshal Put on Leave After Shooting
description: The United States Marshal who shot and wounded a Queens high school student Thursday after mistaking the candy bar he was holding for a revolver was put on administrative leave yesterday, Federal officials announced.

title: Defining Moments; Perugia: Myth and Reality Converge
description: The July sun was merciful, glimmering on the Corso Vannucci as the city prepared for the Umbria Jazz Festival, a joyous summer tradition. I had not come to Perugia for the jazz or the chocolates or the elegant shops I could not afford when a student. I had not come for the beautiful Pisano fountain that was in restauro, wrapped in plastic like a minor Christo, nor for the mighty Etruscan walls of the city. I came for my past, as though this noble city should serve as a mere receptacle of personal memory. There's the Rosetta where we dined when the Fulbright check came through. There's the pensione where the padrona passed her unswaddled babe round the table in a game of della Robbia roulette. But this past seemed quaint, even thin, in the energy of the prosperous modern city.

title: Ramona Ponce and Eric Mueller
description: EVEN though their Manhattan apartment is small, Ramona Luz Ponce and Eric Anthony Mueller give parties there that are palatial in spirit. They regularly send elaborate homemade invitations -- ones with wax seals and large heavy envelopes that evoke another era, or others as complex as origami or lighthearted as paper airplanes.

title: The Publisher as Impresario
description: RICHARD D. BECKMAN was sweating.

title: Marie Cuneta, Enrique Bernabe
description: Marie Frances Jennifer Nepomuceno Cuneta, the daughter of Marie and Dr. Gener C. Cuneta of Manila, was married yesterday to Enrique Siegfried Panedo Bernabe, a son of Evelyn and Lucito A. Bernabe of Paramus, N.J. The Rev. Robert M. Brennan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Holy Trinity Church in Hackensack, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESTEROWITZ, CELIA RAUCH
description: ESTEROWITZ-Celia Rauch, 91. BA Hunter, MA Columbia. Modern dancer, teacher, school director, peace activist. Widow of George Esterowitz. Survived by daughters Naomi and Joan, grandchildren Sarah, Isaac, Daniel, and Michael; great grandsons Nathan and Noah. Memorial gifts may be sent to Children's Defense Fund, 25 E. St. NW, Washington, DC 20001.

title: SOAPBOX; Burning Issue
description: IN rural Warrren County (population 96,385), the little town of Oxford (population 1,822) is down for the count. Beating it repeatedly nonetheless is Ogden-Martin, the world's largest builder of incinerators and owner of New Jersey's first garbage burner. For Ogden to win all the prize money, Oxford must not be allowed to get up and walk away from the fight. Therefore, the assault continues.

title: A Year of 'Star Wars' Starts at Smithsonian
description: The Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum, which chronicles the history of manned flight, is paying homage to some of the most famous fictional space travel.

title: Valuing the Ganz Collection
description: Tomorrow, Christie's will auction a remarkable group of modern artworks purchased over half a century by Victor and Sally Ganz. Victor Ganz died in 1987, and Sally Ganz died in January. For the past two weeks, the paintings and prints in the Ganz collection have hung against a white background at Christie's. Visitors and staff speak in normal voices there, without the hush audible in museums. The auctioneer's summons can be heard coming from a distant room -- the naming of lots, the calling of prices. It is an age-old business, and it fixes, for this moment at least, one way of valuing the work by Picasso, Jasper Johns, Robert Rauschenberg, Frank Stella and Eva Hesse that forms the core of the Ganz collection.

title: November 2-8; Medical Experts Endorse An Ancient Treatment
description: Western doctors have long resisted the idea that sticking any kind of needle besides a hypodermic in patients could be good for them. In large part, modern medicine couldn't swallow the traditional theoretical underpinnings of the practice: that when opposing forces in the body called Yin and Yang get out of balance, they disrupt the normal flow of Qi (pronounced chee).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEVENSON, JOHN REESE
description: STEVENSON-John Reese. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, November 19, 1997, at 4 PM, Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Ave, NYC. Donations in his memory may be sent to the Community Hospice of Forth Worth, TX, or to a charity of your choice.

title: Bargains Abound In the West 80's
description: AZURE +

title: JERSEYANA ; Beauty, Utility and Paychecks, All Built on a Base of Clay
description: This is the beauty of ceramic art: a piece can be anything its maker wants it to be. A lump of clay can assume any shape, any color, any glaze (or none at all), any design. It can turn into a polar bear or a Polish bride, a dinner plate stately enough for a White House table or a lowly chamber pot.

title: Sports of The Times; Still Talk of the Town: A Sport Misses Tyson
description: MIKE TYSON was not here, but he dominated conversations leading to Evander Holyfield's knockout of Michael Moorer last night that unified the World Boxing Association and International Boxing Federation heavyweight titles.

title: Band Sings About What It's Like to Raise a Family in the 90's
description: BETH RUDD was playing the organ at the First Reformed Church here when she did a double take. Looking down from the choir loft, she saw a tall blond woman walk in with four small children. ''She looked just like me,'' Ms. Rudd said. ''We are both very tall and blond with red lips and extravagant glasses. I had four children, too, in the same order: three little boys and a baby daughter.''

title: CUTTINGS; Love Bulbs but Hate Their Dying Foliage? Hide It
description: Purists will tell you that daffodils should be grown in wide sheets, the way William Wordsworth liked them, ''continuous as the stars that shine.'' Tulips, too, look better in broad swaths of enameled color, like fields in the Netherlands. But what do you do if you love daffodils and tulips and you're gardening on three-sixteenths of an acre in a Long Island village and don't want to look at a wide sheet of dying foliage?

title: Shhh! The House Plants Are Resting
description: NOW is the time for house plants to become the center of a gardener's attention. Caring for them should be a pleasant task, but a review of some vital points might make things easier.

title: An Odd Definition
description: To the Editor:

title: Rapid Transit
description: THE GAY METROPOLIS

title: A Liberal Parish, Not-So-Liberal Pastor, Trouble
description: When the Jesuit officials who run the Church of St. Francis Xavier on West 16th Street had to pick a new pastor last year, they were well aware that they would have to choose carefully. The parish has long been one of the city's most iconclastic, sponsoring adult education programs and support groups for people with H.I.V. and AIDS that reflect the liberal attitudes of many parishioners.

title: Wistful Resignation
description: To the Editor:

title: Laura Fisher and Adi Raviv
description: Laura Lani Fisher, an internist specializing in infectious disease, and Adi Raviv, an investment banker, both of New York, are to be married today at the Pleasantdale Chateau in West Orange, N.J. Cantor Henry Butensky is to perform the ceremony.

title: 2 Police Detectives Shot In Asbury Park Standoff
description: Two police detectives and a third man were shot and wounded in a standoff in Asbury Park last night, officials said. The two detectives, Terrence Fellenz and Charles Smentkowski, were taken to Jersey Shore Medical Center, where they were listed in stable condition.

title: Spano Revels in Strength of Victory
description: THANKS to a campaign that cost him about $3 million, Mayor Ted Dunn of Rye, a relative unknown just a few months ago, has name recognition today but will soon have no job, as an overwhelming number of voters gave their support to his opponent for county executive, Andrew J. Spano, a Democrat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIANTINI, MARIANNE
description: PIANTINI-Marianne. November 7, 1997. Loving daughter of Mercedes Sagredo Rincon. Devoted mother of Susan, Vivian, Albert and Frank. Cherished grandmother of nine. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, November 10, 11 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington and 65th St., NYC. Interment Flushing Cemetery.

title: A Delicate Balance Of Then and Now
description: ''DANCE IS A MOMENT, AND then it is finished,'' Jose Limon once wrote. ''I do not believe durability is one of the great virtues. I don't think I would appreciate a lily that has been embalmed. There will be other dancers.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COURTNEY, IRVING
description: COURTNEY-Irving. Life isn't forever, Love is. I'll always miss you. Norma

title: Sammy and Rosie Get Old
description: LOVE IN A BLUE TIME

title: Giving Saturday Morning Some Slack
description: Remember Saturday morning? The expectancy, the blissfulness, the sense of utter freedom? The most sublime moment was the first -- the instant when, unprodded by either alarm clock or parental summons, you emerged into consciousness and experienced an almost physical sense of release, a floating up from the mattress, as you realized that you didn't have to go to school. And the rest of the day -- of the whole weekend -- then seemed to spead out limitlessly from the edge of the bedcovers, a blank and beckoning horizon.

title: Brighton Beach Memories, Sold!
description: Bits and pieces of a bygone era were sold to the highest bidders last month, when furnishings and memorabilia from the Brighton Beach Bath and Racquet Club were auctioned off, including the Adirondack chairs where people including Mayor John V. Lindsay and Tallulah Bankhead sunbathed by the sea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, ADA
description: ABRAMS-Ada. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Ada Abrams, associated with The Times from 1946, until retiring in 1977.

title: Parallel Lives
description: I can't tell you how much I enjoyed your special issue ''Parallel Lives'' (Oct. 19). It was cover-to-cover reading for me. I, too, am one of those who would name New York the place they would most like to live, and your magazine gave all of the reasons why -- the people!

title: Roy Dominates Blues as Avalanche Cruises
description: Patrick Roy stopped 31 shots and earned his 356th victory, moving past Rogie Vachon into seventh place on the career victory list for goaltenders, and the Colorado Avalanche beat the visiting St. Louis Blues, 4-1, yesterday.

title: Bottled Up
description: The name -- Boylan's Original Birch Beer -- suggests one of those products bottled in modern plants but marketed to sound as if it comes out of a barrel. But in fact, getting out of barrels and into bottles was an achievement Boylan's makers are proud of. The original was concocted as an elixir at an apothecary in Paterson in 1891 and then bottled by the Boylan Sodaworks of Paterson. When Prohibition came in, Boylan switched to a cheaper packaging method: unused beer barrels. When Prohibition went out, Boylan decided to jettison its birch beer for the real thing. One of the company's drivers, Frank Fiorina, offered to buy the birch beer formula, the customers and the routes. For decades he made birch beer by night and delivered kegs around northern New Jersey by day, all by himself. His grandsons Ronald and Mark Fiorina got involved in the early 70's, switching to selling it through institutional soda dispensers. Finally, in August 1993, Boylan's got a bottler. Now bottles are sold all over the region, in specialty food stores, cafes, pizzerias and the like. The Boylan offices are now in Haledon, where Frank, 84, still stops in every day to make sure his grandsons are doing it the right way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, DR. WILLIAM JAMES
description: NELSON-Dr. William James. On October 25, 1997 at his home in Damariscotta, Maine. Born in Brooklyn, NY, December 2, 1922, the son of William S. and Edna (McKenna) Nelson. Graduate of Poly Prep Secondary School, class of 1941, earned his B.A. Degree from Williams College, and his medical degree from New York Medical College. He served as a medical officer in the US Naval Reserve Medical Corps during WW II aboard the USS Frank Knox in the Pacific. Following his discharge, he began his surgical & urological residency at Bellevue Hospital and Roosevelt Hospital. In 1953, he entered private practice in New York City and became Director of Urology at Roosevelt Hospital, where he remained until relocating to Maine in 1988. While in Maine, he was on staff at Miles Memorial Hospital, Damariscotta, St. Andrew's Hospital, Boothbay Harbor and Maine Medical Center, Portland. He retired in 1991. He was active in several medical organizations, including the American Urological Association, where he served in many capacities, including President of the New York Section in 1978-79. He was President of the New York State Medical Society, President of the Roosevelt Hospital Alumni Assoc., and for many years taught at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was a founding member of the New York State Urological Society, and was a member of the Societe Internationale D'Urologie, United States Section. In Maine, he was a member of the Maine Medical Association. He leaves his wife Olive (Daley) Nelson, of Damariscotta, six children, Peter M. Nelson of Woodbridge, VA., Nora N. Tiffany of Winchester, MA., Michael J.T. Nelson of Orgeval, France, Andrew W. Nelson of Darien, CT, Sarah N. Dillaway of Natick, MA, William J. Nelson, Jr. of Darien, CT, and 13 grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Jude's Childrens Hospital, P.O. Box 1818, Memphis, TN 38101.

title: Dalmatian Coast
description: To the Editor: Having recently come back from Croatia, I enjoyed reading Perri Klass's article ''The Dalmatian Coast Beckons Once More'' (Sept. 28). One should note that the jewel of Sibenik is the late Gothic-early Renaissance Cathedral of St. Jacob, whose distinguishing characteristics include a frieze of heads depicting local nobles and plebeians.

title: Ruth Goode, 92, an Author On Maine, Medicine and More
description: Ruth Goode, who wrote about subjects as disparate as the scenic attractions of Maine, advancements in medicine and the life of the impresario Sol Hurok, died on Oct. 27 at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 92 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Sam Hairston, 77, First American Black on White Sox, Dies
description: Sam Hairston, who spent more than 50 years as a professional baseball player, scout and coach but played in the major leagues just long enough to qualify for an asterisk, died on Oct. 31 at a nursing home in Birmingham, Ala. He was 77 and the first American-born black player on the Chicago White Sox.

title: Q and A
description: Solar Eclipse in February

title: Miss Krahmer, Mr. Keating
description: Elizabeth Miles Krahmer and Robert Ridgely Keating Jr. are to be married today in Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Dr. Jon M. Walton will perform the ceremony at Westminster Presbyterian Church.

title: The Ultimate Modern
description: THE HITLER OF HISTORY

title: The $700,000-a-Year Drone
description: If Michael Lewis is right when he says that a job as a bond trader today is basically a six-digit sinecure that leaves time for 18 holes of golf a day, I would suggest that New York's financial barons not invest all of their earnings in country-club fees (The Capitalist: ''The $700,000-a-Year Drone''). Any half-time job that can be done by a clerk can't be safe for long, as those graying whiz kids who promoted downsizing in the 1980's must realize.

title: Installing Openers for Garage Doors
description: GETTING out of your car on a cold, rainy night to open the garage door can be inconvenient, uncomfortable and even harmful if the door is heavy and you're not in good physical condition. An automatic opener will lift the door while you remain in your car. Most models are reasonably priced and easy to install.

title: Bruised and Burned, Body of a 9-Year-Old Girl Is Found in a Bronx Apartment
description: The severely burned and bruised body of a 9-year-old girl, who had moved from one troubled home to another since she was an infant, was found in a Bronx apartment yesterday morning by police officers responding to a 911 call about an unconscious child, the authorities said.

title: Philip Hirshman, Jennifer Sherwood
description: Dr. Jennifer Beth Sherwood and Dr. Philip Gregory Hirshman, both fourth-year residents in obstetrics and gynecology at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia, were married last evening. Rabbi David Ackerman officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Alice Burress and Robert Sarlls
description: Alice Anna Burress and Robert John Sarlls were married yesterday at the Lovely Lane Chapel, Epworth by the Sea, on St. Simons Island, Ga. Canon John H. Backus, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Au Pairs Aren't Nannies, and Many Are Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Defining Moments; Moscow: Encountering A Memory
description: One of the signs of the coming breakup of the Communist regime in Russia was that foreigners were, unofficially, invited to visit museums that had been reserved strictly for Soviets. In 1989, I was taken with others by a Russian friend to the Bolshoi museum in Moscow, near the Bolshoi Theater. The winter afternoon was dark with snow and, to save electricity, only one museum room was lighted at a time.

title: The Spirit of Your Backyard
description: George Heaven, an aeronautical engineer from Van Nuys, Calif., is out to fill an odd niche in pilot history. Heaven (pictured) is the creator of the Rubber Bandit -- an adult-size version of that ubiquitous toy the rubber-band-powered balsa-wood airplane. If officials at the local airport give their consent, he plans to fly it next month, a feat that would represent an aviation first. For? ''Piloted rubber-band-powered aircraft.''

title: New Residents, And Happy to Be Here
description: To the Editor:

title: Laura Hunt, F. D. Van Arnam
description: Laura Susanne Hunt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin G. Hunt of New York, is to be married today to Frederic Deming Van Arnam Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Van Arnam of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Nancy G. Wright, a minister of the United Church of Christ, is to perform the ceremony at the Three West, a private club in New York.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions on pages 18 and 39 of the Television section today about the ABC movie ''Into Thin Air'' misspell the surname of an actor. He is Christopher McDonald, not MacDonald.

title: Memory Therapy Is a Danger to Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMPSEY, MARIE GRAVEL
description: DEMPSEY-Marie Gravel, 71. Daughter of the late M. et Mme. Charles-Edouard Gravel, of Montreal, died at Cleveland Clinic Hospital, November 2, 1997, following a sudden set back to what had seemed to have been a successful recovery from peritoneal cancer surgery a year ago. Wife of John B. Dempsey, II, of Vero Beach, Florida; Cleveland, Ohio; and of Pointe au Pic (Murray Bay), Quebec. Mother of Louise (Mrs. E.D., III) McKean and of Gertrude (Mrs. W.J., III) McLean, both of Gilford, New Hampshire; and of Marie (Mrs. Hugh D.) Carter, of Richmond, Virginia; and of Ernest D. (Diana M. Common), of Montreal; and of James H., III (Kathryn Wagner) and of Richard B. (Mary Margaret Maley), both of Cleveland, Ohio. Grandmother to twelve. Also survived by a brother, Jean J.J.-O. Gravel, of Ottawa, and by a sister, Mme. Jean (Marthe) Ducharme, of Rougemont, Quebec. A funeral service was held on November 4th, 1997, at The Cathedral of St. John The Evangelist in Cleveland, Ohio. Mrs. Dempsey had requested that in lieu of flowers contributions in her name to be made to Kenyon College, Gambier, Ohio, 43022, to the attention of The Office of the President. For more than thirty years Mrs. Dempsey regularly visited Kenyon in her capacities as wife of a trustee and both parent and grandparent to students where she took a special interest in the College's French language and francophone cultural programs.

title: Photography Firm Grows With 3 Partners
description: TAKE three photographers younger than 30, add a fatherly boss and a local bank, then back off and watch a new enterprise grow. But the company, Bernstein Associates Photographers, is not new; it was started by Herman Bernstein in the mid-1950's and in 1970 began specializing in the construction photography it is known for today.

title: The Demonization Of the Upper West Side
description: Adam Nagourney's article on Upper West Side politics was a perfect 10 (''The Demonization of the Upper West Side''). As a three-decade, not-so-casual observer of the New York political scene, I would add one final point: the Upper West Side of Manhattan is in the United States but is not a part of it.

title: The Ultimate Modern
description: THE HITLER OF HISTORYBy John Lukacs.279 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $26.

title: Contradictions
description: To the Editor:

title: Acapulco Tourist Areas Are Open After Storm
description: Hurricane Pauline, which roared through Acapulco on Oct. 9, largely spared beachside hotels there, and they are working almost normally. Since the storm packed more rain than wind, it did not blow down palm trees or chew up beaches as past hurricanes have.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, WLADISLAW
description: LEWIN-Wladislaw. Died November 6, 1997, aged 96. A courageous, devoted physician. He is survived by his wife Lotte, stepchildren, grandchildren, great-grandaughter, sister Lisa Parode and niece Claudia. Services Sunday, 12 PM at the Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard at 76th Road.

title: The End of Equality

title: VIEWPOINT; Putting the Children First
description: AN infant is dead. A 19-year-old au pair is sentenced to life in prison.

title: Clinton Is Greeted Warmly as He Speaks to Gay Group
description: It is rare that a politician can draw an ovation with such a stock line as ''I'm delighted to be here.''

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Move Over, Tamagotchi: Yo-Yo Rolls Back
description: Never mind those ultra-tech toys that light up and talk. The centuries-old yo-yo is back.

title: Ideas & Trends; In an Age of Consent, Defining Abuse by Adults
description: MENTION child sexual abuse and the kind of image that creeps to mind is a depraved adult taking muscular advantage of an 8-year-old's rag-doll frailty, strangling an incipient cry of protest with threats or promises.

title: Soup Takes a Starring Role With Salad and Bread on the Side
description: IT seemed for many years that Americans were ignoring soup. No longer. As mentioned last week, soups often sell out almost as soon as they are made. Through thick and thin, the warming, restorative properties are again giving soup a starring role. Soup kiosks have opened in malls. Carryout shops, supermarkets and restaurants have a daily changing menu of soup.

title: Thieves With Eyes for Detail
description: Garden statues, limestone and terra cotta planters, lanterns and other architectural ornaments are being stolen from buildings in Hamilton Heights, and residents say the thieves, whoever they are, have a real eye for detail.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOHO -- BUZZ ; At Chaos, the Early Returns
description: THE SETTING: Election night, 9:30. In the red velvet confines of Chaos, a hot spot on Watts Street in SoHo, it was the first night of Fashion Week, and the only returns being discussed were probably made of silk or chiffon.

title: East Side-West Side, Part II
description: Three weeks ago, The City reported on the differences between the Upper East Side and the Upper West Side. Census data showed that Upper West Siders are younger; Upper East Siders more affluent; that East Siders tend to have more higher education; West Siders bigger families. To see if these differences were evenly distributed, The City subdivided the East Side and West Side along Lexington Avenue and Broadway, respectively. Among the findings: Most of the wealthier East Siders live near Central Park, as do most of the young West Siders. Here are those and other results, based on 1997 figures. For some readers' thoughts on the topic, see the Soapbox page. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

title: Results of Senate Races; The Party Lines Hold in the Senate
description: The election did not change the partisan balance in the Senate, though four seats changed hands. There are still 24 Republican senators and 16 Democrats. Here are the winners reported by the Associated Press.

title: Peaceful Pretenders
description: Dr. Vamik Volkan, author of the new book ''Bloodlines: From Ethnic Pride to Ethnic Terrorism,'' believes that it's time to try a little group therapy on global conflicts. A psychiatrist and founder of the Center for the Study of Mind and Human Interaction at the University of Virginia, Volkan has actually tried his methods in the wee Republic of Estonia. There, during talks between Russian and Estonian representatives in 1993, he says, ''big-shot parliamentarians spent hours at a rabbit-elephant'' role-playing game to understand how they could coexist peacefully. And? ''The deadliness and rigidity of the negotiations became more playful,'' he says. ''It doesn't mean that we are making them all lovey-dovey. That's not what we are. We are serious.''

title: Show Me the Original
description: To the Editor:

title: In Louima Case, Dream Team and Perhaps Overkill
description: If a victim's nightmare can be a lawyer's dream case, then a relatively obscure squad of Brooklyn lawyers seemed to be on a flight of their own to lawsuit nirvana. Then came the real Dream Team.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Oct. 12 about ''Beyond the Threshold: A Life in Opus Dei,'' by Maria del Carmen Tapia, misidentified the prelate who oversees the Roman Catholic organization Opus Dei. He is Javier Echevarria, not Julian Herranz.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Dancing at the Harvest Moon
