description: Dave Barry is from

title: Quick Bite/Bergenfield; An Enterprise That Takes the Cake
description: If the Museum of Modern Art gave up on Picasso and Matisse and put cakes on exhibition instead, the show would look like the display case at K Enterprises Inc.: A breathtaking raspberry-almond tart. A deceptively simple-looking almond cake. A diet-busting Reese's Peanut Butter Cup Pie. And the in-house birthday party favorite, an all-American chocolate chocolate-chip cake that is kosher and made without dairy products.

title: Children's Books
description: MY LIFE WITH THE WAVE

title: Symposium Focuses On Animal Cruelty
description: THEY are neglected, starved, abandoned in empty apartments, chained outside in freezing temperatures, tossed into the garbage, beaten and deliberately mutilated and tortured. They are pitted against one another in bloody fights so that their owners can gamble on the outcomes. Yet the dogs, cats and other animals who suffer such inhumane treatment cannot speak for themselves. They must rely on humans to protect them and to enforce laws preventing their abuse.

title: Did a Southern Schism Hurt McGreevey's Chances?
description: In the final days before last June's Democratic primary, Republican officials around the state were confidently asserting that they preferred to face James E. McGreevey in the general election. The conventional wisdom at that time among people supporting the incumbent Governor, Christine Todd Whitman, was that Mr. McGreevey would be easier to knock off in a general election than would Representative Robert E. Andrews, the southern New Jersey Congressman who was also seeking the nomination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINN, CATHERINE CONVERSANO
description: FINN-Catherine Conversano. Of Sea Cliff, New York, on November 6, 1997. Beloved wife of the late John F. Finn, Jr. Loving mother of John C. and Terence T. Dear grandmother of Heather, Lauren, Kevin and Timothy. Dear sister of Isabel, Helen and Louise. Visiting Sat 2-4 PM and Sun 2-4 and 6-8 PM. Whitting Funeral Home, Inc., Glen Head, New York. Funeral service 10 AM, Monday at the Funeral Home. Interment Mount St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Contributions may be made to Nightingale-Bamford School, 20 East 92nd St., New York, NY 10128.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERNIKOFF, ROBERT E., PH.D.
description: WERNIKOFF-Robert E., Ph.D. Of West Newton, MA, on November 5. Beloved husband of Denise (Piotrkowski). Devoted father of Anne Wernikoff of West Newton, MA. Loving son of Mina (Mil) Wernikoff of New Jersey and the late Leopoldo Wernikoff. Dear brother of Serge Wernikoff of New Jersey. Services at the M.I.T. Chapel, 48 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, MA on Wednesday, November 12, at 10:30 A.M. Remembrances may be made to the American Cancer Society, 30 Speen Street, Framingham, MA 01701 or a charity of your choice. For information the Levine Chapel, Brookline, MA.

title: Editorial Notebook; A Fateful Miscalculation in Turkey
description: Since his election three years ago as Mayor of Sariyer, a district of Istanbul bordering the Bosporus and the Black Sea, Yusuf Tulun has tended to the parks, roads and sewage of some 400,000 constituents a good deal more effectively than the secular politicians who preceded him. Aside from the copy of the Koran resting atop his computer and a scarf-cloaked assistant who appeared briefly at the door during a recent visit, little about Mr. Tulun or his office suggested a fervor to remake Turkey into an Islamic fundamentalist state.

title: Photography in Many Forms, and Humors
description: SILVERMINE GUILD galleries in New Canaan has added a National Photography Biennial to its roster of competitions, and it's off to a promising start. The inaugural show, Spectra 97, stresses technical proficiency but humor runs through it. Its freshness might be due, at least in part, to its judge having been imported from afar. Robert A. Sobieszek is curator of photography at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

title: Parallel Lives
description: Congrats for your edition about parallel lives in New York. It addressed a fundamental and fascinating element of life in the Big Apple. The faint reference to those in Latino communities, however, was striking, particularly given their formidable demographics and diverse contributions to the city's cultural life.

title: Woody Allen's Best (Hence Very Secretive) Friend
description: HER FRIENDS CALL Jean Doumanian ''brilliant.'' The writers at ''Saturday Night Live,'' where, for one brief, infamous season in 1980, she was the executive producer, called her Ayatollah Doumanian. Jean Doumanian has been Woody Allen's best friend for more than 30 years, and for the last four years she has been the executive producer of his films, including his latest, the dark comedy ''Deconstructing Harry,'' to be released Dec. 12. The movie is a typically Woodyesque roundelay of ex-wives, lovers and ex-lovers.

title: Bigger, Better Sports, Better Students?
description: President Philip Austin of the University of Connecticut says that unless his school upgrades the football program to the Division 1-A level, other teams, most notably their successful men's and women's basketball squads may suffer (''Will Huskies Embrace Big Time Football?'' Oct. 26). Considering the enormous appeal those basketball teams have and the money they thus bring in, it's almost comical to think that other schools would boycott them. One might as well suggest that the Chicago White Sox will quit playing the New York Yankees.

title: Backtalk; A People's Surprise, a Player's Anguish
description: By a show of thoughts, how many of you believed that at the beginning of November the Giants would be a first place? Not many, I understandably suppose.

title: Seminoles Defense Helps Halt Tar Heels
description: It was quick-moving and unbeaten Florida State against slow-starting and unbeaten North Carolina tonight. And in the end, it was Florida State that moved closer to an Atlantic Coast Conference championship and an Orange Bowl bid.

title: Pasts Are Prologue as Jones v. Clinton Moves Nearer to Trial
description: With legal delays exhausted and settlement talks unavailing, the sexual misconduct case of Paula Corbin Jones v. William Jefferson Clinton appears headed for trial, subjecting Mr. Clinton to legal and public scrutiny of his sexual history that is without precedent for a sitting President.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROWES, BERNARD
description: ROWES-Bernard. An orphan, he achieved legendary success in the diamond industry. He produced a physician son and Ph.D daughter in a fifty-six year marriage of love to Emily. He was shrewd, aggressive and devoted to his aunts, uncles and cousins who raised him. A life well lived.

title: The Internet and Children
description: Do children need protection from objectionable material on the Internet? Should some content be censored?

description: SIMMONS-Helen E. Missed and remembered always. Deirdre, Maud, Charles

title: High-Stakes Poker Is the Game for the Yankees
description: Maybe the Yankees are serious about trading Bernie Williams, but their words and actions sound suspiciously as if they've been heard and seen before.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FICALORA, SALVATORE
description: FICALORA-Salvatore. On Nov. 6, 1997, in Tucson, Arizona. Beloved husband of Gloria. Loving father of Maria (Arthur), Elizabeth, Michael (Pat), Patricia and Robert. Adoring grandfather of Martin, Elisha, and Adam. Services held in Tucson on November 8.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Can Closing Costs Be Predicted?
description: ONE of the more predictable questions real estate lawyers are asked by clients buying a house is: ''How much are the closing costs going to be?''

description: AS the stock market sank on Monday, Oct. 27, the smartest money was not on Wall Street. It was in some of the nation's public-school classrooms.

title: After the Revolution, Comes 'Anastasia' the Cartoon
description: POOR ANASTASIA: murdered by the Bolsheviks with the rest of the Romanov royal family in 1918; impersonated by a bevy of pretenders in the years to follow; exploited by Hollywood as a 1956 star vehicle for Ingrid Bergman, and later for Amy Irving, in a mini-series that seemed to drag on almost as long as the Communist regime.

description: GOLDBERG-Bertrand. Beloved husband of the late Nancy Florsheim Goldberg. Devoted father of Lisa, Nan (Nickel Van Cleve) and Geoffrey (Lynne Remington) Goldberg. Loving grandfather of Lillian Van Cleve and Nathan Goldberg. Dear brother of the late Lucille Goldberg Strauss. Fond uncle of Peter (Susan) Strauss, Ellen (William) Hunt, Jr. and the late Barbara (James) Heller. Memorial Services Friday, November 14, 1997, 3:30PM, at The Art Institute of Chicago (in the Stock Exchange Trade Room), 230 S. Columbus, Chicago, IL. For information, please call Furth Funeral Direction, (773) 784-4300.

description: FOR Jesus I. Duarte, the 41-year-old portfolio manager of the Montgomery Latin America fund, Tuesday morning, Oct. 28, was the worst.

title: From Young Designers, A Do-It-Yourself Dream Park
description: ''I like things calm,'' said Loama Estime-Amira, 17, one of 25 teen-agers who have designed a little park in the west Bronx. ''I like gray -- soothing. Nothing running about. I like rocks.''

title: Members Only
description: As a former New Yorker (I immigrated to Virginia in 1992), I read ''Parallel Lives'' with great interest. Based on your articles, I think I would find New York much changed in five years. Although you covered more important issues, Toure's ''Members Only'' came closest to my heart, perhaps because it brought back many pleasant memories.

title: Washington Talk; Q. Goes Before A., Except in G.O.P.
description: Republicans have spent so much time accusing President Clinton of leading the country by following the polls that they seem to have decided, ''If you can't beat him, join him.''

description: Special Today: The Sophisticated Traveler

description: Pitfalls Of Seller Financing

title: Clinton, Schminton: Hell's Kitchen Is on the Web
description: The otherwise authoritative Encyclopedia of New York City dismisses Hell's Kitchen as ''a largely disused name'' for the area of Manhattan just west of the theater district. But don't tell John Fisher that. In March 1996, Mr. Fisher, a computer consultant, started Hell's Kitchen Online, a neighborhood guide, web forum and personal soapbox.

title: Streetscapes/101 East 75th Street; When Doormen Were Sparse Along Park Avenue
description: SINCE its white paint was stripped off, its red brick sticks out like an intruder among the lighter, more refined shades of the co-ops on Park Avenue. But the five-story building at the northeast corner of Park Avenue and 75th Street, built in 1891, has seniority over its fancier neighbors. Now it is close to what it looked like when Park Avenue was nothing special.

title: When an Inmate Books the Ticket
description: GLORIA and Dan Bohan, who own a travel agency with offices coast to coast, a school for travel agents and a company that sells wholesale tickets and services to other agencies, have started a project to train prisoners to make computerized travel reservations.

title: Island's Natural Beauty Captured in Photographs
description: COLOR photographs of wind-swept sandy dunes and fields of golden grass, glistening kettle ponds and vast cranberry coppers beckon the reader to leave -- if only for a bit -- the Long Island of pavements and malls and step into a nature turned magical in a new book, ''Long Island, a Natural History'' (Harry N. Abrams) by a nature photographer and writer, Robert Villani.

title: An Action-Movie Hero Who Eludes the Label
description: EVEN BRUCE WILLIS SAYS THAT Bruce Willis is an unlikely movie star. ''When I was coming up, there were guys like Robert Redford and Paul Newman and Warren Beatty -- those were movie stars,'' he said. ''I never imagined -- '' His voice trailed off. ''It all got handed to me pretty quickly.''

title: The Castles of Jagua, Without the King
description: GOOD times seemed a long way off for Sergio Ramirez back in 1965. He was 23 and illiterate when he made his way to New York from his father's small coffee farm in the Dominican Republic. He slipped into the country via Canada and took a job washing dishes in an Italian restaurant.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 9, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Elizabeth Larson, Brian Heffernan
description: Elizabeth Burleigh Larson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Larson of Wilton, Conn., was married there yesterday to Brian Joseph Heffernan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Heffernan of Milltown, N.J. The Rev. Zdenek F. Bednar performed the ceremony at the Wilton Congregational Church.

title: Answering the Call of the Wild
description: IN 1973, LOU REED RELEASED HIS INFAMOUS song ''Walk on the Wild Side,'' a three-and-a-half-minute journey into transvestism and other illicit activities that was his biggest hit and perhaps the most licentious song ever to have escaped the wrath of radio censors. This Wednesday, when the pop opera ''Time Rocker,'' his collaboration with the director Robert Wilson and the essayist Darryl Pinckney, has its American premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Mr. Reed will be taking another walk on the wild side.

title: A New Bullet Train For the Olympics
description: A new bullet train has been introduced in Nagano, Japan, in preparation for the Olympic Winter Games next February. Called Asama, after a mountain it passes through, this shinkansen train makes 24 round trips a day between Tokyo and Nagano, 143 miles northwest. Only one train in each direction travels nonstop, so, although the train travels at 180 miles an hour, the trip between Tokyo and Nagano can last 90 minutes to three hours. Each train has eight cars, five of which have reserved seats.

title: 'Illiberal' Democracies?
description: To the Editor:

title: The View From: Katonah; A Night Filled With the Sights, Scents and Sounds of Morocco
description: THE road leading to the party was far from Moroccan in mood: a typical northern Westchester country lane, lined with tall maples in full red leaf and, on this recent night, drenched with rain. But once the BMW's and Mercedes-Benzes and Land Rovers had driven through the gates of the estate, once the occupants had stepped gingerly through the mud and into a vast, private riding ring that was the site of a gala, they found themselves surrounded by the sights, sounds and smells of the Middle East.

title: Ravaging Deer Herd Leads to Fences and Loss of Forests
description: OFTEN these days Dr. Margaret M. Carreiro stomps angrily about the deer-ravaged forests in Armonk, searching vainly for saplings, the next generation of tall trees. And Catherine Reilly is fighting mad in Pound Ridge, where her neighborhood of million-dollar homes with their electrified fences looks more like a scene from ''Stalag 17'' than pricey hideaways in the woods.

title: Guess Who's Coming To Serve Dinner?
description: THAT strange night, the night that would change her life and touch thousands of others, she was on her way to work at one of the Atlantic City casinos when she saw a man taking food from a garbage can.

title: These House Calls Make You Beautiful
description: IT'S 6 A.M.; do you know where your manicurist is?

title: November 2-8; Ex-Presidents Gather
description: They are members of ''a very small fraternity,'' as Jimmy Carter put it, and each had battled at one time against another man on the stage, but now they were all full of smiles, laughs and kind words. The rare gathering of Presidents Ford, Carter, Bush and Clinton came at the dedication of the George Bush Presidential Library and Museum, an $83 million complex on the campus of Texas A & M University in College Station, Tex.

title: Trying To Win A Park (And Jobs)
description: SIX FLAGS Theme Parks, a Time Warner Company with 12 parks in operation, is coming to New England. The company, known for its fantasy and adventure exhibits and rides tied to corporate properties like Bugs Bunny and Superman, is aggressively marketing locations, with things appearing to have narrowed down to East Hartford and Hopkinton, R.I.

title: The Nation; Money Buys a Lot More Than Access
description: Since Senator Fred Thompson pulled the plug on his committee's campaign-finance hearings, lawmakers have retreated comfortably to an old certainty: However obvious it may be that big donors buy access to power -- over coffee at the White House, say -- the purchase of favors is almost impossible to prove.

title: Shira Pfeffer, And Zvi Romm
description: Shira Yael Pfeffer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Pfeffer of Woodmere, N.Y., is to be married today to Zvi David Romm, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. J. Leonard Romm of Bellmore, N.Y. Rabbi Mordechai Willig is to perform the ceremony at the Best Western Hotel and Conference Center in Hempstead, N.Y.

title: November 2-8; A Loophole for the Ages
description: States have frothed for years as they watched a tax loophole grow to immense proportions with the popularity of mail-order shopping. Shoppers who ordered from out-of-state companies saved as much as $1.2 billion a year by paying no sales tax.

title: Commercial Property/The Westchester Office Market; Leasing Out Space Left by Corporate Downsizings
description: THE building at 1311 Mamaroneck Avenue in White Plains is in many ways typical of the problems and opportunities in the office market in Westchester County.

description: ATKINSON-Walter. To our longtime friend of forty yearswe'll miss you very much. Peter, Mary, Nicholas and Kathryn Kalikow

description: HYMAN-Sydney. At age 63, on November 7, 1997. Loving husband of Arlene. Adored father of Deborah and Mark, Laura and Jim. Caring stepfather of Dana and Michael, David and Jessica. Devoted grandfather of Jamie, Rian, Tyler, Trevor, Emma and Jared. Funeral services Monday, November 10 at Wien & Wien, 129 Engle St., Englewood, NJ, 1-800-322-0533.

title: Doing Surf and Turf With Finesse
description: TO the surprise of its many fans, the Homestead Inn in Greenwich recently changed hands, after 21 years of the same ownership and same chef, a rarity in the restaurant business.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Judge Barry Schaller; The Use of Literature to Illuminate the Law
description: IN teaching courses on the law to judges, lawyers and law students, Judge Barry Schaller often makes his point by drawing not only on the literature of William Faulkner, Nathaniel Hawthorne and Mark Twain, but also on the works of contemporary writers. He says that stories in literature are more interesting and fruitful resources than the hypothetical cases that law schools usually deal with.

title: Urban Renewal; Politicians Even A Voter Could Love
description: MAYOR PAT McCRORY of Charlotte, N.C., a Republican, is so revered that several big-name Democrats refused to take him on this year. That left him two walk-on opponents: a disciple of Lyndon LaRouche and a convicted bank robber given to sporting a pith helmet and a pair of bayonette sheaths. The Mayor practically walked to re-election Tuesday.

title: Au Pairs Aren't Nannies, and Many Are Better
description: To the Editor:

title: A Kindergartner Who Knows the Moves
description: Joshua Gluck looks like a typical 5-year-old. Blond-haired, blue-eyed and munchkin-size, Joshua loves Star Wars, Beanie Babies, building spaceships with Duplo blocks and hugging his mother.

title: Throngs Mark Rabin Killing And Mourn Fading Peace
description: Scores of thousands of Israelis gathered from across the country here today to commemorate the second anniversary of Yitzhak Rabin's assassination, and to mourn the politics of peace that foundered with his death.

title: The World; The Jobless Are Snared In Europe's Safety Net
description: EVEN today, after years of rising unemployment, it isn't hard to see why Germany once won worldwide praise as a workers' paradise.

title: Long Island Q&A;: Capt. Ann Sanborn; Being a Leader in the Merchant Marine
description: CAPTAIN Ann Sanborn, a Master Mariner in the United States Merchant Marine, is an associate professor at the United States Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point and a lawyer licensed to practice maritime law in the State of Texas. Since her graduation from the Texas Maritime Academy in 1979, where she had also held a faculty position, she has sailed both domestically and internationally on a wide range of ships, including a 210-foot oceanographic research vessel, a towing and transportation tanker and a 7,000-foot oil exploration tanker.

title: Park Slope Cooperative Is Robbed by Gang of 5
description: Five men armed with a shotgun and a knife stole $2,400 from a popular food cooperative in Park Slope, Brooklyn, last night, the police said. Two employees were slightly injured, and no suspects had been arrested as of last night.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MAKING PORTRAITS

title: China and Mount Vernon Sign Joint Pact
description: ON an unusually warm autumn morning, at a news conference at City Hall, Mayor Ernest D. Davis discussed the details of a preliminary multimillion-dollar joint development project with China that could change how this city and other communities deal with economic development.

title: Report of Plot Sparks Hirschfeld Inquiry
description: Prosecutors are investigating allegations that Abraham Hirschfeld, the real estate developer, initiated a plot last year to murder a longtime business associate with whom he had a bitter feud and a ''survivor takes all'' agreement covering some jointly held property, a law enforcement official said yesterday.

title: Foley, Ready for More Big Games, Takes Over
description: While the football world wondered last week whether Jets Coach Bill Parcells was going to bench the veteran Neil O'Donnell for the unproven Glenn Foley, Parcells phoned Tom Coughlin.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A turbulent political melodrama set in the Congo, a sly comedy about California eccentrics, a rounded salute to a famed bandleader and thoughtful sciencefiction brighten the film agenda this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORSS, WELLS
description: MORSS-Wells. 80, former Commodore of the Eastern Yacht Club, in Marblehead, MA. Died Thursday at St. Andrews Hospital in Boothbay Harbor, ME. He was born December 4, 1916 in Boston, MA, the son of Henry A. and Edith Sherman Morss. He graduated from the Fessenden School in Newton, MA, St. George's School in Newport, RI and from Harvard College in the class of 1938. He worked for his family's Boston based business, Simplex, a cable and wire company, for many years as the controller and treasurer. After he retired he pursued his true love of yachting. He started sailing at the age of five and sailed all his life. He was a member of the Cruising Club of America. He sailed in races all over the world winning race after race in his 52 foot, Sparkman and Stephens yawl, ''Legend.'' Some of the races he won included Bermuda races, Halifax races, and transatlantic races, Fastnet and races to Spain. Some of his world sails included sailing from Buenos Aires to Rio De Janiero, Marblehead to Bermuda, and Bermuda to Spain. When he wasn't racing he was helping other skippers bring their boats back. He sailed his last Bermuda race in 1981. He had sailed in 15 regular Bermuda races, 12 of them in his own boat, since his first in the fabled Grenadier in 1934 (after voyaging to England in her for the Fastnet the previous year). He had sailed in 12 Halifax races since 1939, when Grenadier won the Schooner Class, and in 1969 won Class B in the only custom boat he ever owned, the 44 foot Sparkman and Stephens sloop Carillon. He also completed Southern Circuits in his latest Legend, a Swan 48, and Errant in 1973 and 1975. He sailed in 17 of the Portland Yacht Club's Monhegan races, he took home silver more than half the time, and won the race overall twice. He was a member of many yacht clubs throughout the world including for 60 years at the Eastern Yacht Club and Boothbay Harbor Yacht Club. He was a veteran of WWII serving in the U.S. Army. He is survived by his wife, Nancy Rice Morss of West Boothbay Harbor, ME; son John Addel of Franconia, NH; daughter Leslie Morss Kane of Stratham, NH; sisters Eleanor Morss English of Liberty Corner, NY; Virginia Morss Galpin of North Bramford, CT; sister-in-law Elisabeth Morss of Hardwick, MA. A memorial service will be held at a later date in the Spring to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Andrews Hospital, 3 St. Andrews Lane, Boothbay Harbor, ME, 04538. For more information call Simmons & Harrington Funeral Home, Boothbay Harbor, ME.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We still have not found the smoking blunderbuss, but boy we have found a lot.'' JEFFREY CROW, on the discovery off North Carolina of what may be the flagship of Blackbeard the pirate. [34]

title: Havel Lectures the Czechs On the Rights of Gypsies
description: President Vaclav Havel, one of the world's champions of human rights, has been forced to lecture his own people about tolerance at home after the widespread discrimination against Gypsies by Czechs came into the international spotlight for the second time in recent months.

title: When Babies Arrive In Bunches, So Do the Bills
description: MOST parents worry about the costs of raising their children, but a recent boom in multiple births has introduced a new level of parental panic: financing babies in triplicate.

title: A Much-Needed Rest
description: NOW is the time for house plants to become the center of a gardener's attention.

title: To Hanoi by Train, a Journey Of 1,000 Miles
description: It is a muggy night and the train, making its way north from Hue through what was once the demilitarized zone and into the former North Vietnam, is crowded and steamy. Across the aisle, a dutiful daughter has removed the undershirt from her elderly father, a man with the wispy beard of Ho Chi Minh, and is massaging his shoulders; he looks weary but gratified as the cool smell of camphor fills the torpid air. The windows, covered with steel mesh to guard against stones and thieves, open just so far and provide little relief. Seven makeshift ceiling fans, gyrating from one end of the car to the other, do little better.

title: Chancellor Sees Summer Classes Easing Crowds
description: Now that New York State voters have rejected borrowing $2.4 billion to help relieve severe school crowding, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew is pushing a more contentious alternative: sending some students to school through the summer months, so other pupils can occupy their desks in the winter.

title: Italian Favorites With a Warm Welcome
description: IT is the warmth as much as the food that makes Italian restaurants the No. 1 favorite on Long Island. Angelina's II in Syosset epitomizes that warmth. Note the two in the name. The recent expansion to a second outpost reflects the popularity of the 15-year-old original Angelina's in East Norwich, a thin sliver of a spot.

title: Groups Told of Arts Fund Limits
description: LEADERS of the arts community in Westchester gathered here recently to assess the damage after the latest round of legislation concerning the National Endowment for the Arts and after the resignation of its chairwoman, Jane Alexander.

title: Holyfield Stops Moorer in 8, Adding a 2d Heavyweight Title
description: Evander Holyfield threw everything he had at Michael Moorer tonight, knocking him down five times, but Moorer kept getting up for more. But after two straight knockdowns in the eighth round, the ring doctor, Flip Homansky, was not as concerned about Moorer's heart as he was about his head, and Homansky advised Referee Mitch Halpern to stop the bout with Moorer sitting on the stool in his corner ready to come out for the ninth round.

title: POSTINGS: $12.3 Million Expansion for the College of Aeronautics Includes 10 Classrooms and Lab Space; A New Hangar, for Planes That Don't Fly
description: What are a parking lot full of assorted aircraft and a hangar and observation tower under construction doing opposite La Guardia Airport on the other side of the Grand Central Parkway?

title: Grace of Experience Faces Urgency of Youth
description: The old warrior never took off his warm-up sweats and checked into the game. Buck Williams, 37 and perfectly healthy, watched from the bench with wonder and concern. Kobe Bryant was gliding down the court in front of him.

title: November 2-8; She Recovered Memories, Then Millions in Damages
description: Some of the ''recovered memories'' that psychiatrists told Patricia Burgus she had were fantastical: that she cannibalized people, was raped by dozens of men, had sex with President John F. Kennedy, engaged in satanic rituals. When her years of therapy were over, she accused doctors of implanting false memories. Last week, she won a $10.6 million legal settlement, the largest in a series of similar cases.

title: Arithmetic of the Avenues
description: Hunting for an address on an avenue in Manhattan without knowing the cross street does not have to be difficult. Just drop the last figure, divide by 2 and add or subtract as indicated below. The answer is the nearest numbered cross street. This key does not aply to Broadway below Eighth Street because of the many streets with names rather than numbers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLACK, DR. RITA BECK
description: BLACK-Dr. Rita Beck. A service will be held at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University on Thursday, November 13 at 5:30PM.

title: Cornell Waits for a Pumpkin to Plummet
description: It is said that what goes up must come down. So the question at Cornell University is when the 60-pound pumpkin atop the school's 173-foot bell tower will finally make its descent.

title: Cashing In on Art: All in the Timing
description: THE SAVVIEST COLLECTORS ARE CANNY about finding the finest art, getting it exhibited prominently in museums and then knowing just when to donate or sell it. Until recently, this approach was usually reserved for owners of master paintings and furnishings with impressive pedigrees. Now even the owners of esoteric art are taking this route, as can be seen in the highly publicized sale of medieval enamels taking place at Sotheby's in New York on Nov. 20.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column on Oct. 12 about taxicabs powered by natural gas misstated the percentage of air pollution produced by cabs. It is not 40. Community Consulting Services, an engineering firm, calculates that medallion cabs are responsible for 6.3 percent of the city's air pollution.

title: William Turner, 93, Industrial Philanthropist
description: William Heyward Homer Turner, former executive director of the United States Steel Corporation's foundation and an early developer of corporate philanthropy, died on Oct. 30 at St. Joseph Medical Center in Stamford, Conn. He was 93 and a resident of Stamford.

title: United Way, Faced With Fewer Donors, Is Giving Away Less
description: Justine and Jasmine Scott, 7-year-old twins, wanted to spend the summer at Challengers Boys and Girls Club, which for almost three decades has provided a haven for youngsters from the dangerous neighborhoods south of downtown Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACE, COREEN E. (NEE COLEMAN)
description: WALLACE-Coreen E. (nee Coleman) November 5, 1997. Beloved wife of James, mother of Frank, Jay and Ellen Wallace and Coreen Wallace Scharfe. Devoted grandmother to eight loving grandchildren. Beloved aunt to Judson Lange. Services November 10th, 10am at St. George's Episcopal Church where she served on The Alter Guild, Choir and Choral Society for many years. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave, November 8th and 9th between 2-4pm and 7-9pm.

title: Complex Conclusions
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Towns in The Big Town
description: John Tierney's article ''Small Towns in the Big Town'' offered a great insight into New York, its inhabitants and what makes this metropolis unique, wonderful and ultimately overwhelming.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Long Island copies last Sunday about mortgage programs for moderate-income homeowners misstated aspects of the First Home Club program of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York. For every $1 placed by buyers in special savings accounts, the program provides up to $3 in grants, not $2. The bank has invested $3 million in the program, not $1 million.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, HELEN ROSENTHAL
description: KLEIN-Helen Rosenthal. Dec. 2, 1923-Nov. 9, 1995. Cherished sister, always caring, giving and loving. Now always missed.

title: November 2-8; The Story Was True -- For Somebody Else
description: Over and over, James Ware had told the tale, moving audiences to tears with his account of how his teen-age brother's murder by white racists in Birmingham, Ala., in 1963 had inspired him to become a lawyer and, later, a Federal judge. The story was moving. It just wasn't Judge Ware's. Last week he acknowledged the lie and asked President Clinton to withdraw his nomination for a promotion that would have made him the only active black judge on the Federal appeals court in San Francisco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREASH, FLORENCE
description: CREASH-Florence. Beloved wife of the late Norman. Devoted mother of Linda and Alan. Adored grandmother of Leah and Jared. Devoted sister of Harold Sherman and Ethel Mittelman and sister-inlaw of Diane Sherman and Edward Mittelman and nieces and nephews. Services Sunday 10AM, Schwartz Bros, 114-03 Queens Boulevard Blvd., Forest Hills, NY.

title: As Obscurity Turns to Absence, a Composer Thrives
description: FOR MUCH OF THIS CENTURY, they were lumped together under the vague, and vaguely pejorative, phrase ''American eccentrics.'' They paid little heed to European traditions. Their training was often spotty, leaving them open to jazz, folk and non-Western music. Working in obscurity, they hewed stubbornly to private visions.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; Spoonfuls of Sugar, But Barrels of Salt
description: SO you believe in Mary Poppins? As a career woman with three wonderful children, I can attest to such faith -- much as a small child is devoted to the Tooth Fairy.

title: Medicare Pays Millions in Ambulance Overbilling, Report Says
description: Federal investigators, having documented many instances of overbilling and false claims by ambulance operators, say that Medicare wastes hundreds of millions of dollars a year by paying for unnecessary ambulance services provided to elderly patients.

title: How To Fight City Hall
description: SO you voted for the Mayor, the rasp in his voice has almost become endearing and you are looking forward to four more years of feeling safe when you walk the dog at night. Then you find out that the city wants to put an off ramp from the Gowanus Expressway in your neighborhood, and suddenly you are sticking voodoo pins in your Giuliani doll. That makes you feel better, but it is not going to stop the ramp. You cannot afford to hire a lobbying firm of a mayoral ally like Raymond B. Harding, so what is a community to do?

title: Westchester Q&A: Dr. Thomas S. Butera; Defining What Makes a Good Teacher
description: ARE great teachers born or can they be created? Is teaching an art or a craft? The answer borrows a little from each question, said Dr. Thomas S. Butera, the director of graduate education at Mercy College. He oversees a master's degree program at Mercy's Yorktown campus that trains people who are in non-teaching fields to become teachers.

title: Asia Strategy, From One Who Has Been There
description: WARREN B. BAILEY is no J. Mark Mobius, the guru of emerging markets at the Franklin Templeton mutual funds.

description: HERE'S the picture: The market has roared back, and you again hear buzz about a possible merger. So you call your broker and buy shares in one or both potential partners. Right?

title: End of an Era at Hartford Stage
description: MARK LAMOS is a tough act to follow; in the particular world of regional theater, it's hard to think of a tougher one.

title: Dead-End Kids
description: CircumnavigationBy Steve Lattimore.211 pp. New York:Houghton Mifflin Company.$20.

title: Earning Its Stripes
description: I HAVE a great restaurant I want you to try,'' the message on my answering machine says. ''But I'm not going to tell you the name unless you promise to take me with you.''

title: It's Only a Test: City Agencies Practice Responding to Attacks by Terrorists
description: With an eye toward reducing the potential danger of a terrorist chemical attack, the city's Office of Emergency Management started a series of antiterrorism drills yesterday that will culminate today with a full-scale enactment of a toxic disaster in TriBeCa.

description: Alistaire Bambach and James Philip Bodovitz, both lawyers, are to be married today at the Maidstone Arms Inn in East Hampton, N.Y. Judge Michael B. Mukasey of the Federal District Court in Manhattan is to officiate.

description: Columbia's athletic director, John Reeves, joked early in yesterday's game that he was waiting for a torrential downpour; after all, the Lions had shut out Princeton last week in monsoon-like conditions.

title: What's Fair In Setting Fund Value?
description: FIDELITY INVESTMENTS outraged scores of investors placing buy orders during last month's market turmoil when it valued more than a dozen of its international stock funds based not on closing stock prices in battered overseas markets, but on prices in the United States, where stocks had rebounded sharply.

title: Corrections
description: The mutual fund tables last Sunday misstated percentage changes for the Dean Witter stock mutual funds for the week ended Oct. 31. The figures, from Morningstar Inc., reflected changes from the close of Monday, Oct. 27, through Friday, Oct. 31, thus disregarding the large drop in stock prices on Oct. 27. A corrected list appears in the fund tables today, on page 20.

The Rev. Michael Zeman, a minister of the United Church of Christ who is an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Club in Washington.

title: To the Fund-Raiser Born
description: Robin Duke is ''so beautiful,'' not for age 74 but for any age. It would take a very brave supermodel to have her picture taken next to her.

title: As Crimes Decline, Chinese Thank Two Detectives
description: They may be strangers to most of the city. But Edward Miller and Peter Tartaglia have made a name among Chinese in New York as two of the toughest detectives who deal with Chinese gangs. Their recent retirement brought out emotional farewells from Chinese New Yorkers.

title: Slower Population Growth Won't Last Forever
description: To the Editor:

title: SPOTLIGHT; The Fight Game
description: Don King was many things before he became the most successful boxing promoter in the history of the sport: a numbers-runner, for one, and a convicted felon who served prison time for manslaughter. But it was as the brains behind such cinematically titled boxing matches as the Rumble in the Jun-gleaned the Thrilla in Manila that he gained his considerable notoriety.

title: The Speed Demons on My Mind
description: LAW-abiding citizens do not steal, mug or even spit in the subway. And, even if they did, they sure wouldn't brag about it. But speeding, that's different.

title: For a Giants Coach, a Step Back Was a Leap Forward
description: John Fox always wanted to be a coach. In the 19 years that followed his college graduation, he chased 13 coaching jobs, from his native California to Idaho, through Utah, Kansas, Iowa and Pennsylvania.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Openers

title: Surrendering After Facing The Music
description: OF all noises,'' Samuel Johnson once said, ''I think music is the least disagreeable.'' The Illinois State Police think so too.

title: Chicago's Modernist Beauty
description: Sitting beside the window of Spiaggia, a tony Italian restaurant, watching ferries skim Lake Michigan's improbably Caribbean blue, weighing the painful choice between the fresh pasta with a ragout of morels and the oven-fired pizza with goat cheese, sage and duck sausage, you might have a hard time believing that this is the city Carl Sandburg called the ''Hog Butcher for the World.'' At least from this perspective -- two stories above the Magnificent Mile, the local version of Rodeo Drive -- Chicago appears to have sanded off some of its abattoir edge, the gritty residue deposited by its romantic association with Al Capone, John Dillinger and, more recently, John Belushi. But, of course, the grit still remains: in the blues clubs, in the downtown streets of the Loop circumscribed by the rumbling elevated train tracks and in the frenzy of the trading pits of the Chicago Board of Trade, where, from the placid remove of the visitors' gallery, one can watch blood pressures plummet and soar along with soybean futures.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REACH, BARBARA
description: REACH-Barbara. November 8, 1992. Lovingly remembered. Deeply missed. Ellie

title: Correction
description: An article on Oct. 26 about Dr. Sheldon N. Grebstein, who teaches courses at the Westchester Holocaust Commission, misstated his relationship with the commission. While he is not paid for the courses on Holocaust literature, he is indeed paid for his job as the commission's director of education. The books acquired by Dr. Grebstein for the group's library are financed not just by his contributions but by those of other donors.

title: The Artist Becomes A Storyteller Again
description: EVERY CHILD WANTS A STORY, AND NO adult ever outgrows that want, which virtually amounts to a need. It has probably been like this since the first campfires when tales were told of the hunt for mastodons, and later when the lives and adventures of the gods were recounted.

description: To the Editor:

description: The head-shaking has not stopped for days. People around here still cannot believe what happened last Sunday night. They say they are stunned, saddened and amazed.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: The Pop Perfectionist on a Crowded Stage
description: Paul Simon is sitting in an Irish tavern on Columbus Avenue, finishing off a plate of roast turkey and mashed potatoes, watching the Yankees' season crash to a close and insisting that he is not a perfectionist. He has just come from the theater. For seven years, Simon has been writing a Broadway musical called ''The Capeman.'' Now the show is just weeks away. (The first preview performance is scheduled for Dec. 1, with opening night set for Jan. 8.) Earlier this evening, several scenes were staged for an audience of group-ticket-sales agents, who seemed to like it quite a bit. More surprisingly, so did Simon.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEGRAFF, ERWIN
description: DeGRAFF-Erwin. On October 8, age 88, at his home in Hague, NY. Retired 1971 after long career at McGraw-Hill: Regional VP of Advertising Sales, including Business Week; Publisher Petroleum Week. B.A. in English, N.Y.U. 1935. Lt. U.S. Navy, WWII. Survived by wife of 58 years, Billie (Maranghi), three sons, William, Thomas and John; two grandsons. Memorial contributions to Lake George Basin Land Conservancy, Bolton, NY 12814.

title: Tarnishing That Image At Rutgers
description: A Rutgers alumnus dies and leaves the school his prospering local brothel. It is renamed The Scarlet Nights Motel, and staffed with students on scholarship. A big-time madam is brought in from Las Vegas, Nev. There is controversy, but officials at Rutgers point out that the program, which is very popular with alumni, stimulates donations as well as a steady revenue stream that will help support the library. Besides, how else would these student-prostitutes get college educations?

description: MY BROTHER JOSEPH

title: Two Teams Traveling A Similar Course
description: Significant events involving two talented Russians on two sub-.500 hockey teams just happened to occur, almost simultaneously, on Friday. The players are Aleksei Kovalev and Alexander Mogilny. The teams are the Rangers and the Vancouver Canucks. Like astronomical bodies coming into conjunction on an astrological chart, these events, players and teams could soon interact to create movement and improvement for all involved.

title: Maria Nunes, Carlos Sanchez
description: Maria Valentina Nunes, a daughter of Dr. Manuel J. Nunes of Waterbury, Conn., and the late Valentina St. Aubyn Nunes, was married last evening at the New York City Municipal Building to Carlos Felix Sanchez, a son of Mercedes and Manuel P. Sanchez of Valencia, Spain.

description: LEE W. HIGGINS'S first Manhattan apartment was a one-bedroom divvied up for three in an Upper East Side doorman building.

description: To the Editor:

title: Doctoring Reality to Document What's True
description: IN 1898, AS PART OF A NORTH PACIFIC expedition for the American Museum of Natural History, an anthropologist named Harlan Smith went into the wilderness of British Columbia to take photographs of native people and collect artifacts. Smith hadn't come all that way to let chance decide what he would find. He carried descriptions of what he wanted and photographs of the display cases in which the objects would reside. And when his camera didn't see what he needed, he staged it.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BRYER, RICHARD
description: BRYER-Richard. 32 years without you, my precious Richie. Ever cherished, ever remembered with love. Mom

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Lunch With a Thousand Eyes
description: Go to your local greengrocer. Select a nice bell pepper and rotate it in your hand. Observe it closely. Do you see a rabbit? Never mind, you will. PLAY WITH YOUR FOOD (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, $19.95), by Joost Elffers, might better be called ''Look at Your Food,'' particularly at a panoply of fruits and vegetables that, with a little help, can become something quite other. Some 150 weirdly hilarious photographs document the metamorphoses: pear bears, lemon pigs, okra grasshoppers and bunches of wild-haired people who are really leeks and scallions (the leeks look fashionable, the scallions panic-stricken) are only the beginning. Minimal means are used to produce these transformations; for garlic-clove geese, for example, the peel of each clove has merely been twiddled to suggest the head and neck of the bird in question, while the bell-pepper rabbit is achieved by the simple additions of big almond teeth and snow-pea lop ears. Elffers, an advocate of finding the natural visual puns inherent in his materials, is almost reluctant to give how-to instructions, since he wants his readers to invent their own menageries. Nonetheless, there are recipes for each of the creatures, as well as a section on what materials to use for eyes (peppercorns, olives, black-eyed peas), ears (mostly folded out from the host fruit or vegetable) and, especially, noses. ''Anything that sticks out of a fruit or vegetable is a potential nose,'' Elffers writes, and illustrates that maxim with a gallery of gnarly-nosed jack-o'-lanterns. As a practical note, he suggests that having fun with veggies might help a fussy-eating child to see the light. Perhaps, but doesn't it seem a bit heartless to boil a brussels sprout that you've learned to love as a pig or a goldfish or a hippo? Sarah Ferrell

title: Smells Like Teen Enthusiasm
description: For months, many fans of rock music have been tuning in to the rumor that

title: Grocery Bills With a Bonus
description: YOU don't have to volunteer. You don't have to write a check. You don't have to find a stamp.

title: A Matter of Degrees; Grading Colleges Requires More Than Math
description: WHEN high-school seniors apply to colleges, they have all sorts of ways to compare quality, and some of them are quantifiable: the average SAT scores of the last entering class, for example, or the student-faculty ratio.

title: More on Melchior
description: To the Editor: Regarding your Q & A letter on Lauritz Melchior sites in Europe (Sept. 28), I thought that readers might also want to know that there is much to see in the United States.

title: Heart Surgeon Uses New Bypass Methods
description: DR. MOHAN SARABU, associate professor of surgery at New York Medical College and on the staff of the Westchester County Medical Center, both in Valhalla, wondered about the passage of oxygen throughout the human body from the time he was 10 in his native India. From then on, he planned to become a doctor who would work to insure that future patients would have an uninterrupted flow of oxygen.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLEIBERG, ROBERT
description: BLEIBERG-Robert, on November 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Diane Beverly. Loving father of Ellen Van Landingham Smith and Richard Bleiberg. Devoted brother of Lawrence. title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Botanizing in the Balkans
description: In MONTENEGRO (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23), Starling Lawrence has created a stirring account of turn-of-the-century political intrigue -- and an intriguing romance. Even though a prefatory deathbed scene hints at a terrible final tragedy, we read compulsively on, hoping somehow that the inevitable will be avoided. At the center of the novel is a reluctant spy, Auberon Harwell, the agent of a corrupt English peer who hopes to turn British ignorance of the tensions between the Austro-Hungarian and Ottoman empires to his own advantage. Harwell is traveling through the Balkans posing as a botanist, much to the contemptuous disbelief of the fierce Montenegrins, who cannot fathom why an able-bodied man in full possession of his faculties would spend so much time looking at flowers. Harwell soon comes to agree with them. Impelled in part by his growing attachment to a local family, he begins to loathe his backer and even himself, seeing in his dutiful reports only ''the grinding of empires and his own dishonor.'' He renounces neutrality to become wholeheartedly engaged in the escalating violence, which comes to a climax when an earthquake threatens to turn matters -- even mountains -- upside down. Early in his stay in Montenegro, as he watches a group of monks leaving church, Harwell reflects on the sweetness of issuing forth from services at Oxford, his slate having been wiped clean so he could re-enter ''the bright sin and glory of the world.'' Lawrence's novel captures all that brightness and glory. Julie Gray

title: Skip Away Electrifies Racing's Big Day
description: After staggering to the starting gate under a wave of injuries to its star horses, the Breeders' Cup was staged today at Hollywood Park with 75 thoroughbreds competing in seven races for $11 million. And the show went on before a crowd of 51,161 with electric performances in the Classic by Skip Away and in the Juvenile by the undefeated Favorite Trick, both of whom raced toward the wide-open title of Horse of the Year.

description: WILLIAMSBURG/GREENPOINT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBRECHT, ARTHUR J.
description: ALBRECHT-Arthur J. A recognized leader in developing marketing strategies and advertising for nationally-known consumer products, died from Lymphoma on October 14, 1997 at Boca Raton Community Hospital in FL. He was 66. Mr. Albrecht's reputation was such that when he authored a marketing plan for a new product, the plan was virtually certain of support from venture capitalists. In the early '90s, as a consultant to the Himmel Corporation, he originated the advertising that fueled the dramatic comeback of two ''forgotten brands,'' Gold Bond Medicated Powder and Ovaltine. Following his graduation as BA cum laude from FL State University in 1957, Mr. Albrecht began his career in 1958 with the Vick Chemical Company. He started as a salesman, was promoted to promotion manager and later assumed management of the Vick subsidiary in Canada. Mr. Albrecht then moved on to senior marketing/advertising positions at Whitehall Labs, Revlon, J.B. Williams and the William Esty Advertising Company. From 1981 to 1991 he was President of his own advertising agency, Petersen & Albrecht, responsible mainly for the advertising of Bausch & Lomb contact lenses. In recent years, he served as marketing and advertising consultant to Combe Inc., Bausch & Lomb and Himmel, Inc. as well as companies headquartered in Europe and Japan. As Adjunct Assistant Professor at the Pace Univeristy Business School, he shared his knowledge and kindled excitement about the power of marketing among hundreds of Pace students from 1976 to 1985. Mr. Albrecht was the author of numerous articles in trade journals and was also active in many professional groups. He was a member of the Pharmaceutical Advertising Club, The National Writers' Club, FL State University Alumni Association, The International Platform Association, Phi Beta Kappa as well as Phi Kappa Phi, Phi Eta Sigma and Alpha Delta Sigma. For many years, he has been listed in Who's Who in America. He is survived by his wife of 44 years, Sandi and their daughter, Sherylyn. Memorial services will be held at a future date in Westchester, NY.

title: Editorial Observer; Reading the Landscape of the New West
description: Between Casper, Wyo., and Denver, Colo., Interstate 25 bends through several landscapes, each distinctively Western. Some are agricultural, like the plowed ground near Wheatland, Wyo. Others, like the stretch south of Douglas, Wyo., have the wide-open look of high grassland rising into rimrock and pines. Whenever I drive this road, I'm struck by the forgotten complexity of a terrain I thought I knew well. Each new vista seems to offer something surprising -- an enormous power plant set in a Frederic Remington landscape, a trio of 55-gallon drums laid out in a dry riverbed by a die-hard barrel racer or, most surprising of all, the spareness that is still this region's most characteristic feature.

title: Replaying The Birth And Styles Of the Blues
description: The first concert of the New York Autumn Blues Festival, which started on Friday night at Symphony Space, traced a familiar story: the passage of the blues from rural Mississippi to northern cities like Chicago. The concert was also a tribute to the persistence of music that still hangs on in its birthplace and continues to draw far-flung disciples.

The thin line that separates a game-turning play from the old college try was not crossed by Toomer, Alexander and the rest of the Giants yesterday.

Terrorists have released plumes of deadly nerve gas -- the kind the Iraqi government was recently accused of producing -- instantly killing at least 17 people, and transforming a sleepy TriBeCa street into a nightmare of chemical terrorism.

title: Already Struggling, Dominicans Sink Deeper Into Poverty, Study Finds
description: A new study of Dominicans, New York City's largest and fastest growing immigrant group, has found that they have stumbled badly in the 1990's on the road to the American dream. Their per capita income has declined precipitously. Unemployment and poverty have risen substantially, as has the proportion of Dominican families headed by women with no spouse around to help out financially.

title: Two Faces, And Both In Trouble

But as a bloodthirsty leader of the French Revolution named Chauvelin, the original star of the Broadway productions of ''Les Miserables'' and ''Beauty and the Beast'' somehow suggests that slaughtering innocent aristocrats definitely beats warm milk for making a fellow sleepy.

title: Trial of Au Pair Reveals Unease in U.S. Society; In Case of Dead Baby, a Common Ground

She would tell acquaintances about the trial that had hooked her, and the ''incredible pre-Raphaelite face'' of the defendant. What got her, she said, was ''the dark undertone, that secret fear in the back of every mother's head that the people she's left her kids with are going to hurt them.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSKOWITZ, LOUIS
description: MOSKOWITZ - Louis. Retired teacher, Erasmus Hall High School, Brooklyn, New York. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Devoted father of Kenneth Moskowitz and Susan Abrams. Cherished grandfather of Andrea and Stephanie. Dear brother of Benjamin and Bernice. Services ''BoulvardRiverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Monday at 1:30 PM.

title: PENTAGON TO TRIM THOUSANDS OF JOBS HELD BY CIVILIANS
description: Under pressure from Congress to reduce the Pentagon's bureaucracy before ordering more cuts in troops or weapons, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen plans to trim thousands of civilian jobs at the Pentagon and transfer thousands more military personnel out of their headquarters and into the field, officials said.

title: New Broom Is Sweeping In Argentina
description: When Fernando de la Rua became the first elected Mayor of this capital city last year, he promised to curb the corrupt practices of past mayors who had long been appointed by the country's President.

title: The Sonnets, Treated as Terra Incognita
description: THE ART OF SHAKESPEARE'S SONNETS

title: Baggage Rules Will Cause New Headaches
description: To the Editor:

title: O'Connor Says He'll Work to Propose Sainthood for Dorothy Day, Servant of the Poor
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, said yesterday that he would take the first steps toward proposing sainthood for Dorothy Day, the legendary advocate for social justice and servant of the poor who co-founded the Catholic Worker movement in 1933.

title: Taking In the Sites ; On-Line Banking Doesn't Always Cover the Basics
description: Nearly all of the big banks now offer some sort of on-line banking. But in their frenzy to provide their customers with the ability to zap their money all over the world, many of the most sophisticated banks have forgotten to answer even the most basic questions about their services.

title: Senate Adjusts Legislation, Hoping to Remove Obstacles and Avoid a Veto
description: The Senate voted tonight to consolidate the three remaining Federal spending bills for the 1998 fiscal year into a single piece of legislation. It also voted to strip out or soften most of the issues that have stalled the bills and drawn veto threats from President Clinton.

title: Blast Shatters Windows Near Mock Attack
description: A crude explosive device fashioned from a coffee can went off outside an office building in lower Manhattan early yesterday morning, damaging a revolving glass door and blowing out several windows but causing no injuries, law enforcement officials said.

title: Right Hands Knowing What Lefts Are Doing
description: The arithmetic of the two-piano literature promises much. Certainly the most versatile and all-embracing instrument of the classical tradition, when added to another of its kind, will increase the listener's rewards accordingly. It so seldom happens.

title: Abroad at Home; Caving to the Ultras
description: The Democrats who then controlled the Senate handled judicial nominations by Presidents Reagan and Bush in a reasonable way, confirming most in good time. Suppose, instead, that voices on the extreme left had called for sabotage of the process and Democratic senators had yielded to that demand, blocking nominations for years. There would have been, and should have been, an outcry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SESSA, LUCY M.
description: SESSA-Lucy M. On November 8, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Joseph V. Loving mother of Francis X. and Robert J. Cherished Noni of Peter, Jay, Lisa, Paul, Serna, Steven and 11 great-grandchildren. Visiting Monday, 7-9 PM, and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Joseph V. Sessa Funeral Home, 6924 Ft. Hamilton Parkway. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 9:30 AM, St. Ephrem's Church.

title: A Soloist Hails Homeland and Hosts
description: There are a few classical-music performers whose appearances come with a virtual seal of quality, and the Swedish mezzo-soprano Anne Sofie von Otter is one. Her compelling interpretations in a widely varied repertory over the last decade have produced a considerable following, which she continues to find ways to surprise and delight.

title: King World's Chiefs Hope for New Syndication Success With Old TV Standbys
description: Today in Los Angeles, Michael and Roger King, the astute and assiduous salesmen who run King World Productions Inc., will meet with a handful of institutional investors for the first time in at least five years.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''No new car, no vacation. My life is no different. I've given it up to God. I live in His presence and do His will, and I did that from the start.'' Eleanor Boyer, 72, who won $11 million in the New Jersey lottery last week. [A1]

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUTTON, BEN JOSEPH
description: DUTTON-Ben Joseph. On November 8, 1997, in New York. Gentle and loving husband of Pauline Kasmedor. Inspirational and devoted father of Deborah and Pamela. Cherished grandfather of Alexandra and Sebastian. Twin brother of Chester. His proud bearing, absolute goodness, generosity of spirit and wise counsel will be, as they have always been, a model to us all. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., on Monday, November 10, from 2:30-8:30. Mass of Christian Burial on Tuesday, November 11, at 10 AM, at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89 St., New York City. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memeory may be made to the Calvary Fund, Inc., 1740 Eastchester Rd., Bronx, NY 10461.

title: Affirmative Action Rollback Exposes Inequity; No Precedent Here
description: To the Editor:

title: New Faces and Jobs Announced at WPP
description: WPP Group P.L.C. has made several moves involving its operations in marketing technology and health care advertising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABBOTT, SUSAN
description: ABBOTT-Susan. 74. November 7, 1997. Holocaust survivor from Vienna, Austria. She sailed into New York Harbor in 1940 and has lived in the city ever since. Artist and peace and justice activist. She will be missed for her extraordinary inspiration, creativity, hospitality and generosity. Beloved mother of Peter, Thomas and Michael; and grandmother of Andrea, Rebecca, Gabriel and Nathaniel. Services 2 PM, Tuesday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: In the Land Of Double Meanings
description: At the beginning of Jay Leonhart's hilarious song ''Customs,'' a globe-trotter's peevish complaint about his detainment before being permitted to re-enter the United States, you identify with this inconvenienced traveler whom Mr. Leonhart portrays with an air of lofty disdain. But by the end of the song -- the high point of the new, witty cabaret revue, ''Secrets Every Smart Traveler Should Know'' -- your sympathy has ebbed. In addition to exotic wildlife, including alligators, goats and some mysterious eggs gathered from around the globe, this intrepid explorer has also brought back ''monkey droppings from Zaire.'' Both the song, with its slicing rhymes, and Mr. Leonhart's haughty delivery recall the golden days of Tom Lehrer's sang-froid comic spoofs.

title: Corrections
description: The Wine Talk column on Wednesday about the Chateau de Goulaine, in Nantes, France, misspelled the name of the biscuit company that is to exhibit its artworks there. It is Lefevre-Utile, not Lefevbre-Utile. The article also misspelled the name of the company's founder. He was Louis Lefevre-Utile.

title: Victorious Americans Qualify For France
description: With a 3-0 victory over Canada today, the United States soccer team guaranteed itself a place in the 1998 World Cup and most likely assured that Steve Sampson will be going along as a head coach, not as a tourist.

title: Bronx Woman Held in Death of Her Sister, 9
description: The 32-year-old Bronx woman who was arrested early yesterday morning in the death of her 9-year-old sister had been deemed fit to take custody of the child only nine months ago by a Family Court judge, the authorities said.

title: Canadian Olympic Team
description: Canadian Hockey, the umbrella organization of the Canadian Olympic team, has told Paul Kariya that he will have to present a conditioning plan by Dec. 1 if he intends to play at the Winter Olympics in Nagano, Japan.

title: J. Edward Corn, 64, an Opera Manager
description: J. Edward Corn, an arts manager and administrator, died on Oct. 16 at St. Joseph's Hospital in St. Paul, Minn. He was 64 and lived in Sunfish Lake, Minn.

title: Day of Senate Action On '98 Spending Bills
description: The Senate approved the consolidation of the three remaining Federal spending bills for 1998. Earlier, House Republican leaders and the White House agreed to a compromise over a controversial method for estimating the population in 2000, the major issue that had stalled the spending bill for the Departments of Commerce, Justice and State.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the ''At the Movies'' column in Weekend on Friday about Francis Ford Coppola's directing of an adaptation of John Grisham's ''Rainmaker'' misidentified the winner of the 1972 Academy Award for best director. Bob Fosse won for ''Cabaret.'' (''The Godfather,'' directed by Mr. Coppola, won the Oscar for best picture that year but not for best director.)

title: Frank Graziano, 79, Former Crompton Chairman
description: Frank J. Graziano, a former chairman and chief executive of the Crompton & Knowles Corporation, died Oct. 27 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York. He was 79.

title: Swedish Match Surges Ahead
description: Swedish Match opened a lead of 44 miles over EF Language overnight Saturday as the eight-month Whitbread Round the World Race began the second of its nine stages. The sailboats left Cape Town on Saturday on the 4,600-nautical-mile leg to Fremantle, Australia.

title: Parcells Angered by Decision on Chrebet's 'Catch'
description: Jets Coach Bill Parcells did not have much to say to reporters today about a controversial call that ended his team's drive toward a late tying touchdown. But Parcells had plenty to say to the officials as he came steaming off the field after the Jets' 24-17 loss to the Dolphins.

title: Sharpton Says He May Run For Congress
description: With a host of Democratic officials encouraging him, the Rev. Al Sharpton is considering a bid for the seat in Congress held by Representative Edolphus Towns, a Brooklyn Democrat who crossed party lines to support Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Man Held After Officers Are Shot During Search
description: A 20-year-old Asbury Park man was charged with five counts of attempted murder yesterday after, the authorities said, he opened fire on police officers trying to execute a search warrant. Two officers were wounded, though not seriously.

title: Crash During Chase Leaves Officer Dead
description: A Newark police officer, Dewey Sherbo 3d, 32, died from head and internal injuries yesterday afternoon at University Hospital, a day after his patrol car struck a tree during the pursuit of a stolen car, the police said.

title: Pataki Continues 7-State Fund-Raiser
description: Gov. George E. Pataki continued his cross-country fund-raising trip for a second day yesterday, part of a tour that is taking him to seven states.

title: Sports of The Times; Now, the Toughest Fight Begins
description: INSTEAD of moving and throwing the right jab that confused Evander Holyfield three years ago, Michael Moorer decided to stand there and fight. And against Evander Holyfield, now the two-thirds heavyweight champion, standing there and fighting is a mistake, as Mike Tyson twice discovered.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Studenica Journal; If the Walls Could Speak, Serb Epic Would Unfold
description: Well before dawn has cast its pale light over these scrub-covered hills, an 80-year-old abbot leads 14 monks and novices into the hulking marble walls of a 12th-century church for morning devotions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITOFSKY, ELSIE
description: MITOFSKY-Elsie. On November 8, 1997, in Buffalo, NY. Beloved wife of the late Howard; mother of Warren (Mia) and Lenore Levy (late Morton). Noted for her extensive volunteer work in Monticello, NY, she is also survived by a brother, Arthur Sonderling, five grandchildren and seven greatgrandchildren. Graveside services at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY, Tuesday at 1 PM.

title: Richmond Trade Talk And Push For a Title
description: Mitch Richmond said he feels as if he has been in jail for a long time, or as close as you can get to feeling imprisoned while making $3 million to play basketball. Downstairs at Arco Arena, he goes through the motions in practice. Upstairs, club officials work the phones and try to negotiate his departure.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Catamaran Speeds Alcone to Victory
description: Matt Alcone, an offshore racer from Laguna Beach, Calif., took advantage of light winds and calm seas yesterday to win the Superboat title in the Key West World Championships off Key West, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COMMERFORD, SR. ROSE MARY (FORMERLY SISTER MARY RAYMOND)
description: COMMERFORD-Sr. Rose Mary (formerly Sister Mary Raymond). Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity. Social worker, administrator, teacher, and former counselor for the Sisters of Charity. On November 8, 1997. Survived by cousins. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark St., Yonkers, NY, on Sunday, 4-8 PM, and Monday 1-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10:30 AM, at St. Mary's Church. Interment at St. Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Ave., Bronx, NY 10471.

title: To Aborigines, 100-Year-Old Matriarch Is Proof of Ownership
description: Pipe between her lips, wavy white hair blowing in the hot, dry wind, Clara George sat under a eucalyptus tree and reminisced about her 100th birthday party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREM, SYBIL GERTRUDE NICHOLS
description: PREM-Sybil Gertrude Nichols. On November 6, 1997 in Bridgeville, PA., at The Country Meadows Nursing and Rehabilitation Center at age 98. A long-time resident of Larchmont, N.Y., and New York, NY, she was the wife of the late F. Herbert Prem, a senior partner in the New York City admiralty law firm of Bigham, Englar, Jones & Houston, who died in 1974. For many years she had been active in fund raising activities for the New York Philharmonic Society, and had also served as Chairwoman of the Comite Maritime International Meeting in the United States. She is survived by her son, F. Herbert Prem, Jr. of New York, New York, Sharon, CT., and West Brooksville, ME., her daughter, Lois Prem Simon, of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL., five grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. Services will be private.

title: Patents; A new device helps emergency workers find people who use a mobile phone to call for help.
description: IF a person suffering a heart attack dials 911 from his or her home phone, a dispatcher can send an ambulance right away to the correct address -- even if the victim is unable to speak. That is because conventional telephone lines are specially outfitted to give emergency dispatchers the address of callers.

title: On-Line Sales And Off-Line Taxing Collide
description: Harry Smith and Ron Wyden look at the Internet and see a tax nightmare. But what arouses their anxiety are different visions regarding taxes in cyberspace.

title: A Memorial for a Master And an Example of Mastery
description: Edgar Kaplan, who died in September, was an extraordinary man who did more for bridge in every way than anyone else in the game's history: player, teacher, writer, editor, system-maker, administrator, commentator and lawmaker. That was the consensus of a hundred of his friends and relatives who gathered Saturday at Honors Club, 115 East 57th Street, to share memories. Among them were two former presidents of the World Bridge Federation: Jaime Ortiz-Patino, who came from London, and Ernesto D'Orsi, who came from Brazil.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Harrison Roth, a Wall Street expert on the trading of options, omitted a reference to his previous marriage. His first wife, Hazel Gery Roth, died in 1970.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKO, SOL
description: BERKO-Sol. Beloved grandfather, great-grandfather, in our hearts forever. Children and grandchildren of deceased son Irwin: Patti, Alan, David, Cathy, Ivan, Illon, Annie, Max and Leif

title: Woman Found Slain in Brooklyn Apartment
description: A 22-year-old woman was found fatally shot yesterday morning in her basement apartment in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Atop F.C.C., Still Trying To Be Nice
description: William E. Kennard may be the best-liked bad guy in Washington.

title: Apartheid's Satirist Now Eyes The U.S.
description: This is such a cute little town (its three cafes are the Darling, Dinky's and the Small Fry) that one is prompted to ask Pieter-Dirk Uys how he keeps his insanity.

title: Backing Inspectors, Clinton Urges 'Very Strong' U.N. Action on Iraq
description: President Clinton urged the United Nations today to take ''very strong and unambiguous action'' to force Iraq to comply with international weapons inspections, a day before the Security Council is to meet to consider its response to the Iraqi defiance.

title: Affirmative Action Rollback Exposes Inequity; Access Isn't Denied
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BONHAM, WILLIAM R.
description: BONHAM-William R. 1921-1987. You are still with me every day. I've never remarried and never will. You are still the only one for me. My love for you is everlasting as is the pain of knowing you are gone. Mo

title: G.O.P Leader Says Nominee Will Be Halted
description: Confident that he has the votes to scuttle Bill Lann Lee's appointment to the nation's top civil rights job, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee said today that the nomination was ''dead.''

title: Troubled Economy Stirs Fears in South Korea
description: Relaxing on a couch in the basement of the upscale department store he manages, Kwak Yang Seo sat back and mused that because of this country's long economic boom, he has never known anybody who lost a job.

title: The BBC Adds 24-Hour News in Britain
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation, seeking to position itself for the multimedia world of the 21st century, took a big step toward that goal today by starting a 24-hour news channel in Britain.

title: Rebuild CUNY, but Fairly
description: After a decade of budget cuts and hiring slowdowns, the City University of New York is running with a stripped-down faculty and with poorly paid adjuncts who stand at the very margins of academic life carrying more than half the teaching load.

title: Albert Baer, 92, Heart Research Supporter
description: Albert M. Baer, a cutlery manufacturer and a supporter of heart research, died on Oct. 26 at his home in Rapidan, Va. He was 92 and also kept a residence in lower Manhattan, a family home for five generations.

title: A campaign draws attention to the accountability factor in measuring visits to Web sites.
description: REMEMBER when commercials for Winston cigarettes proclaimed, ''It's what's up front that counts?'' Now the Audit Bureau of Circulations, in the first campaign in its 83-year history, is urging advertisers and agencies to demand what counts up front.

title: Newly Elected Opposition to Fight Zedillo's Budget
description: President Ernesto Zedillo could face the greatest political test of his presidency starting this week as opposition lawmakers, in control of Congress for the first time in recent history, try to challenge his economic policies by rewriting Mexico's 1998 budget.

title: Poor Workers Turning Down Employers' Health Benefits
description: More Americans than ever are being offered health insurance through their jobs. Even so, a Government study finds, more and more workers, especially those who earn low wages, are declining to take the benefit.

title: Netanyahu Will Visit U.S.; No Clinton Talks Scheduled
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will travel to the United States next week but, apparently in a sign of Washington's displeasure with the pace of peace negotiations, no meeting has yet been scheduled with President Clinton, Israeli and American officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAMAN, ELINOR MCNAMEE
description: LEAMAN-Elinor McNamee. On November 7, 1997. Beloved wife of Leonard S. Leaman. Devoted mother of Lauree Longobardi, Leonard S. Leaman, Jr, and John G. Leaman. Also survived by six grandchildren: Francis J. Longobardi III, Elinor A. Longobardi, Kathryn F. Longobardi, Matthew J. Leaman, Daniel N. Leaman and Sarah A. Leaman. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (at 20th St), NYC, Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Interment Tuesday at Sacred Heart Cemetery, Philmont, NY.

title: Nature and Nurture
description: To the Editor:

title: Prospero DeBona, 77, Ex-Casino Regulator
description: Prospero DeBona, a lawyer, member and past president of the Monmouth County Board of Taxation and one of the first members of the New Jersey Casino Control Commission, died on Oct. 22 at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J. He was 77 and lived in Red Bank.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Veterans Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDER, BARBARA STRAUS
description: EDER-Barbara Straus. Died November 8, 1997, after a long illness. Beloved wife of Howard Eder, M.D. Loving mother of Rebecca Eder and Peter Shile of St. Louis, MO, Susan Eder and Jonathan Flescher of Raleigh, NC, and Michael and Gundi Eder of Acton, MA. Dear grandmother of Sam, Max, Betsy, Daniel and Robert. She was a unique and vibrant woman; an early activist in the peace and civil rights movements. A graduate of Cornell and New York School of Social Work. She was a psychotherapist with a strong interest in psychoanalytic ideas and a talented artist. Service private. Memorial donations may be sent to Planned Parenthood Federation, 810 7th Ave., NY, NY 10019.

title: Foreign Banks Are Behind In Repairing 2000 Glitch
description: Big United States banks and investment firms, prodded by regulators, are making progress on a widespread software problem that could cause computers to crash seconds after midnight on Dec. 31, 1999. But many overseas banks in the increasingly interdependent global financial system may be woefully behind or even ignoring the problem.

title: Nebraska . . .Wait a Minute!
description: In Nebraska, the thrill of victory came on tape delay.

title: Trial of Au Pair Reveals Unease in U.S. Society
description: Anne Bernays, a Cambridge novelist and teacher, caught it early and bad. She would eat her lunch in front of the television, so as not to miss a moment of testimony. She would tell acquaintances about the trial that had hooked her, and the ''incredible pre-Raphaelite face'' of the defendant.
