What got her, she said, was ''the dark undertone, that secret fear in the back of every mother's head that the people she's left her kids with are going to hurt them.''

title: Leon Forrest, 60, a Novelist Who Explored Black History
description: Leon Forrest, a writer who explored black American history in his richly complex, epic novels, died on Thursday at Evanston Hospital in Evanston, Ill. He was 60 and lived in Evanston.

title: Cycles of Campaign Reform
description: Last week brought the end to another election season choking on campaign donations. Just as discouraging, many in Congress still think the public does not care about cleaning up the system. They are mistaking skepticism for lack of desire, and it is no wonder that Americans are skeptical about the chances for reform. Propagandists for the status quo are arguing that money will always overwhelm American politics, no matter what the law says. They also contend that there are insurmountable constitutional barriers to limiting the influence of money. But such conclusions are not only defeatist. They fly in the face of hard experience.

title: Foreign Affairs; With Allies Like These . . .
description: The most frightening thing about the latest flare-up over Iraq is not how Saddam Hussein is behaving, but how our allies are behaving. Saddam is evil. But France, Russia and the U.N. -- they're scary.

title: Updates/Media and Technology; Ziff-Davis Creates A Media Giant
description: Ziff-Davis announced a consolidation yesterday that incorporates two of the other major American companies of its Japanese owner, the Softbank Corporation, under the Ziff-Davis name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAIKEN, SALLY
description: LAIKEN-Sally. Wife of the late Samuel. Mother of Stuart, Robert, Nancy and Deborah. Grandmother of Scott, Lisabeth, Jennifer, Gregory and Jena. Life member of Hadassah and past President of its Corona Chapter. Passed away peacefully on November 9. Supported by the love of her family and friends. Services Monday, 1 PM, at Gutterman's Funeral Home (Parkside Building), 98-60 Queens Blvd., near 66th Avenue, Rego Park, Queens. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to the American Diabetes Association.

title: Foley Tightens His Grip on the Starting Job
description: The Jets have fight in them, and it comes from Coach Bill Parcells, who likes to bully, scrap and win at any cost. Their fighting mood actually began early last week, away from the field and on a chalkboard, when the coaching staff developed a new running play for Adrian Murrell called 35 tango.

title: Gene Therapy Gives Blood a Path Around Leg Blockages, Researchers Say
description: Gene therapy has prompted patients with hopelessly blocked blood vessels in their legs to grow their own bypasses, researchers said yesterday. Most patients in a small study saw a dramatic reversal of the predictably downhill course of that type of cardiovascular disease.

title: September Tool Orders Set High for Year So Far
description: Domestic orders for machine tools rose 13.4 percent in September from the month before as manufacturers purchased more tools than in any month this year, an industry survey said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERNIKOFF, ROBERT E., PH.D.
description: WERNIKOFF-Robert E., Ph.D. Of West Newton, MA, on November 5. Beloved husband of Denise (Piotrkowski). Devoted father of Anne Wernikoff of West Newton, MA. Loving son of Mina (Mil) Wernikoff of New Jersey and the late Leopoldo Wernikoff. Dear brother of Serge Wernikoff of New Jersey. Services at the M.I.T. Chapel, 48 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, MA on Wednesday, November 12, at 10:30 A.M. Remembrances may be made to the American Cancer Society, 30 Speen Street, Framingham, MA 01701 or a charity of your choice. For information the Levine Chapel, Brookline, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDERSON, PETER, JR.
description: HENDERSON-Peter, Jr. Died after a long illness on November 7. Survived by his wife Anne, and three children Aline, Vinton Bauer and Peter III, and one grandchild. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to St. Bernard's School Scholarship Fund, 4 East 98th St. NY, NY 10128.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKER, RITA
description: ZUCKER-Rita. On November 8, 1997. Beloved wife of Stanley. Loving mother of Judy and Stephen Gardner. Devoted sister of Jerome and Selma Gold and adored by grandson Drew. Her memory will be cherished by her family and friends. Services Tuesday, November 11, at 12:15 PM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave. Burial at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROLLE, RICHARD K.
description: ROLLE-Richard K. Of Red Bank, New Jersey on November 2, 1997. Husband of the late Loretta (nee Butcher) Rolle. Father of Richard C. Rolle. No visitation. Memorial service Saturday, November 22, 1997, 11:30 AM, at the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Avenue, Red Bank, NJ. Interment private. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the American Cancer Society, NJ Division, Inc., Monmouth Unit, 1540 Route 138, Suite 303, Wall, NJ 07719

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Metro Matters; A Drug Court Takes a Risk To Aid Addicts
description: TEN years ago, Eddie Santiago was doing pretty well for himself. As a plumber, he had so many jobs that he often worked six days a week. He owned a home in Queens and another one in Florida. He had a wife and two young children.

title: The New Pipeline Politics
description: In obvious disregard for American sanctions against Iran, the French oil company Total recently announced a $2 billion joint venture with Gazprom, Russia's gas conglomerate, and Malaysia's state oil company, Petronas, to develop Iran's gas reserves. At the same time, the Royal Dutch/ Shell Group, based in the Netherlands, is preparing to build a $2.5 billion gas pipeline from Turkmenistan to Turkey via Iran.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLMAN, THEODORE
description: HELLMAN-Theodore. Beloved husband of Jane. Devoted father of Marilyn and Paul Ptalis, and Lisa Hellman. Grandfather of Evan and Sarah. Brother of the late Adele Ussiker. Graveside service Monday, November 10, 11:00 AM, at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Affirmative Action Rollback Exposes Inequity; For Victims of Slavery
description: To the Editor:

title: Tree Taking River Trip To Rockefeller Center
description: The first time Barbara Rickard saw the slate-blue house that was for sale in Stony Point, N.Y., she told her husband that the tall Norway spruce in the yard had to go -- to Rockefeller Center, that is. It would be the perfect centerpiece for the carefully assembled urban forest where holiday shoppers ooh and ahh, she said. Or words to that effect.

title: 2,000 Years, What's the Big Deal?
description: QUESTIONING THE MILLENNIUM

title: Dartmouth Reveals Anti-Semitic Past
description: The president of Dartmouth College has confronted the anti-Semitism in its past, giving one of the most vivid illustrations ever of an attitude that was prevalent for years at elite private colleges and universities.

title: Knicks' Problem May Lie in Their Stars
description: The box that the Knicks came in this year did not say there was some assembly required. And yet it is somewhat alarming to see how far they are from having it all together as a team.

title: Temple Receipt for a 3-Shekel Donor
description: AFTER a close study of the Old Hebrew script, European and American scholars have determined that an inscription on a piece of ancient pottery is the oldest known reference, other than in the Bible, to King Solomon's temple in Jerusalem.

title: Kricker James, 58, Theater Founder
description: Kricker James, the producing director of the Chain Lightning Theater in Manhattan, died on Nov. 3 at his home in Manhattan. He was 58.

title: Patterns
description: Piers Pressure

title: No Charges for Youths In Birth of a Baby
description: The father of a healthy baby girl who turned her over to an ambulance driver, saying that he had found her, will not be charged with a crime, a prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Comptroller's Questions Block Police Lab Computer Contract
description: Concerned about the way the Police Department awards contracts, the City Comptroller's office has blocked the department's attempt to award a $900,000 project to a company that has still not delivered a $2.5 million computer software system that was due three years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, HELEN CHARLOTTE
description: KRAMER-Helen Charlotte. Beloved wife of the late Horace Z. Devoted mother of Linda, Jon and Peter. Dear sister of Norman Knittle. Mother-in-law of Murray Evans and Martha Kramer. Adoring grandmother of Lee Kramer, Hollie, Sara and Carrie Evans. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 10:30 A.M. today.

title: Above 43d St., Every Second Still Counts
description: ON Friday, as she does every week, Kim Ramos phoned the Treasury Department and the Census Bureau for a set of numbers, which she handed to Laszlo Szabo, who computer-crunched them into a new battery of figures, which became the latest readings of the ''national debt clock,'' which flashes on a nondescript building at West 43d Street and the Avenue of the Americas, aka Sixth Avenue.

title: Robinson Helps Spurs Come Back
description: SPURS 100, RAPTORS 98

title: By Design; Anything Goes, Even Pretty
description: Now that the shows of the spring collections have ended, it's clear that there is no one way to dress after winter coats are shed. As in recent seasons, hemlines are wherever you want them to be, even on pants, with walking shorts and capris vying with full-length trousers. Clothes are either snugly wrapped around the body or soft and billowing.

title: November Darkness, November Light
description: The last of the World War I veterans are almost impossibly old by now, as old as the century. They flicker past in footage from that war shown repeatedly on late-night television, young men burdened by the weight of arms, with everything that implies. Now nearly all those men are dead, and the few still living seem to symbolize the enormous changes that have swept across the world in the years since the Armistice was signed on this day 79 years ago.

title: In Beijing, Yeltsin Finds Jiang Speaks His Language
description: Boris N. Yeltsin gave Jiang Zemin a bear hug when they met on the steps of the Great Hall of the People in Beijing today, apparently eager to show the world that all is well between Russia and China. Mr. Jiang returned the embrace.

title: Disney and Katzenberg Reach Pact on Lawsuit
description: The Walt Disney Company and its former studio chief, Jeffrey Katzenberg, announced an unexpected settlement today that avoids a legal battle in court but leaves open the amount Mr. Katzenberg will receive to further negotiations.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about monitoring of Iraq's military arsenal misstated the date of the downing of an American U-2 surveillance plane over the Soviet Union. It was 1960, not 1957.

title: Trump Grade School?
description: To the Editor:

title: Opera Musicians Can Share the Stage
description: When James Levine began bringing the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra to Carnegie Hall for concerts, the idea was to give these superb musicians a chance to take on the weighty repertory they never get to play: Stravinsky ballet scores, Mahler symphonies.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Tuesday about students who participated in a mock trial in Queens Criminal Court misidentified the school attended by several. While two of the students, Tiffany Tillman and Cassandra Luxama, go to Springfield Gardens High School, three others -- Guylene Destin, Cheri Davidson and Danill Wallace -- attend Mary Louis Academy in Jamaica.

title: Metro Business; Allstate Is Creating A New Jersey Unit
description: Allstate Inc. said yesterday that it would invest $463 million in a new subsidiary dedicated to insuring homes and autos in New Jersey, a state that the company was poised to exit six years ago.

title: Hilton Decides Not to Revise Offer for ITT
description: In a move that surprised and disappointed many on Wall Street, the Hilton Hotel Corporation said yesterday that it would not raise its cash-and-stock offer of $80 a share to acquire the ITT Corporation, a prize it has sought for nearly 10 months.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ETHER, CURTIS
description: ETHER-Curtis. A memorial service for Curtis Ether will be held Saturday, November 15, 2 P.M., at St. George's Church, 16 St. and Stuyvesant Square, NYC. All family and friends are invited.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNEVINS, ALFRED C.B., JR.
description: McNEVINS-Alfred C.B., Jr., Age 75. Former life insurance executive in New York City. Surivived by two sons, A.C. Barnes and James F. McNevin. Two daughters, Katharine K. McNevin and Nora McNevin Brenneis. Also two sisters and seven grandchildren. Funeral liturgy at St. Lawrence Church in Killingworth, CT., on Monday at 11 A.M. For further information, contact Swan Funeral Home, Clinton, CT.

title: Tijuana Drug Arrest Tests U.S.-Mexican Cooperation
description: In a case likely to test Mexico's willingness to extradite powerful drug traffickers to face American justice, United States officials said yesterday that they would seek to prosecute a suspected Mexican cocaine smuggler who was arrested in Tijuana over the weekend.

title: Pollution Flow In U.S.-Canada Called Mutual
description: Air pollution from factories and power plants in Canada and the United States flows both ways across the border and will get worse unless abatement efforts reflect the international nature of the problem, according to a report to be issued on Tuesday.

title: Accounts
description: * Wallcovering Council of America, New York, to Pagano, Schenck & Kay, Boston, as the first agency to handle advertising for the association. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: Republicans Abandon Plan To Take Survey About I.R.S.
description: Republican leaders in Congress today dropped their plan to survey taxpayers next year about the performance of the Internal Revenue Service, bowing to opposition from Democrats who called it a partisan ploy and a waste of money.

title: Lights in Statehouse Recall Kristallnacht
description: The lights were left on at the Statehouse last night in commemoration of Kristallnacht, the ''Night of Broken Glass'' in 1938 when Nazis smashed Jewish businesses, burned synagogues and killed hundreds of people in Germany, Austria and Czechoslovakia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AFFATATO, TESSIE (NEE PACELLI)
description: AFFATATO-Tessie (nee Pacelli). On Nov. 9, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Frank J. Devoted mother of Rosemarie Wenick. Cherished grandmother of Jennifer Wenick. Also survived by her sister Vivian Basile. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th Street), NYC, on Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Chapel service and burial Thursday 11AM, at George Washington Memorial Park. Donations in her memory may be made to Spence Chapin Holiday Angels Program, 6 East 94 Street, NYC 10128-0698.

title: Prized Picasso Leads the Ganz Collection to a Record Auction of $206 Million
description: The art collection of Victor and Sally Ganz, a low-key Manhattan couple who spent 50 years and about $2 million buying the work of artists like Picasso and Jasper Johns, sold at Christie's last night for a record $206.5 million.

title: For U.S., Free Trade Is Self-Interest; Commerce Brings Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDLEY, SANDEE
description: LEDLEY-Sandee. From lung cancer on November 10. Loving wife of James. Devoted mother of Austin, Charles, Richard, Harry and Elliot, daughter, daughter-inlaw, sister, aunt and friend. The Riverside, Mount Vernon, Noon, Wednesday, November 12. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Columbia Presbyterian Hospital for lung cancer research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMSON, MAE (NEE KUPERMAN)
description: WILLIAMSON-Mae (nee Kuperman), wife of the late John Williamson, Saturday, November 8, in England. She was 91-yearsold. Beloved mother of Bob, Neil, and their wives Robyn and Jenny. Devoted grandmother of Cathy, Paul, Anne, Nicholas, Benjamin, Daniel, Samuel, Joshua, Yvonne and Paul. Adored aunt of 29 nieces and nephews and their children.

title: DMZ Duty: Dangerous but Highly Prized by U.S. Soldiers
description: CAMP BONIFAS, South Korea  You are an American soldier and have a choice between two overseas tours. One is at a U.S. base in Western Europe. Your family accompanies you, you rent a house in a neighborhood near the base and you enjoy the delights of Europe on the weekends. After the collapse of the Soviet Union, the likelihood of conflict is minimal.

title: Georgia-Pacific Gets Stock Plan Approval
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved the Georgia-Pacific Corporation's application to create a separate class of stock for its timber business, according to a company announcement Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HARRIS, SYLVIA
description: HARRIS-Sylvia. May 15th, 1906November 11th, 1966. Greatest, most dedicated, loving wife of Joseph and mother of J. Robert and James B. Very loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Jim and I so very dearly love you and miss you very much. God bless you forever, Mom. All our love, your very loving sons, Bob and Jim.

title: Giants' Defense Feels Injury Sting
description: It is the loss within the loss that may brand Sunday's 10-6 defeat by the Tennessee Oilers a pivotal setback in a promising Giants season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKENNA, VINCENT H.
description: McKENNA-Vincent H. 84. Of Riverside, CT., died on Saturday, November 8, 1997, at Greenwich Hospital. Beloved husband of Margaret Shea McKenna; father of Deborah Schurman and Brian V. S. McKenna. Also survived by two grandchildren, Shea and Katherine Schurman. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Wednesday, November 12, 10 AM, at St. Mary R.C. Church, Greenwich, CT. Interment will follow at Putnam Cemetery. Friends may call on Tuesday from 4-8 PM at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Disease Association, P.O. Box 3556, Stamford, CT. 06905.

title: Consumer Groups Sue to Block Partial State Takeover of Lilco
description: Consumer groups opposed to the $7.3 billion partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company sued today to block it, arguing that the state had shirked its obligation to conduct an environmental review of the deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPLACK, RABBI KENNETH DAVID
description: POPLACK-Rabbi Kenneth David. On November 9, 1997. Survived by loving family and a multitude of friends and respected colleagues. Funeral services were held yesterday at ''Gutterman's,'' Woodbury, L.I. Shiva is being observed at the family residence, 52 Sullivan Drive, West Orange, New Jersey.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBERG, BETTY
description: WEISBERG-Betty. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Lucile Weiss. Grandmother of Barbara Weiss, Richard and Robyn Weiss and Lee and Michael Friedland and great grandmother of Jennifer and David and Steven and Lauren. Services private.

title: Hingis Expects Success Next Week
description: Martina Hingis, the No.1 ranked women's player, is approaching the Chase Championships next week with a symmetrical ideal in mind.

title: On Williams, Yankees Keeping Options Open
description: George Steinbrenner whispered as he discussed the stagnant negotiations between the Yankees and Bernie Williams. Joe Torre spoke about the possibility of not having Williams in center field for 1998. Bob Watson insisted that he felt no pressure to trade Williams, but admitted he would have dealt him yesterday if a package had been appealing.

title: Nets Owe Quick Start To That 9-Player Deal
description: Allan Houston was asked last week whether the unexpected success of the Nets motivated the Knicks to register consecutive 30-point blowouts over Boston and Phoenix. The question was asked facetiously, which made Houston smile.

title: INSIDE
description: Disney Settles Lawsuit

title: Undiscovered Bach? No, a Computer Wrote It
description: IN a low-key, musical version of the match between Garry Kasparov and the chess-playing machine called Deep Blue, a musician at the University of Oregon competed last month with a computer to compose music in the style of Johann Sebastian Bach. Steve Larson, who teaches music theory at the university, listened anxiously while his wife, the pianist Winifred Kerner, performed three entries in the contest -- one by Bach, one by Dr. Larson and one by a computer program called EMI, or Experiments in Musical Intelligence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MINNIE MALLOV
description: STONE-Minnie Mallov, 94. Died November 7, 1997. Survived by daughter Elaine, of New York, son Richard (Anita), of Athens, Greece. Three grandchildren, four great-grandchildren. Active in many philanthropic causes. She will be remembered as a loving, gentle friend to all. Services Wednesday, Nov. 12, 12:30, the ''Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABBOTT, SUSAN
description: ABBOTT-Susan, 74. November 7, 1997. Holocaust survivor from Vienna, Austria. She sailed into New York Harbor in 1940 and has lived in the city ever since. Artist and peace and justice activist. She will be missed for her extraordinary inspiration, creativity, hospitality and generosity. Beloved mother of Peter, Thomas and Michael; and grandmother of Andrea, Rebecca, Gabriel and Nathaniel. Services at 2 P.M., on Tuesday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Biofeedback Offers Help To Hyperactive Children
description: IN May 1987 Mary Obringer and her husband adopted a 5-month-old South Korean infant. But there were problems with the baby they named Max. ''He had speech disabilities, motor skill problems, was hyperactive and had trouble concentrating,'' Ms. Obringer said. He could not be in a large group of people without hitting, kicking and screaming.

title: COKE TO BUY BOTTLING ASSETS OF KOREAN CONCERN
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it would acquire the soft drink bottling assets of the Doosan Beverage Company for $450 million, giving it control over bottling, distribution and sales of Coca-Cola products in South Korea. The move follows Coca-Cola's acquisition of its other Korean bottlers -- the Honam Foods Company and the Woosung Food Company -- earlier this year. Coca-Cola has about 59 percent of Korea's $1 billion soft drink market, according to the industry publication Beverage Digest. Pepsico Inc. has 12.3 percent.

title: Nestle to Buy Rest Of San Pellegrino Water
description: Nestle S.A. of Switzerland, the world's largest food maker, said yesterday that it would buy the 51 percent stake that it did not already own in San Pellegrino, an Italian mineral water company. The stake is now held by the Mentasti family. Nestle did not disclose the price in announcing that its Perrier Vittel mineral water unit would buy the unit.

title: In Books, It's Boom Time for Spirits; Angels, Conversations With God, Even Fairies and Elves Sell Well
description: The hot line to heaven is open for sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTER, MILTON
description: WINTER-Milton. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Devoted father of Michael and Lloyd. Adored grandfather of Barbara, Steven, Marc and Hallie. Great-grandfather of Nicole and Alexandra. Services at ''Boulevard Riverside Chapel,'' 312 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn (at Prospect Park), Tuesday, 9:30 a.m.

title: Stocks Stage a Retreat, With the Dow Falling by 28.73
description: Most stock indexes fell yesterday, as continued concerns about slower growth in international markets, particularly Southeast Asia, erased early gains.

title: Sports of The Times; On Day After, Jets Really Move Fast
description: THERE is good news for Jets fans. From firsthand observation, I can report that the Jets were once again moving like a mighty juggernaut yesterday, although none of this would immediately be reflected in the standing.

title: 21-Year-Old Russian Outwits Kasparov in First Encounter
description: What started as an easy trip to victory for Garry Kasparov in the Fontys International Tournament in Tilburg, the Netherlands, became tough, and he had to share first place with his Russian compatriots Peter Svidler and Vladimir Kramnik.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESLEY, GOLDIE H.
description: WESLEY-Goldie H., 78. Died November 9, 1997 in Newport Beach, CA. Goldie, cherished mother of George (Bud) Wesley, beloved grandmother of Sarah and Abigail, and beloved sister of Philip Heller and Alfred Heller, was married for 44 years to Jack W. Wesley, who passed away in 1988. Daughter-inlaw Ana Chu, and sisters-in-law Muriel Goldsmith and Edith, Anne, and Lillian Heller also survive and lovingly remember Goldie. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hadassah-Orange Co., 666 Baker Street, Costa Mesa, CA. Graveside services 11 A.M., Wed, Nov. 12, Mt. Nebo Cemetery, 82-07 Cypress Hills St., Glendale, NY.

title: FIGGIE REVISES ITS AGREEMENT TO SELL SNORKEL
description: Figgie International Inc. revised its agreement to sell its Snorkel aerial platform unit to Omniquip International Inc. yesterday in a way that might lower the original $150 million price by as much as a third. Under the revised terms, Omniquip, which is based in Port Washington, Wis., would pay $100 million in cash plus up to another $50 million depending on Snorkel's sales between April 1, 1998, and March 31, 1999. Omniquip would also assume some debt. Omniquip had tried to back out of the purchase after learning that third-quarter sales at the unit were lower than expected. Figgie said it now valued the transaction at $120 million. Omniquip's shares rose $1.75, to $18.8125, in Nasdaq trading, where Figgie's shares slipped 6.25 cents, to $12.3125.

title: Iraqi Assails U.S. at the U.N. And Says Albright Is a Liar
description: Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, sharply attacked the United States today as he pressed his country's case at the United Nations, calling Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright a liar. But Iraq failed to make good on its threat to shoot down American U-2 surveillance flights over Iraq as the flights resumed today.

title: On My Mind; Jews Against Jews
description: The Prime Minister of Israel was ticking off the problems most important to the country at the moment. He listed the negotiations with the Palestinians as second.

title: Aborigines' Lands
description: To the Editor:

title: Gene Therapy Company Is Set
description: A new company has been formed to pursue a gene therapy that could form new blood vessels and heal ulcers in patients with blocked arteries.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BARBARA BARRIE, the film and television actress, has broken through one of the last taboos in public discussion of cancer: the colostomy.

title: For U.S., Free Trade Is Self-Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: Pastor Pleads Guilty To Drug Possession
description: The pastor of an Episcopal church in Brooklyn, who the police said was smoking a crack pipe while typing a Sunday sermon when he was arrested in his rectory, pleaded guilty yesterday to a drug possession charge.

title: Warsaw Journal; Old Cold War Enemies Exhume One Battlefield
description: For four years he was one of the most wanted underground dissidents in Communist Poland, branded a counterrevolutionary by the Government and always on the run, eluding the police with a different guise every month.

title: Veterans Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Suharto Kin Lose a Fight on Bank Closings
description: Indonesia's Finance Minister held the line today on the forced closing of three ailing banks partly owned by relatives of President Suharto, sending a strong signal that the Government is serious about making painful economic reforms.

title: AT HOME WITH: Barbra Streisand; Love Soft as an Easy Chair (Cue the Violins)
description: Barbra Streisand's in love. And she's wearing a white-diamond engagement ring on her elegantly manicured right hand. And she's waxing every bit as ecstatic as the lyrics to one of her hit songs.

title: Journal; Marv Spins ABC
description: It was 21 years ago that Howard Beale, a silver-haired anchorman of the Cronkite-Brinkley school, decided to protest his network's tabloidization of the news by performing the ultimate ratings stunt: He threatened to blow his brains out on the air.

title: A Cigar by Any Other Name Isn't Cuban
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Media Company Arrives
description: With the assistance of two venture capital firms and the New York City Investment Fund, Star Media Network, an on-line media company that offers electronic mail, classified advertisements and other services to Internet users in Latin America, relocated its offices last week from Greenwich, Conn., to New York City, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAYERS, LILLIAN
description: SAYERS-Lillian. Beloved wife of Theodore, loving mother of Barbara and Mark, cherished grandmother of Lauren & Nichole Braun, surviving sister May Green, of Los Angeles. Lillian Sayers was a pioneer in the Internet apparel industry and held over ten patents. She was the Chief Designer for Exquisite Form Industries, Bali Bras, and Lillyette. Mrs. Sayers worked for the Community AIDS Society and The 62nd Street Association. Lillian was a unique and vibrant woman and will be missed for her extraordinary inspiration, creativity, hospitality and generosity to her family and friends. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, Nov. 13 at 12:00 Temple Emanuel, 65th Street and Fifth Avenue in the Beth El Chapel. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Lung Cancer Research Fund at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ESTHER QUITT
description: LEVINE-Esther Quitt. A Memorial Service will be held on Sunday Nov. 16, 1997, at 1 P.M. The Pleasantville Community Synagogue, 219 Bedford Road, Pleasantville, NY. Call the answering machine at 914-769-2672 for directions. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Esther Quitt Levine Scholarship Fund at the School of American Ballet, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, N.Y. 10023, or The Parents, Families, and Friends of Lesbians & Gays, 1101 14th Street N.W., Washington, D.C. 20005, would be greatly appreciated.

title: Marv Albert Marches Deeper Into the Mud
description: It is almost impossible to watch the Marv Albert post-guilty plea media tour without wishing he would pipe down, right now, before tonight's whistle-stop with Larry King on CNN, tomorrow's with David Letterman on CBS, and Thursday's with Katie Couric on NBC's ''The Today Show.'' Marv, just say no more.

title: Apple to Offer Custom Orders Over the Internet
description: Falling significantly short of announcing any of the jolting deals that had been rumored for weeks, Steven P. Jobs spoke today at a college auditorium packed with more than 2,000 Apple Computer employees, journalists and analysts, and said the struggling computer maker would begin selling by way of the Internet and building computers to order in its factories.

title: Mars Map Will Come A Year Late
description: AFTER a month's delay because of problems with a solar-power panel, Mars Global Surveyor has resumed maneuvers to descend to a mapping orbit of the planet, but ever so deliberately. The spacecraft is thus not expected to be in position for its primary mapping operations until March 1999, a year later than originally planned.

title: To People the World, Start With 500
description: AS few as 500 or so people, trekking out of Africa 140,000 years ago, may have populated the rest of the globe. These estimates are derived from a novel kind of archeology, one that depends not on pick and shovel but on delving into the capacious archive of the human genome.

title: After a Delay, Text Gets Out On Internet
description: It was to be a triumph for the Internet, the legitimization of the medium as the fastest, most democratic means of distributing data in high demand.

title: Samuel Gurin, 92, Medical School Dean
description: Dr. Samuel Gurin, a biochemist who was the only dean of the School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania who did not hold a medical degree, died on Oct. 22 at the Pine Run Village retirement home in Doylestown, Pa. He was 92.

title: German Bid Reported For Hambros of Britain
description: The shares of Hambros P.L.C. rose yesterday after The Daily Telegraph reported that Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale had made an offer for the London-based investment bank. Shares of Hambros rose 4.5 pence, to 255 pence ($4.24), on the London Stock Exchange. A spokesman for Hambros had no comment on the report. A spokesman for Westdeutsche Landesbank in Germany could not be reached.

title: Coffee Prices Surge as Storm Threatens Mexican Harvest
description: Prices for coffee rose to three-week highs yesterday as torrential rain and gusting winds from Hurricane Rick lashed Mexico's main coffee growing regions.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Oct. 7 about the effect of grapefruit juice on the body's absorption of certain drugs misspelled the surname of a researcher on the subject. He is Dr. Paul Pisarek, not Pizarek. A telephone caller reported the error last week.

title: Shady Fairy Tale Characters
description: It is likely that Pascal Rioult chanted out the fables of Jean de La Fontaine as a French schoolboy. But the darker, slyer side of those famous 17th-century cautionary tales was fully realized in Mr. Rioult's new ''Fables,'' performed by the Pascal Rioult Dance Theater on Saturday night at Florence Gould Hall.

title: Excerpts From Kaczynski Diaries
description: Following are three excerpts from diaries that prosecutors say were found in Theodore J. Kacznyski's mountain cabin. The first entry, dated Dec. 27, 1995, described the bombing death of Hugh Scrutton on Dec. 11, 1995. The second, dated Dec. 29, 1979, was made after a fire on an American Airlines flight from Chicago to Washington. The third, dated Feb. 22, 1982, was made after a bomb was defused at the University of Utah Business School in October 1981.

title: Clinton Backs Expanding Definition of a Hate Crime
description: Uncertain of the scope of the problem or how best to address it, President Clinton convened a White House Conference on Hate Crimes here today, saying that such acts ''strike at the heart of what it means to be an American.''

title: Osborne Scott, 81, Professor Known For Ethnic Studies
description: The Rev. Osborne E. Scott, one of the first black chaplains in the Army, who later created some of the earliest college courses in urban and ethnic studies, died on Nov. 2 at Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 81 and a Mount Vernon, N.Y., resident for the last 45 years.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: New Dig at a 9,000-Year-Old City Is Changing Views on Ancient Life
description: THE mound swells 65 feet above the vast, dusty Konya Plain, an unremarkable bump to a motorist passing through this remote stretch of wheat and sugar beet fields 150 miles south of Ankara. But astonishing remnants of ancient life have been dug from this grassy mound, the signs of a 9,000-year-old settlement called Catalhoyuk, perhaps the largest settlement of the Neolithic age.

title: Observer; Top This, George
description: The most ludicrous news story of the month was the firing of the Baltimore Orioles manager Davey Johnson on the day he was voted baseball's ''manager of the year.''

title: Party, Spurned, Repays Clinton With Rebellion
description: Since he first announced for the Presidency in 1991, Bill Clinton has almost always kept the Democratic Party at arm's length, saying that his ambition was to rise above the ''brain-dead politics'' of both parties. To prove his independence from his party, Mr. Clinton stiff-armed Democrats on welfare, crime and the balanced budget.

title: Executive Shake-Up at Medical Concern
description: The shares of Medical Resources Inc. fell 26 percent today after the company removed the chief financial officer and accepted resignations from two other top managers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON CLEMM, MICHAEL
description: von CLEMM-Michael. The Officers, Directors and staff of the ESU of the United States wish to extend their deepest sympathy to the family of Michael von Clemm, Vice Chairman and past President. It was through his perseverance that we face the realities of modern day not-for-profit governance and we are grateful for his vision and leadership.

title: Man, 20, Is Found Guilty In 3 Harlem Killings
description: The second of two men charged with killing a mother and two of her children in their Harlem apartment two years ago was found guilty of murder yesterday.

title: Review/Fashion; Bringing Women In From the Cold
description: As a new coterie of designers has moved to the forefront in the last few years, critics both inside and outside fashion have taken issue with the lack of designer clothes appropriate for a mature woman's body.

title: Clinton Adviser Agrees to Settle Conflict Charge Over Stocks
description: President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, agreed tonight to pay $23,043 to settle conflict-of-interest charges arising from his failure to sell oil company stocks.

title: Enter Smiling but Elusive, as Always
description: ''Just because you know some details about a person's life doesn't mean you know the person.'' That's Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis speaking, or at least the simulacrum of her that is now addressing Broadway audiences in Gip Hoppe's sketchbook of a show, ''Jackie: An American Life,'' which opened last night at the Belasco Theater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTSTEIN, HILDA
description: GUTSTEIN-Hilda, 90. Died peacefully Nov. 9. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of Leila Passoff, Emanuel Stonewood, Helen Chusid, Edye and Harold Davis, Leo and Joyce Gutstein. Loving grandmother of Dave, Jan, Michael, Candee and Mark, Alan, Robert and Marie, Scott & Alayne, Shari & Bruce, Lynn and Allison and 7 great grandchildren. Adored sister of Ruth Hiller and Kate Ring. She will be missed.

title: Nissan's Profits Jump as Exports Offset Slump in Japan
description: The Nissan Motor Company said today that pretax profit rose 47 percent in the fiscal first half as cost reductions and higher exports offset a slump in Japanese sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAISER, ETTA
description: KAISER-Etta, 88. Of Hallandale, FL., formerly of New York City, November 8, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Emil, most loving mother of Diane Kaiser Berger and Dr. Melvyn S. Berger, cherished grandmother of Elisabeth, beloved aunt and friend of many. In our hearts forever. Service Tuesday, I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, at 11:30 A.M.

title: Blacks' Story of Harassment Is the Backdrop for New Fines
description: William and Gloria Smith finally found a place they wanted to live in 1993, on two acres of land in Belle, W.Va., just south of Charleston. Two years later, they put up a home.

title: Q&A
description: Dancing Angels

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, AARON H.
description: GREENBERG-Aaron H. Beloved husband of the late Alice, devoted father of Barry and Susan Greenberg, Gail and Jeff Elkins and Susan and Scott Schildhaus. Cherished grandfather of Seth, Zachary, Carly, Sam and Jordan. We love you all there is and then some more. Graveside services today, 11 AM, at New Montefiore Cemetery, 516-295-3100.

title: 'A Tribute To Boston' On Sunday
description: Even though the United States has qualified for the World Cup finals, Coach Steve Sampson will field practically the same lineup that beat Canada, 3-0, on Sunday when the United States plays El Salvador at Foxboro Stadium next Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONT, JEFFREY B.
description: MONT-Jeffrey B. On November 9, after a long and courageous battle against AIDS. Through it all, Jeff never gave up or lost his spirit. To the very end, he was alert and grateful for the friends in his life. We remember Jeff for his work on Broadway and love of the theatre and his devotion to exploration of every corner of the globe, often on rollerblades. We will miss his wit, his intellect, his intense curiosity and most of all, his devotion to his friends. Jeff wanted no special memorial service and none is planned. Donations in his name can be made to the Gay Men's Health Crisis, Attention: The Development Department, 119 West 24th Street, New York City 10011.

title: TBWA to Close St. Louis Office
description: TBWA Chiat/Day said yesterday that it would close its St. Louis office, opened in 1983, by the end of the year.

title: Rangers Search for Revitalized Kovalev and Power Play
description: Ranger Coach Colin Campbell leaned on a hockey stick today as he spoke in the team's dressing room. Considering the lack of support Campbell has received from a slumping Aleksei Kovalev and a lethargic power play, it's a wonder his stick didn't break.

title: In a Startling Turnabout, Judge Sets Au Pair Free
description: After 279 days in an American prison, the British au pair Louise Woodward walked free today.

title: Deeper Partisanship Bedevils Nominees
description: Senate confirmation of President Clinton's nominees for surgeon general and assistant attorney general for civil rights seemed a foregone conclusion. Then they reached the Senate floor, where it now seems that both nominations will die, victims of a new aggressiveness by Republicans toward Clinton nominees. By many accounts, this is a legacy of the failed Supreme Court nomination of Robert H. Bork in the 1980's.

title: Swedish Match Holds Big Lead
description: On the third day of the second leg of the Whitbread Round the World Race, Swedish Match continued to dominate the fleet of nine yachts that left Cape Town for Fremantle, Australia.

title: Big changes are afoot in the multimillion-dollar blue-chip accounts of Nike, I.B.M. and Ford.
description: NIKE, I.B.M. and Ford are joining a lengthening list of advertisers taking a second look at plans for big blue-chip accounts.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, DOROTHY
description: GOODMAN - Dorothy. Temple B'nai Sholom mourns the loss of our long-time member. We extend condolences to the family. Services were held Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, Sunday, Nov. 9th. Dr. Martin Greenberg, President Dr. Barry Dov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: CLINTON RETREATS ON TRADE POWER; PROSPECTS SLIGHT
description: President Clinton conceded today that the trade legislation he had called crucial to the nation's global leadership was dead for this year, and the Republican leader of the Senate said that the measure's chances of being passed are even more remote for next year, when Congress is up for re-election.

title: Metro Business; Dissolve Fund, Suit Asks
description: SB Partners, a real estate limited partnership started by Smith Barney in 1970, faces a lawsuit to dissolve the money-losing fund.

title: Au Pair's Hometown Celebrates Release
description: To many Britons, there has never been any doubt that Louise Woodward, the 19-year-old au pair convicted of killing the baby she had been hired to care for, is innocent.

title: Sex Offender Drops Suit Against Neighbors
description: John Becerra, a convicted sex offender whose presence here sparked shock and anger, has agreed to drop a $10 million lawsuit against two of his neighbors. In return, they have agreed to stop staging protest rallies in front of his house, lawyers for both sides said.

title: Miriam Phillips, 98, Stage and Film Actress
description: Miriam Phillips, an actress on Broadway and in regional theaters for more than four decades, died on Oct. 24 at the Actors' Home in Englewood, N.J. She was 98.

title: 'Fast Track' Is Derailed
description: President Clinton has been dealt a vengeful rebuke by Democrats over free trade. Mr. Clinton sounded the right note yesterday when he vowed to fight again next year for legislation granting trade negotiating authority to the President. But it will be an even harder fight as the President suddenly finds himself struggling to overcome the image of a lame duck in Washington. Another aspect of the defeat was that the philosophical arguments over trade and other matters may now be overwhelmed by the politics of the 2000 Presidential race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INGERSOLL, MARGARET CUSTIS
description: INGERSOLL-Margaret Custis. On November 8, 1997. Born August 1, 1903 in Onancock, VA. Resident of NYC for 52 years. Fabric Editor, Vogue Magazine, 1952-1972 and member, Fashion Group International and Fashion Inner Circle. Survived by nieces, Mary Custis Hart (VT), Jane R. Buck (MS), Margaret Custis Green (TX), nephews, Robert Custis Coleburn (VA) and James Douglas Coleburn (VA). Services Wednesday, November 12, 2 PM, at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at 53rd Street, NYC. Donations to St. Thomas Episcopal Church for the Ingersoll Endowment Fund benefiting the Choir School.

title: TEXTRON TO BUY A BRITISH GOLF AND LAWN CARE BUSINESS
description: Textron Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Ransomes P.L.C. for $:137.1 million ($231.7 million) in cash, to expand its golf and lawn care business. Textron said it would also assume about $60 million of the Ransomes debt. The purchase will complement Textron's E-Z-GO golf carts and Jacobsen mowing and lawn care equipment businesses. Ransomes makes turf-care machinery for golf, municipal and commercial markets under brand names that include Ransomes, Cushman, Ryan, Steiner and Brouwer. It has about 1,400 employees and eight plants in Britain, the United States and France. Textron, based in Providence, R.I., also makes Cessna business jets, Bell helicopters, auto-seat adjustment systems and trim components.

title: Market Place; Some analysts think Kodak won't cut deep enough today.
description: THIS morning, dozens of analysts will gather at the Hudson Theater in Manhattan to hear Eastman Kodak's chief executive, George M. C. Fisher, disclose a long-awaited plan for whipping his troubled company into shape. But already, some analysts are speculating that his measures will not go as far as they would like.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, DOROTHY
description: GREENFIELD-Dorothy. On November 9, 1997. Age 95. (Former co-owner B. Greenfield Auto Supply of NYC). Beloved Wife of the late Benjamin, Loving Mother of Herbert Greenfield and the late Maxine Church. Cherished GrandMother and Great-Grandmother. Services on Tuesday at 3 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Officials Uphold Vote To Keep Ward System
description: Essex County officials yesterday upheld voters' decision last Tuesday to keep their ward-based form of government rather than switch to a board of commissioners elected at large.

title: TENNIS: Father Knew Best; Sisters Thrive Under Family Tutelage, Not Conventional Training
description: This was a sister act that always came with a parental warning label attached. But not everybody believed Richard Williams seven years ago when he predicted that his gangly daughter, Venus, then 10 years old, was going to be No. 1 in the world and that his youngest daughter Serena, then 9, would turn out even better than Venus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAINE, STEPHEN D.
description: PAINE-Stephen D. The Board of Trustees and staff at the Whitney Museum of American Art note with great sadness the passing of our beloved patron and founding member of the Museum's Drawing Acquisition Committee, Stephen D. Paine. He will be warmly remembered for his steadfast support of American artists and his dedication to furthering the study and appreciation of American Art. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Susan. Flora M. Biddle, Hon. Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Gilbert C. Maurer, President David A. Ross, Director

title: In Latest Confirmation Delays, a Tougher G.O.P. Strategy
description: The Senate confirmation hearing of Dr. David Satcher for surgeon general early last month was so tame that it drew virtually no press coverage. Two weeks later, the hearing of Bill Lann Lee for the nation's top civil rights job was so tranquil that Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Vermont Democrat, told him, ''There won't be so many good things said about you again until your funeral.''

title: Power Lunch Is 2 in a Row, Just New York Minutes Each
description: In the hushed forest-green of the dining room at Le Bernardin in Manhattan, people are racing against the clock. On any weekday, at least five or six of the 35 tables are having the ''Timely Lunch,'' a menu introduced in May that promises four stars in 30 minutes or less.

title: Penders Will Watch Opener at Home
description: When the season opens tonight in East Rutherford, N.J., Coach Tom Penders's Texas team will play Princeton, while Penders will watch on television from his home in Austin, Tex.

title: Catholic Grass Roots
description: To the Editor:

title: British Giant Cashes In, All Set to Shop Anew
description: Having agreed to sell its stake in MCI Communications for a quick profit of $2.25 billion, British Telecommunications may already be on the prowl for a new American partner.

title: Browning Sets $1.45 Billion Sale Overseas
description: Browning-Ferris Industries agreed today to sell its overseas operations to a subsidiary of Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux in a cash-and-stock deal valued at $1.45 billion.

title: AMR Increases Purchase of Jets
description: The AMR Corporation's American Airlines unit has ordered four more Boeing 767 long-range aircraft worth $380 million, adding to a 103-plane purchase announced last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, WILLIAM THOMPSON
description: BAKER-William Thompson. Holland Lodge #

title: Deep Underwater, the Breath of Life
description: A RIDDLE of the sea is how air-breathing animals manage to dive so far beneath the waves and stay down for so long. Such acts are obviously no problem for fish, which have gills. But people diving without the aid of special gear can stay under for no more than minutes and go down no more than a few hundred feet before facing blackout and eventual death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLEN, REV. FRANCIS W.
description: GILLEN-Rev. Francis W. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the parochial vicar of Our Lady of Guadalupe Church, 7201 15th Ave., Brooklyn, November 9. Reposing in Our Lady of Guadalupe Chapel, Tuesday, Nov. 11, 2-5 and 7-9:30 P.M. and Wednesday, November 12, 2-5 P.M. Mass of Transferral Wednesday, Nov. 12 at 7:30pm. in Our Lady of Guadalupe Church. Funeral Mass Thursday, November 13 at 10:30 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKS, LILLIAN ROGERS
description: PARKS-Lillian Rogers. On Thursday, November 6, 1997, in Washington, DC. Beloved godmother of Peggy B. Holly. Also surviving are her cousin Lillian Byrd, dear friends Louise Carrera, Cornelia Stokes and Inez Dade, and a host of other friends. On Wednesday, November 12, from 10 AM until service at 11 AM, friends may call at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 1514 15th Street NW, Washington, DC. Interment Lincoln Memorial Cemetery in Suitland, Maryland. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to St. Luke's Church Candle Guild.

title: Effects of Adoption
description: To the Editor:

title: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES TO BUY 3 FLORIDA CAR DEALERSHIPS
description: Republic Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire three Florida automotive dealerships for $58 million in stock. Republic Industries will acquire two Abraham Chevrolet-Geo dealerships, one in Miami and one in Tampa, which had combined 1996 revenues of about $200 million, the company said. Republic is also acquiring Coastal Cadillac of Port Richey, which had 1996 revenues of about $30 million. Including these deals, Republic, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, will own or have agreements to acquire 45 dealer groups in 17 states. Republic, which also owns auto-rental and waste collection operations, is controlled by H. Wayne Huizenga.

title: Ganz Art Collection Brings $206 Million
description: The art collection of Victor and Sally Ganz, a Manhattan couple who spent 50 years and about $2 million buying the work of artists like Picasso and Jasper Johns, sold at Christie's last night for a record $206.5 million. Quality art coupled with clever marketing proved an unbeatable combination: the Ganz name received the art world's blessing, carrying a pristine provenance and therefore a high price tag.

title: An Angry Parcells Chews Out the Bumbling Jets
description: Jets Coach Bill Parcells, his voice lowered but still angry over Sunday's loss at Miami, chewed out his players today and threatened to bench some of them, the veterans in particular.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEDEL, ROBERT H.
description: SCHAEDEL-Robert H., 91. Of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL., formerly of South Orange, NJ, passed away November 9, 1997. He was born June 16, 1906, in Newark, NJ. He is survived by his wife, the former Doris Ahern; his sons Peter A. Schaedel and Robert W. Schaedel; his sister Helen Roellke; five grandchildren; and two greatgrandchildren. For information, contact Hardage-Giddens Funeral Home and Crematory, Jacksonville Beach, Florida.

title: Telefonica of Spain To Acquire All of Unit
description: Telefonica de Espana will pay the Spanish Government 127 billion pesetas ($876 million) for the 23.78 percent of Telefonica Internacional S.A. that it does not already own, Spain's stock market authorities said yesterday. The move had been expected since no other companies bid for the shares. The deal will give Telefonica complete ownership of Tisa, which controls telephone companies in Latin America.

title: Arts in America; Words That Bring Mist to the Snow Shovelers' Eyes
description: It was the gala banquet of an annual congress of snowplow drivers, big taciturn men, some with tattoos. Empty beer bottles littered the tables by the time Baxter Black, an impish man in an orange shirt, climbed the stage to read poetry.

title: Wrestling With Hard Expansion Choices
description: Twenty-eight teams are making their lists and checking them twice, not to mention three, four and five times, before they have to submit their rosters of protected players by 2 P.M. today.

title: In Belgium, Leuven-Louvain Split Speaks Loud
description: LEUVEN, Belgium  There was the Latin American who turned up for post-graduate studies at the ancient Roman Catholic university here and attended courses for a month before discovering he was actually supposed to be at the French-speaking university of Louvain-la-Neuve, 25 kilometers away across Belgium's invisible language frontier.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARSON, BROOKE
description: CARSON-Brooke. 11/11/46-9/9/96. At 3 this was your ''bird-day.'' At 6 all for you-the school closings, parades, etc. Afterwards you never forgot the veterans on their day just as we shall never forget to celebrate you, Brookie, today and everyday. Much love, Mother, Ian and Devereaux

title: Ruling Could Nullify Most Nassau Parking Tickets
description: In a decision that could invalidate hundreds of thousands of parking tickets in Nassau County, an appeals court has thrown out summonses issued in Great Neck Estates as defective.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARSHAW, MARGARET
description: HARSHAW-Margaret. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of beloved artist and teacher, Margaret Harshaw. Singing first as a mezzo-soprano and later as a soprano, she sang more Wagnerian roles than any other singer at the Metropolitan-24 in all, including 14 in the ''Ring'' alone-during a career that lasted nearly a quarter century. Equally distinguished as a teacher, this great American artist leaves us an immeasurable legacy through her many students. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZGER, RICHARD
description: METZGER-Richard. On November 7, 1997, of New Rochelle, NY, formerly of Scarsdale, NY. Husband of Helene (nee Schoenfeld) Metzger. Father of Thomas Metzger and Carol Vanecek. Brother of Elizabeth Stough. Also survived by five grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Funeral services were held privately. Donations in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Post Plans a Printing Plant For the Bronx or Jersey City
description: The New York Post is negotiating with New York State officials to lease a site in an unused rail yard in the South Bronx for a $150 million printing plant, while simultaneously considering an alternative location in Jersey City.

title: Baskin-Robbins Chooses Deutsch
description: Baskin-Robbins USA in Glendale, Calif., said yesterday that it had named the New York and Santa Monica, Calif., offices of Deutsch Inc. to handle its account, with billings estimated at $18 million to $25 million. The incumbent agency of four years -- D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in Los Angeles, part of the MacManus Group -- resigned in September rather than participate in a review.

title: Marshal Who Shot Youth Faced '94 Beating Charge
description: A deputy United States marshal who shot a 17-year-old Queens high school student on Thursday after mistaking the teen-ager's candy bar for a gun was the central suspect three years ago in the beating of a handcuffed prisoner with a lead-filled leather pouch.

title: Effects of Adoption
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA REVIEW; Marco Polo's Voyage to a World of Ideas
description: The journey of Marco Polo from Venice to China is an epic adventure that transcends its time, and its fashioning into a music-theater work of beauty and power by the Chinese composer Tan Dun has brought that past to the present. Mr. Tan's own journey, from China (where he worked in the rice paddies during the Cultural Revolution) to New York City, has been, for him, as momentous, and its effect is seen in the sweep and strength of his musical response. His ''Marco Polo'' was given its United States premiere (after performances in Munich, Amsterdam and Hong Kong) on Saturday night by the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater.

title: Alcohol Taxes Favored To Help Poor, Study Says
description: Most New Jerseyans would prefer an additional tax on alcohol and cigarettes to pay for health care for poor, uninsured patients at hospitals, according to a survey released yesterday.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Asks Ex-OTB Head to Resign
description: The executive committee of the N.A.A.C.P. has asked for the resignation of Hazel N. Dukes, a board member who pleaded guilty last month to stealing $13,000 from a cancer-stricken woman with whom she had worked, the chairwoman of the civil rights group said last night.

title: Senator X Kills Measure On Naming
description: A quixotic proposal to shine a spotlight on senators who anonymously block action on bills and nominations has died quietly, a victim of the secrecy it was meant to end.

title: Managers Are Buying BTR Polymer Unit
description: BTR P.L.C., Britain's biggest diversified industrial company, agreed yesterday to sell its polymer products operation for $:515 million ($858 million) as part of its plan to focus on engineering. The London-based BTR, which said in September that it intended to sell a third of its assets, will sell the unit to its management team backed by the Legal and General Ventures Group and Fuji Bank Ltd. of Japan.

title: Light Computer Comes With Heat Warning but Isn't That Hot
description: WHAT comes to mind when somebody mentions ''a hot computer''? Probably not a machine whose manual advises against using it ''directly on your lap because it can generate heat enough to cause low-temperature burns'' and notes that if you try ''to use a smoking or unusually noisy computer system, this could result in a fire or electric shock to you.''

title: Suspect in Princeton Bank Robbery Is Sought in New York and Puerto Rico
description: A Federal arrest warrant has been issued for one of the men suspected of stealing about $140,000 Thursday evening from a bank in the heart of Princeton's commercial district, a block from Princeton University, the authorities said today.

title: BOMBARDIER PLANS TO ACQUIRE GERMAN RAIL CAR MAKER
description: Bombardier Inc., the Montreal-based transportation equipment company, said yesterday that it planned to buy Deutsche Waggonbau A.G., one of Germany's largest rail car makers, for an undisclosed price to expand its European business. The seller is a group of institutional investors. Deutsche Waggonbau has 4,000 employees and annual revenue of about 1.1 billion marks ($643 million) this year. The acquisition is Bombardier's first foray into the former Eastern bloc and will increase its plants in Europe to 11 from six. Before Germany was reunified, Deutsche Waggonbau was a state-owned company that sold much of its production of freight and passenger rail cars to Russia. The company, near Berlin, was privatized two years ago.

title: Free Speech at New Paltz
description: The Pataki administration endangered both free speech and academic freedom when it joined in an attack on the State University of New York at New Paltz for sponsoring a conference on women's sexuality, which included discussions of sadomasochistic and lesbian sex. Some who attended the discussion were ill at ease with the subject matter. But to foreclose a topic because it makes people uncomfortable is to abdicate the university's role as a forum for free and open exchange.

title: Justice Restored
description: Judge Hiller Zobel's ruling in the case of Louise Woodward, the British au pair, will not satisfy either those who believe she murdered 8-month-old Matthew Eappen or those who believe she did not harm the child. But his decision to reduce the verdict to involuntary manslaughter and to sentence her to time served showed common sense and mercy in a situation where the prosecution's case was too weak to support a sentence of life in prison.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's; Longer Songs to Fill Shorter Days
description: This column isn't dictated so much by a trend in music as by weather. The cold currents in the air create a more serious basis for emotions, and one needs to put the summer hits away in favor of music with longer melodies and stronger pleasures. These sublime albums are full of songs that go on and on, brimming with extended versions of melodic and narrative form.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When REGINE CRESPIN, the French mezzo-soprano, announced her intention to retire 10 years ago after 37 years on the stage, she recalled yesterday, ''All my friends said, 'You are going to be so annoyed doing nothing.' ''

title: 7 Years of Evasion, Tons of Illicit Arms
description: A seven-year game of hide-and-seek has allowed President Saddam Hussein to preserve his power to make chemical, biological and nuclear weapons capable of killing millions, United Nations and United States officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHALFIN, MIRIAM
description: CHALFIN-Miriam. Today is your birthday. Your memory will live in our hearts and minds forever. Your children and grandchildren

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a proposal to survey taxpayers misstated the name of the president of the American Association for Public Opinion Research. He is James R. Beniger, not Richard Benziger.

title: Limo Ride Left Her Hostage, Tourist Says
description: What better way to cap off a New York vacation, Jennifer Isaacs and her daughter thought Sunday evening, than to take a stretch limousine to La Guardia Airport. And for only $28 from midtown.

title: Billions for N.B.A. in TV Deal
description: NBC and Turner Sports will be paying dearly to hold on to the television rights to valuable National Basketball Association games for four more years.

title: Sky-High On Their Own Potent Poetry
description: Little white pills, diet pills stolen from a mother's medicine cabinet, are the drug of choice in ''Mojo,'' the electrifying new play from the young British dramatist Jez Butterworth. They do turn your urine black and you have to take scads to feel anything, but, boy, can they make a guy talk.

title: Clemens Puts A Fourth Cy Young On Resume
description: After Roger Clemens gained his 20th victory of the season for Toronto on Aug. 22, he remarked, ''Not bad for the twilight.'' The distinction he gained yesterday isn't bad for the twilight either.

title: Personal Health; Parents Can Bolster Girls' Fragile Self-Esteem
description: ALTHOUGH opportunities for girls and young women to develop to their fullest potential as human beings have never been greater than they are today in the United States, several studies in recent years have documented that far more girls than boys founder on route.

title: Public Housing Shows Its Age; A Crisis of Advancing Repairs and Declining Money
description: In the 57 years since Mayor Fiorello La Guardia laid their cornerstone to the strains of a brass band, Vladeck Houses on the Lower East Side have embodied the promise of public housing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEFTER, SAMUEL
description: HEFTER-Samuel. On November 10, 1997. Brother of Charles and Alfred Hefter, brother-in-law of Lillian and Rose Hefter. Graveside services Wednesday, 12:30 PM, at the United Synagogue Cemetery, Calverton, New York.

title: Marriage and Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, MATTHEW H.
description: MURRAY-Matthew H. On November 10, 1997. Musical Director of the Saint Sebastian R.C. Church located in Woodside, N.Y. Cherished friend of the Old 199th Army Band Regulars. Reposing at the Kennedy-Roth Funeral Home, 4145 58 Street, Woodside, N.Y. Tuesday, 4-9PM. For service information, please call the Kennedy-Roth Funeral Home at 718-429-0552.

title: A Cigar by Any Other Name Isn't Cuban
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasuries Finish Mixed On Quiet Day
description: The prices of Treasury securities were mixed in quiet trading yesterday, as those with longer maturities outperformed the middle and short ends of the market. Analysts said market participants were waiting for the meeting tomorrow of the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee and a report to Congress on Thursday by Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman.

title: Margaret Harshaw Dies at 88; A Wagnerian Opera Singer
description: Margaret Harshaw, an American soprano and mezzo-soprano who was best known as a Wagnerian singer but whose performances in Mozart and Verdi operas were also highly regarded, died on Friday at Condell Memorial Hospital in Libertyville, Ill. She was 88 and lived in Lake Forest, Ill.

title: N.Y.U. Students Seize The President's Office
description: There are fewer than 30 chimpanzees left at New York University's primate laboratory, down from about 230 in 1995. But 16 students occupying the president's office have vowed to remain until the animals are released into retirement sanctuaries. Even the university's announcement yesterday that it would retire some chimps immediately, and the rest when the research they are involved with was complete, was not enough to pry the students loose. Nor was a threat to begin suspension proceedings this morning.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Worldcom Raises Its Offer And Wins Deal With MCI

title: After 47 Years, Port Authority Ends Carey Bus Contract for Airports
description: In a heated dispute that could affect thousands of people commuting to New York City's airports, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has suddenly canceled its 47-year-old agreement with Carey Bus Lines to provide airport service from midtown Manhattan and replaced it with Gray Line New York, the city's largest tour bus company.

title: A Sax Traditionalist Who Shuns Traditional Forms
description: The saxophonist Mark Shim brought an odd little unbalanced group into the Jazz Standard for the weekend. Mr. Shim, a talented young player perhaps best known for the year he spent in Betty Carter's band, was there as part of a Blue Note-label showcase; newly signed to the label, he looked nervous and played tentatively.

title: Chancellor Says Schools Failed In the Case of a Girl Found Dead
description: In a blunt admission of fault, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that Sabrina Green -- the 9-year-old girl who was found dead last Saturday covered with bruises and burns and missing a thumb -- did not attend a single day of school this academic year and school officials never adequately tried to find out why.

title: ESC MEDICAL IN A $270 MILLION DEAL FOR LASER INDUSTRIES
description: ESC Medical Systems Ltd., which is based in Yokneam, Israel, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Laser Industries for about $270 million in stock. Each share of Laser Industries, which is based in Tel Aviv, would be exchanged for three-quarters of an ESC Medical share. The combined laser technology companies are expected to have about $185 million in revenues this year. The shares of ESC Medical fell $2.8125, to $39.1875, on the Nasdaq, where the stock of Laser Industries rose $3.625, to $26.875. ESC Medical had 1996 sales of $32.9 million. Laser Industries had 1996 sales of $58.7 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, NORMA
description: ROSENTHAL-Norma. November 10, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Irving, devoted mother of Judi and Lynne. Cherished grandmother of Allison, Carrie and Brooke.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, HENRY
description: CARTER-Henry. On November 10, 1997. Beloved son of the late Clarence and Mabel Carter. Dear brother of Ben Carter and cousin of Arthur Carter, Ellen Wiesenthal and Carolyn Sapir. Services Wednesday, 12PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELY, SUSAN BARCLAY
description: ELY-Susan Barclay. Of Locust Valley, Long Island, N.Y. on November 8, 1997. Beloved wife of Stephen. Loving mother of Lyda, Lynn, Sara and Sterling. Dear daughter of Lyda, Hall, and the late Henry Barclay. Beloved sister of Anthony and Rutgers Barclay. Memorial Service St. John's of Lattingtown on the 15th of November at 11AM. In lieu of flowers donations to American Red Cross, Grenville Baker Boys and Girls Club and Save the Children.

title: Max Waldgeir, 80, Social Service Official
description: Max Waldgeir, a former administrator of social services in New York City, died on Oct. 30 at Northridge Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Formerly of Douglaston, Queens, he was 80 and lived in Boca Raton.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I believe that the circumstances in which Defendant acted were characterized by confusion, inexperience, frustration, immaturity and some anger, but not malice (in the legal sense) supporting a conviction for second-degree murder.''

title: In the West, Pataki Raises Money for '98
description: From a $1,000-a-head reception at a Los Angeles estate on Sunday to a $300-a-person dinner for the Pima County Republican Party in Tucson, Ariz., last night, Gov. George E. Pataki of New York has embarked on a weeklong cross-country fund-raising trip that could add a half-million dollars to his already formidable re-election bank account. If the trip is as successful as promised -- Mr. Pataki estimated yesterday that he would raise between $300,000 and $500,000 this week -- he would start the 1998 race with $10 million, about two-thirds of what he spent to become Governor in 1994.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about an increased offer by Starwood Lodging Trust for the ITT Corporation misstated a provision. Starwood will pay an annualized 7 percent interest on its bid, not just on the cash portion, if a merger with ITT takes place after Feb. 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, HARRY A.
description: KRAUS-Harry A. Died November 8, 1997, born August 11, 1936 in New York City, N.Y. Was a resident of New York City and Elizaville, NY. Mr. Kraus distinguished himself as a leader in the field of Direct Marketing at Modular Direct and most recently as President of Horah Direct in NYC, NY. Mr. Kraus was the recipient of the CLEO, Andy and Ecco awards, was a member of the Friars Club, was a board member of the Queens Symphony Orchestra and was listed in the Who's Who of American Business. He was predeceased by his father and namesake, Harry Kraus, Sr. and is survived by wife, Diana Izzi Kraus, daughter, Juliana Kraus, mother, Rosalie Kraus, sister, Adelle Kraus, two children from a previous marriage and four grandchildren. In lieu of flowers donations to the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital. Family will receive friends at the Walter B. Cooke/Kennedy Funeral Home, 117 West 72 St., Monday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Tuesday 9:30 AM, St. Paul the Apostle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIORENTINO, HELEN D.
description: FIORENTINO-Helen D. Of Potomac, MD, on Friday, November 7, 1997. Beloved wife of Louis C. A memorial service will be held at Collins Funeral Home, 500 University Blvd. West, Silver Spring, MD, Friday, November 14, at 11 AM. Interment private.

title: Hewlett-Packard's Consumer Brand Strategy
description: Quick, a free-association test: Hewlett-Packard. What comes to mind?

title: A Cigar by Any Other Name Isn't Cuban
description: To the Editor:

title: Syracuse's McIntosh Becomes A Threat
description: With Rob Konrad, Syracuse's best running back, out with an injury again, Kyle McIntosh took over for the Orangemen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFEE, EUGENE VICTOR
description: JAFFEE-Eugene Victor. On Nov. 10, 1997. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Devoted father of David; dear father-in-law of Barbara Brooks. Loving grandfather of Isadora. Services on Wednesday, 12:15 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations may be made in his memory to the American Parkinson's Disease Association.

title: From Football Player To Can-Can Dancer
description: To promote his students' annual Thanksgiving canned food drive, the principal of Wildwood High School, Walter Dull, 51, a 220-pound former college football player, promised he would appear in drag, as a can-can dancer, if students collected 1,000 cans of food.

title: WorldCom Wins Over MCI With New $36 Billion Bid
description: NEW YORK  With a sweetened offer of $36 billion, WorldCom Inc. brushed aside two rival bidders and emerged Monday as the suitor of choice for MCI Communications Corp.

title: Mets Keep Eye On Marlins' Cook
description: The Mets, who have a glaring need for a left-handed relief pitcher, are setting their sights on Dennis Cook, whom the Florida Marlins have made available because of their intention to reduce their payroll. But baseball officials say the Marlins probably won't seriously discuss trades until after the expansion draft next Tuesday.

title: INSIDE
description: A girl is attacked by a man with a hypodermic needle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, HAROLD
description: PETERS-Harold. The Board of Directors of Our Lady of Mercy Healthcare System, Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center, and Saint Agnes Hospital extend their deepest sympathy to our President and CEO, Gary S. Horan, his wife, Arlene, and their entire family as they mourn the death of Mrs. Horan's beloved father. Edwin S. Mruk, Chairman, Board of Directors, Our Lady of Mercy Healthcare System William F. Harrington, Esq., Chairman, Board of Trustees, Saint Agnes Hospital

title: Pakistani Convicted of Killing 2 Outside C.I.A. Headquarters
description: A Pakistani immigrant was convicted of murder tonight for killing two C.I.A. employees stuck in morning rush-hour traffic outside the intelligence agency's Virginia headquarters nearly five years ago.

title: U-Turn or Merely A Jog in the Road?
description: President Clinton's conclusion that he could not win the votes he needed for broad trade authority marked a resounding change. Since the New Deal era, Congress has always concluded that freer trade benefits more American workers than it harms.

title: Unabomber Sought Revenge, Papers Show
description: The Unabom attacks by Theodore J. Kaczynski were part of a ''plan for revenge on society'' and when his bombs failed, he was disappointed, his journals show, according to a detailed account from prosecutors who are to begin their case against Mr. Kaczynski this week.

title: SPECIALTY FOODS TO SELL ITS CHEESE UNIT FOR $405 MILLION
description: The Specialty Foods Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its cheese subsidiary, Stella Foods Inc., for $405 million to the dairy company Saputo Group Inc. of Montreal. Stella's product line is sold under brand names that include Stella, Frigo, Lorraine, Dragone and Gardenia. Specialty Foods, a closely held company based in Lincolnshire, Ill., said it would use the proceeds to reduce debt and invest in baking operations and acquisitions. The baking business of Specialty Foods includes the Metz Baking Company, Mother's Cake and Cookie Company and Andre-Boudin Bakeries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLON, HELEN FITZGERALD
description: MALLON-Helen Fitzgerald. On November 10, 1997. Of New York City and Fort Lauderdale, FL. Retired NYC school teacher. Widow of Patrick J. Mallon. Pre-deceased by sister Loretta F. Mallon and brother John P. Fitzgerald. Aunt of Mary Mallon Cleary, Bernard Mallon, John E. Fitzgerald, Barry Fitzgerald and Noreen Fitzgerald Merrill. Grand Aunt to sixteen and great grand aunt to twelve. Viewing 10:30 AM Thursday, November 13, at Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Ave, New York City, followed by Mass of Christian Burial 11AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: France Plays Its Part
description: Is France leading an anti-American coalition that is soft on Saddam Hussein, putting commercial and geopolitical self-interest before the security of Middle East allies and concern about terrorism? Some Americans may think so, but the reality is more pragmatic. The dynamic now at work is a classic division of diplomatic labor, one that could help all involved.

title: Brazil Backs Its Currency In Austerity
description: Battered by turmoil on world financial markets, Brazil today announced a drastic program of tax increases and spending cuts aimed at slashing its budget deficit and restoring international confidence in its currency and economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKER, RITA
description: ZUCKER-Rita. Tifereth IsraelTown and Village Synagogue mourns the loss of its beloved member and extends heartfelt condolences to her husband Stanley Zucker and the entire family. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert President, Fred Karp

title: Studying the Method at Its Source
description: The American Repertory Theater and the Institute for Advanced Theater Training at Harvard University have announced a groundbreaking partnership with the Moscow Art Theater School, where the Stanislavsky Method was introduced and evolved, to offer a two-year program in acting, directing and theater management.
