The program will include a semester of training, working and performing in Moscow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMILTON, MARK
description: HAMILTON-Mark. Died on November 2, 1997 after more than a decade of fighting AIDS. Memorial service will be held at 1 P.M., Thursday, November 13, at the United Nations Church Center, 44th Street and First Avenue.

title: Louise Campbell, Actress, 86
description: Louise Campbell, a screen and stage actress, died on Wednesday in Norwalk Hospital in Norwalk, Conn. She was 86.

title: MCI ACCEPTS OFFER OF $36.5 BILLION; DEAL SETS RECORD
description: Selecting a winner among competing bids, MCI Communications, the nation's No. 2 long-distance telephone company, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired for about $36.5 billion in cash and stock by Worldcom Inc. in a deal that would be the biggest merger in American business history.

title: Pop Artist Peter Max Pleads Guilty to Charges of Tax Fraud
description: Peter Max, the darling of the psychedelic 1960's, whose distinctive Pop Art was splashed on coffee mugs, T-shirts, postage stamps and Super Bowl posters, pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of concealing more than $1.1 million in income from the Internal Revenue Service in connection with sales of his works.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAAC, MIRIAM
description: ISAAC-Miriam. Children's Day Treatment Center and School (Godmother's League) mourns the loss of Miriam Isaac, a dedicated, hard-working and long standing member who has diligently served as Secretary of the Board of Directors. She will be sorely missed. Henrietta Berk, President

title: Crumbling Walls: U.S. Effort to Isolate Both Iran and Iraq Is Fraying Badly
description: For six years, the United States has tried to rein in and isolate Iran and Iraq at the same time. The current confrontation with Iraq shows how much harder it gets, year by year, to keep Saddam Hussein under control. And perhaps more ominously, it comes as Iran is moving on its own toward breaking free of American-led restraints.

title: Tracinda to Buy a Larger Stake in MGM
description: The Tracinda Corporation, the holding company controlled by the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, will invest another $75 million in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as part of the entertainment company's initial public offering.

title: Isles Get Opportunities; Brodeur Smothers Them
description: The Devils played their usual game tonight: patient on offense, persistent on defense. And as usual, their goaltender, Martin Brodeur, did the rest.

title: Spare Poetic Songs Of a Gentle Dreamer
description: The word fetish is often misused in describing objects of passion, but it fits Nick Drake's body of work. Fans of the English songwriter, who died in 1974 at the age of 26, treasure the 31 songs he recorded as if they were amulets to be meditated upon privately and shared with the sympathetic few. To love Nick Drake's meditative folk-pop is to join an esoteric society. Organizing an evening in which more than a dozen singers interpret him is a daring, iconoclastic move.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPINOLA, LUCRETIA G. (NEE RUSSO)
description: SPINOLA-Lucretia G. (nee Russo). Of Clifton, November 9, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Stanley R. Spinola. Devoted mother of Dr. Stanley Michael Spinola and Dr. Teri Spinola Campbell. Dear sister of Josephine and Michael Russo. Loving grandmother of three grandchildren. Funeral services will be 9:30 AM, Wednesday from Bizub-Quinlan Funeral Home, 1313 Van Houten Avenue, Clifton and 10:00 AM, from St. Philip's RC Church, Clifton. Entombment Immaculate Conception Cemetery, Upper Montclair. Visiting Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Memorial contributions to Visiting Health Services of New Jersey, Inc., 783 Riverview Drive, Totowa, New Jersey 07511.

title: At CUNY, Statistics Miss the Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Sticks Girl, 8, With Needle on a Street in Brooklyn
description: An 8-year-old Brooklyn girl who was walking to school with her mother yesterday morning in Sunset Park was attacked by an unidentified man who stuck her with a hypodermic needle, the police said.

title: A Pragmatic Agenda For Residential Service
description: Bernard J. Ebbers, the president of Worldcom Inc., has built his company into a powerhouse and a Wall Street favorite by sidestepping the dregs of the telecommunications industry -- the messy, less profitable business of catering to residential phone customers.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about Russian ballet dancers in the United States misstated the affiliation of two dancers appearing with the Staten Island Ballet. Gennadi Saveliev and Alexandra Koltun were guest artists, not company members. Mr. Saveliev is a member of the American Ballet Theater; Ms. Koltun performs as a guest with the Boston Ballet.

title: 2d Female Executive Quits at Thompson
description: Helayne Spivak, one of three worldwide creative directors at the J. Walter Thompson Company, has unexpectedly resigned, effective immediately. Her decision, announced on Friday, came eight days after the departure of another top Thompson female executive, Susan Gianinno, who had been chief executive of the flagship New York office before leaving by mutual consent.

title: At CUNY, Statistics Miss the Point; Struggling Students
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BOEING CO., Seattle, won a $333.4 million contract from the Air Force for a combat training simulator that allows pilots in one site to train with other pilots in distant locations.

title: High Court Upholds Ruling on Trash
description: The United States Supreme Court today let stand a lower court decision that found unconstitutional and anticompetitive New Jersey's system of dictating where and how to dispose of all the state's garbage.

title: A Handicap, but Clinton Still Has Trade Leverage
description: Until today, no Congress had ever blocked a major American initiative toward freer trade since Franklin D. Roosevelt started slashing America's sky-high tariffs in 1934. Even in the depths of recession, the closing of steel and textile mills in the 1970's, and the rise of Japan in the 80's, Congress always came to the reluctant conclusion that freer trade benefits more American workers than it harms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALTON, MARTIN T.
description: DALTON-Martin T. November 8, 1997. 28 years old. Beloved son of Thomas and Anne Dalton. Loved by all who knew him. Taken from us much too soon. We will always cherish him. He will be missed. Reposing McManus Funeral Home, Flatbush and Flatlands Avenues, Brooklyn, NY. Visiting Tuesday from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9. Funeral service Wednesday, November 12, St. Bernard's Church, 9:30 AM mass.

title: When Waaa Turns to Why; Mom and Dad Both Work? Sure. But What to Tell the Children?
description: Claudia E. Mott, a research analyst on Wall Street, spends most of her days answering questions from investors about small-company stocks. But on a recent morning, she received the most intense grilling from her 5-year-old son. Although she usually leaves for her office before he gets up, he was already wide awake at 6 A.M. He then threw a tantrum, insisting that he did not want her to go to work that day. ''Sometimes it's just that they know it's Monday,'' Ms. Mott sighed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLTANO, BETTE JANE
description: SOLTANO-Bette Jane. Beloved wife of Murray, devoted mother of Lisa Paige, Andrew and Susan, Emily and Ben. Cherished daughter of Anne Warren. Dear sister of Wendy Tooker and Heidi Goldstein. Service today at 3 P.M., at ''Parkside Memorial Chapel'', 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn (near Avenue V).

title: European Jobless Need Their Safety Net
description: To the Editor:

title: Underwear Maker to Cut 2,900 Jobs
description: In a cost-cutting move that employees dreaded and Wall Street had been expecting, Fruit of the Loom Inc. said today that it would eliminate 2,900 jobs in Kentucky and Louisiana, or just more than 17 percent of its domestic work force.

title: Alaska Airlines Names Wong Doody
description: Alaska Airlines has named Wong Doody in Seattle to handle its account, which the agency had been handling on a project basis for the last year.

title: Giants' Jones Gets Chance As Injury Sidelines Bratzke
description: In the fourth quarter in Memphis on Sunday, Tennessee Oilers quarterback Steve McNair fumbled the snap and pounced on the ball. Almost before he hit the ground, the Giants' Cedric Jones darted in from his spot at right defensive end and dived on top of McNair. The play did little to help or hurt the Giants, but with a kindly official scorer, it could have been a momentous occasion for Jones.

title: Don't Look to Israel for Help Against Iraq; Pay the U.N. Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: A Stranger Whose Magic Is to Feed the Starving
description: THE ILLUSIONIST

title: Slave Posters Withdrawn From Auction
description: After a flurry of outraged phone calls, Christie's East has withdrawn three reward posters for runaway slaves that it was scheduled to auction today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WINIKOFF, ELLEN
description: WINIKOFF-Ellen. It is 25 years since your tragic accident, we love you and miss you terribly. Marcia, Stanley, Linda, Amy, and now Samantha

title: Metro Business; Village Voice Owner Buys Its 7th Weekly
description: Stern Publishing, owner of The Village Voice and five other weeklies, has reached an agreement to buy its seventh property, The Cleveland Free Times, the company announced yesterday. When the deal is completed, The Free Times will be the third free-distribution weekly acquired by the company this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, STEPHANIE G.
description: HIRSCH-Stephanie G. Of Larchmont, NY on November 10, 1997. Beloved sister of Dorothy Korngold. Beloved aunt and great aunt. Memorial service Sunday, 2 PM, John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Rd., Larchmont, NY.

title: Lillian Parks, 100, Dies; Had 'Backstairs' White House View
description: Lillian Rogers Parks, who surprised President William Howard Taft in his bedroom in 1909 and lived to tell that and many another juicy White House tale, died on Thursday at a hospital in Washington. She was 100 and the writer of ''My Thirty Years Backstairs at the White House.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, WINIFRID M.
description: ROBERTS-Winifrid M. Of West Islip, NY on November 11, 1997. Beloved wife of W. John, ''Jack.'' Long-time member of the Magoun Landing Yacht Club. Friends may visit at the Claude R. BoydSpencer Funeral Home, 448 West Main St, Babylon, NY today 7-9pm.

title: Au Pair's Release Disturbs Jurists as an Excess of Mercy
description: WASHINGTON  Legal experts said Tuesday that they supported a Massachusetts judge's decision to lower a British au pair's murder conviction to manslaughter, but many of them criticized the sentence sharply as being surprisingly lenient and out of line with normal practice.

title: Schuyler Meyer, 79, Foundation Chief And Entrepreneur
description: Schuyler Merritt Meyer Jr., a retired entrepreneur and longtime head of the Edwin Gould Foundation for Children, died Nov. 4 at his home in Dover Plains, N.Y. He was 79.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: It's a Lobster Port! No, It's a Village!
description: Thirty years ago, it was not unusual to see a dozen or more tractor-trailer trucks lumbering down the narrow streets of this village. Nor was it unusual to see the harbor choked with fishing boats, most owned by the 350 or more Portuguese families who once lived here.

title: Pain Management
description: To the Editor:

title: Voters Reject Compromise On Clear-Cutting in Maine
description: After almost three years of debate and two referendums, Maine once again must decide how to sort out the future of its 17 million acres of forests.

title: After a Triumph, a Night of Moderation at Christie's Sale
description: Christie's came back to earth last night. After a magical auction on Monday, when the 20th-century art collection of Victor and Sally Ganz sold for a record $206.5 million, Christie's sale of Impressionist and modern art was sobering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, JOHN ALAN
description: WALKER-John Alan. Beloved son of Helen Walker-Brodie and the late Jack Walker. November 7, 1997. Dearest companion of Gloria. Services private.

title: Desperate Eagles Try Hoying
description: It's official. Philadelphia quarterback Bobby Hoying will get his first National Football League start against the Baltimore Ravens on Sunday.

title: Critic's Notebook; In the Pop Kingdom, Flying Is the Reigning Metaphor
description: In her new song ''Butterfly,'' Mariah Carey entreats, ''Spread your wings and prepare to fly.'' In its current hit ''Fly,'' Sugar Ray pines, ''I just want to fly.'' In a forthcoming single from its debut album, Hanson dreams, ''Fly on the wings of an eagle, glide along with the wind.'' In his most recent Top 10 single, R. Kelly emotes, ''I believe I can fly.'' Every one of these songs is upbeat and every one, if it isn't already a hit, has the makings of a hit. And these are just a few of the songs about flying on the pop charts. Even Elton John's ''Candle in the Wind 1997,'' modified to mourn the Princess of Wales instead of Marilyn Monroe, has added a flying metaphor, changing the line ''Who sees you as more than sexual'' to ''Who'll miss the wings of your compassion.''

title: Work Begins on Center Devoted to Vietnam War
description: After an eight-month delay, work began yesterday on the Vietnam Era Educational Center, the first museum in the country devoted solely to the Vietnam War and its effect on American history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBY, DR. JOHN III
description: JACOBY-Dr. John III. The Board of Trustees, Sisters of Charity, Medical Staff, Hospital Auxiliary, and Administration of St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York mourn the passing of our esteemed friend and colleague. Born on August 17, 1957, ''Jack'' was an attending physician with the Cystic Fibrosis Center at St. Vincent's Hospital until the time of his death. The second of four children with Cystic Fibrosis, Jack's achievements were exceptional by any standard. He graduated from Duke University and received his M.D. at Northwestern University. As a CF physician at St. Vincent's, he served as both care giver and proponent of C.F. research. He will long be remembered for his special ability to empathise and encourage patients with Cystic Fibrosis to set, achieve, and exceed their goals. It is with great sadness that we extend our prayers and condolences to his family. Thomas A. Coleman, Chairman of the Board Karl P. Adler, M.D., President, Chief Exec. Officer

title: Crew Seeks to Suspend or Fine Principal for Abuse Case Delay
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has recommended that the principal of a Brooklyn elementary school be suspended without pay or fined for failing to inform the authorities promptly of evidence that a 7-year-old student was being physically abused at home -- a delay that, investigators have said, resulted in further abuse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, WILLIAM THOMPSON
description: BAKER-William Thompson. Died November 8, 1997. He is survived by his beloved wife, the former Elizabeth Baird; a daughter, Barbara Phyfe Baker; a son, William Thompson Baker, Jr. and three grandchildren; Alice Whetherly Baker, Richard Cass Baker and Heather Thompson Baker. Donations in his memory may be made to The Lighthouse, Inc., 11 East 59 Street, New York, New York, 10022 or St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10021.

title: Students End Protest Over Use of Chimpanzees
description: Students occupying the president's office at New York University on Monday to protest the fate of 28 chimpanzees at the university's medical laboratory left the office around 1:30 A.M. yesterday. They had faced suspension if they did not leave by 9 A.M.

title: Food Stuff
description: Candy Speaks A Universal Language

title: Calendar
description: An Italian Tasting

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, BERNARD CHARLES
description: ROSS-Bernard Charles. On November 10, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Estelle Ross. A kind and loving man who savored life until the end, he is survived by his children, Jane and Gerry Siegel and Larry and Lynn Ross. Donations can be sent to the Daughter of Israel in West Orange, N.J. Mourning period will be observed at the home of Jane and Gerry Siegel, Wednesday and Thursday, 3-8 PM.

title: $25 and Under; Where the New Argentine Beef Hits the Plate
description: BEEF! That's the main reason to visit Pampa, a stylish Argentine restaurant that opened about a month ago on a stretch of Amsterdam Avenue where Spanish is the main language.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Things were going just right Sunday evening in the Murray Hill loft of PETER DUCHIN and BROOKE HAYWARD. CHRISTOPHER WALLING, a jewelry designer, had brought 10 friends for a dinner he bought at an auction to benefit the New York City Opera. The dinner, with duck cassoulet on the menu, was ready to be served. JOHN GUARE, the playwright, was acting as major domo, and his wife, ADELE CHATFIELD-TAYLOR, the president of the American Academy in Rome, served as cigarette girl. THOMAS N. ARMSTRONG 3d, the former director of the Whitney Museum of American Art, was the bartender, and LYNN NESBITT, the literary agent, and JEAN VANDERBILT were waitresses. Mr. Duchin was all set to play the piano for some after-dinner singing.

title: Brodeur: Stats Show He's Better Than Ever
description: Martin Brodeur is convinced he cannot match last season's statistics, and they were indeed impressive. Brodeur, the Devils' goaltender, ended up with a 1.88 goals-against average, the best since Chicago's Tony Esposito in 1971-72 His 10 solo shutouts also made him the first goaltender to post that many in a season since Montreal's Ken Dryden in 1976-77. Based on his play so far this season, Brodeur may have to revise his projection.

title: Pediatric Experts Express Doubt on Au Pair's Defense
description: A day after the British au pair Louise Woodward was released from prison, specialists in child abuse from around the country challenged her lawyers' assertion that the medical evidence supported her claim of innocence in the death of an 8-month-old boy in her care.

title: N.B.A. TV Deals Grow By More Than Double
description: After agreeing to new contracts with NBC and Turner Sports worth $2.6 billion through the 2001-02 season, the National Basketball Association has watched its television revenues grow tenfold since the 1980's.

title: Goldberg Moser Wins New Account
description: Smartalk Teleservices Inc., a telecommunications company in Los Angeles, has named Goldberg Moser O'Neill in San Francisco as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINGARTEN, MICHAEL, M.D.
description: WEINGARTEN - Michael, M.D. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the leadership of our parent corporation Greater Metropolitan Health Systems, in acknowledging with sadness the passing of our dear friend, colleague and benefactor Michael Weingarten, M.D., who was affiliated with Beth Israel for more than sixty years. Dr. Weingarten served in numerous roles during his distinguished career, including a term as President of the Beth Israel Medical Board, and as President of the New York Chapter of the American College of Gastroenterology. He and his wife, Beatrice, also will be remembered for their philanthropic support of our institution. To Beatrice, his daughter Muriel Dachs and her husband Samuel, his daughter-inlaw Joan Weingarten, widow of long time Beth Israel physician Leonard Weingarten, M.D., the entire Weingarten family, and all who loved him, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, GMHS and BIMC Robert G. Newman, M.D., President, GMHS Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President, BIMC Jerome S. Breslaw, M.D., President, Medical Board Sidney K. Stein, M.D., President, Doctors Alumni Assoc. Stephen G. Baum, M.D., Chairman, Dept. of Medicine Alvin M. Gelb, M.D. The Ethel and Milton Bornstein Chief of Gastroenterology

title: Postscript to Sarajevo's Anguish: Muslim Killings of Serbs Detailed
description: In the chaotic first days of the war in Bosnia, when hastily organized Muslim militias and paramilitary units scrambled to defend this city from heavily armed Serbs, men like Musan Topalovic rose from the shadows to become warlords and folk heroes.

title: Frank P. Bibas, 80, Director Won Oscar
description: Frank P. Bibas, an Academy Award-winning producer and director, died on Oct. 16 at a hospice in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 80.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about structural problems in New York City public housing misstated the name of a project with crumbling masonry. It was the Williamsburg Houses, not the Red Hook Houses.

title: Powell Says No Once Again to Making a Run for the Presidency
description: Trying to head off years, perhaps, of speculation and draft movements, Gen. Colin L. Powell made clear today that he had no intention of seeking the Republican nomination for President in 2000.

title: Mexico's Legislators Finally Get Taste of Real Budget Authority
description: Just as he has in years past, Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz strode briskly up to the lectern high above the floor of the Mexican Congress today and presented the new federal budget to a chamber filled with attentive deputies.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Why should African-Americans want their kids to pay respect or pay homage to someone who enslaved their ancestors? This was the most degrading thing that ever happened in North America, and Washington was a part of it. To African-Americans, George Washington has about as much meaning as David Duke.''

title: Market Place; ITT, Hilton and Starwood shares fall before the big vote.
description: INVESTORS pushed down prices of all three companies involved in determining the fate of ITT yesterday, a day before a critical shareholder vote that could mark an end to a protracted takeover battle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, RUBEN
description: SCHWARTZ-Ruben. November 10, 1997. Brigham and Women's Hospital, Boston. Beloved husband of Yvonne, devoted father of Thomas, Mountain View, CA., Victoria Rudolph, Bryn Mawr, PA., Charlotte Rosenberg, Huntington, NY, dear father-in-law of Alan Rudolph and Robert Rosenberg, cherished grandfather of Cassandra, Alexander, Olivia, Chelsea and Adam. Graveside service on Thursday, at 10 A.M., at Mt. Eden Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. Call 914769-0603 for directions. Contributions to Brigham and Women's Hospital, in memory of Ruben Schwartz, Development Office, Attn: John Lindi, 116 Huntington Avenue, Boston, MA. 02116.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Kodak Cuts 10,000 Jobs In Bid for a Turnaround

title: Yanks Pay Hayes to Play for Giants
description: Charlie Hayes will be remembered for catching the final out for the Yankees in the 1996 World Series, but if he contributes anything else to baseball history, it won't be in a Yankees uniform.

title: Battling the River, The Wind and the Odds
description: Tonight's nuts-and-bolts look at the construction of a ''Super Bridge'' is a tribute to the know-how, muscle and daring of those who did the job. A day's work can often be 12 hours or more (at $21 an hour), in bitter weather. ''Yeah, it's a little unbearable up there this morning,'' a construction man says after a long shift 250 feet above the water with the temperature around zero and the wind at 25 or 30 miles an hour. It's dangerous duty. ''Make a wrong move,'' says another, ''and you'll be singing soprano for the rest of your life.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAINE, STEPHEN D.
description: PAINE-Stephen D. The Sterling and Francine Clarke Art Institute in Wiliamstown, MA., mourns the passing of our beloved friend Stephen D. Paine, a trustee since 1981. He immeasurably shaped and directed the Institute through his dedicated and active involvement. His wise counsel and passion for art and art museums will be sorely missed by everyone at The Clarke, who valued his sage advice. Our hearts go out to his devoted wife Susan, who was such a vital support to him. Robert J. Geniesse, President, Michael Conforti, Director

title: Outdoor advertising is winning respect as many museums put billboards and placards on display.
description: THAT most evanescent of media, outdoor advertising, is attaining a kind of permanence. Museums, galleries and archives across the country are beginning to pay attention to the history of billboards, signs, posters, bus and subway placards and even the carved figures that once stood outside stores.

title: INSIDE
description: Doctors Support Evidence

title: Essay; The Demo-Labor Party
description: The ''new'' Democrats have been routed by the old. The Democratic Party is now America's Labor Party. Richard Gephardt has replaced Al Gore as front-runner for the Democratic nomination in 2000.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about an herbal preparation sold as a diet drug referred incorrectly to the hospital where the psychopharmacology clinic is headed by Dr. Richard A. Friedman, an expert who said he was concerned about the marketing of such preparations. It is New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, not New York University-Cornell.

title: Wolfpack And Tigers Are First Winners
description: Princeton's basketball team can cast a spell on its opponents. The Tigers, not the most athletic players, sometimes look like pussycats -- more like student-students than student-athletes.

title: Mets Pursue Olerud and Expose Pulsipher
description: The Mets appear to be in a strong position to re-sign John Olerud, their top run producer, because their preemptive bid last week has apparently chased off the Seattle Mariners, their main competition for the free agent first baseman.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Buona Notte, Guten Tag: Europe's New Workdays; With Unemployment High, the Continent Experiments With the Time Clock
description: For 20 years, Amadeo Nassetti's routine had been as immovable as the huge machines he works on at a factory here owned by Bonfiglioli Group. He put in the same eight hours a day, starting at 8 A.M., five days a week.

title: Colleges Getting Serious About Prize Fellowships
description: Call it a modern-day Pygmalion story.

title: Don't Look to Israel for Help Against Iraq; A Reckless Demand
description: To the Editor:

title: Zagat's New York Survey: Entries Up, Contributors Off
description: THE latest vintage of Zagat's New York restaurant guide -- with its familiar burgundy covers -- was released on Monday.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Doris Kearns Goodwin; Foundations of a Lifetime, Found in the Box Scores
description: In her new book, ''Wait Till Next Year'' (Simon & Schuster), Doris Kearns Goodwin is a historian of her own life. Growing up in the 1950's in the Long Island suburb of Rockville Centre, she defined herself by her family, her street, her town, her Roman Catholic religion and her team, the Brooklyn Dodgers. Looking back at her childhood, she evokes a thoroughly harmonious and often humorous portrait of a loving family that never would recognize the word dysfunctional.

title: Small Grants Help Poor To Start Own Businesses
description: Mildred Robbins Leet and Glenn Leet could easily be gardening and socializing their way through their golden years. There are apple and cherry trees to tend on their wraparound terrace overlooking the Upper West Side and friends and associates, cultivated during two lifetimes of public service, to keep up with.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, NATHAN
description: GOULD-Nathan. Nathan Gould was a true humanitarian. During his 40-year tenure as executive director of Women's American ORT, he formulated the concept of ORT as a movement in Jewish life. He built this organization from a small group to a major national Jewish women's organization. He educated us. He moved mountains for us. He inspired us to move mountains. Nathan Gould spearheaded ORT's movement into Latin America, North America and Russia. He mobilized Women's American ORT's support to answer the needs he found abroad, especially in Israel. The School of Engineering in Jerusalem, the Braude International College in Karmiel, and, in particular, the Syngalowski Center in Tel Avivthe first college-like campus for a vocational high school, the likes of which the world had never seenwere his vision. He put Women's American ORT on the map of prominent world Jewry. Nathan reached out and touched every one of us. At national conventions he would walk down an aisle through thousands of people and touch them on the shoulder; he knew their name. He knew everyone's name. We all have personal stories about Nathan. One woman said, ''What Nathan did for me...'' He had empowered her to speak out against censorship in Texas public schools, something this elderly woman didn't know she could do. A longtime Women's American ORT officer tells how Nathan helped her make a meaningful connection between the basic human values she learned from her parents and her own Jewish identity. ''He encouraged me to act on my principles,'' she said. ''And he made it feel like an imperative.'' Nathan Gould was a mentor, a teacher and a friend. His legacy will live on in Women's American ORT. The officers, Board of Directors and members together extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Ruthie, and his family. Ruth S. Taffel President Pepi Dunay First National Vice-President Rosina K. Abramson, Esq Executive Director and CEO

title: Veteran, 100, Recalls How War to End Wars Didn't
description: They played the too-loud tape recording of taps at the end of the Veterans Day ceremony today, after the prayer and the poem about the poppies in Flanders fields in World War I. His war. George S. Bergman raised his hand to the headgear he brought home from the Marines -- a brown, broad-brimmed hat, not a pie-plate helmet -- and gave the briefest of salutes.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the United Nations visit of Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, misstated the timing and circumstances of the scene shown. Mr. Aziz was leaving the Security Council after talking with its president, Qin Huasun of China; a meeting with Secretary General Kofi Annan took place earlier in the day.

title: Time Is Now for Bertuzzi
description: ISLANDERS

title: Avoiding Adjournment Blunders
description: The final hours before Congress takes a long recess are usually dangerous. It is a time when bad riders are attached to blameless appropriations bills, and complex legislation is denied the measured debate it deserves. With these cautionary notes, we urge Congress to avoid the following pitfalls as it stumbles toward the door.

title: Too Many Beatings; The Boxer's Disease Haunts Wilfred Benitez and His Family
description: Wilfred Benitez recognized his mother right away and his brother Gregory in about a minute. Even before the nurse at the San Agustin nursing home unlocked the front gates, Wilfred saw the family car pull up to the entrance and positioned himself at the door of the rec room, where he could watch his mom approach. He was clutching his tattered Bible and smiling like a stoned Cheshire cat.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: More on 'Joy of Cooking'
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Stanley Bendelac, chairman and chief executive at Delvico Bates, Madrid and Barcelona, part of Cordiant P.L.C., was named to the additional position of regional director for Bates Latin America, succeeding Dan Reid, who left. Mr. Bendelac also continues as chief operating officer at Bates Europe.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a recipe for Chicken Breasts in Foil last Wednesday with an article about the new revision of the cookbook ''Joy of Cooking'' included an error in the method. Four 12-inch squares of foil are required, not 12 squares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBURG, JACK
description: GINSBURG-Jack. Beloved husband of Ruth, devoted father of Ted and Barbara, Michael and Carole. Dear brother of Irene, Ruth and Frances. Cherished grandfather of Evan, Corey, Samantha and Jason. Services today 12 noon at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Swat Team at World Trade Center Foils Would-Be Human Fly
description: Daniel D. Goodwin is a recidivist daredevil, a serial skyscraper scaler who gained fleeting fame in the early 1980's when he spent several Memorial Days climbing up the walls of the Sears Tower in Chicago and the north tower of the World Trade Center and then being arrested for his troubles.

title: Nike's Outside Critics Can Help It Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Notes; Answered Prayers
description: Hits apparently can come from anywhere in these times of diminished performance by the big broadcast networks, and as proof, one of the two would-be networks, WB, is pointing to the success of its Monday night drama, ''Seventh Heaven.''

title: Another Preventable Death
description: Monitoring and protecting tens of thousands of children who pass through New York City's child welfare system is a sizable challenge. But Sabrina Green's wretched death could have been prevented had school officials and child welfare workers done their job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDLEY, SANDEE
description: LEDLEY-Sandee. From lung cancer on November 10. Loving wife of James. Devoted mother of Austin, Charles, Richard, Harry and Elliot, daughter, daughter-inlaw, sister, aunt and friend. The Riverside, Mount Vernon, Noon, Wednesday, November 12. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Columbia Presbyterian Hospital for lung cancer research.

title: Restaurants; Hamptons Hot Spot Has a City Cottage
description: SOME restaurants fit so perfectly into their neighborhoods that it is almost impossible to imagine a time when they were not there. Payard Patisserie and Bistro, to take one recent example, is only a couple of months old, but it is already hard to remember where the Upper East Side ladies lunched before it opened. Nick & Toni's Cafe is its mirror image: although it has a completely different atmosphere, the five-month-old restaurant fits so seamlessly into the low-key streets of the Upper West Side that it seems to have been there forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIEDER, AL
description: RIEDER-Al. The Faculty, Administration and Board of Directors of Manhattan Day School/Yeshiva Ohr Torah record with profound sorrow the passing of Al Rieder, father of Denise Karasick, the wife of our president, George Karasick and grandfather of current and former students Yael, Tami, Shimon, Nomi and Chaya. May his wife Edith, his children and the entire family be comforted in this hour of their untimely loss. Rabbi David Kaminetsky, Principal Elliott Gibber, Chairman of the Board

title: Further Restraint Is Sought For Improvement Districts
description: Seeking to curb the growing influence of business improvement districts, the City Council leadership is releasing a package of proposals today that would make it harder to create and maintain the self-taxing districts and would also more closely regulate them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIORENTINO, HELEN D.
description: FIORENTINO-Helen D. Of Potomac, MD, on Friday, November 7, 1997. Beloved wife of Louis C. A memorial service will be held at Collins Funeral Home, 500 University Blvd. West, Silver Spring, MD, Friday, November 14, at 11 AM. Interment private.

title: School File Of Dead Girl Gives Details Of Great Hopes
description: Sabrina Green's final report card at the Children's Storefront School in Harlem, given in June of 1996 as she was finishing second grade, included a bit of advice: ''Next year is a much more serious year, and third grade means giving up many childish things.'' And it concluded with the notation: ''We will watch Sabrina with love and a certain worry.''

title: Stew: Warming, Comforting And Now, Fashionable
description: DOES any place but an Irish pub call a stew a stew? In French, the language of ''le mot juste,'' there is an uncharacteristically long list of words for stew, like garbure, casserole, ragout, estouffade and daube. While those dishes may sound more elegant than plain stew, they have the same warming, comforting effect on a chilly night.

title: SMART CHOICE TO ACQUIRE 2 FORD DEALERSHIPS IN FLORIDA
description: Smart Choice Automotive Group Inc. said it had agreed to acquire two Ford dealerships in east-central Florida. Terms were not disclosed. One, Bill Redditt Ford in Stuart, has annual revenues of about $38 million. The other, Warren Wooten Ford in Cocoa, has about $61 million in annual revenues. It is the second-oldest Ford dealership in Florida and one of the oldest in the United States, the company said. Smart Choice, a new- and used-car dealership operator based in Titusville, Fla.,, had revenues of $22.9 million for the first six months of 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OST, WARREN W.
description: OST-Warren W., Rev. On November 6, 1997. Survived by his wife, Nancy and daughter, Laura. Services at Madison Ave. Presbyterian Church, Madison Ave. at 73rd St., Thursday, November 13 at 11 AM. Memorial gifts may be made to A Christian Ministry in the National Parks or to the above church.

title: Frustrated Kovalev Seeks Out His Coach
description: In an attempt to repair his deteriorating relationship with Ranger Coach Colin Campbell, Aleksei Kovalev arrived at 8 A.M. for a 10:30 practice today. He approached Campbell and suggested they talk about why Kovalev spent most of the previous game on the bench and why Campbell is so often unhappy with Kovalev's play.

title: 2d-Class Guests on 'A' Lists; Some Spouses Are Unidentified and Unheralded
description: Bette Bao Lord, the author born in Shanghai who now lives on the Upper East Side, was pleased to be invited to the recent White House state dinner for President Jiang Zemin of China. At the same time, it was hardly a surprising invitation, given that she has written four books about her homeland, two of them best sellers.

title: Parents' Secrets Cry Out, But Children Don't Hear
description: The question lingers ambiguously in the air of a musty Manhattan loft. ''Do things really stay secret that long?'' a son asks in ''Three Days of Rain,'' Richard Greenberg's new play about the mysteries of the heart that parents bequeath to their children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, HENRY
description: CARTER-Henry. On November 10, 1997. Beloved son of the late Clarence and Mabel Carter. Dear brother of Ben Carter and cousin of Arthur Carter, Ellen Wiesenthal and Carolyn Sapir. Services Wednesday, 12PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Stocks End Mixed in Moderate Trading as the Dow Rises 6.14
description: Despite overnight gains among Asian markets, broad equity indexes in the United States ended mixed yesterday, as stocks meandered for a second consecutive session characterized by moderate trading volume.

title: Waste Management, Under Pressure, Plans Wide Revamping
description: Waste Management Inc., long pushed by dissident shareholders for drastic changes in its management and operations, announced a broad reorganization plan today that will eliminate 20 percent of its corporate and support staff, about 1,200 employees, and save $100 million annually.

title: Redefining The Etude For Four
description: The Ying Quartet arrived at Weill Hall with plentiful experience and good opinions behind them, which made their opening performance of the Verdi quartet all the more surprising. There were problems of intonation, cross-rhythms were fumbled, and the interpretation was plain. This was not their night.

title: Russian Partner in Iran Deal Postpones Its Bond Offering
description: Facing extraordinary pressure from Washington, a major Russian partner in a project to explore for natural gas in Iran today postponed a bond offering to raise up to $3 billion.

title: Meyer Berger, 85, A Top Businessman
description: Meyer Berger, a self-made businessman, philanthropist and national fund-raiser for the Democratic Party, died on Saturday at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 85.

title: To Build an Instant Art Collection, Put Some English on It; A Denver Patron Knows What He Likes
description: For the grand reopening of the Denver Art Museum's European and American galleries on Saturday -- the culmination of a $7 million, seven-year museum-wide makeover -- pride of place was to go to a sweeping exhibition called ''600 Years of British Painting: The Berger Collection.''

title: The Chef Who Got Away
description: TWO hours or so northwest of Toronto, near the intersection of Osprey Township Tenth Line Road and Side Road 30, almost within sight of Georgian Bay, a driveway branches off a lonely dirt road.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELY, SUSAN
description: ELY-Susan. The Grenville Baker Boys and Girls Club mourns the passing of one of its most vital and spirited board members. Our deepest condolences to her husband, Stephen and loving family.

title: Ideology on the Bench
description: To the Editor:

title: Indonesian Reforms Called Vital to Prevent Recurrence of Haze : Asian Skies Clear, Outlook Is Cloudy
description: SINGAPORE  Clear skies have returned, at least temporarily, to Singapore and Malaysia, following rain and a change in the direction of the wind that for much of the last few months was blowing dense smoke from fires in Indonesia across the region.

title: New Challenge to Idea That 'AIDS Is Special'
description: Behind the swinging glass doors that welcome visitors to the Gay Men's Health Crisis is a world where H.I.V. is not just a deadly virus, but also a ticket to a host of unusual benefits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBOWITZ, ESTHER
description: LIEBOWITZ-Esther. November 10, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Loving mother of the late Ira. Devoted sister of Edith and Emanuel. Dear aunt. Graveside service Wednesday, at 11:30 A.M., at Mount Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CULBERSON, EARL
description: CULBERSON-Earl, 40, on October 13 of a heart attack. A master photographer, his memory will live on in his images and our hearts.

title: From Collards to Kale, It's the Greening of America
description: NOW we know that anything can become trendy: dark, leafy greens have finally made it. You see kale, broccoli rape, dandelions, chard and more almost everywhere, and people are actually eating them.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Oct. 7 about grapefruit juice's effects on the body's absorption of certain drugs, and a correction in this space yesterday, misspelled the surname of a researcher on the subject. He is Dr. Paul Pisarik.

title: Critic's Notebook; On an Odyssey With the Homer Of Rugelach
description: ''THIS is a tragedy!'' Ed Levine moans, craning his neck as the car speeds down Neptune Avenue in Brooklyn. ''Did you see that? There's a FOR RENT sign in Gerace's bakery. It can't be!''

title: Don't Look to Israel for Help Against Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Universities to Study Illnesses Tied to Gulf War
description: Two New Jersey universities chose Veterans Day to announce that they have joined the effort to find out what has caused as many as 100,000 Americans who fought in the Persian Gulf war to complain of mysterious ailments.

title: Abortion Issue Imperils $3.5 Billion U.S. Payment to the I.M.F.
description: Angered over the Clinton Administration's stand on abortions overseas, Senate Republicans are threatening to withhold the $3.5 billion the Administration wants to use to deal with financial crises, like those in Southeast Asia.

title: El Paso Journal; Clothes Sold by Pound Attract Mexican Buyers
description: Carmen Hernandez rummaged carefully through the racks at Ropa por Libra, the downtown El Paso store she has visited two or three times a week, nearly every week, for the past 20 years.

title: Microsoft Says U.S. Challenge Is 'Perverse'
description: The Microsoft Corporation yesterday portrayed the Government's recent challenge to the way it markets Internet software as a ''perverse'' attempt to meddle in product design, threatening to stifle innovation in the computer industry.

title: Hopes for a Revived Coalition
description: The United Nations Security Council has a timely opportunity to erase the damaging impression of division and weakness it created last month when it failed to punish Iraq for obstructing the work of international weapons inspectors. It can do so by approving a new American-sponsored resolution to restrict international travel by Iraqi officials who fail to cooperate with investigations into Baghdad's secret missile-building efforts and its biological, chemical and nuclear weapons programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBRISH, BONNIE P.
description: DOBRISH-Bonnie P. On November 10, 1997. She made the world more beautiful by, and with, her presence. Her family and friends will miss her dearly. Memorial services on Thursday, November 13, at 4 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Hale House.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLSAPPLE, MERRITT CURTIS
description: HOLSAPPLE-Merritt Curtis. On November 9, 1997. Beloved son of Henry T. and Ann Curtis Holsapple of Winston-Salem, NC, and brother of Peter Livington Holsapple of New Orleans, LA.

title: A Tale Seldom Told in Oratorios
description: Probably the most important contribution that Leon Botstein's Bard Music Festival makes is reminding listeners that there are unknown and musically significant sides to even the most ubiquitous composers. Of all the composers the festival has examined so far, none comes close to Haydn, this year's subject, for sheer quantity of high-quality rarities. As in the past few seasons, the festival began with two summer weekends at Bard, in Annandale-on-Hudson, and ended with a coda at Lincoln Center.

title: Hispanic Exit Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: Indonesian Auto Maker Posts Quarterly Loss
description: PT Astra International, Indonesia's largest car maker, has posted its first quarterly loss in more than two years as the cost of borrowing money rose and foreign exchange charges soared with the plunging rupiah. The loss -- at Indonesia's top industrial company and maker of the country's hot-selling utility vehicles -- underscores the toll that this year's 21 percent decline in the rupiah is taking on companies.

title: Another Staggering Finish For Knicks
description: Their nightly panic attack had ended. The Knicks could wipe off their sweaty palms and exit the court after almost allowing their fear of the fourth quarter to unnerve them again.

title: U.S. FILTER SWEETENS BID FOR MEMTEC TO $379.5 MILLION
description: The United States Filter Corporation said it had sweetened its unsolicited bid for Memtec Ltd. of Australia to $34.50 a share, or about $379.5 million, from $30 a share, or $330 million. United States Filter, a provider of water treatment systems based in Palm Desert, Calif., owns 4.9 percent of Memtec's shares. The new offer -- which is conditioned on Filter's receiving at least half of Memtec's shares -- comes after Memtec, a producer of water filtration products, called the initial offer of $30 far too low and encouraged shareholders to reject it. Memtec also said a merger of the companies would violate Australian antitrust laws. Memtec shares were up $1.75, to $35.625, while United States Filter shares were down $1.25, to $29.625.

title: Metro Business; New-Media Centers
description: Columbia University and Carnegie Mellon University plan to open new-media centers in a lower Manhattan office building known for its high-speed computer connections and preference for new-media tenants, school officials have said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEFTER, SAMUEL
description: HEFTER-Samuel. On November 10, 1997. Brother of Charles and Alfred Hefter, brother-in-law of Lillian and Rose Hefter. Graveside services Wednesday, 12:30 PM, at the United Synagogue Cemetery, Calverton, New York.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Asian Transformation

title: Unlike Public, Teachers Oppose National Tests
description: By the time the 28 pupils in Adele Schroeter's fourth-grade class move on to fifth grade next June, they will have taken eight standardized tests in 14 months.

title: Browser Short At Microsoft
description: In trying to convince the Government and the public that there is plenty of competition in computing, the Microsoft Corporation has consistently pointed to the Internet.

title: Man Is Arrested In Death of Toddler
description: The police arrested a man yesterday who they said stood by while his girlfriend punched and kicked her toddler to death earlier this month in Manhattan.

title: For Messinger, No Regrets (and No Parade)
description: There was a parade yesterday, but Ruth W. Messinger did not go.

title: Labor Victory On Trade Bill Reveals Power
description: The stinging blow to President Clinton's trade policy delivered by House Democrats reflects the growing political aggressiveness of the nation's labor unions, their ability to mobilize members and labor's increasing importance in financing Democratic candidates.

title: Updated Scams From Tom and Huck
description: Shaw once advised an aspiring writer who boasted he had a great idea for a play that one cannot write a play about a notion. The notion behind ''H. Finn, Esq.,'' Peter Zablotsky's new stage effort, might have come from the kind of after-dinner conversation that turns into a literary ''what if'' exercise. What if, for example, Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn had grown up and had families?

title: Corrections
description: The TV Weekend column on Friday, about the ABC film ''Into Thin Air: Death on Everest,'' which was broadcast on Sunday, misstated the hometown of Scott Fischer, a professional guide who died on Mount Everest in May 1996. He was from Seattle, not San Francisco.

title: Officials Foresee No Problems For Tickets in Nassau County
description: Nassau County officials said today that parking tickets issued by the county police were valid and conformed to a new state court ruling that found defects in tickets in the Village of Great Neck Estates.

title: Sweet Seeds of Knowledge?
description: THOUGH the apple is said to represent the fruit of the tree of knowledge that tempted Eve, some scholars believe that fruit may have been the pomegranate, which has been cultivated in the Middle East since at least 4000 B.C. A symbol of fertility, this round fruit with a leathery skin is packed with tiny seeds, each encased in a glittering little jewel-like cell filled with tart-sweet juicy pulp. The red pomegranate is the most familiar, but the fruit also comes in yellow, green and white. It is in season now until mid-January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHLER, GARY
description: KOHLER-Gary. Temple Israel of Lawrence, New York mourns the death of the beloved son of our members, Edythe and Harold Kohler and extends deepest sympathy to his family. Brooks R. Susman, Rabbi David M. Land, President

title: Blacks Strip Slaveholders' Names Off Schools
description: By the reckoning of John Riley, the historian at Mount Vernon, there are about 450 schools in the United States named for George Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDER, BARBARA
description: EDER-Barbara. The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University sadly notes the passing of Barbara Eder, wife of Dr. Howard A. Eder, professor emeritus of medicine who has been one of our medical school's leading lights for over 40 years. We extend our heartfelt condolences to him, to his daughter and son-in-law Drs. Susan Eder and Jonathan Flescher, both Einstein alumni, class of '83, and to the entire family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: In MCI-Worldcom Theory, New View of Competition
description: Consolidation is good for competition.

title: Business Travel; British Airways says the Concorde is good for another 20 years of trans-Atlantic flights.
description: ALTHOUGH the Concorde has been flying for more than 20 years, British Airways says it can operate for another 20.

title: Essex County Politicians Plan For Next Election
description: Only one week after the last election, politicians in Essex County are already thinking about the next one. Joseph DiVincenzo of Nutley, a Democrat and the president of the county Board of Freeholders, said yesterday that he would run for County Executive in the June primary.

title: Don't Look to Israel for Help Against Iraq; A Devious Culture?
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; Waiting Game: Easier to Play On Level Field
description: DUST clouds hung in the sunny rooms of Gregory Bortnik's home, where work crews broke through floors and walls with jackhammers and drills. They had got a late start on the project, since Mr. Bortnik had only closed on the three-story brick house in Bensonhurst a few days earlier. No problem. In the month that it will take for renovations, his family will double up with their oldest daughter on Long Island.

title: Executives Say Trade Bill Defeat Will Hurt Economy
description: The managers of many American businesses said today that the inability of Congress and the Clinton Administration to pass a measure granting the President broad authority to negotiate trade deals could cost companies and the economy dearly in the long run.

title: Nike's Outside Critics Can Help It Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Real Estate; For Building Operators, 2000 Stirs Visions of Turmoil
description: Office workers heading back to their buildings after all the celebrations accompanying the advent of the year 2000 may be in for a surprise. They may find that the building's security system does not recognize their magnetically coded card. They may also find all the elevators stubbornly insistent on staying on the ground floor.

description: In all the hubbub over their quarterback, several compelling facts have emerged about the Jets' passing game:

description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Liberties; Tanned, Taut and Rested
description: Bob Dole should not have to play hide-and-seek about a nip-and-tuck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUNG, KIT
description: FUNG-Kit. On November 8, 1997. Beloved mother of Yen. Loving sister of Han-Yen. Reposing at Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, 117 West 72nd Street, NYC Thursday 6 PM-9 PM. Funeral service Church of Our Savior, 48 Henry Street, NYC Friday 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Church of Our Savior or Chinese Christian Fellowship, 549 West 123rd Street, NYC.

title: ARCO to Decide on Coal Business Soon
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company should decide by the first quarter of next year whether to sell its struggling coal business or spin it off to shareholders, ARCO's chief executive, Michael Bowlin, said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BESSELINK, HERMAN
description: BESSELINK-Herman. On November 10, 1997. The Lawrenceville School mourns the death of beloved teacher and dormitory master, Herman Besselink. Born August 15, 1925, in Valburg, Netherlands. Lawrenceville history teacher for 31 years, former Chairman of the History Department, Master of the Kinnan House dormitory from 1970 through 1995. A memorial service is being planned for a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Mr. Besselink's memory may be made to the Lawrenceville School, P.O. Box 6125, Lawrenceville, New Jersey 08648.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RAYTHEON CO., Lexington, Mass., said it had received six engineering and construction contracts with a total value of more than $100 million.

title: The Minimalist; For Lovers of Buttery Sauce, A Recipe Writ in Water
description: THE flour-enriched water in which pasta has cooked -- the shorthand is ''pasta cooking water'' -- appears only occasionally in recipes. Although its use probably originated as a cost-free, effortless substitute for stock, olive oil, butter, cream or other moist ingredient somewhat more precious than water, pasta cooking water, for me, is emerging in one particularly significant role: It can replace most of the butter in many traditional sauces, while maintaining a good deal of the original flavor and texture.

title: Acupuncture Is Alchemy, Not Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: DOMINION TEXTILE URGES REJECTION OF BID FROM POLYMER
description: The board of Dominion Textile Inc. urged shareholders to reject a takeover bid by Polymer Group Inc. while it holds talks with potential rival bidders. Polymer, which owns about 14.5 percent of the company, offered $11.75 (Canadian) for each common share and $109.50 for each preferred share of Dominion Textile, which is based in Montreal. The deal totals $415 million (Canadian), or about $300 million (United States). Polymer, based in North Charleston, S.C., wants to own Dominion Textile's nonwoven business and sell its other businesses to Galey & Lord Inc. of Greensboro, N.C. Dominion Textile executives say the bid is low and they are considering other offers.

title: To Streamline, G.M. Will Take Charges Up to $3 Billion
description: The General Motors Corporation announced today that it would take a charge against earnings of $2 billion to $3 billion as early as the fourth quarter to pay for job cuts, write-downs in the value of some factories and other changes intended to streamline the company in the long term.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERAGHTY, PHILLIPS R.
description: GERAGHTY-Phillips R. On November 10, 1997, of Rye, New York. Beloved husband of Ellen, loving father of Kathleen G. Hubert, Ellen G. Rubino, Phillips R. Geraghty, Megan G. Whelan, and James P. Geraghty. Also survived by six grandchildren. The family will be receiving visitors on Wednesday from 3-5 PM and 7-9 PM at The William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, N.Y. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 10AM at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye. Interment to follow, Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye. In lieu of flowers contributions to Hospice of Westchester or Fairfield University Urban Retreat House preferred.

title: Sips; Idaho Vodka? Don't Even Think of Calling It Mr. Potato Head
description: LIKE 007, vodka has a mission. Its assignment is to slip into a cocktail unnoticed and try not to blow its cover. In the entertainment business, it would be a straight man. In politics, it would be the ideal vice president. This self-effacement is written into United States law, which states that an alcoholic spirit, to qualify as vodka, must be ''without distinctive character, aroma, taste or color.''

title: KODAK TO LAY OFF 10,000 EMPLOYEES IN A 10% CUTBACK
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, which has spent more than a decade reducing its work force, said yesterday that it would cut another 10,000 jobs, the biggest layoff announcement this year by any American company.

title: Dollar Rallies Again vs. Yen On Weak Outlook for Japan
description: The dollar rose to its third consecutive six-month high against the Japanese yen yesterday on expectations that officials in the United States and Japan will let the yen weaken further as Japan's economy shows more signs of faltering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODS, CHARLES
description: WOODS-Charles. Veteran ABC New York staff announcer and early radio personality, died on November 10, 1997. He was a founder and the first Director of the AFTRA-Broadcasting and Recording Industry Council on Alcoholism (ABRICA). A memorial service will be held on Saturday, November 15, at 11:30 AM, at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVEY, LILLIAN BUTLER
description: DAVEY - Lillian Butler. The trustees and staff of Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts mourn the passing of Lillian Butler Davey, a true friend and generous patron. Michael E. Gellert, Chairman Board of Trustees Howard Herring, Executive Director

title: Metro Business; Lender Acquires Retailer
description: Gordon Brothers Capital, a lender to troubled companies, said it has acquired control of I. Kleinfeld & Son, the Brooklyn bridal retailer, by purchasing its bank debt.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SMITH, RICHARD ALEXANDER (BOYIE
description: SMITH - Richard Alexander (Boyieick)/d. Of 21 Wint Road, Mandeville, Jamaica, W.I. Formerly of Kaiser Bauxite Co. On 9/5/97.

title: INSIDE
description: A sober, $70 million reality check at Christie's. PAGE B2

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit on Saturday with a front-page article about paintings by gorillas misstated the photographer's given name. He is Ronald Cohn, not Russell.

title: U.N.'s Council Moves to Block Travel by Iraqis
description: The Security Council moved today toward all but certain passage of a resolution that will punish Iraq by banning travel by its officials, trying to avert military action by the United States. But no mention will be made of authorizing the use of force or other ''serious consequences'' if Iraq fails to comply, as the United States had wanted.

title: 3 Dealer Groups Select Gianettino
description: Three additional dealer groups that sell cars and trucks for the Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation have awarded their accounts to Gianettino & Meredith in Short Hills, N.J. The assignments bring the agency's total Chevrolet dealer group billings to more than $22 million.

title: Gershwin Variations Raise Spirits and Cash
description: For a jazz band, a concert program of George Gershwin's music is like prime rib to a hound. There isn't a reasonably educated jazz performer around who hasn't internalized ''Embraceable You,'' or at least Charlie Parker's rewriting of it; after Louis Armstrong's and Miles Davis's versions, every trumpet player knows the songs from ''Porgy and Bess.'' And ''I Got Rhythm'' is a template for thousands of jazz tunes. Gershwin is the friendliest of pretexts for the musicians and the audience.

title: Conceding Design Flaw, Daimler-Benz Halts Car's Release
description: In a remarkable admission of a serious engineering error by a renowned German manufacturer, Daimler-Benz A.G. today halted shipments of the star-crossed Mercedes A-Class for three months while it refits the chassis to keep the new subcompact from flipping during high-speed turns.

title: A Driver Is Arrested In Dispute Over Fare
description: A 50-year-old limousine driver from Brooklyn was arrested yesterday and charged with trying to extort money from three tourists on Sunday after locking them in his vehicle, the police said.

title: An Ex-Teller Is Arrested In a Robbery In Princeton
description: A former teller at a Princeton bank robbed of about $140,000 last Thursday has been arrested and accused of planning the robbery and driving the getaway car, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today.

title: Homeless Man Charged In Attack on Subway
description: A homeless man hit a Queens woman in the face with a bottle yesterday after she tried to take a subway seat that he was occupying with his belongings, the police said.

title: Strife Claims Small Victim as Rachel's Tomb Is Reopened
description: Ali Jawarish, 9, lay very still on a street here today, blood and brain tissue oozing from a hole in his forehead where he had been shot at close range by an Israeli soldier firing on fleeing young stone-throwers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDEL, GERTRUDE S.
description: SEIDEL-Gertrude S. Adored wife of the late Dewey A. Seidel. Beloved mother of Dorothy (Suzy) and Robert Wigod, Judith and Leon Jacobson. Cherished grandmother of Dewey and Emily Wigod and Alex and Matthew Jacobson. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue, Wednesday 11/12 at 1PM. Graveside services on Thursday, in Wakefield, MA. Contributions to NCJW Council Senior Center and Repeat Performance Thrift Shop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSH, EMANUEL
description: HIRSH-Emanuel. After a lengthy, devastating illness. Beloved husband of Rose for 70 years. Devoted father of Sara H. Cohen and Jules Hirsh. Loving grandfather and great-grandfather. Shivah at his home through Monday, November 17, his 93rd birthday.

title: Making Books; Literary Cachet: The Line Fades
description: The covers said Knopf and Farrar, Straus & Giroux and Putnam and Bantam, and each publishing house had its own personality and image. So actually, until fairly recently, one could indeed generally judge a book by its cover. No longer. It's all blurred now.

title: FEDERAL-MOGUL TO CLOSE 13 SERVICE CENTERS
description: The Federal-Mogul Corporation said yesterday that it would close 13 service centers, eliminating 25 to 30 jobs. The company, a maker of bearings and other automobile parts based in Southfield, Mich., said the closings stemmed from its change to a ''hub and spoke'' distribution system with six central hubs. The move comes in part because auto makers are pressuring suppliers to cut costs and improve service. The company will close service centers by Dec. 5 in Birmingham, Ala.; Hayward, Calif.; Omaha; Long Island; Oklahoma City; Portland, Ore.; Philadelphia, and San Antonio. By Dec. 30 it will close centers in Cleveland, Indianapolis and Richmond. Overseas, centers in Singapore and Malaysia will close.

title: Dull Griddle, Good Pancakes
description: To the Editor:

title: A Low-Risk Philosopher
description: Sir Isaiah Berlin, who died last week at the age of 88, once described himself to me as ''preternaturally ugly in a peculiarly foreign way.'' He was so negligent of his tailoring that, as someone said, he ''appeared to float inside his clothes.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: Don't talk to TONY RANDALL, who is 77 years old, about the limitations of age. His wife, Heather, 27 (''She's a bit long in the tooth,'' Mr. Randall said), is expecting the couple's second child in June.

title: Untamable Spirits Wrangle With the Wild West
description: You've got to love a woman who would print ''Big Matilda, 300 pounds of black passion'' on her business card. And a narrator who admits that after knowing Matilda he never again had anything ''bad to say about a fat woman.'' And then there's the madam who calls a younger woman ''a common mining-camp whore.''

title: Thailand Eases Curbs On Foreign Holdings
description: The Bank of Thailand said yesterday that restrictions on foreign holdings in domestic financial institutions would be eased. Domestically incorporated banks and finance companies ''with sound financial status'' would be allowed to hold 49 percent of other financial institutions for 10 years, the central bank said. These measures will apply to 15 commercial banks, 33 active finance companies and 12 property finance companies that have not been suspended, the central bank said.

title: 46 Years Later, Recalling a Scandal Shot Down
description: ''Your story is nothing short of an inspiration. Your early days in college basketball, where your integrity was instrumental in bringing to a halt a point-shaving scandal that forever altered the landscape of college basketball. . . .''

title: Orange Juice Prices Climb As Cold Threatens Florida
description: Frozen concentrated orange juice futures climbed yesterday to their highest level in three months on speculation that cold weather headed toward Florida might develop into a freeze that could damage crops.

title: Accounts
description: * Advanced Systems Concepts, Hoboken, N.J., to Ciociola & Co., New York, to handle advertising for the software engineering and consulting company, which had been handled in-house and by various agencies on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $1.5 million to $2 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the dedication of the George Bush Presidential Library and Museum referred incorrectly to a warplane on exhibition, similar to the one in which Mr. Bush was shot down in the Pacific during World War II. The Avenger was a bomber, not a fighter.

title: Onetime Hero Prosecutor Rises To Political Stardom in Italy
description: First there was Antonio Di Pietro the hero, the dashing young member of Milan's zealous team of public prosecutors who became a national star in the early 1990's for his role in exposing the rot and corruption in the Italian political system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENKOFF, IRENE
description: GOLDENKOFF - Irene. Passed away November 10, 1997. Loving wife of the late Samuel, adored mother of Ralph, mother-in-law of Isabel, grandmother of Robert and Karen and great-grandmother of Jeremy, Elyssa and Elana.

title: Acupuncture Is Alchemy, Not Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: Wine Talk; Vintages vs. Blending: Champagne's Side of the Story
description: WHEN it comes to wine, Americans are fascinated by vintages. Mention a wine in a group of people, and someone will ask, ''What year was it?'' Pick a year out of a hat: 1994, 1983, 1970. It doesn't matter; everyone will nod sagely and murmur approval. But knowledge has little to do with it. There are wine enthusiasts who can rattle off the good vintages in Bordeaux for the last 20 years but who would have great difficulty distinguishing one year from another by the taste.

title: London Journal; Blair's 'Rebranded' Britain Is No Museum
description: It's the new and improved Britain!

title: Sports of The Times; It Again Comes Down To Ewing
description: SO now it's Mitch Richmond to the rescue. In the wake of a mediocre West Coast swing, the panic button has been pushed, the verdict rendered: the Knicks need more troops.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HAAS, RHODA WILLNER
description: HAAS-Rhoda Willner. Dearly beloved, you are always in our thoughts. Stella, Abbie, Jane and Jay

title: Bogus Polls
description: When Speaker Newt Gingrich jettisoned plans to survey the public about the Internal Revenue Service's performance, the House leadership did much more than sidestep squandering up to $30 million of Americans' hard-earned tax payments. Whatever their motivation or embarrassment, House leaders struck an involuntary but necessary blow against pseudo-polls.

title: TV Notes; News by the Numbers
description: The same week that CBS News got Dan Rather to sign a contract extension that will keep him in the anchor chair until 2002, it also got heartening news about Nielsen ratings. For the first time since August 1992, the CBS ''Evening News'' last week finished tied with ABC for second place kin household ratings, and slightly ahead of ABC in total viewers.

title: Gephardt, Long on Sideline, Scores a Touchdown at Last
description: For years, Richard A. Gephardt, the Democratic leader in the House, has fought the lonely battle. He has opposed major trade bills, the balanced-budget agreement and changes in welfare, popular initiatives that united the Republican-led Congress and the Democratic President, split House Democrats and left Mr. Gephardt a minority within the minority.

title: By the Book; Real or Americanized?
description: MANY Americans have fond memories of the Chinese-American dishes, like chicken chow mein, that were commonplace in neighborhood restaurants a few decades ago. Ken Hom is not one of them.

title: Iraqi Official Says Baghdad Will Continue to Defy U.N.
description: Iraq's Foreign Minister said today that his country saw no alternative to its stand of defiance against the United Nations and remained committed to its threat to expel American weapons inspectors.

title: Spirlea Beats Williams, Politely, to Even Score
description: No bumps, no bruises, no fisticuffs. Anybody who was hoping for another full contact tennis contest tonight between Venus Williams and Irina Spirlea, who worked a head-on collision into a changeover during their United States Open semifinal two months ago, went away from Villanova University's cozy Pavilion Fieldhouse disappointed. So did Williams, but for a different reason.

title: TRINITY INDUSTRIES ENDS TALKS TO BUY AMERICAN RAILCAR
description: Trinity Industries said yesterday that it had indefinitely suspended negotiations to acquire American Railcar Industries from the financier Carl C. Icahn because the two sides were unable to agree on terms. Trinity, a maker of industrial, transportation and construction products based in Dallas, said in August that it had tentatively agreed to acquire American Railcar of St. Louis for about $300 million, mostly in cash. A Trinity spokesman, Michael Conley, said the talks faltered because the company was not able to ''separate and cleanly acquire'' American Railcar's assets from its parent, ACF Industries, a subsidiary of the Icahn Holding Corporation. Trinity said it would continue to seek acquisitions. Trinity shares fell $1.1875, to $44.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVID, LESTER
description: DAVID-Lester. On November 10, 1997. Prominent author and journalist. Beloved husband of the late Irene. Loving father of Margery Rosen and Susan Lewin and father-in-law of Baran Rosen and Robert Lewin. Cherished grandfather of Sarah, Michael, Alex, and Jessica. Services private.

title: ING Offers $4.68 Billion for Belgian Bank
description: ING Groep N.V. made a bold move to extend its spree of acquisitions today with a $4.68 billion offer to buy Banque Bruxelles Lambert of Belgium.

title: Shelters Improve Under Private Groups, Raising a New Worry
description: The first time Elizabeth Squires ended up at the Park Avenue Armory women's shelter two years ago, she found a place she described as forbidding, marked by discourteous guards, indifferent social workers and cold meals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINSTOCK, PENNY BINN
description: BINSTOCK-Penny Binn. On Tuesday, November 11, 1997, at St. Vincent's Hospital. Loving and devoted wife of Moreton Binn. Adored and respected mother of Jeffrey, Jonathan and Jason. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Gay Mens Health Crisis (GMHC), 119 West 24th Street, New York, New York 10011. Services will be held today at 11:00 A.M., in Manhattan at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street.

title: On Way Out, Martinez Grabs Cy Award
description: The budget-minded Montreal Expos have come close but have never quite been able to upend the well-heeled Atlanta Braves in the National League East. But the Expos did derive some satisfaction yesterday when Pedro Martinez, a right-hander about to be traded to the highest bidder, ended the Braves' stranglehold on the National League Cy Young award.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARRANZA, GUILLERMO
description: CARRANZA-Guillermo. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Guillermo Carranza, associated with The Times from 1980, until retiring in 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOOS, SEYMOUR
description: MOOS-Seymour. Congregation Orach Chaim mourns the loss of a true son of Orach Chaim whose love, devotion and years of service are immeasurable and unforgettable. A memorial service at his beloved Orach Chaim will be held in the near future. Dr. Michael D. Shmidman, Rabbi Wolf Scheck, President

title: European Union Court Upholds Affirmative Action for Women
description: In a much-awaited ruling, the European Union's high court today upheld the principle of giving hiring and promotional preferences to women as a valid way of correcting earlier discrimination. The decision could affect affirmative action programs across the Continent.

title: TV Notes; In Historic Footsteps
description: Ken Burns remains the most valuable producer in the history of public television, judging by the ratings.

title: European Jobless Need Their Safety Net
description: To the Editor:

title: Everybody Must Go! Marlins Are Liquidating
description: ''Be sure to get your tickets for the 1998 season,'' trumpets the telephone recording at the offices of the Florida Marlins. ''With the Marlins winning the World Series, tickets are sure to go fast.''

title: 5,000 Absentee Ballots Are Seized in Miami Fraud Inquiry
description: State officials have seized more than 5,000 absentee ballots as part of an investigation into possible fraud and vote-buying in last week's mayoral election.

title: The Chef
description: BANGKOK changed my life. When I arrived for two years of work there in a hotel kitchen, I was a classically trained French chef who knew little else. By the time I was ready to move on, my repertory included lemon grass and cilantro, coconut milk and ginger -- and in fact, all the sharp, sour, salty and spicy flavors of the East.

title: Scaling the Skies With the Sax
description: Steve Lacy, the soprano saxophonist, lives in Europe, and since the dissolution of his long-standing sextet four years ago, he has been scarce around here. But he is touring the United States with the bassist Jean-Jacques Avenel and the drummer John Betsch, both members of his old sextet. His performance on Sunday night at the Knitting Factory had a graceful, nearly perfect contour. It began with easy-swinging songs and a salon-style quietness, working up to a spikier piece called ''The Hoot,'' dedicated to the saxophonist John Gilmore, and finishing with the evening's only fast-burning song, ''Blinks,'' which worked like a cleansing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEJBZON, OLEK
description: LEJBZON-Olek. WSIS sorrowfully mourns the passing of Mr. Olek Lejbzon, our longtime and devoted member. May his memory be a blessing for all. Moshe Meir Morduchowitz, Rabbi Richard Wigler, President

title: TV Notes; No Highlight Reel
description: Marv Albert turns up with David Letterman tonight for the more than 100th time; but, as they say in the movies, this time it's personal.

title: PETRIE RETAIL TO CLOSE 96 STORES IN BID FOR SOLVENCY
description: Petrie Retail Inc. said yesterday that it would close 96 of its women's clothing stores, mostly in the Midwest, as the company seeks to return to solvency by focusing on the East and the South. Petrie said it would close stores in the Petrie, Marianne, Stuarts and Jean Nicole chains and would dismiss workers at its headquarters in Secaucus, N.J. The company has been operating under protection from creditors since October 1995. This is the third time this year it has said it will close stores. The company also operates the Winkelman's and G&G/Rave chains, which will not be affected by the closings.

title: 4 Americans Killed
description: Four Americans and their Pakistani driver were killed today when gunmen fired on their vehicle in Karachi, the authorities said. No one claimed responsibility for the slayings, but the city's police chief said that ''there is a strong possibility'' that they were linked to the conviction Monday of a Pakistani for fatally shooting two employees of the C.I.A. outside its headquarters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAYERS, LILLIAN
description: SAYERS-Lillian. Beloved wife of Theodore, loving mother of Barbara and Mark, cherished grandmother of Lauren & Nichole Braun, surviving sister May Green, of Los Angeles. Lillian Sayers was a pioneer in the Intimate apparel industry and held over ten patents. She was the Chief Designer for Exquisite Form Industries, Bali Bras, and Lillyette. Mrs. Sayers worked for the Community AIDS Society and The 62nd Street Association.
