Lillian was a unique and vibrant woman and will be missed for her extraordinary inspiration, creativity, hospitality and generosity to her family and friends. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, Nov. 13 at 12:00 Temple Emanuel, 65th Street and Fifth Avenue in the Beth El Chapel. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Lung Cancer Research Fund at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, NYC.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Nov. 1 about a proposed purchase of JDW Enterprises Inc. by the Rental Service Corporation misstated Rental Service's rank in the business. While Rental Service has the most outlets in the nation, the Hertz Equipment Rental Corporation is the largest in sales.

title: House Yields to Clinton in 2 Spending Bills
description: Rushing to complete work and to adjourn for the year, the House of Representatives yielded to the Clinton Administration early this morning in passing 1998 fiscal year spending bills for foreign operations and for the District of Columbia.

title: General Assembly Takes Small Steps on Chief's Path of Reform
description: The General Assembly gave its approval today to a package of United Nations administrative reforms proposed by Secretary General Kofi Annan.

title: Kenya to Vote Next Month; Opposition Cries Foul
description: Ending months of speculation, Kenya's electoral commission announced today that the country's general elections would be held on Dec. 29. The announcement kicked off what most analysts predict will be a lopsided contest favoring the longtime President, Daniel arap Moi.

title: PLASTIC PRODUCTS MAKERS TO MERGE IN $110 MILLION DEAL
description: The Puretec Corporation, a plastic products maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Tekni-Plex Inc. for about $110 million in cash plus assumption of $215 million in debt. Puretec, of Ridgefield, N.J., makes home and garden products, medical plastics, packaging and specialty materials. Tekni-Plex, in Somerville, N.J., specializes in pharmaceutical and food packaging. Tekni-Plex's offer of $3.50 a share is a 30 percent premium above Puretec's closing price Tuesday. The combined companies will operate under the Tekni-Plex name. Puretec shares rose 34.375 cents, to to $3.0625.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROBERT F. KENNEDY Jr. and his wife, MARY RICHARDSON, have a new son, WILLIAM FINBAR KENNEDY, born on Saturday in the Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco.

title: A Run on Coffee Stockpiles Sends Prices to 4-Week High
description: Coffee rose to a four-week high yesterday as strong demand and delays in shipping newly harvested beans from Latin America sent United States exchange stockpiles to an 11-month low.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULTZ, GERTRUDE PARKOFF
description: SCHULTZ-Gertrude Parkoff. On November 11th, 1997, shortly before her 90th birthday. Died at peace in Florida. Beloved wife of the late Ben Parkoff and Jack Schultz. Loved, honored and cherished by her daughters, Sondra Henry and Linda Davidson, her sons-in-law Edward Henry, M.D., and Jeff Davidson, grandchildren Scott and Terry Henry, Trisha and Howard Sachs, Gordon and Deborah Henry, Justin and Ari Davidson, and Christopher Davidson, nephew Howard Kamens, great grandchildren Rachel, Benjamin, Jennifer, Oliver, Logan and Milo, and dear friends Herma Sherwood and Eastlyn Clarke. Rest, Beloved Mother.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC., Sunnyvale, Calif., a maker of integrated circuits and microprocessors, said it had invested in the closely held Digital Anvil, Austin, Tex., a digital-game maker. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Law Is Satisfied, but Answers Don't Cover Every Question
description: It was almost five years ago, but the images are still etched in memory: the explosion rumbling over the city like summer thunder, a blast furnace of fire under the World Trade Center, smoke and panic rising through the falling snow, jangling alarms, death and America awaking to the horrors of terrorism.

title: Mayor and Mr. Bush: Just Friends, They Say
description: In an hour of noncommittal good cheer, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and George W. Bush, the Governor of Texas, got to know each other at City Hall yesterday, but the two Republicans insisted that national politics was not what brought them together.

title: Emerging Markets' Slump Taking Toll on U.S. Banks
description: Rumors of the demise of the Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Helu were greatly exaggerated yesterday, but it is a measure of the skittishness afflicting emerging markets that false reports of his death had the power to briefly disconcert traders paid to keep a close eye on the Mexican economy.

title: Fast-Track Falsities
description: The refusal of House Democrats to give the leader of their party ''fast track'' authority to negotiate trade pacts is disturbing testimony to the power of organized labor's campaign money -- and of flagrantly false rhetoric.

title: McCann-Erickson Wins Top Honors
description: McCann-Erickson Worldwide has taken top honors, winning the most awards, at the fifth annual Cresta International Advertising Awards competition sponsored by the United States chapter of the International Advertising Association and Media International.

title: PREMIERE RAISES OFFER FOR XPEDITE TO $34 A SHARE
description: Premiere Technologies Inc. raised its offer yesterday to acquire Xpedite Systems Inc. to $34 a share in stock, or about $319 million, from $30 a share, or about $285 million. Xpedite, based in Eatontown, N.J., makes broadcast-fax and electronic-messaging systems. It had 1996 revenue of about $130 million. Premiere, based in Atlanta, makes technology that allows communication between fax machines, telephones, personal computers and pagers. Shares of Xpedite were up $2.6875 a share, to $30.0625, and Premiere Technologies were at $29.75, down $1.625. The deal, which calls for the assumption of $30.3 million in debt, offers an alternative for Xpedite shareholders to a $23.25-a-share management buyout agreed to in August.

title: Youth Held As Cult Killer Places Blame On a Friend
description: Luke T. Woodham, the 16-year-old student from Pearl, Miss., who is charged with murder in the fatal stabbing of his mother and then the killing of two girls in a shooting rampage at Pearl High School, maintained in a television interview broadcast last night that he had been directed to kill by Grant Boyette, a friend whom the police have described as the mastermind of a teen-age cult.

title: Bob Jones Jr., 86, Leader of Fundamentalist College, Dies
description: The Rev. Dr. Bob Jones Jr., the chancellor and board chairman of Bob Jones University in Greenville, S.C., who in the late 1970's forfeited his college's Federal tax exemption rather than permit students of different races to date or marry, died yesterday at his home in Greenville. He was 86.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRY, REILLY, MARY. D. ATTY. MARY CURRY, REILLY
description: CURRY - REILLY - Mary. d. Atty. Mary Curry-Reilly, 80, formerly of Borghland Rd., Wilton, CT, widow of Atty. Hugh Reilly, died Sunday, November 9, 1997. She was a graduate of the University of Wyoming and received her law degree from Yale Law School. Atty. Curry was a longtime member in the firm of Arthur, Dry and Dole in New York City for over 30 years until her retirement. Funeral Services were held Wednesday in CT.

title: Metro Business; Metlife Faces Class Action
description: A lawsuit against the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for failing to pay the post-operation costs of policyholders has been granted class action status by a New York judge.

title: The Good Knicks Show Up, and Easily Defeat Toronto
description: This was not out of vanity, just necessity. Larry Johnson had been looking at himself over the last week, trying to find the flaws that were ruining the slick appearance he had at the start of the season.

title: Rod Milburn, 47, High Hurdler; Earned Gold at Munich Games
description: Rod Milburn, one of track and field's greatest high hurdlers and a gold medalist in the 110-meter hurdles at the 1972 Munich Olympics, was found dead on Tuesday night, submerged in a liquid-chemical tank at a Georgia Pacific paper plant in Port Hudson, La. He was 47.

title: Currents; SHELTER MAGAZINES -- Taking a New Perspective On What Makes a House a Home
description: Home magazines have traditionally been the repositories of style ranging from high-end to wanting to be high-end. But a spate of new shelter magazines has upset expectations of what good taste and even homes themselves are supposed to be. Last year, Wallpaper magazine came out with glamorous pseudo-homes occupied by young models. Nest magazine reached newsstands this week.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NARDELLI, CAMILLO
description: NARDELLI-Camillo. November 13, 1987. At ten years gone but always remembered with love. Kay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBRISH, BONNIE P.
description: DOBRISH-Bonnie P. On November 10, 1997. She made the world more beautiful by, and with, her presence. Her family and friends will miss her dearly. Memorial services on Thursday, November 13, at 4 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Hale House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSANES, ILSE
description: ROSANES-Ilse. 94. Beloved wife of the late psychoanalyst Dr. Leo Rosanes. Memorial services on November 16, 2 P.M., at Ansche Chesed, 251 West 100th Street.

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column yesterday, about the blurring of distinctions between so-called literary and commercial publishers, referred incorrectly to a literary imprint, Nan A. Talese Books. It is part of Doubleday, not of Bantam.

title: Au Pair Judge Overruled Himself, Not the Jury
description: To the Editor:

title: First, Uphold The Law
description: Suppose that the Eisenhower Administration had nominated a known segregationist to become a top Justice Department official after the Supreme Court's decision in Brown v. Board of Education. Suppose that the nominee told the Judiciary Committee that he believed that despite the Supreme Court's strong wording, room still might remain for the continuation of at least some state-sponsored programs that classified Americans by race.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think we have more answers than questions but there are still questions.''

title: Currents; BEHIND GLASS WALLS -- A Tree as Real Performance Art
description: A tree not only grows in Chelsea, but also breaks through the steel-plate wall of a new three-story building there. The architects Douglas Thompson and Phillip Smith came up with the idea after visiting India, where nature is often incorporated into design. It was just the right idiosyncratic gesture for a project 10 years in the making.

title: Calendar; Antiques, Artists' Wares and Holiday Collectibles
description: Antiques on the Hudson

title: Justice Dept. Investigators Question Clinton and Gore on '96 Fund-Raising
description: Department of Justice investigators questioned President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore on Tuesday about possibly illegal political fund-raising telephone calls in 1994 and 1996.

title: An Intimate Afternoon With Mozart et al.
description: The intimacy that Good Shepherd Presbyterian Church on West 66th Street provides is one reason that concerts there by the Jupiter Symphony are so pleasurable. It was bracing to hear Mozart's ''Haffner'' Symphony on Monday afternoon with the string players just a few feet away, and the sound resonating from the church's vaulted ceiling.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; Outpouring of Sibelius Takes in All the Angles
description: Much of the joy of a New York concert season is to be found in the coincidences, the minifestivals, even miniseasons, that arise between competing institutions. For no apparent reason, this turns out to be, among many other things, a Sibelius season. Lincoln Center presents Colin Davis and the London Symphony Orchestra as the centerpiece of its festival, ''Northern Lights: The Music of Jean Sibelius,'' next month, and Carnegie Hall follows in February with Jorma Panula leading a Sibelius Academy Conductors' Workshop, focusing largely on music of the master.

title: F.B.I. Men Sent to Karachi To Investigate the Slaying
description: Federal counterterrorism officials said today that they had no hard evidence to link the killing of four Americans in Karachi to a Pakistani immigrant's conviction, 28 hours earlier, on charges of murdering two Central Intelligence Agency employees in 1993.

title: The Genuine George
description: So what's the big deal over the J.F.K. and other Presidential tapes? Now it's Seymour Hersh who is citing tapes among other sources (but not the Marilyn Monroe ''correspondence'') in his new book on Kennedy. You want tapes? I'll give you tapes. Of George Washington. Bought them from a guy on Eighth Avenue:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Falls 157 Points After Declines Overseas

title: Looking for the Worst and the Darkest in Kennedy
description: THE DARK SIDE OF CAMELOT

title: LAWMAKERS EASE IMMIGRATION CURBS APPROVED IN 1996
description: Seeking to avert a possible political problem for Republicans, Congress is relaxing two important provisions in a 1996 law that threatened to uproot hundreds of thousands of immigrants living in the United States.

title: Three New Architectural Landmarks
description: Last month three structures -- the Ford Foundation Building at 321 East 42d Street, the CBS Building at 51 West 52d Street and the Chase Bank Building at 510 Fifth Avenue -- were given landmark status by New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission. Each is an emblem of the unequal tension that prevails in the city between a delicate sense of the past and the overwhelming seductions of the present. There are 951,660 properties in New York City, a figure that approximates the number of buildings currently standing there. Of those, 21,192, or roughly 2 percent, have been designated landmarks -- a remarkable achievement for only 32 years of work.

title: 4 Americans Slain in Pakistan; Link to Killing at C.I.A. Is Seen
description: Gunmen leaped from a car during the morning rush hour in the central business district here today, fired virtually at point-blank range and killed four Americans working as auditors for a Texas-based oil and gas company and their Pakistani driver. The police said they were looking for at least four men in what they called a terrorist attack.

title: Of Puppets and Pottery
description: You've got to hand it to that Yachiyo. She's got spunk.

title: Bell Atlantic Is Raising Pay-Phone Local Calls to 35 Cents in 8 States
description: In another example of the fallout from telecommunications deregulation, the Bell Atlantic Corporation said yesterday that it was raising the price of a local call from its pay phones in New Jersey, seven other states and Washington, D.C., to 35 cents next Wednesday.

title: Orthodox in Israel Foster Intolerance; Monopoly on Faith
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSTOWITZ, ELSIE
description: MOSTOWITZ-Elsie. The entire multi-generational membership of Congregation of Children of Jacob mourn the loss of our President Emeritus and matriarch, Elsie Bilger-Mostowitz. As a woman of natural grace, humor, compassion and wisdom, she touched all who knew and loved her. We will forever cherish her memory and be thankful for sharing her life. Martha Goldstein, President Nathan Bilger, Gabbai

title: Currents; WEST COAST PATTERNS -- Fabrics That Have A Historical Perspective
description: ''Everything I look at inspires me to do something else,'' said Rose Tarlow, the West Coast style doyenne who has started her first line of fabrics with Scalamandre. The designer's Los Angeles showroom holds fabrics that look like they were made for an Italian count exiled to the English countryside. The collection -- eight patterns with multiple subtle mutations in such fabrics as handkerchief linen and cotton Jacquard -- is distinguished by adaptations of historical originals. Her diktat: Color ''must be faded but fresh.'' Information, (800) 932-4361.

title: He's Crazy. A 2d Opinion? Funny, Too.
description: If the man with the wispy red hair at the head of the table had tried to explain what was going on yesterday -- and that would have been difficult, even for him, a world-class master of the carefully constructed one-liner -- he could have reduced the whole improbable scene to four words: ''Take my life. Please!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOZSA, JOAN
description: DOZSA-Joan. Died November 11, 1997 at home. Beloved wife of the late Paul. A true friend to many. Private cremation.

title: Residential Resales
description: Big Deal

title: Au Pair Judge Overruled Himself, Not the Jury; Blame Must Be Placed
description: To the Editor:

title: Moscow Journal ; On Russian TV, Suddenly the Screen Is Steamy
description: In a garish yellow and purple television studio, Vladislav, 19, was discussing his frustration over still being a virgin.

title: A Problem With Envy And Carving
description: In ''The Sculptress,'' pretty much everybody has a dark side. You'd expect it of the title character, Olive Martin (Pauline Quirke), an obese woman with dead eyes who is in prison for having murdered her mother and her sister and carved them up in the kitchen. But the cool, sophisticated, blond Rosalind Leigh (Caroline Goodall), who is writing a book about Olive, has her own psychological problems, thanks to her alcoholic ex-husband having killed their daughter in a car crash. Hal Hawksley (Christopher Fulford), the detective who found the bodies and arrested Olive, was so unnerved by the experience that he quit the police force and now operates a dimly lighted restaurant that is always empty. The taciturn, unsmiling Hal makes David Caruso's police characters seem lighthearted. Even the priest (Dermot Crowley) who tries to introduce Olive to God has some complex reactions to her behavior. (O. K., it was wrong to steal candles from the chapel, but so what if she carved them into little white wax fertility goddesses? She did hum ''Rock of Ages'' while she worked.)

title: Daubs of Oil and Exultation As Caspian Pipeline Opens
description: Daubing their cheeks with crude, foreign oilmen and regional leaders today marked the unfettered opening of the world's richest new oil reserves to the West.

title: Mets Show Serious Interest in Reed
description: Jeff Reed's agent said the Mets made an offer to the catcher yesterday. Steve Phillips, the Mets' general manager, said the team did not make an offer. Either way, it's apparent that the Mets' interest in the free-agent veteran is serious.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLISTER, LOUIS H.
description: HOLLISTER-Louis H. November 11, 1997. Beloved son of the late Buhl and Louise Hollister. Services and interment private.

title: Events; Lectures and Interior Shows
description: Fashion and Interiors

title: Edwards Joins Kittles on Nets' Injury List
description: It is starting to get ridiculous around the Nets. Kevin Edwards, who has been starting at shooting guard in Kerry Kittles's place, became the latest casualty this season when he strained his right groin late in practice today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBY, JOHN Z. III, M.D.
description: JACOBY-John Z. III, M.D. On November 9, 1997, at age forty. We mourn with overwhelming sadness the untimely passing of our beloved friend and most esteemed colleague. As Medical Advisor for over a decade to the Young Adult Program of the Cystic Fibrosis Association of Greater New York Dr. Jack Jacoby worked endlessly to advance the life, hope and horizons of the growing CF young adult population even as he too battled the ravages of this relentless disease. With his caring, compassion and dedicated medical expertise he imparted extraordinary strength and courage as he ministered to the cystic fibrosis young and their families. He was truly one of the Lord's chosen messengers. The beauty of his love will live in our hearts. The Cystic Fibrosis Association extends profound sympathies to his beloved family, his parents John and Joanne Jacoby, brother Jeff, sister-in-law Mary Jean and their adored children. Phyllis L. Kossoff, President Jerome Hershman, Exec. V.P.

title: Our Towns; Deep in the Wilderness, A Man's Castle Besieged
description: THE stranger showed up some months back as if he had lived here all along.

title: N.F.L. Takes Notice Of N.B.A.'s TV Deals
description: The National Basketball Association signed deals with NBC and Turner Sports on Tuesday that will increase TV rights payments by 140 percent to $2.64 billion through the next four seasons. Can the National Football League expect a similar leap when its network negotiations begin next month?

title: Shellfish Beds Closed After Sewage Is Spilled
description: About 10,000 acres of shellfish beds in northern Monmouth County have been closed and 200 clammers idled because a broken pipe at a sewage pumping station spilled about 2,000 gallons of raw sewage on Monday near the mouths of the Shrewsbury and Navesink Rivers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, SUZANNE S.
description: MILLER-Suzanne S. Passed away on November 12th, 1997. She is survived by her beloved husband John B. Miller, adoring mother Alice Shapiro and devoted son Craig D. Miller. Loving grandmother of Rachel and Scott Miller. Graveside services are on Friday, November 14, 2 PM at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue Cemetery (Westchester Hills), Hastings-onHudson. 914-478-1767.

title: Citing Success Among Worst City Schools, State Raises Expectations
description: The State Education Commissioner, Richard P. Mills, said yesterday that he was raising the standard for placing New York City's schools on a list that threatens their existence unless they improve. The reason, he said, was that the city has made great progress in its efforts to fix its worst schools.

title: Girardi Holds No Bitterness For Being Left Unprotected
description: Five years ago, Joe Girardi left his home in Lake Forest, Ill., to purchase items for his fireplace because he did not want to watch the major league expansion draft. Girardi, who was with the Chicago Cubs, feared he would be chosen by the Colorado Rockies or the Florida Marlins. He was right. Colorado grabbed him.

title: Suit Planned Over Recording of G.O.P. Discussion
description: Representative John A. Boehner is preparing to sue Representative Jim McDermott, accusing him of making public an intercepted conference call between House Republican leaders. Mr. Boehner has also asked for permission to use campaign money to bring the lawsuit.

title: For WTA, More Roadblocks in Search for Leader
description: Next week or never. It is not a biological clock. It is more like a time bomb ticking away as the tennis brass, searching for a new chief executive officer for women's tennis, reveals itself hard-pressed to overcome a tradition of cronyism to find the best -- instead of the least threatening -- person for the post.

title: Market Place; With turmoil abroad, some wanted the Fed to ease credit.
description: WHEN the expected happens, markets are not supposed to react. And certainly not with the violence seen yesterday afternoon after the disclosure by the Federal Reserve that it would not change short-term interest rates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, SCHUYLER
description: MEYER-Schuyler. Audrey Cohen College and its Board of Trustees sadly note the passing of Schuyler Meyer, a man with an extraordinary sense of justice, who devoted himself to making a difference in the world. In recognition of his outstanding achievements, the college awarded him both its Crystal Award and the Doctorate of Humane Letters. We pay tribute to his dedication to his passion and to a life well spent in fighting the critical social problems faced by our country. Alida Mesrop, President Audrey Cohen College Mildred Robbins Leet, Chairperson, Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCAULIFFE, MARY ROSE
description: McAULIFFE-Mary Rose. On Nov. 12, 1997, of New York City, N.Y. (retired NYC school teacher). Devoted sister of Dorothy, John, and the late Margaret and Eugene. Dear daughter of the late Margaret and John McAuliffe. The family will receive friends Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. at Mulligan & Reilly Funeral Chapels Inc, 1170 Castle Hill Avenue, Bronx, NY. Mass of Christian Burial at The Church of Saint Athanasius, Friday 9:30 A.M. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUNICK, CARL
description: TUNICK-Carl. In memory of our dear Buzzy. He will always be the greatest and we will always love him. Chip, Lisa and Caroline Rieger

title: Friend of the Pentagon
description: To the Editor:

title: Au Pair Judge Overruled Himself, Not the Jury; Justice Under Pressure
description: To the Editor:

title: Global Stock Slide Reaches U.S. as Dow Falls 157.41
description: The fallout from a worlwide slide in share prices continued to rattle stock markets in the United States yesterday, sending all the major indexes tumbling sharply.

title: The Pop Life; Critics Assail Lyrics Hearings
description: ''A real disaster for free speech and for music'' is how Nina Crowley of the Massachusetts Music Industry Coalition described the Senate hearings she attended last week on the impact of rock and rap lyrics on today's youth. Music executives and fans across the country are echoing her sentiments, calling the hearings unfair and one-sided. Staff members for Senator Sam Brownback, a Kansas Republican who is chairman of the subcommittee that held the hearings, argued that they tried to enlist as broad a cross-section of speakers as possible in the two hours alloted for the discussion.

title: Leetch and Richter Open the Door for the Devils
description: Lou Lamoriello, general manager of the Devils, is also the boss of the United States Olympic team that will play in the Winter Games in Japan in February. Lamoriello accompanied his New Jersey team to Madison Square Garden last night for a game against the Rangers. Two of the best Blue Shirts, defenseman Brian Leetch and goalie Mike Richter, have been selected by Lamoriello for the American team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAINE, STEPHEN D.
description: PAINE-Stephen D. The Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute in Wiliamstown, MA., mourns the passing of our beloved friend Stephen D. Paine, a trustee since 1981. He immeasurably shaped and directed the Institute through his dedicated and active involvement. His wise counsel and passion for art and art museums will be sorely missed by everyone at The Clark, who valued his sage advice. Our hearts go out to his devoted wife Susan, who was such a vital support to him. Robert J. Geniesse, President, Michael Conforti, Director

title: 56 Home Runs Later, Griffey Named M.V.P.
description: Ken Griffey Jr. continued to fulfill his destiny as baseball's undisputed best player when he was the unanimous choice for the American League's Most Valuable Player award in balloting by the Baseball Writers Association of America.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of Business Day on Monday, about the appointment of Robert LaBarge as vice president and group creative director of Ziccardi & Partners in New York, misidentified the job for which his predecessor, Susan Black, left the agency. She joined Talbots Inc. as a senior art director, not as executive vice president and creative director.

title: Au Pair Judge Overruled Himself, Not the Jury; Manslaughter Option
description: To the Editor:

title: Kmart President to Retire After Only 2 Years
description: Warren Flick, the president and chief operating officer of the Kmart Corporation, will retire after only two years at the company, Kmart announced yesterday.

title: Snowboarder Leaves No Ground Unturned
description: It was a rugged off season for Mike Jacoby, a world champion snowboarder. Living as he does in this arid region of white-capped mountains and swiftly moving rivers, Jacoby has used the landscape as a personal gym.

title: Expeditions; Where Nothing Is Gone With the Wind
description: FOR Peter Woloszynski, a British photographer, it was stranger than any adventure he'd had. Getting lost in the casbah of Tangier, being questioned by security police in Cuba -- nothing prepared him for being invited into the antebellum mansions of the South. He didn't dare take so much as tea with his hosts, mostly indomitable matrons in their 70's, during the two years he spent tracking down homes that have been in the same family since the Civil War.

title: Personal Shopper; Let It Rain, Let It Snow
description: WITH or without El Nino, rain happens. So do snow, sleet and hail. But you can prepare for the inevitable onslaught of dripping umbrellas, wet coats and soggy hats. Racks and stands are also good organizers, keeping umbrellas off closet floors.

title: The Fed Holds Rates Steady As It Weighs Global Risks
description: Torn between fear of incipient inflation at home and concern about unsettling financial markets around the world, the Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged and ride out the storm for a while longer.

title: South African Bank to Buy U.S. Securities Firm
description: Investec Group, a South African investment bank, agreed yesterday to buy Ernst & Company, a United States securities firm with $26.7 million in capital, giving Investec a foothold in the world's biggest securities market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, ANNE I.
description: LAZAR-Anne I., 88. One-of-a-kind, fun-loving, vital personality; a private person, generous, with strong family ties. She leaves behind: two sisters, Edith Stern and Miriam Magnifico; brother Nat Lazar and his wife, Roberta; and Sadie Ruth Lazar, with whom she shared a wonderful home for 45 years. She was loved and will be remembered by an extended family and many friends. Services today, 1 P.M., at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Foreign Affairs ; The New American Politics
description: Well, I guess it's official now: America has a four-party system.

title: Man in Harlem Stabbed With Hypodermic Needle
description: A 46-year-old man was stabbed in the head with a hypodermic needle in a Harlem subway stairwell last night, the police said. The stabbing was the second involving a hypodermic needle in three days.

title: Parcells Demotes Cornerback as Jets' Shake-Up Continues
description: The demotions and promotions that Coach Bill Parcells promised continued today when Jets right cornerback Otis Smith lost his starting job.

title: An Odd Pair Backs Rights Nominee
description: So far, backing for Bill Lann Lee, the Los Angeles lawyer who is fighting an uphill battle to become the Justice Department's top civil rights enforcement official, has come from a variety of groups. But the idea of the nomination's making strange bedfellows reached a new level today.

title: Islanders Tie Panthers After Early Penalties
description: Shouting and profanity could be heard coming from a side room at Miami Arena tonight during a closed-door meeting between Coach Rick Bowness, his captain and two assistant captains after the team's comeback 2-2 tie against the Florida Panthers.

title: CREDIT SUISSE FIRST BOSTON BUYING BARCLAYS BUSINESSES
description: Credit Suisse First Boston said yesterday that it would pay $:150 million ($255 million) for the British and European equities and mergers businesses of Barclays P.L.C.'s investment bank BZW. The sale, which also includes part of BZW's equities derivatives business, will result in the transfer of 960 BZW employees to Credit Suisse First Boston, a unit of the Credit Suisse Group. Barclays said it would take a $:50 million charge, the amount by which the price paid by Credit Suisse First Boston falls short of the book value of the business.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about Tuesday's stock trading referred incorrectly in some editions to the change in the Dow Jones industrial average. The 6.14-point figure was a rise, not a drop.

title: Five Choreographers Compare Notes on Dance, Black and Otherwise
description: Cleo Parker Robinson recalls the day some 30 years ago that she waited for students to arrive at the dance school she had just opened in her native Denver. She had renovated a studio (though it was so small that dances choreographed there in later years tended to look very vertical). She had printed and distributed fliers.

title: Editorial Observer; America's Hollow Embargo on Iran
description: Anyone who thinks the United States is conducting an effective embargo of Iran ought to visit the Iranian capital. It is flooded with American computers, drilling equipment and parts for everything from trucks to tanks. Ask Iranians about the embargo and they smile. ''We get whatever we want,'' one businessman told me.

title: Ms. Reno's Lazy Investigations
description: Attorney General Janet Reno's usually invisible campaign finance investigation has blipped into view again. First there was the White House announcement that F.B.I. agents have questioned President Clinton and Vice President Gore about their fund-raising calls. Then came The Times's report that Justice Department officials are urging Ms. Reno to extend her inquiry into whether Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt ruled in favor of American Indian contributors on the White House's orders. Rather than offering hope that we will someday know the full story of the 1996 campaign, these tidbits of news simply underscore the damage done by Ms. Reno's continuing refusal to appoint an independent counsel right now.

title: Giants Look to Restart Bandwagon on Sunday
description: It isn't often that a National Football League coach calls the 11th game of his team's season a must win. But Giants Coach Jim Fassel used the term today to describe Sunday's game with the Arizona Cardinals at Giants Stadium. And he had a reason.

title: Metro Matters; Eastern Dude, New in Town: Pataki Who?
description: THIS columnist would like to be able to report that she has been thrown out of a lot better places than Gov. George E. Pataki's fund-raiser Tuesday night.

title: Four Men Are Arrested In 16 Store Robberies
description: Four gunmen who the authorities say ran an illegal van service by day and robbed gasoline stations and convenience stores by night were charged yesterday in at least 16 robberies over the last 22 months on Long Island.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLBROOK, ALFRED W.
description: HOLBROOK-Alfred W. Nov. 11, 1997. Loving husband of Dolores, dear brother of Joseph Holbrook and Joan Barnes. Loving uncle and dear friend to many. Retired from the U.S. Naval Reserve in 1992 after 42 years of service. Reposing at John J. Barrett & Son Funeral Home, 424 West 51 St., NYC, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Thursday. Funeral Mass 10:15 A.M. Friday at Saint Michael's R.C. Church, 412 W. 34th St. Interment Saint Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Unanimous Security Council Tightens the Vise on Iraq
description: The Security Council, in a unanimous vote, made good today on its intention to impose new sanctions on Iraq, including banning foreign travel by Iraqi officials who do not cooperate with a United Nations disarmament commission. But Iraqi officials immediately said they would defy the demands, raising new questions about what will happen next.

title: Brooklyn Lawyer Pleads Guilty in Fraud Case
description: In a case that has roiled Orthodox Jews from New York to Europe, a lawyer who was prominent in Brooklyn's Orthodox community pleaded guilty yesterday to swindling scores of investors out of more than $80 million through bogus mortgage and real estate schemes.

title: Treasury Prices Move Up As Stocks Take a Tumble
description: For the most part, Treasury securities again danced the dance with stocks yesterday, gaining as stock prices retreated in response to further erosion in the Asian markets.

title: Justice Officials Urge Reno to Press Babbitt Casino Case
description: Justice Department officials have urged Attorney General Janet Reno to extend an investigation that could lead to the appointment of an independent prosecutor to examine Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt's role in a decision to kill an Indian casino project, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: A Further Distinction for the Au Pair
description: In the annals of Massachusetts history, Louise Woodward will merit mention not only as the state's most famous alleged murderess since Lizzie Borden.

title: WIDENING FAIRWAYS -- A special report.; In New, Different Fans, Can Golf Find Golfers?
description: Just a few blocks from the Pro Kids Golf Academy, gangs are competing for territory and drug deals are being made. On many days, the serenity of a golf lesson is broken by the sound of sirens.

title: Garden Notebook; Jungle of Inspiration
description: THE bright California sun falls on so many big-leafed tropical plants here, the effect is like filtered jungle light. ''It feels enormous because you can't see where the edges are,'' Marcia Donahue said, standing in her backyard jungle. ''And what you see in the foreground is big, so you assume it goes on like that.''

title: Gulf Alliance: A Falling Out
description: In the heady aftermath of the Persian Gulf war of 1991, American officials dreamed of transforming the Arab coalition that helped to oust Iraq from Kuwait into a new Arab coalition for peace.

title: U.S. Seems to Rule Out Meeting Between Clinton and Netanyahu
description: The White House appeared today to rule out a meeting between President Clinton and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel during Mr. Netanyahu's visit to the United States next week, although American spokesmen took pains to say that this did not represent a snub to the Israeli leader over the lack of progress in Middle East peace talks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, RUBEN
description: SCHWARTZ-Ruben. November 10, 1997. Brigham and Women's Hospital, Boston. Beloved husband of Yvonne, devoted father of Thomas, Mountain View, CA., Victoria Rudolph, Bryn Mawr, PA., Charlotte Rosenberg, Huntington, NY, dear father-in-law of Alan Rudolph and Robert Rosenberg, cherished grandfather of Cassandra, Alexander, Olivia, Chelsea and Adam. Graveside service on Thursday, at 10 A.M., at Mt. Eden Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. Call 914769-0603 for directions. Contributions to Brigham and Women's Hospital, in memory of Ruben Schwartz, Development Office, Attn: John Lindi, 116 Huntington Avenue, Boston, MA. 02116.

title: Building a Classier Image; Las Vegas Hotels Woo Blue Chip Visitors
description: The newest way to make an impression on the garish Las Vegas Strip is through Impressionism itself. The Bellagio, a luxury hotel being built in a city known for its girlie shows, clanging slot machines and the Liberace Museum, will have its hallways graced by about $130 million worth of paintings by the likes of Renoir, Monet and Picasso.

title: Partners Plan Night Cruises For Gamblers
description: The partnership that helped create the nation's most profitable casino, Foxwoods Resort Casino in southeastern Connecticut, is planning daily gambling cruises out of midtown Manhattan on a much larger scale than has ever been attempted before, the company said yesterday. The cruises could begin as early as next month.

title: 'Cabaret' Revival to Be Staged in Real Nightclub
description: Club Expo, a nightclub in the former Henry Miller Theater at 124 West 43d Street, off Seventh Avenue, will be transformed in coming weeks into the Kit Kat Club, a 1930's German honky-tonk, to play host to a revival of the musical ''Cabaret'' early next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SURINACH, CARLOS
description: SURINACH-Carlos. On November 12, 1997, 82, of New Haven, CT., formerly of Miami, FL., and New York. The officers and executives of BMI mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Carlos Surinach. Carlos was a distinguished Composer and Conductor who won particular acclaim for his music for dance. His wide-ranging contributions to our musical culture will live on for generations to come, and we shall greatly miss his warmth and wise counsel. Funeral services will be conducted Friday, November 14, 1997, at 1 P.M., at Woodlawn Cemetery, Jerome Avenue, Bronx. For information the SpinelliMalerba Funeral Home, 62 Beaver Street, Ansonia, CT.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: In Letter, Rubin Warns Japan It Must Bolster Limp Economy
description: In another sign of Washington's concern about an escalation of the financial crisis in Asia, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin wrote a private letter to his Japanese counterpart late last week warning that the health of Japan's banking system was deeply imperiled and urging strong action to spur the Japanese economy.

title: Accounts
description: * Triarc Beverage Group, White Plains, to Blum/Herbstreith, New York, to handle advertising for Royal Crown and Diet Rite colas, with combined billings estimated at $10 million. Royal Crown had been handled by GSD& M, Austin, Tex., part of the GGT Group, and Diet Rite had been handled by Harris Drury Cohen, Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Currents; DESIGN -- Simple Kitchen With Lots to Hide
description: John Pawson, the British architect who sees perfection in simplicity, has designed a kitchen that's a still life with spout. ''I like big pieces and a sense of volume -- stretching effortlessly the full length of the room,'' said Mr. Pawson, who designed the kitchen for the Belgian custom-kitchen manufacturers Obumex. Here, you get what you don't see.

title: Delay in Presenting Data Brings Attention to Program on Infants
description: Public health researchers said today that the Clinton Administration had canceled a presentation of preliminary data suggesting that an ambitious Federal program to reduce infant mortality had fallen far short of its goals.

title: Man Is Killed And a Store Is Firebombed
description: Detectives were searching last night for two gunmen who opened fire on a Harlem grocery store earlier in the day and then set it ablaze with a firebomb, killing a man who worked in the store, slightly injuring several neighbors and destroying an upstairs apartment, police and fire officials said.

title: It's a New Pole As Santa Remodels
description: DRILLS buzzed through the ringing of sleigh bells. The construction crew was working to a Frank Sinatra tape being piped into the new sound system. The Chairman of the Board's voice soared above the Christmas village, crooning ''Come Fly With Me'' -- competition, under the circumstances.

title: Shareholders of ITT Reject Hostile Takeover by Hilton
description: The ITT Corporation, the once-sprawling conglomerate that shrank into what is now primarily a hotel and gaming company, moved to the brink of extinction yesterday, as shareholders essentially endorsed a sale of the company to Starwood Lodging Trust.

title: Savoring Mahler in a Nanosecond World
description: Simon Rattle and the Philadelphia Orchestra have borne witness once again to Gustav Mahler's extraordinary success in the last quarter of the 20th century. On Tuesday at Carnegie Hall, one was tempted to call this splendid performance of the Second Symphony the continuation of a general Mahler revival.

title: Currents; REPRODUCTIONS -- The Highest Compliment For the Eames Chairs
description: What becomes a legend most? A copycat, of course. The 1956 Eames lounge chair is just such a legend, contends Herman Miller Inc. And that is fueling the company's lawsuit for infringement of trademark against Palazzetti, which, since 1990, has been selling its own reproduction Charles Eames lounge and ottoman (below, $2,666), called the Lounge by Charles Eames. Serge Palazzetti says the design is a matter of public domain and that the Herman Miller company secured trademark use of the name only in 1994. Mark Shurman, a Herman Miller spokesman, noted that the chaise (above, $3,350) was designed in collaboration with Herman Miller and that the company pays royalties to the Eames studio. The lawsuit, scheduled to go to trial this month, has been postponed. ''There are a lot of knockoffs out there,'' Mr. Palazzetti said. Herman Miller is ''not going after them, so I guess we're making a good chair.''

title: Currents; RUG COMFORT -- Preferring Warm Toes
description: Cold feet led the French designer Denis Colomb to go from ceramic tiles to rugs. Handmade in India, his wool rugs come in 11 appliqued patterns. ''Some might say they have a New Age look,'' he said. ''I just wanted them to look beautifully modern.'' Rugs, from 6-foot-2-inch squares at $1,500, are at Studio Five in New York (212-228-1929), and at Limn, San Francisco.

title: Changes Urged for Olympic Games
description: Olympic soccer may revert to being restricted to players under 23 years old.

title: Dollar Advances Against Yen On Economic Doubt in Japan
description: The dollar surged against the yen as Japanese stocks tumbled on concern that Tokyo would not soon remedy the country's economic ills.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the legal problems facing McShell Moye-Clark, the president of a branch of the N.A.A.C.P. in Ulster County, N.Y., misspelled the surname of the county District Attorney, who has supported her. He is Michael Kavanagh, not Kavanaugh.

title: Metro Business; Insurer Will Expand In Lower Manhattan
description: American International Group, which already has a sizable presence in lower Manhattan, is expanding by 135,636 square feet at 110 William Street, the 32-story tower at the corner of John Street.

title: Spielberg Film Faces Charge of Plagiarism
description: One month before the release of ''Amistad,'' Steven Spielberg's film about a true-life revolt of African slaves in 1839, this widely anticipated movie has been ensnared in a plagiarism suit that could halt its distribution.

title: ING Groep's Offer May Set Off Counterbid
description: ING Groep N.V.'s $4.68 billion bid to acquire Banque Bruxelles Lambert S.A., Belgium's fourth-biggest bank, touched off speculation yesterday of a counterbid. ING offered 9,500 Belgian francs ($268) a share for Banque Bruxelles. Banque Bruxelles shareholders will receive six shares of ING, one call warrant and 300 Belgian francs for each share. Aad Jacobs, the chief executive of ING, said the company did not expect a counterbid.

title: KOS SHARES PLUNGE ON NEWS OF SLOW SALES OF DRUG
description: The shares of Kos Pharmaceuticals Inc. fell 46 percent yesterday after the company released first-quarter results that showed sales of its new drug Niaspan were not rising as fast as analysts expected. Shares of the Miami-based Kos dropped $14.375, to $16.5625. Kos shares had almost tripled over the last eight months on expectations that it could compete with larger pharmaceutical companies in the cholesterol-lowering drug market. Analysts now say that Kos's drug has trailed expectations. Niaspan was approved by the Food and Drug Administration this July for use in treating disorders of lipids, fatty substances that serve as energy reserves in the body but which can lead to health problems when they build up to high levels.

title: Helen Church, 95, Nutritionist
description: Helen Nichols Church, a pioneering nutritionist who began her career telling Howard Johnson what to serve at his very first restaurant and ended it as the last word on the nutritional content of more than 8,000 popular foods, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Lakewood, N.J. She was 95 and had been the editor of Bowes and Church's Food Values of Portions Commonly Used.

title: Princeton Discovers Back Door To a Title
description: When you talk about S.A.T. scores, Princeton gets respect. When you consider endowments, Princeton gets respect.

title: 'MASTERMIND' AND DRIVER FOUND GUILTY IN 1993 PLOT TO BLOW UP TRADE CENTER
description: Concluding what is likely to be the final major trial in the calamitous explosion at the World Trade Center in 1993, a Federal jury in Manhattan yesterday convicted Ramzi Ahmed Yousef of directing and helping carry out the deadly bomb plot to punish the United States for its support of Israel.

title: Tracking a Deadly Secret; How a Lone Investigator Brought Together The Hidden Strands of an H.I.V. Outbreak
description: On Sept. 6, 1996, a state health investigator drove to the tiny Chautauqua County jail in upstate New York to talk to a young man charged with stealing a car. A blood test at the county clinic showed that the man had H.I.V., and the investigator tracked him down in jail to talk about medical options and urge him to identify sexual partners so they could be warned. That part, often the hardest, was easy: the young man seemed proud of his exploits and recounted them in detail.

title: Group Pays $300 Million For United Artists Theaters
description: United Artists Theater Group, the nation's second-largest cinema operator and a descendant of a company founded by the silent-movie greats Mary Pickford and Douglas Fairbanks, was sold today to a Texas investment firm in a deal that reflects the industry's rapid consolidation.

title: Nickelodeon Adds to Children's Hours
description: Building on an experimental foray into the evening hours that began last year, Nickelodeon plans to announce today that it will extend its prime-time weekday lineup of children's shows to 9 P.M., starting next fall, in a move to capture even more of the family audience.

title: Economy Hotel Is Planned On West Side by Schrager
description: Ian Schrager, the Manhattan-based hotelier known for his ultracool but expensive brand of hospitality with hotels like the Royalton and Paramount, plans to convert the current home of WNET-TV, Channel 13, on West 58th Street into a hotel that he says will offer a more downscale version of cool.

title: Public Eye
description: SEEING faces in space is as old as the man in the moon. What changes is what the faces say about life on Earth.

title: '81 Reversal by Au Pair Judge Resulted in Homicidal Sequel
description: WASHINGTON  When Judge Hiller Zobel overruled a jury's finding and freed a British au pair who had been convicted of murder, it was the fourth time he had thrown out a verdict.

title: Lawsuits' Settlement Brings New Hope for Abortion Pill
description: The settlement of several lawsuits concerning the French abortion pill, mifepristone, could lead to new investment for the troubled effort to sell the drug in this country.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, BLANCHE K.
description: MORRIS-Blanche K. Beloved wife of the late Philip B. Mother of Ronald and the late Dr. Joel. Motherin-law of Elaine and Mary Lee. Grandmother of David, Michael, Danielle and Jeanine. Greatgrandmother of Avital, Ronit and Dylan. Sister of the late Esther Dubois and Miriam Gorchman. Funeral service Thursday 11AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Au Pair Judge Overruled Himself, Not the Jury; Shameful Celebration
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAYERS, LILLIAN
description: SAYERS-Lillian. Beloved wife of Theodore, loving mother of Barbara and Mark, cherished grandmother of Lauren and Nicole Braun, surviving sister May Green, of Los Angeles. Lillian Sayers was a pioneer in the Intimate apparel industry and held over ten patents. She was the Chief Designer for Exquisite Form Industries, Bali Bras, and Lillyette. Mrs. Sayers worked for the Community AIDS Society and The 62nd Street Association. Lillian was a unique and vibrant woman and will be missed for her extraordinary inspiration, creativity, hospitality and generosity to her family and friends. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, Nov. 13 at 12:00 Temple Emanuel, 65th Street and Fifth Avenue in the Beth El Chapel. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Lung Cancer Research Fund at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASBERG, NETTIE RIVEN
description: GLASBERG-Nettie Riven. Of Sunrise, FL., at age 83. Wife of the late Dave. Dearest mother of Irene and beloved mother in law of Jerry Weinberger. Loving grandmother of her precious Gregory with Diane and Jeffrey with Patti. Adoring great grandmother of Jack David, and Alexander Simon. Cherished sister of Lillie Wechsler. Services today 11:30 AM at Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, NY.

title: Oklahoma Bomb Figure Tells Of Explosives-Laden Locker
description: Michael J. Fortier, a crucial witness for the prosecution in the first Oklahoma City bombing trial, told the jury at the second today that Terry L. Nichols and Timothy J. McVeigh took him to an Arizona storage locker filled with explosives seven months before the bombing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILBERG, MYRTLE (BUCHWALTER)
description: MILBERG-Myrtle (Buchwalter). On November 12, 1997. Beloved wife for almost 60 years of Lester; mother of Barry and Andrew (Betsy); grandmother of Michelle and Daniel; sister of Sydelle Kwait. Graveside services are on Friday, November 14, 1997, 1 PM at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale. For further information, Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, Florida, 800-992-9262.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, NATHAN
description: GOULD-Nathan, 84. November 10th, 1997. Child of a close-knit immigrant family. Rebel youth and revolutionary in Chicago and then New York in the 1920's and 1930's. Organizer, eloquent orator, and lover of poetry. Courageous soldier, seriously wounded in Merrill's Marauders, W.W. II. Visionary leader and builder of Women's American ORT for forty years. Never lost his connection with his roots, his care for the downtrodden, or his anger at injustice. Loving husband of Ruth, father of Andy and Jon, and grandfather of Lisa, Greg, and Annie. We will remember his warmth, humor, generous spirit, gentle guidance, and example. Funeral services at 2 PM, November 14th, RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: F.B.I. Ends Inquiry Of Flight 800, Finds No Sign of a Crime
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has formally ended its criminal investigation into the 1996 crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, saying that it had ''found absolutely no evidence'' of a criminal act, according to a letter the agency's top investigator in the case sent to families of crash victims.

title: Bridge; 2 Left in Von Zedtwitz Race
description: Two teams, each beaten once, survive in the New York Double Knockout Team Championship for the Von Zedtwitz Trophy. One is a group captained by Mark Feldman and including Adam Wildavsky, Michael Massimilla, Irina Levitina, and Judi and Michael Radin. The other is the defending champion team: Lapt Chan, Liz Reich, Brad Moss, Phillip Alder, Jim Krekorian and Jon Heller.

title: Board of Nassau County Medical Center Votes to Dismiss Executive Director
description: The executive director of the Nassau County Medical Center, Joseph R. Erazo, was dismissed today from his $191,000-a-year post by a unanimous vote of the center's board.

title: Police Cameras Planned For More Housing Projects
description: The New York City Housing Authority and the Police Department said yesterday that they would expand a much-debated surveillance program for public housing projects that uses police video cameras to watch the elevators, mailboxes, doorways and courtyards there.

title: Economic Scene; The Asian tigers may falter, but the Japan lion is the worry.
description: BANKS, securities brokers and insurance companies, once too eager to cash in on booming real estate and stock markets, are awash in bad debts. While the economy remains in many ways sound -- the savings rate is high, unemployment is low, the work ethic is strong -- creditworthy businesses cannot borrow and a recession is imminent. Yet political leaders, buffeted by contradictory advice and compromised by financial ties to special interests, lack the will to act decisively.

title: AT HOME WITH: Bell Hooks; The Eye of the Storm
description: WHILE the folksy, funky strains of a Celtic-Afro band played from a sleek Bang & Olufsen compact disk player, light and shadows danced freely about Bell Hooks's modest-size living room as if they were being cast by an invisible Calder mobile. The room is the centerpiece of a Greenwich Village condominium that serves as the New York home and sanctuary of Ms. Hooks, one of the most provocative of American feminist writers.

title: 'Is There Relief in This? Yes. Is It Closed? I Doubt It.'
description: William Lavin remembers wanting to see the snow. So on his lunch break one Friday in February nearly five years ago, he left his colleagues in a subterranean conference room of the World Trade Center and climbed up to the lobby. Minutes later, a bomb blasted through an underground garage and the crumbling walls buried four of Mr. Lavin's colleagues, killing them instantly.

title: County Has a Flood of H.I.V. Tests
description: More than 1,000 people have been tested for H.I.V. in Chautauqua County over the last two weeks, but only one of those people has turned out to have the virus, state health officials said today.

title: Advance in Inquiries On Babbitt and Calls
description: Officials have urged Attorney General Janet Reno to prolong an investigation of Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt's role in killing an Indian casino project. In a separate matter, President Clinton and Vice President Gore were questioned about possibly illegal fund-raising.

title: Sports of The Times; N.F.L. Needs Policy to Save Quarterbacks
description: IT'S the National Football League's most persistent problem: how to protect its quarterbacks from being mugged, if not dismembered or disconnected from their senses.

title: Rights Post a Political Lightning Rod
description: Within two weeks of each other, Bill Lann Lee and Seth P. Waxman, candidates for two of the Justice Department's top jobs, were asked their views of a recent Supreme Court ruling on affirmative action. They gave answers that seemed remarkably similar: that racial and gender preferences were permitted in strictly limited circumstances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHMAN, IRVING R.
description: ROTHMAN-Irving R. Beloved husband of Diana. Devoted father of Joan Starkman, Stephen and Carol. Adored grandfather of Marshall and Allison, Scott and Warren. Services 12:30 Thursday at ''Boulevard - Riverside Chapel'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, N.Y.

title: Ameritech Suit To Be Settled
description: The Ameritech Corporation said today that it would take a $42 million charge in the fourth quarter to settle a class-action suit that contended the company used unfair sales practices for a maintenance plan.

title: Old Enough to Retire, A Show Stays Young
description: Purists may argue all they want about when the Christmas season truly begins, but for thousands of people there is no question: It begins the night the curtain goes up on the official opening of ''The Radio City Christmas Spectacular.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, LEONID
description: BRODSKY-Leonid. The partners, constituents and a multitude of coworkers at Newmark mourn the loss of our longtime colleague. With great sadness, we bid you farewell. We will miss your sharp mind, your wit and your incredible dedication. Our heartfelt condolences to Rosa and the entire family. Your memory will live in our hearts forever. You effused so much love here, Lenny, nothing will ever be the same.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Arts & Ideas pages on Saturday about the scholar and historian Isaiah Berlin misspelled the surname of Israel's first President, who was the subject of a reminiscence in a collection of Sir Isaiah's essays. The President was Chaim Weizmann, not Weizman.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The simple boyhood home of PAUL McCARTNEY will be open to the public next summer after a facelift by the National Trust, according to The Associated Press.

title: Arts Abroad; In France, Cyrano, 100, Is Still a Nose for All Seasons
description: Poor Cyrano. Over the years, his famed proboscis has been variously portrayed as hooked, Gallic, Roman, broad, aquiline and reminiscent of a ski jump, but always large enough to invite mockery, always grotesque enough to persuade him that no woman -- certainly not Roxane -- would ever accept him. Yet how the French love their poetry-spouting musketeer!

title: Independence at ABC
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Agrees to Settle for $300,000
description: Keeping secrets from shareholders can get corporate executives into big trouble -- as Peter R. DeGeorge has learned to his cost.

title: In Houston, Tears for Four Who Roamed Far Afield
description: They were a roving team of auditors, four Houston-based men who spent up to half their work time each year checking the books at Union Texas Petroleum's overseas operations. Joel B. Enlow, the company's manager of audit projects, was one of those who thrived on all the travel to far-flung places like Pakistan, Kazakhstan, Tunisia and the North Sea; others were not so keen on the grueling pace.

title: Living Wills Lead to Confusion, Not Mercy
description: To the Editor:

title: MCI TO SELL STAKE IN INTERNATIONAL VENTURE
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said yesterday that it would buy back the 24.9 percent stake that the MCI Communications Corporation holds in Concert Communications, the companies' international phone venture. The move follows Worldcom Inc.'s plan to pay British Telecommunications $7 billion in cash for its 20 percent stake in MCI as part of its planned $41.8 billion acquisition of MCI, the No. 2 United States long-distance company. Full ownership of Concert may make British Telecommunications more attractive to potential United States partners reluctant to join a venture that included MCI. British Telecom and MCI have yet to agree on a price for the stake.

title: Ex-Teller Gave Robbers Bank Plans, F.B.I. Says
description: A former teller provided floor plans from his bank and details of its operations to two gunmen who robbed $164,000 from a Princeton bank last week, the F.B.I. said yesterday.

title: Utah Senator To Offer Bill On Tobacco
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, who is expected to play a pivotal role in the coming Congressional debate on tobacco, said yesterday that he planned to introduce legislation that would slightly increase the cost of the proposed settlement with cigarette companies and stiffen fines against them if youth smoking failed to drop.

title: Grocery Clerk Indicted In Fatal Stabbing of Wife
description: A former grocery clerk was indicted yesterday on charges of killing his wife on July 4 by stabbing her repeatedly after kicking in her car door, prosecutors said.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Irrepressible Montauk Daisy

title: Orthodox in Israel Foster Intolerance
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREANEY, PATRICK J.
description: GREANEY-Patrick J., age 58, of Wyckoff, New Jersey, died on Tuesday, Nov. 11, 1997. President and Chief Operating Officer of NY-based Cellular Vision USA, former Senior Vice President and member of the Executive Management Committee with Philips Electronics North America Corporation where he had been employed for 26 years. Listed in Who's Who in America. Graduated with a BEE from Manhattan College & MBA from Iona College. Member of Ridgewood Country Club, N.J., and the Union League Club, N.Y. Beloved husband of Susan (nee Kleinermann). Father of Kathleen Margaret, Patrick Joseph Jr. and John Michael. Visiting at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, 257 Godwin Ave., Wyckoff on Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass St. Elizabeth's RC Church, 700 Wyckoff Ave., Wyckoff, N.J. 07481. Saturday 9:30 AM. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to St. Elizabeth's RC Church.

title: HAEMONETICS TO CUT JOBS AND CLOSE PLANTS TO CUT COSTS
description: The Haemonetics Corporation said it planned to take a charge of about $25 million in its third quarter, which ends in December, to cut jobs, write off assets and inventory and close operations as it attempts to cut costs. The company, a maker of automated blood processing systems and blood products, said it had dismissed an unspecified number of workers and managers worldwide as it closed or relocated several operations businesses that are no longer part of its key business. Haemonetics, based in Braintree, Mass., said that after taking the charges, it expected earnings to increase by 20 percent to 30 percent in the next two quarters.

title: Bach's Genius in a Computer? Perhaps
description: To the Editor:

title: Hand-Held Cameras, In-Your-Face Films; A Four-Week Series Recalls the Glory Days of Cinema Verite
description: During the 1960's, almost by chance, an extraordinary window opened onto American life. It came with the advent of cinema verite, the approach to documentary filmmaking that could reveal lifelike, unself-conscious behavior to a camera's discreet gaze. It flourished because lightweight synchronous sound was suddenly possible for 16-millemeter cameras, because the new medium of television could serve as its showcase, because novelistic detail was still welcomed by mass audiences, and because cinematic naturalness was not yet something to be feigned by a camera-conscious population or packaged by MTV. Real life, as recorded so astonishingly by the daring documentaries of the era, still looked real.

title: Death Penalty Issue Is Raised as Unabomber Jury Selection Begins
description: When he came into the courtroom, he looked like what he might have been if his life had not taken a turn: a genial math professor, slightly oblivious to fashion.

title: In America ; Redemption for a Killer
description: In the first act of Paul Simon's musical, ''The Capeman,'' the mother of one of the boys stabbed to death in a playground by Salvador Agron finds that she cannot summon the compassion, the forgiveness that her church tells her she should feel for the killer of her son.

title: Glazing Lies and Lust With Sweet Melodies
description: The seven deadly sins are good for something: the arts. Joe Jackson has joined Hieronymus Bosch, Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill, George Balanchine, Thornton Wilder and, of course, Brad Pitt among those who have found modern possibilities in the ancient list. On Monday night at the Supper Club, starting a two-night stand, Mr. Jackson performed his new song cycle, ''Heaven and Hell'' (Sony Classical), which includes an instrumental prelude and one song per sin.

title: ACCUSTAFF TO PAY $85 MILLION FOR OFFICE SPECIALISTS
description: Accustaff Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the closely held Office Specialists Inc. for as much as $85 million in stock in a move to offer more specialized temporary workers and consultants and expand into the Northeast. Accustaff, of Jacksonville, Fla., will issue 2.5 million to 3 million shares for Boston-based Office Specialists, Accustaff's chief executive, Derek Dewan, said. The number issued and the purchase price will depend on the price at which Accustaff stock trades over a 10-day period around the time the transaction closes in December, he said. The shares' value would be $71.9 million to $86.3 million right now, based on Accustaff's closing price on Tuesday. Accustaff's shares fell 50 cents, to $28.25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTH, EDWARD S.
description: NORTH-Edward S. On November 11, 1997, of Kings Point, NY. Adored husband of Patricia and loving father of Candice and Cassandra. The devoted and loving family of Ruth Drucker-Nancy, Howard, Chad and Randi StoneSteven, Gail, David and Megan Drucker-mourn the passing of Edward and deeply embrace with love and devotion Patricia, Candice and Cassandra. Services to be held today, Nov. 13, at Nassau North Chapel in Great Neck, NY.

title: Cabinetry Factory Is Being Converted By Federal Express
description: Federal Express is converting a former cabinetry factory in Canarsie into its largest distribution center in Brooklyn, a further sign of the transformation of much of the city's industrial base from manufacturing into warehousing and shipping.

title: F. Schumacher's Waverly is starting a campaign to update its image in home furnishings.
description: WAVERLY, the moderately priced home furnishings division of F. Schumacher & Company, is starting a campaign in an effort to update its image and compete more effectively against designers like Ralph Lauren and Liz Claiborne.

title: Fight Aboard a Subway Injures Seven Students
description: A subway car full of high school students erupted in violence yesterday in Brooklyn, the police said. Seven students were injured and at least three teen-age suspects were being sought, the authorities said.

title: People
description: * David Haan was named to the new position of managing partner and chief operating officer of the Philadelphia office of Earle Palmer Brown. He had been president and chief executive of Foote, Cone & Belding Canada, Toronto, part of True North Communications. At the New York office of Earle Palmer, Alan Zorfas was named partner and chief marketing officer, a new post; he had been integrated marketing director at the DDB Needham New York unit of Omnicom Group.

title: Modern-Art Sale Ends In a Loss for Sotheby's
description: Great expectations went awry at Sotheby's in Manhattan last night. Its sale of modern art from the the estate of the hotelier Evelyn Sharp was too highly estimated. To make matters worse, Sotheby's had given the heirs a guarantee -- an undisclosed sum of money, generally hovering around the low estimate, to be paid to the seller regardless of the sale's outcome. And therefore Sotheby's ended the evening at a loss.

title: INSIDE
description: A hotelier plans to convert the home of Channel 13. PAGE B6

title: As Defensemen Drop, Devils Just Keep Reloading
description: The Devils have been missing defensemen without missing a step this season, and they did it again last night, displaying their depth in a 3-2 triumph over the Rangers at Madison Square Garden.

title: Hearing on Hidden Fees for 401(k) Plans
description: Hidden fees are being charged to some of the 401(k) plans that 25 million workers use to save for retirement, but full disclosure of fees would lead to lower costs, leaders of the industry said at a Labor Department hearing today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSH, MAX
description: RUSH-Max. On November 12, 1997, in Flushing, Queens. Beloved husband of the late Miriam, cherished father of Ira and Steven and father-in-law of Carol, devoted grandfather of Dara & Jacqueline. He gave of himself generously to his family, his friends, and his neighbors. Funeral services at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway (Long Island Expressway), Fresh Meadows, NY at 12 noon Thursday, November 13. Burial following at Mt. Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, New Jersey.

title: In Bushmanland, Hunters' Tradition Turns to Dust
description: ''If the kudu barks when you hit it, you will eat tonight,'' said Tomas Xaixae. ''It means you hit the stomach. But if you hit the leg, you must follow it for two days.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARLUCK, IRVING M
description: ARLUCK-Irving M. On November 12th, 1997. In Somers Point, N.J. Beloved husband of Renie (nee Barotz) Arluck of Great Neck, LI. Devoted father of Dr. Stephen B. Arluck of Great Neck, L.I., and Dr. David L. Arluck of Ocean City, NJ. Loving grandfather of Samantha, Michael, Jeremy and Chloe. Services today at 4 P.M. at the Emeth Shalom Synagogue, 8501 Ventnor Avenue, Margate, N.J. Donations may be made to the synagogue. Burial will be private. For information contact the Roth-Goldsteins' Memorial Chapel, Atlantic City NJ.

title: INSIDE
description: Interest Rates Unchanged

title: WPP Forms Agency To Focus on Women
description: WPP Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it had opened Intuition Group, a worldwide agency specializing in advertising to women. The start-up of Intuition, which begins with accounts from the Clairol Worldwide division of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, is part of a wider reassignment by Bristol-Myers Squibb of products in hair care and other categories with total billings estimated at $100 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAFTER, CORINNE K.
description: KLAFTER-Corinne K. November 13, 1997, of Great Neck, Long Island. Beloved wife of Horace. Loving mother of Dr. Lois and Jerry Snyder, David Klafter, Esq. & Nancy Kestenbaum, Esq; Rabbi Beth Klafter and Rabbi Jonathan Hecht. Cherished grandmother of Daniel, Deborah, Jordan, Gabriel, Rebecca and Samuel. Devoted & beloved friend to many. Services Sunday, 12:30 P.M. at Temple Beth El, Old Mill Road, Great Neck, Long Island. In lieu of flowers or other gifts kindly direct contributions to Temple Beth El of Great Neck or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: On Stage and Off; Dramatic Diplomacy
description: Informal talks have begun on significantly loosening, and perhaps temporarily abolishing, restrictions on British and American actors' working on opposite sides of the Atlantic.

title: Weekly Aimed at Blacks Is Moving to Newark
description: A new national newspaper aimed at middle-class black readers will move its headquarters here from Baltimore by January, its publisher said on Wednesday.

title: Discovery of Gene Offers Clues on Deafness
description: A large extended family in the town of Cartago, Costa Rica, has long had an unusual affliction to set against its blessings.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Why Do Americans Gorge On Gothic?
description: NIGHTMARE ON MAIN STREET

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: David Sandlin

title: HBO's Movie on King Has Promoter Jabbing
description: HBO's decision to make a movie about Don King looks as odd as Rupert Murdoch's ordering his 20th Century Fox studio to film the life of his archenemy, Ted Turner. How objective could HBO be, seven years since one of boxing's biggest feuds began, when HBO refused to sign a $90 million deal with Mike Tyson if it meant agreeing to King's demand that it curb the analyst Larry Merchant's barbed criticisms of Tyson.

title: TEKNOR INDUSTRIAL AGREES TO BUY SACO SMARTVISION
description: Teknor Industrial Computers Inc. agreed yesterday to buy SACO Smartvision Inc., a maker of big screens for stadiums and arenas, for $78 million (Canadian), or $55 million (United States). Teknor, based in Boisbriand, Quebec, is to acquire closely held SACO of Montreal for 4.53 million shares and the rest in cash. The stock portion is valued at $31.7 million (Canadian), based on Teknor's closing share price yesterday of $7 (Canadian). The purchase complements Teknor's business because SACO's screens, which are used at sports arenas and concerts, will be operated by the company's high-end computers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIALKOFF, JACK
description: FIALKOFF-Jack. Beloved husband of Maxine. Devoted father of Jay and Steven. Adored grandfather of Jamie, Phoebe and Piper. Dear brother of Esta Smelson. Loving father-in-law of Iris and Marcia. Service is today at 11:30 A.M., ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn (near Avenue V).

title: Heart Checks Urged for Users of Diet Pills
description: Millions of Americans who took either of two diet pills removed from the market in September should get medical checkups for evidence of possible heart damage, Federal health officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALCONE, PHILIP F.
description: FALCONE-Philip F., 84. Of Jamaica, Queens, New York, on November 11. Beloved husband of Janet Wirth Falcone, devoted father of Philip F. Jr., Roger W. Falcone. Loving grandfather of Joshua, Rachel, Elizabeth and Michael. Loving brother of Michael, and the late Concetta and Joseph Falcone. A memorial service will be held Saturday, November 15, at 12:30 PM at St. Helen's Roman Catholic Church in Westfield, NJ.

title: Pure Color, Pure Shape: An Abstract Influence
description: Although he kvetched and moaned wittily about other artists and the art world, the pre-Minimalist painter Ad Reinhardt (1913-1967) owned up to a few mentors. A major one was the Dutch abstractionist Piet Mondrian (1872-1944), whose powerful, reductive influence pervaded the New York art scene well before he fled to the United States in 1940 to escape the war in Europe.

title: Gun Importers Are Rushing For Permits, Eye on Clinton
description: Amid indications that President Clinton intends to clamp down on imports of assault weapons, gun dealers have obtained permits to bring in thousands of these firearms before a deadline bars them from doing so.

title: Charges Are Reinstated Against Police Officer
description: Murder charges were reinstated yesterday against an off-duty New York City police officer accused of killing a 39-year-old Irish immigrant after an argument in a bar.

title: Return of Partisanship to Capitol Hill
description: As the 105th Congress ended its first session tonight, it could boast of one paramount, bipartisan achievement: the midsummer legislation to balance the budget and cut taxes. But the ill will, stalemate and destruction of the session's closing weeks point to a return to sharp partisanship next year.

title: Pill Found for Baldness; F.D.A. Backing Awaited
description: For as long as there has been baldness, there have been men, no doubt, who have wished for a little pill that might make their hair grow back -- or at least stop falling out.

title: In Apparent Shift, Tobacco Defender Seeks Industry Documents
description: Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., one of the tobacco industry's fiercest defenders in Congress, demanded yesterday that cigarette companies release hundreds of secret internal documents before lawmakers consider legislation to resolve legal and regulatory issues surrounding tobacco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENTHAL, HAROLD
description: LEVENTHAL-Harold. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member, and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Amiel Wohl, Rabbi

title: People
description: * Kate Holmes was named to the new position of senior vice president and media director at Long Haymes Carr, Winston-Salem, N.C., part of the Interpublic Group of Cos. She had been media director at Fallon McElligott, Minneapolis.

title: FOOTBALL: COLLEGE NOTEBOOK
description: Princeton-Yale

title: Hong Kong Journal; For China to Ponder: The Dark Side of Easy Street
description: Fruit Chan Kuo paints a different Hong Kong, not the Hong Kong of mirrored office towers, not of Gucci, Versace, Chanel, not of hushed Rolls-Royces and growling Mercedes, not a Hong Kong at ease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ESTHER QUITT
description: LEVINE-Esther Quitt. A Memorial Service will be held on Sunday Nov. 16, 1997, at 1 P.M. The Pleasantville Community Synagogue, 219 Bedford Road, Pleasantville, NY. Call the answering machine at 914-769-2672 for directions. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Esther Quitt Levine Scholarship Fund at the School of American Ballet, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, N.Y. 10023, or The Parents, Families, and Friends of Lesbians & Gays, 1101 14th Street N.W., Washington, D.C. 20005, would be greatly appreciated.

title: Mediterranean Fare
