description: ''Mediterranean'' has been a consistently appealing buzz word in the last few years, connoting both a great-tasting, healthful way of eating and the sunny warmth of life by the sea. These dozen places have a claim to the Mediterranean label. (Here are summaries, written by Eric Asimov, taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Racial Gap in Testing Is Really a Reading Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAINE, STEPHEN D.
description: PAINE-Stephen D. The Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute in Wiliamstown, MA., mourns the passing of our beloved friend Stephen D. Paine, a trustee since 1981. He immeasurably shaped and directed the Institute through his dedicated and active involvement. His wise counsel and passion for art and art museums will be sorely missed by everyone at The Clark, who valued his sage advice. Our hearts go out to his devoted wife Susan, who was such a vital support to him. Robert J. Geniesse, President, Michael Conforti, Director

title: Former Mayor Wins an Upset In Miami Ballot
description: Former Mayor Xavier Suarez upset Mayor Joe Carollo today in a runoff election that had been filled with mud-slinging and charges of ballot fraud.

title: Priests' Missive Reveals Tensions in Chicago Archdiocese
description: Six months after Francis E. George's installation as Archbishop of Chicago, one of the most influential archdioceses in the country, a group of prominent priests here has written a memorandum expressing concern that Archbishop George has not been consulting with pastors and has been too quick to micromanage even the smallest matters.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Beattie & Davidson

title: New Rules at U.S. Borders Provoke Criticism
description: Early one morning in August, Neil G. Shearar, a Canadian yachtsman bound for a Pacific sailing excursion, got in his car at his home in Vancouver, British Columbia, and headed for Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, as he had done many times before.

title: NEW STUDIES OFFER HOPE AND CAUTION ON AIDS THERAPIES
description: Powerful drug combinations being taken by many people infected with the AIDS virus do not eliminate it from the body, scientists have found. But neither does the virus develop resistance to the drugs in people who follow the strict schedule of medicine.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Susan Rothenberg

title: Girl Gets Care in Death That She Was Denied in Life
description: In death, the attention paid to Sabrina Green was exquisite. A white bow had been placed in her perfectly curled hair. A white dress of satin and lace had been placed on her body. And a white glove had been slipped on her right hand.

title: At Home Abroad; Meet Yesterday's Men
description: Richard Gephardt, meet William Hague. The Democratic leader in the U.S. House and the Conservative leader in Britain are pointing their countries and their parties in the same direction: backward toward economic and political disaster.

title: Utility Receives Offer for a Unit
description: Northeast Utilities received an unsolicited $1.4 billion cash offer from the nonprofit New Hampshire Electric Cooperative yesterday for its distribution service to 400,000 customers, the largest in New Hampshire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEINIGER, DAVID H.
description: SEINIGER-David H. Of Westhampton Beach on November 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Sandy, devoted father of Kimberley C. Seiniger, Torre K. Falkner, and David H. Seiniger, Jr., adored son of Charles and Torre Seiniger, dear brother of Tony Seiniger and Christine Mayer. Reposing Friday 2-4 and 2-9 PM Follett & Werner Funeral Home, 60 Mill Road, Westhampton Beach, New York. Funeral Service Saturday 9:30 A.M. St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Westhampton Beach. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Family Counseling Service, P.O. Box 1348, Westhampton Beach, New York.

title: New Video Releases
description: Love! Valour! Compassion!

title: FILM IN REVIEW
description: 'Bugis Street'

title: Walker Is the First Canadian M.V.P.
description: Canada's flag continued to fly high over baseball's post-season awards yesterday when Larry Walker of the Colorado Rockies was named the National League's most valuable player by a vote of the Baseball Writers Association of America. He became the first Canadian to win an m.v.p. award in either league.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: ''A thousand welcomes,'' said our waiter. ''Thank you for joining us.'' His enthusiasm was just the start of what proved to be an entirely surprising evening.

title: Metro Business; Tree is High, But Not Tall
description: Never mind the Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center, perennially one of the world's tallest. The people who run the observation decks atop Two World Trade Center have started looking for their own local evergreen with its own superlative: ''World's Highest Christmas Tree.''

title: Stacked Up At Boeing; Plane Giant Tries to Recover From Its Snarls in Production
description: The Boeing Company is especially proud of its gigantic assembly plant here, 30 miles north of Seattle. Cranes glide across the ceiling in a high-technology ballet, piecing together a true emblem of the modern age: the jumbo jet. Last year, 135,000 tourists visited the factory, which, covering 98.3 acres, could comfortably house all of Disneyland.

title: Black Panther Legacy Includes Crime and Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: HIDDEN HORRORS: A special report.; Uncovering the Guilty Footprints Along Zaire's Long Trail of Death
description: The rebellion in Congo that ended in the spring was conducted largely out of the sight of the rest of the world. Most of the fighting took place in remote jungles with impassable roads and decrepit communications, and rebel commanders barred journalists and aid workers from the combat zone.

title: Compromise in Congress Saves Amtrak but Eliminates Its Board
description: Amtrak will apparently survive its latest fiscal crisis under a compromise reached in the closing hours of the House and Senate sessions for the year. But the railroad's board will not; part of the agreement requires that the panel be replaced by the President in consultation with Congressional leaders.

title: With Lead in His Pockets And Heart on His Sleeve
description: John Savage is one actor who has never feared venturing to the brink of hysteria when disgorging the emotional lives of his often obsessive characters. And in ''The Mouse,'' a small sentimental comedy about the real-life boxer Bruce (the Mouse) Strauss, who gained notoriety in the 1970's and 80's as a tireless but inept ''professional opponent,'' Mr. Savage does an engaging take on the stock caricature of the cuddly loudmouthed palooka.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Tunga'

title: Chief of Staff For Whitman Will Resign
description: Harriet E. Derman, who has served as chief of staff to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman for the last 18 months, resigned today, saying that she wants to spend more time with family and friends.

title: Moonlighters Fleeing High Art and Letting Their Hair Down
description: There was a good deal of curiosity about Ballet: The Daring Project when the company first performed in New York in 1995. Could the ''daring'' refer to a major donor? Was it an acronym?

title: First Foreigner to Lead Japanese Company Retires
description: The Mazda Motors Corporation said today that Henry D. G. Wallace, the first gaijin, or foreigner, to head a Japanese company, was retiring.

title: Sale of One Penn Plaza Could Happen Today
description: Steven Roth's Vornado Realty Trust is expected to win out in the bidding for One Penn Plaza, a 2.4-million-square-foot tower next to Madison Square Garden, in a deal that would give the publicly traded company control of about one-third of the real estate in the neighborhood.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DREW NIEPORENT, the owner of Nobu, TriBeCa Grill and Montrachet restaurants, and his wife, ANN NIEPORENT, long suspected that something was wrong with their son, Andrew, 10, but were repeatedly assured that he was fine and would grow out of his hyperactive behavior.

title: Court Rules Against CNN
description: In a case that could restrict efforts by news organizations to accompany law enforcement officials on searches of private property, a Federal court ruled today that the Government and a CNN news crew violated a Montana rancher's rights when CNN recorded a search for evidence that he had been poisoning eagles.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column on Nov. 5 about a public reading of an Ernest Hemingway story by his son John Hadley Nicanor Hemingway misidentified the bookstore owner in Paris who sold copies of Hemingway's first book. She was Sylvia Beach. (Sylvia Plath, who died in 1963, was a poet.)

title: Regents Ready to Get Tougher on Students
description: In the biggest overhaul of high school standards in two decades, the State Board of Regents will formally vote today to make it harder to earn a diploma in New York, requiring that students in the class of 2005 and beyond take three years each of mathematics and science and pass college-preparatory exams in five subjects.

title: Iraq Carries Out Threat to Expel U.S. Inspectors
description: Iraq carried out its threat to expel American weapons inspectors today, rebuffing every diplomatic attempt to resolve the impasse and propelling the Clinton Administration closer to a military response.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WASHINGTON MUTUAL INC., Seattle, said it would close 85 branches in California early next year as part of its consolidation after its $8 billion merger with Great Western Financial Corp.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a study showing that Mevacor, a cholesterol-lowering drug made by Merck & Company, could help healthy middle-aged people with ordinary cholesterol levels reduce their risk of heart trouble misstated the drug's generic name. It is lovastatin, not pravastatin. (Pravastatin, made by theBristol-Myers Squibb Company, is sold under the brand name Pravachol. That drug figured in an Australian doctor's study on the usefulness of cholesterol-lowering medicines for those with heart disease.)

title: A Balanced Act: Childs and Ward
description: It must have been something to see when the angelic Charlie Ward got a little hot under the halo.

title: Holik Moves to the Front of the Line
description: There are a number of reasons the Devils are having so much success so far this season. Some say the major ones is the goaltending of Martin Brodeur and the effectiveness of Coach Jacques Lemaire's defensive system. Others, though, cite the contribution of Bobby Holik.

title: Despite Market Turmoil, Cash Keeps Pouring Into Mutual Funds
description: In a demonstration of resilience following October's stock market turmoil, mutual fund investors have continued to funnel new money this month into mutual funds that invest in the largest American stocks, analysts say.

title: Reality Bites But Slackers Can Dream
description: Art Alexakis, the leader of Everclear, has spent his entire adult life aiming to be where he was Tuesday night at Irving Plaza: to stand, at age 35, in front of a roomful of people half his age who have memorized his lyrics and will thrash passionately to his beat. While many of his peers turned to experimentalism or roots music, or settled for smaller careers, Mr. Alexakis never abandoned his conviction that he should be a rock star. He just kept trying different formulas until he found the one that worked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUMWAY, FLOYD M.
description: SHUMWAY-Floyd M. Died on November 12, 1997. Services November 17, 2:00 P.M., First Church of Christ, New Haven, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEAVER, JOHN G.
description: WEAVER-John G. On November 6th, at age 82. After Wittenberg University he started as a sportswriter, and following service in World War II he held marketing positions at Procter & Gamble, Swift & Co., Crosley and Benton & Bowles. Later he was Communications Director for the U.S. Committee for UNICEF and the Valley Health Plan in Amherst, Mass. An avid sailor, he was a longtime member of the Larchmont Yacht Club. He leaves his loving wife of fifty-six years, Betty A. Weaver, sons Thomas, David and Richard, and grandchildren Elisabeth, Nicholas and Emma.

title: An Officer's Dream Is Shattered by a Lie
description: Jackie Flanagan is back working in a butcher shop, a long way professionally from her beat as the first and only female police officer in this community on the bluffs above the Hudson River.

title: Crisis in Asia No Big Threat, Fed Chief Says
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, teamed up with the Clinton Administration today to offer soothing comments about the turmoil in global markets, saying the problems in Asia and elsewhere should not threaten prosperity in the United States or the soundness of the nation's financial system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, PAUL
description: FRIED-Paul. Beloved husband of Regina, devoted father of Pamela Rechtschaffen, adored grandfather of Andrew and Eric. Service Friday, 10 A.M., Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Chance Encounter Enlivens a Vapid Life
description: In a career of major ups (''Leaving Las Vegas'') and downs (''Liebestraum,'' ''Mr. Jones''), Mike Figgis takes a regrettable swan dive with ''One-Night Stand.'' Though it has the inviting surface allure of all this musician-turned-filmmaker's richly textured work, this film dwells so earnestly on such empty characters that its slinkier virtues become more oppressive than steamy.

title: Chase's Trading Losses in October Totaled $160 Million Before Taxes
description: Whipsawed by the economic turmoil sweeping across Asia and Latin America, the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's largest bank, said yesterday that it had suffered a pretax trading loss of $160 million for October.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 29 about a campaign by preservation groups to restore part of Ellis Island misstated some of the amounts raised by two groups. Loews Hotels requested that $20,000 of the money it has contributed to the World Monuments Fund, not $10,000, be earmarked for the project. And the Landmarks Conservancy raised about $20,000 worth of materials and labor, not $30,000, from nine private contractors.

title: The Dog Ate My 7:55 From Stamford ; Train Late? Railroads Write Nervous Commuters an Excuse
description: Striding through Grand Central Terminal, Leslie Fellows broadcasts the telltale signs of tardiness. You can see it in the purposeful set of her gaze, the shoulders hunched slightly forward, the glasses slightly askew.

title: Players' Salaries Passed $1 Billion Mark
description: General managers suffered a double dose of frustration today as their annual fall meetings began. They were able to talk about trades all they wanted, but they cannot make any until after the expansion draft next Tuesday. And they received a salary report that painfully reminded them how much they spent on their players this year.

title: INSIDE
description: Mourners recall the sad life of 9-year-old Sabrina Green.

title: James Laughlin, Publisher With Bold Taste, Dies at 83
description: James Laughlin, the fiercely independent publisher, editor and poet, who, as the founder and longtime head of New Directions, published many of the most consequential and revolutionary writers of his time, died Wednesday on the way to Sharon Hospital from his home in Norfolk, Conn. He was 83.

title: Sports of The Times; Yanks Need To Be Patient On Williams
description: THIS notion that the Yankees must trade Bernie Williams if they do not sign him to a long-term contract within several weeks is patently absurd, nothing more than a line of organizational propaganda as George Steinbrenner tries to pressure Williams into surrendering the leverage he has waited years to have.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times or by contributors of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.

title: Paybacks for Riders Sought As Transit Surplus Increases
description: The cash surplus at New York City Transit grew by an additional $19 million during September as riders continued to flock to buses and subways, according to figures to be officially released next week.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Tobias Rehberger

title: Suspect Is Still Being Sought In Trade Center Bomb Case
description: With the conviction on Wednesday of the former fugitive Ramzi Ahmed Yousef in the World Trade Center bombing, an Indiana native named Abdul Rahman Yasin now inherits the dubious distinction of The Man Who Got Away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, ANNIE
description: ADAMS-Annie. The American Friends of Tel Aviv University is profoundly saddened by the untimely passing of our much beloved and cherished friend, Annie Adams, from Montreal, Canada. A recipient of an Honorary Doctorate from Tel Aviv University and a member of its Board of Governors, she touched us with her personal warmth and enthusiastic dedication to the University. We mourn her death and cherish our memories of her kindness and compassion. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her devoted husband, Marcel, their children, Sylvan, Julian, Linda and Lenora and their families, and her mother, Shoshana Cohen. The American Friends of Tel Aviv University Bernard Rapoport, Chairman, Board of Directors Melvin S. Taub, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Topchik, President Jules Love, Executive V.P.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It is utterly boneheaded for Congress to fail to meet the commitments that the United States has at the U.N. in terms of our arrears.''

title: Rumor Sends Shares Up At Indonesian Bank
description: Shares of Bank Danamon, one of Indonesia's largest banks, surged as much as 37 percent yesterday on speculation it was a takeover target. The speculation was given credence because the central bank has been urging Indonesia's banks to merge or go out of business. Bank Indonesia's aim is to forge a stronger financial sector, and last week it made a start by closing 16 of the wobbliest banks.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies yesterday about Sotheby's auction of art from the estate of the hotelier Evelyn Sharp was published in error. The painting shown, which sold for $6 million, was ''Nudes,'' a 1934 work by Picasso. (Modigliani's 1917-18 ''Reclining Nude With Arms Raised'' failed to find a buyer.)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: CONGRESS DEPRIVES CLINTON OF MONEY FOR U.N. AND I.M.F.
description: Congress voted today to defeat the carefully negotiated plan to make overdue payments to the United Nations and rejected contributing more money to the International Monetary Fund to help stave off foreign financial crises.

title: Towing Companies Fight Over Service Contract
description: Two towing companies are fighting over a prized state concession to offer towing service on a 13.6-mile stretch of the Garden State Parkway.

title: Jets' Grind-It-Out Game Not What It Used to Be
description: It has been years since Bill Parcells stood on a podium the morning after a Super Bowl and proclaimed, defiantly, to those who said he was old-fashioned, ''Power football still wins.''

title: Jury in C.I.A. Killings Considers Death Penalty
description: In a murder case that reverberated around the world, a jury in Virginia is set to decide on Friday whether to impose the death penalty on a Pakistani immigrant convicted of killing two Central Intelligence Agency employees.

title: Columbia Ouster Costs Nearly $10 Million
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to pay its former chairman and chief executive nearly $10 million when he was forced out in July in the wake of an unfolding criminal investigation of the company.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology and Design; New Writing on the Wall at Ford
description: IS there a Ford in your future? If so, its styling may already be taking shape in the brain of J. Mays, a fast-rising designer who recently took the top design job at the Ford Motor Company.

title: Cynic vs. Killer: Who's More Macho?
description: One of the few compensatory pleasures of ''The Jackal,'' an earnest, gadget-crazed thriller that grows steadily more preposterous as it skids off the track of its own premise, is the opportunity to watch Richard Gere play a character who is something more than a suave cynic flashing facetious little grins. As Declan Mulqueen, a jailed I.R.A. soldier recruited by the F.B.I. to help find a mysterious terrorist-for-hire whom only he can identify, Mr. Gere deftly adopts an Irish accent to play a man of passionate conviction. Without making his character a martyr, Mr. Gere imbues Declan with an ambivalent mixture of cunning and vulnerability.

title: Senate Panel Fails to Vote On Nominee For Rights Job
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today failed to act on the nomination of Bill Lann Lee to head the Justice Department's civil rights division, leaving his prospects for getting the job dim, but uncertain.

title: DELTA SAYS IT WILL PURCHASE 10 MORE PLANES FROM BOEING
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. said yesterday that it would exercise options to buy 10 Boeing 777 wide-body planes, valued at $1.42 billion, for use on international flights. The purchase adds to a $6.7 billion order for 106 Boeing aircraft that was signed last month. Delta is one of three major carriers -- along with American Airlines and Continental Airlines -- to sign 20-year contracts to buy planes only from Boeing. Under its original contract, Delta received options to buy aircraft through 2018.

title: Gettysburg Remembered
description: To the Editor:

title: Filmmaker Falls for The Tango In Paris
description: In an act of wild hubris, Sally Potter assumes center stage in her new film about dance and love. Ms. Potter, celebrated for her rarefied ''Orlando,'' this time appears before the camera in an autobiographical role. Stiffly playing a filmmaker with a growing passion for the tango, she makes this a handsome, drily meticulous film with no real fire anywhere beyond its supple dance scenes. The lessons are numbered and catalogued with an obsessive care like that of Peter Greenaway, but this material has little of his corresponding complexity.

title: PRIME RETAIL AGREES TO ACQUIRE HORIZON GROUP
description: Prime Retail Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the factory-outlet developer Horizon Group Inc. for nearly $365 million in stock and the assumption of $540.4 million in debt. The combined company would be the nation's largest owner of factory outlet centers, with 43 centers in 25 states. Prime Retail, based in Baltimore, is a real estate investment trust. Under the agreement, it will pay $12.87, or 0.2 of a preferred share and 0.597 of a common share, for each Horizon share outstanding. Holders of Horizon common partnership units may also receive preferred and common units in Prime Retail L.P., a unit of Prime Retail. Before the acquisition, Horizon, which is based in Norton Shores, Mich., plans to spin off 17 of its worst-performing outlet centers.

title: Residential Real Estate ; Co-op in Unusual Site Pushes Plan Toward Goal
description: Like a sentinel, the 42-story Citylights building looms over Long Island City's scattering of stooped row houses and aluminum-sided homes with their chain-link-fenced backyards, dwarfing even the smokestacks of abandoned factories and the steeple of St. Mary's Church just to the east.

title: Man Who Promised Profits Pleads Guilty in $95 Million Fraud
description: A California man pleaded guilty in Manhattan yesterday to Federal charges that he defrauded nearly 1,600 investors nationwide of more than $95 million by promising them quick profits through buying the life insurance policies of terminally ill people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KADE, MILTON
description: KADE-Milton. Beloved husband of Estelle, loving father of Iana Davis, Daryl Schoenbach and Paul. Cherished brother of Sam Kade, Fay Choleff and Norma Kade. Funeral service today, 1pm, Sinai Chapels 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows.

title: Misguided Iran Sanctions
description: To the Editor:

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Holyfield Wants Lewis Fight to Unify Title
description: Becoming the undisputed heavyweight champion is still paramount in the mind of Evander Holyfield, who stopped Michael Moorer in eight rounds last Saturday night in Las Vegas, Nev., to gain control of the both the World Boxing Association and International Boxing Federation titles.

title: One Immigrant Breathes Free; Another Has No Hope
description: For the first time in 12 years, 18-year-old Rafael Baez can celebrate an American Thanksgiving without anxiety. Finally, his adopted country has released him and his family from immigration limbo.

title: Shortsighted Arab Diplomacy
description: Arab countries that favor long-term stability in the Middle East are making a sad mistake by boycotting this weekend's economic conference in Qatar and by resisting more forceful steps to keep Saddam Hussein from developing weapons of mass destruction.

title: Life or Death? Prosecutors Needn't Justify
description: AS a prosecutor in the age of capital punishment, ''You're playing God,'' was how the Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, put it a few months ago.

title: Focus for M.B.A.'s Turns to Women
description: Tacitly acknowledging that its vaunted case studies do not reflect the reality of the late-90's workplace, the Harvard Business School plans to add more case studies that feature women in senior management.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELY, SUSAN BARCLAY
description: ELY-Susan Barclay. Of Locust Valley, Long Island, N.Y. on November 8, 1997. Beloved wife of Stephen. Loving mother of Lyda, Lynn, Sara and Sterling. Dear daughter of Lyda Hall, and the late Henry Barclay. Beloved sister of Anthony and Rutgers Barclay. Memorial Service St. John's of Lattingtown on the 15th of November at 11AM. In lieu of flowers donations to American Red Cross, Grenville Baker Boys and Girls Club and Save the Children.

title: A Mafia Widow's Brood: Smart, Trashy and Powerful
description: As a meek Mafia widow swathed in black, Vanessa Redgrave takes target practice at a tree on the grounds of her Palermo estate. ''Mama, Mama,'' her daughters-in-law yell as they run out of the house. They look devoted to their hair stylists and dressed for the Rainbow Room. In fact, the Luciano women have been hanging around the villa, mourning because the men in the family, Roberto Luciano (Dennis Farina) and his three sons, have been murdered with poisoned wine. Though the actresses play this straight-faced, we know that Vanessa Redgrave knows better. That is the saving feature of the mini-series ''Bella Mafia'': at moments, it all but acknowledges that it's a hoot.

title: Between a Rock And the Way Down
description: Every one of my handful of rock-climbing adventures has made me revisit several questions.

title: Racial Gap in Testing Is Really a Reading Gap; How to Grade?
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Miami Now Extends Beyond Deco
description: Move over, ''Miami Vice.'' Make ready for Miami nice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEID, HOWARD
description: SCHNEID-Howard. Died suddenly November 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Terry Martin. Loving father of Loren, Pernod, Jared and Dana Doran. Dedicated graphic artist and piano playing master chef who loved life in Haiti, New York City and Paris. Howard, you will be missed by all who love you.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Writing a book may be a solitary occupation that may be desirable considering what follows publication. Consider, for example, the whirlwind schedule of THOMAS CAPLAN, whose third novel, ''Grace and Favor,'' has just been published by St. Martin's Press.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSPAN, JULIUS
description: GREENSPAN-Julius. On November 12. Beloved husband of Esther. Father of Natalie Andersen and Madge Rosenberg. Father-in-law of Barry Rosenberg. Brother of Sandra Wolovnik and Ben Greenspan. Grandfather of Peter, Lili and Joanna Rosenberg. Founder of Abacrome Inc.

title: Golf's Leading Groups Start an Ambitious Expansion Project
description: The crowd grew silent yesterday morning as Earl Woods stood in Central Park, his voice cracking with emotion.

title: Both Injuries And the Cavs Take a Toll On the Nets
description: If the Nets' depth chart gets any thinner, Coach John Calipari will be able to write out his available roster on an index card.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: First Lady's Ex-Aide Denies Soliciting Campaign Money
description: The First Lady's former chief of staff told House investigators today that Johnny Chung, a discredited fund-raiser in President Clinton's re-election, was such a relentless pest in seeking Administration access that his $50,000 campaign donation was finally accepted at the White House to ''quiet him,'' not to transact some improper quid pro quo.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Pat Steir

title: Misguided Iran Sanctions
description: To the Editor:

title: Antiques; At a Fair, Modernism Must-Haves
description: Architects do it. Decorators do it. Young collectors can't help but do it. Like truffle hunters, they all root around at the annual Modernism fair at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue and 67th Street, sniffing out ''les musts de 20th-century modernism'': a Jacques Adnet chair, a Jean Royere lamp, an Andre Arbus console or anything in blond wood from the American designers Charles Eames, George Nelson, Eero Saarinen and Donald Deskey.

title: On My Mind; The Problem With Bibi
description: Benjamin Netanyahu has a problem. If he allows it to go on, it can overshadow his own substantial accomplishments as Prime Minister of Israel.

title: Cassell and Gatling Off Ballot
description: Chris Gatling and Sam Cassell both called it politics. Both Nets were left off the All-Star Game ballot, which was released today. But four other teammates made it: Kendall Gill, Jayson Williams, Kerry Kittles and the rookie Keith Van Horn. The omissions of Gatling and Cassell were curious because Gatling was named to the All-Star Game last year and Cassell is leading the Nets in scoring. ''Chris Gatling has really been wronged, because he was an All-Star,'' Nets General Manager John Nash said. ''How can a guy who was in the game last year not be on the ballot?''

title: Bowness Won't Hang His Head
description: Three hours after animatedly criticizing his players, Islanders Coach Rick Bowness invited them into his hotel room here in the early hours today for beer, pizza and a hefty portion of camaraderie.

title: Judge Kills Texas Affirmative Action Plan
description: Barely one week after Houston voters decided against banning affirmative action in the city's contracting and hiring, a Federal judge today threw out a similar program for the county transit authority, accompanying his ruling with a blistering criticism of affirmative action that seems likely to fuel the nation's unresolved legal and political debate over the issue.

title: Latest Turn in Iraqi Dispute Lifts Crude Oil Prices by 1%
description: Crude oil rose yesterday after Iraq ordered the immediate expulsion of American arms inspectors in a dispute that could lead to a military confrontation in the Middle East.

title: A Utopian Whose Vision Remains Intact
description: Good Lord, the man was a polymath: real achievements in painting, sculpture, photography and film; in typography; in industrial, commercial, exhibition and stage design; in theory and in education. It never occurred to him to think one field more important than another; the arts were meant to contribute to society, and it didn't much matter which one did the work.

title: Echoes of H. G. Wells, Rhythms of Lou Reed
description: Time is like love, ineffable and transcendent; time implies death, inevitable and natural. Those are the bromidic lessons of ''Time Rocker,'' the collaboration of Robert Wilson (direction and design), Lou Reed (songs and music) and Darryl Pinckney (text), which had its first of 10 performances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday night.

title: Dollar Finishes Lower vs. Yen For the First Time in 10 Days
description: The dollar ended lower against the yen yesterday for the first time in 10 days on concern that the Bank of Japan might sell dollars to curb the United States currency's rise.

title: Just Got In, but He's Eager To Take In a Little Theater
description: ''The Man Who Knew Too Little'' is yet another movie high on concept and low on execution.

title: Metro Business; Goodwill Changes Its Logo
description: Goodwill Industries of Greater New York Inc. is changing the logo on its clothing collection bins in an effort to differentiate the nonprofit charity from the growing number of for-profit salvage organizations that have entered the collection business.

title: U.F.O. Fan Ruled Unfit for Trial in Long Island Murder Plot
description: John J. Ford, a U.F.O. enthusiast accused of masterminding a plot to assassinate three political officials in Suffolk County, was found unfit to stand trial today. A judge ordered that he be sent to an upstate psychiatric institution for at least a year.

title: COOPER AGREES TO BUY BRITISH COMPANY FOR $280 MILLION
description: Cooper Industries, a Houston-based auto parts maker, agreed yesterday to buy Menvier-Swain Group P.L.C., a British lighting and security company, for $:164.5 million ($280 million) in cash. Cooper, which makes electrical, industrial and automotive products like Champion spark plugs and Anco windshield wipers, offered 310 pence a share. Menvier shares closed up 41 pence, or 15 percent, to 302 pence. Cooper's shares slipped 12.5 cents, to $50.0625.

title: A Renoir Leads a Conservative Night at Auction
description: Welcome to the age of auction realism. With the exception of once-in-a-lifetime sales like Monday night's auction at Christie's of contemporary and modern art from the collection of Victor and Sally Ganz, when buyers were willing to pay big prices for art that just wouldn't be available again, buyers for the most part are far more careful at auctions these days. It's cool to pay as little as possible; paying too much, as buyers did in the late 1980's, is definitely not the thing to do.

title: Brazilian Slowdown Forces Rethinking and Retrenching
description: Southeast Asian auto sales have collapsed, and now the other shoe has dropped for the world's biggest auto makers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLISTER, LOUIS H.
description: HOLLISTER-Louis H. November 11, 1997. Beloved son of the late Buell and Louise Hollister. Services and interment private.

title: $1 Million Is Approved To Support Van Pools
description: In an effort to comply with the Federal Clean Air Act, New Jersey Transit yesterday approved spending $1 million to subsidize van pool fares for the 2,500 people who commute that way.

title: Giants Hoping to Stay Out Of the Meadowlands Wind
description: Dave Brown calls it ''Dead Man's Corner'' at Giants Stadium, and he only laughs when asked if he is trying to give credence to the old rumors that Jimmy Hoffa is buried somewhere at the football stadium in the Meadowlands.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING ; A Canadian agency group hopes to persuade potential clients to take a look north of the border.
description: WHEN advertisers introduce campaigns with provocative or contentious creative elements, they often say they are trying to ''push the boundaries.'' Now an agency association is asking them to consider doing that literally.

title: Facing Storm, Regents Alter Teacher Plan
description: Facing fierce opposition from the powerful teachers union, the State Board of Regents has backed away from a proposal that would have ended lifetime licenses for new teachers in New York. Instead, the board is considering a requirement that all teachers pass performance reviews every five years or face dismissal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ORRIN S., M.D.
description: STERN-Orrin S., M.D. Died on Tuesday, November 11 in Boca Raton, FL. He was born in 1937. He trained in general surgery at Berkshire Medical Center and NYU Medical Center in plastic surgery. He was the beloved husband of Jeffrie. Father of Rachel, Rebecca, and Jamie. Grandfather of Samantha and brother of Mark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENWALD, SHIRLEY
description: GREENWALD-Shirley. On November 12, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, loving mother of Gloria and Joan, dear mother-inlaw of Seymour and Joseph, cherished grandmother of Leslie, Hadley, Pamela, Craig and Dana, great-grandmother of Brandon, Jesse, Ryan and Matthew, devoted sister of Belle and Robert. Service today 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Calmer Trading Overseas Helps Bolster U.S. Stocks
description: Stocks ended higher yesterday, bolstered in part by calmer markets overseas and by expectations that economic slowdowns in Asia and Latin America would keep United States interest rates low.

title: S.D. Paine, 65, Art Collector and Donor
description: Stephen D. Paine, an art collector and museum benefactor, died on Saturday at Beth Israel Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 65 and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: In Slap at U.S., Israel Reduces Role at Talks
description: With growing numbers of Arab countries staying away from the Middle East economic conference in Doha, Qatar, to protest against Israel's policies, Israel announced today that Foreign Minister David Levy would not attend.

title: A Bold Start Stretched To 16 Fruitless Months
description: On July 28, 1996, 11 days after the fiery destruction of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, James K. Kallstrom, the top F.B.I. official in the crash inquiry, displayed the fierce confidence of a seasoned crime fighter, announcing at a news conference: ''I think within the next 48 hours we'll get something that we think is going to give us the clues that we need.''

title: From a Fantasy Film, Luxury Transformed
description: Matthew Barney is as obscure as he is flamboyant and considerably more elusive, in all ways, than his media-crazed doppelganger, Damien Hirst of England. Working in film and sculpture, with a strong performance-art component, Mr. Barney continues to push the envelope of his eccentric ideas about beauty, sexual ambiguity, symbolic narrative and the body's potential for transformation. Still, it helps to remember that he is a young, developing artist who does some things better than others, despite his considerable achievement and influence.

title: Looking at Cars Through a Critical Eye
description: As J. Mays takes Ford's top design job, his best-known work, the Volkswagen Concept One, above, is coming to market as a reborn VW Beetle. A critic of backward-looking styling, the outspoken Mr. Mays describes the Concept One as ''very modern.'' Here are some of his other picks and pans in auto design.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODBODY, MARY BLAIR
description: GOODBODY-Mary Blair, 89. Widow of Harold P. Goodbody Sr., died November 13 in Williamstown, MA. Survivors include a daughter, Sally G. Arrowsmith Norris and three sons, James B. Goodbody, Harold P. Goodbody Jr. and William K. Goodbody. Funeral and burial services will be held November 18 in Williamstown. In lieu of flowers contributions in memory of Mrs. Goodbody may be made to either St. John's Episcopal Church or to the Harold P. and Mary B. Goodbody Fund at Williams College through the office of the George M. Hopkins Funeral Home, 61-67 Spring Street, Williamstown, MA 01267.

title: William Matthews, 55, Poet Who Won Prestigious Awards
description: William Matthews, a poet who was praised for his personal voice and who won the National Book Critics Circle Award in 1996, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 55.

title: With Cinderella in His Cab, A Prole Becomes a Prince
description: In ''Nick and Jane,'' a likable little film with no great urge to set the world on fire, opposites collide. Jane (Dana Wheeler-Nicholson): we know all about her from her first scene, in which she rides in a limousine while working her laptop and cell phone and making plans for a business meeting. As if that weren't unhappy enough, Jane is seen avoiding a lunch with friends (''I can't, I have too much work'') and dealing with a yuppie boyfriend who uses the phrase ''No can do'' in conversation. Clearly Jane is ready for a change of scenery.

title: SUNY Chief Backs Leader At New Paltz
description: The Chancellor of the State University of New York expressed confidence yesterday in Roger W. Bowen, the president of SUNY at New Paltz, who has been attacked for allowing a conference that included sessions on sadomasochism and sex toys to take place on campus earlier this month.

title: Three Opening Specialty Agency
description: Three executives who create, produce and direct television commercials are opening Hungry Man, a company specializing in commercials and films.

title: F.B.I. Inquiry Over, Safety Board Seeks Flaw in Flight 800
description: With the Federal Bureau of Investigation ruling out crime as the cause of the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 off the coast of Long Island last year, the National Transportation Safety Board is now engaged in an aviation engineer's worst nightmare: the search for a mysterious flaw that may be unique or may be lurking in airplanes still flying.

title: A Feeling We're Not in Russia Anymore
description: Hardly a moment passes in ''Anastasia,'' 20th Century Fox's splashy foray into the Disney-ruled sweepstakes of the animated musical, when you don't have the queasy feeling that a nervous corporate committee was breathing down the neck of this unfortunate movie, forcing it to be all things to all people no matter what had to be sacrificed in elementary common sense.

title: In the Fog, A New Fagin Is a Mensch
description: In the wonderful world of Disney, Oliver Twist and Fagin make a getting-to-know-you buddy movie: the genteel but spunky young orphan finds a pal in the soft-hearted if close-fisted old thief.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Don't Compare Bork To Clinton Nominee
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANK, SUSAN
description: HANK-Susan. Beloved daughter of Selma Horowitz, loving sister of Barbara Horowitz and John Meyer, cherished sister-in-law of Ralph Slone, devoted aunt of David Slone, wonderful friend to so many, and especially Mommy to her ''girls'' Rose and June Ann. Susan held leadership positions in refugee resettlement organizations and with numerous charities. She was a Member of the Board of the Krohns Disease Foundation and was a benefactress to many charities related to Krohns disease and animal welfare. Susan was a partner in Hank-Kross Ltd., a legal recruitment firm in New York. In a difficult and often non-feeling business, she exhibited integrity and compassion. A most remarkable woman, she will be remembered for her keen intelligence, her generous spirit, her strong moral and religious convictions, and her hilarious wit. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, at Amsterdam Avenue at 9:30 A.M., today. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the ASPCA in the memory of Susan H. Hank. All her family and friends.

title: Racial Gap in Testing Is Really a Reading Gap; Congress Can Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the H.I.V. cases in Chautauqua County, N.Y., linked by officials to one man included a town erroneously among those where they occurred. Cases were reported in Jamestown, Dunkirk, Fredonia and Kennedy, but none in Mayville, the county seat shown in the picture.

title: From Albany and City Hall, Stars That Don't Always Ascend
description: Two truths about New York mayors and governors have endured for most of this century. The first is that the most successful -- from Dewey to Lindsay, from Rockefeller to Cuomo -- often think they have what it takes to win national office. The second is that, as a rule, they do not.

title: An Ultimatum for Iraq
description: Perhaps the most important of the United Nations Security Council's decisions after the Persian Gulf war in 1991 was its resolution that Iraq's program to build weapons of mass destruction must be eliminated.

title: When Cash And Culture Fell in Love, They Begat A Museum
description: ''A Grand Design'' happens to be a beautiful exhibition, worth a trip from New York City, or anywhere else within reason, to see the sculptures, paintings, furniture, prints, clothing designs, photographs and so on from the great Victoria and Albert Museum in London, handsomely installed at the Baltimore Museum of Art.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 12
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: YACHTING: WHITBREAD ROUND THE WORLD RACE -- A SAILOR'S JOURNAL; Sitting Off Cape Town, Waiting for the Wind
description: Ten yachts, all about 64 feet long with a maximum crew of 12, completed the grueling first leg of the Whitbread Round the World Race from Southampton, England, to Cape Town. Nine boats restarted the 31,600-nautical-mile race last Saturday for a 4,700-nautical-mile voyage from Cape Town to Fremantle, Australia. The route is through the treacherous Southern Ocean, where wind and weather conditions are as brutish as they are capricious. The competitors are hoping the trip will take about 16 days.

title: Man and Teen-Ager Hurt In Fights Among Youths
description: A 32-year-old man was slashed across the face yesterday afternoon while trying to break up a fight among teen-age girls in the Atlantic Avenue subway station in Brooklyn, the police said. A separate fight among teen-agers in Queens left a 16-year-old boy injured.

title: THEATER REVIEW
description: In need of a psychic recharge? Here's some advice. Mosey on down to the Westbeth Theater Center on Bank Street, grab a drink and let Sandra Bernhard explain all of life to you.

title: Depositors In Indonesia Count Losses As Banks Shut
description: The economy was suddenly collapsing and the 72-year-old construction contractor was worried about his savings. ''Is this bank in trouble?'' he said he asked the tellers. ''They said no, so I calmed down.''

title: Jury Hears of McVeigh Remarks About Nichols and Bomb Making
description: Several months before the Oklahoma City bombing, Timothy J. McVeigh said Terry L. Nichols ''no longer wanted to help him mix the bomb,'' the Government's chief witness testified today.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Andrea Fraser

title: Hospitals Are Promised A Reimbursement Plan
description: Legislative leaders promised yesterday to establish a permanent means of reimbursing hospitals for treating uninsured patients by Dec. 31 -- the day that the state's current program expires.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASS, ELLIOTT
description: BASS-Elliott. On November 12, 1997. Loving husband of Judy Cory, beloved father of Carla, Daniel, Franklin and Sharon. Stepfather of Karen, Paul, Darcy, Mark and Laurel. Adoring grandfather of David, Alexis, Emily, Katie, Allison, Julia and Nora. Services on Friday, November 14, 12:15 P.M., at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 16.

title: A Coloratura Sees a New Role As a Departure, Not a Danger
description: Ruth Ann Swenson has not gotten to where she is by taking risks. At 38, she is one of the leading lyric coloratura sopranos of her generation. But she has exercised uncommon caution in choosing repertory.

title: Lawrence Wins In Semifinal
description: In the opening game of the Long Island high school football playoffs yesterday, Lawrence (8-0-1) overcame a 12-0 halftime deficit to defeat Carey (6-3) by 15-12 in a Nassau County Conference II semifinal game at Hofstra University.

title: Metro Business; Trust Buys Ohrbach's Site
description: Health and Retirement Properties Trust, a real estate investment trust based in Newton, Mass., has bought the former Ohrbach's department store at 7 West 34th Street for $110 million. The building is the headquarters of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York and Fairchild Publications.

title: Racial Gap in Testing Is Really a Reading Gap; Admissions Windfall
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SMITH, G.E. KIDDER
description: SMITH-G.E. Kidder. A memorial service will be held for Kidder Smith on Monday, November 17, 11AM at the Church of the Epiphany, 1393 York Avenue at 74 Street.

title: INSIDE
description: Israel Downgrades Meeting

title: World News Briefs; Mexico Denies Welders Right to Pick a Union
description: Despite balloting last month in which workers voted overwhelmingly to switch unions, a Government labor board has denied a request by welders at an automotive chassis factory in Tijuana to replace the Government-controlled union at their plant.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DIMSTON, BLANCHE
description: DIMSTON-Blanche. The smell of the day, the taste of the night, we miss being part of your pleasure in it all.

title: Kennedy Did Not Use I.R.S. as a Weapon
description: To the Editor:

title: Keenan, Canucks' New Coach, and Messier Reunite
description: As coach of the Rangers during the peak of the Mark Messier era, Mike Keenan won a Stanley Cup but could not coexist with General Manager Neil Smith. Their bitter rift led to Keenan's departure in 1994 after one tense and successful season.

title: Hey, Look Me Over (for $5,000)
description: New York, one of the nation's most solidly Democratic states, is suddenly awash with famous Republican politicians. Since his re-election this month Mayor Rudolph Giuliani of New York City has been profiled all over the national media, visited by a Presidential hopeful, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, and has turned down an invitation from Iowa Republicans to attend a casting call for national candidates. Meanwhile, Gov. George Pataki has been on a stealth tour of the West and South, speaking privately to Republican loyalists and sacking contributions of up to $5,000.

title: N.Y.R.A. Pulls Signal To Off-Track Outlets
description: There were no Aqueduct races on local cable television and in Off-Track Betting outlets yesterday as the New York Racing Association yanked the signal from the track to New York City OTB in a continuing financial dispute.

title: Iraqi Action Halts Effort To Curb Arms
description: Iraq's expulsion of six American weapons inspectors today brought an effective halt to an effort that has been at the center of the United Nations mission in Iraq for nearly seven years. Richard Butler, the head of the United Nations team charged with ferreting out Iraqi efforts to acquire weapons of mass destruction, said that only a skeleton staff would be left in place after all United Nations inspectors are withdrawn Friday.

title: South African Tycoons Apologize for Gaining From Apartheid
description: For the last three days, South Africa has been treated to a remarkable sight: the chief executives of the nation's biggest corporations and banks lining up to apologize for their actions over the last century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIEDER, AL
description: RIEDER-Al. The Officers, Members of the Board and Administration of OHEL, BAIS EZRA and The Lifetime Care Foundation for the Jewish Disabled mourn the passing of the beloved brother of Rabbi Harry Rieder, devoted Vice President of the OHEL Board, and selfless and devoted friend of OHEL's children. The entire Rieder family is renowned for its concern for the welfare of those in need in the Jewish community. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Moishe Hellman, OHEL President David Jacobson, BAIS EZRA Pres Moshe Zakheim, Chairman of the Board Mel Zachter, Exec Committee Chairman David Mandel, Chief Exec Officer

title: Honda, Beating Out G.M., Plans to Build Cars in China
description: Beating out a competing bid by the General Motors Corporation, the Honda Motor Company announced today that it had won the right to manufacture passenger cars at a plant in southern China.

title: 8 Stockbrokers Indicted On Charges of Fraud
description: Eight stockbrokers from a defunct brokerage house, L.C. Wegard & Co. of New York, were accused in a Federal indictment yesterday of cheating thousands of investors with fraudulent sales techniques.

title: Cub Comes of Age: A Twice-Told Cosmic Tale
description: Suddenly, you're 4 years old again, and you've been taken to the circus for the first time. You can only marvel at the exotic procession of animals before you: the giraffes and the elephants and the hippopotamuses and all those birds in balletic flight. Moreover, these are not the weary-looking beasts in plumes and spangles that usually plod their way through urban circuses but what might be described as their Platonic equivalents, creatures of air and light and even a touch of divinity.

title: Reno Extends Investigation of Babbitt Casino Case
description: Attorney General Janet Reno today extended an investigation into whether to seek the appointment of an independent prosecutor to examine Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt's role in a decision to kill an Indian casino project in Wisconsin.

title: Racial Gap in Testing Is Really a Reading Gap; Tracking Creates Gaps
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTH, EDWARD S.
description: NORTH-Edward S. The best father, the most wonderful husbandmy only true love-we'll miss you forever. We'll always love you. Your Girls

title: Of Childhood Past and Future
description: Tomorrow children will have a chance to visit their parents' childhoods. Ikea, the Swedish home furnishings chain, is introducing a new children's line with an event designed to appeal as much to baby boomers as to their little ones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POURFARROKH
description: POURFARROKH. On November 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Arleen West and dear brother of Ali. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81 Street, on Saturday at 9 A.M. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: TEJAS GAS TO ACQUIRE PIPELINE SUBSIDIARY FROM AMOCO
description: The Tejas Gas Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Amoco Gas Company, a natural gas pipeline and processing subsidiary of the Amoco Corporation. Financial terms were not disclosed, but Tejas said it would be a stock transaction. Tejas, a Houston-based natural gas company, said its 387-mile system serves an Amoco refinery, two Amoco chemical plants and other customers on the Texas Gulf Coast.

title: Top U.N. Drug Aide Hopes to Rid Globe of Poppy and Coca Crops
description: The new head of the United Nations drug control agency announced today that he would pursue a program to eliminate the cultivation of opium poppies, the raw material of heroin, and coca, the source of cocaine, within 10 years.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Smaller Pay For Big Names

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Fandom'

title: Black Panther Legacy Includes Crime and Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, ROBERT S.
description: KANE-Robert S. The Northeast Chapter of the Society of American Travel Writers mourns the loss of the Society's former twoterm president and distinguished author of more than twenty-five guidebooks to travel around the world and countless magazine and newspaper articles. Mr. Kane died at home November 10.

title: Inside Art
description: Met Acquires Photo Collection

title: FILM IN REVIEW
description: 'Slaves to the Underground'

title: Cheeky Satirist Now on Rewind
description: Often snubbed by people he tries to interrogate during his gadfly campaigns against manifold injustices and absurdities, the documentary maker Michael Moore also ran into a stiff arm when he tried to get his television show ''TV Nation'' issued on home video.

title: Political Donations Taint Blair and His Image of 'New Labor'
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair's Labor Government swept into office last spring on lofty promises to remove sleaze and back-door dealmaking from public life. But it has recently found itself in an embarrassing furor over influence-peddling and campaign finance.

title: Market Place; Starwood's earnings once ITT is absorbed should more than offset an increase in shares.
description: AS it fought with Starwood Lodging Trust for control of the ITT Corporation, the Hilton Hotels Corporation repeatedly said that Starwood, a much smaller company than ITT, was issuing too much stock as part of its $10.2 billion offer and that investors were taking a big gamble if they accepted its bid.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Stocks Bounce Back As Foreign Markets Relax

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes highly recommended shows.

title: Conservative Group's Fund-Raising Offer of Access Draws Fire
description: At a time of increasing attention to how politicians raise campaign donations, a conservative lobbying group has stirred criticism for its effort to raise money for itself by offering large donors private meetings with lawmakers.

title: Gains for Treasury Bonds Are Pared by Stock Rally
description: Treasury prices overcame early weakness yesterday, only to fall victim again to a rally in stocks.

title: Flack Turns Back the Clock, Delicately
description: Ballad singing has bulked up in the 1990's. The most tender sentiments arrive in grand dramatic swoops and showy swirls; belters like Celine Dion flaunt their range and power, sounding steely even when they're promising devotion. Roberta Flack, who is playing a rare club date this week through Sunday at the Blue Note, reveals how much pop fashion has changed in the two decades since she had her biggest hits. She uses her voice, which she called a ''blessed instrument'' on Tuesday night as she talked about quitting smoking, with determined restraint, demonstrating that delicacy is not the same as weakness.

title: FILM IN REVIEW
description: 'Habit'

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were available at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth last weekend for last Friday and Saturday nights' performances. ++ means discounted tickets were available for Saturday night only.

title: Racial Gap in Testing Is Really a Reading Gap; Incomparable Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Army Official Creates Furor Calling Marines 'Extremists'
description: The Army's senior personnel official apologized to the Marines today for describing them as ''extremists'' who were at risk of ''total disconnection with society.''

title: Disdain in the Senate
description: Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee acted with contempt for civil rights and the rights of Senate colleagues yesterday when they refused to clear President Clinton's nominee for the top civil rights job in the Justice Department. The nominee, Bill Lann Lee, is an outstanding lawyer who had become a target for conservatives opposed to affirmative action. Senate Democrats believed he could have won confirmation. But with the eloquent exception of Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, Republicans on the Judiciary Committee opposed his nomination.

title: Palestinian Boy, 8, Shot by Israelis Is Declared Brain Dead
description: As his 8-year-old son slipped toward death in the next room with an Israeli Army bullet in his head, Mohammed Jawarish kept a vigil in the intensive-care unit of an Israeli hospital today and struggled with his impending loss.

title: THIOKOL PLANS TO RAISE STAKE IN HOWMET INTERNATIONAL
description: The Thiokol Corporation said yesterday that it would buy 13 million shares of Howmet International Inc. from a Carlyle Group affiliate for between $175 million and $200 million, increasing its ownership in Howmet to 62 percent from 49 percent. Thiokol's purchase of 11 million shares is to be closed at the same time as an initial public offering of Howmet shares being made by Carlyle, and Thiokol plans to exercise an option to buy an additional 2 million shares within 30 days. Thiokol produces high-technology solid rocket motors and precision fastening systems. Howmet makes precision castings for jet aircraft and industrial gas turbine engines and aerospace structural components.

title: F.B.I. Is Said To Have Kept Data on China
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation inadvertently withheld information that could have been useful to a Congressional inquiry into possible attempts by the Chinese Government to buy political influence in the United States, senior Justice Department officials said tonight.

title: Leetch Plays Through Troubles
description: What began as a slow start for Brian Leetch hasn't shown signs of relenting. He has neither scored many goals nor prevented many this season.

title: Conspiracies, Real and Imagined
description: Federal inquiries into two deadly explosions that captured the attention of all Americans, and especially New Yorkers, yielded different results on Wednesday. In one case, suspicions of a terrorist plot received further validation. In the other, suspicions of a terrorist plot were repudiated. What links the two verdicts is a reassuring sense that both resulted from painstaking and professional investigations by law enforcement officials.

title: Yankees Are Still Talking With Twins About a Trade
description: Earlier this month, the Minnesota Twins asked the Yankees if they would be interested in acquiring second baseman Chuck Knoblauch. But they wanted Andy Pettitte, not Bernie Williams, in return, and the Yankees rebuffed Minnesota's attempt to get Pettitte, one of the elite pitchers in the American League and an untouchable for the Yankees.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Raymond Pettibon

title: Lizzie Borden Revived Under a Red Sky
description: It is not only recently that Massachusetts has had its share of sensational murder trials, as American Ballet Theater's revival of Agnes de Mille's ''Fall River Legend'' reminded all at City Center on Wednesday.

title: Medical Tests Urged For Users of Diet Pill
description: Two months after two widely used diet pills were removed from the market, Government health officials have recommended that everyone who took them have medical examinations.

title: Mordant or Mysterious, As the Spirit Moved Him
description: ''There is no progress in art, any more than there is progress in making love. There are simply different ways of doing it.'' -- Man Ray

title: 2d Defendant in Murder By Fire Is Sentenced
description: The second defendant in the 1995 murder of a 20-year-old Brooklyn woman who was tortured for three days and then burned alive in a botched kidnapping was sentenced to a long prison term yesterday.

title: Informer Reportedly Didn't Warn Israel About Rabin's Assassin
description: A radical Jewish militant who worked as an informer for Israel's domestic security agency failed to report threats by Yigal Amir to kill Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, months before the assassination, according to findings of a state inquiry made public today.

title: Metro Business; Tax Breaks Provided For Publisher's Move
description: City and state officials have agreed to provide at least $4.3 million in tax breaks to the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company to subsidize its move to new offices at 63 Madison Avenue, at 28th Street, from the company's longtime headquarters four blocks away at One Park Avenue.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBNER, ELEANOR
description: LEIBNER-Eleanor. November 13, 1997. Beloved wife of Sol for fiftynine years. Devoted mother of Jerry and Denise Leibner and Richard and Carole Leibner. The most loving and adored grandmother of Adam and his wife Amy, Matthew, Jonathan, David, Elizabeth, Evan and Jordan. Dear sister of Allen and Irving Zelon. Tireless and committed founder, worker and officer for Congregation Beth Shalom of Kings Bay and their sisterhood, officer and board member of the Brooklyn Woman's Division of UJA. She gave of herself to all who knew her. She denied herself but was extraordinarily charitable. She was an unselfish woman with a strong moral code that she always tried to pass along to her children and grandchildren. She will be sorely missed by her family, many friends, and the community. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in her memory to Brooklyn Woman's Division of UJA. Visitation Saturday evening, 7:309:30pm. Service 11AM on Sunday, November 16, Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, (corner Avenue M). For directions call 718-377-2700.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENGER, KENNETH R.
description: WENGER-Kenneth R. November 11, 1997. Beloved husband of Virginia. Dear step-father of Paolo and Theo Gianakos. Loving brother of Gayle Whitney and Lenore Kriezel. Visiting Tuesday, November 18, 7-9:00 PM. Service Wednesday, 12:00 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Now, Obstruction of Justice Is Focus of Milken Inquiry
description: The Government's long investigation of Michael R. Milken, the former junk bond king, is focusing on allegations that he obstructed justice, according to a letter filed in Federal court in Manhattan this week.

title: INSIDE: Arts & Ideas
description: How obscurity turns to fame for the long dead in the arts.

title: Relief Near for Weary Nets
description: The site could have been Valley Forge, given the state of John Calipari's Nets right now.

title: Bruised and Battered, G.O.P. Rebels Learn Ropes
description: Less than an hour after House Republican leaders had assured Representative Linda Smith, a Washington Republican, that there would be no effort to push through a Congressional pay raise, a Democratic colleague called Mrs. Smith's office, saying, ''Did you hear they're pushing through a pay raise?''

title: A Package Deal Reduces Railroad Fares, but Not for All Commuters
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has an offer that many suburban commuters are finding hard to resist: Buy $60 worth of bus and subway fares on a Metrocard and get a 9 percent discount on a monthly rail ticket.

title: High Court to Weigh Sexual Harassment Issue
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide when an employer can be held liable for a supervisor's sexual harassment of a lower-level employee.

title: Tiring Trip for Americans
description: With a carload of Iraqi policemen in front and another to the rear, six American weapons inspectors arrived here today after an overnight journey that was clearly intended to be an ignominious departure from Baghdad.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Chronicle column yesterday about a party in Washington for the author Thomas Caplan included an erroneous name among those of the guests. Chelsea Clinton was not at the party.

title: With Jets' Future in Mind, Parcells Makes More Moves
description: Bill Parcells believes the Jets can win a division title this year, but because he also has to develop players for next year, he continued to tinker with his surprising team today.

title: About New York; Urban Lesson: Times Square As Classroom
description: IT'S daunting enough to think you can understand this city, where millions of people speak dozens of languages in hundreds of neighborhoods. Some lifelong New Yorkers gave up on trying, content to live on the narrow path between work and home, sometimes in the same zip code.

title: Former Miami Mayor Regains Power
description: Quoting the poet Maya Angelou and the Cuban patriot Jose Marti, Xavier Suarez returned today to the Miami mayor's post he left four years ago, saying, ''Yes, indeed, we are a city on the edge, on the edge of greatness.''

title: French Speakers Meet Where Few Will Hear
description: Under siege in Africa, intimidated on the Internet, fighting for its life in Indochina, the embattled French language is rallying its defenders this week in Vietnam, a former colony of France where less than 1 percent of the 75 million Vietnamese still speak French.

title: Rangers Win After Kovalev's First Goal
description: It has been a season-long struggle for many Rangers. But none have struggled more than Aleksei Kovalev.

title: TCI Trims Loss For 3d Quarter
description: Tele-Communications Inc. reported a narrower-than-expected third-quarter loss today, reflecting cost reductions and renewed focus on the company's domestic cable business.

title: Isles Give Demers a Harsh Introduction to His New Post With Lightning
description: The Islanders weren't exactly cringing tonight at the prospect of facing Tampa Bay in tough-talking Jacques Demers's debut as head coach of the Lightning.

title: Denounced for Remarks on Marines, Army Official Quits
description: The Army's chief personnel official resigned today after apologizing to the Marines for having described them as ''extremists'' who were at risk of ''total disconnection with society.''

title: Henman Has Long Day
description: For Pete Sampras, it was another day at the office as he marched into the semifinals of the season-ending ATP Tour championship.

title: Dominicans May Allow Voting Abroad
description: In a move that promises to turn the Dominican immigrant community in New York City into a powerful electoral force in its homeland, the Dominican Government is poised to grant its citizens abroad the right to vote from polling places where they live.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROTHKRUG, LEONARD F.
description: ROTHKRUG-Leonard F. 3/22/2811/15/96. Lovingly remembered by his family.

title: Ford, After Latin Success, Sends 2 to Beef Up Sagging Europe Unit
description: Seeking to strengthen day-to-day management at the regional level of an important but troubled division, the Ford Motor Company created the positions of president and chief financial officer today at Ford of Europe.

title: Wantagh Ends Bethpage's Run
description: On the second day of the Long Island football playoffs, Wantagh (6-3) snapped Bethpage's (8-1) 48-game winning streak against Nassau County opponents by registering a 7-6 overtime victory in a Conference III contest at Hofstra.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KRAKAUER, EDWIN G.
description: KRAKAUER-Edwin G. June 19, 1921-November 15, 1991. Missed and remembered by all who loved you.

title: Teachers' Unions Will Attack D'Amato's Education Record
description: A year before Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato will face re-election, the New York City and state teachers' unions plan to launch a public attack on his education record, in response to a series of television ads in which the Senator denounced the ''liberal'' unions as standing in the way of education reform.

title: For U.S. Retailers, Grinch Brings a Tight Job Market
description: Godiva Chocolatier is practically giving away candy to new employees. Managers at a Sears, Roebuck & Company store in Detroit are offering recruiting bonuses of $100. And August Max Woman, a clothing company, has raised part-time wages as much as 20 percent.

title: Businessmen Seek Ways To Fire Up Atlantic Trade
description: Last Thursday, the heads of some of the world's largest tire makers, including Goodyear, Pirelli and Michelin, sat together in a Rome hotel to talk tires. Antitrust officials might have suspected the executives of setting prices for, say, next season's radials. But no, the executives were actually here at the behest of political leaders in Europe and the United States, who are asking business leaders on both sides of the Atlantic to come up with suggestions for increasing the already huge $2 trillion in trans-Atlantic trade.

title: Beliefs
description: ''When you go to confession on a Saturday night. . . . '' That is how Dorothy Day began ''The Long Loneliness,'' her 1952 memoir of her radical younger days, her religious conversion and the founding of the Catholic Worker movement in the 1930's. Reread today, when going to confession seems a more genuinely iconoclastic act than most of the dark deeds memoirists rush to record, that opening is arresting.

title: U.N. Chief Attacks Congress Over Back Dues
description: In an unusually sharp criticism of Congress and the anti-abortion lobby that on Thursday killed a plan to pay the United Nations more than $1 billion in back dues, Secretary General Kofi Annan today called the vote ''unreasonable and regrettable.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, HOWARD A.
description: BERNSTEIN-Howard A. We remember you especially today on your birthday. It is twenty years since you left us. We will always love you and miss you. Our Family

title: GIBSON GREETINGS IS SET TO BEGIN ACQUISITION DRIVE
description: Gibson Greetings Inc. will begin making acquisitions in the first quarter as part of a plan to broaden its product lines and distribution channels, according to the company's chief executive. The Cincinnati-based greeting-card maker has about $106 million in cash that it will use to buy smaller card makers and other businesses, Frank O'Connell, Gibson's chief executive since August, said this week at a presentation for the Cleveland Society of Security Analysts. Acquisition candidates outside the greeting-card business must have revenue of more than $100 million as well as products and distribution methods that will help transform Gibson into a company agile enough to exploit promotional tie-ins to motion pictures and customers' changing life styles.

title: Westinghouse 2-Company Plan Dropped
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its remaining industrial businesses instead of spinning them off into a separate, publicly traded company.

title: 2 Banks, One Goal: Cast Long Shadows; For First Union, Big Is Beautiful
description: When Edward E. Crutchfield took full command of the First Union Corporation scarcely a decade ago it was an $8 billion also-ran, the No. 3 player in what was pretty much a two-bank state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUENO DE MESQUITA, CLARA
description: BUENO de MESQUITA-Clara, on November 13th, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Loving mother of Mireille, Judy and Bruce. Dear sister of Joseph. Cherished grandmother. Service Sunday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Asian-Americans Set To Flex Political Muscle
description: For leaders of Asian-American organizations, the outcome of the 1996 elections promised to be a turning point. Voters chose two governors of Asian-Pacific descent, and in California, home to nearly half the nation's Asian-Americans, turnout among them reached record levels. Hopes rose that an Asian-American would win a Cabinet post in the Clinton Administration.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sunday Styles this week about teen-agers and pop culture misidentified a host of the MTV show ''Singled Out.'' She is Carmen Electra. (Daisy Fuentes is a former host of MTV's ''House of Style.'')

title: 2 Views of Don King: His and the Legend
description: Don King, who got out of prison in the early 1970's, then insinuated himself into the fight game and went on to become boxing's most powerful promoter, has long been the stuff of which movies are made. But this larger-than-life character with the loud hair and louder mouth is still very much alive. How do you fashion a film that exploits the legend in the interests of drama but is still fair to the real person, someone who has made legions of enemies as he has helped make boxing more big-money entertainment than sport?

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY ; Storms Leave the Waves Only 7 Feet From Condos
description: Buffeted by three storms in as many weeks, the town's southern beaches have lost nearly 70 feet of sand, leaving a $4 million condominium complex only 7 feet from the water, state and local officials said yesterday.

title: Bill Would Delay Derivatives Rules at Banks
description: Senator Lauch Faircloth, Republican of North Carolina, has introduced a bill that would stop new derivatives rules from the Financial Accounting Standards Board from taking effect for banks unless regulators first certify the standards.

title: LeClair's Goals Lift The Flyers
description: FLYERS 5, PANTHERS 2

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, DR. ALTON D.
description: O'BRIEN-Dr. Alton D., 88, of Matawan, NJ on November 12, 1997. Dean Emeritus of Kean College of NJ. Father of Maureen O'Brien. Funeral Services Monday at 9:00 AM at Flynn & Son Funeral Home, 23 Ford Ave, Fords. Services at 10 AM, Old Tennent Presbyterian Church, Tennent, NJ. Burial will be in Old Tennent Church Cemetery, Tennent. Visitation Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Contributions may be made to your local chapter of the Humane Society.

title: Scandal Deepens for Russia's Top Economic Reformer
description: A roiling scandal over a hefty publishing advance taken by First Deputy Prime Minister Anatoly B. Chubais, Russia's most prominent reformer, deepened today when President Boris N. Yeltsin dismissed one of Mr. Chubais's co-authors from his Kremlin job.

title: Acupuncture's Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AND U.N. LINK IRAQI ARMS CRISIS TO GERM-WAR DATA
description: The showdown over Iraq's secret arsenal began when United Nations inspectors sought to uncover its biological weapons program, including germ-warfare tests and suspected caches of anthrax, United Nations and United States officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARTIGANER, LILLY
description: KARTIGANER-Lilly. November 13, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Devoted mother of Esther and Joseph. Loving grandmother of Debbie and Alison. Services Sunday, 11 AM, ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in her memory can be made to Hebrew Home for the Aged, Riverdale, New York.

title: Agencies Told by Mayor to Prepare for Budget Cuts
description: The Giuliani administration is warning city agencies that though the local economy is rebounding and tax revenues are greater than expected, they must prepare for the possibility of new spending cuts next summer to help close large budget gaps projected for the years ahead.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
