description: PHILIP MORRIS COS., New York, said it expected to record a fourth-quarter pretax gain of at least $700 million from the $930 million sale of Kibon, Brazil's biggest ice cream maker, to Unilever N.V.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an answer in the Q&A column of Science Times on Tuesday, about a physicist's calculation of how many angels can dance on the head of a pin, misstated the notation for the distance scale at which space is no longer divisible. It is 10-35 meters, not 10-35 meters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRUNG, BARBARA EDITH BAER
description: SPRUNG-Barbara Edith Baer. Wednesday, November 12, 1997. Beloved wife of Arthur Edward Sprung, mother of Reggie (David) Townsend, Edith (James) McGrath and Susan (Grant) Birtch, loving daughter of Howard and the late Isabel Aloe Baer, grandmother, sister-in-law of Emanuel A. Sprung and friend. Memorial Service on Sunday, 1:30 P.M. at Temple Emanuel, 12166 Conway Road. Interment Private. Tributes may be made to Missouri Botanical Gardens or to charity of your choice.

title: Second Stimulus Plan Is Announced in Japan
description: Japan's ruling party announced another plan yesterday to stimulate the economy, and stocks plunged on disappointment that the package lacked measures to provide immediate relief. The Liberal Democratic Party's plan did not mention income tax cuts or substantial public works spending, focusing instead on infrastructure improvements. The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell below 15,000 during the session for the first time since July 1995.

title: How Fickle Fortune and Men's Eyes; Bach, Wilde and Melville Had Long Waits for Return to Favor
description: It does not yet exist, but someone in our market-oriented world is bound to devise a cultural stock exchange upon which the fluctuating fortunes of deceased writers, artists and composers can be tracked. Were it a reality, its Big Board would be posting unexpected gains in Britain for shares in the half-forgotten poet and Latin scholar A. E. Housman as well as for long-neglected Pre-Raphaelite painters, notably Burne-Jones, Rossetti and G. F. Watts.

title: At SUNY, 'Outrageous' Views Have Their Place; Women Under Scrutiny
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign-Policy Vandalism
description: In an extreme example of legislative irresponsibility, the House of Representatives on Thursday abruptly killed the carefully negotiated compromise on the United States' delinquent dues to the United Nations. It also deleted an urgently needed spending provision for the International Monetary Fund, which is trying to contain a dangerous Asian financial crisis.

title: National Parks Get Low Marks in History
description: Millions of Americans visit national parks and battlefields every year for what may be their only regular dose of American history, but historians who have begun scrutinizing the exhibits, films and lectures there have found some of them one-sided and disturbingly out of date.

title: Albright Expresses Irritation After Talks With Netanyahu
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright expressed some irritation today with the Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, saying after long talks with him that Israeli and American interests required faster movement toward Middle East peace.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY ; Ruling on Competition Brings Lower Trash Fees
description: Getting rid of garbage in New Jersey is getting cheaper. On Monday, the United States Supreme Court let stand a lower court ruling allowing local communities to shop around for the lowest waste-disposal rates. In response, rates in some places, including Essex and Somerset Counties, have dropped as much as $50 a ton, said Gary Sondomeyer, the state's director of hazardous and solid waste.

title: Journal; Endless Shining Moment
description: The real victim of Seymour M. Hersh's scandalous account of ''The Dark Side of Camelot'' isn't the Kennedy myth, which is as unshakable an article of American faith as the cherry tree that George Washington did not chop down. No, the loser once again is the adversary Kennedy defeated in 1960 and has been vanquishing posthumously ever since, as eternally and humiliatingly as the Roadrunner outwits Wile E. Coyote -- Richard M. Nixon.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK ; 90 Held as Drug Sweep Ends Red Hook Inquiry
description: A five-month investigation of drug sales at the Red Hook Houses in Brooklyn has ended, after a three-day police sweep resulted in the arrests of 90 suspects, two-thirds of them on felony drug charges, the police said.

title: CLINTON IS SENDING 2D CARRIER TO GULF
description: President Clinton signaled with words and with the dispatch of an aircraft carrier today that the United States is prepared to act -- with or without its allies -- to prevent Iraq from developing the ability to use chemical or biological weapons.

title: House Starts Ethics Investigation Into Lawmaker's Tie to Lobbyist
description: The House ethics committee announced today that it had begun an investigation into Representative Bud Shuster, the Pennsylvania Republican who is chairman of the House Transportation Committee.

title: Carlos Surinach, 82, Composer Inspired by Flamenco Rhythms
description: Carlos Surinach, an American composer of Spanish birth who drew freely on the rhythmic and melodic conventions of flamenco in his works, died on Wednesday at his home in New Haven. He was 82.

title: St. John's and Seton Hall Climbing at Different Paces
description: St. John's and Seton Hall begin their seasons today looking to revisit a recent past: the days when they were competitive in the Big East and made regular appearances in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENBIN, ZELDA
description: DENBIN-Zelda. On November 14, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Max Denbin. Cherished mother of Evelyn and Bernard Smith, and Leonard and Ruth Denbin. Adored grandmother of Ellen, Howard, Andrea, Debra and Craig. Caring great-grandmother of Mara, Jaime, Matthew, Sara, Ethan, Max and Eric. Dear sister of Samuel and Irving Sklar and of the late William and Charles Sklar, Miriam Schneer and Florence Kret. Services Sunday, 12:00 noon, at I.J. Morris, Inc, at 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, New York.

title: GREEN TREE SHARES SLIDE ON PRETAX CHARGE REPORT
description: The shares of the Green Tree Financial Corporation tumbled 18 percent yesterday after the company said it would take a pretax charge of as much as $150 million to write down the value of asset-backed securities on its books. Green Tree said the value of ''interest only'' bonds it holds dropped because owners of manufactured homes paid back the loans backing the securities. The company will add $125 million to $150 million to reserves in the fourth quarter. Several analysts downgraded Green Tree, which until this year was touted as much for its skill in packaging and selling asset-backed bonds as for financing mobile homes and prefabricated housing. The stock of the St. Paul-based Green Tree fell $7.625, to $32.75, on the Big Board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAGUIN, SIMEON
description: BRAGUIN-Simeon. Noted designer, illustrator and abstract artist of Essex, CT., died Nov. 9. Memorial gathering to be announced. Contributions to Tri Town Youth, P.O. Box 897, Deep River, CT 06417.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIFKIN, LILIANN LIHN
description: RIFKIN-Liliann Lihn. On November 13, 1997. Devoted mother of Matthew and daughter-in-law Tomoko, dear sister of Katie and Tom Riggione. Services Sunday 4:30PM, ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory can be made to the American Foundation For Aids Research, 733 3rd Avenue, NYC 10017.

title: Gigantism on the Yangtze
description: A milestone was reached recently when China's Yangtze River was diverted to a side channel to make way for construction of the world's biggest dam. The rhetoric of Chinese leaders at the riverside ceremonies revealed an outdated Communist pride in gargantuan engineering projects and a stubborn belief that sheer size testifies to the vitality of the political system.

title: XPEDITE ACCEPTS SWEETENED OFFER FROM PREMIERE
description: Xpedite Systems Inc. has accepted the sweetened offer of $34 a share in stock from Premiere Technologies Inc. Premiere raised its bid this week from its previous offer of $30 a share. An investment group that includes Xpedite executives made a bid of $23.25 a share last summer. Xpedite, based in Eatontown, N.J., provides computer and fax-based documents, and fax, telex and Internet services. It has offices in North America, Europe and the Pacific Rim with 610 employees and had 1996 sales of $130 million. Premiere will issue stock valued at $34 a share for each Xpedite share, or a total of about $305 million. It will also assume debt of $117 million. Expedite shares rose 25 cents, to $28.875, while Premiere's shares fell 93.75 cents, to $27.3125.

title: Spending Plan In Westchester Surpasses $1 Billion
description: In his 15th and last budget as Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke today proposed a spending plan for 1998 that surpasses $1 billion, by $25 million, and that would raise county property taxes an average of 8 percent.

title: Democrats Sound Like a Couple in Need of Therapy
description: The complaints about the White House from Democrats on Capitol Hill this week sounded like voices from a pop psychology book about a communications breakdown in a failing marriage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLINGER, SYLVIA
description: KLINGER-Sylvia. On November 13, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Martin. Loving mother of Judith, Myron and Edward. Cherished sister of Alexander Sands, Guta Selinger, and the late Harry Sands. Also survived by four grandchildren and two great grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHMAN, RUTH
description: FISCHMAN-Ruth. On November 13, 1997. Survived by her brother, Jacob H. Fischman, nephew Mark B. Fischman, nieces Elaine Zekind, Lois Halpern and Barbara Klibanoff and six grand-nieces and three grand-nephews and five great grand-nieces and five great grandnephews. Interment at Beth David cemetery, Elmont, New York, Sunday, November 16, 11:30 AM.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Choral Effects Enhance Quiet Bernstein Pleasures
description: The Carnegie Hall Jazz Band's concert on Thursday night, given over to a program of the music of Leonard Bernstein, was bizarrely divided. In fact, it called into question the whole idea of serious institutional jazz programming.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK ; He Lost City School Post But Wins Virginia Job
description: Daniel A. Domenech, the Long Island educator whose tentative appointment as New York City Schools Chancellor in September 1995 lasted only 24 hours, has been selected as the new superintendent of schools in Fairfax County, Va., the 12th-largest district in the country.

title: Waste Management Takes a Pretax Charge
description: Waste Management Inc. said today that it had taken a pretax charge of about $173 million and restated its accounts for the last two years.

title: DEL MONTE BUYING SOME OF CONTADINA LINE OF PRODUCTS
description: The Del Monte Foods Company said yesterday that it would buy the Contadina brand of canned tomato products and some related operations from Nestle S.A.'s United States unit, doubling annual sales of its canned tomato brands to $400 million. Terms were not disclosed. The San Francisco-based Del Monte Foods, which is owned by Texas Pacific Group, will receive Contadina's pizza sauce and bread crumbs business as part of the purchase, as well as two tomato processing factories in Woodland and Hanford, Calif. Nestle will keep the Contadina line of refrigerated pasta and sauces.

title: Illinois Electoral Votes Didn't Put J.F.K. Over Top
description: To the Editor:

title: Think Tank; New Vision of Eden as a Scientific Garden
description: Ever since Plato wrote the ''Republic,'' idealists have been setting out their visions of the perfect society. Thomas More, who wrote ''Utopia'' in 1516, wanted to restore the traditional village and fend off the emerging market system that allowed ''rich men to buy up all.'' The Frenchman Charles Fourier believed man could rationally determine the most harmonious social unit: by his calculations, 1,620 people on 5,000 acres. In the 1780's, the religious, communal Shakers began establishing villages with celibacy as the cardinal principle; seven decades later, John Humphrey Noyes founded the religious and socialist Oneida community, where every woman was the wife of every man and vice versa.

title: Fire and Humanity From Five Legends
description: Much can be said about the five women being paid tribute to this weekend in ''Dance Women: Living Legends'' and about the modern-dance companies they founded across the nation. But Joe Nash, the dance historian, put it best in his introductory comments on Thursday night at the Majestic Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where the first of two ''Living Legend'' programs was presented. ''We honor these women,'' Mr. Nash said, ''for keeping dance alive.''

title: Strong Blow Is Delivered To State Law On Aliens
description: When Proposition 187 was on the California ballot three years ago there were protests, student boycotts, accusations of racism and cries of immigrant bashing, over the ballot initiative, which sought to deny undocumented immigrants an array of social services.

title: At SUNY, 'Outrageous' Views Have Their Place; Selling Their Wares
description: To the Editor:

title: High-Speed Trains, Low-Speed Lines
description: Amtrak has been scrambling to make good on its promise to provide rail service between New York and Boston in just three hours by the end of the decade. But because the list of vital construction projects is long and the pool of capital funds shallow, Amtrak's goal of offering swift, dependable service can easily be derailed unless Connecticut, Metro-North and Amtrak officials give high priority to a particularly antiquated section of power lines.

title: Orioles Owner Isn't in Steinbrenner's League
description: To the Editor:

title: For Dance, Variety And Depth Atop Basics
description: Drum-'n'-bass, the electronic dance music that arrived in the early 1990's under the name jungle, can be as austere as its new moniker: just a bass line and a beat. The low, stolid bass lines come from dub and dancehall reggae; the beat, double or quadruple time, jitters up above like an insomniac's worries. The basic combination easily propels clubgoers around a dance floor. But the most innovative drum-'n'-bass disk jockeys have set out to add depth and variety without sacrificing the music's wallop or confining it to song forms.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: For Store Workers, Christmas Comes Early

title: New Silicon Valley Proceeds Despite the Region's Problems : Malaysia's Wired 'Supercorridor'
description: CYBERJAYA, Malaysia  When a baby cobra slithered into the offices of Multimedia Development Corp. a few weeks ago, the office workers jumped up and down and screamed, "Kill it! Kill it!"

title: Leon William Johnson, 93; Led Wartime Raid on Oilfield
description: Gen. Leon William Johnson of the Air Force, who won the Medal of Honor for leading a daring low-level raid in the all-out air assault that throttled enemy fuel supplies from Romania's vast oil fields in 1943, died on Monday at the Belvoir Woods health care center in Fairfax, Va. He was 93 and lived in McLean.

title: In Bomb Trial, Expert Cites Fingerprints
description: An expert from the Federal Bureau of Investigation laboratory testified today that he had found Terry L. Nichols's fingerprints on a cardboard wrapper for explosives and on documents used to rent a storage locker in Kansas and a motel room in Oklahoma under false names.

title: Mythology for the Young and Lighthearted
description: Basic mythology has rarely been as much easygoing entertainment as ''Disney on Ice: Hercules,'' the show that just pulled up stakes at Madison Square Garden and is bound for performances from Tuesday to Nov. 23 at the Continental Airlines Arena in New Jersey and from Nov. 25 to 30 at the Nassau Coliseum on Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLUM, IRWIN JACK
description: ROSENBLUM-Irwin Jack. On November 13, 1997, at age 73. Devoted husband of fifty-one years of Rhoda, loving father of Alice Loubaton, Henry and Rita, caring father-in-law of Dr. Sam Loubaton, adoring grandfather of Emily and Jeremy Loubaton, dear uncle, cousin, and friend; musician extraordinaire; tireless volunteer. Funeral services Sunday, November 16 at 1 PM, I.J. Morris, Inc., 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. Burial at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, New Jersey. Shiva at the Rosenblum residence, 2067 Royce Street, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBNER, ELEANOR
description: LEIBNER-Eleanor. Beloved sister and aunt. Allen, Zaneta, Rachel and David

title: Files on China Embarrass F.B.I. and Reno, and Miff Subject
description: F.B.I. and Justice Department officials said today that they were deeply chagrined by the recent discovery of raw counterintelligence files that provided additional classified information about possible Chinese plans to influence American politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, ANN (NEE CZACHOR)
description: KING-Ann (nee Czachor). On Nov. 13, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Walter T. Loving mother of Deborah King Cechura and motherin-law of Radim. Devoted grandmother of Michael and Lukas. Dearest sister of Valerie Perlstein, John and Edward. Aunt of Janice Conroy. Cherished friend of Margaret Orthel, Sylvia Fox and Alejandra Vazquez. She will be forever in our hearts. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the American Heart Association or the American Cancer Society.

title: Israeli Synagogue Parity
description: To the Editor:

title: Demonic and Devout, Opposites That Attract
description: With only two works, both French, and no soloists, the current program of the New York Philharmonic is simplicity itself, inviting listeners to compare and contrast. Berlioz's familiar ''Symphonie Fantastique'' is preceded by ''L'Ascension,'' four ''symphonic meditations'' by Olivier Messiaen, who, as Christopher H. Gibbs of the State University of New York, Buffalo, observed in a preconcert talk, admired Berlioz's music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNER, ROSE ROSEN
description: POSNER-Rose Rosen. November 13, 1997, of Muttontown, Long Island. Beloved wife of the late Max J. Devoted mother of Libby and Joseph Shapiro, Estelle and Arnold Riback, Sydelle (Marian) and Allan Sydney. Also survived by nine loving grandchildren, and fifteen adoring great-grandchildren. Services Sunday, 10:30AM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: At Funeral, 2 Worn Dolls Left Behind
description: One of the saddest moments in a funeral of sad moments was when Jamila Spencer held up two careworn, chocolate-brown dolls that belonged to her 9-year-old sister, Sabrina Green, and said, ''This is all that's left of Sabrina,'' and then bowed her head.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTHEWS, WILLIAM
description: MATTHEWS - William. Faculty and students of the English Department and Creative Writing Program join The City College in mourning the loss of our distinguished friend and colleague and in sending our heartfelt condolences to his family. Wry and passionate poet, lover of jazz, opera, Horace and basketball, generous mentor of countless aspiring younger poets, he will be deeply missed and long remembered and read.

title: Expert in Bomb Trial Tells of Fingerprints
description: An expert from the Federal Bureau of Investigation laboratory testified today that he had found Terry L. Nichols's fingerprints on a cardboard wrapper for explosives and on documents used to rent a storage locker in Kansas and a motel room in Oklahoma under false names.

title: Mets Show Interest in Marlins' Fire Sale
description: The Mets, of all people, have taken a number and are standing in line at the Marlins' meat market.

title: New York High School Diploma To Require 3 Years of Language
description: Stunning even some of its own members, the State Board of Regents voted today to require most high school students to pass three years of a foreign language in order to earn a diploma.

title: At SUNY, 'Outrageous' Views Have Their Place; Arrogance of the Elite
description: To the Editor:

title: President Blocks 600,000 Orders For Assault Rifles From Overseas
description: Facing a huge surge in requests by gun dealers to bring modified assault weapons into the United States, President Clinton today temporarily halted such imports, blocking permits already issued to dealers for 600,000 guns and freezing applications to import a million more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORODENSKI, ANNE POMEROY
description: HORODENSKI-Anne Pomeroy, on November 14, 1997. Quiet service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, November 17 at 11 AM.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There doesn't seem to be one person in the caucus who has a relationship with the President. It could very well be a personality thing. The President is not the type of person that creates these types of relationships. But that allows a lot of steam and tension to be released. A drinking buddy, a poker buddy, one way or the other you get the message out.''

title: SOCCER: Making Room for Four; In Connecticut, the DeMichele Quadruplets Share and Compete On and Off the Field
description: The sun had dipped behind steel-wool clouds, darkening the trodden-green field and the newly bare limbs of fall trees. A wind picked up and some of the spectators standing along the sidelines or seated in the small bleacher section last Tuesday at Rocky Hill High School near Hartford shivered from the chill and the tension.

title: Eddie Arcaro, Only Jockey to Win Racing's Triple Crown Twice, Is Dead at 81
description: Eddie Arcaro, the master of thoroughbred racing for 31 years as America's premier jockey, who five times won the Kentucky Derby and twice swept the Triple Crown, died yesterday at his home in Miami. He was 81.

title: In a Reversal, N.A.A.C.P. To Back a Local Leader
description: In an abrupt reversal, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has agreed to defend a Kingston, N.Y., chapter president who was sued after she helped publicize a tape in which a Kingston police officer was heard making racially derogatory remarks.

title: Limon's Mass as Communal Outpouring in a Gothic Setting
description: A setting for a dance performance does make a difference and ''Missa Brevis,'' one of Jose Limon's most stirring tributes to the human spirit, looked magnificent in the nave of Riverside Church on Thursday night.

title: A Couple Are Missing And Friends Are Baffled
description: After six years together, they had developed their little routines.

title: Devils' Defense Derails Avalanche
description: The Colorado Avalanche, the team with the best sharpshooters in the Pacific Division and winner of the Stanley Cup two years ago, marched into New Jersey tonight and ran into the brick wall called the Devils.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TINKOFF, CARRIE
description: TINKOFF-Carrie, 93. Died Nov. 13. Widow of Frank, devoted mother of Lucille Merkowitz and Barbara E. Friedman, grandmother of Howard, Neil, Arlene and Sharon, and great grandmother of Woody, Benjamin, Elana, Eric and Matthew. Services 10:30AM, Sunday, November 16, at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows.

title: After Running Everest, Everything's Downhill
description: Last week, 65 competitors from around the world traveled thousands of miles to Katmandu, Nepal, and then endured a nine-hour bus ride to begin a three-week trek that will culminate with the Everest Marathon, the highest, and arguably the world's most difficult, 26.2-mile race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIRSCHWELL, ALEX
description: TIRSCHWELL-Alex. 88. Died November 13, 1997. Adoring husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Perry and Barbara, Joel and Connie. Cherished grandfather of Mark and Cathy, David and Carolyn, Eric, Peter, Robert and Matthew. Great grandfather of Jessica and Max. Brother of Rose and Edward. Service Sunday, November 16, 1 PM, at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, New York.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Classical Music and Dance Guide in Weekend yesterday about today's performance of ''Marco Polo'' by the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater misstated the performance time. It is 1:30 P.M., not 8.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTH, EDWARD S.
description: NORTH-Edward S. The best father, the most wonderful husbandmy only true love-we'll miss you forever. We'll always love you. Your Girls

title: College Is a Privilege
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Chicago Police Official Will Retire Over Disclosure
description: Hours after it was disclosed that he had a close friendship with a convicted felon, Chicago's police superintendent said today that he was retiring, a decision that followed a stream of troubling incidents that had been gnawing at the police department for months.

title: Liberties; Trouble In Mind
description: I learned many strange and wonderful things when I went to Texas A & M for the opening of the Bush Presidential Library.

title: $7.4 Billion in Revenues, but No Name
description: The firm does not even have a name yet, but it had at least $7.4 billion in revenues last year, its lead partners said yesterday.

title: Confidence Of Consumers Remains High
description: Despite recent stock market gyrations, the nation's consumers have actually grown more confident about current economic conditions, the Survey Research Center at the University of Michigan told clients today.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column of House & Home on Thursday about handmade rugs designed by Denis Colomb misidentified his studio, where they are sold. It is Studio 11, not Studio Five. The telephone number is (212) 517-1512.

title: Too Interesting to Be a Saint
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, said this week that he planned to propose sainthood for Dorothy Day, the advocate for social justice who died in 1980. At first glance she seems a good candidate: like Saint Paul, she underwent a dramatic conversion, was fearless, lived a life of heroic poverty and mortification, loved the least lovable of the poor, went to prison to bear witness to her pacifism, obeyed church teaching to the letter even at her most defiant, and radiated spiritual integrity.

title: Kings Are Test for the Knicks
description: When the Knicks were outhustled and outplayed in Sacramento last Sunday night, Chris Mills was confused. He remembered what it was like as a member of the Cleveland Cavaliers to play the Knicks with a twinge of fear. Now that he was on the Knicks' bench and in the locker room, he was not seeing the toughness he saw from the other side.

title: Moonstruck Magic By the Grandfather Of Film Fantasies
description: If you're trying to imagine more inventive ways of making all those music videos and special-effects film fantasies being turned out so quickly and so often banally these days, you might try looking backward to the turn of the century. There, you'll find the films of Georges Melies moving happily between the old-world magic of legends and fairy tales and a brave new world of science fiction (rocket ships, interplanetary travel) that had yet to become fact.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUGHLIN, JAMES
description: LAUGHLIN-James. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be mourned by the world of literature.

title: My Kind of Dinosaur
description: What do you get for spending all your time teaching young children manners, healthy eating habits and the joys of singing? If you're Barney, the zaftig purple dinosaur, you get beaten in effigy at hockey games by a man in a chicken suit, not to mention pilloried by late-night talk show hosts.

title: Illinois Electoral Votes Didn't Put J.F.K. Over Top; Clean Bill of Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquiry Into Congo Killings Meets Obstacles
description: The United Nations team that arrived in Congo this week to investigate allegations of massacres by troops loyal to President Laurent Kabila has already run into difficulties.

title: At SUNY, 'Outrageous' Views Have Their Place; 'Disruptive' Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: The Irresponsibility That Spreads AIDS
description: Two and a half years ago I tested positive for H.I.V. Since then I have discovered a support system that steadfastly refuses to encourage responsible behavior and a society whose silence insures the continued spread of this disease.

title: Someone Is Killing Pigeons, Birds That New Yorkers Love to Hate
description: Maybe it's the way they cling to window sills and terraces, cooing, cooing, cooing. Maybe it's the way they slop on pedestrians, swarm on sidewalks and buzz through plazas like a squadron of crop-dusters. Or maybe it's just the look of them, the beady eyes, the dirty gray feathers, the arrogantly plump rumps.

title: GOLDMAN, SACHS PLANNING TO ADD CHARTWELL LEISURE
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment firm, said yesterday that it planned to acquire Chartwell Leisure Inc., a hotel owner and operator, for $17.25 a share, or about $272 million. Whitehall Street Real Estate L.P., a $1.6 billion real estate investment fund run by Goldman, will acquire all of Chartwell's 15.7 million shares outstanding. It will carry out the deal in partnership with Westmont Hospitality Group Inc., a hotel investment and management company. Chartwell, based in New York, owns 124 hotels either by itself or in joint ventures. Shares of Chartwell rose 75 cents, to $16.625.

title: Arts & Ideas
description: The Saturday arts pages now focus on coverage of intellectual trends and issues. Today, tracking the reputations of writers and artists on the cultural stock exchange, along with the attempt to update one-sided historical exhibits at national parks, and the latest version of Utopia.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY ; Airline Agrees to Hire 1,000 Newark Residents
description: Continental Airlines has agreed to hire 1,000 Newark residents to staff its support operations at Newark International Airport, city and airline officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTHEWS, WILLIAM P., III
description: MATTHEWS-William P., III. On November 12, 1997. Son of Mary and the late William P., Jr. Father of William P. IV and Rochelle, Sebastian and Alison. Brother of Susan E. Matthews; grandfather of Alison, Davey, Raven and Rosemary. Companion of Celia Bellinger. Service Sunday, November 16, 3 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Berkshire School, Sheffield, MA. 01257.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: City Reports a Big Reduction Of Crime in Jail, of All Places
description: It is well known that New York City's crime rate has fallen significantly over the last three years, but yesterday officials announced a less-heralded reduction of crime: inside the city's jails.

title: PICTURES OF SABRINA: A special report.; A Slide Into Peril, With No One to Catch Her
description: The images all add up, now that Sabrina Green, 9 years old, is dead and buried.

title: For Traditional Church, New Traditions, New Life; From Lands of the Old British Empire, Immigrants Fill Emptied Episcopal Pews
description: One part of the history of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Flatbush, Brooklyn, is etched into its huge stained-glass windows. Besides the requisite Bible scenes, it tells the story of a small chapel built in 1836 by the prominent descendants of English and Dutch settlers and transformed a century later into a sprawling church, its pews filled with the affluent and influential.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCKNEY, DONALD J.
description: HOCKNEY-Donald J., Ph.D. The Board of Trustees, President David C. Chang, the faculty, alumni and students of Polytechnic University mourn the passing of their colleague Donald J. Hockney, professor of computer science and humanities. During his 21 years at the University, Dr. Hockney was a major force in enhancing Polytechnic's reputation as a research university. He held prominent leadership positions, including vice president for strategic initiatives, vice provost for academic computing and director of Advanced Software Kinetics. He helped build Polytechnic's well-respected computer science programs and counseled many young faculty members on how to obtain research funding. An accomplished scientist who had also earned a doctorate in philosophy, Dr. Hockney believed that college was a time for students to stretch their intellectual boundaries and study diverse subjects. Professor Hockney was an inspiration to those who worked and studied with him. We will sorely miss his presence, fellowship and dedicated service and extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Helen; son, Richard; and daughters, Sarah and Tanya. Services at 10:30 A.M., Monday at Cobble Hill Chapels, 171 Court St., Brooklyn.

title: Fassel Says He Wants Toomer to Play More
description: With wide receivers Ike Hilliard and Thomas Lewis both lost for the season, the Giants have wanted to make Amani Toomer -- the only receiver on the team taller than 5 feet 10 inches -- a starter and a featured part of the offense.

title: Mexico and U.S. Take Steps on Arms, Drugs and Border Issues
description: President Clinton and the Mexican President, Ernesto Zedillo, said today that the United States and Mexico had made modest progress in resolving a number of the central problems in their complex diplomatic relationship.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sunday Styles this week about Sebastian Junger, who wrote ''The Perfect Storm,'' a book about a swordfishing boat with a six-man crew that perished in 1991 in a hurricane off the coast of Nova Scotia, misspelled the given name of another author, the writer of ''Into Thin Air.'' He is Jon Krakauer, not John.

title: At SUNY, 'Outrageous' Views Have Their Place
description: To the Editor:

title: GLATFELTER SET TO BROADEN ITS PAPER PRODUCTS BASE
description: The P. H. Glatfelter Company agreed yesterday to buy a unit from Scholler & Hosch of Germany for $198 million including about $40 million in debt to broaden its speciality paper products. The unit, which makes tea bags, tobacco papers and other lightweight printing papers, is owned by Deutsche Beteiligungs A.G. and Scholler & Hosch's management. The unit had 1996 sales of about $173 million. Glatfelter, a Spring Grove, Pa., paper maker, said the purchase would give it a strong position in the world tea bag market and would strengthen its tobacco paper business in Europe.

title: City Reinstates Contracts With a Troubled Agency
description: More than a year after canceling a series of contracts with a Queens social services agency because of bidding and financial irregularities, the Giuliani administration has quietly begun restoring many of those contracts after reaching a settlement requiring the agency to undergo intense financial oversight.

title: The Timberwolves Are Fined for a Fashion Foul
description: The fashion police have raided the locker room of the Minnesota Timberwolves and decided that Kevin Garnett and Stephon Marbury do not look as hip as they think they do in those tent-sized trunks.

title: Campaign Finance Witness Describes Role Informally
description: Johnny Chung, the wheeling-dealing California businessman who gave $366,000 to the Democratic Party in last year's election campaign and visited the White House about 50 times, refused today to testify under oath to investigators from the House of Representatives. But, behind closed doors, Mr. Chung gave the investigators an informal account of his political activities.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASS, ELLIOTT
description: BASS-Elliott. On November 12, 1997. Brother of Kermit Bass and Rita Lubin. Services were held on Friday, November 14th.

title: Sports of The Times; Parcells And Greater Expectations
description: BILL Parcells sat behind a table on an elevated platform yesterday afternoon as a skeleton contingent of reporters prepared to hear a routine pre-game briefing. But this briefing was not so routine.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Blackout of Aqueduct Ends
description: Television pictures of races at Aqueduct were restored to Offtrack Betting shops in New York City yesterday after a one-day blackout over a payment dispute between OTB and the New York Racing Association.

title: Rose Bowl Matchup Wide Open
description: This is how muddled the picture is for the Rose Bowl:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, BENJAMIN B.
description: COHEN-Benjamin B., MD. On November 14, 1997. Beloved husband of Nan. Dear brother and uncle. Service on Sunday at 1:30 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OST, WARREN W.
description: OST-Warren W. The Officers, members of the Board, Staff and Alumni of ''A Christian Ministry in the National Parks,'' mourn the loss of its founder and Director. For 45 years, he gave superb pastoral leadership to this unique ministry, to the employees, staff, and visitors of our National Parks. William L. Mundy, President Don Winne, Vice President Richard P. Camp, Jr., Director

title: Bonds and Currency Take Turns On Seesaw as Stock Markets Rally
description: A resurgence in global stock markets yesterday helped erase the remnants of Wall Street's midweek tumble, but the rebound was partly overshadowed by other volatility that hurt the dollar, buffeted bonds and sent gold prices down to 12 1/2-year lows.

title: Editorial Observer; Loving and Hating Those Big Dream Machines
description: Some fathers joined the Elks, the Masons or Rotary. But during the 1960's my father, my grandfather and my uncles belonged to the Big Wheels, a club of men who drove trucks for a living and for whom the very act of breathing required vehicular motion. Every fourth Sunday the Big Wheels put on their sharpest suits and motored to meetings in Lincolns, Buicks and Cadillacs, the biggest, curviest, most lusted-after cars in American history.

title: Kevorkian Helps Woman Die In a Roman Catholic Church
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian's argument with the Roman Catholic Church over assisted suicide intensified today after his lawyer said that Dr. Kevorkian had helped an elderly woman die on Thursday night in a church in the Detroit archdiocese.

title: Sprinkling Sweet Seasoning on Sour Dishes
description: Music directors shape their orchestras in their own image, so it is not surprising that Vladimir Spivakov, a violinist whose interpretive roots are in the Russian Romantic school, emphasizes lushness and warmth when he conducts the Moscow Virtuosi. At Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, the ensemble's rounded tone proved seductive at times, overwhelming elsewhere.

title: Jury Recommends Death for Pakistani In Killing at C.I.A.
description: Under tight security, a jury recommended a death sentence today for a Pakistani immigrant who was convicted this week of gunning down two Central Intelligence Agency employees in 1993 in a case that has reverberated in the defendant's homeland.

title: INSIDE
description: Dominican Voting Plan Would Empower Expatriates

title: PIONEER NATURAL TO SELL GAS AND OIL PROPERTIES
description: The Pioneer Natural Resources Company agreed yesterday to sell natural gas and oil properties for $105 million to two companies to pay down debt stemming from a planned acquisition. A subsidiary of Titan Exploration Inc. of Midland, Tex., will pay Pioneer $55 million for assets in West Texas and New Mexico, said Marsha Sheffield, a Pioneer spokeswoman. Houston-based Sheridan Energy Inc. will pay about $50 million for properties in Oklahoma, Texas and coastal Louisiana, she said. Pioneer, formed in August from the Parker & Parsley Petroleum Company and Mesa Inc., is shifting from older oil and gas properties to more aggressive exploration and acquisitions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREVELLO, HANNA HAHN
description: CAREVELLO-Hanna Hahn. The faculty, administration, board of directors and students of the Jewish Theological Seminary record with sorrow the passing of Hanna Hahn Carevello, the sister of JTS chancellor, Rabbi Ismar Schorsch and daughter of Rabbi Emil and Fanny Schorsch. Born in Germany, she immigrated to the US as a child and lived in Pottstown, PA and Vineland and Linwood, NJ. A nurse and a social worker, Mrs. Carevello took a lifelong interest in Jewish learning and was active in her synagogue. She is pre-deceased by her first husband, the late Dr. Calvin Hahn. She is survived by her husband, Anthony Carevello, two sons, Dr. Jan Hahn of Lenoir City, TN and Dr. David Hahn of Philadelphia, a daughter, Dr. Leslie Hahn of Minneapolis and six grandchildren. Funeral services Sunday, 11AM, Congregation Beth Judah, Ventnor, NJ. May her memory be for a blessing and her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Gershon Kekst, Chairman of the Board

title: A Tough One for Champions
description: For five world champions to take part in a club game is very rare. It happened Wednesday at the Harmonie Club's annual Expert-Member night, and one, Lisa Berkowitz of Old Tappan, N.J., is still celebrating victory in the World Women's Teams in Hammamet, Tunisia.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY ; Conviction Is Overturned For Montclair Teacher
description: A judge yesterday overturned the conviction of a former Montclair school teacher who was accused of assaulting a fifth grader after the child tossed a bag of grapes at a trash can.

description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Classical Briefs
description: DELIUS: ORCHESTRAL WORKS

title: Balktalk; Rule Books, Videotape and Common Sense
description: A little old lady from Dubuque is injured by a product from a nasty conglomerate. Because her sloppy lawyer files her lawsuit one day after the legal deadline, she may go uncompensated. This is the problem that faces generations of first-year law students who generally are shocked to learn that -- other than suing her lawyer for malpractice -- she will have no recourse: a rule is a rule.

description: RAPUNZEL

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A sizzling little western co-starring two Hollywood legends, a fable set in London, an expert version of a classic play about journalists and a salute to a yesteryear's Cuba are standouts on this week's movie schedule.

title: Close Encounters With Speed Demons
description: After reading ''The Speed Demons on My Mind'' [Opinion, Nov. 8], I wished to commend the author on a well-written article. I am sure that Shirley Simon's sentiments are shared by many drivers.

title: Northern Exposure
description: THE GIRL

title: A Nice Jewish Lumberjack
description: MARVEN OF THE

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE BEAR COMES HOME By Rafi Zabor. Norton, $25.

title: 'God Created Me To Be a Slave'
description: I was dismayed at the sensational tone of Elinor Burkett's article on slavery in Mauritania, a tone mirrored in the article's title '''God Created Me to Be a Slave''' (Oct. 12). Is there a reason she prefers the word ''slave'' to the more accurate ''Haratin,'' the Mauritanian word meaning ''former slave? Fatma may refer to herself as a slave, but repeating the term wholesale does not do justice to Mauritania's sincere and complex dialogue on the status of Haratin.

title: Brande Stellings, David B. Soskin
description: Brande Marie Stellings and David Bruce Soskin were married last evening by Rabbi Ari Fridkis at the TriBeCa Grill in New York.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 19 about the diminished influence of Manhattan's Upper West Side on New York politics misspelled the middle name of a deceased Congressman. He was Bill Fitts Ryan, not Fitz Ryan.

title: Worth a Detour In the East Village
description: CIRCA * [rating: one star]

title: November 9-15; Sentence in Rape Case
description: A former teacher was sentenced to six months in jail for having an affair with a 13-year-old boy she taught in a Seattle-area elementary school. Mary Kay LeTourneau, 35, who pleaded guilty in August to two counts of second-degree child rape and bore a baby girl in prison from the liaison, was also ordered to enter a sexual deviancy treatment program.

title: New Jersey by Mail: The State's Catalogues
description: On the off-chance that the catalogue of your choice hasn't already appeared in your mailbox this holiday shopping season, here is a sampling of mail-order marketers in New Jersey.

title: Soccer in the City: Coach Yells, Player Translates, Team Wins
description: At halftime, chilled and dispirited after playing poorly and leading by only one goal, the defending city soccer champions of Martin Luther King Jr. High School sprawled in the locker room at Riverbank State Park in Harlem. Their coach was ranting.

title: High-Flying Circus Fun From Down-Under Acrobats
description: WITH rock music and acrobats -- and no animals -- the Australian troupe Circus Oz has entertained people around the world for 20 years and is about to arrive at the New Victory Theater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINRICH, JOHN E.
description: WEINRICH-John E., BS, MS, PhD. Survived by wife Linda, daughter Jonelle and sons Johnathan, Jarret, Jann, Jeth. Memorial Service St. George, Astoria, Nov. 23, 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SMITH, G.E. KIDDER
description: SMITH-G.E. Kidder. A memorial service will be held for Kidder Smith on Monday, November 17, 11AM at the Church of the Epiphany, 1393 York Avenue at 74 Street.

title: The Nation; Washington Steps Back, and Cities Recover
description: NATIONAL political leaders used to talk about fixing up urban America. They mostly don't now. Even pretending to have a broad vision for what the cities could be, or should be, let alone having a plan to pay for it, is no longer required or expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, LILLIAN FINKLE
description: BRODY-Lillian Finkle. Graduate Beth Israel School of Nursing. Accomplished bridge player. Daughter of Annie Becker and Nathan Finkle. Loving mother and grandmother. We will miss her goodness, her humor, her sharp wit and her unflagging optimism. Joan and Sam Hellerman Loving daughter and son-in-law

title: MGM Can't Fill Seats at Premiere of Kerkorian, the Sequel
description: KIRK KERKORIAN, the Las Vegas-based financier, should have learned by now. Some of his past dealings may make investors, even naive ones, very wary of buying a minority stake in a company in which he is running the show.

title: A Makeover For Money?
description: IT looks as if Money -- the country's highest-circulation personal-finance magazine -- could be facing some major content changes.

title: Keyboard Undermines the Humane
description: IN some plays, it's not the sounds of people talking that you hear, it's the words of a writer writing, the clicking of a keyboard.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: On the Lam

title: Making a Case That Bigger Means Better
description: Rhonda Sanderson, an obstetrician, and her husband, Richard Schuman, an oncologist, feel they have little time to waste. So once a month they go on a food-shopping expedition to a hangar-like discount store called BJ's Wholesale Club and buy enough groceries, prepared frozen foods and paper towels to equip a small army.

title: Who's Sorry Now? One Guess, Please
description: Janet Reno is livid, again, about what she cannot find out from her own staff about possible Chinese Government contributions to American campaigns. She is also embarrassed, yet again, that she misled Senator Fred Thompson by saying that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had no more information about the Chinese connection. She has apologized to Mr. Thompson, who shut down his inquiry on foreign money in the 1996 election on Oct. 31, six days before Ms. Reno experienced her most recent discovery that she, the Senate and the American people were not being told what her agents knew and when they knew it.

title: Stuyvesant Innovations Extend to Police and Fire
description: To the Editor:

title: The Two Hollywoods; The $75 Million Difference
description: The great thing about movies is that there are several ways to tell the same story. It can be cheap or it can be expensive, depending upon the approach. The cheapest way is not necessarily the safest way -- independent movies lose money, too. But if you are a producer or a studio executive, the most expensive way is always the most hazardous to your health. If you survive the big-budget process, however, the rewards can be vast.

title: That Day in Dallas
description: KENNEDY ASSASSINATED!

title: Over 50 Years, a Landmark Loses Some of Its Luster
description: FIFTY YEARS AGO LAST WEEK, ''Gentleman's Agreement,'' directed by Elia Kazan and starring Gregory Peck as a journalist who poses as a Jew and confronts deep-seated discrimination, opened in New York. Critics were overwhelmed. The New York Post noted that with this film the producer Darryl F. Zanuck, who was the prime force behind it, and American movies ''gained a new honor.'' Even Greta Garbo temporarily abandoned her characteristic silence to offer Zanuck a terse ''Absolutely wonderful.'' ''Gentleman's Agreement'' was more than a hit; for many people, it was a landmark in American culture, blowing the whistle on anti-Semitism in the country.

title: Gay Youths To Get Place To Call Home
description: It's a nondescript six-story building, not much to look at. But 30 East 39th Street will soon be making history: recently purchased by the nonprofit Hetrick-Martin Institute, it is to become the first group home in New York for gay and lesbian young people.

title: Harvard Grabs Share Of Ivy Title
description: Something was bound to give in today's matchup between first-place Harvard and Pennsylvania, the Ivy League's two best defensive teams.

title: No Swoon in Index Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Fight With Knives and Guns Leaves 5 Wounded at Club
description: An argument at a Bronx social club escalated into a fight with guns and knives that left five people wounded yesterday, at least one of them a bystander in a shop next door, the police said.

title: Two Rivals Up the Ante With New Theme Parks
description: THESE days, visitors to Universal Studios Florida are greeted with signs that read: ''Pardon our stardust while we expand our universe.'' Behind them 600 workers are laboring on Universal's biggest expansion yet -- a new theme park and nighttime entertainment and hotel complex, scheduled to open in the next two years.

title: The Two Hollywoods; Meeting Halfway
description: The best movie moment of recent months didn't require much: just a few men standing on a welfare line, doing their damnedest to resist a disco beat. But this scene from the British comedy ''The Full Monty'' worked as a great sight gag, summed up the film's graceful way of fusing humor with poignancy and showed how one sharp, humane image could count for so much more than lavish overkill. Most of all, it bridged the chasm between independent cinema and Hollywood product by telling a high-concept comic story with loads of heart. Built on nothing but ingenuity and talent, it had no set place on the film-making spectrum between spectacle and soul, all-star and no-name, big and small. It was a moment that could work anywhere.

title: Amateurs Steering New Class of Sailboat
description: A new class of one-design sailboats hit the market six months ago with remarkable success. In promoting the yacht's innovations, its design team came up with a unique sales angle: only amateur sailors are allowed to steer the boat during its class races.

title: The Two Hollywoods: The Screenwriters; Shane Black; Harmony Korine
description: Shane Black, at 35, already holds the record for the biggest script sale in movie history: $4 million for ''The Long Kiss Goodnight.'' Maybe he shouldn't have been the one to arrive first, but here he was, in the empty dining room of the Regent Beverly Wilshire Hotel, waiting for Harmony Korine, the 23-year-old writer and director of ''Gummo,'' whose indie career took off two years ago with ''Kids,'' for which he wrote the script. Korine is running about 45 minutes late, which is what you'd expect: he enjoys his reputation for trying people's patience.

title: Manufacturers See Lack of Basic Skills
description: United States manufacturers see serious shortcomings in basic reading, writing and math skills among their workers, according to an industry survey released on Friday.

title: Creating a New Breed of Prime Suspects
description: THE IMAGE OF MAFIA WIVES may never be the same. In ''Bella Mafia,'' a two-part CBS movie to be shown tonight and Tuesday night at 9, a quartet of recent mobsters' widows gets tough after all the men in the family are killed by a single hit man in one night. Pretty soon, this improbably glamorous group -- played by Vanessa Redgrave, Nastassja Kinski, Illeana Douglas and Jennifer Tilly -- are taking up firearms, planning assassinations and digging backyard graves. And even if their florid story includes beach-novel coincidences about a lost illegitimate grandson, viewers may find the sight of these talented actresses undergoing transformations like Al Pacino's in ''The Godfather, Part II'' memorable.

title: Leslie Fear, Lawrence Rusoff
description: Leslie Karen Fear, a dance-movement therapist and a special education teacher, was married last evening to S. Lawrence Rusoff, an investment analyst. Dr. Harlan J. Wechsler, the rabbi of Congregation Or Zarua in New York, officiated at the Glen Island Harbor Club in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: A Revival of Small Stocks: Big Rewards but More Risk
description: WITH small companies in their sixth month of leading the market, investors need to realize that shopping for them is far different from shopping for the large outfits that had long set the pace on Wall Street.

title: The Two Hollywoods; What Does The Audience Want?
description: Movie makers who assume they know what the audience is looking for learn, more often than not, that they have misunderstood yet again. It could hardly be otherwise, when the spectators themselves scarcely know. We scan the abbreviated titles on the marquee of the 12-screen multiplex (Edge Game Kiss Girls Ice Storm Tibet) as if a secret message were encoded there, or roam disconsolately among the aisles of a video store crammed with movies we aren't quite in the mood for. The 20th century draws to a close amid a glut of product and a pervasive loss of surprise.

title: November 9-15; Rights for European Women
description: Affirmation action for women got a big lift across Europe when the European Union's high court ruled that governments were allowed to impose hiring and promotional preferences in order to combat ''deep-rooted prejudices and stereotypes.'' The decision gives a green light to programs that give priority to women in public-sector jobs in the 15 countries that belong to the European Union. EDMUND L. ANDREWS

title: Park City
description: Before the snow -- authentic or man-made -- fell here last month, a worker was scraping and scrubbing off the Park City Ski Area logo from a pillar near the entrance to town. The owners of Utah's largest ski area have changed the name to Park City Mountain Resort. But despite efforts to bill this mining-town-turned-resort into a year-round destination, Park City will likely always thrive on its reputation for light powder snow.

title: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS
description: Hudson Hills Deal

title: Un-Naming Names; Today's Battles Topple Yesterday's Heroes
description: AT the end of the 20th century, the divide between blacks and whites in America has been measured in the polarization over subjects as varied as affirmative action and the acquittal of O. J. Simpson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANLEY, ROBERT
description: STANLEY-Robert. New York, NY. November 15, 1997. Beloved husband of Marylin. Beloved stepfather of Perry Brandston and Lori Brandston-Greene. Also survived by four grandchildren and many admiring friends, students and collectors of his paintings. Services 11 AM, Monday, at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave and 81st.

title: In Refinancing, Homeowners Find a Source for Saving
description: A MINI-BOOM of mortgage refinancings has occurred in recent weeks, in large part because of the recent turmoil in the stock market.

title: It Takes Two (Sexes) to Make Berries
description: THIS is a sexy column, a study in compatible pairs, a look at those plants that need two to bear fruit.

title: November 9-15; It's on the Edge. It's . . . British.
description: Jacques Chirac and Lionel Jospin, the President and Prime Minister of France, may wonder where it was they spent a just completed London summit conference with Prime Minister Tony Blair. There were no smart-stepping Grenadiers in scarlet tunics and bearskin hats to greet them, no banquets in paneled great rooms to fete them, no fusty Victorian arm chairs in which to seat them.

title: As Push Comes to Shove, O'Dwyer Can't Seem to Hide
description: Matt O'Dwyer can't explain it, but he has enjoyed tussling with people since he was a kid in the playgrounds in Lincolnshire, a Chicago suburb.

title: Belgrave's Actions On Denitrification
description: In an Oct. 12 letter to the editor of the Long Island Weekly, a lobsterman charges a coalition of North Shore sewage treatment plants with ''suffering a huge case of denial.'' He does so because these plants formed a coalition to challenge the issuance of reduced nitrogen discharge limits by the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, the agency that enforces discharge standards into the Sound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOBRINETZ, MORRIS
description: KOBRINETZ-Morris. On October 25, 1997. Husband of the late Belle (nee Nusbaum). Father of Chaplain General Simeon and Beverly, Rita and Irwin Bassett. Grandfather of five; great-grandfather of seven. We will miss him.

title: Jewish Life, From a Number of Vantage Points
description: FROM the 1920's through the 1950's, Camden was a hub of Jewish life in South Jersey. Its flourishing community supported six synagogues, a Y.M.H.A. and a Talmud Torah, an independent religious school. Given the subsequent demographic changes, it is rather bittersweet that ''Chosen,'' an exhibition celebrating Jewish culture, is being held at the Walt Whitman Cultural Arts Center here. At the same time, the show is a tribute to the center's namesake, who, writes David S. Reynolds, the poet's biographer, had a ''liberated openness to all kinds of religious discourses.''

title: Hipification Reaches the Street Where Peddlers Once Pushed Carts
description: FROM the outside, the new Xuly-Bet Funkin' Fashion store fits in so seamlessly with the discount clothing shops on Orchard Street that it's easy to pass by without noticing the first New York outpost of this hot Parisian label.

title: Nathalie Yerkes, Quintin George Jr.
description: Nathalie Spofford Yerkes and Quintin Hector George Jr. were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York. The Rev. John Halborg performed the ceremony.

title: New Language Standard Is Supported by Giuliani
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday embraced a decision by state officials to raise the foreign language requirement for most high school students, putting him at odds with his frequent ally, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, who has contended that the New York City system does not have the staff to comply with the new rules.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Education Life section on Nov. 2 about educational innovators referred imprecisely to some scientific developments that became legacies of Franklin D. Roosevelt's era. Although advanced by financing from by the National Science Foundation, the development of nuclear warheads, rockets and missiles was mainly the work of the Atomic Energy Commission. Polio vaccines were primarily the responsibility of the Public Health Service, through its National Institutes of Health.

title: Exotics Sounds From Far Beyond the Horizon
description: A FEW seconds of listening to the unnerving, eerie tones of the Throat Singers of Tuva is all it takes to prove that, while technology makes the world seem small, some places are still indeed far away. The four-man Tuvan ensemble's very name, Huun-Huur-Tu, enhances the feeling of vast distance, as do the names of instruments -- igil, byzaanchi and toschpular -- that accompany extended growling and whistling songs about the land.

title: Agency Says Gas Emissions Will Be Worse Than Thought
description: The emissions of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases from energy use will grow faster than previously expected in the United States in the next few years, the Energy Department said this week. This would make it more difficult for the United States to live up to President Clinton's proposal to cap emissions of these gases at 1990 levels over the next 10 to 15 years.

title: The Two Hollywoods: The Actors; Tom Hanks; Ben Affleck
description: At 41, Tom Hanks is the biggest star of his generation: back-to-back Oscars for his lead roles in Philadelphia and Forrest Gump; total domestic box-office receipts in the last 10 years of $1.3 billion, and a reputation as a very nice guy.

title: The Two Hollywoods
description: If you are thinking of going to a movie tonight, you might begin to narrow your choices by asking, Which Hollywood do I want to see? Do I want special effects or affectless dialogue? Do I want to see what can be done for $100 million or what can be done for a tenth of that? Do I want something finely cooked or something raw? What do you say, honey: ''Starship Troopers'' or ''Eve's Bayou''?

title: The Nation; Once More, With Feeling: Recycling the Kennedys
description: JUST what is it about the Kennedys, anyway?

title: Super-Bookstore Opens in Glasgow
description: Travelers who consider a visit to the local bookstore as a necessary stop on their itineraries have a new option in Glasgow. Waterstone's -- which began business in 1982 and now has 108 book shops in Britain, Ireland and North America -- has recently opened the largest bookstore in Britain in 50 years. Situated on Glasgow's Sauchiehall Street, the store has 28,000 square feet of space on five floors and offers 150,000 titles (including an extensive travel section). Amenities include a coffee shop, chairs and sofas, an Internet cafe and an interactive database called Ossian, with information on 1.2 million titles, as well as local events. Throughout the store are headphones allowing customers to listen to readings and interviews with authors, who will also make personal appearances. Waterstone's, 153-157 Sauchiehall Street, Glasgow G2 3EW; (44-141) 3329105, fax (44-141) 3310478.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KLEBAN, FRANCIS J.
description: KLEBAN-Francis J. November 14, 1909 to November 18, 1995. Lovingly remembered.

title: It's His Half-Year To Wash The Dishes
description: AFTER more than 30 years of marriage, two children, a major career change (his) and a hard-fought degree in photography (hers), Charles and Elizabeth Handy found themselves, about four years ago, at a personal and professional crossroad.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRACT, HAROLD M.
description: TRACT-Harold M. ''A truly noble man.'' Passed away on November 18, 1991.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, PAUL
description: FRIED-Paul. Yeshiva University and its Sy Syms School of Business are saddened by the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, beloved husband of Regina and father of Pamela Rechtschaffen, National Board member of the Y.U. Women's Organization and a Y.U. Guardian with her husband, Manfred Rechtschaffen, member of the SSSB Board. We extend our heartfelt condolences to grandchildren, Andrew and Eric Rechtschaffen, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: For Vencor, Ambition and a Sagging Stock
description: VENCOR INC., the nation's largest operator of long-term hospitals and the second-largest operator of nursing homes, is surrounded by a big question mark.

title: Deferring to 'Great Yellow Father'; Kodak Workers Say Layoffs May Be Necessary Medicine
description: Bill States, a supervisor at an Eastman Kodak plant here, is searching the want ads and polishing his resume -- tasks that, at age 55, he thought were behind him. But like thousands of his colleagues, he is suddenly worried that he will be among the 10,000 people the company plans to lay off.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-14

title: An Admired Citizen, a Killing, a Paralyzed School Board
description: By all accounts, Perry Buckley has been something of a local celebrity in Corona: a retired fireman, Cub Scout leader and the former P.T.A. president at P. S. 14. He was also one of the nine members of Community School Board 24, a man many neighbors thought to be a model citizen who cared about the children in his community.

title: In and Out Of the Zone
description: I TOOK my first ski lesson at Lake Tahoe when I was 52 and learned to ski at the same time my son Forrest was learning to walk. It was a nice empathetic overlap of joyful learning, my first turns mixing with his first steps.

title: U.S. Weighs the Value of Bombing to Coerce Iraq
description: In the 1991 Persian Gulf war, the United States-led coalition dropped more than 88,000 tons of bombs on Iraq, crippling the country's electricity networks and oil refineries, severing bridges and destroying roads.

title: Rachel Lebowitz, Ephraim Y. Cohen
description: Rachel Lebowitz, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Elliot W. Lebowitz of Brookline, Mass., is to be married today to Ephraim Yonah Cohen, a son of Prof. and Mrs. Getzel M. Cohen of Cincinnati. Rabbi Yecheskel Spitzer is to perform the ceremony at the Copley Plaza in Boston.

title: Kimchi Alley
description: I read with pleasure Ruth Reichl's overview of Manhattan's Korean food scene (''Kimchi Alley,'' Oct. 19). I have one cavil. However finger-licking good Korean food is, Koreans do not, as your article states, ''eat with their fingers.'' With one exception, they eat with chopsticks and spoons. (Often, the chopsticks are of silver -- something that distinguishes Korean utensils from those of other Asian countries.) The exception: lettuce-wrapped meats. These are finger foods because they are hard to negotiate with chopsticks or spoons.

title: Final Step for Garage Door Openers
description: LAST week the Home Clinic outlined the procedures for installing a garage door opener. The first part of the procedure consisted of assembling the drive rail and power unit, then mounting them in place. The next step is to connect the drive mechanism to the door. The link between the two is the door arm; it connects the traveler on the drive rail to a bracket bolted to the door.

title: Simple, Austere, An Old Genre Is Daringly New
description: SAY IT WAS 1780 OR SO, AND A modestly successful Boston merchant wanted a portrait of himself. An elaborate oil painting on canvas, typically commissioned by a wealthy aristocrat, would be beyond the merchant's means. Instead, he would probably opt for a silhouette, hiring a local amateur or itinerant professional to create his shadow portrait, as silhouettes were also called.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PARADNY, ROBERT, M.D.
description: PARADNY-Robert, M.D. It seems like yesterday that you were here with us making our tomorrows better. Our loving memories of you make even today seem brighter. Forever in our hearts, we miss you always. Love, Your Family.

description: A DOCTORAL candidate in history at the University of Chicago, Alexis Bray Dudden has so many books that there are novels and historical texts instead of food stored on her kitchen shelves.

description: DOVMAN-Frances. Age 94, died November 10, 1997 in Los Angeles, California. Born April 6th, 1903, in Brooklyn, NY. Lived in NYC until 1990. Loving sister to Bea and Pearl. Kind and generous aunt to Roslyn, Lola, Harriett and Irving. Devoted stepmother to Allan and Margie. Devoted member to B'nai B'rith and the NYPL-Center for Humanities. Burial was held at the Hillside Memorial Park, Culver City, California. For further information, McKenzie Cremation and Burial 562-989-3606.

title: Attack of the Bloids
description: YOU'VE probably seen them lingering around the doors of your favorite bookstore, coffee shop or bar. Some are polite, others bellicose and almost all of them will get your hands dirty.

title: From Court House to Opera House
description: The law came first for Judge Richard Owen, who fulfilled his childhood dream of becoming a trial lawyer before taking his seat on the bench of Federal District Court. But the judge, who has presided over cases ranging from the Mafia Commission to the suit against George Harrison, who was found to have subconsciously plagiarized the tune for ''My Sweet Lord,'' has also passionately pursued his avocation: composing operas.

description: When the South Bronx deteriorated during the 70's and 80's, its public libraries did, too. Buildings and books were defaced and relatively few services were offered. Frequently, it was a dangerous walk to the branch libraries.

title: The Two Hollywoods; Studios Ignoring You? Quick, Make an Indie!
description: 'Who is Simon Baker Denny?'' asks Matthew Modine, looking up from a stack of head shots and facing a room full of William Morris agents. The Morris team, in gray-and-brown business attire, has assembled one fall afternoon in the gray-and-brown Morris conference room to help their client cast his writing-directing debut, ''If . . . Dog . . . Rabbit.'' Modine, who came to prominence in the 80's in movies like ''Streamers,'' ''Birdy'' and ''Full Metal Jacket,'' will also act in this independent film, a black comedy about an American trailer-park family of thieves and their misguided attempt to rob a Mexican bullring. For Modine, directing offers autonomy and, after a series of missteps, a chance to reinvent his career. The agents are firing names at him -- all up-and-coming Morris clients who could possibly play Modine's brother: Denny, Christopher Eccleston, Jake Busey. Talented newcomers like these are the lifeblood of independent film making, and while the agents are keen to help Modine, they are also keen to help the rest of their stable find roles. An agent tosses out Christian Bale, the refined English actor who made his debut in ''Empire of the Sun.'' ''I love Christian Bale,'' Modine says, sighing. He continues, ''If we're going to go English, how about Ewan McGregor?'' McGregor, a Scot, is the highly-sought-after star of ''A Life Less Ordinary'' and the upcoming prequels to ''Star Wars.'' An embarrassed agent gently breaks it to Modine that McGregor is ''really unavailable.''

title: New Jersey Tops Hasek
description: They booed Dominik Hasek during the introductions, booed him when he was the subject of a trivia question and booed him when the Devils scored their third goal after just 22 minutes.

title: From Iceland to the Brooklyn Art Scene, It's Gen Ice-X
description: Nearly a thousand years after Leif Ericson settled Vinland, Icelanders are again invading the New World. This time it's the Brooklyn art scene.

title: A Dress Was Her ID
description: DINA VIERNY, THE LAST model of the sculptor Aristide Maillol, worked with Varian Fry's covert rescue network in the south of France during World War II. Now 78, she recalled those years in a recent interview at the Maillol Museum here, which she created.

title: A Closing Notice, or Not
description: The company no longer has need of someone's services, and the message must be delivered. How does it come? Often, awkwardly: The corporate apartment's landlord asks for a moving date, the computer no longer recognizes a password, or the office lock is changed. How has your company handled dismissals? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. title: Now at the Movies: Seating More Like Broadway Than the Subway
description: It was 10 minutes before the movie ''The Jackal'' was to begin, and Allan Pilson had managed to surmount one of the more daunting challenges of Manhattan living: he and two others had been assured they would be sitting together at a first-run movie on a Friday night.

title: BOOKEND; James Marshall, Wicked Angel
description: The picture book is a peculiar art form that thrives on genius, intuition, daring and a meticulous attention to its history and its various, complex components. The picture book is a picture puzzle, badly misunderstood by critics and condescended to by far too many as merely a trifle for ''the kiddies.'' Children are routinely patronized, and thus so are we who spend our creative lives entertaining them and nourishing their spirit. Given this minefield of confusions and uncertainties, when such a work turns out looking as easy as a James Marshall picture book, it says everything about the man. Marshall is the last of a long line of masters that began in the late 19th century with the pre-eminent English illustrator, Randolph Caldecott; then continued in our century with Jean de Brunhoff in France and Edward Ardizzone in England; and then via Tomi Ungerer arrived full blast in America, where the laurel wreath settled finally, splendidly, on the judicious, humane, witty and astonishingly clever head of James Marshall.

title: Pointing The Kids Downhill
description: THE first sign that we were headed for the right place came as we boarded the plane to Steamboat Springs, Colo.: it was at least half-filled with kids, a sight dreaded by most travelers but one that filled me with hope.

title: Hackley Students Enter Stock Tournament
description: AARON SIEGEL of Harrison is a natural. The lanky 11th grader at the Hackley School here projects exuberance as he describes the Hornets, a school investment club he founded last month. Words like ''incredible,'' ''exciting'' and ''amazing'' vault through his conversation..

title: The Swish Of Fringe
description: Flapper, urban cowboy, disco queen, hippie. They had one thing in common: fringe. Now that neo-romantic, neo-bohemian look is back, turning up on everything from a Christian Dior couture gown to a handbag to a Chanel suit.

title: In 'The Rake's Progress,' Love Conquers All -- Almost
description: ON THURSDAY EVENING, THE Metropolitan Opera will give its first performance of Igor Stravinsky's ''Rake's Progress'' since 1953, when the opera was brand new. It was conceived almost exactly 50 years ago, on Sept. 30, 1947, when W. H. Auden met in New York with Ralph Hawkes of Boosey & Hawkes, Stravinsky's publisher, and agreed to furnish the libretto. What had up to then been only Stravinsky's vague wish, to write an opera in English on the theme of some Hogarth engravings that he had seen in Chicago, became a project on that day.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

description: LEAFING through information on quick trips to Europe this winter is like opening a gift box of chocolates: They look wonderful, the price is right, and it's just a matter of making a choice.

Schlenger of Florham Park, N.J. Rabbi Donald B. Rossoff performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

Their glossy black-and-silver publicity stills defined the glamour of old Hollywood. And the photographer who created the look was George Hurrell, a would-be painter from Cincinnati.

title: A Retail State of Mind
description: FOR some it is compulsion, the need to possess yet one more thing. For many, it is clear-cut purpose, an essential item for home or work. And for others, it is a way to pass the time on a rainy day, or maybe just a cloudy one.

title: Carsten Sierck, Allen Shapard 4th
description: Carsten Wentworth Sierck, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander W. Sierck of Washington, was married yesterday to William Allen Shapard 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Shapard 3d of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. The Rev. David Poist performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Paul's Memorial Church in Charlottesville, Va.

title: The Two Hollywoods; Robert Redford Has This Problem
description: Tucked in the lower right-hand corner of Robert Redford's dressing-room mirror is a black-and-white photo of Samuel Beckett. The great Irish playwright of existential despair looks wintery and hawklike, his visage a crumbling tombstone of deep cracks. It's not the face one would think a Hollywood superstar known for playing sunny romantic leads would want staring back at him every time his hair is brushed. At least not while working on Redford's current project, ''The Horse Whisperer,'' a big-budget, big-emotions melodrama based on the shamelessly corny best-selling novel by Nicholas Evans. ''The Horse Whisperer'' -- which Redford is being paid about $20 million by Touchstone Pictures to produce, direct and star in -- isn't Beckett, or even close, and Redford's role as a kind Montana rancher with a gift for soothing traumatized animals is frankly heroic and warmly optimistic. It's a movie about ''healing,'' according to Redford, a movie about the ''textures of the West.''

title: The View From: New Haven; Schools Looking for Spot on Renovation List
description: THE City of New Haven has embarked on an ambitious, unusually financed school construction program that promises long-overdue improvements in the daily lives of the district's 20,000 students and 1,500 teachers and administrators.
