title: At Home and Under Duress With Bosnian Croats
description: There is no electricity in this village, no telephone service, no running water, no school, no clinic or store. Nearly every building, including the Catholic church, has been wrecked, the walls splattered and dismembered by the ordnance of war, some roofs nothing more than gaping holes to the sky.

title: Best Illustrated Books 1997
description: The illustrations on these pages have been taken from the Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 1997. Since 1952, the Book Review has annually asked a panel of judges to make a selection from among the several thousand children's books published each year. The judges this year were Barbara Barstow, from the Cleveland Public Library; Barbara Cooney, an illustrator whose most recent book is ''Eleanor''; and Sam Swope, a critic and author. As a matter of note, Lisbeth Zwerger has been a winner four times previously, Gennady Spirin three times, Leo and Diane Dillon and Jerry Pinkney twice before.

title: Rare Lobster Lands in the Spotlight Instead of the Pot
description: Bill Coppersmith says the traffic in his fish market here has never been so intense, ''what with visits by curious folks and the television and newspapers.''

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Oct. 19 about headsets with anti-noise technology misstated the timing of their introduction on commercial airlines. United, which began installing the technology last month, was not the first line to do so. Japan Airlines has had the headsets since October 1992.

title: Big Questions At Taos
description: ''WHERE'S the snow?'' my daughter Charlotte said. On a sunny morning in early March, 7-year-old Charlotte, my husband, Throop Wilder, and I were driving the 22 miles from Taos to the Taos Ski Valley. Bulbs and willows were budding; horses frisked in corrals by the roadside. Edging the New Mexico horizon, the Sangre de Cristo Mountains, risen from the same red sandstone as the Taos plateau, seemed tiny. The road turned east across the immense plain toward the mountains, and the snow cover began when we entered the long canyon leading to the ski area. It felt as if we were leaving the Southwest and heading into a different country.

title: Pregnant With Complications
description: Your article addresses many of the ethical questions that arise out of the egg-donor program -- issues that involve the potential parents, the children who are born as a result of these procedures and the women who provide eggs. The ethical issues surrounding these young egg ''donors'' concern me most. I shuddered when I read, ''They see it as giving blood.'' This is not blood. These young women become biological mothers, with all the inherent fantasies that understandably accompany this. Is there any sort of follow-up to help donors with the psychological issues that may arise? What happens 20 years down the road, when the child who is conceived wants to meet its biological mother? Is anyone preparing the donors for this possibility?

title: The Two Hollywoods: The Producers; Lawrence Gordon; Christine Vachon
description: Lawrence Gordon, 61, has been a producer for 30 years, working on such box-office hits as ''Die Hard,'' ''Field of Dreams'' and ''48 Hours.'' He was involved with one of the most notorious Hollywood big-budget extravaganzas, ''Waterworld.'' Interestingly, he is the executive producer of ''Boogie Nights,'' this fall's most talked about indie.

title: THEATER REVIEW ; From Little Disputes, Great Media Events Grow
description: A CHILISICLE is a ''glob of chili frozen on a stick.'' That may be the most inventive line, but not the most unappetizing, in Jim Lehrer's play ''Chili Queen'' at the Helen Hayes Performing Arts Center here.

title: Make It Floral Park Nassau, Not Queens
description: COMDEN and Green wrote the lyrics, ''Fame, if you win it/Comes and goes in a minute.'' Warhol raised the ante to 15. Now, Susan Jeremy, in her journey from the arithmetical to the analytical, has an interrogatory, newly reflective spin on fame's sum and substance.

title: INSIDE
description: American Jews Troubled

title: 'Racechanges'
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: MURDER BOOK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, SAMUEL
description: BROOKS-Samuel. Beloved husband of Irene, devoted father of Shari Berk, Laura Schwartzapfel, and Jerome Zisfein, dear brother of Betty and Joe, adored grandfather of Seth, Michelle, Beth, Stuart, Julie and Alex. Services were held. For information ''Gutterman-Musicant'' 800-522-0588.

title: Pregnant With Complications
description: I was struck by Sophia's fortitude, resourcefulness and capacity to love -- all qualities that will serve her well as a mother. To impose an arbitrary age limit on a woman's right to conceive would be cruel. The greatest loss would be to the unborn children, for, in my experience, women with a history of infertility are among the most devoted and loving parents, continually aware that their children are precious miracles.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Artist's Angst Is All in Your Head
description: ONE of the most powerful ideas of modern science -- right up there with Darwinian evolution and the magnificent theories of relativity and quantum mechanics -- is a comparatively obscure dictum called the Church-Turing hypothesis. Laid out in the 1930's by the great mathematicians Alonzo Church and Alan Turing, this principle, which lies at the very core of computer science, holds that any procedure whatsoever can be carried out by a machine.

title: Lauren Chottiner, Alan S. Maza
description: Dr. Lauren Mandy Chottiner, an internist, and Alan Stuart Maza, a lawyer, are to be married today. The bridegroom's father, Rabbi Joseph Maza, is to perform the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Syracuse.

title: Is the Great One Still Good Enough to Play in the Olympics?
description: If Team Canada is reserving one honorary position on its Olympic hockey roster for a living legend, it should go to Gordie Howe, not Wayne Gretzky. The 69-year-old Howe has seniority, Lord (Stanley) knows, and Howe is still willing to lace up the skates every now and then.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS; Woodchuck Nation
description: MEAN MARGARET By Tor Seidler. Illustrated by Jon Agee. 165 pp. New York: Michael di Capua Books/ HarperCollins Publishers. $14.95. (Ages 5 and up)

title: F.Y.I.
description: Where's Tonto?

title: Microsoft, A Pioneer In Quality Accounting
description: It's not often that companies voluntarily disclose that their profits may be substantially overstated. But that is just what Microsoft has done in its latest quarterly report. For communicating frankly with its owners, Microsoft deserves a gold medal for quality accounting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMAN, FRANCES
description: HARTMAN-Frances. Died October 8. Mourned deeply. Her loving friends

title: If Money's No Object, Mets Want Sheffield
description: Gary Sheffield won't go away. As improbable it might seem, the Mets just won't let him disappear from their thinking.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Nov. 2 showing Ken Burns, Dayton Duncan and Stephen Ambrose -- director, writer and commentator for the television documentary ''Lewis and Clark'' -- carried an an incomplete credit. The photographer was Lucy Kraus, for General Motors.

title: Retro Potions
description: For Caswell-Massey, everything old is truly new again. The 245-year-old apothecary, which boasts George Washington as an early client, is trying to restore its historic cachet with a line in retro packaging, including copies of old labels. It is a concept that marketing strategists embrace (another case: the vintage repackaging of Porter's Lotion, for dry skin). Dr. Hunter's Original Remedies, named for Caswell-Massey's founder, feature updated classics like body cleanser and tooth powder, in aluminum tubes or amber glass. In a bow to progress, some bottles are plastic. What would Washington say?

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday in The Sophisticated Traveler, part 2 of The Times Magazine, with an article about Chicago's architectural heritage, misstated the address of a green glass skyscraper shown overlooking the El in an illustration of the city's architecture. It is 333 Wacker Drive, not 333 North Michigan Avenue.

title: Pregnant With Complications
description: Sophia is deluding herself when she asks that she be given the same forbearance accorded to older fathers. By definition, the partners of these men are of childbearing age. While I disapprove equally of older men having children, there is nevertheless a fair degree of certainty that at least one parent will see the child safely into adulthood. I can sympathize with the depths of her feelings, but I think the world needs menopausal parents about as much as it needs cloned sheep.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: National Football League

title: Native Faces, Native Voices
description: IN A SACRED MANNER

title: Fighting Tour Buses, Picture May Be Worth 1,000 Petitions
description: New York is a city of angry letter writers, screaming phone callers and drafters of not-too-subtle petitions. Then there are the picture takers, like Alicia Civitello.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: Some Gray Around the Edges; While Bulls Show Their Age, Rodman Struggles Just to Show Up
description: It was 7 o'clock in the evening and there was still no Dennis Rodman at the United Center. The Chicago Bulls' game against Charlotte was scheduled for 7:30 Friday night, and it wasn't going to wait for Godot, let alone Rodman, who has pulled so many stunts he could have earned a living on a Hollywood set. And what was this one now?

title: Nice Timing Indeed For Celebrating Big League Baseball
description: AN exhibition called ''It's A Hit! The History and Heroes of Baseball,'' at the Barnum Museum in Bridgeport through March, celebrates the players and explores their impact on American culture.

title: Sydney Pruitt and Dr. Al Fraser
description: Sydney Thompson Pruitt and Dr. Wilmot Alfred Fraser were married yesterday at the Church of the Intercession in New York. Canon Frederick B. Williams officiated with the Rev. Earl Kooperkamp. Both are Episcopal priests.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Monday's Meal By Leslie H. Edgerton. University of North Texas, paper, $14.95.

title: Be Thankful This Isn't a Story About Cannibalism
description: GUARD your mother's batter-stained favorite recipes because with the right prose and packaging they might be literature.

title: Sidewalk Superintendents Stayed on Job for Years
description: To the Editor:

title: Tracy Dreis and Peter Leto
description: Tracy Dreis, the daughter of Nancy and Alfred Dreis of Freehold, N.J., is to be married this afternoon to Peter Leto, the son of Nina Leto of Manhattan. Justice Harold Silverman of State Supreme Court in the Bronx is to perform the ceremony at One if by Land, Two if by Sea, a Manhattan restaurant.

title: Cecil F. Poole, 83, a Legal Leader for Blacks
description: Cecil F. Poole, the first black United States Attorney outside a United States territory and the first black Federal judge in Northern California, has died in Kentfield, Calif. He was 83.

title: School Sheds Stigma and Renews Dedication
description: On the day after Jordan L. Mott Junior High School regained its good name, there was no celebration. The morning bell rang as always, ushering in the succession of small sacrifices that has become common in this South Bronx school that considers itself reborn.

title: OUT THERE; A Cuban Fantasia Mambos Into Main Street
description: A CUBAN beat was pounding from the heart of America's pop Main Street. Inside Bongos Cuban Cafe, a theme restaurant in Disney World that celebrated its official opening on Nov. 6, a band drummed out the propulsive rhythm of a traditional Afro-Cuban conga while the Cuban-American pop star Gloria Estefan danced triumphantly down a curving staircase. She was followed by Minnie Mouse in a Carmen Miranda fruit headdress and ruffled dress carrying Emily, Ms. Estefan's young daughter.

title: Park May Be Dump, but Golf Center Proposal Stirs Protest
description: Dreier-Offerman Park, 73 mostly undeveloped acres, has some of the best fishing spots in Gravesend. But in recent years, it has become more of a dumping ground than a recreational resource.

title: Julie Glover, Kirk Mitchell
description: Julie Mable Glover, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Price Glover of New York, was married yesterday to Kirk Francis Mitchell, the son of Kandy A. Mitchell of Eden Prairie, Minn., and William F. Mitchell of Victoria, Minn. The Rev. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Simple Chic by Lalique
description: When Rene Lalique created a cabochon ring from one solid crystal orb in 1931, he could not have known that it would one day be the catalyst for a whole new perspective on the venerable crystal company he founded. Lalique has become hip. At least a bit.

title: Two Visions Compete for Struggling La Marqueta
description: During its heyday, La Marqueta, once known for its wide selection of Puerto Rican products, was a bustling shopping complex of 400 vendors that stretched five blocks on Park Avenue from 111th Street to 116th Street underneath the Metro-North viaduct. But since the 1970's, business has declined, and many attempts to revive it have failed. Today, only 20 vendors operate in a blocklong building between 114th and 115th Streets, one of the four remaining indoor buildings. Neither the renovation of that building nor a newly constructed outdoor plaza could lure customers.

title: Washington Exhibition Underscores Thomas Moran's Stature
description: UNCANNY expanses of tall, lavender rock formations crowned in orange and silhhouetted against pink-tinged horizons were a revelation to Congress in 1872, when Thomas Moran's Yellowstone watercolors were presented as supporting evidence in the debates that led to the establishment of the National Park Service. The Government subsequently made the artist's panoramic canvases ''Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone,'' 1872, and ''Chasm of the Colorado,'' 1873-74, its first painting purchases for the Capitol, thus propelling him to national prominence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATIUCHOK, WILLIAM
description: BATIUCHOK-William, M.D. On November 14, 1997. Born May 26, 1920. Beloved and devoted husband of Margaret. Loving father of John and his wife Louisa, Margaret and Susan. Devoted grandfather of Daniel and Beth. Graduate of Columbia College '41, Cornell University Medical College '44, Emeritus Director Thoracic Surgery of Wyckoff Heights Hospital and Flushing Hospital. Secretary, Board of Trustees Wyckoff Heights Hospital; past President of Medical Board Flushing Hospital; past President and current Member, Board of Trustees, Garden School. Reposing in Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd, Flushing. Visiting hours Sunday and Monday 2-5 and 7-10 PM. Service Monday, 7:30 PM. Funeral Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment Maple Grove Cemetery. Donations to Wyckoff Heights Hospital, Flushing Hospital, Columbia College '41 or Garden School.

title: November 9-15; Hail Fellows Well Met
description: Boris N. Yeltsin and Jiang Zemin were eager to do the bear-hug thing when they met before the cameras in Beijing. No embrace of socialist brothers that; more an attempt by the Russian and Chinese leaders to show neighborly solidarity.

title: Classical Briefs
description: BEETHOVEN: PIANO SONATAS NOS. 29, 31

title: November 9-15; Attention, Snuff Eaters: See a Shrink
description: Mental institutions have come a long way since the 19th century. For one thing, they no longer carry stigmataizing names like Lunatic Asylum West of the Allegenys, which the Western State Hospital in central West Virginia was called when it opened on Oct. 22, 1864.

title: SOAPBOX; Buying Time
description: SHOPPING -- what can I write about shopping?'' I thought, as I raced home from school, past several shopping centers and strip malls, dashing into Boston Market in order to get home on time, to put down my thoughts on the shopping that I never have time to do.

title: Mean Streets
description: Charles Dickens's novel OLIVER TWIST, about the adventures of an orphan boy in 19th-century England, comes to television in a new production on the Wonderful World of Disney.

title: On Language; The Full Monty
description: How do you describe ''every-thing''? I don't mean a few cosmic items, or a bunch of stuff; I mean the whole shootin' match, the works, the entire kit and caboodle, the whole ball of wax. Everything, including the kitchen sink.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARDEN, EDITH FROMKIN
description: ARDEN-Edith Fromkin. Beloved wife of the late Harold Fromkin and the late Sidney Arden, loving mother of Barry and Miles, devoted grandmother to Heather and Alissa. Services at BoulevardRiverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, NY on Monday November 17, 1997 at 11:30AM. For information call 516-295-3100.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Alison Napack, Christian Malone
description: Alison Jane Napack, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Napack of Old Brookville, N.Y., was married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., to Christian Bernard Malone, a son of James L. Malone of Jamestown, N.C., and the late Mary R. Malone. The Rev. Joseph M. Zorawick officiated. The Rev. James F. Hynes, a Roman Catholic priest, assisted.

title: Pregnant With Complications
description: I read with interest the story on pregnancy in older women and the issues surrounding egg donation. Especially intriguing was the statement of the bioethicist Arthur Caplan that egg donation is primarily egg sale. ''Would anyone be doing it if there was no payment involved?'' he asks.

title: Jay M. Gates, Laurie Brett Rabine
description: Laurie Brett Rabine, a daughter of Sally and Joel H. Rabine of Melville, N.Y., was married last evening to Jay Marshall Gates, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Gates of Manhattan. Rabbi Marc Gellman officiated at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan.

title: No Swoon in Index Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Alma Mater Gets a Makeover
description: TO L. JAY OLIVA, dean of the College of Arts and Science, fell the unhappy task in 1973 of lowering the flag for the last time at New York University's uptown campus, a Bronx landmark by McKim, Mead & White, which the struggling institution could no longer afford.

title: Danish Modern
description: Thumbelina

title: Brian Wilson Returns, Enigmatic as Ever
description: IN THE CHAOS OF POPULAR MUSIC, Brian Wilson has emerged as one of this fall's strange attractors, a reference appearing too often for coincidence. Capitol Records has just released ''The Pet Sounds Sessions,'' a four-CD set based on the 1966 Beach Boys album that lasts all of 36 minutes. The present-day Wilson has showed up alongside his daughters, Carnie and Wendy, as a producer, songwriter and backup vocalist in four songs on their album ''The Wilsons'' (Capitol), and he wrote a new song for it with Tony Asher, his lyricist from ''Pet Sounds.''

title: In the Region/Connecticut; In New Haven, Habitat Tackles a Rundown Building
description: LAST month, on a rainy Saturday, seven architects and five interns in grimy work clothes spent more than seven hours at 93-95 Read Street in New Haven initiating the job of gutting a dilapidated two-family house in a rundown neighborhood called Newhallville.

title: Final Steps for Garage Door Openers
description: LAST week the Home Clinic outlined the procedures for installing a garage door opener. The first part of the procedure consisted of assembling the drive rail and power unit, then mounting them in place. The next step is to connect the drive mechanism to the door. The link between the two is the door arm; it connects the traveler on the drive rail to a bracket bolted to the door.

title: When It Takes Two (Sexes) to Make Berries
description: THIS is a sexy column, a study in compatible pairs, a look at those plants that need two to bear fruit.

title: Iraq Says Attack Would Not Alter Its Ban on U.S. Inspectors
description: Iraq said today that its decision to expel American arms inspectors working for the United Nations could not be reversed even by military attack, and it warned of a new chapter in the ''great and eternal mother of battles.''

title: Carmen Gomez and Michael Bruce
description: Maria Carmen Gomez, a loan officer, and Michael Bruce, an advertising executive, were married yesterday at the Church of Our Lady of Good Counsel in New York. The Rev. Richard Terga officiated with Rabbi Dennis C. Tobin.

title: Bucks County Art
description: To the Editor: There's so much to do in Bucks County that it is no surprise that you couldn't cover it all (''What's Doing in Bucks County,'' Oct. 5). Works of some of the wonderful artists mentioned can be found in the ''Creative Bucks County'' exhibition at the James A. Michener Art Museum across from the Mercer Museum in Doylestown.

title: Soft Touch; Sometimes, the Punishment Fits the Gender
description: AFTER a jury convicted Louise Woodward of murdering the 8-month-old boy in her care, much of America, nearly all of Britain and one judge in Cambridge, Mass., reached a consensus about her: the 19-year-old au pair was just a girl.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WASHINGTON HEIGHTS; How Cloistered the Cloisters?
description: Last month, the rape of a woman who had been jogging in the shadow of the Cloisters stunned Washington Heights residents who view the section of Fort Tryon Park inhabited by the medieval museum as their own little urban oasis.

title: The Tale Of the Secret Tapes
description: THE executives from four competing companies found their seats in a room at the Palace Hotel in Tokyo and plotted the details of the crime.

title: Account Belies Nixon's Despair Over Watergate
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Right's Point Man on Race
description: In many ways, Clint Bolick, a 39-year-old Washington lawyer, is the maestro of the political right on issues of race. He is increasingly setting the tone and defining the terms of the national debate, forcing civil rights groups to respond to his view, rather than enacting their own, of what Government policy on race ought to be.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Paul Stringer; Making the Case Against Land Mines
description: PAUL STRINGER, 48, is the principal of Bulkeley High School in Hartford. Last month, Mr. Stringer, who survived the explosion of a land mine while serving in the Marine Corps in Vietnam, was a keynote speaker at the Connecticut Conference to Abolish Land Mines in New Haven. The conference took place just a week after the International Campaign to Ban Land mines, of which the Connecticut Coalition is a member, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.

title: That 800 Number You Dial for T-Shirts or Orchids Just Might Be in Secaucus
description: You dream of snuggling up this winter under the flannel sheets with the ''Let It Snow'' motif and the Berkshire down comforter from the Company Store catalogue. So you fill out your order blank and mail it to 500 Company Store Road in La Crosse, Wis., where some latter-day elf shuffles off to the stockroom of a quaint old-fashioned warehouse, finds the sheets, wraps them up and sends them on their way. Right?

title: Joanne Chaseman, Steven Bloomstein
description: Joanne Amy Chaseman and Steven Jay Bloomstein were married last evening at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington. Rabbi Leonard Cahan performed the ceremony.

title: Articles of Faith
description: THE ILLUSTRATED HISTORY

title: Up by 13, Nets Find A Way To Lose
description: The Nets were playing a reeling Detroit Pistons team that was without Grant Hill and Joe Dumars tonight. They had Kerry Kittles back in their starting lineup. They had a 13-point lead with less than a minute to play in the third quarter.

title: VIEWPOINT; . . . Or the Growl of a Bear?
description: FOR investors, the main question after the market tumble last month is whether it was just another short-term correction or the beginning of a prolonged bear market. I believe it is a bear.

title: Diann Cameron, Damyn Kelly
description: Diann Ellen Cameron, the daughter of Dorothy and Harry S. Cameron Sr. of the Bronx, was married yesterday to Damyn Whitfield Kelly, a son of Myra Kelly of Elmsford, N.Y., and Edwin W. Kelly Sr. of the Bronx. The Rev. Calvin R. Kendricks performed the ceremony at Trinity Baptist Church in the Bronx.

title: The Flowering of Uncle Jim
description: The Gardener

title: The Founding of a Father
description: GEORGE WASHINGTON

title: Honoring the Greats
description: To the Editor:

title: As Complexity Grows, So Does the Lawyer's Role
description: THIRTY years ago the commercial real estate lease was a simpler document, lawyers say. Their second point is that changes since then -- some of them quite recent -- have drawn lawyers more than ever into the process of getting deals done.

title: Americans, Stop Whining
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAUSSEN, SILVILYN
description: GAUSSEN-Silvilyn. With deep regret we mourn the passing of our beloved employee and friend Silvilyn Gaussen. The Argo Corporation

title: Not Just Skiing Anymore
description: SKI resort owners have been engaged in a high-stakes Monopoly game in the past year, battling for ownership of the continent's largest ski areas. Four firms -- the American Skiing Company, Intrawest Corporation, Vail Resorts and Booth Creek Holdings -- now control nearly one third of North America's ski and snowboard areas, and all indications are that the consolidation is far from over. Happily for skiers, this heated competition will manifest itself this season in a record $500 million worth of improvements, including new lifts, luxury hotels, trails, terrain parks, family activity centers and base lodges -- all to lure skiers, snowboarders and especially potential second-home buyers to a particular mountain.

title: Racism Is Not The Issue
description: Why are we having a national argument on race? By all objective measures -- recent opinion polls, demographic data and academic studies -- race relations between blacks and whites have never been better. What is more, the majority of African-Americans are content, even optimistic, about their interactions with European-Americans, according to a close reading of a recent Gallup Poll, for example, and other surveys.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: TRACKING DOWN THE BEST FARES

title: A Long Way From the Back of the Bus
description: THE ORDEAL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENRICH, EDWARD F.
description: ENRICH-Edward F. Of Woodland Hills, CA, formerly of NY, on November 12, 1997. Beloved father of Julie Ann and Jennifer Lee. Devoted son of the late Henry A. and Frances J. Enrich. Dear brother of William J. Enrich of Manhattan. Burial today 1 PM, Mt. Sinai Memorial Park, Los Angeles, CA.

title: Eat Right and Exercise
description: To the Editor:

title: Pregnant With Complications
description: Belkin reports that Jacquelyne Gorton sorts potential egg donors by hair color. She quotes Gorton as saying that ''it was the only way I could think of to classify people.'' Plainly, however, Gorton also classifies her donors by race, and should just say so.

title: Selling to the Man in the Gray Flannel Suit and the Lady of the House
description: JAMES DEAN had just been killed in a car crash in Hollywood. In South Jersey, a news report on a local civic group began: ''Pictures of the atom bomb tests in Nevada were shown as a feature of the meeting of the Moorestown Rotary Club Thursday.''

title: What's Cooking?
description: Many children hate to eat. No child hates to cook. This point, unfortunately, seems to have eluded the authors of the current crop of children's cookbooks. Cooking is as natural to children as making mud pies or playing in the sand. It is tactile and sensual, an activity that feels good, smells good and seems like magic: what child can watch a lump of dough puff itself into a loaf of bread without being seduced? A child flipping through these books, however, would quickly conclude that cooking was unsafe, unpleasant and strictly for women.

title: Hold Me! Squeeze Me! Buy a 6-Pack!
description: ON a blustery evening in August, six Manhattan women gathered in the air-conditioned studios of Focus Suites, a market-research company on Lexington Avenue where hand-picked groups meet to critique consumer products like soap or perfume or cereal.

title: Speed Humps That Divide
description: Christopher R. Lynn was the most unpopular man in Brooklyn last week, at least among the borough's community boards. In district after district, Mr. Lynn, the Transportation Commissioner, was under fire for what critics described as an autocratic management style, characterized by a refusal to consult or advise the boards.

title: November 9-15; A Rough Week for Clinton
description: In the waning hours of the first session of the 105th Congress, an impasse over abortion scuttled the Administration's effort to negotiate a plan to make nearly $1 billion in overdue payments to the United Nations and to contribute $3.5 billion to the International Monetary Fund to help bail out faltering economies.

title: PRO BASKETBALL ; Knicks Banish Bad Memories of Bad Loss
description: Less than a week ago, the Knicks walked off the court in Sacramento shaking their heads. They had failed to build on a fourth-quarter lead against a staggering team last Sunday night and ended up falling apart in the final minutes.

title: U.S. Mistakenly Cuts Benefits For Many Disabled Children
description: Social Security officials have found evidence that the Government improperly terminated disability benefits for many poor children, misinformed parents of their legal rights and actively discouraged some parents from appealing the decisions.

title: A Gracious Way with Lively Indian Fare
description: FEW towns can boast even one good Indian restaurant, but with the opening of India Palace, Stamford now has three (the others are Bonani and Meera).

title: The Saddam Hussein Problem
description: The world has a Saddam Hussein problem. To say it that way defines the threat that he represents to the biosphere, the envelope of air and water that he proposes to infest with pestilences that respect no political boundaries. It also helps frame the reality that another round of American military action may be needed to deal with a man who seems determined to be both a nuclear renegade and a transporter of timeless plagues.

title: Employers of Bike-Riders Should Give Lesson in Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester Q&A: Caryle Gulker ; A Fund That Sends Children to Camp
description: WINTER may be coming soon, but Caryle Gulker, chairwoman of the New Rochelle Campership Fund, has her eyes on summer. Will the fund, now celebrating its 40th anniversary of raising money to send disadvantaged children to camp, be able to raise enough for the growing number of families in need of help?

title: Mets' Park Needs Intimacy
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Park Safety
description: To the Editor: When I read ''Dos and Don'ts for Park Safety'' (Practical Traveler, Oct. 19), I remembered that one way to avoid accidents with animals is to respect their habits. A ranger at Rocky Mountain National Park told us that a tourist had coaxed a bear cub into the front seat of his car where his wife was sitting, to take a picture of them. The ranger said that he managed to extricate the cub before the mother bear charged.

title: Free Namibia Stumps the Naysayers
description: In 1990, when Namibia became an independent country under black majority rule, there were bitter jokes that goats would soon be grazing on grass in cracks in Windhoek's streets.

title: Pregnant With Complications
description: At the same time some physicians glorify the Wild West atmosphere of their fertility frontier, we ought to be concerned for the women who are corralled into risky medical intervention, as the specialty pursues new breakthroughs. A young donor's 35 eggs, for instance, come at a cost beyond her fee -- including dangerously high doses of potent fertility drugs, not to mention punctures of her hyperstimulated ovaries to retrieve this ''scarce resource.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POOLE, BRIAN C.
description: POOLE-Brian C. November 1, at age 41, founder of Kaboom! Inc. Contributions may be made to the charity of one's choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, NEWTON
description: FRANK-Newton. Extraordinary father, grandfather, brother, friend, human being. Lifelong Market Research Executive and Dodger Fan. You inspired us with a unique blend of courage, loyalty, service to others, vitality, and individuality. We salute you, good friend. Memorial Service 12 Noon, Sunday, Nov. 23, Carlyle Towers, 100 Winston Dr., Cliffside Park, NJ. Call 201-244-9525 for directions.

title: Deformed Frogs, 40 Years Ago
description: I am glad that scientists are looking into the matter of frogs with deformed or missing hind legs -- ''These Frogs Have a Story to Tell (And It's a Mystery),'' Oct. 26. When I was in college in Missouri 40 years ago we found such frogs in local ponds. Some had deformed hind legs, some were legless, and some had multiple pairs of legs. They were not considered rare. The biology lab had similar frogs collected in earlier years.

title: The Two Hollywoods; Peace Is Hell
description: Foreign-policy wonks in Washington are said to be hopelessly at sea in today's brave new world. They supposedly pine for the good old days of the cold war with its Soviet threat, nuclear danger, proxy wars and perpetual arms-control meetings. (Be still my heart!) But another town is struggling with this balmy time of peace as much as Washington -- Hollywood. Even though movie stars held cocktail parties for nuclear disarmament, the cold war was good for their profession. It nourished that distinctive American genre, the action-and-adventure movie.

title: Should Sea Bright Be Gone With the Wind?
description: To the Editor:

title: At a Family Castle, a Bridge Over a Financial Moat
description: SOMETIMES, the good news is also bad. How else to describe inheriting a 70-room, 12th-century castle in the heart of the Tyrolean Alps?

title: Our Towns; Hard Cases Find Soft Spot In Sweet Place
description: GARRY NASH, the Greyston Bakery troubleshooter, was having a double barrel day. A glitch in the machinery had brought the day's brownie production -- 8,000 pounds destined for Ben and Jerry's chocolate fudge brownie ice cream -- to a halt. With the bakery's 45 employees just coming off a month of seven-day weeks to fill holiday orders for Balducci's and Sardi's, would it be fair to ask them to work yet another extra shift to make up for lost time?

title: James Michener Memorial
description: Friends and colleagues of James A. Michener will take part in a tribute to the writer on Tuesday at 2:30 P.M. at the Metropolitan Club, 1 East 60th Street, in Manhattan. Mr. Michener died last month at 90.

title: Ukrainian Accent Gets Stronger
description: Long before the East Village was the East Village, it was known as Little Ukraine, reflecting a Ukrainian population that may have topped 60,000 after World War II. That number then dwindled. But the latest wave of newcomers and a surging national pride have spurred a small renaissance.

title: Inquiry Begun on Klan Ties Of 2 Icons at Virginia Tech
description: Virginia Tech has begun an investigation into whether a longtime professor for whom a dormitory was named was a student leader of the Ku Klux Klan a century ago.

title: Paris Buses
description: To the Editor: After reading Craig R. Whitney's account of a Paris sightseeing tour by city bus (Sept. 14), I'd like to add a few favorites of my own. No. 29 begins at the Gare St.-Lazare, passes the Opera, winds through the Marais, skirting the Place des Vosges, and continues on to the Bastille and the very interesting urban-development area on the Avenue Daumesnil, filled with artisans' ateliers. This is one of my favorite routes not only because of the sightseeing, but also because the buses have the unenclosed area in the back where passengers can stand in the open air. For those whose earliest memories of Paris are meshed with old photographs and films, this is a treat.

title: Running With the Wolves
description: Julie's Wolf Pack

title: November 9-15; F.B.I. Ends Flight 800 Inquiry
description: Concluding a lengthy investigation that has been the focus of countless conspiracy theories, the Federal Bureau of Investigation sent a letter to the families of the victims of T.W.A. Flight 800 stating that it had ''found absolutely no evidence'' that a criminal act led to the 1996 crash that killed 230 people.

title: The Clown Princess Of Chic
description: A CLIQUE of baby models sat at the back of the Westbeth Theater on Bank Street late Wednesday night, recovering from fashion week and celebrating the return of Sandra Bernhard. The theater had been turned into a cross between a casbah and a cabaret for Ms. Bernhard's new performance piece, ''I'm Still Here . . . Damn it!''

title: The Two Hollywoods; Her Brilliant Career
description: Fame, somebody once said, is the collection of misunderstandings that gather around a person. You see this most clearly in the myth of the modern actor. Of all the things a star holds forth on in the boilerplate celebrity interview -- love, sex, power, diet, childhood traumas, blah, blah, blah -- the one thing you never hear about is the one thing everybody in Hollywood is always thinking about: money. ''It's funny,'' says Julianne Moore, ''because people ask you all the time, 'Why did you do this?' or 'Why did you do that?' And I mean, actors are regular people. You do it because you need the money. You do it because you need a job.''

title: Park Avenue Stalinist?
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Poor Especially, AIDS Is Still Rampaging; Early Treatment a Must
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLUM, IRWIN JACK
description: ROSENBLUM-Irwin Jack. On November 13, 1997, at age 73. Devoted husband of fifty-one years of Rhoda, loving father of Alice Loubaton, Henry and Rita, caring father-in-law of Dr. Sam Loubaton, adoring grandfather of Emily and Jeremy Loubaton, dear uncle, cousin, and friend; musician extraordinaire; tireless volunteer. Funeral services Sunday, November 16 at 1 PM, I.J. Morris, Inc., 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. Burial at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, New Jersey. Shiva at the Rosenblum residence, 2067 Royce Street, Brooklyn.

title: Where Rage Lives
description: HABIBI

title: At the Packed Wineries, It's Nose to Nose
description: NORTH FORK wine country was awash on a recent Sunday. From Aquebogue to Orient heavy rains pelted pumpkins and gusty winds sent the fall foliage flying.

title: Conquering Cancer, but Depleting Her Savings
description: FOR Joan Winer Brown, the medical setbacks began in August 1984, when a stray bullet came barreling into her Bronx home, shattering an arm bone.

title: Albright to Consult Arab Countries on Iraq
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright will make a rapid tour of Arab countries on Sunday to consult with them on how to deal with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, American officials said this evening.

title: Just a Little Get-Together, but Bring Your Checkbook
description: Somewhere in the world, a demonstration of how to burp and seal plastic food containers made by Tupperware starts every two seconds of every day, says the company that was once alone in selling its products at parties in people's homes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNER, ROSE ROSEN
description: POSNER-Rose Rosen. November 13, 1997, of Muttontown, Long Island. Beloved wife of the late Max J. Devoted mother of Libby and Joseph Shapiro, Estelle and Arnold Riback, Sydelle (Marian) and Allan Sydney. Also survived by nine loving grandchildren, and fifteen adoring great-grandchildren. Services Sunday, 10:30AM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Pregnant With Complications
description: As a feminist, aging boomer and mother of two, I was so upset by Lisa Belkin's article ''Pregnant With Complications'' (Oct. 26), on the very complicated and controversial topic of manipulating women's fertility, that I buttonholed my mother, who is a minister, and pleaded with her to write a sermon about it.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: The Deli

title: POSTINGS: Hamilton Heights Walking Tour; A Voyage on Foot To the 19th Century
description: Alexander Hamilton's home sits -- sideways -- in Hamilton Heights, a neighborhood that contains picturesque rowhouses more than a century old. ''Take away the cars and it's like being in the 19th century,'' said Andrew S. Dolkart, an architectural historian who has co-written a book on the area.

title: King Kullen Closing Based on Fairness
description: On Oct. 19, the Long Island Weekly section published an article [''Warehouse Closing by Venerable Firm Angers Its Workers''] quoting those who say that King Kullen is doing serious harm to Long Island because it is closing a warehouse. I believe the company's critics are complaining not because of some ''greater good,'' but rather because of their own interests.

title: Lisa Wallace, William Weisser
description: Lisa Joy Wallace, a daughter of Rita and Ewald Wallace of Morganville, N.J., is to be married today to William Jay Weisser, the son of Marcia Z. Weisser of New York and the late Albert S. Weisser. Rabbi George Schlesinger will officiate at the Marlboro Jewish Center in Marlboro, N.J.

title: San Francisco's Mass Transit Faces Scrutiny
description: Federal transportation officials warned this week that problems plaguing San Francisco's mass transit system could lead to a catastrophic accident, and they repeated their call for a comprehensive review of training, management and safety procedures.

title: Feeling Abandoned by Israel, Many American Jews Grow Angry
description: For nearly 50 years, American Jews have looked to Israel as the anchor that held them steady against the powerful currents of assimilation in the United States. Now many fear that very source of unity is driving them apart.

title: The Two Hollywoods; Hollywood Squares and Hipsters
description: Life styles of the rich and famous versus the not so rich and famous.

title: Pregnant With Complications
description: Sophia says of her baby boy, ''I didn't know that I could ever love anyone this much.'' As a mother of four and a grandmother of eight, I understand her feelings.

title: Mental Health Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: LEADING DISSIDENT IS FREED BY CHINA TO AN EXILE IN U.S.
description: The Chinese Government this morning released from prison its best-known democracy advocate, Wei Jingsheng, on medical grounds and put him on a plane to the United States, according to members of Mr. Wei's family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, DOROTHY
description: SCHIFF-Dorothy. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Adored mother of the late Marcelle Fremont, Jack and Harlan. Cherished grandmother of Lisa, Allison, Shelly, Amy, Alan, Craig, Andrew and Carla. Great grandmother. Services at ''Boulevard Riverside Chapel,'' 312 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn (at Prospect Park), Sunday, 1:00PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTHEWS, WILLIAM P., III
description: MATTHEWS-William P., III. On November 12, 1997. Son of Mary and the late William P., Jr. Father of William P. IV and Rochelle, Sebastian and Alison. Brother of Susan E. Matthews; grandfather of Alison, Davey, Raven and Rosemary. Companion of Celia Bellinger. Service Sunday, November 16, 3 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Berkshire School, Sheffield, MA. 01257.

title: Out of the Ring, Still Fighting
description: IT had been a busy weekend for Chico Vejar. On Friday, after work at his office-cleaning company, he had played golf with friends at the E. Gaynor Brennan golf course in his hometown of Stamford. On Saturday it was the Harvard-Princeton football game in Cambridge, Mass., with another friend. And on Sunday he and his wife, Caryl, had driven to Hawthorne, N.J., to have dinner with Danny Rubino and his wife, longtime friends.

title: I.R.S. Does Problem-Solving on a Saturday
description: At 8:10 on this cloudy morning, a 42-year-old Baltimore water department worker named Frank and his fiancee, Cynthia, were lined up outside the Fallon Federal Office Building hoping to end a long-festering dispute with the Internal Revenue Service over a tax credit that had been denied.

title: Operation Desert Dream
description: HOSNI THE DREAMER

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: DANCE INNOVATIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, HARRY
description: GOLD-Harry. Beloved husband of Hattie. Loving father of Laura and Jerome (Suzanne) Gold and special Poppy to Sandee and Amanda. A loving person to all who knew him. He will be sorely missed. Graveside services Monday, 1 PM, at Mount Hebron Cemetery.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Cabernet Sauvignon

title: Tailspin
description: AN EXHIBIT DENIED

title: The World; Global Good Times, Meet the Global Glut
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON'S failure last week to persuade Congress to give him freedom to negotiate trade deals reflected skepticism among Americans about the benefits of a global economy -- not only free trade, but an entire system that allows money, factories and jobs to move anywhere.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEVENSON, JOHN REESE
description: STEVENSON-John Reese. A memorial service will be held Wed. November 19, 1997, 4 PM, Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Ave., NYC. Donations in his memory may be made to the Community Hospice of Fort Worth, TX, or to the Columbia School of Law for the Research and Study of Law in Latin America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLAHERTY, ROBERT
description: FLAHERTY-Robert. The Board and staff of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society mourn the loss of their Honorary Life Director. A loyal and devoted colleague of the Society, ''Bud'' Flaherty had been an active member of the National Board since 1980 until his retirement last year. His commitment to the Society included serving on the Executive, Chapter Relations, Fund Raising and Nominating and National Services Committees. He also served as Regional Vice Chairman and was a past Vice President and Trustee of the Southern California Chapter. We remain grateful for his tireless work to ''end the devastating effects of multiple sclerosis'' and for his friendship. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Nancy and his three children. Richard L. Snyder, Chairman General Michael J. Dugan (Ret), President and CEO

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 7 of the Arts and Leisure section today about David Mamet misstates the date and outcome of the Leo Frank case, the subject of Mr. Mamet's novel ''The Old Religion.'' Frank, a Jewish factory manager in Georgia, was wrongly convicted in 1913, not 1915, of the murder of an employee. His death sentence was eventually commuted, but an anti-Semitic mob dragged him from jail and lynched him in 1915. He was not executed by the state.

title: Dauntless Spirit, Life of the Mind
description: ATTEND the death and life of Vivian Bearing, Ph.D., as told by the professor of 17th-century poetry herself, in Stage IV of ovarian cancer. ''It is not my intention to give away the plot,'' she tells the audience, ''But I think I die at the end. They've given me less than two hours.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHTON, JOHN
description: ASHTON-John, 65. Nov. 8, 1997. Son of Helen, brother of Gerry and sister-in-law Gloria, uncle of Heidi, Mike and Devon, and friend to many. We will all miss you. Contributions in John's memory will be appreciated by St. Rose's Home, 71 Jackson Street, NY, NY 10002.

title: In a Lost Legal Battle, Gay Activist Sees Potential Gain
description: In 1988, six weeks before graduation, Joseph C. Steffan was dismissed from the United States Naval Academy after acknowledging that he was gay. He sued, won an initial decision but then lost on appeal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVID, LESTER
description: DAVID-Lester. On November 10, 1997. Prominent author and journalist. Beloved husband of the late Irene. Loving father of Margery Rosen and Susan Lewin and father-in-law of Baran Rosen and Robert Lewin. Cherished grandfather of Sarah, Michael, Alex, and Jessica. Services private.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; California Dreamin'
description: This scrapbook-cum-autobiography by Kristin Nelson Tinker is a quick trip from the 1960's to the 90's, as seen through the lens of her primitivist paintings, family photographs and snatches of text. Tinker's life is emblematic of postwar prosperity in California: her father was the all-American halfback Tom Harmon, her mother the movie actress Elyse Knox and her brother the actor Mark Harmon. She married the teen idol Ricky Nelson when she was pregnant and not yet 18 years old; her twin sons became the long-tressed rock duo Nelson. OUT OF MY MIND: An Autobiography (Abrams, $35) is wistful rather than tell-all: the biggest disclosures here are that Harriet Nelson, the perfect mother of ''Ozzie and Harriet,'' didn't bake apple pies and drank a vodka martini before dinner. The spotty text is overly padded with quotations from Rilke and Billy Joel. Tinker's brightly colored, perspectiveless paintings range from ''When the Kennedys Were in the White House'' (1964) to ''The Day He Died'' (1990), a commemoration of her father with images of funereal vines, raining clouds and a country church painted on a window frame. Despite her breakup with Rick Nelson, problems with drugs and alcohol and a breakdown, Tinker seems to have survived the journey in remarkably good spirits. Eric P. Nash

title: In America; No More Excuses
description: There was a time when a New York City police officer could kill a civilian under almost any circumstances and get away with it. That seems to be changing.

title: Top Ranking, and Wisconsin, Isn't Too Much for Michigan
description: Michigan's game against Wisconsin this afternoon was a watershed of sorts for the Wolverines, who were ranked No. 1 in the Associated Press poll. The last three times they had been No. 1 in the nation, they had lost the next week, getting only a whiff of the rarefied air at the top.

description: Think Globally

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LANE, STEPHEN (LONNY)
description: LANE-Stephen (Lonny). Happy Birthday, Sweetheart. You are loved and missed every single day. Your loving wife, Audrey.

title: Cafe los Negroes, Virtual Hangout
description: When McLean Greaves, a manager of alternative bands, started Virtual Melanin Inc., his assets were the rudimentary computer skills in his head, the spare cash in his pocket and a sluggish personal computer on his desk in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sept. 28 with an article about law enforcement in Washington Square Park referred incorrectly to the game courts on the south side of the park. They are for a French game, petanque, not for boccie. The error was pointed out by a reader in a Sept. 29 letter that was misdirected at The Times.

title: A 'New' Kennedy Airport
description: To the Editor:

title: Australian Dance, With No Hint of Kangaroos
description: AT 21, THE SYDNEY DANCE COMPANY is ''on the verge of adulthood,'' says its artistic director, Graeme Murphy. And its current American tour, the first in nearly a decade, may indeed prove to be the Australian troupe's rite of passage.

title: Out and About Before Winter
description: Celebrating the arts, and raising funds for preservation, children and animals.

title: Q and A
description: Chinese New Year

title: To the Lighthouse
description: IN 1994, after 13 casinos, a restored railroad station, a supermarket, a convention center, several blocks of new housing and the pro-gambling Casino Control Commission still hadn't transformed Atlantic City into a tourist paradise, John Williams got the job.

title: Chiropractor Is Indicted In Fraud Case
description: In April and May of 1994, Federal investigators say, a chiropractor, William Lindemann, claimed that on a half-dozen occasions his staff had provided ''chiropractic adjustment'' to a patient named Anthony Liberatore at one of the doctor's Brooklyn offices.

title: 2 Women Arrested In Killing of Cabbie; Police See Gang Tie
description: Cruising along the wet streets of Spanish Harlem on his customary 12-hour night shift early Friday, an immigrant livery driver earning money to bring his fiancee from Africa was shot to death by two women who were members of the Bloods gang, the police said.

title: The Two Hollywoods: The Actresses; Lili Taylor; Sharon Stone
description: It's 6:30 on a fall evening when Sharon Stone arrives at Pier 59 Studios in Manhattan, a little late. She had been uptown in Harlem, on the set of her next movie, ''Gloria,'' a studio remake of the film by John Cassavetes, who was an independent film maker when there weren't many.

title: Board Sets Budget Hearings
description: THE County Board of Legislators has scheduled three public hearings on the 1998 budget.

title: Roman Holiday
description: ROME ANTICS

title: The Capitalist; The Money Pit
description: In the past few years the holly-wood publicity machinery has become nearly as concerned with movie finances as with the movies themselves. In reporting the ticket sales of a particular week's blockbuster, the big studios even have taken to fibbing to the trade magazines that compile weekly authoritative lists of the week's best-selling movies.

title: A Best Buy in an Easy-to-Miss Location
description: IF you never heard of the Bayville Landing Restaurant, you probably have plenty of company. It should be on every Long Island best buy and bang for the buck list, if only for its four-course early week dinner, but it is not, perhaps because this storefront spot, at 275 Bayville Avenue (628-2309), is in the lovely, though somewhat isolated waterside village of Bayville.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Starship Troopers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, WALTER BARRON WILTON
description: WILSON-Walter Barron Wilton. Of NYC. His family mourns the loss on November 14 of a devoted father, doting grandfather, brother and uncle. Born in New York, educated at Trinity College and the Fletcher School of Foreign Diplomacy at Tufts, served in the U.S. Navy. Foreign Service aide, investment broker, prospector, publisher. He dedicated his keen intellect, instinctive good will, and warm sense of humor to his family and many friends. He was the gentlest of men. He loved to dance. For funeral information contact Frank E. Campbell at 212288-3500. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to House of the Redeemer, NYC, Trinity College, Hartford, CT, or the Fletcher School at Tufts.

title: Going Undercover
description: For the covert peacock in every man, the London designer Ozwald Boateng may have the perfect suits: conservative on the outside and eye-popping on the inside, with linings of bright solid silk. The suits from Mr. Boateng, a Savile Row tailor by training, are so deceptively traditional -- in gray pinstripe or navy wool -- that some of his best customers in England are bankers, lawyers and politicians. Even Prime Minister Tony Blair recently ordered a few suits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, CAROL (NEE SMILEY)
description: LEWIS-Carol (nee Smiley). On November 14, 1997. Beloved wife and lifetime partner of Ira. Devoted and cherished mother of Deborah and Lawrence Berliner, and adored grandmother of her delicious Rachel Hope. Dear sister of Phyllis Kushner and the late Lorraine Nachbar. Loving aunt and great-aunt. Treasured lifelong friend of Erna Grand and Edith Degani. She was a beloved and respected New York City English teacher who graduated from Queens College in 1942, and received a Master's Degree from NYU in 1945. You gave so much so often, and always from the heart. Your love, inner goodness and remarkable wit and wisdom will stay in our hearts forever. Services ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel,'' Queens Blvd and 76th Rd, Forest Hills, Sunday, 1 PM.

title: From Bowling Alley to Shopping Center as Times and Economics Change
description: Birthday parties. Roller skating. Disco and rock-and-roll. From 1967 to 1986, these were the ingredients that made the Livingston Roller Rink the only place a child growing up in this bedroom community in Essex County wanted to go to celebrate a birthday, bar mitzvah or other special event.

title: Sports of The Times; Recalling Those 17-0 Miami Dolphins and, of Course, the Alligator
description: WHEN the 1972 Miami Dolphins gather today and tomorrow for the 25th anniversary reunion of their unbeaten, untied, unprecedented and unequaled 17-0 season, they will flash their Super Bowl VII rings and bask in their memories.

title: Washington Set the Stage for Slavery's End
description: To the Editor:

title: In Case of Working Mothers, Plenty of Judges
description: The ''nanny trial'' may be over, but it has reignited a national debate not so easily settled by a judge or jury: Should parents of younger children work if they can afford to stay at home?

description: Anastasia

description: To the Editor:

description: Federal authorities have disclosed some of the classified information they are using in an effort to deport an Egyptian man who has been held in solitary confinement in New York City for 18 months without being charged with a crime.

title: Love in the Time of H.I.V.
description: PLAYS WELL

title: For the Poor Especially, AIDS Is Still Rampaging  To the Editor:    ''New Challenge to Idea That 'AIDS Is Special' '' (front page, Nov. 12) is the latest in a series of disquieting articles that question the need for continued ''AIDS exceptionalism.'' Unfortunately, these discussions largely ignore the more pressing needs of the increasing numbers of disadvantaged and minority people with H.I.V.
description: The focus on more sensational examples of AIDS-related largess gives ammunition to critics whose agendas threaten not just ''candlelight dinners'' at Gay Men's Health Crisis but also decent housing and drug treatment for those H.I.V.-infected people who never visit G.M.H.C. Indeed, the growing backlash against AIDS exceptionalism could well replace the much-maligned ''welfare deadbeats'' of past political debates with ''H.I.V. hogs.''

title: Meghan Hall, Ryan Donaldson
description: Meghan Whitney Hall, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Turnbull Hall 3d of Princeton, N.J., was married last evening to Ryan Edward Donaldson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick F. Donaldson of Glencoe, Md. The Rev. Christopher R. Sherrill, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Trinity Church in Princeton.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Oct. 26 with an article about buildings seen in television comedies was printed in error. The town house used in the series ''The Nanny'' is at 7 East 75th Street, not 7 East 76th.

title: Editorial Observer; When Old Cold Warriors Replay Poland's Crisis
description: Viktor Kulikov is a blunt man, and he sent a blunt message last weekend when he arrived in a small town outside Warsaw. The Russian general was a participant in a conference to reconstruct a significant event of the cold war -- the Polish crisis of 1980 and 1981, which saw the rise of Solidarity and Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's attempt to crush it by imposing martial law. Mr. Kulikov came to the meeting with a retinue of aides, in full uniform and with Soviet insignia on the shoulderboards.

title: Spano Sees Himself As a Conciliator
description: AL GORE called him, and strangers stared at him, sure that they recognized him. Thus began Andrew J. Spano's first week as the Westchester County Executive-elect.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page contents entry on Nov. 2 for a profile of a district in ''The Parisians' Paris'' misspelled the area's name. It is Passy-Auteuil, not Passy-Auteil.

title: Money: Hard, Soft and Dirty
description: Max Frankel's column ''Money: Hard, Soft and Dirty'' (Word & Image, Oct. 26) is the best analysis of the campaign finance reform problem: the candidates' need for money to pay for television time.

title: Once Anonymous, but Now Under Bright Lights
description: SETTING: Barnes & Noble at Union Square. History department, top floor. About 120 people have gathered in this paneled, well-lit space to see a man who knows a little something about trying to fade into the woodwork: Joe Klein, a.k.a. Anonymous.

title: P. R. Bauble of the Week
description: Squeezable stress balls pitching this week's press preview of spring lines at Barneys New York. But will they replace Valium?

title: Rome Police Help
description: To the Editor: On a September visit to Rome, my friend and I benefited from a positive experience with the Italian police.
