description: HOWARD PRINCE and Lucille Poirier bought their three-story brick building in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn as much for the neighborhood as for the possibilities the structure possessed.

title: Don't Get Me Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: All the Wrong Places
description: WET PLACES AT NOON By Lee K. Abbott. 192 pp. Iowa City: University of Iowa Press. $22.95.

title: St. John's Gets a Boost In Easy Season Opener
description: The game was meant to be a confidence builder, and St. John's handled it with confidence last night. Against slower, shorter Lafayette, the Red Storm eased to a 72-49 victory in its season opener at Alumni Hall.

title: Pregnant With Complications
description: I welcome the coming obsolescence of the biological clock. As a perimenopausal woman in her late 30's, I believe it is natural and reasonable for women of my age to plan for a pregnancy in the coming years. American society has bred us to push the envelope. So let's offer a child a mother's love and wisdom that deepens with age. Isn't this one of the reasons we are all here anyway -- to evolve?

title: Even Vassals Get Vacations
description: Modern Manors

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARCARO, EDDIE
description: ARCARO-Eddie. The Officers and Trustees of the New York Sports Museum & Hall of Fame regret the passing of a charter member of the New York Sports Hall of Fame on November 14, in Miami, Florida. Bill Shannon, President Jordan Sprechman, Secretary

title: The Two Hollywoods; Harry Knowles Is Always Listening
description: Harry Jay Knowles is sprawled on the edge of his bed, clicking at the keyboard of his Packard Bell computer. It's 10 A.M, and he is just starting his day in a tiny airless room crammed with videos, unread film scripts, movie posters (''Bride of Frankenstein,'' ''King Kong,'' etc.) and 8-by-10 glossies of Marilyn Monroe, Britt Ekland, Ray Milland and the original Superman, Kirk Alyn. A grinning Vincent Price shrunken head lies in a box on the floor.

title: Runaway From Virginia Is Raped at Queens House
description: A 17-year-old runaway from Virginia was lured to a man's house in Richmond Hill, Queens, on Thursday and raped and sodomized by four men, the police said yesterday. The victim had hitchhiked from Virginia to New York earlier that day.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS; Everyday Valor
description: Seven Brave Women By Betsy Hearne. Illustrated by Bethanne Andersen. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books. $15. (Ages 4 to 9)

title: A Rescuer of Intellectuals From Vichy France
description: WHO DID WHAT TO WHOM in occupied France? Now more than ever, with the current trial of Vichy police officials in France and the investigations into Swiss wartime banking practices, individuals and governments beyond the German borders are being called to account for their actions during the Holocaust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTH, EDWARD S.
description: NORTH-Edward S. You will always be ''The Coach'' and live in our hearts forever. Love, David and Ellen

title: A New UConn Campus Takes Shape
description: UNIVERSITY and city leaders alike are embracing the University of Connecticut's new campus in Stamford, a three-story, 243,000-square-foot building under construction at the corner of Washington Boulevard and Broad Street. The downtown campus, scheduled to open in January, will accommodate 3,000 students, double the number at the Scofieldtown Road campus in North Stamford, which is reverting to the city of Stamford.

title: Trade Fight Was Battle of Perception Against Analysis
description: In the days since Congress handed President Clinton a major defeat on trade, top White House aides have been asking themselves the same question: at a moment when the economy is booming and other nations say they are terrified by the competitive edge of American companies, why did Congress become convinced that trade was threatening the livelihoods of working Americans?

title: The Mystery of Missing Park Ave. Lights
description: Sure, other cities have illuminated red and green hands, zebra crossings, even pips (in London) to warn pedestrians to get out of the street. But New York is where you will find big boxy ''Walk/Don't Walk'' signs sprouting from the corners; they are so much a part of the landscape that they have become a city trademark.

title: Concern Grows on Where Trash Will Go After Fresh Kills
description: For Brooklyn residents, particularly those living in Red Hook, Greenpoint and Williamsburg, the closing of the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island in 2001 looms like a giant headache -- a 13,000-ton headache, to be exact.

title: A Second 'Wife' for a Second Home
description: WHAT do you do if you leave your wallet at your weekend house in Connecticut, but don't realize it until late Sunday night when you're back home in Manhattan? Or if you want a massage or need a fourth for bridge?

title: A Closer Look at the Work of an Organist
description: THE keyboard reigns at several recital, chamber and orchestral concerts this week, starting tonight at 7 when the pipe organ, traditionally known as the king of instruments, meets modern technology at First Church of Christ in Wethersfield.

title: Mr. Dornan's Wasteful Crusade
description: The House Oversight Committee's investigation into the election of Representative Loretta Sanchez, a Democrat, has become a costly farce that should come to a quick end. The inquiry began after former Representative Robert K. Dornan, a Republican, contested the 1996 election in which he lost his Orange County, Calif., seat to Ms. Sanchez by 984 votes. He claims the election was tainted by voter fraud and voting by non-citizens.

title: Tethered To a Trend
description: Sometimes what seems like a good idea just isn't. And sometimes it just takes a little while to know.

title: With Dearest Love, Marianne
description: THE SELECTED LETTERS OF MARIANNE MOORE Bonnie Costello, general editor. Celeste Goodridge and Cristanne Miller, associate editors. Illustrated. 597 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: A Legend's Goodbye At Home
description: Eddie Robinson said goodbye to his home fans today the only way he knew. By stalking the sidelines of a stadium named for him. By trying forcefully, desperately, to coax one more record-building victory from his Grambling State Tigers.

title: It's Not Over Till the Car Door Closes
description: SAMPLING the fragrances, fingering the merchandise, trying on the clothing for size, making the agonizing choice: all these are part of the cherished routine of shopping. But in a state of malls and shops and cars and highways, the ritual is not yet complete. Carrying the bagged trophies of the day across the parking lot and putting them in the car provides the necessary closure. Here are scenes from the parking lots at the Bergen Mall, left; Riverside Square Mall, bottom left, and Toys ''R'' Us in Paramus. Of course, at home again, another ritual begins: opening, assembling, second thoughts, perhaps, and the seed of plans for another trip to the mall.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLUSHING

title: Dark Doings
description: Nunally Johnson's NIGHT PEOPLE (1954) is a perfectly dandy and intelligent suspense melodrama about espionage and a kidnapping in divided postwar Berlin. The city's ruins loom authentically behind the tingling project. This is one of Gregory Peck's best roles as a tough, imaginative Army officer assigned to a ticklish project involving a Communist emissary (Anita Bjork, above with Peck) and a visiting politico (Broderick Crawford). Buddy Ebsen is excellent as Peck's understanding sidekick. Incidentally, that broken-down piano player is Laurence Olivier's first wife, Jill Esmond. Rita Gam fills in neatly as Peck's romantic interest and comrade in uniform -- SATURDAY at 10 A.M. on MAX. Howard Thompson

title: November 9-15; Downsizing the Pentagon
description: The Pentagon has cut the number of troops on active duty from 2.1 million at the end of the cold war in 1989 to 1.4 million today. Now Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen says it's time the Pentagon itself trimmed down.

title: Great Lawn or Great Yawn?
description: MOTHER and son tossed a light ball on Central Park's newly restored Great Lawn on a warm mid-October afternoon. This was the first weekend in two years the lawn was open after an $18.2 million renovation. And it was stunning. Six sparkling softball diamonds were sculptured on the lush 13-acre oval. The boy's 3-year-old eyes beamed as the ball floated to him and landed safely in his arms. It was as perfect a moment as parent and child could hope for.

title: November 9-15; 4 Americans Killed in Pakistan
description: Four American employees of a Texas-based oil company and their Pakistani driver were killed on Wednesday by gunmen in Karachi, Pakistan. A group calling itself the Aimal Secret Committee took responsibility for the attack, which was believed to be linked to the conviction two days earlier of a Pakistani in the 1993 killing of two Central Intelligence Agency employees near Washington.

title: A Woeful Yale Loses To Princeton
description: A century ago Princeton-Yale was the Game, played at the Polo Grounds in New York from 1887 to 1896 before capacity crowds.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Want a New Jazz Club? Open Your Own

title: Seven Artists Offer Lineup of Works at Neuberger in Purchase
description: LIKE the Energizer Bunny, the Neuberger Museum at Purchase College here just keeps going and going. After a spring and summer packed with attractions, including the June Wayne retrospective, a small tribute to Fairfield Porter, various group shows and, recently, its first biennial of public art, the museum sails into fall with two anthologies, ''Basically Black and White'' and ''Eye to Eye.''

title: Total Immersion
description: THE ART

title: AT TEA WITH: Alek Wek; When Fair of Face Looks African
description: ELLE'S November cover model is from the Sudan's Dinka tribe, a cherubic face peering out from an austere magazine.

title: A Doctor's Look At Life and Death
description: THE library of Dr. Sherwin Nuland begs for readers and ruminators. Scented faintly with cherry wood, the room rests off a second-floor landing in a Colonial-style house designed in 1929 by Alice Washburn, an eminent Connecticut architect. The library, preserved in its original state, is classical and disciplined, lined with old and new literature, a reading desk and chair.

title: Dealers Get Serious About Quick Fixes
description: MERCEDES-BENZ is preparing to do battle with the Jiffy Lubes and Precision Tunes of the world. Like a few other auto makers who have acted to make service operations more convenient, Mercedes is setting up auxilliary centers where customers can get oil changes, basic maintenance and quick repairs.

title: Teaming Up: Bids Are In for Seifert to Roam Sidelines Again in 1998
description: He is the most wanted man in the National Football League. But do not bother trying to call his house in California, because the man is enjoying himself in Mexico for a few days.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 16, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Big Nick Nicholas, 75, Singer And Jazz-Band Saxophonist
description: Big Nick Nicholas, a tenor saxophonist and singer who played with some of the greatest musicians of postwar jazz, died on Oct. 29 at St. Joseph's Hospital in Queens. He was 75 and lived in Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENIG, FRANCES ROSE
description: FENIG-Frances Rose. Age 91. Loving wife of the late Murray Fenig. Beloved mother of Dori Rose and Samuel Fenig. Beloved grandmother of Susan Rose, Terri Angstreich & Lara Fenig. Loving sister of the late Mary Weinberger. Service Sunday, November 16, 12:30 P.M., at Sinai Chapels, 16205 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Anita Hill's Story
description: To the Editor:

title: A Promising Career Reaches a Hurdle
description: IN THE FINNISH FOLK EPIC known as the Kalevala, one character plays the zitherlike kantele so movingly that all the creatures of the sea and forest come out to listen.

title: They're Everywhere. But They Didn't Used to Be.
description: 1. BED, BATH AND BEYOND

title: Amaker's Debut Is Triumphant
description: When Tommy Amaker walked away from Duke this summer to take over the head coaching job at Seton Hall, he left behind a perennial national contender, a program steeped in tradition that he contributed to as a player and as an assistant coach.

title: Pamela Ostroff and Marc Intrater
description: Pamela Joy Ostroff and Marc Jeffrey Intrater are to be married today at the Pleasantdale Chateau in West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Rolando Matalon is to perform the ceremony.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; After The Shock, An Ode to Resilience . . .
description: ON Tuesday, Oct. 28, Americans turned on their TV's and picked up their newspapers, were deluged with fears of a market crash and calmly concluded that the experts were wrong.

title: Dig They Must; Finding Paydirt on This Rock
description: THE caretaker of a parking lot on the Hebron Road needed water to wash his trucks, so he ran an underground pipe through an adjacent olive grove to the nearest tap. That soon brought the Israel Antiquities Authority. In an area where you can't poke into the ground without disturbing some shard of ages past, no digging can be done without a preliminary check by the agency.

title: In the Blue Mountains, Wild Meets Tame
description: WE were near the edge of an escarpment that could have been cut with a knife, taking in the dizzying view of the Jamison Valley from Australia's Blue Mountains, when my 2 1/2-year-old son Lachlan announced to my husband, ''Da, Mom's got bees.'' The buzzing black cloud besieging me was in fact of bush flies, but the sight must have reminded him and his twin brother, Cameron, of one of the apian pursuit scenes from their favorite Winnie the Pooh videos.

title: Pregnant With Complications
description: Sophia says, ''When my son is 20, I'll be 71. That doesn't sound too old to me.''

title: . . . Some Day
description: A COUNTRY OF STRANGERS Blacks and Whites in America. By David K. Shipler. 607 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 40 of the Book Review today, about the best illustrated children's books of 1997, misstates the affiliation of one judging panelist. Barbara Barstow works at the Cuyahoga County (Ohio) Public Library, not the Cleveland Public Library.

title: Rhonda Taylor, Kevin McDonald
description: Rhonda Leigh Taylor, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Taylor of Fort Worth, was married last evening to Kevin Francis McDonald, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. McDonald of Menlo Park, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Walter J. Smith, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony with Rabbi Charles D. Lippman at the Pierre in New York.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS; Perhaps She'll Die
description: THERE WAS AN OLD LADY WHO SWALLOWED A FLY Retold and illustrated by Simms Taback. Unpaged. New York: Viking. $14.99. (Ages 5 to 8)

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL; Tottenville Turns the Tables
description: Cassel Smith could not wait for Tottenville's playoff game with its Staten Island rival Susan Wagner to begin yesterday. Smith, still smarting from last year's quarterfinal elimination by Wagner, responded by rushing for 123 yards and 2 touchdowns to help Tottenville (9-1) knock Wagner (8-2), last year's runner-up, out of the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs with an 18-8 victory.

title: John Hines Jr. And Amy Wolf
description: Amy Therese Wolf and John Galvin Hines Jr. were married yesterday by Msgr. Paul P. Enke at St. Brigid of Kildare Roman Catholic Church in Dublin, Ohio.

title: The Two Hollywoods: The Directors; Woody Allen; Martin Scorsese
description: While both Woody Allen, who is 61, and Martin Scorsese, who is 55, work within the studio system, neither is of it. They might best be thought of as proto-independents, taking their cues from European auteurs of the 1960's while continuing to take the Hollywood money. ''Kundun,'' Scorsese's new film, which tells the story of the Dalai Lama's early life, and Allen's ''Deconstructing Harry,'' which he wrote, directed and stars in, are examples of American cinema at its most audacious. (Both open in December.) On a Saturday afternoon last month, which happened to be Yom Kippur, Allen and Scorsese met in Scorsese's plush, poster-lined offices on Park Avenue in Manhattan. Fellow New Yorkers and contemporaries, they hardly knew each other -- maybe that's how insider-outsiders are. Allen spent most of the conversation curled up with a pillow on the couch while Scorsese, dressed all in black, sat bolt upright in a chair and sparked the dialogue.

title: On the Trail Of Jan Hus
description: UKALICHA, which means ''At the Sign of the Chalice,'' is a venerable tavern in the middle of Prague at Na Bojisti (On the Battlefield Street). Not by accident it was the beer hall of choice for the Good Soldier Schweik, the subversive Czech hero of the comic novel of Jaroslav Hasek. In this subtle way the author paid tribute to a symbol of Czechdom. The chalice acquired this status four centuries earlier through followers of Jan Hus, the revolutionary preacher and patriot who was burned at the stake as a heretic at the outset of the Council of Constance in 1415. To this day the ceremonial cup retains an almost mystical gravity for the Czechs.

title: SHOPPING AROUND: RENEWAL ; By Helping People Do More Than Shop, Local Merchants Find Ways to Prosper
description: For 151 years, Clayton & Magee, a family-run haberdashery in Red Bank's downtown shopping district, supplied businessmen with some of the finest custom-made suits, silk shirts and woolen trousers in central New Jersey. When other men's clothiers in this quaint town along the Navesink River closed because of competition from a nearby mall, Clayton & Magee stood firm and barely altered its format.

title: For the Poor Especially, AIDS Is Still Rampaging; Heart Disease vs. AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: A Master Who Confounded the Categorizers
description: ''ROCCO AND HIS BROTHERS'' is the kind of film you either embrace as one of the most powerful moviegoing experiences ever or dismiss as corny and overwrought. When it opened in 1960, this three-hour epic about five southern Italian brothers and their mother, who migrate to Milan driven by economic hope only to encounter tragedy and the family's destruction through the perversity of goodness, was as close as I could imagine to a novel on film.

title: Iraq's Top Secret; Intent Is the Ultimate Mystery
description: AS any good spy will tell you, there are secrets, and then there are mysteries. Secrets can be unveiled. Mysteries are mosaics of secrets, far harder to decipher.

title: Eye Candy
description: Until recently, people didn't eat on the silver screen. With the exceptions of that erotic scene in ''Tom Jones'' and the plot of ''Who Is Killing the Great Chefs of Europe?'' food figured in film about as prominently as dental floss. But in the last decade or so, the cinema has begun to pig out. Food has been both plot and motive. It has been both grand and sumptuous, poignant and deary, sexy and scary.

title: Anne Park Ko, John Chia Lin Hou
description: Anne Park Ko, a daughter of Ohseun Park and Yung Hoe Ko of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., was married yesterday to John Chia Lin Hou, a son of Grace and Joseph Kang Hua Hou of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Bertram Watkins performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: Priests and Town Battle Over Business Zone and Taxes
description: IN a closely watched battle between church and state here, a group of Roman Catholic priests and local officials have gone to the mat over an issue that could affect the taxing powers of municipalities throughout New York. The question: can a jurisdiction legally create a business zone and exclude tax-exempt organizations?

title: Corrections
description: A caption last Sunday with a drawing by Al Hirschfeld about the Broadway play ''Jackie: An American Life'' was incomplete. The actress shown playing Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, in the production at the Belasco Theater, was Margaret Colin.

title: Without Love
description: THE FACTS SPEAK FOR THEMSELVES

title: Seeking Answers in Yiddish Classics
description: AT A TIME WHEN YOUNG American Jews are increasingly exploring how to remain Jewish and even asking why they should, it may not be surprising that a couple of successful American playwrights have turned to the Yiddish canon -- to two plays that took on those questions in the early 20th century.

title: Yeltsin Ousts More Officials In Scandal Over Book Fee
description: Two top allies of Russia's leading economic reformer were dismissed by President Boris N. Yeltsin today, as the scandal grew over a large book contract awarded to the reformer, First Deputy Prime Minister Anatoly B. Chubais.

title: Delay of Game Wins at Aqueduct
description: Delay of Game, an 18-1 shot regarded as a front-running speedster, kept running for a mile and one-eighth in the mud yesterday at Aqueduct to win the Stuyvesant Handicap over the favored Concerto and Mr. Sinatra.

title: Call the Plumbers
description: ABUSE OF POWER

title: Tonight's Feature? Typhoon
description: ABOUT 10 years ago I gave the after-dinner talk at the annual meeting of the Weather Channel shareholders. I had written a magazine piece saying what a relief it was that there was something boring on television. Instead of the frenetic excitement of car chases, shootings, sex and explosions - sometimes all at once - there was the soothing ennui, so much like life, of watching endless maps with arrows indicating highs, lows, fronts and, everyone's favorite, lake-effect snow.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 19 about the Lygon Arms hotel in Broadway, England, quoted a legend above a portal incorrectly. It is ''Now good digestion wait on appetite and health on both,'' not ''Now good digestion with an appetite and health or both.''

title: Energy Leader Gets the Ear of the President
description: THOMAS R. CASTEN has been rising before the sun, the ideas flowing even before his head leaves the pillow. Position papers, a book, all are taking shape under headings like ''The Environmental Benefits of Electric Company Restructuring'' and ''Combining Production of Heat and Power.''

title: Falling in Love With the Endlessly Flirtatious Fan
description: NO ONE KNOWS MORE ABOUT fans than Helene E. Alexander, the founder of the exquisite but little-known Fan Museum here in Greenwich.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 16, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 26 about the island of Dominica misidentified its newer airport. It is Canefield, not the larger and busier Melville Hall.

title: Jilted Texas Judge Takes On His Foes in Partisan Congress
description: From his chambers atop the old Federal Building here, Judge Jerry Buchmeyer administers a corps of 12 judges, two fewer than he is supposed to have. He frets about an increasingly congested caseload and whether his judges will have the time to fully consider cases and turn out first-rate opinions.

title: Jamie Heller, Jed Weissberg
description: Jamie Gale Heller, a daughter of Barbara and Lawrence A. Heller of Armonk, N.Y., was married last evening to Jed Wagner Weissberg, a son of Kate Carmel of New York and Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, and Norbert S. Weissberg, also of New York. Rabbi Daniel L. Pernick performed the ceremony at Brae Burn Country Club in Purchase, N.Y.

title: Editor of Irish Paper Brings Dublin Home
description: DUBLIN is booming and Ireland is hot, attracting many new businesses, said Claire O'Gara Grimes whose words tumble out as quickly as the rapid-fire steps in an Irish jig. ''In Dublin there are cranes on every horizon,'' she explained. ''New hotels and new buildings are popping up all over the city.''

title: Chinese Puzzle
description: UNDERSTANDING

title: A Star in the Making
description: YOU can eat at Lincoln Center in New York or at the Kennedy Center in Washington, but why would you want to when both cities offer better restaurants?

title: Happily Disappearing Behind a Gallery of Masks
description: THE WOMEN IN Jayne Atkinson's life have been a cheerless lot recently. There was the rejected Queen Katherine in Shakespeare's ''Henry VIII'' in Central Park last summer; then the molested heroine of Paula Vogel's Off Broadway hit ''How I Learned to Drive''; and now, Kevin Kline's neglected, consumptive wife in the Lincoln Center Theater production of Chekhov's ''Ivanov,'' directed by Gerald Gutierrez.

title: POSTINGS: Retail Store to Open at 666 5th Ave.; N.B.A. Seeks A Net Profit
description: It seems unlikely that anyone would head straight for Fifth Avenue to buy a San Antonio Spurs hat or Vancouver Grizzlies replica jersey. But the National Basketball Association hopes to change that.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It takes a village to raise a child, and there have been times when I felt like I was the only person home in the village.''

title: Matthew Hoffman, Claudia Friedman
description: Claudia Frances Friedman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome T. Friedman of New York, was married last evening to Matthew Stephen Hoffman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Hoffman of Kansas City, Mo. Dr. Ronald A. Sobel, the senior rabbi at Temple Emanu-El in New York, performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Essay; The President's Friend
description: Bill Clinton is a lucky President. In the long run-up to his sexual misconduct trial, along comes a book detailing President Kennedy's sexual obsession that makes Clinton look like a choirboy.

title: Kirsten Mercer And Eric Cobb
description: Margaret Kirsten Mercer, a daughter of the Rev. M. Francis Mercer of New York and Douglas D. Mercer of East Hampton, N.Y., was married yesterday to Eric Jan Cobb, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard A. Cobb of Seattle. The Rev. John D. Twiname, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.

title: Q & A
description: Rights of Domestic Partners

title: In the Region/Long Island; After Home Ownership, 'Home Keepership' Is Key
description: THOUSANDS of Long Island homeowners lose their houses to foreclosure each year, even though the region's unemployment rate of 4 percent is the lowest it has been since 1988.

title: River Patrol
description: The Riverkeepers

title: A Handwritten Life
description: I grew up at FOrdham 7 and loved calling a dear aunt at TRafalgar 3 (Lives: ''A Handwritten Life,'' by Richard F. Shepard, Oct. 26).

title: A Hitch in Co-op Tax Abatement
description: IN the last few weeks, more than a quarter million apartment owners in New York City have been reaping the benefits of a 1996 amendment to the state's local property tax law that mandates nearly $200 million in tax abatements for co-op shareholders and condominium owners.

title: Fabrics Fit to Be Ties
description: IT might even stagger Stephen Hawking to contemplate how many ties there are in the world. But what must be even more puzzling is how a man can reach into a tangle of 50 ties in his closet each morning and, in some amazing feat of legerdemain, extract the exact one he will consent to wear.

title: November 9-15; Two Men Convicted in Bombing At World Trade Center
description: A Federal jury in Manhattan convicted Ramzi Ahmed Yousef on charges that he orchestrated the bombing of the World Trade Center in 1993, one of the deadliest acts of terrorism in American history. The jury also convicted Eyad Ismoil, whom prosecutors accused of driving the bomb-laden van into the Trade Center's underground garage.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE GOOD NAZI

title: Catharine Carver, 76, an Editor Of a Luminous List of Writers
description: Catharine Carver, who won trans-Atlantic esteem as the editor of a galaxy of mid-20th century authors, including Hannah Arendt, John Berryman, Saul Bellow and Flannery O'Connor, died on Tuesday at the Chelsea and Westminster Hospital in London. Ms. Carver, an American who lived in London, was 76.

title: Cross-Country Central
description: DRIVING into the calendar-perfect village of Craftsbury Common in Vermont on a chill January day, it was not the snowy town green, or the picket fence enclosing it, or the fact that every house was painted white, that first caught my eye. These things I saw later. What I noticed was a girl, maybe 15, maybe younger, standing in front of the Craftsbury Academy, the town's well-regarded public school. She was wearing what seems to be the universal school uniform these days: baggy pants, baggy shirt, no parka. On one shoulder was slung a book bag. On the other -- and this is what got my attention -- was a pair of long, skinny cross-country skis.

title: The Two Hollywoods; The Man Who Changed Everything
description: Quentin Tarantino, in shorts and a T-shirt, is padding around his palatial mansion in the Hollywood Hills on Sunday afternoon in late October. He has lived here less than a year, and the previous occupant, the pop singer Richard Marx, left most of his overstuffed furniture behind. Tarantino has added some touches: movie posters are strewn everywhere; there are bronze sculptures of characters from ''Reservoir Dogs,'' his first movie, and ''Pulp Fiction''; a goldfish, a gold lamp and Tarantino's screenwriting Oscar for ''Pulp Fiction'' (also gold), are carefully arranged in front of a picture window. ''Feng shui,'' Tarantino explains.

title: Island's Influence in Works of the Moran Family
description: The Moran Family Legacy

title: Filming the Tango: The Intricate Steps of Life and Love
description: EVEN IN TODAY'S WORLD OF filmmaking, where independence has become a byword, Sally Potter is a singular example of artistic self-sufficiency.

title: Big Mac Attack
description: McLIBEL

title: Dealing for Dollars
description: The Dark Lady

title: Pamela Finger, Kaare Weber
description: Dr. Pamela Ann Finger, the daughter of Dorothy and Kenneth J. Finger of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Kaare John Weber, a son of Joan and Dr. Carl P. Weber of Purchase, N.Y. Rabbi Lester Bronstein officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Three Lenders Begin Loan Programs for Some Foreign Students at N.Y.U.
description: Japanese students attending New York University got an unusual offer in the mail recently: the chance to borrow up to $50,000 to help pay for college.

title: In Mount Kisco, a Place to Sample Fish
description: EAGERLY awaited by those in the fish- know that is, patrons of Joe DiMauro's Mount Kisco Seafood shop -- Joan and Joe DiMauro's Fish Cellar opened to full houses last June on the spot once occupied by Sotterra, and before that the Brownstone Cafe. Obtaining a reservation is still best done in advance, and we cannot think of a better place to have fish.

title: Shortcut To Sitting Pretty
description: This season, the straight knee-length skirt has been slashed, reviving the sexy style of the pre-power suits of the 1970's. The look took over the front rows at this season's New York and Paris shows. When the wearer sits, the skirt seems a mini. Stiletto heels heighten the long-limbed illusion. As one retired buyer pointed out, ''Honey, the legs are the last to go.''

title: Protecting Students From Travel Scams
description: A group of tour operators and travel agencies that serve students and young people has created a trade organization to raise standards and help consumers identify reliable companies. The goal is to steer students and their parents away from companies that take the money and run.

title: Up to His Old Tricks
description: DELUGE

title: In Adoption, New Help From Employers
description: ADOPTIVE parents don't get morning sickness or swollen ankles, and they can dine out to celebrate the night their child is born. But they face some hardships that other parents do not: costly travel, complex legal proceedings and visits from social workers to determine whether they are fit for parenthood -- all of which can cut into a career.

title: Making Adjustments to Allay October Fears
description: OCTOBER'S stock panic provided a vivid textbook lesson in mutual fund risk.

title: Roasting, Parboiling Or Glazing Vegetables
description: FOR many people, the stuffing is the best part of Thanksgiving dinner. But I also like the late-fall vegetables that are a traditional part of this meal.

title: Giuliani Camp Got Back Part Of Lost Funds
description: Soon after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's re-election campaign was forced in September to return more than $340,000 in illegal contributions, campaign officials quietly set out to get some of that money back. The officials imparted a bit of private advice to the donors who received refunds of their contributions: if they were still interested in giving, there was a way they could do it, one that was entirely legal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, RUBEN
description: SCHWARTZ-Ruben. Friend, confidant, wise counselor. He will be greatly missed by all whose lives he touched. Evelyn and Arthur Glasser

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE CAFE OF MIRRORS By Giuliana Morandini. University of Exeter/Northwestern University, paper, $16.95.

title: Lisa Applebaum, Gary Jacobson
description: Lisa Susan Applebaum, a daughter of Marcia and Eugene Applebaum of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was married last evening to Gary M. Jacobson, the son of Dr. Judith Kabus of East Brunswick, N.J., and Dr. Norman Jacobson of Las Vegas, Nev. Rabbi Irwin Groner officiated at the St. Regis in New York.

title: Vegetables: How About Some Room for Meat?
description: THERE'S nothing wrong with eating your vegetables. They are even classified as food by some nutritionists. What upsets me is the all-too-common syndrome of Obsessive Vegetable Compulsion by Proxy -- summed up in the phrase ''It's good for you.'' This was what our mothers always said before dosing us with some particularly noxious medicine.

title: Aliza Dworken, Jonathan Frohlich
description: Aliza Shoshana Dworken, a daughter of Rabbi Steven M. Dworken and Mrs. Dworken of Linden, N.J., is to be married this afternoon to Jonathan Steven Frohlich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Frohlich of Willowbrook, Staten Island. The bride's father, the executive vice president of the Rabbinical Council of America, is to perform the ceremony at El Caribe Country Club, a restaurant in Brooklyn.

title: Jennifer Stanley and Peter Fleischer
description: Jennifer Stanley, a daughter of Linda E. Stanley of Belvedere, Calif., and Dr. John A. Stanley of Mill Valley, Calif., is to be married this afternoon to Peter Benjamin Fleischer, a son of Martha and Alan A. Fleischer of New Canaan, Conn. Rabbi Herbert Morris is to officiate at Old St. Hilary's Landmark in Tiburon, Calif.

title: The Making of a Mall: Managing the Mood and the Merchandise
description: THERE are no subliminal messages in the Muzak that wafts through the Cherry Hill Mall. Really.

title: Terminal 4 to Ease Crush at Kennedy
description: Groundbreaking is set for tomorrow on a terminal to replace the maddeningly inefficient International Arrivals Building, also known as Terminal 4, at Kennedy International Airport in New York.

title: The Last Flip
description: SUN & SPOON

title: Too Big? Depends on Where You Sit
description: FORGET the tension between liberals and conservatives, blacks and whites -- even men and women. A new schism has formed, which has divided suburban residents as surely as the yellow line that splits the road: there are those who drive sport utility vehicles and those who drive passenger cars.

title: On Tiemann Place, Image-Conscious Is Redefined
description: Up and down Tiemann Place, people were talking about the two large hand-written signs that appeared at either end of the block Wednesday morning when Propaganda Films came to make a music video starring Fiona Apple.

title: Pregnant With Complications
description: Am I missing something? This woman went through all that to have a child and now is looking for a nanny to do the grunt work involved in raising it.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Sutton Place; Secluded, but With a Neighborly Feel
description: ENGLISH bulldogs seem to be the accessory of choice this year for Sutton Place residents on their nightly strolls around the affluent neighborhood.

title: Controlling Pests Without Growing Poison Apples
description: With more forethought, Adam might not have bitten the apple and I might not have planted apple trees. I did not realize that apple trees had so many pest problems, especially in the Northeast. But Adam did bite the apple, and I did plant apples -- 25 dwarf trees -- and we both had to face the consequences.

title: Sheryl Shade and Matthew Mazer
description: Sheryl Lee Shade and Matthew Charles Mazer are to be married this afternoon in New York. Rabbi Emily Korzenik is to officiate on the concourse at Rockefeller Plaza.

title: Commercial Property/The Garment District; A Bit of Madison Avenue Is Moving to Seventh
description: MANHATTAN'S garment district projects a raffish image, with side streets jammed by trucks making deliveries and picking up finished goods and racks of garments being rushed along crowded sidewalks presenting hazards for unwary pedestrians.

title: November 9-15; Powell Says No, Again
description: Maneuvering for the White House in 2000 has grown so intense that candidates appear to be already taking themselves out of a race that is three years off. After drawing outsized attention for traveling to the early Presidential caucus state of Iowa for a motivational conference, Colin L. Powell told reporters that he had no intention of seeking the Republican nomination.

title: Yourself Esq.
description: HASKEL SCHNITZER shuffled into the small courtroom wearing his dusty black overcoat and hat and waited patiently while the staff called around the courthouse looking for a someone who could speak Yiddish.

title: Miss Midgley, Mr. Komosa
description: Susan Hunt Midgley and Christopher John Komosa were married yesterday at the Union Church of Pocantico Hills in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. F. Paul DeHoff, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: 50 Years of Children's Books
description: Here is a selection of children's books published over the last half-century: a mixture of now-classic older titles and some wildly popular contemporary examples as yet untested by time. For the older books, the names of the original hardcover publishers are given. Those books are currently available in paperback editions.

title: On California Trip, Clinton Blends Politics and Fund-Raising
description: Mixing a little retail politics with his wholesale fund-raising, President Clinton came here today to show that he shares Californians' environmental concerns and to support the local Democratic Congressman, Vic Fazio, by dedicating a wet and grassy refuge for birds on their wearying migrations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROFF, RABBI DR. PALTIEL
description: ROFF-Rabbi Dr. Paltiel. We regretfully announce the passing of our beloved Rabbi, Dr. Paltiel Roff, on Thursday, November 13, 1997. He is survived by his wife, Barbara, daughter Naomi Roff; mother Beatrice Roff, brother Kenneth (Sandra) Roff and niece Felicia Roff. Services will be held on Sunday, November 16 at 10 AM in the main sanctuary at Madison Jewish Center, 2989 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, NY. Shiva will take place at the Rabbi's home, 1648 East 31st Street, Brooklyn, NY 11229 from Sunday, November 16 through Thursday, November 20.

title: Sports of The Times; When Fans in Italy and Russia Held Their Collective Breath
description: MOST Americans know nothing of the deep national sporting terror that gripped Italians and Russians yesterday.

title: Slow Roasting, Parboiling or Glazing Vegetables to Perfection
description: FOR many people, the stuffing is the best part of Thanksgiving dinner. But I also like the spread of late fall vegetables that are a traditional part of this meal.

title: Setting It Straight
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Problem Child
description: WHEN SHE

title: Sexy and Smart
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Stettinius, Mr. Benevento
description: Mary Stuart Stettinius, the daughter of Mrs. Michael Ballentine of Richmond and Joseph Stettinius of Williamsburg, Va., was married yesterday to Francis Anthony Benevento 3d, a son of Judith Lynn Free of Billings, Mont., and Mr. Benevento 2d of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Thom William Blair Jr., an Episcopal priest, officiated at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Richmond. The Rev. William Carr, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: The Florida Marlins' Model: Draft, Then Make a Trade
description: Jeff Conine is the answer. The question is, who was the only player the Florida Marlins selected in the 1992 expansion draft who played for them in the 1997 World Series?

title: Washington Set the Stage for Slavery's End; A Message for Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Now, a Manolo a Month
description: First there was the Book-of-the-Month Club. Then a club for records and even one for fruit. Now, for those whose feet ache for members-only status, there's a shoe club. The initiation fee: $7,200.

title: Number of Victims of Crime Fell Again in '96, Study Says
description: The rate at which Americans were victimized by crime fell last year to the lowest level since the Government began keeping data in 1973, according to a Justice Department report issued yesterday.

title: Bond Ratings Now Allowed
description: FOR years, bond rating agencies have wanted to evaluate how vulnerable bond mutual funds would be if interest rates moved sharply.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Generations

title: Frazier Likes Fines, Hates Look of Shorts
description: In the beginning, there were tighty whities, and that was fine with Walt (Clyde) Frazier. He was comfortable, and his game shorts did not inhibit his movement on the court.

title: Streetscapes/Hudson View Gardens; In Upper Manhattan, a 1924 Touch of Tudor Suburbia
description: THE labyrinth of long one-way streets in upper Manhattan just north of the George Washington Bridge gives the neighborhood a sequestered air. And one of the best-kept secrets is Hudson View Gardens, a 1924 garden-apartment co-op complex between Pinehurst Avenue and Cabrini Boulevard, from 183d to 185th Street. The complex has almost completed a restoration campaign begun six years ago, and the nearly suburban enclave is a delight for anyone dissatisfied with the traditional New York City apartment.

title: Theme Restaurants Draw Mall Crowds
description: T. J. CARROLL of Bellerose pointed at the fish in the ceiling-high aquarium at the Rainforest Cafe in Westbury. ''Look at that!'' T. J., 4, shouted to his mother, Margaret.

title: Funds Urged to Speed Capital Gain Estimates
description: A PROMINENT group of investment advisers wants mutual fund companies to speed up their disclosure of how much their funds are likely to pay in year-end capital gains and dividend distributions.

title: A Calm Heart Helps Kanell Deal With Adversity
description: Eight years ago today, Danny Kanell's brother-in-law Jeff Hall, the husband of his oldest sister, Debbie, was killed in a construction accident. For Kanell, in many ways, things have never been the same.

title: The View From: Yonkers; Dispensing Maxims on Love and Loss in 30-Second Sound Bites
description: DR. GILDA CARLE was analyzing a ''patient'' recently:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILSTEN, HELEN F.
description: GILSTEN-Helen F. On Thursday, November 13, 1997, at 90. Wife of the late Philip H., mother of Meg Hale, step-mother of Bud Gilsten. Also survived by Peter and Eric Gilsten, and Luke and Rachel Hale. Private services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENGER, KENNETH R.
description: WENGER-Kenneth R. November 11, 1997. Beloved husband of Virginia. Dear step-father of Paolo and Theo Gianakos. Loving brother of Gayle Whitney and Lenore Kriezel. Visiting Tuesday, November 18, 7-9:00 PM. Service Wednesday, 12:00 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: In Maine, Signs of Hope For Rivers and Anglers
description: Since the early 19th century, hydroelectric power brokers and entrepreneurs eager to service industry and the needs of a budding nation freely took rivers away from the fish and other creatures that inhabited them. Now it appears that fish may be getting some rivers, or at least some critical parts of them, back.

title: Should Sea Bright Be Gone With the Wind?
description: To the Editor:

title: What's Easy on the Ears Can Be Painful to Describe
description: ''MUSICAL LANGUAGES,'' HOT OFF the presses at W. W. Norton, is Joseph P. Swain's earnest attempt to make connections between music and words. Despite its meticulous hedging of bets -- its fair-minded and many acknowledgments of the gulf between two media -- Mr. Swain's book begins with an unavoidable bias. For it is indeed a book, a collection of sentences, paragraphs and printed musical examples. They make not a sound. What musical sounds they imply are conveyed by proxy. Taken for granted is that written symbols will have the power over music somehow to cope with its mysteries. Why else write the book?

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS; Monk's Music
description: Mysterious Thelonious Written and illustrated by Chris Raschka. Unpaged. New York: Orchard Books. $13.95. (Ages 3 and up)

title: November 9-15; Shadowed Memories
TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Dena Sacco, Daniel Rosen
description: Dena Terese Sacco and Daniel Mark Rosen, lawyers in Washington, were married last evening in Boston. Judge Marian Blank Horn of the United States Court of Federal Claims officiated at the Swissotel.

title: Unlucky Fichaud Is Beaten
description: For more than 40 minutes tonight the focus was on Eric Fichaud, the Islanders' young backup goalie. Once again he was keeping his team in the game with dazzling saves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ESTHER QUINT
description: LEVINE-Esther Quint. The Board of Trustees, Administration and Medical Staff of The Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center extends sincere condolences to Jack Levine, MD, our esteemed Chairman Emeritus of the Department of Orthopedics, on the loss of his beloved wife. Edwin L. Schulman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Frank J. Maddalena, President and CEO Alvin I. Kahn, MD Sr Vice President Medical Affairs Joel Teicher, MD Chairman of Orthopedics I. Akiva Wulkan, MD President, Medical Board Eric I. Saltzman, MD President, Medical Staff

title: Message to the Governor: Was Anyone Else Listening?
description: New Jersey voters sent a loud and clear message to Governor Whitman this month.

title: From Sidewalk Skirmish to Main Event
description: MELVA Max, almost prim in a black-and-white houndstooth wool suit, sat in a back row of Midtown Community Court on West 54th Street last week trading war stories with a fellow defendant, a young man who had been arrested while smoking marijuana on the street. He seemed sheepish; the last one of four on a toke, why didn't he have the sense to throw it away when the cops showed up?

title: A Real Dogfight
description: To the Editor:

title: Numbers Racket
description: Lucky You

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIEDER, AL
description: RIEDER-Al. The Board of Directors of Be'er Hagolah Institutes express their deep sorrow on the passing of Al Rieder, beloved father of our devoted board member Ralph Rieder. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family, a family reknowned for their dedication and service to the Jewish community. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marc Ratzersdorfer, President

title: Army Gets Closer To Saving Season
description: Buoyed by Eric Olsen's four field fields and a rejuvenated running game, Army inched closer to salvaging its season today with a 25-14 victory over North Texas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, ROBERT S.
description: KANE-Robert S. Suddenly on November 10, 1997. Age 72 at his home in NYC. Renowned journalist and author of 25 travel guide books. Survived by Dr. Max Drechsler. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: NATO Vote In Hungary Fails to Stir Enthusiasm
description: Hungarian politicians are hoping that voters will overcome a lingering apathy toward a referendum on Sunday and show their approval for what has virtually been decided for them: that Hungary will be a new member of NATO.

title: November 9-15; A Record at Christie's
description: The art collection of Victor and Sally Ganz, a quiet Manhattan couple who spent 50 years and less than $2 million to buy the work of artists like Picasso and Jasper Johns, went on the auction block at Christie's Monday night and broke all records for a single-owner sale, bringing in $206.5 million.

title: INSIDE
description: MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 8/

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUMWAY, FLOYD M.
description: SHUMWAY-Floyd M. Died on November 12, 1997. Services November 17, 2:00 P.M., First Church of Christ, New Haven, CT.

title: Funny 'Mojo' Can Dazzle As It Appalls
description: JEZ BUTTERWORTH'S ''MOJO,'' THE ENGLISH play that opened last week at the Atlantic Theater Company, is something to curl your hair, meaning that it's seriously scary: a grotesque, violent, obscene, linguistically dazzling melodrama set in late-night London, a place where morality is no more easily recognized than a pothole is in New York at 3 A.M.

title: Baldies Deserve Kinder Cuts
description: IF I tell anyone that I've gone for a haircut, I hear snickers. As if a bald man does not require -- nay, crave -- a shampoo and a cut. Yes, the remains of my hair continue to grow, albeit slowly. But if I report a visit to a stylist, I hear guffaws. These smug and overhaired cynics note that the fringed remains of my hair hardly constitute raw material for any trained tonsorial practitioner.

title: A Mature, Wealthy Israel Gives Its American Cousins a Jolt: 'Jews Are Not News'
description: American visitors to Israel these days might be forgiven for suspecting that they never left home, what with the proliferation of McDonald's arches, Blockbuster videos, football games on cable, shopping malls, epic traffic jams and the air of prosperity.

title: Annie D. Wauneka, 87, Dies; Navajo Medical Crusader
description: Annie Dodge Wauneka, who broke custom and became the Navajo Nation's first female legislator and a health crusader, died on Monday at Flagstaff Medical Center in Arizona. She was 87 and lived in Klagetoh, in northeast Arizona.

title: Hasidic Community Opposes Bike Lane Plan
description: A plan to create a series of bicycle lanes through Borough Park, Brooklyn, has raised protests about safety among residents of the largely Orthodox Jewish community, some of whom also say the bike paths would attract skimpily clad cyclists.

title: Iron Curtain Chills; A Cold War Spy Doesn't Dare Go Home
description: COL. RYSZARD KUKLINSKI may go down in cold war history as one of the United States' most valuable spies. For nine years he gave the Central Intelligence Agency top-secret documents that detailed the inner workings of the Polish army and the Warsaw Pact, until on a cold November night in 1981 he left his post on the Polish General Staff and was bundled onto a plane to America. The Polish authorities were on his tail, and Poland's Communist Government was about to crush the Solidarity movement with martial law.

title: In Tokyo, Flavors of the Past
description: SLEEK office towers and modern apartment buildings have erased much of the old Tokyo skyline, once dominated by wooden houses, temples and shrines. Still, you can catch glimpses of the past in shita machi, the old commercial section of the city. Here, traditional shops and houses that have survived earthquakes, war and attempts at gentrification stand stubbornly beside newer structures. Many pubs and restaurants have preserved the flavors of old Edo (as Tokyo was once known) -- simmered clams, aromatic glaze-grilled eels, crisp tempura and bubbling oden (fish dumpling stew). And these dishes continue to delight modern Tokyo residents.

title: Save the Penny: Her Thoughts Are Giveaways
description: When Ally McBeal's ex-boyfriend pays her a fatuous compliment, the scene changes for a second to show us how the remark hurt: three arrows pierce her heart (no blood, just whimsical special effects). While she smiles politely at a man she has just met, a flash cut of her kissing him reveals her hankering. And when Ally realizes she has made a faux pas, we see her, for an instant, with her foot in her mouth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIFKIN, LILIANN LIHN
description: RIFKIN-Liliann Lihn. On November 13, 1997. Devoted mother of Matthew and daughter-in-law Tomoko, dear sister of Katie and Tom Riggione. Services Sunday 4:30PM, ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory can be made to the American Foundation For Aids Research, 733 3rd Avenue, NYC 10017.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAXMAN, VIVIAN K.
description: WAXMAN-Vivian K. November 13, 1997, of Coconut Creek, Florida (formerly of Great Neck, New York). Beloved wife of Herbert for fifty eight years, devoted mother of daughter Jill Polymeropoulos and son Jonathon (Jon), loving grandmother of Marc, cherished sister-in-law of Juliette Sack and Cecille Ellner, David Litan and Harry Buchman. She was one of the world's special people, doer of good deeds and a blessing to all who knew her. No one who ever met her, will ever forget her. She will live forever in our hearts.

title: Editors' Note
description: On July 16, 1995, The New York Times Magazine published an article, ''The Deadliest D.A.,'' written by Tina Rosenberg. The article focused on Lynne Abraham's use of the death penalty in Philadelphia. In one paragraph, it also referred to Barbara Christie, a longtime Philadelphia assistant district attorney and former chief of the Homicide Unit. Through a lawsuit, Ms. Christie informed The Times that the information in that paragraph was inaccurate.

title: November 9-15; Immigration Curbs Eased
description: Courting Hispanic voters, the Republican-led Congress relaxed two provisions in a restrictive 1996 immigration law.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; O Mistress Mein
description: It's hard to forget a novel that spreads across the imagination like a mysterious and evil stain. Based on Eva Braun's actual diary entries and fleshed out by Alison Leslie Gold's imagination, THE DEVIL'S MISTRESS (Faber & Faber, $24.95) shadows Braun, also known as Fraulein Effie, as she schemes to keep herself in lipstick and crocodile shoes, nipping at a bottle of vermouth while waiting for the rumble of a Mercedes staff car outside her door. Many of Effie's evenings with the Chancellor end the same way: the two circle his bedroom, sniffing each other like dogs. (Sometimes Adolf nips her.) Because Gold's writing is so consistent in tone, her invented version of Braun seems almost indistinguishable from the real one. Effie reveals herself in short, enervated blurts, as if her staggering self-centeredness has left her with no means to shuttle her thoughts to the outside world. And yet her boxed-in existence is lavishly furnished. ''In every shop window -- in a gilt frame -- a twig and flower garlanded photo of him. Spilling down house fronts, red bunting dotted with white circles offsetting black hooked crosses.'' What does this imperiled nonentity have to say about what she's getting into? Only this: ''If I can't get good lingerie, I'll surely have to end it all.'' Sally Eckhoff

title: A Book on China Dam
description: A DISSIDENT book protesting the damming of the Yangtze River in China is being published in Westchester.

title: Sports of The Times; Giving Game-Set-Match a Bit of Sis-Boom-Bah
description: MAKING his annual pilgrimage here last week to speak at his alma mater, the Harvard Business School, John Korff felt no allegiance to the corporate conscience. He did not wear a suit to Myra M. Hart's class, Starting New Ventures, because he does not own one.

title: Bomb Attack's Terrifying Hold
description: Taina Rodriguez will not ride an elevator or school bus. She refuses to go on class trips. She has nightmares and cries for the slightest reason.

title: A Dancer's Collection, and Sloganeering
description: HOW a museum gets to be strong in a particular area often owes more to whim and circumstance than to systematic planning. The Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford is a good example. A major repository of theater design relating to the most important ballet companies in this century, it achieved its status largely because one of the major dancers of Serge de Diaghilev's Ballets Russes fell on hard times in 1933, four years after the demise of the company.

title: The Two Hollywoods; The End Of the Middle
description: One thing about Hollywood: it is always in the throes of a revolution. This year's revolution erupted last February when the Academy Award nominations were announced and only one big studio picture, ''Jerry Maguire,'' was among the five anointed for Best Picture. The rest, including the eventual winner, ''The English Patient,'' were what those in the business call ''indie'' productions, which is to say that they were distributed and in many cases financed by small independent companies operating on the periphery of the Hollywood plantation.

title: . . . But Only Minchello Can Make a Tree
description: GERMANY started it, many people say. Queen Victoria brought it to England. America modernized it. And then along came Philip Minchello -- and the Christmas tree tradition may never be the same.

title: Learning at Home, Playing at School
description: JEFFREY ARON plays trumpet in the school band at Whiting Lane Elementary School in West Hartford, but he is not a student there. Rather, his mother teaches him at home, but school officials permit him to take trumpet lessons at the public school and play in its band.

title: Kelly Richards, Michael Puma
description: Kelly Ann Richards, a daughter of Kristine M. Stadler and a stepdaughter of Martin F. Stadler of Totowa, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Salvatore Puma, a son of Carmine C. Puma of Ridgefield, Conn., and the late Teresa M. Puma. The Rev. Thomas F. Gallagher performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Holy Angels Roman Catholic Church in Little Falls, N.J.

title: Tears Over Soccer Story
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: At 50, a Mellower David Mamet May Be Ready to Tell His Story
description: THE REHEARSAL TOOK place on a recent Sunday in an obscure, cellar-like space in this city's South End. The room was spare. Two actors, Peter Riegert and Vincent Guastaferro, sat on folding chairs against the backdrop of a brick wall, observed by only a few others. One was the playwright, David Mamet, who sat directly in front of them, a familiar, stocky figure with a bluntly trimmed beard, round glasses and a baseball cap.

title: Irish Car Rental
description: To the Editor: Last spring, ''Uphill and Down in West Cork'' (June 1) endorsed Dan Dooley Car Rental in Ireland. On June 26, I rented a car from Dooley -- a 1995 Ford Mondeo with more than 40,000 miles. Before leaving, I pointed out dents, scratches and other body problems to the office manager, asking for another car. I was told this was the only car available to me. The manager noted the problems.

title: Kevin Rampe, Christine Siegfried
description: Christine Elise Siegfried, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David C. Siegfried of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Kevin Michael Rampe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Rampe of Warwick, N.Y. The Rev. Johann J. Bosman performed the ceremony at the Community Congregational Church in Short Hills.

title: For the Poor Especially, AIDS Is Still Rampaging; Therapy, but No Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: The Wind in the Willows

title: Kodak Moments
description: A Day With Picasso Twenty-four Photographs by Jean Cocteau. By Billy Kluver. 99 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $25.

description: A DIRECTOR CALLS

description: BIOTECHNOLOGY UNZIPPED

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMBROSE, REVEREND THOMAS
description: AMBROSE-Reverend Thomas, S.J. Beloved brother of Helen, loving uncle of Paul, Marck. Reposing at the West Side Jesuit Community Residence, 53 East 83rd Street, on Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, and on Thursday, 2-5 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 8 PM, at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th St. For further information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors 718-654-0500.

description: CURIOSITY AS ART
