description: Felix in the Underworld

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mercedes-Benz CLK320; The Coup de Grace In Grand Coupes
description: THE master chefs at Mercedes-Benz have spent the last few years in the kitchen, testing all sorts of zesty new recipes. And now, dinner is served.

title: Washington Set the Stage for Slavery's End; How to Honor Diversity
description: To the Editor:

title: An Intrepid Pioneer, A Consuming Fury
description: ECSTASY VERSUS FURY. Rapture versus rage. In Shakespeare these clashing ''humors'' yielded timeless drama: Romeo and Juliet and Iago and Lear. Jazz gives us Armstrong and Bechet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELL, SAMUEL
description: MANDELL-Samuel. Beloved husband of Emily. Devoted father of Andrew and Marilyn, Ellen and Jim Edmundson. Loving brother of Yetta Aaron and Esther Grad. Services 1:30 PM, Sunday, at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapel,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Word for Word / Regionalisms; In Plainspoken English, America's Still Whopperjawed
description: ASK any computer expert trying to design workable voice-recognition technology for standard American English: Despite predictions that Americans would all be speaking by now in a bland, homogenized dialect of network TV newscasters, the United States remains a country of stubbornly persistent regional accents, idioms and slang.

title: Thinking Toys, Thinking Safety
description: The best friend a child can have this holiday season isn't Santa Claus, the New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs says. It's parents and grandparents who buy only safe toys.

title: The Rabbi's Lost Tribe
description: RABBI KHAIMOV stood at his apartment window in Corona, Queens, salsa music rumbling from his radio. Upstairs, a dozen South Asian cab drivers came and went in shifts. One particular man likes to lift weights in the middle of the night, keeping the rabbi and his wife from sleeping.

title: Senate Committee Demands 70 Tapes of Fund-Raisers
description: Complaining about ''a rather dismal record of delay,'' the Senate committee investigating campaign finance abuses has demanded that the White House turn over 70 additional videotapes of President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore attending fund-raising events at the White House and around the country.

title: The More Things Change . . .
description: If you rummage through the Book Review archives from 50 years ago, you may be tempted to conclude that in the world of children's books, at least, nothing much has changed: parents tend to worry about what their children read. They did then, they do now.

title: Science Advisers Retain Independence but Must Be More Open
description: The National Academy of Sciences, the leading dispenser of scientific advice to the Government, will recast its procedures as a result of legislation passed last week by Congress.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; Now It's a Car for Every Lawn
description: BESIDES the usual mix of compact evergreens edged with colorful perennials livening up the front of my neighbors homes, I've noticed a new element added to the landscaping hodgepodge in both front and side yards. No squat goofy gnome, gosling windsock or stone-cold Madonna contributes as much to overall visual impact as the latest must-have outdoor accessory: lawn cars.

title: The Vroom and the Wail: Motorcycles Trigger Car Alarms
description: Coping with noise is part of being a New Yorker, but people who live along 10th Avenue say they never bargained for motorcyclists making a sport of setting off car alarms with bikes that have been modified to be extra loud.

title: DIARY
description: TRADE

title: Why Judy Blume Endures
description: Twenty-five years ago, Dutton published ''Tales of a Fourth Grade Nothing,'' Judy Blume's comic novel of sibling rivalry. In the two preceding years, Blume had already written two coming-of-age classics: ''Are You There, God? It's Me, Margaret'' (a girls' book: it deals with menstruation and breasts) and ''Then Again, Maybe I Won't'' (for boys: wet dreams and puppy love). By 1996, ''Tales of a Fourth Grade Nothing'' had sold over six million copies and was the third-highest-selling children's trade paperback ever, behind ''Charlotte's Web,'' by E. B. White, and ''The Outsiders,'' by S. E. Hinton; four other Blume books were in the top 20.

title: Endpaper; The Mother of All Independents
description: Elsewhere, to promote morale, movie companies waste fortunes sending employees to the San Ysidro Ranch for a weekend of bonding and war games. Here at Miramax, they just send in Miriam Weinstein. Miriam is everyone's favorite Jewish mother, which is to say: not your own -- although she is the mother of the company's founders, Harvey and Bob. Miriam is chatty, nurturing, interested but not interfering (unless you like that) and comes to the company's TriBeCa offices several times a year, as she has today, bearing bagels, bags of Hershey's Kisses and 250 pieces of rugelach. Bonding, schmonding -- have some cake.

title: Grim Reckoning in Japan -- and Beyond
description: The financial whirlwind sweeping through Southeast Asia has now struck the Japanese stock market with the swirling fury of a tsunami. On Friday, the Nikkei 225 average tumbled to 15,082, its lowest close in two years. Despite sharp gains in early trading today, this downward trend portends problems of a magnitude dwarfing those emanating from the smaller East Asian countries. So long as financial instability seemed confined to Hong Kong, Thailand et al., one could blandly argue that the problem was somehow small and containable. Now that the contagion has infected Japan, the global ramifications could be profound.

title: Dropping Barriers Can Rescue Third World Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article by Reuters in Business Day on Friday about quarterly results for four retailers referred incorrectly to the earnings of Saks Holdings Inc. The figure, 29 cents a share excluding the effect of an adjusted tax rate, matched Wall Street analysts' estimates; it did not exceed them.

title: Grand Rapids Boosters Borrow the Renaissance
description: Financial problems and a general disdain on the part of the community nearly closed the Grand Rapids Art Museum in 1991. At one point, half the staff was let go. When a new director, Celeste Adams, arrived two years ago, she found a dead bat in her second-floor office. It had apparently strayed through a duct from one of the two upper floors, which the museum has never used.

title: Hungarians Approve NATO Membership
description: Hungarians casting ballots in a referendum on their country's entry into NATO overwhelming approved the measure today, even though it barely attracted enough voters to make it valid.

title: Russian Reformer's Credibility Undercut by Scandal
description: The architect of Russian economic reform the free-market crusader who also promised to rid the country of its entrenched corruption -- is now reeling under scrutiny of his own ethical conflicts.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Now our only enemy is water.''

title: Working Moms Take the Blame; Respite From Home
description: To the Editor:

title: She Won't Let Go Of 70's Soul
description: Lisa Stansfield does a lot of living in the past. Her music is a revival of 1970's soul on the cusp of disco. And her best songs, like ''All Around the World'' from 1990 and ''All Woman'' from 1991, have been the confessions of a woman who won't let go of a failing romance. Ms. Stansfield's current album, ''Lisa Stansfield'' (Arista), has arrived six years after her previous one, ''Real Love'' (Arista). When she sang at the Supper Club on Thursday night, a fervent, packed house mingled nostalgia for the early 90's and the 70's.

title: New Kind of Championship Drops Nationality Barriers
description: A new type of world championship was introduced last month in Hammamet, Tunisia, and was a considerable success. It was the Transnational Open Teams, in which players were not restricted to their own countrymen, and it attracted 74 entries. One of them, fully in the spirit of the event, had players from four countries: France, Germany, Lebanon and Egypt. Since the Egyptian player was Omar Sharif, much excitement ensued.

title: Oklahoma Bombing Trial Is No Replay
description: During jury selection for the second Oklahoma City bombing trial, some potential jurors knew so little about the defendant, Terry L. Nichols, that they referred to him as Terry McNichols, combining his last name with that of his co-defendant, Timothy J. McVeigh.

title: Not-So-Funny Call By N.Y. Fox Station
description: Viewers in New York were unable to see the last 20 minutes of Dallas's 17-14 victory over Washington yesterday because Channel 5, the Fox affiliate, showed ''World's Funniest!'' Channel 5 had televised the Cardinals-Giants game from 1-4 P.M., but had the option to return at 7 P.M. for the end of Dallas's victory.

title: Internet Merchants Try to Fight Fraud in Software Purchases
description: When it comes to the security risks of using a credit card to buy something on line, consumers often fear that a thief may intercept the card number for a cybershopping spree. But Internet merchants, especially those selling software for immediate download, know the bigger financial risk is their own.

title: Beating Michigan Is No Sure Ticket to Roses
description: They will gather on Saturday to conduct an annual ritual the way Woody Hayes would want it done. Ohio State and Michigan should play for the highest of stakes, preferably under a slate-gray sky, with temperatures low enough to require various beverages.

title: A 'Dybbuk' Foresees 'The Martyred Dead'
description: A dark, soul-sapping force seems to have taken possession of Tony Kushner's adaptation of ''A Dybbuk, or Between Two Worlds,'' which opened last night at the Joseph Papp Public Theater. And it's not the sad supernatural creature of the play's title, a homeless spirit that seeks refuge in the bodies of the living.

title: Young & Rubicam Hires Forecasters
description: Young & Rubicam Inc. has hired two executives in the fields of consumer trend forecasting and business development.

title: What Pollsters Miss
description: To the Editor:

title: At Home Abroad; Peace and Justice
description: ''We feel a strong belief of my own,'' Robin Cook said, ''that we can't have peace in Bosnia unless we have justice against those who committed atrocities.''

title: Working Moms Take the Blame; Put Children First
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMBROSE, REVEREND THOMAS, S.J.
description: AMBROSE-Reverend Thomas, S.J. Beloved brother of Helen, loving uncle of Paul, Marck. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray Weigel Hall, Fordham University on Thursday, 2-4 and 79 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Friday, 11:30 AM at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray Weigel Hall, Fordham University, Bronx. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors 718-654-0500.

title: A Lifeline for the Everglades
description: Early next month, when the Everglades National Park marks its 50th anniversary, the Clinton Administration will have a rare opportunity to celebrate the occasion in grand style and, in the process, accelerate President Clinton's ambitious program to restore the Everglades to its former grandeur.

title: A Xenophobic Weed Is Growing in Denmark's Tidy Little Garden
description: COPENHAGEN  In the mind of its people, Denmark has been a preserve of good nature and gentle fortune, scrubbed and apple-cheeked, without arrogance or subservience, a small place so fair, decent, and mild that it stands out in its cosy virtue as God's own little red house with white picket fence.

title: Pied Piper Who Leads March Out Of the Hall
description: You have to admire Leonard Slatkin, the music director of the National Symphony Orchestra, for his boundless enthusiasm about unfamiliar repertory and for his important advocacy of American music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUNES, DONALD
description: NUNES-Donald. Died in Bath, England, on Tuesday, November 11, after courageous battle with cancer. Son of Kenneth and Helen Nunes, husband of Ann Biddick Nunes, father of Becky and Jonathan. Don was inspirational, much loved and irreplaceable. A celebration of his life will take place in Lacock Church, Wiltshire, at 2 PM on Monday, November 24. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Don Nunes Memorial Scholarship Fund, c/o Advanced Studies in England, 2 Pierrepont St., Bath BA1 1LB, England.

title: Leap Consolidating Ethnic Agencies
description: The Leap Partnership unit of Leap Group is combining its two New York agencies that specialize in ethnic advertising and marketing -- YAR Communications and Kang & Lee -- into a unit named One World Communications.

title: When the Musician Is the Drama, Working Magic Onstage
description: Instrumental music is irredeemably real. Singers, actors or dancers can disappear entirely into imaginary worlds onstage, but instrumentalists are always doing something earthbound and actual, their attention devoted to a physical machine for making sounds in the here and now. It becomes hard, therefore, to believe in an instrumentalist as a character in a drama. Instrumental performance is a drama all of its own, and it is happening now, before us, not in some make-believe action.

title: Equity Issues Set for Offering During Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Half-Measures on British Freedoms
description: The country that gave the world the Magna Carta lags, paradoxically, behind other developed nations in protecting the rights of its citizens. Britain, which has neither a written constitution nor a real bill of rights, grants its Government powers that citizens elsewhere would not tolerate. The Labor Party, in opposition, advocated several overdue measures to close the rights gap. Now that it is in power, Labor has introduced a bill that falls short of its promises.

title: Dissident Impudently Ridiculed Harsh Rule
description: During Wei Jingsheng's years in prison, he often played a dangerous game.

title: Cadets No Match for Blue Devils
description: The Duke-Army season opener yesterday felt like a one-on-one game in the driveway at a family reunion. Big brother clobbers little brother and everybody has a good laugh.

title: Woman's Body Found In Recreation Area
description: A parks enforcement worker on a routine patrol in the Bronx discovered a woman's badly burned body in a heavily wooded area yesterday, the police said. The woman has not been identified.

title: Suspect in Cabby Killing Glimpsed Hope, but Life Fell Apart
description: She was only 17, but four years on the streets of El Barrio had made her hard. Friends said the young runaway had drifted from bed to bed, from man to man. One had slashed her face, another had knocked out her front teeth. Three cigarette burns on her arm signified her only loyalty, to the Bloods gang. She dressed, talked and fought like a thug. She smoked dope and always needed cash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATIUCHOK, WILLIAM, M.D.
description: BATIUCHOK-William, M.D. On November 14, 1997. Born May 26, 1920. Beloved and devoted husband of Margaret. Loving father of John and his wife Louisa, Margaret and Susan. Devoted grandfather of Daniel and Beth. Graduate of Columbia College '41, Cornell University Medical College '44, Emeritus Director Thoracic Surgery of Wyckoff Heights Hospital and Flushing Hospital. Secretary, Board of Trustees Wyckoff Heights Hospital; past President of Medical Board Flushing Hospital; past President and current Member, Board of Trustees, Garden School. Reposing in Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd., Flushing. Visiting hours Sunday and Monday 2-5 and 7-10 PM. Service Monday, 7:30 PM. Funeral Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment Maple Grove Cemetery. Donations to Wyckoff Heights Hospital, Flushing Hospital, Columbia College '41 or Garden School.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SMITH, G.E. KIDDER
description: SMITH-G.E. Kidder. A memorial service will be held for Kidder Smith on Monday, November 17, 11AM at the Church of the Epiphany, 1393 York Avenue at 74 Street.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEVENSON, JOHN REESE
description: STEVENSON-John Reese. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, November 19, 1997, at 4 PM, Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue, New York City. Donations in his memory may be made to the Community Hospice of Fort Worth, TX., or to the Columbia School of Law for the Research & Study of Law in Latin America.

title: William Roberts Sees More Action
description: Is Bill Parcells warming up William Roberts for the cold-weather stretch drive? The 35-year-old, who played in three Super Bowls under Parcells, came in for a second consecutive week and again threw the key block on Adrian Murrell's longest run of the game. Roberts was pulling to the right on Murrell's 15-yarder yesterday. Last week, Murrell ran behind him on a 43-yard score. Roberts, who had seen virtually no action until the last two games, replaces Lonnie Palelei.

title: Taking In the Sites; Contests Galore on the Web, but Sales Pitches, Too
description: Win! Win! Win! Free! Free! Free! The World Wide Web offers access to hundreds of contests in all shapes and sizes, including trivia quizes, giveaways, lotteries, essay contests, raffles and scavenger hunts, in which clues to contests are scattered throughout a Web site.

title: 32 in Latin Kings Gang Are Arrested in Brooklyn
description: Antonio Fernandez, the leader of the Latin Kings gang, was arrested on a residential street in Brooklyn on Saturday night along with 31 other members of his gang after the police received reports of disorderly conduct by armed men, the police said.

title: Brave New World of Competition
description: In the display window of a little corner bookstore hangs an oversized question mark, a poster that Erika Tapp, one of the managers, put up several years ago to attract customers. But recently, this symbol has assumed a significance that Mrs. Tapp did not anticipate: She is beginning to fear for her store's survival.

title: Sensing The Souls Of Five Matriarchs
description: ''Dance Women: Living Legends,'' a four-day series in tribute to five women who founded modern-dance companies with deep roots in black communities around the country, presented its second program on Saturday afternoon. The hosts at Davis Hall at City College were Judith Jamison, artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, and George Faison, the Broadway and modern-dance choreographer and former Ailey dancer.

title: Gordon Clinches Winston Cup
description: When you are the Yankees, the Dallas Cowboys or Jeff Gordon, you have the luxury of deciding which of your championships is more esthetically pleasing than the others. In Gordon's case, the Nascar Winston Cup that he clinched here today in the Napa 500 at Atlanta Motor Speedway will belong on a slightly lower shelf.

title: Sports of The Times; Cedric Jones Takes A Big Step Forward
description: ''You try to go where you think you can run the football. They've got new guys and you'd like to see if they can stand up.''

title: Patents; Presenting amylin, which is being called the first new diabetes drug since the discovery of insulin.
description: THE onset of diabetes rarely compels people to scour medical texts or the Internet for experimental drugs or alternative treatments. Millions of Americans are diabetic, and they, along with most everyone else, know that the potentially life-threatening condition can be controlled with insulin injections or a combination of weight loss, exercise and oral medication.

title: Collapse of Japan's 10th Largest Bank Sets Off Large Market Rally
description: A major Japanese bank collapsed this morning in a new reminder of the weakness in Asia's financial system, just as American and Japanese officials were discussing new ways of responding to financial emergencies in the region.

title: Working Moms Take the Blame; Try Flexible Scheduling
description: To the Editor:

title: America's Energy Independence
description: The worldwide scramble to develop new and existing energy sources has become a driving force in contemporary foreign policy. The Clinton Administration, building on America's dual role as the world's largest energy producer and largest energy consumer, has made itself a main player in this new world energy game, promoting increased production at home and abroad. Its sensible goal is to lessen the country's vulnerability to pressures from energy exporters and protect Washington's freedom to make foreign policy based on larger American and global interests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAPOLI, NATE (NATALE)
description: NAPOLI-Nate (Natale). May 21, 1910-November 15, 1997. Living is what he loved. Giving is what he did. Love is what he got. He had no complaints as he traveled the highway of life taking us along with him. It was a great trip for those of us who really knew him. A part of us is gone, yet a part of him will always live on. He will be forever loved and respected. Viewing at the Fairchild Funeral Home, Manhasset, LI, Tuesday. Funeral mass at St. Mary's Church, Roslyn, LI. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Diabetes Foundation or the American Heart Association would be appreciated.

title: Isaiah Berlin, Enemy of Tyranny
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STAR, LEON D., M.D.
description: STAR-Leon D., M.D. Beloved husband, loving father and grandfather. We miss you every day but especially today, your birthday. Your Family

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Dropping Barriers Can Rescue Third World Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Frost Clouds the Crystal Ball: Cold Now Doesn't Necessarily Mean Cold Later
description: It is cold. Very cold. The high temperature in Central Park yesterday -- peaking at 39 degrees by midafternoon -- was 15 degrees below normal for the middle of November, prompting one meteorologist to describe the weekend as ''almost ridiculously cold.''

title: A Private Eye; Wanted: Space for Eve, Pandora and Homemakers
description: ''Why is woman the originator of sin -- in Judaism, Christianity and Islam?'' asked Merry Conway. She and Noni Pratt, who as Conway and Pratt have worked together for 11 years at their hybrid of performance and installation art, have been thinking about Eve and Pandora for ''A Woman's Work Is Never Done,'' their work in progress.

title: Columbia/HCA Planning to Cut Network by at Least a Third
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation is expected as early as today to announce a broad reorganization that would cut its giant network of almost 350 hospitals by at least a third and reduce the number of its administrators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, GERTRUDE
description: SHERMAN-Gertrude. On November 16, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Devoted mother of Carol Sherman, Judy and Dick Krain. Loving grandmother of Jennifer and Amy Krain. Dear sister of Samuel Rudey and Mary Hirshhorn. For further information call Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1-800468-3232.

title: An Awards Show Is Therapy for Cable's Complex
description: ''And the Cable Ace goes to . . .'' is not a phrase that generates a thrill, unless you're sitting in the audience gripping the cheat notes that remind you to thank Mom. Cable television's version of the Emmys, the Cable Ace Awards were handed out for the 19th year and shown live on TNT on Saturday night. The experience was so low-wattage in terms of stars and suspense that it became revealing. These awards seem on the verge of outliving their purpose, which is special pleading for cable channels.

title: In Death, a Journey Home to Senegal
description: In his last phone call home to his mother in Senegal, Elhadji Gaye promised to return for a visit soon. It had been 11 years since he left his family behind to seek his fortune in New York, and he had not been back once.

title: Netanyahu Calls for Unity In U.S. Talk
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel issued a call for unity tonight to some 3,500 leaders of American Jewish groups gathered here as word spread of diplomatic activity aimed at getting the battered Middle East peace process off its knees.

title: Lonesome Glory Wins 4th Title
description: Lnesome Glory nailed down his fourth title as steeplechasing's horse of the year yesterday when he took the lead at the 17th and last fence and galloped out to a half-length victory in the $100,000-added Marion duPont Scott Colonial Cup Steeplechase at the Springdale Race Course in Camden, S.C. He also collected a $250,000 bonus for winning both the Carolina Cup and the Colonial Cup and assured himself a place in the National Museum of Racing's Hall of Fame after his retirement.

title: Shellfish Beds Reopen Five Days After Spill
description: About 2,000 acres of shellfish beds in northern Monmouth County reopened on Saturday morning, five days after a broken pipe at a pumping station dumped thousands of gallons of raw sewage near the mouths of the Shrewsbury and Navesink Rivers.

title: Indian Tribes Say Aid Comes Only to Those Who Donate to Democrats
description: Centuries of hardscrabble history have taught some American Indians that the Federal Government will always take more than it gives. In recent weeks, however, those suspicions have been at least partly turned on their head.

title: Few Points for Artistry, but Giants Show They Can Bounce Back
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel had called today's game against Arizona a ''must win'' for his Giants. He had not been specific about how it must be won.

title: Accounts
description: * Selfcare Inc., Waltham, Mass., to Warwick Baker O'Neill, New York, to handle advertising for a recently acquired line of vitamins, including Posture and Stresstabs. The account had been inactive when those brands were owned by the American Home Products Corp. Billings were estimated at more $5 million.

title: 'Next Generation' Telephone Service
description: Daniel Briere, an Internet consultant and author, sends dozens of hefty faxes every day from his office in Verona, N.J., some of them to far-flung locales abroad. Yet his telephone bill for faxes -- once nearly $1,000 a month -- is only pennies. In other offices, people routinely make international calls for the price of calling across town.

title: Israel's Controversy Over Religion Affects Donations by Jews in U.S.
description: While American Jews are contributing record sums to Jewish causes at home and abroad, thousands of them are withholding or diverting up to $20 million in donations this year, partly to protest the religious and peace policies of Israel's conservative Government, leaders of Jewish organizations say.

title: U.S. Regains No. 1 Spot as Maker of Fastest Supercomputers
description: In a significant reversal, the United States has regained its lead as the maker of the world's fastest supercomputers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 11 about The New York Post's plan for a new printing plant referred incorrectly to incentives offered to The Daily News in 1993 to move to Jersey City. Though the amount was widely reported at the time to be $35 million, The News calls that figure exaggerated. Its grants and loans totaled at least $15 million, along with other incentives.

title: Lucent Ships a Digital Television Chip
description: Lucent Technologies announced last week that it was shipping prototype versions of a chip designed to serve as a signal receiver in digital television sets, computers and cable boxes, among other possible digital applications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARP, IRWIN
description: KARP-Irwin. Beloved husband of Lynn. Devoted father of Cindy, Jeff and Doug. Dear brother of Marvin and loving grandfather. Services today, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPULER, WILLIAM P., M.D.
description: KAPULER-William P., M.D. On November 16, 1997. Beloved husband of Sylvia; loving father of Alan, Genevieve and Kathryn. Cherished grandfather of Matthew, Kusra, Serena, Dylana, Sarah, and Emily. Services Tuesday, 12 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: WebTV is Microsoft's linchpin in its drive for the interactive media market.
description: WHEN the Microsoft Corporation snagged a little Silicon Valley start-up called WebTV Networks for $425 million in April, the acquisition was duly noted, but no one seemed to completely understand the attraction.

title: Kalgoorlie Journal; As a Tourist Lure, the Leer of a Naughty Museum?
description: As a tourist attraction, it hardly competes with Sydney's Opera House or Ayers Rock, but fat tour buses inevitably crawl along Hay Street, the brothel quarter of this hard-edged capital of Western Australia's goldfields. Skimpily dressed young women wave from gaudily lighted stalls. Sometimes tourists wave back.

title: Foreign Affairs; Tame the Beast
description: It is becoming an intolerable threat to American interests and world stability. President Clinton is going to have to deal with it unilaterally, before its reckless, irresponsible, dictatorial leadership destroys us all. Things can't be allowed to continue like this, with all talk and no action. Whatever powers the President needs to meet this threat are fine with me. Whatever it takes, baby, whatever it takes. Because this out-of-control beast has got to be stopped.

title: Redskins Game Is Key for Giants
description: Next Sunday, if the Giants (7-4) win their National Football Conference East game with the Washington Redskins (6-5) and the Dallas Cowboys (6-5) lose at Green Bay, the Giants will not only lead Washington and Dallas by two games, they will also have all the major division-title tie breakers strongly in their favor.

title: Anna's World; In Industry of Glamour, Editor of Vogue Turns a Lot of Heads
description: It was fashion week, and there was Vogue's editor, Anna Wintour, at the Marc Jacobs show in her usual front- row seat, wearing her signature sunglasses and a Marc Jacobs gray waffle-knit cashmere sweater.

title: Spirlea Minces Opponents, Not Words
description: At first she did not have a reputation to live up to or live down. But Irina Spirlea is finding it hard to shake her sudden renown as the wildest player to grace or disgrace a tennis court since her Romanian countryman Ilie Nastase's blue language made folks see red.

title: Can Marv Albert's Voice Lift Acclaim's Fortunes?
description: Jae Min, a high school sophomore in Sunnyvale, Calif., and an avid video game enthusiast, knew exactly what new title he wanted at the local Electronics Boutique recently: Acclaim Entertainment Inc.'s NFL Quarterback Club '98 for his Nintendo 64 console. Why not the perennial leader in football video games, the Electronic Arts game bearing the likeness of John Madden, the popular sportscaster and former coach? Two words: Marv Albert.

title: Footlights
description: EVENTS

title: Penny Binn Binstock, 58, a Psychologist
description: Penny Binn Binstock, a clinical psychologist, died on Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York from injuries she suffered in a fall. She was 58 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Chinese Dissident Lands in U.S. And Enters Hospital in Detroit
description: Wei Jingsheng, China's most prominent dissident after spending most of the last 18 years in jail for advocating democracy, arrived here today on a nonstop flight from Beijing following his release from prison, and was immediately admitted to a local hospital.

title: Blair, 'Hurt and Upset,' Apologizes for Handling of Campaign Finance Issue
description: Trying to use personal popularity to put an end to his Government's first crisis in public confidence, Prime Minister Tony Blair went on television today to apologize for the way he had dealt with a contentious campaign finance matter.

title: Political Spectrum Is Too Complex for Simple Charts
description: To the Editor:

title: Mechanic Held in Series of Killings; Police in Louisiana Say Gambling Habit Motivated Suspect
description: At the Airline Motors lunch counter in sugar-cane country, a rifle-shot away from the muddy churn of the Mississippi River, the talk about Daniel J. Blank is as straightforward as the food served here: he was a gifted mechanic, a quiet customer with deep blue eyes, a family man who drank his coffee black.

title: Georges Marchais, 77, Dies; Led France's Communists
description: Georges Marchais, whose rigid leadership of the French Communist Party from 1972 to 1994 was blamed for reducing it to the margins of French political life, died yesterday in Paris. He was 77.

title: Corrections
description: A music review in Weekend on Friday about ''Time Rocker,'' directed by Robert Wilson at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, misidentified a work by Mr. Wilson and Tom Waits previously produced there. It was ''The Black Rider,'' not ''The Blue Rider.''

title: Foley Is Hurt, Offense Sputters, So Jets Win With Defense
description: They haven't been doing this long enough to be perfect. But the Jets strung together enough defense today to offset the loss of their new starting quarterback, Glenn Foley, and extended their stay in first place.

title: Lady Lucks Wins the Lotto, Dead Newspaperman Lives, and Other Miracles
description: LUCKY YOU

title: Arab Youths Vent Anger Over Shooting
description: Violent protests erupted here today after the funeral of a Palestinian boy shot by an Israeli soldier, even as the boy's organs were transplanted in Israel in keeping with his family's wishes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCFADDEN, BRUEGGER, DOROTHY LOA
description: McFADDEN - BRUEGGER - Dorothy Loa. 95, author, lecturer, and photographer, died November 5. She was a member of the La Jolla, California Presbyterian Church where a memorial service will be held on Saturday, December 6.

title: Child's Minor Fall Can Cause Brain Trauma
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Sports of The Times; Giants' Next Foe: Theory of Relativity
description: Although the Giants are alone in first place in their division at 7-4, they must now test the National Football League's theory of relativity.

title: For Those No Longer Homeless, Free Furniture
description: The off-white silk lampshades caught the eye of 24-year-old Licia Olmos as she shopped for furniture for the first time in her life. She coveted an antique-style brass lamp with black trim. And she fell in love with a brown-and-beige sofa bed and a mauve contemporary recliner.

title: Rev. Warren William Ost, 71, Pastor of Parkgoers
description: The Rev. Warren William Ost, who made his ministry among those who travel, live or work in the national parks, died on Nov. 6 at his home on the East Side of Manhattan. He was 71.

title: First Commuter Ferry Proposed Between Connecticut and Manhattan
description: Train passengers in Connecticut were a little surprised last week to receive pamphlets promoting a new commuting option. The pamphlets, handed out at station entrances, were not the usual fliers from Metro-North.

title: Sports of The Times ; From Picked On to Picking Off
description: ''THE Much-Maligned Otis Smith'' became ''The Great Otis Smith'' in one game. One half, in fact. Reputations in sports may be won or lost swiftly, but this was some kind of record.

title: Political Spectrum Is Too Complex for Simple Charts
description: To the Editor:

title: HUD Questions Prompt Suspension of Program
description: Atlantic City has suspended the operations of a community development program in response to allegations of mismanagement and questions about spending, officials said last week.

title: Children's movies, facing a tough market, find a home on a revived Disney series.
description: VIEWERS of ''The Wonderful World of Disney'' on ABC last night were treated to the first new version of ''Oliver Twist'' by Charles Dickens in years. As part of Disney's effort to revive its old television showcase, it is spending heavily on such original family fare, and in this instance the movie cost $6 million -- about double the average for a made-for-television film -- and starred Richard Dreyfuss.

title: Isaiah Berlin, Enemy of Tyranny; The Restless Fox
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUSS, G. GEORGE
description: DRUSS-G. George. Age 80, of Florida. Husband of Jessie. Father of Barry, Bob and Bradley. Services Tuesday, 1 PM, New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Aching Williams Lifts Nets
description: There is a difference between being hurt and being injured. That is what Jayson Williams went out of his way to tell his teammates during a team meeting on Friday. And that is what Williams went out and proved tonight against the Cavaliers.

title: Judge Rejects Suit Against Store Chain
description: A Federal judge has thrown out a lawsuit that accused Limited Inc. and two suppliers of trying to avoid trade quotas, fines and duties by misidentifying the origin of imported garments.

title: In Millionaire's Killing, Debate on Trying Youths as Adults
description: Two months after the kidnapping and slaying of a New Jersey millionaire, lawyers are still pushing to resolve a question that rarely comes before Federal courts: whether two teen-agers arrested in the case can be prosecuted as adults.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, HARRY
description: GOLD-Harry. Beloved husband of Hattie. Loving father of Laura and Jerome (Suzanne) Gold and special Poppy to Sandee and Amanda. A loving person to all who knew him. He will be sorely missed. Graveside services Monday, 1 PM, at Mount Hebron Cemetery.

title: National Westminster Said to Be In Merger Talks With Barclays
description: Barclays Bank P.L.C. and National Westminster Bank P.L.C., two of Britain's largest banking companies, are discussing a merger that would be valued at more than $20 billion, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: China Loses, China Wins
description: By releasing Wei Jingsheng, China's leading dissident, and sending him into exile in the United States, Chinese leaders have made a major concession to international pressure. They have also rid themselves of China's most potent political martyr.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GETZELS, GEORGE
description: GETZELS-George. November 11, 1997. Adored by wife Blanche, his children and grandchildren. Remembrance at home November 22 and 23 from noon on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTZER, ROSLYN B.
description: MELTZER-Roslyn B. Beloved wife of the late Paul P. Big sister to Myriam Langfelder and Irma Fixler. Always supportive and caring mother of Barbara and Neil. Mother-in-law of Morty Rochman. She was Nana to her loving grandchildren Diane, David, Larry, Joannah and Annie. To her greatgrandchildren Paul, Zoe, Max and Laura, she was Nana-Roz. She always had a point of view and knew how to have a good time. You will forever be in our hearts. Thanks, Mom. Services 1 PM, Wednesday, November 19, 1997, at Gutterman's in Woodbury, LI. Shiva will be at 31 Ryder Ave., Dix Hills, LI.

title: Several blue-chip brands announce account winners after a hectic week on Madison Avenue.
description: ANOTHER busy week along Madison Avenue ended with a hectic burst of activity on Friday involving several blue-chip brands. There was a consolidation of a worldwide assignment and there were decisions on interactive and traditional advertising accounts, with combined billings estimated at $70 million to $90 million.

title: Catholic Schools Get a Repeat
description: Mount St. Michael and St. Anthony's will meet again in the Catholic High Schools Football League Class A final next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMAC, ROBERT
description: CAMAC-Robert. Beloved husband of Violet; devoted father of Diana Sandor, Howard Camac and Laura Shahinian. Adored grandfather of Lawrence, David, Steven and Sherry Sandor, Jennifer, Lauren and Samantha Camac, Eric and Ross Shahinian. Great-grandfather of Tanner and Jacob Sandor. Funeral service Monday, 12 noon, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 1300 Pleasantville Ave., Briarcliff, NY.

title: Clinton to Approve Sweeping Shift in Adoption
description: President Clinton is preparing to sign into law the most sweeping changes to the nation's adoption and foster-care system in nearly two decades.

title: Oakley Tunes Out Barkley
description: Charles Oakley's high threshold for pain allows him to ignore even the most ubiquitous of irritants, like Charles Barkley's mouth.

title: Working Moms Take the Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Inching Toward Trading for Sheffield
description: The Mets' owners are prepared to give General Manager Steve Phillips approval to take on the second-biggest contract in baseball history.

title: A Dominating Drive Rights the Cowboys
description: The distance between disaster and triumph is sometimes short. For the Dallas Cowboys, it was exactly 97 yards.

title: Pakistan's Jailing of a Drug Agent Sours U.S. Ties
description: In much of the drug-producing world, where frail governments struggle with rampant corruption and enterprising organized crime, American drug-enforcement agents depend heavily on men like Ayyaz Baluch.

title: Trying to Use the Saw But Spare the Forests; 80 Years Later, Logging Rebounds
description: A half-ton log of white oak cut from a Hudson Valley tree thumped from a sorting rack into the mud. ''That one's going to Spain,'' said Brian Arico as he pulled a lever that sent another log rolling in front of him.

title: Title Hunt Begins For Rowan
description: Rowan, which has lost in the Division III championship game in three of the last four seasons, will begin the title hunt again Saturday when it plays host to a first-round playoff game in Glassboro, N.J. The Profs (9-0) will meet Coast Guard (9-1).

title: At Los Angeles Times, a Debate on News-Ad Interaction
description: For years, editors at The Los Angeles Times talked about starting a weekly personal health section. But nothing happened.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSCHILD, ANN (NEE SCHLOS)
description: ROTHSCHILD-Ann (nee Schlos) died November 15, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Louis Rothschild. Survived by loving daughter, Beatrice and son-in-law Marvin Sacks. Adored grandmother of Wendy, Nancy and Amy Sacks; sister Vera Pipers, brother-in-law John and nephew Dr. Frank Pipers. Contributions to Selfhelp Community Services (Forest Hills), 440 9th Avenue, NY NY 10001 would be appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Oct. 28 with a review of ''Peer Gynt,'' by the National Theater of the Deaf at the Kaye Playhouse of Hunter College on Oct. 24, omitted a director of the production. As the review said, Robby Barnett's co-director was Will Rhys.

title: On 'Happy Day' for Wei, U.S. Is Careful Not to Gloat
description: President Clinton pressed for the dissident Wei Jingsheng's freedom from prison last month while meeting in Washington with President Jiang Zemin of China, White House officials said today. But they insisted that he made no deals for Mr. Wei's release, and had received no promises of action from Mr. Jiang.

title: Chiefs Win on Big Boot
description: Pete Stoyanovich spoiled John Elway's comeback with what he described as ''the kick of my life.'' But it was Marty Schottenheimer's coaching that made Stoyanovich's 54-yard game-winning field goal possible.

title: Sweeney Scores Two on 'Toughest Day'
description: Right after his two goals helped the Rangers beat a good Colorado team by 4-1 yesterday, Tim Sweeney talked on the telephone and it probably was not about his splendid afternoon or his successful season. Sweeney's newborn daughter, Emily, is back in the hospital. While his teammates planned their Sunday evenings with family and friends around New York, Sweeney headed for Boston, to join his wife, Christina, and the baby.

title: Douglas MacArthur 2d, 88, Former Ambassador to Japan
description: Douglas MacArthur 2d, a diplomat who was Ambassador to Japan from 1957 to 1961, a period when relations between Tokyo and Washington were put on a new footing of equality after 15 years of Japanese subordination, died on Saturday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 88 and lived in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLOTSKY, RUTH S.
description: WOLOTSKY-Ruth S. On November 16. Beloved wife of Hyman. Cherished mother of sons, Gene and Paul, daughters-in-law, Audrey and Jaimi, and loving grandmother of Jonathan, Max and Sam. Services today, 1 PM at ''The Riverside'' 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Chronicle
description: WILLIAM T. COLEMAN JR., a former Secretary of Transportation, adviser to six presidents and a prominent lawyer, has received many honors during his career. But few have as personal a resonance as the one he is to receive Thursday: the Thurgood Marshall Lifetime Achievement Award of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund.

title: Gang Gunfire May Chase Chicago Children From Their School
description: At any other school, it might have been time for recess around noon on an Indian summer day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACHNER, CHARLES
description: BACHNER-Charles. 77. Beloved husband of Juliette. Loving father of Vivian Claire and Monica. Cherished grandfather of Michelle and Daniel Garzone and Samuel Reynolds. Dear father-in-law of Michael Garzone and Thomas Reynolds. Services Monday, November 17, 12 noon at Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, NJ.

title: Once Upon a Time, And for Years After
description: At noon on a dress-down Friday a few weeks ago, the bright white offices of Simon & Schuster Children's Books were empty. The corridors, lined with colorful books and posters, were deserted. The large conference room, however, was jammed, warm and smelled of sandwiches. The entire staff, about 75 people, from editors and assistants to receptionist, casually attired, had gathered for a brown-bag lunch, to hear Margaret K. McElderry answer questions about a publishing career that spans more than half a century.

title: U.N.'s Cosmetic Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a gathering of leaders from the early days of the Solidarity movement and their adversaries in the Polish and Soviet governments omitted one of three main organizers of the event. Along with the National Security Archive, an American group, and the Institute for Political Studies, a Polish group, major sponsors included another American group, the Cold War History Project.

title: Is McClatchy Bid for Cowles Too Rich?
description: When the sale of the Cowles Media Company was announced late Thursday, the surprise was not just the identity of the buyer, but the price.

title: IRAQ SENDS SIGNAL IT DOES NOT WANT TO FIGHT WITH U.S.
description: In signs that both Iraq and the United States would like to step back from another conflict in the Persian Gulf, Iraq sent signals today that it did not want a military confrontation, and the United States persuaded Russia, once Iraq's strongest ally, to press Saddam Hussein to back down in the dispute over weapons inspections.

title: 3 Leftist Mayors Win in Italy, Adding to Coalition's Fortunes
description: Leftist Mayors in Rome, Naples and Venice won overwhelming victories today in nationwide municipal elections, delivering a big boost for Prime Minister Romano Prodi's center-left Government and a strong endorsement of one of Italy's most successful political reforms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINN, ELI A.
description: FINN-Eli A. 107, Norwalk, CT. Husband of the late Sylvia Dietz Finn, Saturday at home. Retired sales executive, Magic Chef and Unity Appliance Distributors, New York City. Survived by son, Robert Finn; daughter, Miriam Smolev; stepdaughter, Libby Miller; stepson-inlaw, George Miller; 10 grandchildren, many great-grandchildren. Services Tuesday, 11:30 AM, Collins Funeral Home, 92 East Ave. (at I-95, Exit 16), Norwalk, CT. Interment private.

title: Michael P. Tierney, 53, Lawyer; Helped on Anti-Abortion Cases
description: Michael Patrick Tierney, a Manhattan lawyer who specialized in international antitrust and insurance matters and whose pro bono work put him in the front lines of the anti-abortion movement, died on Nov. 5 at Kennedy International Airport. He collapsed at the airport after arriving from Singapore. He was 53 and lived in Rutherford, N.J.

title: INSIDE
description: Bank Failure Propels Nikkei

title: Chronicle
description: It is customary when a new administration comes into office for some staff members to tender their resignations. But what about highly placed pets?

title: Metro Matters; Fine on Paper, Truant Policy Fails a Child
description: THE routine would, by now, seem almost comic if the consequences were not so often tragic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGFRIED, CHARLES A.
description: SIEGFRIED-Charles A. Of Madison, NJ, also of Bloomfield and West Hartford, CT, on Friday, November 14, 1997. Husband of the late Marjorie (nee Young) Siegfried. Father of David C. Siegfried of Short Hills, NJ, and Susan Cerciello of West Hartford, CT. Brother of Elsie Siegfried of Orwigsburg, PA, and the late John Siegfried. Also survived by three grandchildren and one greatgrandson. Funeral services on Monday, November 17, 1997, at the Presbyterian Church of Madison, at 2 PM. Interment at the Restland Memorial Park, East Hanover, NJ. For information contact Burroughs, Kohr and Dangler Funeral Home, 106 Main St., Madison, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory may be made to the Presbyterian Church of Madison, 19 Green Ave., Madison, NJ 07940, or to Franklin & Marshall College, Lancaster, PA 17603.

description: KAILES-Ruth. Wife of the late Charles. Beloved mother of Howard and Nancy. Dear sister of Dottie Lichtman, Nat Cohen, and Eleanor Hochberg. Service Monday, November 17, 1:45 PM at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Police Arrest Parents of Boys With Injuries
description: A Brooklyn couple were arrested early yesterday after they took their 4-year-old son to a hospital with a broken arm and hospital workers discovered belt marks and bruises on his 5-year-old brother, the police said.

title: INSIDE
description: It's colder than normal, but don't blame El Nino. PAGE B3

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a Virginia jury's recommendation of a death sentence for a Pakistani immigrant convicted of killing two Central Intelligence Agency employees misstated the state law regarding the judge's discretion in the case in some editions. The judge can impose a lesser sentence; he is not bound by the jury's recommendation.

title: Treasury's Sales This Week Are Limited to Bills
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: 50 Nations Join to Promote French Ties
description: A meeting of some 50 countries in which French is spoken ended here today with a decision by all of them to form a loose political bloc with the former Secretary General of the United Nations, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, as its first permanent spokesman.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Barclays Said to Discuss A Merger With NatWest

title: O'Donnell Cannot Light a Fire in the Cold
description: In a season of new experiences for Jets quarterback Neil O'Donnell, this was the newest. Soon after Glenn Foley went down after a sack by Bears defensive end Jim Flanigan in the second quarter today, O'Donnell began warming up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CABBLE, LYDIA (NEE PORTER)
description: CABBLE-Lydia (nee Porter). On November 16, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted sister of Sr. Kathryn Porter (The Dominican Convent), Fred and Vincent. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 9:30 AM, at St. Patrick's RC Church. Visitation Monday, 7-9, and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at McLaughlin & Sons, 97th St. at 3rd Ave., Brooklyn. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMBROSE, REVEREND THOMAS
description: AMBROSE-Reverend Thomas, S.J. Beloved brother of Helen, loving uncle of Paul, Marck. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray Weigel Hall, Fordham University Thursday, 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 11:30 AM at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray Weigel Hall, Fordham University, Bronx. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors 718-654-0500.

title: Observer; Small Sky Country
description: Americans are getting big. Did I say big? Big isn't good enough. Americans are getting huge.

title: On My Mind; Six Years of Sabotage
description: The United States, its allies and the world press tell us that a new crisis about Iraq erupted last month that might be solved by diplomacy without the use of military power. That is a double somersault over reality and grows more dangerous by the day.

title: Homeless Need More Than a Key and a Lease; A Cure Takes Time
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Rises 125 Points In Rally Inspired by Japan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTZER, ROSLYN B.
description: MELTZER-Roslyn B. Beloved wife of the late Paul P. Big sister to Myriam Langfelder and Irma Fixler. Always supportive and caring mother of Barbara and Neil. Mother-in-law of Morty Rochman. She was Nana to her loving grandchildren Diane, David, Larry, Joannah and Annie. To her greatgrandchildren Paul, Zoe, Max and Laura, she was Nana-Roz. She always had a point of view and knew how to have a good time. You will forever be in our hearts. Thanks, Mom. Services at 1 P.M., Wednesday, November 19, 1997, at Gutterman's, in Woodbury, Long Island. Shiva will be at 31 Ryder Avenue, Dix Hills, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUSH, BRENDA M., PHD.
description: BRUSH-Brenda M., PhD. Age 64. Died November 17 at home in Bethesda, MD. Born 27th November, 1932. Wife of William E. Spencer, sister of Craig B. Brush. Graduate of Miss Hewitt's Classes and the University of Michigan. After teaching philosophy at Ohio State University, she worked in the Bureau of Indian Affairs and in the Equal Economic Opportunity Commission as an expert on opportunity law and policy. Donations to the National Breast Cancer Coalition, 1707 L St N.W., Washington, D.C. 20036.

title: Homeless Need More Than a Key and a Lease; Lack of Repair Money
description: To the Editor:

title: In a surprise move, Publicis is proposing a merger with True North Communications.
description: PUBLICIS S. A., whose fractious relationship with True North Communications ended in a frosty divorce, is startling Madison Avenue with a potential takeover battle. Publicis is unexpectedly proposing a combination with True North in place of the pending True North acquisition of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAXTER, VIRGINIA R.
description: BAXTER-Virginia R. Died November 15, 1997 in Dallas, Texas. Survived by her husband, Edmund F. Baxter, Jr. of Dallas, her parents, James H. and Marie M. Reedy of Scarsdale, her sisters, Barbara Fraser of Manhattan and Margaret Hayes of Novato, CA., and her brother, James H. Reedy, Jr. of Coral Springs, FL. Mass of Resurrection to be celebrated by Rev. Michael Guadagnoli on Wednesday, November 19, at 10 AM at St. Patrick's Church, Dallas. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to a charity of your choice or to The American Cancer Society, 8900 Carpenter Freeway, Dallas, TX 75247, would be appreciated.

title: 'Seinfeld,' A Finale? And Yada Yada Yada
description: One thing Jerry Seinfeld is sure of: he is not about to let a few critics tell him when the time is right to exit the stage.

title: A Need to Break Free From Stifling Reality
description: American Ballet Theater closed its season at City Center with exhilarating programs that demonstrated the soundness of its eclectic artistic policy. Dancers were given a wide variety of roles and turned each fresh challenge into an opportunity to shine. Versatility became as dazzling as virtuosity.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Bailing Out of the Bailout Game; Tokyo Does the Unthinkable and Lets a Big Bank Fail
description: The failure today of the Hokkaido Takushoku Bank, the first of Japan's big banks to collapse under the weight of bad loans, is the latest -- and strongest -- sign yet that the Japanese Government is prepared to encourage market forces to reconfigure the domestic financial landscape.

title: Russians Order Expulsion of Iranian Detained as a Missile Spy
description: Russia has detained and ordered the expulsion of an Iranian it accuses of trying to buy missile technology, the Russian Foreign Ministry said today.

title: U.N. Investigates Report of Slaying of 2,000 Taliban Fighters
description: United Nations officials are looking into reports that as many as 2,000 fighters from the Islamic Taliban movement were killed and buried in mass graves after being taken prisoner in northern Afghanistan by forces of the coalition driven out of Kabul last year.

title: Little Time for Bed Rest In Rangers' Recovery
description: Like a common cold, a slump sometimes comes on gradually and leaves the same way. This is sort of what it is like for the Rangers, currently on their first two-game winning streak of the season.

title: In a New South Africa, Old Anti-Gay Bias Persists
description: Busi Kheswa, chairwoman of a black lesbian organization in Soweto, was dancing with her girlfriend at a downtown nightclub recently when a stranger started shouting at them.

title: A Musical Iconoclast Exports His Vision
description: It has been a long time since Russian musicians or artists were forced to submit their work to Communist censors before presenting it to the public. Perhaps as a reaction to so many years of stifling regularity, experimental productions of classical plays and operas have now become routine here.

title: Wall St. Sex Bias Suit Is Said to Be Settled
description: Smith Barney is expected to announce a settlement of a class-action lawsuit contending sexual harassment at the firm. While not including any set amount of money, the settlement would allow women employees to take their claims to an independent arbitrator.

title: Journal; Calling Perle Mesta
description: Let the rest of the diplomatic community fret about Saddam Hussein. Life was so low-key at the Luxembourg Embassy in Washington Friday evening that the Ambassador was picking up the phone himself. He graciously stayed on the line as a stranger asked for a few basic facts about his country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAUBARD, MYRON
description: GRAUBARD-Myron, 79. Of Short Hills, New Jersey, on November 16, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Dear father of Carla Graubard of New York City and Cinda Graubard of Boulder, Colorado. Devoted grandfather of 4. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, November 19, 1997 at 11 AM, Bernheim Apter Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, New Jersey. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPULER, WILLIAM P., M.D.
description: KAPULER-William P., M.D. The officers and members of the Psychoanalytic Association of New York mourn the loss of their honored teacher, esteemed colleague, and cherished friend. We express our deepest sympathy to his family.

title: Expenses Limit Growth in Profit at Hewlett
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported strong growth in revenue and earnings for its fiscal fourth quarter today, but the results fell slightly short of Wall Street estimates. The company said that operating expenses had grown more rapidly than it had anticipated, but that profit margins remained strong.

title: Board of Education Tackles Its Complicated Election Process
description: Just over a year after New York City's school board elections brought out just 5.2 percent of the vote -- the lowest turnout ever -- the Board of Education began work yesterday on ways of revising an election process so Byzantine that it took six weeks to find out who won.

title: AVON SAYS EARNINGS WILL FALL SHORT OF EXPECTATIONS
description: Avon Products Inc. said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would not meet analysts' estimates because of worse-than-expected sales in a number of countries, including Brazil, the United States, China and Japan. The company, a direct marketer of cosmetics, said it expected to earn $1 to $1.05 a share in the quarter. The company had been expected to earn $1.13 a share. Last year, the New York-based Avon earned $132 million, or 99 cents a share, in the fourth quarter. Its shares closed unchanged at $62.50. It had been up almost $3 a share before the announcement.

title: DOMINION TEXTILE ACCEPTS SWEETENED BID FROM POLYMER
description: The Canadian fabric maker Dominion Textile Inc. said yesterday that it had accepted a sweetened takeover offer from Polymer Group Inc. worth $596 million (Canadian), or $421 million (United States). Polymer had previously offered $483 million (Canadian) for Dominion, but Dominion rejected that bid to search for a better deal. Polymer, a maker of nonwoven fabrics based in North Charleston, S.C., has said it intends to keep Dominion's nonwoven operations and sell its denim and other apparel-fabric businesses to Galey & Lord Inc., a textile company based in Greensboro, N.C. Under the terms of the offer, Polymer must receive 66 percent of Dominion's shares outstanding.

title: Q&A
description: The Falling Leaves

title: Virtual Power Lunch
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Checkup on Doctors
description: Two large health organizations announced a new business yesterday that they said would streamline the process of checking doctors' credentials.

title: Migrating Songbirds Switch Their Diets For Long Trips South
description: IT is not really news that many North American songbirds eat wild berries in autumn. Some plants need help to disperse their seeds, so they produce colorful arrays of pulpy fruit that are almost guaranteed to attract fall migrants. The birds scatter the indigestible seeds in their droppings, perpetuating a seasonal food source.

title: Some Serious Money For the 'Silly Season'
description: Players on the PGA Tour call it the silly season the period between the year's last official tournament in early November and the beginning of the next season in January.

title: Georgia Bankers in Hot Millennium Water
description: In the first of what could become a series of tough actions against banks whose computers are not ready to handle dates beyond 1999, Federal and state regulators severely reprimanded a small Georgia banking company yesterday for having inadequate computer systems.

title: U.S. Offers Iraq Opportunity Of Buying More With Its Oil
description: The Clinton Administration, finding itself forced to retreat from its unswerving refusal to negotiate with Saddam Hussein, is offering to allow Iraq to buy more goods with its oil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTEINER, LUCY
description: GOTTEINER - Lucy (Holocaust survivor, a kind and loving human being). Beloved wife of the late Dr. Abraham. Devoted mother of Aviva Leberfeld. Sister of Helen Rosenblatt and Isaac Diament. Loving grandmother of Michelle and Daniel and greatgrandmother of Maxine. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Wed., 11:00 AM, Gramercy Chapel, Second Ave (9-10th St).

title: Smith Barney Accord Seen In Bias Case
description: Smith Barney Inc. is expected to announce today a settlement of a class-action lawsuit that accused the firm of denying women promotions and doing nothing while brokers harassed women employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELL, SAMUEL.
description: MANDELL-Samuel. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member, and extends its condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus Alan S. Roth, President

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts by merchants to prevent fraud on the Internet misstated the name of an on-line retail Web site operated by Cnet Inc. It is Buydirect.com, not Buynow.com.

description: MORAN-Gladys (nee Rathbone). On Nov. 17, 1997. Beloved wife of the late John A. Moran, Sr, loving mother of John A. Moran, Jr., and Mary Patricia Baxter, and the late Barbara J. Moles. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, HERMAN, M.D.
description: EPSTEIN-Herman, M.D. Of Wyncote, PA. On November 16, 1997, at age 93. Beloved husband of Ida (nee Fratkin) and the late Fay (nee Colton). Devoted father of Jane and Myron Blumenfeld and Diane and James Kauders. Grandfather of Jeffrey Gracer, Dr. Ann Gracer, Bonnie Gracer, Debbie Simon, Jill Levine and Ellen Starr. Proud great-grandfather of eleven. Devoted physician for 68 years. He will live forever in the hearts of those he touched. Funeral services will be held Tuesday 1:30PM, Joseph Levine & Son, 7112 North Broad Street, Philadelphia. Interment Roosevelt Memorial Park, Trevose, PA. Shiva will be held in Wyncote at the late residence. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to a charity of the donor's choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RASKIN, MICHAEL
description: RASKIN-Michael. Loving husband of Christine of East Rockaway, L.I. Cherished son of Dr. Milton Raskin of Huntington Woods, MI. and Sharon Raskin of Farmington Hills, MI. Dear brother of Terrie and Paula of Huntington Woods, MI.

title: Tiny Spies to Take Off for War and Rescue
description: WAITING in ambush, the soldiers hardly notice a small, birdlike device flying overhead. Later, however, those taken captive wonder how the approaching enemy knew so precisely where they were hiding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZACCARO, ROSE M.
description: ZACCARO-Rose M. On November 16, 1997, of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved wife of the late Philip J. Mother of John A. and Geraldine A. Ferraro, and the late Frank P. title: Patterns
description: From Savile Row to Runway

title: Treasury Prices Rise on Benign Industrial Production Report
description: Rebounding from early weakness, Treasury securities prices moved higher yesterday, after a benign industrial production report for October alleviated some fears of inflation among investors.

title: North Korea Called Ready For Talks
description: After months of false starts, North Korea finally appears ready to start serious negotiations on a formal end to the Korean War, which ended inconclusively 44 years ago, a senior State Department official said today.

title: Bausch & Lomb and S.E.C. Settle Dispute on '93 Profits
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc., the optical company, and four former managers of the company settled allegations by the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that they had violated securities laws by overstating profits in 1993.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, HELEN KAUFMAN
description: KLEIN-Helen Kaufman. On November 16, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Carl Klein. Loving mother of Alice and Peter. Cherished grandmother of Amy and Caryn. Sister of the late Lee Glick, Ben, Jack, and Lou Kaufman. Private graveside services on Tuesday, November 18. Contributions may be made to the Jewish Home and Hospital Development Fund, 120 West 106 St, New York, NY 10025, or a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAPOLI, NATE (NATALE)
description: NAPOLI-Nate (Natale). May 21, 1910-November 15, 1997. Living is what he loved. Giving is what he did. Love is what he got. He had no complaints as he traveled the highway of life taking us along with him. It was a great trip for those of us who really knew him. A part of us is gone, yet a part of him will always live on. He will be forever loved and respected. Viewing at the Fairchild Funeral Home, Manhasset, Long Island, on Tuesday. Funeral mass is at St. Mary's Church, Roslyn, Long Island. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Diabetes Foundation or the American Heart Association would be appreciated.

title: For Douglas, Home Is Where The Court Is
description: As far as Sherman Douglas is concerned, home is where he hangs his bag.

title: 2 Are Missing; Now Landlord Is Also Gone
description: In a strange twist to the missing-persons case of a real estate agent and the actor she had lived with in a loft in lower Manhattan, the police said yesterday that the couple's landlord was also missing and wanted for questioning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUNES, DONALD
description: NUNES-Donald. Died in Bath, England, on Tuesday, November 11, after courageous battle with cancer. Son of Kenneth and Helen Nunes, husband of Ann Biddick Nunes, father of Becky and Jonathan. Don was inspirational, much loved and irreplaceable. A celebration of his life will take place in Lacock Church, Wiltshire, at 2 PM on Monday, November 24. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Don Nunes Memorial Scholarship Fund, C/O Advanced Studies in England, 2 Pierrepont Street, Bath BA1 1LB, England.

title: Despite Crackdown, Islamic Group Keeps Killing
description: Even after years of harsh Government repression, even with 15,000 sympathizers imprisoned and its top leaders in jail, exile or both, the militant movement thought to have killed scores of foreign tourists in Luxor remains Egypt's most active Islamic fundamentalist organization.

title: 70 Die in Attack at Egypt Temple
description: At least 70 people, including 60 foreign tourists, were killed outside a 3,400-year-old temple here this morning, in what Government officials called the deadliest attack by Islamic militants in their five-year campaign to overthrow the Egyptian Government.

title: Coetzer Sees Other Side of an Upset
description: The Chase Championships, the year-ending competition that brings the top 16 players in women's tennis to Madison Square Garden to appoint a world champion, got under way last night with an upset of fourth-seeded Amanda Coetzer, a re-emergence by the injury-plagued Mary Pierce and a segue into early retirement by the doubles specialist Gigi Fernandez.

title: Russ Meyer, a Fiery Pitcher For Dodgers in 50's, Dies at 74
description: Russ Meyer, a right-handed pitcher for the Philadelphia Phillies' pennant-winning Whiz Kids of 1950 and the Brooklyn Dodgers' World Series champions of 1955, who was notorious for hot-tempered displays, died Sunday in Oglesby, Ill. He was 74.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, CHARLES
description: ROSENBERG-Charles. Elected President Emeritus, after serving as President of the Institute for 15 years, he served with honor and distinction as Board Member and officer for more than 30 years. His leadership was all inclusive, as he led by example, the members of the Board and staff. He left a heritage of fellowship and compassion with all who served with him. His goals were to serve handicapped children and their families at the highest possible level. For this, his spirit will endure. May his family, Min, Jackie, Ronnie, Ellie and grandchildren be comforted in the memory of his many kindnesses and good deeds, both to the Agency and to many board and staff members who came to him for help and comfort. Members are advised that funeral services will be conducted at the Westchester Jewish Center Tuesday, November 18 at 1 P.M. The center is located at Palmer and Rockland Avenues, Mamaroneck, N.Y. The Shield Institute for Retarded Children Ralph E. Spiegel, President, Phil Zaro, Board Chairman

title: From 'Happy Camper' to 'Out of Sight'
description: RANDOM HOUSE HISTORICAL DICTIONARY OF AMERICAN SLANG

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUPURTON, JOHN F.
description: DuPURTON-John F. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John F. DuPurton, associated with The Times from 1944, until retiring in 1976.

title: Head of Channel 2 Resigns; His Boss Will Take His Place
description: Bud Carey, the vice president and general manager of WCBS-TV, Channel 2, New York's underperforming CBS station, has resigned, the president of the network's television stations group announced yesterday, adding that he would take charge of the station himself.

title: Ice Shifts May Be Tied to Warming
description: WEATHER satellites operating over an 18-year period have revealed an increase in the ice covering Antarctic waters and a decrease in the extent of Arctic sea ice. This asymmetric trend, a team of scientists says, is consistent with one theory of what would happen if a gradual increase of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere were causing global warming.

title: Clinton Urges More Companies to Hire People on Welfare Roll
description: On a four-day trip in which he has repeatedly asked businessmen to give money to Democrats, President Clinton took a break from fund-raising here today and instead called on businessmen to give jobs to more welfare recipients.

title: ART REVIEW: Religion That's in the Details; A Madonna and Drain Pipe Radiate an Earthy Spirituality
description: No matter how you tally it, any list of great works of modern religious art made since the century's midpoint is not very long. Mine begins with Matisse's great chapel at Vence, Barnett Newman's austere ''Stations of the Cross'' cycle of paintings, perhaps Brice Marden's ''Annunciation'' paintings with their palette of tamped-down primaries, and many of Mark Rothko's evanescent canvases with their clouds of dark, glowing color intimating a diffuse otherworldly presence.

title: I.B.M. Plans $700 Million Research Plant
description: I.B.M. announced plans yesterday to build a $700 million computer chip development plant in East Fishkill, N.Y., about 40 miles north of New York City. Gov. George E. Pataki said it would be the largest single industrial investment in the state's history, surpassing a 1994 joint venture in the same town that also involved I.B.M.

title: Market Place; Wealthy Executives Have Compensation Troubles, Too
description: As problems go, it is a good one to have.

title: Sun Is Approved to Oversee Java Language
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. said today that it had won approval from a global standards body to be the channel for all changes in the Java programming language it developed.

title: New Faces but Less Civility on the Links
description: To the Editor:

title: Homeless Need More Than a Key and a Lease; Regional Response
description: To the Editor:

title: CUNY Trustees Narrow Search for Chancellor to Three as Board Meeting Approaches
description: Two months after the departure of Dr. W. Ann Reynolds as its Chancellor, the City University still has no acting chancellor, the deputy chancellor has resigned and no search committee for a permanent chancellor has been named.

title: Power Suits Fade, and Romance Comes Into Focus
description: If fashion truly mirrors social changes, American designers are reflecting a new attitude in the culture of the country.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, ELLA
description: FISHMAN-Ella. On November 16, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Ferdinand. Loving mother of Gloria Gari, George and Edward Fontaine. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Services are on Wednesday 12:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue

title: New Clues Show Where People Made The Great Leap to Agriculture
description: THE greatest thing before sliced bread, to reverse the cliche, was bread itself. The first cultivation of wild grains, that is, turned hunter-gatherers into farmers, beginning some 12,000 to 10,000 years ago. In the transition, people gained a more abundant and dependable source of food, including their daily bread, and changed the world forever.

title: Science Watch; Chardonnay Chauvinism
description: MERCHANTS take heed: A team of English psychologists has demonstrated that wine buyers listening to French accordion music tend to choose French wines, while customers exposed to German beer-cellar tunes tend to buy German wines.

title: Snobs Hit the Road
description: To The Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLINT, SELMA
description: FLINT-Selma. On November 15, 1997, age 96 and yet still young. Beloved wife of Sam for over half a century. Dearly loved and deeply loving mother of Carol and Philip. Selma gave so much to so many, and yet in the end her greatest gift was to teach us about the true meaning of a life well lived. Selma love abundantly, gave unselfishly and deeply cherished friends, family and life itself. Mother-in-law to Mike, loving grandmother and friend to Andy, Peter, Kathryn, Jimmy, Clare, Barbara, Roy and Ramon, and the adoring and loving great grandmother of Adam. We will miss her deeply and treasure her memory and friendship throughout our lives.

title: Crude Oil Prices Take Big Drop Amid Talk of Iraq Compromise
description: Crude oil posted its biggest drop in a month yesterday as Iraq and the United States sought to resolve a dispute over weapons inspections without a military confrontation that could disrupt world oil supplies.

title: ELECTRO RENT COMPLETES PURCHASE OF G.E. UNIT
description: The Electro Rent Corporation said yesterday that it had bought GE Capital Technology Management Services' computer rental business for $241 million, a lower price than previously announced. In September, Electro Rent, which rents computers and other equipment for testing and measurement projects, had said it would buy a similar business run by GE Capital, a unit of the General Electric Company of Fairfield, Conn., for $320 million. The lower price reflects GE Capital's retention of some assets, Electro Rent said. The purchase will more than double the revenue, equipment value and employee base of Electro Rent, which is based in Van Nuys, Calif. The company had sales of $150.5 million in the year that ended on May 31.

title: Homeless Need More Than a Key and a Lease
description: To the Editor:

title: Williams Unwanted
description: Nobody wants Bernie Williams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREVELLO, HANNA HAHN
description: CAREVELLO-Hanna Hahn. The trustees and staff of The Jewish Museum extend heartfelt condolences to the family of Hanna Hahn Carevello, sister of Dr. Ismar Schorsch, Chancellor of The Jewish Theological Seminary of America. Our thoughts are with him and his family as they mourn this sad loss. Robert J. Hurst, Chairman Philip A. Laskawy, President Joan Rosenbaum, Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOLBERT, VICTORIA A.
description: TOLBERT-Victoria A. The family announces with profound regrets the death of Mrs. Victoria Anna David-Tolbert widow of the late Dr. William R. Tolbert, Jr. former President of the Republic of Liberia, 1971-1980. The sad event occured on Saturday, November 8, 1997 at the hour of 9:52PM in Plymouth, Minnesota following a brief illness. She was 81. She is survived by her children, grandchildren, great grandchildren, brothers, sisters, cousins and a host of other relatives and friends. Wake-keeping for the late Victoria Anna David-Tolbert will be Friday, November 21 at Manhattanville College Chapel, 2900 Purchase Street, Purchase, N.Y. from 6PM until 12 midnight. Funeral services Saturday, November 22, at Manhattanville College Chapel, 10AM. Interment Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARTSIS, MILDRED STORCH
description: ARTSIS-Mildred Storch. Of Great Neck, N.Y. and Boynton Beach, FL. Died November 17, 1997. Loving and devoted wife of the late Jerome M.
