Artsis; beloved mother of Leslie Artsis Adams of West Palm Beach, FL., and Steven M. Artsis of New York City. Adored grandmother of Michael Artsis. Caring sister and sister-in-law of Clifford and Doris Storch of Lake Worth, FL., and Shirley and Arnold Friedman of Roslyn, N.Y. Favorite aunt to Marilyn and Bob Schoenberger; Adele and Neil Bayer; Dana and Ira Effron; Cherie and Bruce Bramley; Loren and Robert Gelber; Jeffrey and Joan Grossman; Stephanie and Kenny Lichtman; Sally Storch Cooney; and Sam and Robin Storch. Mother-inlaw to Doris Mele, Glenda Artsis, and Kathryn Scott. Devoted fiancee to Alan Brandt of Great Neck, N.Y. and Boca Raton, FL. Gracious and elegant, this beautiful dignified lady inspired us all through her great courage, sense of humor and zest for life. Considerate, kind and generous, she was always there for her family and friends. A contributor to multiple charities, she served as a past-president of Womens American Ort, Great Neck Chapter. Mildred, we will remember and miss you forever. You will always be in our hearts. Funeral services will take place Wednesday, November 19, 1997, at 9:30 AM, at Temple Beth-El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, N.Y. A memorial service to be announced, will be held at Temple Emanuel in Palm Beach, FL. Contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, VIRGINIA M.
description: LYONS-Virginia M. Of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, formerly of Shelter Island, New York, on November 16, 1997, after a loving gracious life and a brief illness. Beloved by her nieces and nephews, cousins and many friends. Viewing at The Shelter Island Funeral Home on Wednesday, November 19. Mass of Christian Burial is at Our Lady of the Isle Church, on Thursday, at 11 A.M. The Reilly, Lyons and May Families.

title: Georgie Tapps, 85, Tap Dancer; Performed Onstage and in Films
description: Georgie Tapps, a tap soloist and Broadway musical dancer, died on Nov. 1 at St. Joseph's Center Hospital in Burbank, Calif. He was 85 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: For the Injured Barkley, Needling Oakley Is Out
description: The sideshow has been postponed. Any psychological games Charles Barkley had in store for the mentally steeled Charles Oakley were put on hold after yesterday's injury report.

title: Flyers Will Unveil Black Home Jerseys
description: The Philadelphia Flyers will wear a black alternate jersey for the first time on Nov. 28, when they play host to the Islanders, becoming the sixth National Hockey League team to wear a third jersey.

title: Jilted Governor Embarks on a Lucrative Life
description: And so, the irrepressible Governor, vanquished by the immovable Senator, finally forsook his summer quest and came home. Where, he announced just today, he has started work at the nation's ninth-biggest law firm and embarked upon a lucrative life split between Boston and Central Park South.

title: Mother Accused of Trying to Pull Life-Support Tubes of Girl Who Later Died
description: A Brooklyn woman was charged with attempted murder yesterday after she tried to remove the breathing and feeding tubes from her 22-month-old daughter, who was in the hospital after being scalded in a tub of hot water last week, the police said last night.

title: How to Control Microsoft
description: Ralph Nader gathered critics of Microsoft last week in a Washington hotel to warn that the company was quickly extending its monopolistic tentacles from Windows, the operating system that runs nearly every personal computer, to browser software that connects computer users to information services over the Internet and, ominously, to the information services themselves. Mr. Nader orchestrated collective groaning against Microsoft's forays into selling cars, real estate and other consumer services over the Internet.

title: $20 Million Trading Loss for BankBoston
description: The BankBoston Corporation reported today that it had a trading loss in October of $20 million in securities and foreign exchange after volatility in Latin American and Asian markets.

title: CUTOFF SWITCHES FOR CAR AIRBAGS WILL BE ALLOWED
description: Soccer moms, people who drive school carpools and others who can state that they drive more children than will fit in back seats will be permitted to have switches installed to disable passenger-side airbags, as part of a new Federal policy to be announced on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, JACK
description: BERKOWITZ-Jack. Beloved husband of Clara. Devoted father of Judith and Susan and Robert Koweek. Loving grandfather of Sharon, Jeffrey and Lynne, and Andrea. Donations in his memory to United Cerebral Palsy-Nassau County, 380 Washington Avenue, Roosevelt, New York 11575.

title: Arizona Gives Bell $34 Million For 5 Years
description: Putting their money where their mouth is, the Arizona Diamondbacks signed an expensive free agent today on the eve of baseball's expansion draft.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 8 about an Iranian opposition figure misstated his interpretation of the new President's thinking on Iranian-American relations. The opposition figure, Abdolkarim Soroush, said he did not believe President Mohammed Khatami would make any overtures soon toward the United States, but Mr. Soroush did not say Mr. Khatami wanted improved ties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREINER, LUISE
description: GREINER-Luise. On November 16, 1997. Beloved daughter of Victoria. Dear sister of Stephen, Joseph, William and Marilyn. Visiting at Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, 117 West 72 Street, New York City, Tuesday, November 18th, 6-9PM. Service at 8 PM.

title: Praise for Free Speech, and Censure for the Censors
description: Walter Bernstein, one of the last surviving blacklisted writers from the 1950's, remembered the regular visits to his house by F.B.I. agents, always in pairs, yet always a different pair, dressed alike in dark suits and dark hats. They looked similar, he said, ''yet somehow mismatched, as if they were unrelated, but from the same orphanage.''

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's; Twinkling Ahead of the Holidays
description: November is last call for album releases. As the Christmas rush looms, procrastinating million-sellers are pushed to get their albums out while they can still lift fourth-quarter sales figures. In the meantime, deserving lesser-known musicians struggle against the annual avalanche of live albums and greatest-hits collections, eager to get noticed before their work becomes one of last year's albums. Here are November releases from two superstars and a worthy hopeful.

title: Gay Nominee for Envoy Hits a Roadblock
description: The Senate held up confirmation of President Clinton's choice for Ambassador to Luxembourg in the final hours before adjournment last week after Republicans had objected to quick approval of the nominee, a business executive who is openly gay.

title: Approving the Rail Link to Kennedy
description: Of the 10 busiest world airports, New York City's John F. Kennedy International has a dubious distinction. Although 42 percent of its arrivals are headed for Manhattan's central business district, it does not have a decent rail link to the city. Today the Federal Aviation Administration can help the region's economy, and all users of the airport, by approving the Port Authority's request to help finance a $1.5 billion rail link with revenue from a passenger surcharge.

title: Poor Without Cars Find Trek to Work Can Be a Job
description: If Laura Garcia had a car, it would take half an hour to get from her live-in housekeeping job in nearby Pleasantville to a second domestic job in Westport, Conn. Without one, she rides a train, a bus and then another train, spending four hours and $30 for a round trip.

title: Injury Won't End Foley's Season
description: Quarterback Glenn Foley's knee injury on Sunday will sideline him for at least one game, but not for the season, a relieved Jets Coach Bill Parcells said today.

title: Rifle Linked To Robbery In Bomb Case
description: Her testimony was about a robbery of deadly weaponry said to have financed the Oklahoma City bombing, but an Arkansas ammunition dealer also provided a change of pace today in the trial of Terry L. Nichols.

title: Zurich Group to Buy a Big Piece of a Hong Kong Investment Bank
description: The Zurich Group has agreed to pay $200 million to become the biggest shareholder in Peregrine Investments Holdings Ltd., a fast-growing Asian investment bank that has been hurt by the plunge in regional stock and bond prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANZISKA, NAOMI M.
description: ANZISKA-Naomi M. On November 17, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Harry H., both formerly of Cape Town, South Africa, mother and mother-in-law of Brian and Shelley and Don and Enid, loving grandmother of Yaacov, Daniel, David, Evan, Suzanne, Seth, Nina and Zachary.

title: Woman Pleads Guilty in Case Of Deaf Mexican Peddlers
description: A woman who prosecutors say helped lead the Queens branch of an operation that forced deaf Mexican immigrants to peddle trinkets in the subways and streets pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiring to violate the constitutional ban on slavery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUNGS, REVEREND EDWIN S.J.
description: HAUNGS-Reverend Edwin S.J. Survived by four loving nieces and nephews. Repossing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray Weigel Hall, Wednesday 2-4 and 79 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Murray Weigel Hall Chapel on Thursday 11:30 AM. For further information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors 718-654-0500.

title: Even More Tales of Diana: The Princess and the PBS
description: In need of another Diana fix? Tonight's supplier is not your common news magazine, but the usually upright ''Frontline.'' The pretext for ''The Princess and the Press'' is an investigation of the relationship between the Princess of Wales and Britain's tabloids. If that sounds a little familiar, well, after the Anglo-American gush set off by Diana's death, what about her isn't familiar?

title: National Living Treasure and His Sighing Sarod
description: Ali Akbar Khan's sold-out concert at Town Hall on Saturday night had an air of solemn devotion. Mr. Khan, who is 75, has been named a National Living Treasure in his native India; in the United States, where he founded the Ali Akbar College of Music in Marin County in California in 1968, he has won a MacArthur Foundation grant and the National Heritage Fellowship. As he improvises, his knowledge of tradition and technical mastery are subsumed in pensive, graceful melodies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANCUSO, ANTHONY E.
description: MANCUSO-Anthony E. On November 17, 1997. Beloved husband of Rose (nee Ingrassia), devoted father of Peter and John, eight grandchildren. Also survived by brothers, Joseph, Rosario and Philip, sister, Connie Curro and the late Adolph and Rose DeVito. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 345 Ave U, Brooklyn, NY Wed. and Thursday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 10. Mass of Christian Burial, Our Lady of Grace RC Church, Friday, 10:15 AM. Interment Resurrection Cemetery, Staten Island, NY.

title: Jury Awards $17.9 Million To Family of Slain Officer
description: A Brooklyn jury has awarded $17.95 million to the family of a New York City police officer who was accidentally shot to death by his partner during a drug arrest in 1988, after a civil trial that hinged on whether the partner's gun was cocked at the time of the shooting.

title: Chemists Find Ways to Save Monuments From Pollution
description: WHAT if there was a way to rescue decomposed stone, particularly the marble and limestone that make up some of the world's best-loved monuments? Many of them, like the Parthenon, the Taj Mahal and even the Lincoln Memorial, have long been threatened by acid rain and other effects of airborne pollution.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BUILDING ON THE ARTS: A special report.; Cities Are Fostering the Arts As a Way to Save Downtown
description: In this city in the heart of Silicon Valley, where the rise in property values (and taxes) over the last decade has fueled a mammoth redevelopment effort, the city government has built from scratch, among other things, a children's museum, a new wing for the art museum, and, opening next month, a 525-seat theater that will be the new home of the San Jose Repertory Theater. All in a downtown that was, a dozen years ago, in the words of one city official, ''a wasteland, chaos everywhere you looked.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, RENA
description: EPSTEIN-Rena, 91, Of Ft. Lauderdale, FL., formerly of Flushing (Hillcrest), NY, passed away on Sunday, November 16, 1997. Wife of the late Harry Epstein. Beloved mother of Ira of Orange, CT., and Gerald of Boynton Beach, FL. Mother-in-law of Julia and Muriel. Beloved grandmother of Robert, Jordana and Steven. Graveside services will be held on Tuesday, Nov. 18, 1997 at 1:30 PM at Beth Moses Cemetery in Pinelawn, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORAN, WILLIAM DEAN
description: MORAN-William Dean. On November 16, 1997, Beloved husband of Margaret Walsh Moran, loving father of William, Daniel, Jacqueline Dickson, and Katherine Moran. Former husband of Rae L. Moran. Services Wednesday, 11:30 AM., Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Homeless Need More Than a Key and a Lease; Housing Counterpart
description: To the Editor:

title: Group Will Sell Health Care Unit
description: Personnel Group of America Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell its Nursefinders home health care and staffing services unit to an investment group led by Atlantic Medical Capital L.P. and CIBC Capital Partners for $65.3 million.

title: The M.T.A. Doesn't Like The 'S' Word
description: LONG, long ago, in a galaxy far, far away -- to be more precise, in the first term of Mayor Edward I. Koch -- the proposed education budget one year mentioned something called ''service delivery system consolidations.''

title: Ron Tindiglia, 51; Developed a TV News Format
description: Ron Tindiglia, a television news consultant who had earlier been the general manager of WCBS-TV and the news director of WABC-TV, both in New York, died on Nov. 10 at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 51 and lived in Harrison, N.Y.

title: In Performance: OPERA ; A Surprising Voice For Puccini's Liu
description: 'Turandot'

title: CHRONICLE
description: Theodore Roosevelt was one American President whose name cannot be besmirched by even the merest hint of infidelity. Or so says, RUTH WARRICK, the actress and matriarch of the soap opera ''All My Children'' for almost 28 years, and a not-so-secret fan of the 26th American President.

title: At Kentucky, Tradition Takes a Twist
description: One of the first things that Tubby Smith did after being named Kentucky's head basketball coach last May was to visit Adolph (Herky) Rupp Jr., the son of the legendary Wildcats coach.

title: City Asks Bids to Export Residential Trash in 2 Boroughs
description: The city's Sanitation Department began soliciting bids yesterday from private companies to begin exporting residential garbage from Brooklyn and Queens by the end of next year. The plan, another step toward closing the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island in 2001, has drawn the fire of City Council members and residents of the two boroughs.

title: Nigerian Dismisses Cabinet and Says He Will Release Detainees
description: In a move that appeared intended to consolidate his power, Nigeria's military leader, Gen. Sani Abacha, dissolved his Cabinet today and promised to release a number of political detainees.

title: REGISTRY IN $164.4 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR HUNTER
description: Registry Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the closely held Hunter Group for stock worth $164.4 million, based on Friday's closing price, to expand its line of technology-consulting services. Registry said it would issue 3.8 million shares for the Baltimore-based Hunter. The shares rose $3 yesterday, to $46.25. Registry, based in Newton, Mass., designs computer systems and employs consultants who show customers how to install and use the systems. By acquiring Hunter, the company will add more than 450 consultants. Hunter filed last month to offer 4.1 million shares in an initial public offering.

title: Britain's Weak Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: In Performance: DANCE ; 'Unspoken' to the Point It Borders on a State of Mind
description: Russell Maliphant Company

title: Unclear Distinction
description: To the Editor:

title: Lights in Bronx Sky Courtesy of Meteors
description: Yes, there were green lights flashing in the sky last night over the Bronx. But please do not call the producers of ''The X-Files.''

title: Fassel Sides With Hamilton
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel rebuked defensive tackle Keith Hamilton on Sunday for kicking Arizona Cardinals center Mike Devlin; the kick got Hamilton ejected from the game. But after watching a videotape of the game today, Fassel said: ''I can understand why Keith was mad. It was a cheap shot. It would have made me mad, too. It would be a normal response.''

title: For the South, G.O.P. Secures Defense Bounty
description: In the decades that the Democrats controlled Congress, influential members from the South proudly brought home military-procurement contracts like eight-point bucks strapped to the hoods of their trucks.

title: Record Nearly Falls
description: Though fifth in the nine-boat fleet's overall standing on the second leg of the Whitbread Round the World Race, Silk Cut stole the spotlight yesterday while failing to steal a record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUR, REBECCA (RITA)
description: SCHUR-Rebecca (Rita). Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Cherished mother of Elaine Batchker and Harvey Schur. Loving grandmother of Craig Batchker and Margot Shaw. Great-grandmother of five. Dear sister of Jack Cohen. Services Wednesday, 10 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: Chinese Dissident Is Called 'Fair and Stable'
description: Wei Jingsheng, China's best known dissident, remained in a hospital here tonight, two days after his release from a Chinese prison, as doctors treated him for high blood pressure and evaluated him for other health problems that developed during his nearly 18 years in Chinese prisons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATIUCHOK, WILLIAM, M.D.
description: BATIUCHOK-William, M.D. The Medical Staff Society of The N.Y. Hospital Medical Center of Queens, grieves the loss of its distinguished colleague and extends its heartfelt sympathy to his family. Marvin A. Leder MD, President Talat Addasi MD, Vice President and Gabriele F. De Angelis MD, Secretary/Treasurer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABERMAN, MAURICE
description: HABERMAN-Maurice. Beloved husband of Eve. Proud father of Jeffrey and Mitchell. Adoring grandfather of Stephanie, David, Jordan, Joshua and Alex. Loving brother of Paul Haberman and Barbara Carter. Funeral services Wednesday, November 19th, 12 noon, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: Judge Rules Ancient Sicilian Golden Bowl Was Illegally Imported
description: In an odyssey reminiscent of the Maltese Falcon's, a hammered gold platter made in Sicily about 450 B.C., lost for centuries and bought for $1 million by a New York financier and art collector was imported under false pretenses and in violation of Italy's antiquity protection laws, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, HERBERT
description: FELDMAN-Herbert. Beloved husband of Miriam. Devoted father of Madeleine, Amy, Peter, Sharon, Leslie and Michael. Cherished grandfather of Harrison, Spencer, Courtney, James, Jillian, William, Dana, Sandy, Joshua and Kimberly. Brother of Milton. Services ''Boulevard - Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, Wednesday, at 11:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name to Memorial-Sloan Kettering Hospital would be appreciated.

title: Boy, 14, Is Slashed At a Troubled School
description: An eighth-grade student was slashed yesterday at a middle school where officials have defied a state order to remove 500 fifth graders after a rash of violence. A boy, 14, was slashed by a classmate using a sharp object during an argument in a bathroom at Albany Avenue School, said Detective Joseph LaTorre, a police spokesman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'SHEA, THOMAS J.
description: O'SHEA-Thomas J. November 16, 1997. Beloved husband of Hannah, devoted father of John, Thomas, Richard and Michael. Also survived by five grandchildren. Friends may call at the Williams Funeral Home Inc., 5628 Broadway at 232 St, Bronx, Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial Thursday, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, at 11 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBOWITZ, BLANCHE
description: LEIBOWITZ - Blanche. Beloved mother, grandmother and great grandmother. Forever you shall be in our hearts. Services held Wednesday, November 19, 10AM at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre.

title: Mets Hope to Make Deal For Mariners' Johnson
description: The Mets' need for a big-time starter has them in pursuit of the Big Unit -- Randy Johnson, the Seattle Mariners' All-Star left-hander.

title: In a Surprise, South Korea Ends Its Attempts to Defend Its Currency
description: South Korea suspended efforts to defend its currency with its own, fast-depleting financial reserves today as American, Asian and European officials scrambled to determine if the world's 11th-largest economy -- and one of America's largest trading partners -- will become the latest Asian nation needing an economic bailout.

title: By Design; As Mercury Drops, Boots Rise
description: Trend spotted in the audience at the recent spring shows in New York: knee-high boots.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEVENSON, JOHN REESE
description: STEVENSON-John Reese. A memorial service will be held on Wed, November 19, 1997, at 4 PM, Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue, New York City. Donations in his memory may be made to the Community Hospice of Fort Worth, Texas, or to the Columbia School of Law for the Research and Study of Law in Latin America.

title: German Ministry Official Spied for Iraq in Gulf War
description: Shortly after Saddam Hussein's army marched into Kuwait in August 1990, a German Foreign Ministry official provided Baghdad with piles of secrets, including Western assessments of Iraq's missile strength.

title: Arts in America; Folk Music With No Threat of a Formal Education
description: Sasha Simmons, 5, was struggling mightily with her G chord. Her nose was wrinkled; her cheeks were taut. The ukulele on her lap was a little cockeyed. ''Place your third finger on the third fret,'' said Dan Fulkerson, her instructor, a directive more complex than it appeared. She had to count -- both fingers and frets -- and didn't quite get it right. At first. Didn't faze her, though.

title: Liberals Still Run Strong
description: To the Editor:

title: Findings Back Einstein In a Plagiarism Dispute
description: ONE of the triumphs of modern science is the general theory of relativity, which defies common sense by describing the gravitational attraction between planetary bodies as the curvature of a bizarre entity called space-time.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about increased interaction between editors and business executives at The Los Angeles Times misstated a word in a quotation from Mark H. Willes, the chairman and chief executive of the paper's parent, the Times Mirror Company, who commented on sources of ideas for the paper. He said, ''I would be surprised and disappointed if most of the ideas didn't come from the editorial side,'' -- not ''the business side.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERN, ETHEL
description: FERN-Ethel, on November 16th, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Devoted mother of Joseph and Susan. Loving grandmother of Jason and Lisa. Services at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY, Tuesday, 1 PM. For info, call ''Wien & Wien,'' 800-322-0533.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about the soprano Ruth Ann Swenson included a role incorrectly among those she has not recorded. She has indeed recorded Juliette, in Gounod's opera ''Romeo et Juliette''; it is on a 1995 RCA Victor compact disk, with Placido Domingo as Romeo.

title: In Performance: POP ; Casting Singer as Shaman With High-Minded Humor
description: John Kelly

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, ROBERT C.
description: SULLIVAN-Robert C., 91. Died on November 10, 1997. Beloved husband of fifty years of the late Elizabeth Durant Sullivan. Devoted father of Cornelia S. Northway of Valhalla, New York, Henry A. Sullivan of New York, New York, and the late R. Clark Sullivan. Also survived by five grandchildren. Tributes may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Growth in Singapore Beats Expectations
description: Singapore's third-quarter gross domestic product expanded a better-than-expected 10.1 percent, as accelerating construction and rising electronics manufacturing propelled the economy to its fastest pace in seven quarters. The rise, driven by United States and European demand, prompted the Government to project growth for the full year of 7 percent, at the high end of its forecast range of 6 percent to 7 percent. It also predicted a 1998 rise of 5 percent to 7 percent.

title: U.S. Penalizes Israeli-Owned Company for Dealing With Cuba
description: The Clinton Administration said today that it would punish an Israeli-owned citrus company for doing business in Cuba on land expropriated from Americans.

title: PEPSICO BUYING SNACK UNITS WORTH $440 MILLION
description: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that it would buy salty snack businesses in Europe and Australia from United Biscuits Holdings P.L.C. of Britain for $440 million. The deal includes the Smith's Snackfood Company of Australia, the Crik Crok brand in Belgium, the Nibbit brand in the Netherlands and the Croky potato chip brand in France. Pepsico will also acquire a chip production plant in Veurne, Belgium. Pepsico, in turn, will sell Biscuiterie Nantaise, its French cookie business, to United Biscuits for $30 million. The acquisition is part of a move by Pepsico, based in Purchase, N.Y., to concentrate on its main snacks and beverage businesses after spinning off its restaurant operations earlier this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOGURI, DAVID MEGUMI
description: TOGURI-David Megumi. Peacefully at his Toronto home on Saturday, November 15, 1997, after a courageous battle with cancer. Beloved brother of Samuel, Etsuko, Makiko and husband Roy, James and wife Elsie, Grace and husband Edward, Allan and wife Emilie, and Miki. David was much loved by his 16 nephews and nieces. Many thanks to Dr. Stanley Zheng (Mt. Sinai Palliative Unit), nurses Brenda Metherall and Ainat Cohen; homemaker Ruth Richardson, and Community Care Coordinator Louise Sandy-Deare for their valuable support and comfort to David. At David's request a private family service was held Monday, November 17, 1997. If desired, memorial donations may be made to the Division of Palliative Medicine, Mt. Sinai Hospital Foundation, 600 Universtiy Avenue, Toronto Ontario, Canada M5G1X5.

title: ALLIED SIGNAL'S PRESTONE ADDS OVERSEAS OPERATIONS
description: Allied Signal Inc.'s Prestone Products unit bought the British car-care company Holt Lloyd Group Ltd. yesterday for $155 million to expand its overseas presence. Prestone, which makes antifreeze and other car-care products, bought Holt Lloyd from the closely held investment firm Electra Fleming Ltd. Holt Lloyd makes cleaners and waxes in Britain, France, Australia and New Zealand, while Prestone operates largely in the United States. Allied Signal, based in Morristown, N.J., said it expects Holt Lloyd to have 1997 sales of $150 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARKEY, JOSEPHINE
description: STARKEY-Josephine. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Jacquelyn, Richard, and Ralph. Dear sister of Salvatore LaValle and the late Connie Smoltino. Survived by two loving grandchildren. Reposing at Farenga Bros. Funeral Home, 920 Allerton Avenue until Friday, 9 AM. Mass of Christian Burial, Holy Rosary Church, Friday, at 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, RICHARD
description: BAUM-Richard. Nov. 15, 1997. Beloved husband of Valerie Greenly. Devoted father of Garrison Mathew and Elizabeth. Loving brother of Vicki and brother-in-law Steven Roth. Dear uncle of Tracey and cousin of Charles Finder. Services Thursday, 11 AM, ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory can be made to the American Museum of Natural History, att: Larry Ludwig.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACCIO, FRANK J.
description: SACCIO-Frank J., 88 of Southbury, CT, Nov. 14, 1997. Retired manager for the John Hancock Insurance Company, Manhattan East Office. Beloved husband of the late Theresa Messina Saccio. Loving father of Dr. Joseph D. Saccio and Francine T. Saccio. Brother of Leonard Saccio. Grandfather of Damijan and Tatjana.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's not easy to keep a secret from JANE ROBELOT, the co-anchor of CBS News's ''This Morning.'' After all, she prides herself on catching the slightest whiff of news.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLINGFORD, ELSIE A. HOSTETTER
description: WALLINGFORD-Elsie A. Hostetter. On November 16, 1997 of Rockville Centre, Long Island, in her 88th year. Beloved wife of the late Walter F. Wallingford and Dean Jacob W. Hostetter. Dear mother of Jacob R. Hostetter and Margery H. Clayton. Loving grandmother of Robert and Marcia Hostetter, Dr. Barbara and Marc Ward, Daniel and Laura Clayton, Peter and Beth Clayton. Also survived by two nephews, a niece, five great-grandchildren, stepchildren, step-grandchildren and a brother-in-law. The family will receive friends on Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the Fairchild Sons Funeral Chapel, 20 Lincoln Avenue, Rockville Centre, LI. Service 11 AM, Thursday at Church of the Ascension, North Village Ave, Rockville Centre. Cremation is private. If desired, memorials may be made to a charity of choice.

title: Crusader Takes On the Postal Piggy Bank
description: He is called Japan's Don Quixote, and indeed, it does seem that Junichiro Koizumi is tilting at windmills.

title: 5-State Inquiry On D. H. Blair
description: State securities regulators are investigating possible sales-practice abuses at the brokerage firm D. H. Blair & Company.

title: 5 Tough Games Await Eager Giants
description: The Giants did little today to conceal their zeal for Sunday night's nationally televised game with the Washington Redskins.

title: The Release of Wei Jingsheng
description: After spending all but six months of the last 18 years in prison, Wei Jingsheng, the father of China's democracy movement, has been released to get the medical attention he has long required. The world has reason to rejoice that the cruel imprisonment of Mr. Wei is over and that he is resting in a hospital in Detroit. But his release is not necessarily an indication that the Chinese Government is changing its repressive policies on human rights.

title: U.S. Output Rose in October For 15th Consecutive Month
description: United States industrial output advanced in October for the 15th straight month, though at a subdued rate, indicating that inflation does not greatly threaten the economy, analysts said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURLAND, HAIM
description: GURLAND-Haim. Beloved husband of Estelle for 55 years. Devoted father of Judith and Robert, father-in-law of Warren Blaker and Gaby Jordan. Adored grandfather of Avram, Lauren and Emily. Loyal brother, uncle and friend. After a valiant struggle with cancer in his 93rd year. Services Tuesday, 1 PM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: INSIDE
description: Stocks Soar on Tokyo Rally

title: Personal Health; Acupuncture: An Expensive Placebo or a Legitimate Alternative?
description: IN 1971, James Reston, The New York Times columnist, introduced the Western world to the ancient Chinese therapy of acupuncture. Mr. Reston, who underwent an emergency appendectomy in China, described acupuncture's success in relieving his postoperative pain.

title: Death in the Family, Now and Long Ago
description: You can almost hear the stentorian tones of Don Pardo over the public-address system: ''Live from East 15th Street, it's the 'Veanne Cox Show!' ''

title: From Under the Sea, Signs of Climate Jolts
description: AS scientists seek to improve their imperfect understanding of how and why the world's climate is changing, evidence continues to mount that most of the last 10,000 years -- long thought to be a benign era whose stability was crucial to the rise of civilization -- has in fact been typified by episodes of warmth, cold, drought and flooding more extreme than anything experienced in the 20th century.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the expulsion of American weapons inspectors from Iraq misstated the action of an Iraqi escort. The Iraqi policemen accompanied the American motorcade to the Jordanian border but did not continue to Amman, Jordan.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Oct. 8 comparing the amount of pollutants emitted from fuel-cell motors with those emitted from battery-powered car motors and combustion engines carried incomplete labels. The emissions caused by the generation of power to charge a battery-powered electric motor were based on figures at electric plants in Germany. Figures at plants in California, for example, would be much lower, while those in the Midwest would be much higher. Research for this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Invisible, and in Anguish; A Slain Driver's Service Brings Attention to Senegalese
description: The first 150 or so people to arrive at Francisco's Funeraria in East Harlem yesterday were able to squeeze into the upstairs room where Elhadji Gaye's body lay inside a plywood crate, the word ''Senegal'' scrawled across it in black marker as a crude shipping instruction.

title: Mexico Holds Brother Linked To His Family's Drug Dealing
description: Mexican authorities were holding a member of Mexico's top methamphetamine trafficking family today, seeking to draw up drug and other charges against him after his arrest at a highway checkpoint for illegal possession of a pistol.

title: ESPN on Mark to Last Pick for Expansion Draft
description: On Oct. 10, 1961, officials of the Mets and the Houston Colt .45's gathered in the Netherland-Hilton Hotel in Cincinnati -- the city where the former National League president, Warren Giles, kept his office. The occasion was the league's expansion draft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINDEL, EDITH (NEE SOLOMON)
description: MINDEL-Edith (nee Solomon). Beloved wife of the late Dr. Leo E. Mindel passed away on Tuesday, November 17th, 1997, surrounded by her children, son Lee and daughters Laney, Sunny and Meg. In addition she leaves behind her deicated sons-in law Gary Menken and Tony Marchese and three grandchildren: Luke, Lucy, and Margo Marchese. Services at Highland Park Conservative Temple, 201 South 3rd Street, Highland Park, New Jersey, at 11:30 A.M. today. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Research Institute.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Kazakh Chief, in U.S., to Back Oil Deals
description: President Nursultan Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan began a two-day visit yesterday to Washington, where his agenda included approval of two long-awaited energy deals between Kazakhstan and big oil companies.

title: Cowboys Are Pumped Up by Victory
description: The Dallas Cowboys were holding hands on the sidelines, watching Richie Cunningham's kick barely sail through the uprights. In the last several years they have been involved in everything from drug abuse to being accused of rape. They are a hardened group, their outer shells like cement, yet here they were after an emotional victory over Washington, crying like babies.

title: Growth Predicted in Computer-Based Jobs
description: Strong growth is expected to continue through the first years of the next century in computer-related employment in the New York City metropolitan region, in fields from telecommunications to Wall Street to the small start-up companies in the Internet industry, state officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut say.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TOM, JIMMY
description: TOM-Jimmy. Special memories today from Linda, Jennifer, Mike and good friends.

title: AT&T to Reduce Its Agency Roster
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that as expected it would reduce its agency roster from three shops to two by eliminating McCann-Erickson Worldwide, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Ron Carey's Sad Fall
description: A Federal election monitor made the right decision yesterday in disqualifying the teamsters' president, Ron Carey, from a court-ordered rerun of the union's 1996 elections. The rerun was made necessary by the discovery of an illegal campaign funding scheme operated on Mr. Carey's behalf.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOHL, DAVID
description: WOHL - David. 6/9/55 - 11/18/94. Darling boy, you were born and my circle of life was perfect and complete. You died and that beautiful circle was broken and so was my heart. Love, Mommy

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Information Technology Field Is Rated Largest U.S. Industry
description: Sales by the computing and telecommunications industries have grown by 57 percent during the 1990's, to $866 billion, making those businesses an increasingly important force in the nation's economy, according to a study to be released today.

title: 1839 Slave Revolt
description: To the Editor:

title: Princeton to Use Gift For Engineering Center
description: A $10 million gift to Princeton University from an alumnus will be applied toward a new engineering center named for a classmate who died before graduating, a university spokesman said yesterday. The gift is from Dennis J. Keller, a member of the class of 1963. He is chairman of DeVry Inc., in Oak Brook, Ill., which operates business and management institutes throughout North America, Justin Harmon, a Princeton spokesman, said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WSMP INC., Claremont, N.C., a restaurant and food processing company, has an agreement to acquire the Sagebrush Inc. restaurant chain, also of Claremont, in a stock deal worth $41.5 million to $44.4 million, based on an exchange ratio of 0.3214 WSMP share for each share of Sagebrush.

title: Buenos Aires Journal; Argentina's Bereft Mothers: And Now, a New Wave
description: Every Thursday the famed Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo march to memorialize their children, who were killed during Argentina's military dictatorship from 1976 to 1983.

title: Two California Representatives to Leave House
description: Two stalwart California Democrats, Representatives Vic Fazio and Ronald V. Dellums, announced their retirement from the House of Representatives today after decades of lawmaking on Capitol Hill.

title: Columbia Plan Would Recast Health Care
description: With Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation's plan to shrink its size drastically, the world of for-profit hospitals appears on the verge of transforming itself into a variation of the industry that existed in the 1980's, before Columbia was created.

title: Military Extremists?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPUA, GIULIO J.
description: CAPUA-Giulio J. Of White Plains, NY. Husband of Mary Capua. Father of Giulio F. Capua. Brother of Concetta Rice. Funeral Mass Thursday 11 A.M., at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church, White Plains, NY. Memorial contributions to Save the Children Foundation would be appreciated.

title: Newcourt Credit to Acquire AT&T Capital
description: Newcourt Credit Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the AT&T Capital Corporation for $1.6 billion in cash and stock, creating one of the world's biggest lenders that is not a bank.

title: McGreevey Offers a Bill To Cut Auto Premiums
description: Two weeks after losing a gubernatorial election fought largely over auto insurance, State Senator James E. McGreevey yesterday introduced a bill that mirrored his campaign pledge to roll back premiums by 10 percent. He said his legislation would also crack down on insurance fraud by creating a special prosecutor, and would compel insurance companies to open their books every two years for public review.

title: Where Prices Are Out of This World
description: Marvin Killgore comes from a long line of prospectors, rough-hewn men who scoured the Southwest for specks of gold.

title: Weighing Pros and Cons While the Jury Is Out
description: MISCONCEPTIONS about acupuncture abound. While some believe that it is a highly effective pain reliever, others say it is nothing more than a glorified and expensive placebo lacking scientific proof for the many claims made in its behalf. The truth, according to nearly a score of reports made to a Federally sponsored conference this month, lies somewhere in between.

title: Stefan Lorant, 96, Author and Magazine Editor
description: Stefan Lorant, a Hungarian-born editor and author who cut a serendipitous swath through the 20th century while pioneering modern photojournalism, died on Friday at a hospital in Rochester, Minn. He was 96 and lived in Lenox, Mass.

title: God and Man at Dartmouth
description: James Freedman, the president of Dartmouth, dedicated a new Jewish center on campus last week and took the occasion to quote from anti-Semitic letters written by the college's admissions director in 1934. Mr. Freedman also quoted a remark made by one of his predecessors, Ernest Hopkins. In 1945 Hopkins told The New York Post that his college had a quota system because ''Dartmouth is a Christian college founded for the Christianization of its students.'' That was the Dartmouth past, not to be confused with the Dartmouth present.

title: Nassau Leader Accepts Ouster of Medical Chief
description: The Nassau County Executive, who was out of town when the County Medical Center's board voted last week to remove the institution's executive director, said yesterday that he accepted the board's decision.

title: INSIDE
description: A plan to export garbage angers two boroughs. PAGE B3

title: Sports of The Times; O'Donnell Gets Another Crack at Job
description: AS he was about to take a seat on Bill Parcells's bench two weeks ago, a reflective side of Neil O'Donnell surfaced. Borrowing from the philosophic scriptures of Yogi Berra, O'Donnell said, ''I know this game well enough that you never know what's going to happen.''

title: COLLEGES: NOTEBOOK -- Temple; Dickerson Quits Post
description: Ron Dickerson was true to his word. He promised that if he could not turn Temple's football program around in five years, he would quit. His fifth season, another losing one, ended Saturday, and yesterday the 49-year-old Dickerson resigned.

title: The Glasses, The Hair, The Angst
description: When Woody Allen phones the heroine of ''Just Shoot Me'' at the end of tonight's show, that really is Woody Allen's voice, not an impersonator's. The brief, disembodied guest appearance has everything to do with impersonators, though. This exceptionally funny and clever episode of the series, about an intellectual named Maya (Laura San Giacomo) who works for her philistine father (George Segal) at a fashion magazine called Blush, is shaped as an ''Annie Hall'' parody and features a character who looks, talks and acts like the Woody Allen of Maya's dreams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANOV, ABEL
description: BANOV-Abel. Of Roslyn Heights, New York, on November 16, 1997. Beloved husband of Joan Heineman-Banov. Adoring father of Beverly Brown. Dear grandfather of Robin Brown. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASKET, HYMAN DAVID
description: MASKET-Hyman David. Age 91 died, suddenly on November 16, 1997. Devoted husband of the late Raissa, beloved father of Susan, Lawrence and Nadine. Cherished grandfather of Raime, Michael, Raissa, and Diane. Funeral service from Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Avenue, New York City, Wednesday, 12:15 PM. Interment Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLOSSBERG, BEATRICE QUINT
description: SCHLOSSBERG-Beatrice Quint. Former Director of Queen Lake Camp, Athol, Mass. Survived by her sister, Judith Q. Schreider of Newton Centre, Mass. Daughter and son-in-law Jane and Alan Winslow of San Francisco, California. Donations may be made to Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Boston, Massachusetts 02215.

title: Emulating Machines, Humans Just Aren't As Exact
description: Conlon Nancarrow's significance as a composer is more a promise than a fact. But this has not stopped many of us, like speculators in a futures market, from investing in what he may well turn out to be. Put in religious terms, Nancarrow came to music not as a messiah but as a prophet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRNBAUM, MIRIAM S. (NEE ALTMAN)
description: BIRNBAUM-Miriam S. (nee Altman) ''Mimi''. Monday, Nov. 17, 1997, of Short Hills, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Sidney H. Birnbaum. Devoted mother of Philip and Steven Birnbaum. Dear sister of Sara Malamud, Dottie Freeman, Samuel, Irving and the late Harry Altman. Loving grandmother of Kyle. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd, Union, NJ, Tuesday, Nov. 18, 1997 at 1 P.M. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, MICHAEL G.
description: SHAW-Michael G. Of New York, FL. and Fair Harbor. November 17th. Beloved husband of Vivian (Cantor) Shaw. Devoted father of Andrea Shaw-Resnick and Steven Shaw. Loving grandfather of Joshua and Zachary Resnick. Brother of the late Ann Rubin and uncle of Howard and Alan Rubin. Mr. Shaw was employed by the Merck & Company, Rahway, N.J. for 42 years. He was also a member of the Trout Unlimited Fly Fishing Club of New York. Services will be held at the Garlick-Hellman Funeral Home, 1091 Yonkers Avenue, Yonkers, on Wednesday, at 10 A.M. Interment will be in Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: The Trade Show Talk That Wasn't, on the Horror of Virtual Quality
description: THIS week more than 200,000 members of the computer world have descended on Las Vegas for the 18th annual Comdex fall trade show, where daily keynote speeches by industry luminaries discuss scintillating issues like ''open standards-based computing with a horizontal market model.'' Yesterday, outside the Aladdin Theater for the Performing Arts, I discovered a battered floppy disk labeled ''Computopia and What It Means, or the Horror!'' None of the keynote speakers appear to have been responsible for the address it contains:

title: Fare Beating in the Subways Falls Off Under a Tougher Arrest Policy
description: For the public, turnstile jumping is probably the common cold of crimes in New York City, a nuisance rather than a threat. But for the police, subway scofflaws are responsible for costly violations and in many cases go on to commit more serious crimes.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Failure to disqualify in this case would constitute a damaging precedent that would undermine the deterrent effect of the election rules.''

title: Even the Resilient Kasparov Can Be Deflated by a Loss
description: No one is immune from the effects of losing a game, not even the world champion. In the recent Fontys International Tournament in Tilburg, the Netherlands, Garry Kasparov shot out of the opening gate with five wins and a draw. But then, for the first time, he encountered Peter Svidler, a 21-year-old player who had won three of the four last Russian Championships, and lost.

title: Marino Keeps Dolphins in a Tie With Jets
description: With most of the Dolphins' unbeaten 1972 team looking on, it took awhile for Miami to live up to that legacy tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BABETCH, ALEX
description: BABETCH-Alex. On November 7. As a group of close friends for fifty years, we mourn his passing, recall his many kindnesses and will miss his companionship.

title: U.S. Stocks Surge After Strong Rally in Japan
description: A strong rally in Japan spurred a surge in United States stocks yesterday as American investors apparently were encouraged by the handling of a bank failure by the Japanese government.

title: AN OVERSEER BARS TEAMSTER LEADER FROM RE-ELECTION
description: A court-appointed union monitor yesterday barred Ron Carey from running for re-election as teamsters' president after finding that the man who came into office as a reformer had backed a plan in which more than $700,000 in union funds was used to help his own campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, MINNIE
description: MORRIS-Minnie. Retired attorney and long time resident of New York City. Died on October 11, 1997. Interment private.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Drive Is Begun to Tow Battleship to Bayonne
description: Proponents of berthing the U.S.S. New Jersey in Bayonne began a drive yesterday to raise funds to tow the battleship from Washington State before their hopes are foiled by the handing over of the Panama Canal.

title: Texas May Drop All Texts, for Laptops
description: What began as an off-the-cuff remark by the chairman of the Texas Board of Education now has state officials seriously examining whether to give all public school students laptops instead of textbooks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSMORE, COL. FRANCIS B.
description: MESSMORE-Col. Francis B. On November 16, 1997. Beloved husband of Dorothy; loving father of Pamela Tobiason; adored grandfather of Peter. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St, Thursday at 6-8 PM and Friday 2-4 PM and 6-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday 10 AM at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street. Interment, private.

title: TV Notes; Mob Scores at CBS
description: The lessons of television are learned quickly: Shortly after seeing a new special, ''Kids Say the Darndest Things'' with Bill Cosby, score an outstanding rating, CBS's programming boss, Leslie Moonves, moved to turn it into a regular series.

title: Phone Subsidy for Poor As Pay Phones Cost More
description: New Jersey regulators approved a plan yesterday to require Bell Atlantic to help subsidize local phone bills for as many as 600,000 phone customers who receive welfare benefits.

title: SOCCER: ROUNDUP
description: 1999 WOMEN'S WORLD CUP

title: After Baseball Draft Comes Trade Deluge
description: On a day when baseball's two newest teams, the Tampa Bay Devil Rays and the Arizona Diamondbacks, filled out their rosters, baseball's World Series champions, the Florida Marlins, began emptying theirs in payroll-cutting trades.

title: PHELPS DODGE TO SELL A UNIT FOR $480 MILLION
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation agreed yesterday to sell 90 percent of a subsidiary, the Accuride Corporation, to Accuride's management and an affiliate of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company for $480 million. Phelps Dodge will retain ownership of 10 percent. Accuride, which had sales of $307.8 million in 1996, or about 8 percent of Phelps Dodge's $3.79 billion in sales, makes wheels and rims for trucks, trailers, buses and sport utility vehicles. Phelps Dodge, based in Phoenix, operates copper mines and produces magnet wire and specialty conductors; the company employs more than 16,000 people in 26 countries. Its stock slipped 68.75 cents a share yesterday, to $69.4375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLKIND, SYLVIA
description: WOLKIND-Sylvia. A woman who loved her family above all else, loved life and would make a detour anytime, anywhere to play golf at some wonderful course she had not yet seen (and there weren't too many of those) had a sudden, tragic end. She was truly a woman of valor. Those fortunate to know her will never forget her. A great loss to her husband of fifty-nine years Murray, son Richard, daughter Dale, daughter-inlaw Marta, son-in-law Stephen and grandson Bryan. Goodbye Sylvia. Services will be held Thursday, November 20th, 12:30PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St at Amsterdam Avenue, N.Y.

title: CAMBRIDGE TECH TO PAY $127.8 MILLION FOR CHADWICK
description: Cambridge Technology Partners Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the British consultant Peter Chadwick Holdings Ltd. for about $127.8 million in stock to expand in Europe. Cambridge, an information technology consulting company, will issue about 3.255 million shares for all of Peter Chadwick. The transaction is valued at $127.8 million based on Cambridge's closing price of $39.25, down 62.5 cents. The buyer, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., said it expected to take a charge of $4.5 million in the current quarter for costs related to the deal. The agreement extends Cambridge's consulting business in Europe and strengthens it in big markets like Britain, France and Germany.

title: Players Back Guerin For Olympic Spot
description: Some of the hockey players chosen to play on the United States Olympic team are considering a boycott of the Winter Games in Japan next year if Bill Guerin is not named to the team. The most outspoken of them is Brett Hull of the St. Louis Blues, who said he is ready to join other players in protest if Guerin isn't named.

title: Plea of Guilty In '94 Shooting Is Renounced
description: A Jordanian immigrant who pleaded guilty to hindering prosecution after a 1994 terrorist attack on yeshiva students on the Brooklyn Bridge has asked a state judge to withdraw his guilty plea.

title: $25 and Under; Down-Home Ribs, Certified by Somebody or Other
description: ''BEST Ribs in New York City -- the Georgia BBQ Council,'' crows a sign in the window of the Hog Pit, a genial bar in the center of the meatpacking district. Well, wouldn't you be intrigued?

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the funeral for Elhadji Gaye, a Senegalese immigrant who was shot and killed while driving a livery cab in East Harlem, misstated the time of his death. It was early Friday, not Friday night.

title: Threat From Washington Has Chilling Effect on Oregon Law Allowing Assisted Suicide
description: The single-page form, titled ''Request for medication to end my life in a humane and dignified manner,'' is circulating now in the only state ever to legalize assisted suicide. But whether doctors in Oregon will actually do what the law allows them to is suddenly clouded by a threat from Washington.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Food Chain
description: Foolproof Cheese Sauce

title: Roasting Turkey Lost Its Allure? No Problem, Just Deep-Fry It
description: THE stage was set for the quintessential macho performance: three charcoal grills, assorted long-handled forks and tongs out on a wooden deck at the back of a house. Two things made it extraordinary: the spectacular view of the Potomac River and the 45-quart pot filled with boiling oil. The pot, atop of large propane burner, was about to receive a 22-pound turkey. Whole.

title: Profit Taking Sends Dow Down to 7,650.82
description: Stocks fell yesterday for the first time in four sessions as investors took profits.

title: It's O.K. to Buy a Crust -- Really
description: MILLIONS of accomplished American cooks can saute, simmer, bake and broil with equanimity, but when pie time rolls around, they fall into culinary catatonia. It's the crust that's the problem. I have to admit that I can make perfectly decent pie crusts, but they lack that final brilliance, the secret ingredient of a born pie baker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGEDORN, CHARLES
description: HAGEDORN-Charles. 79, on Nov. 17, 1997, beloved husband of the late Jane, devoted father of Christopher, cherished grandfather of Christopher and James. At Charles' request a private family service was held. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. Donations in his memory can be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave, NY, NY 10021.

title: Could Iraq Have the Atomic Bomb?
description: While the United States, Russia and other countries search for diplomatic solutions to the crisis in Iraq, the risk grows that the weapons inspectors will never again be able to do their jobs effectively. Last night, for example, Yevgeny Primakov, the Russia Foreign Minister, proposed that in return for allowing the inspectors to go back to work, their efforts would have to be brought to a quick conclusion.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: First Union and Corestates

title: Sehorn's Quiet Intensity Makes Believer of Fassel
description: When Jim Fassel took over as the head coach of the Giants, he watched film and thought he saw a lack of intensity by Jason Sehorn. When he met Sehorn, he thought the laid-back demeanor did not fit the emotional requirements of a cornerback. Then Fassel put Sehorn on the field, and what he saw quickly changed his mind.

title: New Agency In Seattle
description: Two employees at Herring Newman in Seattle have left to open a shop in that city, Voice L.L.C., specializing in marketing to women.

title: Making Books; Neither Big Fish Nor Choice Fowl
description: ''Midlist'' is the dirtiest word in book publishing. Everyone defines it differently, but mainly it means a book somewhere in the middle or lower part of a publishing roster that doesn't get the publisher's most muscular energy and support. Writers surely hate the word. It brands them as underachievers, they feel; agents and publishers don't like it either.

title: 13-Year-Old Runaway Is Found in Bus Terminal
description: A 13-year-old runaway who was missing for nearly five weeks after fleeing a Bronx center for teen-agers run by the Administration for Children's Services was found yesterday in the Port Authority Bus Terminal, officials said. A Bronx Family Court judge ordered yesterday in an initial hearing that the girl again be placed in the agency's custody, despite the objections of the girl's mother.

title: P.& G. Names One Agency to Handle Billion-Dollar TV Operations
description: The biggest assignment in the history of advertising was made yesterday as the Procter & Gamble Company consolidated responsibilities for the tactical planning and buying of television commercial time in the United States -- with an estimated $1 billion to $1.2 billion in annual spending -- at a single agency.

title: U.S. Wants a Cut of Tobacco Settlements
description: The Clinton Administration has told the states that the Federal Government will take at least half of any money they recover through lawsuits against tobacco companies for the costs of providing health care to smokers under Medicaid.

title: IRAQ AND RUSSIANS DRAFT A PROPOSAL TO END GULF CRISIS
description: Russia and Iraq have drafted a proposal to end the standoff between the United States and Saddam Hussein, Russia's Foreign Minister said this evening.

title: Finding What Was and Is In a Village Near Moscow
description: ECHOES OF A NATIVE LAND

title: An Athlete Challenges a Stealthy Rule
description: Michael Bowers, a 6-foot-7-inch, 240-pound offensive lineman, was a teen-age celebrity in his hometown of Palmyra, N.J. Captain of the football team, a varsity wrestler, a baseball player. From sophomore to senior year he received hundreds of recruiting letters from colleges and universities, 50 from the University of Iowa alone, which also telephoned weekly.

title: Liberties; Anthrax, Shmanthrax
description: I was peaceably eating my penne at lunch the other day when my friend, another reporter, told me he thought Washington was in imminent danger of being gassed, germed, VX'ed or anthraxed.

title: Conspiracy Inoculation
description: The stated reason for the Federal Bureau of Investigation's extraordinary news conference yesterday was to announce the termination of its 16-month criminal investigation into the 1996 explosion of T.W.A. Flight 800. Its real purpose was to persuade skeptical Americans that the explosion was not a terrorist act.

title: Recruits in the War of the Sexes
description: ''How I Spent My Summer Vacation,'' John Fisher's breezy, good-natured look at the stormy relationship between two attractive black college students who are in love but can't live together peacefully, is a reminder of how few movies (either from Hollywood or the independent sphere) seriously explore the thorny textures of contemporary relationships.

title: Blackbirds Start Slowly, But Recover in Time
description: L.I.U. 106, SACRED HEART 69

title: On Race, Americans Only Talk a Good Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTNOY, LOUIS DAVID
description: PORTNOY-Louis David, on November 16, 1997. Beloved husband of Sara Portnoy. Dear father of Sharon Siegel, Robert Portnoy and Susan Portnoy. Loving grandfather of Jessica Siegel, Leah Beth and Michael Portnoy. He will be greatly missed.

title: Osborne Improves
description: Soon after Nebraska's overtime victory over Missouri on Nov. 8, Coach Tom Osborne started having trouble with an irregular heartbeat. Osborne, who had heart surgery in 1985, went to a hospital last Sunday where he received medication to have the problem corrected. Doctors performed more tests on him Monday and found nothing abnormal, the 60-year-old coach said.

title: To U.P.S. Workers in Queens, Carey Remains a Regular Guy
description: In Queens, where Ron Carey began as a reform-minded United Parcel Service truck driver and rose to the teamsters' highest office, union leaders and the rank and file stood solidly behind him yesterday after a court-appointed monitor ruled that he could not run for re-election because he had improperly diverted members' dues to his campaign.

title: You, Behind the Potted Palm: Come Out!
description: You can almost hear Emma Thompson's well-bred British accent in the written statement she released about tonight's ''Ellen,'' in which she appears as herself: ''I love the idea of playing around with one's public persona.'' By the end of this outrageously funny half-hour, she has kissed a woman at a party, privately admitted she is gay and guzzled enough alcohol to pickle all of England. In the last surprise twist, she even sends up the elegant Thompson accent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORAN, WILLIAM DEAN.
description: MORAN-William Dean. On November 16, 1997, Beloved husband of Margaret Walsh Moran, loving father of William, Daniel, Jacqueline Dickson, and Katherine Moran. Former husband of Rae L. Moran. Services Wednesday, 11:30 AM., Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Stand Firm on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: CHALLENGE TO AUTHORITY: A special report.; Disrespect as Catalyst for Brutality
description: After dropping her young daughter with a baby sitter, Taquana Harris rushed to her hostess job at the fashionable Bowery Bar one night last February, her leopard-print evening gown sweeping elegantly through the dark, icy streets of the East Village. Then a strange woman crudely grabbed her by the arm and demanded to know what she had done with the drugs.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about the presentation of history at national parks misspelled the surname of the artist who engraved ''Pickett's Charge at Gettysburg.'' He was A. R. Waud, not Ward.

title: The Minimalist; Give Thanks: In Three Hours, From Scratch
description: IF a minimalist approach to satisfying food makes sense most ordinary days, a holiday like Thanksgiving demands it in the name of survival. This year, I vowed to minimize everything but my expectation for a great meal: time, number of ingredients and, most of all, work. Heretical as it may seem, I thought it might be fun for the cook to have enough energy to enjoy the meal for a change.

title: Consumer Price Index: Again No Surprises
description: Despite the nation's economic strength, consumer prices rose only modestly again in October and helped push inflation during the last 12 months to the lowest level since oil prices collapsed a decade ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELLEN, CONSTANCE L.
description: MELLEN-Constance L. On Saturday November 15, 1997 in Washington D.C. Beloved daughter of Frederic W. and Sophie Ross Loudon. Beloved sister of Barbara. Memorial service December 6 at Christ Church, Georgetown, Washington D.C. 1:30PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations should be sent to Martha's Table, 2114 14th St NW, Washington D.C. 20009.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Multiple Choices For Thanksgiving

title: British Legal Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEZENIK, ALFRED JOEL, ESQ.
description: PEZENIK-Alfred Joel, Esq. In his 80th year. Dearly beloved husband of Dorothy. Dear uncle of David and Steven of New York, and Lisa and Wendy World of Toronto. Loving brother-in-law of Phyllis Pezenik of Old Westbury and Sanford World of Toronto. Friend to many. Funeral service Thursday, 12 Noon at ''Gutterman's Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island. Interment Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, New York. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Diabetes Foundation.

title: $17.1 BILLION DEAL FOR BANK CREATES EAST COAST GIANT
description: Two of the nation's biggest banking companies, the First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., and the Corestates Financial Corporation of Philadelphia, agreed late yesterday to merge in a $17.1 billion deal.

title: CALENDAR
description: Cookbook Bargains

title: A Protest Opens Defamation Trial of Brawley's Advisers
description: The defamation suit against three advisers of Tawana Brawley began yesterday in the same angry, racially charged vein that surrounded the Brawley case a decade ago: One of the defendants, acting as his own lawyer, refused to enter the Poughkeepsie, N.Y., courthouse until more than 100 supporters marching on the sidewalk were also allowed inside.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, NATHAN
description: LIEBERMAN-Nathan, Nov. 18, 1997, 86 years young, after a severe short illness, of Deerfield Beach, FL., formerly of New Rochelle, NY. A partner in Academy Hardware of N.Y.C. before retiring to FL. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice. Loving father of Barry (Lenore), Lynn (Michael), and Ronni. Devoted brother of Rosey, Jeanie and the late Morris. Adored grandfather of David (Evy), Caryn (Paul), Jennifer and Joanna. Proud great grandfather of Rachel and Eric. He will be thought of by cousins, nieces, nephews and friends. ''Nato'' will be missed for his loving guidance, his mastery of the piano and dance, and his achievements in bowling. Services are today, Nov. 19th, 1:30PM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4 East Paramus, NJ.

title: Ethical Blindness in the Kremlin
description: Anatoly Chubais is both the agent and enemy of Russian reform. Without Mr. Chubais's wily advice and determination to shed Communist economics, Boris Yeltsin might not have brought Russia so far along the road to democracy and free markets. But Mr. Chubais, Mr. Yeltsin's top economic and political adviser, has also condoned unseemly dealings between the Kremlin and Russian businessmen. Even by the raw standards of Russian politics, he has now disgraced himself and ought to vacate his post as First Deputy Prime Minister.

title: On Race, Americans Only Talk a Good Game; For Whites, Confusion
description: To the Editor:

title: Retailers' Earnings Near Expectations
description: Several big retailers -- Home Depot Inc., the Dayton Hudson Corporation, the Ann Taylor Stores Corporation and Limited Inc. -- reported fiscal third-quarter operating earnings yesterday that were in line with or above analysts' expectations.

title: INSIDE
description: States' Tobacco Money Draws Washington Eyes

title: Japan Announces Modest Economic Plan
description: The Government has released a widely anticipated package of measures intended to invigorate Japan's faltering economy but conceded it would bring little relief any time soon.

title: United States of Excess?
description: To the Editor:

title: On Using the Subway Surplus
description: Despite their reluctance to admit it in public, the executives who run New York City's mass transit are accumulating a 1997 surplus that would make some on Wall Street salivate. At $126.8 million and rising, the surplus could wind up close to $150 million. But whatever it totals come Dec. 31, every penny ought to finance vastly improved bus and subway service -- plus discounts and marketing efforts that will persuade more people that you can get around faster underground than above.

title: Legally, Death Comes When Brain Stops
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTSCHNEIDER, IDA
description: GUTSCHNEIDER-Ida. On November 18, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Paul. Services Thursday, 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting hours Wednesday 7-9 PM.

title: On the Deadly Roads of India, A Bus Claims 29 Young Lives
description: At least 29 schoolchildren were killed and more than 60 others injured today when an overloaded school bus skidded off a bridge and plunged into the Yamuna River in the outskirts of New Delhi.

title: British Legal Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Hawks Improve To 11-0
description: HAWKS 98, WIZARDS 89

title: Business Travel; Cathay Pacific is offering a big discount on round-trip fares from the U.S. to Hong Kong.
description: HOPING to revive Hong Kong's slumping tourist industry, as well as increase passenger loads, Cathay Pacific is offering an economy-class round-trip fare for two from New York or Los Angeles for $999, plus taxes. Travel, which includes five nights at one of the approximately 60 participating hotels, must be booked no later than Dec. 3 and completed by Feb. 15, 1998. Seats are limited.

title: Sweet and Sour, a Romantic Blend
description: Though not noted for her humor, the filmmaker Chantal Akerman has attempted light romantic comedy in ''A Couch in New York,'' which opened on Monday at Anthology Film Archives. And though this 1995 film has been discussed in terms of Lubitsch, Cukor and Capra, it has a premise that could work for Neil Simon, too. In what Ms. Akerman describes as ''what Hollywood calls a 'double fish out of water film,' '' a rich and glum New York psychoanalyst (William Hurt) impulsively offers to switch his Fifth Avenue apartment for a place in Paris. He winds up trading places with a beautiful dancer (Juliette Binoche) who is as fresh and exuberant as he is dour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELSKY, ESTELLE (NEE SHULTZ)
description: BELSKY-Estelle (nee Shultz). On November 17, 1997. Beloved mother of Barbara and Herbert Vanefsky and Ilyne and Herbert Herling. Grandmother to Jeffrey, Marc, Beth, Lisa and Greg Meisel, Shari and Russell Cohen, Bari and Paul Shurman. Great grandmother to Max, Aliyah, Benjamin, Jordan and Jared. Service at Guttermans, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre Wednesday 12:30PM.

title: TV Notes; Child Abuse on Tape
description: The printed accounts of parents trying to smother their infant children in the hospital were horrifying enough. Now ABC's ''Prime Time Live'' has the videotaped evidence.

title: Majoli Hopes to End Her Post-Paris Slump
description: Ever since Iva Majoli became the French Open champion last June and the first Croatian woman ever to capture a Grand Slam title, her life has been different, which she has enjoyed. But her tennis has not necessarily been better, which she regrets. And at 20, she is too young to have regrets.

title: Miscellany
description: * Publishers Information Bureau, New York, said that magazine advertising pages in October increased 6.3 percent from October 1996, to 22,830. For the first 10 months of 1997, ad pages rose 5.4 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier to 184,998.

title: INSIDE
description: A court case against three of Tawana Brawley's advisers opens with a protest. PAGE B5

title: Bowler Gets Scholarship
description: Nebraska has become the first college in the United States to give a full bowling scholarship to an athlete. Jennifer Daugherty, a junior from Bloomington, Ill., who averages 210, was the recipient.

title: For 2 States, Only Top Spot Is Acceptable In 2000 Race
description: In an early warning that interlopers better not poach on their states' outsized influence in Presidential primaries, Govs. Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire and Terry Branstad of Iowa announced today the creation of a commission to preserve the states' early contests.

title: SEAGATE WARNS OF LOWER RESULTS IN ITS SECOND QUARTER
description: Seagate Technology Inc. said after the stock markets closed yesterday that earnings in its second quarter would be below analysts' expectations because of weak demand for high-end computer disk drives and steep price declines. The company, the world's largest disk drive maker, also said that charges for restructuring and other moves were expected to exceed the range of $50 million to $100 million that it had previously estimated. It said it expected to be ''marginally profitable'' in the quarter before any charges. Analysts had been expecting earnings of 34 cents a share in the quarter. Last month, Seagate reported earnings that fell far below analysts' expectations and its stock tumbled. Earlier yesterday, its shares fell $1.0625, to $24.3125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, DEIRDRE MARIE
description: RYAN-Deirdre Marie. November 18, 1997. Beloved daughter of James V. Ryan of Fairfield, CT, formerly of Rye, NY and the late Anne M. Ryan. Beloved sister of Maureen Ryan Smith, Kevin A., Emmett F. and James J. Ryan and the late Marybeth Ryan. Mass of Resurrection to be celebrated Saturday at 10AM at Convent of the Sacred Heart, Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Department of Surgery, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021.

title: Netanyahu Going Home To a Mutiny In His Party
description: Snubbed by President Clinton in America, assailed by Arabs at a conference in Qatar, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu returns home on Wednesday to a mutiny in his Likud Party.

title: Mets Can Say So Long To Lidle and Mendoza
description: Mets officials debated for hours about whether to protect Cory Lidle from the expansion draft. On the one hand, he was small in stature and apparent talent, with no pedigree. On the other hand, Lidle had awed the Mets with his gutsy approach to pitching. No one had a strong sense of how good he really is.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Behemoth of a Building Is Set for a Tenant Influx
description: It is larger than the Empire State Building, with square footage in the millions. It straddles a major transportation hub. It was built by the Port Authority. It commands views stretching to the Statue of Liberty and beyond.

title: Restaurants; All That Intensity, in Small Bites
description: THERE are two kinds of diners: those who share and those who don't.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: A Rattler of Status Quo With Status in His Veins
description: It seems incongruous that George Strawbridge Jr., a member of an old Main Line family, a historian and the biggest individual shareholder in the Corestates Financial Corporation, has played an instrumental role in the takeover of Philadelphia's last independent banking franchise, ending a tradition that stretches back to colonial days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, JACK
description: BERKOWITZ-Jack. It is with deepest sorrow that the United Cerebral Palsy Association of Nassau County, Inc. (UCP Nassau) records the passing of Jack Berkowitz, a founder of the organization and esteemed board member. Mr. Berkowitz was active with the Spastics Society of Long Island, the predecessor of the agency. When it incorporated as UCP Nassau in 1948 he was elected treasurer and served in that capacity for nearly 30 years, remaining active on the board and key committees throughout his life. His inspired leadership guided the agency through many milestones including the opening of the Roosevelt facility, residential development and computerization. His wisdom, concern and devotion to the agency, and to those it serves, stands as a testament to his legacy. He will be sorely missed. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Clara, their daughters Judith and Susan, son-in-law Robert and grandchildren. Sidney Schwartz, Association President Robert McGuire, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOHNSON, STEPHAN PATRICK
description: JOHNSON-Stephan Patrick. July 15, 1960-November 19, 1990.

title: Saul Chaplin, 85, Songwriter Who Won 3 Academy Awards
description: Saul Chaplin, an Academy Award-winning songwriter, producer, musical director and vocal arranger who worked on more than 60 Hollywood films, died on Saturday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 85.

title: Rangers Start Trip With a Big Finish
description: Call it quibbling, but Rangers Coach Colin Campbell, noting his team's seven penalties tonight, is concerned that the team's four-game trip in five nights could present an endurance problem.

title: Market Place; Health care stocks? Some like managers of doctors' practices.
description: TAKING the plunge on a health care stock these days seems akin to bracing for a trip to the doctor. Unpleasant surprises may knock you off your feet.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: American League

title: Gunmen Take Microsoft Items in Scotland
description: Masked gunmen broke into a Microsoft plant in Scotland last week and stole an estimated 200,000 certificates of authenticity, 100,000 CD-ROM's and computer equipment, Microsoft said today.

title: The Painful Choice Faced by Wei Jingsheng
description: For Wei Jingsheng, China's best-known dissident, freedom came three days ago only after a difficult choice. He could leave his homeland and press for democracy in China from the United States, or he could continue to serve as a political martyr by enduring a series of untreated illnesses and a harsh prison life.

title: Sun Belt Suburbs Set Pace for Fastest-Growing Cities
description: Highlighting three trends continued migration to the Sun Belt, immigration from Mexico and the growth of cities that serve as nearby alternatives to traditional urban centers -- the Census Bureau today released its list of the country's fastest-growing cities.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They just liked the idea of going down the Nile. It was their dream. I tried to persuade them not to go, but my father said he could get killed just as easily at home.''

title: Strange Thing; A Vegetable Debut: Don't Let It Scare You
description: HOW a vegetable that looks part larva, part seashell, part Michelin Man will fare in the eyes of New Yorkers is yet to be seen. But the crosne (pronounced CRONE), which tastes nutty and sweet like a Jerusalem artichoke and snaps between your teeth like a water chestnut, will soon find out.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Bernie Williams to Tigers?
description: Bob Watson, the Yankees' general manager, said Monday that nobody wanted Bernie Williams, but the Detroit Tigers apparently did.
