Although Randy Smith, the Tigers' general manager, declined to name the team and the player, he apparently had worked out a deal late Monday for a Yankee outfielder who, from the description of a member of the Tigers' organization, could only have been Williams.

title: On Race, Americans Only Talk a Good Game; A Blurred Distinction
description: To the Editor:

title: Sips; A New Crop of Beers Just in Time for Winter
description: JUST as food has its seasons -- shad in the spring, venison in the fall -- so, too, does beer. Summer calls for lighter-bodied, thirst-quenching beers, or what some American brewers cheerfully call ''lawn mower'' beers, to be quaffed under the blazing sun by bare-chested men. Winter is the time for richer, heavier and sometimes spicier brews.

title: U.S. Appellate Panel Rules Ohio Ban on Late-Term Abortion Is Unconstitutional
description: Ohio's effort to ban a late-term method of abortion was declared unconstitutional today by a Federal appeals court in Cincinnati. It was the latest Federal court ruling to block state versions of the legislation that has been twice passed by Congress and twice vetoed by President Clinton.

title: Americans Uncertain on Egypt Travel
description: Despite the World Tourism Organization's statement yesterday that tourists should not be discouraged from visiting Egypt, after nearly 60 foreign tourists were killed in a shooting in Luxor on Monday, United States travelers appear uncertain.

title: Auction of Buildings Sets Off Tense Battle for a Prized Site
description: What the record will show is that on Nov. 18, 1997, a bankruptcy proceeding called ''Notice of Auction Sale of Certain Real Property at 1517-1525 Third Avenue'' was held at the Doral Court Hotel in Manhattan, soliciting a winning bid of $15 million from a company called Elk Investors.

title: 11 Injured in a Pileup In Midtown Manhattan
description: Eleven people were injured, one seriously, when a Cadillac sedan driven by an 80-year-old man struck two pedestrians and a taxicab on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan shortly after noon yesterday, setting off a chain reaction that involved several other vehicles, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUNDERLIN, SYLVIA S.
description: SUNDERLIN-Sylvia S., 86, of Washington, DC and Cambridge, NY, died November 17th at home in Cambridge. Wife of Dr. Charles Eugene Sunderlin and mother of Elizabeth, Katherine, and William Sunderlin and Molly Oakley. Author of many children's books, monthly columnist for House Beautiful magazine and contributor to other national magazines. Services on November 24, 11 AM at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Cambridge. Contributions to Cambridge Library Children's Book Fund, Cambridge, NY 12816.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, GREGORY
description: WALSH-Gregory. New York Housing Conference and Settlement Housing Fund extend deepest sympathy to Al and Nan Walsh on their loss. Clara Fox, John Kelly, Carol Lamberg

title: Laura Ashley Dismisses Its Chief Executive
description: Ann Iverson, the American turnaround specialist hired two and a half years ago to breathe life into Laura Ashley Holdings P.L.C., the clothing and home-furnishing retailer, was dismissed today as chief executive after a turbulent tenure marked by board room infighting, heavy financial losses and the forced reduction of her ambitious expansion plans.

title: The Bronx: An All-America City, Thonx
description: Sure, plenty of Manhattan residents still raise their eyebrows at the prospect of setting foot in the Bronx -- at least anywhere outside of Riverdale.

title: TEST KITCHEN
description: WITH the annual turkey cooking contest about to begin, entrants should take note: flimsy pans and imprecise measuring tools are not capable of carrying a bird to greatness, no matter how skilled the cook or how fresh and fine the bird. But not to worry: the right stuff is not far away.

title: Leave the Crystals at the Door
description: Tonight ''Scientific American Frontiers'' goes in for some debunking of what Alan Alda, our amiable host, calls ''the realm of pseudo-science.'' Given the unflattering job that the evening's investigators do on such diversions as reading palms, analyzing handwriting, dowsing for water, discovering the source of free, unlimited energy, healing people by something called a ''therapeutic touch'' and, of course, making connections with unidentified foreign objects, the program's title, ''Beyond Science?'', sounds like a compliment. The case made here is that all are far beneath science.

title: Surgical Happiness
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Might Already Have Insurance at Quarterback
description: When Glenn Foley was knocked out of their victory over the Chicago Bears on Sunday, the Jets seemed to face some drastic quarterback moves. Instead, here are the not-so-drastic things that will probably happen:

title: In New Jersey, A.M.A. Unveils National Test to Grade Doctors
description: Seeking to set national standards for physicians and patient care, the American Medical Association is offering to give doctors its seal of approval under a new nationwide accreditation program that is to begin in New Jersey.

title: Knicks Are the Cure For Rockets' Malaise
description: The beat thundering through the headphones clasped to John Starks's ears did not make him bob or sway. His stillness and stoic stare belied the music, and the lively performance he had just put on against the Houston Rockets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERCE, HENRY H., JR.
description: PIERCE-Henry H., Jr. Of Hamden, CT, died November 13, 1997.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK
description: Clark Re-signs

title: Finance Minister Dismissed In South Korea as Won Slides
description: President Kim Young-Sam of South Korea dismissed his Finance Minister, Kang Kyung-Shik, today in a move to overcome the country's economic crisis, but the announcement failed to calm financial markets as the currency fell to a new low.

title: N.B.A. Teams With Broadway to Promote All-Star Game
description: And now, New York's most unlikely promotional alliance: basketball and Broadway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUTREICH, THE HONORABLE EDWARD M.
description: BLUTREICH-The Honorable Edward M. Beloved husband for 61 years of the late Beatrice. Devoted father of Arlene Saditsky. Dear brother. Services at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Ave. and West 76 Street, N.Y.C., Thursday at 10:45AM.

title: Critics Say N.R.A. Uses Safety Campaign to Lure Children
description: Faced with a slump in gun sales and a raft of negative publicity, the National Rifle Association is trying to cultivate a new generation of gun owners by using some of the same strategies to hook children on guns that the tobacco industry has used to hook them on cigarettes, according to a new study by an anti-gun group.

title: Sports of The Times; Call This Expansion? It's a Joke!
description: IN spring training of 1962, a young pitcher named Aubrey Gatewood was trying to gain a spot with the New York Mets, an expansion team that had not yet played an official game.

title: U.S. Names Team To Face Sweden
description: Sticking with the theory that the same Davis Cup team that humbled Australia in the semifinals to get the United States into next week's final in Goteborg, Sweden, is the squad most likely to prevail in the championship round, the Davis Cup captain Tom Gullikson yesterday nominated Pete Sampras, Michael Chang, Todd Martin and Alex O'Brien to face the highly rated Swedes atop a carpet surface at the frigid Sandinavium Arena.

title: A Theatrical Building With Its Own Drama; Bright Lights, Big Hopes on 42d Street
description: A 10-story building containing rehearsal studios, workshop spaces, offices and a 199-seat theater is to rise by mid-1999 on the north side of 42d Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, the last major performing-arts site in the block's rebirth.

title: Bozell and Valvoline Split After 13 Years
description: Bozell Worldwide in New York and the Valvoline Company are parting ways after 13 years on the Valvoline account, with billings estimated at $20 million to $25 million. As a result, Valvoline placed the account in review as Bozell pursues the account of a Valvoline competitor, Quaker State motor oil, which was recently placed in review.

title: De Kooning's Abstract Women Bring Millions at an Art Auction
description: Sparks flew for only a few brief intervals at Christie's auction of contemporary art last night. But what the evening may have lacked in fireworks, it made up in strength and sensibility.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FASTENBERG, VERA
description: FASTENBERG-Vera, age 91. Beloved daughter of the late Dorrothy and Hyman Fastenberg. Sister of Eleanor Miller, Arnold, Irwin, Sanford and the late Joseph Forster. For 40 years a teacher at PS 48, the Bronx. Vera also had a profound influence on her siblings, nieces and nephews, all of whom she loved dearly. Graveside services Wednesday, November 19, 11am at Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: Off the Menu
description: Gray Kunz Returns

title: Reserved Seats at the Movies Have a Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Antiques column in Weekend on Friday about the Modernism show that ran through Sunday at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan misidentified the site of the auction house and gallery of the dealer David Rago, who took part in the show in its early years. They are in Lambertville, N.J., not Lambertville, Pa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHMAN, SANDOR
description: FISCHMAN-Sandor. The Westchester Day School family extends sincere sympathy to our esteemed Principal, Stanley Fischman, on the loss of his beloved father, Sandor Fischman. May the entire Fischman family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Elimelech Gottlieb, Headmaster David Savitsky, Chairman of the Board Caren Hammerman, President

title: CHRONICLE
description: JACKSON BROWNE, the folk-rock singer and composer, is concerned not only with the sounds produced by the guitars he plays, but also with the logging methods used to obtain the wood from which they are made.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about a study that found an increase in sea ice in Antarctic waters and a decrease in Arctic waters misidentified the journal that published the study. It was Science, not Nature.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Wine Talk; To Tame the Bird, Good Choices and a Favorite
description: THE food and wine magazines, always eager for something new, leaped on the pairing of food and wine a few years back and have often taken it to absurd lengths.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARDOS, JAMES
description: SARDOS-James on November 17, 1997. Beloved husband of Rita DeCarlo Sardos. Also survived by his father, George Sardos, his brother Christopher and sister-in-law Carol; sister-in-law Catherine White and brother-in-law Larry White; nieces and nephews George, John, June, Nancy, Lauren and Carol. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81 St., Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5:00 PM and 7-9:00 PM. Funeral mass at Blessed Sacarament Church, 152 W. 71 St., Friday, 10:00 AM. Interment to follow at Beechwoods Cemetery, New Rochelle, NY.

title: Declassified Papers Show Anti-Castro Ideas Proposed to Kennedy
description: The Pentagon offered President John F. Kennedy an extraordinary variety of dirty tricks intended to sabotage Fidel Castro, newly declassified documents show.

title: Deal by National City
description: The National City Corporation has agreed to acquire Sterling Ltd., an Ohio company that provides financial services to the very wealthy. Terms were not disclosed. National City, based in Cleveland, is a $53 billion financial services company. Sterling, based in Pepper Pike, Ohio, manages about $435 million in individual investment portfolios and limited partnerships.

title: Pataki Delivers Another Paid Speech, in Tennessee
description: Continuing a practice that has been widely criticized, Gov. George E. Pataki delivered another paid speech tonight, this one to a student group at the University of Tennessee at Knoxville, and his fee went up, to $17,000 from $15,000.

title: French Insurer's Board Backs Offer by Allianz of Germany
description: The managing board of Assurances Generales de France S.A. has endorsed a takeover offer by Allianz A.G. of Germany that values the French company at $10.4 billion, higher than an unsolicited, $9.5 billion bid by Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A. of Italy.

title: Floyd Mallory Shumway, 80, History Writer
description: Floyd Mallory Shumway, a New Haven historian and a former professor at Columbia University, died last Wednesday at Connecticut Hospice in Branford, Conn. He was 80 and lived in New Haven.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INDOVINO, PETER K.
description: INDOVINO-Peter K. in his 28th year, of Syracuse and Brooklyn, NY on November 15 in Washington, D.C. in a tragic accident. Energetic, vivacious, inspirational M.B.A. student at Syracuse University. Beloved son of Louis and Joan (nee Alice). Loving brother of Lisa Indovino Ottens and Jay. Dear brother-in-law of Jill and Paul. Marathon uncle of Emma, Nicole, Lauren and Ethan. Funeral Friday 8:30AM from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd, Brooklyn. Mass Good Shepherd RC Church 9:30AM. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. Visiting hours Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-10PM. A memorial service will be held Saturday, Nov 22, 11AM at the Poly Prep Country Day School, 9216 7th Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11228.

title: Preaching Caution, Officials Allow Air Bag Cutoff Switch
description: The Federal Government announced a new rule today that would let millions of car owners get toggle switches to shut off their air bags, but officials said the change could cost more lives than it saves.

title: In Northeast Bank Flux, Who's Next in Line?
description: By winning the battle for the Corestates Financial Corporation, the First Union Corporation will achieve more than simply expanding its presence in Pennsylvania and New Jersey. It will solidify its role as the dominant retail bank in the Northeast, positioning itself for even more acquisitions.

title: Essay; Untouchable Huang
description: Has John Huang, the Lippo banker and Clinton fund-raiser at the vortex of the campaign finance scandal, been notified that he is a target of a Federal investigation?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, FLORENCE
description: ROSENTHAL-Florence. Beloved wife of the late Randy. Mother of Bonnie and Mark Hassin and Nancy Klein. Cherished grandmother of Rick, Brett and Jason Weinstock, Randy and Jordan Hassin, Marissa and Jamie Klein. Loving great grandmother of Camen Weinstock. Services 12:30 PM, Thursday, November 20 at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: Warhol Films and Videos Are Going to 4 Institutions
description: Say the name Andy Warhol, and Campbell soup cans, Red Liz, multiple Marilyns and many other Pop images of his paintings and silk-screens come immediately to mind. But Warhol also stirred up the art world with his creative and often shocking films, videos and television programs, and today the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts plans to announce a gift intended to put those works back in the limelight.

title: Regulatory Setback For Sears of Britain
description: Britain's antitrust authority said yesterday that it would not permit the British retailer Sears P.L.C. to sell its Freemans mail order unit to a rival, dealing a blow to the retailer's reorganization plans. The proposed $:367.5 million ($624 million) sale to the Littlewoods Organization P.L.C., a closely held catalogue retailer, would ''operate against the public interest,'' the Department of Trade and Industry said.

title: To Go; Thanksgiving Dinner a Phone Call Away
description: WHY should Thanksgiving be different?

title: FIGURE SKATING ; A Lingering Foot Injury Leaves Kwan in a Cast
description: The United States' hopes for a gold medal in Olympic figure skating suffered another setback yesterday when it was announced that Michelle Kwan had sustained a stress fracture and that her left foot was placed in a cast, which could keep her off the ice for two weeks.

title: Boehringer Drafted, Then Sent to Padres
description: When Tampa Bay and Arizona staged massive raids on young pitchers in the first-round of the expansion draft yesterday, the Yankees lost a 22-year-old relief pitcher and figured that even slightly seasoned arms might be vulnerable in the following rounds. They were right right away because Tampa Bay used its first pick of the second round to draft Brian Boehringer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIS, RALPH
description: ELLIS-Ralph, 82, Chester, CT. Former V.P. of Leo Burnett, Advertising and of Brunswig Drug Company. Husband of Nancy Buell Ellis. Father of Martha Boto and Ann Bowman. Brother of Ann Symmers and four grandchildren. Donations to Asheville School, Asheville, N.C.

title: Copper Drops on Fears of Excess Supplies
description: Copper prices fell 3.6 percent yesterday, dropping to the lowest level in more than a year, as output is rising at a time of weaker demand, particularly from Asia.

title: David Ignatow Is Dead at 83; Poet Wrote of Ordinary Life
description: David Ignatow, whose clear, direct, seemingly effortless verse won him one of poetry's highest honors, the Bollingen Prize, in 1977, died on Monday at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 83.

title: Metro Business; Real Estate Databases
description: RE/Locate, a Manhattan company that provides electronic databases on the commercial real estate industry, has signed an agreement to do research for and supply electronic information to Black's Guide, a publisher of commercial real estate directories, the companies have said.

title: TV Notes; Renewing Mickey
description: On Mickey Mouse's 69th birthday yesterday, the Walt Disney Company announced it would begin producing a new cartoon series of the famous mouse -- and his pals Minnie Mouse, Donald Duck, Daisy, Goofy and Pluto -- for the first time in more than 40 years. The new cartoon series, to be called ''Mouseworks,'' is not expected to be ready until early 1999, and the company hasn't decided how or where to distribute it. LAWRIE MIFFLIN

title: TV Notes; 'X-Files' Tries Frankenstein
description: ''The X-Files'' is already the programming monster of Sunday night television; now the series is turning to Frankenstein.

title: Officials Show Bomb Parts In Atlanta
description: Still stymied in their investigation of a series of three Atlanta bombings that began 16 months ago, law-enforcement officials today made an unusual disclosure of details about the components of the bombs, hoping to shake the memory of a sales clerk or someone who knows the bomber.

title: From Carrier Nimitz, F-14 Tomcats Ride Shotgun for the U-2
description: At 10:15 this morning, Lieut. J. J. Cummings vaulted off the stubby deck of this aircraft carrier in his screaming F-14 Tomcat, heading for Iraq with rockets and missiles to escort the first United Nations U-2 weapons inspection flight in eight days.

title: Lakers Remain Undefeated
description: LAKERS 97, JAZZ 92

title: Unknowns Are Drafted as the Famous Are Traded
description: While name after virtually unrecognizable name went up on the Arizona and Tampa Bay boards in the expansion draft today, six well-known names, including Devon White and Robb Nen of the dismantling Florida Marlins, were traded in an unprecedented orgy of deals. When the weeklong moratorium on trades was lifted as soon as the draft ended, a stunning series of deals-in-waiting was announced in rapid order:

title: Band-Aids, Not Cake, Would Help Ease Pain for Nets
description: The Nets brought out a birthday cake today for Sam Cassell at the conclusion of a long, arduous practice session at Ramapo College. But Cassell, who has taken his meals through an intravenous needle for the past five days while fighting the flu, waved his slice off, choosing to continue to work on his shooting and await his first real meal later in the day.

title: PCD TO ACQUIRE SIEBE ELECTRONICS UNIT FOR $130 MILLION
description: PCD Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Wells Electronics unit from the British engineering company Siebe P.L.C. for about $130 million in cash. Wells makes equipment used to test semiconductor chips for defects. It is based in South Bend, Ind., and has manufacturing plants in Lewisberry, Pa. PCD, with headquarters in Peabody, Mass., makes a range of electronic connectors for the semiconductor, industrial equipment and aviation industries. Its stock rose $1.125 a share yesterday, to $24.875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIGGINS, EDWARD M.
description: HIGGINS-Edward M. Survived by his wife Margaret (Canny); sister Rita Tiedemann; children Edward, Clare, Ellen and Daniel; and grandchildren. Hours: Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Funeral Mass: Sacred Heart Church, Thursday 10 A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, MONROE THOMAS, M.D.
description: DIAMOND - Monroe Thomas, M.D., age 80, of Chilmark, MA, formerly of Chappaqua, N.Y. On November 14, 1997. Beloved husband of Rhoda; adored father of John, of Tiburon, CA; Ginnie, of McLean, VA; and Paul, of Charlottesville, VA. Loving grandfather of Danny Diamond; Robby, Rachel and Jacob Bensinger; and Jeffrey and Will Diamond. Memorial service to be held on Sunday, December 14, 1997, at 1:30 PM, at Temple Beth El of Northern Westchester in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: A Chorus of Silence From China's Few Dissenters
description: Inside an ash-gray apartment block, up a stairway made narrow by stacks of winter cabbage, a gray-haired veteran of China's dissident movement held a finger to his lips as he opened the front door, silencing a visitor until the door was safely closed, the shades drawn and tea served.

title: Too Many Trees Are Falling
description: The only trouble with the movement for the preservation of our forests,'' Theodore Roosevelt noted in 1908, ''is that it has not gone nearly far enough.'' That is still the problem today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENTMACHER, PAUL SIDNEY
description: ENTMACHER-Paul Sidney. On Nov. 18 at home. Cherished husband of Viola. Adored father of Dr. Susan Entmacher. Loving fatherin-law of Dennis Dunn. Loving brother of Stanley and Jack. Services Thursday, 12 noon at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd., Manhasset. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Center for Extended Care and Rehabilitation of North Shore Univ. Hospital, 330 Community Dr, Manhasset, NY, Attn: Dr. Arthur Feinberg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DERIVAN, ELAINE F.
description: DeRIVAN-Elaine F. On November 17, 1997 of Selden, Long Island. Beloved by all. Elaine is survived by Robert DeRivan, Rose Gould, Peter Ciaccio, three nieces, one nephew, two great nephews, one great niece and her beloved pets, Stephanie and China. Ms. DeRivan was an assistant Vice President for Royal Alliance Associates Inc, NY., Reposing at O.B. Davis Funeral Homes, 4839 Nesconset Hwy (347) Port Jefferson Station, L.I. Visitation Thursday and Friday, 2-4 and 7-10PM. Mass Saturday 10AM St. Louis de Montfort RC Church. Entombment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORAN, JAMES J.
description: DORAN-James J. Of Staten Island on November 15, 1997. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Loving father of Erin Reid, Brian, Eileen and James J. Doran, Jr. Dear brother of Ann Tuff, Timothy and the late William and John Doran, Joseph and Anthony Konczynski and the late Walter Konczynski. Funeral from Casey Funeral Home, 350 Slosson Avenue, Staten Island on Friday. Mass of Christian Burial Blessed Sacrament Church 10AM. Interment St. Peter's Cemetery. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the SI Center for Independent Living, 470 Castleton Avenue, SI 10301 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, WALTER B. W.
description: WILSON-Walter B. W. A memorial service for Walter B. W. Wilson, who died on November 14, will be held at 1:30 PM on Sunday, November 23, at The Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 E. 90th St, NY. A reception will follow at the House of the Redeemer, 7 E. 95th St. An alternate service will be held at 1:30 PM on Saturday, November 29, at Trinity Church, 11 Mercer St., Princeton, NJ. Private interment.

title: China Feels the Pressure
description: To the Editor:

title: In Graphic Simulation, F.B.I. Tries to Show Jet's Fiery End
description: Sixteen months after an explosion blew apart Trans World Airlines Flight 800, the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday provided an unusual public explanation of how it had become convinced that the crash was not the result of sabotage.

title: In Afghan Refugee Camp, Albright Hammers Taliban
description: Speaking to Afghan refugees here, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright today issued her harshest criticism of the Taliban movement that rules most of Afghanistan, calling its treatment of women and children ''despicable.''

title: Wash Up: Big Brother Is Now in the Bathroom
description: SIGNS in restaurant bathrooms reminding employees to wash their hands may one day be obsolete. When workers wear a new electronically controlled badge, the choice will be clear: wash up, or the company's computer will get you.

title: Illegal Iraqi Oil Shipments Increase, U.S. Says
description: Senior officials of the United States Navy and State Department told a Security Council sanctions committee today that Iraq's illegal exports of oil through the coastal waters of the Persian Gulf have jumped 500 percent in the last year.

title: Aid to Needy Schools May Grow, Official Says
description: The State Education Commissioner left open the possibility yesterday that New Jersey's poorest school districts may be able to receive an increase in state aid to use for programs for disadvantaged students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANCUSO, ANTHONY E.
description: MANCUSO-Anthony E. On November 17, 1997. Beloved husband of Rose (nee Ingrassia), devoted father of Peter and John, loving grandfather of eight. Devoted brother of Joseph, Rosario, Philip, Connie Curro and the late Adolph and Rose DeVito. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 345 Ave U, Brooklyn, NY Wed. and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-10PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Our Lady of Grace RC Church, Friday, 10:15 AM. Interment Resurrection Cemetery, Staten Island, NY.

title: Quixotic Quest to Invent A Different Car Engine Fails
description: After four years and $24 million, the brothers Ben and Harold Rosen -- one a successful venture capitalist and the other a celebrated rocket scientist -- are abandoning a quixotic quest to remake the automobile industry.

title: New Atlantic City Hotel Offers Only Its Rooms
description: The first new gambling-free hotel in 10 years in Atlantic City opened for business yesterday. Aimed at conventiongoers and families, the $79 million 16-story Sheraton Atlantic City has 502 rooms and is linked by a skywalk to the new Atlantic City Convention Center, said Bush Bell, the general manager.

title: Police Copters Scan Property Of Landlord
description: Police investigators looking into the mysterious disappearances of a Manhattan couple and their landlord used helicopters yesterday to search for evidence on the landlord's Orange County property after his family stopped cooperating in the case and refused to let officers conduct a search.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARREL, DOROTHY
description: SARREL-Dorothy, 90 years. Beloved wife of Arthur. Loving mother of Kenneth, Eileen and Stan Rosenberg. Devoted grandmother of Lynn and Laura. Admired aunt. Life member of the Order of the Eastern Star. Services Wednesday, 11AM, at ''Schwartz BrothersJeffer Memorial Chapels'', 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY.

title: On Race, Americans Only Talk a Good Game; Goldwater Red Herring
description: To the Editor:

title: Breeding Seeds of Discontent; Cotton Growers Say Strain Cuts Yields
description: One year ago, Rodney Garrison was a true believer in a breakthrough cotton strain that had been genetically engineered to resist spraying with the Monsanto Company's Roundup weed killer. ''Roundup Ready cotton is going to be as revolutionary to the cotton industry as the cotton picker,'' he proclaimed under a grinning photograph in a corporate brochure.

title: About New York; Having to Park In Manhattan Is a Handicap
description: AUTO auction commercials make Joshua Prager feel a little edgy. Those frenzied late-night television come-ons for deals on unclaimed cars send a twinge of fear and anticipation through him. His 1990 Lexus ES 250 vanished from its curbside spot near the World Financial Center last month, so he wonders if one night he'll see it -- the one with the moccasin dangling from the rear-view mirror -- while flipping channels.

title: Topics of The Times; The Democrats Head Home
description: Talk about a party with the getting-out-of-town blues. The Clinton-Gore campaign spent all the Democrats' money. Hopes for retaking the House and the Senate in 1998 look dim, and that was before the wave of retirements among senior members of Congress. The latest to announce plans to go home are Representatives Ronald V. Dellums and Vic Fazio. Both said they wanted to spend more time with their families, but the unstated message was that it is the Democratic family that needs help.

title: FIRST CHICAGO TO BUY DETROIT BROKER FOR $95 MILLION
description: The First Chicago NBD Corporation, the eighth-largest United States bank, said it had agreed to acquire Roney & Company, a regional brokerage firm based in Detroit, for $95 million in cash to expand its securities business. Roney's 500 brokers sell stock, bonds and other investments to 300,000 customers in Michigan, Indiana and Ohio. First Chicago said it would keep the Roney name. First Chicago also said it had formed a partnership with the Tokio Marine and Fire Insurance Company of Japan to sell derivatives and other products for companies in Asia. First Chicago, with $113 billion in total assets, serves three million households in Michigan, Indiana and Illinois.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about reports of killings of captive Taliban fighters in northern Afghanistan referred incorrectly to the superior of an international official in that country. The ''general'' cited, who is represented by Lakhdar Brahimi, a former Algerian Foreign Minister, is the Secretary General of the United Nations -- not Gen. Rashid Dostum, an Afghan warlord.

title: Arkansas Gun Collector Tells Bombing Jury About Robbery
description: An Arkansas gun collector told a Federal District Court jury today how he was robbed by a man who carried a shotgun, wore a black ski mask, and bound him with duct tape before taking dozens of guns, cash, gold and silver coins, pieces of jade and semi-precious stones.

title: TRIBUNE TO ACQUIRE 80.5% STAKE IN CHILDREN'S PUBLISHER
description: The Tribune Company of Chicago agreed yesterday to buy 80.5 percent of the mass-market children's publisher Landoll Inc. for about $80 million. Landoll's chairman, James Landoll, and its president, Martin Myers, will keep the remaining 19.5 percent of the company and will continue to manage the company's headquarters in Ashland, Ohio. The Tribune's Tribune Education unit, which is the acquiring company, has the right to buy the rest of Landoll later. Landoll, which is closely held, sells education books, activity books, storybooks and educational puzzles to retailers like Kmart, Wal-Mart and Target.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ULTRAMAR DIAMOND SHAMROCK CORP., Greenwich, Conn., said it planned to sell a stake in a 408-mile Texas pipeline to a subsidiary of Phillips Petroleum. Terms were not disclosed.

title: In Latvia, the First Token of Swiss Remorse: $400
description: Reva Shefer woke before dawn this morning. She put on her special outfit -- a plaid tartan suit -- and black orthopedic shoes. Then she and her husband rode to the Jewish Community Center, where she became the first person to receive a check for $400 from Switzerland for any suffering she might have endured during the Holocaust.

title: Metro Business; For American Chain, Its First U.S. Store
description: Gant, the men's and boys' clothing retailer, will open its first store in the United States tomorrow, at 645 Fifth Avenue, near 51st Street, in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABERMAN, MAURICE
description: HABERMAN-Maurice. Beloved husband of Eve. Proud father of Jeffrey and Mitchell. Adoring grandfather of Stephanie, David, Jordan, Joshua and Alex. Loving brother of Paul Haberman and Barbara Carter. Funeral services Wednesday, November 19th, 12 noon, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUNES, DONALD
description: NUNES-Donald. Died in Bath, England, on Tuesday, November 11, after courageous battle with cancer. Son of Kenneth and Helen Nunes, husband of Ann Biddick Nunes, father of Becky and Jonathan. Don was inspirational, much loved and irreplaceable. A celebration of his life will take place in Lacock Church, Wiltshire, at 2 PM on Monday, November 24. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Don Nunes Memorial Scholarship Fund, C/O Advanced Studies in England, 2 Pierrepont Street, Bath BA1 1LB, England.

title: From Sonnets to Ransom Notes; Shakespeare Sleuth Helps Police in Literary Detection
description: You are what you write. At least, that's how Donald W. Foster sees it.

title: NBC Rivals Look to Times Square In Quest for Studio Space on Street
description: Hoping for some of the street-theater vitality and ratings adrenaline NBC's ''Today'' show got from its curbside studio in Rockefeller Center, ABC and CBS are shopping for studio space in the newly revitalized Times Square, network and real estate executives said yesterday.

title: Beware the Greens
description: To the Editor:

title: Morally Sightless, a Writer Loses His Words as Well
description: The actress in the black wig and dowdy nightgown looks vaguely familiar -- with the streak of silver in her hair and the song of the South in her drawl, she could pass for the younger sister of Virginia Kelley, President Clinton's mother. Hold on a sec. Could that be . . . Judith Ivey?

title: CHRONICLE
description: About four years ago, JOEL SOLER, 30, a former journalist for French television, decided it was time to assemble a multimedia exhibition of the 1,000 most important women of past and present to serve as role models.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEDELSON, ABRAHAM
description: SCHWEDELSON - Abraham on November 18, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Pauline. Devoted father of Roy and Marc. Cherished grandfather of Robert, Matthew, Jay, Sara, Jodi and Paul. Services 1:30 on Wednesday at ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', 114-03 Queens Blvd, (76 Road), Forest Hills, NY.

title: Rain Is a New Agony for Somalia, As Villages Are Suddenly Islands
description: From the air, the place where the Juba River used to run is just a serpentine current threading through vast tracts of swamped fields and newly formed lakes. Alongside the turgid current, the roofs of villages peak out in clusters above the gray waters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREISTER, MELVIN
description: TREISTER-Melvin. On November 18, 1997. Beloved husband of Loretta, devoted father of Shelley Claar. Loving grandfather of Jamie and Courtney. Services private.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Benefits column of Sunday Styles this week about a screening of ''The Imax Nutcracker'' at the Sony Imax Theater, to help the Foundation for Treatment of Children With AIDS, misstated the date, and the price of adult tickets at the door. The event is tomorrow, not Friday. Tickets are $125, not $100. For information: (212) 734-5400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULMAN, SHIRLEY
description: SCHULMAN-Shirley. On November 17, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Henry. Devoted mother of Mortimer and the late Marilyn Kaufman. Dear mother-in-law of Thelma. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Graveside services Wednesday at 11 AM at New Montefiore Cemetery, Long Island.

title: Topics of The Times; When to Unplug The Air Bag
description: Just because the Federal Government has decided to allow drivers to install switches to deactivate their air bags does not mean that doing so is a good idea. The vast majority of riders are safer with a functioning air bag in the event of a crash than without one. More than 2,600 lives have been saved by the bags, and of the 87 people killed by air bag deployment, most were not wearing seat belts.

title: Newark Waterfront Park Denied Landmark Status
description: State officials dealt a blow to community groups in Newark on Monday by declining to confer historic landmark status on a cherished waterfront park that was once proposed as the site for a minor league baseball stadium.

title: Virtuosic Workout for Sarah Chang
description: Sarah Chang, at 16, has already established her credentials on an international scale. New York audiences have heard her play concertos in recent seasons, but it was not until Sunday afternoon that she presented a recital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAPPER, MURRAY
description: KLAPPER-Murray, of New York City and Boca Raton, FL, died November 17, 1997. Loving husband and companion of Connie Klapper. A wonderful father to Janis Kerbs of Mattituck, NY, and Steven Klapper of Madison, WI. Former owner of Oxford Neckwear of NYC. Will be remembered for his wit, charm and devotion to family. A remembrance will take place Wednesday, November 19, 1997, at his home in Boca Raton.

title: Swedish Match Pulls Away
description: After seeing the last boats in the fleet wipe 200 miles off her lead in 48 hours, Swedish Match was again dominating the second leg of the Whitbread Round the World Race yesterday as the fleet continued through the Indian Ocean en route to Fremantle, Australia.

title: N.F.L.: ROUNDUP
description: Police Talk To Bledsoe

title: Japan Fears Push Bonds Slightly Lower
description: Prices for Treasury securities slipped slightly yesterday, hurt by talk in the market of Japanese selling but buoyed by a Government report showing that consumer prices rose only mildly last month.

title: Robert S. Kane, 72, Writer of Travel Guide Series
description: Robert S. Kane, a travel writer and creator of the ''A to Z'' and ''World at Its Best'' series of guides, died on Nov. 10 at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 72.

title: Devils Dominate Game, But Brodeur Saves It
description: The Devils entered tonight's game with a six-game winning streak and the best winning percentage in the National Hockey League. The Calgary Flames arrived on an eight-game stretch without a victory and the second-worst winning percentage.

title: New Yorkers Tell Congressmen of Suffering They Attribute to Police
description: Mothers spoke about losing sons, sisters about losing brothers. For hours, the stage of Medgar Evers College in Crown Heights was given over to a sort of speak-out on police brutality, convened by a member of Congress, that was part memorial service, part Congressional hearing, part political rally.

title: City Opera's 'Boheme' Returns With a New Mimi
description: In its quest for a balance between directorial trendiness and solid, traditional stagings, the New York City Opera has been letting its directors experiment with new works and curiosities, but has stuck to the basics in works that are likely to have long shelf lives. Graziella Sciutti's 1995 staging of ''La Boheme,'' which returned to the New York State Theater on Saturday evening, has the warmth and intimacy that this Puccini classic needs to work its manipulative magic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORANT, STEFAN
description: LORANT-Stefan. The brilliant and legendary life of the pioneer editor of photographic publications ended at age 96. His influence on the century's development of visual communications remains inestimable. We all owe him a great debt. Willis Hartshorn Cornell Capa Int'l Center of Photography

title: Foreman Blocks the Way as Briggs Moves Up
description: With new medication to treat his asthma and a dairy-free diet, Shannon Briggs is feeling like a new man, and he can't wait to get in the ring with George Foreman on Saturday night to prove it.

title: Civil War Novelist Wins the National Book Award
description: In a year that saw the publication of several big new novels by major American writers, a first novel about the Civil War that had seemed to come out of nowhere onto the best seller lists, ''Cold Mountain,'' by Charles Frazier, won the 1997 National Book Award for fiction last night. The awards were announced at a ceremony at the New York Marriott Marquis Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Islanders Running Low on Defensemen
description: When the Islanders play the Stanley Cup champion Detroit Red Wings on Wednesday, they will be without half their regular defensemen as they face the best offensive team in the National Hockey League.

title: With Woods Worn Out, Els Tops Major Winners
description: Maybe it was all the travel. Maybe it was the cold he picked up during a lucrative series of skins games and other events in Japan recently. Or maybe it was a combination of the two.

title: UConn Sees Support Faltering For a New Football Stadium
description: Two years ago, when the University of Connecticut men's and women's basketball teams visited the Capitol, legislators greeted them wildly, crowding around for autographs. The school's president later attributed the state's decision to give the university $1 billion for renovations to the ''Huskymania'' generated by the top-ranked basketball teams.

title: Delay of Election Is Sought To Allow for Hoffa Inquiry
description: A day after a court official barred the teamsters' president, Ron Carey, from running for re-election next March, another court-appointed monitor said yesterday that she would seek a postponement of the election to allow more time to investigate the campaign finances of Mr. Carey's rival, James P. Hoffa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TILLMAN, MORTON
description: TILLMAN-Morton. Beloved husband of Susan. Loving father of Pamela and the late Jonathan. Cherished son of Evelyn Silver and son-in-law of Sylvia and David Sverd.

title: 2d Inquiry May Slow Teamsters' Election
description: A court-appointed election monitor is seeking to postpone the teamsters union's election to allow more time for an investigation of the campaign finances of the chief rival of the president, Ron Carey, a day after he was banned from running for re-election. Since it raised the possibility that the rival, James P. Hoffa, could be disqualified, the request drew applause from Mr. Carey's supporters.

title: At Ancient Site Along the Nile, Modern Horror
description: In the Middle Court of the Temple of Hatsepshut today, piles of newly strewn sand could not disguise the plain fact that a structure dating from before 1400 B.C. had become a late 20th century slaughterhouse.

title: Smith Barney Plaintiffs Agree To Incentives For Settlement
description: Twenty-three of the 25 women who had sued Smith Barney Inc. for sexual harassment and bias are to collect ''incentives'' ranging from $20,000 to $150,000, atop whatever else they may ultimately win, for agreeing to submit their disputes to panels of professional mediators paid for by the big Wall Street firm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLOMB, LOUIS
description: GOLOMB-Louis. Teacher, writer, humanitarian, champion of lost causes and of underdogs. Loving husband of Lillian; father of Elan; brother of Irving; uncle of Norma, Jolie Beth and Abby; great-uncle of Robert, Alex, Caitlin, Hannah and Adam.

title: Transit Manager's Sexism Suit to Be Tried
description: In 1993, several days after Diane Leibovitz, a manager at a New York City Transit subway car maintenance shop, complained that several female workers were being harassed by a male manager at the shop, her annual evaluation was downgraded from ''good'' to ''marginal,'' according to court papers.

title: Catholic Bishops Say Immigrants Are Harassed
description: The state's 17 Roman Catholic bishops accused the Immigration and Naturalization Service yesterday of conducting an inhumane crackdown on immigrants in New Jersey. As evidence of the crackdown, the bishops cited figures showing that 879 people were deported from New Jersey in the 12 months ending Sept. 30, compared to 174 during the same period the year before, said Regina Purcell, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Catholic Conference, a policy making body made up of bishops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARTSIS, MILDRED STORCH
description: ARTSIS-Mildred Storch. Of Great Neck, N.Y. and Boynton Beach, FL. Died November 17, 1997. Loving and devoted wife of the late Jerome M. Artsis; beloved mother of Leslie Artsis Adams of West Palm Beach, FL., and Steven M. Artsis of New York City. Adored grandmother of Michael Artsis. Caring sister and sister-in-law of Clifford and Doris Storch of Lake Worth, FL., and Shirley and Arnold Friedman of Roslyn, N.Y. Favorite aunt to Marilyn and Bob Schoenberger; Adele and Neil Bayer; Dana and Ira Effron; Cherie and Bruce Bramley; Loren and Robert Gelber; Jeffrey and Joan Grossman; Stephanie and Kenny Lichtman; Sally Storch Cooney; and Sam and Robin Storch. Mother-inlaw to Doris Mele, Glenda Artsis, and Kathryn Scott. Devoted fiancee to Alan Brandt of Great Neck, N.Y. and Boca Raton, FL. Gracious and elegant, this beautiful dignified lady inspired us all through her great courage, sense of humor and zest for life. Considerate, kind and generous, she was always there for her family and friends. A contributor to multiple charities, she served as a past-president of Womens American Ort, Great Neck Chapter. Mildred, we will remember and miss you forever. You will always be in our hearts. Funeral services will take place Wednesday, November 19, 1997, at 9:30 AM, at Temple Beth-El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, N.Y. A memorial service to be announced, will be held at Temple Emanuel in Palm Beach, FL. Contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Lemieux Scores 3
description: Capitals 6, Avalanche 6

title: WACHOVIA AGREES TO A $71 MILLION DEAL FOR AMERIBANK
description: The Wachovia Corporation of Winston-Salem, N.C., agreed yesterday to buy Ameribank Bancshares of Hollywood, Fla., for $71 million in stock. Ameribank shares are privately traded. Last week, Wachovia completed its $222 million purchase of 1st United Bancorp of Boca Raton, Fla . Ameribank will be merged into 1st United. That merger, combined with Wachovia's mergers with Central Fidelity Banks in Richmond and Jefferson Bankshares in Charlottesville, Va., would give Wachovia a retail network of more than 750 banking offices and 1,200 banking machines throughout Virginia, the Carolinas, Georgia and Florida. The mergers would also make Wachovia the 18th-largest bank in the country, with assets of more than $60 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUR, REBECCA (RITA)
description: SCHUR-Rebecca (Rita). Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Cherished mother of Elaine Batchker and Harvey Schur. Loving grandmother of Craig Batchker and Margot Shaw. Great-grandmother of five. Dear sister of Jack Cohen. Services Wednesday, 10 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: Daiwa Securities Indicted Along With 3 Ex-Officers
description: Prosecutors in Tokyo indicted the Daiwa Securities Company, Japan's second-largest brokerage firm, and three of its former executives yesterday on charges that they had paid off a corporate racketeer. The three indicted were Nobuhiro Kaneda, 54, former head of the equity department; Naoyoshi Kito, 60, a former manager of the general affairs department, and Yasuo Terashima, 61, the former head of the general affairs department.

title: Young Talent From Russia
description: It ain't over until the Russians run out of dancers, as Yogi Berra might have said after an unexpectedly fine program on Monday that introduced an entire new generation from the Bolshoi and the Kirov.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: Scene: Friday night on an M-66 crosstown bus.

title: The Chef
description: AS the holiday season begins, two of the dishes I've been refining over the years strike me as especially festive, one with a brilliant orange-colored sauce and the other with a shimmering green one.

title: Tarnished Knight of a Revived Labor Movement
description: Soon after Ron Carey won the teamsters' presidency in 1991, he was being hailed as labor's Mr. Clean -- a reformer who took on a union famous for Mafia muscle, looted pension funds and mysterious disappearances of men and merchandise.

title: Critic's Notebook; Altering Reality: Potential for Evil, the Power to Sell
description: ''One night in 1984, I made my way up Kirov Street, which was ill-lit even by Moscow standards, to the studio of Aleksandr Rodchenko,'' David King writes in the introduction to his book ''The Commissar Vanishes: The Falsification of Photographs and Art in Stalin's Russia.'' Mr. King continues, ''I began the long climb up.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEVASTOPOULO, ELISABETH
description: SEVASTOPOULO-Elisabeth. Died on Thursday, November 18 at the home of her daughter and son-in-law in Mauchline, Ayrshire, Scotland. She was born Princess Cantacuzene, Countess Speransky in 1911 in St. Petersburg, Russia. Elisabeth Sevastopoulo is survived by her son, Dimitri Sevastopoulo, her daughter, Viscountess Weir, two grandsons, Andrew Weir and Marc Sevastopoulo, and her brother, Prince Michel Cantacuzene, Count Speransky. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, December 4th at 6:30 PM at St. Nicholas Cathedral, 17 East 97th Street in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to: The Tolstoy Foundation, 104 Lake Road, Valley Cottage, NY 10989.

title: For Many Physicians, E-Mail Is the High-Tech House Call
description: Dr. Leonard Wexler, a pediatric oncologist, struggled to comfort Helen and David Eisman, aching from the loss of their 19-year-old son, Jonathan, who died earlier this year of a rare form of cancer.

title: Economic Scene; One world, one economy, one big problem with currencies.
description: THE global economy is here, and the consequences can be unnerving. Currency after currency has come under pressure in recent months as investors, fearing that their assets would erode in value, converted their holdings into dollars.

title: Atlantic City Man Is Charged in Robberies
description: A 28-year-old Atlantic City man was arrested at the Showboat Casino Hotel Tuesday and charged with robbing at least seven elderly women within the last two months, the police said.

title: Power Jeopardy!
description: Studio Announcer: ''His movies include 'Natural Born Killers' and 'J.F.K.' He's the master of the paranoid style in modern-day movie-making -- meet Oliver Stone!

title: TEXAS PACIFIC LOWERS ITS BID FOR ZILOG TO $421.6 MILLION
description: Zilog Inc. said yesterday that Texas Pacific Group had cut its offer to buy the maker of computer chips by 20 percent, to $421.6 million, or $20 a share, from $527 million, or $25 a share, because of a decline in sales and earnings at Zilog. Texas Pacific said it expected fourth-quarter sales and profits at Zilog to fall below its third-quarter performance. Zilog earned $2 million, or 10 cents a share, in the third quarter. Shares of Zilog, based in Campbell, Calif., were unchanged at $19.1875 yesterday. Texas Pacific, based in Fort Worth, is a private investment group led by the financier David Bonderman.

title: FINANCIER-LED GROUP OFFERS TO BUY REST OF TELEMUNDO
description: A group led by the financier Leon Black said yesterday that it had offered to buy the 60 percent of the Spanish-language TV network Telemundo Group Inc. that it does not own. Mr. Black and TLMD Partners II L.L.C. said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that they had sent their offer to the investment bank Lazard Freres & Company. Telemundo hired the bank earlier this year to help it pursue discussions with potential partners. Telemundo, which is based in Miami, owns and operates stations and affiliates in 60 markets. Shares of Telemundo rose $1.9375, to $38.8125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: The Last Suspect Is Arrested In a Princeton Bank Robbery
description: Acting on a tip from inspectors of the Postal Service, a task force arrested the last suspect today from the bold and bloody Nov. 6 bank robbery in downtown Princeton.

title: Addiction Addicts
description: Many of my friends have recently become addicts. They have not taken up some new drug or habit. They're doing the same thing they have been doing for years. They smoke.

title: TV's Darling, the Stock Market in a Go-Go Mood
description: Every so often, distracted by war or social reform or natural disaster, America forgets, as Calvin Coolidge instructed us, that its chief business is business. But then the fundamentals, as the analysts call them, reassert themselves, and the nation goes back to dollars and cents. With about half the populace playing, pardon, investing, in the stock market, never have so many been so infatuated with business ups and downs, and naturally television feeds the phenomenon even while reporting on it.

title: On Sidewalk, Fatal Collision With Bicyclist
description: A fast-food deliveryman who was riding his bicycle on the sidewalk on the Upper West Side on Tuesday night struck and killed a 68-year-old businessman who was leaving a restaurant, the police said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ELEANOR LAMBERT, the doyenne of fashion publicity who organized the Council of Fashion Designers in 1962, will be honored by the High School of Fashion Industries at a dinner tonight at the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers on Seventh Avenue.

title: Hapless Lightning Trounces Rangers
description: Sizing up the opposition and the schedule, Coach Colin Campbell concluded tonight that this would be a nice spot for the Rangers to use the backup goalie Jason Muzzatti.

title: Colleges Did Jews No Favor of Exclusion ; Faith on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a conservative group's distribution of a videotape that featured four Republican senators talking about ''judicial activism'' reversed two senators' comments about their awareness of the uses of the tape. Senator James Inhofe of Oklahoma said he had been aware that the group, the Free Congress Foundation, would use it to raise money; Senator Robert Smith of New Hampshire said he did not know of its fund-raising purpose.

title: Mantle's Memorabilia Source of Estate Battle
description: Lawyers for Mickey Mantle's estate are battling with his former agent over her right to sell personal items like the late Yankee's neck brace, bathing suits, worn socks, flip-flops, golf shoes, letters, expired credit cards and sweaters at a memorabilia auction Saturday in Manhattan.

title: Estee Lauder Is Acquiring Maker of Natural Cosmetics
description: Continuing an aggressive shopping spree intended to strengthen its position as a diversified producer of powders and perfumes, the Estee Lauder Companies said yesterday that it would buy the Aveda Corporation for $300 million in cash.

title: Good Golly, Miss Mali: A World Music Superstar
description: Oumou Sangare began her performance Sunday night at Symphony Space wearing the traditional garb of her native Mali, her head adorned with a carefully knotted brown sash. Soon the singer's unbridled gestures loosed the fussy headdress, and impatiently she wrapped it around her waist, letting her long braids fly. When she lifted her skirts, Ms. Sangare showed her contemporary side: shiny bronze pumps and a black slip lined with scalloped French lace.

title: Freshman Sparkles For UConn
description: The freshman Khalid El-Amin had 23 points and Jake Voskuhl added 15 points and 14 rebounds to lead No. 12 Connecticut to an 80-67 victory over No. 20 Rhode Island last night in the quarterfinals of the Preseason N.I.T.

title: INSIDE
description: Calls to reconsider a foreign language measure for schools. PAGE B3

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a refusal by Congress to appropriate funds for United Nations dues and the International Monetary Fund confused two I.M.F. loan programs in some copies. The new program is called the New Arrangements to Borrow. (The General Agreement to Borrow is an older program.)

title: Colleges Did Jews No Favor of Exclusion
description: To the Editor:

title: N.H.L. vs. the Olympics
description: Devils goalie Martin Brodeur, a likely member of Team Canada, can understand the support that players who will be members of the United States Olympic hockey team showed for Bill Guerin, threatening to boycott the 1998 Winter Games in Japan. But just because he understands does not mean he agrees with them.

title: TOTAL RENAL CARE IN $1.1 BILLION DEAL FOR RIVAL
description: Total Renal Care Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Renal Treatment Centers Inc. for $1.1 billion in stock, almost doubling the size of one of the nation's largest operators of dialysis centers. Adding Renal Treatment, based in Berwyn, Pa., will give Total Renal 358 centers serving 25,900 patients. Under the agreement, Total Renal said it would exchange 1.335 shares of its stock for each share of Renal Treatment. The transaction values Renal Treatment at $41.55 a share, based on Total Renal's closing price of $31.125 a share on Tuesday. The offer represents a premium of 15.4 percent to Renal Treatment's closing price of $36 a share yesterday. Shares of Total Renal, which is based in Torrance., Calif., fell $3.3125, to $27.8125.

title: Securities Firm Chief to Be Priest
description: The head of a major securities firm is resigning to study for the Roman Catholic priesthood.

title: Race Panel Excludes Critics of Affirmative Action Plans
description: President Clinton's advisory panel on race held a hearing today on how to achieve diversity on college campuses but chose not to solicit the views of opponents of affirmative action.

title: Search Blocked In Case of 3 Who Vanished
description: Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau turned down a police request yesterday for a warrant to search the upstate property of the missing landlord of two downtown loft dwellers who disappeared almost two weeks ago. Mr. Morgenthau said there was not yet probable cause to justify the search.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLKIND, SYLVIA
description: WOLKIND-Sylvia. A woman who loved her family above all else, loved life and would make a detour anytime, anywhere to play golf at some wonderful course she had not yet seen (and there weren't too many of those) had a sudden, tragic end. She was truly a woman of valor. Those fortunate to know her will never forget her. A great loss to her husband of fifty-nine years Murray Wolkind, son Richard Wolkind, daughter Dale Kramer, daughter-in-law Marta Wolkind, son-in-law Stephen Kramer and grandson Bryan Wolkind. Goodbye Sylvia. Services will be held Thursday, November 20th, 12:30PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue, New York.

title: Up to 3,000 Jobs May Be at Stake in Latest First Union Deal
description: The First Union Corporation and the Corestates Financial Corporation disclosed further details yesterday about their pending $17.1 billion merger, but still declined to quantify the number of layoffs the deal would entail.

title: Currents; THE SURREAL ON SCREEN -- In the World of the Imagination
description: A weekend of surreal cinema starts tomorrow at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center. It features Jan Svankmajer, a Czech animation artist who is a modern Lewis Carroll. In his imagination an inanimate splop of clay becomes two talking bald heads. In one short, a Punch and Judy tale is told by hand puppets that interact with a live guinea pig in and around a charming folk cottage.

title: Foreign Affairs; Hard Problem
description: Why am I not comforted by this picture: Saddam Hussein is flat on his back from a war he started, and lost, seven years ago. Yet he has just managed to evict the U.N. weapons inspectors whose job it is to insure that he never again acquires weapons of mass destruction, and he is now deep in negotiations with the U.N. over what it will give him to let the inspectors back in. On top of it all, our lawyers in this negotiation -- France and Russia -- are his business partners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINCIPE, THOMAS
description: PRINCIPE-Thomas. The management and staff of North Bay Cadillac, Hempstead Jaguar and North Shore Infiniti mourn the death of their friend and colleague Thomas Principe. Tom brought a rich automotive heritage with him when he joined our firm over 15 years ago. His dedication to his customers and perseverance through times of challenge are an example for all. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Jane and his beautiful children Jennifer, Meghan, Victoria, John, and Christina.

title: Bridge; Omar Sharif's Team Is 11th In a Strong Championship
description: The World Championships in Tunisia last month attracted Omar Sharif, movie star and bridge enthusiast, who now lives in Cairo.

title: Gangster's New Image
description: Antonio Fernandez, a k a King Tone, the supreme leader of the Latin Kings, claims to be transforming the gang from violent thuggery into community activism. But the question is: How much of this is for real? The police have their doubts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINKOFF, HELEN HARVEY
description: LINKOFF-Helen Harvey, 81. On November 17th, 1997, from complications from a car accident. Loving mother of James, Sarah and Frank, mother-in-law of Ted, adored grandmother of Jason, Sarah, Raimy, Daniel, Thomas, Benjamin and Henry. Beloved partner of Marion Matera. Was a notable theatrical literary agent happily retired to her home nestled in between her apple orchard and garden in New Milford, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMBROSE, REV. THOMAS E. S.J.
description: AMBROSE-Rev. Thomas E. S.J. Beloved brother of Helen. Loving uncle of Paul and Thomas Merck, Joan Reagan, and Kathleen LeBlancq. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel, at Murray-Weigel, 515 East Fordham Road, on Thursday 2-4 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 11:30 A.M., at Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel. Contributions to the Father McKenna Center, 19 Eye Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARDS, GERALD L.
description: RICHARDS-Gerald L. November 14, 1997. Beloved husband of Geraldine. Devoted stepfather of Carol and Tom. Also survived by four grandchildren, three great grandchildren. Professional actor for nearly 50 years. Services are Friday, 1:30 PM at Edward J. Kuhn Funeral Home, West Reading, PA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, DEIRDRE MARIE
description: RYAN-Deirdre Marie. November 18, 1997. Beloved daughter of James V. Ryan of Fairfield, CT, formerly of Rye, NY and the late Anne M. Ryan. Beloved sister of Maureen Ryan Smith, Kevin A., Emmett F. and James J. Ryan and the late Marybeth Ryan. Mass of Resurrection to be celebrated Saturday at 10AM at Convent of the Sacred Heart, Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Department of Surgery, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: An Enemy of That Old Opera Shtick
description: Hands were on Jonathan Miller's mind the other day. His own hands flew in all directions as he settled into a late lunch at O'Neal's, across from Lincoln Center. He had just come from the Metropolitan Opera and a rehearsal of his new production of Stravinsky's ''Rake's Progress,'' which opens this evening.

title: Arts Abroad; Down and Out in Istanbul: Cinema on a Shoestring
description: A gritty film about Turks who have been left behind by their country's economic boom may have set a record for the greatest cinematic return on its investment.

title: Candidates Emerge to Take on Hoffa
description: With Ron Carey barred from running for re-election as teamsters president, a former oilfield repairman from West Virginia, a former truck driver from Boston and a former warehouse worker from Oregon have emerged as the most likely candidates to challenge James P. Hoffa for the teamsters' presidency.

title: Our Towns; I.N.S. Raid Reaps Many, But Sows Pain
description: THE first big snowstorm has come and gone and Torrey Farms still has 3,000 tons of cabbage on the ground, encrusted in ice.

title: Rebuilt T.W.A. 800 Fuselage Shows Limits of Sleuthing
description: A lofty old hangar here that once turned out gleaming Grumman jet fighters now houses a monument to the power, and the limits, of technological sleuthing -- the assembled wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, which fell in flames into the Atlantic 16 months ago.

title: Wish You Weren't Here; It's Been Live and Let Live Until Today, But Now the Greeting Card Wars Are Under Way
description: When it comes to finding ways to express truly modern sentiments, greeting card companies have long been at a loss for words.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Korea's Troubles Worsen As Pressure for Aid Grows

title: Injury-Depleted Isles Surprise the Red Wings
description: The Islanders faced their biggest challenge of the season: stopping the Detroit Red Wings, the most productive offensive team in the National Hockey League, down three defensemen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLEN, CARL
description: KAPLEN-Carl. Husband of the late Eva. Loving father of Cary and Marsha. Dear brother of Walter. Service Thursday, November 20, at 12 Noon, at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: With Flattery for None and Scorn for Many
description: Humor, like wine, often travels poorly. So it is a pleasure to report that the volatile cargo of satire packed by South Africa's comic conscience, Pieter-Dirk Uys, has arrived in the United States in most savory form.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, MICHAEL M.
description: PERLMAN-Michael M. Beloved husband of Simona, devoted father of Dina, Ariel and Noah. Loving son of Ruth and Emanuel, a dear brother of Susan Yoselowitz, and Shelley Rudes. Services on Friday, 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Executive Changes At 3 Agencies
description: Changes involving executives have been made at three agencies in New York.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the search for a missing Manhattan couple and their landlord misstated the profession of Chuck DeLaney, a neighbor of the couple's. He is a photographer, not a lawyer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGBAUM, NETTIE
description: LANGBAUM-Nettie, ninety-four. Forever our matriarch. Beloved wife of the late Murray Langbaum. Loving mother of Robert, Larry and Audrey. Treasured grandmother of Roanne, Emily, Elise, Avery, Craig, Eric and Pearl. Bubbe of 13 great grandchildren. Funeral services 2 PM, Thursday, November 20, at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset. The family will sit shiva through November 26.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANSKY, ROBERT STANLEY
description: MANSKY-Robert Stanley. Loving brother of Marvin and Ivy Mansky, devoted uncle of Adam and Alexandra. Memorial service Friday 12 noon at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street.

title: Boat Builder Closes, Eliminating 130 Jobs
description: After 50 years, the Egg Harbor Yacht Company closed its doors Monday, putting 130 people out of work. The boat-building company was one of the largest employers in Egg Harbor, which has a population of 4,500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FASTENBERG, VERA
description: FASTENBERG-Vera. The Board and Staff of the American Associates, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, deeply mourn the passing of Vera Fastenberg beloved sister of Arnold Forster, a longtime, generous supporter and Board member of AABGU. We extend sincere and heartfelt condolences to the Fastenberg and Forster families. Lis Gaines, N.Y. Regional Chairperson Vered Mallon, Director Greater N.Y. Region Kenneth M. Farber, Executive Vice President

title: Shake-Up in Cairo Follows Tourists' Killings
description: Nearly two dozen top Egyptian officials were stripped of their posts today in a sign that the Government believes security lapses may have opened the way to the killing here on Monday morning of 62 people, including 58 foreign tourists.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MILLSTEIN, S. GEORGE
description: MILLSTEIN-S. George. 10/7/25-11/ 20/95. In loving memory of my sweet, darling twin brother. Rest in peace. Love you, your twin, Annie

title: A.E. Gropp, 94, Librarian of Latin America
description: Arthur Eric Gropp, a champion of closer United States-Latin American ties and a former library director for the Organization of American States, died on Nov. 8 at his home in Greenbelt, Md. He was 94.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEVASTOPOULO, ELISABETH
description: SEVASTOPOULO-Elisabeth. Died on Thursday, November 18 at the home of her daughter and son-in-law in Mauchline, Ayrshire, Scotland. She was born Princess Cantacuzene, Countess Speransky in 1911 in St. Petersburg, Russia. Elisabeth Sevastopoulo is survived by her son, Dimitri Sevastopoulo, her daughter, Viscountess Weir, two grandsons, Andrew Weir and Marc Sevastopoulo, and her brother, Prince Michel Cantacuzene, Count Speransky. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, December 4th at 6:30 PM at St. Nicholas Cathedral, 17 East 97th Street in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to: The Tolstoy Foundation, 104 Lake Road, Valley Cottage, NY 10989.

title: Minus Star And Coach, Celtics Fall
description: Rick Pitino and Antoine Walker have fonder memories of Continental Arena.

title: Reno Allows First U.S. Death Penalty Trial in Manhattan in Decades
description: Setting the stage for the first Federal death penalty trial in Manhattan in more than 40 years, Attorney General Janet Reno authorized Federal prosecutors yesterday to seek the execution of a Connecticut man accused of burning his fiancee to death in the trunk of his car.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INDOVINO, PETER K.
description: INDOVINO-Peter K. in his 28th year, of Syracuse and Brooklyn, NY on November 15 in Washington, D.C. in a tragic accident. Energetic, vivacious, inspirational M.B.A. student at Syracuse University. Beloved son of Louis and Joan (nee Alice). Loving brother of Lisa Indovino Ottens and Jay. Dear brother-in-law of Jill and Paul. Marathon uncle of Emma, Nicole, Lauren and Ethan. Funeral Friday 8:30AM from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd, Brooklyn. Mass Good Shepherd RC Church 9:30AM. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. Visiting hours Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-10PM. A memorial service will be held Saturday, Nov 22, 11AM at the Poly Prep Country Day School, 9216 7th Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11228. Please omit flowers.

title: Two 13-Year-Olds Raped Girl at School, Police Say
description: A 13-year-old girl was sexually abused by two 13-year-old boys yesterday in a public school in Manhattan, the police said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DEBI MAZAR, the movie and television actress, estimates that she has made six or seven attempts to stop smoking over the last five years, sometimes succeeding for months at a time, only to resume.

title: Currents; EARTHBOUND KITE -- Sculptural Cube
description: Like a chic box kite, the Pio table lamp is a serene sculptural object. The beech base is stained to look like rosewood; the shade is rice paper. The lamp, 16 inches ($325) or 21 inches ($350), is at Interieurs, 114 Wooster Street (Prince Street); (212) 343-0800.

title: Accounts
description: * Polaroid Sunglasses, Norwood, Mass., to Eisner & Associates, Baltimore, to handle the American introduction of the [X]oor brand. Billings for a three-city market test were estimated at $2 million; billings for a national rollout, scheduled for 1999, are being estimated at $8 million to $12 million.

title: Design Notebook; 'Honey, They Fixed Up the Castle!'
description: Clients do not always feel like giving parties for the people who have just finished remodeling their homes, but that's what the Queen of England did here at Windsor Castle, her favorite residence.

title: Bomb Suspect Hid Cash, Ex-Wife Testifies
description: Terry L. Nichols and his former wife both sobbed today as she told a Federal jury how, worried for his safety, she opened a package he gave her and found letters and evidence that prosecutors say tie Mr. Nichols to the Oklahoma City bombing.

title: In Digital Age, Willoughby's Remakes Itself
description: Willoughby's.

title: Unreading Election Law
description: The White House has mounted a campaign to defend the legality of the scheme by which President Clinton's 1996 election campaign financed over $40 million worth of television commercials largely with huge soft-money contributions from unions, corporations and wealthy donors not legal in Federal campaigns. Even the vaunted White House spin machine cannot erase the facts and the law.

title: New Law Hurts Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: Big-Name Stocks Push Dow Up 73.92 Points
description: Broad stock market indexes closed mostly higher yesterday, as investors seemingly turned to a round of safe-haven buying after a day of profit taking on Tuesday.

title: In Brawley Case, Racial Composition of Jury Pool Is Questioned
description: Jury selection in the defamation lawsuit against three former advisers of Tawana Brawley was delayed today while lawyers for the defendants challenged the jury pool's racial composition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVERTY, RUTH M.
description: LAVERTY-Ruth M. Of Bethpage on November 18, 1997. Beloved friend of Carol G. Dort. Miss Laverty was a brilliant concert pianist, a dedicated church musician and New York City High School music teacher. Religious Service on Thursday at 8 P.M., at Redeemer Lutheran Church 17 New South Road, (Corner Old Country Road) Hicksville, New York. Funeral Friday 9:30 A.M., from the church. Cremation to follow at Fresh Pond Crematory, Middle Village, New York. In lieu of flowers donations to your favorite fund for animals in need would be appreciated. Info: the Thomas F. Dalton FH, Hicksville, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIAMIE, SAMIE N.
description: KIAMIE-Samie N. Of Eastchester, N.Y., November 19, 1997. Husband of Carmen, father of Rose Meltzer (Clifford), Don Kiamie (Olive), Phillip Kiamie (Annette) and Alma Perez-Vidal (Angel), grandfather of seven. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM Thursday and Friday. Service Holy Trinity Church, Mill Road, New Rochelle, New York, Saturday, November 22, at 9:30 AM.

title: Reliving the Trial Blow by Blow, Especially His Own Anger
description: ANOTHER CITY, NOT MY OWN

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the last asking price before the sale. ''Weeks on market'' refers only to the listing by the most recent broker.

title: Pataki's Trusted Budget Director Is Leaving for a Top Job at the University of Chicago
description: Patricia A. Woodworth, the sharp-edged architect of Gov. George E. Pataki's efforts to end New York's tradition of big government, announced today that she was resigning her position as budget director to become vice president of the University of Chicago.

title: New Canaan Wins State Championship
description: The New Canaan High School girls soccer team defeated Holy Cross Academy of Waterbury, 4-1, yesterday in Madison, Conn., to capture the state championship for schools with midsized enrollment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUCILLI, NINA
description: MARCUCILLI-Nina. A gracious, charming lady and a dedicated associate who served our company for over twenty years effectively and with total dedication. To her loving husband Fred, and to her two wonderful, devoted and loving sons, Mark and John, we offer our heartfelt sympathies. Nina will be missed by us all. Jerome Belson, Chairman Aaron Silberman, President Michael Mansueto Director of Operations Jerome Belson Associates, Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSMORE, COL. FRANCIS B.
description: MESSMORE-Col. Francis B. On November 16, 1997. Beloved husband of Dorothy; loving father of Pamela Tobiason; adored grandfather of Peter. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St, Thursday at 6-8 PM and Friday 2-4 PM and 6-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday 10 AM at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street. Interment, private.

title: Gazli Journal; Free of the Russians, but Imprisoned in Cotton
description: The classic description of Uzbek geography as two-thirds desert and one-third cotton fields is something of an exaggeration, but it does seem that wherever there is arable land here, there is cotton.

title: Rolling Stones to Play Garden in January
description: The Rolling Stones are bound for Madison Square Garden, where they are to perform on Jan. 14 and 16 as part of their Bridges to Babylon tour.

title: Esiason to Start For the Bengals
description: Cincinnati Bengals Coach Bruce Coslet said Boomer Esiason will replace Jeff Blake as starting quarterback against the Jacksonville Jaguars on Sunday. The move will end Blake's American Conference-leading streak of 52 straight starts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPLIN, SAUL
description: CHAPLIN-Saul. The Board of Directors and members of the National Academy of Popular Music regret the passing of Saul Chaplin, an esteemed member of the Songwriters' Hall of Fame. Frank Sinatra, Chairman Bobby Weinstein, President

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS IN DEAL FOR AMATI COMMUNICATIONS
description: Texas Instruments Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Amati Communications Corporation for $395 million, topping a bid from Westell Technologies Inc. in a race to cash in on products that send data over phone lines. Texas Instruments will pay $20 a share in cash for Amati, which makes software for high-speed data connections. The bid by Texas Instruments, based in Dallas, is more than Westell's stock offer of $315.3 million. Shares of Westell rose 81.25 cents, to $18.5625, while Amati climbed $4.5625, to $19.75. Texas Instruments fell 62.5 cents, to $98.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTOR, IDA
description: CANTOR-Ida, 94. Dearly loved died at home Oct. 26. Barbara, please fax your tel #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUTTON, JOSEPH
description: SUTTON-Joseph A.D. On November 19. Funeral Thursday at 10AM, Magen David Congregation, 2025 67th Street, Bensonhurst, Brooklyn. Beloved husband of Sarah Maleh Sutton, cherished father of Sally and Elliot Heller, Lisa Sutton and James W. Smith, Naomi and Peter Neustadter, Ralph Sutton and six grandchildren. After a career as a businessman, Mr. Sutton authored two books on the Syrian Jewish community in Brooklyn. Shiva will be observed at 1432 East 9th Street, Brooklyn

title: Art Can't Save Cities
description: To the Editor:

title: New Executive Director For Jacob's Pillow
description: Ella Baff has been appointed executive director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass. She replaces Sali Ann Kriegsman, who resigned on Oct. 31, and Robert Yesselman, the festival's interim managing director, who is to resign when Ms. Baff arrives on April 1.
