title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPULER, WILLIAM, M.D.
description: KAPULER-William, M.D. The Officers and Members of The New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute express their profound sorrow at the death of their respected and beloved colleague and member, Dr. William Kapuler. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his wife, Sylvia, and family. Lester Schwartz, M.D., Pres/Soc Edward Hartmann, M.D., Pres/Inst

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUCKMAN, DAVID
description: DRUCKMAN-David. November 18, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Charlotte (Kaufman). Loving father of James and Nancy. Adoring grandfather of Charlotte and John. Devoted brother of Beatrice Preefer and Frances White. Visiting Thursday 7-9 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. Service Friday, 9:30 A.M. at Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 E. 87 St, NYC. Contributions in his memory to the Alzheimer's Association, NYC Chapter, 420 Lexington Ave, Suite 610, NY, NY 10170, or the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: Kaczynski Worried About 'Sick' Label
description: Writing in his journal, Theodore J. Kaczynski worried that society would dismiss him as a ''sickie'' after he committed a series of killings, according to a legal filing today by the prosecutors who say Mr. Kaczynski was the Unabomber.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARTSIS, MILDRED
description: ARTSIS-Mildred. It is with profound sorrow that we mourn the loss of Mildred Artsis, wife of our former member, the late Jerome Artsis. We extend our condolences to the entire family. Fresh Meadow Country Club Board of Governors President, Steven Howard Secretary, Allen Kaplan

title: Public Eye
description: CALL it the Return of Babes in Toyland: female dolls have been proliferating in popular culture. Appearing front and center in television shows, print advertising and contemporary art, the plastic esthetic seems to embody extremes in female passivity and power.

title: Yeltsin Offers to Curtail Powers of Embattled Deputy Premier
description: Seeking to squash a growing ethics scandal that could derail Russia's economic reforms, President Boris N. Yeltsin offered today to strip the embattled first Deputy Prime Minister, Anatoly B. Chubais, of his second post of Finance Minister.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARROW, SADIE
description: ZARROW-Sadie. Dearly loved and loving wife of the late Joseph, mother of Walter and the late Marilyn, grandmother of Laura, Andrew, Gayle, Scott, and Susan, and great grandmother of Matthew, Anna, Blaire, and Danielle on Nov. 17th at the age of eighty-seven after a brief illness. She was a great lady. Contributions to the Daniel Cantor Senior Citizens Center, Sunrise, FL, will be appreciated.

title: An Impostor's Joy Ride Runs Out of Steam Again
description: Tuesday night started out as a typical one on the tracks for Darius McCollum, the authorities said. He picked up a repair truck, they said, at New York City Transit's 38th Street train yard in Brooklyn, drove to his locker at the Jerome Avenue yard in the Bronx, changed into his blue uniform, took his lantern and his hard hat and spent the night inspecting sections of track in the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn.

title: Currents; DESIGNS 'R' US -- In Brooklyn, A Revival Of the Fittest
description: Seventies revivalists, meet your match: Zesty Meyers and Evan Snyderman are dealers in in what Mr. Meyers describes as ''later 20th century'' furnishings, resulting from ''the race to come up with something new after World War II.'' The two have operated at the 26th Street flea market for years, and last month opened a retail shop in Brooklyn called R, for no good reason except for the red neon letter they found at auction. Their collection includes functional objects, from the downright gaudy to the progressively middlebrow, from plastic wall calendars to a rare cast-fiberglass lounge chair by an unknown California artist ($1,200, top). It stands on a lime-green shag rug ($500, and they'll throw in an original Rug Rake, from the era of conversation pits and leisure suits). A new arrival: a six-foot walnut-veneer desk by Edward Wormley ($2,000). The store is at Wythe Avenue and South First Street, a block from the Domino Sugar factory in Williamsburg. For hours and directions: (718) 599-4385.

title: Merrill to Acquire Mercury, British Firm, for $5.3 Billion
description: In the most expensive acquisition ever in the money management business, Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Mercury Asset Management Group P.L.C. of Britain, one of Europe's largest investment firms, for about $5.3 billion in cash.

title: Williams, Nearly a Tiger, Is Still a Yankee for Now
description: Maybe the Yankees weren't fooling or posturing after all, though if they were serious they sure had a strange way of demonstrating it.

title: 2 Deals for Halter Marine
description: Halter Marine Group Inc. of Gulfport, Miss., said this week that it had received two contracts with a total value of $136 million to build two jack-up drilling units for Chiles Offshore L.L.C. It said the contracts, valued at $68 million each, were the largest in its history. The rigs will be built at its Pascagoula, Miss., shipyard with assembled parts from its Texas shipyards.

title: Legislature Hears Both Sides of UConn Stadium Issue
description: Thousands of people cried for joy after Marshall University in Huntington, W.Va., won a championship football game in its brand-new stadium, recalled Jim Nantz, a CBS sportscaster, as he testified at a legislative hearing today on behalf of a proposal to build a $102 million football stadium complex at the University of Connecticut.

title: Market Place; Egg on Face, But Analyst May Profit
description: On Sept. 18, Thomas H. Hanley, an influential analyst with UBS Securities, pegged Bankers Trust New York as takeover bait for the Travelers Group. Bankers Trust's market value jumped $1.16 billion before trading was halted that morning, seeming to offer proof that the merger maven's word was as good as gold.

title: Mattel Sets a Conduct Code for Its Suppliers
description: Mattel Inc., the world's largest toy company, has set a code of conduct for its suppliers, subjecting their working conditions to auditing and monitoring by an independent commission.

title: A Regional Utility Is Sold in Brazil
description: Brazil said yesterday that it had sold the regional utility Empresa Energetica do Mato Grosso do Sul for 625.5 million reais ($565 million) to the Brazilian utility Espirito Santo Centrais Eletricas S.A., or Escelsa.

title: Spending Ted Turner's Money: State Dept. Aide Gets U.N. Job
description: Ted Turner, who has promised to give $1 billion to the United Nations over the next decade, today named the man who will allocate the money, the largest donation ever made to the organization. He is Timothy E. Wirth, a former Senator from Colorado who is now the Undersecretary of State for Global Affairs.

title: Despite Fears of Others, Foreman Still Has Fun
description: George Foreman used the adage of whistling past the graveyard this afternoon when talking about his heavyweight fight against Shannon Briggs at Trump's Taj Mahal on Saturday at 9 P.M. on Home Box Office.

title: At a Swiss Airport, 36 Dead, Home From Luxor
description: Just a few days ago, they had gathered cheerfully enough, ignoring misgivings about terrorism to seek pre-winter sun in Egypt on package tours. Tonight their bodies were loaded in coffins onto an Egyptian plane in Cairo and flown home, a final voyage to the same airport that some had flown out from.

title: TIME WARNER TO SELL 3 CABLE SYSTEMS TO PARTNERSHIP
description: Time Warner Inc., the nation's second-largest cable operator, agreed yesterday to sell some cable systems in three Southern states to a partnership of Renaissance Media Partners L.L.C. and Morgan Stanley Capital Partners, a unit of Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company, as part of an effort to trim $17 billion of debt. Financial terms were not disclosed. The cable systems being sold are in southeastern Louisiana; Picayune, Miss., and Jackson, Tenn. Time Warner also reiterated its plans to sell cable systems in Michigan. Analysts have valued these systems at $350 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, MICHAEL A.
description: HARRIS-Michael A. Age 47, of Jersey City, N.J. Died November 17. Manager of Jersey City Best Western Inn. Survivors include his mother Regina A. Richards HarrisSchaefer and sister Valerie (Theodore) Hoca. Calling 7-9 Thursday at H.E. Turner Funeral Home of Batavia, N.Y. where services will be held at 10AM Friday. Burial in Jamestown, New York.

title: Though Mobutu Is Buried, Corruption Dies Hard
description: Mile 42 on National Highway No. 1 was the end of the line for Nsimba Ndona, who makes his living driving a truck hauling boards from the capital, Kinshasa, to Congo's only seaport, Matadi.

title: Sunday Night at the Fights: Giants and Redskins
description: Washington Redskins quarterback Gus Frerotte knows what to expect Sunday night against the visiting Giants.

title: Questioning of Unabom Jurors Is Not Always What It Seems
description: As he questioned a potential juror one day this week, Stephen P. Freccero, one of the prosecutors of Theodore J. Kaczynski, sounded as if he was trying to save the life of the man who is accused of being the Unabomber.

title: Dilbert walks and talks, and he bobs his head. On TV. For office products. Yes, office products.
description: DILBERT, the character from the popular cartoon strip who has become the overworked, underappreciated poster boy of today's cubicle dweller, has a new employer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELTHAM, IRENE
description: FELTHAM-Irene. Of Dix Hills, New York, on November 19, 1997. A brilliant and dedicated teacher of English in the New York City School System, at Martin Van Buren High School, Queens Village, New York. She was the beloved wife of John. Cherished mother of Lynne (Ralph) Stewart, Donald (Andrea) Feltham, and Laurel (Seth) Freedman. Loving grandmother of Brenna and Geoffrey (Marta) Stewart, Dr. Zenobia (Timothy) Brown, and Alexander and Andrew Freedman. Beloved great-grandmother of Milana Velasquez, Ernesto and Arthur Stewart. Reposing at Jacobsen Funeral Home, Huntington, New York, Thursday and Friday. Christian Burial Service at Sweet Hollow Presbyterian Church, Melville, New York, Saturday morning.

title: A Night of Records for 8 Contemporary Artists
description: Eight artists scored record prices at Sotheby's last night as dozens of contemporary-art buyers willingly spent millions of dollars on works by artists like Mark Rothko, Bruce Nauman, Roy Lichtenstein and Andy Warhol.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGEDORN, CHARLES
description: HAGEDORN-Charles, 79, on November 17, 1997, beloved husband of the late Jane, devoted father of Christopher, cherished grandfather of Christopher and James. At Charles' request a private family service was held. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. Donations in his memory can be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave., New York, N.Y. 10021.

title: Fernandez Comes Back To Upset Davenport
description: The big bang theory had seemed to be working for Lindsay Davenport: when you're pushing 6 feet 3 inches, there's almost no excuse for not outmuscling the opposition or for not putting the opposing player into a position most often assumed by doormats.

title: MANHATTAN BAGEL FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: The Manhattan Bagel Company said yesterday that it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after its primary lender, First Union National Bank, placed it in default. The bagel shop operator blamed its company-owned stores for most of its recent losses and said it would either sell those stores to franchisees or close them. The company-owned stores account for 9 percent of Manhattan Bagel's total retail outlets. The company, based in Eatontown, N.J., also said it expects to report a loss of $1.6 million for the third quarter ended Sept. 30. In the quarter a year earlier, the company lost $2.4 million.

title: Clinton to Call for Health-Plan Regulation
description: President Clinton wants Congress to protect consumers with a ''bill of rights'' setting detailed Federal standards for all health plans and health insurance companies in the United States, the White House said tonight.

title: INSIDE
description: Dow Jones to Report Loss

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 30 about a swing in the market for collectibles toward general merchandise like children's toys referred incorrectly to the maker of Beanie Babies. It is Ty Inc. not Ty Toy.

title: Sports of The Times; A Budding Rivalry On Parquet
description: AT his usual brisk pace, Rick Pitino walked into Continental Arena early last night with his nouveau Boston Celtics, and talked about what a nice place it was to visit. Fate, he understood, wanted him and this place to have a long, eventful relationship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, LEONARD
description: RUBIN-Leonard. Age 70. Beloved husband of Sondra. Devoted father of Alan and Brenda Rubin and Howard and Lisa Rubin and a cherished grandfather. Shiva will be observed until Tuesday morning at 34 White Drive N. in Cedarhurst, New York.

title: TWO BANKS IN EASTERN PENNSYLVANIA AGREE TO MERGE
description: Heritage Bancorp Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to merge with the BCB Financial Services Corporation in a deal that combines two banks in eastern Pennsylvania. The value of the merger was not disclosed, but the two companies have a combined market value of $180 million. Shareholders of each company will own a 50 percent stake in the new company. Under the deal, BCB shareholders will receive 1.335 shares of the new company for each of their shares, and Heritage shareholders will receive 1.05 shares for each Heritage share. Shares of BCB Financial rose $1.75, or 8 percent, to $23.75. Heritage shares slipped $3.50, or 15 percent, to $20. Heritage, based in Pottsville, Pa., had total assets of $342 million at the end of last year. BCB Financial, based in Reading, Pa., had total assets of $324.5 million.

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK; Brooding Forest As Artist's Medium
description: AN INSTALLATION called ''A Reclamation Garden'' at the Abingdon Art Center stands at the corner where art and nature meet, but also at the haunting, paradoxical intersection where wanting-to-let-it-disappear and wanting-it-to-live-forever run into each other. As such, it is a great place for gardeners to visit.

title: CHRONICLE
description: And the winner is . . .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, SCARLETT
description: CLARK-Scarlett. Died at her Southampton home, November 17 at the age of 91. She is survived by her husband, Robert Clark; a sister Anita Weinstein; and a brother Walter Fried. In accordance with her wishes, there will be no funeral. Memorial donations can be made to International Fund for Animal Welfare, Box 193, Yarmouthport, MA. 02675-0193.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENTMACHER, PAUL SIDNEY, M.D.
description: ENTMACHER-Paul Sidney, M.D. We note with sorrow the passing of a highly respected colleague, a physician whose career in medicine was marked by devotion and sensitivity. A long-term consultant to North Shore's Medical Staff, he will be remembered for his analytic mind and caring nature. Our most sincere condolences are extended to his family. Peter F.R. Walker, M.D. Chairman, Medical Board Paul Karafoil, M.D. President Medical Staff Arthur W. Feinberg, M.D. Medical Director, Center for Extended Care and Rehabilitation Lawrence Scherr, M.D., MACP Sr. Vice President Medical Affairs North Shore University Hospital

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, GREGORY
description: WALSH-Gregory. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to Nan and Al Walsh on the sudden and shocking death of their son Greg. May the concern and love of our Offices, Directors and Members be a comfort to them at this most terrible of moments. Jerome Belson, President Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York, Inc. Michael Kerr, Arnold Sollar Co-Chairmen Nicholas LaPorte, Exec. Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLTIN, IRENE
description: COLTIN-Irene. Passed away on November 15, 1997 in Los Angeles, California. Devoted mother of Steven Coltin and Ruth-Ann Huvane (Kevin); beloved sister of Dr. Sidney (Shirley) Cohlan, Irving Cohen, and Harold (Phyllis) Cohen. At the family's request in lieu of flowers, donations will be accepted in Irene's memory to Cardiac Research at Cedar Sinai Medical Center, 8700 Beverly Blvd., Plaza #

title: Colleges Did Jews No Favor of Exclusion ; Implied Anti-Semitism?
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton's Race Panel Restricts Testimony
description: President Clinton's advisory panel on race decided to restrict testimony and not consider the views of opponents of affirmative action when it held a hearing on how to achieve diversity on college campuses. The chairman of the panel, John Hope Franklin, said opponents of affirmative action, like Ward Connerly, the University of California regent who led the fight to ban the use of race in admissions to state universities, were unlikely ''to contribute to this discussion.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUCHY, FREDERICK
description: SUCHY-Frederick. The Board of the Mount Sinai Children's Center Foundation extends its deepest sympathies to our Board Member and Chairman, Department of Pediatrics at Mount Sinai, Doctor Frederick J. Suchy, Jr. upon the death of his beloved father, Frederick Suchy. Please know that you are in our thoughts and prayers. Merryl and James S. Tisch, Chairmen The Mt. Sinai Children's Center Foundation

title: Calendar; Exhibitions And Holiday Bazaars
description: A Furniture Original

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHISSER, MILDRED
description: SCHISSER-Mildred, age 86. Died peacefully. Beloved wife ot the late Morton, devoted mother of Rosalie Oliff and Joseph Schisser, loving grandmother of Paul, Jordan, Marc, Susan and Amy. Loving great-grandmother of Sara, Sam, Ezra and Jared. Services will be held at Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, NJ, Thursday 11 AM.

title: Women's World Cup At Giants Stadium
description: Giants Stadium was chosen yesterday to be the site of the opening ceremonies and the opening game for the 1999 Women's World Cup of soccer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAVA, ETHEL
description: FAVA-Ethel. On November 18, 1997, of Jericho, Long Island. Beloved wife of John. Devoted mother of Howard and Elayne Haymes, Ronnie and Dr. Arnie Chusid, Bruce and Ellen Mittman. Adored grandmother of Lloyd, Evan, Jesse, Rebecca, Emily and Andrew. Cherished great-grandmother of Benjamin. Services today, at 1:45 PM, ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: The Pop Life
description: The Return Of Pearl Jam

title: Jim Kepner, in 70's, Is Dead; Historian of Gay Rights Effort
description: Jim Kepner, an early gay rights advocate who preserved the movement's history even as he helped to write it, died on Saturday at Midway Hospital in Los Angeles. He was about 74 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Mexico City Police Block Arrests Of Fellow Officers in 6 Killings
description: Rebellious policemen from an elite unit barricaded themselves inside their barracks here today to block the arrests of fellow officers in connection with a notorious case involving the abduction and execution of six Mexico City youths.

title: Killer of 5 at Shoe Store Gets Life Sentences
description: Vernon Michaels, who killed five people, including a mother and her two sons who were shot in the back, at a Pelham Parkway shoe store two years ago, was sentenced to five life sentences without parole yesterday, to be served consecutively.

title: 4 Strings In Unity With Bach
description: For many musicians, Bach is a respite. They may use his music to start or end the day, to relax or meditate, to return, as it were, to the source, for refreshment and inspiration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, ARTHUR
description: KAYE-Arthur. Beloved father, grandfather, husband, brother, uncle and friend. We love you with all our hearts and will miss the laughter and love you gave so freely to all you met.

title: Friends From Sports World at Arcaro Funeral
description: Joe DiMaggio was among a cross section of sports, entertainment and business people who attended funeral services today for the Hall of Fame jockey Eddie Arcaro.

title: The Script Is Modest, But Not The Buzz
description: Less than two years ago, during a snowstorm in New York, Harvey Weinstein, co-chairman of Miramax, was seated at the bar of the Four Seasons Hotel when he saw Lawrence Bender, the producer of ''Reservoir Dogs'' and ''Pulp Fiction.''

title: Mysteries Much Pondered by a Young Pianist
description: The progress of Per Tengstrand's young career will be an interesting test of health for a concert world already bulging with aspiring pianists and half suffocated by diminishing opportunity.

title: Clinton in a Crisis: A Question of Style
description: Faced with a crisis in Iraq, President Clinton left on Friday on a four-day fund-raising trip across the country. On Tuesday, after returning, he went golfing. Today, he spoke up at the White House about the international standoff, but he did so while promoting a domestic policy, slipping 150 words about Iraq into remarks on speeding adoption of children in foster care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERIN, FRANCES HANFORD SAMPSON
description: HALPERIN - Frances Hanford Sampson. Died in Springfield, MA., November 19. Widow of Nathan Halperin and mother of Edward H. Sampson and Susan S. Wilt. Visitation at Dickinson-Streeter Funeral Home, 305 State Street, Springfield MA., on Friday from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Private interment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROUSSEAU, SHIRLEE
description: ROUSSEAU-Shirlee. On Thursday, November 13, Shirlee Rousseau died of complications arising from breast cancer. She will be missed by her many friends and family. She is survived by her brother Edward Pierson III; her niece Kay Pierson and nephew Edward Pierson, IV; two grandnephews Malcolm and Marcus Hendricks; her grandniece and godchild Nikki Hendricks and three cousins, Bessye Lois Spears, Bernice Benbow and Stanley Smith. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions to the Breast Cancer Resource Center, 1765 N Street, NW, Washington, DC 20036, 202-463-8040. Memorial service will be held on December 4, 1997 at 6 PM at the Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th Street, New York, N.Y., 10016.

title: Asian Nations Affirm I.M.F. As Primary Provider of Aid
description: After two days of discussion among a dozen of Asia's deputy finance ministers and their counterparts from the United States and Canada, a broad agreement was reached today that would open up Asian economies to greater scrutiny by their neighbors and international financial institutions while strengthening the ability of the International Monetary Fund to respond swiftly to a crisis.

title: Public Advocate Faults Child Welfare Agency in the Deaths of 15
description: Despite the Giuliani administration's efforts to improve the city's child welfare agency, 15 children died last year in cases in which the agency failed to monitor abuse adequately or provide needed services, according to a study released yesterday by the Public Advocate's office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSTRINSKY, DANIEL
description: KOSTRINSKY-Daniel. Of Marlboro formerly of Matawan. Husband of Marjorie nee Reiss, father of Lee and Sherri, Kenneth, Joyce, brother of Benjamin Kye, grandfather of Oliver. Services Friday, 10:00 A.M., at Temple Shalom, Aberdeen, New Jersey. Bloomfield-Cooper 1-800-247-5235.

title: Judge Stops Company From Phone Solicitations
description: A Federal judge in Camden granted an order on Tuesday temporarily halting the operations of a Mount Laurel telemarketing company accused of preying on thousands of elderly people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPPEL, PAUL M.
description: KOPPEL-Paul M. On Monday, November 17, 1997, of Springfield, NJ. Formerly of Brookline, MA. Beloved husband of Eva Irene (Grunebaum). Loving father of Erika Arevuo and her husband Mikko of London, Victoria Koppel of New York City and William Koppel of Los Angeles. Adored grandfather of Eva and Max Arevuo. Dear brother of Irma Weinbaum of Elsmere, NY. Graveside services at Sharon Memorial Park, Sharon, MA., on Thursday, November 20 at 10:45 AM. Levine Chapel, Brookline, MA.

title: Thompson New York Gets Unilever Nod
description: Unilever said yesterday that as expected it had named J. Walter Thompson New York to introduce a hair care product line from its Helene Curtis division. The line, which trade publications say will carry the brand name Therma Silk, has an introductory budget for 1998 estimated at $82 million -- one of the largest recent new-product blitzes in the hair care category.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; Familiar Songs, Freshly Interpreted
description: Recordings of Schubert's two most famous song cycles are absurdly plentiful. There are 41 versions of ''Winterreise'' and 26 of ''Die Schone Mullerin'' available on compact disk. That even one more can get recorded makes the field of classical music seem stuck in place.

title: A Middle-Aged Man Goes Home, to Mametville
description: They speak in code, of course, the characters in ''The Old Neighborhood,'' David Mamet's heart-piercing new play. Middle-aged people with shared pasts usually do: boyhood pals, former lovers, a brother and sister who recall the unhappy Christmases of their youth. And when the author who has created them is Mr. Mamet, a playwright whose baldness of dialogue is matched only by its indirection, what these people say to each other can at first seem like a foreign language.

title: PHYSICIANS RESOURCE GROUP DISMISSES CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Physicians Resource Group Inc. said yesterday that it had dismissed its chairman and chief executive, Emmett Moore, and that it would not buy more eye doctors' practices in the near future. The company, which is based in Dallas and manages practices for optometrists and ophthalmologists, said the company would be managed by three executives while it looked for a replacement for Mr. Moore. Physicians Resource also released third-quarter earnings. The company said third-quarter profit fell 6.1 percent, to $3.3 million, or 11 cents a share, from $3.5 million, or 13 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Wall Street had expected Physicians Resource to earn 13 cents a share. Shares of Physicians Resource fell $1.0625, to $6.875.

title: Colleges Did Jews No Favor of Exclusion ; Indian Objections
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Denies Report of Burial Plots Traded for Donations
description: Several Congressional leaders reacted with outrage today at a magazine report that said White House officials ''sold'' burial plots at Arlington National Cemetery for large campaign contributions, but the White House dismissed the report tonight as ''scurrilous and untrue.''

title: M.T.A. Discounts for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Currents; TABLE DRESSING -- Thinking Globally for Tradition Without Cliches
description: Holiday tables ought to reflect tradition, but why declare a seasonal moratorium on innovative thinking? The colorful, hand-glazed dishes from China, Thailand, Japan and the Netherlands found at Global Table have simple lines but vivid finishes. Imagine candied yams in a 15-inch canary-yellow stoneware bowl ($83, below left) or pumpkin pie on square sushi plates in indigo or lime green ($14 to $24). Nathalie Smith's table-top store has a caravan of unusual items, some exclusives: dishes from China with an oxblood glaze, Michael Fischer's raku bowls with a crackly glaze like cobwebs and vintage glassware from estate sales. The shop is at 107 Sullivan Street (Prince Street); (212) 431-5839.

title: Whitman's Chief Counsel to Head Staff
description: Two weeks after her narrow re-election, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman named her inner circle of top aides today, promoting her chief counsel, Michael P. Torpey, to chief of staff, the most powerful position in the administration.

title: Huskies Get Top-Ranked Recruit
description: One of the nation's top-ranked women's high school basketball players said Tuesday she would play at Connecticut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURLAND, HAIM
description: GURLAND-Haim. Beloved husband of Estelle for 55 years. Devoted father of Judith and Robert, father-in-law of Warren Blaker and Gaby Jordan. Adored grandfather of Avram, Lauren and Emily. Loyal brother, uncle and friend. After a valiant struggle with cancer in his 93rd year. Services were held November 18, 1997, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUNICK, MOE
description: TUNICK-Moe, 83. Real estate developer, partner in Tunick Bros (dealers in Army surplus vehicles and equipment), and collector of antique automobiles died suddenly November 19. Beloved husband of Marion L. Tunick. Loving father of David, Edward, Budd, and Susan. Adoring grandfather of Jason, James, Liz, Julianne, and Alex. Services at Temple Beth El, 350 Roxbury Road, Stamford, CT., on Friday, November 21 at 1 PM.

title: Big Salaries Don't Scare New Teams Off Deals
description: In the space of two days, the Arizona Diamondbacks acquired three players whose combined 1998 salaries are greater than the entire 1997 payrolls of the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Oakland Athletics.

title: HFS to Buy Tax Preparer, Jackson Hewitt, for $480 Million
description: HFS Inc., the franchise company whose stable of brands includes Avis Rent-A-Car, Century 21 and Ramada Inn, added another yesterday, agreeing to pay $480 million in cash, or $68 a share, for Jackson Hewitt Inc., a tax preparation company.

title: Making an Au Pair Relationship Work
description: THE baby is in the tub, the toddler just tripped down the stairs, someone is at the door, the phone is ringing. What do you do?

title: National Power Reports Profit Surge Abroad
description: National Power P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that a threefold surge in earnings from international projects saved the company from posting lower first-half profits than a year earlier. Profits from international operations rose to $:67 million, or $113.2 million, in the six months ended Sept. 30, from $:20 million a year earlier.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Japan Stocks Soar on Possibility of Bank Bailout
description: Stocks surged in early trading today on renewed optimism that the Government would use public funds to bolster the troubled banking system.

description: ROSENTHAL-Florence. Beloved wife of the late Randy. Mother of Bonnie and Mark Hassin and Nancy Klein. Mrs. Rosenthal is also survived by a dear brother, Alan Fleischer along with nieces, nephews and cousins. description: KRAKAUER-Billie. 11/20/94. Slowly the years go by, but cherished memories linger and are always remembered. You are sorely missed, always remembered and dearly loved. Davie and your loving family

title: Metro Business; Extension for Maidenform
description: Maidenform Worldwide Inc., the biggest maker of women's underwear in the United States, was given more time yesterday to file a plan for exiting Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Geraldo Accepts Fox Offer, But NBC Vows to Match It
description: Geraldo Rivera, the host of the most popular interview program on the cable network CNBC and the longtime host of a syndicated talk show, accepted an offer yesterday to jump to the Fox News network as the host of both a nightly newscast and an interview program.

title: Turf; Co-op Buyers Sidestep Rules
description: IN New York City real estate circles, there is what even proponents call ''a dirty little secret'' that is getting bigger: buyers are taking loans and deceiving strict co-op boards, while using the loans to free their own money for investment.

title: Currents; ADVANCE PLANTING -- Dig Before December
description: A live Christmas tree, one you can drag outside and plant post-Yule, takes some advance planning, not to mention a wheelbarrow. The hole for the root ball should be dug now, before the soil freezes. To prevent accidents, be sure to cover the hole with an upturned bucket or a sheet of plywood.

title: THE 'DRAWER PEOPLE' -- A special report.; Newest Challenge for Welfare: Helping the Hard-Core Jobless
description: After 14 years on and off the welfare rolls, Kimberly Malcom still had a few problems to work out before settling into a job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, PHYLLIS ANN (NEE ZWEIG)
description: FRIEDMAN-Phyllis Ann (nee Zweig) of Ridgewood, NJ. Beloved wife of H. William. Devoted mother of David, Michael and Heather. Dear sister of Steven Zweig and Ellen Zweig Brill. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ, Friday 8:30AM.

title: Former Boyfriend of Mother Goes on Trial in Brooklyn in Death of a Child, 8
description: Her name was Justina Morales and she was 8 years old when she was beaten and asphyxiated at home. Her death was not reported for more than a year as school administrators failed to realize that she had vanished from their system.

title: Schools Chief in New Jersey Is Pressed on Education Plan
description: Given their first chance to question New Jersey's Education Commissioner at length, lawyers for poor schoolchildren tried to prove today that the state's plan to improve opportunities for those children was frugal and hopelessly vague.

title: The Asian Virus Spreads
description: Until now the financial chaos buffeting Thailand, Hong Kong and other small Asian economies has posed little threat outside the region. But this week the contagion hit South Korea, the world's 11th-largest economy. Korea's misfortune has already shaken Japan and other countries.

title: Foley Says the Only Thing Stopping Him Is the Doctors
description: If the medical staff weren't so cautious, Glenn Foley said today, he would start at quarterback on Sunday against the Minnesota Vikings -- even with the discovery of an old injury to his left knee that clouded his status following the injury he suffered last Sunday against the Chicago Bears.

title: Getting Slapped Is Just Part of The Job
description: ''Free Radicals,'' an ingenious modern-dance production that mixes percussionists and dancers onstage with complex playfulness, is very different from the pieces previously presented by the Sydney Dance Company from Australia.

title: Man of Vision or of Violence?; Where Gang Leader Talks Peace, Police See Just Talk
description: King Tone threaded his arms through the cloth straps of his bulletproof vest. ''I've got to be ready to receive from someone's gun or knife,'' he said, slapping at the vest's midsection as if praising a big meal. ''I don't carry any weapons. This is all there is between me and the next life.''

title: Customs Officer Charged In Drug Smuggling
description: A customs inspector was arrested yesterday and charged with conspiring to import more than 300 pounds of cocaine and 4 pounds of heroin into the United States through Kennedy International Airport from 1994 to 1996.

title: P.S.A.L. Soccer Final Set
description: Martin Luther King Jr. and Cardozo advanced to the championship game of the Public Schools Athletic League soccer tournament yesterday with overtime victories.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report yesterday about a dog owner's encounter with the New York police, illustrating a front-page article on brutality, misstated his given name, as did a picture caption in some editions. He is Robert A. Marino, not Ralph. The report also misstated the time of day when Mr. Marino was released from custody. It was 7 P.M., not 11.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

description: KOPPERMAN-Muriel Z. Beloved wife of the late Louis H. Kopperman, devoted mother of Diane Podell, darling grandmother of Janet Anzovin, Susan Mason, David Podell, and Roger Podell, dear great grandmother of Rafael, Miriam, and Hannah Anzovin, Emily and Seth Mason, and Kevin Podell. Adored sister of Sylvia Grutman Feiner, Doris Marrow Kovar, Howard Zalkin, and the late Ada Spar. Service Thursday 11 A.M. at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Visiting Nurses of L.I., 193 South Street, Oyster Bay, L.I. 11771.

title: Colleges Did Jews No Favor of Exclusion ; Dartmouth's Record
description: To the Editor:

title: Second-Language Rule Draws Protest
description: Less than a week after the State Board of Regents voted to require high school students to pass three years of a foreign language in order to graduate, critics of the measure in Albany and New York City said yesterday that they would press the 16-member body to reconsider.

title: Women's Heart Risk Linked To Types of Fats, Not Total
description: The kinds of fats consumed, not the total amount of fat, determine a woman's risk of suffering a heart attack, according to the first major study of the effects of all dietary fats in women.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Agapanthus

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUIRE, LILLIAN J.
description: MCGUIRE-Lillian J. On November 18, 1997. Wife of the late Harold F. McGuire. Mother of Harold and Bartlett McGuire. Grandmother of Christopher, Katherine and Daniel. Sister of Mrs. Johnson D. Hill, Jr. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street, Saturday, November 22 at 11:30 A.M. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to The Visiting Nurse Service of New York.

title: The Balance of Light
description: This time of year the light is always coming and going. Dawn swells until noon, and then, after a brief hesitation, twilight takes over. The sun edges around the day like a fox making homeward tracks along the margin of a snow-covered field. Summer, in memory, seems almost like a plain of sunshine, without undulation. There is an astronomical explanation for it all -- the sun cuts a much lower angle across the sky in late autumn and sets farther south -- but it is simpler to say that at this time of year, in the country at least, emotion and light are one and the same.

title: Housing Starts Were High In October
description: Construction of housing in the United States rose in October to the highest level in eight months, confounding expectations of a slowdown.

title: Johnson and Knicks Trying To Fix What Ails Them
description: Normally, the lively hitch in Larry Johnson's gait makes him weave a tad when he walks. Lately, he has been swerving.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KANE, ROBERT S.
description: KANE-Robert S. A memorial service for Robert S. Kane, respected colleague and past President of the Association who died on November 10, will be held at the CCUN Chapel, 777 United Nations Plaza (Southwest corner of First Avenue and 44 Street) on Monday, December 8, at 5:30 PM. New York Travel Writers' Association Alan Tucker, President

title: In America; The Game Is Rigged
description: The unemployment rate in the United States dropped to 4.7 percent in October, the lowest it has been in 24 years. Inflation has, for all practical purposes, vanished. Alan Greenspan continues his mad hunt for the dragon of wage inflation, threatening always to kill it, but he can't find it.

title: U.N. Council Gets Evidence Of Illicit Iraqi Arms Buildup
description: The head of the United Nations team disarming Iraq went to the Security Council today armed with photographs, documents and a team of experts to demonstrate that Baghdad continues to pose a threat in almost every area of weapons development and cannot hope to be free of sanctions if it does not cooperate with inspectors.

title: Even Careful Logging Threatens Nature
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: STAR TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC., Santa Barbara, Calif., agreed to buy United Digital Network Inc. of Dallas for $25 million in stock.

title: Mets Still Look To Make Deals
description: Steve Phillips, the Mets' general manager, said yesterday that he expects to resume trade talks for both pitcher Randy Johnson of Seattle and outfielder Gary Sheffield of Florida by the end of the week.

title: Fox Said to Be Ousting Children's TV Pioneer
description: Margaret Loesch, who built the television industry's leading children's network for the Fox Broadcasting Company, will resign from Fox this week, in effect pushed aside by Haim Saban, the chairman of the children's network, people at the companies said yesterday.

title: Dow Jones Sets Wide Cutbacks At Data Unit; Loss to Result
description: In an unexpected shift, Dow Jones & Company announced layoffs and other cutbacks yesterday at its troubled financial-information division that would result in the first annual loss for the company since it went public 34 years ago.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's not just a matter of telling people, 'You ought to work.' Many of these families have real significant problems.''

title: ON-LINE PUBLISHING ARM OF WIRED TO LAY OFF 33 WORKERS
description: Wired Digital, the on-line publishing arm of Wired Ventures, said yesterday that it would lay off 20 percent of its staff, or 33 employees, as part of a reorganization that will allow the company to turn a profit by the fourth quarter of 1998. Wired Digital initially had greater ambitions than the fledgling on-line advertising market could support. The division, which publishes a Web site, Hotwired, and syndicates its Wired News service, has jettisoned features that focused on health, sports and entertainment. Wired Ventures, which is based in San Francisco, has been recasting itself in a narrower mold since its efforts to sell shares to the public failed last year. This summer, after Wired's founder, Louis Rosetto, stepped down as chairman, the company abandoned plans to become an independent book publisher.

title: State Regents Get It Wrong
description: Up to now, New York State's Board of Regents has been careful to build broad support for curriculum changes that affect the state's 3.2 million public school students. But last week the Regents inexplicably passed an extremely disruptive resolution without public hearings or debate. The measure, which would require students to take three years of language classes and pass a challenging exam to graduate, sounds fine in the abstract. But with teacher and resource shortages already common, the new policy could create havoc. The Regents would be wise to reconsider it.

title: M.T.A. Discounts for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Albright Says Iraq Agrees to Let U.S. Inspectors Back
description: Iraq has told Russia that it will allow the unconditional return of all United Nations weapons inspectors, including Americans, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said this morning after an extraordinary 2 A.M. meeting here of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council.

title: Safety Plan Devised for Troubled School
description: Chicago school officials announced today that a safety plan had been adopted to keep pupils at a school in a gang-infested housing project from being transported to another school because of violence nearby.

title: Gruntal Plans To Purchase Hampshire
description: Gruntal & Company, one of the country's oldest securities firms, is expected to announce today that it plans to acquire, for an undisclosed sum, the Hampshire Securities Corporation, a New York investment bank that specializes in providing services to relatively small companies.

title: Chinatown's Fujianese Get a Statue
description: The bronze statue of Confucius has dominated the landscape in Manhattan's Chinatown since 1984, casting a learned and paternal look toward Mott Street, the World Trade Center and the world beyond.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Monday about Wei Jingsheng, the Chinese dissident who was expelled to the United States on Sunday, misstated the year of the photo in some copies. It was 1994, not 1996.

title: The Great Mall of China; As innovators explode stereotypes, Chinese design steps into the spotlight.
description: WHEN Shanghai Tang, the new emporium at Madison Avenue and 61st Street, opens tomorrow night at the propitious moment of 6:18 -- chosen by a feng shui master -- the Tang Army in fuchsia and green will march, lion dancers will pounce, drums will throb, and David Tang, the store's 43-year-old commander in chief, will stab at a roast suckling pig and burn incense -- all ceremonial gestures to bring him good luck. But when the doors open to customers on Saturday, they may find that whatever stereotypes they may harbor about Chinese design -- pale celadon rice bowls, austere wood chairs, and silk lanterns painted with shy peonies -- Mr. Tang has unceremoniously swept away.

title: Seoul Will Ask U.S. and Japan For Assistance
description: South Korea said today that it would ask the United States and Japan to help rescue the country from potentially the most damaging outbreak yet in a financial crisis that has erupted across Asia. But American officials, while encouraging South Korea to seek assistance, made clear that the International Monetary Fund, not Washington, would have to take the lead in any bailout of South Korea, the world's 11th-largest economy.

title: Currents; RECYCLING MADE EASY -- Materialist Minimalism Invades Both Coasts
description: Elizabeth Paige Smith, a Los Angeles furniture designer, typifies the trend there for extreme minimalism softened by a lighthearted use of recycled materials. Her Cube pedestals (far left) are made of end-cut balsa wood found in what she called a ''high-tech junkyard'' used by the aerospace industry.

title: Iowan Makes U.S. History, Giving Birth to 7 Live Babies
description: A shy Iowa seamstress accomplished the extraordinary today, giving birth to seven babies, the first time in this country that so many infants have been born alive.

title: Metro Business; 5 Said to Defraud Banks of $15 Million
description: Five people were charged yesterday with defrauding several New York banks out of more than $15 million by lying on loan applications.

title: Luxembourg Post; Underlying Antipathy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, SOL
description: GOLDSTEIN-Sol. November 19, 1997. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Loving father of Anita, Barry and his wife, Suzanne. Dear brother of Harry. Adored grandfather of Jeffrey, Mindy, Jill, Sharon and Beth. Great-grandfather of Carly and Liza. Devoted brother-in-law of Barbara and Evelyn. Cherished uncle. Service on Friday, at 11 A.M., at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: O'NEIL-Beatrice L. On November 17, in California. Beloved wife of the late George M. O'Neil, Jr. Adored mother of Susan, Michael, John, Jane and Ann. Grandmother to nine. Sister of Lawrence, Mary Agnes, and John. Aunt to many nieces and nephews. She shall be missed dearly. Lawrence Funeral Home, Darien, Connecticut, on Thursday 3-5 and 7-9. Mass of Christian Burial, 10 A.M., Friday, St. John's, Darien CT. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Europe's Pollution Fighter Draws a Bead on U.S. and Japan
description: In the gray world of the European Union's bureaucracy in Brussels, Ritt Bjerregaard, an unwavering politician from Denmark, stands out as a splash of color. While other officials deliver criticism in whispers and avoid confrontation, Ms. Bjerregaard speaks her mind.

title: Currents; URBANE RENEWAL -- The Old World Meets the New
description: Robert Marinelli, an innovative traditionalist, has designed interiors in Europe and Japan. Last year, he opened World Design, a store that features his 70-piece line of furniture handmade overseas in a small workshop. His sofas, chairs and tables, put together with Old World care, are displayed under modern Italian lighting by Luce Plan.

title: Big Deal; The House Tiffany Built, or Did He?
description: JERRY HAMMER, a theatrical producer and creator of game shows, bought a 28-room brownstone with an exquisitely curved copper bow window on 80th Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, 28 years ago. Shortly after he moved in, his elderly neighbors told him that Louis Comfort Tiffany once lived there.

Mass of Christian Burial, Our Lady of Grace RC Church, Friday, 10:15 AM. Interment Resurrection Cemetery, Staten Island, NY.

title: Velasquez Sets a Time to Go
description: Jorge Velasquez, who became a jockey in Panama ''to get my family out of poverty,'' said yesterday that he would ride for the last time at the end of December after a 30-year career that placed him among the leading money-winners for 20 straight years.

title: Mob Leader Ordered to Jail
description: An appeals court judge yesterday ordered a reputed Mafia leader in New York City's private garbage-carting industry to immediately begin serving a 10- to 30-year prison term on racketeering charges.

title: Colleges Did Jews No Favor of Exclusion ; Quota Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL: At 11-0, No Vacancy; The Hawks Surge, Despite Few Advantages of Home
description: There is no nameplate or logo above Dikembe Mutombo's cubicle at the Georgia Dome. In the cavernous, part-time digs of the Atlanta Hawks, anything resembling a team identity has been packed up and carted off until the Knicks arrive on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUCHY, FREDERICK
description: SUCHY-Frederick. The Department of Pediatrics notes with sorrow, the passing of Frederick Suchy, father of our Chairman Frederick J. Suchy, MD. We extend our sympathies to the entire Suchy family.

title: Sheffield Deal May Hinge on Dividing the Dollars
description: Mets officials are cautiously optimistic about their chances of acquiring Gary Sheffield, the Florida All-Star with a $61 million contract, and any deal apparently hinges completely on how desperate the Marlins are to shed Sheffield's six-year pact.

title: Dollar Falls Against the Yen But Rises Versus the Mark
description: The dollar fell against the yen yesterday on a renewed expectation that Japan would bail out its ailing banks, but rose against the mark on speculation that German interest rates will not head higher soon.

title: Art Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Reno Authorizes a Second Death Penalty Case for Prosecutors in Manhattan
description: For the second consecutive day, Attorney General Janet Reno has authorized Federal prosecutors in Manhattan to pursue the death penalty, this time against a man accused of committing nine murders while leading a violent drug gang.

title: Vanished Landlord Has Difficulties With Finances
description: As the police remained stymied in their search for a vanished landlord and his two Manhattan tenants, a portrait of the landlord, Robert Rodriguez, has begun to emerge that is somewhat different from the initial picture of a hard-working immigrant locksmith.

title: Clinton Panel on Race Relations Is Itself Biased, Gingrich Says
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich today sharply criticized President Clinton's race relations advisory board, asserting that the panel did not seek the views of conservatives or foes of affirmative action to help it explore the means to bring about better race relations.

title: Stifling the Race Debate
description: Many Americans were skeptical when Bill Clinton called for ''a national dialogue'' on race but then delegated responsibility to a panel that has been slow to get started. The skepticism deepened this week when the panel held a hearing on diversity but declined to hear from opponents of affirmative action. That does not make for much of a dialogue. The race panel's work should involve more than shouting matches among enemies and advocates of affirmative action, of course. But if the panel is to make a meaningful contribution to the debate on race, it must do more than preach to the converted.

title: Dashed Dreams: Visas Invalid, Airline Workers Told
description: When Delta Air Lines decided in January to shut down its base in Warsaw, Slawek Bardski, a flight attendant there, saw it as an opportunity. The company said it would move him and his wife, Anna, to New York.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: ''If you want me to stop talking about wine, just tell me,'' said Charles Scicolone. ''Sometimes I get too enthusiastic.''

title: S.E.C. Charges 3 in Bond Fraud Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged two former executives at Lazard Freres & Company and a former Stephens Inc. official with fraud in connection with their roles in two Georgia municipal securities offerings.

title: Quiet Time in Quaint Nantucket
description: The first sight of Nantucket from the ferry's deck, with your back to the mainland and your face catching the full sea blast, is one of a thin, dark line with a faint purple aura rising out of the water.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Foreign Language Classes Offer Cultural Insight
