title: Green's Battles in 907 Games Earn Him Ironman Status
description: He begins each day in dawn's darkness pulling warmth from his Bible during a solitary hour of devotion. He ends it late at night plucking ice bags from his knees and stiffly walking out of an arena.

title: Many Specialists Are Left In No Mood for Celebration
description: Amid the celebrations and talk of miracles that swirled around the birth of septuplets in Iowa on Wednesday, some doctors said they felt pangs of dismay.

title: Crude Oil Hits a 4-Month Low As Dispute With Iraq Eases
description: Crude oil prices fell 3.2 percent yesterday, to a four-month low, after Iraq appeared to retreat from a standoff with the United Nations over arms inspections, defusing a dispute that threatened to disrupt Middle East oil exports.

title: Living With the Septuplets, From Some Who Can Guess
description: Terri Stubbs, a Massachusetts mother of 3-month-old triplets, has already calculated that while she and her husband can expect to change 15,000 diapers before Mark, Michelle and Michaela are toilet-trained, Bobbi and Kenny McCaughey, the new parents of septuplets in Iowa, face an unimaginable mountain of 35,000.

title: On Third Down, Barber Makes the Giants Click
description: He was a second-round draft pick for what he could do on third down. And two-thirds of the way through the season, his skill in that role has never been more valuable to the Giants.

title: Foreign Language Classes Offer Cultural Insight; Don't Dismiss French
description: To the Editor:

title: Installations of Glass That Try to Shatter Conceptions
description: Glass, the only art medium that seems to function as a movement in itself, is the subject of a four-person show at the American Craft Museum. But this one is billed as pushing glass work beyond the making of unique objects. ''Four Acts in Glass: Installations by Chihuly, Morris, Powers and Vallien'' is meant, a wall label says, to ''challenge our conception of the relationship of glass to its surroundings and define anew the dynamics between glass and the viewer.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKE, RICHARD M. SR.
description: DICKE-Richard M. Sr. On November 20, 1997 of Garden City, New York. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth, loving father of Cindy Dicke, Mary Dicke Robinson, David Dicke, Deborah Long and the late Richard Jr. Dear grandfather of Jackie Emily, Amanda, Carrie, Steven and Tommy. Loving brother of Harriet Hartline. Visiting at The Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12 St., Garden City, Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Religious service, The Cathedral Of The Incarnation, Garden City, on Monday 10 A.M. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery, Locust Valley, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations to The National Center For Disability Services, Albertson NY, appreciated.

title: TERRA AGREES TO BUY BRITISH FERTILIZER BUSINESS
description: Terra Industries, a fertilizer and crop services company, announced yesterday that it would expand outside North America by buying the British fertilizer business of Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. The purchase price is $340 million. The operation, which would be renamed Terra Nitrogen U.K., had revenues of about $350 million last year. The fertilizer business employs 600 people at two plants and at Imperial Chemical's headquarters in Wilton, England. More than 85 percent of output goes to agricultural and industrial users in Britain. Terra, based in Sioux City, Iowa, produces and distributes fertilizer, crop protection products, seed and services.

title: Chief Financial Officer of Delta Steps Down
description: The chief financial officer of Delta Air Lines Inc., Thomas Roeck, abruptly resigned today, and the company said it had begun looking for a replacement from outside the airline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RACHELSON, FRANCES (NEE KLEIN)
description: RACHELSON - Frances (nee Klein). Of Hackensack, N.J. Formerly of Miami Beach, FL. On November 19, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Luis Rachelson. Loving mother of Sandra Weiner and Claire Milchman. Adored grandmother of Ira Weiner, Ilene Hertz, Scott, Mindy and Gary Milchman. Devoted great-grandmother of David and Eric Weiner, Lindsay and Joshua Hertz, Brian, Brett and Alexa Milchman. Services Sunday November 23, 1997, 10:45AM at ''Wien & Wien'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey.

title: Trying to Crack You Up So You Won't, Driving School Hires Comedians
description: The instructor's chart was headed, ''Top 5 Ways to Avoid Getting In a Car Accident.''

title: Eli A. Finn, 107; Lived Life With Unflagging Zest
description: Eli A. Finn, whose vigor and wry views of a 100-year swath of the modern era earned him a measure of fame in his later years, died on Saturday at his home in Norwalk, Conn., at the age of 107.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Yves Klein

title: Acupuncture in Context
description: To the Editor:

title: HOWELL TO PURCHASE PROPERTIES IN WYOMING FROM AMOCO
description: The Howell Corporation agreed yesterday to buy a package of oil and gas producing properties in Wyoming for $302.5 million from the Amoco Corporation. Howell, based in Houston, said the deal included interests in 2,449 wells, of which 1,812 are operated by Amoco. The properties have proven reserves of 59.6 million barrels of oil equivalent and generated about $46 million in pretax cash flow in 1996, Howell said. After the deal, Howell's total proven reserves would increase to 77.6 million barrels of oil equivalent. Howell said it would hire most of the 115 Amoco workers in Wyoming. Shares of Howell rose $1.75 yesterday, to $19.75. Amoco rose $1.25, to $93.625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELTHAM, IRENE
description: FELTHAM-Irene. Of Dix Hills, New York, on November 19, 1997. A brilliant and dedicated teacher of English in the New York City School System, at Martin Van Buren High School, Queens Village, New York. She was the beloved wife of John. Cherished mother of Lynne (Ralph) Stewart, Donald (Andrea) Feltham, and Laurel (Seth) Freedman. Loving grandmother of Brenna and Geoffrey (Marta) Stewart, Dr. Zenobia (Timothy) Brown, and Alexander and Andrew Freedman. Beloved great-grandmother of Milana Velasquez, Ernesto and Arthur Stewart. Reposing at Jacobsen Funeral Home, Huntington, New York, Thursday and Friday. Christian Burial Service at Sweet Hollow Presbyterian Church, Melville, New York, Saturday morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOCHICHIO, VIRGINIA A. (NEE TARANTO)
description: BOCHICHIO-Virginia A. (nee Taranto). Of Greenwich, Conn. On November 19. Beloved wife of Anthony. Devoted mother of Laura and Anthony, Jr. Loving daughter of Adeline Taranto and the late Anthony. Fond sister of Eleanor Hertel and Joyce DiNatoli. Adored aunt. Reposing Leo P. Gallagher and Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT., Thursday 7-9 PM, Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial Saturday 10:30AM, at St. Paul's R.C. Church, cremation to follow at Ferncliff Crematory.

title: An Ex-Spymaster Revives Russia's Mideast Influence
description: Seven years ago, Yevgeny M. Primakov was racing around the Middle East in a futile bid to stop the Persian Gulf war. The Americans regarded him as a meddlesome nuisance. The Iraqis were not eager to listen.

title: The Deal With Iraq
description: The crisis over Iraq has taken a surprising turn. Baghdad and Washington, which only days ago seemed headed for a military confrontation over weapons inspections, now seem close to a diplomatic resolution. But Iraq's apparent change of heart has come about so swiftly that it is hard to tell how long the deal, arranged by the Russians and announced yesterday, will hold together.

title: Capote Belle Wins at Aqueduct
description: After an absence of four months for rest and freshening, Capote Belle returned to the races yesterday and scored a one-length victory in the well-cast allowance feature of fillies and mares at Aqueduct.

title: On Stage and Off
description: Disney's Thanks: Deed and Word

title: Bo Diddley Objects To Cigarette Ad
description: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company has discontinued a print advertisement featuring a blues guitarist after Bo Diddley complained that the photograph resembled him and threatened to sue.

title: Taking the Children
description: Many parents find it agonizing to decide where to go out with their children, feeling that their choices are limited to either theme restaurants or those that give away gifts and candy. What children require, however, is not toys but tolerance, the sort of welcoming attitude that relaxes parents and makes children less conscious of having to be on their best behavior. That, and maybe one dish they are bound to like. Here are a dozen such restaurants. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRANK, NEWTON
description: FRANK-Newton. Memorial Service 12 Noon, Sunday, November 23, Carlyle Towers, 100 Winston Drive, Cliffside Park, NJ. Call 201224-9525 for directions.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Mantle Estate Files Lawsuit
description: Mickey Mantle's estate charged yesterday in a Federal lawsuit that the late Yankee's former agent stole and concealed personal items that are part of a memorabilia auction scheduled for tomorrow in Manhattan.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: FRESH AMERICA TO BUY ASSETS OF FRANCISCO DISTRIBUTION
description: The Fresh America Corporation signed a letter of intent yesterday to acquire substantially all the assets of the Francisco Distribution Company of Norwalk, Calif., a food marketing, distribution and repackaging company. Terms were not disclosed, but Fresh America said Francisco's 1998 revenues are expected to be more than $100 million. For the nine months that ended Sept. 26, Fresh America, a food distribution management company, had revenues of $249.2 million. Its stock gained $1.25 yesterday, to $21.25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBIN, MURIEL ROSENTHAL
description: EBIN-Muriel Rosenthal. Age 88, passed away on Thursday, November 20, 1997 in San Antonio, TX. She was born on August 14, 1909 in Brooklyn, New York. She was a graduate of Hunter College in New York City and was a longtime high school art teacher. Mrs. Ebin previously resided in Brooklyn, New York and Royal Palm Beach. She was preceded in death by her first husband: Benjamin H. Rosenthal. Survivors include her husband: Herbert Ebin; sons: Saul H. Rosenthal and wife, Cindy and Daniel M. Rosenthal and wife, Deanne; and grandchildren: Jesse, Sadie, and Amy Rosenthal. Graveside Services will take place at Knollwood Park Cemetery in Ridgewood, New York.

title: Children's TV Pioneer Officially Quits
description: Margaret Loesch announced yesterday in Los Angeles that she was resigning as vice chairwoman of Fox Kids Worldwide, effective today.

title: Market Place; The board of Dow Jones is said to vote for selling the data unit.
description: THE board of Dow Jones & Company met yesterday and voted to put the company's troubled financial-information division up for sale, a person close to Dow Jones said.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 13
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: A Young Legal Eagle Flies With Vultures
description: John Grisham, who in ''The Rainmaker'' explored the shadier regions of the insurance game, is himself the closest thing to an insurance policy Hollywood has these days. Yet for Francis Ford Coppola, what would filming a Grisham courtroom drama offer beyond a means of paying the rent? Plenty, as it turns out: despite Mr. Coppola's taste for moodier and more eclectic material, this mainstream opportunity pays off. Drawing a parade of colorful performances from a constantly surprising cast, the curiously titled ''John Grisham's 'The Rainmaker' '' is Mr. Coppola's best and sharpest film in years.

title: F.B.I. Agent Testifies That Nichols Told of Driving for McVeigh
description: Terry L. Nichols told investigators that three days before the Federal Building bombing he searched downtown Oklahoma City for Timothy J. McVeigh, driving past the building several times before finding Mr. McVeigh in an alley, a Federal agent testified today.

title: Quantum Closes a Plant and Cuts 430 Jobs
description: The Quantum Corporation has halted production at its Louisville, Colo., plant, eliminating about 430 jobs.

title: Elegant Exotica On Small Screen
description: It was the mid-1960's and with the sexual revolution in full cry, movie audiences weren't averse to a little ''exploitation.'' In so-called grindhouse films, sex had become explicit, though rather restrained, compared with the hard-core pornography that was then also emerging, and even with some of the steamier encounters in R-rated movies today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROIDY, GERALD
description: BROIDY-Gerald. Beloved husband of Sue Broidy of Santa Barbara, died on November 19 of cancer after a long illness. He is survived by his daughter Ellen and her life partner Joan Ariel of Irvine, CA, his stepchildren Christian Greenfield and his wife Laura of Santa Barbara and Sophie Greenfield of London, UK, his brother Alfred of West Haven, CT. and cousin Joan Fallert and her husband Jerome of Santa Barbara. Jerry was born in Pittsburgh, PA on May 4, 1919 and grew up in NY where he graduated from CCNY in 1942. He served in the US Army Counter Intelligence Service in Germany during the war. His long career with Time, Inc. began in NY in 1949 where he worked in marketing, promotion and telphone sales culminating in a move to London in 1976 with Time Life Books. Following his retirement in 1984 he worked as a fundraiser for Cancer Relief in London before moving to Santa Barbara in 1993. Jerry served on the board of The Arts Fund of Santa Barbara and the advisory board of Women's Economic Ventures. He was a passionate advocate of social justice and equality for women and minorities and worked for many years for the National Urban League and the Democratic Party. He loved New York and London, music and the theater and above all the company of his numerous friends all over the world. Donations in his memory may be made to The Arts Fund, PO Box 91926, Santa Barbara, CA or The Leigh Block Hospice House, 900 Calle de Los Amigos, Santa Barbara, CA. 93105.

title: It's Never Too Late to Fall In Love, the Tango Shows
description: Two's good company. It takes two to tango, and the seven couples in the Argentine company called Tango x 2 danced very enticingly in a program called ''Una Noche de Tango,'' which opened a two-week season at City Center on Wednesday night.

title: Apartheid Inquiry Again Insists Ex-Leader Testify
description: The Truth and Reconciliation Commission looking into the crimes committed under apartheid subpoenaed former President P. W. Botha for the second time today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGEDORN, CHARLES
description: HAGEDORN-Charles, 79, on November 17, 1997, beloved husband of the late Jane, devoted father of Christopher, cherished grandfather of Christopher and James. At Charles' request a private family service was held. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. Donations in his memory can be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave., New York, N.Y. 10021.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MAIL BOXES ETC., San Diego, said its shareholders had approved its merger with U.S. Office Products. Each Mail Boxes Etc. share will be exchanged for 1.349 shares of U.S. Office.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Sometimes, the Knicks Look Good
description: Before the Knicks ended Atlanta's nice little run last night, Herb Williams, 39 years old, was asked how it felt to be the oldest player in the league on the oldest team in the league.

title: Meditrust Bids $1.3 Billion To Buy Interstate Hotels
description: The Meditrust Corporation, one of the nation's biggest health care companies, has offered about $1.3 billion to acquire the Interstate Hotels Company, which owns and manages hotels, people close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Political Memo; End Is in Sight for Campaign Fund-Raising Inquiry
description: The campaign-finance investigation that has preoccupied the Justice Department, the White House and Congress for much of the past year is coming to a turning point, particularly for two main characters: President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore.

title: Yeltsin, to Mollify Parliament, Strips Besieged Deputy of Post
description: Seeking to end an ethics scandal that is threatening economic reform, President Boris N. Yeltsin appointed a new Finance Minister today to replace the embattled Anatoly B. Chubais.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Communism And Crimes: French Bristle At Best-Seller
description: In a good many countries, an 846-page historical tome about the crimes of Communism would head straight for university libraries. In France, ''The Black Book of Communism,'' as it is called, has gone to the top of the nonfiction best-seller list, with sales fueled by heated debate in Parliament and the news media and by squabbling among its authors over how its material should be interpreted.

title: INSIDE
description: Some smokers puff away during the Great American Smokeout.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Myron Stout

title: On 1994 Blood Bath in Rwanda, Tribunal Hews to a Glacial Pace
description: The witness's voice quavered slightly as she recalled the horrific scene three years ago in Rwanda. She said she had watched while several Hutu militiamen gang-raped three Tutsi women, one of them pregnant, and then bludgeoned them to death before throwing them into a shallow grave.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Gabriel Laderman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELSEY, ELSIE (NEE LUDDECKE)
description: KELSEY-Elsie (nee Luddecke). Of Montclair, New Jersey, formerly of Short Hills, on Wednesday, November 19, 1997. Wife of John F. Kelsey, Jr. Mother of John F. Kelsey, III, and Bruce C. Kelsey. Grandmother of Katherine Elizabeth and John F. Kelsey, IV. Sister of Ralph, Dr. Hugh and William Luddecke. A memorial service will be held in Central Presbyterian Church, 70 Maple Street, Summit, New Jersey, Saturday, November 22 at 1:00 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Overlook Hospital Auxiliary, 99 Beauvoir Ave., Summit, NJ 07901 or Montclair-Kimberley Academy Foundation, 201 Valley Road, Montclair, New Jersey 07042.

title: An Era With the Bomb on Its Mind
description: DR. STRANGELOVE'S AMERICA

title: Corrections
description: A brief report yesterday about the sentencing of a man convicted of killing five people in a Bronx shoe store two years ago misstated his name. He is Michael Vernon, not Vernon Michaels.

title: HOSPITALITY PROPERTIES TO BUY 15 CANDLEWOOD HOTELS
description: Hospitality Properties Trust said yesterday that it would buy and then lease back 15 hotels from Candlewood Hotel Company for $100 million, adding Candlewood, a fast-growing extended-stay chain, as a tenant. The properties are in 13 states. The purchase is the latest for Hospitality Properties, based in Newton, Mass., a real estate investment trust that invests in hotels. It has spent about $550 million this year. The move would give Candlewood capital for its expansion. The company, based in Wichita, Kan., operates about 45 midpriced hotels for travelers who need a room for five nights or longer. The purchase would bring the portfolio of Hospitality Properties to 135 hotels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COVALSKY, ANNA
description: COVALSKY-Anna. Of Staten Island, November 19, 1997. Loving mother of Barbara Stewart, Donna Danforth and Denise Kaye. Sister of Ken Yanik and Sue Seaman. Funeral service St. Paul's U.M. Church Monday 10 AM. Interment Cemetery of the Resurrection. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Bedell-Pizzo Funeral Home, Staten Island.

title: At the Movies
description: Getting the Role Was a Fight

title: New Video Releases
description: Chasing Amy

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; Beetlemania: Snug Bugs and Other Specimens
description: ALL it Bug II: Early in 1998, some 65 years after the Volkswagen Beetle was conceived -- as the brainchild of Adolf Hitler -- a new Beetle will make its debut, updated for the 21st century.

title: A Jew's Slaying Fuels Tensions in Jerusalem's Muslim Quarter
description: In the alley where Gabriel Hirschberg was cut down by a burst of automatic weapons fire early today in Jerusalem's walled Old City, four of his fellow yeshiva students held a study session opposite a makeshift memorial of Israeli flags and a candle.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW ; Studying His Children's Faces: Portals Into Lives Uncluttered and Vibrant
description: When the Brazilian photographer Mario Cravo Neto made his solo debut in New York City five years ago, his work easily made the leap across boundaries and cultures. His black-and-white prints of birds, masks, balloons, tortoise shells or stones held enigmatically against faces or naked torsos were rich with iconographic symbolism. But they were also so fluid and packed with raw energy and a darkly elegant symmetry that viewers ignorant of pantheistic rituals could still savor the intricate play of the fantastical with the real.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about legislative hearings in Hartford on a new stadium for the University of Connecticut referred incorrectly in some copies to a CBS sportscaster who testified on behalf of the plan. He is Jim Nantz, not Nance.

title: De La Hoya Adds Clancy as Trainer
description: Oscar De La Hoya, the World Boxing Council welterweight champion, has added the veteran trainer Gil Clancy to his corner for his Dec. 6 bout against Wilfredo Rivera at Caesars Palace in Atlantic City. De La Hoya dismissed the trainer Emanuel Steward last week because he did not feel Steward was spending enough time getting him ready for his fight against Rivera.

title: Stocks Soar as Turmoil in Asia Seems to Ease
description: Stocks rallied again yesterday, gaining some momentum after the global financial and political turbulence that has rocked markets around the world over the last few weeks eased somewhat.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: May Stevens

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLICKMAN, NANCY (NEE COPELAND)
description: BLICKMAN-Nancy (nee Copeland). Age 77, November 10, 1997 of Pearl River, New York. Wife of Newton A. Blickman; mother of Victoria Jacqueney and Stewart Blickman; grandmother of Benjamin Jacqueney; sister of Harry C. Copeland, Jr., and Cynthia Stephenson. Memorial Saturday, November 22, 3 PM, Nauraushaun Pres. Church. Contributions may be made to Rockland Country Day School, Congers, New York.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Trade Deficit Jumps

title: CHRONICLE
description: Friends will be congratulating GENE FRANKEL, the Obie Award-winning theatrical director, on his 50th anniversary in the theater Monday night. And then they will congratulate him again on his newest play, ''Hallow'd Ground: The Private Thoughts of Abraham Lincoln,'' which opens that night at the Gene Frankel Theater at 24 Bond Street in Greenwich Village. Then, to add to the mix, they will wish him well for his 74th birthday, which actually occurs on Dec. 23 but will be celebrated then anyway.

title: White House Keeps Videos From Congress
description: Asserting the authority of the executive branch of the Government, the White House today withheld videotapes of 43 events attended by President Clinton that had been sought by Congressional investigators, but turned over tapes of 24 other fund-raising and political affairs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERGES, WILLIAM T.
description: GERGES-William T. On Saturday, November 15, 1997, in his 91st year. A resident of Coler Memorial Hospital, Roosevelt Island, NY, formerly of Elmhurst, NY. Veteran, WW II, Pacific Campaign. Devoted brother of the late Viola Gerges. Reposing at the Shaffer Funeral Home, Little Neck, NY. Visiting Friday, 9AM. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday 10:45 AM, St. Anastasia R.C. Church. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Phillips Let Go After Troubling Signs
description: The troubled career of running back Lawrence Phillips took another problematic turn yesterday when the St. Louis Rams released their former No. 1 draft pick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAFFORD, TERRY
description: STAFFORD-Terry. On November 19, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Sol. Loving mother of Barbara (Rob Armstrong) and Meri. Cherished aunt of Marc, Jimmy, Tracy and Betsy. Dear sister-in-law of Evelyn and Jerry Shapiro, sister of Charles (Rita) Tenenbaum. Services Friday, 1:15 PM, at ''RiversidePark West,'' 333 Amsterdam Ave.

title: FOOTBALL NOTEBOOK
description: BUCKNELL-COLGATE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAIKEN, IRWIN
description: CHAIKEN-Irwin. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Loving father of Joan Kalmenson, Beth Cohen and the late Amy Chaiken. Cherished grandfather of Lindsay, Brian and Adam.

title: A Shift to Diplomacy and Coexistence
description: President Clinton came into office executing the policy toward Iraq that he had inherited: Keep Saddam Hussein cornered and respond to provocations with force.

title: Glendale Federal Offers to Settle
description: Glendale Federal Bank offered to settle its longstanding suit against the Federal Government yesterday for $1.5 billion and lend the money to people of low and moderate income.

title: A Radical Revolution Traditionally Chronicled
description: The American Revolution makes it onto television on Sunday in emphatically nonrevisionist fashion. ''Liberty'' offers six hours of historical personages, portrayed by Broadway and Hollywood professionals, delivering excerpts from letters, diaries and pronouncements that touch the high points of America's war for independence. They are abetted by American and British historians, period music, prints, maps, newspaper cartoons and battle re-enactments on land and sea.

title: Foreign Language Classes Offer Cultural Insight; How to Test Fluency
description: To the Editor:

title: Hughes Supply in Deal
description: Hughes Supply Inc. agreed today to acquire the International Supply Company, a construction- and industrial-materials distributor, for an undisclosed amount of cash and stock. International Supply, based in Dallas, sells water and sewer equipment, plumbing supplies, valves and fittings. It has annual sales of about $150 million. Hughes Supply, based in Orlando, sells construction and industrial materials.

title: The Green-Eyed Monster Fells Men of Every Color
description: In the past, white actors who played Othello inevitably became obsessed with makeup. ''The whole thing will be in the lips and the color,'' Laurence Olivier observed in a 1964 Life magazine interview, in the midst of preparing his legendary portrayal. ''I'll use just a little tiny touch of lake and a lot more brown and a little mauve.''

title: House Ethics Charade
description: Nearly two years after news accounts first raised questions about his dealings, the wildly misnamed House Ethics Committee has finally gotten around to opening an investigation into Representative Bud Shuster, the Pennsylvania Republican who heads the Transportation Committee. But it is hard to have confidence in the vigor of this inquiry.

title: Silent 20 Years, but Really Listening
description: ''What the Deaf Man Heard,'' the latest Hallmark Hall of Fame movie, has even more of a cotton-candy heart than most Hallmark productions.

title: ON COLLEGE FOOTBALL ; The Best Campaign For the Heisman Is . . .
description: Well, this is where I sign off from college football and segue to the pros. This is the time of year when hard work, long drives and stunning performances in campus stadiums give way to polls and beauty pageants.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Joaquin Torres-Garcia

title: Sports of The Times; Excellence Becomes Expensive
description: IF the industry known as Major League Baseball continues to wonder why it continues to disenchant more and more fans, it has only to watch the butchering of the Florida Marlins by their bottom-line owner.

title: Predecessor of Chekhov Gets a Chance in the West
description: Years before Chekhov chopped down the cherry orchard that was 19th-century Russia, Aleksandr Ostrovsky was honing the ax with dozens of plays that satirized the greed and hypocrisy of the landed gentry.

title: Robert Stanley, 65, Pop Artist Who Painted From Photographs
description: Robert Stanley, a painter who translated newspaper photographs and other commercial imagery into gritty works on canvas, died on Saturday in Manhattan on his way to Beekman Hospital. He was 65.

title: Meet U.S. Energy Needs With Domestic Reserves
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: As if the mastery of 110 different characters, the ownership of a Spanish restaurant and the delivery of advice to taxi passengers to buckle their seat belts were not enough, PLACIDO DOMINGO is preparing three new operatic roles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARROW, SADIE
description: ZARROW-Sadie. Dearly loved and loving wife of the late Joseph, mother of Walter and the late Marilyn, grandmother of Laura, Andrew, Gayle, Scott, and Susan, and great grandmother of Matthew, Anna, Blaire, and Danielle on Nov. 17th at the age of eighty-seven after a brief illness. She was a great lady. Contributions to the Daniel Cantor Senior Citizens Center, Sunrise, FL, will be appreciated.

title: Trade Deficit Widens; Impact From Asia Fell
description: The nation's trade deficit jumped to an eight-month high of $11.1 billion in September, the Government said today, as financial turmoil in Asia helped widen the gap. The deficit with China and Japan widened significantly.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Meet U.S. Energy Needs With Domestic Reserves; Technology Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Rejects Plea For Change of Venue In the Louima Case
description: A New York State appeals court has rejected a request by one of the officers accused of brutalizing Abner Louima that his trial be moved out of the New York region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOOKBINDER, GEORGE HARRY
description: BOOKBINDER - George Harry. With profound sorrow, we announce that George Harry Bookbinder passed away peacefully at his home in New York City on November 10, following a protracted illness. Interment took place at the Wooster Cemetery in Danbury Connecticut on Wednesday, November 12. He is survived by his sons, David and Jay, and two grandchildren, Jeremy and Eliana. In lieu of flowers, we would be grateful for contributions to Oxfam America.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY ; High Ozone Levels Occur More Often, Report Says
description: Levels of ground-level ozone in the state exceeded Federal clean-air standards this summer more than twice as many times as last year, according to a report released yesterday by the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, an environmental group.

title: ROBBINS & MYERS IN $104 MILLION DEAL FOR J. M. HUBER UNIT
description: Robbins & Myers Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a J. M. Huber Corporation unit for about $104 million, broadening Robbins & Myers's oilfield business. The unit being acquired is Flow Control Equipment Inc., a supplier of valves and wellhead equipment for the oil and gas recovery market. It has annual sales of about $60 million. Flow Control Equipment, based in Tomball, Tex., would operate as a separate unit initially and would later be integrated with Robbins & Myers's Moyno Oilfield Products unit. Flow Control Equipment has production operations in Borger, Tex., and Edmonton, Alberta. Shares of Robbins & Myers, based in Dayton, Ohio, rose $1.4375 yesterday, to $38.50. Huber, which is closely held, is based in Edison, N.J.

title: Foreign Language Classes Offer Cultural Insight; Start With Basics
description: To the Editor:

title: A Deep Split On Policing Of Sweatshops
description: As a Presidential task force nears its deadline to set up a code of conduct for apparel factories, the labor unions, human rights groups and corporate giants in the group remain badly divided, fighting over issues like how much the public should be told when inspectors discover labor violations in factories.

title: Collection of Medieval Enamels Fails to Attract Interest or Dollars at Auction
description: The sale of what was believed to be the last great collection of medieval art still in private hands fell completely flat last night, when the Keir Collection of mainly 12th- and 13th-century enamel work fetched a mere $5.5 million at Sotheby's. The auction house had estimated it would bring more than $25 million.

title: The Greed-Fear Cycle
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREMENTZ, ROBERT
description: KREMENTZ-Robert Middleton, formerly of New Vernon, NJ, died November 15, 1997, at Hilton Head Island, S.C. He retired in 1974 as Chairman of Krementz & Co in Newark, NJ. He was a member of the New York Yacht Club and the Cruising Club of America. A memorial service will be held at First Presbyterian Church of New Vernon, 4:00 PM, Tuesday, November 25. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to The Newark Museum. Attn: Mary Sue Sweeney Price, 49 Washington Street, Newark, NJ 07101.

title: Metro Business; ABC Confirms Lease For Times Sq. Studio
description: ABC confirmed yesterday that it had leased space for a studio and office complex at 1500 Broadway, at 43d Street. The idea is to turn Times Square into a backdrop for ''Good Morning America'' and other news, sports and entertainment programs.

title: 87 Are Hurt as Subway Train Runs Into Another in Queens
description: Rounding a curve in the waning minutes of the morning rush yesterday, a six-car subway train rear-ended another train that had paused at a red light in the tunnel between two stations in Queens, bumping and bruising 87 passengers and disrupting the underground lifeline for thousands of workers in three boroughs.

title: Uzbek Sculptor's Dreams Of Castro and Bill Clinton
description: One of Central Asia's best-known sculptors spends his days in bed surrounded by his busts of world figures and statues of nudes, animals and joyful-looking children.

title: With Tricks and Sticks, Going Thump in the Night
description: Sticks and shticks both played a part in the concert by Ondekoza, the Demon Drummers of Japan, on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall. Ondekoza, founded 28 years ago, takes its drumming seriously; its members live as a commune and train as both drummers and long-distance runners. The original group divided in 1981 and Kodo, a similar group, was formed. Both groups treat drumming as a secular ritual and a spectacle, approaching their drums -- including the giant two-headed o-daiko, five feet in diameter and weighing 700 pounds -- with the movements of martial artists and dancers.

title: Hasek Stops the Bruins
description: Dominik Hasek stopped 29 Boston shots and Miroslav Satan had two goals and an assist as the Buffalo Sabres continued their recent dominance over the Bruins with a 5-0 victory last night in Boston.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AHRENS, LESLIE JAY
description: AHRENS-Leslie Jay. On November 19, 1997. Revered, loved and dedicated kindegarten teacher at The Epiphany School. Loving wife of Charles. Loving daughter of Marion and the late Henry Jay. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (at 20 Street) NYC, today, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Church of the Epiphany, Saturday, 10AM. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to The Epiphany School Scholarship Fund, 234 East 22 Street, New York, NY 10010.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Nicolas de Stael

title: All's Quiet On Yankee Front
description: George Steinbrenner, volunteer diplomat in the Bernie Williams negotiations and point man on the pursuit of Randy Johnson, made no moves yesterday. Instead, the Yankees' hierarchy huddled on a conference call, outlining strategy and taking care of housekeeping items such as the formation of the 40-man roster.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Global Pact Bans Bribery In Victory For U.S. Business

title: Two Exchanges Post Rises In Uncovered Short Sales
description: In a short sale, shares are borrowed from a broker and sold in hopes that prices will fall, so that they can be bought back at lower prices for a profit. If the share price rises, the short-seller faces a loss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBETT, SPENCER
description: GARBETT-Spencer, 27 years old. Survived by his parents Irene Sperber and Marshall Garbett. He was an actor and television host in Los Angeles and New York. Memorial Service 5 P.M., on Friday, November 21, 1997 at Church of the Hills, Forest Lawn, Hollywood Hills. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Make a Wish Foundation, 1875 Century Park East, Suite #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, FLORENCE (NEE FLEISCHER)
description: ROSENTHAL - Florence (nee Fleischer). Sister, aunt. We all love you dearly. Alan and Martha, Michael, Peter and Jennifer, Ari Fleischer.

title: Edwin Mansfield, 67, Scholar Of Economics and Technology
description: Edwin Mansfield, a leading scholar of the economics of technological change, died on Monday at his home in Wallingford, Pa. He was 67.

title: Chairman of RJR Food Unit Will Retire
description: H. John Greeniaus, the chairman and chief executive of the food subsidiary of RJR Nabisco, will retire at the end of the year because of a health problem, the company announced late yesterday, stunning analysts who were still at their desks. He will be replaced by James Kilts, who was most recently an executive vice president of the Philip Morris Companies, in charge of the Kraft Foods Worldwide division.

title: CLINTON SAYS U.S. WILL WAIT AND SEE AS IRAQIS BACK OFF
description: With a ''wait and see'' edge of wariness, President Clinton welcomed Saddam Hussein's decision today to back down and allow United Nations inspectors to resume their search for weapons of mass destruction in Iraq.

title: Delays Anger Judge in Suit Against Sharpton and 2
description: The judge in the defamation lawsuit against three former advisers of Tawana Brawley betrayed a rapidly growing impatience today with the trial's frequent delays and glacial pace, shouting at one of the defendants, Alton H. Maddox Jr., who is representing himself, when he stood to make one of his many complaints.

title: 29 NATIONS AGREE TO OUTLAW BRIBING FOREIGN OFFICIALS
description: After years of lobbying by the United States, the world's industrialized countries formally agreed today to a treaty that would outlaw the practice of bribing foreign government officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, FRANK
description: WEISSMAN-Frank. The volunteers of the Central Park Medical Unit deeply mourn the loss of our esteemed crew chief, colleague and friend.

title: Robert Palmer Is Dead at 52; Critic Covered Rock and Blues
description: Robert Palmer, a music critic, historian, musician and producer, died yesterday at the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 52 and had lived in New Orleans.

title: Three Brothers Accused Of Running Deadly Gang
description: In an indictment unsealed yesterday, Federal prosecutors accused three brothers of running a drug gang in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx that was responsible for the slayings of six men.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY ; Advocacy Groups Urge Tougher Fuel Standards
description: The average New Jersey family could cut its gasoline costs in half if Congress enacted the tougher fuel efficiency standards recommended by a Presidential advisory committee, two nonprofit groups said yesterday.

title: Rahal Won't Race After 1998 Season
description: Bobby Rahal, winner of the 1986 Indianapolis 500 and a three-time Indy-car champion, announced yesterday that the 1998 season would be his last as a driver. Rahal, 44, said that his decision was precipitated by the demands of his family as well as his role as owner of his own Indy-car team. Rahal also owns a number of auto dealerships.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY ; New Jersey Transit Expands Train Seating
description: Starting next month, commuters who ride New Jersey Transit's crowded Midtown Direct railroad line at peak periods will have an easier time finding a place to sit. Yesterday, the agency announced that it would add 476 new seats to the service on Dec. 1, using new cars that hold more people.

title: CABARET REVIEW ; A Romantic Seasoned By Time
description: Ten years ago Andrea Marcovicci, an actress and sometime nightclub singer, first appeared at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel and immediately became a cabaret icon, wafting the mystique of a beautiful high-strung socialite as she conjured up a romantic never-never land of classic popular songs and old movies. A lot has changed since then.

title: MIZAR PLANS TO MERGE WITH LOUGHBOROUGH SOUND IMAGES
description: Mizar Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to merge with Loughborough Sound Images Ltd. of Britain for stock currently valued at more than $50 million. Both companies make computing products used to process signals like radar, sonar or digital voice communications. Mizar primarily serves the military industry, while Loughborough focuses on telecommunications. Under terms of the deal, Mizar would issue 7.8 million new shares plus options for 599,000 more shares. Mizar, which is based in Carrollton, Tex., has about 5.1 million common shares outstanding. Loughborough shareholders would have a 60 percent stake in the new company, and Mizar shareholders would have 40 percent. Shares of Mizar rose 50 cents yesterday, to $6.625.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times, or by contributors, of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: For Citibank, A Problem Plum; Mexican Deal Survives, Despite Fraud Case and Political Turmoil
description: Julio de Quesada, the head of Citibank's operations in Mexico, did not know that the chairman of a Mexican bank he was negotiating to buy had installed a secret door and an underground tunnel in a palatial mansion in northern Mexico.

title: Brazil Passes Bill to Shrink Public Sector
description: Under intense pressure to distance itself from the volatility shaking Asian markets, the Brazilian Government has won an important legislative victory in its drive to strengthen the economy by slashing the country's bloated public work force.

title: Accounts
description: -- U. S. Care, Santa Monica, Calif., to Kovel Kresser & Partners, Santa Monica, as the first agency for the long-term care provider. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Cabaret Guide
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes highly recommended shows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FASTENBERG, VERA
description: FASTENBERG-Vera. The National Commission and staff of the Anti-Defamation League mourn the passing of Vera Fastenberg, beloved sister of our General Counsel, Arnold Forster. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Arnold and his family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Howard P. Berkowitz, Nat'l Chmn. Abraham H. Foxman, Nat'l Dir.

title: Some Go All Out for Smokeout; Others Go Out to Smoke
description: The Great American Smokeout, that annual antismoking ritual, was duly ignored yesterday by many in Manhattan's tribe of outdoor smokers. Shivering as usual, they populated doorways and office lobbies in a smoke-out of their own.

title: J.D. Salinger To Be Focus Of a Memoir
description: The novelist and journalist Joyce Maynard said yesterday that she would publish a memoir in which she would describe her relationship with the famously reclusive writer J. D. Salinger, the author of ''The Catcher in the Rye,'' breaking a 25-year silence about the affair.

title: Officer Slain and Suspect Killed At Bridge as He Flees to New York
description: One police officer was shot and killed and another critically wounded last night at the beginning and end of a 60-mile, high-speed chase that started outside a Chinese restaurant in the shore town of Long Branch, N.J., and concluded in a dramatic shootout at the George Washington Bridge.

title: Progress Made By 7 Babies Encourages Their Doctors
description: One day after the stunning birth of seven babies to an Iowa woman, the tiny infants were making good medical progress, and the family's media-besieged doctors said they were amazed that there did not seem to be more complications in their development so far.

title: Pierce Ousts No. 1 Hingis With Power And Control
description: Martina Hingis, the undisputed No. 1 player in the world, had her magical angles. Mary Pierce, the seventh-seeded player at the Chase Championships, had her magnum force. It was not a match made in heaven, but that's the level of tennis it yielded; that's what it took for might to make right in the form of Pierce's passionate and pulverizing 6-3, 2-6, 7-5 upset of the near-invincible Hingis last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: On My Mind; Bowing Saddam Back
description: After three weeks of intensive round-the-clock, round-the-world negotiations that summoned all its diplomatic and moral power, the Clinton Administration achieved these landmark results:

title: As the Moral and the Analytic Meet
description: ''The Sweet Hereafter'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Here are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 3. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: G.O.P. Tries to Win Hispanic Support Reagan Once Had
description: When Ronald Reagan dug into a plate of rice and beans at a Cuban restaurant in Miami to the sound of cheering crowds in 1983, it was obvious he had wooed Florida's Hispanic voters.

title: Conjuring Up Eccentrics Amid the Oaks and Azaleas
description: When Clint Eastwood's film version of the hugely popular ''Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil'' arrives in Savannah, Ga., it offers the standard shot of Spanish moss. And when the film's main character, a newly concocted Town and Country writer called John Kelso (John Cusack), first gets to town, he hops onto a double-decker tour bus. Sure enough, it's guided-tour time, as Mr. Eastwood brings on the gracious settings and colorful eccentrics that have given John Berendt's book its phenomenal staying power (nearly three years as a best seller). But the fundamental magic of Mr. Berendt's account is not on the itinerary here.

title: 3 Admit Guilt In Intercepting Of Pager Calls Of Officials
description: Three executives of a company that sells news tips to newspapers and broadcasters pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of illegally intercepting private communications of the Police and Fire Departments.

title: U.S. FILTER RAISES ITS BID FOR MEMTEC TO $380 MILLION
description: The U.S. Filter Corporation said yesterday that it had raised its offer for Memtec Ltd. a second time, to $36 a share, making the acquisition worth about $380 million. Memtec's directors said they would recommend that shareholders accept the higher offer. U.S. Filter, based in Palm Desert, Calif., made its first unsolicited bid for Memtec, an Australian water-filter company, in October, offering $30 a share, or $330 million. Earlier this month, it increased the bid by 15 percent, to $34.50 a share, or $379.5 million. U.S. Filter is a provider of industrial, municipal and residential water and waste-water filter systems.

title: Swiss Struggle to Understand Killings at Luxor
description: In the land that reaped the most pain from the massacre on Monday in Luxor, when 35 Swiss were among 58 foreigners killed, the bereaved turned today to the riddles that still confront them: how to understand the deaths of loved ones when no clear picture of each individual killing has emerged; what to do about children left with grandparents while mom and dad went on vacation in Egypt only to be shot to death or wounded.

title: Spate of Skinhead Violence Catches Denver by Surprise
description: The emergency call about a prowler seemed normal enough. But when a Denver police officer searched the working-class neighborhood this morning, a young white man with short cropped hair popped up from behind a bush and emptied an automatic pistol at him.

title: At Home Abroad; By Arms And Diplomacy
description: If Saddam Hussein's intention was to exploit division among the permanent members of the U.N. Security Council, the crisis he provoked has proved counterproductive. In the end, Russia and France rejoined the United States and Britain in insisting that he let the U.N. inspection team resume its search for weapons of mass destruction, and he backed down.

title: Metro Business; Gray Line Buses at N.Y.U.
description: New York University, with a campus in Greenwich Village, a medical center and 22 residence halls between 34th Street and Wall Street, said on Wednesday that it had retained Gray Line New York Tours to run free shuttle buses for students and faculty members.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, LILLIAN
description: GORDON-Lillian. The family of Lillian Gordon mourns the passing of a wonderful person. We will miss your loving presence, great sense of humor and your intelligent attitude toward life. You will always live in our hearts. Memorial services will be held Friday at 12 noon, at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Kline, in Chekhov, Finds Esprit in Ennui
description: Attention, acting students. How would you read this line: ''We're so tired''? Now remember, you're a disaffected, middle-aged man who has just said that your energy and your illusions have all been spent, and, though you're speaking in the first person plural, it's your own scooped-out, selfish self you're describing. And, yes, the character was created by Chekhov.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, SARA
description: KAHN-Sara. Beloved wife of the late Maurice. Devoted mother of Donald and the late Michael. Adored mother-in-law of Arlene. Services ''Wien & Wien,'' 129 Engle Street, Englewood, New Jersey, on Sunday, November 23, at Noon. For info 1-800-322-0533.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY ; HUD Urges Punishment Over Limousine Ride
description: Five officials of the Camden Housing Authority face disciplinary proceedings for allowing a delegation of public housing tenants to travel by limousine to a statewide convention in Newark, Federal housing authorities said yesterday.

title: Near-Perfect Knicks Put Stop to Hawks' 11-0 Start
description: It had been a nice dinner, a little Italian between old friends who discussed everything from their kids' growth spurts to the good old days at Georgetown.

title: Acupuncture in Context
description: To the Editor:

title: Seoul Said to Foil Spy Ring for North That Included a Top Scholar
description: The Government announced today that it had broken up a ring of North Korean spies, one of whom was identified as an eminent scholar known as the father of sociology studies in South Korea.

title: Army Seizes Police Base In Mexico
description: Army soldiers occupied the barracks of a rebellious elite police unit today, ending a one-day standoff between police officers and the military troops who have increasingly taken charge of security in the capital.

title: A Teetering Coalition
description: With Iraq's agreement to let all United Nations weapons inspectors return, the immediate crisis appears to have ended without use of military force, and the United States is declaring a victory for a united Security Council and for diplomacy.

title: Unabom Judge to Address Sanity Evidence
description: When Theodore J. Kaczynski refused to be examined by prosecution psychiatrists in preparation for his trial, was he a sane man acting crazy or a disturbed man feigning sanity?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, GREGORY
description: WALSH-Gregory. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to Nan and Al Walsh on the sudden and shocking death of their son Greg. May the concern and love of our Offices, Directors and Members be a comfort to them at this most terrible of moments. Jerome Belson, President Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York, Inc. Michael Kerr, Arnold Sollar Co-Chairmen Nicholas LaPorte, Exec. Director

title: Airbus Industrie Wants to Use Euros
description: Airbus Industrie said yesterday that it wanted to offer airlines the option of buying planes in euros, a move that would break a tradition of pricing aircraft in dollars. A task force has met several times already to establish how it could set prices in euros for airlines interested in buying commercial aircraft in the future currency, Airbus said.

title: Negative Poll Has UConn Trying to Cut Cost of Stadium Proposal
description: With a new poll showing that Connecticut voters oppose building a $102 million football stadium for the University of Connecticut by a 2-to-1 ratio, school officials are looking to trim the cost.

title: Celebrating McCartney and a New Work
description: Whatever one thinks of Paul McCartney's recent forays into classical music, he knows how to transform a symphonic concert into a celebratory event.

title: MAGNA GROUP TO PAY $100 MILLION FOR CHARTER FINANCIAL
description: Magna Group Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Charter Financial Inc. for $100 million in stock to expand its banking business in southern Illinois. Magna Group, based in St. Louis, has assets of $7.04 billion and 141 branches in Illinois, Iowa and Missouri. Charter, based in Sparta, Ill., has assets of $388 million and eight branches in southern Illinois. Under the agreement, Magna would swap 0.5751 share for each Charter share. Shares of Charter rose 75 cents yesterday, to $21.625, while Magna slipped 81.25 cents, to $39.

title: Bicyclists Are Police Priority After a Fatal Crash
description: Earl Morton, a nine-year veteran of the bicycle messenger wars, stood near his bike in midtown Manhattan yesterday as a team of six police officers swooped down on a bewildered restaurant deliveryman who had coasted through a red light.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONRAD, YVONNE (NEE CORPUZ)
description: CONRAD-Yvonne (nee Corpuz). On November 20, 1997. Former Assistant Administrator/Director of nursing at St. John's Hospital, Smithtown. Devoted mother of Lori Conrad and Dr. Lisa Conrad Larkin and son-in-law Dr. John J. Larkin. Also survived by two grandchildren, Sydney and John, and devoted friend to Carl Piraino. Reposing at the Branch Funeral Home, Inc., 190 E. Main St, Smithtown. Visiting Friday 2-4 and 7-9:30 p.m. Service 10 a.m. Saturday conducted by Rev. William C. Godfrey. Interment to follow, Nassau Knolls Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations would be appreciated to The American Cancer Society.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Flight 800 Theory; Fiber Optics for Jets
description: To the Editor:

title: Greenspan Issues Call for Action To Rescue Social Security System
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, urged Congress today to act quickly to fix the looming problems in Social Security, saying the political and economic difficulties of addressing the impending shortage in the program's financing would only grow with time.

title: Germ Weapons: Deadly but Hard to Use
description: The horror of germ weapons is easier to describe, experts say, than to translate into practice. How far Iraq's scientists have succeeded in building a practical arsenal of biological weapons remains unclear despite five years of investigation by United Nations inspectors.

title: In Japan, Tricky Course on Bailout Calls for Double Reverse
description: First he flipped, then he flopped, then he flipped again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUCKMAN, DAVID
description: DRUCKMAN-David. On Nov. 18, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Charlotte (Kaufman). Loving father of James and Nancy. Adoring grandfather of Charlotte and John. Devoted brother of Beatrice Preefer and Frances White. Service Friday, 9:30 A.M., at Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87 St, NYC. Contributions in his memory to the Alzheimer's Association, NYC Chapter, 420 Lexington Avenue, Suite 610, NY, NY 10170, or the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: Auto Maker to Build Cadillac of Sport Utility Vehicles
description: For nearly a century, Cadillac has cultivated a reputation for building elegant cars. Now it wants to sell elegant trucks.

title: Now the Time Is Right For a Coming-Out Party
description: While the Nets try to find believers outside their own locker room that their early success is not an illusion, some members of the team think that Friday night's nationally televised appearance against the Boston Celtics is just the sort of coming-out party they need. And some worry because it is also the sort of show that has brought less than rave reviews in the past.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Christopher Wool

title: London Journal; Royals' Golden Day, Graced by Common Touch
description: New Britain and Olde England, a couple whose relationship has grown increasingly strained in recent times, came together today in a ceremony drawing on symbols from both their traditions to celebrate the 50th wedding anniversary of Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip.

title: Second Suspect Arrested In Death of Police Officer
description: A second Queens man was arrested yesterday and charged in the death of Sgt. Walker Fitzgerald, who was killed with his own gun on Sept. 6 under mysterious circumstances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, JONATHAN
description: KING-Jonathan. Honorary AIA, Professor Emeritus of Architecture, died of cancer at age 71 at his home in Houston, TX., November 19, 1997. Born in NYC, graduated Columbia College 1949. Best known for his work in building systems as Vice President and Treasurer of Ford Foundation's Educational Facilities Laboratories and as Senior Vice President of CRS. He taught at the Universities of Michigan, Rice and Texas A & M. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Cynthia; two sons, Gordon B. of Marblehead, and Nathaniel B. of Ft. Lauderdale and five grandchildren. A third son Austin A. died in 1986. Services private. In lieu of flowers contributions to support student research may be sent to the King Student Research Fund, CRS Center, College of Architecture Texas A & M University, College Station, TX 77843-3137.

title: Recapturing the Drama Of the Ballets Russes
description: There is in the Wadsworth Atheneum here an in-house exhibition called ''Design, Dance and Music of the Ballets Russes 1909-1929.'' As its title indicates, it pays homage to Sergei Diaghilev, who for 20 years had no rival as an inspired innovator in the world of ballet. Even his failures bear thinking about.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRETZ, ALFRED F., M.D.
description: FRETZ-Alfred F., M.D. Memorial service for Dr. Fretz at St. Luke's Hospital Chapel, 113 St and Morningside, Monday, 11/24, at noon.

title: Asian Crisis Swells U.S. Trade Deficit
description: The United States trade deficit jumped to an eight-month high of $11.1 billion in September, the Government said, as financial turmoil in Asia helped widen the gap.

title: Assault by Bicycle
description: The death of a 68-year-old businessman hit by a bicycle on a Manhattan sidewalk three days ago has left New Yorkers wondering what more can be done to curb the city's legions of reckless cyclists. Two constituencies are perfectly positioned to reinvigorate a behavior modification campaign against ignorant and daredevil cyclists: police officers and the businesses that use cyclists for deliveries.

title: Crime and False Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Visa prepares an early and aggressive campaign to capitalize on its ties to the Olympic Games.
description: THERE may still be six more days until Thanksgiving and 34 more days until Christmas, but Visa U.S.A. Inc. is already looking to Feb. 7, the start of the 1998 Winter Olympics in Nagano, Japan.

title: Inside Art
description: 2 Big Steps For a Museum

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, STANLEY L.
description: MAYER-Stanley L. On November 18, 1997 in Santa Cruz, CA, age 79 of natural causes. Native of Brooklyn. Survived by wife Rhoda, son Robert and daughter Merry. Memorial service Sunday, November 23, 3 PM at Temple Beth El, 3055 Porter Gulch Road, Aptos, CA.

title: Flight 800 Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; Paths to Pleasure: Wheeling and Dealing
description: Riding a mountain bike isn't a right, it's a privilege, I think to myself as I hoist 24 pounds' worth of steel, aluminum and rubber onto the roof rack of my car. No, normally I don't relive Civics 101 while I'm preparing to exercise, but this is an exception. The only reason I'm getting ready to drive instead of biking already is that three trails within five miles of my home in Montclair, N.J., were closed to mountain biking by the complaints of hikers.

title: Metro Business; Fund Buys Four Buildings
description: The Blackacre Capital Group, a real estate hedge fund in New York, signed a contract on Monday to buy four commercial buildings in Manhattan from the Sylvan Lawrence Company for $387 million, according to real estate brokers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITZ, ANN L.
description: LITZ-Ann L. Of Smithtown, LI, died November 19, 1997. Survived by Eugene Litz and their son, Leverett Litz, and her mother, Garetta Lyons. Funeral 12 noon, Saturday, November 22, at St. James Episcopal Church, North Country Road, St. James, L.I. Burial later will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Smithtown Historical Society, Box 69, Smithtown, N.Y. 11787, would be appreciated.

title: Lawrence Wins Nassau Crown
description: Alec Diamond, the senior halfback for Lawrence, rushed for three touchdowns last night as the Golden Tornado (9-0-1) won the Nassau County Conference II championship by beating Garden City (8-1-1), 20-14, before a crowd of 3,500 at Hofstra University.

title: Residential Real Estate; Hybrid Attached Houses Popular on Staten Island
description: Developers are building a variation of a housing style that has been typical on Staten Island to meet what they say is demand from buyers for more space, a garage and a bigger patch of land they can call their own.

title: Foreign Language Classes Offer Cultural Insight; When English Suffices
description: To the Editor:

title: Army Secretary Denies Political Tie to Burials at National Cemetery
description: Army Secretary Togo D. West Jr. today defended his decision to grant 58 Americans special permission to be buried at Arlington National Cemetery, saying that the high honor was not awarded to anyone in exchange for past generosity to the Democratic Party.

title: Glaxo Sells Drug Lines
description: Glaxo Wellcome Inc. sold several prescription drug product lines to the closely held King Pharmaceuticals Inc., King said today. King, based in Bristol, said the deal included Septra, used to treat infectious diseases; Neosporin ophthalmic ointment, for eye infections, and Neosporin irrigant, to help prevent catheter-related problems.

title: WPP Buying Stake In Singapore Agency
description: WPP Group P.L.C., making a significant expansion in Asia, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a large stake in a leading independent agency based in Singapore.

title: A Native Russian 'Onegin,' With the Original Ending
description: The Martin Beck Theater was not built for opera. So it could not have been easy for the Moscow Novaya Opera Theater to adapt the 1,300-seat space to its production of Tchaikovsky's ''Eugene Onegin,'' which runs through Nov. 30 as part of the Moscow Arts Festival on Broadway.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Celebrating Canaletto'

title: Peregrine Investments Plans to Downsize
description: Peregrine Investments Holdings, the Hong Kong-based investment bank, whose star has risen with the fortunes of Asia, said yesterday that ''there will be cutbacks'' of employees across the region. The downsizing follows an announcement on Sunday that Peregrine would sell a 24.1 percent stake to the Zurich Group for $200 million.

title: Jets Are on Sack Alert From Vikings' Randle
description: Patience returns to the Jets' quarterback position on Sunday. But how long can the offensive line wait when John Randle of the Minnesota Vikings, perhaps pro football's most dangerous pass-rusher, is leading the charge?

title: Mayor Picks Ex-Prosecutor To Take Job of Top Lawyer
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had a tendency to appoint old friends from the legal profession to high-level positions in his first term. Yesterday, in the first major appointment of his second term, he followed that pattern, naming Michael D. Hess to be the city's Corporation Counsel.

title: Packer Fans Embrace Unusual Stock
description: The brutally honest warning appears on the opening page of the Green Bay Packers' new offering of 400,000 shares at $200 apiece: ''It is virtually impossible for anyone to realize a profit on a purchase of common stock or even to recoup the amount initially paid to acquire such common stock.''

title: Suspect in Cabby Slaying Says She Didn't Take Part in Crime
description: One of two women charged last week with the killing of a livery-cab driver claimed in court yesterday that she did not participate in the crime, but was a prisoner who was forced into the cab before the driver was shot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSPAN, DR. FRANK P.
description: GREENSPAN-Dr. Frank P. Of Charlotte, NC, died on Tuesday, November 18, 1997. He is survived by his wife, Sylvia Koffler Greenspan; a son, Gary H. Greenspan, M.D; and two grandsons, Daniel and David Greenspan.

title: An All-Bach Program That, the Fact Is, Isn't Quite
description: On any scale of scandal and mayhem, it doesn't even register, but truth in advertising perhaps requires full and immediate disclosure. Of the 25 Bach cantatas that Canticum Novum, a New York chorus, is performing this season to celebrate its 25th anniversary, two, or at least one and a half, are not by Bach: No. 53, ''Schlage Doch, Gewunschte Stunde,'' which was written by Georg Melchior Hoffmann, and No. 118, ''O Jesu Christ, Meins Lebens Licht,'' which was either conceived or arranged by an unknown second hand.

title: South Korea Moves Closer To Requesting I.M.F. Aid
description: The Government today moved toward seeking a huge bailout from the International Monetary Fund, with the state broadcasting network saying the Finance Ministry had decided to request roughly $60 billion in assistance to avoid an economic crisis that would paralyze the world's 11th-largest economy and ripple around the globe.

title: Once a Victim, She Is Seeking New Spotlight
description: EVEN if you knew nothing about her, you could tell right away that something really bad had once happened to Renee Katz. When she smiled hello, she stretched out her left arm to shake hands.

title: Family Fare
description: Children's TV The World Over

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNAN, PETER JAMES
description: BRENNAN-Peter James. Of Bronxville, New York, on November 19, 1997. Husband of Dorothy Niven Brennan. Father of Kim Brennan Carmody (Paul), Susan P. Brennan Melchiori (Edson), Peter James Brennan III (Adriana Prado). Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 24 and 7-9 PM, on Saturday and Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Monday, November 24, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Lawrence Hospital or New Rochelle Humane Society.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sunday Styles last weekend about people who identify themselves like brand-name products misstated the name of a company that creates brand identities for consumer products. It is the Nickandpaul Brandagency, not the NickandTom Brand Agency.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Think what we would have missed if we had never heard the Beatles, or seen Margot Fonteyn dance; never have watched television, used a mobile phone or surfed the Net -- or, to be honest, listened to other people talking about surfing the Net.''

title: Ruling Backs Worker Suing Transit Unit Over Injury
description: A ruling today by the state's highest court opens the door to a new group of lawsuits by transit workers who are injured on the job, which could cost New York City Transit millions of dollars a year in judgments.

title: U.N. Experts Face Daunting Task: Picking Up the Trail of Illicit Iraqi Arms
description: Although Iraq has agreed to allow United Nations arms inspectors back to Baghdad, officials and diplomats here fear they will return as a weakened force, facing the same intransigence as in the past but possibly with less ability to uncover weapons of mass destruction that Saddam Hussein has had three weeks to hide.

title: New Works in Many Styles
description: William Thomas McKinley, a prolific and enterprising composer based in Boston, also runs a new-music record label called MMC, for Master Musicians Collective. Mr. McKinley regards MMC more as a project or a mission than a company, and since he started it with the pianist Robert Black in 1992 he has recorded about 500 works, most of them by American composers. Seven works by MMC composers were given world premieres at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday by Gerard Schwarz and the New York Chamber Symphony, who are about to record them.

title: School for the Scandalous
description: When the State University of New York at New Paltz sponsored a conference earlier this month on ''Revolting Behavior: The Challenges of Women's Sexual Freedom,'' some called it borderline pornography and others celebrated it as an exercise in free speech. But what is at once interesting and depressing about the controversy is that both sides are indulging in the usual forms of bad faith.

title: Arab Capitals Are Relieved: No Need No Pick Sides
description: Arab leaders and diplomats expressed satisfaction and relief tonight over the agreement that appears to have averted the threat of a military confrontation between the United States and Iraq.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Cy Twombly

title: Rangers' Frustrations Get Better of Them
description: The tension created by the Rangers' poor performance Wednesday night against a woeful Tampa Bay team boiled over in practice today, as Coach Colin Campbell and defenseman Doug Lidster yelled at each other and afterward had a closed-door meeting.

title: OCCIDENTAL IS PLANNING TO SELL $1.6 BILLION IN ASSETS
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it planned to streamline its business by selling about $1.6 billion of exploration and production assets by the middle of 1998. The company plans to sell what it deems low-return properties, which generate a return on assets of 5 percent to 8 percent. The moves come in addition to Occidental's plan to sell its natural-gas pipeline unit, Midcon, to pay for the acquisition of a large Government-owned petroleum field, Elk Hills. Occidental officials said they had received interest in Midcon from 28 companies, including utilities, pipelines and gas marketers. They expect the sale to generate at least $3 billion in net proceeds. Occidental's stock rose 75 cents yesterday, to $29.6875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, JOAN
description: WEINSTEIN-Joan. On November 19, 1997. Beloved daughter of the late Helen and Sidney. Dear sister of the late Ann Jacobs. Loving aunt of Lisa Goldsmith, Betsy Jacobs, and Jeff Jacobs.
