title: Treasures That Rule the Senses by Imperial Decree
description: Two of the most ravishing exhibitions of the season have just opened side by side at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. One consists entirely of carpets, the other of pages from a single book. Neither may sound like don't-miss fare, but together they are close to perfection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLKIND, SYLVIA
description: WOLKIND-Sylvia. The Directors and Staff of the New York Association for New Americans, Inc. extend heartfelt condolences to our esteemed board member, Dale Kramer and her family on the tragic passing of her mother, Sylvia Wolkind. In this time of sorrow our thoughts and prayers are with you. Laura G. Ross, President Mark Handelman, Exec. V.P.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY ; Police Say Accident Caused Gunman's Death
description: A 29-year-old Warren County man who killed a state trooper last month and then was fatally wounded with a bullet from his own gun died accidentally, the state police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAPIRO, ROSE
description: SHAPIRO-Rose. November 21, 1985. 12 years since you left us. You live forever in our hearts. Janet, Fred and Children

title: A News Hawk With a Bloodhound's Nose and a Tabloid Eye
description: You know that magazine ad that says ''We get closer''? If only they had known Weegee.

title: Ratt, Without the Big Hair
description: Surely one of the most ignored rock reunion tours is the one Ratt is grinding through, which arrived at Irving Plaza on Tuesday night.

title: Islamic Militants Taunt Cairo, Demanding Break With Israel
description: The militant Islamic Group, which has claimed responsibility for the strike that killed 58 foreign tourists in Luxor, issued a statement today taunting the Egyptian Government, which it has said was the real target of the attack.

title: Wadsworth Flourishes as a Senior at Florida State
description: Andre Wadsworth, the Florida State defensive end, has just about everyone singing his praises. ''An 'A' player,'' was what Tom Braatz, the Miami Dolphins' director of college scouting, called Wadsworth, one of only about 20 such players in the next National Football League draft. ''A playmaker'' with a ''hunger'' to keep pursuing the person with the football, in the words of the Seminoles' defensive coordinator, Mickey Andrews. A potential No. 2 overall pick in the draft, behind only Tennessee quarterback Peyton Manning, according to the draft guru Mel Kiper Jr.

title: THE DEAL ON IRAQ: Chronology; Four Weeks of Tension
description: OCT. 27 -- Richard Butler, chief United Nations weapons inspector, tells Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Deputy Foreign Minister, which sites his team wants to inspect for biological and chemical warfare and missile warheads.

title: COOPER SAYS IT WILL ACQUIRE BRITISH CONTACT LENS MAKER
description: The Cooper Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Aspect Vision Care Ltd., a British maker of contact lenses, for $51 million in cash and notes. Cooper, based in Irvine, Calif., makes contact lenses and surgical equipment. Aspect Vision, based in Southampton, England, sells contact lenses in Europe. It has had compounded revenue growth of 55 percent in the last three years, Cooper said. Under the agreement, Cooper would also make an additional payment to Vision Care after three years, based on performance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELL, ESTHER
description: MANDELL-Esther. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Irving and Elaine. Adored grandmother of Jonathan and Melissa. Loving great grandmother of Randi and Remi.

title: Cigar Store Indians On Parade
description: With today's craze for cigars, one might assume that cigar store owners and smoking clubs are scooping up all the old cigar store Indians -- but they aren't. Allan Katz, an Americana dealer in Woodbridge, Conn., who claims he has sold more antique cigar store Indians than anyone over the last 10 years, says the buyers are not tobacconists. ''A cigar shop owner might sell a $40 cigar, but he won't spend the money for a good Indian,'' Mr. Katz said.

title: Islanders No Match For Devils
description: The Islanders were not supposed to be so confident tonight, not against the best team in the National Hockey League and the league's top goaltender.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OAKES, EVELENA ''DEEDE'' STEVENS
description: OAKES-Evelena ''Deede'' Stevens. Age 71, wife of Judge James L. Oakes, of Brattleboro, VT, died October 21, 1997. Deede (as friends and family called her) was known for her good spirits and a warm smile for everyone. Born in New York City on June 14, 1926, she was the daughter of Byam K. and Clare (Reynders) Stevens. Her childhood years were spent on Long Island, graduating from Green Vale School, as well as Garrison Forest School in Baltimore, MD. She also attended Vassar College from 1944-46. Mrs. Oakes lived in Brattleboro, VT, and Edgartown, MA, as well as New York City where her husband is a Senior Judge of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit (NY,CT,VT). From 1985 to 1990 she was Chairman of the Board of Directors of the then mental hospital division of the Brattleboro Retreat. She was active for years as a member of Brattleboro Youth Services and also served as a Trustee and supporter of various Brattleboro organizations, as well as of World Learning, Inc., Marlboro College, Planned Parenthood of Vermont, and Southern Poverty Law Center. Mrs. Oakes was known as a lifelong lover of music, an avid reader of The New York Times, a gracious hostess at Second Circuit Judicial Conferences, a gardener, and, as a young woman, an accomplished pianist and field hockey player. Survivors besides her husband are her beloved four sons: Richard A. (of So. Glastonbury, CT), Scott (of Stamford, CT), Albert (of Bridgeport, CT), and Michael (of New York City) Kenworthy, all by her late first husband Dr. Richard A. Kenworthy III, two daughters-in-law, Beth and Eliane, wives of Richard and Scott; and two grandchildren, Albert Oakes Kenworthy and Anne Casey Kenworthy, children of Richard and Beth. She also leaves her brother Byam K. Stevens, Jr. of Jericho, NY, and sister Mrs. Daniel (Clare ''Pat'') Ingersoll of Chestertown, MD; seven nephews and one niece; three stepchildren; six step granddaughters; and a host of friends in all corners of the U.S.A. A memorial service was held at Brattleboro's West Village Meeting House on Saturday, November 8, at 1 PM. Friends were invited by the family, in lieu of flowers, to make donations to Brattleboro Memorial Hospital, Brattleboro Women's Crisis Center, Brattleboro Youth Services, or Vermont Planned Parenthood, all in care of Ker, Westerlund & Fleming Funeral Home, 39 High St, Brattleboro, VT, attention Edward F. Hurley.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UGHINI, IMO
description: UGHINI-Imo. Died peacefully on November 18, 1997. Calling hours at the Giove Funeral Home, 640 Middle Country Road, Middle Island, Long Island, on Saturday and Sunday from 2-4 and 7-10 P.M. Religious service Sunday 3 P.M. at funeral home. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to the Mather Memorial Hospital, Port Jefferson, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUIRE, LILLIAN J.
description: MCGUIRE-Lillian J. On November 18, 1997. Wife of the late Harold F. McGuire. Mother of Harold and Bartlett McGuire. Grandmother of Christopher, Katherine and Daniel. Sister of Mrs. Johnson D. Hill, Jr. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street, Saturday, November 22 at 11:30 A.M. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to The Visiting Nurse Service of New York.

title: Paths to Pleasure: Wheeling and Dealing
description: Riding a mountain bike isn't a right, it's a privilege, I think to myself as I hoist 24 pounds' worth of steel, aluminum and rubber onto the roof rack of my car. No, normally I don't relive Civics 101 while I'm preparing to exercise, but this is an exception. The only reason I'm getting ready to drive instead of biking already is that three trails within five miles of my home in Montclair, N.J., were closed to mountain biking by the complaints of hikers.

title: Securities Prices Lose Early Gains
description: The prices of Treasury securities rose early yesterday, briefly sending the yield on the 30-year bond down to nearly 6 percent -- the lowest level in about two years -- before investors cashed in profits.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHESLER, CLAIRE (NEE SCAROLA)
description: CHESLER-Claire (nee Scarola). 6 years today. Always missed, always loved. But thankful for those 47 wonderful years together. Rest in peace my love. Til we meet again. Sey

title: Jewish Works (Though Not 'White Christmas')
description: Last season the 92d Street Y started Project America, a series written and directed by Michael Barrett and George Steel, in which the strands of the performing arts in America would be examined from a variety of cultural, social and historical perspectives. The installment presented on Tuesday evening looked at Jewish contributions to American music.

description: In New York City, everyone is willing to give you a piece of his mind, but few people have the talent to steal one.

title: A Killer's Wild Run After the Ambush Of a Police Officer
description: It began with the cold-blooded assassination of a police officer targeted at random in a quiet New Jersey shore town, officials said. And after three stolen cars and a high-speed chase punctuated by wild gunfire, it ended in chaos at the George Washington Bridge with a crash and more shots that left the killer dead and an officer critically wounded.

title: Op-Art; Sure-Fire Ways To Improve The I.R.S.
Deere to Acquire Cameco
description: Deere & Company said today that it had agreed to acquire a 49 percent stake in Cameco Industries, a closely held sugar-cane harvesting equipment maker based in Thibodaux, La. Terms were not disclosed. Deere said Cameco's products are crucial to cane harvesting, which is becoming increasingly mechanized.

title: Hint of Top Aide's Rebellion Weakens Image of Assembly Speaker
description: For the last three years, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver has acted as a brake on the changes Gov. George E. Pataki has sought in state government, standing fast to save rent controls and tempering the Republican Governor's cuts in welfare, health care and other social programs.

title: The Stakes: Rivalry, Revenge and Roses
description: They first played 100 years ago, one year before ''Hail to the Victors,'' Michigan's stirring fight song, was written. Their game does not determine possession of a barrel or an ax or a jug. There is no need for any of that. In any season, Michigan and Ohio State play for far more. This season, on this long-anticipated weekend, the stakes begin with a spot in the Rose Bowl, and go up from there.

title: INSIDE: Arts & Ideas
description: Foundations turn to death, and the issue comes alive. PAGE B7

title: Yanks Stand Still; Mets Fail to Sign Catcher
description: The Yankees yesterday did not get Randy Johnson, did not trade Bernie Williams, did not make an offer to Brady Anderson. But they did speak with Anderson's agent and said an offer for the center fielder would be forthcoming on Monday.

title: Sainthood Wouldn't End Debate on Dorothy Day; Political Pressure
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITNEY HOLDING TO ADD MERITRUST FEDERAL SAVINGS
description: The Whitney Holding Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire a rival Louisiana banking company, Meritrust Federal Savings Bank, for $60.5 million in stock. Under the agreement, Meritrust shareholders will receive $73 in Whitney common stock for each Meritrust share, subject to certain limits on the issuance of Whitney shares. Meritrust did not trade yesterday; its last trade was $51.4375. Whitney closed yesterday at $50, down 50 cents a share. Whitney, based in New Orleans, has assets of about $4.2 billion and more than 100 bank branches in southern Louisiana and the coastal regions of Mississippi, Alabama and Florida. Meritrust, based in Thibodaux, La., has assets of about $233 million.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FELDMAN, HENRY
description: FELDMAN-Henry. November 22, 1994, 19 Kislev 5755 Beloved, we miss you. Your wife Helen and son Leonard

title: Fear of Lower Asian Demand Hurts Copper
description: Copper prices tumbled yesterday on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange as concern grew that Asia's financial crisis would sharply depress demand.

title: Sports of The Times; A Jagged Climb, A Steep Fall
description: THERE is an odd connection between Shannon Briggs and Lawrence Phillips. Briggs is a heavyweight boxer with a big chance before him tonight; Phillips is a football player who has blown his first big chance.

title: Mother's Testimony Helps to Convict Son
description: A Paterson man was convicted of murder yesterday after his mother testified that he had admitted taking part in a shooting that left a 15-year-old bystander dead and four other people wounded, prosecutors said.

title: Complexity of H.I.V.
description: To the Editor:

description: SILVER-Theodore J. Engineer (NYU) and W.W. II Veteran. Most devoted husband of Adrienne, loving father of Babette and Louis (Michal). Brother of Miriam. Grandfather to Anntal.

title: Liberties; Something Sacred, After All
description: The horrible thing is that it sounded so plausible. It did not seem such a stretch to think that this White House, where everything is political and everything is for sale, would even peddle eternity.

Should friends desire, contributions may be made to Cancer Care.

description: HUSTING-Eugene E. (Gene). Of Locust Valley, Long Island, died peacefully on November 20, 1997. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The Hartford Heritage Auto Museum, 147 North Rural Street, Hartford, WI. 53027. There will be no service.

title: Iran's New Policies Face Conservative Backlash
description: A series of increasingly violent confrontations that have shaken Iran in recent weeks reflect growing tension between forces wanting to liberalize Iranian society and others who want to keep it strictly conservative, diplomats and political analysts say.

title: Time Warner Stock Plan
description: Time Warner Inc. has increased the number of shares it plans to repurchase to 35 million from 15 million. The media and entertainment company's buyback program is intended to offset the exercise of stock options. Time Warner, based in New York, began its 15-million-share buyback program in April 1996 and since then has repurchased about 14 million of its common shares. Shares of Time Warner closed at $60 yesterday, down 18.75 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, WILLIAM
description: ALLEN-William. Cherished son of Minnie Allen. Dear brother of Bruce L. Allen. Loved friends. Services will be held at Wien & Wien, Hackensack, N.J. Sunday 9:30AM. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America, 386 Park Avenue South, NY, NY 10016.

title: Judge Grants 45-Day Delay In Balloting By Teamsters
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered a 45-day delay in this winter's teamsters' election to give investigators more time to look into accusations that the leading candidate, James P. Hoffa, son of the legendary union leader, received improper campaign contributions in the previous election.

title: Subway Surplus May Be Optimistic Accounting; Reward Transit Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Subway Surplus May Be Optimistic Accounting; Support Bus Service

title: Stravinsky in Disguise As an Off-Center Mozart
description: ''The Rake's Progress'' revisited its early childhood on Thursday night. Stravinsky himself had conducted the world premiere in Venice in 1951. Two years later came the Metropolitan Opera production in which he placed so many hopes and found so many disappointments. ''The Rake'' had eight performances in two seasons at the Met and then quietly slipped out of its life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARMATZ, MILDRED
description: HARMATZ-Mildred. Beloved wife of the late Abraham (Ratners, 2nd Ave.). Devoted mother of Suzanne Slotnick (Edwin) and Carol Bregman (Ronald). Loving grandmother of Jacqueline, Peter and Jeffrey. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue, NYC.

title: Stocks Rally Globally Despite Asian Worries, and Dow Gains 54.46
description: Stock markets around the globe rallied again yesterday despite persistent concerns that the economic and financial crisis that has gripped much of Asia could spread to other parts of the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHALIT, MILTON J.
description: SHALIT-Milton J. On November 21, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Francine. Loving father of Patricia and Anthony. Dear grandfather of Julie, Tony, Natasha and Kevin. Great grandfather of Sasha. Devoted brother of Blanche and Maxine. Graveside service Monday, 11 A.M., Mount Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

title: U.N. Inspectors Face a Difficult Task
description: The United Nations' weapons inspectors returned to Iraq today with an arduous agenda: Finding missiles that they fear may be armed with anthrax, uncovering Saddam Hussein's stores of biological and chemical toxins, and unveiling the ways in which he has concealed his arsenal from the world.

title: When Foundations Chime In, The Issue of Dying Comes to Life
description: When George Soros, the financier and philanthropist, told trustees of his Open Society Institute in 1993 that he had decided to spend at least $15 million in the next three years trying to change American attitudes toward death, a stunned board member asked what the effort would be called.

title: A Mission To Put Manhattan On the Map
description: In creating their map of the Upper East Side, the Maio brothers could have settled for labeling major institutions like hospitals. Instead, they pinpointed all the ground-floor doctors' offices, which look on the map like a swath of baby-blue measles along Park Avenue.

title: Starting on a 'Long Road,' North Korea Agrees to Talks With Seoul, U.S. and China
description: North Korea agreed today to begin peace talks in Geneva next month with the United States, South Korea and China to bring a formal end to the Korean War more than four decades after the fighting stopped.

title: ISLANDERS
description: Islanders defenseman Dennis Vaske, who suffered his third concussion in three seasons in last Friday's game against Tampa Bay, is not planning to retire.

title: SHARED TECHNOLOGIES TO ACCEPT INTERMEDIA BID
description: Shared Technologies Fairchild Inc., a telecommunications-services provider to office buildings, agreed yesterday to accept an unsolicited takeover bid from Intermedia Communications Inc. for $15 a share, or $366 million, plus assumed debt of $274 million. The deal terminates an earlier agreement by Tel-Save Holdings Inc. to acquire Shared Technologies, which is based in Wethersfield, Conn., for $11.25 a share in stock. In a related move, Intermedia paid $237 million to Tel-Save, including about $174 million for the purchase of the Shared Technologies debt securities owned by Tel-Save. Intermedia Communications, based in Tampa, Fla., is a local exchange carrier. Tel-Save, based in New Hope, Pa., is a long-distance provider.

title: INSIDE
description: A Tumult in Iran

title: Everyone's in Love With Sharon. Why?
description: The largest question in Michael T. Folie's well-plotted comic drama ''The Adjustment'' is why all the characters are so in love with Sharon Gray, one of the most unlikable 90's heroines yet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, HARRIET J.
description: BECKER-Harriet J. Of New Rochelle, N.Y. On November 18, 1997. She brightened many peoples lives with her caring and compassion. She lived with elegance and dignity. In addition to raising a family, she was active in volunteer work, including fund raising for cancer research, transcribing books into Braille and acting as an advocate for battered women in the courts. She was a wonderful wife, mother, grandmother and friend. Her husband, Howard Becker, preceded her in death, but she will be sorely missed by her son Mark, daughter Susan, son-inlaw Jim, grandchildren Jonathan and Kate and many others. Contributions may be made to Hospice of Boulder County, 2825 Marine Street, Boulder, CO. 80303.

title: Who's Afraid to Debate Affirmative Action?
description: Alas, critics of President Clinton's race initiative were right. Mr. Clinton wants not a dialogue, they said, but a monologue. And indeed, on Thursday, when the President's advisory panel on race held hearings on diversity on college campuses, neither Ward Connerly nor any other dissenting voice on affirmative action was heard. John Hope Franklin, chairman of the advisory panel, said that Mr. Connerly, the University of California regent who led the fight to ban the use of race in admissions to state universities, had ''nothing to contribute'' to the discussion.

title: Guerin and Devils Finally Agree to a Deal
description: Bill Guerin signed a multiyear contract with the Devils today, putting an end to his seasonlong holdout and a dispute with his general manager, Lou Lamoriello, that had broadened into a debate on whether Lamoriello would name Guerin to the United States Olympic team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGEDORN, CHARLES
description: HAGEDORN-Charles, 79, on November 17, 1997, beloved husband of the late Jane, devoted father of Christopher, cherished grandfather of Christopher and James. At Charles' request a private family service was held. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. Donations in his memory can be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave., New York, N.Y. 10021.

title: About New York; Plain to See, 'Stolen' Car Was Misplaced
description: JOSHUA PRAGER found a fresh parking ticket on his borrowed Chevy Suburban when he left for work Thursday. At least the truck, his father's, wasn't towed, as it had been three weeks ago when traffic-control officers decided that the copy of his handicap placard wasn't good enough to justify parking in his usual spot -- a No Parking zone -- on Riverside Drive near West 91st Street.

title: Clarke Wins Nassau Crown
description: Kevin Pierce passed for three touchdowns and ran for another as Clarke (9-1) defeated Wantagh, 34-14, last night in the Nassau County Conference III high school football championship game at Hofstra.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMERJIAN, ARSHALUS
description: DEMERJIAN-Arshalus, 93. Of Park Avenue, died Tuesday at Bellevue Hospital. Miss Demerjian was former President of U.S. Grinding Wheel Inc. Funeral service private. Contributions to the NY Tisch Hospital or the Rusk Institute for Rehabilitation at New York University Medical Center. For information Bryce Funeral Home Inc., Troy.

description: In percent

title: Inquiry Into Subway Crash Focuses on Misplaced Sign
description: As officials searched yesterday for the cause of Thursday's two-train subway crash in Astoria, Queens, engineers from New York City Transit pored over drawings of all 458 subway stations to see whether any of them shared a basic flaw that might have contributed to the crash.

title: Barney's Reports a Wider Loss for Year
description: Barney's Inc.'s loss in its most recent fiscal year widened to $95 million from $71.9 million in the 1996 fiscal year, according to papers that the New York retailer filed in Manhattan Bankruptcy Court.

title: CO-STEEL IN DEAL TO PURCHASE NEW JERSEY STEEL
description: Co-Steel Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the New Jersey Steel Corporation for about $138 million. It will also assume $32 million in debt. Co-Steel, a Toronto steel producer, said it would pay $23 a share for New Jersey Steel. Shares of New Jersey Steel rose $6.1875, or 44 percent, to close at $22.4375 on the Nasdaq stock market. New Jersey Steel, based in Sayreville, N.J., produces steel reinforcing bars. Co-Steel said it planned to expand New Jersey Steel's product line and sell the products in Canada and the United States.

title: From Out of the Gym, Into the Grocery Store; Energy Bars Jump Into the Mainstream
description: They're called energy bars, and the people who make them are certainly showing no signs of letup as they slug it out with one another these days.

title: Judge Says Dow Corning Implant Plan Is Flawed
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge has ruled that there are numerous legal flaws in the Dow Corning Corporation's proposals for disposing of breast implant damage claims. As a result, the judge said, it would be a ''monumental waste of time'' for the claimants and other creditors to vote on a bankruptcy reorganization plan containing the proposals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVALSKY, ANNA
description: KOVALSKY-Anna. Of Staten Island, November 19, 1997. Loving mother of Barbara Stewart, Donna Danforth and Denise Kaye. Sister of Ken Yanik and Sue Seaman. Funeral service St. Paul's U.M. Church Monday 10 AM. Interment Cemetery of the Resurrection. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Bedell-Pizzo Funeral Home, Staten Island.

title: Subway Surplus May Be Optimistic Accounting; Don't Reduce Tolls
