title: Continental Is Ending Some Commuter Service
description: Continental Airlines will discontinue its commuter service from Newark to Atlantic City International Airport as of Dec. 31, officials said yesterday. The airline lost more than $1 million on the route in 1996, said Bruce Kink, a company spokesman.

title: The Rights of Patients, by Law
description: President Clinton embraced the patients' ''bill of rights'' issued this week by an advisory commission, but upset some of its members by proposing that Congress put the recommendations into law. The commission intends to debate how best to institute its proposals, and some felt the President's remarks prejudged the issue.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: SETTLEMENT ENDS HIGH COURT CASE ON PREFERENCES: TACTICAL RETREAT
description: An affirmative action case that began at a suburban New Jersey high school and evolved into a major Supreme Court test of the role of race in the workplace ended abruptly today when the parties announced an unusual financial settlement.

title: Roadblocks Made Just for Vans
description: Policy makers from across New York State met this week to discuss a problem I've known about for decades: many poor people don't have a way to get to work. A number of proposals were on the table, from vouchers for mass transit to no-interest car loans.

title: Killers on Wheels? City's Cyclists Are More Likely to Be Victims; Drivers Flout Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: A Woman of Power in the Ivory Tower
description: In the tiny realm of poetry, with its fragile rewards -- the $1,000 prizes, the transient euphorias after a word of praise in a review -- Helen Vendler is a kingmaker. With one critique in The New Yorker or The New Republic, she can enshrine a poet in the canon or rip a reputation to shreds.

title: Mariental Journal; How a Flightless-Biped Dealer Feathered His Nest
description: Timotheus P. Voges says he has gone straight these days, but there was a time when he was the most devious ostrich smuggler in Africa.

title: Novotna Halts Upset Flurry For Semifinal With Spirlea
description: The 16 women who started play in the $1.5 million Chase Championships this week at Madison Square Garden were the most successful on this year's Corel tennis tour. But something jarring has happened to the best of the best en route to tomorrow's final.

title: Killers on Wheels? City's Cyclists Are More Likely to Be Victims; Mandate Safety Features
description: To the Editor:

title: ST. JOE NO LONGER SEEKING ALL OF FLORIDA EAST COAST
description: The St. Joe Corporation said yesterday that it was no longer seeking to acquire the 46 percent of Florida East Coast Industries that it does not already own. St. Joe, which sought to convert itself into a real estate development company, offered in May to buy the rest of the railroad and real estate company for $102 a share, or $428.4 million. Buying the company, based in Jacksonville, Fla., would have given St. Joe sole ownership of a 55-building commercial real estate portfolio. The news was released after St. Joe's shares fell 50 cents, to $93.75, while Florida East Coast shares fell 87.5 cents, to $111.75.

title: Wilder at Heart: A Playwright's Life and Legacy
description: The prismatic nature of Thornton Wilder was explored this weekend at ''Wilder Rediscovered,'' a Classics in Context festival at the Actors Theater of Louisville Through plays, films and an abundance of talk, the festival illuminated the art and life of this very American playwright and novelist, in his centennial year.

title: Doctors in Spotlight Are Role Models for Black Youths
description: The day after the momentous birth of seven live babies, a group of youngsters from a small private school for minority students here visited the office of Dr. Paula R. Mahone and Dr. Karen L. Drake, the two perinatologists who delivered the septuplets. The students were carrying a newly minted certificate.

title: 'Just Incredible,' Says Mother, Holding 1st of Her 7 Babies
description: The mother of the first septuplets born alive in the United States was able to hold one of her babies today, shortly after doctors decided the boy was doing so well that he could breathe on his own, without the help of machines.

title: Raw History Unretouched
description: Stanley I. Kutler's new book, ''Abuse of Power: The New Nixon Tapes'' (Free Press) is a skeleton key to a haunted White House. Mr. Kutler, the E. Gordon Fox Professor of American Institutions at the University of Wisconsin, sued former President Richard M. Nixon and the National Archives to force the release of thousands of hours of secret White House tapes recorded between February 1971 and July 1973. Less than 60 hours of the famous tapes had previously been made public. The book includes edited transcripts of 201 hours defined by law as examples of Mr. Nixon's abuse of power. They lay bare the President's mind and thoughts as he slowly destroys himself. They are unimpeachable evidence that alters the historical view of Mr. Nixon and his Presidency. As Mr. Kutler said in an interview this week with Tim Weiner of The New York Times, there is nothing quite like them.

title: Based on a Video Game. Need to Know More?
description: Here's the lowdown on the latest chapter in Mortal Kombat: deadly dull.

title: France Undergoes Heart Surgery
description: Bill France Jr., one of the most powerful figures in American motorsports, was reported yesterday to be resting comfortably in a hospital in Japan following an angioplasty. France, 64, is president of Nascar, which operates the Winston Cup series.

title: Religion Journal; Universalism Embraces Many Faiths as It Evolves
description: Many are the houses of worship that put their theology right up front, declaring essential beliefs in the title they put on the building. Thus, if one sees a church that uses a word like grace or redemption in its name, one might expect to hear that concept preached from the pulpit inside.

title: SETTLEMENT ENDS HIGH COURT CASE ON PREFERENCES: Rights Groups Ducked a Fight, Opponents Say
description: They were ready to fight and the other guy backed out, disappointed affirmative action opponents said yesterday, complaining that the $433,500 settlement in the Piscataway, N.J., case amounted to hush money paid by frightened civil rights groups.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAPLAN, GEORGES
description: KAPLAN-Georges. Toujours dans nos coeurs. Ta famille

title: Bermuda Bowl Runners-Up Try for a Title in St. Louis
description: Among the hundreds of players who began play here today in the Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League were a handful who returned recently from competing in the world championships in Hammamet, Tunisia. They include the American team that finished second there in the Bermuda Bowl: Nick Nickell, Dick Freeman, Jeff Meckstroth, Eric Rodwell, Bob Hamman and Bob Wolff. Here they will be trying to regain the Reisinger Team title that they won in four straight years, from 1992 to 1995.

title: Police Dog Used in Search For Couple And Landlord
description: Investigators looking into the disappearances of a Manhattan landlord and his two tenants grew so frustrated yesterday that they sent a police dog sniffing around the edges of the landlord's seven-acre upstate property to search for clues. But that effort, too, was in vain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, LEONA (NEE BLACK)
description: LANE-Leona (nee Black). Beloved wife of Ted. Loving mother of Allison Barron and her husband, Richard. Dear sister of Norman Black. Cherished grandmother of Lindsey Barron. Beloved aunt of Leslie and Graham, Karen and Stephanie. Services at 12 noon, Sunday, at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway (Route 4 West), Fair Lawn, New Jersey.

title: Legitimate Quotas
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDREWS, ANTOINETTE G.
description: ANDREWS-Antoinette G. On November 20, 1997, of Rye, NY. Devoted wife of the late Thomas H., dear mother of Michele A. Henry of Rye and the late Thomas A. Loving sister of Rose MacEvoy, Evelyn Blauvelt and Anne Ferrara and the late Michael and Joseph Guadagno. Beloved grandmother of Tabbatha and Justin Henry and Emily Andrews. The family will receive friends Sunday, 7-9 PM at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Post Road, Rye, N.Y. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church Monday, 10:30 A.M., in Keyport, N.J. Interment St. Joseph's Cemetery, Keyport. In lieu of flowers contributions to St. Vincent's Hospital, Harrison, New York, would be appreciated.

title: A 64 Puts Hurst in Lead
description: With her friends and family providing vocal support, Pat Hurst wanted to do something good in the second round of the L.P.G.A. Tour Championship. She ended up putting on the show of her young pro career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RINDLER, REGINA
description: RINDLER-Regina. On November 19, 1997. Beloved and adored wife of Julius. Loving mother of Gerald and Peggy. Devoted sister-in-law and aunt. Remembered with great love. You will be part of our lives forever. Services Sunday, November 23 at 12:15PM at the Riverside, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Nichols and McVeigh Discussed Interest in Bombs, Agent Testifies
description: Terry L. Nichols told investigators two days after the Oklahoma City bombing that he and Timothy J. McVeigh were curious about bombs, read books and magazines about them, and talked about how they would work, a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent testified today.

title: Sports of The Times; Athletes Toe the Nike Line, But Students Apply Pressure
description: MARION TRAUB-WERNER, a 20-year-old junior from Toronto, was a member of the women's crew for one year at the University of North Carolina. More recently, she and some friends were invited to huddle with the campus basketball legend Dean Smith. The retired coach made his best recruiting pitch, and failed.

title: Schools Must End Teacher-Director Post, Arbitrator Says
description: Dozens of small, experimental New York City public schools that are led by teachers rather than trained administrators must elevate those leadership positions to the level of principal, under the terms of an arbitrator's ruling released yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBROT, SUSAN
description: LIBROT-Susan. On November 20, 1997. Of New City, NY. A graduate of Columbia University, she had a special interest in music therapy. Worked as a volunteer with senior citizens for many years. Devoted wife of Dr. Irwin. Loving mother of Mitch and Ken and their wives Diane and Lynn, of Allendale, NJ. Cherished grandmother of Justine, Michael, Amanda, Jeffrey, Emily and Andrew. Services Sunday 1:30 PM, at Hellman Memorial Chapels, 15 State St, Spring Valley, NY. Entombment to follow at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramus, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Tomorrows Children's Fund, 30 Prospect Avenue, Hackensack, NJ 07601 in the name of Sue Librot, or Temple Beth Shalom, 228 New Hempstead Road, New City, NY 10956, to the Rabbi's Discretionary Fund in the name of Sue Librot.

title: Deloitte & Touche Ex-Partner Is Convicted
description: A former tax partner at Deloitte & Touche L.L.P. has been convicted of aiding the fraud scheme of Christopher K. Bagdasarian, the supposed whiz-kid investor whose glowing track record turned out to be a fantasy.

title: Dissident's Advice to Clinton: Only Pressure Sways Beijing
description: Wei Jingsheng, China's most prominent democracy advocate, said in an interview in New York yesterday that he would tell President Clinton that only continued pressure from the West could help free more Chinese political prisoners. He said he intended to use his time in exile to act as a campaigner for human rights.

title: A Tribute to Bechet, With Tunes, of Course
description: Eight horn players sat toward the front of the stage in a neat semicircle, on folding chairs; they shot one another sidelong glances and joked with one another, and except for the tuxedos, they looked as though they could have been in rehearsal. This was the lasting image from Thursday night's concert at Alice Tully Hall, when Jazz at Lincoln Center put on its Sidney Bechet centennial concert, ''The Wizard at 100.''

title: First Juror Is Selected In the Brawley Case
description: Four days into the defamation lawsuit against three former advisers of Tawana Brawley, the first juror was sworn in yesterday, a white man in his late 20's who works at a pharmaceutical warehouse and said that while he had heard about the case, he did not have any strong opinions about it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, JOAN
description: WEINSTEIN-Joan. On November 19, 1997. Beloved daughter of the late Helen and Sidney. Dear sister of the late Ann Jacobs. Loving aunt of Lisa Goldsmith, Betsy Jacobs, and Jeff Jacobs. Devoted great-aunt. Service Sunday, 10:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to The American Cancer Society and End DWI.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Windsor Castle in Britain referred incompletely to the broadcast schedule for a film on its restoration, produced by Prince Edward. The one-hour film, which was seen Thursday night in Britain, will be broadcast in the United States on the Learning Channel on Monday at 10 P.M., Eastern time.

title: Case No. 3: Asian Illness Threatening Vital Organs
description: As Thailand's economy imploded during the summer, the International Monetary Fund rushed in to try to confine the problem to one of Asia's most promising -- but still small -- economic powers.

title: Grayson Kirk, 94, President of Columbia During the 1968 Student Protests, Is Dead
description: Grayson Louis Kirk, the scholarly president of Columbia University whose ill-fated decision in the spring of 1968 to turn 1,000 police officers in riot gear against student protesters became an emblem of the generational conflict characterizing the Vietnam War era, died early yesterday morning.

title: Subway Crime Bringing Calls To Add Police
description: While crime continues to drop citywide, a persistent increase in subway muggings and pickpocketing has subway advocates and some transit police supervisors questioning whether more officers and detectives should be assigned to the subway system.

title: CORPORATE EXPRESS GETS 17 COMPANIES IN EXPANSION
description: Corporate Express Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired 17 companies to expand internationally and it expects fiscal third-quarter earnings of 19 cents to 21 cents a share. The office-supply company said the acquired companies had revenue of about $150 million, with $40 million from international sales. Through the transactions, Corporate Express said it entered Ireland and expanded in Italy, Germany and Canada. Corporate Express, based in Broomfield, Colo., was expected to earn 21 cents a share, the average estimate of four analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. International Inc. Corporate Express employs 27,000 people in the United States, Canada, Britain, Ireland, Germany, France, Italy, Australia and New Zealand.

title: Cigarette Tax Urged to Cover Health Costs
description: A state health panel recommended today that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and lawmakers consider raising the cigarette tax to help New Jersey hospitals cover the cost of free medical treatment for the uninsured.

title: Anderson, Blissful Blazer With a New Perspective
description: Kenny Anderson said he sometimes sits in a Portland, Ore., coffee shop and ponders his life over a cup of java. ''I know it sounds weird, but it helps me solve my problems,'' he said. ''There is nothing like figuring out your life over coffee.''

title: Killers on Wheels? City's Cyclists Are More Likely to Be Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Statement by School Board Lawyer on Lawsuit's Settlement
description: Following are excerpts from the statement issued yesterday by David B. Rubin, the Piscataway school board's lawyer, announcing the settlement of the lawsuit filed by Sharon Taxman, a teacher who was dismissed in 1989.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREENE, SUSAN
description: GREENE-Susan. 9/20/12-11/22/95. Beloved, treasured sister of George (Gert), Hy (Mattie) and Toni. Sister also of the late Rose and Louis. Devoted daughter of the late David & Sadie Greenspan. Cherished aunt, great aunt, dear cousin and loving friend of many. Our darling Sue, remembered and missed every day.

title: Tough Cops, Thin Skin
description: A common thread connects the most severe examples of police brutality, such as the Abner Louima case, to garden-variety police harassment. Most of the time, police abuse starts when an officer feels that his or her authority has been challenged. In reviewing dozens of cases of police misconduct, two Times reporters, Deborah Sontag and Dan Barry, found that wrongful arrests, strip-searches and even beatings can be triggered by talking back to an officer, asking for a badge number or merely inquiring why.

title: Selling Kids on Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: James Levine Will Lead the Munich Philharmonic
description: The Munich City Council announced yesterday that the conductor James Levine would succeed the late Sergiu Celibidache as music director of the Munich Philharmonic Orchestra.

title: Killers on Wheels? City's Cyclists Are More Likely to Be Victims; Ban Sidewalk Skaters
description: To the Editor:

title: Unabom Jury Might Hear Psychiatric Evidence
description: The judge at the trial of Theodore J. Kaczynski indicated today that he would permit the defense to present evidence that the man accused of being the Unabomber is mentally ill. But he indicated he might not permit testimony by defense psychiatrists who had examined Mr. Kaczynski.

title: Corrections
description: The Spare Times guide in Weekend yesterday misstated the time and ticket price for tomorrow's performance of the Moss Hart comedy ''Light Up the Sky'' by the Actors Company Theater at the New-York Historical Society in Manhattan. The show is at 3 P.M., not 7:30 P.M. Tickets, available at (212) 645-8228, are $10, not $15.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the Warhol Foundation's plan to divide its collection of the artist's film and video works among four institutions misstated the surname of the appraiser hired by the foundation to value the works. She is Audrey Kupferberg, not Kupferman.

title: Corrections
description: A profile on Monday about Wei Jingsheng, the Chinese dissident released last weekend, misstated the month of his last trial. It was in December 1995, not November 1995.

title: Killing Wasn't Much, Skinhead Says
description: Red hair shaved down to his skull, Nathan Thill lounged in a black leather jacket and mulled over why he shot to death a West African man at a bus stop here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREAKSTONE, JACK
description: BREAKSTONE-Jack. On November 21, 1997. Beloved son of the late David and Sadie Breakstone and friend to all. Services Monday, 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUIRE, LILLIAN J.
description: MCGUIRE-Lillian J. On November 18, 1997. Wife of the late Harold F. McGuire. Mother of Harold and Bartlett McGuire. Grandmother of Christopher, Katherine and Daniel. Sister of Mrs. Johnson D. Hill, Jr. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street, Saturday, November 22 at 11:30 A.M. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to The Visiting Nurse Service of New York.

title: Birthplace of Klan Chooses a Black Mayor
description: The 20th-century Ku Klux Klan was born here in 1915, and for half a century afterward this quaint town on the outskirts of Atlanta played host to an annual rally of cross-burning Klansmen.

title: Court Rebuffs Appeal on Release Of Official's Talk With Lawyer
description: A Federal appeals court today declined to reconsider an earlier ruling that the notes of one of Vincent W. Foster Jr.'s last conversations with his lawyers could be surrendered to the Whitewater independent counsel because they are not absolutely protected by the lawyer-client privilege.

title: MICRON STOCK SLIDES ON LOWER EARNINGS ESTIMATE
description: The stock of Micron Electronics Inc. fell 16 percent yesterday after the company said its first-quarter earnings would fall well below Wall Street expectations. The personal computer maker said yesterday that it expected to report only a small profit for the period ending next Thursday. But Micron said it expected modest growth in sales for the first quarter. In the fourth quarter the company earned $14.9 million, or 16 cents a share, on sales of $513.1 million. Analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation had expected the company to earn 22 cents a share. Shares of Micron Electronics, based in Nampa, Idaho, fell $2.3125, to $11.5625, on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Cutting the Supply of Bribes
description: In the past few years dozens of developing countries have begun programs to cut corruption and prosecute officials who take bribes. But little has been done by the developed world to crack down on bribe-givers. That changed Thursday in Frankfurt, when the 29 industrialized countries belonging to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development agreed on a treaty outlawing bribes to foreign government officials.

title: New York Ends Appeal On Runway Extension
description: New York City dropped a legal appeal yesterday that threatened to halt a $92 million runway extension intended to reduce delays at Newark International Airport, city officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDY, ROBERT PAUL
description: RUDY-Robert Paul. On Thursday, November 20, 1997. In his 83rd year. After a long and valiant battle with cancer. Beloved husband for fifty-six years of Joan Price Rudy. Loving father of John and Janice and the late Richard. Adoring grandfather of Hilary, Brett and Kerri. Devoted brother of Selma Sacks, Leonard and Nancy Rudy and much loved uncle to Sayres Rudy, Lisa and Peter Cook, Gail and Matthew Jenkins, Jane and John Scully and Wendy and Kaiser Zaman. Services Sunday, November 23, 1 PM, at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 E. 79 Street, at 2nd Avenue. Contributions in Robert's memory may be sent to the Richard P. Rudy and Robert P. Rudy Memorial Fund (M.I.T., Office of the Treasurer, 238 Main Street, Cambridge, Mass. 02142).

title: All Even for Pitino, Calipari, Celtics and Nets for Now
description: John Calipari contends that it's a rivalry. Rick Pitino says, no, it is not. It's obvious the subject is still open for debate.

title: At F.D.A., Overhaul Of Headless Agency
description: President Clinton signed into law a measure that he said would earn the Food and Drug Administration ''a gold medal for leading the way into the future.''

title: An Endurance Test for Any Taste Bud
description: Finally, I understand why people climb walls of sheer rock, enter triathlons and hike for hours under the burning desert sun.

title: Detective Was Known as a Hero Who Stayed True to His Roots
description: In 1977, as a northeaster battered the New Jersey coast, crashing waves against the bluffs and swallowing entire patches of beach, Patrick A. King, then a rookie in the Long Branch Police Department, plunged into the churning Atlantic to rescue a priest who nearly drowned.

title: Health-Maintenance Groups Are Seen Entering a Troublesome New Phase
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Kansas City is shutting down 11 of its health maintenance organization's 22 clinics, laying off 30 of its 65 primary-care doctors and cutting the salaries of the rest.

title: Briggs Sees His Destiny in a Matchup Against Foreman
description: Shannon Briggs said he is going to be himself when he steps into the ring against George Foreman tonight at Trump's Taj Mahal in Atlantic City in a 12-round heavyweight bout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAAL, MIRIAM (NEE ALTER)
description: SCHAAL-Miriam (nee Alter). Most dearly beloved wife of the late Eric Schaal. Adored daughter of Dian and the late Benjamin Alter. Dearly loved sister and aunt of Herb and Ann and Mio Alter. Graveside services Sunday, 1 PM, Wellwood Cem., Pinelawn, NY.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BOMBARDIER INC., Montreal, a maker of transportation equipment, said its de Havilland unit had received a $350 million order from Scandinavian Airlines System and a $100 million order from Horizon Air.

title: Army Releases List of Exceptions for Arlington Cemetery Plots
description: Army Secretary Togo D. West Jr. today released the names of the 69 people who were given special permission to be buried at Arlington Cemetery during the Clinton Administration, in an effort to halt Republican accusations that cemetery plots were traded for campaign contributions.

title: Hobbled Miller Is Eager To Play Against Redskins
description: In front of Corey Miller's locker, among a pile of cleats and sneakers and a mound of fan mail, sits a large leather-bound Bible and a book titled ''Faith to Faith.'' And in the training room, he has the Giants' medical staff talking about miracles.

title: Clinton, Remembering Rabin, Sees Urgency of Mideast Peace
description: President Clinton warned the Israelis and Palestinians today that they were running short of time. He spoke at a ceremony at which he recalled the push for peace made by Yitzhak Rabin, the Israeli Prime Minister assassinated for his efforts two years ago.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, CHARLES I., DR.
description: SIEGEL-Charles I., Dr. Of Lake Worth, Florida, formerly of Forest Hills, New York, passed away peacefully on November 20, 1997. Beloved father of Kenneth and Joy, and adored grandfather of Anne, Catherine, Leslie, Susan, Michelle and Caryn. Services will be held 1:30 P.M., at the Beth Israel Funeral Home in Delray, Florida. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Alzheimer's Association would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PRICE, BARRY
description: PRICE-Barry. Beautiful boy, away from us 22 years. You're always in our hearts. Love and Kisses. Mommy, Daddy, Jodi and Blair.

title: COTT'S BRITISH UNIT ACQUIRES HERO DRINKS
description: The Cott Corporation said yesterday that its Cott U.K. Ltd. unit had acquired Hero A.G.'s Hero Drinks Group U.K. Ltd. subsidiary for $79.7 million and up to $34.8 million in deferred payments. Cott, a Toronto soft drink maker, said the deferred payments will be based on the future profitability of the combined businesses in the next five years. Hero Drinks is a major supplier of soft drinks in Britain. For the year that ended on Oct. 31, Hero Drinks' revenues were $103.6 million. For its latest fiscal year, which ended on Jan. 25, Cott had sales of $951 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENSCH, ROSE
description: MENSCH-Rose. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Max Mensch. Loving mother of Bebe and Ralph Mann and Dorothy and Milton Mensch. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 10 AM, Sunday. Please omit flowers.

title: Journal; The Baptist Pratfall
description: ''Let's go out and terrify some Baptists!'' cracked Emma Thompson to Ellen DeGeneres on TV's first openly gay sitcom, ''Ellen,'' this week. The studio audience roared its approval. Five months after America's largest Protestant denomination -- the 15-million-plus Southern Baptist Convention -- voted to boycott all Disney products to protest its allegedly ''Christian-bashing, family-bashing, pro-homosexual agenda,'' Disney is getting the last laugh. The boycott is a bust.

title: DRESSER AND INGERSOLL-RAND TO CUT JOBS AT VENTURE
description: Dresser Industries and the Ingersoll-Rand Company said yesterday that they planned to cut about 7 percent of the staff, or 900 jobs, at their two pump and natural gas compressor joint ventures, as part of a consolidation to increase profits. The companies will close a plant in Europe, which has about 395 employees, and reduce administration and sales support positions elsewhere. They will also drop certain types of products. The joint ventures have 13,000 employees worldwide. The actions are being taken to cut costs and improve profits at Dresser-Rand and Ingersoll-Dresser Pump Company ventures. Dresser and Ingersoll-Rand will each shoulder about $19 million in costs related to the moves and both will take charges in the fourth quarter.

title: Sainthood Wouldn't End Debate on Dorothy Day
description: To the Editor:

title: A Partial Fix for Immigration Flaws
description: When Congress passed the 1996 immigration act, many legal experts argued that the law went too far to truncate immigrants' rights and speed deportation of hundreds of thousands of people who had lived in the United States for many years. Congress acknowledged the truth of those complaints when it passed legislation this month to undo two provisions in last year's law. Other flaws, however, still need to be corrected when Congress convenes next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUTTON, JOSEPH
description: SUTTON-Joseph. Congregation Shearith Israel, the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, mourns the passing of a distinguished scholar and a scion of the Syrian Jewish community. We extend our condolences to his daughter, Naomi Neustadter, and our Segan, and the entire Sutton family. Alvin Deutsch, Parnas

title: Prospect of a Costly Loss Led Board to Drop Case
description: In the end, the Piscataway Board of Education decided not to take a nine-year-old affirmative action case to the United States Supreme Court for practical reasons: most of its nine members did not believe they could win.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSZEWSKI, CELIE
description: OLSZEWSKI-Celie. The students, faculty and staff, families and friends of Celie Olszewski at the Dalton School mourn the passing of an extraordinary person. We will miss your loving presence, endless ability to always make us laugh and your bright outlook on life. We extend our heartfelt condolences to your family. Our thoughts and prayers are with you. You will live forever in our hearts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTONE, ROSE ORLIANSKY
description: SILVERSTONE-Rose Orliansky of Providence, RI, Jamaica Estates, NY and Orient, L.I. died November 21 just short of her 90th birthday. Rose had been a librarian at Queens College, James Monroe High School and Forest Hills High School. Beloved wife of the late Max, beloved mother of Vida Wagner, and David Silverstone, grandmother of five, great-grandmother of two. Graveside services New Montefiore Cemetery, L.I., on Sunday, November 23, at 1 PM. For information 1-800-382-4145.

title: Norman Topping, 89, Scientist Who Guided the Rise of U.S.C.
description: Dr. Norman H. Topping, who helped to develop the typhus vaccine and went on to lead the University of Southern California's transformation into a prominent research center, died on Tuesday. He was 89.

title: Subway Surplus May Be Optimistic Accounting
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Keep Their Focus and Rout the Wizards
description: Maybe it was the sound of rain pelting the hangarlike roof, or the popcorn popping at the concession stands. Any noise emanating from USAir Arena had nothing to do with clapping.

title: Seoul Plans to Ask the I.M.F. For a Minimum of $20 Billion
description: In a remarkable humiliation for one of the most glittering economic success stories of the late 20th century, South Korea announced tonight that to avert a financial crisis it would seek a bailout from the International Monetary Fund.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 11 about a new educational partnership by the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., the Institute for Advanced Theater Training at Harvard University and the Moscow Art Theater School referred incorrectly to its uniqueness. The affiliation is not the Moscow school's first with an American University.

title: Rival Asserts Philip Morris Smuggles in South Africa
description: In a trial here pitting the Philip Morris Companies against Rembrandt Group Ltd., the South African industrial and tobacco conglomerate, accusations have been made that smugglers helped Philip Morris get a foothold in the lucrative South Africa market, which has opened up since the end of apartheid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFFER, MILDRED
description: SCHIFFER-Mildred, age 86. Died peacefully. Beloved wife ot the late Morton, devoted mother of Rosalie Oliff and Joseph Schisser, loving grandmother of Paul, Jordan, Marc, Susan and Amy. Loving great-grandmother of Sara, Sam, Ezra and Jared. Services will be held at Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, NJ, Thursday 11 AM.

title: Russians Press U.N. to Relax Iraq Sanctions
description: Russia followed up on its promise to help Iraq by asking today that the country be declared free of nuclear weapons and nearly free of prohibited missiles, diplomats said.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Major Overhaul for F.D.A. As President Signs New Law
description: President Clinton signed into law today a major overhaul in the Food and Drug Administration, saying the agency would earn ''a gold medal for leading the way into the future,'' but he offered no indication of when he would choose someone to lead the agency on that path.

title: RENO AIDES OPPOSE OUTSIDE COUNSELS IN FUNDS INQUIRY
description: Justice Department officials have recommended in a memorandum that Attorney General Janet Reno not seek independent counsels to investigate fund-raising telephone calls made by President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Appeals Court Decides Military May Bar Sale of Sex Magazines
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Defense Department could enforce a law that bars the sale of sexually explicit magazines and videotapes on military bases.

title: Mantle Items Off the Block
description: A Mickey Mantle memorabilia auction will proceed in Manhattan today without most of the personal items his estate sued to remove from the sale. The Federal lawsuit had charged that Greer Johnson, a former agent for the late Mantle, had stolen the items from a Georgia condominium the former Yankee star had bought and deeded to her.

title: Works for Prepared Ears
description: The nature of the music changes when the composer is there in the hall talking with us. The composer explains how and why the work came to be written, what technical problems had to be addressed, what personal experiences and obsessions had to be accommodated. Then we hear the work, and it speaks not with its own voice but with the composer's. It tells the story we have been prepared by the composer to hear.

title: Jobless Rate Declined To 5.2% in October
description: The state's unemployment rate dipped to 5.2 percent in October, tying a seven-year low for the third time this year, the State Department of Labor said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Humbled By Debt Crisis, Seoul Seeks I.M.F. Aid

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LALOR, MARGARET
description: LALOR-Margaret. Of Hampton Bays on November 19th, 1997. Loving aunt of Barry Keefe and Rosemary Cyr. For information R.J. O'Shea Funeral Home, Inc., in Hampton Bays. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at noon on Saturday from St. Rosalies Church, Hampton Bays, followed by an interment in Westhampton Cemetery.

title: Hide-and-Seek, Iraqi Style
description: Although the confrontation between the United Nations and Iraq has eased, the crisis over the elimination of Iraq's biological, chemical and nuclear weapons is far from over. Baghdad, for instance, has had almost four weeks to hide evidence that it produced such arms.

title: Student's Stepfather Gets Jail in Teacher Assault
description: An Atlantic City man was sentenced to 364 days in the county jail yesterday for assaulting a physical education teacher who had disciplined his stepson, county prosecutors said.

title: Lukewarm Endorsement As Vikings Approach
description: Neil O'Donnell will be on the spot Sunday. The Jets will be host to the 8-3 Vikings, with a chance to remain at least tied for first place in their division. The Jets will do it, if they can, behind a slumping O'Donnell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, RITA M.
description: O'BRIEN-Rita M., on November 20, 1997. Devoted wife of the late Vincent de Paul, beloved mother of Mary Ellen, Vincent de Paul and Virginia, S.U., grandmother of Paul, Kathryn, Kelly, Kimberly and Keri, great-grandmother of Samantha, Ryan and Ben Jacob. Wake at Fox Funeral Home, 98-07 Ascan Ave., Forest Hills, November 22nd and 23rd, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of the Resurrection, Our Lady Queen of Martyrs, Queens Blvd. and Ascan Ave., Monday November 24th at 10:30AM. Contributions in lieu of flowers to the O'Brien Memorial Scholarship Fund, Notre Dame School, 104 St. Mark's Place, NYC 10009.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It became a no-brainer. We did what we thought was right for the taxpayers and for our school district.''

title: Fourth-Biggest Brokerage House In Japan Is Considering Closing
description: The Yamaichi Securities Company, the most troubled of Japan's four largest securities firms, will spend the weekend deciding whether to liquidate its business or to try to reorganize under the protection of the bankruptcy court after disclosing previously unknown liabilities that are expected to exceed $1.6 billion.

title: Kovalev Stays Hot as Rangers Win
description: If they keep playing entertaining games like this one, they might sell more tickets for hockey in the Carolinas. If the Rangers keep playing this way, they will soon surge above the .500 level that they reached again tonight. And if Aleksei Kovalev keeps playing as he did tonight, he will end all those trade rumors and all those critical comments from Coach Colin Campbell.

title: Kimberly-Clark to Dismiss 5,000 Workers and Eliminate 18 Plants
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation said yesterday that it would dismiss 7 percent of its employees, or about 5,000 workers, and sell or close as many as 18 plants. The cuts, which will start immediately, come as company products like Kleenex tissue and Scott paper goods are facing pricing pressure and stiffer competition.

title: Gerstner Agrees to Be Chief of I.B.M. Until at Least 2002
description: Louis V. Gerstner Jr., who helped reverse I.B.M.'s slide through aggressive cost-cutting and layoffs, has agreed to a five-year extension of his contract as chief executive, saying he has still not completed his turnaround work at the world's largest computer company.

title: G.M. to Close Car Factory, Delivering Big Blow to Flint
description: Faced with dwindling demand for large cars as more Americans switch to sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks, the General Motors Corporation announced today that it would close its 2,900-employee car factory in Flint, Mich., during the third quarter of 1999.

title: Lizards Outlasting The Rock
description: Don't be misled by the fact that the backup band for ''Loungeville, Vol. I: Music to Watch Girls By,'' an effervescent new revue at Rainbow and Stars, is togged out in brocaded smoking jackets and Ascot ties and named Sonic Wallpaper. The show, which runs through Dec. 6, is not a mocking parody of 60's sophisticated attitudes but a humorous celebration of vintage pop style. How could it be otherwise? The dirty little secret behind the much-publicized ''lounge'' music scene, in which young audiences and performers emulate the swank martini-swilling ways of Las Vegas swingers, is a winking acknowledgment that the songs of Henry Mancini, Burt Bacharach and others who form the backbone of the lounge music canon, have proved more durable than much of the rock made during the same period.

title: A Dissident Speaks: 'I Don't Want to Wait' for Democracy
description: Following are excerpts from an interview yesterday with Wei Jingsheng, the Chinese dissident, by Patrick E. Tyler. Mr. Wei spoke in Chinese, and his remarks were translated by Xiao Qiang, executive director of Human Rights in China.

title: East, South, West . . . and North Carolina
description: The men's college basketball preview was prepared by Malcolm Moran, who understands that Dean Smith could have a serious problem in the last weekend of March. If North Carolina, Kansas and South Carolina reach San Antonio, Smith will have to choose among his home for 36 seasons, his alma mater, and former assistants Roy Williams and Eddie Fogler. El Deano, exiled to the cheap seats, needs to have Duke there; he can't root for everybody.

title: Suzanne Miller, Douglas Ewing
description: Suzanne Elizabeth Miller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Miller of Lancaster, Pa., was married there yesterday to Dr. Douglas Robinson Ewing, the son of Madelyn B. Ewing of New York and Douglas C. Ewing of Stockholm. Canon David P. Thomas performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: Holiday Homicide
description: You think you have a hard time with the holidays?

title: Sidney Lumet
description: Lumet's latest movie is ''Critical Care,'' a satire about American medicine.

title: Sumo's Mt. Everest Retires, Giving Japan and Its Sport Pause
description: He is to other men what Mount Everest is to a hillock, and for 15 years the 600-pound wrestler known as Konishiki has been one of the most famous and even influential foreigners in Japan, helping to open the ancient sport of sumo to the outside world.

title: The World; A Century Later, Letting Africans Draw Their Own Map
description: FROM the earliest days of Africa's postcolonial era, a critical pair of thoughts have been virtual articles of faith for generations of African intellectuals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVEY, HAROLD D.
description: SILVEY-Harold D. On behalf of the Officers, Trustees and entire Congregation, we mourn the loss of our esteemed honorary president. Harold led this congregation with devotion, loyalty and distinction. He was always jovial and always gave his first concern to his family and to the Temple. Our heartfelt sympathy is expressed to his beloved wife Lucille and family. May his memory be for a blessing. Linda Henry Goodman, Rabbi Hortense Hurwitz, President Union Temple of Brooklyn

title: The Population Explosion Is Over
description: For 30 years, one notion has shaped much of modern social thought: that the human species is reproducing itself uncontrollably, and ominously. In his best-selling book of 1968, ''The Population Bomb,'' Paul Ehrlich warned that ''the cancer of population growth must be cut out'' or ''we will breed ourselves into oblivion.'' He appeared on the Johnny Carson show 25 times to sell this idea. Lester Brown's ''29th Day'' compared people to geometrically multiplying waterlilies; on the 30th day, the world would end. A study by the Club of Rome (which it later renounced) described how rapacious humans would soon ''run out of resources.''

title: 10 Heroin Deaths in Texas Reflect Rising Use by Young
description: This suburb of about 190,000 people hardly looks like a place where young people regularly die of heroin. Plano, 20 miles north of Dallas's forlorn downtown, is all big and new, with similar sprawling houses crammed side by side.

title: Personal Watercraft Split Industry
description: It is open war in the boating industry these days. And like so many battles of economic magnitude, it is being waged over the smallest of objects: boating's flourishing but controversial line of personal watercraft.

title: The High Cost of Education Means Fixing Schools, Too
description: Shortly after Jack Collins became Speaker of the Assembly last year, he proposed raising the cigarette tax to provide $6 billion for repairing dozens of old schools and building new ones. The Assembly went along with the plan, even though Republicans are reluctant to raise taxes of any kind these days. But the Senate rejected the proposal, and Governor Whitman offered only lukewarm support.

title: Teachers' Unions And Charter Schools
description: The article on charter schools in Connecticut (''It's Shakeout Time at New Charter Schools,'' Nov. 2) concluded with the implication that teachers' unions are opposed to charter schools. As president of Connecticut's largest teachers' organization, the Hartford-based Connecticut Education Association, I am compelled to set the record straight.

title: November 16-22; Tracking Seinfeld's Last Laugh
description: Whenever Jerry Seinfeld decides to shut down production on his now-classic television situation comedy, he is committed to insuring that he leaves his audience laughing -- and crying for more.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-16

title: A New Day In Congo, But Fingers Stay Sticky
description: This hilly suburb of Congo's capital, where the breeze blows cool, and the meticulously kept tropical gardens of the wealthy fairly resemble visions of earthly paradise, had not seen such a change since the end of Belgian rule in 1960.

title: Don't Say Hurtful Things, Good Buddy
description: Perhaps you saw the recently broadcast Mercedes-Benz TV commercial in which the company boasted that even ''mean old truckers'' couldn't frighten its new M-Class sport utility vehicle off the road. If you didn't, you won't. The commercial was run off the air, thanks in part to Loved Ones and Drivers Support, or Loads, a small but feisty Wisconsin-based watchdog group on the lookout for ''those who use a negative stereotype . . . of truckers to sell their products.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CONHEIM, SUE
description: CONHEIM-Sue. November 19, 1950. In ever loving memory, Daughter Marilyn

title: Broken Arrow
description: Wild Justice The People of Geronimo vs. the United States. By Michael Lieder and Jake Page. 318 pp. New York: Random House. $25.95.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Beyond Self-Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrating Half a Century of a Constitution That Has Aged Well
description: WORLD WAR II veterans returning to Newark or Paterson or Camden came home to report that people from other states were making fun of New Jersey, but not because of its turnpike or refineries or the way people said ''Joisey.'' In those days, the soldiers learned that people laughed at New Jersey because it was seen as corrupt, chaotic and ungovernable ''a raucous little state,'' as John Gunther wrote in ''Inside USA.''

title: Bailout Time ; The Stock of 'Asian Values' Drops
description: AS Asia's economic ascendancy in the 80's and early 90's moved from the astounding to the mildly terrifying, the world began to look for the magic formula that built such prosperity from poverty. Asian leaders themselves were the first to give the recipe a label, writing about ''the Pacific way'' and lecturing about ''Asian values.''

title: Queens Man Shot to Death In Brooklyn
description: A 48-year-old Queens man was shot dead in Brooklyn's Prospect Park on Friday night by an assailant who apparently fled in the victim's car, the police said yesterday.

title: November 16-22; Service for Seven
description: A 29-year-old Iowan gave birth to seven babies Wednesday. It was the first time that so many infants were born alive in this country. Though the mother, Bobbi McCaughey, took fertility drugs, experts hope the septuplets will be seen as an aberration that careful fertility programs can almost always avoid. PAM BELLUCK

title: Clinics Selling Embryos Made For 'Adoption'
description: Kathy Butler, a 47-year-old New Jersey woman, is pregnant with triplets. But the babies bear no relationship to her or to her husband, Gary. Instead, they are growing from ready-made embryos that the Butlers selected and paid for at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan.

title: Amy Chapman, John Freeman
description: Amy Roanne Chapman, a political organizer in Washington, and John Forsyth Freeman, a Michigan state legislator, were married last evening at the Historic Car Barn in Washington. Rabbi Reeve R. Brenner officiated with the Rev. H. Lynn Johndahl, a minister of the United Church of Christ.

title: Much Is Shown
description: To the Editor:

title: Hopping From Key To Key
description: IN my hotel room in Islamorada, Fla., a telephone jangles and an unnervingly chipper voice tells me it is 5:30 A.M. Time to fish. I come awake slowly to stars in the failing dark outside and a hot breeze soughing through the curtains. Only on vacation can you get up this early and feel a vague thrill about what you'll be doing once you find your car keys.

title: Hotel Business Is Growing Bigger, Busier and Faster
description: The American Radiator Building, the Gothic tower on 40th Street whose gold crown was once lighted to resemble a hot radiator in a tribute to the automobile age, is being recast as a hotel in the midst of an extraordinary rush by developers to meet the soaring demand for hotel rooms in New York City.

title: Jagr's Goal in Overtime Spoils a Big Comeback
description: The Rangers might like to file this one under the unlikely heading of ''positive defeat.'' They lost in overtime by 4-3 to the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight on a Jaromir Jagr goal that left defenseman Ulf Samuelsson shattering his stick in frustration.

title: November 16-22; Bombs and Dead Ends
description: In what has seemed a desperate trickle of disclosures, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has released information about three unsolved bombings in Atlanta, beginning with the deadly explosion at Centennial Olympic Park on July 27, 1996. On Tuesday, officials displayed replicas of the bomb components in all three incidents. They were hoping that someone somewhere would remember selling the items, including batteries, nails and alarm clocks. KEVIN SACK

title: 9 Months In Style
description: ''Nine months is a long time to be unfashionable,'' said Liz Steinberg Lange, a fashion designer. While every designer seems to have an odd-sounding decree these days, hers may be more practical than most: her audience is pregnant women.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: Cruising Across Europe in 23 Days
description: Since 1992 when the Main-Danube Canal opened, linking the Rhine and Danube Rivers by way of the Main River, barges have been able to go all the way across Europe, from the North Sea to the Black Sea.

title: Ladies Who Launch
description: AS 25 ballet dancers in white feathers posed stock-still, Samantha Kluge Cahan animatedly rushed about the gardenia-festooned foyer at the 69th Regiment Armory. A few burgundy-colored flowers poked from her blond hair, and her embroidered-tulle Tocca dress, designed by her close friend Marie-Anne Oudejans, swept the floor. Sipping Champagne, Mrs. Cahan -- who is known as Sam to her friends -- described her mother's reaction when she was invited to the Tocca party.

title: It's Back From the Wings: Vaudeville, Good and Bad
description: HURTLING into the 21st century, Americans like to think that they have more entertainment choices than any people in human history. A world-dominating film industry churns out hundreds of motion pictures every year. Cable channels too numerous to count operate around the clock to satisfy every possible whim. So where's the singing-duck act?

title: Sarah Tanz, Ronald Rich
description: Sarah Diane Tanz, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Tanz of Manhattan, was married last evening to Ronald Alan Rich, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Rich of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein performed the ceremony at the Grand Hyatt in Manhattan.

title: Saying Aah! on Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Reports on Iraq Arms
description: The governing board of the commission disarming Iraq told the Security Council yesterday that Iraq had not met the requirements for reducing surveillance of its biological, chemical or missile weapons systems but that the country appeared to be close to compliance on ending its secret nuclear program.

title: Killing Widens Age-Old Rift
description: ''Many residents see us as vandals or hoodlums,'' says a letter circulating these days around City Island. ''But the truth is we are your children. Let's get together and get this guy off our streets. Become our ally instead of our enemy.''

title: Running the F.B.I.
description: Why was there not a single woman in the photo showing the early-morning run of three dozen recruits at the F.B.I. Academy in Quantico, Va.? A photo of so-called brick agents depicts a lone woman, symbolically standing at the outer left margin. Minority faces are equally rare. Despite Freeh's appointment of the first female assistant director, as well as two blacks and a Hispanic, the male club atmosphere of the F.B.I. has remained visibly unchanged.

title: Ally, the Talk Around the Water Cooler
description: WHEN Janey Burley, a 24-year-old freelance publicity agent for Barneys New York, recently met a prominent creative director for a fashion magazine, she became so nervous that her hands started to sweat. ''I went to shake her hand and I felt like a wet sponge,'' Ms. Burley said. ''I could have been Ally at that moment.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The Man Who Would Rule Everything
description: In 334 B.C., King Alexander of Macedon, then 21 years old, led an army of 44,000 from Greece into Persia, beginning a 22,000-mile, 11-year march of conquest that stretched across the whole Middle East and down into India -- across some of earth's harshest deserts and steepest mountains -- leaving him master of an empire of two million square miles when he died in Babylon in 323. IN THE FOOTSTEPS OF ALEXANDER THE GREAT (University of California, $27.50) is not only a history of Alexander but also an account by the intrepid British documentary maker Michael Wood of his tracing of Alexander's entire route with a film crew to prepare a program for broadcast on the BBC and on public television in this country. Relying on Greek and Roman sources, Wood tells a glorious story with some very dark shadows. On the whole he gets it right, and his writing is clear and crisp. The harrowing tale of his own trek over the same ground makes clear how heroic Alexander's army was. And in a dozen countries, in cities and villages, in desert camps and on mountains of the Hindu Kush, he found that Alexander is fiercely alive in poetry, songs and folk tales, in the imaginations of millions. He has been ever since he set out on his conquest. In the Middle Ages there were more than 200 Alexander epics composed in European languages alone, and every ruler wanted to emulate him. One of them was Charles the Bold, Duke of Burgundy, whose great-grandson, the Emperor Charles V, would rule an empire even greater than Alexander's, one that included the Americas. THE HISTORY OF ALEXANDER THE GREAT (The J. Paul Getty Museum, $140), by Scot McKendrick, reproduces the magnificent paintings of Charles the Bold's copy of a French translation of the history of Alexander by the Roman historian Quintus Curtius and places them in the context of the literature and art of the late 15th century in northern Europe. The paintings and surrounding illuminations in this book blaze with the opulence of the Burgundian court, brilliantly depicted in a frontispiece showing the translator presenting the book to the Duke. The ability of the anonymous painters to render palpable action in brilliant colors is admirable, and so is the reproduction of the pictures by the Stinehour Press on the 17-by-13-inch pages of this formidable volume. D. J. R. Bruckner

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, HARRIET G.
description: COHEN-Harriet G. November 3, 1983. In cherished and loving memory of beloved mother, grandmother and sister-in-law. Always in our hearts. Sadly missed. Richard, Hope, daughters Lindsey and Ashley, sister-in-law Lucille

title: Between Fathers and Sons, Values and Politics
description: IT has been more than 50 years since a narrator named Tom (for Tennessee) leaned against a fire escape, lit a cigarette and addressed the audience. With that monologue, he unwittingly defined a genre that would haunt and inspire playwrights forevermore.

title: A Little Discipline For the Glory of Vines
description: NOW that the leaves have fallen from the trees, remnants of vines may be seen climbing on arbors, twining on fences, growing up tree trunks -- reminders of the summer that has gone by.

title: For Volatile Times, The Psychology of Risk
description: Even if most investment advisers can tolerate the stock market's recent volatility, some individual investors may need help coming to terms with market risk.

title: For Unpaid Interns, A Lack of Legal Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: Writing His Way Through Show Biz
description: IMAGINE a life so rich that every memory involves extraordinary people. In what he wryly refers to as ''this next-to-closing era, my A.A.R.P. years,'' 77-year-old Max Wilk, author, humorist, playwright and Emmy Award winning television writer/producer, considers it his particular gift to look back and remember.

title: Down a Peg
description: Any woman who slips her foot passionately into high-heeled shoes or boots this season only to teeter around, unable to walk, can relax. Top Service, the cobbler of the well heeled, at 845 Seventh Avenue (54th Street; 212-765-3190), will take some height out of that heel, for a mere $5. Fabrice Gallean, the manager, said that balance is the most important aspect of high heels. The balance is off, he said, if your foot slides down and your toes smoosh. Most often, he takes off 1/4 or 3/8 of an inch, but he has trimmed as much as 2 inches. Chanel, Prada, Gucci and Manolo Blahnik are no strangers to Mr. Gallean, who works with them for fashion shows. ''I don't have to look at the fashion pages to know the heels got really high this season,'' he said. ''I can tell by the amount of women walking through my door.''

title: Solution Prevails
description: Solution, owned by John Thomson of Sands Point, N.Y., defeated six boats yesterday to win the four-day Farr 40 Gold Cup regatta at Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: A Neighbor Reveals Site of 'Friends' Building
description: o the Editor:

title: THEATER REVIEW ; The Old Testament In Song and Dance
description: THE wit and wisdom of musicals can be a ceaseless source of comfort and reaffirmation, validation and sustenance. Take ''La Cage aux Folles,'' with its lyric ''I am my own special creation.'' But none of the masters of musical theater have presumed to tell us about Creation, the theme of ''Children of Eden'' at the Paper Mill Playhouse here.

title: Stacey Orbuch, Stephen Blumberg
description: Stacey Leigh Orbuch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Orbuch of Merrick, N.Y., was married last evening to Stephen Michael Blumberg, the son of Warren Blumberg of Hatboro, Pa., and the late Barbara M. Blumberg. Rabbi Charles A. Klein performed the ceremony at the Woodbury (N.Y.) Jewish Center.

title: Reassessment On Migration Of Students
description: Almost 38 percent of New Jersey's high school graduates who go on to college go to schools in other states. Only Connecticut sends a larger percentage of its high school graduates to out-of-state colleges.
