description: Honoring libraries, authors, institutions and a Duchess.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: WALES

title: Is It Opera? Maybe, but Who Cares?
description: ''TIME ROCKER,'' A SELF-DESCRIBED rock opera at the Brooklyn Academy of Music by Lou Reed and Robert Wilson, has sent me to the dictionaries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDY, ROBERT PAUL
description: RUDY-Robert Paul. On Thursday, November 20, 1997. In his 83rd year. After a long and valiant battle with cancer. Beloved husband for fifty-six years of Joan Price Rudy. Loving father of John and Janice and the late Richard. Adoring grandfather of Hilary, Brett and Kerri. Devoted brother of Selma Sacks, Leonard and Nancy Rudy and much loved uncle to Sayres Rudy, Lisa and Peter Cook, Gail and Matthew Jenkins, Jane and John Scully and Wendy and Kaiser Zaman. Services Sunday, November 23, 1 PM, at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 E. 79 Street, at 2nd Avenue. Contributions in Robert's memory may be sent to the Richard P. Rudy and Robert P. Rudy Memorial Fund (M.I.T., Office of the Treasurer, 238 Main Street, Cambridge, Mass. 02142).

title: New Route For Bus Hits Roadblock
description: To New York City Transit officials, the idea must have seemed simple: a shift of a block or two on the M1 bus route from lower Park Avenue to Madison and Fifth Avenues, where other buses already run.

title: A.S.P.C.A. Has Changed Role in Animal Rescues
description: To the Editor:

title: Parisians' Paris
description: To the Editor: A couple of details to add to Ann Pringle-Harris's article about Paris, ''The 15th, a World of Its Own'' (Nov. 2):

title: Penn State's Quarterback Exits Smiling
description: Mike McQueary knows how to make an exit. In his final home game, the fifth-year senior quarterback was a a model of efficiency today in engineering Penn State's 35-10 victory over Wisconsin. He completed 16 of 19 passes for 269 yards and 3 touchdowns, 2 of them to another senior, Joe Jurevicius.

title: Young Prepares to Leave Giants at End of Season for N.F.L. Post
description: George Young, one of the most respected men in the National Football League and a Hall of Fame candidate, has essentially made it official: after 18 years at the helm, he will retire at the end of this season as general manager of the Giants.

title: And Now, the Next Four Years
description: ON the morning after her narrow re-election victory, Governor Whitman stood before the television cameras, appearing unfazed by her near-defeat and promising to tackle the two problems that dominated the campaign: auto insurance and property taxes.

title: A Brother's Bitterness
description: David Kaczynski, who turned in his brother, Theodore J. Kaczynski, as the suspected Unabomber, bitterly describes what he calls a cynical reversal by the Government. He says that prosecutors had earlier described his brother as a ''disturbed individual,'' but are now seeking the death penalty in four of the bombings that began in 1978.

title: Hitler's Germany Provides A Lesson on Gun Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Lectures on Responsibility Won't Help Addicts; Deficit Disorder Is Real
description: To the Editor:

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/ Norwalk, Conn.; No Longer That 'Hole in the Doughnut'
description: IN the 70's the Norwalk Chamber of Commerce tried to attract business to the city by calling it ''the hole in the doughnut.'' ''They thought it would appeal to businesses as an undiscovered place on the Gold Coast -- a good area on the cheap, '' said former Mayor William A. Collins.

title: Oh, Those Rock Band Names; Recalling 'Victory at Sea' And the Beatles' 'Bad' Name
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: TOUCH AND GO

title: Jennifer Bird, Richard Newton
description: Jennifer Lynne Bird and Richard Philippe Newton were married yesterday at the Rihga Royal Hotel in New York. The Rev. Adam Curry of the Universal Life Church officiated.

title: Word for Word/Disaster Do's and Don'ts; From Bitter Experience, New Ways To Handle Aviation Calamities
description: LAST week the families of the victims of TWA Flight 800 got one answer, however unsatisfactory, to the mystery of the jet's explosion off Long Island two summers ago: it wasn't sabotage, the F.B.I. concluded.

title: Children's Village: Solace, Second Chance, Success
description: ''BEING a doctor has always been my dream,'' Cleveland Edwards said. Now that dream is within reach: Cleveland, 17, is a full-scholarship, premed freshman at Cornell University.

title: A Little Discipline for the Glory of Vines
description: NOW that the leaves have fallen from the trees, remnants of vines can be seen climbing on arbors, twining on fences, growing up tree trunks -- reminders of the summer that has gone by.

title: Black Fraternity Makes Helping a Priority
description: LONG before there was the Million Man March, which focused national attention on black men who proclaimed their determination to help their communities escape poverty, ignorance and addictions, members of Alpha Phi Alpha -- the oldest Greek-letter fraternity in the world for black men -- have been serving their communities.

title: F.Y.I.
description: 'Dixie' in the Bowery

title: A Growing Market in Computer Solutions
description: IN the new world order, computers are the life blood of business. Keeping them productive and healthy has given rise to a hot new industry: technology services, a market that is expected to grow more than $100 billion to $413 billion between now and 2000.

title: The Politics of Personality
description: I for one, am delighted that Susan Molinari has a new profession (''The Politics of Personality,'' by Elisabeth Bumiller, Nov. 2). At least now I can keep her from having any impact on my life simply by changing the channel.

title: For the Screwdriver Challenged, Fix-It Advice by Phone
description: WHEN Carmela DeBellis accidentally dropped a dust cloth into the lint filter of her dryer, she started calling repair services to come to her Florida home and fix the damage.

title: Helen Harvey, 81, A Theatrical Agent
description: Helen Harvey, a New York theatrical agent who in her 50-year career represented some of the most important playwrights, directors and designers, died on Monday at Hartford Hospital in Connecticut. She was 81 and lived in New Milford, Conn.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Lexus GS 300 and GS 400; Now What the Devil Has Gotten Into Lexus?
description: A COUPLE of years ago, over dinner with Jim Press, the general manager of Lexus, the conversation turned to passion -- the kind stirred up by a handful of high-performance luxury cars.

title: Bringing Battle Ribbons to a Semi-Camelot
description: Before Inspector Joanne Jaffe took command in June of the 19th Precinct, which covers the Upper East Side, she had had her taste of the city's toughest precincts, as well as what police officers call the Camelot precincts, where crime is low and community relations gentle. Now, she says, she plans to apply lessons from both experiences.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the effects of annual fees on the value of workers' 401(k) plans referred incorrectly to the Exxon Corporation's plan. The company, not the employee, pays nearly all of the 5 cents in costs per $100 in each employee's account.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRK, GRAYSON L.
description: KIRK-Grayson L. On behalf of the entire University commmunity, the President and Trustees of Columbia University express deep sorrow at the passing of President Emeritus Grayson L. Kirk. During his 17 years of leadership, Dr. Kirk forged a new and expanded role for the American university through the creation of purposeful programs of study at Columbia. His creativity and dedication led to the creation of numerous international programs of exchange and scholarship; major new programs in business, physics, medicine, oceanography, and the arts; and cutting-edge institutes of urban environment and community affairs. Dr. Kirk's efforts also strengthened the University's fiscal standing and led to the doubling of the University Library. Columbia University extends profound sympathy to his son John and his family. George Rupp, President Stephen Friedman, Chair of the Trustees

title: St. John's Is Given A Scare By Terriers
description: All St. John's wanted last night was a tuneup, a soft touch to get the team ready for the Puerto Rico Shootout that begins on Thursday. Beach clothes were packed, itineraries planned, and all that remained was for the Red Storm to dust off the St. Francis Terriers, the way it had every time the two teams had met since 1956.

title: Correction
description: A brief article last Sunday about a former Seattle-area teacher who pleaded guilty to child rape for having an affair with a 13-year-old boy misstated the sentence in some editions. She did not avoid a prison term; she was sentenced to six months in jail and ordered to enter a sexual deviancy treatment program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGINLEY, REV. JAMES J., S.J.
description: McGINLEY-Rev. James J., S.J. Beloved cousin of Florence. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel in Murray-Weigel Hall, 515 E. Fordham Rd., Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Murray-Weigel Chapel, Monday, 11:30 AM. For information contact Farenga Bros., Inc., 718-654-0500.

title: Democrats Gain Control Of the Board of Legislators
description: IT appears that the Democrats have taken control of the County Board of Legislators -- for the first time in the Board's history.

title: Bosnia Revisited, With an Eye on the Future
description: THE BOSNIAN WAR IN THE early 1990's was truly a conflict of the new information age. It was covered live, in color and in detail. No one could say, ''I didn't know,'' because journalists and camera crews were risking their lives daily to keep the world informed by satellite. Yet this was not enough. Governments and members of the public everywhere ''knew''; they even expressed outrage, dismay and embarrassment. But the bombardment of Sarajevo continued for almost four years.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Romans and Christians
description: In Rome, Marcus Aurelius is Emperor, and in faraway Lusitania, in a city called Tarcisis, on the western edge of the Iberian peninsula in what will one day be Portugal, Lucius Valerius Quintius is his humble servant -- the duumvir, or magistrate. Dedicated and loyal, Lucius lives in a contentious time, caught between the dominance of what he calls ''Romanity'' -- built on its Latin heritage as well as the Empire's global reach -- and the fast-growing influence of the cult of Christianity. While the Christians spread their unfamiliar Gospel, the old guard sticks to comfortable tradition: animal sacrifice and entrail reading, bloody games and public punishment to please the masses, and stubborn adherence to the laws of Rome. Added to this precarious situation is an unseen but very real menace: Moorish hordes who have come from North Africa intent on looting and burning the Roman settlements. In A GOD STROLLING IN THE COOL OF THE EVENING (Louisiana State University Press, $26.95), the Portuguese writer Mario de Carvalho (aided by his skillful translator, Gregory Rabassa) captures the fear and suspicion that surrounded the early years of what Lucius dismisses as ''the sect that worshiped fish.'' The right-minded Lucius is intent on remaining a just and respected leader by upholding Roman authority, but his colleagues scheme behind his back, and the Moors descend on his vulnerable city with deadly force. At the same time, Lucius' mind becomes clouded by a strangely decorous love for the Christian daughter of one of his most trusted friends. Elegant and erudite, Carvalho's novel is an absorbing study of a single man's moral code, as well as a provocative meditation on the difficulty of leading a virtuous life in an era of tumultuous change. Erik Burns

title: Resort With A Conscience
description: MAYBE it was guilt that led us to the Florida Keys and Cheeca Lodge. Feeling ecological guilt in southern Florida is as natural as breathing. Strip malls rule, and unmolested beachfront is history.

title: Mount St. Michael Rolls On
description: Mount St. Michael (10-0), led by halfback NcHendia Tajong, captured its second straight Catholic High Schools Football League Class A title by routing 6-4 St. Anthony's, 40-14, yesterday in front of 1,500 boisterous fans at St. John's University.

title: Putting the Brakes On High-Speed Chases
description: ON April 29, a 38-year-old mother of four, Cynthia Hearst, was killed and her sister, Tammy Cheatham, critically injured when their parked station wagon was rear-ended by a pick-up truck being pursued through Bridgeport by the Trumbull police.

title: Q and A
description: Rio's Carnaval

title: Stolen Passport
description: To the Editor: My wife and I recently returned from the Riviera. The night before our departure for Frankfurt, someone entered our room and stole several items, including our passports. We reported it to the police. Using the police report as identification, we drove through Italy and Switzerland to Frankfurt, where the Consulate General could issue new passports. We filled out the forms, and our new passports were ready. The fee was about $150. I told the officer it would take all my money and was told I could charge it, but my credit card had been stolen, too. I suggested we pay after our return home but was told there is no such procedure. I had to empty my wallet.

title: Why They Kill Their Newborns
description: Your article on infanticide illustrates how silly evolutionary explanations of human behavior have become. When mothers protect their newborns (which almost all do), it's because that behavior is evolutionarily adaptive. And now, when a few mothers kill their newborns, that's evolutionarily adaptive, too.

title: Bombs Away For Tigers
description: Princeton put on an impressive display of 3-point shooting tonight, making 13 of 25 shots from beyond the arc in a 64-52 defeat of Rutgers.

title: Continuing Ed
description: Tuesdays with Morrie An Old Man, a Young Man, and Life's Greatest Lesson. By Mitch Albom. 192 pp. New York: Doubleday. $19.95.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARTER, DAVID
description: CARTER-David. Four years in heaven and you're missed as much as ever. Watch me this year, Pop, this one's for you. Love, Donny, Nancy, Lauren and Stephanie.

title: The View From/White Plains; Making Thanksgiving for Those Without a Place to Call Home
description: VICKY SANTIAGO remembers the Thanksgiving 10 years ago when she was homeless. ''My kids and I had slices of pizza in a place in Jackson Heights, Queens,'' she said. ''That was it -- sitting there in an empty pizza place, each eating one slice. We were living in a shelter, and that was all we could afford.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHOOR, FRANCES
description: SCHOOR-Frances. Beloved wife of Gene Schoor. Memorial service Sunday, December 7, 4 P.M., at Darech Amuno Synagogue, 53 Charles Street, West Village.

title: Nancy Shive, Jude Tanella
description: Nancy Butler Shive and Jude Anthony Tanella were married yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bound Brook, N.J. The Rev. Joseph Lugo performed the ceremony.

title: November 16-22; Disconnect and Beware
description: The Transportation Department, agreeing that airbags sometimes do more harm than good, loosened the rules on installing on-off switches. But a medical advisory panel said airbags are still a benefit -- especially if short people adjust the seat back, and children sit in the rear. MATTHEW L. WALD

title: Reinventing Thanksgiving in Tuscany
description: WHEN Roger and I realized that no family members could gather with us for Thanksgiving, at first we were despondent. The notion of a Thanksgiving for two seemed bleak. Disorientation, though, quickly turned to anticipation. There was nothing holding us down, and we had some free time, so why not go away? We decided to take advantage of the cheap seasonal air fares, and do something wild and different. We'd go to Tuscany, where the food is incomparable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARFINKEL, HENRY ''HANK''
description: GARFINKEL-Henry ''Hank'', at home on November 21 at age 57 after a valiant battle with cancer. A Ph.D. from Columbia University, his creativity shone through during his career as a toy inventor. Proud to be Andrew and Allison's father, beloved and adored husband of Susan, devoted son of the late Sol and Katherine, brother of the late David, special uncle to Heather and Adam and grateful brother-in-law to Penny. Services today, 11:30 AM, at ''Gutterman's,'' Woodbury, LI. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in his memory to Hospice Care of LI.

title: The Skate Pit
description: In September, when Dr. Wayne Halliwell, a Montreal sports psychologist, stood before the men who wear stripes as National Hockey League referees, his message was an image of simple carpentry. ''These are guys who are under immense mental strain,'' he says. ''I draw them a table. The top is their confidence. I tell them they've got four legs to maintain -- mental, physical, technical and tactical, and they need an improvement plan for each one.''

title: Children Find Locks, Not Slides
description: For weeks, there has been clamoring at the gates, gnashing of teeth, stomping of feet, screams and tears. The Henry Street playgrounds at Long Island College Hospital, with their fortlike slides and swings decorated with giant Pop Art flowers, are closed.

title: Why They Kill Their Newborns
description: How dare you publish Steven Pinker's argument for extending some measure of understanding to women who kill newborn babies, under dire circumstances, because they are descended from generations of women who cut their losses by killing infants they could not raise (''Why They Kill Their Newborns,'' Nov. 2).

title: Streetscapes/The Racquet & Tennis Club; A Park Ave. Anomaly Dedicated to Arcane Sports
description: IT'S an architectural Alamo, a masonry Park Avenue holdout now almost completely surrounded by glass and steel buildings. Now the 1918 Racquet & Tennis Club, between 52d and 53d Streets, home to some of the most arcane sports in the world, is embarking on a restoration program, caused in part by the loss of some melon-sized chunks from its terra-cotta cornice.

title: New Arcade Owner Finds Magic in Aisles
description: BOB PAQUETTE had one foot on a shelf partly filled with bottles of laundry detergent in assorted colors and sizes. To his right, a virtual garden of silk flowers grew from a peg board, their green wire stems stuck through the holes in the fiberboard.

title: Getting an Education in Casino City
description: HAULING gamblers like day laborers to the farm fields, the crowded casino bus lumbered into Atlantic City on Monday morning. A frisson of anticipation roused passengers who had been dozing on the long trip down from North Jersey. They began joshing one another about having good luck.

title: Martha Schall, Morris Czaczkes
description: Martha Eleanor Schall, a daughter of Susanne and Edmund W. Schall of Woodbridge, Conn., is to be married this afternoon to Morris E. Czaczkes, a son of Eva and Harry Czaczkes of North Franklin, Conn. The Rev. Peter A. R. Stebinger, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Battell Chapel of Yale University in New Haven. Rabbi Steven J. Mason assisted in the service.

title: Brazilian Beat
description: Marcel Camus's BLACK ORPHEUS (1959), an Oscar winner for best foreign film, loosely parallels the Orpheus and Eurydice tragedy. In this gorgeously colored French-Portuguese film (shown with subtitles) Orpheus (Breno Mello) strums a guitar rather than a lute and is a streetcar conductor. Eurydice, the object of his ill-fated desire, is a beautiful country girl wistfully portrayed by Marpessa Dawn. The two fall in love in Rio de Janeiro at carnival time. The movie is full of intoxicating samba music, frenzied dancing and violent costumes, focusing on the rhythm and melody of the city. -- MON. at 8 P.M. MON.-TUES. at 2 A.M. and TUES. at 3:30 P.M. on BRAVO. Howard Thompson

title: A.S.P.C.A. Has Changed Role in Animal Rescues
description: To the Editor:

title: November 16-22; A Reformer Barred
description: Ron Carey, the teamsters' president who earned a reputation as Mr. Clean, got muddied last week. A court-appointed union monitor barred him from running for re-election, ruling that he took part in a conspiracy that improperly funneled union funds into his campaign last year. His victory was overturned in August. The reversal leaves James P. Hoffa, son of the legendary teamsters leader, as the front-runner. STEVEN GREENHOUSE

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2

title: Word & Image; Pimpernel, Of the Press
description: Can you even imagine it in this era of media villainy: a righteous journalist? There once was such a scribbler whose sudden and selfless concern for humanity clashed tragically with America's indifference. It has taken more than half a century to render due tribute, and posthumous apology, to the still too little known Varian Fry.

title: What Is an Artist's Style, and Is It Her Own?
description: A THIEF steals property. A plagiarist takes another's words and calls them his own. But what is the offense when an artist adopts a style and techniques that another artist says are hers?

title: Florida State Tastes the Bitters as Michigan Smells the Roses
description: The sweetest rose was in Charles Woodson's hands.

title: Records of Big Municipal Union Are Subpoenaed
description: Stanley Hill, the leader of the city's largest municipal workers' union and a supporter of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, said yesterday that the Manhattan District Attorney's office had subpoenaed the union's financial records and other documents.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Large 'Nutcracker'

title: IMPACT STATEMENT
description: Skydive Arizona, a company based near Tucson, held its second annual Junk Day this week. Sky divers, borne aloft by a cargo plane, tossed old Honda Civics, motorcycles and a hot-water heater into the Sonora Desert from 13,000 feet. Experienced divers rode along with the junk until their chutes opened at 3,000 feet. It was all environmentally correct -- the junk was cleaned up -- but what was the point? ''It's art,'' says Bryan Burke, the company's general manager. Sounds like a rationalization, but you can see how this event would offer more kinetic thrills than doing, say, a drip painting. ''It's amazing how demolished things get,'' Burke says. ''If you're going through a divorce, it's a great way to dispose of your ex's belongings.''

title: Tours of Historic Places On the Internet
description: The National Park Service has begun to post on the Web tours of buildings and sites listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Three city itineraries and one regional itinerary are already available.

title: Dyan Finguerra, Seth Du Charme
description: Dyan Mary Finguerra, a lawyer, and Seth David Du Charme, a deputy with the United States Marshals Service in Brooklyn, were married yesterday at Our Lady of Hope Church in Carle Place, N.Y. Lawrence V. Hammel, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony.

title: The Yankees Perfect the Art of the Denial: The Confusing Deal That Wasn't
description: Randy Smith probably knows a trade when he sees one. Just last week, in less than 48 hours, he made four trades involving 17 players. In a nine-day span last December, he made seven trades involving 23 players. In his two years as general manager of the Detroit Tigers, he has completed 31 trades.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Last Great Snake Show By Tim McLaurin. Putnam, $24.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREAKSTONE, JACOB (JACK)
description: BREAKSTONE-Jacob (Jack). We mourn the passing of our dear cousin who suffered for so many years with MS. May he now rest in peace. With love. Juliet Diamond, Marilyn Meadow Jon Meadow

title: The No. 1 Customer: Sorry, It Isn't You
description: THE information revolution arrived at Merrill Lynch on Feb. 7, 1995.

title: 'God Created Me to Be a Slave'
description: Having returned last month from a stay in Mauritania, I was astonished by Elinor Burkett's article on slavery there. As an African-American serving as the editor of Martin Luther King Jr.'s papers, I am of course sensitive about the issue of slavery and used every opportunity to question Mauritanians (including black citizens and public officials) and foreign residents (including American and German diplomats) about the validity of reports that slavery persists in that country. Nothing I saw and no one with whom I talked offered any confirmation of these reports.

title: YOUNG NEW JERSEY ; Dinner Is Served: Etiquette for the Uninitiated, or the Just Plain Antsy
description: All year I threatened.

title: Kara Madden, Randall DuRie
description: Kara Burlington Madden, a daughter of Patricia B. Madden of Wyckoff, N.J., and Thomas J. Madden of Carmel, N.Y., was married yesterday to Randall Brittin DuRie, a son of Marcia and William W. DuRie, also of Wyckoff. The Rev. Joseph J. Gross, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart in Newark.

title: From Different Paths, Muslims Seek Common Ground
description: On Friday afternoons, the parking lot of the new Muslim Center of Middlesex County is often jammed. Once the white-lined spaces are full, the cars double up in the driving lanes.

title: Our Towns; At Toy Stores, Early Birds Get the Crowd
description: IT is well past rush hour, a time when the New Jersey Turnpike usually takes a breather. But no: Just past Newark International Airport, where the containers at Port Newark and Elizabeth are suspended above the cars on their massive lifts, the traffic is heavy and getting pretty ugly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, RONALD STANTON
description: SMITH-Ronald Stanton. Ronnie was a wonderful human being. He was a truly honorable man. His talent, sense of humor and kindness will be greatly missed. He was retired from Tiffany & Co, where he worked for 27 years. He is survived by his sister Carolyn, his brother-in-law Richard, nieces and nephews, and his companion Richard Currier. Donations can be sent to the National Association for the Visually Handicapped, 22 West 21st St, NY, NY 10010.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: MUSEUM MILE ; Stories of Departures, At the Gate or Waiting
description: THE cemeteries of Queens ''reflect the living as much as they reflect the dead,'' says Ilana Harlow, curator, photographer and writer for ''Beyond the Grave,'' an exhibit at the Museum of the City of New York through next March.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Brawley Suit Showcases One Man's Fiery Style
description: The first week of the defamation lawsuit against Alton H. Maddox Jr. and two other former advisers of Tawana Brawley has made at least one thing abundantly clear: being threatened with millions of dollars in damages has done nothing to temper Mr. Maddox's tongue.

title: Commercial Property/866 Third Avenue; For One Building, Three Uses: Retail, Medical, Hotel
description: A LARGELY vacant office building at 866 Third Avenue, between 52d and 53d Streets, is about to be converted to an unusual mix of uses as a result of a complex agreement announced last May and made final in recent weeks.

title: Pierce Sets Up Chance to End Her Comeback Season With a Championship
description: Sometimes she's quirky, sometimes she's querulous, and sometimes the importance of keeping up an imperious front makes it hard for her to keep up with the score.

title: INSIDE
description: Western Gamble in Bosnia

title: Habitats/119 West 80th Street; First He Bought a Co-op, Then the Whole Building
description: STEVEN JAY WEISZ thought he was buying a one-bedroom co-op in an Upper West Side brownstone back in 1985, but in the end what he got was the entire building.

title: Random Drug Tests Win Backing of School Group
description: The New Jersey School Boards Association voted yesterday to support giving school districts the power to conduct random drug testing for students. At its semiannual meeting here, the association approved an amendment to test all students, expanding an earlier proposal to test student athletes only.

title: Balanchine's Baby Reaches a Certain Age
description: FOR 10 YEARS BEFORE HIS DEATH IN 1983, George Balanchine advertised the premieres in his company, the New York City Ballet, as Ballet No. 1 and Ballet No. 2. The troupe's new season, which opens on Tuesday at Lincoln Center, has the same number of nontitles, and for the same reason, one that has nothing to do with secrecy. The company simply wants to keep its options open until the last minute.

title: Somehow, Parcells's Team Is Outscoring the Opposition
description: The last time the Jets had seven victories before Thanksgiving was in 1986. Now, with the 1997 season reaching its make-or-break stages today against the Minnesota Vikings, the Jets enter the game at Giants Stadium with a 7-4 record.

title: ART REVIEWS ; In Montclair, the Primitive Meets the Modern . . .
description: AMERICAN artists in the 1940's were intoxicated by myth. Perhaps it was because of their need to repudiate the provincialism of the American scene-painting of the previous decade while also avoiding European abstraction's tendency toward formalism. Many artists, in search of a way to paint a reality more fundamental than that of mere appearance, tried using ideographic symbols to bring forms and themes from cultures as far-flung as those of the Northwest Coast Indians and the ancient Greeks into a modern context.

title: Two Detectives Raising Fresh Doubts Over Dr. King's Murder
description: In the 29 years since the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was shot to death here, a crowd of lawyers, journalists, movie producers and other would-be inquisitors have trailed through Memphis hoping to cash in on or figure out lingering mysteries surrounding his assassination.

title: Beyond the Dow
description: Most investors are familiar with the Dow Jones industrial average or their nation's equivalent, and many people follow other indexes as well, such as the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index (gray line below). However, Bloomberg Financial Markets lists no fewer than 337 stock indexes in its data base. And while many of these are well-known groupings of, say, oil companies or small-capitalization companies, other indexes may be unknown to even the most sophisticated investors.

title: In Search of Chow Mein
description: IN Marcel Proust's ''Remembrance of Things Past,'' a stream of memories is triggered by the taste of a madeleine cookie, the kind the narrator used to eat in his childhood.

title: Court With Appeal
description: I have long had plans for this weekend. I am going to get into my car and drive down to where I used to go to school: Drew University. I will be spending the weekend watching its men's and women's basketball teams compete in the Rose City Classic.

title: Witness to the Century
description: The Pritchett Century By V. S. Pritchett. 704 pp. New York: The Modern Library. $23.

title: Some Hints for Lifting Heavy Objects
description: SOONER or later every homeowner has to lift a large item or move a heavy object. Sometimes the load can be made lighter with a few simple adjustments. For example, it's easy enough to reduce the weight of a heavy carton of books by removing a few volumes. Many times, however, there is nothing that can be done to lighten the load, and you have no choice but to try and move the object as it is. There are, however, a number of tools and techniques available that can make it easier to move heavy burdens with less strain and less chance of personal injury.

title: Thanks for Life's Blessings
description: ON the second Sunday of every April, all of Montauk turns out for the Blessing of the Fleet. ''The priest stands on the deck of the Coast Guard cutter,'' said Mary Ann Carman, ''and he blesses each boat as it passes by. We're a small community here. Everybody knows everybody.

title: Food; A Pilgrim In the Bayou
description: The first time i went to new orleans I was scrambling to conquer the world. It was Thanksgiving; I was 30 and a recent convert to the ethos of success, which I took to mean shut up and fit in. The Big Easy, unfortunately, was not the place for such simple prescriptions. It was chaotic and hedonistic, the very antithesis of the ''real world.''

title: Over There, Monetary Union. Over Here, an Opportunity.
description: WITH less than 14 months to go before European monetary union, much of the American business and investment community has still not awakened to the big changes and opportunities it will create.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Another Country

title: Democratic Values ; Clinton's Way Isn't His Party's
description: WILL Clintonism outlive Bill Clinton?

title: Corrections
description: A listing of financial advice programs for the seriously ill last Sunday, with an article about a cancer survivor's efforts to save money, referred incorrectly to a developer of one such program, which should be available to patients and their families sometime in 1998. The American Cancer Society is working on the program with the National Endowment for Financial Education, not the College for Financial Planning.

title: THEATER REVIEW ; Find That Boy, Jocasta, and Don't Fall in Love
description: IT may be too soon to declare a trend, but manifestations of Oedipus Redux have been sighted in New Jersey theaters.

title: A Bargain Detour in Jordan
description: IN early October, I took a trip to Kennedy International Airport with a homesick Punjabi taxi driver. As it happened, I was going to India. When I told him, he grew excited and said, ''If I only could, I would drive you there.''

title: No More Systems
description: AFTER 1989 Morals, Revolution and Civil Society. By Ralf Dahrendorf. 179 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $35.

title: Swinging 'Nutcracker' From Duke Ellington
description: THE day after tomorrow, the Danbury Concert Chorus starts rehearsing Handel's ''Messiah'' for a performance on Dec. 17 in St. Peter's Church. And tickets for ''The Nutcracker,'' Dec. 13 and 14 at Danbury High School, go on sale tomorrow. The number to call for more information is (203) 748-1716.

title: Coach Walsh's Drive to Semipro Championship Is Sacked
description: Time had expired, and the handful of fans disappeared into the frigid night. As the Brooklyn Mariners prepared for the long bus ride home, Coach Pudgie Walsh's rasp was a mere whisper. After four months of practice, pep talks and games, his team's dream of a making it to semiprofessional football's version of the Super Bowl had vanished in the New England snow.

title: Mets End Pursuit of Sheffield
description: The Mets' pursuit of the slugger Gary Sheffield appears to be over, after they could not convince the Florida Marlins to assume nearly a third of Sheffield's $61 million contract.

title: Karla Vermeulen, Michael Frank
description: Karla Vermeulen, a daughter of Barbara and David J. Vermeulen of Boston, was married last evening to Michael David Frank, the son of Nadine and Dr. Arnold J. Frank of Seattle. The Rev. Betty Zimmer, an interfaith minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at Layla, a restaurant in New York.

title: Rear Guard Painting
description: To the Editor:

title: Running the F.B.I.
description: Louis Freeh has brought a fresh viewpoint to many areas of the F.B.I. However, he has apparently forgotten the criticisms of his predecessor, William Sessions, whose wife used F.B.I. employees for personal favors.

title: Why They Kill Their Newborns
description: The truth is that the abortion culture is in a bind. How can we convict teens of murdering a newborn when they could have done away with that same baby a few weeks earlier, legally, antiseptically and with the approval of some in our society?

title: Asian Protests CUNY's Denial Of His Tenure
description: When Ravi Kalia, an expert on the history of post-colonial India, left his tenured position at the University of North Carolina at Wilmington in 1993 to join the history department at City College, it seemed like a match made in academic heaven.

title: Big, Beautiful Numbers: 820, 834, 960
description: NANCY RICHARDSON, a longtime Fifth Avenue resident, calls it a ''juste milieu.'' That, she says, is ''a silly French phrase'' that means finding the right tone or happy medium for her way of life.

title: Show of Impressionists From Pennsylvania
description: THE Pennsylvania Impressionists, popularly called the New Hope School, may not have had a sister art colony in Old Lyme. Too many significant differences existed between the two places. But they were close relatives nevertheless, as is brought home at the Florence Griswold Museum in a show titled, ''An American Tradition: The Pennsylvania Impressionists,'' organized by Beacon Hill Fine Art in Manhattan.

title: Scientist Says Sleepy Teen-Agers Aren't Just Tired
description: MORNINGS are not pretty for 15-year-old Lizzy Schulzinger, a high school sophomore. On school days, her parents begin her day by waking her at 6 A.M. Usually, she falls promptly back to sleep. Sometimes, Lizzy's parents sit her up in bed and then make sure her feet are on the floor. On really bad days, her little sister pries her eyelids open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORVATH, ELSIE
description: HORVATH-Elsie. Beloved cousin and friend. A native New Yorker, she traveled, but her heart was always in NYC. Inquiries 518-734-3912

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOLAN, BISHOP JOHN GAVIN
description: NOLAN-Bishop John Gavin, S.T.D. On November 19, 1997. Auxiliary Bishop of Archdiocese for the Military Services USA, Chaplain, NY Athletic Club for 20 years and former Secretary General Catholic Near East Welfare Association. Survived by brother Michael of Schuylerville, NY, sister Kathleen Nolan of Albany and many nieces and nephews. Reposing at The Abbey, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9PM and at Saint Patrick's Cathedral, 5th Avenue and 51 St, Monday from 9:15AM until Mass at 10:30AM celebrated by His Eminence John Cardinal O'Connor. The family will receive friends at the DeVito-Salvadore Funeral Home, 39 South Main St, Mechanicville, NY Monday evening. Funeral Mass at AssumptionSaint Paul's Church, William Street, Mechanicville Tuesday 11AM. Interment to follow at Saint Peter's Cemetery, Stillwater, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Catholic Near East Welfare Association, 1011 1st Avenue, NY, NY 10022, or The Archdiocese for Military Services, USA, POB 4469, Washington, DC 20017-0469.

title: Parisians' Paris
description: To the Editor: ''Bucolic Pleasures in Ile-de-France'' (Nov. 2) brought back nice memories of our trip to France and lunch at Auberge Ravoux last year.

title: November 16-22; Greetings Take a Nasty Little Turn
description: The business of sweet sentiments and cheerful greetings is turning ugly.

title: A Caution Light Remains for Union Pacific's Stock
description: RAILROADS don't come any prouder -- some might say arrogant -- than the legendary Union Pacific, which was founded during the Civil War to build the first transcontinental railroad. No one was surprised that the railroad tried to stop the 1995 merger of two longtime rivals, the Burlington Northern and the Santa Fe railroads, and then, after failing, that it raced to swallow Southern Pacific to reclaim its status as the nation's largest railroad.

title: In the Region/Westchester; A Start in Enlivening New Rochelle's Downtown
description: FOR years this city has been struggling to attract business and enliven its deteriorating downtown. Now, with the announcement that construction of a 375,000-square-foot entertainment, sports and shopping complex in the city's center is about to begin, many here say it is poised for a long-awaited turnaround.

title: In Beethoven Quartets, Room for One More?
description: AS THE CLASSICAL-RECORD business casts about in all directions these days, nothing happens in a vacuum. In a market hopelessly glutted with reissues and repackagings, any new recording competes not only with its contemporaries but also with virtually all of recorded history. Such, at least, is the case with Beethoven's string quartets.

title: Avoiding the Need For Lemon Aid
description: Kurt Allen Weiss, author of ''Have I Got a Deal for You! -- How to Buy or Lease Any Car Without Getting Run Over'' (Career Press, $12.95), offers these suggestions for used-car buyers:
