description: LOST MAN'S RIVER

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Accord on Golf Course
description: WESTCHESTER County will move ahead with a plan to buy 174 acres in New Castle for the county's sixth public golf course.

title: Schools of Thought
description: To the Editor:

title: Asia Nations Limp Into Fiscal Talks As Turmoil Rages
description: Since first meeting as a group in 1993, the leaders of the United States, China, Japan and other nations of the Pacific Rim have swaggered into their annual gatherings, almost arrogant in their confidence that the region would be the 21st century's economic engine and the new locus of world power.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the conjunction of language and music misspelled the surname of a translator of Proust, whose work was described as the kind of parallel that words about music should represent. He is Scott Moncrieff, not Moncrief.

title: Erotica Whose Purpose Was Scholarly
description: TWO ELDERLY WOMEN pressed their noses to the display case of erect Japanese phallus fetishes while students peered at photographs of copulating couples and glistening musclemen in classical poses. Tattoo art of a naked woman grappling with a cobra and posters from stag movies like ''I Want More'' and ''Jungle Virgin'' shared the gallery walls with a Matisse odalisque and a Rembrandt boudoir scene.

title: Opportunity Lost
description: ILLUSIONS OF OPPORTUNITY

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Former Inmate's Art

title: . . . and Urban Landscapes Shine in Photography
description: ONE of the little-known treasures of the art world is the collection of more than 800 photographs assembled from 1973 to 1984 by Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc. Gathered under the direction of Phyllis Lambert, director of planning for the company's headquarters in Manhattan, the images in the collection focus on American city life, a theme that has fascinated photographers throughout this century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNBERG, PAUL
description: GRUNBERG-Paul, 72. November 8 at St. Peter's Hospital in Albany, after a long illness. Born in Milan Italy, educated in Italy and France, came to New York at age fifteen. A graduate of the Columbia University School of Architecture, he maintained a private practice in Manhattan for twelve years prior to moving with his family to a Columbia county farm in 1965. In 1972, he earned a Master's Degree in Urban-Environmental Studies from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute while becoming increasingly involved in civic affairs. A former Democratic Committeeman, he was an active member of numerous boards including Columbia Memorial Hospital (Hudson), the Spencertown (NY) Academy and Columbia County Habitat for Humanity. He served for twenty years on the Chatham ZBA, for fifteen years as its chairman. Mr. Grunberg was a founder and director of Jackson Hewitt, Inc., the second largest tax preparation service in the nation. Personal interests included painting, writing and working his land in Chatham Center, where he designed and built passive solar studios for his wife and himself. The first solo exhibit of his paintings was held at the Spencertown Academy in 1992. His 1977 science fiction novel, ''Sociex'', was recently published. For the past several years, he maintained a studio in Chatham village, dining often at the nearby Blue Plate Restaurant, owned by his wife, debating the issues of the day with family and friends. Mr. Grunberg is survived by his wife of 37 years, Judith (Backer) Grunberg, four sons, John of West Orange, NJ, Daniel of Lexington, MA., David of Somerville, MA, and Noah of Boston, MA., and five grandchildren, as well as by a sister, Loti Gaffney of Pittsburgh. Donations in his memory can be made to the Spencertown Academy, Columbia County Habitat for Humanity or the Chatham Rescue Squad. A memorial celebration will be held next month.

title: Pedomania
description: MADELEINE'S WORLD

title: The World; Who's Afraid of Wei Jingsheng?
description: TAN LIFENG was a persistent caller. He left a dozen messages and then called again, insisting when he finally got hold of a reporter that he could reveal a case that involved a major violation of human rights in China.

title: Lots of Pasta, No Fooling Despite Jesters
description: QUATTRO PAZZI (Four Crazies in Italian) has had such success with its tiny Stamford restaurant that a second Quattro Pazzi has opened in Fairfield.

title: Crash
description: SOUTH OF RESURRECTION

title: Face Time at the Fontainebleau of Youth
description: CALL me Ish Kabibble. Whenever it is a damp, drizzly November in my soul here in this insular city of the Manhattoes, instead of knocking people's hats off or going down to the sea, I take myself to Kiehl's Since 1851 Inc. on Third Avenue between 13th and 14th Streets, where an herbal-based deodorant stick costs only $13.50. Having been to Kiehl's always makes me feel better afterward, although actually being in there is almost too intense to bear.

title: A Woman Forgotten And Scorned No More
description: AS AN ACTRESS SHE TRADED HARDBOILED retorts with Humphrey Bogart in ''High Sierra'' and defied Edward G. Robinson in ''Sea Wolf.'' For Ida Lupino, though, some of the toughest scenarios took place not on screen but behind the camera as a director in the male-dominated Hollywood of the 1950's.

title: Group Opposes Work At Concrete Plant Site
description: FLORENCE VITIELLO could not believe her eyes. When she walked out onto her terrace in Yonkers a few days before Halloween, she saw a sight more horrifying than the most gruesome mask.

title: Much-Debated Mall Runs Into a New Delay: Toxic Hazard
description: The start of construction of a 15-acre shopping center in Forest Hills will be delayed for at least a year while a toxic industrial solvent that was found in the soil and ground water is cleaned up, state health officials said.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: Two for Thanksgiving

title: THEATER; Prometheus Finds the Torture Is Worth It After All
description: You don't have to be crazy to run a nonprofit New York theater company for 25 years, but it probably wouldn't hurt: the crises, the endless hunt for money, the effort behind every production. The 25th anniversary of the celebrated Ensemble Studio Theater on West 52d Street, which Curt Dempster founded in 1972, has prompted some soul-searching on the part of Mr. Dempster, who is the company's artistic director.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHALIT, MILTON J.
description: SHALIT-Milton J. On November 21, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Francine. Loving father of Patricia and Anthony. Dear grandfather of Julie, Tony, Natasha and Kevin. Great grandfather of Sasha. Devoted brother of Blanche and Maxine. Graveside service Monday, 11 A.M., Mount Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on Oct. 26, about Cape Town, referred imprecisely to the place where the Indian and Atlantic Oceans meet. It is Cape Agulhas, the southernmost point in Africa, not exactly at the Cape of Good Hope.

title: Even Computer Art Isn't Just in Eye of Beholder; What's Mechanical?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, CHARLES I., DR.
description: SIEGEL-Charles I., Dr. Of Lake Worth, Florida, formerly of Forest Hills, New York, passed away peacefully on November 20, 1997. Beloved father of Kenneth and Joy, and adored grandfather of Anne, Catherine, Leslie, Susan, Michelle and Caryn. Services will be held 1:30 P.M., at the Beth Israel Funeral Home in Delray, Florida. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Alzheimer's Association would be appreciated.

title: No Training Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa Toyama, Peter Brzechffa
description: Lisa Mari Toyama, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Y. Toyama of Westminster, Calif., was married yesterday to Dr. Peter Roger Brzechffa, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leszek Brzechffa of Whippany, N.J. The Rev. Joseph Diele, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: Success Is Like a Drug
description: At 8:30 A.M. on a Friday morning, as trainloads of sleepy commuters rolled past heading north for San Francisco, David Goeddel's lab group convened in a conference room of a low-slung, two-story building hard by the railroad tracks. One by one, young biologists drifted into the room: mostly 20-something, willfully underdressed, a rainbow coalition of the test-tube set from China and Korea and Germany and France, each clutching notebooks and lab results that contained dazzling but half-revealed secrets about the inner life of cells.

title: Stephanie Smith, Joseph Gentile
description: Stephanie Worthington Smith, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard H. Smith Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Lieut. Joseph Angelo Gentile, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Angelo J. Gentile of Belle Mead, N.J. Msgr. William P. Devine performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Church.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Safety Tips for Winter Driving
description: IF winter driving is your thing, there is a special school for you in Steamboat Springs, Colo., where for $225 you can get a day's instruction and practice in braking, skidding and staying alive on hills of pure ice. If, like most of us, you drive in the winter because you have no choice, there are some less difficult ways to enhance your safety.

title: No One Here but Us Turkeys
description: Normally the on-line staff of Kaplan Educational Centers, which is based in midtown Manhattan, spends its time developing Web pages for anxious high school students taking Kaplan prep courses for the SAT. But when the moon is full and a major holiday is near, staff members also develop what they delicately call study breaks.

title: A Memorial With Memories
description: SEPARATE but equal.

title: VIEWPOINT; Some Privacy, Please, For E-Mail
description: AN employee's right to E-mail privacy has little or no legal foundation. Various courts have ruled that neither the Federal nor state constitutions provide privacy protection regarding E-mail in the workplace, and only a few states have passed laws that specifically protect employees' E-mail messages. In general, office E-mail is no more protected than employees' telephones, which are fair game, given proper warning by the employer.

title: Op-Art
Briggs Wins, Crowd Boos and Foreman Says He Likely Won't Fight Again
description: In a heavyweight bout that seemed more about survival than anything else, Shannon Briggs pounded out a majority decision over 48-year-old George Foreman tonight at the Trump Taj Mahal. Immediately after the decision was announced, a disgruntled crowd of 5,220 began a derisive chant, disagreeing with the decision, and many booed Briggs.

title: Oh, Those Rock Band Names; Recalling 'Victory at Sea' And the Beatles' 'Bad' Name
description: To the Editor:

title: As Others Try to Fill Voids, UConn Flirts With the Top 10
description: Allen Iverson, Ray Allen, Tim Thomas and other luminaries keep leaving the Big East before their time is up, reinforcing a cycle that is keeping the conference down. ''If you recruit well, you end up losing them to the N.B.A.,'' St. John's Coach Fran Fraschilla said.

title: A Chance for People With Mental Disorders
description: STEP into the Ben & Jerry's ice cream shop on East 86th Street in Manhattan and the senses are bombarded by bright colors, the aroma of fresh-baked waffle cones and the choice of 40 frozen treats, including flavors like Phish Food and Chubby Hubby. But what is not apparent is that half of the shop's 12 employees have various mental disorders and are on medication.

title: Stupid Dirty Tricks ; The Trouble With Assassinations
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Group Offers Support To Adoptive Parents
description: FEW parents think twice about helping their children complete a classroom project like assembling a family tree or discussing the significance of a cherished family heirloom for a homework presentation. But for parents of adopted children, such routine assignments can lead to serious issues and sometimes major soul searching.

title: Stangassinger Wins
description: Thomas Stangassinger, the 1994 Olympic champion, took advantage of a mistake by his Austrian teammate Thomas Sykora to win the sixth World Cup slalom of his career yesterday in Park City, Utah.

title: A Star's Choice: Dollars or a Diploma
description: She is the greatest player in women's college basketball, a junior with skills every bit as resonant as her name. And at the age of 20, Chamique Holdsclaw of Astoria, Queens, has the rest of the hoops world watching her career as if it were a ball bouncing on a rim with a tantalizing, uncertain destiny.

title: Nathan Hale Was Here . . . and Here . . . and Here
description: DID the American patriot Nathan Hale meet his fate where a Gap store now stands on Third Avenue at 66th Street? Did he lose his one life for his country at the site of the Yale Club in midtown? Or did the British string him up downtown, at what is now City Hall Park?

title: IN BRIEF; Personal Bankruptcies Continue to Increase
description: Analysts predict that by the end of 1997, about 41,000 New Jerseyans will have filed for personal bankruptcy during the year, capping a three-year upward trend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRISWOLD, MARY (BROOKS)
description: GRISWOLD-Mary (Brooks) of New Haven, CT, and West Tisbury, MA, November 15. Wife of the late A. Whitney Griswold (former President of Yale University); mother of Sarah G. Leahy of Chestnut Hill, MA, Mary G. Flender of Cambridge, MA, Susanna G. Kaleck of Hamden, CT, and A. Whitney Griswold, Jr., of West Tisbury, MA. Also survived by nine grandchildren, seven great-grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, December 2, at 12 noon in the Battell Chapel, Yale University, New Haven, CT. Relatives and friends are invited to attend. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Mary Brooks Griswold Scholarship Fund, Smith College, Northampton, MA 01063.

title: A Dilemma Led to a Deal Over Hiring Tied to Race
description: The proposal put forward at a meeting of some of the nation's most prominent civil rights leaders in a hotel near Dulles International Airport in late August was surprising and bold -- some might say desperate.

title: Proposed AIDS Residence Has Had No Impact Study
description: To the Editor:

title: To the U.S. Envoy in Hanoi, the Future Is Paramount
description: For Pete Peterson, a former Air Force pilot who spent six and a half years as a prisoner here during the Vietnam War, coming to Hanoi six months ago as the Ambassador of the United States was ''the final act in a cathartic process.''

title: Newspaper History On the Island
description: I enjoyed reading the article about the 100th anniversary of The Southampton Press [''The Southampton Press at 100,'' Nov. 9], our good friends to the west. They indeed have pursued an honored tradition.

title: November 16-22; Risky Recipes
description: All recipe errors are not created equal. A pinch too much salt and civilization would still survive. But recipes for flavored oils in Reader's Digest Christmas omitted a crucial word: refrigerate. Failure to do so carries the risk of botulism. A word short and 600,000 copies late, Reader's Digest recalled its guides. HUBERT B. HERRING

title: Three Certainly Rhymes With Tennessee
description: The women's college basketball preview was prepared by Frank Litsky, who, like many men long past their basketball prime, likes the women's game because he thinks it is played the way he once played. These men are correct in some respects because the women offer no flying dunks, no slam-jam. The women offer passing, ball-handling, boxing out, unselfishness and basketball intelligence, admirable qualities all. As a schoolgirl in Boston once said, ''I like women's basketball better than men's because the men play above the rim, the women above the shoulders.''

title: Jeffay Chang, Elaine Cheng
description: Elaine May Cheng, the daughter of Charmian Jaw-mei Cheng and Robert Chung-nan Cheng of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Jeffay Frederick Chang, the son of Eleanor I. Chang of Irvington, N.Y., and Ifay F. Chang of Katonah, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Joseph C. Williamson, a minister of the United Church of Christ and the dean of religious life at Princeton University, performed the ceremony in the university's chapel.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Nov. 9 about new bullet train service between Tokyo and Nagano misstated the travel time. It is 79 minutes to 1 hour 45 minutes -- not 90 minutes to 3 hours.

title: Renee Healy And Eric Fill
description: Renee Elizabeth Healy, a daughter of Edith C. Healy of Rye, N.Y., and the late Thomas M. Healy, was married yesterday to Eric Christian Fill, the son of Antje and Dr. J. Herbert Fill of New York. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUFT, HENRIETTA
description: LUFT-Henrietta. On November 16, 1997. Beloved sister of Doris Winter, devoted aunt of Mark and Joan Winter. Funeral services were private.

title: Singing the Skateboards Electric
description: THE BOOMING BEATS THAT BEGIN THE BAND Sugar Ray's platinum-selling album, ''Floored,'' carry a surprising echo: the bass-and-drum rumble of Vanilla Ice's notorious 1990 rap crossover single, ''Ice Ice Baby.'' It could be a coincidence. But Sugar Ray and the many similar bands crowding the Top 40 charts -- Smashmouth, Sublime, Reel Big Fish, No Doubt and 311, to name a few -- share more than well-packaged funkiness with Vanilla Ice, the much-loathed Florida rapper.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARRY, PAUL
description: BARRY-Paul. Tenth anniversary. Remembering our beloved Paul. Amy, Judith, Susan, Jonathan, Susan Jean, Sharon, Peter, Michael, Gideon, Nicholas, Rachel, Justin, Katie, Adam

title: Sports of The Times; Americans Pull Off a Power Play
description: THIS will teach hockey executives to preach teamwork to their superstars. Even in these days of free agency and multimillion-dollar contracts, some of the lads actually get carried away and show respect and loyalty to one another.

title: Mean Streets
description: The Corner

title: 'God Created Me to Be a Slave'
description: Despite denials from Mauritania and its paid advocates in the United States, slavery continues to characterize the lot of many of its people ('''God Created Me to Be a Slave,''' by Elinor Burkett, Oct. 12). Although the state formally outlawed slavery several times, abd are bought and sold today, subjected to obscene punishments and forced to labor without compensation. Denials and obfuscations are expected from those who profit from slavery. But why should those denials be embraced by international institutions?

title: Washington Talk; Election Oversight Unit Barely Treading Water
description: Life these days at the Federal Election Commission -- the orphaned oversight agency of big-money politics -- summons images of Lucy Ricardo on the chocolate-factory assembly line, desperately trying to keep up as the candy rolls by on the conveyor belt.

title: Ideas & Trends; Germany the Unloved Just Wants to Be Normal
description: IMAGINE the political cartography of Europe a decade from now: at its hub, the reunified Germany, encircled by lands it once occupied yet locked in peaceful step with them by a common European currency and by common membership in the NATO alliance.

title: Clinton Rejects Call By Russians to Ease Sanctions on Iraqis
description: President Clinton today rejected Russia's call for an easing of sanctions on Iraq, saying Baghdad continued to impede United Nations weapons inspectors.

title: Emboldened G.O.P. Governors Prepare to Seize Education Issue
description: Fresh from victories in Virginia and New Jersey, Republican governors met here this weekend to plot strategy for 36 gubernatorial elections in 1998, and declared that education would be the next issue they would use to try to move power from Washington to the states.

title: The Many Incarnations Of the Painted Egg
description: IN 1972, while teaching studio art at Westhill High School in Stamford, Jane Pollak, who has a studio in Westport, was introduced by a colleague to one of the student projects: painting Ukrainian Easter eggs.

title: Baby Beautiful
description: The hottest cover girl in town? It's Ava Louis Schrager, the second daughter of Rita Narona Schrager and Ian Schrager -- he of all those hotels -- whose birth on Sept. 8 was announced last week. Her parents mailed a ''model's card'' (below) from the fictitious Schrager Models Inc., which included the finicky newcomer's special conditions: ''no nudity and no speaking or walking parts.''

title: Pants Suits Tres Soignes
description: Trousers or pants suits represent a truly modern look. This fall, women are wearing many variations, from the elegant matching ensemble, right, to nonchalant contrasting jackets and trousers, top far left and bottom far right. Individual takes include a bellhop jacket with a clown collar of fringed fabric, second from right, and an asymmetrical black leather jacket, top far right, with only one sleeve and half a collar. Equally important are accessories: long scarves and designer bags.

title: November 16-22; Recluse and Mentor
description: J. D. Salinger, the author called ''the most private man in America,'' will be the focus of a 1999 memoir by Joyce Maynard, who will break a 25-year silence on their relationship. Ms. Maynard, who lived with Mr. Salinger for nine months in 1972, said: ''He was the first man I ever loved. My purpose is not to divulge his story. I'm sticking to my own story.''

title: To Practice Here You Must Hang Out a Shingle, Court Says
description: Lawyers who don't literally hang a shingle in New Jersey can't practice law here, even if they passed the state bar exam, the United States Supreme Court affirmed last week. In 1994, Robert J. Tolchin challenged a New Jersey Supreme Court regulation requiring lawyers to maintain offices in the state because he wanted to practice international law from his office, then in Scarsdale, N.Y. But the regulation was upheld in Federal District Court in Newark and then by the Third Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia, which ruled in May that the requirement, ''had rational relationship to benefit of attorney accessibility for clients, courts, counsel, and parties.''

title: Tea and Conversation 101
description: ''OH my goodness, lucky me!'' Judith Re exclaimed. ''Everyone is coming!'' The 15 children before her stared.

title: Giuliani Lets His Hair Down, Briefly
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is usually so careful about mussing his carefully combed public image that he rarely dons one of the many emblazoned hats he often receives on the job, for fear of looking silly. But last night, in an extremely concerted effort to leaven his national reputation, he put on a French pompadour and a mustache and appeared on millions of television sets as the host of the NBC comedy show, ''Saturday Night Live.''

title: Q&A; In a Grand Recycling Effort, New Homes for Old Books
description: What separates man and woman from beast, at least since the invention of the printing press, may be the angst humans feel when parting with their books.

title: Fast Forward; Justice Delayed
description: Say you already use microsoft's Internet Explorer 4.0. As far as the Justice Department's Antitrust Division is concerned, you represent captured territory. The latest round of United States v. Microsoft is not about you.

title: On East 14th Street, the Edge Is Fading Away
description: Walking east on desolate 14th Street from Union Square used to be a reliably jumpy experience. Strollers encountered bodegas fronting for drug dealers, hotels fronting for houses of prostitution, porn-video stores and muggers.

title: Parisians' Paris
description: To the Editor: It was interesting to read Alice Furlaud's article ''The Discreet Charm of Passy-Auteuil'' (Nov. 2), a place I too have enjoyed for its quiet delights. However, one area not to be avoided is the old Passy cemetery on the Rue de Commandant Schloesing, where lie the artists Edouard Manet and Berthe Morisot and the composers Claude Debussy and Gabriel Faure. At the entrance the attendant will give you a little map, which will help you to find the graves of both the famous and obscure.

title: No Satisfaction in Loss
description: While Mike Milbury said today that he believes the Islanders are ''on track'' to reach their goal for the season, which is to make it to the playoffs for the first time in three years, he also said that the .500 record they brought into today's game against the Buffalo Sabres could be better.

title: Outside In
description: The atmosphere is both frantic and informal at the Tel Aviv office of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in the sprawling Defense Ministry compound, in the best tradition of Israeli politics. Assistants in jeans and bodyguards in safari jackets mill about talking loudly; cell phones jangle, and ministers and aides in open-collar shirts dart in and out through Netanyahu's padded door, all somehow controlled by Ruchama Avraham, the Prime Minister's tall, striking secretary. There is always a crisis these days, and on this day it is the buildup to the annual meeting of the Likud central committee, whose 2,700 members want to ditch the primary election system and take back the power to pick candidates.

title: Amy Norman, Barry Surman
description: Amy Lisa Norman and Barry Scott Surman are to be married this afternoon in Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Stephen A. Klein is to perform the ceremony at the Scarsdale Synagogue/Tremont Temple.

title: The View From: Ninth Square, New Haven ; Fabrics by the Yard From the Horowitzes
description: HOROWITZ BROTHERS, a New Haven institution, opened in its current location on lower Chapel Street in 1942, according to Arthur Horowitz. ''No, it was 1938,'' chorus his cousins, Leonard and Philip. ''You can't trust a word Artie says.''

title: Love Among the Rouens
description: HEAT LIGHTNING

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Rachael Horovitz and Mark Wallace
description: Rachael Keefe Horovitz, a film executive, and Mark Jonathan Wallace, a financial editor, were married yesterday. Mayor Bruce H. Tobey of Gloucester, Mass., officiated at Gloucester City Hall.

title: Doctors of Civility
description: IT'S a jungle out there on the average elementary-school playground. That's where the popular kids prey on the nerds. Sure, a lot of fun goes on, too, but if you're looking for fights, tears, social isolation, bruised feelings and humiliation, look no farther than your average neighborhood jungle gym.

title: Cornelia Kiley And Frank Casa
description: Cornelia Lucy Kiley was married yesterday to Frank Joseph Casa. The Rev. Donald J. Desmond performed the ceremony at the Most Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Why They Kill Their Newborns
description: Jonathan Swift would be the first to understand your article ''Why They Kill Their Newborns.'' It was reminiscent of his ''Modest Proposal'' of 1729, in which he suggested that the children of the poor be sold as food for the rich.

title: POSTINGS: $2.6 Million, 4,500-Square-Foot Minicampus Doubles as a Community Garden; For the New School, a New Courtyard
description: The recently planted red maple saplings are almost bare, but the Boston ivy has begun creeping up a stucco wall in the 4,500-square-foot Vera List Courtyard at the New School for Social Research in Greenwich Village.

title: The House That Roared
description: It may not be the last chapter, but last week brought what may well be the next to the last chapter in one of the thorniest disputes on the East Side in recent memory. The squabble involves the city -- specifically, the Transit Authority, the Parks Department and the Mayor -- and the affluent blocks of 46th, 47th and 48th Streets near the United Nations.

title: Allure, and Mystery, in the New I.R.A.'s
description: FOR many Americans it will soon seem as though an old friend -- the I.R.A. -- has stirred from an 11-year hibernation. But this time it is emerging as a more complex and, in many ways, a more attractive creature.

title: Jennifer Genel, Randy Herz
description: Jennifer Rebecca Genel, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Myron Genel of Woodbridge, Conn., was married last evening to Randy Stuart Herz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roman Herz of Avon, Conn. Rabbi Richard L. Eisenberg performed the ceremony at Congregation B'nai Jacob in Woodbridge.

title: Sorenstam Surges Into Lead
description: Annika Sorenstam shot a 67 yesterday in the third round of the season-ending ITT L.P.G.A. Tour Championship at Las Vegas, Nev., and took a one-shot lead over Nancy Lopez and Kelly Robbins at nine-under-par 207.

title: I Was a Red-Diaper Baby
description: Not to be critical, but Erica Manfred's nostalgia about Communism strikes me as a bit of a cop-out (Lives: ''I Was a Red-Diaper Baby,'' Nov 2). I, too, was a red-diaper baby. My parents were party members in the 30's and 40's, and are active Progressives today. The values they instilled in me -- compassion, honesty, caring about society and the environment -- are very much alive and more important now than ever. Manfred says that if only the perfect ''fantasy party'' existed, she would embrace it. Until then, she can assuage her guilt by not crossing a picket line.

title: For Turkey, the Traditional and the Ethnic
description: LONG Islanders, like diners elsewhere, can go to a restaurant on Thanksgiving and have an outstanding turkey dinner. But unlike many Americans in other areas, there are additional options open to them. In Nassau and Suffolk Counties, Southwestern, Persian, Middle Eastern, kosher, Indian and Italian spots will be offering inventive ethnic spins of their own.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Underpainter

title: Style; A Model Bride
description: The invitation said 4 o'clock, but at five minutes past a latecomer rushed in to find only the groom, four other guests, a gaggle of photographers and 60 gilt chairs arranged in rows, with names on the seats: Boy George, David Bailey, Rupert Everett. Already, this was shaping up to be more like a fashion show than a wedding. It was a brisk Tuesday in October, and Kristen McMenamy, the self-proclaimed ugly duckling whose success as a model has been her revenge on all the cool kids in junior high who wouldn't let her sit at their table in the cafeteria, was marrying, in London, Miles Aldridge, a young English photographer she met in Karl Lagerfeld's car.

title: Correction
description: An article on Nov. 2 about issues in the election campaign misstated Governor Whitman's reason for vetoing a bill that would have banned a late-term abortion procedure. At the time, on June 23, she cited the absence of an exception for cases in which the mother's health was endangered. She did not cite danger to the mother's life, and the legislation did include such an exception. (A letter on the issue appears today on page 23.)

title: Lectures on Responsibility Won't Help Addicts; Careful Evaluation
description: To the Editor:

title: After Slashing, New Wounds
description: When four teen-agers slashed a priest across the face with a box cutter on the A train early one morning in July, it set off a string of events in which nothing much good happened.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILES, FRANCES RANKIN
description: MILES-Frances Rankin. On November 21, 1997. Devoted wife of the late Charles Howard Miles. Loving mother of Susan and Barnaby. Dear grandmother of Matthew, Elizabeth and Claire. Beloved sister of Dr. Joseph E. Rankin. Mass of Christian Burial, Immaculate Conception Church, Monday, 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave. (at 20th St.), Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the film maker for the WLIW-TV documentary ''Another Mitzvah'' misspelled his surname. He is Roman Brygider, not Brygidier.

title: Alexis Brinkley, Jeremiah Collins
description: Alexis Rose West Brinkley, the daughter of David Brinkley, the television commentator, and Susan M. Brinkley of Bal Harbour, Fla., was married last evening at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Washington to Jeremiah Collins, a son of Joan and Jeremiah C. Collins of Bethesda, Md. Msgr. Peter J. Vaghi performed the ceremony, in which Rabbi Lewis Solomon took part.

title: Meredith Wolf, David Schizer
description: Meredith Jane Wolf, a daughter of Louise and Alan M. Wolf of Cincinnati, was married there last evening to David Michael Schizer, the son of Zevie and Hazel Schizer of Brooklyn. Rabbi Hanan Balk performed the ceremony at the Hyatt Regency.

title: Cold-War Liberals
description: To the Editor:

title: Flying Men and Machines
description: BEYOND THE WILD BLUE

title: In the Region/Long Island; On East End, a Transfer Tax for Land Preservation?
description: SHOULD property buyers on the East End be required to pay a 2 percent tax on a portion of the purchase price as a contribution to future land preservation?

title: Miss Snow-Johnson, Mr. Moynihan
description: Sarah Christiana Snow-Johnson, a daughter of Gretchen and James Loring Johnson of Far Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Patrick Joseph Moynihan, a son of Carol and Joseph V. Moynihan of Rochester. The Very Rev. Joel W. Pugh 2d, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Memorial Chapel on Jupiter Island, Fla.

title: Labor's Story in Wartime Bridgeport
description: BRIDGEPORT was a different city in 1944. Many of the men were overseas fighting the war. Though industry, particularly war-related production, thrived, the labor shortage demanded that women go into the work force.

title: November 16-22; Breakthrough for Koreas
description: North Korea, South Korea, the United States and China agreed Friday to meet early next month in Geneva to discuss a lasting peace for the Korean peninsula. North Korea is insisting that the talks produce specifics on the removal of 37,000 United States troops from South Korea. It is also seeking to make a separate peace with the United States, something that Washington and Seoul have long rejected.

title: Harrah's Outdoes Itself in Las Vegas
description: Any casino hotel that wants to be noticed along the Strip in Las Vegas has its work cut out, what with all the sidewalk spectacles featuring blasts of flame and thunderous explosions. But Harrah's, an established resident of the Strip since 1983, is giving it a new try.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLATBUSH

title: Editorial Observer; Hey Buddy, You Wanna Run for Governor?
description: Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin has authorized his staff to go to any lengths necessary to make it clear to the world that he is not going to run for governor of New York. ''You can be as Shermanesque as you want to,'' he told his spokesman, Howard Schloss. Compliantly, Mr. Schloss will now tell callers that if nominated for governor, his boss would not run, and if elected, he would not serve. With some extra prodding, he will also say that Mr. Rubin would prefer being slowly devoured by man-eating guppies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRESDALE, DAVID, DR.
description: DRESDALE-David, Dr. The Department of Medicine records with sorrow the passing of Dr. Dresdale. Dr. Dresdale was a leader in the field of Cardiovascular Diseases and made many important contributions during his many years as a member of the Department of Medicine at the Maimonides Medical Center. He was a pioneer in the field of Cardiac Catheterization and in studies of pulmonary hypertension. His contributions will be long remembered and he will be missed. Our condolences to the family. Dr. Edgar Lichstein, Chairman of the Department of Medicine

title: The Model of Consistency Is a Player Named Starks
description: John Starks's on-court personality is an untamed mix of swirls and colors. He is paisley. And this is how it has to be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPITZER, WALTER H.
description: SPITZER-Walter H. Beloved husband of Adele, loving father of Susan and husband, attorney William D. Grady, cherished grandfather of Jennifer L. and Steffanie E. Grady. Died November 17, 1997, Hartford Hospital, CT. Interment Sharon Gardens, Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: A Family That Perpetuates Artistic Impulse
description: Art in Three Generations

title: IN CONTROL: A special report. ; Reno's Loner Image Hides a More Complex Reality
description: It is a nice, concise image: Janet Reno, a brilliant orange life vest adorning her broad frame, furiously paddles a kayak down the Potomac to escape the pressures of her office. A panting consort of F.B.I. agents desperately tries to keep up by canoe; unsuccessful, they are ordered into kayak training so their important charge does not elude them in the future.

title: Donald B. Goodall, 85, Founder Of College Art Museum in Texas
description: Donald Bannard Goodall, a professor of art history, founding director of the University of Texas Art Museum in Austin and a specialist in Latin American art, died on Oct. 27 at his home in Glendale, Calif. He was 85.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: ENCHANTED EVENINGS

title: A Black Panther's Mellow Exile: Farming in Africa
description: For more than a quarter century, the man who thinks of himself as the last Black Panther has lived in exile in a village at the foot of a mountain in Tanzania, a fugitive from American justice.

title: On I.P.O.'s, This Book May Be a Few Pages Short
description: HE knows how to get rich, and J. Morton Davis wants to share that knowledge -- or, at least, some of it.

title: Junk Today, on Runways Tomorrow
description: ''NO pictures! No pictures!'' the blonde in outsize sunglasses shouted to the camera-toting cad who had invaded her space on the blacktop. But she was no celebrity, and he was no paparazzo. This tussle was between a dealer and an amateur photographer at the Sixth Avenue flea market on a recent weekend. Call her the George Clooney of 26th Street, but the Nikon-shy Sunday morning merchant may have a right to her hauteur.

title: Spiraling To the Peak Of Pop Art
description: A COLORFUL collage of New York glitterati gathered on the top level of the Guggenheim Museum on Tuesday night, for a party to honor Robert Rauschenberg. There they stood under the illuminated glass dome: artists, actors, art dealers and models, chatting and brushing shoulders like one big family, which in a sense, they are. After all, Mr. Rauschenberg's retrospective opened two months ago, so it was a sign of the greatest cachet, a truly fashionable form of lateness, to climb the museum's ivory rings with the other A-list guests. (Although some people took the elevator.) The elite dinner was given by Ronald O. Perelman, the museum's president.

title: On Language; The Non-Crash
description: Like the conservative New Year's Eve celebrator who wanted to purchase a noisemaker that wasn't too loud, headline writers were recently faced with a challenge: how to deal with a precipitous (''steep,'' not precipitate, ''abrupt, rash, headlong'') decline in the stock market without encouraging a panic. (Come to think of it, precipitate would be accurate, too, if you wanted to describe the behavior of the professional investors rather than the graph showing stock movement. Celebrator is New York Times style for celebrant.)

title: One Hundred Years of Strife
description: A HISTORY OF THE TWENTIETH CENTURY Volume 1: 1900-1933. By Martin Gilbert. Illustrated. 927 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $35.

title: Fitting the Food of the Pilgrims Into a Thanksgiving Menu
description: FINDING inspiration for some of the Thanksgiving menu in the indigenous food of this continent, that is, the ingredients that predated European settlement, is always appropriate.

title: All Not Together Now
description: Next month marks the ninth anniversary of the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, to be followed in February by the ninth anniversary of the founding of Victims of Pan Am Flight 103. Finding strength through activism on antiterrorism and airline-security issues, this group of families of the 189 Americans who died became a role model for groups that emerged after the T.W.A. Flight 800 and Valujet 592 crashes and the Oklahoma City bombing. But the groups have also been vivid examples of how quests for truth can lead to frustration and infighting -- there are now four 103 outfits, and they don't always get along. ''The fights can be vicious,'' says a partisan. Leaders in all the camps say they want the same thing: justice. They just have wildly different opinions on how to achieve it. Here's a factional guide.

title: A Rare Merger of Art, Literature and the Backside
description: IN 1856, WITH OXFORD UNIVERSITY behind them, two young artists named William Morris and Edward Burne-Jones headed for London to check out a studio on Red Lion Square in Bloomsbury. They had heard of it from a former tenant, Dante Gabriel Rossetti, the painter who was their mentor. Morris and Burne-Jones took the studio and immediately began producing furniture to fill it. The chairs, chests and cupboards, described at the time as huge and ''intensely medieval,'' represented Morris's first efforts at designing and producing decorative art. Of the rare pieces of his painted furniture that survive, several came from the studio.

title: Children's Books
description: A Friend for

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKE, RICHARD M., SR.
description: DICKE-Richard M., Sr. The National Center for Disability Services family sincerely mourns the passing of our dear friend and longtime Director, and former Chairman of the Board, Richard M. Dicke, Sr. A gentleman of unparalled humanity and generosity of spirit, his support, encouragement and enthusiasm helped lead our center to greater heights of service for all people with disabilities. Rick will be deeply missed by all of us who knew and loved him. We express our most heartfelt condolences to his children, grandchildren, family and many friends. Edmund L. Cortez, President And CEO and The Board of Directors, National Center for Disability Services

title: Killer of New Jersey Officer Called Career Criminal
description: The gunman who assassinated a police officer in a New Jersey shore town and led a wild chase that ended with his suicide at the George Washington Bridge last week was described yesterday as a career criminal from Massachusetts who had used many aliases and made his living promoting prostitution and selling drugs.

title: Even Computer Art Isn't Just in Eye of Beholder; The Soul's Passions
description: To the Editor:

title: Q. & A.
description: Who Pays To Move This Piano?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, SYLVIA
description: LERNER-Sylvia. On November 21, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Devoted and cherished mother of Elissa Teichberg and Ira Lerner. Loving grandmother of Joyce, Danny, Karin, Ben, Katie, Edward and Jonathan. Graveside services Sunday, 10:15 AM, Mt. Judah Cemetery, Ridgewood, NY.

title: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS
description: County Settles Suit

title: Shipp Has Been Down, But Don't Count Him Out
description: Through the flickering red of emergency lights on Campus Drive, Rod Baker found Kevin Simmons sitting on a curb, staring blankly at the crushed remains of the car he had been a passenger in just moments before.

title: I Was a Red-Diaper Baby
description: Perhaps Manfred wasn't listening when her parents and mine taught a key lesson of their Communist doctrine to their children: the new society can be made only by very imperfect people of the old society.

title: Tube Tops, Improved
description: In the midst of a 1970's revival, it's not a shock that tube tops a la Cher (inset, with Gregg Allman) are back. But with improved spandex now available, it might be easier to keep them on this time.

title: Corrections
description: A review in the Book Review last Sunday about ''Wyatt Earp: The Life Behind the Legend,'' by Casey Tefertiller, misstated the location of Dodge City, a town where Earp was a law officer. It is in Kansas, not Missouri.

title: QUICK BITE/Bayonne; A Bakery That Will Take You Back in Time
description: If you don't know Polish, just point.

title: The Cuisine Makes a Royal Statement
description: ''LET them eat cake'' and foie gras, caviar, venison, lobster, even a dessert called the Marie Antoinette doll. The opening of the Louis XVI restaurant in Patchogue signals a return to elegant dining. Long Islanders who want more from a meal out than a bowl of pasta at a casual cafe have reason to rejoice.

title: The Fall After the Fall
description: Since February, when he emerged from a two-month stay at a Washington halfway house, which followed 19 months at a Federal minimum-security prison camp in Cumberland, Md., Webster L. Hubbell, the former Associate Attorney General of the United States and dear friend of both Bill and Hillary Clinton, has been living a rather austere life. He earns $10 an hour looking into penal reform for a tiny research institute in northern Virginia. He drives to work a few days each week in a well-traveled sky blue 4-by-4. He and his wife, Suzanna, and his youngest daughter, Kelley, live in a small brick townhouse in northwest Washington, and depend even for that on the charity of Hubbell's sister. He hasn't picked up his golf clubs in three years.

title: November 16-22; Fat and Then Some
description: Butter? Margarine? Will the controversy ever end? Four years ago, following a report from the ongoing Nurses' Health Study that certain fats, called trans, in margarine increased the risk of heart attack, Americans decided butter was better. Now in a more detailed report, Boston researchers confirmed the hazards of trans fats, saying that these, along with the saturated fats in meat and dairy fat, are more important to coronary risk than the total amount of fat in one's diet.

title: Used Cars: Not Usually A Hard Sell These Days
description: IN the past, buying a used car often meant haggling with a high-pressure huckster in a plaid suit. Warranty? No way. That oily puddle on the pavement under the engine? Oh, that's nothing. The price? A special for you today only on this baby.

title: Elizabeth Hammock, S. N. Benjamin
description: Elizabeth Mary Hammock, a daughter of Irene Hammock of Huntington, N.Y., and the late Gordon L. Hammock, was married yesterday to Stephen Nicoll Benjamin, a son of Judith B. Benjamin of Cortlandt Manor, N.Y., and the late Samuel Nicoll Benjamin Jr. The Rev. J. Oscar McCloud performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Father Christmas Is Their Business
description: THE Victorians gave us quite a legacy, some of it bad, but in terms of Christmas traditions, some of it very good indeed. The sentimental period resulted in the revitalization of many ancient customs, and the firm planting in our time of Christmas trees, cards, elaborate decorations and something known as Father Christmas dolls.

title: New Language Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: I Was a Red-Diaper Baby
description: Regarding ''I Was a Red-Diaper Baby'': Can we look forward to ''I Was a Swastika Baby'' and ''O.K., So My Parents Were Nazis -- but at Least They Believed in Something''?

title: Bosnian Vote Could Backfire on West
description: Acrid cigarette smoke hovered in the room of the Book Lovers' Club of Banja Luka, with its worn wicker chairs, steady clink of small coffee cups, noisy chatter and shelves of well-thumbed Serbian literature.

title: A Loving, Riotous Spoof Makes A Serious Point About Passion
description: CHANCES ARE, YOU NEVER saw people literally fall out of their seats with laughter. Unless, that is, you attended a particular performance by La Gran Scena Opera Company, whose distinctive version of the second act of Puccini's ''Tosca'' once propelled a spectator into the aisle. Perhaps the Kaye Playhouse, on the campus of Hunter College, will provide seat belts when that ''Tosca'' excerpt is presented again, beginning on Tuesday evening, as part of the company's new show, ''Vera: Life of a Diva.''

title: Where It's a Jungle in There
description: In the Asian jungle habitats of the Bronx Zoo, visitors do not coo or yell at the animals. They simply watch and wait. In this quarter-acre artificial rain forest called Jungle World, wild creatures are free to hide. People who want to see gibbons swing from vines or tree kangaroos clamber up fallen tree trunks must wait until the animals come into view.

title: The Old Curtain Falls . . . And a New Curtain Rises
description: TWO theaters have bowed out slowly -- but not completely -- and a new one has risen on the combined sites over the last year. The 1903 Lyric and 1920 Apollo Theaters have been torn down, replaced by the Ford Center for the Performing Arts on 42d and 43d Streets between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. The Italianate facade of the Lyric, at lower left in these photographs, has been incorporated as one entrance to the new theater.

title: Of Mice and Fantasy Men
description: It's ''Nutcracker'' season again, and several companies will perform the ballet in New Jersey through early January. For something a little different, you can choose from the traditional Christmas story told with lasers, on ice or set to the swinging rhythms of Duke Ellington and Billy Strayhorn.

title: Dawn Zappetti, Patrick Sullivan
description: Dawn Michele Zappetti, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Zappetti of Holbrook, N.Y., was married last evening to Patrick Joseph Sullivan, the son of Barbara J. Sullivan of Chappaqua, N.Y., and the late Mr. Sullivan Sr. The Rev. James J. Gardiner performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier in New York.

title: Essay; Clinton's Cave-In to Saddam
description: As Bill Clinton continues to pretend that no concession has been made to Iraq, Saddam Hussein has arranged with Russia's Yevgeny Primakov to remove the element of surprise from the U.N. Special Commission's searches for long-concealed germ-warfare facilities.

title: Sara Eisner, Michael Richter
description: Sara Lynne Eisner and Michael Judd Richter, associates at law firms in New York, are to be married today at the Plaza in New York. Rabbi Leonard Troupp is to officiate.

title: IN BRIEF; To Help Collect Cans, A Cancan Can't Hurt
description: Walter Dull is anything but. To promote the annual Thanksgiving food drive at Wildwood High School, where Mr. Dull, 51, is the principal, the 220-pound former college football player promised to appear in drag, as a can-can dancer, if students collected 1,000 cans of food -- more than 10 times the yearly average. The community rallied, and when students met the goal last week, Mr. Dull vowed to make a surprise strut thgough school sometime before the holiday. ''I'm not going to dance,'' Mr. Dull said flatly. ''That wasn't part of the deal.'' STEVE STRUSNKY

title: Crime
description: The subtle villain who creates psychic havoc in Frances Fyfield's new suspense thriller, WITHOUT CONSENT (Viking, $21.95), is not content to rape his victims. By choosing emotionally needy women and then humiliating them with his warm eyes and sensitive hands, he violates their spirit. On occasion, he kills -- again, with the same lacerating gentleness that makes him such a menace. ''This creature was a performing trickster,'' we are told, ''a foul kind of magician.''

title: The Nation; Liberals to Court: Don't Take This Case, Please
description: AS a pioneering civil rights lawyer more than a half century ago, Thurgood Marshall had a deceptively simple motto to describe his litigation strategy: never lose.

title: Good Times for Gibbons
description: The way to gauge a captive animal's happiness is to count its offspring, said Dr. Robert Cook, the chief veterinarian of the Wildlife Conservation Society. By that measure, gibbons apparently regard the Bronx Zoo as someplace close to heaven.

title: The Brakes at Justice
description: Justice Department officials are predicting that Attorney General Janet Reno will not allow an independent counsel to investigate fund-raising telephone calls by President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore. This looks like test-marketing for an official announcement, perhaps as early as tomorrow. Whenever it comes, such an announcement will mean that Ms. Reno still has the lid on what was, by all the indications from journalistic investigations and Congressional evidence, a hefty financial scandal.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: WHEN JESSIE CAME ACROSS THE SEA. By Amy Hest. Illustrated by P. J. Lynch. Candlewick. $16.99. (Ages 6 to 12) At the age of 13, Jessie was given a ticket and sent from a poor village in Eastern Europe to America to help a widowed seamstress in New York City. She is a brave and hard-working girl, who finds love and a measure of success, so hers is a kind of Thanksgiving story.

title: November 16-22; A Caution on Assisted Death
description: After two elections and a long court fight, Oregon became the first place in the world this month to legalize doctor-assisted suicide. But the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, in a notice solicited by Congressional opponents of the law, warned that doctors prescribing drugs for suicide risk sanctions.

title: Board Works to Trim Tax Increase
description: WITH a decision finally made as to the future of the County Medical Center, the Board of Legislators has begun directing its full attention to the proposed 1998 county budget, which would raise the property tax rate 8 percent.

title: Old Money Sniffs at the Nouveau Deal
description: SETTING: A black-tie dinner benefiting the restoration of Edith Wharton's country home. And while the house, called the Mount, is in Lenox, Mass., the 172-person party, held at a men's private Park Avenue club, was filled with members of old New York families.

title: Dr. Aaron J. Sharp, 93, Botanist and Master of Moss
description: Dr. Aaron J. Sharp, a botanist and avid popularizer of botany who applied his studies of moss around the world to such sweeping questions as plate tectonics, died on Nov. 16 at Fort Sanders Regional Medical Center in Knoxville, Tenn., where he lived. He was 93.

title: By the Time You Read This
description: Not long ago, when my daughter Madeleine was almost 2, a neighbor's chicken pecked her foot and she ran from it, wailing. She spoke of the disaster for weeks afterward. This seemed to be the first instance of her remembering something for more than a day or two, and with memory comes the first inkling of duration. ''That happened a month ago,'' I would say. ''That happened two months ago.'' In her mind, I imagined, the chicken pecking her foot was not only the founding event of her life, but the Big Bang of the cosmos. Before it: nothingness, oblivion. After it: time.

title: Lectures on Responsibility Won't Help Addicts; Acceptance Required
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; 129 Games (and Counting): Now That's a Rivalry
description: PERHAPS to soothe their senses, some Giants keep pretending that it's just another game. Apparently they just don't understand yet. But in only his third season and his first on a winning team, Charles Way knows what tonight's rumble with the Redskins is all about.

title: Lester David, 83, the Author of 14 Books
description: Lester David, who wrote 14 books and hundreds of magazine articles, died on Nov. 10 at South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside, N.Y. He was 83 and lived in Woodmere, N.Y.

title: Easing Into the Florida Way of Life
description: MEN have a much easier time adjusting than women,'' said Elaine Charles, 66, who was active in civic causes in Syracuse before she and her husband moved permanently to Florida 14 months ago. ''No one cares what you were president of where you used to live. You start at the bottom and prove yourself.''

title: Gulf and Tennis
description: IT had been years since we took a family vacation to a place that did not feature accommodations, meals and activities arranged by other, better organized family members. So it was with no little trepidation that I found myself -- with my husband, our three children and our indispensable baby sitter -- boarding a flight for Tampa last March and heading for Longboat Key, Fla.

title: When Lifting Heavy Objects, Protect Your Back
description: SOONER or later, every homeowner has to lift a large item or move a heavy object. Sometimes the load can be made lighter with a few simple adjustments. For example, it's easy enough to reduce the weight of a heavy carton of books by removing a few. Many times, however, nothing can be done to lighten the load, and you have no choice but to try moving the object as it is. There are, however, a number of tools and techniques that can make it easier to move heavy burdens with less strain and less chance of personal injury.

title: In America; Last-Minute Reprieve
description: It took them long enough. On Thursday the Piscataway, N.J., school board, in a 5-to-3 vote, agreed to settle an affirmative-action case after taking it all the way to the Supreme Court.

title: Identity Crisis; Gay Culture Weighs Sense and Sexuality
description: ONE night last May, a handful of New York City's best-known gay journalists, artists and academics called together some friends to bemoan what they viewed as a backlash against the sexual practices of homosexuals. The turnout surprised them: five dozen people jammed into an overheated room.

title: As Brookhaven Changes Manager, It Seeks New Role
description: CALLED a time projection chamber, a six-ton $10 million chunk of scientific equipment that arrived at the Brookhaven National Laboratory this month seemed to embody the past and future of the Energy Department lab.

title: Savings on Mortgage Transfers
description: To the Editor:

title: Now, a Pure Play Among Top Battery Makers
description: DON'T forget to get batteries for the kids' holiday toys! And as you snap them into that video game, you and legions of other gift givers may idly wonder if you should invest in batteries as well as buy them.

title: Fire Island Dunes And Ownership
description: The article ''State Revives Plan to Control Building in Fire Island Dune Area'' [Nov. 9] emphasizes the controversy over the coastal erosion hazard line, but obscures the fact that the real conflict involves ownership of ocean-front property.

title: 'Spectral Evidence'
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Hotel Sarajevo By Jack Kersh. Turtle Point, paper, $13.95.

title: Classical Briefs
description: SAINTE-COLOMBE: 'CONCERTS A DEUX VIOLES ESGALES'

title: Backtalk; Kids From King Are Champs Again
description: The kids from King are champions again. Soccer is my life.

title: Modernist Conveniences
description: THE ERRANCY

title: Sheila Moore, Michael Potter
description: Sheila Elizabeth Moore, a daughter of Maureen and Stanley A. Moore of Palos Verdes Estates, Calif., was married yesterday to Michael Lawrence Potter, the son of Maribeth Brown of Elk City, Okla., and Lawrence R. Potter of Boston. The Rev. Donald F. Finlay, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Good Shepherd in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: MIR WITHOUT FEAR
description: A unique tourist attraction is now on display at the Wisconsin Dells region north of Madison: a complete Mir spacecraft, 20.4 tons in bulk, 43 feet long, $8.75 to crawl through the hatch. This Mir is not a replica but a replacement craft that was never deployed by the financially strapped Russian space program. It was purchased for an undisclosed sum by Tommy Bartlett, a locally famous water-skiing impresario who calls the Mir ''frosting on the cake'' of his career. Visitors, of course, are spared the computer glitches, oxygen leaks and overall fear of death-in-space, but some see the Mir as a vivid illustration of why Earth is still man's favorite habitat. ''It's very small,'' says Jim Priest, a Chicago tourist. ''I can't see spending a whole lot of time in a craft like this.''

title: Slow Going For Recovery On Myrtle
description: Eel-Isaiah Bellamy didn't get the warm welcome he expected when he opened his tailoring shop, 4UII Wear on Myrtle Avenue in 1995, and he soon discovered why. The previous tenant had been selling drugs, he said, and old-timers assumed Mr. Bellamy would do the same.

title: On Bayou, Non-Cajuns Fight for Recognition
description: When they finally found refuge on the banks of the muddy bayous here, amid the moss-draped live oaks, the graceful egrets and the lurking 'gators, the struggle to preserve old ways and customs did not end for the Acadians, the French-speaking Catholics expelled from Canada in the latter half of the 1700's by the Anglican English.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, JOAN FRANCES
description: CASEY-Joan Frances. On November 21, 1997, of Jericho, NY. Beloved wife of Patrick J. Loving mother of Patrick, Thomas, Megan Crayne, Douglas and Christopher. Cherished grandmother of Matthew and Justin Casey, and Nicholas Crayne. Dear sister of Thomas and Lawrence Gillick. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home, Inc., of Syosset, 79 Berry Hill Road. Visiting hours 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Monday at 10:45 AM, from St. Paul the Apostle R.C. Church, Upper Brookville. Interment St. Patrick's Cemetery, Huntington.

title: Remembering the Gipper
description: THE CITY ON A HILL

title: Rise in Crime Puzzles Pioneering Artists and Writers
description: They were four young people looking for a place to crash, and a sculptor friend offered them the use of her studio. But a sweet arrangement turned sour when three of them returned to 135 Plymouth Street near midnight on Nov. 11 and were accosted by two armed, masked men. They were forced up to the sculpture-filled studio, where their hands were tied; the intruders were preparing to rape the woman in the group, neighbors said, when their fourth friend returned home and screamed.

title: Fax Attack Puts Garden Defender in Legal Paper Jam
description: In August, L. A. Kauffman, 33, a freelance journalist and part-time rabble-rouser, decided to tell the New York City Partnership what she thought about a plan to demolish a handful of community gardens in the East Village to make way for medium-income housing. Her sentiment was brief -- merely ''Leave our Gardens Alone'' -- so she thought she'd just fax it over.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; The Slug: A New Appreciation
description: SNAKES and the fat kinds of spiders have always made me shudder but there is one other creature I have found more repulsive yet: that uncooked albumen of the animal kingdom, the garden slug. Simply pronouncing the name starts me gagging. Slug. Rhymes with ugh. Graceless and colorless, they devour my prized plantings then document their larceny by arrogantly silver-plating the ruins. In response I have salted them, tricked them into mickeys of stale beer without a trace of guilt. Though separated by an immense evolutionary gap, I have felt we were worthy adversaries, each possessing weapons and defenses, each summer's campaign ending at an impasse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAAL, MIRIAM (NEE ALTER)
description: SCHAAL-Miriam (nee Alter). Most dearly beloved wife of the late Eric Schaal. Adored daughter of Dian and the late Benjamin Alter. Dearly loved sister and aunt of Herb and Ann and Mio Alter. Graveside services Sunday, 1 PM, Wellwood Cem., Pinelawn, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURLAND, HAIM
description: GURLAND-Haim. Beloved husband of Estelle for 55 years. Devoted father of Judith and Robert, father-in-law of Warren Blaker and Gaby Jordan. Adored grandfather of Avram, Lauren and Emily. Loyal brother, uncle and friend. After a valiant struggle with cancer in his 93rd year. Services were held November 18, 1997, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, New York City.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report on Nov. 9 about the transformation of a vacant lot into a park in the High Bridge section of the Bronx misidentified a local street. It is Edward L. Grant Highway, not Edward El Grand Highway.

title: Backtalk; Young Athletes Are Being Unlawfully Locked Out of the Money
description: Nineteen-year-old Andy Katzenmoyer was in Michigan Stadium yesterday, playing for Ohio State in its annual showdown with the Wolverines. In exchange for being a starring linebacker for Ohio State this season, he will receive only his athletic scholarship.

title: Sylvan Winds Opens a Series
description: AS the Pleasantville Chamber Music Society enters its third decade, its goal remains unchanged: to present free recitals of the highest quality so that everyone, especially children, can attend. This season four top-notch ensembles will appear: the Manhattan String Quartet, the Queens College Trio, members of the Connecticut Early Music Festival and -- at today's opener at 3 P.M. -- the Sylvan Winds. The program offers music by four Eastern European masters: Liadov, Janacek, Ligeti and Shostakovich. While tickets are not necessary, early arrival is recommended since the hall tends to fill up quickly.

title: Lectures on Responsibility Won't Help Addicts

title: SHOPPING WITH: Gregory Hines; Soft-Shoe Tiptoe Through the Designer Racks
description: STEPPING out of an afternoon's chill last week, Gregory Hines, the actor, singer and tap dancer of screen, Broadway and television, bounded warmly into one of his favorite New York clothing shops as if it were a stage on which to play out a sartorial conceit.

title: Sorry, No Gold Watch
description: The company no longer has need of someone's services, and the message must be delivered. How does it come? Often, awkwardly: The corporate apartment's landlord asks for a moving date, the computer no longer recognizes a password, or the office lock is changed. How has your company handled dismissals? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: New Language Teachers; A Waste of Time

title: Harvard Ends 7-0 To Capture Ivy Title
description: Harvard concluded one of its finest seasons today with a 17-7 victory over Yale in the 114th game of their series. The reward for the Crimson (9-1, 7-0 Ivy League) was an outright league championship, its first in a decade.

title: Tibet's People
description: To the Editor: Having returned on Oct. 17 from a wonderful visit to Tibet, I voraciously read the Oct. 19 articles ''A Rugged Pilgrim's Progress'' and ''Approaches to Tibet.'' Perhaps even more than the wonders of the still culturally and artistically rich monasteries and temples, what impressed me were Chinese efforts to eradicate the heart of the Tibetan people by destroying all but the shell of their cultural and religious heritage.

title: No Time to Ease Up on Iraq
description: With United Nations weapons inspectors back in Iraq and the threat of military confrontation in the Persian Gulf receding, the Security Council has begun to focus on the most urgent next priority. At Russia's request, the Council is considering how the investigators can move more effectively toward completing their assignment.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE SCANDAL OF PLEASURE:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESS, HENRY
description: PRESS-Henry. Of Brooklyn, NY. Born December 4, 1919. Loving husband, father and grandfather. 52 year employee of J. Press Clothiers, Inc., Manhattan. Died on November 15, 1997, after a brief illness. All donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Fund.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A sturdy seafarer, a venerable detective and a non-pareil nanny lend zest to the week's peak screen achievements on television.

title: Carl G. Hempel Dies at 92; Applied Science to Philosophy
description: Carl G. Hempel, whose rigorously empirical approach to scientific logic was at the center of American scholarly writing on the philosophy of science for several decades, died on Nov. 9 at a nursing home near Princeton, N.J. He was 92.

title: Four High School Students Show They Know Their Cows
description: Four high school students from southern New Jersey took top prizes from the FFA (formerly the Future Farmers of America) by predicting which cow will produce the most milk and which will have the best calves. Their first-place finishes came during e competitions held at the national FFA convention in Kansas City, Mo., earlier this month.

title: Instant Friendship Takes Red Smith
description: Eleven horses were scratched from the Red Smith Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday after the race was switched from the soaked grass course to the muddy dirt, but none of that bothered Instant Friendship, who demonstrated again that he is one tough traveling horse.

title: T. Thumb, Esquire?
description: It's not a calling card for Lilliputians, but it could be carried by one. The miniature calling card is in, toted by people who want to keep their business and social pleasures separate. ''It's a romantic, turn-of-the-century way of identifying myself,'' Laurel Myerson, a cosmetics marketing representative, cooed as she opened a tiny leather case and produced a wee card with her name, address and telephone number. ''I have a business card for work, but I keep this for social reasons.''

title: Nicole Contos, Tasos Michael
description: Nicole Contos, the daughter of Carol and Demetrios Contos of New York, and Tasos Michael, a son of Demetrios and Kay Michael of London, were married yesterday at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York. The Rev. Dr. Robert G. Stephanopoulos, the cathedral's Dean, performed the ceremony. Archbishop Iakovos, who retired last year as the leader of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese in North and South America, took part in the service.

title: Peekskill Group Rallies to Stop Development of a Battle Site
description: IN 1777, Colonial militia unsuccessfully defended Peekskill against a British invasion. More than two centuries later, citizens' groups are fighting to prevent the battle site here from being developed.

title: Indigenous Food in a Modern Menu
description: FINDING inspiration for some of the Thanksgiving menu in the indigenous food of this continent -- that is, the ingredients that predated European settlement -- is always appropriate. The larder is rich and familiar, yielding corn and beans for a succotash, wild rice for a pilaf and pecans for pie.

title: A New York Tradition Started in Newark
description: To the Editor:

title: The Grand Tour
description: FIFTY YEARS OF EUROPE

title: What Happened to the Basics?
description: To the Editor:

title: GOBBLING ART
description: * The ''hand turkey,'' a beloved grade-school art project produced by decorating the outline of a hand with turkey features (pictured), is under attack in American classrooms. Educators says the exercise is a bore. * Turkeys haven't tended to inspire great American art. Mike Nelson, an official with the Audubon Naturalist Society, suggests one possible reason: wild turkeys are skittish, so it has always been difficult for artists to see them. * Audubon solved that one: he killed three dozen specimens and posed them for his famous turkey images. * One modern artist who makes the turkey fly is Rob Keck, executive vice president of the National Wild Turkey Federation. The group sells limited-edition prints for up to $900 each. * For budget buyers, Hallmark's 3-D crepe-paper-and-cardboard tabletop turkey sells for $4.69.

title: POSTINGS: No Need for New 'C of O' in Combining Apartments; Simpler Rules On Alterations
description: The New York City Department of Buildings has simplified the paperwork and reduced the time and cost involved in the process of combining two or more apartments to create a single unit.

title: ON THE MAP ; A Jewish Congregation Marks a Journey of 150 Years
description: B'nai Jeshuran, the oldest Jewish congregation in New Jersey meets in a modern synagogue in northwest Bergen County. Its roots, though, are in 1847 Paterson. The congregation will celebrate its 150th anniversary this weekend under the leadership of Rabbi Elyse D. Frishman, a member of the Reform movement who, since she was hired in 1995, has seen her congregation grow from 325 families to 470.

title: 'The Lion King' Earns Its Roars Of Approval
description: AS AN AIR OF JUBILATION filled the meticulously restored New Amsterdam Theater following the final preview performance of ''The Lion King,'' I was somehow reminded of a comment attributed to Ethel Merman about Mary Martin. ''She's O.K.,'' said Merman, who had better things to do than talk about the latest competition, ''if you like talent.''

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a recent increase in the refinancing of home mortgages referred incorrectly to a formula for figuring interest rates for adjustable-rate mortgages. After a low, teaser rate in the first year, the rate often rises to the sum of two figures: the one-year Treasury bill rate plus a premium of 2.75 percentage points, not 2.75 percent.

title: A New Yorker And Proud of It
description: Like Elyse Trevers, who wrote about New York bashers [''Bashing New York Includes Us,'' Nov. 9], I am appalled by the insults heaped upon New Yorkers and by our willingness to accept these insults.

title: Veronica Lynn, Robert Chasanoff
description: Veronica Lynn Schermerhorn, a dancer whose stage name is Veronica Lynn, was married yesterday to Robert W. Chasanoff, a real estate developer. Justice Jacqueline W. Silbermann of State Supreme Court officiated at the Colony Club in New York.

title: Lori Fiverson, Joseph Tahl
description: Lori Fiverson, the daughter of Nancy and Stephen B. Fiverson of Livingston, N.J., was married last evening to Joseph Allen Tahl, the son of Marilyn and Elliot Tahl of Westbury, N.Y. Rabbi Barry R. Friedman performed the ceremony at the Plaza in New York.

title: Decent but Cranky the Fourth Time Around
description: DURING LUCILLE BALL'S final years as a television star, even her most devoted fans winced at her pratfalls and scatterbrained coquettishness. Some of Jack Benny's long-running shtick, particularly his relationship with his ''girlfriend,'' Mary Livingstone, wore thin by the 1960's. Even Michael Landon, in his last series or two, could have used a grown-up haircut.

title: Q&A/J. Scott Crystal ; Extending National Geographic's Scope
description: ATTENTION, National Geographic Society members: you can clear out your bookshelves and coffee tables of decades-old (or more) stacks of magazines. National Geographic -- all 108 years of it -- has come to CD-ROM (actually 30 or so CD-ROM's).

title: It's Time To Deal With Winter
description: THIS is the time of year when many homeowners in the metropolitan area engage in an annual ritual of sorts -- trying to decide whether to buy a snowblower -- known in the trade as a snowthrower -- by trying to guess whether the winter will be bad enough to warrant one.

description: Outlawing bribery sounds as controversial as being against sin, but it took 29 of the world's industrial nations 20 years before they agreed on it Thursday.

description: I DOUBT you would wander into Acqua because of the sign, which isn't pretty, or the exterior of the restaurant, which resembles a box, although an attractively landscaped one.

title: Running the F.B.I.
description: Why does your article on Freeh constantly quote his colleagues calling him ''Louie,'' as if he went by a nickname? Most of the men I know named Louis have been brought up to pronounce it that way, although some, like the residents of St. Louis, undoubtedly pronounce it ''Lewis.''

title: Running the F.B.I.
description: It sounds as if Freeh is doing a pretty good job. But if he's so concerned with inflating overtime (''banging the books''), then why is he not concerned, as I am as a taxpayer, with having Government employees feed and diaper his son Liam and watch his other children when they are in the office?

title: Running the F.B.I.
description: Bull's-eye! Bruce Porter's profile captures the essence of Director Louis Freeh and accurately depicts the F.B.I. today (''Running the F.B.I.,'' Nov. 2). I served 31 years as an agent, mostly in New York City. Louis Freeh is a complete professional. More important, he is a man of rigorous honesty and humility.

title: Rare Voice, Gracious Neighbor

She was already acclaimed as the greatest contralto of her time. Now her fortitude and serenity, in the face of exclusion from Constitution Hall on account of her color, would touch millions of hearts around the world.

From local playhouses, regional theaters and drama schools to the farthest reaches Off Off Broadway, the search was on. Where, oh, where was that combination so rare? A fresh singing, dancing, acting talent, fetching in form and in face, the singular sensation who would transform the make-believe of yesteryear when musicals were musical, into a real option for modern times. And also do back flips and handsprings. Finding her was essential, for no one was having any fun.

title: Wilson and McCarthy: Still Entangled
description: Eight years after her death it seems that people still find it hard to decide whether or not they like Mary McCarthy. Edmund Wilson has been dead for 25 years, during which time the publication of his journals has added to the already ample evidence that he was not, on the whole, an amiable character; yet surviving acquaintances, and others, continue to speak of him with affection, or at any rate a disposition to excuse. Can this be because our culture is still more tender to talented drunken male lechers than to talented free-living and free-loving women? Two books -- ''Twenty-four Ways of Looking at Mary McCarthy: The Writer and Her Work,'' edited by Eve Stwertka and Margo Viscusi, and ''Edmund Wilson: Centennial Reflections,'' edited by Lewis M. Dabney -- lend some color to that hypothesis. One essay in the McCarthy volume is titled ''Our Leading Bitch Intellectual.'' Nobody calls Wilson ''Our Leading Stud Intellectual.''

title: Boston
description: Strange to think that the Puritans, who founded this city in 1630, forbade the celebration of Christmas. Current residents must be making up for lost time: almost every block on the calendar marks another concert, festival, parade or revel.

title: November 16-22; Islamic Militants Attack Tourists in Egypt
description: An ancient Egyptian temple in Luxor became a modern killing field in which 58 foreign tourists were slain in the space of 45 minutes Monday. The attack, the most vicious act of terrorism in years, gave pause to travelers around the world who had come to regard Egypt as a safe destination.
