Family will be sitting Shiva through Thursday morning, November 27, at 53 Trenor Drive, New Rochelle, NY.

title: For a Lobsterman, Toil and Pleasure
description: IT'S still dark at 5 A.M. on a brisk November day when Billy Carman, captain of the Glass Slipper, eases his lobster boat out into Block Island Sound. Fumes of oil-packed salted bunker mingle with those of bluefish and striper carcasses, but the rank odor is perfume to a fisherman's nose. Without bait, you can't catch lobsters.

title: Q&A;: Noel Schwerin; The Ramifications of Gene Mapping
description: NOEL SCHWERIN, a documentary film maker for the last 15 years and former associate producer for the NOVA science and technology series on the Public Broadcasting System, produced, directed and wrote ''A Question of Genes: Inherited Risks,'' which aired this fall on public television. Through several first-person stories, the film explores the conflicted decision of individuals at risk for heart disease, breast and ovarian cancer and Alzheimer's disease to undergo genetic testing, and the practical and moral problems that their decisions -- and the findings -- force them to confront.

I once received a Canadian lottery ticket as a birthday gift and, luckily, was a winner. I received a $500 check drawn on a Canadian bank. Because I was planning to visit Montreal shortly, I kept the check.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VISSCHER, STEVEN H.
description: VISSCHER-Steven H. On November 21, Steve lost his long battle against AIDS. A celebration of his life will be held on Sunday, November 30, at 2 PM at B. Smith's Rooftop Cafe, 711 Eighth Ave, NYC, 212-247-2222.

description: MOST students just take a pencil and a calculator to the math Regents. Alexandra Wertis had to bring a court order.

title: Why They Kill Their Newborns
description: I feel no greater sympathy for Amy Grossberg or Melissa Drexler than for Susan Smith. What can be said is that these girls were younger than Susan Smith and that they feared parental reprisal for having got pregnant, which Susan Smith did not. We can sympathize with Amy's and Melissa's fear but not with their decisions. The outcome is the same: all three made a choice to kill their children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALY, JAMES E. (''JED'')
description: DALY-James E. (''Jed''), 56, financial specialist. James E. Daly, known as ''Jed,'' died of heart failure at New York Hospital Nov. 15. Mr. Daly suffered from end-stage renal disease since 1989 and received hemodialysis at home from his wife. An unsuccessful transplant in 1995 left him physically disabled and curtailed his ability to work. Born in Attleboro, Massachusetts, Mr. Daly spoke frequently of his ''rebirths.'' The first occurred when he left Armstrong Cork to enter Harvard Business School. After graduation in 1971, he worked in bond sales for First Boston, where he was instrumental in creating a marketing department. In the 1980's, at Salomon Bros., he worked in Canadian fixed-income securities sales and in new-business, real-estate finance. Mr. Daly was ''reborn'' again when survival of kidney failure spurred him to apply a life-long interest in finance to estate planning and insurance sales. Employed by MetLife, he was appointed manager of his own branch in 1994 due to his pioneering efforts to use The Bloomberg business computer as an insurance channel of distribution. He spoke of establishing an ''interactive, multi-media, office-shopping network.'' Mr. Daly was a board member of Ursinus College in Pennsylvania. He was a member of the American Kidney Association and served as a fund-raiser for The New York Police and Fire Widows' and Children's Fund. He was a long-time member of the Calyx Club of Dallas, Texas; the Harvard Clubs of New York and Boston; the Harvard Business School Club of Greater New York; and the Larchmont Yacht Club. He is survived by his wife, Margarethe, and their two children, Peter, age 12, and Karen, age 16, all of Larchmont, New York, and his sister, Kathryn Daly Leahy of Hanover, Massachusetts. A memorial service wil be held at 10 A.M., on November 29 at Sts. John and Paul Church in Larchmont. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Rogosin Institute (505 East 70 Street, New York, NY 10021).

title: Ancient Gold

They pillage past millenniums. The pieces, handmade in Beirut, Lebanon, where the women live, are reinterpretations of ancient Greek, Roman, Byzantine and Phoenician styles. Made of materials like lapis lazuli, ancient bronze and 18-karat gold dipped in 22-karat gold, they range from a brooch ($1,800) to a bracelet (inset, $3,500) to a necklace ($12,000).

It is a Sunday morning ritual shared by alumni everywhere, a few seconds that make a small connection to a place and a time of one's past.

title: Suit in Oyster Bay Stymies Redevelopment

title: A Gentle Interpreter Of Human Fallibility
description: THE NARROW REDDISH BUILDING that houses the director Atom Egoyan's offices is on a secluded downtown street, within view of a loading dock. It has the weathered feel of a summer house. Inside, an old Steenbeck editing machine vies for space with posters from Mr. Egoyan's films, jokey memorabilia about his first name and photographs of his wife, the actress Arsinee Khanjian, and their 4-year-old son, Arshile. On the back of a chair hangs a baseball cap with a question mark on it -- fitting for a director who in seven feature films has delved into some of the more disturbing aspects of human nature.

title: Crime Against Tourists Rises in Mexico City
description: MEXICO'S giant capital city has become plagued with perils for tourists. Purse-snatching, armed robbery and car theft against both tourists and Mexicans have reached epidemic proportions. According to figures from the mayor's office, reported crime surged by 35 percent in 1995 and 33 percent in 1996 and is still growing, though more slowly, this year.

title: Brother Asserts Prosecutors Misled Him in Unabom Case
description: David Kaczynski, who turned in his brother as the suspected Unabomber, said in an interview on Friday night that he had been misled by investigators and prosecutors into believing that they saw Theodore J. Kaczynski as a mentally ill man who would ''be happier in jail.''

title: Parallel Lives
description: THE DEVIL'S CHIMNEY

title: Running the F.B.I.
description: Porter's account of Louis Freeh is somewhat less than critical. At one point, he reports that the Director ''mistreated Frederic Whitehurst, the F.B.I. whistle-blower,'' then quotes Freeh as saying, ''Our employees are not shy, and they know that whatever they tell me is not going to come back in an adverse way.''

title: Katherine Holt, James Hill 3d
description: Katherine Reston Holt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Holt 3d of Charleston, S.C., was married there yesterday to James Chapelle Hill 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hill Jr. of Raleigh, N.C. The Rev. John Haden McCormick performed the ceremony at St. Philip's Episcopal Church.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEAVY, EDWARD T.
description: LEAVY-Edward T. November 21, 1979. In loving memory, remembered always. Your Children and Grandchildren

title: Not a True Hermit
description: To the Editor:

title: Lemaire Takes Blame For End of the Streak
description: The Devils' team-record eight-game winning streak came to an end today with Mike Dunham in goal, but Coach Jacques Lemaire was quick to take the blame for the 2-1 overtime loss to the Florida Panthers.

title: Undercover Beat to Executive Suite; Case Over, He Assumes the Life of His Assumed Identity
description: The moment had come in the career of a successful New York real estate executive when he finally had to tell the truth about himself to the colleagues he had worked with for two and a half years. So on a June afternoon in 1996, the executive called a friend into his office, looked him in the eye, and said, with a slight tone of apology, ''I'm not who you think I am.''

title: Argentina Is Pursuing New Lead In Bombing
description: In the three years since the bombing of a Jewish community center here killed 87 people and wounded hundreds, the Government has made little progress in identifying those responsible for the attack.

title: Harold S. Geneen, 87, Dies; Nurtured ITT
description: Harold S. Geneen, an executive seen by many as both the architect of the international conglomerate and the most significant and controversial businessman of the 1960's and 70's, died of a massive heart attack at New York Hospital on Friday evening, his secretary, Marie Serio, said. He was 87.

title: Between the Career Path And a Spiritual One
description: WITH THE ROLE OF Merton Densher, the young journalist beloved by two women and seduced into a deceptive and disastrous scheme in ''The Wings of the Dove,'' the British actor Linus Roache has taken on yet another part that turns on torturous moral questions. In the 1994 movie ''Priest,'' he played a Roman Catholic priest struggling with his homosexuality and the hypocrisy of the church.

title: In the Hands of a Collector, a Passion for Photographs of Hands
description: THE eyes may be the windows of the soul, but hands sometimes can tell something even more intimate about a person, said Henry Mendelssohn Buhl, who owns more than 400 photographs of hands.

title: Melissa Marks and Michael Shih
description: Melissa Sandra Marks and Michael Ming-Yu Shih are to marry this evening at the 200 Fifth Avenue Club in New York. The Rev. Doug Phillips, a Presbyterian minister, is to officiate with Rabbi Howard Cohen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANISH, ROY
description: DANISH-Roy. Died on November 20, 1997, at the age of 78. He is survived by his daughters Elisabeth Wheeler and Caroline Thies, his brother Keith, and three grandchildren. Born in Manhattan on March 2, 1919, he graduated from Columbia in 1940, earned an MBA from Harvard in 1942, then served as lieutenant in the U.S. Navy from 1942-1946. His career in broadcasting began with nine years at Mutual Broadcasting System, where he rose to the position of Vice President and Assistant to the President. From 1955 to 1959 he worked at McCann-Erickson as account supervisor and Vice President, then became a partner at Smith-Greenland Advertising in 1959. In 1960, Roy began his 27 year career with Television Information Office, where he served as Director from 1962 to 1987. He worked with his multi-talented staff to maintain a bridge of understanding between the television industry and its many publics. Donations in his memory may be made to the Alzheimers Association, 420 Lexington Avenue, NY, NY 10170.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: From Sushi Waitress to Star, But the Work Is Harder

title: BENEFITS
description: Fighting Cancer on a Fast Track

title: A Pipe Organ Victim
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I regret every day of my life the pain Ted is suffering right now. And I regret the Government's decision to seek the death penalty, which I think is a grossly unjust decision. On the other hand, I realize I did what I had to do.''

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column on Friday, about a discussion by the board of Dow Jones & Company to put its financial information division, Dow Jones Markets, up for sale, misstated a result of that meeting. The board did not vote on the matter.

title: Scott, Rejected by Cardinals, a Stalwart for Giants
description: Lance Scott was having a really bad Monday. It was 6 A.M. last Aug. 18. The phone rang in his bedroom. ''Bring in your playbook,'' the voice on the other end of the line said. ''Coach wants to see you.''

title: When Insurers Deem That Surgery Is Purely Cosmetic
description: AFTER a weight loss of 200 pounds, the Suffolk County man, who had once weighed more than 500, was left with a pouch of excess skin that itself weighed almost 100 pounds. The man, who asked that his name not be used, complained that the pouch weighed him down so much that it was difficult to walk and impossible to drive because he could not fit behind the steering wheel of his car.

title: How Tough Questions and Shrewd Mediating Brought Iraqi Showdown to an End
description: As an unarmed U-2 spy plane soared high over central Iraq two weeks ago, President Clinton was poised to order the biggest military operation of his Presidency.

title: Running the F.B.I.
description: As Bruce Porter correctly notes, Louis Freeh has accomplished some long-overdue changes in the administration of the F.B.I. Most of these reforms, along with his personal accessibility, have given the Director a degree of internal support that even some serious, self-admitted management mistakes have not dampened.

title: Kathleen Mellon, Rahamim Ron
description: Kathleen Mellon, executive director of the America-Israel Cultural Foundation, and Rahamim Ron, a dancer and teacher of dance, are to be married today in Bristol, Conn. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein is to perform the ceremony at Bel Eden, the home of Dr. Steven Wernick, a friend of the couple.

title: Teamster Group Debates Whether to Continue Backing Carey
description: The teamster group that was pivotal in electing Ron Carey president of the union debated feverishly today whether to stand by him as he appeals a decision barring him from running for re-election.

title: CHATTER ; The Gubernatorial Squeaker
description: Why do you think that Governor Whitman, once expected to be re-elected easily, won this month by such a narrow margin?

title: Arizona's Backcourt Shoots for 2
description: On most Friday nights, Miles Simon and Mike Bibby and their Arizona teammates lounge around the locker room on overstuffed red leather couches watching each other maneuver a video game that is hooked up to a big-screen television. They eat pizza and argue over who is the best Nintendo player.

title: Woman Dies of Gunshots After a Domestic Dispute
description: A Brooklyn mother died at Kings County Hospital Center at 4:30 P.M. yesterday, hours after her estranged husband shot her four times with an AK-47 assault rifle during a domestic dispute, the police said.

title: New Seekers in Jazz Look To the East
description: FROM DUKE ELLINGTON and John Coltrane to Henry Threadgill and John Zorn, jazz musicians have long flirted with Eastern influences. Yet these have been largely casual encounters, prompted by a desire to widen jazz's palette, rather than systematic attempts at fusion.

title: Q&A: Stephen C. Robinson ; The Need to Give Back to the Community
description: STEPHEN C. ROBINSON, a lawyer who did his undergraduate work and law school training at Cornell, is only 40 years old but he has worked as a special assistant to the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, as an assistant Federal prosecutor in New York and for the past two years as chief compliance officer at Aetna U.S. Healthcare in Hartford.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: JEFFERSON'S CHILDREN Education and the Promise of American Culture. By Leon Botstein. Doubleday, $21.95.

title: Mediterranean Family Fare in Armonk
description: THE hand-painted grapevine edging the walls and the new color scheme of dark leaf green and burgundy tints freshen dining rooms once called Maddalena but now known as the Grapevine. Along with the name, the owners Gino Izetta, the chef, and Janis Pettit changed the menu and focus. The name, Mr. Izetta said, was inspired by the many grapevines that grow around the Mediterranean, and the change in menu resulted from his interest in branching out into that cuisine.

title: Misdirections In Sands Point
description: Obviously, Mayor Leonard Wurzel, whose letter was published in your Oct. 19 issue, is not one of those who ''thrives on their anonymity'' in Sands Point.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEUSTEIN, ROSALIND B.
description: NEUSTEIN-Rosalind B. 10/2/05 - 11/23/77. Remembered with love these twenty years. Lois, children and grandchildren

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: DIVIDED HIGHWAYS

title: Heavy Bets on a Few Stocks Pay Off
description: ON a list of the 100 best-performing domestic stock funds of the last 12 months, those that buy the shares of small and midsize companies dominate. Only a handful that focus on large companies are scattered throughout this stratosphere. But flying highest among these, and eighth on the overall list, is a young fund that hails from an insurance company family and favors big, fast-growing businesses.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Benefits column last Sunday about the opening night of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's winter season at City Center misstated the date. It is Dec. 3, not Dec. 1.

title: Why They Kill Their Newborns
description: Steven Pinker's article has skirted a central problem of sociobiology -- the conflating of biology and morality. Yes, it is worth noting that primitive cultures, and possibly most of humanity's cultures, have practiced neonaticide, and that there is undoubtedly a genetic foundation out of which such behavior arises.

title: A Misnomer
description: To the Editor:

title: Homeowners Vs. Commerce On Broome St.
description: At the eastern end of SoHo, artists coexist, sometimes uneasily, with the neighborhood's bustling wholesale vegetable and garment manufacturing businesses. Residents complain about noise, odor and congestion.

title: Job Climate Improves With More Public Transit; Cycling to Work
description: To the Editor:

title: White House May Tighten Data Exports
description: The Clinton Administration is debating whether to further tighten controls on the export of electronic data scrambling systems by narrowing a special exemption that has let financial institutions export the strongest encryption technology.

title: Albany Cuts Effort to Urge Conservation
description: New York State, once a national leader in promoting energy conservation, has, with little public notice, cut its conservation effort to about one-fourth its former size, even though the program has been highly praised by environmentalists.

title: While Congress Is Away, Clinton Toys With Idea of an End Run
description: A constitutional power rooted in the muddy roads and farm rhythms of the 18th century may give President Clinton a chance to salvage -- at least for a few months -- the troubled nomination of Bill Lann Lee to head the civil rights division in the Justice Department.

title: Job Climate Improves With More Public Transit; Making Work Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBER, LARRY C
description: GARBER-Larry C. Of Rahway, NJ. Died on November 23, after a valiant battle with cancer. Beloved husband of Susan. Loving father of David and Daniel. Adoring grandfather of Adam, Alysa and Drew. Dear friend of Marilee and Gary Bleetstein. Graveside service Monday, November 24, at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, 11 AM, Iselin, NJ. Contributions may be made to Rahway First Aid Squad or Clark Rehabilitation. We express our heartfelt sympathy to the entire Garber family. We will miss him.

title: Andy Warhol's Durability
description: Andy Warhol is back, if only to remind us that he never went away. The third floor of the Whitney Museum has been surrendered to an exhibition exploring Warhol's sense of glamour, beginning with his childhood-film-star scrapbooks. The windows at Barneys paid blunt homage to Warhol, at least until the holiday displays started going in. Last week, the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts announced that Warhol's film and television works will be divided among four institutions, including the Whitney Museum and the Museum of Television and Radio. That gift alone will insure the steady re-estimation of a figure who needs no retrospective. The culture we live in is retrospective enough for Andy Warhol.

title: Connecting at 56 Kilobits? Probably Not Yet, as Makers of Modems Fail to Agree
description: In January, the modem industry introduced a technology that promised to allow personal computer users to connect to the Internet and other on-line services at twice the previous speed. But the new modems came in two dueling, incompatible formats, which have yet to be resolved with a common standard. And, as for the speed: as they say in Detroit, mileage may vary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORET, AARON
description: PORET-Aaron. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Howard and Pamela, Jay and Nete, Elizabeth and Kenneth Christ. Cherished grandfather of Rebecca, Jacqueline and Max. Services today 11:30, at ''Parkside Memorial Chapels,'' 2576 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn, (corner Ave V).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENTHAL, MARTIN
description: LOWENTHAL-Martin. On November 21, 1997. Beloved husband of wife Anne. Loving father of Bette, Sylvia and Helen and spouses. Dear grandfather of David and Fred Thaler. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLZ, SAMUEL S
description: STOLZ-Samuel S. On November 23, 1997, after a long and glorious life, in his home peacefully at the age of 91. Husband of Freda. Father of Margrit, Robert and James. Grandfather of Erik, Oliver, Adam, Daniel and Freda. Father-in-law of Roger, Marlene and Chris. Survived by his sister Barbara Roth. Loved by all. A sweet, wise, gentle man. We learned so much from him and we will miss him so. Funeral services will be Tuesday, November 25, at 12:30 PM, at Temple Israel, 112 E. 75 St.

title: Havas Unit Wins A Project for Buick
description: The Buick division of the General Motors Corporation has named the Euro RSCG Tatham unit of Havas Advertising in Chicago to handle an undisclosed project.

title: In Connecticut, a Privately Run Welfare Program Sinks Into Chaos
description: Last April, Connecticut became the first state to hire a private company to handle its entire program of child-care benefits for families on welfare and the working poor, a bold move toward privatization that was watched closely by other states.

title: Sorenstam's Victory Caps a Banner Season
description: Annika Sorenstam ended the year where she has been since the third week of the season: on top of the money list and ahead of the field. Sorenstam won a playoff with Lorie Kane and Pat Hurst today to capture the ITT L.P.G.A. Tour Championship, secure the top spot on the money list and claim player of the year honors.

title: Quirky Campaign Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting the Picture; TV Stations Develop New Enthusiasm for Digital Future
description: Flip back eight months, and listen to the broadcast television industry as it tried to persuade the Government to accept its slow, lazy schedule for making the transition to digital broadcasting.

title: Concert Rivals to Run Irving Plaza
description: For more than 25 years, one of the most notorious rivalries in the music business has been between John Scher and Ron Delsener, competing concert promoters constantly sparring for rock bands and concert halls. Now, for the first time, the two will be working together long term. And not necessarily by choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPIENZA, NICOLO ''PAT.''
description: SAPIENZA-Nicolo ''Pat.'' Founder of ''The Theatre Bar Restaurant'' of 45th St. passed away peacefully 11/22/97 at the age of 92. Friend of many young budding actors and actresses of the 40's and 50's, with an encouraging word, sympathetic ear and a free meal when needed. Loving father of Mr. Sam Sapienza, Mrs. Tina Grillo and Dr. Frank Sapienza. Grateful fatherin-law of Gloria, Joseph and May. An inspiration to his 13 grandchildren and 32 great-grandchildren. Reposing at The Branch Funeral Home of Nesconset, New York.

title: MEDIA: PUBLISHING ; An author tells of his frustrations in trying to promote diversity in the industry.
description: ALTER MOSLEY'S day job is mystery writing -- sharp, unsentimental prose with plots that weave around the character Easy Rawlins, a reluctant detective featured in the novels ''A Little Yellow Dog'' and ''Devil in a Blue Dress.''

title: Leach and Stark Earn Title
description: Leander Paes and Mahesh Bhupathi of India, ranked 109th and 231st in singles, respectively, have been the hottest doubles tandem in tennis with six straight titles on the ATP Tour since August.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENEEN, HAROLD S
description: GENEEN-Harold S. The management and employees of General Bearing Corporation mourn the loss of Harold Geneen, an extraordinary man. Mr. Geneen was a good friend of our company as well as a director and advisor. The loss of his special brand of wisdom and guidance will be difficult to bear. His imprint of ideas and concepts on our organization will be everlasting. The Management and Employees of General Bearing Corp

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING ; Nordstrom and Allure create a 'magalogue' of premium-priced cosmetics and fragrances.
description: BIG retailer hopes to add allure to an ambitious holiday catalogue promotion by adding, well, Allure.

title: Letting Shostakovich Blaze and Sprawl
description: The American conductor Richard Westerfield, recently appointed the associate conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, first performed with the New York Philharmonic in 1993, when he substituted at the last minute for an ailing Erich Leinsdorf. On Thursday night, he conducted the orchestra for the first time in a subscription concert, highlighted by a blazing, authoritative performance of Shostakovich's sprawling Eighth Symphony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, EDWINE ADRIANCE AKA TEDDY
description: LYONS-Edwine Adriance aka Teddy, 71, died November 19, 1997, in Lakeland, FL. Wife of K. Mark. Mother of twin sons Ted and Jereand daughter Mikey. Grandmother of six. Survived by twin sisters Louise Gardner and Sarah Scoville and brother George Adriance.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: EXTRA POINTS ; Celebration Leaves Frerotte Woozy
description: Redskins quarterback Gus Frerotte did not play in the second half after he injured his neck celebrating his second-quarter touchdown. Frerotte scored on a 1-yard scramble and ran through the end zone, where he head-butted the padded exterior wall that surrounds the field.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOYES, ELLIOT ''RED.''
description: NOYES-Elliot ''Red.'' He made the world a better place, we will miss him. The Gribin Family

title: Editorial Observer; The Profane and Defiant World of the Iranians
description: Teheran is a city of interior lives. The narrow streets downtown and the broader avenues that climb through the foothills of the snow-capped Elburz Mountains are crowded by day. But in the evening Iranians retreat to their homes, the best sanctuary they can find from the suffocating restrictions of Iran's Islamic code. Everything that is forbidden in public is possible at home.

title: Uniforms to Be Allowed For Moonlighting Officers
description: New York City police officers will be permitted to wear their uniforms while working off duty in a pilot program to start in February, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

title: Ex-Official Now Looks To Church For Solace
description: This morning, the former Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary walked to the front of her mother's Presbyterian church in nearby Newport News, which she described as ''a groovy place,'' and came to God.

title: Miscellany
description: * Market Facts Inc., a marketing research information company, and Juno Online Service L.P. teamed up to create an interactive market research panel that will conduct surveys using the Juno E-mail service.

title: Chronicle
description: CHARLES M. SCHULZ, the creator of ''Peanuts,'' turns 75 this week, and he still remembers the one that got away -- his ''little red-haired girl.''

title: Job Climate Improves With More Public Transit; Too Many Expenses
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOBEL, HAROLD
description: SOBEL-Harold. November 24, 1922-March 20, 1981. Lovingly remembered on what would have been your 75th birthday. Bernice, Peter and Jonathan

title: Jorge Mas Canosa, 58, Dies; Exile Who Led Movement Against Castro
description: Jorge Mas Canosa, who came to the United States as a penniless refugee from the dictatorship of Fidel Castro and built the Cuban-American National Foundation into one of Washington's most effective lobbying groups, died here this afternoon at home. He was 58.

title: Patents
description: FEW of the turkeys sitting on American dinner tables this Thanksgiving will have been shot in the wild in the same way that the Pilgrims, at least according to legend, hunted their birds. Instead, turkeys of today are produced commercially.

title: Luxor Survivors Say Killers Fired Methodically
description: When Linka Fingerhuth, 32, a Swiss tourist, heard the pop-popping of automatic rifle fire at the Temple of Hatshepsut in Luxor, Egypt, last Monday, she thought that someone was shooting at a troublesome dog she could see scuttling away in the distance. But she soon discovered that she was a likely target herself.

title: Thinking Deeply About Thinking and Having Fun, Too
description: HOW THE MIND WORKS

title: Nathan Gould, 84, an Executive With a Jewish Women's Group
description: Nathan Gould, who built Women's American ORT into a force in American Jewish life and a mainstay of a worldwide network, died on Nov. 10 at New York University Medical Center. He was 84 and lived in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: F.B.I. Fears Reno Will End Case on Clinton
description: The likelihood that Attorney General Janet Reno will reject the appointment of an independent prosecutor to investigate fund-raising phone calls by President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore has created a strain between the Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Government officials said today.

title: Job Climate Improves With More Public Transit
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; A Big Game at Last, and It Turns Into a Dud
description: The question hung above Jack Kent Cooke Stadium last night like a blimp: could these Giants win their first big game?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SISKIND, ADELE (NEE CROOG)
description: SISKIND-Adele (nee Croog). On November 21, 1997. Wife of the late Louis. Mother of Deane S. Sevel (Bernard J.), the late Gail S. Sternlicht (Martin W.). Sister of Frances Saunders and the late Mildred Kaplan, Samuel and Jack Croog. Also survived by five grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. Services and interment today in Baltimore, MD. For more information call Sol Levinson & Bros., 800-338-1701.

title: At Home Abroad ; A Philistine Nation?
description: During the long torment of Federal arts financing in the United States, Britain has seemed a place where the system worked. Government money supported galleries, museums, music, dance, theater -- and all without prurient Congressmen trying to impose their taste on the arts.

title: San Antonio Journal; Symbol of Texas Liberty Faces a Relentless Siege
description: The graceful limestone mission has withstood one of the most fabled military sieges of all time, as well as subsequent decades of relative obscurity and neglect, to assume its modern identity as the shrine of Texas liberty. But esteemed as the Alamo is today, it remains under relentless attack: the enemy is water.

title: Novotna Proves She's a Champion, Even to Herself
description: Always a bridesmaid, never a bride: it's a cliche, and Jana Novotna was tired of living it. But with three failed trips to Grand Slam finals marring her lengthy resume, the 29-year-old Novotna had to be wondering if it would forever be her lot to stumble one step short of the finish line whenever a big-time title was on the line.

title: Share Offerings For This Week
description: These equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Clinton Expresses Optimism on Asia's Economic Future as Pacific Rim Meeting Opens
description: President Clinton used a gathering of Pacific Rim leaders here to reassure the world today that the current financial turmoil in Asia is temporary and that leaders were acting aggressively to stem it.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BALCOFF, FANNY
description: BALCOFF-Fanny. Grandma Fanny: Your good and gracious deeds, your caring and giving will be remembered, Always. The special meaning of your life remains inscribed forever in our hearts and minds; and lives on within us. Remembering you today and every day. Bill, Robin and Sarah Faye Pollack

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Clinton Expects Asia To Overcome Crisis

title: Jolting New Life Into an Emotional, Old Rivalry
description: Giving new meaning to the notion of using one's head, Gus Frerotte certainly did not, in the end, use his.

title: Updates/Media and Technology; Knoxville Station Will Join Emerging TV Network
description: The Paxson Communications Corporation's planned television network has added another station.

title: Teamster Camp Hails Fallen Carey Even as It Scans Room for a Successor
description: The moment Ron Carey stepped into the ballroom on Saturday night, 600 teamsters jumped to their feet and clapped thunderously for two minutes, first shouting ''Carey, Carey,'' and then chanting ''fight, fight.''

title: Sports of The Times ; O'Donnell's Revival, By Passing to Johnson
description: AS intermission wound down, bands struggled off the field and Jets and Vikings players straggled back on, a Vikings official examined a statistics sheet in the press box yesterday. Minnesota was coming off a horrible loss to Detroit, and now it was down by 20-7, on the verge of adding to the Jets' fairy tale.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Big Japanese Securities Firm Falls, Putting the System on Trial
description: The Yamaichi Securities Company, the fourth largest brokerage firm in Ja pan, moved to close its doors on 100 years of business today, and the Gov ernment mobilized its forces to re assure global markets that it is com mitted to an orderly overhaul of the country's shaky financial system.

title: Job Climate Improves With More Public Transit; Reward Easy Access
description: To the Editor:

title: National News Briefs; $1 Billion Merger Pact In Oil and Gas Industry
description: Sonat Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy the Zilkha Energy Company for stock valued at $1.04 billion. The deal would make Sonat, which is based in Birmingham, the sixth-largest independent oil and gas company in the nation.

title: Feeling the Pain When a Film Fails; Some Find Their Careers in Tatters, But Others Appear Unscathed
description: It's the dark side of the Hollywood dream, the subject no one wants to talk about.

title: As Hate Spills Onto the Web, a Struggle Over Whether, and How, to Control It
description: The World Wide Web site of a group called the Charlemagne Hammerskins opens with an image of a man in a ski mask, carrying a gun and standing by a swastika. A click on a button below labeled, in French, ''Access for sub-humans'' yields a picture of what appears to be a concentration camp, accompanied by a not-so-veiled threat: ''Be assured, we still have many one-way tickets for Auschwitz.''

title: INSIDE
description: On or off duty, a uniform look for police officers. PAGE B3

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILSTEIN, RITA (NEE MEYER)
description: KILSTEIN-Rita (nee Meyer). On November 20, 1997. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Richard I. Kilstein. After a long illness in Tuscaloosa, AL. Beloved mother of daughter Star (Stan) Bloom and the Rev. Dr. Bonnie Ring. Adored grandmother of Tara and Ashley Bloom. She was a longtime resident of New York City until her retirement to Laguna Hills, CA. Well known in the furniture industry as an officer of Wycombe Meyer Furniture Co. Surviving family include Sydney, Theodore R. Meyer, Norman and Constance Sadek. Contributions may be made to breast cancer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, JOHN P
description: O'BRIEN-John P. On November 23, 1997. Survived by his brothers Thomas and James, devoted nieces and nephews, and his lifelong companion Durwood Herron. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Stephen of Hungary Church, 414 E. 82 St, Tuesday 10 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the American Heart Associaton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTLOB, MARK
description: GOTLOB-Mark. The trustees and staff of The American Federation of Arts mourn the untimely death of Mark Gotlob, Deputy Director of the organization. Our hearts go out to his beloved wife and son, Ellen and Evan, his mother and family. He will be deeply missed. Robert M. Meltzer, Chairman Jan Mayer, President Serena Rattazzi, Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAGIN, EDNA A
description: GAGIN-Edna A. On 11/22/97 of Douglaston, NY. Beloved wife of the late James P. Gagin. Dear mother of Marie A. Kisseberth. Loving grandmother of Joanne Heller, Leslie Hauspurg and the late James Kisseberth. Greatgrandmother of ten, and greatgreat-grandmother of three. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, on Monday from 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass on Tuesday, 10:45 AM, St. Anastasia R.C. Church, Douglaston. Family requests a private burial.

title: 55-TO-64 BRACKET SEEMS NEXT IN LINE FOR INSURANCE AID
description: Having succeeded in extending health care coverage to millions of children, the White House and some members of Congress are now turning attention to another group of uninsured Americans -- the 3 million who are 55 to 64 years old.

title: 'Working' Finds Dignity in the Second Shift
description: The first time I saw ''Working,'' the musical based on Studs Terkel's oral history of American labor, I got a headache. The second time, I was moved to tears.

title: U.S. Pushes Israel for 'Credible' Withdrawal Plan
description: President Clinton and his Administration are turning up the heat on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to produce substantial progress with the Palestinians in talks in December, senior American officials said today.

title: A Wedding Of Theater And Social Issues
description: Anna Deavere Smith, the playwright and performer who invented her own form of theater and has used it to explore matters like race and class, will head a new summer institute at Harvard University devoted to finding ways in which the arts might enhance the public discussion of social issues.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HARNEY, CYNTHIA
description: HARNEY-Cynthia. We miss youyour humor and your sharp critiques. Love always, your friends Margaret and Michele

title: Fraud Investigator Hires Bratton
description: William J. Bratton, the former New York City Police Commissioner, will resign from his job as vice chairman of First Security Services Corporation in Boston to become president and chief operating officer of the Carco Group, a company in Suffolk County that runs background checks and investigates automobile insurance fraud.

title: U.S. to Sell Bills and Notes
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week comprises today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and the auction tomorrow of new two-year notes, five-year notes and 15-day cash management bills.

title: W. B. Doner Gets Cigarette Account
description: Imperial Tobacco Ltd., a division of Imasco Ltd. in Montreal, has named W. B. Doner & Company in Southfield, Mich., to introduce the company's first product for the American market, a ''natural'' tobacco cigarette named Mercer. Initial billings were estimated at $1 million to $2 million, but are expected to increase if the brand -- now being test-marketed in Portland, Ore. -- is successful.

title: Government Study Says F.A.A. Fails to Follow Up on Violations
description: The Federal Aviation Administration routinely fails to determine whether violations that its inspectors uncover at aircraft repair stations are ever corrected, according to a report by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress.

title: Shaky Asia, New Shivers
description: For nearly a quarter-century, Washington has usually assumed that its main allies in Asia, who are also some of America's leading economic rivals, would grow ever stronger.

title: POP REVIEW ; A Band That Harnesses Spanish Rhythmic Power
description: In the decade after the death of Franco, the arts in Spain flowered; forbidden subjects were explored, and pleasure was pursued. In music, the connections between Gypsy and Andalusian culture from both sides of the Mediterranean were made concrete, and for a while in Madrid it was impossible to go to hear live music that wasn't some sort of cultural search for identity disguised as club music.

title: Material Battle for Spiritual Place; Dorothy Day's Retreat Is Enmeshed in a Property Fight
description: A beachfront bungalow on Staten Island, more shack than cottage, beckoned an old woman in the last years of life. After a half-century of serving her God by feeding the hungry and protesting for peace, the time had come to rest a bit. Her heart, the doctors told her, was enlarged.

title: Giants Keep Division Lead With a Tie
description: As expected, tonight's game between the Giants and Redskins was a tense, physical struggle between two old rivals. It was hardly pretty football, with two clumsy offenses awkwardly trying to break a tie in sudden-death overtime.

title: Foreman Takes His Cheeseburgers to Go
description: After Shannon Briggs had won a controversial 12-round majority decision over George Foreman on Saturday night in Atlantic City, Briggs's promoter flashed back to April 22, 1995, and another controversial decision, one that benefited Foreman.

title: Crew's Next Goal Is to Scrap Tenure System for Principals
description: A year after the State Legislature radically changed the way New York City schools are run -- giving the schools chancellor vast new powers -- Chancellor Rudy Crew is focusing on what city officials describe as the next rung on the ladder of reform: eliminating tenure for principals.

title: Dust and Doubts Clear at Michigan
description: After all the judgments, big and small, that have taken place this season, the biggest surprise became official yesterday. As each measurement was registered, the conflicts of the past few weeks were resolved into -- can this be possible? -- a consensus.

title: Turkish Court to Rule on Future of Former Premier's Islamic Party
description: Former Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan has completed three days of testimony before the Constitutional Court, where a case has been brought that could result in a five-year ban on his party and a similar ban on his own political activity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLORES, MOE
description: KLORES-Moe. Survived by wife Betty, daughter Lenore Harmon, grandchildren, great-grandchildren and brother. He will be missed.

title: The Alamo Under Attack
description: The Alamo is suffering the ravages of time and the elements, especially water. Like four other missions in San Antonio, Texas, and countless other buildings and monuments across the Southwest, the Alamo is susceptible to ''rising damp,'' in which moisture seeping into the structure starts a chemical reaction that causes small chips of stone to fall off. A14

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIBUSCH, ROSE
description: SEIBUSCH-Rose. Age 92, on November 23, 1997. Beloved mother and mother-in-law of Lucy and Leonard Dome. Loving grandmother of Jeffrey, Lauren and Eric. Great-grandmother of Garrett Benjamin. Dear grandmother-inlaw of Lauren. Services Monday, November 24, 12 noon, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St at Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

title: A Familiar Face Returns to Harlem
description: It has been 25 years since the cavernous expanse of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem last resonated with the voice of Adam Clayton Powell Jr., its charismatic leader.

title: Americans Narrowly Beat An Icelandic Pair for a Title
description: Two Icelandic stars seemed about to capture a major title at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall National Championships here on Saturday night, but they were overtaken in the stretch run. Adalstein Jorgensen, a former world team champion, and Sigurdur Sverrisson, both of Reykjavik, had to settle for second place in the Life Master Open Pairs, behind Jeff Schuett of Riverwoods, Ill., and Kerry Smith of Milwaukee, who scored 95 percent in the final round.

title: MUSIC REVIEW ; A Song Festival, Heavenly and Earthy
description: ''I'm glad I don't believe it.'' One of Emily Dickinson's responses to heaven, voicing skepticism with a joy implying there is quite enough heaven here on earth, could have been the motto for Thursday evening's New York Festival of Song program. But then these words would have had to be linked with others by Dickinson, again from a poem sung at the recital in Copland's setting: ''Why do they shut me out of heaven? Did I sing too loud?'' -- not because anyone was singing too loud at Weill Hall, but because the sense of expulsion was the shiver behind all the exultation in the earthly pleasures and wonders of love and nature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVEY, HAROLD D
description: SILVEY-Harold D. On behalf of the Officers, Trustees and entire Congregation, we mourn the loss of our esteemed honorary president. Harold led this congregation with devotion, loyalty and distinction. He was always jovial and always gave his first concern to his family and to the Temple. Our heartfelt sympathy is expressed to his beloved wife Lucille and family. May his memory be for a blessing. Linda Henry Goodman, Rabbi Dr. A. Stanley Dreyfus Rabbi Emeritus Hortense Hurwitz, President Union Temple of Brooklyn SILVEY-Harold D. We mourn the loss of our esteemed president's loving husband. He was always there to help us, guide us and entertain us. His smiling face will be sorely missed. Our sincere condolences to his wife Lucille, his daughter Susan, his son Bruce, his daughter-in-law Shari, and his granddaughter Laura. Child Care Women's League Nettie Rosenthal, Vice President

title: Cuban-Americans Promise to Carry On Leader's Efforts
description: Jorge Mas Canosa, the Cuban-American businessman and political stalwart who died today, was mourned as an irreplaceable figure in the fight for the democratization of Cuba, but officials of his Cuban-American National Foundation vowed to double their efforts to accomplish his goals.

title: Settling on Affirmative Action
description: The Piscataway, N.J., school board's decision to settle a lawsuit brought by a white teacher who was dismissed in 1989 to preserve a black teacher's job concludes a case that might have been used to dismantle affirmative-action law in this country. A coalition of civil rights groups made the settlement possible by agreeing to pay 70 percent of the $433,500 judgment that Sharon Taxman won in a lower court for back pay and lawyers' fees.

title: The Mayor and the River
description: Historically, New York City has done a poor job of opening up its extensive waterfront to its citizens. So when an opportunity comes along to improve the city's marine environment, New York's political leaders are duty-bound to seize it.

title: Sports of The Times ; Parcells Rolls Dice With the Greenest Jet
description: LONG before Victor Green picked up a ball he shouldn't have touched, and Dennis Green called for a run when he should have passed, Bill Parcells nominated the greenest participant on either sideline to run a quarterback draw for a first down and an eventual 3 points in a game the team in the green helmets wound up winning by 2.

title: One Step Closer To Most Improved
description: With their eighth victory of the season, the Jets crept closer to the National Football League record for improvement.

title: Chronicle
description: It's 21 days and counting. What MARGARET HALSEY GARDINER is counting is not the number of days she has left before Christmas, but rather the time she has to raise $58,000.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: FOOTBALL

Church, Tuesday, 10 AM, celebrated by His Eminence John Cardinal O'Connor. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. For information contact the R.J. O'Shea Funeral Home, Hampton Bays, LI.

title: Trade Deficits Won't Ruin Us
description: There is widespread agreement that the American economy has been performing far better than expected in the last year. Growth has been stronger than predicted, inflation has been weaker, and the unemployment rate has hit lows that most economists doubted they would ever see again. Moreover, popular measures of the economy's performance -- for example, the growth of gross domestic product and changes in the consumer price index -- almost certainly understate just how well the economy has done.

title: Knicks' Sunday Stroll Has a Couple of Twists
description: With a convincing display of unselfishness, the Knicks were less than 12 minutes away from heading for their Thanksgiving break polished, poised and healthy. But Charles Oakley could not govern his passions, Larry Johnson twisted his ankle, and however well they happen to be playing simply does not matter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIN, YAFFA, CHARLOTTE
description: MARGOLIN-Yaffa-Charlotte. Beloved mother of Yael MargolinRice. Dear mother-in-law of James Rice and loving grandmother of Ilana. Funeral service Monday, 1 PM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 1300 Pleasantville Road, Briarcliff, NY.

description: Nowadays she wears tinted glasses with a glittering rhinestone rim. Her suits are tailored but flashy. She is dripping with gold jewelry.

description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, in another in a series of advertising moves, has expanded its relation

description: In the unpredictable world of art auctions, sometimes marketing and promotion pay off, and sometimes they don't. During the boom years of the late 1980's, there was such indiscriminate buying that even a bit of publicity could push prices to record highs.

title: Peace Sculpture Plan Meets Resistance in San Francisco
description: Thirty years after the flower children gathered in this city to spread the message ''Make love, not war,'' a proposal to place a giant peace sign in Golden Gate Park has provoked complaints from city residents who would rather see the legacy of the Summer of Love put to rest.

description: Top-ranked and undefeated Villanova will begin its voyage in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I-AA tournament on Saturday with a home game against Colgate (7-4), the Patriot League champion and the lowest-seeded team in the 16-team playoffs.

description: INVESTORS have stepped up their betting that Hambrecht & Quist, the leading investment bank for high-technology companies, will be taken over -- and sooner rather than later.

title: Investigators in Officer's Slaying Find Family in Gunman's Photo
description: The authorities said yesterday they had found the woman and two children whose picture was swallowed by a gunman who killed a police sergeant in Long Branch, N.J., on Thursday and then led officers on a chase that ended with his suicide.

title: Large Securities Firm In Japan to Be Shut
description: The Yamaichi Securities Company, Japan's fourth largest brokerage house, moved to close its doors, and Tokyo mobilized its forces to reassure global markets that it is committed to an orderly overhaul of the country's financial system.

description: The Oyster Creek nuclear power plant, the third-oldest in the country, was cited last week by the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission for five violations of operating guidelines, commission officials said.

title: Accounts

Inc. and Dentsu Inc. Billings were estimated at under $10 million.

title: James Robert Baker, Satirical Novelist, 50
description: James Robert Baker, a novelist known for his wildly imaginative satires, committed suicide on Nov. 5 at his home in Pacific Palisades, Calif., said Ken Camp, a friend. He was 50.

title: COLLEGES: SOCCER ; Blur of a Bicycle Kick Stuns Ivy Champions
description: St. John's Shane Mulholland says he does not practice bicycle kicks. After his acrobatic goal today against Brown in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, he is not about to start.

title: Foreign Affairs; Backlash
description: It is not yet clear how the Iraq crisis will end. But it's already clear what it has exposed -- the serious tensions just beneath the surface of the U.S.-Russia relationship. Last Friday night, I found myself in Moscow watching CNN report from the White House that some U.S. officials suspect that the Russians and Iraqis may have cooked up the whole Iraq crisis in order to help Baghdad escape from U.N. sanctions. Wow. That's a serious charge. We haven't heard that kind of conspiracy talk since Khrushchev was pounding his shoe at the U.N. But after meeting here with Russian officials and analysts I can report that such charges certainly reflect the prevailing mood of U.S.-Russian ties. The U.S.-Russia relationship has gone in the last seven years from a strategic partnership, to a pragmatic partnership, to a relationship of benign neglect, to a relationship heading for malign neglect. Is it time to break out the reruns of ''Seven Days in May'' and ''From Russia With Love''?

title: Job Climate Improves With More Public Transit; What About Insurance?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about New York State's Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, misidentified the hometown of Michael J. Bragman, the majority leader. It is Cicero, not Syracuse.

title: A Girls' Choir Finally Sings In Spotlight
description: In the 18 years since it was founded, the Girls Choir of Harlem has never sung a sunrise concert for the Pope on the Great Lawn in Central Park or performed on the same bill as Pavarotti. Unlike its world-renowned male counterpart, it has never recorded an album or received a key to a city, like the ones that sparkle tantalizingly in the boys' trophy case at the Choir Academy of Harlem.

description: President Clinton is preparing for another election-year battle over health care as he proposes sweeping new Federal regulations for insurance companies and health maintenance organizations to protect patients' rights.

title: 12 People Left Homeless By Blaze in Elizabeth
description: Fire officials yesterday were investigating a fast-burning, three-alarm blaze in three buildings in downtown Elizabeth that left 12 people homeless early Saturday morning. Several people were forced to leave, but no serious injuries were reported.

description: An accident at Rockefeller Center killed a 23-year-old construction worker yesterday morning when an improperly rigged mechanical hoist collapsed and sent the worker falling four stories, officials said.

description: IGNATOW - Archie. Greatly missed every day of the last five years. Remembered with love. Gene, children and grandchildren.

title: Why Run the Ball? Don't Ask Green
description: In the final frantic seconds of today's game, with bodies and flags flying, Dennis Green's Vikings had a chance to tie the score. With his team trailing the Jets by 2 points with no time left, Green called a running play on a 2-point conversion and it never had a chance, as Rick Lyle crashed into the backfield to pull down Robert Smith.

title: MUSIC REVIEW ; An Orchestra's Piquant Reminders of Postwar Berlin
description: From abroad, it is sometimes hard to remember that Berlin has a second major orchestra. Yet in the United States, of all places, the Deutsches Symphonie-Orchester Berlin should not be forgotten, for it was founded with considerable American financial support as the RIAS Symphony Orchestra in 1946, while the august Berlin Philharmonic struggled through postwar disarray.

title: Corrections

title: The Internet in the courtroom results in more clamor than consensus.

title: A Private Eye; On Getting and Spending, Reading and Listening
description: This autumn in New York, I've had many interesting evenings, but none more interesting than a party I attended, with some 50 others, at the Cosmopolitan Club. My host was a modest, sociable man who has lived in New York City since youth and who has remained loyal in many ways to his native Tennessee. It was his 70th birthday, and I was among a handful there who were younger than that and who did not sound as if they came (as he does) from Nashville.

title: LaFontaine Is Filling A Void Left by Messier
description: Much was made of Mark Messier's departure from the Rangers last summer, and much more will be said when Messier and the Vancouver Canucks visit Madison Square Garden tomorrow night in their only Manhattan appearance of the regular season. title: Gateway Italy Struggles With Flood of Immigrants

Traveling by night, on foot and by donkey, they sneaked across the border and made their way to Istanbul, where they waited three months before booking passage, at $5,000 a head, on a ship bound for the Italian coast.

title: Packers End Woes Against Cowboys

During the second quarter of Green Bay's 45-17 thrashing of the Dallas Cowboys today, Favre threw a floater toward the left sideline, where Deion Sanders was hovering. That is, of course, a no-no.

Rick will be deeply missed by all of us who knew and loved him. We express our most heartfelt condolences to his children, grandchildren, family and many friends. Edmund L. title: Journal; L.A. Inconsequential
description: Lest you think Alec Baldwin's sole political ambition is to look more Presidential than Michael Douglas on as many magazine covers as possible, be reassured that it is not. As the star raised his partisan profile in the media last week, the organization of show-biz activists he leads, the Creative Coalition, staged an elaborate show offering substance by the ton. The event was an all-star tribute to the First Amendment titled ''Seconding the First.'' There hadn't been so much pushing to get into Town Hall since the Robert Brustein-August Wilson prizefight last winter.

title: White House Memo; President Using Fund-Raising Speeches to Test Campaign Themes for '98

title: Another Route for Bill Lann Lee
description: Senate Republicans led by the Judiciary Committee chairman, Orrin Hatch, and the majority leader, Trent Lott, have succeeded in blocking the confirmation of Bill Lann Lee, President Clinton's excellent choice to head the civil rights division of the Justice Department. But Mr. Clinton is said to be considering a challenge to this abuse of the Senate's confirmation powers by installing Mr. Lee in the civil rights job -- at least for a few months -- using his constitutional authority to fill vacancies when Congress is in recess. It would be the right thing to do.

title: Metro Business; New WCBS-TV Manager
description: Steve Friedman, a longtime producer of NBC's ''Today'' show, was named vice president and station manager of WCBS-TV/Channel 2 yesterday, becoming second in command to Jonathan Klein.

title: Young Foster Children Face Speech Problems
description: PROBLEMS in learning to speak and understand language occur far more frequently among babies and toddlers in foster care than among others, researchers have found. But if the children get help while they are still very young, they can overcome their disorders, the researchers said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENEEN, HAROLD S.
description: GENEEN-Harold S. November 21, 1997. Beloved husband of June. He is survived by his five nephews and their families. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Tuesday, November 25, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. A private interment will folllow. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Bio Physics and Bio Mechanics Research Fund, Cornell University Center, c/o Dr. Edmund Herrold, 525 E 68th St., New York, NY 10021.

title: Those Saturday Nights Of High-Tech Romance
description: ''I can't wait for the next right moment to come,'' sang Ric Ocasek in a song from his new solo album, ''Troublizing'' (Columbia), at Irving Plaza on Friday night. The ex-leader of the Cars might have been commenting on his return to performing after a long stint as a producer of glossy modern rock. In the late 1970's, the Cars essentially defined that genre by taking a high-tech approach to the classic pleasures of an American Saturday night: romance, sex and the party scene. Now Mr. Ocasek is back, with a crew of young musicians and one old friend, to see if his insights still hold.

title: Columbia President Faced Insurrection
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: After a long search, CUNY chooses an interim chancellor.

title: BRITISH RIVAL REJECTS A $1.8 BILLION HERCULES BID
description: Hercules Inc., a maker of specialty chemicals based in Wilmington, Del., bid $1.8 billion in cash yesterday for Allied Colloids Group P.L.C. But Allied Colloids, a British specialty chemicals maker, rejected the offer as too low. Allied Colloids shares rose 41.5 pence, or 33 percent, to 167.5 pence in London trading, well above the Hercules bid of 155 pence. Analysts said the offer could open a bidding war for the company. Hercules executives said they met with Allied Colloids twice over the weekend but failed to agree on a price. Hercules cited Allied Colloids' ''poor investment record'' and said its return on capital employed ''slumped by nearly 70 percent'' between 1988 and 1997.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fallout from Yamaichi Weighs on Markets

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, an article on Saturday about economic sanctions against Iraq misstated the year they were imposed and referred incorrectly to Iraqi threats of retaliation. The sanctions began after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990, not at the end of the Persian Gulf war in 1991. The Iraqi authorities threatened to shoot down American U-2 surveillance planes wherever they might fly over Iraq, not only over areas where the United States and other allies have forbidden Iraqi planes.

title: Hanging Out With the Mall; Stamford Youths Get Jobs, Advice and Respect
description: It is a law of nature that things end up, if at all possible, in places where they are not wanted. Ants invade picnics, popcorn slips between the teeth and teen-agers converge on shopping malls.

title: A Mandela In the Dock: Accusers' Day
description: A former anti-apartheid fighter testified today that Winnie Madikizela-Mandela had an activist killed in a feud over control of his guerrilla unit.

title: Dubious Estrogen Claims
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, EVELYN BAKER
description: NELSON-Evelyn Baker, died on Friday, November 21, age 76. Mother of Callie Angell and Alice Angell Evangelista, grandmother of Laura and Lily, sister of Susan MacKenna, Mary Carr, and the late Peggy Stewart. Married to Clifford C. Nelson for 23 years and previously to Roger Angell for 19 years. Born in Boston, MA., she lived in Mystic, CT. for the last 28 years. Elegant and proudly independent, she loved her friends, family, and home. She was a champion knitter, and avid reader and painter, and a great gardener and cook. She will be missed by us all. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Diabetes Association, 1660 Duke Street, Alexandria, VA. 22314.

title: Williams, in a Big Pipeline Deal, To Buy Mapco for $2.65 Billion
description: The Williams Companies, one of the largest natural gas pipeline companies in the nation, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Mapco Inc., the biggest United States pipeline system moving propane and butane, for $2.65 billion in stock and the assumption of $750 million in Mapco debt.

title: For a Jilted Bride, No Wedding Bell Blues
description: Nicole Contos's telephone kept ringing yesterday, but none of the callers had the voice she had first heard on a beach in Greece in August a year ago, the voice that belonged to the man she had expected to marry on Saturday evening in a Manhattan cathedral filled with friends and relatives.

title: Speeding Along With Beethoven
description: What the curious listener would not give to hear Beethoven's contemporaries playing his early G major Quartet. Performing colleagues in 1800 divided themselves between informed amateurs and part-time professionals, a far distance from ensembles-for-life like the Emerson String Quartet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, RUTH
description: GREENE-Ruth. Died on Sunday, November 23, 1997. Of Bayside, Queens, and Pembroke Pines, FL. A courageous woman who battled cancer with dignity and humornever losing touch with the friends and family who were such an important part of her life. A remarkable wife, mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, great aunt and an incredible friend to so many. An indomitable spirit who took on all of life's challenges with a commitment and enthusiasm that inspired and motivated all those around her. The very first to help everyone and the very last to give up. She will be missed by her family and friends who will still find her part of their lives every day. A New Yorker by birth and attitude, a graduate of Hunter College and Evander Childs High School.

title: TEAMSTERS AGREE TO U.S. OVERSIGHT OF THEIR FINANCES
description: The Justice Department and the teamsters' union yesterday reached an unusual agreement in which a Federal financial monitor will oversee the union's spending to prevent any improper expenditures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, SAM
description: SAMUELS-Sam. Beloved husband of Frances, father of Ron and Mark, father-in-law of Debbie, dear grandfather of Ron II, Lauren and Joseph. Attorney for over sixty years, Arbitrator and former Chief Law Assistant of the Civil Court, Kings County. Religious and Masonic services today 1:30 P.M., at Boulevard Chapel, Hewlett, New York. Shiva through Monday at the family home.

title: No Wonder the Brothers Wanted Wings
description: It's a miracle that airplanes were ever invented, considering what a dysfunctional family Orville and Wilbur Wright apparently grew up in. Actually, Arthur Giron, who tells their story in his comic drama ''Flight,'' doesn't claim that it happened exactly this way; he has just taken five real-life characters and some basic biographical facts and supposed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEPPER, STANLEY B.
description: TEPPER-Stanley B. Died suddenly Nov. 22, 1997. Beloved husband of Shirley for 56 years. Devoted father of Lesley Solomon and the late Jeffrey. Dear father-in-law of Stanley Solomon and Sandra Tepper. Cherished and adored grandfather of Philip, Barry, Jorden, Melissa and Amanda. His unconditional love and generosity will live in our hearts forever. He will be sorely missed. Graveside service Wednesday 11/26, 12:30 Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Shiva at 215 East 68 Street, NYC

title: What the Fed Can't Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WITHERS, ROSAMOND F.E.
description: WITHERS-Rosamond F.E., M.D. Quintessential consort, incomparable friend, I will keep you with me forever. Donald

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELTZER, SIDNEY
description: SELTZER-Sidney. On November 23, 1997, beloved and wonderful husband of Bailey. Outstanding father of Daniel, Linda, Elaine, and Alan. Caring brother of Esther Solomon. Cherished grandfather of Nicole and Michael. Father-inlaw of Steve. Devoted uncle. Proud owner of G & S Electric Company. Services today 12 noon ''Parkside Chapels'', Queens Boulevard and 66th Avenue, Forest Hills. We will miss him.

title: Dropped Charges Don't Hide Police Misconduct; Badge of Impunity
description: To the Editor:

title: Using New Digital Technology, MTV Adds Specialized Channels
description: Looking to appeal to an ever-changing range of musical tastes, the MTV music network plans to offer a selection of well-defined channels next year that specialize in rock, rap, country and other genres to viewers willing to pay an extra monthly charge.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL TO BUY FIVE HOTELS FOR $119 MILLION
description: The American General Hospitality Corporation said yesterday that it would buy five hotels in two separate transactions for $119 million, part of its plan to expand aggressively. The company, a real estate investment trust based in Dallas, is buying Holiday Inns in Alexandria, Va.; Annapolis, Md., and Hanover, Md., and one near O'Hare airport in Chicago. It is also buying a Ramada Plaza in Alexandria. American General had 26 hotels in 16 states with 6,757 rooms, and these acquisitions will increase its number of rooms by 19 percent. The company has enjoyed robust growth in a booming hotel market.

title: YACHT RACING; Big Waves And Wind Make For Wild Ride
description: Ten yachts, all about 64 feet in length with a maximum crew of 12, completed the grueling first leg of the Whitbread Round the World Race from Southampton, England, to Cape Town. Nine boats restarted the 31,600-nautical-mile race on Nov. 8 for a 4,700-nautical-mile voyage from Cape Town to Fremantle, Australia, and Swedish Match was the first to finish, completing the leg in 16 days on Sunday.

title: Kramnik the Tactician Is Also a Technician
description: People are taking Vladimir Kramnik for granted. All the fuss surrounding the Fontys International Tournament in Tilburg, the Netherlands, centered on how Gary Kasparov, the top-ranked player in the world, once again demonstrated his great strength and how a comparative newcomer to top-flight chess, Peter Svidler, the Russian champion, won their individual game and shared first place with him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRARI, LARRY L.
description: FERRARI-Larry L. Nov. 20, 1997 of Cinnaminson, NJ. Age 65 years. Beloved son of the late Colomba Resteghini Ferrari of Boston, MA. Dearest cousin of Edith Resteghini, Genevive Resteghini, Alfred Resteghini, Louis Resteghini, Peter Resteghini, John Resteghini, Rita Giannaocari and Ann Marie Noone. Relatives & friends are invited to his visitation on Friday, November 28, 1997 at Snover/Givnish Funeral Home, 1200 Rt 130, Cinnaminson, NJ, from 9 AM to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Saturday, Nov. 29, 1997, at 10:30 AM at the Cathedral of The Immaculate Conception, Broadway & Market Sts., Camden, NJ. Interment will be private.

title: Hindenburg Hangar Fire Burns Through Night
description: Sixty years after the Hindenburg burst into flames, killing 35 people after arriving from Frankfurt, Germany, the hangar where the giant dirigible was stored caught fire yesterday, officials said.

title: Market Place; As the accounting world shifts, conflicts are items to audit.
description: ACCOUNTING firms have adjusted their eye shades in recent years to explore a broad array of businesses. Companies can hire them to tally the books. Corporations can tap their expertise in technology to help prevent computers from crashing when the year 2000 arrives or solicit their advice about the impact of mergers on them. The firms' partners can even head a creditors committee.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's; Scratches That Disks Didn't End
description: Somebody stop all this scratching. The skittering sound of a record groove being scraped back and forth against a tonearm is not just returning to rap records and rhythm-and-blues singles like Janet Jackson's latest. It can be heard in the latest albums, singles and concerts by Portishead, Sugar Ray, Beck, Hanson, Less Than Jake, Joan Osborne, Cornershop and Primus, to name just a few rock acts, as well as Branford Marsalis, Courtney Pine and other jazz musicians.

title: East Asians Expected to Flood U.S. Market : A Tidal Wave of Exports
description: SINGAPORE  East Asia's plunging currencies and shrinking economic growth prospects will result in a new wave of exports to the United States, increasing political pressures for protectionist measures, analysts in the region and U.S. officials said Monday.

title: Computer 'Life Form' Mutates in an Evolution Experiment
description: IN an experiment that may shed light on basic evolutionary processes, researchers have created an artificial ''life form'' that dwells on a network of 150 computers worldwide and is undergoing sophisticated mutations that appear to mimic the transition from simple to more complex organisms.

title: Joyce Wethered, 96, Top Golfer of the 20's
description: Joyce Wethered, an elegant Englishwoman described by ''The Encyclopedia of Golf'' as ''the supreme woman golfer of her age, perhaps of all time,'' died last Tuesday, the day after her 96th birthday.

title: God Save the Queen? Britons Surely Would
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIBUSCH, ROSE
description: FEIBUSCH-Rose. Age 92, on November 23, 1997. Beloved mother and mother-in-law of Lucy and Leonard Dome. Loving grandmother of Jeffrey, Lauren and Eric. Great-grandmother of Garrett Benjamin. Dear grandmother-inlaw of Lauren.

title: Don't Faint. Parcells Praises Neil O'Donnell.
description: The first-place Jets are being led again by the quarterback who on Sunday proudly reminded people, ''I helped start this thing.'' Neil O'Donnell not only remains the Jets' quarterback for next Sunday's game at Buffalo, but he is a very real candidate to keep the starter's job even when Glenn Foley returns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOTTENHAM, DINAH
description: TOTTENHAM-Dinah. The Directors of the Parkinson's Disease Foundation mourn the death of their former executive director, a woman of great integrity, industry, compassion and grace. Under her leadership of eighteen years, the Foundation became transformed into a major force in the quest for the cause and cure of Parkinson's disease. This Board, and the entire Parkinson's community, have lost a champion, a conscience and a friend. Lewis P. Rowland, MD, President

title: Stew Leonard's Plans Big Store in Yonkers, Singing Cows Included
description: Stew Leonard's, the carnival-style dairy store in Connecticut, isn't letting a tussle with the law interfere with its success.

title: Enter Another Dazzling Mezzo
description: Eve Queler, whose Opera Orchestra of New York has given us the chance to hear so many neglected works, also has a notable record of introducing important artists to the city. She accomplished both again on Sunday night at Carnegie Hall with a concert performance of Rossini's ''Tancredi,'' which seldom turns up in opera houses, and in which she presented a Bulgarian-born mezzo-soprano, Vesselina Kasarova, in her New York debut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRACE, MARY JULIA
description: GRACE-Mary Julia. Devoted wife of the late Edward J. Loving mother of Margaret White, Msgr James Grace, Mary D'Alessandro, Winifred Grace, Susan Woolsey and Edward D. Grace. Also survived by 13 grandchildren and seven great grandchildren. Dear sister of the late Sr. Margaret Dunn, D.W. Reposing at Cecere Funeral Homes, 290 Post Avenue, Westbury, New York. Mass Wednesday 12:30PM St. Edward the Confessor RC Church, Syosset, New York.

title: U.S. Says Iraq Spied on Inspectors To Know When to Hide Weapons
description: Iraqi intelligence agents successfully spied on United Nations weapons inspectors this year and last, learning in advance of the team's targets and moving swiftly to hide suspected weapons caches, United States military and intelligence officials said today.

title: On My Mind; Time for Repairs
description: President Clinton and the people he chose to help him steer American foreign policy have steered it straight into a collision that left it a near-wreck.

title: BMW to Review Parts of Account
description: BMW of North America said yesterday that it had placed in review three large portions of its account, involving national media planning and buying and regional dealer associations in the Midwest and West.

title: Dispute at Justice Dept. Over Clinton Inquiry Comes Into Sharper Focus
description: Their argument sums up a problem at the heart of the campaign finance case. The F.B.I. Director, Louis J. Freeh, wants an outside prosecutor to investigate the tangle of shadowy events and powerful politicians that surround the immediate issue of whether President Clinton illegally made a fund-raising call from the wrong phone at the White House.

title: Japan Stocks Fall in Wake Of Brokerage Firm's Failure
description: Stocks tumbled here today, in the Tokyo's market first response to the failure of the Yamaichi Securities Company, the nation's oldest and fourth-largest brokerage firm.

title: Yankees Showing Interest In the Free Agent Fletcher
description: Even as George Steinbrenner continued to delay a possible offer to Brady Anderson, who might soon vanish from the free agent market, and failed to continue discussions with the Mariners about Randy Johnson, the agent for catcher Darrin Fletcher said the Yankees have serious interest in his client and could make an offer soon.

title: Monsanto's Cotton Seed
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo's Testimony Sought in Sharpton Slander Case
description: One of the defense lawyers in the defamation lawsuit against three advisers of Tawana Brawley said today that he planned to call former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and former State Attorney General Robert Abrams to the witness stand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, NORMAN M.
description: MORRIS-Norman M., 99. In his sleep on November 24. Beloved husband of the late Adele (nee Groden) for sixty years. Devoted father of Arline and Marvin Lubin and Robert and Sandi Morris. Proud grandfather of Kenneth Lubin, Wendy and Paul Aglietti, Carol and Michael Hundert, Lee and Merry Morris, David and Eta Morris, Richard Morris, Jeffrey and Lauren Morris and Deborah Morris and adored by eleven great grandchildren. Devoted brother to Edward and the late Rose and the late Bessie. Services 12:30 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELZNICK, DAVID J.
description: SELZNICK-David J. Beloved husband of Lillian Kaltman. Loving brother-in-law, uncle and great uncle. Service Tuesday 12 noon, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Sharp Spending Rise In the 1996 Elections
description: The 1996 Federal election campaigns accounted for $2.2 billion in spending, an increase of more than 37 percent from the $1.6 billion in 1992, a new study has found. The increase made the elections the most expensive in history. That was reflected in the rise in the median cost of a House race to $559,807 and a Senate race to $3.5 million. That was up from $348,287 for a House race in 1994 and $2.7 million for a Senate race.

title: Towns Near Pequot Casino Object to Annexation Plan
description: If the Mashantucket Pequot Indians, the owners of the hugely profitable Foxwoods Resort Casino, are allowed to incorporate 165 acres of land in eastern Connecticut into their reservation, it will be a legal green light for the tribe to take over vast swaths of neighboring towns, the State Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, argued today in Federal District Court.

title: Study Traces Key Role Of Caribbean Currents In Shaping Reefs' Life
description: SCIENTISTS have long known that the ocean's swirling currents can swiftly carry the young of fish, corals and other creatures from place to place in the sea. Now a study in the current issue of the journal Science has revealed the importance of those currents in conserving the world's beleaguered coral reefs.

title: Nabisco Offers to Buy $1.23 Billion in Notes
description: The Nabisco Holdings Corporation offered today to purchase $1.23 billion of Nabisco Inc. notes due in 1999 and 2000, as it seeks to secure lower interest rates on its debt.
