title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIES, PATRICIA (65)
description: DAVIES-Patricia (65). Of NYC and Nantucket, passed away Sunday, November 23. She was born in Montreal and is survived by two brothers: John A. and Gerald T. and their families. A reception for family and friends, Friday evening at her Nantucket home.

title: BOLIDEN IS TURNED DOWN IN OFFER FOR WESTMIN RESOURCES
description: Westmin Resources Ltd. of Vancouver, British Columbia, said yesterday that it had rejected an unsolicited offer of almost $809 million (Canadian) in stock and assumed debt from Boliden Ltd. because the price was too low. Boliden offered $5.40 a share and said it would assume $228 million of long-term debt. The deal was valued at $575 million (United States). It would let Boliden, which is based in Toronto and is 44.9 percent-owned by Trelleborg A.B. of Sweden, gain a foothold in South America through Westmin's Lomas Bayas copper mine in Chile. Westmin shares jumped $2.07, to $6.05, on the Toronto Stock Exchange, and Boliden was unchanged at $4.85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSON, ALBERT
description: RUBINSON-Albert. Age 91, of Belle Harbor, Queens. Husband of the late Martha; brother of Dr. Solomon Rubinson of Long Beach, LI; father of Ellen R. Zamore; grandfather of Dr. Phillip D. Zamore of Charlestown, MA., and Rabbi Mary Lande Zamore of Westfield, NJ; great grandfather of Hannah Hillis Zamore of Charlestown, MA. Graveside services Beth Moses Cemetery, Pine Lawn, Long Island, on Tuesday at 1 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the West End Temple, Neponsit, NY, 11694 or a charity of your choice in his memory will be appreciated. The traditional Shiva Period will be observed at his daughter's home.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DOUGHERTY, JAMES
description: DOUGHERTY-James. Happy birthday. 11/25/40 - 12/1/95 Tish

title: Postal Compost
description: HERE'S how to get rid of junk mail: shred thoroughly, pour in some stale beer or soda, then mix with wood chips, chopped vegetable matter and animal manure. Wait about three or four months, then feed it to the tomatoes.

title: Sampson's Lads Still His Lads
description: The United States Soccer Federation will exercise its option and keep Steve Sampson as coach of the national team for the World Cup in France next summer. A person within the sport's governing body in this country said yesterday that Sampson would be officially named coach of the United States a day or two before the World Cup draw in France on Dec. 4. One of the key factors that led to the decision to retain Sampson, who came up through the college ranks, was his understanding of his players.

title: F.C.C. to Open Phone Market To Foreigners
description: Federal regulators plan to take a major step today to open America's $200 billion telecommunications market to foreign competition, hoping to lower international calling rates for consumers and bolster opportunities for American communications companies elsewhere in the world.

title: Taking Shorter Deal, Olerud Signs With Mets
description: The phone rang yesterday afternoon in the Arizona home of Tom Robson, the Mets' hitting coach. The soft, polite voice on the other end belonged to John Olerud.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTHER, PAULETTE ROSSELET
description: WALTHER-Paulette Rosselet. On November 21, 1997. Devoted mother of Bruno, Ronda and Karen. Daughter of the late Nelly Flint. Grandmother of Emily, Harold and Brooke. Will be remembered for her warm smile and compassionate, giving nature. We love you always.

title: Housing Laws Broken, Says U.S. in Suits
description: Posing as prospective renters or condominium buyers, handicapped people in wheelchairs went to 49 housing developments under construction in the Chicago area.

title: Patterns
description: Margiela's New Line

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: CONNECTICUT ; A Power Plant Chief Submits His Resignation
description: The chief of nuclear operations at Northeast Utilities' Millstone Station has resigned after less than a year, the utility announced yesterday. Neil S. Carns, who started working with the company in February, will leave his post as chief of Millstone Station on Dec. 1.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Dropped Charges Don't Hide Police Misconduct
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHNEIDER TURNS DOWN A TAKEOVER BID FROM MAPLE LEAF
description: The Schneider Corporation said yesterday that it had rejected a takeover bid by Maple Leaf Foods Inc. of $19 (Canadian) a share. It called the bid inadequate. The Schneider family, which controls 75 percent of the common shares, as well as the company's directors and senior officers, do not plan to tender their shares, the company said. But the family said it would consider a more financially attractive offer. Maple Leaf Foods, which is based in Toronto, is a food processor with 1996 sales of $3.21 billion (Canadian), or $2.26 billion (United States). Schneider is a meat processor based in Kitchener, Ontario. It had sales of $418.3 million (Canadian), or $294.9 million (United States), for the first six months of 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATSON, FRANCIS P.
description: MATSON-Francis P. Beloved husband of Rita Knoblock, dear father of Lenore of Coral Gables, FL., and Howard of Westport, CT. Devoted grandfather of Lewis, Kenneth and Lesley. Dear brother of Stanley. Contributions in his memory to Westport Public Library, Westport, CT. 06880.

title: Personal Health; Making Sense of Latest Twist on Fat in the Diet
description: FOR a generation, Americans have been advised to curtail the fat in their diets to save their hearts. Now the findings of a large long-term study seem to suggest that it is not how much fat is eaten but what kinds of fat that make the real difference to heart health.

title: Emissions Testing Starts, But Few Cars Fail
description: The state began conducting voluntary auto emissions tests under toughened standards yesterday, with far fewer cars than expected failing the test, officials said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the killing of an Israeli student in East Jerusalem included a garbled sentence. It should have read, ''Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met with several Cabinet ministers and security officials and announced later that a police post would be set up near the site of the shooting and that more security forces would be sent to the Old City.''

title: A New Owner To Take Over An Old Classic
description: Jerry I. Speyer, an owner of Rockefeller Center, emerged yesterday as the winning bidder for another international landmark -- the Chrysler Building, the beautiful Art Deco skyscraper that set off a fierce bidding war this year despite its long and troubled history.

title: Turning a Page on Cuba
description: No individual had more influence over United States policies toward Cuba over the past two decades than Jorge Mas Canosa, who died Sunday. Mr. Mas, who fled to Miami in 1960, the year after Fidel Castro seized power, founded the Cuban-American National Foundation and turned it into the most powerful lobbying organization on Cuban issues in Washington. The passing years never eroded his belief that Cuba's Communist dictatorship was ripe for overthrow. That dubious assumption drove his campaigns for successive tightenings of Washington's economic embargo on Cuba, culminating in the regrettable Helms-Burton law of 1996.

title: Gasoline Climbs on Forecast Of Heavy Holiday Traveling
description: Gasoline futures prices jumped almost 2 percent yesterday amid forecasts for record highway travel during the Thanksgiving holiday week as retail gas prices hover close to their lowest levels this year.

title: So She Wasn't So Placid, After All
description: JANE AUSTEN

title: Study Hails Inner Heat For Victims of Icy Cold
description: EVEN though they may look dead, with no heartbeat or breathing, their skin blue with cold, people suffering from severe hypothermia, or low body temperature, can sometimes be revived and recover fully.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUCKMAN, DAVID
description: DRUCKMAN-David. New York Metro Chapter of the American Society of Interior Designers mourns with sorrow the passing of David Druckman, a man of vision. His contributions furthering the design industry are well noted. A kind, dear friend of the Chapter, he will be missed. Terry Finkel, ASID, Pres, The Board and Members of ASID NY Metro

title: HOCKEY: For Leetch, A Reminder Of Glory Days; Canucks' Familiar Faces Greet Struggling Captain
description: When Brian Leetch plays for the Rangers tonight against the Vancouver Canucks at Madison Square Garden, he will see Mike Keenan behind the visiting bench and Mark Messier on the other side of the ice. Keenan coached the Rangers in 1993-94 when Leetch won the Conn Smythe trophy as the most valuable player in the Stanley Cup playoffs and the Rangers won their only post-season championship since 1940.

title: Dubious Estrogen Claims
description: To the Editor:

title: A Gantlet We Need
description: Congress has again left Washington with several of the President's nominees hanging in limbo. The political pundits profess outrage; most everyone else has little idea who the dangling nominees are, and could care less. What does this say about American politics? Probably nothing more than that it is highly partisan and that squabbling over nominees, whatever the outcome, is not particularly newsworthy.

title: Outlet Mall Deal
description: Burnham Pacific Properties Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell retail space in Gilroy, Calif., to Horizon Group Inc. for $38.5 million. Burnham, based in San Diego, is a real estate investment trust that owns and leases commercial real estate in California. Horizon, based in Norton Shores, Mich., owns factory outlet malls. The acquisition includes the 203,000-square-foot Pacific West Outlet Center.

title: No Excuse for Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: In Hemingway's Attic, Another Novelist Toils
description: It would be tough to pick the lowest point in William Elliott Hazelgrove's writing career.

title: Sports of The Times; Someday, No. 11 Is Sure To Be Retired
description: SOMEDAY, not tonight, Mark Messier will return to Madison Square Garden and everyone who works there will be happy to see him. The Rangers will roll a red carpet over the smooth ice. They will turn out the lights and show emotional video clips. They will give him a rocker, golf clubs, maybe a new car.

title: Observer; The El Nino Connection
description: The White House still refuses to disclose its role in the growing El Nino scandal. President Clinton's repeated efforts to laugh it off betray an alarming insensitivity toward millions of Americans for whom El Nino is no laughing matter.

title: Metro Business; Hotel Beverly Is Sold To Manhattan East
description: Manhattan East Suite Hotels, a company with nine New York City hotels, said yesterday that it had acquired the Hotel Beverly at 125 East 50th Street, at the corner of Lexington Avenue. Although terms of the transaction were not disclosed, real estate sources said the company had paid $41 million for the hotel to the Highgate Corporation, a Dallas investment company, which had acquired it for $38 million in September from a company based in Phoenix.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CANNON, VICTOR JR.
description: CANNON-Victor Jr. November 15, 1991. Always remembered. Ellen and David

title: Tokyo Squirms Over Questions About Hidden Losses at Yamaichi
description: The collapse of the Yamaichi Securities Company was not a particular shock in Japan, where predictions had been building for months that the nation's oldest brokerage firm, saddled by debts and mismanagement, would go out of business.

title: Entering U.S. Broadcasting, Sony Buys Telemundo Stake
description: In its first thrust into television broadcasting in the United States, the Sony Corporation will take control of programming for the Telemundo Group Inc., the nation's second-largest Spanish-language network.

title: PRESIDENT PRESSES ASIANS AT SUMMIT ON FISCAL TURMOIL
description: A day after describing the spreading economic turmoil in Asia as a mere glitch, President Clinton met today with leaders of the region's largest countries to deliver a tougher message, telling them that while the United States and international organizations could help, they would have to take painful steps on their own to recover.

title: How Will Changes Affect Customers?
description: The plan for a new area code in Manhattan has raised questions among telephone customers. Here are some answers.

title: God Save the Queen? Britons Surely Would
description: To the Editor:

title: A Victorian Skinflint Who's Liberal at Heart
description: In some parts of this county and abroad, Ebenezer Scrooge, as played by Roddy McDowall in this year's version of ''A Christmas Carol'' at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, could get himself elected to high office.

title: Coming Soon: Michael Jordan's Steakhouse
description: Michael Jordan has lent his name and fame to everything from cereal to cologne to sneakers. Now, the basketball and business phenomenon from Chicago is bestowing the Jordan moniker on a strictly New York enterprise -- a steakhouse in Grand Central Terminal.

title: In Disappearance Case, Landlord's Vehicle Is Found
description: The police investigating the disappearances of a Manhattan couple and their landlord have found the truck the landlord had been driving in when he was last seen but said yesterday that they were stopped from searching the vehicle by the man's family, who have offered little cooperation in the case.

title: Sewage Plant To Be Fixed Without Leak
description: New York City officials announced yesterday that they had developed a plan to repair valves in a Manhattan sewage pumping station without dumping 560 million gallons of raw sewage into New York Harbor, avoiding a confrontation with New Jersey officials who had fiercely opposed the release in February.

title: People
description: * Chris D'Rozario was named to the new position of senior partner and group creative director at J. Walter Thompson New York, part of the WPP Group. He had been creative account director at Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG, New York, part of Havas Advertising. Also at Thompson New York, Marie Arteca was named to the new position of senior partner and creative manager. She had been an executive recruiter at Susan Friedman Ltd., New York.

title: Doctor's White Coat Fits All: Jekyll, Kildare, Medicine Man
description: AS totems go, a doctor's white coat is a real bargain. For $22.95, anyone can pick up a very nice wrinkle-resistant cotton-poly version, with three pockets and a dignified belt in the back. For just a little extra, you can have your name embroidered in tremulous red script over the breast.

title: Mexican Partner For Hicks, Muse
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., the Dallas-based investment firm, said today that it had set up a partnership in which a Mexican company would oversee its Mexican investments and help it acquire companies there.

title: CYPRESS GROUP TO BUY GENERAL HOST FOR $320 MILLION
description: Cypress Group said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the General Host Corporation, a specialty-store operator, for about $320 million, including an unspecified amount of assumed debt. Under the agreement, Cypress will pay $5.50 for each of General Host's shares outstanding. The stock jumped $1.875 a share yesterday, or 54 percent, to $5.3125. Cypress, based in New York, is a closely held investment firm that is led by James Stern and other former top executives of Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc.'s buyout group. General Host, based in Stamford, Conn., operates 258 garden-products stores in 15 states under the name Frank's Nursery and Crafts Inc.

title: Investment Firm Buys Siemens Wholesale Unit
description: Siemens A.G., Germany's largest electronics and engineering company, said yesterday that it had sold its electronics wholesale division to Industri Kapital, a European investment company, for an undisclosed amount. The unit, Elektrogrosshandel G.m.b.H., had sales of 1.7 billion marks ($980 million) in the year that ended on Sept. 30. The Nuremberg-based operation employs 2,100 people. Siemens has been selling assets recently to focus on its core businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, GEORGE MACDONALD, JR.
description: PARKER-George MacDonald, Jr. On Saturday, November 22, 1997, at age 61 of prostate cancer. Of Smith's Parish, Bermuda. A graduate of Deerfield Academy, Yale University 1958, and Harvard Business School 1962. He served as a Lieutenant (junior grade) in the U.S. Navy from 1958 to 1960. After working at Booz Allen Hamilton and Lehman Brothers, in 1977 he became President and Director of General Atlantic Group, Ltd and Director of Duty Free Shoppers Group, Ltd. He was a director of Fiduciary Trust Company International. As a trustee of the Cancer Research Institute, his leadership and vision led to the creation of the Institute's Prostate Cancer Initiative. He was a trustee of Deerfield Academy and the Bermuda Marine Biology Station for Research. He is survived by his wife, Susan Bissell Parker, his children Angus MacDonald Parker and Julia duPont Parker, and his brother, Treadway Parker. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be held in Bermuda during January 1998. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Cancer Research Institute to establish the George M. Parker Memorial Program for Prostate Cancer, 681 5th Ave., NY NY 10022. 212-688-7515.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAND, ALFRED
description: RAND-Alfred. Age 89, November 24, 1997. Beloved husband of Rita Lewis Rand and loving father of Dr. Kenneth Rand, and devoted stepfather of Sara Stone and Laura Ross, and adoring grandfather of Erik, Colin, Betsy-Gail, Andrea, Ralph, Elizabeth, and David, and great grandfather of Jamie and Charlie. Services are on Tuesday, November 25, at Park Avenue Synagogue. In lieu of flowers, contributions to his memory may be made to The New York Service For Handicapped.

title: Q&A
description: Spelling Out a Gene

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHENSON, RABBI CHAIM
description: COHENSON-Rabbi Chaim. The Board of Jewish Education of Greater New York and its Staff Organization record with profound sorrow the death of Rabbi Chaim Cohenson. Rabbi Cohenson was a veteran Jewish educator, highly respected and loved by his colleagues and his students. May his entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. David Mann, Executive VP Philip Schatten, President Arlene Spiller, Chair, Staff Org.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATATIA, JOSEPH V.
description: MATATIA-Joseph V. The Executive Committee and Central Council of the Sephardic Jewish Brotherhood of America sincerely mourn the passing of our dear friend and longtime volunteer, Joseph V. Matatia. His dedication, loyalty, and service to our organization spanned more than forty years. His service as President, Chairman of our Funds for the Needy, member of the Scholarship Committee, Constitution Committee, and Executive Committee contributed in large measure to the success of the Brotherhood. Joe will be deeply missed by all of us who knew him and worked with him. We express our most heartfelt condolences to his wife and children, family and friends. Bernard Ouziel, President Sephardic Jewish Brotherhood of America, Inc.

title: MELLON BANK TO ACQUIRE UNITED BANKSHARES OF FLORIDA
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire United Bankshares Inc., a closely held banking company in Florida, for an undisclosed amount of cash and stock. United Bankshares, which is based in Miami, has 11 branches in South Florida and more than $830 million in assets. Mellon, based in Pittsburgh, had banking assets of $43.4 billion as of Sept. 30. United Bankshares will operate as a separate entity under the name Mellon United National Bank. No job cuts are expected among United's 310 employees, Mellon said. United Bankshares is not related to United Bankshares Inc. of Charleston, W. Va., a publicly traded company.

title: James R. Mellow Dies at 71; Author of Literary Biographies
description: James R. Mellow, a distinguished critic and author who wrote a trilogy of biographies about writers of the Lost Generation, died on Saturday at his home in Rockport, Mass. He was 71.

title: Foster Children Are Still Sleeping In City Offices
description: Four months after child welfare officials promised to develop a plan to find homes for foster children housed overnight in municipal offices, hundreds of children still sleep in the city's emergency placement center and officials continue to search for available homes.

title: Burial at Arlington
description: To the Editor:

title: Sarajevo Journal; In Bosnia's Schools, 3 Ways Never to Learn From History
description: On June 28, 1914, Gavrilo Princip shot and killed Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria in a Sarajevo street, an act that set off World War I. So what does that make him in Bosnia?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BIRNBAUM, JACK
description: BIRNBAUM-Jack. January 8, 1919-November 25, 1987. Every day for ten years you've been sitting on my left shoulder, guiding me through life. Your wisdom endures. You left us all with a precious legacy, very full hearts.

title: Seven Works of Bach in One Gulp
description: Some things are better left to the imagination.

title: Dow Falls 113.15 Amid Concerns Over Asian Turmoil
description: The tug-of-war continued in the stock market yesterday, with those worried about the economic fallout from Asia's financial turmoil winning this round.

title: Wild Turkeys Return To American Fields
description: BEN FRANKLIN might have had the right idea when he suggested that the turkey, not the bald eagle, should have been selected to symbolize America. What animal could better represent Americans than the wild turkey -- resistant to extermination, hard to intimidate, highly adaptable, impressionable, sociable and, yes, smart?

title: Stuck in Traffic? Consult a Physicist
description: HATEFUL though they are to most people, traffic jams have fascinated some of the finest scientific minds of the 20th century, who see in them similarities to the freezing of water, the triggering of avalanches, the formation of galaxies and the advent of life itself.

title: On the Court and Off, Nets Are All Business
description: There is something inevitable about the Nets. Some might argue that they have been jinxed ever since they sold off Julius Erving two decades ago to get into the league.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANN, LOIS H.
description: DANN-Lois H. November 19, 1997. Mother of Tyler and Harvey Dann & Mary Claus. Memorial Service Saturday, November 29 at 10:30 AM, Holy Trinity Church, Coulter Ave, Pawling. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Children's Home, 91 Fulton St, Poughkeepsie, New York 12601, Holy Trinity Church, Pawling, NY or Hospice of Dutchess County, 70 S. Hamilton Street, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601.

title: Children of Working Poor Are Day Care's Forgotten
description: At 5 the other morning, Marlene Garrett had her 11-month-old baby in her arms and was guiding her other two sleep-dazed children, ages 3 and 4, through the darkness to the baby sitter's.

title: Dropped Charges Don't Hide Police Misconduct; Skeptics Kept Off Juries
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIXON, FRANCIS COOK
description: DIXON-Francis Cook. Age 76, on November 22. Beloved husband of Constance, brother of Madeleine Dixon Seaman, father to Christopher, Jenny and Cynthia, grandfather to Rachel, Tyler and Jessica. As you pass down life's highways, don't forget to smell the flowers. None of us will. Services 11 A.M., Tuesday, November 25, Calvary Church, Stonington, CT. All donations to Calvary Church, Stonington.

title: Glimmers of the Future on Display
description: THE annual fall Comdex trade show always offers a good look at computing's near future, but once in a while it provides glimmers of something more. Several offerings at this year's event hinted that computer users may be closer to interacting differently with their machines. One fine day, people may be talking to their computers more and swearing at them less and using familiar gestures instead of mouse clicks to indicate their intentions.

title: Figures Show a Decrease In Serious Urban Crime
description: Serious crime in both Newark and Paterson fell 13 percent during the first 6 months of the year, a decline three times as steep as the 4 percent drop experienced nationally for the same period, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday. Serious crime includes murder, rape, assault and several other violent or property crimes.

title: STARWOOD TO BUY CALIFORNIA RESORT FOR $118 MILLION
description: Starwood Lodging Trust agreed yesterday to buy the Westin Mission Hills Resort in Rancho Mirage, Calif., from the Takanaka Corporation of Japan for about $118 million. The deal includes the 512-room resort, two 18-hole golf courses, a health spa, seven lighted tennis courts, two full-service restaurants and lounges, and 75,000 square feet of function space. Westin Hotels and Resorts will continue to manage the hotel. Takanaka will remain a minority partner in the property. Starwood, which is based in Phoenix, is a real estate investment trust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRESDALE, DAVID, MD.
description: DRESDALE-David, MD. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center records with sorrow the death of Dr. David Dresdale. Dr. Dresdale was affiliated with Maimonides Medical Center in the Department of Cardiology for about 50 years. He was the Founder of the Cardio Catheterization Laboratory. He was President of the Medical Staff in 1971-1972. He will be missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his family. Warren Wexelman, MD. Pres. Jacob Shani, MD. Pres. Elect David Feldman, MD. Secy. Sal DeGliuomini, MD. Treas.

title: Rose Bowl Announcers Don't Need a Program to Tell the Players
description: When Michigan plays Washington State in the Rose Bowl on Jan. 1, there will be two unusual connections in ABC's broadcast booth. The first is between Bob Griese and his son, Brian, the Wolverines' quarterback, a familial tie that has been chronicled in part for how the father would analyze the son.

title: With the Movements of Generations, Human and Other
description: Mary Seidman and Dancers offered two ambitious works on Thursday night at St. Mark's Church. But Ms. Seidman's choreography was seldom as imposing as her ideas.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: 2 Men Are Accused Of Raping Teen-Ager
description: A 14-year-old girl was raped by two men Friday, prosecutors said, after she met at least one of them at a mall in Paramus earlier in the week. James Raymonette, 19, and Gerry Ridore, 18, both of New City, N.Y., forced the girl to have sex with them at her house in Ridgewood, said Ike Gavzy, an assistant Bergen County prosecutor.

title: Clue Discovered to Possible Strategy To Block Mad Cow Disease in Brain
description: RESEARCHERS in Brazil and Germany say they have found receptors on the surface of brain cells that may allow infectious agents called prions to enter the cells.

title: ON PRO FOOTBALL ; No Satisfaction Found On Frustrating Night
description: Spinning your wheels for five quarters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, YVONNE B.
description: MILLS-Yvonne B. A Palm Beach, FL, resident, died November 22, 1997, at the age of 94. Predeceased by her husband, Harry C. Mills, she is survived by two daughters, Isabelle Harbolick of Vienna, VA, and Marie-Louise Mills of Lucca, Italy; two sons Arthur B. Kelly of Boca Raton, FL, and Peter E. Kelly of West Chester, OH. Funeral Mass 11 AM, November 26, at St. Edward Catholic Church, Palm Beach, FL. Entombment service 9 AM, November 28, at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: British Aerospace Agrees To Be a Boeing Supplier
description: British Aerospace P.L.C., one of four partners in the European consortium Airbus Industrie, said yesterday that it would supply wing parts for the Boeing Company's 737 jetliner, in a pact that puts British Aerospace in the unusual position of building parts for a rival.

title: Taliban Pledge to Rid Afghan Province of Opium Poppies
description: Leaders of the Taliban, the rigorously Islamic movement that controls most of Afghanistan, have agreed to uproot new poppy crops in part of the country as soon as they appear and to destroy any heroin laboratories in the country.

title: F.B.I. Had Sought Suspect in the Killing
description: F.B.I. agents in Boston began searching in May for the ex-convict who the police say killed Sgt. Patrick King on Thursday in a Chinese restaurant in Long Branch, N.J., but never found him, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, GERTRUDE I.
description: WEINTRAUB-Gertrude I., 91. Passed away November 21, 1997. Survived by daughter Joan Helfgott, sisters Mildred Morganstern, Frances Shore, Lilly Grebanier, brother Morton Greene, grandchildren Sara, Eve and Eric. Graveside services were held at 1PM, Monday, November 24, 1997, Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: Executive Changes
description: BASE TEN SYSTEMS INC., Trenton, named Thomas E. Gardner president and chief executive and said that before the end of the year he would become co-chairman with Alexander M. Adelson, the current vice chairman. The current chairman, Myles M. Kranzler, is retiring.

title: In the Land Of Denial, Delay Is Boss
description: THE board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority held its monthly meeting yesterday, a chance to see if the powers there are as good at bringing down fares as they are at taking down bus ads City Hall doesn't like.

title: De La Hoya Says Change in Trainers Won't Hurt
description: Oscar De La Hoya, the World Boxing Council welterweight champion, said yesterday that while he had been reluctant to have Emanuel Steward dismissed as his chief trainer last week, he did not think the move would hurt him in his title fight against Wilfredo Rivera at Caesars Palace in Atlantic City on Dec. 6.

title: CUNY Trustees Choose A Temporary Chancellor
description: After a two-month search, the trustees of the City University of New York turned last night to a quiet, 58-year-old historian who is the provost at Brooklyn College as their choice for interim chancellor.

title: Dell Computer's Earnings Exceed Analysts' Estimates
description: The Dell Computer Corporation reported third-quarter earnings yesterday that exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates by four cents, as the company continued to grow at more than three times the industry rate during the quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, SAMUEL
description: JACOBS-Samuel. On November 19. Of Lauderhill, FL, formerly of Cranston, R.I.; born NYC. Beloved husband of Ann. Loving father of Lynn of Manhattan, and Robert of Scarsdale, NY. Adored grandfather of Rand, Mason, Neal and Lea. Private interment. Donations to the American Heart Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRK, GRAYSON L.
description: KIRK-Grayson L. The Officers, Directors and Staff of the Tinker Foundation express their profound sorrow on the passing of Dr. Kirk. As an internationalist and scholar, he contributed mightily to the organization of the Security Council at the United Nations, the growth and expansion of Columbia University and to the development of the Tinker Foundationamong numerous institutions and peoples his creativity, generosity and intellectual vigor touched in his distinguished life. Dr. Kirk was Vice President and a Director of the Tinker Foundation for twentyeight years, retiring as Director Emeritus in 1994. All of us at the Tinker Foundation express our profound sympathy to his son, John, and family.

title: Prices Lower For Treasury Securities
description: Treasury prices ended lower yesterday, dragged down by concerns over how Japanese investors will react to the failure of Yamaichi Securities.

title: Thunder Over Asia
description: As President Clinton meets with leaders of the Asia-Pacific rim in Vancouver this week, financial turmoil threatens the Asian economic ''miracle'' on which their partnership is based. The paradox of the summit meeting, however, is that the bailouts in Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea, not to mention the failure of some big banks and securities firms in Japan, are driving home lessons of fiscal discipline better than the Clinton Administration ever could. The turbulence might tempt some countries to back away from harsh measures, but they should realize that the markets are demanding long-postponed moves to open financial systems to scrutiny and competition, lower trade barriers and reduce government economic regulation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, MILTON
description: FRIEDMAN-Milton age 84 of Fairlawn. Husband of the late Esther Friedman. He was a graduate of CCNY and a retired inspector for the federal government. Served in W.W. II in the Navy, the Pacific Theater. Surviving, a sister Evelyn Linker. Services 10:30 AM, today, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150, Rte 4, Paramus, N.J.

title: Guaranty to Buy An Auto Insurer
description: The Guaranty National Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire the nonstandard automobile-insurance business of Strickland Insurance Group Inc. for $42.6 million.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EARL SPENCER, who made a profound impression around the world with his impassioned eulogy for his sister, Diana, Princess of Wales, is facing marital problems in South Africa, according to The Associated Press.

title: Critic of China, Now in U.S., Is Assailed By a Colleague
description: Wei Jingsheng, China's most famous democracy advocate, may still be celebrating his first taste of freedom in the United States, but back in Beijing he has already come under attack from fellow dissidents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIN, ALAN MICHAEL
description: WEIN-Alan Michael. Loving son, devoted brother, loyal family member, friend and distinguished educator. Beloved by everyone, he will be terribly missed.

title: Bulldogs Are Quite A Surprise
description: The Bulldogs have surprised everyone but their coach, Tim Taylor, by winning six of their first seven games and climbing over Cornell to gain first place in the ECAC. Last season's team, with much the same personnel, finished 10th and averaged only 2.8 goals in 32 games, of which it won just 10.

title: Washington Talk; For New Jersey Lawmaker, a Victory on Abortion
description: Every year, Representative Christopher H. Smith waits in the wings and, just as Congress is ripping toward the finish line, he forces colleagues to revisit the explosive question of abortion.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK CITY ; Officials Are Dismissed From Crown Heights Suit
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn dismissed a lawsuit yesterday that sought to hold former Mayor David N. Dinkins and former Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown personally liable for the Crown Heights violence of 1991.

title: Paradox and the Sin of Poverty
description: A guarded tip to Melissa Errico cultists: if you are wasting away from want of a fresh infusion of Ms. Errico's silver soprano, you can get a very quick fix of it just before intermission of the Irish Repertory Theater's production of ''Major Barbara.'' At that point, Ms. Errico, in the title role of George Bernard Shaw's double-talking look at the sin of poverty, leads the cast in a sprightly (and interpolated) rendition of ''Onward, Christian Soldiers.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARDWICK, CRONLEY E.
description: HARDWICK-Cronley E. Survived by wife Dolores, nine children and six grandchildren. Father, friend, bird lover, an inspiration to us all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REYMAN, LORRAINE
description: REYMAN-Lorraine. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Devoted mother of Elaine and Robert Fier, Stuart and Meryl Reyman. Cherished Nana of Steven and Susan Fier, Debbie Fier, Philip and Froma Fier, and Edward and Jonathan Reyman. Loving Gigi of Keith, Joanna, Reyna, Jordan and Sofie. Graveside service is on Tuesday, at 11 A.M., at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. For additional information call I.J. Morris, Inc. 1-800-624-8282.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUBERGER, FRANKLIN, JR. (CHICK)
description: NEUBERGER - Franklin, Jr. (Chick). Died peacefully November 17, 1997, at Rancho Bernardo, San Diego, California, his home for the past ten years, joining his wife, Janet, deceased three years prior, and daughter, Jill, whose passing while in her teens and whose memory stayed with Chick throughout his life. His youth was spent in Chicago, and his career with Chicago's leading mail order house, was interrupted by his service in the United States Army during World War II. He and Janet met in the Pacific theatre while he was serving as a lieutenant and she as a Red Cross worker. Postwar he formed and operated a highly specialized and successful printing company for thirty years in New York, Speedolite Corp. His residences in New York during that time were Roslyn, Southhold and Manhattan, followed by the move to California. Prior to his passing, and afterwards provided for, was his substantial support to the Children's Hospital in San Diego in memory of his daughter, Jill. Chick was truly a man for all seasons, he was an active participant in life, not only an observer. From family to golf to travel to business, and on and on. He enjoyed it all and lived it all. A wonderful man and true friend.

title: Delta Workers Are Given Reprieve From Order to Leave U.S.
description: Twenty-eight Delta Air Lines flight attendants who were told last week to return to Poland because their visas had been issued by mistake can stay in New York while the airline appeals the decision, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOTZ, R. JAMES, JR.
description: LOTZ-R. James, Jr. 74. Saturday, November 22. Born in Reading, PA. Descendant of Col. Nicholas Lotz of the Revolutionary Army. Chairman and Cofounder, International Management Advisors, Inc. Survived by his wife, Constance Klages Lotz, his daughter, Brenda Davidson, his son, Roy James Lotz, III, and grandchildren Nicholas, Cecelia and Ian. Memorial services today, 12:30, Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church (at 55th Street).

title: Astronauts Make a Good Grab And Bring Satellite Back In
description: Two astronauts aboard the space shuttle Columbia used their hands to grab the errant Spartan astronomy satellite yesterday after the two craft came together 170 miles above Earth.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Study Casts Doubt On Wisdon Of Mandatory Terms for Drugs
description: Among drug offenders sentenced to long, mandatory terms in Massachusetts state prisons, nearly half have no record of violent crime, according to a study of the state's prison population released today.

title: At Funeral, Slain Officer Is Mourned by Thousands
description: The winds off the Atlantic Ocean blew cold and hard this morning, but they barely stirred the flowers carried in the open bed of a hearse crawling down Ocean Avenue. Thousands of police officers, standing five deep along the road, blocked the gusts in small tribute to a man murdered simply for wearing police blue.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Wednesday describing genetically altered crops misspelled the name of a developer of a soybean strain and omitted the company from a list of developers of genetically altered corn. It is Mycogen, not Micogen.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Sunday Styles section this week about the marriage of Nicole Contos and Tasos Michael was published in error. The ceremony, scheduled for late Saturday afternoon, was canceled after the section went to press. An article appears today on page B3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPIENZA, NICOLO ''PAT.''
description: SAPIENZA-Nicolo ''Pat.'' Founder of ''The Theatre Bar Restaurant'' of 45th St. passed away peacefully 11/22/97 at the age of 92. Friend of many young budding actors and actresses of the 40's and 50's, with an encouraging word, sympathetic ear and a free meal when needed. Loving father of Mr. Sam Sapienza, Mrs. Tina Grillo and Dr. Frank Sapienza. Grateful fatherin-law of Gloria, Joseph and May. An inspiration to his 13 grandchildren and 32 great-grandchildren. Reposing at The Branch Funeral Home of Nesconset, New York.

title: For White Goods, A World Beckons; But New Markets Are Tough Going
description: In 1994, the Harvard Business Review featured a long interview with David R. Whitwam, the chief executive of the Whirlpool Corporation, entitled ''The Right Way to Go Global.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSLOW, ANNE
description: WINSLOW-Anne. On November 23, at home in NYC. A loyal friend and mentor to so many. We will remember her deep commitment to liberal values and causes. At the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and at Unitar, she provided guidance and training to countless young diplomats and scholars. Memorial service to be announced later.

title: '96 Campaign Costs Set Record at $2.2 Billion
description: The 1996 election campaigns were the most expensive in history, with $2.2 billion in expenditures by the two major parties, political action committees and other political organizations, according to a new study.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: CHRONICLE
description: DONATELLA and SANTO VERSACE, sister and brother of the murdered fashion designer Gianni Versace, and his company, Versace Spa, have won several legal battles with the press.

title: Manhattan, Short on (212)'s, Will get a Second Area Code
description: It may not be the Dodgers leaving Brooklyn for Los Angeles or the impending demise of the subway token. But a tiny bit of New York culture is about to be altered forever. In less than a year, 212 won't be Manhattan's only area code.

title: A Withering Little Town Sees Its Salvation in an Old Asylum
description: Like the center of many other towns in West Virginia, downtown Weston is a sad-looking place, made almost obsolete by the strip malls closer to the Interstate. Only a handful of shops remain open for business on Main Avenue, the central thoroughfare, and pedestrians are rare.

title: Archeologists Unearth Treasure Buried by the Cold War
description: POMPEII, the decrepit, graffiti-scarred heap at the foot of Mount Vesuvius, is probably the world's most famous archeological village. Frozen forever by a volcanic eruption 2,000 years ago, it has long served as ancient history's Disneyland.

title: Robert Lewis, Founder of Actors Studio And Teacher of a Generation, Dies at 88
description: Robert Lewis, a founder of the Actors Studio, a member of the Group Theater of the 1930's, a successful director of Broadway plays and musicals and one of the most renowned acting teachers of the century, died of a heart attack Sunday night on a Manhattan street. He was 88 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Vaudeville: Ed Sullivan Before Ed Sullivan
description: ''Vaudeville'' is a warm two-hour remembrance of several decades of talented, antic, self-made and well-loved purveyors of popular entertainment. On show tomorrow night are precious clips of the dancers, singers, magicians, comedians, animal handlers, acrobats, contortionists and the many ukulele strummers who filled theaters around the land before the coming of radio and movies, not to mention television.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVEY, HAROLD D.
description: SILVEY-Harold D. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowledges with sadness the passing of Harold D. Silvey, beloved husband of our dear friend Lucille Silvey, President of the Child Care Women's League, which has generously supported our pediatric services for almost 30 years. To Lucille and her family, our most heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President Richard J. Bonforte, M.D., Chairman, The Milton and Bernice Stern Department of Pediatrics Stefanie Steel, Vice-President for Development

title: For Korean Bank, 'Worst Is Almost Ended'
description: The head of South Korea's central bank said this evening that ''the worst of the situation is almost ended'' for his country's troubled economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORD, NORMA E.
description: FORD-Norma E. On November 24, 1997, of Longboat Key, FL. after a long illness. Loving mother of Michael N. and Patricia A. Ford. Cherished grandmother of Keira E. Ford. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset Tuesday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass 10:15 AM Wednesday, St. Peter of Alcantara Church, Pt. Washington. Interment Mansion Memorial Park Cemetery, Ellington, FL. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, NY.

title: Corrections
description: The Nasdaq national market table in the Money and Business section on Sunday omitted entries for stocks after Wiztec Solutions Ltd. Readers wishing copies of the entries may write to Business Day, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1474. E-mail: bizday@nytimes.com. (Include a postal return address.)

title: The Mayor as Uncle Miltie
description: Rudolph Giuliani's performance on ''Saturday Night Live'' was not the most embarrassing appearance by a New York City mayor on that long-running show. We are thinking of the time that David Dinkins stood on what appeared to be a flying carpet, wearing Arabian headgear and lip-synching ''It's a Whole New World.'' The dignified Mr. Dinkins's obvious discomfort made that event harder to watch than Mr. Giuliani's utterly unself-conscious display.

title: After the Show With: STEVIE NICKS; Going Her Own Way, But Slowly This Time
description: The miniature cheesecake sat in front of Stevie Nicks like a cruel temptation, crowned with a glaze of mandarin oranges and skirted with puddles of chocolate sauce. She took a bite, just to test it. Then she put down her fork, deciding the pleasure was not worth the penance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASM, RUTH
description: CHASM-Ruth. On November 23, 1997. Loving mother of David, sister of Bradley, cherished sister-inlaw, aunt and great aunt. Teacher and friend of many. Services on Tuesday 1 P.M., at the Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, West 72 Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York. Interment private.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING ; 5 agencies will vie for Levi's jeans account in one of the most closely watched reviews of the year.
description: FIVE agencies were selected yesterday by Levi Strauss & Company to contend for its estimated $90 million domestic jeans account in one of the most closely watched reviews of the year.

title: To Save Stadium Plan, UConn Offers to Cover $20 Million of Cost
description: To salvage its proposal for a new $100 million football stadium, the University of Connecticut offered today to cover $20 million of the cost through fund-raising, revenue from skyboxes and other sources.

title: Another Design Talent Is Lured Away to France
description: If there are any more American designers left for hire, Seventh Avenue would do well to keep them under wraps, far from the prowling eyes of international headhunters. Michael Kors is the last of a young generation of Americans snapped up by a foreign concern in less than four years. Celine, a division of LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, announced yesterday that Mr. Kors will oversee design for Celine. His first collection will be shown at the house's fall 1998 runway show in Paris next spring.

title: Company Briefs
description: HOME DEPOT CO., Atlanta, acquired two closely held wallpaper and blind retailers -- Deekay Enterprises Inc. and Habitat Wallpaper and Blinds -- for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: O'Neal, Olajuwon Lengthen Injury List
description: The Western Conference skyline shrunk considerably yesterday. Two of the National Basketball Association's premier centers, Hakeem Olajuwon and Shaquille O'Neal, are scheduled to miss significant amounts of playing time because of injuries.

title: Messier Comes Back Where He Left 'a Piece of My Soul'
description: Ulf Samuelsson of the Rangers said Mark Messier's return to Madison Square Garden tonight will be ''a little special.''

title: Mary Brooks Griswold, Legislator, 91
description: Mary Brooks Griswold, who served four terms in the Connecticut legislature after the death of her husband, A. Whitney Griswold, a Yale University president, died on Nov. 15 at Fox Hill Village in Westwood, Mass. She was 91, and lived in New Haven.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about Attorney General Janet Reno misstated the given name of a former general counsel at the Immigration and Naturalization Service, who commented on her attention to detail. He is T. Alexander Aleinikoff, not Alexis.

title: Dropped Charges Don't Hide Police Misconduct; Public Trust Is Lost
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAYDE, JACK (YACOB)
description: ZAYDE-Jack (Yacob). On November 24, 1997. Loving husband of Sonia. Devoted father of Bruce and father-in-law of Risa. Proud grandfather of Amanda and Heather. Services Wednesday, November 26, at Noon, at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard.

title: Monsanto Joint Venture
description: The Monsanto Company and Empresas La Moderna S.A. said today that they had agreed to invest $30 million in privately held Mendel Biotechnology Inc. in a bid to accelerate their development of genetically enhanced plants. Monsanto, a biotechnology, drug and nutrition company based in St. Louis, and Empresas La Moderna, of Mexico, the world's largest vegetable-seed company, each invested $15 million for a joint 20 percent stake in Mendel, which is based in San Francisco.

title: In Grim Testimony, Mother Recounts Her Role in Girl's Death
description: The mother of Justina Morales, the 8-year-old Brooklyn girl whose death in 1995 went unreported for more than a year as school officials failed to notice her absence, testified in tears yesterday that she had allowed her boyfriend to asphyxiate her daughter with duct tape. And while the boyfriend was taping the girl's nose and mouth, said the mother, Denise Solero, she held her daughter's flailing hands.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''At this point, if anyone's going to call anyone, it's going to be him calling me.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAY, HAZEL
description: KAY-Hazel, 87, died November 23, 1997. Widow of Benjamin, loving mother of David and Susan, adoring grandmother of Steven and Belinda. Services 9:30 AM today at Parkside Chapels, Queens Blvd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLZ, SAMUEL S.
description: STOLZ-Samuel S. On November 23, 1997, after a long and glorious life, in his home peacefully at the age of 91. Husband of Freda. Father of Margrit, Robert and James. Grandfather of Erik, Oliver, Adam, Daniel and Freda. Father-in-law of Roger, Marlene and Chris. Survived by his sister Barbara Roth. Loved by all. A sweet, wise, gentle man. We learned so much from him and we will miss him so. Funeral services will be Tuesday, November 25, at 12:30 PM, at Temple Israel, 112 E. 75 St.

title: Atlanta Mayor Wins Runoff and 2d Term
description: Bill Campbell was re-elected to a second term as Mayor of Atlanta today after a rough-and-tumble runoff that managed to take on overtones of race and skin complexion even though both candidates are black.

title: Metro Business; Unemployment Dips And Jobs Rise in City
description: New York City's economy, fueled by business services, retailing and tourism, added 53,000 new jobs in the first 10 months of the year -- the best job-creation performance by the city for any comparable 10-month period since 1984, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday.

title: A Cuban Exile Leader Is Mourned in Miami
description: Thousands of mourners holding carnations and miniature Cuban flags crowded a Roman Catholic church today to attend a funeral Mass for Jorge Mas Canosa, the exile leader who died on Sunday and was eulogized by a United States senator as a ''simple'' man who ''united a community, inspired America to a great resolve and gave his life to the cause of a free Cuba.''

title: Mets Wait for Marlins To Give In on Sheffield
description: The Mets are playing the role of predators in their efforts to acquire Gary Sheffield. Steve Phillips, the general manager, is like a lion waiting alone near a watering hole, watching a thirsty wildebeest -- the Florida Marlins -- pace nervously in the distance and mull its options.

title: Kanell Gets Education, Courtesy of the Redskins
description: For the first time as a Giant, the usually polished and poised Danny Kanell looked frustrated and vulnerable. The Washington Redskins had knocked the quarterback out of his game, and in the Giants' locker room after Sunday night's 7-7 tie, Kanell, the 24-year-old with the ever-present smile, wore a scowl.

title: In 2d Park Shooting, Man Is Left Wounded
description: In the second shooting in Prospect Park in less than a week, a man carrying groceries was critically wounded yesterday afternoon during an apparent robbery as he walked along a path near the park's band shell, the police said.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY ; More of the Shore Is Cleared for Clamming
description: For the 10th straight year, New Jersey has increased the area where clamming is allowed in ocean and bay waters, the Department of Environmental Protection said yesterday.

title: HS RESOURCES TO PAY AMOCO $333 MILLION FOR PROPERTIES
description: HS Resources agreed yesterday to acquire oil and natural gas exploration and production properties in northeast Colorado for about $333 million from the Amoco Corporation. HS Resources, based in San Francisco, said it would pay $290 million in cash, issue 1.2 million common shares and transfer to Amoco certain producing properties in the mid-continent region. The properties to be acquired include proven reserves estimated at 15.2 million barrels of oil and 330 billion cubic feet of gas. The properties are on 410,000 acres and have more than 2,050 producing wells, of which more than 800 are operated by Amoco. Shares of Amoco dropped $3.125, to $89.9375, and shares of HS Resources fell 68.75 cents, to $15.875.

title: A-Hunting She Will Go; The Fastest-Growing Group Trooping to the Woods Is Women
description: Fifteen minutes into deer-hunting season, a doe sauntered along a trail in the Black Rock Forest in Cornwall, N.Y. The holder of New York State hunting license No. 31134836 aimed, fired and went home beaming like any hunter at the end of a good day.

title: Calendar
description: Straight Out of Dickens

title: Ripley, Believe It or Not, Has a Secret, and It's Not Pretty
description: Perhaps it counts as a compliment among those who appreciate the dripping, throbbing, drooling intensity of the ''Alien'' movies to say that the series' latest installment is its most freakish and macabre to date. But ''Alien Resurrection,'' the fourth installment and the one that comes closest to suggesting there may be rain-slicked dark alleys in space, also offers the most buff and sexily insolent incarnation of the aliens' favorite antagonist, Sigourney Weaver's Ripley. And this time it's personal: much of Ripley's new swagger comes from the fact that she now apparently has alien blood, or slime, or ooze, or whatever it is, coursing through her veins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, PAULA
description: BAUM-Paula. On November 23, 1997 at age 100. Beloved wife of the late Matthew Baum. Loving aunt and great aunt to many. Retired nurse at Beth Moses Hospital and Maimonides Hospital.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: THE ASIAN CRISIS: TOKYO'S ROLE ; As More Fissures Appear, Japan Starts to Form a Rescue Plan
description: Japan's fragile financial system showed further fractures today as a small regional bank collapsed and speculation intensified that one of the country's largest and most troubled banking companies might seek a bailout.

title: Intuit Posted Narrower Loss in First Quarter
description: Intuit Inc., a maker of financial software, said today that its loss from continuing operations narrowed in its first quarter, helped by strong sales of its small-business products.

title: School Voucher Experiment Will Be Extended and Expanded
description: An experimental program intended to help impoverished New York City public school students get a private school education by giving them vouchers is being extended into a second year, nearly doubling the number of children served, officials said yesterday.

title: AT&T Unit Is Said to Be Up for Sale
description: Continuing to shed low-growth operations that are not vital to its core telecommunications business, the AT&T Corporation has decided to sell off its paging unit, executives close to the company said yesterday.

title: AIDS Underestimated
description: United Nations medical experts say they grossly underestimated the spread of the AIDS virus worldwide and now believe that new infections are occurring almost twice as fast as they thought a year ago -- 16,000 new infections a day, instead of 8,200. The new data suggest that 30.6 million people around the world are now living with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUOHY, DANIEL M.
description: TUOHY-Daniel M. On November 24, 1997. Retired from the Bunge Corporation. Husband of Claire. Father of Stephen, Jo Ann and Mark Tuohy. Brother of Robert Tuohy and Claire Reiner. Grandfather of four. Private cremation was held at Hanley Funeral Home, 60 New Dorp Lane, Staten Island, New York. Friends may call from 11 A.M.-1 P.M. on Saturday.

title: Essay; Labor Takes the Fifth
description: Two weeks after John Sweeney and his fellow union bosses took control of the Democratic Party, the labor movement finds itself hip-deep in a cesspool of corruption.

title: New Coach Wades Into Arizona State Maelstrom
description: Things were beginning to look up for Arizona State basketball. One of the wonderfully improbable coaching stories was unfolding in the Preseason National Invitation Tournament. Don Newman, a professional wanderer, a man who once played a few exhibition downs as a New York Jets defensive back and who had the coaching success of Rich Kotite, found himself in the unlikeliest of places, running a team in the highly regarded Pacific-10 Conference.

title: THE ASIAN CRISIS: THE JAPANESE INVESTORS ; In Tokyo, Taking a Collapse in Stride
description: Tamio Shiraishi arrived at the Yamaichi Securities Company's branch in Otemachi, Tokyo's banking center, at 7 A.M. today with his newspaper and plans to withdraw his assets.

title: Love-In at the Garden Leaves a Hero in Tears
description: It was no ordinary game. Not for the Rangers, and not for the fans who were torn between rooting for their hero and rooting for their team last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Bench Arrives in Time To Help Nets Out of Jam
description: t took three quarters. But the Nets' bench finally kicked in.

title: Cable Competition
description: The big broadcast networks -- ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox -- have become increasingly annoyed at the chipping away of their audiences by cable television. They cannot dispute the decline in their own share of the total audience, but network executives do hasten to dispute the nature of the cable competition.

title: What's Love Got to Do With It?
description: Americans of the late 20th century suffer from many of the same social terrors their ancestors did. We just have different ways of getting over them. Charles Dickens's Miss Havisham was jilted by her fiancee and spent the rest of her life sulking in a dark room with her moldering wedding cake. Nicole Contos, a 27-year-old kindergarten teacher who was left at the church last weekend in New York City, became a local heroine when she switched from her wedding gown into something trendy and black. She urged her guests to turn the reception into a party and boogied to ''I Will Survive.'' Her former fiance, Tasos Michael, who apparently high-tailed it out of town with the honeymoon tickets to Tahiti, was distinctly out of public favor.

title: Commercial Real Estate; In Brooklyn, New Allure For Old Office Buildings
description: In the aftermath of the real estate recession of the early 90's, new owners have emerged in downtown Brooklyn to instill vigor into older office buildings near Court Street.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Leaders Agree on Ways To Contain Asian Crisis

title: Broncos Battling Injuries
description: DENVER

title: Gain Reported In Confidence Of Consumers
description: Consumer confidence increased in November, while home resales rose in October, suggesting that the economy could end the year on an unexpected high note.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK ; Charges Dropped in Case Of Mother Who Hid Baby
description: Criminal charges have been dropped against Shanta Clark, the 17-year-old high school student who hid her newborn son in a bedroom closet for 17 days in October while she attended classes, the Suffolk County District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When it came to naming their fourth child, ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER and MARIA SHRIVER didn't exactly make a hasty choice. Their second son was born on Sept. 27, but they didn't settle on a name -- CHRISTOPHER SARGENT SHRIVER SCHWARZENEGGER -- until a few days ago. He is named, at least in part, for his maternal grandfather, R. Sargent Shriver, the founding director of the Peace Corps.

title: Temptation; Don't Even Bother to Wrap It Up
description: SO thin. So rich. The individual apple tarts displayed on the pastry counter at Jefferson Market, 450 Avenue of the Americas (11th Street), are the Brooke Astors of confections.

title: Tough Action on Drunken Driving Pays Off
description: When Jamrius Cureton opened up a beer, drank a little and spilled some on the floor of his Honda Civic on Saturday night, he was doomed the minute he came upon the checkpoint here.

title: New Yorkers Win Titles in St. Louis
description: Players from the New York metropolitan area captured two major titles here on Monday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall National Championships.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Thanksgiving

title: Illness May Take Kennedy Out
description: The three-time United States Olympic luge team member Duncan Kennedy is suffering from a slight amount of bleeding in his brain stem, doctors said, possibly forcing him out of the Olympic Winter Games in February.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY ; Turnpike Authority Keeps the Tolls Down
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority yesterday made good on a 1995 promise not to raise tolls through 1998 and vowed to keep tolls at this level, at least until the end of 1999.

title: Spending by Union's Leaders Is Investigated
description: Leaders of a union representing nearly 2,800 New York City park and traffic workers are being investigated on allegations that they embezzled tens of thousands of dollars in union dues, union officials and investigators said yesterday.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK ; Lawyer Assails Testimony Of Slain Girl's Mother
description: The lawyer for the man accused of beating 8-year-old Justina Morales to death in 1995 yesterday painted the girl's mother, who is also the prosecution's primary witness, as a brilliant actress and thief who cared nothing about her child and would do anything to keep her man, even allow him to kill her daughter.

title: DENBURY IN $202.2 MILLION DEAL FOR CHEVRON PROPERTIES
description: Denbury Resources agreed yesterday to acquire oil properties in Mississippi from the Chevron Corporation's Chevron USA Inc. for $202.2 million. Denbury, based in Dallas, is a developer of oil and gas properties, mainly operating in Louisiana and Mississippi. Denbury also acquired minor interests in Mississippi property from three other companies for about $5.9 million. The acquisitions give Denbury additional net proven reserves of 29.9 million barrels of oil and 1.8 billion cubic feet of gas. The purchase price included $75 million for unevaluated properties, Denbury said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARDWELL, FREDERIC KOPPE
description: WARDWELL-Frederic Koppe. Of Brooklyn, NY, died November 24, 1997. Husband of Frances Jacoby Wardwell (deceased); father of Paul Wardwell. Served in WWII, United States Merchant Service. Graduate of The University of Chicago. He is survived by his son Paul and sisters Dorothy, Kathryn, Marjorie and Laura. Visitation 7-9 PM, Wednesday, November 26, 1997, Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The American Heart Assoc. Interment and services at Oak Grove Cemetery Logan, OH.

title: Surprising Few, Silver Rejects Bid for Governor
description: Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, the highest-ranking Democrat in the State Legislature, said today that he would not seek his party's nomination for governor next year.

title: Branch of State University Will Run Brookhaven Lab
description: Six months after dismissing the nonprofit organization that had operated the Brookhaven National Laboratory for 50 years, the Federal Government today turned to a Long Island neighbor of the lab, the State University of New York at Stony Brook, to run it.

title: State Court Sets New Rules For Repetitive Stress Cases
description: Saying that people who suffer from repetitive stress injury from using computer keyboards pose legal problems that set them apart from other personal injury plaintiffs, New York's top court issued guidelines yesterday about when they can sue manufacturers. Although they must still file their cases within the standard state limit of three years, the court said, the clock can start ticking either upon the onset of their symptoms or after the last time they used a keyboard -- whichever is earlier.

title: Israel's Conflict Within
description: The Government of Israel is vexed by a dispute with American Jews. The conflict springs from a challenge by Reform and Conservative Jews to the Orthodox rabbinate's monopoly over conversions and other rites in Israel. The rancor recently prompted Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to assure American Jewish leaders that ''no power on earth can rob any Jew of his or her identity.'' He has also appointed a Cabinet committee to negotiate a resolution. Success will require flexibility by all sides and perhaps some rethinking of the role of the state in Israel in determining Jewish identity.

title: Metro Business; Magazine Sues M.T.A.
description: New York Magazine filed suit in Federal court yesterday to try to stop transit officials from removing a bus advertisement in which the magazine calls itself ''possibly the only good thing in New York Rudy hasn't taken credit for.'' The agency started pulling down the ads on Monday, after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani complained that his name was being used without his permission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATUNAS, ANTHONY L. M.D.
description: MATUNAS-Anthony L. M.D. Retired from the Veteran's Administration. He died peacefully in his sleep on November 23, 1997 in his home at the age of 86. He is survived by his wife Marian and his son Tony.

title: Beleaguered Carey Steps Aside As President of the Teamsters
description: Ron Carey stepped aside as president of the teamsters' union yesterday, announcing that he would take a leave of absence, just hours before a Federally appointed oversight board accused him of diverting union money to his election campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GROSS, SIDNEY
description: GROSS-Sidney. Time cannot steal you from us. Today, your legacy of love, goodness and laughter is passed on to your newborn grandson, Langdon. You are always in our hearts and memories. Zenith and the family

title: No Storm In Pacific
description: To Clinton Administration officials, the meeting of leaders from the Pacific Rim that ended here today was a clear success, putting on display American political and economic influence over a vital and unsettled region.

title: Crowd in Denver Rallies Against Skinhead Violence
description: Jeannie VanVelkinburgh could not make it to Denver's anti-hate rally today. She was in a hospital bed, learning to cope with severe wounds inflicted by the gunfire of a skinhead who had exploded on seeing a white woman come to the aid of a black man he had just shot.

title: 'Miracle' of Septuplets Betrays Common Sense; Abortion Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: She's a Rookie Officer, He's Trouble
description: Wouldn't it be interesting to make a movie about a young female police officer in Harlem who falls in love with a local hustler?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMBURG, MIRJANA M.
description: HAMBURG-Mirjana M. November 25, 1997. Beloved wife of Nikola, mother of Giselle and Sandra. The family will receive friends at their residence, Friday, 3 P.M.

title: Williams And Mills To Start For Knicks
description: It has been a strange and strained existence for Buck Williams. He has been on the bench, not even in the rotation, and now he has to prepare for the head rush of leaping to his feet.

title: Sex and Intrigue in Prewar Egypt
description: ONE OF US

title: Giuliani Aide Is Nominated For Crime Post
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today nominated Katherine N. Lapp, the criminal justice coordinator for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani since 1994, as the state's new director of criminal justice.

title: Far-Eastern Flavors Add Zip to Leftovers
description: CURRY powder and kaffir lime leaves are not ingredients that appear on most Thanksgiving menus -- which makes them perfect complements for the next day's leftover turkey.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: By the Book; This Room Is Called the Kitchen
description: MITCHELL DAVIS'S new book, ''Cook Something'' (Macmillan), joins a handful of cookbooks trying to lure a take-out generation off the phone and into the kitchen. Mr. Davis's effort may just work. After all, the book revolves around a party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POHS, JACK
description: POHS-Jack. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of NYC, died November 24, 1997. Dearly beloved husband of Lois, devoted father of Joyce Pohs and Linda Pohs Supino, father-in-law of David J. Supino and brother of Edith and Eva. Founder of Bergere Inc. and past-president of Fenway Golf Club. Services will be held 11:30AM Friday, November 28, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: CHRONICLE
description: What kind of conversation are you likely to overhear at a party brimming over with female lawyers and judges?

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY ; Casinos Show a Drop In 3d-Quarter Profits
description: Third-quarter profits at Atlantic City's casinos were off 11 percent from a year ago, the State Casino Control Commission reported yesterday.

title: Government Ruling Paves Way for Limousine Drivers' Union
description: The effort to unionize 10,000 New York City limousine drivers has received a boost from the National Labor Relations Board, which ruled that the drivers are not independent contractors, as management insisted, but are instead employees with the right to join a union.

title: Lawyers in Sharpton Suit Fear Jury Tampering
description: After a prospective juror revealed that she had been approached by someone at work and told how to think about the case, lawyers in the defamation lawsuit against three former advisers of Tawana Brawley raised concerns today about jury tampering.

title: Class Notes; The community is the textbook for one teacher. 'I want them to see history, touch history, climb on history, smell history.'
description: Mr. O., as his students call him, is up to his usual tricks, teaching seventh-grade social studies with props and sound effects, hikes and treasure hunts instead of textbooks, homework and exams.

title: Lakers Lose First Game
description: HEAT 103, LAKERS 86

title: New York City Now Expects an Additional $319 Million in Revenues
description: The Giuliani administration expects New York City to end the fiscal year with $319 million more in revenues than it had forecast, largely because of continued robust profits on Wall Street, and it is proposing that the city salt away much of that money for the future.

title: Prosecutors in Bombing Trial Seek to Shake Defendant's Alibi
description: The prosecutors at the second Oklahoma City bombing trial, near the end of their case against Terry L. Nichols, today elicited testimony intended to show that Mr. Nichols lied about where he was the day the bomb was built.

title: An Emotional Messier Leaves Rangers Blue
description: On one level, it was merely a midweek, early-season hockey game between teams that are high-salaried and underachieving. After two relatively tepid periods, the third one was robust, and the game ended in a 4-2 victory for the Vancouver Canucks over the Rangers last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Off the Menu
description: Grand Central Palazzo

title: 'Miracle' of Septuplets Betrays Common Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Miracle' of Septuplets Betrays Common Sense; Parentless Embryos
description: To the Editor:

title: Playing Fourth Potato and Getting Raves
description: POTATOES rarely evoke excitement, but they do command loyalty. So much loyalty that it has been nearly impossible for specialty potato growers to tear Americans away from the three-potato establishment held down by the russet, round white and red.

title: INSIDE
description: The City Council votes an independent police watchdog.

title: Could Japan Be Next?
description: Could Japan be next?

title: Gold Prices Hit 12 1/2-Year Low On British Official's Remarks
description: Gold fell to a 12 1/2-year low yesterday after Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England, said that a new European central bank would not need much gold in its reserves.

title: 'Miracle' of Septuplets Betrays Common Sense; Doctors, Not Deities
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Bombing Suspect Lands His Dream Job
description: Nearly 15 months after becoming the focus of the investigation into the bombing at Centennial Olympic Park, Richard A. Jewell today found the job he had been looking for and was sworn in as one of five members of the Luthersville, Ga., Police Department.

title: Nasdaq Reports a 3.6% Rise In Uncovered Short Sales
description: Nasdaq reported that the overall short interest in stocks traded on that market rose 3.6 percent, to a record 1.75 billion shares. The figures report short positions taken by Nov. 11, as compared with positions on Oct. 10. The period was one of market turbulence, including Oct. 27, the day the Dow Jones industrial average fell 7 percent and forced stock markets to close early.

title: Weeklong Postal Workers' Strike Snarls Deliveries in Canada
description: After a week without mail, Canadians across the country are starting to feel the impact of a nationwide postal strike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, BETTY
description: COHEN-Betty. On November 23, 1997. Devoted mother of Roy and Earl Colson; loving mother-in-law of Helen; cherished grandmother of Nancy, Adam, Amy and Deborah.

title: No Gains for Skinheads
description: To the Editor:

title: Winnie Mandela Killed Youth, Apartheid Inquiry Is Told
description: A former member of Winnie Madikizela-Mandela's entourage testified today that in 1989 he saw her stab and kill a young activist she had accused of being a police informer and who was later found dead.

title: Dangers And Jitters Of Life in Sarajevo
description: Unlike more exotic and elliptical films that have tried to depict the chaos of war in the former Yugoslavia, such as ''Before the Rain'' and ''Underground,'' Michael Winterbottom's ''Welcome to Sarajevo'' tackles its subject head on. Set in 1992 and based on a memoir by an English journalist, Michael Nicholson, ''Welcome to Sarajevo'' plunges directly into pandemonium.

title: About New York ; Shelter Artist Puts the Pieces Back Together
description: A MAN walking along Hinsdale Street in Brooklyn slowed down when he spotted a woman lugging a mannequin's naked brown torso into a community garden ringed by chain link fencing and razor ribbon. He watched as she propped the body on a makeshift staircase she had made as part of a sculpture in progress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOTTENHAM, DINAH L.
description: TOTTENHAM-Dinah L. Died Nov. 14, 1997 in London, England after a long illness. She is survived by her daughters Philippa Gerard and Amanda Outerbridge, and by five grandchildren: Ashley, Nina, Wylie, Robin and Ben. Until recently, she resided in New York City where she was the Executive Director of the Parkinson's Disease Foundation from 1978 to 1996. Donations may be made to the Dinah Tottenham Memorial Fund, C/O The Parkinson's Disease Foundation, Columbia University Medical Center, 710 West 168 Street, New York, New York 10032.

title: Company Briefs
description: ENOVA CORP., San Diego, a supplier of electricity and natural gas, said its San Diego Gas and Electric utility would sell all of its power plants in an auction next year. The sale of some plants is required by California law to reduce market power among the state's three investor-owned utilities.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK ; Man Accused of Killing Neighbor in East Village
description: A Manhattan man was arrested yesterday and charged with fatally stabbing his neighbor in their East Village apartment building, the police said.

title: A 'Nutcracker' in 3-D Gift Wrapping
description: ''The Imax Nutcracker,'' an abridged, mostly nondancing version of the Tchaikovsky ballet, is the movie equivalent of a Christmas tree smothered with tinsel or a layer cake that's so rich it can only be consumed in tiny nibbles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, GEORGE MACDONALD
description: PARKER - George MacDonald. The Board of Directors of Fiduciary Trust International mourns the passing of its esteemed friend and colleague on November 22 in Frankfurt, Germany. He rendered thoughtful and cogent advice for the benefit of the company and its clients during his six years as a director. Our deepest sympathy to his wife, Susan Bissell Parker, and his daughter Julia and son Angus.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEWIS, ROBERT
description: LEWIS-Robert. ''A was a man, take him for all in all, I shall not look upon his like again.'' Michael and Cheryl

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REICHART, MIMI
description: REICHART-Mimi. 11/26/78. Nineteen years have passed since you left me, but you are still the love of my life. I miss you, I love you. LLoyd

title: Steinbrenner Wants Williams to Stay
description: George Steinbrenner said yesterday that he did not want to lose Bernie Williams and that he wanted to meet face to face with the center fielder after the Christmas holiday to try to settle the contentious negotiations between the Yankees and their best all-round player.

title: Connecticut Goes to 5-0 but Gets a Scare
description: fter being blown away by unranked Arkansas by 26 points on Sunday and falling to 20th place from 11th in the Associated Press ranking, the Iowa women's basketball team did not seem to stand a ghost of a chance against unbeaten and third-ranked Connecticut tonight.
