title: Big East Championship On the Line in Miami
description: Why remind the players that Syracuse (8-3, 5-1) has never defeated Miami (5-5 , 3-3) since the Hurricanes joined the Big East in 1992? ''We don't talk about the past,'' Coach Paul Pasqualoni said yesterday. ''I don't believe the past has anything to do with today.''

title: Baghdad Risks New Sanctions Or Even an Attack, U.S. Says
description: Secretary of Defense William Cohen said today that Iraq ''continues to evade and to deceive'' United Nations weapons inspectors and that its defiance could lead to still-tighter sanctions or a military attack.

title: Genetics Institute Receives Approval for Platelet Drug
description: Genetics Institute Inc., a subsidiary of the American Home Products Corporation, said yesterday that it had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to begin marketing a new drug that stimulates the production of blood platelets. The drug was approved for use in conjunction with cancer chemotherapy, which can destroy platelets, a component of blood necessary for clotting.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an obituary of the acting teacher Robert Lewis carried an incorrect date in some editions. The photo, of Mr. Lewis with the other founders of the Actors Studio and their associates, was taken in 1977, not 1997.

title: Still Weighing Decision on Inquiry, Reno Goes to Mexico
description: Attorney General Janet Reno departed today for an official trip to Mexico without announcing whether she would ask for independent prosecutors to investigate fund-raising telephone calls by President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore.

title: Regents to Rescind the New 3-Year Language Requirement
description: In an abrupt reversal, the head of the State Board of Regents said yesterday that the board would scale back its recent decision requiring high school students to take three years of a foreign language and for now require only one year.

title: To U.S. Workers, Trade Deficits Are a Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Lessons of Boesky and Milken Go Unheeded in Fraud Case
description: Late last month, a young couple met over drinks at C. S. Barrington's, a lobster and pasta restaurant on the corner of East 54th Street and Second Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Tidbit; Beef Is Still the American Meat of Choice
description: DESPITE all the health-conscious clucking about the low-fat benefits of eating chicken and other alternatives to red meat, Americans last year made beef their meat of choice, according to the Agriculture Department. In fact, 1996 was the third consecutive year in which per-capita beef consumption increased. Driven by a rise in the sale of hamburgers and cheeseburgers -- the most popular beef dishes -- restaurant servings of beef reached seven billion in 1996, a 2 percent rise over 1995, according to NPD, a food research group in Rosemont, Ill. Last year, per-capita consumption of beef was 64.2 pounds, compared with 49.8 pounds for chicken. MICHEL MARRIOTT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCHMANN, HILDEGARD J.
description: TUCHMANN-Hildegard J. Age 83, formerly of Forest Hills, suddenly on November 23 in Canton, MA. Beloved wife for 59 years of Frederick. Devoted mother of Doris Cohen and the late Richard, Carol Berde and Michael, Robert and Naomi. Survived by grandchildren David Cohen and Rachel Pastan, Lisa Cohen, Daniel and Matthew Berde, Paul and David Tuchmann, sisters Annemarie Teutsch and Margaret Rosskamm, and two great-granddaughters. Memorial service at a later date.

title: Quebec Journal; To Some Canadians, the Maple Leaf Is a Red Flag
description: The red and white Maple Leaf is not a flag that normally stirs intense passions among Canadians.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on the Education page on Nov. 12 with an article about the competition for postgraduate scholarships misstated the number of Marshall scholarships won by Harvard students in 1996-97. It was eight, not two.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Stadium Plan Quickly Dies In Hartford
description: One month after enthusiastically endorsing plans for a $107 million football complex at the University of Connecticut, Gov. John G. Rowland declared the issue dead today, saying the proposal lacked the votes to pass in the State Senate.

title: The Ratings, From All Angles
description: The November ratings sweep month for the broadcast networks officially ends tonight, but the analysis reached its peak yesterday as network executives took turns skewing the results to their best advantage.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOMERVILLE, DR. ROBERT A, M.D.
description: SOMERVILLE-Dr. Robert A, M.D. 5 November 26, 1995. M.O.S.L. 2 years gone. Please know that you are still deeply loved, sadly missed and joyfully remembered for your passion, compassion, warmth and T.L.C. by your family, friends and most especially by me-Y.O.S.S. Peace be with you. Jackie

title: Dollar Reaches a 5-Year High Vs. Yen on Japan's Problems
description: The dollar climbed to a five-year high against the yen yesterday after Japanese traders, returning from a national holiday on Monday, reacted to the closing of the Yamaichi Securities Company, the oldest securities firm in Japan. The dollar rose against the mark after a Bundesbank official suggested German rates would remain steady.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCHMANN, HILDEGARD
description: TUCHMANN - Hildegard. The board and staff of the Margaret Tietz Center for Nursing Care and The New York Foundation for Nursing Homes mourn the death of one of our most dedicated Directors and senior volunteers. Her devotion to our cause over almost 30 years will never be forgotten. Our heartfelt condolences go out to her husband Frederick and her entire family.

title: Haitians Get Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Stuff
description: Bright Persimmons, The Essence of Autumn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, SHERILL SANDERSON
description: SMITH-Sherill Sanderson. Of New Canaan, CT., on November 25, 1997. Daughter of Coralie Childs Hansen. Wife of Richard R.S. Smith. Mother of Hadley, Jennison and Richard. Sister of Jeffrey C. Sanderson and Ian C. Sanderson. Memorial service Saturday, November 29, 1PM, Congregational Church, Park St, New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, Boston, MA., or the Bennett Cancer Center, Stamford, CT or the Congregational Church of New Canaan.

title: Quarterback Turns Around His Fortunes, and Hofstra's
description: When Hofstra finished its spring practices this year, Joe Gardi was not feeling great about his team's prospects. The defense that had carried the team last year was decimated by graduation and the designated starting quarterback had just blown out his knee in the spring game.

title: ASIA PACIFIC TALKS VOW TOUGH ACTION ON ECONOMIC CRISIS
description: Leaders gathered for the annual Asia Pacific economic summit meeting declared today that stringent domestic economic policies and closer international monitoring are the only way to contain the financial emergencies that have crippled South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand in recent months and have endangered Japan's already weakened financial system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELZNICK, DAVID
description: SELZNICK-David. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of David Selznick, beloved husband of our esteemed colleague Lillian Kaltman. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marlene E. Post, Nat'l President

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Geraldo Will Stay at NBC, With New Duties in News
description: NBC made a deal yesterday to retain the services of Geraldo Rivera, the talk show host, keeping his top-rated interview program on its CNBC cable network while expanding his duties to include numerous assignments with NBC News.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARETSKY, IRVING
description: ZARETSKY-Irving. Congregation Kol Ami Jewish Community Center of White Plains records with sorrow the passing of our cherished member, and conveys sincere condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Shira Milgrom Rabbi Tom Weiner Mark Hershey, President

title: Metro Business; Former Executives Guilty
description: Two former executives of the company that makes Sweet 'n Low were convicted yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn of conspiracy and tax evasion in the theft of $3 million from the company. Prosecutors said they used it for personal expenses, including the construction of a million-dollar home in Old Westbury, N.Y.

title: On Campus; Idaho Helps Vietnam In Business Training
description: As Vietnam strives to expand its new market-oriented economy, a Hanoi university has linked with the state college here to develop educational opportunities for Vietnamese teachers and business leaders.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK ; Suffolk County Raises Sales Tax to 8.5%
description: To help repay excess property taxes on the abandoned Shoreham nuclear power plant, the Suffolk County Legislature approved an increase in the sales tax yesterday of a quarter of a percentage point. The increase raises the total sales tax in Suffolk to 8.5 percent, the highest for any New York county except Nassau County, which also charges 8.5 percent.

title: Critic's Notebook; Foie Gras, the Sin for the Season
description: I WILL never forget watching my friend Robin experience foie gras for the first time. We were in a fancy restaurant, but she was in another world. ''Oooh,'' she began to moan. ''This is so good!'' Her face went pink with pleasure. ''Oh, oh, oh, it feels fabulous. Why have I spent my whole life without this?'' Each bite brought a new sigh of ecstasy; then everyone in the room began looking our way. It was like being in the middle of that scene from ''When Harry Met Sally,'' but Robin wasn't faking a thing. All over the restaurant people were summoning their waiters to say, ''I'll have what she's having.''

title: Fitzgerald Joins The Interpublic Fold
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies has signed a letter of intent to acquire Fitzgerald & Company in Atlanta and merge Fitzgerald with the Atlanta office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, part of Interpublic's McCann-Erickson World Group. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Sports of The Times; Garden Gave Due Respect To a Leader
description: THE banner still hangs from the rafters. Nobody chants ''1940'' at the Rangers anymore. There are still people in New York who talk about the night the Stanley Cup itself came waltzing into their bar, with a couple of big lugs with scars attached to it.

title: To U.S. Workers, Trade Deficits Are a Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VIOLA, THERESA M.
description: VIOLA-Theresa M. Beloved wife of Anthony J. Viola. Died Nov. 25, 1997. Also survived by a daughter, two sons, seven grandchildren and their families. Friends may call at Brueggemann Funeral Home of E. Northport, 522 Larkfield Rd, Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Service at Saint Anthony of Padua R.C. Church, East Northport, Friday, 10:30AM. Interment to follow Saint Vincent de Paul Cemetery, Sterling, New Jersey.

title: BROKERS AND MOB LINKED IN SWINDLE
description: In what Federal investigators described as the most ambitious scheme by organized crime to infiltrate Wall Street in decades, the Government charged 19 men yesterday with duping investors in seven states to make millions of dollars in profits.

title: Seeking a Bridge to Medicare
description: The White House is debating ways to extend health coverage to three million ''near elderly,'' between the ages of 55 and 64, who are too young to qualify for Medicare. The Clinton Administration is right to try to help a vulnerable group. But the financial and political risks are steep.

title: Israel Suggests New Pullback In West Bank
description: Under stiff pressure from Washington to start moving on peace and from his restive supporters to hold fast, Israel's beleaguered Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, was reported to be considering an Israeli withdrawal from another 6 to 8 percent of the West Bank.

title: Mayor and Dissident Celebrate Democracy, and New York City
description: There was a certain tautness to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's face yesterday, a vague twitch of impatience, as he stood next to the recently released Chinese dissident, Wei Jingsheng, in the Blue Room of City Hall. The Chinese reporters in the room were asking endless questions about China, everyone was looking at Mr. Wei and no one was asking the question the Mayor wanted asked.

title: A 2-Pound Truffle Takes Flight As a Chef Seizes the Moment
description: ABOUT two weeks ago, Alfredo Landucci, the head of Boscovivo Tartufi in Arezzo, Italy, was awakened at 3 A.M. by a telephone call. It was a truffle hunter who had just pried what seemed to be the mother of all white truffles loose from the damp soil around an oak tree in the hills of Alba, in the truffle-rich Piedmont region.

title: Barbara, 67, a French Singer Who Wrote Melancholic Songs
description: The French singer and songwriter known simply as Barbara, who earned a huge following in the French-speaking world for her melancholic lyrics and melodies, died on Monday in the American Hospital in Paris. She was 67.

title: Restaurants; Culinary Surprises in a Warm Oasis
description: A PALE, tiny scallop nestles against brilliant orange sea urchin roe, glistening with mustard oil. In the mouth they become a single bite of bright, intense flavor. Kumamoto oysters sparkle beneath a quilt of basil-infused gelatin, the textures somersaulting across each other as they hit the palate. Smooth, sweet sea bass, its skin crisp, encounters the softness of black figs and the crunch of sunflower seeds. Soft nuggets of sweetbread matched with pears are a stunning combination, revealing the similarity of texture, the contrast of taste. The sweetness of juicy, warm pineapple beignets is tempered by the surprise of freshly ground cardamom. Who thought up these incredible combinations?

title: VF AGREES TO ACQUIRE BESTFORM TO DOUBLE LINGERIE SALES
description: The VF Corporation agreed yesterday to purchase the Bestform Group, the closely held maker of Bestform and Christian Dior lingerie, for an undisclosed amount of cash as part of a plan to double its United States lingerie sales by 2000. Bestform makes intimate apparel under brands including Bestform, Christian Dior, Natori and Oscar de la Renta. Bestform, based in New York, had 1996 sales of $270 million. VF, which makes apparel under brands including Lee, Wrangler and Vanity Fair, had 1996 sales of $5.1 billion. Shares of VR, which is based in Wyomissing, Pa., rose 56.25 cents, to $46.5625. The company had a 2-for-1 stock split this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUTCHENCE, MICHAEL KELLAND
description: HUTCHENCE-Michael Kelland. January 22, 1960-November 22, 1997. Much loved son of Patricia and Kelland, beloved father of Tiger Lily, brother of Rhett and Tina, loving partner of Paula, brother-in-law of Mandy and Ken (Shorr), stepson of Susan and Ross (Glassop), uncle of Brent, Erin and Zoe Angel, nephew of Croy and Maureen, cousin of Melissa, much loved by Fifi, Peaches and Pixie. A service of thanksgiving for the life of Michael will be celebrated at St. Andrews Anglican Cathedral, George Street, Sydney, Australia, next Thursday (November 27, 1997), commencing at 2:30 P.M. At the conclusion of prayers, a private family service will be held. No flowers by request. In lieu, a donation may be made in memory of Michael to the Starlight Foundation, 80 Chandos Street, St. Leonards, or UNICEF Australia, Level 3, 303 Pitt Street, Sydney, Australia. For more information, contact Walter Carter Pty. Ltd. 302 Oxford Street, Woollahra, Sydney, Australia. +612 - 9389 - 3499; +612-9389-3367.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING ; A soft-bodied toy and cause-related marketing.
description: ENTHUSIASTIC free publicity from Rosie O'Donnell, in the form of product plugs on her talk show, has helped sell everything from snack cakes to theater tickets to mouthwash. Now the promotional abilities of her image are being harnessed to peddle a doll in her image.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAND, ALFRED
description: RAND-Alfred. The Board of Directors of The Lombardy, the residents and staff mourn with sorrow the passing of Alfred Rand on November 24, 1997. Mr. Rand, a resident of The Lombardy for 29 years dedicated his services to the organization as a Member Director, Chairman of the Board and Treasurer. During his tenure on the Board of Directors spanning over 20 years, his commitment and professional guidance greatly contributed to the success of our organization. To Mrs. Rita L. Rand and members of the family, we extend our heartfelt condolences.

title: $25 and Under; A Restaurant That All but Gives You Its Paw
description: YOU can't have enough good neighborhood restaurants. When it's cold outside, when things at work, at home, maybe in love, aren't going your way, these places still make you feel welcome. Like a good pet, they are happy to see you, and they make you feel better.

title: Wine Talk; A Burgundy House, at 200, Continues to Age Well
description: MAISON LOUIS LATOUR, one of the best-known wine shippers in Burgundy, celebrates its 200th anniversary this year. In the wine business, 200 years is not a particularly long time. The Hugels in Alsace are celebrating their 350th aniversary, and in Tuscany, Antinori and Frescobaldi trace their beginnings back six centuries.

title: Reality Works
description: Trying to capture viewers who are bored with familiar comedies and dramas, the broadcast networks offered many hours of news-magazine programs and so-called reality specials this month: specials ranging from ''Kids Say the Darndest Things'' on CBS to ''World's Scariest Police Stings'' on Fox.

title: Sips; A Less Boisterous Entrance Than Usual for Beaujolais Nouveau
description: ''LE Beaujolais Nouveau Est Arrive,'' the signs say, as usual. But this year, the purply new wines from Beaujolais arrived very quietly.

title: Corrections
description: Because of word processing errors, two diagrams with the Bridge column on Thursday displayed the bidding and a partial hand incorrectly. In the bidding diagram, the four bids on the sixth line (starting with 6 should have been distributed under the column headings for the four hands, not bunched on the left. In the diagram of the hands after the first eight plays, the north hand should have included the king of clubs, not the king of diamonds; the C in the north's diamond holding was extraneous.

title: Fans Get Wish: Milutinovic Is Out
description: After Bora Milutinovic had been fired as coach of Mexico's national soccer team yesterday, two things became apparent: he is expected to resurface next season in Major League Soccer and he will not play any role with the United States team during the 1998 World Cup in France.

title: Laptops Won't Be Education's Silver Bullet
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Stymied on Access to Closed Iraq Sites
description: Even as Russia backed away from a campaign to relax pressure on Iraq, the Security Council remained immobilized today in the face of mounting obstacles, including security leaks, to its effort to gain access to Baghdad's most sensitive sites, where it may be hiding banned weapons.

title: Making Books; Hooray For Hollywood
description: The pinballing-around-the-country effect of a big new movie often makes for a glorious paperback best seller. Even a Hollywood clunker will do. Sometimes movies create a second life for a book that had quickly expired. Of course, the symbiosis between the two arts works both ways, for ever since the first image flickered on a screen, books have been the fodder of movies.

title: Corrections
description: Two picture captions in Science Times yesterday, with an article about the rescue of wild turkeys from extinction, were reversed. The upper picture showed a biologist, Dr. William Healy of the United States Forest Service.

title: New Motorola Task Goes to Leo Burnett
description: The Semiconductor Products Sector of Motorola Inc. in Austin, Tex., said yesterday that it had named the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago to handle a new assignment -- creating worldwide image advertising for Motorola semiconductors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRESDALE, DAVID, M.D.
description: DRESDALE-David, M.D. The Division of Cardiology at Maimonides Medical Center mourns the loss of a devoted physician, superb clinician and dedicated teacher. David Dresdale distinguished himself over many decades of service to his patients and to Maimonides Medical Center. He integrated unbending scientific principles with the application of compassionate, clinical medicine into a unique blend, defining the art of medicine. He served as an example of excellence for generations of physicians and he will be sorely missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPIENZA, NICOLO ''PAT.''
description: SAPIENZA-Nicolo ''Pat.'' Founder of ''The Theatre Bar Restaurant'' of 45th St. passed away peacefully 11/22/97 at the age of 92. Friend of many young budding actors and actresses of the 40's and 50's, with an encouraging word, sympathetic ear and a free meal when needed. Loving father of Mr. Sam Sapienza, Mrs. Tina Grillo and Dr. Frank Sapienza. Grateful fatherin-law of Gloria, Joseph and May. An inspiration to his 13 grandchildren and 32 great-grandchildren. Reposing at The Branch Funeral Home of Nesconset, New York.

title: Business Travel; Those headed for the Middle East and South Asia are warned to be extra cautious these days.
description: THE Middle East and South Asia are hot spots for business travelers these days because of Muslim terrorist attacks in Egypt and Pakistan, along with the still- simmering confrontations between the United States and Iraq.

title: Norman Morris, Watch Seller And Foundation President, 99
description: Norman M. Morris, an entrepreneur and philanthropist, died on Monday at his home in Harrison, N.Y. He was 99.

title: Haitians Get Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Guerin's Role Undecided
description: DEVILS

title: A 1621 Dinner at 1997 Prices
description: The other day a friend and I were bemoaning the enormous smack in the pocketbook that it takes to put on a Thanksgiving feast. In the midst of our lamenting I wondered idly what it had cost the Pilgrims to put on the original celebration. My friend went one better. ''What do you suppose it would cost to put on the same feast today? Say, in some corner of Central Park.'' We decided to work it out together.

title: Treasury Prices Bolstered by 5-Year Note Sale
description: Treasury prices edged up yesterday, bolstered by strong demand at an auction of new five-year notes.

title: Orioles' Davis Wins Conigliaro Award
description: Baltimore Orioles outfielder Eric Davis will receive the 1997 Tony Conigliaro Award, given each year to a major leaguer who has overcome adversity through spirit, determination and courage.

title: In a World of Civility, A Sudden Mozart Shift
description: Mozart wrote no piano concertos more interesting than the early E flat major and the mature C minor. The chamber orchestra Orpheus made them and their soloist, Richard Goode, the center of a program at Carnegie Hall on Monday night.

title: The Minimalist; For the Leftover Turkey, There's a Life Beyond Sandwiches
description: AS we all know, turkey is really about leftovers. The typical course calls for sandwiches at 10 P.M. on Thanksgiving and twice a day thereafter until the meat expires.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK ; Photograph Is Released In Disappearance Case
description: The police yesterday released a photograph of David King, whose disappearance in 1991 is being investigated along with the disappearance ealier this month of a Manhattan couple and their landlord, for whom Mr. King worked.

title: THE ASIAN CRISIS: THE U.S. INVESTORS ; Government Bond Funds Receiving Influx of Cash
description: Mutual fund investors turned their backs on overseas stock funds in October and instead sought the shelter of United States Government bond funds, which received new cash for the first time in four years.

title: Veto of Police Review Board Overridden
description: Setting the stage for yet another court battle with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over how the city should investigate police corruption, the City Council voted overwhelmingly yesterday to override the Mayor's veto of a bill to create an independent police review board.

title: Harold Evans of Random House To Be Zuckerman Editorial Czar
description: Harold M. Evans, the colorful president and publisher of Random House's trade group, will leave the publishing house to head Mortimer B. Zuckerman's publications, which include The Daily News of New York, U.S. News & World Report and The Atlantic Monthly.

title: Unabom Defendant Angered Over Questions on His Sanity
description: Theodore J. Kaczynski threw his pen across the defense table today as lawyers debated his refusal to be examined by Government psychiatrists.

title: New U.N. Estimate Doubles Rate of Spread of AIDS Virus
description: Medical experts working for the United Nations say they grossly underestimated the spread of the AIDS virus worldwide, and they now believe that new infections are occurring almost twice as fast as they thought a year ago. Instead of 8,200 new infections a day, they now believe there are 16,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORNSTEIN, HENRIETTA (NEE HOFFMAN)
description: BORNSTEIN-Henrietta (nee Hoffman), 90. On November 24 in Erie, PA., formerly of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved mother of Cynthia Leopold, Natalie Levine and Sonia Weiss. Loving grandmother of seven and 4 great-grandchildren. Sister of Beatrice Farber and Lillian Kislak. Friends are invited to a graveside service Wednesday, 1 PM, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Burton Funeral Home 1-814-454-4551.

title: Dissident's Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Roger Brown, 55, Leading Chicago Imagist Painter, Dies
description: Roger Brown, a leading painter of the Chicago Imagist style, whose radiant, panoramic images were as passionately political as they were rigorously visual, died on Saturday at Piedmont Hospital in Atlanta. He was 55 and had homes and studios in Chicago, New Buffalo, Mich., and Carpenteria, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, GRAY, ELIZABETH (BETTY) NEE LEWIS
description: SMITH-GRAY-Elizabeth (Betty) nee Lewis. On November 22, 1997. Survived by two children, five grandchildren, one great-grandchild, two sisters and a brother. She is mourned and remembered with love by friends and family and will be missed.

title: Child's Tale About Race Has a Tale Of Its Own
description: In December 1934, the poet Langston Hughes went to Mexico City to wrap up the business affairs of his late father, James, only to discover that he had been disinherited. Father and son had had a difficult relationship. James Hughes, a wealthy lawyer and landowner and himself a black man, hated both the racism of the North and Negroes, whom he portrayed in crude racial caricature. Langston had spent only brief periods with his father, many of them in Mexico.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a theater review on Monday about ''Working,'' at the Signature Theater in Arlington, Va., included an erroneous credit for the artistic director, Eric D. Schaeffer. He was not associated with the original production in 1978; the composer, Stephen Schwartz, was.

title: Hotel Group Said To Seek Bids
description: The Interstate Hotels Company, which is said to have received an offer valuing the company at $1.3 billion, has been talking to other suitors about a possible higher bid, according to people close to the negotiations.

title: Liberties; One Life To Give
description: I have met egomaniacal rich guys like Donald Trump, who thinks every woman wants him and every politician fears him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUPPERBLATT, ALEXANDER J.
description: KUPPERBLATT-Alexander J. On November 23, 1997. Devoted son of Harry, loving brother of Jean Gothelf. Services Friday, 12:30PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: DAVEL COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY RIVAL PAY-PHONE PROVIDER
description: Davel Communications Group agreed yesterday to acquire a rival pay-phone provider, Communications Central, for $70 million, including an unspecified amount of assumed debt. The shares of Communications Central surged $1.50 each, or more than 17 percent, to $10. Shares of Davel slipped 75 cents, to $23.75. Davel, based in Tampa, Fla., operates pay telephones and provides long-distance services. It had 1996 revenue of $37 million. Communications Central, based in Atlanta, owns more than 20,000 installed pay phones in 31 states and the District of Columbia. Under the agreement, Davel will pay $10.50 for each of Communications Central's shares outstanding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZARUS, RICHARD
description: LAZARUS-Richard. On November 25, 1997. Devoted father of David and Matthew. Loving brother of Jerome. A leader and a pioneer in the derivatives markets and active in New York politics for over 30 years. Graveside services Friday, 11AM, Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale NY.

title: New Charges for Ex-Judge Who Fled Prison
description: A former Tennessee judge who fled to Mexico was charged today in Federal court with failing to appear to finish a 25-year sentence for sexual assault.

title: WARNER-LAMBERT BOARD APPROVES 3-FOR-1 STOCK SPLIT
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said yesterday that its board had approved a 3-for-1 stock split, pending shareholder approval of an increase in the number of authorized common shares to 1.2 billion from 500 million. If the authorization is approved at the drug maker's annual meeting in April, the split would be payable on May 22 to shareholders of record May 8. The company, which is based in Morris Plains, N.J., said its quarterly dividend, currently 38 cents a share, would be proportionately adjusted. Warner-Lambert last split its stock 2for 1 in May 1996. Warner-Lambert shares rose 37.5 cents, to $142.625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFFERTY, HOPE R.
description: RAFFERTY-Hope R. Age 75, on November 24, 1997, in Greenwich, CT. Beloved sister of James Rafferty, Mrs. Jesse Brownback, and Mrs. Bryan F. Smith, also survived by several nieces and nephews. Funeral services and interment will be private. Memorial donations can be made to Smith College, Northampton, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, J.J.
description: JOSEPH-J.J., 83. Economist, political writer, and peace activist, died Sunday from complications of Parkinson Disease. He graduated from the University of Michigan with a B.A. and a Master's in Public Administration. He worked with the OSS and UNRRA but a promising career in public service was derailed by the political blacklist. At The Purdue Frederick Company he rose to the position Senior Vice President. Mr. Joseph campaigned against the Viet Nam War and the Nuclear Arms Race. ''J.J.J.'', as he was known to his friends, loved to travel, was an avid tennis player, and enjoyed classical music. He remained a Marxist his entire life. Mr. Joseph is survived by Leepee, his wife of 36 years; his siter Tuz; his four children and ten grandchildren.

title: Correction
description: Because of word processing errors, two diagrams with the Bridge column on Thursday displayed the bidding and a partial hand incorrectly. In the bidding diagram, the four bids on the sixth line (starting with 6

title: Second 'Miracle' for Iowan: A Touch-Up
description: In the newsmagazine business, it seems that what goes around comes around.

title: High-Tech Gunk Returns: Splat!
description: Flubber, the magical flying rubber substance first invented by Fred MacMurray in the 1961 hit ''The Absent-Minded Professor,'' is a souvenir of the innocent past. Thanks to John Hughes's head-bashing approach to children's comedy, flubber is now more akin to a dangerous weapon. Just as the ''Home Alone'' films acquainted tiny viewers with the joys of throwing bricks off rooftops, the new ''Flubber'' (written by Mr. Hughes and Bill Walsh, and directed by Mr. Hughes's ''Miracle on 34th Street'' protege Les Mayfield) has fun with flying bowling balls. It also has fun with Robin Williams, but he takes a back seat to the film's main attraction: green Jell-O with attitude.

title: Johnson Tunes In As Parcells Speaks Out
description: Quietly but firmly, Bill Parcells has been helping to reshape Keyshawn Johnson on the field and off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSON, ALBERT
description: RUBINSON-Albert. West End Temple Neponsit New York mourns the death of a devoted member and extends deepest sympathy to his daughter Ellen and family.

title: $48 Million Bank Deal
description: The Union Planters Corporation agreed today to acquire Capital Savings Bancorp of Jefferson City, Mo., for $48 million in stock. Union Planters will pay 0.3812 share, worth $23.13 at today's closing price, for each share of Capital Savings. That is a 25 percent premium to Capital Savings' closing price today of $18.50. Union Planters announced the purchase after the close of trading.

title: Sent From Gay Berlin To Labor at Dachau
description: Seventeen years after ''Bent'' was first produced on Broadway starring Richard Gere and David Dukes, Martin Sherman's harrowing concentration camp drama about the Nazi persecution of homosexuals still has some power to unsettle. In establishing the pink triangle, a concentration camp badge denoting homosexuality, as a symbol of embattled gay pride, ''Bent'' has earned its place in cultural history. And it's still impossible to watch the scene set on a train transporting prisoners to Dachau, in which Nazi officers force a young man to beat his lover to death, without feeling a sickening shudder of dread.

title: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES IN DEALS FOR 5 AUTO DEALERSHIPS
description: Republic Industries has agreed to buy five closely held auto dealer franchises for $30 million in stock, adding to its holdings in Florida and Georgia. Republic, the world's largest auto dealer, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Hub Ford of Tucker, Ga., which generated about $75 million in 1996 revenue, from the franchise owner, Paul Sanders. Terms of the individual purchases were not disclosed. In Florida, Republic agreed to buy Lokey Honda and Lokey Isuzu of Clearwater, with $45 million in revenue from a single location, from Tom Lokey. It agreed to buy Sunrise Nissan of Orange Park, with $40 million in revenue, and Sunrise Nissan of Jacksonville from Phil Risley.

title: A Map for the Blind
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELSKY, LOUIS
description: BELSKY-Louis. Cherished father of Carole Bracco and Steven Belsky. Adored grandfather of Nanci Zubar and Eric Belsky. Dear brother of Philip Belsky. Loving brother-in-law of Esta Rogasky. Beloved uncle of many nephews and nieces. Services on Friday, November 28, at 11 A.M., at the ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', Brooklyn, 312 Coney Island Avenue at Prospect Park.

title: Synovus, on Index, Soars
description: Synovus Financial Corporation stock rose 18 percent yesterday after the Standard & Poor's Corporation said it would add the company to its 500-stock index. It will replace Salomon Inc. after the completion of its acquisition by the Travelers Group. Synovus gained $4.75, to $31.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Synovus, of Columbus, Ga., operates community banks in Georgia, Florida, Alabama and South Carolina.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, NORMAN M.
description: MORRIS-Norman M. 99. In his sleep on November 24. Beloved husband of the late Adele (nee Groden) for sixty years. Devoted father of Arline and Marvin Lubin and Robert and Sandi Morris. Proud grandfather of Kenneth Lubin, Wendy and Paul Aglietti, Carol and Michael Hundert, Lee and Merry Morris, David and Eta Morris, Richard Morris, Jeffrey and Lauren Morris and Deborah Morris and adored by eleven great grandchildren. Devoted brother to Edward and the late Rose and the late Bessie. Services were held at ''The Riverside''.

title: Thomas Is Teamed With Costas on NBC
description: With his dream of team ownership on hiatus, Isiah Thomas yesterday became NBC's top National Basketball Association analyst for at least two seasons.

title: Regents Scale Back New Language Rule
description: In an abrupt reversal, the head of the New York State Board of Regents said yesterday that the board would scale back its recent decision requiring high school students to take three years of a foreign language and for now require only one year.

title: New Works That Use Incantation And Tumult
description: As one of the few orchestras in New York that nurtures new work, the New Juilliard Ensemble has a particular importance in our musical life, and particular responsibilities. In many respects, those responsibilities are being seriously and energetically discharged.

title: Regulators Approve New Manhattan Area Code
description: Facing an imminent shortage of telephone numbers within the 212 area code, state utility regulators today approved a plan to phase in another area code in Manhattan starting in April 1998.

title: ACX TECHNOLOGIES TO BUY BRITTON GROUP FOR $335 MILLION
description: ACX Technologies Inc. of Golden, Colo., agreed yesterday to buy the British paper and packaging company the Britton Group P.L.C. for 140 pence in cash for each Britton ordinary share and 100 pence for each convertible share for a total of $335 million. It will also take on about $85 million in debt and transaction costs. Last month, Britton rejected an offer of about $270 million from the American paperboard company Caraustar Industries. The shares of ACX, which makes ceramics, packaging products and solar electric systems, rose 18.75 cents, to $26.6875. Britton's shares soared 39 pence, to 136.5 pence, in London. The purchase would almost double the size of ACX's graphic packaging unit, which produces folding cartons and flexible packaging.

title: With Airport Bus Routes Lost, Carey Files for Bankruptcy
description: Carey Bus Lines said yesterday that it was withdrawing from a bitter fight for control of bus service to New York City's airports and that it had filed for bankruptcy protection. It turned the remains of its airport service over to another carrier, Private One of New York, in a deal that appeared to cost 136 employees their jobs.

title: Eating Too Well; One Day of Craziness Is Fine, But Then Watch Out
description: THE amount of damage most people can do to themselves on Thanksgiving Day, even if they have seconds of everything, is minimal. Bingeing tomorrow may well cause some immediate regret: bloating, drowsiness, indigestion. But lasting weight gain? Unlikely.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You take enough of them off the road, you're going to save somebody.''

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Thursday about the appointment of Ella Baff as executive director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., misstated her affiliation with Cal Performances, an international arts organization, at the University of California at Berkeley. She was the group's director of education and community programs; the program director is Robert Cole.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in the Footlights column yesterday with a report about the pianist Emanuel Ax was published in error. The pianist shown was Ignat Solzhenitsyn.

title: Embarrassment And Big Losses For Pacificare
description: Joining a lengthening cortege of managed health care companies that have recently apologized for computer glitches and management fumbles after mergers or acquisitions, Pacificare Health Systems said yesterday that it faced unexpected losses in the fourth quarter.

title: Before Playing a Sonata, Play a Bit of Tag ; Musicians Loosen Up Both Muscles and Minds
description: Too often, the field of classical music, with its stiff attire, formal concert settings and tradition-bound programs, seems uptight through and through. And that uptightness is most alarming, and potentially harmful, when it seeps, as it often does, into the actual performance.

title: A Display of U.S. Influence
description: The meeting of leaders from the Pacific Rim brought no quick solutions, but showed American muscle in the area. News analysis, page A12.

title: 2 Are Accused of Faking Celebrity Ties
description: Prosecutors charged two men with fraud yesterday, saying they posed as representatives of the Rolling Stones to get invitations to gala dinners and gifts from hotels and charity groups.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: The Age of Indulgence; Self-Denial Takes a Holiday
description: GET ready for the big one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, EDWARD
description: RYAN-Edward. Born in Hancock, MI, August 24, 1907. Graduate Yale University 1929, New York District Manager for Anaconda Wire and Cable Co., Vice President Anixter Cable Co. Knight of Malta. Survived by daughter, Elaine Ryan Phillips of Bridgewater, NJ, eight grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Memorial services will be held Saturday, November 29 at Boylan Funeral Home, 188 Easton Ave., New Brunswick, New Jersey at 2 P.M. 732-545-4040.

title: Critic's Notebook; Looking Back With Cooled Passions at Che's Image
description: It might be hard, and perhaps a bit painful, for the aging members of the 1960's generation to come to grips with an awful fact: that almost half of America was born after the martyrlike death of Che Guevara in 1967. Indeed, it is probably true that a good portion of that half, currently perhaps living in college dormitories where Che's poster once adorned the walls, has never heard of him or has only a vague idea of who he was and why, for a flickering 20th-century moment, he seemed so important.

title: Subway Crime, on the Rise
description: Crime may be falling in New York City, but it is rising in the city's subways. It is still nearly 70 percent below the 1990 level, and crimes that occur on subways and buses constitute a mere 2.5 percent of all crime committed in the populous five boroughs. But whatever level of comfort one derives from those realities, this is a problem that needs to be squelched before it undermines the public's rebounding confidence in mass transit.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ANHALT, SIDNEY
description: ANHALT-Sidney. April 8, 1876-Nov. 26, 1960. In memory of our dear Dad. Stanley and Amy

title: Fish Are Victorious Over Dam As U.S. Agency Orders Shutdown
description: Handing a landmark victory to fish defenders and river enthusiasts, a Federal agency refused today for the first time to relicense a hydroelectric dam and, going even further, ordered the aging structure on Maine's Kennebec River demolished at the owner's expense.

title: Movements More Figurative Than Literal
description: Wil Swanson describes his new ''Descriptions Without Place,'' performed on Friday night at Dance Theater Workshop, as two dances that are performed simultaneously and then merged. The effect is of dancers lapping out from and back into the wings continuously, drawn very gradually toward the center and moving always as if gently propelled by some force exterior to themselves. Even more, what unfolds before the eyes in this piece and in Mr. Swanson's recent ''to walk among these stones'' is not so much movement that travels through space as much as a shifting tableau. It is as if the deliberately juxtaposed elements in an Oriental garden had come to measured life during the space of the two works.

title: THE ASIAN CRISIS: Watchful Waiting on Japan ; For U.S. and European Markets, a Steady Course So Far
description: Japanese stocks were higher today after a 5.1 percent tumble Tuesday, leaving investors debating whether the Asian turmoil will undermine United States and European stock markets or whether a rebound in both those markets will help bring some stability to Asia.

title: 'Miracle' of Septuplets Betrays Common Sense; Unwitting Siblings?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HATHAWAY, CLEMENS F.
description: HATHAWAY-Clemens F. Former Vice President at J. Walter Thompson died Nov. 13, 1997 at his home in Totowa, New Jersey. The cause of death was complications following a series of strokes. He was 83 years old. Mr. Hathaway began his long career in advertising at J. Walter Thompson in 1935 where he quickly made a mark as an innovative account manager. His work there was punctuated by some intermissions including stints at two other agencies and World War II service as a Navy Lieutenant JG in the Pacific Theater. He spent the years from 1947 to 1961 at Control-O-Gram in Illinois. On his return to New York, he rejoined Thompson as a vice president. There he stayed until 1966 when BBDO hired him to manage their Burger King business. When Thompson won the large national account in 1976, Clem was quickly lured back. A creative account manager, he spearheaded the memorable Burger King work of that period. He retired in 1981 and is still remembered with affection by those who had the pleasure of working with him. His wife of 27 years, Mildred, his sons from a previous marriage, John of Darien, CT., and David of Millbrook, NY, four grandsons and one granddaughter survive Mr. Hathaway. A memorial service will be held Sunday, December 14 at 3PM in the Noroton, CT. Presbyterian Church. Memorial contributions may be sent to Mr. Hathaway's alma mater, Union College, C/O Annual Fund Office, Schenectady, New York 12308.

title: Like Feeding A Jukebox In the 1960's
description: A few years back, a show called ''Catskills on Broadway'' brought the sensibility of Grossinger's to midtown. Now, with ''Street Corner Symphony,'' we get Caesar's Palace on West 47th Street.

title: Agency Shifts Gears As a Founder Retires
description: Liggett-Stashower Inc. in Cleveland said yesterday that it would make changes in management and ownership as a result of a decision by David L. Stashower, chairman and chief executive, to retire and sell his interest in the agency, which he helped form in 1987.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, JOHN
description: KENNEDY-John. On November 23, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Bridget (nee Spellman). Funeral Mass Wednesday, Holy Trinity R.C. Church, 213 W. 82 Street, NYC 11:30 AM. Interment Saint Raymond's Cemetery.

title: Under Fire, District's Police Chief Quits
description: The District of Columbia police chief retired today, declaring that he had to step aside to keep a controversy over his personal life from hurting his department.

title: The Chef
description: THE demand for salmon, both in restaurants and at home, has been climbing steadily for years now. And I concede that anyone can cook it more or less decently. But to cook it truly well -- so that the rich, natural butteriness is not only preserved but also enhanced -- is not as easy as it might seem.

title: INSIDE
description: Fish 1, Dam 0

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYPER, STUART A.
description: MAYPER-Stuart A. November 25, 1997, of Ridgefield, CT. Husband of Irene Ross-Mayper. Father of Monica and Thomas Mayper. Stepfather of Andrea McIlroy and Jamie Ross. Brother of June Mayper. Grandfather of Alexander Mayper. Funeral services Friday, 1:00 P.M., Hawthorne Funeral Home, 21 Stevens Avenue, Hawthorne, New York 914-769-4404. Interment: Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Hudson Waterfront Needn't Become a Mall
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqi Opens His Palaces (but Not to Those U.N. Inspectors)
description: In one of his efforts to head off further trouble over arms inspections, President Saddam Hussein today invited foreign experts -- but not United Nations inspectors -- to come and live in his presidential palaces for up to a month to expose as ''lies'' American accusations that there are weapons hidden in any of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BISSELL, GREGORY F.
description: BISSELL-Gregory F., O.F.M. (Brother Thorn) of Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ, Nov. 25, 1997. Husband of Griselda (Ballester). Father of Griselda Clare Gadsby, Jacksonville, N.C., G. Thaddeus, Allendale, N.J., Mark G., Middletown, NY & Christopher B., Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J. Brother of Stephen J., Valley Cottage, N.Y., Beryl Singleton-Bissell, Minn, MN. and Judy Solay, Douglas, GA. Grandfather of Emilia, Edward, Gregory Lee, Matthew, Elizabeth, Caroline, Jonathan, Kate, Zachary, Julia Grace, Jake, Rebecca and Kyle. Mass will be celebrated on Saturday, Nov. 29, 1997, 10 AM. Presentation R.C. Church, Upper Saddle River, N.J. Interment St. Luke's Cemetery, Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J. Friends will be received on Friday 2-4 & 7-9 PM in the Van EmburghSneider Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Avenue, Ramsey, New Jersey. Donations to: Sacred Heart Friary, C/O Holy Name Friary, 2 Morris Rd., Ringwood, N.J. 07456 would be appreciated. Born March 2, 1930 in Bronx, N.Y. He was raised in the Suffern, N.Y. area. Married 1959. Member of the 3rd order of Franciscans. Parishioner of Presentation R.C. Church, Upper Saddle River. Graduate of the Kings Point Merchant Marine Academy (3 years). Formerly owned the Sneaker Stadium in Englewood, N.J. in 1970s and 1980s. A Lieutenant in the U.S. Army, Korea Conflict (1951-1953). He was in the credit card industry-in sales and marketing with American Express, Carte Blanche, Diners Club, Mastercardand other cards. He was a prolific writer, avid gardener, chef and counselor to many.

title: 16-Year-Old Is Under Arrest In Death of Teacher's Aide
description: At first, it appeared to be a simple case of a heart attack. John Morales, a 61-year-old school aide who worked in the locker room at Midwood High School in Brooklyn and had a history of heart problems, collapsed in a school hallway on Monday morning and died in the hospital on Tuesday, the police said.

title: Islanders Are No Doormats As Rangers Come Visiting
description: It has been difficult to gauge these Islanders. One game they are pulling off the unlikeliest of upsets. Then, a few days later, they are struggling against one of the Eastern Conference's worst teams.

title: Plan to Lease Stewart Airport Is Approved
description: The Federal Government has given preliminary approval to the Pataki administration's proposal to lease Stewart International Airport in New Windsor, N.Y., to a private company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANDEL, MORTON
description: KANDEL-Morton. Temple B'nai Sholom mourns the loss of our long-time member. We extend condolences to the family. Services Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, graveside on Sunday at 1 P.M. Dr. Martin Greenberg, President Dr. Barry Dov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: Mutilated Female Body Is Found in a New Jersey Lake
description: The New Jersey State Police removed the body of an unidentified woman from a lake in rural northwestern New Jersey yesterday afternoon, and police officials in New York City said they were investigating the possibility that it was a missing Manhattan woman.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Last Domino
description: Russia has got Thailand disease, and I'm not talking about the flu.

title: Topics of The Times; Getting Off The List
description: State Education Commissioner Richard P. Mills announced earlier this month that a record number of New York City's worst schools had improved enough to leave the state's list of failing schools. It was an uplifting accomplishment after so much pessimism about the plight of urban education.

title: INSIDE
description: Art Vandal Strikes Again

title: LUND BUYING DEFLECTA-SHIELD FOR $90 MILLION
description: Lund International Holdings Inc. agreed to buy the Deflecta-Shield Corporation for $90 million, creating the nation's largest maker of light-truck accessories. Lund plans to pay $16 a share for all 4.8 million Deflecta-Shield shares outstanding. Lund would also assume $10 million of debt. Shares of Deflecta-Shield jumped $3.5625 a share, to $15.5625, in Nasdaq trading, where Lund rose 25 cents, to $12.875. The acquisition would increase Lund's 1998 revenue to $130 million. Deflecta-Shield, based in Indianola, Iowa, makes bug shields, running boards, visors, tool boxes and other accessories for trucks, while Lund, based in Anoka, Minn., makes similar products for light trucks, including pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and mini-vans.

title: Metro Matters; For D'Amato, Trying to Pick Right Critics
description: AS his 17 years in the Senate have amply demonstrated, Alfonse M. D'Amato is a man who loves a good fight. Especially one in which his opponent is already on the ropes. Just think of the pummeling he gave the Swiss. Or his recent grandstanding against toxic waste.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think the argument traces back to a fundamental split in educational philosophy. One view is sort of characterized by this Rousseauian romanticism that sees children as wildflowers that bloom naturally when they are ready. The other sees children as crops that you have to plow, water and fertilize.''

title: Hudson Waterfront Needn't Become a Mall
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Your Typical Russian Revolution
description: The Irondale Ensemble Project likes its plays layered. The company usually takes a story or drama and turns its performance into a dramatic disquisition on the ideas in the tale. With its production of Bertolt Brecht's 1931 parable ''The Mother,'' it may be performing its ultimate stretch: this version spans 92 years.

title: In America; The Quality of Mercy
description: Angela Thompson will be praying today for a favorable nod from Gov. George Pataki. She has reason to hope.

title: J. W. CHILDS TO BUY UNIVERSAL HOSPITAL FOR $133 MILLION
description: J. W. Childs Equity Partners L.P. agreed yesterday to acquire Universal Hospital Services Inc., a medical-equipment rental concern, for $15.50 a share, or $133 million, including assumed debt. Shares of Universal Hospital surged nearly 23 percent, rising $2.75, to $14.75, on the Nasdaq stock market. J. W. Childs, based in Boston, is an investment management firm. Universal Hospital, based in Bloomington, Minn., rents movable medical equipment to more than 3,300 hospitals and alternate-care providers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUTTNER, SHARLAND TROTTER
description: KUTTNER-Sharland Trotter. After an inspirational 3-year journey, at home, November 25. Loving wife of Robert Kuttner, sister of John Trotter, mother of Gabriel and Jessica, mother-in-law of Kate, and daughter-in-law of Polly. Grace was her middle name. Memorial service Wednesday, December 3, 11 A.M., at Memorial Church, Harvard Yard. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent in Sharland's name in honor of Dr. Lowell Schnipper to Boston's Beth Israel Hospital.

title: Embryo 'Adoption' Is Ethical Conundrum
description: To the Editor:

title: Lots of Lobbying, but No Decision on Rail Link to Kennedy Airport
description: Federal officials, who were expected to rule last week on a $1.5 billion plan for a rail connection to Kennedy International Airport, have still not issued a decision, a delay that seems to reflect the extraordinary pressure being applied by both proponents and foes of the project.

title: House Proud; A Book Collector's Walls of Words
description: THIRTY years ago, Polly Wittenberg, a lawyer, avid reader and collector of books, moved into a one-bedroom apartment in Greenwich Village. Built in the 1930's, it had crown moldings and a working fireplace -- the comforting touches of a grander house.

title: Rise in Hunger Prompts City to Approve $2 Million for Food
description: Since the end of summer, when Federal welfare law cut off thousands of immigrants from food stamps, there has been a significant increase in hunger in New York City, the directors of food pantries and social service agencies say. Many assistance programs have begun to run out of food and are cutting back their hours or preparing less expensive, meatless meals.

title: Tests on Mice Block a Defense by Cancer
description: Many drugs work well at first against cancer, but the tumor cells quickly develop resistance. A concept for getting around the resistance problem has now been proved, at least in laboratory mice, and may well prove relevant to the treatment of human cancer.

title: Meditrust Drops Out of Interstate Talks
description: The Meditrust Corporation's chairman and chief executive, Abraham Gosman, said today that his company had withdrawn from talks about acquiring the Interstate Hotels Corporation.

title: Civil Rights Groups Misjudged Piscataway Case; Easy Case, Bad Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Area Code Angst in Manhattan
description: The proliferation of modern electronic conveniences -- fax machines, cellular phones, computer modems -- has nearly depleted the available supply of telephone numbers in the 212 area code. New York State's Public Service Commission has therefore voted to add a second area code, 646, for any new phone connections in Manhattan, beginning next year. That would seem a trivial price to pay for all those wonderful new gadgets. But as the commission discovered, changing an area code is not a trivial matter. Getting the big things done in Manhattan can be so difficult that people tend to cling to small conveniences and howl inordinately when one of them is threatened.

title: Moving Quickly, Blue Jays Snatch Myers From Orioles
description: The Baltimore Orioles can complain about piracy on the high seas, because the Toronto Blue Jays stole Randy Myers away from them yesterday by way of an ocean liner docked in Barbados.

title: RUSSIA IS SEEKING MORE WESTERN AID FOR FINANCIAL ILLS
description: Worried that the global economic turmoil could overwhelm its financial system, Russia is quietly seeking American support for an expanded program of Western assistance, government officials and private bankers said.

title: Civil Rights Groups Misjudged Piscataway Case; Debate Is Stifled
description: To the Editor:

title: Despair Grows Over Problems Of Governing U.S. Capital
description: Allegations this week of corruption in the District of Columbia's police force have led to another round of despair over the management of the nation's capital.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Bernie Casey; A Filmmaker Battling Flawed Images of Blacks
description: Bernie Casey is ordering lunch at Aquavit restaurant, and the one thing he is insistent about is that he doesn't want any of ''those purple leaves'' in his salad. He doesn't eat red meat, either. He orders a bottle of water rather than a glass of wine.

title: President's Proclamation
description: Following is the text of President Clinton's Thanksgiving Day proclamation:

title: What AIDS Education?
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics of The Times; Weighing the Needs Of Nature
description: In 1986, Congress required the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which oversees the nation's privately run hydroelectric dams, to balance environmental values with energy generation when renewing a dam's license. On Tuesday, the agency invoked that mandate for the first time when it refused to relicense a small, aging hydroelectric dam on Maine's Kennebec River and ordered that it be removed. The decision means that nine species of Atlantic fish, including salmon and sturgeon, will recapture access to their traditional upriver spawning grounds.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about two brothers who created the new Living Map of Manhattan reversed their identities. Danniel S. Maio was on the right and Jackson C. Maio on the left.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: SHARES OF GREAT ATLANTIC AND PACIFIC TEA DECLINE 16%
description: Shares of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company skidded 16 percent yesterday after the company, the operator of the A&P supermarket chain, said its third-quarter profits would be below Wall Street's expectations. The company, based in Montvale, N.J., and a unit of Tengelmann A.G., said Tuesday after markets closed that it expected to earn less for the quarter ending on Saturday than it did a year ago. It had net income of $14.1 million, or 37 cents a share in the period a year ago. Analysts surveyed had predicted profits of 44 cents. Shares of Great Atlantic and Pacific dropped $5.8125, to $30.

title: Holiday Gift Books: From the Inspiration Front (And Hardly Bookish); A Sherwood Forest of Fringe, and Advice on Stencils and Patterns
description: DESIGN books that truly inspire often do it on the sly. The lessons they reveal are more likely to apply to the life of the imagination than the latest style in window treatments. Luckily, there are books out for the holidays that will catch the attention of the restless eye. They encompass worlds that are recognizable but at the same time alluringly creative, from a rural French farm family's home ''decorated'' with a frieze of corncobs to the Windsors' elegant exile in the Bois de Boulogne, customized to within an inch of its life with watermarked ''Don't Forget'' memo pads. The books delve into the texture of sensibility -- not just color or pattern. Here's what our contributors have brought back from their travels through some of the season's best titles.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SUSSMAN, JACK R.
description: SUSSMAN-Jack R. Today is your birthday, lovingly remembered. Bette

title: Broncos' Secret Is Out: Psst! It's Rod Smith
description: It was a locker room filled with spirit, filled with joy, just the kind of emotion expected from one of pro football's top teams.

title: The Fight In Mexico Over Big Oil
description: The restless man holding forth on politics, perched on the edge of a hospital bed in a musty jail, would seem an unlikely human rights hero.

title: Thai Good News Sends Stocks Up
description: Thai stocks rose today for the first time in eight days, buoyed by an International Monetary Fund endorsement of the country's latest economic measures and the release of additional credits to bolster foreign reserves.

title: A Nostalgic Balladeer In Fog and Foggy Love
description: In Harry Connick Jr.'s new songs, love is a hypothetical situation. The best moments of his concert at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night, his first New York City appearance in two and a half years, were the cuts from his new orchestral ballad album, ''To See You'' (Columbia/Sony). They intimated romance not so much as highs and lows, thrills and pain, but a zone of intriguingly spaced-out indecision.

title: 40 on Trial in Paris on Charges of Aiding '95 Algerian Bombers
description: Forty people accused of helping Algerian Islamic militants plant bombs that killed 8 people and wounded more than 170 in Paris in 1995 went on trial this week.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about efforts to increase the work force at the Federal Election Commission referred incorrectly to its current staff. While the office has 52 enforcement specialists, only 2 are investigators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTONE, EDMUND F.
description: JOHNSTONE-Edmund F. Age 88, of Point Manalapan, died Sunday, November 23, 1997. Mr. Johnstone was an area resident since 1973, coming here from New York. He was an advertising executive from the mid 1930's until his retirement in 1973. He was preceded in death by his son, Edmund F. (Ned) Johnstone, Jr., in 1988. Survivors include his wife of 47 years Janet Olcott Johnstone; 2 sons Chauncey O. Johnstone of Charlotte, NC and Charles T. Johnstone of New Canaan, CT; two daughters Lammy O. Johnstone-Kockler of Solvang, CA and Jyll Johnstone-Davis of Belvedere, CA. He is also survived by 2 daughters from his first marriage: Heather Beebe of Wellington, FL., and Dawn Gulvas of Chaverstown, PA; 10 grandchildren and three great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11:30 A.M. Friday, November 28, 1997 at Babione-Stephenson Funeral Home, 1004 S. Dixie Hwy., Lantana with the Rev. William E. Hamilton officiating. Memorials may be made to the Lighthouse for the Blind, 7810 S. Dixie Hwy., West Palm Beach, FL 33405 or the American Heart Association, 1301 S. Olive Ave., West Palm Beach, FL. 33401 in memory of Mr. Johnstone.

title: Schroder Unit Buys Swiss Clothing Retailer
description: Schroder Ventures said yesterday that it had bought Charles Voegele Group, a Swiss family-owned clothing retailer, for $:340 million ($544 million). Schroder Ventures, the venture capital arm of the London investment bank Schroders P.L.C., said it planned to take Voegele public within three years.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about an announcement by Pa cificare Health Systems that it faced unexpected losses in the fourth quarter misstated the name of a subsidiary. It is Secure Horizons, not Security Horizons.

title: Whitman Urged to Block Increase in Price of Milk
description: A trade association of dairy processors asked Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday to block a proposed 10-cent-a-gallon increase in the price of milk, saying it could cost consumers as much as $19 million a year.

title: The Neediest Cases; Offering Thanks in a Shelter for the Abused
description: There is a flash of defiance in Tasha B.'s expression, a self-assured grace in her walk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINER, OSCAR
description: STEINER-Oscar. On November 23, 1997 in Pompano Beach, FL. Beloved husband, father, greatgrandfather and great-greatgrandfather. Survived by his wife Mitzi, three children, Gloria, Robert and Michael.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARETSKY, IRVING
description: ZARETSKY-Irving. To Allan, Irving's great gift of life will always live through you. Our heartfelt condolences to you and your entire family. The Kaufman Family

title: Netanyahu Says Clinton's Refusal to Meet Him 'Humiliated' Israel
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel lashed out at President Clinton today, declaring that ''the entire Jewish state feels humiliated'' by Mr. Clinton's refusal to meet him during Mr. Netanyahu's visit to the United States last week.

title: A Trio That Shows Itself Mainly by Thirds
description: Trio, a collective group featuring Joshua Redman on saxophone, Christian McBride on bass and Brian Blade on drums, has all the blessings of a supergroup and all the curses, too. By this point in their careers, the three have established themselves as some of the better-known, and more imposing, musicians in the jazz world. On Tuesday night at the Village Vanguard, for their second set, they relied less on a group concept than on individual improvising.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Nov. 11, about research on mammals able to dive deep in the oceans, misstated the extent to which seven juvenile seals in one study slowed their heart beats while diving. Their mean heart rate fell to 39 beats per minute -- not 68 beats -- from 107 beats on land.

title: Kenya's Leader Moves to Divide His Enemies Before Election
description: In a move that appeared calculated to further divide an already splintered opposition, President Daniel arap Moi's Government lifted a ban on the liberal Safina party today, clearing the way for it to field candidates in general elections next month.

title: As Devils Coast, Guerin Is Looking to Catch Up
description: It has been less than one week since he returned to the Devils' lineup, but Bill Guerin can already feel the improvement. His legs are stronger, owing to the conditioning the rangy forward maintained during his contract dispute. What will take longer to come into place is his timing.

title: Behind Korea's Plunge
description: South Korea has competed brilliantly in basic industries like steel and semiconductors, and has moved ahead quickly in high technology. Yet financial markets are teetering, the Korean currency has nose-dived, and International Monetary Fund officials are considering South Korea's request for a $20 billion bailout loan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAYLIS, CHESTER, JR.
description: BAYLIS-Chester, Jr. November 25, 1997 at his home in Locust, New Jersey at age eighty-nine. He is survived by his wife Dorothy Smith, his son Robert M., three grandsons Robert W., David M. and John C., and one great granddaughter Emma Kate. His career at Bankers Trust New York Corporation spanned 44 years, and he was Chairman of the Executive Committee. Funeral services will be held at St. George's By The River Episcopal Church in Rumson, New Jersey, Saturday, November 29 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544 or to Riverview Medical Center, Red Bank, N.J. 07701.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELSON, KATHY PLASZNER
description: BELSON-Kathy Plaszner. On November 26, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Michael, cherished mother of Jaclyn and Jonathan. Devoted daughter of Ervin and Terry Plaszner. Adored sister of Suzanne Weinstein. Beloved niece of Michael Plassner. Loving daughter-in-law of Jerome and Maxine Belson. Services Friday 11AM, from Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83 St, NY, NY.

title: Palette Is Small, but Colors Are Bright
description: The marimba can be an important part of many musical puzzles. Indeed, as an ensemble instrument, its striking qualities both fit in and set off. It does a handful of things very well and others not at all. And this is the built-in condition confronting Makoto Nakura, an engaging young Japanese marimbist presented by Young Concert Artists at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday night. Mr. Nakura does excellent things with his instrument; the question remains, can it do enough for him in return?

title: Annals of the Scholarly Afterthought
description: THE FOOTNOTE

title: Ex-Video Company Chief Settles Charges
description: Charles O. Huttoe, the former chairman and chief executive of Systems of Excellence Inc., has agreed to surrender $8 million to settle regulators' charges that he manipulated his company's stock in one of the biggest cases ever of Internet stock-touting fraud.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVINE, SIDNEY
description: LEVINE-Sidney. Nov. 6, 1923-Nov. 27, 1972. Remembered everyday. Zulema, Dodi, Nina, Noemi, Josh, Matthew

title: A Healthy Economy Shows Some Signs of Taking It a Little Easier
description: The economy remains strong but is cooling off, Government reports indicated today, showing lower orders for long-lasting goods in October and a little less total output over the summer than initially estimated.

title: Laidlaw Files Suit Against Safety-Kleen
description: The Laidlaw Environmental Services Corporation has sued the Safety-Kleen Corporation to prevent it from selling itself to a group led by the Philip Services Corporation for $1.58 billion.

title: Ira Wolfert, 89, Whose Novel Is Basis of a Film Noir of the 40's
description: Ira Wolfert, a Pulitzer Prize-winning war correspondent in World War II who wrote the acclaimed 1943 novel ''Tucker's People,'' on which the cult movie ''Force of Evil'' was based, died on Monday at Mountainside Residential Care Center in Margaretville, N.Y. He was 89 and lived in Lake Hill, N.Y.

title: Life's Emotions, From Love to Despair
description: Dance Rink, a company founded last year, presented an unpretentious and often agreeable program on Saturday night at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center.

title: Civil Rights Groups Misjudged Piscataway Case; Legal Role for Teacher
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Digits Are More Than Just a Number; Many in Status-Conscious Manhattan Draw the Line Between 212 and 646
description: They have always been proud, 212 people. But now they face an uncertain future in which some of them may be 646 people.

title: Samsung Cuts Jobs and Pay As Koreans Brace for Pain
description: South Koreans received a taste today of the painful overhaul of their economy that lies ahead as the Samsung Group, the nation's second-largest conglomerate, announced that it would sharply reduce investment, shift about 30 percent of its 260,000 employees into new jobs and cut management salaries.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Banks in Japan Struggle Despite Cash Aid
description: Japanese banks found it increasingly difficult and expensive to borrow money today despite an enormous injection of cash into the troubled financial system by the Bank of Japan.

title: Italy to Sell Shares In Alitalia to Cut Stake
description: Italy said yesterday that it would reduce its stake in Alitalia S.p.A. to about 60 percent from about 85 percent by selling shares to private investors rather than injecting more Government money into the airline. The decision trims by 340 billion lire ($200 million) the Government's share of a 2.75 trillion lire bailout of the airline approved by the European Commission in July.

title: Sports of The Times; Some 1997 Thank-You Notes
description: IF it's Thanksgiving Day, it's time to remember to thank those who make sports' little corner of the world a better place:

title: F.A.A. Orders Safety Change In Boeing 747's
description: The Federal Aviation Administration ordered an immediate change today in fuel pumps in Boeing 747's and also proposed a change in the wiring of older planes of that model, saying that tests conducted after the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 indicated that both are potential causes of a midair explosion.

title: Werner Hofer, 84, a Fallen Idol Of TV Journalism in Germany
description: Werner Hofer, one of the best-known television journalists in postwar Germany, whose career was ended by reports about his activities under the Nazis, died at his home in Cologne Tuesday night, German television reported. He was 84.

title: Metro Business; Spinoff Company Formed
description: Vornado Realty Trust of Saddle Brook, N.J., plans to spin off a new company in December to allow it to expand into non-real-estate businesses, the company said in a Federal Securities and Exchange Commission filing this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTOFORIDES, NICHOLAS
description: CHRISTOFORIDES-Nicholas. The physicians and staff of The Kyrenia Center for Interventional Cardiology, New York Hospital Queens extend their sympathy to our founder and benefactor, Phillip Christopher and the entire Christopher family on the passing of their father. May his memory be eternal.

title: The Tudjman Tirade
description: Croatia has just become the first country in the former East bloc to criminalize the work of George Soros's Open Society Institute. Last week, a Zagreb court convicted the Croatian institute's director and accountant of falsifying official records, a charge that the institute claims is purely political. There is good reason to doubt the Government's case. The Croatian Government is systematically attacking all the country's major independent institutions in a crude campaign of intimidation.

title: Queens Company Bilked Writers on Internet, State Suit Says
description: The New York State Attorney General's office has filed a lawsuit against a Queens company that it said used the Internet to portray itself falsely as a literary agency to bilk aspiring writers out of thousands of dollars.

title: Fund-Raiser for Young Victim of Crime Is Sued
description: The sheer savagery of the attack seemed to slice into people's hearts.

title: Beijing on the Brink? Perils of a Giant Economy
description: If one country looks most vulnerable to the kind of financial disaster now engulfing much of Asia, it is China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, NORMAN
description: MORRIS-Norman. The Board of Trustees, Administration and Medical Staff of The Hospital for Joint Diseases Orthopaedic Institute and The Officers of The HJD Research and Development Foundation are saddened to learn of the passing of Norman Morris, a Founder of The Foundation and a committed friend and loyal benefactor of the hospital. His lifetime of dedicated service and philanthropic support of our initiatives in pediatric orthopaedics will always be remembered. We extend our condolences to his daughter, Arline Lubin, his son, Robert and to the entire family. William A. Perlmuth Chairman of the Board George M. Jaffin Chairman of the Foundation Victor H. Frankel, MD President John N. Kastanis, FACHE Chief Executive Officer Joseph D. Zuckerman, MD Surgeon-In-Chief

title: 3 Presidents Defend Bid To Belong To NATO
description: The three Presidents of the Central European countries that have been invited to join NATO are unlikely to make an appearance in the Senate committee rooms in Washington where the debate over expanding the alliance will heat up early next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFSON, MARJORIE
description: WOLFSON - Marjorie. Beloved wife of the late Paul Wolfson. Devoted mother of Steven Wolfson, M.D., and Sarah Spoerri. Adored grandmother of Ellen P. Wolfson, Roger S. Wolfson, Michael Spoerri, Karl Spoerri and Sasha Spoerri. She was a psychiatric social worker at the Maimonides Hospital. Contributions to the Shorefront Jewish Geriatric Center, West 29th Street at Boardwalk, Brooklyn, New York. Services were held at ''The Riverside.''

title: BASEBALL: From Kid Hero to Ambassador; The Marlins' Edgar Renteria Takes His Game Home to Colombia
description: For many Colombians, baseball arrived on the last Sunday in October with Edgar Renteria's tie-breaking single in the bottom of the 11th that won the World Series for the Florida Marlins. Renteria may be the Marlins' shortstop, but he is first and foremost Colombia's own.

title: London Journal; All Is Not Lost: Art of Insult Survives 'New Britain'
description: Just when people nostalgic for a pricklier Britain were lamenting that the country was losing its touch for the wounding insult, two of the country's best-known writers have come to the rescue with a cascade of abusive comments about one another.

title: Riffs and Pyrotechnics For an Arty Setting
description: ''Is this place always like this?'' a teen-age girl in neo-1970's clothes asked a security guard at Avery Fisher Hall, before the start of Friday night's Sonic Youth concert. He looked puzzled. ''I mean, these lights, those scooped-out things'' -- she gestured to the pretty rows of light bulbs along the balconies, the sound-sculpturing architectural devices above the stage -- ''did Sonic Youth do that?''

title: Economic Scene ; Players in the Asian crisis: Are they up to the solution?
description: WHILE the pronouncements from the Pacific summit meeting in Vancouver were short on substance, the subtext was clear enough: If the ailing Asian tigers are prepared to let free markets work their healing wonders, the industrial powers will do what is necessary to prevent collateral damage.

title: Police Investigate Fatal Fall as Possible Homicide
description: An 18-year-old woman fell 11 stories to her death yesterday morning from a housing project in the East Village, and the police said they were investigating the case as a possible homicide.

title: Civil Rights Groups Misjudged Piscataway Case; Diversity Is in the Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: Hotter Times Coming
description: To the Editor:

title: Dallas Confident in Defense for the Stretch
description: There is no such thing as a Dallas Cowboys loss without outrageous repercussions. In the wake of Green Bay's 45-17 bombing of the local heroes on Sunday, fingers were pointed at the National Football League's second-rated defense and specifically at the coordinator, Dave Campo.

title: Reader's Digest Eliminates Cash Bonuses
