description: The Reader's Digest Association Inc. has made employee stock options more valuable while saying it will not make enough profit to award annual cash bonuses.

title: An Uncomfortable Winnie Mandela Faces Cleric She Accused
description: For the first time today, Winnie Madikizela-Mandela looked uncomfortable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEADERS, PAUL L., JR.
description: MEADERS-Paul L., Jr. Bronxville, on November 25, 1997. Beloved husband of Jane. Loving father of Phyliss Hurley and Paul L. Meaders III. Cherished grandfather of Patricia R. and William P. Hurley. Memorial service at Christ Church in Bronxville, on Friday, November 28, at 1 P.M.

title: MILLER BREWING SELLS ITS 20% STAKE IN MOLSON
description: The Molson Companies Ltd. and Foster's Brewing Group Ltd. bought the Miller Brewing Company's 20 percent stake in Molson Breweries for $306 million, giving them each 50 percent of Canada's largest brewery. The Toronto-based Molson Companies said it would pay $147 million for half of Miller's position in Canada's largest brewer. Molson and Foster's also acquired an interest in a United States distribution company headed by Miller. The venture, Molson USA, would distribute Molson and Foster's brands in the United States. Each would own 24.95 percent of the venture. Miller, a unit of the Philip Morris Companies, would own the rest.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; Adulation Gone, Delights Remain
description: Carl Maria von Weber was a hero to our own Romantic heroes, but they are long dead, and a lot of Weber's reputation died with them. Chopin, not known for charity toward colleagues past or current, admired and learned from Weber's piano style. Berlioz described him as ''one of the most refined and intellectual of musicians.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORLIKOFF, DAVID
description: ORLIKOFF-David. Of North Branford, CT., died peacefully on November 23, at the age of 88. Born in Brooklyn, NY, he graduated from Columbia College in 1929 and from Columbia Law School in 1932. During World War II he served overseas with the Army Corps of engineers. As a trial attorney with the Department of Justice from 1948 to 1977, he represented the government in many important cases, earning commendations from several different Attorneys General. David Orlikoff was universally admired during his lifetime, and will long be remembered after his death, as a man of extraordinary intellect and cultivation. His wife Dorothy and sister Sylvia Schein having predeceased him, he is survived and mourned by his sister Anne O. Schiller, his nephews Seth Schein, Jonathan Schein, Daniel Schiller, and Joel Schiller; and his seven grandnephews and grandnieces. Funeral Friday, 10 AM at Morris Brothers, Dix Hills, L.I.

title: Arts Abroad; For Western Paintings, Chinese Curiosity (and Yawns)
description: When the director of a Paris gallery arrived here recently for an international art show, he carried with him a handful of paintings by modern masters. He had little hope of selling them, but the director, Jean-Marc DeCrop, felt sure that the pieces, some of which were having their China debuts, would draw a crowd of admirers.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: INSIDE
description: The regulars in Prospect Park are fearful, and resolute, after 2 shootings.

title: Stocks Close Mixed, With Dow Off 14.17
description: Investors gained some solace from calmer markets in Asia yesterday, but uncertainty about the extent of the problems in the region and the fallout on corporate earnings of American multinationals left Wall Street stocks mixed.

title: Metro Business; Owner Sells Mansion Leased by Polo Store
description: The 99-year-old Rhinelander mansion at Madison Avenue and 72d Street, which has been the flagship store for the Polo/Ralph Lauren Corporation since 1986, has been sold to an undisclosed German institution for $36.25 million, or a lofty $1,300 per square foot, but less than the amount it was sold for eight years ago.

title: The Nets Just Can't Keep Up With Suns
description: The Nets could look across the court tonight and see the image of what they are aspiring to. The way they reacted to a huge second-half deficit, that someday may not be far off. New Jersey's opponent, the Phoenix Suns, is athletic and deep, a mixture of proven veterans and younger stars. They can shoot and they can run.

title: Bridge; Defense, Winning a Trick, Lets a Contract Succeed
description: Players from the New York metropolitan area are winning most of the titles at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here this week. First, Sylvia Moss of Manhattan was a winner in the Women's Pairs. Then Jim Krekorian and Bob Blanchard of Manhattan, who are defending the Blue Ribbon Pairs title, won the Open Board-a-Match Teams with John Rengstorff, also of Manhattan, and Doug Doub of West Hartford, Conn. And the Women's Teams was won by Sue Picus of Manhattan, Lisa Berkowitz of Old Tappan, N.J., Rozanne Pollack of Warren, N.J., and Connie Goldberg of Philadelphia.

title: Jets Rely On Defense For Ride Into First
description: Of all the units on the Jets team in the stunning turnaround from league doormat to first-place resident, none has received as much tinkering and tender loving care from Coach Bill Parcells as the defensive line.

title: Civil Rights Groups Misjudged Piscataway Case; Moving Beyond Dialogue
description: To the Editor:

title: One Tough Bird, After All; How Public Broadcasting Survived the Attacks Of Conservatives
description: Three years ago, the Republicans who had just won control of Congress made abolition of public broadcasting a major goal of their conservative revolution, contending that it was an electronic soapbox for a liberal agenda.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the last asking price before the sale. ''Weeks on market'' refers only to the listing by the most recent broker.

title: Civil Rights Groups Misjudged Piscataway Case
description: To the Editor:

title: A Windfall Is In Hand, But Shortfalls Still Loom
description: Even as it presented plans for using an unexpected windfall in tax revenues, the Giuliani administration emphasized yesterday that the city still faced large projected budget shortfalls in the coming years -- gaps that officials said they would try to close in part by cutting spending at municipal agencies.

title: Holiday Gift Books: From the Inspiration Front (And Hardly Bookish); When Humans Encounter Nature, Something (and Someone) Will Change
description: DESIGN books that truly inspire often do it on the sly. The lessons they reveal are more likely to apply to the life of the imagination than the latest style in window treatments. Luckily, there are books out for the holidays that will catch the attention of the restless eye. They encompass worlds that are recognizable but at the same time alluringly creative, from a rural French farm family's home ''decorated'' with a frieze of corncobs to the Windsors' elegant exile in the Bois de Boulogne, customized to within an inch of its life with watermarked ''Don't Forget'' memo pads. The books delve into the texture of sensibility -- not just color or pattern. Here's what our contributors have brought back from their travels through some of the season's best titles.

title: Smell Something? Yes, The Scent of a Dollar; Costly Factors Drive the Perfume War
description: A woman can smell like just about anything she wants to these days.

title: Personal Shopper; Inspiration a la Carte From show house to your house.
description: THE theme ''home for the holidays'' is woven throughout the Cancer Research Institute's show house, open through Dec. 10. But some of the ideas spotted inside -- potpourri in the fireplace, a wire menorah that looks like the Brooklyn Bridge, an electronic Yamaha player piano to make holiday music -- could be at home anywhere.

title: Girl Ordered To Disclose Sexual Past In Her Lawsuit
description: Last year, a 15-year-old girl calling herself Nancy appeared on the Sally Jessy Raphael show and described her life as a runaway and a prostitute. When her mother learned of the show from friends, she was not pleased. After the mother and daughter were reunited, the two of them sued the show, denying that the girl was a prostitute, and contending that the show had violated the girl's privacy and ruined her reputation.

title: Civil Rights Groups Misjudged Piscataway Case; Race Panel's Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Shootings Cast a Pall Over a Cherished Haven
description: Jeff Hasler says Prospect Park has become an integral part of his life. He has dressed up like a monster to entertain youngsters during the annual Halloween walk. He and his wife, Cheryl, often take walks in the Long Meadow when they need to discuss important things. And just sitting on a bench on a Sunday is one of the pleasures of his life.

title: Bang the Pipe Loudly
description: In the evolution of electronic music, KMFDM is Cro-Magnon man: a creature bridging the gap between the primal goo and the present. Industrial music, with its brute esthetic and vein-popping operatic ambitions, is not much invoked by those techno and ambient performers now driving pop in headier directions. But KMFDM's performance at Roseland on Monday night had the furor of a long-buried ancestor, escaped from a block of ice and on a rampage.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about losses at the Yamaichi Securities Company referred incorrectly to Japanese regulation of financial institutions. Japan indeed has an agency equivalent to the United States Securities and Exchange Commission. It is the Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission, part of the Finance Ministry.

title: Big Deal; Enough Rooms For a Hotelier
description: IAN SCHRAGER, who began his career as a nightclub owner of Studio 54 and continued as a hotelier with the Royalton and the Paramount in Manhattan and the Delano in Miami Beach, closed yesterday on a record-setting $9 million purchase of two apartments at the Majestic. For decades, the 1930 Art Deco apartment building has been known as the poor sister of the Dakota, across 72d Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the first black mayor of Stone Mountain, Ga., misstated the city's population. According to the 1990 census, it is 6,494, not 35,000.

title: Vindication for Florida State, Relief for Kansas
description: For coaches in the Chase Preseason National Invitation Tournament, a Tuesday luncheon called for mock turtlenecks and mock humility. Roy Williams cloyingly poor-mouthed second-ranked Kansas. Jim Calhoun of 11th-ranked Connecticut moaned that his team was overrated. Last night, their early fears were confirmed.

title: Atlanta's Mayor, Re-elected, Vows Quick Action on Problems
description: It was widely regarded as the roughest campaign in Atlanta in more than 30 years, and the most expensive. And when it was over on Tuesday night, Mayor Bill Campbell reflected on the ''messages'' in his narrow victory, vowing quick action on problems.

title: Studio 54 Reawakens, and No Hangover
description: LIKE Andy, Bianca, Calvin and Liza, it was just ''Studio.'' Or like Halston, it was ''54.'' For those who never got past its velvet rope, or weren't born yet to care, there is going to be another chance at the last dance at movie theaters next spring.

title: Missing Landlord Has Checked In But Not With Police, Lawyer Says
description: First his tenants disappeared. Then he disappeared. And, as the police began sorting through a tangled, troubled financial past, it turned out that one of his employees had disappeared, too, six years ago.

title: Canadian Study Says Tainted-Blood Victims Deserve Payment
description: Thousands of Canadians who contracted the AIDS virus and Hepatitis C from contaminated blood in one of the worst public health disasters in Canadian history should be compensated without having to file lawsuits, according to a federal inquiry released today.

title: Big Airlines In Asia See A Rough Landing
description: SINGAPORE  Asian and Pacific airlines will be severely tested in the next few years as the region's financial turmoil cuts into economic growth, air travel and carriers' earnings, executives and analysts say.

title: Op-Art
Calendar
description: Crafts Times Two

title: Jury and Alternates Selected In Sharpton Defamation Suit
description: After more than a week of delays, legal wrangling and occasional episodes of flamboyant courtroom drama, jury selection in the defamation lawsuit against three former advisers of Tawana Brawley ended today, with five alternates joining the six jurors who had already been seated.

title: Embryo 'Adoption' Is Ethical Conundrum
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Asia Lull Helps Markets, But Wall Street Is Still Wary

title: Today's N.F.L. Matchups
description: Chicago (2-10) vs. Detroit (6-6)

title: Bavarian Companies Buy 95% of Grundig
description: The Bavarian Economics Minister, Otto Wiesheu, said yesterday that a group of Bavarian companies had bought a 95 percent stake in the unprofitable consumer electronics maker Grundig A.G. The price was not disclosed. The group purchasing control includes Bayerische Vereinsbank, Bayerische Landesbank Girozentrale and Bayerische Hypotheken und Wechselbank A.G.

title: Two Boards Back Takeover Bid by Paribas
description: The supervisory boards of the French financial concerns Compagnie Bancaire and Cetelem decided yesterday to recommend acceptance of the takeover bid for all outstanding shares in the two units by their parent company, Paribas. Paribas offered late on Tuesday to exchange three Paribas shares plus 500 francs for two shares in its 50.2 percent-owned Compagnie Bancaire unit. Paribas also offered to exchange six Paribas shares plus 1,250 francs for five Cetelem shares. Paribas currently holds a 66.7 percent stake in Cetelem, a consumer credit firm, through Compagnie Bancaire.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Rule On Values Test For Arts Grants
description: The long-running debate over Federal spending on the arts moved to the Supreme Court today as the Justices agreed to rule on whether the Constitution permits Congress to make ''decency'' a test for the awarding of grants by the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Crumpled Magazine Led To Killing, Lawyers Say
description: Prosecutors accused a Manhattan man yesterday of fatally stabbing his building manager on Tuesday because his TV Guide magazine was crumpled when he received his mail.

title: Holiday Gift Books -- From the Inspiration Front (And Hardly Bookish); Where the Past Is Distinct, and Not Yet Extinct
description: DESIGN books that truly inspire often do it on the sly. The lessons they reveal are more likely to apply to the life of the imagination than the latest style in window treatments. Luckily, there are books out for the holidays that will catch the attention of the restless eye. They encompass worlds that are recognizable but at the same time alluringly creative, from a rural French farm family's home ''decorated'' with a frieze of corncobs to the Windsors' elegant exile in the Bois de Boulogne, customized to within an inch of its life with watermarked ''Don't Forget'' memo pads. The books delve into the texture of sensibility -- not just color or pattern. Here's what our contributors have brought back from their travels through some of the season's best titles. JULIE V. IOVINE

title: Treasury Prices Edge Up In Shortened Trading Day
description: Treasury prices ended slightly higher in a quiet, shortened session yesterday.

title: Eurotunnel Plan Avoids Bankruptcy
description: Eurotunnel's creditor banks approved a reorganization today of more than $14 billion in debt, averting the possibility of bankruptcy.

title: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma Is Treatable by a New Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved a new genetically engineered drug for the treatment of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

title: An Opening for City Ballet, A Closing for a Favored Star
description: Ballet has its superstars but few have tarried, if at all, at the New York City Ballet. In this company, unlike any other, choreography is more important than charisma.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POHS, JACK
description: POHS-Jack. The Board of Governors and Members of Fenway Golf Club record with profound sorrow the passing of its long-time former member, Jack Pohs, and extend to his bereaved wife, Lois, and the members of his family our sincere condolences. Joel Langer, President Marvin Leffler, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAND, AL
description: RAND-Al. The Board of Trustees and members of the Ocean Beach Club note with sadness the passing of longtime member Al Rand. We extend sincere condolences to his wife Rita and family. Sandy Paskin, President Laurie Lowenstein, Secretary

title: Public Eye; Wide-mouth design: less glug in beer, more chug in Mountain Dew
description: ANYONE who worries that the hard sell has vanished from the American scene should look at Yoo-Hoo chocolate drink's ''Chug-a-Can Wide Mouth'' and at Mountain Dew's ''Mega Mouth Slam Can.'' The wider pop-top openings are shrilly proclaimed by banners announcing that these are drinks you can chug.

title: Reno Is Briefly Hospitalized and Cuts an Official Trip to Mexico
description: Attorney General Janet Reno cut short an official trip to Mexico today after fainting on Tuesday at a reception and spending the night at a Mexico City hospital, where she complained of nausea and dizziness.

title: ON HOCKEY ; Questions for an Old, Rich and Reeling Team
description: The season is still young and the Rangers are still old. Talk is cheap and the Rangers are expensive. Their 4-1 loss to the Islanders last night was their third in succession and their fourth defeat in five games. After 26 games, they have 8 victories. That says plenty, but what do they have to say for themselves?

title: Scathing Report Is Issued on Illinois Nuclear Utility
description: Nuclear experts from utilities around the country have issued a stinging assessment of Commonwealth Edison's nuclear program, directing their most pointed criticism at the utility's Zion plant near Chicago.

title: For Some, a Holiday Rush; for Others, Just Another Day
description: The Young Spring Farm grocery on 125th Street in Harlem is a Thanksgiving dinner waiting to happen. There are wet bundles of collards, and orange piles of yams, and yellow turnips the size of softballs. And so yesterday, Sherri Softli, needing yams for her sweet potato pie, rushed in, then rushed home to her kitchen to cook into the early morning.

title: Kamuzu Banda Dies; 'Big Man' Among Anticolonialists
description: Hastings Kamuzu Banda, a founding father in postcolonial Africa who led Malawi to independence in 1964 and then ruled it with a combination of caustic wit, eccentricity and cruelty for 30 years, died on Tuesday night in a hospital here.

title: KOOR BUYS INTEREST IN ECI TELECOM FOR $275 MILLION
description: Koor Industries Ltd. agreed yesterday to acquire a 10.6 percent interest in ECI Telecom Ltd. of Israel from the Claridge Israel Group for $275 million. ECI Telecom, based in Petah Tikva, Israel, makes digital telecommunications and data transmission systems. Shares of ECI rose 87.5 cents, to $27.75. Koor is Israel's largest industrial concern. Claridge Israel is a holding company affiliated with the Canadian businessman Charles R. Bronfman. Under the agreement, Koor would acquire 8.35 million ECI shares. Claridge, which owns 25.8 percent of Koor, would raise its stake in Koor to 35.4 percent. Koor would receive 6.6 million ECI shares and a $45 million debt security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, SELMA (NEE HAUSEN)
description: ROSENBERG - Selma (nee Hausen). On Wed. Nov. 26, 1997 of Flushing, Queens, N.Y. Beloved wife of the late Burton Rosenberg. Devoted mother of Susan Woulfin. Loving grandmother of David and Jeffrey. Graveside service at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Queens, N.Y. Friday, Nov. 28. 1997 at 11 AM. For information Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, N.J. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to Overlook Hospital Foundation, 36 Upper Overlook Road, Summit, New Jersey 07901.

title: Credit Suisse First Boston Has Europe Loss
description: Credit Suisse First Boston's European equity options operations lost $50 million in October, which will wipe out department bonuses, according to a senior official at the bank.

title: British Trade Deficit Rises as Exports Slide
description: Britain's global trade deficit grew to $:1.25 billion ($2.08 billion) in September, up from $:616 million in August, the Office for National Statistics said yesterday. It was the nation's largest global deficit since July 1996. Although the merchandise trade deficit with countries outside the European Union remained virtually unchanged at $:794 million in October compared with $:817 million in September, British companies are beginning to export less over all.

title: Model for Dr. Zhivago's Lara Betrayed Pasternak to K.G.B.
description: There is no more enduring Russian love story than that of the writer Boris Pasternak and the woman who was the model for Lara, the radiant heroine of ''Doctor Zhivago.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEGEMAN, GRACE PECKHAM
description: HEGEMAN-Grace Peckham. On November 25, 1997 of Rockville Centre, N.Y. Beloved wife of the late Bernard L. Loving mother of Robert, George and Geoffrey Hegeman. Dear grandmother of six grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Visiting at The Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City N.Y., Friday 6-9 PM. Services at The Fairchild Chapel, 8 PM Friday. Interment, Memorial Cemetery of St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. Saturday, November 29.

title: California Goes to War Over Math Instruction
description: A bitter battle over how best to teach math has broken out in California, agitating parents and pitting school board members and teachers against one another. Its outcome could well affect curriculums in public schools across the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, GEORGE MACDONALD
description: PARKER - George MacDonald. The Board of Directors of Fiduciary Trust International mourns the passing of its esteemed friend and colleague on November 22 in Frankfurt, Germany. He rendered thoughtful and cogent advice for the benefit of the company and its clients during his six years as a director. Our deepest sympathy to his wife, Susan Bissell Parker, and his daughter Julia and son Angus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PURCELL, EDWARD RAYMOND
description: PURCELL-Edward Raymond. Of Tewksbury, N.J., died at home on Sunday, November 23, 1997. He was a respected attorney and real estate developer in Morristown, NJ for 29 years. He is a graduate of Bergen Catholic High School (1961), Boston College (1965) and New York University Law School (1968). He was the beloved husband of Pamela, devoted father of Jennifer, Paige, Nathaniel and Regan, and loving son of Eleanor.

title: 2 Jewelry Salesmen Carjacked and Robbed
description: A gang of armed robbers ambushed two jewelry salesmen on a service road of the Long Island Expressway early Tuesday and took their car and two suitcases filled with samples worth an estimated $250,000, the Nassau County police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOHEN, JEWEL D.
description: MOHEN-Jewel D. On November 25, 1997, aged 90. New York City public school teacher for sixtyfour years. Childhood member of The Corps de Ballet of The Metropolitan Opera, and fond patron of the performing arts. Beloved wife of the late James J. Loving mother of Elizabeth Napoli, Joseph C., Girard S., Peter J., and Christopher L. Dear grandmother and great grandmother of many. Reposing at the O'Shea-Hoey Funeral Home Inc, 29-13 Ditmars Boulevard, Astoria, New York, on Friday, from 2-5 and 7-9:30 P.M. Funeral Mass is on Saturday, Immaculate Conception Church, 10:30 A.M. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: VAW IN DEAL FOR EUROPEAN ROLLING MILLS OF REYNOLDS
description: The Reynolds Metals Company agreed yesterday to sell its European rolling mill businesses to VAW Aluminum A.G., a unit of Viag A.G. of Germany, as Reynolds, the second-largest United States aluminum producer, continues to shed assets and trim costs. Terms were not disclosed. VAW would acquire rolling mills in Hamburg, Germany; Cisterna, Italy, and Irurzun, Spain. The European businesses, including the rolling mills, generated about $1.05 billion in sales last year, or 15 percent of the company's total of $6.97 billion. Shares of Reynolds Metals fell 37.5 cents yesterday, to $56.5625.

title: Thanksgiving
description: NEW YORK

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Deerproofing the Hedges

title: Policy Opponent to Join Clinton at Race Forum
description: The White House said today that three authors of books on race relations, including one who opposes affirmative action, are to join President Clinton next week in a nationally televised town hall meeting on race.

title: Metro Business; Loan Pool for Health Care
description: Four of New York City's largest banks have established a $25 million pool of low-interest loans dedicated to building and expanding health care centers in the city's low-income neighborhoods, said the Primary Care Development Corporation, a nonprofit group that will administer the loans.

title: Mills: From Substitute To Starter For Knicks
description: After practice today, Chris Mills joined Chris Dudley, another newcomer to the Knicks, on the court to tape an episode of ''Play It Up,'' a Saturday morning children's show. After showing the hosts of the program some how-tos of basketball, the hosts then conducted a Knick quiz for Mills and Dudley.

title: An Ill Wind Is No Match for a House of Ill Repute
description: IN 1904, an enterprising prostitute named Laura Ziegler dropped into a local bank, negotiated a $3,000 loan and opened an enduring house of ill repute here in this wicked depot of American frontier history.

title: American Negotiator Hedges Over Climate Treaty Talks
description: Saying that criticisms by other countries of the United States' position on global warming are ''ill-founded,'' the Clinton Administration's new chief negotiator on a climate treaty acknowledged today that it might not be possible to bridge the remaining differences with Europe and the developing world.

title: Dow and Cargill in Venture
description: The Dow Chemical Company and Cargill Inc. have formed a company to develop and market polylactic acid polymers. The joint venture, Cargill Dow Polymers, will manufacture polylactic acid polymer resins at a former Cargill plant near Minneapolis. Polylactic acid polymers are derived from agricultural resources, like corn or sugar beets, and are used to make plastics, rubber, finishes and synthetic fibers.

title: Thanksgiving Ruminations
description: This morning is a good time to think about history and food, before everyone is fully sauced, gravied, dressed and unable to think at all. To Americans of a certain age, this day always brings with it the no longer completely canonical image of the celebration that has come to be called the first Thanksgiving, a 1621 harvest feast held at Plymouth Colony and also attended by 90 Wampanoag Indians. That meal, or rather anachronistic depictions thereof, was virtually the only glimpse of the Pilgrims to be found in public elementary schools 30 and more years ago. The image has been hard to dislodge -- a world where Pilgrim men looked like Van Heflin and Pilgrim women like June Allyson, where the actors walked straight from their dressing rooms onto the stage of national consciousness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORTON, JOHN J. (JACK)
description: HORTON-John J. (Jack), 78. On November 25, 1997 of Huntington, New York and Grantham, New Hampshire. Survived by his wife Violet of 50 years. Daughters Holly Horton Mannix of San Francisco, Calif., and Carol Horton Parsons of New London, New Hampshire. His brother James of Silver Springs, Maryland and grandsons Ryan and Drew Parsons. Services will be held Saturday, November 29, at 11 A.M., at Our Lady of Fatima Church, New London, New Hampshire. Donations may be made to the Norris Cotton Cancer Center, Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center, Medical Center Drive, Lebanon, New Hampshire 03756.

title: Clinton's Lawyers Say a Fund for Paula Jones Is Being Misused
description: President Clinton's lawyers say that a fund set up for Paula Corbin Jones exists not so much to finance her lawsuit against the President but to pay for her clothing and hair-styling, the cost of boarding her dog ''and first and foremost, her large public relations operation.''

title: Mayor Found Not Guilty In Harassment Case
description: James Whelan, the Mayor of Atlantic City, was found not guilty yesterday of harassing one of his longtime critics during a public argument last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEGILAH, SHOSHANA
description: MEGILAH-Shoshana. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Shoshana Megilah beloved mother of our devoted Members Ziona and Semone Grossman. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Dismissal of Retarded Men Puts Hertz in Federal Suit
description: The way the people at Hertz look at it, the Government is punishing them for an act of charity: creating make-work jobs for two men with mental retardation.

title: Williams's Career May Be Finished
description: The shouts on that sunny morning of July 21 were uneasy and frightened. Across the grassy expanse where the Giants were practicing, players were screaming: ''Trainer! Trainer!''

title: Israel 'Humiliated,' Netanyahu Asserts
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu lashed out at President Clinton, saying ''the entire Jewish state feels humiliated'' by Mr. Clinton's refusal to meet him last week.

title: Holiday Gift Books: From the Inspiration Front (And Hardly Bookish); Luxury Is in the Details, Whether They're Spare or Grandiose
description: DESIGN books that truly inspire often do it on the sly. The lessons they reveal are more likely to apply to the life of the imagination than the latest style in window treatments. Luckily, there are books out for the holidays that will catch the attention of the restless eye. They encompass worlds that are recognizable but at the same time alluringly creative, from a rural French farm family's home ''decorated'' with a frieze of corncobs to the Windsors' elegant exile in the Bois de Boulogne, customized to within an inch of its life with watermarked ''Don't Forget'' memo pads. The books delve into the texture of sensibility -- not just color or pattern. Here's what our contributors have brought back from their travels through some of the season's best titles.

title: Man Gets Life Sentence in Killing of a Family
description: Lamar Sanchez, one of two defendants who was charged in the first potential death penalty case in Manhattan since capital punishment was reinstated in 1995, was sentenced yesterday to life in prison without parole for his role in the killing of a Washington Heights family.

title: Black Police Groups Denounce Mistaken Shooting of Officer
description: The leaders of three black police groups denounced the wounding of a black Port Authority police officer last Thursday night by a New Jersey state trooper and said today that they would ask the Justice Department to investigate the shooting.

title: Mother Stops Release Of Driver Who Hit Son
description: Robert K. Hyer was scheduled to be a free man yesterday after serving 29 months for the hit-and-run death of a teen-ager. But as a result of a protest by the youth's mother, Mr. Hyer will spend today in a halfway house run by the Department of Corrections and will remain there pending a hearing on Dec. 3, parole officials said.

title: Company Briefs
description: LOCKHEED MARTIN AERONAUTICAL SYSTEMS,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, HOWARD L.
description: KLEIN-Howard L. On November 25, 1997. Dear husband of Lenore Metzger Klein, brother of Helen Levinson, brother-in-law of Carlyle Levinson, Mortimer Metzger, Judith and James Riggs, loving uncle of Jane Laffend, Warren Metzger, Janice Levinson, Elise Levinson, Katherine Riggs, Nancy Riggs, and their spouses. Services Monday 1 PM, at Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd (76 Rd), Forest Hills.

title: Two New Voices Take Up The Wagnerian Challenge
description: There were cast changes in two major roles in the Metropolitan Opera's revival of Wagner's ''Tannhauser'' on Saturday afternoon. The American tenor Jon Fredric West brought vocal heft and stamina to the title role. His singing was vigorous and textually clear. But his sound was often hard-pressed and wobbly.

title: Baby Boomers Force New Rules for H.M.O.'s
description: The managed-care industry has had better years. It is bad enough that doctors and hospitals are clamoring for higher fees, big employers are holding fast in their demands for rock-bottom prices, states are passing restrictive laws and stock traders are punishing companies whose profits do not take double-digit leaps.

title: Dutch Vandal Slashes Museums' Confidence
description: It was an act of desecration so audacious that it traumatized the art community in the Netherlands for years. On a March day in 1986, a tall, brown-haired man walked into the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam and repeatedly slashed ''Who's Afraid of Red, Yellow and Blue III,'' a 1967 masterpiece by the American Abstract Expressionist Barnett Newman.

title: Federal Agencies Raise Mortgage Limits
description: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac said today that they would increase the limit on the size of single-family mortgages they will buy in 1998 by 5.85 percent, to $227,150 from $214,600.

title: SUN HEALTHCARE REVISES ITS OFFER FOR RETIREMENT CARE
description: Sun Healthcare Group Inc. revised the terms of its stock offer for Retirement Care Associates Inc. again yesterday after shares in the rival nursing home operator have fallen. Sun originally agreed to buy Retirement Care and its 65 percent-owned medical supply company, Contour Medical Inc., in February, amending terms twice since then as share prices in both companies fluctuated. Sun would now swap 0.413 to 0.505 share for each share of Retirement Care, to equal $10 a share. The new terms reduce the value of the swap to about $147 million from $164 million in August. Shares of Retirement Care rose 43.75 cents yesterday, to $8.6875. Shares of Sun Healthcare, which is based in Albuquerque, N.M., rose 50 cents, to $21.50.

title: United Asset Buying Stake
description: The United Asset Management Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire a significant stake in the Integra Capital Management Corporation, a Toronto-based provider of investment management services. Terms were not disclosed. Integra oversees about $3.9 billion in assets, mostly for institutional investors. United Asset, based in Boston, manages more than $206 billion in assets. The transaction will not affect the current positions and responsibilities of Integra's 50 employees, United Asset said.

title: AT HOME WITH: Andrew Tobias; Always Playing With Money
description: THE year was 1977, New York City was broke, and a thrifty 30-year-old magazine writer was buying his first apartment: two bedrooms in the San Remo on Central Park West for $41,000. Twenty years later, it will surprise no one that the value of the apartment (more than $600,000) has grown along with the fortunes of the city.

title: Following a Proof of Fermat's Theorem to the Far Horizon of Pure Reason
description: FERMAT'S ENIGMA

title: New Jersey Parishes Await A Powerful Image of Faith
description: Armando B. Fontoura, the Essex County sheriff, recalls that prayers to the Virgin Mary were part of daily life when he was growing up in Portugal.

title: For a Scholar Near Death, A Dose of Deconstruction
description: Do brilliant people have any more of a handle on dying than anybody else? Margaret Edson, a teacher and first-time playwright, thinks not. In ''Wit,'' her lucid and compassionate mortality play at the Long Wharf Theater, a professor of 17th-century poetry, played with a touch of frost by the splendid Kathleen Chalfant, is holed up in an oncology unit, wasting away from advanced ovarian cancer.

title: Inside Art
description: Serra Sculptures Are Given to Dia

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was a pilgrimage into his past when RICHARD BEN-VENISTE went to Salonika, the port city in northern Greece, last weekend.

title: Songs of Innocence and Experience For the Pop Fan of a Certain Age
description: Aging rock-and-rollers don't die. They just fade into a twilight zone of reunion tours, lite-music radio and fussily annotated compact disk anthologies. So goes the conventional wisdom about growing old in the eternally youthful world of pop music, which seems to spawn a new generation of stars every few years. (Hello, Hanson! Hello, Jewel!)

title: Metro Business; Kraft Foods Complex Is Sold to Developer
description: The Cohen Brothers Realty Corporation, a New York City real estate developer, has signed a contract to buy a 39-acre property in White Plains, N.Y., that served for many years as the headquarters for several divisions of Kraft Foods.

title: Volkswagen to Expand Range of Cars
description: Volkswagen A.G. said today that it would spend more than $24 billion to expand its range to 50 from 38 cars, including a new car smaller than its Beetle.

title: Managed Care Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, PHILIP J.
description: CLARKE-Philip J. On November 27, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Loretta. Loving father of Lorraine Coffey and Phyllis DiFonza. Loving grandfather of Brian, Theresa, Michael and Carolyn. Reposing Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28 St., NYC, Friday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Resurrection 10 AM, Saturday, Immaculate Conception Church, 414 E. 14 St., NYC. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Seminoles Looking Up Under First-Year Coach
description: When asked what Florida State's basketball players were looking to see in New York this week, Coach Steve Robinson mentioned snowball fights. Some of the players had never seen snow, he said. Mostly, Robinson was joking. A team stocked with players from New York City, New Jersey and Boston is as familiar with snowballs as basketballs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEMMINGHAUS, FORMAN, PAU LA
description: HEMMINGHAUS - FORMAN - Pau la, 99. November 22, NYC. Born December 31, 1897, Columbus, Ohio. Retired professional singer. Survived by two sisters-in-law, five nieces and nephews (in-law) including Louise and Joseph Meagher, Binghamton, NY, Michael Meagher, NYC, Miriam Dornbirer, San Diego, CA. Burial in Columbus, OH. Memorial contributions suggested to The Juilliard School (Vocal) or Holy Trinity Lutheran Church Music Program, NYC.

title: Mount St. Michael Beats Cardinal Hayes Again
description: Mount St. Michael (11-0), the Catholic High Schools Football League two-time defending champion, continued its dominance over Cardinal Hayes (2-7) yesterday by routing Hayes, 48-13, in the 55th annual Thanksgiving Day clash between the Bronx schools.

title: Two Mezzos Stand Out In the Met's 'Clemenza'
description: This continues to be the season of the mezzo-soprano. For Wednesday night's revival of Mozart's ''Clemenza di Tito'' at the Metropolitan Opera, there were two mezzos commanding attention, both singing trouser roles. The Austrian-born Angelika Kirchschlager made her Met debut as Annio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANDEL, MORTON H.
description: KANDEL-Morton H. In his sleep on November 25, 1997. Beloved husband of Lottie, father of William and Robert, father-in-law of Joyce, grandfather of Ari. Service at home in Palm Beach, FL, Friday, Noon; graveside service Sunday 1 PM, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, ELIZABETH M.
description: MORRIS-Elizabeth M. November 26, 1997. Beloved wife of the late William. Devoted aunt and greataunt. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday 10 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Rangeley Region Health Center, P.O. Box 722, Rangeley, Maine 04970.

title: James Bender, 92, Eclectic Educator, Dies
description: James F. Bender, an eclectic educator who started out training speech therapists in the 1930's and ended up teaching business in the 1970's, but only after he had done star turns as a public pronunciation specialist and pioneering pop psychologist, become a high-paid business consultant and made a fortune on Wall Street, died on Sunday at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 92 and the founding dean of the Adelphi University School of Business.

title: Russians Checking Up on Their Children Adopted by Americans
description: Natasha Bianco's eyes are slightly crossed. It is hard to notice at first as the 20-pounder toddles around the room in a leopard-spot dress and black velveteen leggings, playing to the crowd of dignitaries.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S GAMES

title: Commercial Real Estate; A Housing Plan Where Stores Have Been Included
description: Hundreds of new and renovated low-to-middle-income housing units have been built in the easternmost corner of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, and hundreds more are planned. But this growth has not been matched by the development of retail shops.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Laurent Gras worked for 13 years with Alain Ducasse, most recently as chef de cuisine at Restaurant Alain Ducasse in Paris. He has worked at other big-deal French restaurants, too, most notably Lucas Carton, Maison Blanche and Guy Savoy. Early this year, however, he decided it was time for a change.

title: N.F.L. Matchups -- Week 14
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: Union Pacific's Rail Troubles Take a Toll on Texas Businesses
description: Growing delays in rail traffic since Union Pacific Railroad became the nation's largest railway have cost Texas businesses $762 million, and the losses could climb to $1.3 billion, according to a study commissioned by state regulators.

title: Family Fare
description: A Journey Into the Past

title: In Oakland, Jerry Brown Sees Forum for Change
description: Dressed in black from his banded-collar shirt to his shoes, a balding, 59-year-old man walking along the waterfront of this city of hills and faded factories looked vaguely familiar to a group of tourists from Atlanta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACDOUGALL, RELLA
description: MACDOUGALL-Rella. The members of the board and the shareholders of 480 Park Avenue are deeply saddened by the passing of our longtime director and officer, Rella Mac Dougall. We admiringly remember not only her dedication and judgement but most especially her sensitivity and charm. She graced our building and will be greatly missed by all of us at 480.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELSON, KATHY PLASZNER
description: BELSON-Kathy Plaszner. On November 26, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Michael, cherished mother of Jaclyn and Jonathan. Devoted daughter of Ervin and Terry Plaszner. Adored sister of Suzanne and Michael Weinstein. Beloved niece of Michael Plassner. Loving daughter-in-law of Jerome and Maxine Belson. Services Friday 11AM, from Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 W. 83 St, NYC

title: For Children, Another Night On Office Cots
description: It was after midnight and the teen-age girls waiting for foster care huddled in the city's placement office for abused and neglected children.

title: Metro Business; Building Adds 2 Retailers
description: Barnes & Noble and Circuit City are coming to the Upper East Side.

title: BASKETBALL: The Two Sides of Allan Houston; Knick Guard Combines Suburban Style With City Smarts
description: There was school busing, and in a way, it made the suburban curtain that hung between Allan Houston's new world and the inner city of Louisville, Ky., appear invisible.

title: St. John's Artest Creates Some Excitement in His First Start
description: St. John's Coach Fran Fraschilla chose this tropical setting, and a less-than-challenging opponent, American University of Puerto Rico, for the coming-out party of his prize recruit, the freshman Ron Artest. And Artest was the perfect debutant.

title: SUNY Conference Didn't Advance Education; No Frivolous Subject
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, GEORGE MACDONALD
description: PARKER - George MacDonald. The Board of Directors of Fiduciary Trust International mourns the passing of its esteemed friend and colleague on November 22 in Frankfurt, Germany. He rendered thoughtful and cogent advice for the benefit of the company and its clients during his six years as a director. Our deepest sympathy to his wife, Susan Bissell Parker, and his daughter Julia and son Angus.

title: For Capital Pundits, Money for Speeches Is Scarce This Year
description: For the capital's ''buckrakers,'' those media celebrities who rake in lucrative speaking fees on the lecture circuit, 1997 may be remembered as the year that the bucks stopped here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, ANNA T.
description: DAVIS-Anna T. On November 26, 1997. Beloved daughter of the late Joseph and Anna. Devoted sister of the late Joseph and Marie. Reposing at the Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87 Street, NYC on Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Monday, 10 AM at St. Joseph's RC Church. Burial Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Cabaret Guide
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes highly recommended shows.

title: New Video Releases
description: Speed 2: Cruise Control

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIPER, MARTHA
description: PIPER-Martha. On November 26, 1997. Of Santa Cruz, CA, formerly of Providence, R.I. Survived by her children Brannan and Michael of Brooklyn, New York, and Carrie of Tennessee. Mourned by her family and friends.

title: Chinese-Jazz Fusion in Monkey's Tale
description: For much of his career, the composer and baritone saxophonist Fred Ho has sought to merge his love of jazz, his Asian-American heritage and his determination to protest injustice. He has often been heavy-handed, mixing sloganeering with dissonant squalling. But his new opera ''Journey Beyond the West: The New Adventures of Monkey,'' which had its premiere on Wednesday night as part of the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, achieves his cross-cultural goals with skill, grace and humor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHRAG, ILSE
description: SCHRAG-Ilse. Age 86 of NYC, wife of the late artist Karl Schrag. Mother of Dr. Peter Schrag & Mrs. Katherine Wangh, grandmother of Deborah, Daniel and Jonathan Schrag, and Rebecca and Marina Wangh, great-grandmother of Noam Benkler, died November 26, 1997, following complications of hip surgery. Memorial services will be held at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue, Sunday, November 30 at 10:00 AM. No flowers please.

title: Blustery Winds Kill One, Injure Some and Delay Dinners by the Thousands
description: High winds that whipped the entire Northeast from Wednesday night through yesterday afternoon were blamed in one death and at least five injuries. There were also delays at Newark International Airport and thousands of interrupted Thanksgiving Day cooking schedules because of power failures.

title: Public Backs Tough Steps For a Treaty On Warming
description: As the world's nations gather in Japan to discuss how best to counter the threat of global warming, the American people are far more willing than their Government to take early, unilateral steps, a New York Times Poll has found.

title: Election Risks in Cambodia
description: As has often been the case in Cambodia's tragic history, the country is once again ruled by a tyrant determined to cling to power. Hun Sen is no Pol Pot, but he is a violent, autocratic leader who seized control of Cambodia in a coup in July. The United Nations and Western and Asian countries have decided that the best way to unseat him is to move ahead with parliamentary elections scheduled for next May. Mr. Hun Sen, who is deeply unpopular, would likely lose a fair election. But nothing in his past indicates that he would allow one, and flawed elections are worse than none at all. The international community must proceed cautiously, lest a rigged election give Mr. Hun Sen a veneer of legitimacy.

title: Bucs' Dilfer Is on Target, And Target Is the Giants
description: For his first three seasons in the National Football League, Trent Dilfer of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers built a reputation as an underachiever. He had the size (6 feet 4 inches and 235 pounds) that pro football coaches love in a quarterback and he had a gun of an arm. But his production was poor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNAMEE, MARGARET ELLEN
description: McNAMEE-Margaret Ellen. Beloved daughter of Edmund and Lillian McNamee. Loving sister of Maureen and her husband Frank Liantonio, Michele and her husband Terrance Sullivan and Monica and the late Tom Fleming. Devoted aunt of Kiera and Bridget. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street, Friday 7-9 and Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street, Monday 10 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to American Cancer Society for Camp Adventures, 39 Edgewood Drive, New Hyde Park, New York 11040.

title: Sports of The Times; Pippen Is Right, But Wrong
description: THE school teacher trying to run a class of disadvantaged kids in an inner city has to laugh to keep from crying when Scottie Pippen complains that his contract to play basketball -- a seven-year deal worth $22 million and in its last year -- has become a slap in his face.

title: The Fight Over Principal Tenure
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has made enormous progress in rationalizing New York City's system for public education. Now Dr. Crew is taking on tenure rights for principals. If the principals worked under five-year contracts rather than lifetime job guarantees, he says, it would be much easier to reward good performance and get rid of underachievers.

title: Israeli Offers One Pullback In West Bank
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel proposed today to carry out a single Israeli troop withdrawal in the West Bank within five months, if the Palestinians take adequate steps to fight terrorism, and to start talks immediately on a final peace settlement.

title: The Wild West, Tamed by Victorian Brushwork
description: The American West as depicted in the panoramic landscape paintings of Thomas Moran (1837-1926) has the ponderous, richly crafted, slightly suffocating feel of a Victorian parlor. Mesas and mountains crowd in like heavy furniture. Skies are dense with meteorological incident. Trees and people, on the rare occasions that people appear, have the look of carefully disposed knickknacks. The result is the great outdoors as an exercise in baronial grandeur and topography as an inventory of possessions, the best that money can buy.

title: 80's Corporate Raider Is Focusing on France
description: The investor Asher Edelman, back on the takeover scene after a 10-year hiatus, says he is considering making a bid for a French company, which some analysts said could be the hotel operator Accor S.A.

description: Julian Schnabel

description: ROBBINS-Morris, 90. Of Lakewood, New Jersey; formerly of New York City, passed away on November 25, 1997. title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING ; From airlines to shoes to computer software, accounts worth millions are undergoing changes.
description: HOLIDAY or not, marketers have been busy making decisions affecting advertising assignments. The accounts involved, with billings estimated at $70 million to $80 million, include products and services from airlines and insurance to athletic footwear and computer software.

title: Istanbul Journal; Turks, Ever Zealous, Storm a Magazine's Stunt
description: It is a truism here that Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the founder of modern Turkey, was the greatest statesman of the 20th century, if not of all time. But now millions of Turks are claiming that he was also a more brilliant scientist than Einstein and a better singer than Elvis.

title: Market Place; Rising stock prices and profits reflect a tough three years of revamping at General Cable.
description: IT was culture shock from the moment that Stephen Rabinowitz became chief executive of the General Cable Corporation three years ago.

title: Abroad at Home; Violins In the Wings
description: ''You have to distinguish between means and ends,'' Albert Carnesale said. ''What's important here is the end, diversity. Affirmative action is just one means to that end.''

title: Bristol-Myers to Sell a Medical Devices Unit
description: The Conmed Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a subsidiary of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company for $370 million in cash, expanding its offerings of medical-surgical devices.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FLIER, MILTON R.
description: FLIER-Milton R. 11/28/97. Today you are eighty and we miss you and your hugs and kisses. Love, Dorothy and the whole family

title: No Line? No 'Lion'? That's the Ticket!
description: It would be great to see Bebe Neuwirth in the talked-about, raved-about revival of ''Chicago'' while relatives are visiting over the holidays. To check out the brash young cast of ''Rent'' when old friends come to New York City next week. Or to treat your family to the visual spectacle of ''The Lion King.'' But don't count on it. Those shows are playing to sold-out houses, and the holidays make tickets even harder to get than usual.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTWIN, LEONARD F.
description: LITTWIN-Leonard F. Dearest husband of Cece. Devoted father of Lenore and Peggy. Good friend and father-in-law of Robert Brugger and Robert Kurtz. Proud grandfather of Seth, Rachel, Jared and Lori. Superb teacher and dedicated professional. Principal of Adlai Stevenson High School, Benjamin Franklin High School, Junior High School 38 and P.S. 35. Decorated World War II veteran. Feisty lifelong tennis buff. A wise and respected man. A loving friend whose warmth, wit and wisdom will be missed. Services Sunday, November 30, Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue at 12:15 PM.

title: Accounts
description: * Bolle Inc., Rye, N.Y., a unit of B.E.C. Group, to Hanft Byrne Raboy Abrams & Partners, New York, as the first agency to handle worldwide branding for the eyewear company. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Spare Times
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Critic's Choice/Film; Where Desperation Must Look Itself in the Face
description: The Film Forum's splendid cinema verite series continues with Albert and David Maysles's favorite and most personal film, the one that took them back to Boston to watch Bibles being sold door to door. Having grown up in this community and briefly sold Fuller brushes and encyclopedias themselves, they also took some inspiration from the nonfiction novel format of Truman Capote's ''In Cold Blood'' as they zeroed in on the quiet desperation of the salesman's world.

title: Police Doubt Body Is Linked to Disappearance
description: The police here and in New York City today backed away from speculation that the headless and handless body of a woman found floating in a lake here might be that of Camden Sylvia, the Manhattan woman who disappeared along with her boyfriend earlier this month.

title: At the Movies; Oscar in the Air, Not in the Mail
description: It's that time of year in Hollywood.

title: Marvin Goldstein, 80; Aided Integration
description: Dr. Marvin C. Goldstein, an orthodontist and businessman who defied the segregationist sentiments of the mid-1960's by opening Atlanta's first integrated hotel, died on Saturday at his Atlanta home. He was 80.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, PHILIP I.
description: BERMAN-Philip I. The Jewish Publication Society records with great sorrow the passing of our life trustee and benefactor. Together with his dear wife, our past president Dr. Muriel M. Berman, he supported our publication program through the creation of the Philip and Muriel Berman Endowment. Over the past two decades, some of our most significant, award winning publications were made possible through their generosity. They include Jewish Law, Ketubbah, and The Invisible Thread. Philip Berman's passion made possible the JPS contribution to sustaining the tradition of ''The People of the Book.'' May his memory be for a blessing.

title: Rewards In Galleries Uptown
description: ''Get Down Uptown'' is the clever advertising slogan with which Barneys New York segued out of its West 17th Street store, as if it were necessary to remind its hipper clients that there is life above 23d Street. But sometimes reminders can help, especially with the relentless focus on the states of mind, style and real estate -- not to mention retail -- loosely known as downtown.

title: Between Rhode Island and Connecticut, Just a Question Mark
description: Joseph C. Casavecchia drove a spike into the ground beside a 19th century granite marker that, to all appearances, demarcates the border between Connecticut and Rhode Island.

title: No Problem With Those Wide Open Spaces
description: The drummer Matt Wilson's show at Detour on Tuesday night was a small marvel of balance, and a casual listener might not have noticed how much work it took. Balance because Mr. Wilson, working with a quartet of two saxophones, bass and drums, took musical structure and freedom and merged them so well that the music sounded completely natural.

title: Diana's Brother Learns That the Tabloids Bite Back
description: For a brief, shining moment this fall, Earl Spencer, the sandy-haired younger brother of Diana, the Princess of Wales, rose above the grieving masses and became Britain's stern voice of righteousness.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Shake-Up at General Cable Wins Raves on Wall Street

description: PIERNO-Carmine (member of U.S. Army Band and professional musician). Tuesday, November 25, 1997. Husband of the late Lillian. Devoted father of Guy Philip and Carmine. Dear brother of Matilda Tartaro and Anna Marchese. Loving grandfather of Kerry, Corey, Keith and Christine. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, NY. Mass of Christian Burial: Mary's Nativity RC Church, Saturday, 9:45 A.M. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. Visiting: Friday 2-5:00 P.M. and 7-10:00 P.M.

title: From a Printer to an Artist on His Own
description: Tom Baril was a 27-year-old student and aspiring photographer at the School of Visual Arts in Manhattan when Robert Mapplethorpe called its employment office, looking for a printer. Mr. Baril was sent. That was in 1979, and Mr. Baril went on to become the controversial artist's brilliant printer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTZER, JACK
description: WALTZER-Jack. Beloved husband of Selma. Devoted father of Delores Bernstein (Allen), Alice Cohen (Stuart), Wayne (Arlene), and Paul (Georgia). Loving brother of Roz Schottenfeld. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Meredith, Aaron, David, Gregory, Elyse, Michael and Neil. Founder and proprietor of Jack/Paul Waltzer Furs NYC. Services Friday, 2 PM, Parkside Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The air got squeezed -- it had nowhere to go.''

title: Brodeur Magnificent in Defeat
description: Martin Brodeur had won 10 games in a row, then 11 and then 12. By now, the record was within reach and the Devils goalie wanted to grab it.

title: Down Under In Origin, Upside-Down In Style
description: To set matters straight from the outset, the Circus Oz has not arrived by way of the Emerald City or L. Frank Baum. In the vocabulary of show business, Oz is Australia. And the performers who have invaded the New Victory Theater in Times Square until Jan. 4 have brought with them a little circus that brims with some of the best of Australian characteristics: funny, zany, talented and, perhaps most welcome of all, informal and unpretentious.

title: People
description: * Charlie Rutman was named to the new position of executive vice president and director for client and media services at Carat MBS, New York, a unit of Aegis Group P.L.C. He had been senior vice president and media director at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, owned by MacManus Group, overseeing the media planning account of the Coca-Cola Co.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANTZMAN, LEO
description: FRANTZMAN-Leo. Of the Upper Westside, peacefully on November 27 at age 88. Husband of the late Sally. He is survived by loving sisters Eva Weisbrot and Ceilia Gellman and dear brother George, beloved son Joel and Perry, grandchildren Julia, Seth, Jake and Sara and numerous nieces, nephews and cousins. He has left a hole in the hearts of his closest friends which will not be easily mended. Service Sunday, 11:30 AM, November 30 at Park Avenue Synagogue, 87 St. and Madison Ave. Interment at Mount Lebanon Cemetery in Queens. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the 100299 77th Block Association, C/O Marine Midland Bank, corner of 77th and 3rd Ave., NY, NY 10021 or to a charity of one's choice. For further information call Plaza Memorial Chapel, 212-769-4400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNN, THEODORE I., JR.
description: DUNN-Theodore I., Jr. Peacefully at Greenwich Hospital, November 26, 1997, of Rye, N.Y. Beloved husband of Marlice. Devoted father of Sharla Scharpnick, Linda Dunn and Heidi Meadows. Dear grandfather of Ted, Matthew, Bret, Caylie, Lyndi, and Mollee. Memorial service will be held Saturday, 1PM at The Rye Presbyterian Church. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to: The Greenwich Hospital, C/O The Development Office, 89 Lake Avenue, Greenwich, CT. 06830 or The American Cancer Society, 2 Lyon Pl, White Plains, New York 10601 or The American Heart Association, 3020 Westchester Avenue, Purchase, New York 10577 would be appreciated.

title: Newark Holiday Tree Is to Be Installed Today
description: A 51-foot Norway spruce will be installed downtown today by the same people who put up the Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center in Manhattan.

title: Unregulated Herbal Supplements
description: Echinacea to fight off colds, ginkgo to increase mental alertness and St. John's wort to relieve depression are finding their way into American medicine cabinets, right next to the aspirin. These and hundreds of other botanical remedies, along with vitamins, minerals and amino acids, now form a dietary supplement market that has reached $8 billion in annual sales. Growing consumer interest raises questions about how to protect the public from misleading claims and potentially unsafe products that are essentially unregulated.

title: After Loss To Oilers, Cowboys Can Panic
description: When Dallas quarterback Troy Aikman gets back spasms, all of Texas feels the twinge.

title: SPIES FOR IRANIANS ARE SAID TO GAIN A HOLD IN BOSNIA
description: Iranian intelligence agents are mounting extensive operations in Bosnia and have infiltrated the American program to train the Bosnian Army, according to Western and Bosnian officials.

title: Gill Is Playing for Respect
description: There was a time in Kendall Gill's career when he was Coach George Karl's favorite object of scorn in Seattle. It was a bad time for Gill, and he was on the verge of quitting the game he loved. ''I've got this stigma on me and I just couldn't shake it,'' he said.

title: Stephen L. R. McNichols, 83, Liberal Governor of Colorado
description: Stephen L. R. McNichols, a liberal Democrat who served as Governor of Colorado as the state was emerging from its agrarian past, died on Tuesday at University Hospital in Denver. He was 83 and lived in Denver.

Sun Myung Moon, who once presided over a mass wedding of his Unification Church members in Madison Square Garden, is now inviting 35,000 married couples -- most of whom do not belong to his church -- to attend a marriage blessing ceremony this Saturday at R.F.K. Stadium in Washington.

description: When Mayor Richard M. Daley met with the Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan recently, he told Mr. Farrakhan to establish better relations with Jewish leaders and hinted that if he did not, he could expect rough sledding at City Hall.

description: SHERMAN-Sidney D. On November 26, 1997, of Stratford, CT. Husband of Marguerite Sherman. Father of Ronda Levine of Long Beach, Long Island. description: In some communities, dogs are a nuisance for mail carriers. In West Orange, wild turkeys are the problem. They showed up in the spring, multiplied and then grew brazen.

Service on Friday, 12 noon, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Kidney Fund or the Heart Foundation.

description: Tom Butter

title: Fire Ignites Shack, Killing Harlem Man
description: A man was killed last night when a fire swept through a shanty he lived in on a vacant lot in Harlem.

title: Pawprint Gives Hope That Cougar, Presumed Extinct, Lives
description: Wildlife officials have been prowling the woods around this community in search of an animal that has long been presumed extinct: an Eastern cougar.

title: Antiques; Romanov Treasures Still Rule
description: The Romanovs are coming. Whether it's Russian literature, poetry, ballet, art or pre-Revolutionary dynastic tragedy, Americans can't seem to get enough of the Romanovs. When the Faberge exhibition came to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1996, it broke all attendance records for a decorative arts show. This year we have ''Anastasia,'' an animated movie. We have the Romanovs at galleries, in museums, on the auction block and, of all places, at the New York Public Library. After only three weeks, the catalogues have run out for the library's new exhibition ''The Romanovs: Their Empire, Their Books.''

title: Art In Review
description: Walter Anderson and Charles Burchfield

title: Art Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: A Philharmonic Stand-In Adds Czech Seasoning
description: At a time when high-profile performances are routinely canceled because of unspecified and dubious ''illness,'' the honesty is perhaps refreshing. Christian Thielemann, a fast-rising German conductor, is not appearing with the New York Philharmonic this week because of fatigue, the orchestra announced two weeks ago, as Mr. Thielemann was beginning a two-week stint with the Philadelphia Orchestra.

title: SPARE TIME
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Witness Links Winnie Mandela to Guards' Crimes
description: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela was either aware of the murderous assaults and other criminal activities her bodyguards engaged in during the late 1980's or directed and actively took part in them, a former anti-apartheid colleague told South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission today.

title: U.S. Davis Cup Team Aiming To Topple Bjorkman & Co.
description: It seems as if Jonas Bjorkman's face, coated with seasonal frost, is on every other billboard here in Goteborg, where Sweden and the United States, who have virtually monopolized every Davis Cup final since 1981, will meet for the 1997 championship this weekend at the Scandinavium Arena.

title: America's Top Truck Is Turning 50
description: THE granddaddy of the modern American pickup truck, the Ford F-Series, will be a half-century old next week.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOROWITZ, SARAH GAYER
description: HOROWITZ-Sarah Gayer. Nov. 28, 1967. Miss you Mommy. Your children, grandchidren, great-grandchildren

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCSHEA, ROBERT J.
description: McSHEA-Robert J. Died November 25, 1997. Professor emeritus, Boston University. Survived by his wife of more than 49 years, Naomi S. of Brookline, MA, his daughter Sarah D. of New York, NY, his son Daniel W., daughter-in-law Diane Ritchie and granddaughter Hannah Leah, of Durham, NC, and sisters Marie Dewey and Dorothy Backer. Born November 19, 1917. Served in the U.S. Army, graduated from Queens College and then, with Naomi, ran a chicken farm in upstate New York for 16 years. Earned a Ph.D. in political theory from Columbia University and taught at Boston University from 1967 to 1988. Wrote many articles on political philosophy and two books, ''The Political Philosophy of Spinoza'' (1968) and ''Morality and Human Nature'' (1990). Private burial in Brookline, MA. Memorial gathering to be announced.

title: A Prize Emerges in Merrill's British Deal
description: As one of the few women to reach the top executive ranks in Britain -- vice chairwoman of the Mercury Asset Management Group, one of Europe's largest investment firms -- Carol Galley has been a favored target of the male-dominated tabloid press as well as of jealous male colleagues in the City, London's hub of investment banking.

title: A Conflicted Champion Of the Lonely And Losers
description: When the English singer Steven Morrissey abandoned his first name and began his ascent to cult stardom, it was 1984. Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan had the Western world in their grip, the AIDS epidemic was mounting, and there seemed little for a sensitive, young, sexually ambiguous vegan to do but hang his head and moan. Which Morrissey did, to resounding effect. His searing portraits of lives laid low by repression and fate, sung in a cynical warble suggesting a bookstore clerk in a karaoke bar, made the band he fronted, the Smiths, one of the most beloved groups of its time.

title: Exploring Galaxies In a Dome In Suffolk
description: Eight-year-old Michele Brockington came face to face with George, who could easily be mistaken for a friendly robot from outer space, and asked, ''Does he have any brothers or sisters?''

title: Mexico Editor Hurt in Ambush; His Bodyguard and Gunman Die
description: Jesus Blancornelas, a prize-winning newspaper editor who has crusaded against narcotics traffickers, was seriously wounded today in Tijuana by gunmen who killed his bodyguard. One of the gunmen was also killed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THALER, RABBI RICHARD
description: THALER-Rabbi Richard. Beloved husband of Julie. Loving father of Gilad and Itai. Precious son of Rabbi Albert and Shirley Thaler. Loving brother of Judy Kane and Dena Thaler. Services 10:30 A.M., at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51 Street, New York City.

title: Gunman Kills 2 at a Bronx Football Game
description: A football game on the sprawling lawn of a Bronx housing project broke into pandemonium yesterday as a man on the sidelines drew a semiautomatic pistol and, apparently without a word, opened fire on the scrimmaging players, hitting some and chasing others off the field to shoot them. Two men were killed and three others were wounded, the police said.

title: A Search Is Under Way For an Escaped Killer
description: The authorities are searching for a convicted killer who walked off the grounds of the Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital last week.

title: Gather Round the Counter ; Even a Neighborhood Diner Has Holiday Traditions
description: With its Formica counters patterned like marble and its faux-Tiffany glass wall panels, the Utopia Restaurant is a classic New York coffee shop, the kind of place where you have to check to make sure the table isn't damp before you set down your elbows, and where the air is redolent of toasting bread.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUTRO, JULIA D.
description: SUTRO-Julia D. Of Westhampton Beach, NY on November 25, 1997. Beloved mother of Livingston D. Sutro, dear sister of Mrs. Frank Porter and William L. Delafield, loving grandmother of Eleanor Julia Sutro and Emma Elizabeth Sutro. Funeral service on Saturday 1 P.M., at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Westhampton Beach, NY.

title: Turkish Judge Scolds U.S. for Opposing a Ban on an Islamic Party
description: This nation's highest-ranking judge has strongly criticized the United States, accusing it of trying to discourage a Turkish court from banning the country's pro-Islamic political party.

title: Royal Haven Handles Weight at Aqueduct
description: Kelly Kip, who is either the wonder horse or the mystery horse of New York racing, lapsed into his role as the mystery horse yesterday when he coughed up the lead in the homestretch and lost the Fall Highweight Handicap at Aqueduct to the seasoned warrior Royal Haven.

title: The Worries About Lobster In Maine Rise By the Pound
description: Donald Simmons Sr. had little company when he began setting lobster traps in Muscongus Bay more than 25 years ago.

title: Let Us Give Thanks for the Refrigerator
description: This morning, as America awakes from a food coma and rubs its eyes from its tryptophan-haze, I jump from bed and smack my lips in anticipation of this holiday's most glorious bounty: leftovers.

description: SCANLAN-Irene H. November 26, 1997. Of Jamaica Estates. Beloved wife of John A. Scanlan. Loving mother of Kathleen Casey and Margaret Jean Sullivan. Cherished grandmother of Erin and Sean. Also survived by sons-in-law John Casey and Donald Sullivan. Reposing at R. Stutzmann & Sons, Inc., Funeral Home (224-39 Jamaica Avenue, Queens Village, New York), Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass on Monday, 9:30 A.M., Immaculate Conception R.C. Church, Jamaica Estates, NY. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, New York.

title: Linking Beethoven To Serialist Composers
description: There are many easier ways to make a living, and most pianists find one. But when last encountered, six years ago, Marc Ponthus, a brilliant French pianist, was performing all the solo piano works of Pierre Boulez.

description: A statue of the Virgin Mary from Portugal is to be displayed in New Jersey.

title: Metro Business; Allstate to Aid Community
description: The Allstate Insurance Company has pledged $5.8 million in loans and grants over five years to various housing, youth and community development programs in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

title: A Decade of Poodle Skirts and Paranoia
description: In its peppy eight hours, ''The Fifties'' has time to inspect the highs, lows and in-betweens of what already seems like a remote decade. Based on the 1993 book by David Halberstam, who supplies comments along the way, the series begins on Sunday with the legacy of World War II and ends on Friday with the promise of John F. Kennedy's New Frontier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGFRIED, CHARLES A.
description: SIEGFRIED-Charles A. Franklin and Marshall College of Lancaster, PA, acknowledges with sorrow the passing of Charles A. Siegfried. A 1930 graduate of The College with Phi Beta Kappa honors, Mr. Siegfried went on to an illustrious career with Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, where he eventually served as President from 1966 to 1969. After that, he was Vice Chairman and later Chairman of The Executive Committee before his retirement in 1973. His distinguished service to Franklin & Marshall included tenure on the College's Board of Trustees, with seven years as The Board Chair in the 1970's. His vision, leadership and commitment to the College will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUOHY, CATHERINE (NEE DOWD)
description: TUOHY-Catherine (nee Dowd). On November 26, 1997. Long-time employee of AT&T. Member of Telephone Pioneers of America. Beloved wife of the late Michael; dearest mother of Mary Cunningham and the late John Tuohy; loving grandmother of Mary Lee and John. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Reposing at Quinn-Fogarty, 162-14 Sanford Avenue, Flushing on Friday 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Ozanam Hall, Bayside on Saturday, 10 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery Middle Village.

description: Oliver Herring

title: Across Asia, a Pollution Disaster Hovers
description: This little village is hauntingly beautiful, a patchwork of mud-brick shacks framed by the vastness of the Yellow River on one side and rugged gray mountains on the other. But as peasants shuffle along the ocher paths, their eyes following their children and aching at the sight, the hamlet suddenly seems chilly, frightening and grotesque.

title: A Clash of Unyielding Forces in Australia
description: Christians and Muslims in Bosnia. Arabs and Jews in the Middle East. Catholics and Protestants in Ireland. Hindus and Muslims in India. To the despair of the hopeful, some cultural and religious clashes seem irreconcilable.

title: Big Deals
description: The holiday season is unbelievably upon us, and celebration is in the air. These 12 restaurants are for the biggest of big-deal meals, offering magic in the food, the atmosphere or the view. All, of course, will cost you a Christmas bonus. (Here are summaries, written by Eric Asimov, taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)
