description: Richard Artschwager and Joe Zucker

title: A Tearful Reunion For Three Friends Who Defied Nazis
description: It was 55 years ago this month, on a cruel, rainy night in Ukraine, when a 13-year-old girl in a bathrobe and two long black braids knocked on the front door of the Vavrisevich family's home. She was a stranger to them. But for more than 15 months, with pogroms raging outside, the Vavriseviches hid her and her widowed mother under the floorboards of their house, below a bare room reserved for the cow and goat in winter.

title: Chinese Political Values
description: To the Editor:

title: McKinney & Silver Picks Creative Chief
description: McKinney & Silver, a unit of CKS Group in Raleigh, N.C., has named David Baldwin to head its creative department as senior vice president and executive creative director, effective Jan. 5.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FADEM, THERESA FINE
description: FADEM-Theresa Fine. Beloved mother of Fred and Barbara Fine. Grandmother of Meredith and Lauren. Sister of Stanley and Herbert Buckstone. Private funeral services were held.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; New Air Bag Choices Beyond On-Off Switch
description: FROM all the attention given last week to a new Federal rule on air bags, car owners might think they face just one air bag decision: whether to apply to the Government for an on-off switch.

title: Disabilities Law Protects Bad Doctors
description: It was the patients' screams that finally did it. Officials at Hazleton-St. Joseph Medical Center in Pennsylvania investigated Frank Ruhl Peterson and found the anesthesiologist had been stealing narcotics from surgical intravenous bags to feed his own habit. Dozens of patients had been shortchanged of anesthesia prescribed for procedures that included Caesarean sections, biopsies and spinal surgery.

title: In Uniform She's King For a Day
description: ''Bang,'' a scrappy independent film made for just $20,000, has an unsettling way of pressing buttons that produce little rushes of anger. So what if many of those buttons are preset by television news? If your image of the Los Angeles police is of a bunch of arrogant brutes, ''Bang'' will gratify your ugliest fantasies of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARNEY, PETER J.
description: CARNEY-Peter J. Native of Boyle, Co. Roscommon Ireland. Retired pressman for The New York Times. Fond and loving son of the late Bridget and Patrick Carney. Beloved husband of Kathleen (nee Browne). Devoted father of Jerry and Larry. Devoted grandfather of three: Larry, Jr., Jay and Marykate. Loving father-in-law of Martina. Fond brother of Tereasa and the late Tommy, John, Annie, Kathleen, Mary and Betty. Fond brother-in-law of Denis, Tom, Bridie, Anne, Betty, Sean, Eily, Timie and the late Bob and Danny. Reposing Albert R. Conner-Colonial Funeral Home, 4955 Broadway (207 St.), Friday 3-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 10 AM, Good Shepherd Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Special thanks to the staff of the Frances Schervier Nursing Home for all their love and support, especially the staff on St. Rose's floor. Too many names to mention. From Kathleen Carney and family.

title: A Building Worth a Wait? Not Anymore
description: For more than a year, Theodore W. Kheel has boasted about the unusual town house he was planning to build on the East Side of Manhattan: it would house several foundations, and it would be heated by energy deep in the ground.

title: Two Parades, Same Route? It Can Be Done
description: NOTHING is ever simple in this town (there's a news flash for you), but the strain of organizing a street parade surely claims a special mention in the catalogue of New York ordeals.

title: Spanish Cigar Company Makes Inroads Into U.S.
description: America's love affair with cigars has long since caught the eye of the world's tobacco companies, and Spain's dominant cigar maker is no exception. It just took the company a bit longer than it planned to cross the Atlantic.

title: Thalidomide, Once Banned, Is in Demand
description: There was a time when Vicki Walton was so sick she wished she were dead. A bacterial infection consumed her, pushing her fever to 106 degrees. Painful ulcers lined her throat and genitals. Her joints were swollen, her brain inflamed. Her head pounded with unrelenting migraines. Eating was a faint memory; walking, a distant dream.

title: Students in Germany Protest Cuts in University Spending
description: Tens of thousands of students marched through central Bonn today, blowing whistles and blasting trumpets in a demonstration that crowned weeks of protests and years of discontent over the underfinancing and overcrowding of Germany's colleges and universities. Thousands more boycotted classes across the country.

title: Macy's Parade of Balloons Gets One Thing It Doesn't Need: Wind
description: Sudden bursts of punishing wind spun havoc at Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade yesterday, as many of the parade's signature helium-filled balloons were damaged and as four spectators were hurt when one of the giant balloons struck a lamppost, plunging the top part of it into the crowd. Two people were hospitalized with severe head injuries.

title: Growing Troubles for Labor
description: Three months after triumphing in the United Parcel Service strike, the labor movement is reeling from the corruption charges against the teamsters' union. Now that Ron Carey has stepped aside as teamsters' president, the spotlight has shifted to other labor leaders who may have been involved in the alleged plot to divert union funds for Mr. Carey's election campaign. This is a painful moment for the union cause, but its commanders would be mistaken to hunker down and belittle the charges against them. Only by cooperating fully with investigators can they redeem the promise of a reborn labor movement.

title: Drug Laws Hurt Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Israelis Who Put Acid in the Milk-and-Honey Formula
description: If Israeli writers today are shattering stereotypes of what their country is and who inhabits it, can artists drag their feet? They, too, are out to question platitudes of Israeli life as perceived at home and abroad. In ''Desert Cliche: Israel Now -- Local Images,'' 18 young artists make waves, about issues from the military to the so-called blooming of the desert, from sacred sites to the tourist industry, from collectivism to clothes as proclamations of gender and ethnicity.

title: YACHTING: WHITBREAD ROUND THE WORLD RACE -- A SAILOR'S JOURNAL; A Longing to Reach Shore
description: Nine boats restarted the 31,600-nautical-mile Whitbread Round the World Race on Nov. 8 with the 4,700-nautical-mile voyage from Cape Town to Fremantle, Australia. The route was through the treacherous Southern Ocean, and Swedish Match was the first to finish, completing the leg in 16 days on Sunday.

title: Invading Theaters: Bugs, Drugs And Thugs
description: Consider the shocking movie sights of 1960: a motel assignation, a woman in a shower, a man in a dress, a nasty-looking knife. Those, not to mention a mother who wouldn't hurt a fly, made Hitchcock's ''Psycho'' the envelope-pushing violent film of its day, yet it looks so quaint by current standards. Ratcheting the threshold of audience abuse ever higher, today's filmmaker is likely to confuse the skewering of a green-blooded space insect with transcendent excitement or wit. Trouble is, it isn't smart and it isn't often working. When was the last time you heard applause at the movies? Half-empty theaters are mostly home to the sound of one hand clapping.

title: SUNY Conference Didn't Advance Education; Free Speech Defender
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACCO, GIOVANNI, M.D.
description: SACCO-Giovanni, M.D. Beloved husband of Neva. Devoted father of Cyntia. Brother of Francesco. Loving grandfather of Sara. Services Friday, 1:30PM, ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Grand Tour of Bites and Bargains
description: It seems that I always need something on Grand Street. The lure on the Lower East Side might be yeasty bialys, a concert or bargains in panty hose, linens or toys. In Little Italy, I shop for scamorza, the dried mozzarella properly used in lasagna, or a special pasta cutter or a CD of Neapolitan folk songs. Where Chinatown edges into Little Italy, I buy a bamboo steamer, a fresh-killed guinea hen from a live-poultry market or a palate-tingling Malaysian chili crab. Or I find a glass shade for an antique brass lamp. In SoHo, I am drawn to art galleries, boutiques and the intriguing cuisines of India and Ethiopia.

title: The Other Biological-Weapons Worry
description: Iraq's persistent effort to retain its ability to wage biologi cal warfare rightly frightens all civilized nations. At the same time, Russia has worked hard to defuse tensions over Saddam Hussein's defiance of United Nations Security Council resolutions.

title: Airlines Test Tighter Rules On Baggage
description: After years of complaints, the airlines are moving to clear out their increasingly crowded baggage rooms in the sky, by limiting the amount of bags and baggage passengers can bring on board with them. But they are likely to face a new round of complaints, from infrequent leisure travelers, since most business travelers apparently will be exempt from the baggage restrictions.

title: Barclays Is Ending Tokyo Stock Trading
description: Barclays Bank's Japanese securities arm is shedding its equity sales and trading operation, eliminating about 100 jobs, or about 20 percent of its staff.

title: Compression: A Major Leap
description: ''The Directors Guild sent us a letter,'' Robert Zemeckis said. ''It said there's a new guy in our life: the compressionist.'' For the director, most recently, of ''Contact,'' the space adventure starring Jodie Foster, and in years past ''Forrest Gump,'' ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit'' and the three ''Back to the Future'' movies, that's not a bad thing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEITZMAN, FAYE
description: WEITZMAN-Faye. November 27, 1997. Age 74. Beloved wife of the late William. Mother of Howard (Susan), Larry and Leslie (Edward) Kornfeld. Grandmother of Cathy, Peter, Matthew, Jason, Michelle. Also survived by brothers-in-law and sisters-in-law and many adoring nieces and nephews and wonderful friends. Funeral Friday, November 28, 1:30 PM, Riverside Nassau-North, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York, 516-487-9600.

title: Critic's Choice/Film ; Lighting a Fire in Black and White
description: ''Avant-garde cinema'' has a sliding definition that over the decades has included quite a few films that if revisited today would hardly be deemed revolutionary. But that's not the case with the films of Jack Smith (1932-89), whose small body of work and influence are the focus of a searching retrospective, beginning tomorrow at the American Museum of the Moving Image and continuing through Dec. 14.

title: SUNY Conference Didn't Advance Education; A President's Job
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: When ELTON JOHN cleans out his closets, he doesn't do it in halfway measures. Today he is opening a shop in London at which he will sell more than 10,000 of his favorite clothes at bargain prices to raise money for the Foundation for AIDS, which he has established.

title: Art In Review
description: 'Cambio'

title: Hess's Address to Jets: You're Full of Wonder
description: Firefighters wave from their trucks, cops stop him, and the man in the street beams at Leon Hess these days. For Hess, the 83-year-old owner of the Jets -- that is, the first-place Jets -- it is a time of thanksgiving. ''My expectations have been achieved many times over this season,'' he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, CHRISTINE A.
description: LEE-Christine A. On November 27, of Fort Washington, New York. Beloved daughter of Florence C. and the late John C. Alexion. Services today at 10 A.M., at The Fort Washington Collegiate Church, 729 West 181st Street, Fort Washington, New York. Burial at Saint Johns Lutheran Church Cemetery, Manortown, New York.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: On Black Friday, a B+ (for Bargains); At High and Low End, Season Starts With Quest for Good Price
description: It was only 10:30 A.M., but things were already getting ugly.

title: Treasuries Are Little Changed On Sign Inflation Is Still at Bay
description: Treasury prices were little changed yesterday in a thin, shortened session.

title: Jilted at the Altar
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Skinheads Arrested in Denver In Beating of a Black Woman
description: Five skinheads in handcuffs appeared in court here today, accused of being the latest protagonists in white supremacist attacks that have marred Denver's reputation for tolerance.

title: Trains to the Airport
description: To the Editor:

title: Negro-League Star Dies
description: Buck Leonard, 90, teamed with Josh Gibson and was compared to Lou Gehrig, but his color kept him from the majors. Page A13.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THALER, RABBI RICHARD J.
description: THALER-Rabbi Richard J. With sorrow we record the untimely passing of our beloved colleague, rabbi since 1993 of Sutton Place Synagogue in Manhattan. His religious leadership there and in communities in Israel and Long Island reflected his passionate commitment to his congregational community, to expanding learning and devotion to Israel. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his widow, Julie, his parents, our colleague Rabbi Albert and Shirley Thaler, his sisters Dena, wife of Steve Israel, and Judy, wife of our colleague, Rabbi Steven Kane, his sons, Gilad and Itai and all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi David L. Lieber, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTZER, JACK
description: WALTZER-Jack. Our father was a man of exceptional insight and empathy. He had more energy and vitality than most men half his age, and he was an eager and hearty participant in life-always welcoming opportunities and embracing challenges. His lust for life never flagged. His strength of character and generosity were hallmarks of his business and social relationships. And once you earned his friendship, he was always there when you needed him. He had great presence, even charisma. His emotional strength was impressive and his physical vitality and strenth were imposing. He was a wonderful story teller, who took great pleasure in entertaining his family and friends. He thoroughly enjoyed his fishing, boating and trapshooting. We will miss him-and all of his countless qualities-dearly. We will miss the extraordinary love he had for our mother, to whom he had been married for 54 years, and for the family they had created together. Our children will miss their loving grandfather. We will miss the unabashed pride he took in our accomplishments, as well as his support and solace in our moments of difficulty and disappointment. We will miss a great man...a genuine mensch...our beloved father. Wayne, Paul, Lori, Alice

title: For What Nazis Stole, A Longtime Art Hound
description: A commission formed by the World Jewish Congress to recover art taken from Jewish collectors before and during World War II is expected on Monday to announce the appointment of Constance Lowenthal, the executive director of the International Foundation for Art Research, as its director.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORWOOD, DOROTHY JEAN
description: NORWOOD-Dorothy Jean. On November 27, 1997. Beloved daughter of Dorothy M. and the late James C. Norwood Sr. Loving sister of James C. Jr., Janice E. Becker, Jane M. Kusiak and the late Joan C. Beck. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Friends may call Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Avenue (at RR Plaza), Floral Park, NY. Mass of Christian burial Monday, 9:45 AM at St. Anne's RC Church; interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Lawyers in Accounting Have Conflicting Duties
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTMANN, KURT
description: GUTMANN-Kurt. Died November 28, 1997. Beloved brother of Margot and uncle of Steven. Founder and former president of Kurt Gutmann, Inc. Interment on Sunday, 11 AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Long Island Expressway and College Point Boulevard.

title: MASON-DIXON BANCSHARES ADDS ROSE SHANIS
description: Mason-Dixon Bancshares Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase the Rose Shanis Companies, a family-owned consumer finance company based in Baltimore. Terms were not disclosed. Mason-Dixon, a banking company based in Westminster, Md., which has 22 branches in Maryland, said Rose Shanis has about $47 million in loans outstanding. Mason-Dixon plans to operate Rose Shanis as a unit. The purchase is scheduled to close early next year.

title: Body Discovered in Lake Is Not Missing Woman's
description: Autopsy results showed that the headless and handless body found floating in a Knowlton Township lake on Wednesday was not that of Camden Sylvia, a 36-year-old woman who disappeared earlier this month from her Manhattan loft, Warren County prosecutors said yesterday.

title: A Politician, a Pothole and Plenty of Good Samaritans to Lend a Hand
description: It was one of those things that could have been a holiday traveler's nightmare, but ended up turning into a tale of Thanksgiving good will and good cheer -- not to mention a chance for a politician who does not shy from publicity to take up the cause of pothole-haters everywhere.

title: Sense of Crisis Over Banks Eases, but Japanese Are Still on Edge
description: The sense of crisis looming over Japan's vast financial system subsided a bit today, although investors, analysts and Government officials remained edgy.

title: Miami Lends Good Name, And Bad, to Needy Region
description: When residents of Dade County voted this month to rename their county Miami-Dade, they acquiesced to arguments by public officials that they should bank on the ''magic'' of the name Miami to attract more business.

title: Incomes and Spending Climbed in October
description: Personal income and spending recorded healthy gains as the Christmas shopping season approached, a positive sign for retailers.

title: Perimeter Play Carries Nets To a Victory on the Road
description: Keith Van Horn may finally make his long-awaited debut in Sacramento on Sunday. The Nets may have no other choice.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KROOVAND, WILLIAM, M.D.
description: KROOVAND-William, M.D. Beloved Sonny, missing you for ten long years. Ruthie Kroovand Dwork

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, GEORGE MACDONALD
description: PARKER - George MacDonald. The Board of Directors of Fiduciary Trust International mourns the passing of its esteemed friend and colleague on November 22 in Frankfurt, Germany. He rendered thoughtful and cogent advice for the benefit of the company and its clients during his six years as a director. Our deepest sympathy to his wife, Susan Bissell Parker, and his daughter Julia and son Angus.

title: Toshiba Profit Off 77% In Computer Competition
description: The Toshiba Corporation said yesterday that first-half pretax profits plunged 77 percent, mainly because of competition from low-cost computer companies. The Japanese company reported a pretax profit of 8.74 billion yen, or $68.8 million, for the six months that ended on Sept. 30, compared with 38 billion yen in the period a year earlier. Net earnings fell 43 percent, to 9.55 billion yen. Sales rose 3.8 percent, to 2.601 trillion yen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRITTON, COBURN
description: BRITTON-Coburn, 61. Poet and former publisher, died of cancer on November 26 at his home in Lebanon, New Jersey. Born in Cleveland and longtime resident of New York City, he was co-publisher of Horizon Press in the 1960's and founder of ''Prose'', a belletrist magazine in 1970. After closing ''Prose'' in 1974 he divided his time between writing poetry and tending to his cattle and apple farm in Hunterdon County, New Jersey. Four volumes of his poetry were published. Survived by his partner, Adrian Koppens of London, England, his sister-in-law Lynda Britton, nephews, Sky and Tim Britton all of Chesterland, Ohio, nephew, Terry Britton of Boulder, Colorado, caretaker and friend Robert Benson of Lebanon, New Jersey. A funeral mass will be held at 2:00 P.M., on Saturday December 13, 1997 at St. Thomas's Episcopal Church on Sky Manor Drive in Pittstown, New Jersey. Interment of his cremated remains will follow the service. A Memorial Service in New York City will be announced. For further information contact Martin Funeral Home, Clinton, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLINO, NICHOLAS J.
description: GOLINO-Nicholas J. President, Golino Concrete Company. On November 27, 1997. Of Pelham Manor, NY. Beloved husband of Elsie Conrey Golino. Father of Gerald and John Golino and the late Janice Colangelo. Visiting Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave, Pelham NY, Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, Monday 10 AM. For information call 914-738-1060.

title: Fitting the Lord Into Work's Tight Schedules
description: It is Wednesday, and Louis Tuchman's appointment book is packed, as usual. At 9:45 A.M., he huddles with a fellow lawyer to fine-tune two major real estate deals. At noon, he skips lunch to return phone calls and sign documents. But at 12:30 P.M., Mr. Tuchman steps into his firm's boardroom on the 14th floor of the Chrysler Building for what he calls the most important meeting of all.

title: No Sign of Hangover On the Day After; Eating, Then More Eating
description: People not only shopped, they ate, and not just leftovers. The line at Carnegie Deli on Broadway in Manhattan stretched more than 50 feet, a mixture of locals and tourists undaunted by a pound of pastrami on the day after Thanksgiving dinner.

title: It's Barber vs. Barber When Giants Play Bucs
description: Tiki and Ronde Barber, twin brothers and professional football players, spent Thanksgiving Day apart this year. That never happened before.

title: INSIDE: Arts & Ideas
description: A new opera in Chicago provides more roles for black singers.

title: Letting the Public In On the Quaint Stories Behind the Stories
description: ''I greet you at the beginning of a great career,'' Ralph Waldo Emerson wrote Walt Whitman in 1855 after reading ''Leaves of Grass.'' Emerson's letter, the welcoming of a newcomer by an established master, is one of the most famous -- and influential -- in literary history. It immediately gave Whitman artistic certification.

title: About New York; For Victims, Peace of Mind In a House Call
description: JOHN POWELL rang the lobby buzzer in a Bronx building. Nothing. He pressed the button again and cupped his hand over the door's smudged window. Soon, a woman padded downstairs and shot him a look that was as weary as it was wary.

title: SUBMICRON AGREES TO SELL IMTEC ACCULINE UNIT
description: The Submicron Systems Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Imtec Acculine Inc. unit to a group of senior managers as it focuses on production of wet-chemical processing equipment. Terms were not disclosed. The sale, expected to be completed Dec. 31, will not have ''a material effect'' on earnings, Submicron said. Imtec Acculine makes equipment used in the production of semiconductors. Under the agreement with the closely held IAI Acquisitions Corporation, Submicron will license related technology to the group. Submicron, based in Allentown, Pa., had sales of $171.5 million last year.

title: Audit Firms' Partners Back Deal, but U.S. Must Act, Too
description: The partners at Price Waterhouse and Coopers & Lybrand, two of the world's largest accounting firms, have voted overwhelmingly to merge their practices into one.

title: Liberties; Dressing Down Rudy
description: Marion Barry thinks Rudolph Giuliani is at ''the bottom of the barrel.''

title: Dollar Nears 5-Year High Against the Yen
description: The dollar rose against the yen yesterday, approaching a five-year high, as concern about Japan's weak economy and financial system made traders reluctant to hold the Japanese currency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARR, RUTH
description: STARR-Ruth. 98. On November 26, 1997. Loving aunt of Jane Roland Martin, Laurie Ellen Scher and Anne Louise Scher. Treasured great aunt of Timothy David Martin and Thomas Peter Martin. Memorial services Monday 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside,'' West 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

title: For Exiles From Medicaid, Lessons in Managed Care
description: In an effort to guide the millions of Medicaid beneficiaries around the country who will soon be obliged to sign up for managed care plans, the Community Service Society of New York is starting a consumer education project that will focus initially on recipients in Los Angeles, Philadelphia and New York City.

title: ENTREMED DRUG STUDY SENDS STOCK UP BY 28%
description: Entremed Inc.'s experimental drug drastically shrank mouse tumors in a study that the company reported yesterday, sending shares up 28 percent. Shares in the biotechnology company rose $3.375, to close at $15.25, after the announcement of the study, published in this month's issue of the journal Nature. Researchers at the Children's Hospital affiliate of the Harvard Medical School in Boston found giving the special protein compound to mice reduced the size of a variety of tumors until they were no more than invisible or nearly undetectable lesions. The drug, Endostatin, prevents angiogenesis -- the rapid, abnormal formation of the small blood vessels that feed tumors.

title: Stanton Catlin, 82, Expert on Modern Mexican Mural Painting
description: Stanton L. Catlin, an art historian who did pioneering work in the study and documentation of modern Mexican mural painting, died on Wednesday at his home in Fayetteville, N.Y. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEHINGER, ILSE, NEE SOMMER
description: FLEHINGER-Ilse, nee Sommer. On Friday, November 28. Beloved mother of Steven Flehinger and Miriam Moser. Mother-in-law of Paul and Harriet. Grandmother to Lisa, Rachel, Michael, and Alexandra. Services at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, 12:30 P.M., Monday, December 1.

title: Demolishing the Dams
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S GAMES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUBIN, LEO
description: TAUBIN-Leo. Age 96. On November 27, 1997. Husband of the late Rhoda. Father of Elaine Finkelstein, Harvey Taubin and Marion Lipschutz. Cherished grandfather of Leslie, Arlene, Terry, Mark, Richard, Sharon and Rhonda. Great-grandfather to nine.

title: Just How Sorry Can You Get? Pretty Sorry
description: With instructive prodigality, the English language offers a variety of formulations for the commonest of expressions: I'm sorry. The offending party can beg pardon, apologize, offer regrets or voice remorse, after which the culprit can confess error, fault or guilt while promising to atone, repent and/or compensate. Nowadays contrition in all its shadings seems routine as leaders everywhere engage in a kind of premillennial washing of the spears.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNAMEE, MARGARET
description: McNAMEE-Margaret. Beloved daughter of Edmund and Lillian McNamee. Loving sister of Maureen and her husband Frank Liantonio, Michele and her husband Terrance Sullivan and Monica and the late Tom Fleming. Devoted aunt of Kiera and Bridget. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street, Friday 7-9 and Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street, Monday 10 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to American Cancer Society for Camp Adventures, 39 Edgewood Drive, New Hyde Park, New York 11040.

title: Impasse in Iraq
description: One week after the tense standoff over Iraq's secret arsenal was supposed to have ended, Iraq is still barring United Nations weapons inspectors from its Presidential palaces, military bases and intelligence headquarters.

title: Beliefs
description: Fascinating findings about the religious lives of Americans are constantly surfacing, and none more fascinating -- at least for this particular weekend -- than the claim that people actually spend as much time worshiping in the holiday season as they spend shopping.

title: Protest Disrupts Contempt Case Against Pakistan Premier
description: Supporters of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif climbed over iron gates today and stormed the Supreme Court building, forcing the court to suspend contempt proceedings against the Prime Minister.

title: Words That Give His Oratory Its Fame
description: Following are excerpts from two speeches by Senator Robert C. Byrd. The first is from a 1996 speech to the new members of the Senate about its history and traditions. He concluded with an excerpt from his two-volume study of the Senate's history and customs. The second is from 1 of 14 lectures on ancient Rome he delivered in 1993 against legislation giving the President line-item veto authority. He called them ''Phillipics,'' which was the name Cicero gave to his 14 speeches criticizing Marc Antony.

title: Marguerite Henry, 95, Author Of the 'Chincoteague' Series
description: Marguerite Henry, the author of the children's book classic ''Misty of Chincoteague,'' one of some four dozen books that introduced young readers to animals in the great outdoors, died on Wednesday at her home in Rancho Santa Fe, near San Diego. She was 95.

title: 212 or 646? New York Deserves More Options; More Resonance, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Salvage Tie in LaFontaine's Fond Return
description: He tried to tell himself it was just another night; just one more game in the National Hockey League's 82-game forced march.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSELBRENNER, ISRAEL., M.D.
description: KESSELBRENNER-Israel., M.D. November 27. Beloved husband of the late Ida. He is survived by sons Michael and Dan, daughters-inlaw Doree and Sarah, and grandchildren, Kiersten, Jeffrey, Joseph, David, Sarah, Louis, Joel. Retired director of Manhattan State Hospital & Clinical Professor at Columbia Medical School. He will be missed. Services, Sunday November 30, 1:00 PM, Menorah Chapel, Union, NJ. Interment, Beth-El Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the organization which aided his escape from Nazi Europe, The American Friends Service Committee, 1501 Cherry Street, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 19103. Shiva will be observed, from Sunday-Thursday, 58 East Sherbrooke Parkway, Livingston, New Jersey.

title: CONMED SHARES UP ON DEAL WITH BRISTOL-MYERS
description: The shares of the Conmed Corporation rose almost 19 percent yesterday after the company said on Thursday that it would buy a Bristol-Myers Squibb Company's surgery equipment unit for $370 million. Conmed shares rose $3.75, to $23.75, in Nasdaq trading. Conmed is buying Bristol-Myers's Linvatec Corporation, which had more than $215 million in revenue in 1996, compared with $126 million for Conmed, which is based in Utica, N.Y. Linvatec makes equipment used in knee surgery and other procedures involving bones. Conmed already sells medical and surgical equipment, including devices used in procedures for the heart. It said it expects to take a onetime charge for the acquisition, which could be completed by the end of the year.

title: Dispute Between Magazine And Giuliani Lands in Court
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani asked the city's transit agency to drop a New York magazine advertising campaign from its buses that satirically tweaked him, the magazine's editors were incensed. The Mayor lacked a sense of humor, they said, and his action violated their right to free speech.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYPER, STUART
description: MAYPER-Stuart. The Officers and Trustees of the Institute of General Semantics mourn the death of Stuart Mayper, longtime Trustee, Editor of the General Semantics Bulletin and teacher for nearly thirty years at Institute seminars. He will be sorely missed.

title: Byrd's Eloquent Voice Continues to Fight to Honor Tradition in the Senate
description: Robert C. Byrd's hand shakes a bit these days as he brandishes his worn copy of the Constitution to make a point on the Senate floor. His voice also quavers as he characteristically invokes some obscure event in ancient Rome to emphasize his argument.

title: 212 or 646? New York Deserves More Options; Glamour by the Numbers
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Star-Studded Match, 2 Americans Edge to Victory
description: A star-studded field battled here Thursday night in the final of the Blue Ribbon Pair Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals. Victory went to Adam Wildavsky of Queens and Allan Falk of Okemos, Mich., who led into the final session and held on to win by seven match points. In hot pursuit were two European stars, Tony Forrester of England and Geir Helgemo of Norway, who have built a weird streak: In the past three years they have been second in five major events without scoring a win.

title: Sports of The Times; The Passing Of an Era Of Elegance
description: NEW ORLEANS wakes up to a grand celebration this morning. It is a city that celebrates something every day, and toasts something every night. But this celebration is unusual -- even by Crescent City standards. This one marks the end of eras in so many lives.

title: No Sign of Hangover On the Day After; The World After Woolworth
description: For more than 30 years, Veronica Hawkins started her annual Christmas shopping the day after Thanksgiving in Newark's commercial hub, at the F. W. Woolworth store at Broad and Market Streets. Today, she trudged off to Herald Square in Manhattan, setting out five hours earlier than past years.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Calendar column in the House and Home section on Thursday gave incorrect dates for a Christmas sale at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street. The opening party will take place on Thursday, Dec. 4, from 6 to 9 P.M., and the festival will continue on Dec. 5, from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M., and Dec. 6, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Information: (212) 289-3400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACDOUGALL, RELLA
description: MACDOUGALL-Rella. The Women's Committee of The Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club express their deepest sorrow in the passing of their dear friend and colleague. Rella, who joined the committee in 1973, was a guiding force to all of us. As Chairman of The Kips Bay Decorator Show House, her extraordinary dedication and commitment allowed us to raise more than eight million dollars for the children. We will miss her every day and try to follow in her magnificent footsteps.

title: A Slave Ship Mutiny Opens Opportunities For Blacks in Opera
description: Lucius Jennet, a 27-year-old baritone, will make his professional debut on Saturday night at the Lyric Opera here in the world premiere of Anthony Davis's ''Amistad,'' based on the true story of a 19th-century slave ship rebellion and the subsequent trial of the mutineers. Mr. Jennet makes his living as an Internet advertising salesman for The Chicago Tribune.

title: Jet Returns to Newark After Smoke Is Noticed
description: An American Airlines Boeing 727 passenger jet returned to Newark International Airport 15 minutes after takeoff yesterday when the pilots noticed smoke in the cockpit.

title: Gunman Slain in Attack on Mexican Editor Was Drug Gangster, Officials Say
description: Investigators have identified a gunman who died when he ambushed a prominent Mexican journalist as ''an important active member'' of the narcotics gang that controls the border city of Tijuana, where the attack took place, the Government said today.

title: Buck Leonard, 90, Slugger Of the Negro Leagues, Dies
description: Buck Leonard, regarded as the greatest first baseman in the history of the Negro leagues, deprived of a chance to play major league baseball but a Hall of Famer nonetheless, died Thursday at Nash General Hospital in his hometown of Rocky Mount, N.C. He was 90.

title: Experience Sours a Once-Enthusiastic Reno on Applying the Independent Counsel Law
description: When Janet Reno became Attorney General, she championed the independent counsel law as a way to assure the impartiality of investigations into top Administration officials. Not anymore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHBACH, JEROME
description: FISCHBACH-Jerome. November 28. Loving son of the late Beatrice and Harry. Cherished husband of Eleanore. Beloved father of Stefanie (John) Whalen, Penny Cutler, Bede (Steven) Levinson, and Nancy (Selwyn) Taubman. Loving grandfather of Robin, Sandi, Sara, Jonathan, Matthew, Ethan, and Rachel, and great-grandfather of two. Dear brother of Herbert and the late Rosalind Neuwirth and Allen, and dear stepson of Stella. Services on Monday, December 1, 10 A.M., Riverside Mount Vernon. In lieu of flowers, contributions to: Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, 381 Park Avenue South, NY, NY 10016.

title: Suffolk Teams Take Titles
description: Two teams from Suffolk -- North Babylon and Bellport -- routed their Nassau counterparts yesterday in Long Island title games at Hofstra.

title: Brotherly Intervention
description: Last Saturday, David Kaczynski served notice that he would challenge the prosecutors' decision to seek the death penalty for his brother, Theodore Kaczynski, the man suspected of being the Unabomber, who carried out a string of bombings beginning in 1978.

title: 212 or 646? New York Deserves More Options; Faxes and Modems
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: U.N. Extends Monitoring of Police in Haiti
description: The Security Council voted today to extend the mission of a multinational police-monitoring force in Haiti for a year and to increase its size to 300 members, from 250. The move reiterates the United Nations' commitment to Haiti even as it removes the last of its peacekeeping troops.

title: Stable Russia Needs Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Gain in Japan Stocks Helps Bolster Wall Street

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKER, HERMAN, RABBI
description: DICKER-Herman, Rabbi. (LTC Retired). November 28, 1997. Born Hungary, 1914. Beloved husband of Eileen. Loving father of Anna and Eli and grandfather of Shelley, Michael, Sarah & Jeremy. Loving brother of Jennie, Joseph and Albert and cherished uncle. Faithful minister to Holocaust survivors. Dedicated scholar, librarian and author. Services Sunday, November 30, 1:45 PM, Sinai Chapels, 16205 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing. Call 718-445-0300.

title: The Sun Sets on British Civility
description: If the British yearned for an era of a kinder, gentler public discourse after the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, their hopes have been dashed. An unlikely trio, the writers Salman Rushdie and John le Carre and Diana's younger brother, Earl Spencer, have seen to that, with theatrical flair.

title: 'Buy Nothings' Discover a Cure for Affluenza
description: News flash: Dozens of people did not shop today.

title: Journal; Seven Is Enough
description: Just as there's hope that political correctness might at last be running its course, permitting Americans once more to trade ''farmer's daughter'' jokes and ''Amos 'n' Andy'' videos on the open market, along comes an even more oppressive phenomenon to suck the humor out of life: emotional correctness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMANN, MARTHA MARTEL
description: KAUFMANN-Martha Martel, died Thursday, November 27, at age 82, following a heroic battle against breast cancer. Beloved wife of 55 years to Harold, cherished mother of Renee, Carol, Joan, Charles and Isaac, and adored grandmother of Robert, Marion, Victoria, Sasha, Amelia, and Samuel. A woman of valor, former army nurse, friend to all who knew her. She will be missed. Services Sunday, November 30, 11 AM, Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Rego Park, New York.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''People are entitled to take in the sights. But please! They have to realize where they are.''

title: Buoyed by Japan Gains, Dow Rises 28.35
description: Stocks ended higher in a shortened session yesterday, bolstered by three days of gains in Japanese stocks.

title: Mitsubishi Chief Apologizes for Scandal
description: The new president of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, Katsuhiko Kawasoe, apologized to shareholders today for the auto maker's involvement in a scandal that he said helped pushed down its domestic sales by 30 percent in November.

title: INSIDE
description: Skinheads Held in Denver

title: Using Drugs on the Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELSON, KATHY (PLASZNER)
description: BELSON-Kathy (Plaszner). A gracious and talented lady who knew far too much pain in her eight year struggle with cancer. We are everlastingly grateful to her friends and associates for their caring devotion and love to Kathy and her daughter Jackie and son Jonathan. May Kathy finally experience the peace and comfort that was denied to her in these last pain filled months. Maxine and Jerome Belson.

title: Defeat and Default Dig a Hole for U.S.
description: Tom Gullikson, the captain of the United States Davis Cup team, swore it would not happen this time. There would be no supernatural goings-on, no mysterious injuries, no eerie surrenders inside the hulking Scandinavium Arena. But Gullikson could not have been more wrong.

title: Safety Steps for Boeing 747's
description: Since Federal investigators have found no evidence that a bomb or missile destroyed T.W.A. Flight 800, the only plausible explanation is mechanical failure. Investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board have concluded that the plane was destroyed when vapors in the near-empty center fuel tank ignited. But after 16 months of inquiry, with more than 95 percent of the plane retrieved from the ocean floor, they still do not know what caused the vapor to ignite.

title: PBS Series On Science Departs for The World Of 'X-Men'
description: Ms. Frizzle, the world's wackiest science teacher, will drive her magic bus on a major detour next fall, leaving the education-friendly byways of PBS for the Fox network, joining shows like ''Power Rangers,'' ''The X-Men'' and ''Goosebumps.''

title: After Bronx Killings, Silence and Fear
description: The young man began shaking his head before a reporter could even finish asking whether he had a moment to talk. ''Not about that,'' he said, pointing to bloodstains on the pavement. ''Not about that.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFF, SARAH W.
description: GRIFF-Sarah W., 90. November 13, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Samuel H. Griff; devoted mother of Helen G. Weisgal and former son-in-law Sherman; cherished grandmother of Stephen and Jonathan; and great grandmother of Jacob. Also survived by her sisters Rose and Stella.

title: Jayhawks Wear Down Seminoles to Take N.I.T.
description: They missed 10 of 11 shots between them in the first half last night, but Paul Pierce and Raef LaFrentz are all-America forwards, their talent as rippling at Kansas as the wheat.

title: Rock-Music Shrine, in Pink: After Years, a Buyer Is Found
description: Twenty years ago, when Michael Amitin first thought about buying the salmon-colored ranch house at the end of a rough gravel track here, he had no idea that it was Big Pink, a retreat immortalized in 1967 when Bob Dylan and a group of musicians spent seven months in the cinder-block basement, recording more than 100 songs.

title: Saddam Hussein's Guest List
description: Iraq's invitation to let foreign diplomats stay as guests in President Saddam Hussein's many palaces, while turning away the United Nations weapons inspectors, deserves the scorn it is getting from the U.N. and its member nations. Since the U.N. inspection team began trying in 1991 to monitor Iraq's efforts to make nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, its inspectors have been turned away 73 times from Government buildings and palaces. With suspicions running high that lethal weapons and material, possibly including nerve gas, may be stashed in the palaces, experts, not diplomats, need access.

title: Devils Finally Wake Up And Thrash the Sharks
description: All it took was a cross-country trip, a desultory start to the road trip and then a sleepwalk through much of the first period tonight before the Devils finally awoke from their slumber.

title: Pornography Case Against Lawyer Ended
description: Prosecutors have dropped child pornography charges against the Ontario lawyer who once represented a convicted murderer, Paul Bernardo.

title: Mayor Opens Investigation Into Balloon Accident at Macy's Parade
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he had directed top aides and police officials to investigate whether tighter regulations should be applied to the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, after an accident in which a six-story-high Cat in the Hat balloon knocked down part of a lamppost, injuring four spectators.

title: Richemont to Buy The Rest of Vendome
description: Cie. Financiere Richemont of Switzerland said yesterday that it planned to buy the 30 percent of the Vendome Luxury Group of Britain that it did not own for $:1.036 billion ($1.73 billion), consolidating its hold on the group's global luxury brands like Cartier and Piaget watches and Montblanc pens. The South African- controlled Richemont said it would offer 495 pence in cash for each Vendome share it did not already own, which put a value on the company of $:3.454 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHRAG, ILSE
description: SCHRAG-Ilse. Age 86 of NYC, wife of the late artist Karl Schrag. Mother of Dr. Peter Schrag & Mrs. Katherine Wangh, sister of Henry A. Samton, grandmother of Deborah, Daniel and Jonathan Schrag, and Rebecca and Marina Wangh, great-grandmother of Noam Benkler, died November 26, 1997, following complications of hip surgery. Memorial services will be held at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue, Sunday, November 30 at 10:45 AM. No flowers please.

title: PREMIER OF INDIA QUITS, DEEPENING POLITICAL BEDLAM
description: India's fourth Government in 18 months resigned today, deepening the political chaos and economic uncertainty that have overtaken the country since a 1996 election produced a fractured Parliament, almost no political leaders of national stature and no consensus on the issues facing the impoverished nation of 980 million.

title: Don't Rush to Spend City's Revenue Windfall
description: To the Editor:

title: Congestion Cooperation
description: To the Editor:

title: Winnie Mandela Discredited Herself, Police Official Says
description: South Africa's security police kept Winnie Madikizela-Mandela under 24 hour surveillance. They tapped her phone and they bugged her house.

title: Wry Child of the Unconscious; William Steig, 90, on Art, Life and the Mysterious Orgone
description: One of William Steig's drawings in ''Our Miserable Life'' captures something about the artist who drew it. A man in a coat and hat is sitting up in a baby stroller, stunned. The caption reads, ''The Napper Wakes.'' Mr. Steig, with his intense blue eyes and head of startled hair, is a curious, ingenuous and impertinent child at the age of 90. He had his birthday this month.

title: Doctors for the Deaf
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDAU, RUTH
description: LANDAU-Ruth. On November 28, 1997. Beloved wife of Theodore, loving mother of Beth, devoted sister of the late Dr. William H. Mencher. Service private. Contributions may be sent to the American Cancer Society.

title: Credit Suisse Unit Is Fined in Spain
description: Spanish stock market authorities said yesterday that they had fined Credit Suisse Financial Products 285 million pesetas ($1.9 million), saying the firm had manipulated share prices that affected the benchmark IBEX stock index in Spain. The Comision Nacional del Mercado de Valores said the offense qualified as ''very grave'' and the fine needed to be approved by the Economy Ministry of Spain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, SOPHIA RAYMAN
description: SILVER-Sophia Rayman, 99. Of Miami Beach, Florida. Passed away peacefully on November 27th, at the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Fairfield, CT. She was the mother of June Rayman Lurie of Westport, CT. Mrs. Silver was born in 1898 in Mt. Vernon, NY. The fourth of seven children of Ida and Charles Subitzky, who were among the first Jewish settlers of the City. Mrs. Silver was married to Harry Rayman, with whom she owned a jewelry store in Mt. Vernon. After his death, she married Morris Silver and later moved to Florida. In addition to her daughter, survivors include her sister, Lillian Miller of Albuquerque, NM; her two grandchildren, Diana Lurie Boersma of Sleepy Hollow, NY, & Raymond Lurie of New Haven, CT, and two great grandchildren, Edward and Jacob Boersma of Sleepy Hollow, NY. Services Monday, 10:30 AM at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

title: Tim Ryan Copes, and Crusades
description: The diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease came early for Lee Ryan. She was only 50. Now, eight years later, Ryan, the wife of the CBS sportscaster Tim Ryan, can no longer walk. She can barely speak except to blurt out an occasional word.

title: Wall St., Where Blockbuster Deals Produce Jawbreakers
description: What's in a name? On Wall Street, perhaps a little too much. The year of the megadeal and the consolidation boogie is giving the financial world a proliferation of tongue-twisting names.

title: Duane Reade Plans Initial Public Offering
description: Duane Reade Inc., the largest drugstore chain in Manhattan, has filed for a $92 million initial public offering as part of a plan to reduce debt.

title: Still Your Grandmother's Bingo, but Supercharged
description: Like many women her age, 66-year-old Agnes Myles thinks computers are best left to her grandchildren. ''There is the one at home, but I can't be bothered with it,'' she said.

title: Foxes' Friends in Commons Back Ban on the Hunt
description: Parliament voted overwhelmingly today for a proposal that could one day ban the traditional British sport of fox hunting.

title: Asian Pollution Is Widening Its Deadly Reach
description: Ramli lay on the plank floor of his shack, coughing and breathless, fighting for air like a beached fish.

title: Isles Miss Chances, and Palffy Blames Himself
description: Zigmund Palffy shook his head and muttered to himself in Czech after today's game. He could have been thinking about any one of several crucial moments during the Islanders' 4-1 loss to the Flyers at the Core States Center.

title: Ashamed of George Washington?
description: To serve its students, the majority of whom are black, the New Orleans School Board made a seemingly reasonable decision in 1992. It would rename any school that was named for ''former slave owners or others who did not respect equal opportunity for all.''

title: Storm Gets Hard Look At What Lies Ahead
description: When Georgia Tech's Matt Harpring took an inbound pass, spun and fired a 79-foot shot that swished through the net with one second to go in the third period, St. John's knew this was not its night.

title: Nutrition for Life in Pact With Salesman
description: Nutrition for Life International Inc. said today that it had reached an eight-year agreement with Kevin Trudeau, a key salesman, under which it would pay him a percentage of its monthly revenue and he would sell the company's products exclusively.

title: Traffic Jams the Sidewalk; Times Square, a Magnet for Tourists, Faces a New Problem: Pedestrian Gridlock
description: The two-hour bus ride from Hellertown, Pa., was pleasant enough. It was the four-block walk through Times Square that seemed daunting to Darlene Repash and Nancy Merritt.

title: No Sign of Hangover On the Day After; Hunger for Shopping, and Pastrami
description: Robert Keezer had assumed the position. Seated in a stylish chair beneath a display of bright stylish Asian clothes inside the new Shanghai Tang store on Madison Avenue yesterday, Mr. Keezer could easily have been mistaken for that age-old shopping archetype -- the long-suffering husband. Sales clerks swirled around him, escorting customers into dressing rooms. Everywhere there was movement.

title: As Veteran Goes Down, Jets Give Rookie a Chance
description: If Lamont Burns's grandmother still owned the newsstand at 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue in Harlem (she sold it eight years ago), she would be selling papers with a story to gladden her heart. Her little grandson, now 6 feet 4 inches and 300 pounds, will start playing for the Jets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIFFUNI, MARIE T.
description: GIFFUNI-Marie T. Of Plandome, NY. Beloved wife of Joseph. Cherished mother of Louis and mother-in-law of Allison. Loving grandmother of Katie. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, 3-5 and 7-9 PM, Saturday and Sunday. Funeral Mass 9:45 AM, St. Mary's Church, Roslyn. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the National Center for Disabilities Services, Albertson, NY 11507.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNE, ABRAHAM
description: BERNE-Abraham of Long Beach, NY, November 27 at age 89. Beloved husband for 60 years of Frances; loving father of Marjorie and Bernard; devoted brother of Bernard I.; dear father-in-law of Joseph and Elaine, cherished grandfather of Corey, Jordan and Greg. Former Assistant principal of Far Rockaway High School.

title: Flatter, Smarter and Socially Sensitive
description: Lord knows, Mattel tries.

title: Briefly, Mayor Who Barely Sleeps Leaves the City That Never Does
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who often seems mystified by the concept of leisure time and who prides himself on his sleep-is-for-wimps regimen, went on vacation yesterday afternoon. Well, sort of.

title: 212 or 646? New York Deserves More Options
description: To the Editor:

title: Dixie Flag Continues Streak
description: If there are truly horses for courses in racing, then the horse is Dixie Flag and the course is Aqueduct.

title: Minor Chord Apotheosis: Out With the Hankies
description: Henry Threadgill's quintet, Make a Move, which on Tuesday night started a six-day week of performances at the Knitting Factory, is a five-handkerchief dirge band. With this group, the dramatic element of Mr. Threadgill's writing, which developed in the late 1970's, is taken to its limits: a minor chord is settled into, wrung out through tremolos and different voicings, and slowly another chord replaces it. The pieces are less like songs than successions of tonal clouds, and a zigzagging lead voice connects them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANTZMAN, LEO
description: FRANTZMAN-Leo. Husband of the late Sally. He is survived by loving sisters Eva Weisbrot and Ceilia Gellman and dear brother George, beloved son Joel and Perry, grandchildren Julia, Seth, Jake and Sara and numerous nieces, nephews and cousins. He has left a hole in the hearts of his closest friends which will not be easily mended. Service Sunday, 11:30 AM, November 30 at Park Avenue Synagogue, 87 St. and Madison Ave. Interment at Mount Lebanon Cemetery in Queens. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the 100299 77th Block Association, C/O Marine Midland Bank, corner of 77th and 3rd Ave., or to a charity of one's choice. For further information call Plaza Memorial Chapel, 212-769-4400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, ELIZABETH M.
description: MORRIS-Elizabeth M. November 26, 1997. Beloved wife of the late William. Devoted aunt and greataunt. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday 10 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Rangeley Region Health Center, P.O. Box 722, Rangeley, Maine 04970.

title: From Prison, Old Militant Struggles On
description: At 74, Philip Berrigan is in prison, again; convicted, again, of damaging weapons of war, and staining them with his blood, in the name of peace; sentenced, again, to the confinement he endures to confront what he sees as the militaristic sins of the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEYMOUR, ABBY LEWIS
description: SEYMOUR-Abby Lewis. Actress, active in radio, television and theatre for sixty-five years, widow of John Davenport Seymour, also of the theatre, died November 27, 1997. She is survived by his son Peter Seymour and his daughter Katherine Hollingshead and seven grandchildren. Also surviving her are her sisters Beulah L. Smith, Fredrica L. Yates, Sue L. Wimberly and brother Hunter W. Lewis. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Saturday from 4-7 PM and Sunday 2-4 P.M. Interment to follow in New Mexico.

title: No Sign of Hangover On the Day After; Bracelets and Bargains
description: Tanya Smith stood over the Macy's glass counter at the Fulton Street Mall in downtown Brooklyn, admiring an assortment of pearl necklaces, earrings and bracelets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, PAUL L. M.D.
description: GILBERT-Paul L. M.D. On November 27, 1997. Beloved husband of Harriet. Father of Laura Gilbert-Merrill, David Gilbert and Daniel Gilbert. Cherished grandfather of Jena and Aidan Paul GilbertMerrill, and Michael and Zachary Gilbert. Memorial service Sunday 2 P.M., Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANDES, GERALD, DR.
description: BANDES-Gerald, Dr. Beloved husband of Fredda. Loving father of Dr. John and Erica Bandes and Lynda and Michael Fitz. Cherished grandfather of Rachel and Matthew Fitz. Past President and Chairman of the Ethics Committee of the N.Y.C. Veterinary Medical Association. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30 PM Sunday.

title: OXFORD PROPERTIES TO BUY A CANADIAN COMPANY
description: Oxford Properties Group Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Canadian real estate company Burcon Properties Ltd. for $609 million (Canadian), or $428 million (United States). Burcon owns a majority stake in the Toronto-based Oxford, which owns and manages commercial real estate. It also controls Concord Pacific Group, a company with two key real estate projects: Concord Pacific Place in Vancouver, British Columbia, and Cityplace in Toronto. Oxford will exchange $18.30 (Canadian) in stock for each of Burcon's 33.3 million shares outstanding. Concord will also assume about $50 million (Canadian) in debt. After the merger closes, Oxford intends to sell Burcon's noncore assets. It expects to gain about $50 million (Canadian) from the sale.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Looking for a Legal Strategy in Pullovers and Pastels
description: In high-profile cases, every defendant has a look. For some, it is the business suit, to show polished success that asks, ''Why would I have done it?'' For some, it is the preppy blazer, to display boy-next-door harmlessness.

title: Conformity Comes to the Mailbox
description: They're taking away my initials. Not the ones my parents gave me, of course; the ones the Postal Service gave me -- R.F.D. I'll never again get the same counter-culture fix from my walk to the mailbox.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PINNACLE MICRO INC., Irvine, Calif., said it might have to seek protection under Federal bankruptcy law if it was unable to find financing to meet its cash needs.

title: The Knicks Stand Helpless as a Big Lead Vanishes
description: The veteran Knicks turned into loitering teen-agers tonight. They stood around their favorite hangout, Patrick Ewing, and watched the world go by.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, HAROLD G.
description: KING-Harold G. On November 26, 1997. Formerly of Oceanside, L.I. Beloved husband of the late Dorit. Father of Elizabeth King Engros, grandfather of Victoria and Austin and brother of Bernadette. Friends may call at The Abbey, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street, on Sunday, 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 P.M.

title: Insurers Said to Slight High-Risk Properties
description: A new program designed to help people get insurance coverage for high-risk coastal properties has had disappointing results so far, state officials said yesterday.

title: Editorial Notebook; It's Enough to Make a Baby Blush
description: I suppose the folks at Johns Hopkins University will be distressed to learn that I took my daughter Abby to ''The Full Monty.'' Abby is 8 months old, and ''The Full Monty'' is a loopy British movie about male striptease. Scarred for life, those Johns Hopkins folks might say.

title: A Dance of Imagination Shapes a Child's View Of Life and the World
description: The children's dance program at the Henry Street Settlement has played an important role in the artistic life of New York City, developing performers, a few choreographers and eager dance audiences. A major player in the life of that program in the 1950's and 60's was Murray Louis, whose Murray Louis and Nikolais Dance troupe opens opens a two-week season on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater. The season includes two Saturday family matinees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, DR. ALEX
description: DEUTSCH-Dr. Alex. On November 24, at the age of 84 he passed peacefully in his sleep. Beloved husband of the late Terry (nee Crystal), devoted and beloved father to Beth, Stella, Les, Philip, and adored grandfather of Jon, David, and Jason. He is survived by his sisters Lee and Anne. He loved life, his family and gave his wonderful sense of humor to all he touched. His inner strength was an inspiration to many. He will be missed. Memorial service will be held at New Montefiore Cemetery on Sunday, November 30 at 11:30 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAASE, MARY, FRANCES
description: HAASE-Mary-Frances. Of Pinehurst, NC. Formerly of Pelham Manor, NY. On November 25, 1997. Wife of the late Louis G. Haase. Mother of Cameron A. Haase-Pettingell of Waltham, MA, and L. Bardes Haase of Westerly, RI. Sister of F. Cameron Ludwig of Weare, NH. Grandmother of Gilbert B. Pettingell, Joslin H. Pettingell and Katrina Haase. Memorial service to be held at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made in her memory to a local hospice. For more information, J.S. Waterman & Sons-Waring Funeral Home, Wellesley, MA.

title: Q&A/Dr. Francis L. Belloni; Dean Guides Next Generation in Research
description: THE new dean of the Graduate School of Basic Medical Sciences at New York Medical College, Dr. Francis L. Belloni, compares what is happening today in biomedical research with what happened to art during the Renaissance. Dr. Belloni of Cortlandt Manor said it is an exciting time to be both a scientist and an educator guiding the next generation of scientists.

title: Missoni, In Size 3T
description: Mother-daughter clothing once ran to ruffled pink pinafores, but no more. Now, little girls (and boys) can wear scaled-down versions of their parents' designer clothes.

title: The World; Joining With the Taliban In a New War on Drugs
description: THIS grim, remote town is the capital of Helmand province, the opium-growing capital of the world.

title: PROPOSAL TO TEST DRUGS IN CHILDREN MEETS RESISTANCE
description: Fierce disputes have erupted over a proposal by President Clinton that would require drug companies to test their products in children before putting new medicines on the market.

title: Dena Boronkay and Michael Rashes
description: Dena Ellen Boronkay, the daughter of Serena and George A. Boronkay of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Michael Scott Rashes, the son of Sylvia and Bernard D. Rashes of Fresh Meadows, Queens. Rabbi Stephen A. Klein performed the ceremony at the Fountainhead in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Has Television Found Religion? Not Exactly
description: CHURCH ATTENDANCE IS down, and people seem to be searching for religion anywhere but in the pews, yet Hollywood is experiencing a religious revival this fall with a total of four prime-time television shows about the clergy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLARMAN, EDWIN
description: HALLARMAN-Edwin. Of Boca Raton, FL. Passed away November 18, 1997. Survived by wife Elayne. Gutterman's, Boca Raton.

title: Q and A
description: Fishing in the Gulf

title: With Septuplets, Tax Complexity Times 7

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The Broadway That Was
description: Nicholas van Hoogstraten takes a look in LOST BROADWAY THEATRES (Princeton Architectural Press, paper, $24.95) at the buildings, people and stories that turned a mile of midtown Manhattan into the Great White Way. Along with photographs of the exteriors and interiors of each theater, this updated and expanded edition of a 1991 book offers architectural drawings and lists of the major plays and players. Van Hoogstraten, a television producer, tells marvelous anecdotes that set the imagination spinning: opening nights, beginning early in the evening with hors d'oeuvres, and ending after the play in the early morning with the audience invited to drink from an enormous bowl of Champagne with a nude chorus girl floating in it. (And that was during Prohibition.) The Paradise Roof Garden on Oscar Hammerstein's theater, the Victoria, spilled over to Hammerstein's adjacent theater, the Republic, where strollers could enjoy a Dutch-style dairy farm with a cow and other live barnyard animals and even a costumed dairymaid. Eddie Foy Jr. remembered the glass of warm fresh milk the dairymaid gave him after he and his brothers finished performing. During the Depression, what would the producers think of next? The Waldorf Theater had ''book nights'': a small library was connected to the box office, and you got to choose a book with your ticket. (If the show wasn't any good, I guess you could always read, which must have often been the case, as that theater didn't survive long.) Though fewer than half of the nearly 90 original theaters still exist, all is not lost. For starters, the New Amsterdam and the Victory theaters have been rebuilt with all their marvelous ornateness restored, giving us a much-needed view of the munificence of our past. Betsy von Furstenberg

The 408-foot, 100-foot-wide Argosy VI, docked about 20 miles downstream from Cincinnati on the Ohio River, can accommodate up to 4,000 passengers and 400 employees on its three levels. So almost as many as people can be aboard the Argosy VI as live in Lawrenceburg (population 4,950).

Later that year, Richard Gere received good reviews for his performance in the Broadway production, and he wanted to star in a film version; it was only a matter of finding the right director.

A master builder and developer of hospitals, libraries, university buildings, homes and shopping centers, Mr. Castagna invests and reinvests in Long Island communities.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Undeath in Venice
description: In a world obsessed with UFO's, X files and alien autopsies, the tradition of the ghost story seems hopelessly quaint. But Robert Girardi's VAPORETTO 13 (Delacorte, $19.95) shows that there's still a lot of life left in the unliving. Jack Squire is the embodiment of today's ideal man, a fast-track currency trader clad in Armani armor. When he is assigned to Venice to become his company's eyes and ears on the Italian political and economic scene, he feels that his career has taken a wrong turn. Yet while he sees the crumbling, ancient city as, literally, a backwater, Venice brings him to life in a way Wall Street never could. One night, roaming aimlessly because he can't sleep, Jack makes the acquaintance of an elusive and beautiful young woman, Caterina Vendramin, who will meet him only in the evening and whose past is mysteriously entwined with that of the sinking city. The more he becomes involved with her, the more troubling he finds her evasive responses to his questions: What does she do during the day? Why won't she introduce him to her father? Why does she claim to be a member of an ancient class of impoverished aristocrats that has long since died out? And why, when he attempts to follow her home, does he find a necropolis awash under the waters of the lagoon? In telling the story of Jack, his obsession with Caterina, his fall from corporate grace and his redemption into a world where he is no longer blinded by the dancing cursor on a trading screen, Girardi suffuses his narrative with rich descriptions of the food, fashion, traditions and architecture of Venice. With this artful novel, he invites us to put aside our rational skepticism and enter a world where the past is still hauntingly present. Malachy Duffy

title: NOTICED; Stilettos: Down at The Heels
description: MEENAL MISTRY, a young magazine assistant in Manhattan and a dedicated slave to fashion, was unfolding herself from a cab one night when she felt the sidewalk sinking. It turned out to be a more mundane collapse -- her three-inch stiletto heel had bent. It was the third pair this season. ''I'm definitely looking forward to flats for spring,'' sighed Ms. Mistry, who asked that the fashion magazine where she works not be named to protect the guilty -- it was one of many that promoted one of this fall's most problematic trends.

title: It's on Broadway, but Will It Cross Over?
description: THE PERCOLATING GROOVE of a full-throttle mambo reverberates through the walls of a studio complex in Greenwich Village, where the cast of ''The Capeman,'' the new musical by Paul Simon, is going through its paces. As the number reaches its climax, the festiveness of a Nuyorican street fair is evoked by the singers' swaying bodies and the vibrant tattoo of Afro-Caribbean drums. Even after the music has stopped, a buzz of exultation hangs in the air. Though Mr. Simon will not appear in ''The Capeman'' and its opening night is still a month away, the show is already being hailed as a breakthrough cultural event that gives Latino musicians and actors the media spotlight they long deserved.

title: Artist's East End Landscapes Lead to Overdue Recognition
description: ''IT put me right back to work,'' said Mary Ellen Doyle about the critical success of her recent exhibition at the Phillips Collection in Washington, which featured her watercolor interpretations of the unspoiled shoreline, fields and moraines of Long Island's East End.

title: Food; The Man Who Eats Well
description: The northeast kingdom of vermont changes as slowly and imperceptibly as the Green Mountains that surround it. After summer's relentless bloom and fall's blaze of foliage, the bare-limbed trees might sparkle with a little frost. End of glitter. This portion of the world is untouched by the tempest of modern trends. Food is what you grow, and meals are what you make of it. At least that's how Ed Behr sees it.

title: Sweet Talk: Made in New Jersey; Art and Alchemy With Almond Paste
description: CANDY is big business in America. We eat an average of 23.4 pounds of it a year, split almost equally between chocolate and everything else. We buy the most at Halloween, followed closely by Christmas, Easter and Valentine's Day. Last year, American retailers sold $21.1 billion in candy, $11.7 billion of it on chocolate alone.

title: The Price of Nuclear Preparedness
description: Nuclear weapons are expensive companions. The United States has spent billions of dollars building and improving nuclear bombs since Robert Oppenheimer and his team assembled the first at Los Alamos more than five decades ago. Now that the creation of new weapons is suspended, it turns out that still more billions are needed to keep old weapons ready for use. While some spending is required, the program devised by the Clinton Administration and Congress is extravagant.

title: Back Again In Stamford: Speculative Building

Everywhere, empty office buildings were gaunt reminders of reckless excess. Many in the industry predicted they would never see speculative office construction again.

Loving wife of the late Francis X. Saladin, mother to Barbara Ivy Graham, of Huntington, New York. Loyal friend of many, especially her sorority sisters (the girls) of over sixty-five years. Her death leaves a void in our hearts. All are invited to celebrate her life at a Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs, Monday, December 1st, 10AM, in Centerport, New York. Immediately following the Mass, graveside service will take place at Pinelawn Memorial Park. She attended High School at Bishop McDonald High School, Brooklyn. Over the years she worked for the New York State Savings Bank Association. Served as a volunteer for the Huntington Historical Society, Suffolk County Girl Scouts, The Elwood School District PTA. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to The Sisters of St. Benedict, 350 Cuba Hill Rd., Huntington, New York 11743, where Virginia was a resident during most of her last years.
