description: HIS art took Clifford Odets on a bitter journey of ideological awakening. In his first play, ''Awake and Sing'' (1935), a radical grandfather proclaims: ''Life shouldn't be written on dollar bills.''

title: Wheels of Misfortune
description: THE mail and calls have been angry and anecdotal in recent days in response to a perceived surge in police brutality, or at least discourtesy, toward middle-class citizens, and to the death of a 68-year-old businessman as he stepped out of an Upper West Side restaurant into the path of a food delivery bicycle being ridden illegally on the sidewalk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEYMOUR, ABBY LEWIS
description: SEYMOUR-Abby Lewis. Actress, active in radio, television and theatre for sixty-five years, widow of John Davenport Seymour, also of the theatre, died November 27, 1997. She is survived by his son Peter Seymour and his daughter Katherine Hollingshead and seven grandchildren. Also surviving her are her sisters Beulah L. Smith, Fredrica L. Yates, Sue L. Wimberly and brother Hunter W. Lewis. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Saturday from 4-7 PM and Sunday 2-4 P.M. Interment to follow in New Mexico.

title: Tall Test for Runners: Cold, Ice and Thin Air
description: On the world's highest mountain, 74 runners took their marks in an icy snowfall shortly after 7 A.M. last Sunday. The conditions obscured visibility on a race course that featured steep, rock-strewn trails hugging precipitous cliffs and primitive bridges traversing swift, glacial rivers. The challenge before them was the sixth Everest Marathon, the highest and arguably the most difficult marathon in the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTZER, JACK
description: WALTZER-Jack. Our father was a man of exceptional insight and empathy. He had more energy and vitality than most men half his age, and he was an eager and hearty participant in life-always welcoming opportunities and embracing challenges. His lust for life never flagged. His strength of character and generosity were hallmarks of his business and social relationships. And once you earned his friendship, he was always there when you needed him. He had great presence, even charisma. His emotional strength was impressive and his physical vitality and strength were imposing. He was a wonderful story teller, who took great pleasure in entertaining his family and friends. He thoroughly enjoyed his fishing, boating and trapshooting. We will miss him-and all of his countless qualities-dearly. We will miss the extraordinary love he had for our mother, to whom he had been married for 54 years, and for the family they had created together. Our children will miss their loving grandfather. We will miss the unabashed pride he took in our accomplishments, as well as his support and solace in our moments of difficulty and disappointment. We will miss a great man...a genuine mensch...our beloved father. Wayne, Paul, Lori, Alice

title: Reforming the Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: PRESENT

title: Kathleen Beebe, Jeffrey Szilagyi
description: Kathleen Sue Beebe, the daughter of Sharon and Lawrence Beebe of Gallipolis, Ohio, was married yesterday to Jeffrey George Szilagyi, a son of Marie and John Szilagyi of West Paterson, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Paul DeHoff, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Union Church of Pocantico Hills in North Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEHINGER, ILSE
description: FLEHINGER-Ilse, nee Sommer. On Friday, November 28. Beloved mother of Steven Flehinger and Miriam Moser. Mother-in-law of Paul and Harriet. Grandmother to Lisa, Rachel, Michael, and Alexandra. Services at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, 12:30 P.M., Monday, December 1.

title: Tribute to a Long-Lived Voice From the North
description: MUSIC-LOVERS wish that Mozart had lived longer than his 35 years and lament that Schubert did not have even that much time. But among long-lived composers who surpassed the psalmist's three score and ten, ''or by reason of strength, four score,'' none exceeded Jean Sibelius, whose long, brooding years in the chilly Finland he loved were almost three times Schubert's lifespan.

title: Man Who Was Shot and Robbed in Park Dies
description: A Brooklyn man who was shot last week while walking through Prospect Park died early yesterday, hospital officials said.

title: Classical Briefs
description: MENDELSSOHN: 'ELIJAH'

title: Adam Haynes, Hilary Phillips
description: Hilary Sara Phillips was married last evening to Adam Tudor Haynes at the Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman performed the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONDON, ELEANOR WACHTER
description: LONDON-Eleanor Wachter, M.D. November 26, 1997. Practiced in Queens until 1992. Recently of Durham, NC. Beloved mother of Stephanie London of Chapel Hill, NC, Martin London of Boulder, CO; grandmother of Ava and Jacob Rapp, Emily and George London and Eliza Longnecker. Preceded in death by husband Jack and daughter Deborah Rapp. Buried privately. Memorials may be made to Triangle Hospice, 1804 M.L.K., Jr., Parkway, Suite 12, Durham, NC 27707.

title: The Lighter (and Lesser) Side of Weegee
description: HE STAMPED HIS PHOTOGRAPHS ''Credit Weegee the Famous,'' and he earned his fame on images of murder and fire and car accidents, with some lovers and low-life thrown into the bargain. In 1946, after the huge success of his book ''Naked City,'' he announced that he was through with news photography and no longer interested in the seamy side of New York.

title: In Hartsdale, Fire-Grilled Meat and Fish
description: IN less than a year, the restaurant last known as Koloniale, and before that, Aphrodite, has changed direction again. The stylish new place has dropped the international colonial theme for one that seems to come out of Africa. Dinesen and Hemingway would probably have approved of the oversize palms, dark wood, African masks and mounted game trophies, which set the tone for Mighty Joe Young's, the newest occupant.

title: City Ballet Opening: Of Redecorating and a Rivalry
description: THE SETTING: Opening night gala for the New York City Ballet. While it is the city's major resident dance company, socially it has been a bit in the shadow of the American Ballet Theater, which has had the clout of the late Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis (and now Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg) in its court. But none of the guests expressed a sense of inferiority on Tuesday night.

title: Calculating Maintenance Charges
description: IF the maintenance charges on a 1,000-square-foot one-bedroom apartment in a co-op are $1,000 a month, then the maintenance charges on a 500-square-foot studio in the same building should be about half that, right? Not necessarily.

title: 'Alma Mater Gets A Makeover'
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM LANDMARK ; Nothing Learned
description: To the Editor:

title: Boldly Going, Going, Going . . .
description: THIRTY-ONE years ago Neil Armstrong was just another NASA astronaut, and a Moon walk -- the Armstrong original as well as the Michael Jackson knockoff -- had not yet been imagined. But Kirk, Spock and Bones were becoming real heroes of the 23d century, and this one, too.

title: In Scotland, the Cooking Catches Up to the Growing
description: WHEN you say you are going to Scotland on a culinary tour, some people think of haggis, porridge and overcooked meat -- but that's only because they have not kept up with the dramatic improvement in restaurant dining there in the last several years.

title: Like It or Not, Germany Becomes a Melting Pot
description: Almost 30 years ago, Elbeyi Inci left his home on Turkey's Black Sea coast and came to West Germany to work on construction sites -- one of the so-called guest workers lured by official design to the dynamo of the postwar economic miracle. At that time, foreigners were less than 4 percent of West Germany's population.

title: The Pop Perfectionist on a Crowded Stage
description: Paul Simon seems compelled to deny or defend his reputation as a perfectionist (''The Pop Perfectionist on a Crowded Stage,'' by Stephen J. Dubner, Nov. 9). I'm confused by this. In the world of art especially, why would anyone (Simon, or those lucky enough to work with this accomplished artist) be willing to settle for anything less than the best?

title: St. John's Bounces Back With a Gritty Game
description: St. John's Coach Fran Fraschilla was eager to see how his team would react against Illinois the day after a demoralizing loss to Georgia Tech in the Puerto Rico Shootout.

title: Pulp Fiction
description: Crime Novels

title: Larry McMurtry's Dream Job
description: ''I'm bored to death with the 19th-century west,'' says Larry McMurtry, America's best-known writer of 19th-century Western fiction. ''I wrote more about it than I ever intended to.'' We were driving through West Texas, along the route his grandparents took when they first traveled to Archer County in the late 1880's, and he was trying to explain why ''Comanche Moon,'' his new novel, will probably be his last word on the subject.

title: The Business of Slavery
description: THE SLAVE TRADE The Story of the Atlantic Slave Trade: 1440-1870. By Hugh Thomas. Illustrated. 908 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $37.50.

title: The Sins of a President
description: The Dark Side

title: Making the Founding Fathers Sing and Dance
description: TAKE AWAY ITS MUSIC, ADMIRERS have suggested, and ''1776'' would still be one terrific dramatic disquisition on the Founding Fathers and their Declaration of Independence.

title: Board of Legislators Balks at Pay Raise Plan
description: AS his 15-year tenure as County Executive comes to a close, Andrew P. O'Rourke has acted to protect the jobs of many of his appointees and raise the salaries of others.

title: Choral Works Fill Holiday Events
description: FROM the rehearsals of October and November come the choral concerts of December, and a bountiful harvest of song is here to usher in the holiday season.

title: HAVE A MULTICULTURAL CHRISTMAS
description: * Thanks to a desire not to offend non-Christian groups, religious imagery has long been off-limits in New York store windows at Christmas. Increasingly, even secular holiday symbols are frowned on. * Bergdorf Goodman windows feature ''no traditional Christmas or holiday decor'' but instead ''Legends, Goddesses, Heroines and Divas.'' * Henri Bendel is displaying a wreath in its main window but ''nothing like stockings or Santa,'' says a spokeswoman. * Barneys is celebrating the global ''power of fashion'' with a Siamese-twin mannequin and depictions of ''The Great Queens of England'' (like Queen Victoria and Boy George). * On the (sort of) festive side, Paul Paddock, a designer for Antique Boutique, will display red gas cans this year. Desired effect? That whole red-gas-can, Christmas-holiday-spirit thing.

title: Huskies, Just Making Sure, Leave Rams in Their Wake
description: Connecticut had endured a scare from Iowa in its last game, and the unbeaten Huskies were not about to take Rhode Island lightly today. Still, the young Rams -- a team of freshmen and sophomores, none more than 19 years old -- trailed No. 3 Connecticut by only 5 points after seven and a half minutes.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: The IMAX Nutcracker

title: Carlene Boylen And Ian Damon
description: Carlene Amanda Boylen and Ian MacAlpin Damon were married yesterday in Carmel, Calif. The Rev. Annie Ryder, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Stonepine Estate.

title: Always Faithful
description: ''We fight back for Mac in an honorable way,'' says Jesse (the Sarge) Brown, a former Marine sergeant who heads a band of Macintosh users called the Mac Marines. His goal sounds more wonk than warrior: to protect Apple Computer's market share against ''Wintel boxes,'' the Intel-chip-equipped computers that run the industry gorilla, Microsoft Windows.

title: Assistance for the 401(k) Challenged
description: THERE is too much advice in most places, but it has long been a rare commodity in the world of 401(k) plans. Now that may be changing.

title: Antics by Ditka and Cox Hurting Their Teams
description: They always seem to be angry. They are always explaining their actions, the way a 5-year-old might after his hand is caught in the cookie jar. But for all of their tantrums, the most recent actions of Saints Coach Mike Ditka and Bears linebacker Bryan Cox -- two of the National Football League's most recognized, and explosive, personalities -- may have been the strangest of all.

title: ON THE COURT, IN THE BANK -- A special report.; A Fierce Forehand, a Bold Agent, a Golden Future, All at 13
description: The name of the tennis-playing product is Todd Reid and, according to the relentless publicity package cooked up for him by an assortment of Australian advertising visionaries who estimate his worth in the years ahead to be $150 million, his hair, future and credit card are the same convenient color: gold.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Festival of Trees

title: We, the People . . .; Constitutions Are the New Writers' Market
description: AFTER years of wrangling, Poland finally adopted a Constitution last month that formally enshrined the rule of law. Thailand too has a new Constitution -- the 17th in the 65 years since it became a constitutional monarchy.

title: Musical Muscles
description: Peter Sinclair, a European artist, thinks the American mania for working out is basically exhibitionism -- ''All you'll ever do with the muscles you build in the gym is go to the gym again'' -- so he's turned this belief into an exhibition. Next month, at San Francisco's Exploratorium, Sinclair will orchestrate ''Musical Bodybuilding,'' two short performances by five oiled-up professional male bodybuilders using weight machines.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Sydney Osborne, C. H. Phillips
description: Sydney Watkins Osborne and Christopher Hallowell Phillips were married yesterday at Ascension Memorial Church in Ipswich, Mass. The Rev. Robert A. Bryan, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Cheerleading Contest

title: Q. & A.
description: Changing A Primary Residence

title: Czech Premier Steps Down After Havel Seeks Ouster
description: After a stormy 11-hour session of his political party, Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus announced his resignation and that of his Government shortly after midnight this morning, bringing to an end the longest running premiership in post-Communist Central Europe.

title: Sell Like Mike
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURANO, EMANUEL NICHOLAS
description: TURANO-Emanuel Nicholas. Architect, March 1, 1917 to November 23, 1997. Cooper Union, Certificate in Architecture 1941; served with US Army Air Force 1941-1945, decorated Distinguished Flying Cross Air Medal. Harvard B. Arch. 1947; Fulbright Fellow 1950; Harvard M. of Arch. 1963; Cooper Union Professional Achievement Citation (Honorary Ph.D.) 1964. Received Public Housing Authority Awards, Architectural Award of Excellence from American Institute of Steel Construction for the Pan Am Passenger Terminal Building, 1961; Fellow AIA. Married Sybyl Rosemarin in 1951; widowed 1996; will be missed by his children Lisa, Laurie and Leslie, and grandchildren: Nicholas, Dominic, Gregory, Lacey and Eric. Graveside services will be held December 1st at 11:30 AM at Calverton National Cemetery, New York.

title: All Dressed Up
description: When every calorie counts -- and when doesn't it? -- flavor doesn't always figure in the equation. But that's not the case with Cary Randall's, a line of fat-free salad dressings created in Monmouth County.

title: A Loyalist Legacy In Fredericton
description: WHEN people asked why I was going to Fredericton in January, I answered, ''For joy and rapture.'' That was an abbreviated and heightened way of saying that I had been hearing about New Brunswick's refined little capital for years and now I was going to walk its 19th-century streets myself.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Talking in Turkey; Dissent in a Land of Contradictions
description: A NEW prison drama opened here recently to a packed house, and by the time the premiere performance ended, more than a few of the spectators were in tears as they stood to applaud.

title: Lively Norwalk Emerging From Its Past
description: OFTEN overshadowed by nearby Stamford, Norwalk has in recent years been making its mark by taking advantage of its rich historical past, something that Stamford, to the chagrin of preservationists, has been disinclined to do.

title: Airlines Switch To Paperless Upgrades
description: Those upgrade stickers and certificates that clutter the wallets and purses of frequent fliers are starting to be replaced by electronic upgrades, a change that also means faster check-in at airports.

title: Kind of Surreal All Over
description: JESUS SAVES

title: A World Tour Around the Village
A Funeral Parlor With Nary a Corpse in Sight
description: ''THREE VIEWINGS'' has been making the rounds on the small-scale regional theater circuit since its premiere at Manhattan Theater Club in 1995, but it demands a theater with a mind of its own and a sense of nothing to lose.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Bears are smart, and some are very smart. My problems start when the smarter bears and the dumber visitors intersect.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, GEORGE MACDONALD
description: PARKER - George MacDonald. The Board of Directors of Fiduciary Trust International mourns the passing of its esteemed friend and colleague on November 22 in Frankfurt, Germany. He rendered thoughtful and cogent advice for the benefit of the company and its clients during his six years as a director. Our deepest sympathy to his wife, Susan Bissell Parker, and his daughter Julia and son Angus.

title: The Shoe Leather Debate
description: AMID the typical pre-Thanksgiving torpor and buzz, a few clues last week hinted that something was amiss at the New York University Department of Journalism and Mass Communication. There were the uncollected messages on the office door of the graduate studies' chairman. The cancellation of his Tuesday class. And the letter posted in the elevator that announced, in the terse style of a man accustomed to economy of expression, his resignation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CIRKER, SADIE R.
description: CIRKER-Sadie R. November 30, 1971. In loving memory of our dear devoted mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Children

title: Does She Like It? Hate It? Is It Cute?
description: THE saleswomen in the Polo Ralph Lauren showroom stared tensely at Bonnie Pressman. A model posed a few feet away, her face a blank slate of indifference, her whisper-thin body draped in a coffee-color suit. So, does she like it? Does she hate it? Who can tell?

title: New Hero Every Night: Cage Is Man of Hour
description: Michael Cage stepped out of the shower late Friday night and announced to no one in particular, ''Man, the old-timer's feeling old.''

title: Map May Renew Dispute Over New England Island
description: Touring Britain on a trade mission in October, Gov. Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire watched an archivist at the Hampshire Record Office in Winchester, England, forage through some old records.

title: POSTINGS: Apartments Planned at 23d Street and Avenue of the Americas; For the Ladies' Mile, New Residences
description: The facade of a planned 20-story, 450,000-square-foot residential building planned for 23d Street and Avenue of the Americas has been designed to closely resemble the former 19th-century dry-goods emporiums that are its neighbors in the Ladies' Mile Historic District.

title: The Deerslayers
description: HEART AND BLOOD Living With Deer in America. By Richard Nelson. Illustrated. 389 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50.

title: Gimme the Ol' White Shoe
description: In my Ivy League days (Radcliffe, mid-50's), the word ''shoe'' alone was used to allude to a young man of a preppy background. And yes, he was generally conservative, though not necessarily cautious!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THALER, RABBI RICHARD
description: THALER-Rabbi Richard. The Officers and staff of UJA-Federation of New York deeply mourn the passing of Rabbi Richard Thaler, spiritual leader of Sutton Place Synagogue. An outstanding leader in the NY Jewish community and a dear friend of our organization, Rabbi Thaler was a passionate and ardent supporter of the State of Israel and its people. During his last months, he worked tirelessly with UJA-Federation to ensure his Synagogue's participation in a mission to Israel this coming Spring to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the modern Jewish State. We extend our profound condolences to his wife, Julie; their children Gilad and Itai; his parents, Rabbi Albert and Shirley Thaler; his sisters Judy Kane and Dena Thaler; and the congregants of Sutton Place Synagogue. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Executive VP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, WILLIAM JOSEPH
description: HART-William Joseph. Age 86, of White Plains, NY, Nov. 25, 1997. Beloved husband of Dorothy SharpeHart, father of Mary Ellen Arrington and the late Diane Alston, grandfather of Linda Arrington, Gail Richards. Retired Regional Director of US Dept. of Labor Job Corps. ''Joe'' Hart was District 7230 Governor of Rotary, a founder of 100 Black Men, active with the Boy Scouts of America Greater NY Council, and member of the Boys Harbor Advisory Council. Memorial service Saturday December 13, 11 A.M., at St. Simon Church, 135 Remington Pl, New Rochelle, New York 10801. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Boys Harbor, 1 East 104th St, NY, NY 10029 or to St. Simon Church.

title: Colleen Rowley and Paul Tsao
description: Colleen Marie Rowley, a daughter of Geraldine and David M. Rowley of Centerville, Mass., was married on Friday to Paul Hsucheng Tsao, a son of Anna Chang Tsao and Hung-Duh Tsao of Douglaston, Queens. The Rev. Thomas Edamattam performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Huntington, N.Y.

title: South Korean Chaos Could Eventually Mean Opportunity
description: AN investor in the Mexican stock market at the beginning of 1995, when the country was mired in a currency crisis, could have doubled his money over the last three years.

title: From Carol Gilligan's Chair
description: I read Michael Norman's interview with Carol Gilligan with a mixture of amusement and sad disbelief (''From Carol Gilligan's Chair,'' Nov. 9). Together, they conclude that ''unless men change in fundamental ways, we're not going to have a sea change in the culture,'' with the assumption, of course, that this change is desirable.

title: Restoration Promises Look at 19th-Century Life
description: THE Hudson River Museum's $1.3 million restoration of its 120-year-old Glenview Mansion is well under way here, promising a look back at life among the well-to-do and well connected. The high-Victorian house was built by the financier John Bond Trevor and is considered a prime example of Gilded Age architecture. The city of Yonkers, which bought the estate upon the death of Emily Norwood Trevor in 1922, can be thanked for turning the house into a museum and keeping the prime river property from being subdivided into 300 building lots.

title: Classical Briefs
description: VILLA-LOBOS: 'BACHIANAS BRASILEIRAS' NOS. 4, 5, 7, 9; 'CHORO' NO. 10

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCK, ALFONSO DARRELL, M.D.
description: ROCK-Alfonso Darrell, M.D. Died in Brooklyn, NY, on November 27, 1997. Dr. Rock served the AfricanAmerican community in Bedford Stuyvesant as a devoted physician for more than 40 years. He emigrated from Barbados to America as a child and attended NYC Public Schools, where he received a free college education from Brooklyn College in 1940. Later he earned his medical degree from Meharry Medical School in Nashville, TN, and received further medical training at Harlem Hospital and Freedman Hospital in Washington, D.C. During the Korean War he served as a medical officer. He will be remembered by his family and thousands of grateful patients as a quiet, gentle, compassionate man who cherished his Caribbean roots and embraced the vitality and spirit of the African-American community. Funeral services will be held at Siloam Presbyterian Church at 11 AM, on Tuesday, December 2.

title: Money Store Makes Investment in Politics
description: To many Republicans and Democrats in Washington, the Money Store could not have a better name.

title: Showing a Harrowing World But Not How It Got That Way
description: MIDWAY THROUGH Frederick Wiseman's harrowing new documentary, ''Public Housing,'' a handsome young bureaucrat arrives at Chicago's Ida P. Wells projects with the promise of $300 million in government contracts. All the residents have to do, he explains to a group of them, is create a business of their own. An elevator-repair company, he suggests, or an energy-conservation firm. Then, under a new program, the enterprise could qualify for a share of that $300 million without even going through the usual competitive bidding.

title: November 23-29; Bullish on Crime
description: Nineteen men were indicted in Manhattan in what Federal authorities called the most ambitious scheme by organized crime in decades to infiltrate Wall Street. It suggests that organized crime has set its sights on the lucrative bull market after seeing law enforcers curtail its influence in garbage hauling, the garment business and the Fulton Fish Market.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Nov. 2, about ''Puerto Rico: The Trials of the Oldest Colony in the World,'' by Jose Trias Monge, used the author's surname incorrectly. It is Trias Monge, not just Monge.

title: They've Just Begun; There's So Far to Go
description: The best thing about first-semester basketball is that there's a second semester.

title: DESIGN VIEW; An Emblem of Crisis Made the World See the Body Anew
description: THE RIBBON IS EVERYWHERE. Draped from dresses and T-shirts, it reminds us of runaway children, breast cancer and, most of all, AIDS. It started as a red sign to remind us of those lost to AIDS. It has since appeared as a string of rubies in a Tiffany version and as a thong, the only thing covering otherwise naked men in parades. It has become the shorthand sign for loss, suffering, anger, disease and a commitment not to just let things happen to us.

title: Getting Credit for Being White
description: At the School of the Art Institute of Chicago, teaching part time on the faculty, there is a young academic who calls herself White Trash Girl. She's a performance artist of sorts: think Roseanne hopped up on post-structuralist theory, Larry Flynt toting an M.F.A. In a faux hillbilly accent, she will tell you all about her fictional identity as ''an inbred biological disaster turned superhero,'' the product of ''a 14-year-old girl and her funny uncle.'' She parades around the blue-collar neighborhood where she lives in tacky resplendence: white cowboy hat, T-shirts bearing slogans like ''I'm baby soft,'' short, tight skirts. She makes White Trash Girl videos and trading cards, and is quick with pronouncements about the provocative importance of her own work, which, as it turns out, has as much to do with whiteness as it does with trashiness.

title: Driving While Reading On the L.I.E.
description: Those speed demon items by Shirley Simon [''The Speed Demons on My Mind,'' Opinion Nov. 9] and Beth Rose Feuerstein [Letters, Nov. 16] brought to mind my recent experience on the Long Island Expressway. While driving in the right-hand lane with my speedometer exactly at 55 miles per hour, everyone was passing me. I had the feeling I was holding up the parade -- possibly annoying those who had to slow down until they too could pass.

title: Unfinished Business
description: I was deeply moved by J. Robert Moskin's ''Unfinished Business'' (Lives, Nov. 9). I was in Manila when the Japanese invaded the Philippines, and I stood on the street watching the soldiers pass by on their death march. I was looking for my fiance, who I knew had been in Bataan. I saw him and he saw me, and this was the last time we saw each other.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 3/

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: Promiscuity Is Not the Norm in Gay Culture; Fighting for Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: The Man Who Knew Too Little

title: Small-Town Intimacy Is Possible in City
description: To the Editor:

title: Mentoring Meets Networking In Formal Programs
description: SEVERAL months ago, Kathy Rosol came to a crossroads in her career. She had a new job in administrative support for human resources at a company she liked -- the aerospace manufacturer Hamilton Standard, a division of United Technologies in Windsor Locks, Conn. But she was getting restless and was casting about for options.

title: Violence Therapy For a Country in Denial
description: If you aren't bothered by small-arms fire or the intermittent shudder of heavy explosives, you can get a good night's sleep at the Hotel Ero. Situated on the confrontation line between Croat-controlled West Mostar and Muslim-dominated East Mostar, the Ero offers Sheraton-style glitz in the center of Bosnia's most violently divided city. The rates are reasonable -- $75 a night for a single room, including a lavish breakfast buffet and better security than virtually any other hotel on the Continent. Two Spanish-made Pegaso armored personnel carriers mounted with heavy-caliber machine guns bookend the block. A half-dozen soldiers from SFOR (the NATO Stabilization Force) guard the glass-and-brass entrance, which bears, along with the hotel's four-star rating, the silhouette of an assault rifle crossed by a diagonal red stripe: no small arms permitted in the lobby. Now and then a column of SFOR tanks clatters by.

title: Walking Where Kerouac Did
description: As much as Jack Kerouac traveled, he always needed someplace to come back to, says Bill Morgan, author of the just published ''The Beat Generation in New York: A Walking Tour of Jack kerouac's City'' (City Lights Books, $12.95). And for what were probably the happiest years of the novelist's life, that place was New York. He was always returning to the city to be inspired by his friends, says Mr. Morgan, who has retraced the footsteps of the entire beat circle in his guidebook, which he hopes to make part of this year's 40th anniversary celebrations of Kerouac's most famous novel. ''On the Road.''

title: Meeting a President In a Ridgewood Store
description: To the Editor:

title: IN BRIEF
description: Postal Lawsuit

title: Sports of The Times; The Cowboys: Broken Basket, Broken Eggs
description: ONE by one on Thanksgiving Day, the Dallas Cowboys kept disappearing.

title: IN THE GALLERY WITH: Isaac Mizrahi; Envying Roisterous Lives
description: Isaac Mizrahi had stopped in his tracks, caught up for the moment in awed contemplation of ''Sam Karshowitz, Rag Peddler.'' The image of the salesman, weary but erect, the remnants of an ice storm matted in his beard, was snapped by Weegee, the legendary news photographer, whose raw, revealing portraits of New Yorkers in the 1930's and 40's are on view through March 7 at the International Center of Photography Midtown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNELL, ROBERT E.
description: BURNELL-Robert E. Of Rockville Centre, NY, suddenly Nov. 27, 1997. Beloved husband of Ann F. (nee: Fallon). Loving father of Elizabeth Cornish, Suzanne Walker, Robert, Marybeth, Patricia, Maura, and Ann. Adoring grandfather of Samuel Cornish and Lily Walker. Devoted son of Dorothy Burnell. Dear brother of Judith Gargiulo. Also survived by six nieces and nephews. Sales Operation Director of Newsweek Magazine. Former Parent Board Member Sacred Heart Academy, Parish Council Member of St. Agnes Cathedral & Eucharistic Minister. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc, 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, today 2-4, 7-9 PM, Monday 2-5, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass St. Agnes Cathedral Tuesday 11 AM. Interment Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury, New York.

title: Reporter's Notebook; In Brawley Case, Jurors Are Picked, and Primed
description: In the narrowest sense, the jury selection phase of a trial has a single goal: to winnow a large, eclectic pool of people down to a small group stripped of biases, inclinations or idiosyncracies that might render them partial to either side.

title: EARNING IT; When a Commitment Can Evolve Into an Obsession
description: DAVID B. OPTON'S co-workers at Exec-U-Net, an executive networking and career information service in Norwalk, Conn., had a good chuckle recently when Mr. Opton issued this thought for the day in an in-house memo: ''You never heard anyone on their deathbed say they wished they had spent more time at the office.''

title: The Party's Over
description: We know that anorexia is common among young women (Style: ''The Party's Over,'' Nov. 9). We know that eating disorders are rampant among models, who are valued for their emaciated look. And we know that some women derive their sense of beauty and goals for their own appearance from the models they see in magazines.

title: There's No Stopping Tomorrow
description: Don't stop thinking about tomorrow

title: Q.E.D.
description: FERMAT'S ENIGMA

title: Now About Bob and Those TV Spots . . .
description: TO people who watch television in Connecticut -- and that's most people -- he's like the fly that keeps buzzing around until he seems like part of everyday life and you get the impression that you'd miss him if he flew away somewhere. Or maybe not.

title: The Glow, the Glitter of Fine Antiques
description: THE Antiquarius show in Greenwich is known as an esthetically glowing antiques show, one in a class by itself that frequently serves as a curtain-raising event for the Winter Antiques Show in Manhattan.

title: Investment Fraud Is Soaring Along With the Stock Market
description: The surging stock market has spawned widespread investment fraud across the country, with New York as the epicenter of the problem, according to law enforcement officials and securities regulators.

title: For Wheelchair Users, Cab Is Next Hurdle
description: Frieda Zames considers herself lucky. When Ms. Zames, a retired mathematics professor who uses a scooter because of her polio-weakened legs, wants to hail a taxi, her husband accompanies her. After she gets in, her husband and the cab driver spend five minutes dismantling her scooter and loading the pieces into the trunk. When she reaches her destination, her husband and the driver spend another five minutes reassembling her scooter. People with motorized wheelchairs do not have this option, she said.

title: Cast Out By the Right
description: Try to understand my problem. As a black conservative intellectual, I belong to an endangered species. For if few conservatives choose to think of themselves as intellectuals, even fewer blacks can pass muster as conservatives.

title: A Recipe for Unwanted Guests
description: IT'S a pleasure to have house guests at Thanksgiving, and a positive delight to see them leave. As the last car backs out of the driveway, the happy hosts dance around the living room singing: ''They've gone! They've gone!''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: DISCIPLESBy Austin Wright.Baskerville, $22.

title: DANCE; Is Brahms's Music Timeless? Perhaps, but Not in These Pieces
description: THE SCHUBERT AND Brahms anniversaries this year have been observed differently, partly, no doubt, because one is the anniversary of a birth, Schubert's 200 years ago; the other, of a death, Brahms's 100 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HINECK, DANIEL
description: HINECK-Daniel. 11/3/27-11/30/87 An extraordinary man of talent, erudition and integrity. 10 years gone. Forever loved and remembered. E. J. L. M. & Family

title: Haitian Immigrants Haven't Had Special Help
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Breed of Wildcatter for the 90's
description: TEXAS past: the Oil Patch, where roughnecks and the rig count ruled.

title: Where Water Is Power, the Balance Shifts
description: Over the last century, the American West was remade with exclamation points. Free Land! Unlimited Water! No Chance of Failure! So went the trumpeting in the dust as the Federal Government tried to build an oasis civilization in the driest part of the United States.

title: In Tysons Corner, a Rush to Speculative Building
description: WITH vacancy rates below 3 percent, rents nearing $30 a square foot, and financing available from a variety of sources, developers are racing to deliver speculative office space ahead of the pack in the prime office market of Tysons Corner, Va., 14 miles west of Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHBACH, JEROME
description: FISCHBACH-Jerome. November 28. Loving son of the late Beatrice and Harry. Cherished husband of Eleanore. Beloved father of Stefanie (John) Whalen, Penny Cutler, Bede (Steven) Levinson, and Nancy (Selwyn) Taubman. Loving grandfather of Robin, Sandi, Sara, Jonathan, Matthew, Ethan, and Rachel, and great-grandfather of two. Dear brother of Herbert and the late Rosalind Neuwirth and Allen, and dear stepson of Stella. Services on Monday, December 1, 10 A.M., Riverside Mount Vernon. In lieu of flowers, contributions to: Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, 381 Park Avenue South, NY, NY 10016.

title: The Nation; High-Tech Teaching Is Losing Its Gloss
description: TWO Pilgrims, Priscilla Mullens and Elder Brewster, went on line this month to answer questions from schoolchildren around the country about the first Thanksgiving in 1621.

title: Of Dolls, Karma and the Pursuit of Motherhood
description: LIKE AN ALIEN IN ''CLOSE ENCOUNTERS OF the Third Kind,'' the Asante doll of Ghana known as Akua'ba has entered the Western imagination. With a large moon-shaped head and skinny stick figure, she even resembles the Steven Spielberg creation. But this doll represents a life form yet to have arrived -- the child one hopes to have.

title: Approval of Turnpike Exchange To Advance Secaucus Complex
description: The Turnpike Authority is expected to win approval from the Army Corps of Engineers this week to build a highway interchange in the wetlands of Secaucus, a crucial step in the development of a $448 million rail transfer station that is to have an office and retail complex built on top of it.

title: A Safety Net for the Neediest
description: The city seems safer and more prosperous to those with good jobs and peaceful homes, but New York's most vulnerable residents struggle daily for food, shelter and freedom from violence. With unemployment in the city at 10 percent, boom times have not come to people on the margins of society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARR, RUTH
description: STARR-Ruth. 98. On November 26, 1997. Loving aunt of Jane Roland Martin, Laurie Ellen Scher and Anne Louise Scher. Treasured great aunt of Timothy David Martin and Thomas Peter Martin. Memorial services Monday 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside,'' West 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WASHINGTON HEIGHTS; A Modest A.& P., but a Big Loss for Some
description: The A.& P. on Fort Washington Avenue at West 187th Street may not have been universally loved, but the announcement that it was closing for good last Wednesday after 11 years jolted the area.

title: November 23-29; Teamsters Leader Quits
description: It was a bad week for Ron Carey, as the Federal Government suddenly became more aggressive about cleaning up the teamsters' union. A Government-appointed review board brought charges to oust Mr. Carey as the teamsters' president, accusing him of approving schemes to funnel more than $700,000 in union funds to his campaign last year; just hours before it did, he stepped aside.

title: Jamie Goldberg and J. D. Leigh
description: Jamie Sue Goldberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Goldberg of Roslyn, N.Y., was married on Wednesday evening to Jonathon David Leigh, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Norman Leigh, who lived in Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Ronald Millstein performed the ceremony at the Essex House in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, PHILIP I.
description: BERMAN-Philip I. The Officers and Board of American Friends of the Hebrew University (AFHU) mourn with great sadness the passing of our friend & benefactor Philip I. Berman, a member of of the AFHU Board of Directors whose vision and generosity meant so much to the University. The contributions that he and his beloved wife, Dr. Muriel Berman, both members of the University's Board of Governors, have made over the years will benefit many generations of scholars and researchers in a number of important areas, including medicine, archaeology, and the arts. Among their many important contributions are: The Philip I. and Muriel M. Berman Center for Biblical Archaeology; The Philip I. and Muriel M. Berman National Medical Library, one of the most modern and efficient medical libraries in the world and a center for biocommunications for all of Israel; an apartment home for nurses at the Hadassah - Hebrew University complex at Ein Kerem; a 350-seat auditorium at the Hadassah Hospital on Mount Scopus; the Berman Computer for the University's Index of Jewish Art; and the Muriel M. and Philip I. Berman Scholarship and Fellowship Program, which provides fellowships for advanced overseas studies, teaching fellowships, merit scholarships and visiting professorships. In addition, several important works of art donated by the Bermans grace the University's campuses, reminding all who walk by of their generosity and superb taste. Philip and Muriel Berman received honorary doctorate degrees from the University, and were awarded the Scopus Award, the highest honor that the American Friends can confer. Philip was a role model to all. We want to express our deepest sympathies to his wife, Muriel, their three children, Nancy Berman Bloch, Nina Sheafer, and Steven Berman, their six grandchildren and extended family. The funeral will be held at Keneseth Israel Synagogue, 2227 Chew Street, Allentown, PA., at 11 AM, Sunday, November 30. Keith L. Sachs, President Lawrence Newman, Ch. of Board Adam B. Kahan, Executive VP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIBUSCH, JESSIE
description: FEIBUSCH-Jessie. Beloved Wife of the late Philip, devoted Mother of Michael and Roberta, and Robert. Cherished Grandmother of Neil, Evan, Gwen, Hugh, Stacey and Amanda and Great-Grandmother. Dear Sister of Rivi Klein. Services at Mt. Ararat Cemetery. Exit 33 of The Southern State Parkway, North Lindenhurst, Long Island, today at 11 A.M.

title: Haitian Immigrants Haven't Had Special Help; Another Berlin Wall
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: THIS week's movie menu offers a little something for everyone: offbeat romance, gritty drama, western adventure and old-time music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACDOUGALL, RELLA
description: MACDOUGALL-Rella. The Women's Committee of The Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club express their deepest sorrow in the passing of their dear friend and colleague. Rella, who joined the committee in 1973, was a guiding force to all of us. As Chairman of The Kips Bay Decorator Show House, her extraordinary dedication and commitment allowed us to raise more than eight million dollars for the children. We will miss her every day and try to follow in her magnificent footsteps.

title: Meredith Cudrin, Richard Steigman
description: Meredith Lee Cudrin and Richard Mark Steigman, associates at New York law firms, were married last evening in Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Meyer Berger performed the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center.

title: Two Troves of Bronx Nostalgia
description: There are people who grew up in the Bronx of 30 years ago or more -- and left it long ago -- who love nothing more than to reminisce about the old neighborhoods. People who haven't set foot in the borough for decades have been known to gather in the Catskills and Los Angeles to discuss the street corners and Friday night deli dinners.

title: Avoid Judicial Gerrymandering
description: A hasty, politically motivated Republican drive to break up the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit gave way to compromise just before Congress adjourned. Instead of instantly dismantling the San Francisco-based appeals court as a Senate-approved appropriations rider had called for, a House-Senate conference committee agreed to a one-year study of all regional appellate court boundaries. The study will be conducted by a five-member commission chosen by Chief Justice William Rehnquist and will give special emphasis to the Ninth Circuit.

title: The Big City; Big Brother Is Ticking
description: Harris Silver, a 31-year-old advertising copywriter who describes himself as a pedestrian advocate, credits his most inspired idea -- a breakthrough that could revolutionize transportation and public safety -- to an encounter he had with the front bumper of a taxicab. He was trying to cross 14th Street as a cab was turning east from Sixth Avenue. ''The cabbie literally began pushing me out of the crosswalk with his bumper,'' Silver recalls. ''I tapped on his window and yelled at him. He got out of the cab and looked like he was going to kill me. Fortunately, I had a camera with me. I took a picture of him and his car and said, 'I'll see you in taxi court.' ''

title: Homosexual Foster Parent Sets Off a Debate in Texas
description: When Rebecca Bledsoe, a Texas child welfare supervisor, ordered the emergency removal of a baby boy from his foster parent, her rationale was straightforward: ''We don't ordinarily license persons when we know them to be involved in any kind of crime on an ongoing basis.''

title: Moira Kiltie and Clifford Kentros
description: Moira Robertson Kiltie, the daughter of Dr. Harriet Kiltie of Upper Saddle River, N.J., and the late Patrick Kiltie, was married yesterday to Dr. Clifford George Kentros, a son of Vivi and Dr. George A. Kentros of Destin, Fla. The Rev. Anne Marie Porter, a minister of the American Fellowship Church, performed the ceremony at Cinnamon Ridge Villa on St. John, the United States Virgin Islands.

title: One Woman Takes on the Music of Miles
description: THE SINGER CASSANDRA WILSON STANDS in a darkened recording booth, cigarette in one hand, charts strewn at her feet. A photo of her late father nestles among a few votive candles. Their flickering light illuminates her face, which is framed by her golden brown dredlocks and halo-like headphones. After a run-through of one of her new compositions, she addresses the drummer. ''I dont want you to mark time so much as I want you to mark groove,'' she says. The band launches into the song again, a typically spare arrangement, and when it is finished, the drummer stands up and thanks Ms. Wilson for her direction.

title: Women Draft Dates For Debutante Ball
description: Before Meredith Hembree returned home to Knoxville, Tenn., yesterday after a weekend in New York, she needed to shop for just one more thing: a man, preferably tall and with a strong personality, to escort her to the International Debutante Ball next month.

title: Unhappy Replay for Hofstra In Playoff Visit to Delaware
description: In the days leading up to today's game, the Hofstra players talked about the last time they visited Delaware and the painful memories of that game.

title: Playing Chekhov For Laughs
description: IT looked like the standard Spalding Gray setup: the monologuist at an austere desk, a glass of water at the ready, a devoted audience hanging on every quirky word of his latest meanderings. But on Tuesday night, the Mimi Ferzt Gallery on Prince Street was converted into Moscow on the Hudson when several hundred people showed up to hear Mr. Gray read two recently discovered short stories by Anton Chekhov.

title: Paying Off a Mortgage: Is Fast Always Smart?
description: FOR years, prepaying a mortgage by putting extra money toward principal each month seemed like sound financial advice for those who have extra cash. Recently, lenders have started preaching the prepayment gospel with a new fervor, aggressively marketing mortgages that are paid off every other week rather than monthly, one of the hot products in the home loan business these days.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-19

title: Buffeted Asian Economies Raise Fears of Unrest
description: As Asia's Miracle seems to fade to a mere marvel, many experts on the region worry that growing economic frustrations risk provoking political and social upheavals.

title: Gretzky In, Messier Out As Canada Picks Team
description: Since breaking into the National Hockey League together so many years ago, they had marched through their careers in virtual lock step. Four Stanley Cups with the Edmonton Oilers in the 1980's. Countless appearances for Team Canada on the international stage. A reunion with the Rangers last season.

title: Dispensing Health Care As a Duty
description: There was a time when the term ''health care'' created images of a dedicated professional offering patients relief from pain or illness. Now the more common reference is to an industry in the throes of enormous change where the frequent focus is on limitations in health care coverage, or the lack of any coverage whatsoever.

title: The Tote With the Most
description: You know the Hermes Kelly, the Prada and the Lady Dior. Now, there is a new status bag: J. P.Tod's City Bag, a handmade calfskin handbag that is so popular that there is a waiting list for it at Bergdorf Goodman and at all J. P. Tod's boutiques around the world.

title: Charles Hagedorn, 79, Newspaper Publisher
description: Charles G. Hagedorn, a publisher of a chain of small newspapers in New York and Connecticut, died on Nov. 17 at Greenwich Hospital in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Hagedorn, who lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y., was 79.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN ; Is It a Bird? A Vocalist? No. Flubber.
description: Flubber

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILANO, DANIEL ADAM
description: MILANO-Daniel Adam. Age 26, of NYC, on November 28, after a valiant and determined six year battle with cancer. Loving husband of Laura Aguilar. Beloved son of Joan and Andrew. Cherished brother of Eric and Amy. He was a graduate of Brown University and a neurobiologic researcher at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University. Funeral services at Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, White Plains, NY, Sunday, November 30, 1997, at 11 AM. Donations may be made to Ronald McDonald House in memory of Daniel Milano.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANZHEIM, MELITA
description: FRANZHEIM-Melita. Died Friday evening at 9:20 surrounded by her family and friends. She was an art student in New York and Europe and also resided at 5143 Green Tree, Houston, Texas. She was 28. Born October 28, 1969, in Houston, she was the daughter of Ambassador Kenneth Franzheim II and Barbara Lynn Franzheim Dror. She attended Bard College, The New School for Social Research, New York University and the Albe Steiner School of Mosaics in Ravenna, Italy. She is survived by her mother, father and her sisters Pamela, Larisa, Roberta and Sabrina and a brother Daniel Dror II. A private viewing for friends will be at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Madison Avenue at 81st St. Sunday evening. An Unbirthday Party will be held for her at an undisclosed location this weekend. Please contact Sabrina Franzheim to r.s.v.p. and for further details. Contributions in lieu of flowers should be sent to the American Brain Tumor Association, 2720 River Road, Des Plaines, IL 60018.

title: Promiscuity Is Not the Norm in Gay Culture; Searching for Stability
description: To the Editor:

title: State Is Scouring Stores For Toys Deemed Dangerous
description: Seventy-seven children were killed by toys nationwide from 1993 to 1996, but none in New Jersey, said Mark S. Herr, the state Director of Consumer Affairs. To keep the streak going through this holiday season, the state has sent more than 100 of Mr. Herr's helpers to scour retailers' shelves armed with a list of dangerous toys published by the Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: One Dream That Died Did Not Have To
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Renews Campaign to Safeguard Rights of Foreign Citizens
description: Spurred by complaints from Mexican officials and by controversies over at least two death-penalty cases in Texas, the United States State Department has undertaken a renewed campaign to remind state and local law-enforcement agencies that foreign citizens arrested in this country have the right to contact their Government for help.

title: Villanova Advances, No Thanks to Its Defense
description: Amid the growing interest in Villanova's climb from unranked to top-ranked, the Wildcats' defense is rarely mentioned. No wonder.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: LE DIVORCE

title: Richard Ruopp, 65; Led Bank Street College
description: Richard R. Ruopp, a president emeritus of Bank Street College who adapted up-to-date technologies for the classroom, died on Tuesday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 65.

title: Schoolhouse Revives 'The Country Girl'
description: HIS art took Clifford Odets on a bitter journey of ideological awakening. In his first play, ''Awake and Sing'' (1935), a radical grandfather proclaims: ''Life shouldn't be written on dollar bills.'' In his last play, the biblically derived ''Flowering Peach'' (1955), Noah chooses to live with his rich son rather than his rebellious one.

title: Commercial Property/A 1912 Playhouse on 42d Street; 3,700-Ton Theater to Move to New Role, and Address
description: PAPER stickers with the word ''save'' written on them are attached to stone blocks on the facade of the Empire Theater on 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. They are warnings to workers to preserve as much of the old theater as possible when it is moved early next year to its new location 170 feet west.

title: Veronique Choa and Robert Pittman
description: Veronique Helene Choa, an on-line graphics artist, and Robert Warren Pittman, the president and chief executive officer of AOL Networks in Dulles, Va., a division of America Online, were married on Friday at their home in Great Falls, Va. The ceremony was performed by the bridegroom's father, the Rev. Warren E. Pittman, a United Methodist minister.

title: BENEFITS
description: Letters for Literacy

title: Don't Know Much About History
description: History on Trial Culture Wars and the Teaching of the Past. By Gary B. Nash, Charlotte Crabtree and Ross E. Dunn. 318 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $26.

title: Loyal Partners at Devil's Den
description: THE placid waters of Godfrey Pond in Weston reflected the orange-red leaves of the trees surrounding it as Howard Pierpont, a 72-year-old Stratford man, dug his pitchfork into a mound of wood chips made damp by a weekend of solid rain. Now it was Monday morning, and Mr. Pierpont was using the chips to cover a woodland trail.

title: Lives; Underground Dads
description: For years, while growing up, I shamelessly told my playmates that I didn't have a father. In my neighborhood, where men went to work with lunch pails, my friends thought there was a gaping hole in my household. My father never came to the park with me to toss a softball, never came to see me in any of my school plays. I'd explain to friends, with the simplicity of explaining to someone that there are, in some woods, no deer, that I just had no father. My friends looked at me and squinted.

title: CUTTINGS; In the Garden, Science Isn't Always Exact
description: GOOD science and good gardening go hand in hand. While much of gardening is an act of faith, science knows a great deal about some of the extraordinary biological dynamics in our gardens. Science has not reached a consensus as to exactly how (or why) all these phenomena occur. Such natural puzzles both stimulate speculation and bring a measure of awe to gardening. Some of these phenomena, like root grafting, are very common, but almost unknown to gardeners. Others, like fasciation, are rare.

title: November 23-29; Remember New Math?
description: In the 1960's, educators tried to revamp the way math is taught, coming up with New Math and befuddling an entire generation of parents who had been brought up to crunch numbers the old-fashioned way.

title: IN BRIEF; Gay Alumnus Sues High School, Saying Harassment Ignored
description: A gay former student at a Morris County high school asserts in a lawsuit that school officials failed to respond to his complaints of anti-gay harassment by other students, thereby discriminating against him as well because of his sexual orientation.

title: Sweden Beats U.S. in Davis Cup
description: Sweden won its sixth Davis Cup by beating the United States in doubles. SportsSunday, Section 8.

title: Girls and Computers Still an Issue
description: SISTER JEAN BAPTISTE, principal of the Ursuline School, a Roman Catholic private school in New Rochelle for 6th through 12th-grade girls, said she knew she had made the right decision this year in requiring incoming sixth graders to buy laptop computers.

title: Question After a Fatal Bicycle Crash: At What Price Fast Food?
description: Leonard E. Zimmerman, a Manhattan businessman, was crossing 42d Street and Seventh Avenue when a food deliveryman on a bicycle flew through the intersection, knocking him to the pavement and leaving his right elbow so badly shattered that 17 metal pins were needed to cobble it together.

title: Keeping a Name
description: To the Editor:

title: The Metropolis in a Square Block
description: A SIGN on a building at the corner of Seventh Avenue and West 18th Street bears the names of two dentists, Dr. Andrew B. Schenkel and Dr. Joseph Sachs. ''Used to be just Dr. Schenkel,'' said Tom Shachtman, struggling to contain his curiosity as he walked past. ''I haven't called them. At this point I'd just be bothering them.''

title: With Humor, Poet Lures Fans to the Serious
description: BILLY COLLINS writes funny poems, poems in which a dog barks out a solo with the oboes in a Beethoven symphony or in which the writer spends the morning shoveling snow with Buddha.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, MARK SCHEINMAN
description: STEIN-Mark Scheinman. Of Cambridge, Mass. Beloved son of Adele M. of South Hempstead, N.Y. and the late William A. Stein and beloved brother of Dodie M. Stein of Indianapolis, IN and loved friend, died suddenly in Sydney, Australia on November 24, 1997. Memorial contributions may be made to charity.

title: Designer Formals: Worth It?
description: THE term ''black tie'' conjures up many delights: canapes, orchestras, bubbly stuff. But for many men, the anticipatory thrill of such an evening evaporates the moment they have to dress for it.

title: The Night 911 Couldn't Be Called
description: For nearly five years, the New York City Medical Marijuana Buyers' Club has successful navigated the gray area between the shady drug dealers who are its suppliers and the police, whom the group has been careful to avoid encountering or provoking. By keeping relatively secretive and nomadic, the club thought it had built a peaceable existence to match its ostensibly altruistic purpose: to provide the drug and its physical comforts to those suffering from AIDS, cancer and other disabling diseases.

title: YOUNG NEW JERSEY; A Library Where You Can Do Everything but Curl Up With a Good Book
description: FOR a place that calls itself a library, the Cotsen Children's Library here isn't really geared to the reading of books. It has no holdings, no place to sit and read. But reading is still its focus.

title: Kick Is Up; After That, Anything Can Happen to Giants' Special Teams
description: The Giants may have a new offense and a new defense this season, but nothing has been more changeable, or as variable and paradoxical, as the team's special-teams play.

title: Politics of Ticket Balancing Works Against Statewide Race by Nassau Chief
description: Other things being equal, Thomas S. Gulotta is just the kind of popular suburban politician who would be ideal for the 1998 statewide Republican ticket.

title: Cancun It's Not, but Cuba Welcomes More Visitors
description: DESPITE a recent series of bomb attacks on a half-dozen hotels, restaurants and discotheques catering to foreign visitors, tourism is flourishing here, and the Cuban Government, which for three decades rejected the industry as an exploitative capitalist execration, is stepping up its efforts to attract travelers and provide them with new facilities and attractions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, HOWARD L.
description: KLEIN-Howard L. On November 25, 1997. Dear husband of Lenore Metzger Klein, brother of Helen Levinson, brother-in-law of Carlyle Levinson, Mortimer Metzger, Judith and James Riggs, loving uncle of Jane Laffend, Warren Metzger, Janice Levinson, Elise Levinson, Katherine Riggs, Nancy Riggs, and their spouses. Services Monday 1 PM, at Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd (76 Rd), Forest Hills.

title: Giving Saturday Morning Some Slack
description: Maybe the old Saturday morning experience hasn't disappeared entirely but has instead moved to the other end of the day. Kenan and Kel, Allen Strange, Shelby Woo, in the rotating circle of adolescents in Nickelodeon's Saturday evening Snick block, may be younger than Rex Trailer (''Boomtown''), but they hold out the possibility of moving children into adulthood armed with friendship, intelligence, curiosity and a sense of humor.

title: Mexicans Join Huge March As a Protest Against Crime
description: In a capital where political marches are frequent, loud and rowdy, tens of thousands of Mexicans wearing white ribbons and waving blue flags joined an orderly and silent parade to the central square today to protest the wave of violent crime that has overwhelmed much of the country.

title: Flying High in the Sky, Full Circle
description: THE first mail I ever received was a postcard written aloft. On one side, a message in my grandfather's firm hand, ''I am flying very high in the sky.'' On the other side, centered on a background of cloudless blue, a picture of the very plane he was writing from. The year was 1946, a time when airlines provided passengers with free cards and postage to seduce the folks back home.

title: Go North, Young Man
description: Anne Drennan, a Police Department spokeswoman in Vancouver, B.C., frankly says that ''Vancouver is known for having the highest-grade marijuana in the world,'' adding that busting potheads ''is not a priority with us.'' This climate has given rise to places like Hemp B.C., a Vancouver head shop that features an attached eatery and smokery called the Cannabis Cafe. The cafe is one of North America's only pot bars that allows any adult -- not just ''medicinal'' users -- to smoke openly, and the place isn't shy about this technically illegal arrangement. In fact, in full-page newspaper ads that ran recently, it invited delegates in town for the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation trade forum to drop by for a freebie. Here's what awaited the curious.

title: Fichaud Stifles Rally by Blues
description: Eric Fichaud has made his case for getting more time in the Islanders' net. If his performance against the St. Louis Blues tonight does not convince Coach Rick Bowness that he deserves to share the goaltending duties with Tommy Salo, nothing will.

title: Bad Attitude, Or Just Bad Luck?
description: To the Editor:

title: Smith Still Optimistic As the Rangers Struggle
description: When Neil Smith took inventory on his team in the second week of the season, he confidently declared it the best group he had assembled in his nine years as the Rangers' general manager.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZHEUTLIN, LIONEL J., M.D.
description: ZHEUTLIN-Lionel J., M.D. Of Paramus, NJ. Died of lung cancer November 26, 1997. Noted for devoted family pediatric care. Companion and friend of Ellen Singer. Father of Peter, Michael. Brother of Bill, Harold, Norman, Abe, Sheila Willer and Lila Eurman. Beloved grandfather of David, Daniel, Alex and Noah. Services are 10 AM, Tuesday, December 2, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W. 150, Rt. #

title: Lights! Camera! Grilled Salmon!
description: CONCERN ran through the set of ''The Confession,'' the Alec Baldwin movie that's been filming around Manhattan all month. The night before, the woman who provides the spread of snacks and beverages that keeps cast and crew fueled between meals, had been in a minor car accident. She had not arrived this bright, chilly day in Greenwich Village.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Close to the Machine

title: Partly Sunny
description: There really is something new under the sun: winter sunglasses. They're not meant for winter sports, like skiing on high-glare snowy slopes, but for protecting the eyes from wind, dust and grit on city streets or country lanes on those less-than-sunny days when dark glasses are just not practical.

title: INSIDE
description: Czech Government Resigns

title: Jacey Goldman, Daniel Taub
description: Jacey Goldman and Daniel Marc Taub were married last evening by Rabbi Paul J. Citrin at Temple Beth Shalom in Santa Fe, N.M.
