description: To the Editor:

title: In Shiny New Court, One Dispute Down, Hundreds to Go
description: A public institution closed in the Bronx last week, one that saw thousands pass through its doors daily. And no one shed a tear.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHOOR, FRANCES
description: SCHOOR-Frances. Beloved wife of Gene Schoor. Memorial service Sunday, December 7, 4 P.M., at Darech Amuno Synagogue, 53 Charles Street, West Village.

title: Two Dancers Who Never Step in the Same 'River' Twice
description: TWO DANCERS, A MAN AND A woman, were immersed in the Delaware River, moving almost as slowly as the flotsam of tree branches that wound around them on a late summer night in 1995. Boats slowed so that fisherman, and one barking dog, could watch. Then, suddenly, a heavy night sky broke over Easton, Pa., and poured more water down on the performers.

title: Syracuse Defeats Miami To Take Big East Title
description: Kyle McIntosh's smile could not have been any wider. ''There's a new sheriff in town,'' the Syracuse tailback said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANISH, ROY
description: DANISH-Roy. Died on November 20, 1997, at the age of 78. He is survived by his daughters Elisabeth Wheeler and Caroline Thies, his brother Keith, and three grandchildren. Born in Manhattan on March 2, 1919, he graduated from Columbia in 1940, earned an MBA from Harvard in 1942, then served as lieutenant in the U.S. Navy from 1942-1946. His career in broadcasting began with nine years at Mutual Broadcasting System, where he rose to the position of Vice President and Assistant to the President. From 1955 to 1959 he worked at McCann-Erickson as account supervisor and Vice President, then became a partner at Smith-Greenland Advertising in 1959. In 1960, Roy began his twenty-seven year career with Television Information Office, where he served as Director from 1962 to 1987. He worked with his multitalented staff to maintain a bridge of understanding between the television industry and its many publics. Donations in his memory may be made to the Alzheimers Association, 420 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10170.

title: 'The Piano Man' Becomes 'The Boat Man'
description: BILLY JOEL and his partner are in the midst of a million-dollar venture that is really taking off.

title: Promiscuity Is Not the Norm in Gay Culture; Persecution Unifies
description: To the Editor:

title: Joshua Katz, Naomi Lax
description: Naomi Aliza Lax, the associate director of planned and major gifts in the development office at New York University Medical Center, is to be married this afternoon to Dr. Joshua Adam Katz, a surgical resident at the medical center. Rabbi William B. Horn is to perform the ceremony at the Woodcliff Lake (N.J.) Hilton.

title: Lutherans Reconsider Episcopal Concordat
description: Officials of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America have begun moving to revise a sweeping proposal for closer ties with the Episcopal Church, the first such effort since that proposal for ''full communion'' between the two denominations was rejected by a national Lutheran body in August.

title: A Disappointment
description: To the Editor: On your recommendation in ''What's Doing in Glasgow'' (Aug. 17) my wife and I made a reservation at the Ubiquitous Chip in September.

title: Where Else But in Paris?
description: A poetic style was seen on the streets of Paris last month, in the mixing of European pieces with Tokyo designers' long skirts and layered look. A woman in the garden of the Palais Royal (oval) mixed a cut velvet skirt with a fisherman's sweater. The woman at bottom second from right wore a Rei Kawakubo bump dress. The man bottom far left wore a leather apron over jeans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMANN, MARTHA MARTEL
description: KAUFMANN-Martha Martel, died Thursday, November 27, at age 82, following a heroic battle against breast cancer. Beloved wife of 55 years to Harold, cherished mother of Renee, Carol, Joan, Charles and Isaac, and adored grandmother of Robert, Marion, Victoria, Sasha, Amelia, and Samuel. A woman of valor, former army nurse, friend to all who knew her. She will be missed. Services Sunday, November 30, 11 AM, Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Rego Park, New York.

title: That Patient In the Next Bed Looks Familiar
description: CELEBRITIES have long endorsed sodas, breakfast cereal and clothes, so is it really so surprising that they are now weighing in on angioplasty?

title: All Dressed Up With Someplace To Go
description: Festive celebrations raise money to aid charities and the arts, and honor leaders in those efforts.

title: BOOKEND; Missing Murray Kempton
description: Before Kempton there was Heywood Broun; before Broun, H. L. Mencken. No other columnist's name comes to mind, for these were all subversive of the established order -- individualists so deep and inflexible in their own willful ways that the pro-German Mencken was not allowed to comment about World War II in The Baltimore Sun, though he was the only writer-employee to be a member of the newspaper's board of directors. Broun was fired from The New York World for defending Sacco and Vanzetti. Near the end of his life he left his old radical friends aghast that he had joined the Roman Catholic Church. When prompted to explain himself, Broun said that things had come to such a pass that an honest man could find peace only in the Communist Party or the Catholic Church. But why the church? ''That's easy,'' replied Broun. ''The church is easier on heretics.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 21 about restaurants in Bavaria included a quip based on a mistranslated name for a type of white bread. A reader's letter received Sept. 30 pointed out that the name of the bread -- Franzosenlaib -- means French loaf; thus the quip, about ''Frenchman's corpse,'' reflected an erroneous premise. Research for this correction, in the absence of a writer who was traveling, was delayed by editing lapses.

title: ART REVIEW ; Three Artists and the Space Their Work Shares
description: THE Simon Gallery here is the kind of bright, undistracting space in which most artists dream of showing their work: a near-ideal art gallery.

title: On Language; The Governess
description: ''Au pairs are not nannies, Care Givers Insist.''

title: Greenhouse Gas Issue: Haggling Over Fairness
description: Of all the many issues in the talks that begin here Monday on cutting emissions of heat-trapping greenhouse gases, none carries more considerations of ethics and morality than the question of how big a burden the third-world countries should bear -- and how soon they should take it up.

title: The Pop Perfectionist on a Crowded Stage
description: Dubner gives us some picture of Paul Simon! How does one have to feel inside to treat a person auditioning for a part, or asking advice at a Q. & A. session, the way that Simon did? I am trying to understand how the Paul Simon I read about here can be the same man who wrote such incredibly beautiful words and created such wonderful sounds.

title: The Mad Monk
description: RASPUTIN The Saint Who Sinned. By Brian Moynahan. Illustrated. 400 pp. New York: Random House. $30.

title: Digital Dreams
description: RELEASE 2.0

title: Spending a Surplus
description: For two months, a debate has raged in public meetings and newspaper columns over what to do with the New York City transit surplus, which is expected to grow as high as $167 million by year's end.

title: Powerful Young Actors In a Painful Old Story
description: NEW DANCES COME AND GO. Each season has its classics. But one thing is constant with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, which begins a four-week run at City Center on Wednesday. That is the powerhouse charisma of its dancers.

title: The Call of the Wild
description: CULTURES OF HABITAT On Nature, Culture, and Story. By Gary Paul Nabhan. 338 pp. Washington: Counterpoint. $25.

title: For Gift-Givers: Gadgets, Guides
description: THE most beguiling of this year's crop of potential gifts for travelers are anachronisms: handmade leather backpacks for children in animal shapes. Grandparents are likeliest to be seduced by the packs, since they are not cheap: an owl is $54 and a frog $76. The Leather Zoo, designed by Sandy Vohr in upstate New York, includes two animals with zipper mouths (the frog and a mouse), the owl and an elephant. The creatures are sold at crafts and luggage shows in the East and by phone and mail order. Shipping and handling, around $6. Sandy Vohr's Leather Zoo, 1400 Dean Street, Schenectady, N.Y.; (518) 377-2910.

title: Giving Saturday Morning Some Slack
description: Wonderful perspective by Charles McGrath in ''Giving Saturday Morning Some Slack'' (Nov. 9)! I have two cartoon-consuming children, and I allow them to luxuriate in some free-from-expectation time.

title: GREENBUCKS
description: This holiday season, residents of various Brooklyn neighborhoods will shop using homemade cash -- and it's all legal. The currency is the Brooklyn Greenback (pictured), a form of scrip sponsored by several community groups to encourage locals to spend at home instead of away. Some 100 small businesses have agreed to recognize the stand-in money, and 100 consumers have decided to try it. Upon signing up, users get a pump-priming incentive -- four free Greenbacks, worth $12 each. ''The first thing people ask is, 'What backs it?' '' says Craig Seeman, one of the currency's cofounders. ''The same thing that backs any currency these days -- trust.'' So far trust is relatively dear: only about $6,000 worth of Greenbacks are in use, but Seeman hopes to catch up with a neighborhood in upstate New York that since 1991 has used its own scrip: the Ithaca ''Hour,'' which is circulating to the tune of $65,000.

title: In America; Terrorism by the Book
description: A copy of the decree, translated from Arabic, was given to me by human rights workers in New York who are providing assistance to women fighting against the extreme terror in parts of Algeria. The decree explains, in gruesomely explicit terms, the protocol that is to be followed by terrorists who abduct women for the purpose of raping them.

title: Michelle Apisson and Niclas Fjalltoft
description: Michelle Takouhi Apisson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John G. Apisson of Stony Brook, N.Y., was married last evening to Niclas Fjalltoft, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bo Fjalltoft of Partille, Sweden. The Rev. Kenneth E. Hansen, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the Essex House in New York.

title: Q&A/ Howard Lasher; The Nurturing Side of the Wall Streeter
description: MANY people think Wall Street is comprised of fat cats out to make a buck at any expense, resulting in an ever-widening chasm between the haves and have-nots. Not so, says Howard Lasher, who has been a broker on the American Stock Exchange since 1965.

title: SOAPBOX; Dialing for Dimes
description: I WAS woefully behind in understanding today's telephone features and rates. To catch up, I studied the front of my phone book, my 14-page bill, a month's worth of phone company junk mail, magazine inserts and television ads. I actually spoke to the phone company salespeople who call during dinner. I am now an expert. I'd be happy to share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAROT, DR. EDEN E.
description: SAROT-Dr. Eden E. Professor of Modern Languages and Linguistics at Seton Hall University from the 1930's until his retirement in 1976, died Tuesday evening, November 25, 1997, in Sunrise, FL. He was preceded in death by his parents, Nathan and Sadie Sarot, his brother, Irving Sarot, MD, and his sister Gloria Gold. He is survived by his loving and devoted sister and brother-in-law, Muriel and William B. Sherman and many nieces and nephews. Interment was private on November 28, 1997, in New York City.

title: VIEWPOINT; General Electric's Victory in Europe
description: DO you know the name of the most powerful American investment bank in Europe?

title: The Power of a Million Prayers
description: My thanks to Geraldine Brooks for her insightful article ''The Power of a Million Prayers'' (Nov. 9). Ali Kazuyoshi Nomachi's breathtaking picture -- a rare glimpse of Mecca -- was a masterpiece.

title: Editorial Observer ; The New Age Barbie Is an Old-Fashioned Doll
description: Few product specifications have the political and social import of the ratio of bustline to waistline on a Barbie doll. The average American girl now has eight Barbies, whose measurements would be 38-18-34 if they were adult-sized, a figure not found in nature. Mattel Inc. has just announced that next year it will begin making a Barbie with a wider waist and smaller bust, softer features, less makeup and a closed mouth.

title: Mamet's Stunning Foray Into The Past
description: ''THE OLD NEIGHBORHOOD,'' NOW AT THE Booth Theater on Broadway, is David Mamet's stunning companion piece to his earlier play about childhood, ''The Cryptogram.'' Though lean of line and calm of surface, ''The Old Neighborhood'' is as dangerous as an uncharted vortex. Without warning, it draws you into depths where the terrors are less often physical than emotional, where cruelty is all the more damaging for being without point, as it can seem in childhood.

title: Specialty, Not Season, Makes Retailing Attractive
description: STOCK traders are not the only ones prone to irrational exuberance. Year after year, merchants fatten their inventories in preparation for a blockbuster holiday shopping season, often slashing prices later when goods languish on the shelves.

title: Our Towns ; A New Spin On Car Pools In the Suburbs
description: TENNIS lessons at the Saw Mill River Club. Gymnastics at World Cup. Sewing classes at the Pins & Needles craft shop. Religious instruction at Shaaray Tefillah. What's a mother to do when the kids need a ride and she's stuck at work, shopping or sneaking a manicure?

title: Despite Loss, Robinson Goes Out a Winner
description: In the end, Eddie Robinson's finale wasn't much of a game. The 588th game of his career was an accurate synopsis of everything that had changed, everything that had gone wrong, everything that had allowed the competition to close the gap, finally catch up and pass him by.

title: Techno Hunter
description: Autumn, and I had just sat down for my annual rite. I spread out the hunting catalogues on my living-room floor and primed myself to add to my collection of hats, boots, coats, decoys and calls. Ordinarily, I'm not much of a shopper, but give me a good hunting catalogue and I can lose myself for hours.

title: An Italian Newcomer in a Shopping Mall
description: UGO SGUANCI likes to make an impression. His last restaurant, Due Torri, was in the penthouse of an office building in Hauppauge. There, the sophisticated supper club surroundings sharply contrasted with the welcoming, homey spirit of the place. His new enterprise, La Contessa, is in a shopping center in Plainview. Startled shoppers, expecting a casual cafe, instead find a white tablecloth spot complete with tuxedoed waiters.

title: Waugh Writ Here
description: To the Editor: Your article on English country hotels (''Cromwell Slept Here, Louis XVIII Slept There,'' Oct. 19) enforces the charm of such establishments.

title: The Bubba Stories
description: NEWS OF THE SPIRIT

title: Long Goodbye
description: To the Editor: I identified completely with Susan Jacoby's essay ''Learning to Live With Arrivederci'' Oct. 12. I am back from Cornwall only four weeks. Each time I go I'm sure I was meant to be there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TZOUGROS, ANTHI E. (ATHENEOS)
description: TZOUGROS-Anthi E. (Atheneos). Formerly of Queens, died November 27 in Waukesha, WI, at age 89. Preceded by husband George in 1978. Burial 11 A.M., Wednesday, December 3, Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY. Randle-Dable Funeral Home, 414-547-4035.

title: A Merger Defies the Odds
description: Fund companies often erase a bad record by merging a weak fund into one with better performance. In one case, though, John Hancock is doing just the opposite.

title: Donations Are Sought for Playland Museum
description: THE Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation wants yellowed photographs, dusty souvenirs and discarded admission tickets -- if they are from Playland Amusement Park.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK ; Police Take Material From Couple's Building
description: The police removed materials that appeared to be blood-stained from the apartment building of a missing lower Manhattan couple late Friday, but cautioned yesterday that preliminary tests indicated the substance was not blood.

title: Promiscuity Is Not the Norm in Gay Culture; Self-Defeating Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: Dismissing the Deficit Won't Help Workers; Inflation Fighter
description: To the Editor:

title: Facing Holiday Shopping
description: How do you handle the demands of holiday shopping, including the crowds in stores and parking areas?

title: The World; Castro Foe's Legacy: Success, Not Victory
description: FLAGS are flying at half-staff here and mourners are flocking to a cemetery in Little Havana, the heart of the Cuban exile community, to grieve at the freshly dug grave of Jorge Mas Canosa, the longtime leader of the most powerful Cuban exile organization in the United States, who died here a week ago today after a yearlong battle with cancer.

title: The Holidays Approach With Song
description: FROM the rehearsals of October and November come the choral concerts of December, and the harvest of this season's vocal work has begun.

title: QUICK BITE/Keyport; A Kitchen Accident That Produced a Keeper
description: Accidents happen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERNANDEZ, DR. XAVIER A.
description: FERNANDEZ-Dr. Xavier A. On November 23, in Fort Myers, Florida. Internationally recognized scholar with respect to classical Spanish theater and, in particular, the works of Tirso de Molina. Professor emeritus from State University of New York at Albany. Survived by his wife, Dr. Laura B. Fernandez, by his sons, Xavier J. Fernandez and Dr. Peter G. Fernandez, and by his daughter, Anita F. Palmer. Contributions may be made to the St. Vincent de Paul Church Building Fund of Fort Myers.

title: Man Is Arrested in Killings at Football Game
description: A Bronx man thought to be a member of a gang was charged yesterday with murdering two people and wounding three others during a Thanksgiving Day football game outside his housing project, the police said.

title: A Horror Movie, Complete With Zombies
description: IT'S CINDY SHERMAN'S TURN. Over the past three years, three other ambitious 80's art stars -- Robert Longo, David Salle and Julian Schnabel -- have succumbed to the siren lure of celluloid and decided to try directing movies. Just once. Each. Now Sherman, who called her earliest works, made in the late 70's, ''Untitled Film Stills'' has followed in their footsteps. She may end up being the leader of the pack.

title: Promiscuity Is Not the Norm in Gay Culture; Rethink 'Safe Sex'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Fitness Gurus
description: THE man and the woman were facing each other, crouched down low, their arms out in front of them as if to ward off blows. They were sweating as they hopped around menacingly to the arena rock thumping in the low, hot, mirrored basement of the Crunch gym on Lafayette Street. Then the instructor barked a short command and Michael Linstroth, a 25-year-old actor, grabbed the right arm of a 25-year-old teacher named Robyn Poarch and slung her over his shoulder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, JOHN
description: CLARK-John. The Board of Directors and Stockholders of 1010 Tenants Corporation wish to extend their sincerest and heartfelt condolences to the family of John Clark on their great loss.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MALLIS, MEYER
description: MALLIS-Meyer. October 18, 1916-November 30, 1990. Always missed, always remembered and always loved. Rest in peace.

title: Septuplets Show Normal Progress, Moving to Tubal Feeding
description: It has been 10 days since an Iowa woman made medical history by giving birth to seven live babies, and doctors say the infants are continuing to make remarkable progress.

title: The Hole That Swallowed the Swings
description: It was a mishap with a capital M at Second Avenue between 30th and 33d Streets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSER, MOLLIE MALVIN
description: LESSER-Mollie Malvin. She has been a source of abundant love and inspiration for her 90 years; she will forever be cherished and never forgotten by son Michael, granddaughters Caren and Stacy, daughter-in-law Janice, and beloved brother Arthur Malvin.

title: Many Splendid Things
description: Right about now the soul gets hungry for extravagance.

title: At the Casinos
description: Atlantic City Hilton

title: Easy Victory In Doubles Gives Sweden Davis Cup
description: Hexed and vexed by a combination of bad play and worse luck in snowy Goteborg, where the Swedish Davis Cup team seems to have a patriotic guardian angel whenever a star-studded American squad struts into town, the United States Davis Cup team was eliminated by 3-0 this afternoon.

title: A Gentle Push, or an Rough Shove
description: The company no longer has need of someone's services, and the message must be delivered. How does it come? Often, awkwardly: The corporate apartment's landlord asks for a moving date, the computer no longer recognizes a password, or the office lock is changed. How has your company handled dismissals? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: What the World Looks Like When the Screen Goes Dark
description: The challenge was a big one:

title: Guild Hall Honors 3 for Artistic Achievement
description: BILLY JOEL, the sculptor William King and the playwright Wendy Wasserstein have been chosen as 1997 recipients of the Guild Hall Academy of the Arts lifetime achievement awards.

title: The Neediest Cases; Even as Economy Booms, Working Poor Just Scrape By
description: Wall Street is a money machine, the six-digit bonus is back and excess has become the ethos of New York City in the late 1990's. The bonanza can be measured by the density of smoke at downtown cigar bars and the thickness of sirloin served uptown. It is echoed in the buzz of construction and the clatter of tourists transforming Times Square.

title: Gimme the Ol' White Shoe
description: It strikes me that ''white shoe'' is probably not a reference, in this context, to white bucks. Rather, it refers to the white or light-gray spats worn over dress shoes by many of the tonier Wall Street dressers of the 1920's (give or take a few decades). Spats were also common in the formal day dress of ambassadors, who were also referred to, in denigration, as the ''white-shoe crowd.'' This, at least, was the derivation handed to me, by a strictly oral tradition, from someone old enough perhaps to have worn such trappings.

title: Saba Memories
description: To the Editor: How pleasant to read about Saba (''Sure-Footed on Saba,'' Oct. 26). About 30 years ago, we, too, took the small plane from St. Maarten that landed on the postage-stamp-sized tarmac. At that time, sadness dominated the atmosphere. All the young people would depart to attend high school, either in the Netherlands or elsewhere -- and usually not return once they saw the world.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: TENDER COMRADES

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN; Hot Dogs to Go: Another Outlet Is Gone
description: The hot dog is a New York standard, and there were once a few special hot dog stands that were the standard-bearers. Nedick's in Times Square. Nathan's, of course, also gone from Broadway. Leo's Famous in Herald Square.

title: The Sound and Fury
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pop Perfectionist on a Crowded Stage
description: So much time, talent, money and energy is going into a show that glorifies the life and crimes of a cold-blooded murderer. Sadly, it seems that Salvador Agron's victims have been murdered twice -- first by the killer, in 1959, and now by Simon and his partners in the upcoming musical celebration of their deaths.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCHMANN, HILDEGARD
description: TUCHMANN - Hildegard. The Forest Hills Section of NCJW mourns the death of a former President and dedicated member of the National Council of Jewish Women. Hildegard will be remembered for her innovative support of our social service programs.

title: A Caribbean Breeze Is Christmas Wish
description: Peter Holmberg, a leading match-race sailor from the United States Virgin Islands, has his thoughts on a special Caribbean Sea breeze these days. Ever since growing up as a junior sailor near St. Thomas, V.I., Holmberg has been hearing about Christmas winds.

title: It May Be Time for a Silver Lining in Air Pollution
description: AIR-POLLUTION control stocks, though still as torpid as the air on a muggy day, may finally be ready to stir.

title: INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2

title: Spelling It Out
description: PERFECT AGREEMENT

title: Bananas for Rent
description: I was intrigued by Michiko Kakutani's ''Bananas for Rent'' (Culture Zone, Nov. 9), perhaps because I spent some 20 years in the magazine business, where companies paid hefty sums for a blank page to hawk their wares. But I've never understood why folks would shell out their own dollars to be someone else's walking billboard.

title: West Coast Trip Winds Up Sour For Gasping, Depleted Devils
description: Outnumbered, outskated and out of breath, the last thing the Devils needed tonight was to get caught up in an end-to-end skateathon with the Kings. But Los Angeles dictated the tempo of the game, scored repeatedly on outnumbered rushes and left the Devils reeling on their final stop of a three-game trip to California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIER, BARBARA J.
description: SCHREIER-Barbara J. Age 50, of Stamford, CT, on November 29, 1997, at her residence. Wife of Stephen Schreier, mother of Deborah Leipzig. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, November 30, at 1 PM, at the Leo P. Gallagher and Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St., Stamford, CT. Burial will follow at Agudath Sholom Cemetery, Stamford. In lieu of flowers donations maybe made in c/o Professor Barbara Candales, CCSU Foundation/Social Work Program, 1615 Stanley St., New Britain, CT 06050.

title: Meet Me at the Station. There's Lots to Do.
description: If you're looking for a good book, you might want to borrow one from the train depot in Whitehouse Station. Want a good meal? Try the Bound Brook train station. How about a new toy or a new house? Go to the South Orange station.

title: November 23-29; Judges Tackle Fans
description: In American football, the bashing traditionally takes place on the field, not in the stands -- in contrast to European football, otherwise known as soccer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YORK, BEVERLY
description: YORK-Beverly. Of Palm Beach, FL. On November 29, 1997. Beloved wife of the late George J. York. Devoted mother of Dr. Jonathan L. York and his wife Dorothy of Demarest, NJ, and Cassie J. York and her husband David Ackerman, of Chappaqua, NY. Cherished grandmother of Eric, Marc and Grant. For funeral information call Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St, NYC, 212-288-3500.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 30, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Tilting The Scales From Old To New
description: FACED WITH AN AUDIENCE THAT seems, except in a few encouraging instances, to be getting smaller by the minute, orchestras and concert halls in this country respond by offering an ever narrowing repertory. It never occurs to anyone that what passes for a solution may in fact be increasing the problem, that if you present people with less and less, more and more of them will stay away.

title: Checking the Home for Lead Traces
description: LEAD and its compounds have been a part of our environment since ancient times. During the Middle Ages, litharge -- a white oxide of lead -- was added to wine as a sweetener. Lead has also been used to fashion pipes for drinking water, and in more recent times lead has been added to gasoline and to paint.

title: November 23-29; AIDS Numbers Get Grimmer
description: The United Nations sharply increased its estimates of AIDS infections and deaths, giving a grimmer portrait of the global epidemic. Experts at the United Nations said they believed that 16,000 people were newly infected with the AIDS virus each day, almost double the number of new infections estimated last year.

title: Three People Talking, Lovely Lyrically Talking
description: ''MOLLY SWEENEY'' has been admired for purity of language and depth of perception. But despite superb performances in the first New York production two seasons ago, Brian Friel's narrative involving three characters and three chairs was, for many theatergoers, just that: three people sitting around, talking -- for two hours.

title: ''Nutcrackers'' Showing Personal Touches
description: DURING the 22 years that Frank Ohman danced with the New York City Ballet, he appeared in every production of George Balanchine's ''Nutcracker'' -- performing every male role from the lead father in the opening party scene to candy canes and cavaliers in the second act. The ballet played a major part in his evolving profesional career.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: CRUISE

title: Gulf Syndrome; Americans Decide War May Not Be Quite So Scary
description: THERE'S nothing like a crisis with Iraq to get American blood boiling.

title: Correction
description: A letter to the editor last Sunday about the names of rock bands misstated the title of a song by Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart. It is ''Manhattan,'' not ''We'll Take Manhattan.'' (The first and fourth refrains begin with ''We'll have Manhattan.'')

title: Piers Plan For Leagues Hits a Shoal
description: For a minute or two, it looked as if a group of downtown sports leagues were going to attain its goal of soccer and baseball fields on the waterfront, a sort of poor man's Chelsea Piers.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Nov. 16 with a front-page article about sport utility vehicles and safety misidentified the woman shown greeting two schoolboys at the door of such a vehicle. She was Nancy Vick, a volunteer at Rippowam-Cisqua School in Chappaqua, not Michaela Beitzel, mother of the two boys, Mac and Chase Beitzel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALKOWITZ, FAE
description: SALKOWITZ-Fae. Beloved wife of Abraham. Devoted mother of Vivian and Ronald Feinberg, Ira and Eileen Salk. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Will be missed by all. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Nassau-North Chapel, 10 AM, Great Neck, NY.

title: School for Scandal; The Burning of a Russian Crusader
description: IT is the kind of political parable that enchants Western democrats eager to see Russia adopt the rule of law: A top Government official is implicated in a corrupt financial deal, written about in the press and punished. Accountability, it seems, has gained a foothold in a system that once respected nothing but power.

title: Sweet Talk: Made in New Jersey; Weddings, Communions And Butter Crunch
description: CANDY is big business in America. We eat an average of 23.4 pounds of it a year, split almost equally between chocolate and everything else. We buy the most at Halloween, followed closely by Christmas, Easter and Valentine's Day. Last year, American retailers sold $21.1 billion in candy, $11.7 billion of it on chocolate alone.

title: An Author Adapts To Being Adapted
description: RUSSELL BANKS HAS HAD A long and tangled history with the movie industry. In the past, his wintry, critically admired novels have been snapped up by Hollywood, attracting the enthusiasm of A-list directors from Jonathan Demme to Wolfgang Peterson, but have stopped short of being turned into films.

title: Style; A Trade Secret
description: Is collecting a form of self-definition? If so, my pal V. may be Jean Shrimpton trapped in the body of a middle-aged man. V. is a hard-core and often visionary collector: cartes de visite, Evergreen paperbacks, paint-by-numbers pictures, African trade beads. You name it, he got there first. For the past couple of years V.'s ruling passion has been vintage fashion magazines. As it happens, he's not alone.

title: Appearances; Hitting It on the Nose
description: In every bottle of fragrance there is a story, and the writer of the story is the Nose. The Nose is the inside term for perfumer, the person who takes a collection of words and images and, choosing 60 or so ingredients from a lexicon of more than 3,000, transforms it into smell. Noses call this putting the story into the bottle.

title: The Last Best Friends Money Can Buy
description: Normally you didn't have to interview for a home health care placement -- the agency just told you where to be, and when, and a little background information on the client. But Lorna Kingston didn't mind. It would be a good job if she got it -- $150 a day for a 24-hour live-in. The client, as Nick Newcombe, who was overseeing her home care, had explained, was resisting help and had fired a succession of workers. Newcombe thought the client would feel empowered if she had a choice, and so had arranged for Lorna and two other aides to be interviewed by the woman, her nephew Howard (Buzz) Katzen and his wife.

title: November 23-29; A Star Is Reborn
description: The world of print was buzzing after Harold M. Evans, the president and publisher of Random House's trade group, announced that he was leaving to head Mortimer B. Zuckerman's publications, including The Daily News, U.S. News & World Report, The Atlantic Monthly and Fast Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOSO, LOUIS
description: VOSO-Louis, 66. Died in his sleep November 15 at his home in East Greenwich, NY. Born in Brooklyn, he was a graduate of St. John's University and served in the army stationed in Germany during the Korean War. He was an astute businessman who served as Chief Financial Officer and Director of two corporations over the span of his business career. He was retired since 1992. He was an active part of a generation that popularized sports cars in the United States after World War II. He raced and ralleyed a 1949 MG throughout the Northeast and was a former president of the Bay Ridge Sports Car Club. He also authored articles depicting this world he so enjoyed. His wife, Constance (nee Cullen) died in 1984, and he is survived by his stepdaughter, Gale Leva; two stepsons, Steven Lodes and Charles McGowan; a sister, Florence Powell; a brother, Frank Voso; five nieces and nephews, five step grandchildren, and one step great-grandchild. A private memorial service will be held in Brooklyn. Interment will be at the Holy Cross Cemetery in Brooklyn.

title: Tough Tactics In Ex-Zaire Evoke Ghost Of Mobutu
description: Six months after Laurent Kabila took power at the head of an armed rebellion, his Government has faced the first direct challenge to its authority with a series of shootouts between army units. As many as 18 people have been killed in the clashes here in the last two days.

title: THEATER; A Fresh Look at 'Anne Frank' In Search of the Historical One
description: ON AN UNUSUALLY WARM evening in Amsterdam last May, Wendy Kesselman, an American playwright, and James Lapine, an American theater director, climbed the stairs to the second floor of a magnificent, architecturally complicated old canal house at 263 Prinsengracht. There, they sat down around the same wooden desk at which Otto Frank had first read his daughter Anne's diary in late 1945.

title: Kendra Schwartz, Michael Poster
description: Kendra Lynn Schwartz, the daughter of Jan B. Schwartz of Los Gatos, Calif., and Henry Schwartz of Menlo Park, Calif., was married last evening to Michael Sollod Poster, the son of Sandra S. Poster of Manhattan and Paul M. Poster of Scarsdale, N.Y. Cantor Richard Botton officiated in the Palm House at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Beyond Grace Notes in a Musical Season
description: SOMETIMES, you preach to the choir. Today, we let the choir do some preaching of its own.

title: Arts Centers Open Doors For Hire To Survive
description: AT the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College, bar mitzvahs ease the unrelenting financial crunch. In Yonkers, at the Hudson River Museum, there are weddings after the public leaves. And in Katonah at the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts, Jewish High Holy Day services pay the way.

title: Devious Course Wins Cigar
description: New York staged a dramatic farewell to Grade I racing until next spring yesterday, as the 5-year-old Devious Course used a wild rush to win the Cigar Mile by the length of his neck.

title: A Bamberger's Parade Was Held in the 1950's
description: To the Editor:

title: DIARY
description: ASIAN IMBROGLIO

title: Boston Schoolboy Wins Title
description: Abdira Zak Mohamud of Boston, the defending Foot Locker national high school cross-country champion, raced to a decisive victory yesterday in the northeast regional meet at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: November 23-29; For a Change, the Fish Win
description: It was a red-letter day for American fish.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: Cabernet Franc

title: Nouveau Number, No Cachet
Heart of Suburban Darkness? Here? Uh-uh.
description: ''Why should I mind it? It's fiction. I mean, we've never even heard of key parties.'' -- A 50-ish woman overheard at the New Canaan Playhouse after a showing of ''The Ice Storm.''

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: RIVERDALE ; Artists With Bronx Ties That Bind
description: THREE years ago it started as a small show with two artists. This year, the Art Benefit and Holiday Shop for the Riverdale Neighborhood House has grown to include 11 artists, some with national exposure and all with connections to the Bronx. This year the show coincides with the 125th anniversary of the Neighborhood House, a community service organization. Sandy Shalleck, a board member, said, ''You don't even have to be interested in the neighborhood house to go to the art show.''

title: When Dogs Go Shopping, Common Sense Stays Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Pilgrimage on a Steel Ride

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAILLARD, DR. LESLIE WOODROW
description: MAILLARD-Dr. Leslie Woodrow. On November 29, 1997. Former Chief of Proctology at Flushing Hospital. Respected and loved by his patients and peers. World War II Lieutenant Colonel, Physician for the Pacific Theater Air Corps. He will be missed by his wife Peggy and sons Steven and Robert, and their families. Also survived by his six grandchildren and four great-grandchidlren who all loved and respected their ''Pop-pop.'' In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Monday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Religious service 8 PM, at the funeral home.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Alien Resurrection

title: Not His Fault
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Q&A: Ross Blechman ; Using Nature's Products to Achieve Health
description: AMERICA'S desire to lose may be Ross Blechman's gain. Last year, while the nation was debating the safety of prescription diet drugs like Redux and fen-phen, Mr. Blechman, president and chief executive officer of Twin Laboratories in Ronkonkoma, was hard at work developing ''all-natural'' weight loss products. The company has seen a large increase in sales, as former weight loss ''wonder drugs'' are being pulled from drugstore shelves because of mounting evidence linking them to heart valve damage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENNESSY, HARRY J.
description: HENNESSY-Harry J., 77. Died November 21, 1997. Harry, a retired newscaster for WOR Radio is survived by his wife Helen of Columbus, Ohio, two daughters Maryann of Columbus, Ohio and Caroline of Norwich, CT., four grandchildren, his niece and his nephew.

title: Coleman A. Young, 79, Mayor of Detroit And Political Symbol for Blacks, Is Dead
description: Coleman A. Young, the combative, tart-tongued former union organizer who became the first black Mayor of Detroit when he was elected in 1973 and then went on to run the city for a record 20 years, died yesterday at Sinai Hospital in Detroit. He was 79.

title: Correspondence / Sick in Tokyo ; I Lived to Tell About Japan's Medical Miracle
description: EVERYBODY thinks the Japanese medical system is one of the best in the world; everybody except the Japanese.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Bull Moose on the Menu? Favorites of a Rough Rider

title: A Lush Park Woodland, the Way It Used to Be
description: In a shed in Prospect Park, Curtis Barnhart uses hand tools from another age -- a log peeler, chisels, planes -- to shape hard-as-stone white oak logs into the elements of a rustic bridge. A wood fire crackles in an iron stove. The man squints, then, ever so tentatively, begins to smile, straining to visualize a strategy for joining two gnarled logs.

title: Jack Berry, Florida Citrus Baron, Dies at 81
description: Jack M. Berry, a Tennessee-born New York businessman who made a fortune in Florida orange groves, died on Nov. 21 at a hospital near his home in Winter Haven, Fla. He was 81 and the last of the Florida citrus barons who transformed the industry in the 1960's.

title: Brazil on a Grill
description: MY friend Jesse, an environmental scientist who sampled his first rodizio, or grilled meat festival, in Brazil recently, has this to say about Seabra's Rodizio:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: DANGEROUS VIRTUESBy Ana Maria Moix.University of Nebraska,cloth, $30; paper, $10.

title: Temple-Hopping in South India
description: WALKING along the beach south of Madras, I saw what looked like a rainbow rising out of the palm trees. In fact it was one of South India's famous modern temples covered with radiant stone deities. Each one was painted in flame-red and sky-blue and sea-green and hues I couldn't possibly name. The colors were so fresh I could smell them -- the sweet odor of new paint mixing with the smoky scent of incense and salt spray from the Bay of Bengal. I seemed to hear them as well, but soon identified the sounds as the pounding of drums, the clanging of a brass bell, and the singsong chanting that accompanies Hindu prayer services.

title: Deathbed Confessions
description: BYRNE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, EUGENE A.
description: KELLY-Eugene A. Of Southbury, CT., died on November 20, age 86. A 1936 graduate of The Cooper Union, he had a distinguished career as a chemical engineer with the Kellex Corporation during World War II and later with Hydrocarbon Research Inc., and the CE Lummus Company. Survived by his sons Richard, of Lloyd Harbor, NY, and Bruce, of New Canaan, CT., and four grandchildren. Donations in his memory may be made to the annual fund of The Cooper Union, 30 Cooper Square, New York, New York 10003.

title: In the Community, Out on Their Own
description: IT was a festive affair -- an evening of dining, dancing, laughter and stories of accomplishments.

title: Mexican Mix-Up
description: To the Editor: An impromptu five-day trip to Mexico was shortened by American Airlines when I appeared to check in with my granddaughter Abby, age 12. Our flight was at 6 A.M. Abby, excited by her first trip out of the country, spent the night in her travel clothes and woke me at 3 A.M.

title: Sweet Talk: Made in New Jersey; Do It Yourself, Or Have Them Do It
description: CANDY is big business in America. We eat an average of 23.4 pounds of it a year, split almost equally between chocolate and everything else. We buy the most at Halloween, followed closely by Christmas, Easter and Valentine's Day. Last year, American retailers sold $21.1 billion in candy, $11.7 billion of it on chocolate alone.

title: Consumer Counterculture
description: The Conquest of Cool

title: India's Parties Seek Coalition To Rule Out New Elections
description: India's main political parties maneuvered feverishly today to cobble together a new coalition to replace the 14-party Government that collapsed on Friday, but days of horse-trading seemed likely before the country would learn the outcome.

title: Knicks Tread Unsure Path to Blowout Victory
description: There was a strange uneasiness last night even as the Knicks appeared to be handling the Phoenix Suns in simple fashion.

title: Sports of The Times; Hangin' Judge Brings Peace to the Wild, Wild Frontier
description: EVERY football game needs a hangin' judge, that grand old staple of movie westerns. The National Football League could install one hangin' judge per stadium, in a luxury box, safely behind bulletproof glass, out of the way of snowballs and batteries and tracer rockets.

title: Alternative to State Plan for Lilco
description: FOR months the chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, Richard M. Kessel, and other backers of Gov. George E. Pataki's $7.3 billion plan for a partial state takeover of Lilco have sounded the same refrain.

title: THE VIEW FROM/Middlebury; Westover Is All Girls And Staying That Way
description: THE Westover School in Middlebury invited the public on campus for a performance of Macbeth recently. Chairs scattered around the balcony and downstairs in the ''Red Room'' allowed the audience a full view of center floor and the cast easy access to every exit and entrance, the grand divided staircase and the balcony itself.

title: Hail the Humble Lentil: To Enrich Soup or Meat and Fish
description: THE lentil, wrote the French gastronome Robert J. Courtine, ''brings with it the whiff of the boarding school and the barracks,'' and, he added, ''not to say the prison.'' The true gourmet revels in it, he also said, ''at every moment of the meal, from lentil soup to lentil salad.''

title: November 23-29; This Muse Sang to the K.G.B.
description: Americans have mostly associated her with Julie Christie, the actress who portrayed Lara in the 1965 film version of ''Doctor Zhivago.'' But Russians had always known that the radiant heroine of Boris Pasternak's greatest novel was modeled on Olga Ivinskaya, Pasternak's longtime mistress, muse and literary assistant.

title: The Irish on Canvas, Politically Expressive
description: CONTEMPORARY Irish painting is very much on the map, proving they are blessed with the gift of the brush, as well as of the gab. An exhibition at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven serves to underline this notion, not in an especially spectacular or dramatic way, but in a modest and sturdy fashion. Nearly 80 works, dating from the 19th century through the first decades of the 20th, from the collection of Brian P. Burns, mark the first time the center has shown Irish painting.

title: Streetscapes/Beekman Place; A Two-Block Street Down by the East Riverside
description: THE two-block-long Beekman Place is one of New York's smallest streets, and for the last two decades the residents have watched with concern as project after project was proposed that would substantially change its group of riverfront houses. Now construction activity at the double-width Merle-Smith house, at 25 Beekman Place, dominates the tiny street. But to Beekman Place residents it is only the latest chapter in a long campaign to keep this special enclave unchanged.

title: PETS ; Breed Determines Traits
description: BEFORE selecting the pet that is right for you, look at the word breed. Although it can relate to physical appearance, the look does not describe the package. Metaphorically, breed can be described as a category or grouping of personality traits.

title: Cristina Arico, James Clark
description: Cristina Maria Arico and James Joseph Clark were married yesterday at Le Cirque 2000, the New York restaurant. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, an ecumenical minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Giving Saturday Morning Some Slack
description: Your article brought back memories of a Thanksgiving several years ago, when my two children returned home from college. I came downstairs on Saturday morning to see if they had survived the previous night's partying. I found them wrapped in comforters, sipping coffee and watching cartoons in a nostalgic trance.

title: Beaches for Saints and Sinners
description: THE small state of Goa, tucked away along India's west coast, is -- like India itself, some might say -- a puzzlement, predictably confounding expectations at every turn.

title: Out With the Molasses, In With the Guests
description: In older cities like London and New York, it is not unusual for a building with a lengthy history and unlikely provenance to morph into a hotel. The latest transformation is in Boston, where the Harborside Inn opened last month.

title: Pretty, Quick
description: Models in the fashion shows in Europe sprouted all manner of hairpieces, but by far the most popular were ponytails, reflecting a change in the fashion winds from minimalist androgyny to all-out femininity.

title: Catering Firm Helps the Hungry
description: IN a walk-in refrigerator stocked with shelves of goat cheese mousse, carefully spiced sauces and loaves of delicate, cocktail-size breads, Alison Awerbuch was pondering the hungry.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Birth of an Heirloom

title: John Nolan, 73, Military Bishop
description: Auxiliary Bishop John Gavin Nolan of the Archdiocese for the Military Services, which serves more than a million Catholics in the United States and around the world, died on Nov. 19 at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 73 and most recently lived in Manhattan.

title: Apology and the Holocaust; The Pope's in a Confessional, And Jews Are Listening
description: MORE than any other Pope in history, Pope John Paul II leader of the world's almost one billion Roman Catholics -- has asked forgiveness for the sins, crimes and errors committed in the name of his faith.

title: Make Nike Talk
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Storm Brewing for Umbrella
description: To hear Carole DeSaram tell it, few things in recent history have united tasteful New Yorkers more than their collective animus toward a certain bright red umbrella.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; Out of the Melting Pot, Into the Global Market
description: AMERICA is once again a nation of immigrants. Some 800,000 aliens are admitted every year. The number of foreign-born Americans leaped from less than 10 million in 1970 to more than 24 million last year. One in 10 Americans -- including me -- was born abroad.

title: Another Park Lawn Goes Off Limits
description: For years, the three-acre field at the south end of Riverside Park, between 73d and 76th Streets, served as a gathering spot for dogs and their owners, a place where leash laws were not always observed or enforced and where informal neighborhood teams played sports. Dog claws and touch football games rendered the area, known as the South Lawn, something of a dust bowl.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Elmsford, N.Y.; Diversity's a Cause for Celebration
description: IN 1991, Dr. Angela Fraser-Reid and her husband, Hugh Reid, moved here from the Bronx. Their requirements were a ''perfect'' house within a short radius of St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains, where she practices internal medicine, and a community that valued diversity.

title: Part Security, but Mostly to Lend a Hand
description: IN the summer of '97, Stamford became a more user-friendly town. Once a city of corporate headquarters and a less-than-inviting streetscape, it kicked off its innovative Ambassador Program -- an added security presence that has turned into something far friendlier -- on July 1. The difference is already evident.

title: Singing Baba the Turk
description: To the Editor:

title: And Now for the Fully Chronicled Life, Funeral Video
description: The tape of the recent ceremony begins with a montage of scenes from the subject's life, accompanied by Paul Anka's (and Kodak's) ''Times of Your Life.'' Shots of the guests and of the subject follow, with the service discreetly filmed in its entirety. The guests, who are outdoors at the end, are then shown leaving.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 16 about the Blue Mountain area of Australia misidentified a restaurant. It is the Victory Theater Cafe in Blackheath, not a tearoom in Wentworth Falls.

title: The Pop Perfectionist on a Crowded Stage
description: It is sad that Paul Simon himself will never be able to appreciate, with fresh ears and naive heart, the beauty of his creations, now preserved for posterity, in such collections as the recently released Simon & Garfunkel retrospective, ''Old Friends.'' Imagine the exhilaration and pleasure yet to be experienced by future Simon & Garfunkel fans, 10, 20, 100 years from now. I envy those children of the future.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Bulls and Bears of Yore

title: In Grand Rapids, Grand Italian Works
description: Grand Rapids, Mich., is awash in the Italian Renaissance this winter, with the Grand Rapids Grand Renaissance. The centerpiece of the festival is ''Perugino: Master of the Italian Renaissance,'' at the Grand Rapids Art Museum through Feb. 1.

title: Essay; Russia Needs Alms Control
description: See the spectacle of Moscow selling its latest missile know-how to Iran's ayatollahs and championing the sordid cause of Iraq's Saddam, proudly bestriding the world stage by sticking Russia's thumb in America's eye.

title: Small Business
description: Around the Block

title: A Living Laboratory Where a River Meets the Sea
description: The Mullica River meets the Great Bay at a point between southern Ocean and northern Atlantic Counties. The area is mainly surrounded by undisturbed swamps and marshland. Nearly 115,000 acres of this area was designated last month as the Jacques Cousteau National Estuarine Research Reserve under a program managed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the Federal Department of Commerce.

title: In Alan We Trust. So Why Own Gold?
description: Imagine a world where one religion had been almost universally believed, but was now fading away as a new religion gained widespread acceptance. What would you expect the high priests of the new religion to say about the old one?

title: Deals Abound in a Van-Eat-Van Environment
description: SUPPLY is going up. Demand is flat or declining. Basic economics dictates that prices of mini-vans have to fall. Indeed, consumers stand to benefit from this imbalance in the increasingly crowded van market, particularly with the arrival of the 1998 Toyota Sienna and a new Accord-based van due out from Honda next year.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION ; Fond Memories of a Poet-Mentor
description: ONE evening, in the fall of 1970, I sat across the dinner table from the poet David Ignatow, then my writing professor at Southampton College. ''Before I came to Southampton, during my senior year in military school,'' I was telling him, ''I hid in my barracks room and read. That year, I must have read more than 1,000 books.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SUMMER OF BETRAYAL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, THOMAS M. III
description: GREEN-Thomas M. III. Headmaster, died peacefully at home in Savannah, GA, Thanksgiving Day. Born Baltimore, MD, 1922. For 16 years was headmaster of the Peck School in Morristown, NJ. He is survived by his wife, Dulcinea Lee Green; two brothers, Douglas Sadtler Green and John McEldowney Green; two sons, Thomas M. Green IV and Jonathan Wales Green; four stepchildren, Nichol duPont Conway, Peter Rhett duPont, Alicia Lee duPont and Scott Townsend duPont; and four grandchildren.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK ; Baby Boy Dies and Man Is Charged With Murder
description: A 1-year-old baby boy died yesterday from head injuries he suffered in his home in the Bronx and his mother's boyfriend was charged with second-degree murder and manslaughter in the case, the Bronx District Attorney's office said.

title: Bike Makers Try Comfort and Gizmos to Pump Up Profit
description: THESE have not been easy times for the once-robust bicycle business, but in the view of some experts the prospects for a prosperous future can be summed up in two words: disk brakes.

title: Village Voice
description: LIMELIGHT

title: An 18th-Century Paparazzo
description: HOGARTH

title: Sweet Talk: Made in New Jersey; 26,000 Pounds of Sugar And One Happy Family
description: CANDY is big business in America. We eat an average of 23.4 pounds of it a year, split almost equally between chocolate and everything else. We buy the most at Halloween, followed closely by Christmas, Easter and Valentine's Day. Last year, American retailers sold $21.1 billion in candy, $11.7 billion of it on chocolate alone.

title: Sweet Talk: Made in New Jersey; How to Make Sure The Bunnies Don't Melt
description: CANDY is big business in America. We eat an average of 23.4 pounds of it a year, split almost equally between chocolate and everything else. We buy the most at Halloween, followed closely by Christmas, Easter and Valentine's Day. Last year, American retailers sold $21.1 billion in candy, $11.7 billion of it on chocolate alone.

title: A LA CARTE ; Caribbean Specialties for the Adventurous
description: EVEN though the three-month-old Chez Vous in Freeport accurately bills its fare as international cuisine, the Caribbean specialties prepared by the Haitian chef-co-owner are what stamp it as a destination for adventurous diners. There is an aura of Old World charm, even formality, to the house at 108 West Merrick Road (377-6500), with its mirrored columns, dark wood paneling, white tablecloths and plants, but its smiling inhabitants are casual, affable, down-to-earth fellows who are anxious to please. Although their efforts achieve mixed results, their intentions, especially those of Nelson Williams, the chef, cannot be faulted.

title: Mandy Grunwald, Matthew Cooper
description: Mandy Grunwald, a political and communications consultant, was married last evening to Matthew Stanley Cooper, the deputy chief of Newsweek's Washington bureau. Rabbi Stanley Rabinowitz performed the ceremony at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington.

title: The View From/Ossining ; The Roar of the Crowd On the Community Level
description: AN outsider might wonder: why? Why, on a cold, damp night, when someone is tired from a day at the office, hungry for dinner and maybe a few hours of relaxation in front of the television, why voluntarily go out to a drafty, fluorescent-lighted rented hall and put in three more hours of work?

title: In the Region/Long Island; When the Lot Purchaser Becomes a Home Builder
description: THE landscaping still has to be done, as does the driveway. But otherwise the house that Richard and Laura Osmanski built for themselves in Port Jefferson Station, helped not only by tradespeople but by family and friends as well, is complete.
